Name: Acanthosis nigricans
Overview: Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition that causes a dark discoloration in body folds and creases. Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by areas of dark, velvety discoloration in body folds and creases.
Causes: Acanthosis nigricans often occurs in people who have disorders such as ovarian cysts, underactive thyroids or problems with the adrenal glands. High-dose niacin, birth control pills, prednisone and other corticosteroids may cause acanthosis nigricans. Acanthosis nigricans also sometimes occurs with lymphoma or when a cancerous tumor begins growing in an internal organ, such as the stomach, colon or liver.
Diagnosis: Rarely, a small skin sample is removed (biopsied) for examination in a lab. If the cause of acanthosis nigricans is unclear, the doctor may recommend blood tests, X-rays or other tests to look for possible underlying causes.
Treatment: Examples may include If one is concerned about the appearance of the skin or if the lesions become uncomfortable or start to smell bad, the doctor may suggest: One is likely to start by seeing the family doctor. Prescription creams to lighten or soften the affected areas Antibacterial soaps, used gently, as scrubbing could worsen the condition Topical antibiotic Oral acne medications Laser therapy to reduce the skin's thickness Losing weight.

Name: Achalasia
Overview: Achalasia is a rare disorder that makes it difficult for food and liquid to pass from the swallowing tube connecting the mouth and stomach (esophagus) into the stomach. As a result, the esophagus becomes paralyzed and dilated over time and eventually loses the ability to squeeze food down into the stomach. However, in achalasia the food is coming from the esophagus, whereas in GERD the material comes from the stomach.
Causes: There are theories about what causes this, but viral infection or autoimmune responses have been suspected. Very rarely, achalasia may be caused by an inherited genetic disorder or infection. Achalasia: Treatment, current status and future advances.
Diagnosis: This test measures the rhythmic muscle contractions in the esophagus when one swallow, the coordination and force exerted by the esophagus muscles, and how well the lower esophageal sphincter relaxes or opens during a swallow. The doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube equipped with a light and camera (endoscope) down the throat, to examine the inside of the esophagus and stomach. Endoscopy can also be used to collect a sample of tissue (biopsy) to be tested for complications of reflux such as Barrett's esophagus.
info-Specialty: Thoracic surgery, general surgery, laparoscopic surgery
info-Symptoms: Anorexia (but willing and trying to eat), inability to swallow food, chest pain comparable to heart attack, lightheadedness, dehydration, excessive vomiting after eating (often without nausea).
info-Usual onset: Normally in mid-to-late life, rarely during youth
info-Risk factors: Inconclusive, but possibly: history of autoimmune disorders, air-hunger that accompanies anxiety, faulty eating habits, improper diet
info-Diagnostic method: Esophageal Manometry, Biopsy, X-ray, Barrium swallow study, Endoscopy
info-Treatment: Heller Myotomy and Fundoplomy, POEM, Pneumatic Dilation, Botulinum Toxin
info-Prognosis: ~76% chance of survival after 20 years (in a western country such as Germany)

Name: Achilles tendon rupture
Overview: The Achilles tendon is a strong fibrous cord that connects the muscles in the back of the calf to the heel bone. If the Achilles tendon ruptures, one might hear a pop, followed by an immediate sharp pain in the back of the ankle and lower leg that is likely to affect the ability to walk properly.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of Achilles tendon rupture include Age. Achilles tendon injuries occur more often during sports that involve running, jumping, and sudden starts and stops such as soccer, basketball and tennis. However, this medication can weaken nearby tendons and has been associated with Achilles tendon ruptures. Fluoroquinolone antibiotics, such as ciprofloxacin (Cipro) or levofloxacin (Levaquin), increase the risk of Achilles tendon rupture.
info-Symptoms: Pain in the heel
info-Causes: Forced plantar flexion of the foot, direct trauma, long-standing tendonitis
info-Risk factors: Fluoroquinolones, significant change in exercise, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, corticosteroids
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and examination, supported by medical imaging

Name: Acute coronary syndrome
Symptoms: However, signs and symptoms may vary significantly depending on the age, sex and other medical conditions. One is more likely to have signs and symptoms without chest pain or discomfort if one is a woman, older adult or have diabetes.
Overview: Acute coronary syndrome is a term used to describe a range of conditions associated with sudden, reduced blood flow to the heart. Even when acute coronary syndrome causes no cell death, the reduced blood flow changes how the heart works and is a sign of a high risk of heart attack.
Causes: The death of cells resulting in damage to muscle tissues is a heart attack (myocardial infarction). Even when there is no cell death, the decrease in oxygen still results in heart muscles that don't work the way they should.
Diagnosis: If one has signs or symptoms associated with acute coronary syndrome, an emergency room doctor will likely order several tests. Other tests may be done to learn more about the condition, rule out other causes of symptoms, or to help the doctor personalize the diagnosis and treatment. A long, tiny tube (catheter) is threaded through an artery, usually in the arm or groin, to the arteries in the heart. During the stress test, an ECG, echocardiogram or myocardial perfusion imaging may be used to see how well the heart works.
Remedies: If one has not been exercising regularly, talk to the doctor about the best exercise to begin a healthy and safe routine. Excess weight strains the heart and can contribute to high cholesterol, high blood pressure, diabetes, heart disease and other conditions.
Medication: Depending on the diagnosis, medications for emergency or ongoing care (or both) may include the following: The doctor may recommend one of these procedures to restore blood flow to the heart muscles: Thrombolytics (clot busters) help dissolve a blood clot that's blocking an artery. Antiplatelet drugs help prevent blood clots from forming and include aspirin, clopidogrel (Plavix), prasugrel (Effient) and others. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors widen blood vessels and improve blood flow, allowing the heart to work better. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) help control blood pressure and include irbesartan (Avapro), losartan (Cozaar) and several others. With this procedure, a surgeon takes a piece of blood vessel (graft) from another part of the body and creates a new route for blood that goes around (bypasses) a blocked coronary artery.

Name: Adenomyosis
Overview: With adenomyosis, the same tissue that lines the uterus (endometrial tissue) is present within and grows into the muscular walls of the uterus. Adenomyosis (ad-uh-no-my-O-sis) occurs when the tissue that normally lines the uterus (endometrial tissue) grows into the muscular wall of the uterus.
Causes: Some experts believe that endometrial cells from the lining of the uterus invade the muscle that forms the uterine walls. Uterine incisions made during an operation such as a cesarean section (C-section) might promote the direct invasion of the endometrial cells into the wall of the uterus. Inflammation of the uterine lining during the postpartum period might cause a break in the normal boundary of cells that line the uterus. A recent theory proposes that bone marrow stem cells might invade the uterine muscle, causing adenomyosis.
Treatment: Treatment options for adenomyosis include To ease pelvic pain and cramping related to adenomyosis, The first appointment will be with either the primary care provider or the gynecologist. The doctor might recommend anti-inflammatory medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), to control the pain. By starting an anti-inflammatory medicine one to two days before the period begins and taking it during the period, one can reduce menstrual blood flow and help relieve pain. Progestin-only contraception, such as an intrauterine device, or continuous-use birth control pills often cause amenorrhea the absence of the menstrual periods which might provide some relief.

Name: Adjustment disorders
Symptoms: However, persistent or chronic adjustment disorders can continue for more than 6 months, especially if the stressor is ongoing, such as unemployment. Or call a suicide hotline number in the United States, call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (1-800-273-8255) to reach a trained counselor.
Overview: Adjustment disorders are stress-related conditions. One experience more stress than would normally be expected in response to a stressful or unexpected event, and the stress causes significant problems in the relationships, at work or at school. Work problems, going away to school, an illness, death of a close family member or any number of life changes can cause stress.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis of adjustment disorders is based on identification of major life stressors, the symptoms and how they impact the ability to function. He or she may use the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association. For diagnosis of adjustment disorders, the DSM-5 lists these criteria: The DSM-5 lists six different types of adjustment disorders. Adjustment disorders can be: Having emotional or behavioral symptoms within three months of a specific stressor occurring in the life Experiencing more stress than would normally be expected in response to a stressful life event and/or having stress that causes significant problems in the relationships, at work or at school Symptoms are not the result of another mental health disorder or part of normal grieving With depressed mood. Symptoms mainly include feeling sad, tearful and hopeless and experiencing a lack of pleasure in the things one used to enjoy. Symptoms don't fit the other types of adjustment disorders, but often include physical problems, problems with family or friends, or work or school problems.
Remedies: Resilience is the ability to adapt well to stress, adversity, trauma or tragedy basically, the ability to bounce back after experiencing a difficult event. Building resilience may vary from person to person, but consider these strategies: It may help one to talk things over with caring family and friends, receive support from a faith community, or find a support group geared toward the situation. Many parents assume that talking about a difficult change, such as divorce, will make a child feel worse.
info-Usual onset: Theoretically, within one to three months after a stressful event.
info-Duration: Theoretically, up to six months unless the stressor or its consequences continue.
info-Risk factors: History of mental disorder; low social support.
info-Prognosis: Relatively good compared to many other mental disorders, but severity varies.

Name: Adrenal cancer
Overview: Perched atop each of the kidneys, the adrenal glands produce hormones that help regulate the metabolism, immune system, blood pressure and other essential functions. Adrenal cancer is a rare cancer that begins in one or both of the small, triangular glands (adrenal glands) located on top of the kidneys.
Risk factors: Adrenal cancer happens more often in people with inherited syndromes that increase the risk of certain cancers. Plymouth Meeting, Pa.: National Comprehensive Cancer Network.
Diagnosis: Laboratory tests of the blood and urine may reveal unusual levels of hormones produced by the adrenal glands, including cortisol, aldosterone and androgens. The doctor may recommend CT, MRI or positron emission tomography (PET) scans to better understand any growths on the adrenal glands and to see if cancer has spread to other areas of the body, such as the lungs or the liver.

Name: Adrenoleukodystrophy
Overview: Adrenoleukodystrophy (uh-dree-noh-loo-koh-DIS-truh-fee) is a type of hereditary (genetic) condition that damages the membrane (myelin sheath) that insulates nerve cells in the brain. In adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD), the body can't break down very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs), causing saturated VLCFAs to build up in the brain, nervous system and adrenal gland. The most common type of ALD is X-linked ALD, which is caused by a genetic defect on the X chromosome. X-linked ALD affects males more severely than females, who carry the disease. This form of X-linked ALD usually occurs between ages 4 and 10. The white matter of the brain is progressively damaged (leukodystrophy), and symptoms worsen over time. If not diagnosed early, childhood-onset ALD may lead to death within five to 10 years. Hormone-producing glands (adrenal glands) often fail to produce enough steroids (adrenal insufficiency) in people who have ALD, causing a form of X-linked ALD known as Addison's disease. This adult-onset form of X-linked ALD is a less severe and slowly progressive form that causes symptoms such as a stiff gait and bladder and bowel dysfunction.
Diagnosis: These tests check for high levels of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the blood, which are a key indicator of adrenoleukodystrophy. This allows doctors to detect abnormalities in the brain that could indicate adrenoleukodystrophy, including damage to the nerve tissue (white matter) of the brain. Doctors may use several types of MRI to view the most-detailed images of the brain and detect early signs of leukodystrophy.
Treatment: However, stem cell transplantation may stop the progression of ALD if done when neurological symptoms first appear. Treatment options may include In a recent clinical trial, boys with early-stage cerebral ALD were treated with gene therapy as an alternative to stem cell transplantation. Additional research is necessary to assess long-term results and safety of gene therapy for cerebral ALD. This may be an option to slow or halt the progression of adrenoleukodystrophy in children if ALD is diagnosed and treated early. Hematopoietic stem-cell gene therapy for cerebral adrenoleukodystrophy.

Name: Adult Still 's disease
Symptoms: If one has a high fever, rash and achy joints, see the doctor. Also, if one has adult Still's disease and develop a cough, difficulty breathing, chest pain or any other unusual symptoms, call the doctor. One might have two fever spikes daily, with the temperature returning to normal in between. The joints especially the knees and wrists might be stiff, painful and inflamed. Muscular pain usually ebbs and flows with the fever, but the pain can be severe enough to disrupt the daily activities.
Treatment: Here are ways to make the most of the health if one has adult Still's disease: One is likely to seek advice from the primary care provider, but he or she might refer one to a specialist in joint diseases (rheumatologist). Over-the-counter NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve), may help with mild joint pain and inflammation. These powerful drugs reduce inflammation, but may lower the body's resistance to infections and increase the risk of developing osteoporosis. The medication methotrexate (Trexall) is often used in combination with prednisone, which allows the prednisone dose to be reduced. Drugs such as infliximab (Remicade), adalimumab (Humira) and etanercept (Enbrel) have shown some promise, but their long-term benefit is still unknown. If other medications haven't worked, the doctor may suggest trying anakinra (Kineret), tocilizumab (Actemra) or rituximab (Rituxan). If one is taking high doses of prednisone, talk to the doctor about taking more calcium and vitamin D supplements to help prevent osteoporosis.
Remedies: Even if one is symptom-free some days, it's important to take the medications as the doctor recommends. If one is taking high doses of prednisone, talk to the doctor about taking more calcium and vitamin D supplements to help prevent osteoporosis.

Name: Agoraphobia
Overview: Agoraphobia (ag-uh-ruh-FOE-be-uh) is a type of anxiety disorder in which one fear and avoid places or situations that might cause one to panic and make one feel trapped, helpless or embarrassed. Most people who have agoraphobia develop it after having one or more panic attacks, causing them to worry about having another attack and avoid the places where it may happen again.
Medication: Certain types of antidepressants are often used to treat agoraphobia, and sometimes anti-anxiety drugs are used on a limited basis. For example, the herbal supplement kava, also called kava kava, appeared to be a promising treatment for anxiety, but there have been reports of serious liver damage, even with short-term use. Certain antidepressants called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine (Prozac) and sertraline (Zoloft), are used for the treatment of panic disorder with agoraphobia. Anti-anxiety drugs called benzodiazepines are sedatives that, in limited circumstances, the doctor may prescribe to temporarily relieve anxiety symptoms.
info-Symptoms: Anxiety in situations perceived to be unsafe, panic attacks
info-Risk factors: Family history, stressful event

Name: Alcohol intolerance
Overview: Alcohol intolerance can cause immediate, uncomfortable reactions after one drink alcohol. Although not a true allergy, in some cases, what seems to be alcohol intolerance might be the reaction to something in an alcoholic beverage such as chemicals, grains or preservatives.
Treatment: The only way to avoid alcohol intolerance symptoms or an allergic reaction is to avoid alcohol or the particular beverage or ingredients that cause the problem. For a minor reaction, over-the-counter or prescription antihistamines might help reduce symptoms, such as itching or hives. Although alcohol intolerance usually isn't a serious issue as long as one don't drink alcohol, one might want to discuss it with the doctor at the next appointment. Make a list of: For alcohol intolerance, some questions to ask the doctor include Don't hesitate to ask other questions one has. The symptoms, Key personal information, All medications, vitamins or supplements Questions to ask

Name: Alcohol use disorder
Symptoms: Alcohol use disorder can be mild, moderate or severe, based on the number of symptoms one experience. If one is concerned about someone who drinks too much, ask a professional experienced in alcohol treatment for advice on how to approach that person.
Overview: Alcohol use disorder (which includes a level that's sometimes called alcoholism) is a pattern of alcohol use that involves problems controlling the drinking, being preoccupied with alcohol, continuing to use alcohol even when it causes problems, having to drink more to get the same effect, or having withdrawal symptoms when one rapidly decrease or stop drinking. If the pattern of drinking results in repeated significant distress and problems functioning in the daily life, one likely have alcohol use disorder.
Risk factors: Alcohol use may begin in the teens, but alcohol use disorder occurs more frequently in the 20s and 30s, though it can start at any age. Drinking too much on a regular basis for an extended period or binge drinking on a regular basis can lead to alcohol-related problems or alcohol use disorder. People who begin drinking especially binge drinking at an early age are at a higher risk of alcohol use disorder. The risk of alcohol use disorder is higher for people who have a parent or other close relative who has problems with alcohol. It's common for people with a mental health disorder such as anxiety, depression, schizophrenia or bipolar disorder to have problems with alcohol or other substances. People with a history of emotional or other trauma are at increased risk of alcohol use disorder. Some research studies indicate that having bariatric surgery may increase the risk of developing alcohol use disorder or of relapsing after recovering from alcohol use disorder. Having friends or a close partner who drinks regularly could increase the risk of alcohol use disorder.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects one has a problem with alcohol, he or she may refer one to a mental health professional. To assess the problem with alcohol, the doctor will likely: Ask one several questions related to the drinking habits. While there are no specific tests to diagnose alcohol use disorder, certain patterns of lab test abnormalities may strongly suggest it. The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association, is often used by mental health professionals to diagnose mental health conditions.
Treatment: Treatment for alcohol use disorder can vary, depending on the needs. Treatment for alcohol use disorder may include Detox and withdrawal. It may include goal setting, behavior change techniques, use of self-help manuals, counseling and follow-up care at a treatment center. A drug called disulfiram (Antabuse) may help prevent one from drinking, although it won't cure alcohol use disorder or remove the compulsion to drink. If one drink alcohol, the drug produces a physical reaction that may include flushing, nausea, vomiting and headaches. Naltrexone, a drug that blocks the good feelings alcohol causes, may prevent heavy drinking and reduce the urge to drink. Although similar medication can be taken in pill form, the injectable version of the drug may be easier for people recovering from alcohol use disorder to use consistently. Aftercare programs and support groups help people recovering from alcohol use disorder to stop drinking, manage relapses and cope with necessary lifestyle changes. If one has depression, anxiety or another mental health condition, one may need talk therapy (psychotherapy), medications or other treatment.
Remedies: As part of the recovery, one will need to focus on changing the habits and making different lifestyle choices. For example, good sleep, regular physical activity, managing stress more effectively and eating well all can make it easier for one to recover from alcohol use disorder.
info-Specialty: Psychiatry, clinical psychology, toxicology, addiction medicine
info-Symptoms: Drinking large amounts of alcohol over a long period, difficulty cutting down, acquiring and drinking alcohol taking up a lot of time, usage resulting in problems, withdrawal occurring when stopping
info-Risk factors: Stress, anxiety, inexpensive, easy access
info-Treatment: Alcohol cessation typically with benzodiazepines, counselling, acamprosate, disulfiram, naltrexone

Name: Alcoholic hepatitis
Causes: Alcoholic hepatitis develops when the alcohol one drink damages the liver. Just how alcohol damages the liver and why it does so only in some heavy drinkers isn't clear.
Risk factors: However, alcoholic hepatitis can occur among those who drink less and have other risk factors. Women seem to have a higher risk of developing alcoholic hepatitis possibly because of differences in the way alcohol is processed in women. Having five or more drinks within two hours for men and four or more for women might increase the risk of alcoholic hepatitis.
Medication: If one has severe alcoholic hepatitis, the doctor might recommend: For many people with severe alcoholic hepatitis, the risk of death is high without a liver transplant. Recent studies, however, suggest that carefully selected patients with severe alcoholic hepatitis have post-transplant survival rates similar to those of liver transplant recipients with other types of liver disease. To find a program that works with liver transplant patients who have alcoholic hepatitis To meet the requirements of the program, which would include lifelong commitment to alcohol abstinence as well as other requirements of the specific transplant center Corticosteroids.

Name: Allergies
Diagnosis: Ask detailed questions about signs and symptoms Perform a physical exam Have one keep a detailed diary of symptoms and possible triggers Ask one to keep a detailed diary of the foods one eat Ask if one has stopped eating the suspected food during the allergy evaluation Skin test. Specific IgE (sIgE) blood testing, commonly called radioallergosorbent test (RAST) or ImmunoCAP testing, measures the amount of allergy-causing antibodies in the bloodstream, known as immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies.
Treatment: For severe allergies or allergies not completely relieved by other treatment, the doctor might recommend allergen immunotherapy. Depending on the allergy, medications can help reduce the immune system reaction and ease symptoms. If one has a severe allergy, one might need to carry an emergency epinephrine shot at all times. Given for severe allergic reactions, an epinephrine shot (Auvi-Q, EpiPen, others) can reduce symptoms until one get emergency treatment.
info-Symptoms: Red eyes, itchy rash, runny nose, shortness of breath, swelling, sneezing
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, skin prick test, blood test
info-Treatment: Avoiding known allergens, medications, allergen immunotherapy
info-Medication: Steroids, antihistamines, epinephrine, mast cell stabilizers, antileukotrienes

Name: Alpha-gal syndrome
Overview: Alpha-gal syndrome is a recently identified type of food allergy to red meat and other products made from mammals. The Lone Star tick is found predominantly in the southeastern United States, and most cases of alpha-gal syndrome occur in this region. The condition appears to be spreading farther north and west, however, as deer carry the Lone Star tick to new parts of the United States.
Treatment: As with any food allergy, alpha-gal syndrome treatment involves avoiding the foods that cause the reaction. Always check the ingredient labels on store-bought foods to make sure they don't contain red meat or meat-based ingredients, such as beef, pork, lamb, organ meats or gelatins. Check soup stock cubes, gravy packages and flavor ingredients in prepackaged products. Ask the doctor or allergist for a list of foods to avoid, including meat extracts used in flavoring. Many people don't understand the seriousness of an allergic food reaction, and few realize meat allergies even exist. If one is at all worried that a food may contain something one is allergic to, don't try it. For example, if one is attending a party where guests prepare food on a shared cooking surface, bring the own precooked food. For a severe allergic reaction, one may need an emergency injection of epinephrine and a visit to the emergency room. Many people with allergies carry an epinephrine autoinjector (EpiPen, Auvi-Q, others). Once one has been diagnosed with alpha-gal syndrome, the doctor or allergist likely will prescribe an epinephrine autoinjector. Symptoms of alpha-gal syndrome may lessen or even disappear over time if one don't get any more bites from ticks that carry alpha-gal. To get the most from the appointment, it's a good idea to be well prepared. Be ready to tell the doctor what happened after one ate red meat, including how long it took for a reaction to occur. The doctor will need to know where one has spent time outdoors and how often, as well as how many tick bites one is aware of having experienced.

Name: Ambiguous genitalia
Causes: Whether this tissue becomes male organs or female organs depends on the chromosomes and the presence or absence of male hormones. In males, a region on the Y chromosome triggers the development of testicles, which produce male hormones. In a fetus without a Y chromosome without the effects of male hormones the genitals develop as female. Certain forms of this genetic condition cause the adrenal glands to make excess male hormones (androgens). Certain drugs that contain male hormones or that stimulate production of male hormones in a pregnant woman can cause developing female genitals to become more masculine. A developing baby also may be exposed to excess male hormones if the mother has a disease or condition that causes hormone imbalance. In this condition, developing genital tissues don't respond normally to male hormones made by the testes.
Risk factors: Family history may play a role in the development of ambiguous genitalia, because many disorders of sex development result from genetic abnormalities that can be inherited. Unexplained deaths in early infancy Infertility, absent menstrual periods or excess facial hair in females Genital abnormalities Abnormal physical development during puberty Congenital adrenal hyperplasia, a group of inherited genetic disorders that affect the adrenal glands
Diagnosis: The medical team will likely recommend these tests: In certain cases, minimally invasive surgery may be necessary to collect a tissue sample of the newborn's reproductive organs. Blood tests to measure hormone levels Blood tests to analyze chromosomes and determine the genetic sex (XX or XY) or tests for single gene disorders Ultrasound of the pelvis and abdomen to check for undescended testes, uterus or vagina X-ray studies using a contrast dye to help clarify anatomy Abdominal ultrasound Genetic testing Ultrasound X-ray

Name: Ameloblastoma
Treatment: Ameloblastoma treatment may include After treatment, one will likely have regular follow-up appointments for several years. Ameloblastoma treatment usually includes surgery to remove the tumor. Ameloblastoma often grows into the nearby jawbone, so surgeons may need to remove the affected part of the jawbone. If surgery involves removing part of the jawbone, surgeons can repair and reconstruct the jaw. A variety of specialists can help one work through speaking, swallowing and eating problems during and after treatment.

Name: Amenorrhea
Overview: Amenorrhea (uh-men-o-REE-uh) is the absence of menstruation one or more missed menstrual periods. Women who have missed at least three menstrual periods in a row have amenorrhea, as do girls who haven't begun menstruation by age 15.
Causes: The ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix and vagina (vaginal canal) make up the female reproductive system. Even after stopping oral contraceptives, it may take some time before regular ovulation and menstruation return. It often happens about midway through the menstrual cycle, although the exact timing may vary. Here in the fallopian tube, the egg may be fertilized by a sperm. If the egg isn't fertilized, it's simply reabsorbed by the body perhaps before it even reaches the uterus. Excessively low body weight about 10 percent under normal weight interrupts many hormonal functions in the body, potentially halting ovulation. Women who participate in activities that require rigorous training, such as ballet, may find their menstrual cycles interrupted. Several factors combine to contribute to the loss of periods in athletes, including low body fat, stress and high energy expenditure. PCOS causes relatively high and sustained levels of hormones, rather than the fluctuating levels seen in the normal menstrual cycle. An overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism) or underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) can cause menstrual irregularities, including amenorrhea. But, for some women, the ovarian supply of eggs diminishes before age 40, and menstruation stops. Because her reproductive system didn't develop normally, she can't have menstrual cycles.
Diagnosis: If one has never had a period, the doctor may examine the breasts and genitals to see if one is experiencing the normal changes of puberty. A variety of blood tests may be necessary, including For this test, one take a hormonal medication for seven to 10 days to trigger menstrual bleeding. Depending on the signs and symptoms and the result of any blood tests one has had the doctor might recommend one or more imaging tests, including If other testing reveals no specific cause, the doctor may recommend a hysteroscopy a test in which a thin, lighted camera is passed through the vagina and cervix to look at the inside of the uterus. If one is experiencing increased facial hair and a lowered voice, the doctor may want to check the level of male hormones in the blood. If one has never had a period, the doctor may suggest an ultrasound test to check for any abnormalities in the reproductive organs.

Name: Amnestic syndrome
Causes: Amnesia can result from damage to brain structures that form the limbic system, which controls the emotions and memories. Mild head injuries typically do not cause lasting amnesia, but more-severe head injuries may cause permanent amnesia. Another rare type of amnesia, called dissociative (psychogenic) amnesia, stems from emotional shock or trauma, such as being the victim of a violent crime.

Name: Amniotic fluid embolism
Risk factors: Because amniotic fluid embolisms are rare, it's difficult to identify risk factors. Research suggests that several factors might be linked to an increased risk of amniotic fluid embolism, however, including Advanced maternal age. If one is 35 or older at the time of the child's birth, one might be at increased risk of amniotic fluid embolism. Abnormalities in the placenta the structure that develops in the uterus during pregnancy might increase the risk of amniotic fluid embolism. Limited research suggests that certain labor induction methods are associated with an increased risk of amniotic fluid embolism. Having a C-section, a forceps delivery or a vacuum extraction might increase the risk of amniotic fluid embolism. It's not clear, however, whether operative deliveries are true risk factors for amniotic fluid embolism because they're used after the condition develops to ensure a rapid delivery.
Treatment: Emergency treatments might include If one has amniotic fluid embolism before delivering the baby, the doctor will treat one with the goal of safely delivering the baby as soon as possible. A thin, hollow tube placed into one of the arteries (arterial catheter) might be used to monitor the blood pressure. One might also have another tube placed into a vein in the chest (central venous catheter), which can be used to give fluids, medications or transfusions, as well as draw blood.
info-Risk factors: Unpredictable

Name: Ampullary cancer
Causes: In general, cancer starts when cells develop changes (mutations) in their DNA. The changes tell the cell to begin multiplying uncontrollably and to continue living when normal cells would die.
Diagnosis: A thin, flexible tube (endoscope) with a camera on the end is passed down the throat and into the small intestine. Tests and procedures used to diagnose ampullary cancer include Passing a thin, flexible scope down the throat (endoscopy). Endoscopy is a procedure to examine the digestive system with a long, thin tube (endoscope) equipped with a tiny camera.

Name: Amyloidosis
Symptoms: Some people with amyloidosis experience purpura a condition in which small blood vessels leak blood into the skin, causing purplish patches. Signs and symptoms of amyloidosis may include See the doctor if one persistently experience any of the signs or symptoms associated with amyloidosis.
Overview: Amyloidosis (am-uh-loi-DO-sis) is a rare disease that occurs when an abnormal protein, called amyloid, builds up in the organs and interferes with their normal function. Organs that may be affected include the heart, kidneys, liver, spleen, nervous system and digestive tract.
Causes: The most common type of amyloidosis in developed countries, AL amyloidosis is also called primary amyloidosis. Also known as secondary amyloidosis, this variety is usually triggered by an inflammatory disease, such as rheumatoid arthritis. Formerly known as senile systemic amyloidosis, wild-type amyloidosis tends to affect men over age 70 and typically targets the heart. Typical sites for localized amyloidosis include the bladder, skin, throat or lungs.
Risk factors: Most people diagnosed with amyloidosis are between ages 60 and 70, although earlier onset occurs. People of African descent appear to be at higher risk of carrying a genetic mutation associated with a type of amyloidosis that can harm the heart.
Diagnosis: The biopsy may be taken from the fat under the skin on the abdomen (fat aspirate), bone marrow, or an affected organ such as the liver or kidney. It can also help distinguish between different types of amyloidosis, which can guide treatment decisions.
Medication: If the heart is affected, the doctor may suggest blood thinners to reduce the risk of clots and medications to control the heart rate. One may also need to restrict the salt intake and take drugs that increase urination, which can reduce the strain on the heart and kidneys. For certain types of amyloidosis, drugs such as patisiran (Onpattro) and inotersen (Tegsedi) can interfere with the commands sent by faulty genes that create amyloid. Other drugs, such as tafamidis (Vyndamax, Vyndaqel) and diflunisal, can stabilize bits of protein in the bloodstream and prevent them from getting transformed into amyloid deposits.
info-Symptoms: Feeling tired, weight loss, swelling of the legs, shortness of breath, bleeding, feeling light headed with standing
info-Treatment: Supportive care, directed at the underlying cause, dialysis, organ transplantation

Name: Anal fissure
Risk factors: This inflammatory bowel disease causes chronic inflammation of the intestinal tract, which may make the lining of the anal canal more vulnerable to tearing. Anal fissures can occur at any age, but are more common in infants and middle-aged adults.
Diagnosis: The doctor will likely ask about the medical history and perform a physical exam, including a gentle inspection of the anal region. A chronic anal fissure likely has a deeper tear, and may have internal or external fleshy growths. A fissure that occurs on the side of the anal opening, rather than the back or front, is more likely to be a sign of another disorder, such as Crohn's disease. This test may be done if one is older than age 50 or one has risk factors for colon cancer, signs of other conditions, or other symptoms such as abdominal pain or diarrhea.

Name: Anaphylaxis
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms include Seek emergency medical help if one, the child or someone else one is with has a severe allergic reaction. Make an appointment to see the doctor if one or the child has had a severe allergy attack or signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis in the past.
Overview: Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction. Anaphylaxis causes the immune system to release a flood of chemicals that can cause one to go into shock the blood pressure drops suddenly and the airways narrow, blocking breathing.
info-Symptoms: Itchy rash, throat swelling, numbness, shortness of breath, lightheadedness,

Name: Anemia
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms, if they do occur, might include At first, anemia can be so mild that one don't notice it. Fatigue has many causes besides anemia, so don't assume that if one is tired one must be anemic.
Causes: Anemia occurs when the blood doesn't have enough red blood cells. To produce hemoglobin and red blood cells, the body needs iron, vitamin B-12, folate and other nutrients from the foods one eat. Without adequate iron, the body can't produce enough hemoglobin for red blood cells. Besides iron, the body needs folate and vitamin B-12 to produce enough healthy red blood cells. This rare, life-threatening anemia occurs when the body doesn't produce enough red blood cells. A variety of diseases, such as leukemia and myelofibrosis, can cause anemia by affecting blood production in the bone marrow. This group of anemias develops when red blood cells are destroyed faster than bone marrow can replace them.
Risk factors: If one has cancer, kidney failure, diabetes or another chronic condition, one could be at risk of anemia of chronic disease. Slow, chronic blood loss from an ulcer or other source within the body can deplete the body's store of iron, leading to iron deficiency anemia. A diet consistently low in iron, vitamin B-12 and folate increases the risk of anemia. In general, women who haven't had menopause have a greater risk of iron deficiency anemia than do men and postmenopausal women. If one is pregnant and aren't taking a multivitamin with folic acid and iron, one is at an increased risk of anemia. If the family has a history of an inherited anemia, such as sickle cell anemia, one also might be at increased risk of the condition. A history of certain infections, blood diseases and autoimmune disorders increases the risk of anemia. Alcoholism, exposure to toxic chemicals, and the use of some medications can affect red blood cell production and lead to anemia.
Diagnosis: To diagnose anemia, the doctor is likely to ask one about the medical and family history, perform a physical exam, and run the following tests: Complete blood count (CBC). For anemia, the doctor will be interested in the levels of the red blood cells contained in the blood (hematocrit) and the hemoglobin in the blood.
Treatment: Managing hemolytic anemias includes avoiding suspect medications, treating infections and taking drugs that suppress the immune system, which could be attacking the red blood cells. Doctors might also recommend blood transfusions, folic acid supplements and antibiotics. A cancer drug called hydroxyurea (Droxia, Hydrea, Siklos) also is used to treat sickle cell anemia. He or she may refer one to a doctor who specializes in treating blood disorders (hematologist), the heart (cardiologist) or the digestive system (gastroenterologist). If symptoms become severe, a blood transfusion or injections of a synthetic hormone normally produced by the kidneys (erythropoietin) might help stimulate red blood cell production and ease fatigue. More severe forms of thalassemia generally require blood transfusions, folic acid supplements, medication, removal of the spleen, or a blood and bone marrow stem cell transplant.
info-Symptoms: Feeling tired, pale skin, weakness, shortness of breath, feeling like passing out
info-Causes: Bleeding, decreased red blood cell production, increased red blood cell breakdown

Name: Aneurysm , abdominal aortic
Overview: An abdominal aortic aneurysm occurs when a lower portion of the body's main artery (aorta) becomes weakened and bulges. An abdominal aortic aneurysm is an enlarged area in the lower part of the major vessel that supplies blood to the body (aorta).
Causes: Aneurysms can develop anywhere along the aorta, but most aortic aneurysms occur in the part of the aorta that's in the abdomen. A number of factors can play a role in developing an aortic aneurysm, including Hardening of the arteries (atherosclerosis). Rarely, a bacterial or fungal infection might cause an abdominal aortic aneurysms.
Risk factors: Abdominal aortic aneurysm risk factors include Tobacco use. It can weaken the aortic walls, increasing the risk not only of developing an aortic aneurysm, but of rupture. Men develop abdominal aortic aneurysms much more often than women do. People who are white are at higher risk of abdominal aortic aneurysms. Having a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms increases the risk of having the condition. Having an aneurysm in another large blood vessel, such as the artery behind the knee or the aorta in the chest, might increase the risk of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.
Diagnosis: Abdominal aortic aneurysms are often found during an examination for another reason or during routine medical tests, such as an ultrasound of the heart or abdomen. To diagnose an abdominal aortic aneurysm, doctors will review the medical and family history and do a physical exam. Screening recommendations vary, but in general: There isn't enough evidence to determine whether women ages 65 to 75 who ever smoked cigarettes or have a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm would benefit from abdominal aortic aneurysm screening. For men ages 65 to 75 who have never smoked, the doctor will decide on the need for an abdominal ultrasound, usually based on other risk factors, such as a family history of aneurysm.

Name: Aneurysms
Overview: An aneurysm is an abnormal bulge or ballooning in the wall of a blood vessel. Aneurysms can develop in several parts of the body, including Some small aneurysms have a low risk of rupture. To determine the risk of rupture, the doctor will ask questions about the symptoms and medical and family history, and check the size, location and appearance of the aneurysm. Dr. Bendok says 1 to 2 percent of the population have aneurysms, and only a small percentage of that group will experience a rupture. People who have a family history of aneurysms, have polycystic kidney disease, connective tissue disease, and people who smoke are at increased risk of rupture, and should consider screening.

Name: Angelman syndrome
Overview: Angelman syndrome is a genetic disorder. Developmental delays, which begin between about 6 and 12 months of age, are usually the first signs of Angelman syndrome. People with Angelman syndrome tend to live close to a normal life span, but the disorder can't be cured.
Diagnosis: The child's doctor may suspect Angelman syndrome if the child has developmental delays and other signs and symptoms of the disorder, such as problems with movement and balance, a small head size, flatness in the back of the head, and frequent laughter. This genetic testing can identify abnormalities in the child's chromosomes that indicate Angelman syndrome. This test, known as a DNA methylation test, screens for three of the four known genetic abnormalities that cause Angelman syndrome. Rarely, Angelman syndrome may occur when a person's maternal copy of the UBE3A gene is active, but mutated. If results from a DNA methylation test are normal, the child's doctor may order a UBE3A gene sequencing test to look for a maternal mutation.
info-Symptoms: Delayed development, unusually happy, intellectual disability, limited to no functional speech, balance and movement problems, small head, seizures

Name: Angina pectoris
Symptoms: Angina symptoms include chest pain and discomfort, possibly described as pressure, squeezing, burning or fullness. For example, pain that comes on when one is walking uphill or in the cold weather may be angina. New or different symptoms may signal a more dangerous form of angina (unstable angina) or a heart attack. There's another type of angina, called variant angina or Prinzmetal's angina. For example, chest pain is a common symptom in women with angina, but it may not be the only symptom or the most prevalent symptom for women. If one has been diagnosed with stable angina and it gets worse or changes, seek medical attention immediately.
Causes: Angina is caused by reduced blood flow to the heart muscle. The most common cause of reduced blood flow to the heart muscle is coronary artery disease (CAD). If fatty deposits (plaques) in a blood vessel rupture or a blood clot forms, it can quickly block or reduce flow through a narrowed artery. Unstable angina can also be caused by blood clots that block or partially block the heart's blood vessels. If the blood flow doesn't improve, the heart is starved of oxygen and a heart attack occurs. When one climb stairs, exercise or walk, the heart demands more blood, but narrowed arteries slow down blood flow. Besides physical activity, other factors such as emotional stress, cold temperatures, heavy meals and smoking also can narrow arteries and trigger angina. This narrowing reduces blood flow to the heart, causing severe chest pain. Emotional stress, smoking, medications that tighten blood vessels (such as some migraine drugs) and use of the illegal drug cocaine may trigger Prinzmetal's angina.
Risk factors: Chewing tobacco, smoking and long-term exposure to secondhand smoke damage the interior walls of arteries including arteries to the heart allowing deposits of cholesterol to collect and block blood flow. Diabetes increases the risk of coronary artery disease, which leads to angina and heart attacks by speeding up atherosclerosis and increasing the cholesterol levels. A high level of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, also known as bad cholesterol, increases the risk of angina and heart attacks. If a family member has coronary artery disease or has had a heart attack, one is at a greater risk of developing angina. An inactive lifestyle contributes to high cholesterol, high blood pressure, type 2 diabetes and obesity. Obesity is linked with high blood cholesterol levels, high blood pressure and diabetes, all which increase the risk of angina and heart disease.
Diagnosis: A nuclear stress test helps measure blood flow to the heart muscle at rest and during stress. During coronary angiography, a type of dye that's visible by X-ray machine is injected into the blood vessels of the heart. The X-ray machine rapidly takes a series of images (angiograms), offering a detailed look at the inside of the blood vessels. The doctor can use these images to identify angina-related problems, including heart muscle damage due to poor blood flow. An echocardiogram can be given during a stress test, and this can show if there are areas of the heart that are not getting enough blood. An X-ray tube inside the machine rotates around the body and collects images of the heart and chest, which can show if any of the heart's arteries are narrowed or if the heart is enlarged. In a cardiac MRI, one lie on a table inside a long, tubelike machine that produces detailed images of the heart's structure and its blood vessels.
Remedies: Because heart disease is often the cause of angina, one can reduce or prevent angina by working on reducing the heart disease risk factors. Treat diseases or conditions that can increase the risk of angina, such as diabetes, high blood pressure and high blood cholesterol.
Medication: But medical procedures such as angioplasty, stenting and coronary artery bypass surgery may also be used to treat angina. This procedure improves blood flow in the heart, reducing or eliminating angina. Angioplasty and stenting is a good treatment option if one has unstable angina or if lifestyle changes and medications don't effectively treat the chronic, stable angina. Nitrates relax and widen the blood vessels, allowing more blood to flow to the heart muscle. Aspirin reduces the ability of the blood to clot, making it easier for blood to flow through narrowed heart arteries. Certain medications such as clopidogrel (Plavix), prasugrel (Effient) and ticagrelor (Brilinta) can help prevent blood clots from forming by making the blood platelets less likely to stick together. Beta blockers also help blood vessels relax and open up to improve blood flow, thus reducing or preventing angina. They may also help the body reabsorb cholesterol that has accumulated in plaques in the artery walls, helping prevent further blockage in the blood vessels. Calcium channel blockers, also called calcium antagonists, relax and widen blood vessels by affecting the muscle cells in the arterial walls. This increases blood flow in the heart, reducing or preventing angina. Ranexa can be used alone or with other angina medications, such as calcium channel blockers, beta blockers or nitroglycerin. With ECP, blood pressure-type cuffs are placed around the calves, thighs and pelvis to increase blood flow to the heart.

Name: Angiosarcoma
Treatment: Which angiosarcoma treatment is best for one depends on the cancer's location, its size and whether it has spread to other areas of the body. If the doctor suspects one may have angiosarcoma, one may be referred to a doctor who specializes in skin diseases (dermatologist) or one that specializes in treating cancer (oncologist). In some cases surgery may not be an option, for example, if the cancer is very large or has spread to other areas of the body. Radiation therapy uses high-energy beams, such as X-rays and protons, to kill cancer cells. In certain situations, it may be combined with radiation therapy if one can't undergo surgery.
info-Symptoms: Often asymptomatic, non-specific symptoms common
info-Usual onset: Typically 60-70 however all age groups are affected
info-Risk factors: Lymphedema, radiation therapy, various chemicals
info-Prognosis: Depends on type, overall five-year survival ~ 30-38%

Name: Ankylosing spondylitis
Overview: As ankylosing spondylitis worsens, new bone forms as part of the body's attempt to heal. Ankylosing spondylitis is an inflammatory disease that, over time, can cause some of the small bones in the spine (vertebrae) to fuse. There is no cure for ankylosing spondylitis, but treatments can lessen the symptoms and possibly slow progression of the disease.
Risk factors: Men are more likely to develop ankylosing spondylitis than are women. Most people who have ankylosing spondylitis have the HLA-B27 gene. But many people who have this gene never develop ankylosing spondylitis.
Diagnosis: X-rays allow the doctor to check for changes in the joints and bones, though the visible signs of ankylosing spondylitis might not be evident early in the disease. MRI scans can reveal evidence of ankylosing spondylitis earlier in the disease process, but are much more expensive.
Remedies: Smoking is generally bad for the health, but it creates additional problems for people with ankylosing spondylitis, including further hampering breathing. Practicing standing straight in front of a mirror can help one avoid some of the problems associated with ankylosing spondylitis. 6 tips for living well with ankylosing spondylitis Ankylosing spondylitis: Eat well for bone health Ankylosing spondylitis: Exercising safely Ankylosing spondylitis: Reduce the risk of falling Stay active.
Medication: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as naproxen (Naprosyn) and indomethacin (Indocin, Tivorbex) are the medications doctors most commonly use to treat ankylosing spondylitis. If NSAIDs aren't helpful, the doctor might suggest starting a biologic medication, such as a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) blocker or an interleukin-17 (IL-17) inhibitor. The five TNF blockers approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to treat ankylosing spondylitis are: IL-17 inhibitors approved by the FDA to treat ankylosing spondylitis include secukinumab (Cosentyx) and ixekizumab (Taltz). If one is unable to take TNF blockers or IL-17 inhibitors because of other health conditions, the doctor may recommend the Janus kinase inhibitor tofacitinib (Xeljanz).
info-Symptoms: Back pain, joint stiffness
info-Diagnostic method: Symptom based, medical imaging, blood tests

Name: Anorgasmia in women
Symptoms: An orgasm is a feeling of intense physical pleasure and release of tension, accompanied by involuntary, rhythmic contractions of the pelvic floor muscles. By definition, the major symptoms of anorgasmia are the inability to have an orgasm or long delays in reaching orgasm that's distressing to one.
Causes: Orgasm is a complex reaction to various physical, emotional and psychological factors. Serious illnesses, such as multiple sclerosis and Parkinson's disease, and their associated affects on psychological well-being can hamper orgasm. Gynecologic surgeries, such as hysterectomy or cancer surgeries, can affect orgasm. Also, lack of orgasm often goes with other sexual concerns, such as uncomfortable or painful intercourse. Many prescription and over-the-counter medications can inhibit orgasm, including blood pressure medications, antipsychotic drugs, antihistamines and antidepressants particularly selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). As one age, normal changes in the anatomy, hormones, neurological system and circulatory system can affect the sexuality. Waning estrogen levels as one transition to menopause and menopausal symptoms, such as night sweats and mood changes, can have an impact on sexuality.
Diagnosis: The doctor will probably conduct a general physical exam to look for physical causes of anorgasmia, such as a medical condition. The doctor might also examine the genital area to see if there's some obvious physical or anatomical reason for lack of orgasm.

Name: Anterior cruciate ligament injury
Diagnosis: Often the diagnosis can be made on the basis of the physical exam alone, but one may need tests to rule out other causes and to determine the severity of the injury. An MRI can show the extent of an ACL injury and signs of damage to other tissues in the knee, including the cartilage. Using sound waves to visualize internal structures, ultrasound may be used to check for injuries in the ligaments, tendons and muscles of the knee.
Treatment: Prompt first-aid care can reduce pain and swelling immediately after an injury to the knee. General rest is necessary for healing and limits weight bearing on the knee. When one is awake, try to ice the knee at least every two hours for 20 minutes at a time.
info-Symptoms: Audible "crack" with pain, knee instability, swelling of knee
info-Risk factors: Athletes, females

Name: Anthrax
Symptoms: There are four common routes of anthrax infection, each with different signs and symptoms. However, it's possible for inhalation anthrax symptoms to take more than six weeks to appear. A skin-related (cutaneous) anthrax infection enters the body through the skin, usually through a cut or other sore. Signs and symptoms include A gastrointestinal anthrax infection results from eating undercooked meat from an infected animal. Signs and symptoms include This illustration shows how the spores that cause inhalation anthrax the most deadly form of anthrax infection enter and affect the body. Initial signs and symptoms include This recently identified route of anthrax infection has so far been reported only in Europe.
Overview: Anthrax is a rare but serious illness caused by a spore-forming bacterium, Bacillus anthracis. There's no evidence that anthrax is transmitted from person to person, but it's possible that anthrax skin lesions may be contagious through direct contact or through contact with a contaminated object (fomite).
Causes: In the United States, a few people have developed anthrax while making traditional African drums from the skins of infected animals. Twenty-two people developed anthrax after being exposed to spores sent through the mail, and five of those infected died.
Diagnosis: A sample of fluid from a suspicious lesion on the skin or a small tissue sample (biopsy) may be tested in a lab for signs of cutaneous anthrax. Chest X-rays CT scan Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) Skin biopsy Upper endoscopy Skin testing.
Treatment: The standard treatment for anthrax is an antibiotic such as ciprofloxacin (Cipro), doxycycline (Vibramycin) or levofloxacin. Which single antibiotic or combination of antibiotics, and the length of treatment, will be most effective for one depends on how one were infected with anthrax, the age, the overall health and other factors. Since the 2001 attacks in the United States, researchers have developed antitoxin therapies raxibacumab and obiltoxaximab for inhalation anthrax. Although some cases of anthrax respond to antibiotics, advanced inhalation anthrax may not. Along with antibiotics, people with anthrax may be treated with intensive supportive care including ventilators, fluids and medicines to tighten blood vessels and raise blood pressure (vasopressors). If one know one has been exposed to anthrax or if one develop symptoms after a possible exposure, immediately go to the emergency room. If one has time before one go: Write down any symptoms one is experiencing, including any that seem unrelated to anthrax exposure. For instance, if one is diagnosed with anthrax, one will want to know the route of infection, the proposed treatment and the prognosis. Cutaneous anthrax Inhalation anthrax Write down any symptoms one is experiencing, Write down key personal information. Make a list of all medications, Take a family member or friend along, Write down questions to ask the doctor.
info-Symptoms: Skin form: small blister with surrounding swellingInhalational form: fever, chest pain, shortness of breathIntestinal form: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal painInjection form: fever, abscess
info-Risk factors: Working with animals, travelers, postal workers, military personnel
info-Diagnostic method: Based on antibodies or toxin in the blood, microbial culture

Name: Antiphospholipid syndrome
Symptoms: Seek emergency care if one has signs and symptoms of: Blood clots in the legs (DVT). Signs of a DVT include pain, swelling and redness. Chronic headaches, including migraines; dementia and seizures are possible when a blood clot blocks blood flow to parts of the brain. A clot in the brain can cause sudden numbness, weakness or paralysis of the face, arm or leg. If a clot lodges in the lung, one may experience sudden shortness of breath, chest pain and coughing up blood-streaked mucus. Signs and symptoms of DVTs include swelling, redness or pain in a leg or arm.
Risk factors: Risk factors for antiphospholipid syndrome include It's possible to have the antibodies associated with antiphospholipid syndrome without developing signs or symptoms. However, having these antibodies increases the risk of developing blood clots, particularly if one: The sex. Having another autoimmune condition, such as lupus or Sjogren's syndrome, increases the risk of antiphospholipid syndrome. This condition is more common in people who have certain infections, such as syphilis, HIV/AIDS, hepatitis C or Lyme disease. They include hydralazine for high blood pressure, the heart rhythm-regulating medication quinidine, the anti-seizure medication phenytoin (Dilantin) and the antibiotic amoxicillin.
Remedies: If one take blood-thinning medications, take extra care to keep from injuring theself and to avoid bleeding. One may need to avoid eating large amounts of vitamin K-rich foods such as avocado, broccoli, Brussels sprouts, cabbage, leafy greens and garbanzo beans. These include some over-the-counter pain relievers, cold medicines, stomach remedies or multivitamins, as well as garlic, ginkgo and green tea products.

Name: Anxiety disorders
Symptoms: Anxiety disorder due to a medical condition includes symptoms of intense anxiety or panic that are directly caused by a physical health problem. Generalized anxiety disorder includes persistent and excessive anxiety and worry about activities or events even ordinary, routine issues. Panic disorder involves repeated episodes of sudden feelings of intense anxiety and fear or terror that reach a peak within minutes (panic attacks).
Overview: Experiencing occasional anxiety is a normal part of life. However, people with anxiety disorders frequently have intense, excessive and persistent worry and fear about everyday situations. Often, anxiety disorders involve repeated episodes of sudden feelings of intense anxiety and fear or terror that reach a peak within minutes (panic attacks). Examples of anxiety disorders include generalized anxiety disorder, social anxiety disorder (social phobia), specific phobias and separation anxiety disorder.
Risk factors: Children who endured abuse or trauma or witnessed traumatic events are at higher risk of developing an anxiety disorder at some point in life. A big event or a buildup of smaller stressful life situations may trigger excessive anxiety for example, a death in the family, work stress or ongoing worry about finances. People with other mental health disorders, such as depression, often also have an anxiety disorder.
Diagnosis: To help diagnose an anxiety disorder, the mental health provider may: Give one a psychological evaluation. Anxiety disorders often occur along with other mental health problems such as depression or substance misuse which can make diagnosis more challenging. Many doctors use the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association, to diagnose an anxiety disorder.
Remedies: While most people with anxiety disorders need psychotherapy or medications to get anxiety under control, lifestyle changes also can make a difference. Visualization techniques, meditation and yoga are examples of relaxation techniques that can ease anxiety. Healthy eating such as focusing on vegetables, fruits, whole grains and fish may be linked to reduced anxiety, but more research is needed.
Medication: Several types of medications are used to help relieve symptoms, depending on the type of anxiety disorder one has and whether one also have other mental or physical health issues. In limited circumstances, the doctor may prescribe other types of medications, such as sedatives, also called benzodiazepines, or beta blockers.
info-Symptoms: Worrying, fast heart rate, shakiness
info-Risk factors: Child abuse, family history, poverty

Name: Aortic aneurysm
Overview: An aortic aneurysm occurs when a weak spot in the wall of the aorta begins to bulge (left). An aortic aneurysm is an abnormal bulge that occurs in the wall of the major blood vessel (aorta) that carries blood from the heart to the body.

Name: Aortic valve disease
Diagnosis: Doctors may use this test to evaluate the heart chambers, the aortic valve and the blood flow through the heart. This test can help doctors closely look at the condition of the aortic valve, and the cause and severity of the condition. This test isn't often used to diagnose aortic valve disease, but it may be used if other tests aren't able to diagnose the condition or to determine its severity. Doctors may use this test to evaluate the heart chambers, the aortic valve and the blood flow through the heart.This test can help doctors closely look at the condition of the aortic valve, and the cause and severity of the condition. A chest X-ray can help the doctor determine whether the heart is enlarged, which can indicate certain types of aortic valve disease. Exercise tests help doctors see whether one has signs and symptoms of aortic valve disease during physical activity, and these tests can help determine the severity of the condition. This test isn't often used to diagnose aortic valve disease, but it may be used if other tests aren't able to diagnose the condition or to determine its severity.In this procedure, a doctor threads a thin tube (catheter) through a blood vessel in the arm or groin to an artery in the heart and injects dye through the catheter to make the artery visible on an X-ray.
Treatment: If the aortic valve disease is mild or moderate or one isn't experiencing symptoms, the doctor may monitor the condition with regular follow-up appointments. If one is having another heart surgery, doctors may perform aortic valve surgery at the same time. If one has aortic valve disease, consider being evaluated and treated at a medical center with a multidisciplinary team of cardiologists and other doctors and medical staff trained and experienced in evaluating and treating heart valve disease.
Remedies: The doctor may suggest one incorporate several heart-healthy lifestyle changes into the life, including For women with aortic valve disease, it's important to talk with the doctor before one become pregnant. The doctor can discuss with one which medications one can safely take, and whether one may need a procedure to treat the valve condition prior to pregnancy. If one is overweight or obese, the doctor may recommend that one lose weight. Find ways to help manage the stress, such as through relaxation activities, meditation, physical activity, and spending time with family and friends.

Name: Aphasia
Symptoms: A person with aphasia may: People with aphasia may have different patterns of strengths and weaknesses. People with this pattern of aphasia may understand what other people say better than they can speak. People with this pattern of aphasia struggle to get words out, speak in very short sentences and omit words. A listener can usually understand the meaning, but people with this aphasia pattern are often aware of their difficulty communicating and may get frustrated.
Causes: The most common cause of aphasia is brain damage resulting from a stroke the blockage or rupture of a blood vessel in the brain. Brain damage caused by a severe head injury, a tumor, an infection or a degenerative process also can cause aphasia.
Medication: These include drugs that may improve blood flow to the brain, enhance the brain's recovery ability or help replace depleted chemicals in the brain (neurotransmitters). Brain stimulation is currently being studied for aphasia treatment and may help improve the ability to name things.

Name: Aplastic anemia
Symptoms: Bone marrow is a red, spongy material inside the bones that produces blood cells. When present, signs and symptoms can include Aplastic anemia can be short-lived, or it can become chronic.
Overview: Aplastic anemia is a condition that occurs when the body stops producing enough new blood cells. Treatment for aplastic anemia might include medications, blood transfusions or a stem cell transplant, also known as a bone marrow transplant.
Causes: Stem cells in the bone marrow produce blood cells red cells, white cells and platelets. In aplastic anemia, stem cells are damaged. As a result, the bone marrow is either empty (aplastic) or contains few blood cells (hypoplastic). The most common cause of aplastic anemia is from the immune system attacking the stem cells in the bone marrow. Fanconi's anemia is a rare, inherited disease that leads to aplastic anemia. While these cancer-fighting therapies kill cancer cells, they can also damage healthy cells, including stem cells in bone marrow. Toxic chemicals, such as some used in pesticides and insecticides, and benzene, an ingredient in gasoline, have been linked to aplastic anemia. Some medications, such as those used to treat rheumatoid arthritis and some antibiotics, can cause aplastic anemia. An autoimmune disorder, in which the immune system attacks healthy cells, might involve stem cells in the bone marrow. Viruses that have been linked to aplastic anemia include hepatitis, Epstein-Barr, cytomegalovirus, parvovirus B19 and HIV. In many cases, doctors aren't able to identify the cause of aplastic anemia (idiopathic aplastic anemia).
Diagnosis: In a bone marrow aspiration, a doctor or nurse uses a thin needle to remove a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot in the back of the hipbone (pelvis). A doctor uses a needle to remove a small sample of bone marrow from a large bone in the body, such as the hipbone. In aplastic anemia, bone marrow contains fewer blood cells than normal.
Remedies: If one has aplastic anemia, take care of theself by: Resting when one need to. Because of the risk of bleeding associated with a low platelet count, avoid activities that can cause a cut or fall.
info-Symptoms: pale skin, hematoma, fast heart rate
info-Risk factors: Smoking, family history, ionizing radiation, some chemicals, prior chemotherapy, Down syndrome.
info-Treatment: bone marrow transplant, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, targeted therapy

Name: Appendicitis
Overview: The appendix is a narrow, finger-shaped pouch that projects out from the colon. Appendicitis is an inflammation of the appendix, a finger-shaped pouch that projects from the colon on the lower right side of the abdomen.
Diagnosis: The doctor may also look for abdominal rigidity and a tendency for one to stiffen the abdominal muscles in response to pressure over the inflamed appendix (guarding). The doctor may use a lubricated, gloved finger to examine the lower rectum (digital rectal exam). The doctor may also recommend an abdominal X-ray, an abdominal ultrasound, computerized tomography (CT) scan or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to help confirm appendicitis or find other causes for the pain.
Remedies: If the appendectomy was done laparoscopically, limit the activity for three to five days. Place a pillow over the abdomen and apply pressure before one cough, laugh or move to help reduce pain. They should wait two to four weeks to resume strenuous activity, such as gym classes or sports.
info-Symptoms: Right lower abdominal pain, vomiting, decreased appetite
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, medical imaging, blood tests
info-Treatment: Surgical removal of the appendix, antibiotics

Name: ARDS
Causes: The alveoli are surrounded by the alveolar-capillary membrane, which normally prevents liquid in the capillaries from entering the air sacs. The mechanical cause of ARDS is fluid leaked from the smallest blood vessels in the lungs into the tiny air sacs where blood is oxygenated. Severe illness or injury, however, can cause damage to the membrane, leading to the fluid leakage of ARDS. The most common cause of ARDS is sepsis, a serious and widespread infection of the bloodstream. Breathing high concentrations of smoke or chemical fumes can result in ARDS, as can inhaling (aspirating) vomit or near-drowning episodes.
Risk factors: Most people who develop ARDS are already hospitalized for another condition, and many are critically ill. One is especially at risk if one has a widespread infection in the bloodstream (sepsis).
Diagnosis: It's also important to rule out other diseases and conditions for example, certain heart problems that can produce similar symptoms. Because the signs and symptoms of ARDS are similar to those of certain heart problems, the doctor may recommend heart tests such as: Chest X-ray.
Remedies: If one is recovering from ARDS, the following suggestions can help protect the lungs: Quit smoking. The yearly flu (influenza) shot, as well as the pneumonia vaccine every five years, can reduce the risk of lung infections.
info-Symptoms: Shortness of breath, rapid breathing, bluish skin coloration Chest pain or pressure, Loss of speech of movement
info-Diagnostic method: Adults: PaO2/FiO2 ratio of less than 300 mmÂ HgChildren: oxygenation index > 4

Name: Arteriovenous fistula
Overview: An arteriovenous (AV) fistula is an abnormal connection between an artery and a vein in which blood flows directly from an artery into a vein, bypassing some capillaries. With an arteriovenous fistula, blood flows directly from an artery into a vein, bypassing some capillaries.
Causes: The exact reason why isn't clear, but in some babies, the arteries and veins don't develop properly in the womb. People who have late-stage kidney failure may have an arteriovenous fistula surgically created in the forearm to make it easier to perform dialysis.
Treatment: If the arteriovenous fistula is small and doesn't cause any other health problems, one may need only close monitoring by a doctor. If the arteriovenous fistula requires treatment, the doctor may recommend: If one think one may have an arteriovenous fistula, make an appointment with the primary care doctor. Large arteriovenous fistulas that can't be treated with catheter embolization may require surgery.

Name: Arteriovenous malformation
Overview: In an arteriovenous malformation (AVM), blood passes quickly from the artery to vein, disrupting the normal blood flow and depriving the surrounding tissues of oxygen. An arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is an abnormal tangle of blood vessels connecting arteries and veins, which disrupts normal blood flow and oxygen circulation.

Name: Arthritis
Overview: Osteoarthritis, the most common form of arthritis, involves the wearing away of the cartilage that caps the bones in the joints. With rheumatoid arthritis, the synovial membrane that protects and lubricates joints becomes inflamed, causing pain and swelling. Osteoarthritis causes cartilage the hard, slippery tissue that covers the ends of bones where they form a joint to break down.
Risk factors: Some types of arthritis run in families, so one may be more likely to develop arthritis if the parents or siblings have the disorder. The risk of many types of arthritis including osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis and gout increases with age. Women are more likely than men to develop rheumatoid arthritis, while most of the people who have gout, another type of arthritis, are men. People who have injured a joint, perhaps while playing a sport, are more likely to eventually develop arthritis in that joint.
Diagnosis: Combining radio waves with a strong magnetic field, MRI can produce more-detailed cross-sectional images of soft tissues such as cartilage, tendons and ligaments. This technology uses high-frequency sound waves to image soft tissues, cartilage and fluid-containing structures near the joints (bursae).
Remedies: In many cases, arthritis symptoms can be reduced with the following measures: Weight loss. Swimming and water aerobics may be good choices because the buoyancy of the water reduces stress on weight-bearing joints. Using canes, shoe inserts, walkers, raised toilet seats and other assistive devices can help protect the joints and improve the ability to perform daily tasks.
Medication: An over-the-counter option includes acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). For more-severe pain, opioids might be prescribed, such as tramadol (Ultram, ConZip), oxycodone (OxyContin, Roxicodone, others) or hydrocodone (Hysingla, Zohydro ER). Over-the-counter NSAIDs include ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen (Aleve). Typically used in conjunction with DMARDs, biologic response modifiers are genetically engineered drugs that target various protein molecules that are involved in the immune response. Examples include etanercept (Enbrel, Erelzi, Eticovo) and infliximab (Remicade, Inflectra, others). Other medications target other substances that play a role in inflammation, such as interleukin-1 (IL-1), interleukin-6 (IL-6), Janus kinase enzymes, and certain types of white blood cells known as B cells and T cells. Often used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, DMARDs slow or stop the immune system from attacking the joints. Examples include methotrexate (Trexall, Rasuvo, others) and hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil). This class of drugs, which includes prednisone (Prednisone Intensol, Rayos) and cortisone (Cortef), reduces inflammation and suppresses the immune system.
info-Symptoms: Joint pain, stiffness, redness, swelling, decreased range of motion
info-Treatment: Resting, applying ice or heat, weight loss, exercise, joint replacement

Name: Asbestosis
Overview: In the lungs, the main airways (bronchi) branch off into smaller and smaller passageways the smallest, called bronchioles, lead to tiny air sacs (alveoli). Asbestosis (as-bes-TOE-sis) is a chronic lung disease caused by inhaling asbestos fibers. Asbestosis symptoms can range from mild to severe, and usually don't appear until many years after continued exposure.
Diagnosis: These tests show images of the lungs: A spirometer is a diagnostic device that measures the amount of air one is able to breathe in and out and the time it takes one to exhale completely after one take a deep breath. These scans generally provide greater detail and might help detect asbestosis in its early stages, even before it shows up on a chest X-ray. A light and a small camera on the bronchoscope allow the doctor to look inside the lungs airways for any abnormalities or to get a fluid or tissue sample (biopsy) if needed. In this procedure, the doctor injects a local anesthetic and then inserts a needle through the chest wall between the ribs and lungs to remove excess fluid for lab analysis and to help one breathe better.
