Remedies: Smoking may also cause more damage to the lungs and airways, which further reduces the lung reserves. Talk to the doctor about flu and pneumonia vaccines, which can help lower the risk of lung infections.
info-Symptoms: Shortness of breath, cough, wheezing, chest pain
info-Treatment: Supportive care, stopping smoking, vaccination, oxygen therapy

Name: Ascariasis
Overview: Ascariasis worms are typically pink or white with tapered ends. Female worms can be more than 15 inches (40 centimeters) long and a little less than a quarter inch (6 millimeters) in diameter. Adult worms, which reproduce, can be more than a foot (30 centimeters) long.
Causes: Instead, a person has to come into contact with soil mixed with human or pig feces that contain ascariasis eggs or infected water. Unwashed fruits or vegetables grown in contaminated soil also can transmit the ascariasis eggs. The tiny (microscopic) ascariasis eggs can't become infective without coming into contact with soil. People can accidentally ingest (swallow) contaminated soil through hand-to-mouth contact or by eating uncooked fruits or vegetables that have been grown in contaminated soil. Female worms can be more than 15 inches (40 centimeters) long and a little less than a quarter inch (6 millimeters) in diameter. Female worms can produce 200,000 eggs a day if there are both female and male worms in the intestines, and the eggs leave the body in feces.
Diagnosis: To diagnose ascariasis, the doctor will examine the stool for the tiny (microscopic) eggs and larvae. And if one is infected with only male worms, one won't have eggs. Both types of tests create detailed images of the internal structures, which can help the doctor detect worms that are blocking ducts in the liver or pancreas.
Medication: The most common are: These medications, taken for one to three days, kill the adult worms. In cases of heavy infestation, surgery may be necessary to remove worms and repair damage theyve caused. Intestinal blockage or holes, bile duct blockage, and appendicitis are complications that may require surgery. Before the appointment, one may want to write down the answers to the following questions: During the physical exam, the doctor may press on certain areas of the abdomen to check for pain or tenderness.
info-Symptoms: Abdominal swelling, abdominal pain, diarrhea, shortness of breath

Name: Aspergillosis
Symptoms: Over time and without treatment, however, aspergillomas can worsen the underlying chronic lung condition and possibly cause: This is the most severe form of aspergillosis. Invasive aspergillosis occurs only in people whose immune systems are weakened as a result of cancer chemotherapy, bone marrow transplantation or a disease of the immune system.
Overview: Aspergillosis is an infection caused by a type of mold (fungus). Most strains of this mold are harmless, but a few can cause serious illnesses when people with weakened immune systems, underlying lung disease or asthma inhale their fungal spores.
Risk factors: People taking immune-suppressing drugs after undergoing transplant surgery especially bone marrow or stem cell transplants or people who have certain cancers of the blood are at highest risk of invasive aspergillosis. People who have had chemotherapy, an organ transplant or leukemia have lower white cell levels, making them more susceptible to invasive aspergillosis. People with asthma and cystic fibrosis, especially those whose lung problems are long-standing or hard to control, are more likely to have an allergic response to aspergillus mold. Long-term use of corticosteroids may increase the risk of opportunistic infections, depending on the underlying disease being treated and what other drugs are being used.
Diagnosis: A chest X-ray or computerized tomography (CT) scan a type of X-ray that produces more-detailed images than conventional X-rays do can usually reveal a fungal mass (aspergilloma), as well as characteristic signs of invasive aspergillosis and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. Skin testing, as well as sputum and blood tests, may be helpful in confirming allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. In some cases, examining a sample of tissue from the lungs or sinuses under a microscope may be necessary to confirm a diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis.
Treatment: People who develop aspergillosis usually have an underlying condition, such as asthma or cystic fibrosis, or have a weakened immune system due to illness or to immune-suppressing medications. Simple, single aspergillomas often don't need treatment, and medications aren't usually effective in treating these fungal masses. If the condition progresses, then antifungal medications may be recommended. Antifungal medications by themselves aren't helpful for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, but they may be combined with corticosteroids to reduce the dose of steroids and improve lung function. Because antifungal medications don't penetrate an aspergilloma very well, surgery to remove the fungal mass is the first-choice treatment when an aspergilloma causes bleeding in the lungs.

Name: Asthma
Symptoms: One may have infrequent asthma attacks, have symptoms only at certain times such as when exercising or have symptoms all the time. Signs of an asthma emergency include See the doctor: If the asthma symptoms get worse. If one has frequent coughing or wheezing that lasts more than a few days or any other signs or symptoms of asthma, see the doctor.
Overview: If one has asthma, the inside walls of the airways in the lungs can become inflamed and swollen. During an asthma attack, the narrowed airways make it harder to breathe, and one may cough and wheeze.
Diagnosis: The doctor will perform a physical exam to rule out other possible conditions, such as a respiratory infection or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). These tests may include Lung function tests often are done before and after taking a medication to open the airways called a bronchodilator (brong-koh-DIE-lay-tur), such as albuterol. Other tests to diagnose asthma include To classify the asthma severity, the doctor will consider how often one has signs and symptoms and how severe they are. In these tests, the doctor measures the airway obstruction before and after one perform vigorous physical activity or take several breaths of cold air.
Remedies: Although many people with asthma rely on medications to prevent and relieve symptoms, one can do several things on the own to maintain the health and lessen the possibility of asthma attacks. To reduce the exposure, one should: Taking care of theself can help keep the symptoms under control, including Get regular exercise. Regular exercise can strengthen the heart and lungs, which helps relieve asthma symptoms. Air conditioning reduces the amount of airborne pollen from trees, grasses and weeds that finds its way indoors. If the asthma is worsened by cold or dry air, wearing a face mask can help. Being overweight can worsen asthma symptoms, and it puts one at higher risk of other health problems. It's possible that the acid reflux that causes heartburn may damage lung airways and worsen asthma symptoms.
Medication: The right medications for one depend on a number of things the age, symptoms, asthma triggers and what works best to keep the asthma under control. Preventive, long-term control medications reduce the swelling (inflammation) in the airways that leads to symptoms. Long-term asthma control medications, generally taken daily, are the cornerstone of asthma treatment. These medications include fluticasone propionate (Flovent HFA, Flovent Diskus, Xhance), budesonide (Pulmicort Flexhaler, Pulmicort Respules, Rhinocort), ciclesonide (Alvesco), beclomethasone (Qvar Redihaler), mometasone (Asmanex HFA, Asmanex Twisthaler) and fluticasone furoate (Arnuity Ellipta). These oral medications including montelukast (Singulair), zafirlukast (Accolate) and zileuton (Zyflo) help relieve asthma symptoms. Quick-relief (rescue) medications are used as needed for rapid, short-term symptom relief during an asthma attack. They include albuterol (ProAir HFA, Ventolin HFA, others) and levalbuterol (Xopenex, Xopenex HFA). Short-acting beta agonists can be taken using a portable, hand-held inhaler or a nebulizer, a machine that converts asthma medications to a fine mist. These medications such as fluticasone-salmeterol (Advair HFA, Airduo Digihaler, others), budesonide-formoterol (Symbicort), formoterol-mometasone (Dulera) and fluticasone furoate-vilanterol (Breo Ellipta) contain a long-acting beta agonist along with a corticosteroid. Theophylline (Theo-24, Elixophyllin, Theochron) is a daily pill that helps keep the airways open by relaxing the muscles around the airways. Like other bronchodilators, ipratropium (Atrovent HFA) and tiotropium (Spiriva, Spiriva Respimat) act quickly to immediately relax the airways, making it easier to breathe. These medications which include prednisone (Prednisone Intensol, Rayos) and methylprednisolone (Medrol, Depo-Medrol, Solu-Medrol) relieve airway inflammation caused by severe asthma. These medications which include omalizumab (Xolair), mepolizumab (Nucala), dupilumab (Dupixent), reslizumab (Cinqair) and benralizumab (Fasenra) are specifically for people who have severe asthma.
info-Symptoms: Recurring episodes of wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, shortness of breath
info-Risk factors: Air pollution, allergens
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, response to therapy, spirometry

Name: Asthma attack
Overview: During an asthma attack, also called an asthma exacerbation, the airways become swollen and inflamed. The treatment plan should include what to do when the asthma starts getting worse, and how to deal with an asthma attack in progress.
Diagnosis: For adults and children over 5 years old, lung (pulmonary) function tests are used to check how well the lungs are working. In some cases, lung function tests are also used in asthma emergencies to help the doctor understand the severity of an asthma attack or how well treatment is working. Nitric oxide test for asthma Peak flow meter Spirometry Peak flow.
Treatment: This generally means taking two to six puffs of a quick-acting (rescue) inhaler to get airway-expanding medication, such as albuterol (ProAir HFA, Proventil HFA, Ventolin HFA, others) and levalbuterol (Xopenex), deep into the lungs. If one is having symptoms of a severe asthma attack, such as difficulty speaking because one is so short of breath, use the quick-acting (rescue) medication and get to a doctor's office or urgent care immediately.
info-Symptoms: Recurring episodes of wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, shortness of breath
info-Risk factors: Air pollution, allergens
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, response to therapy, spirometry

Name: Astigmatism
Overview: Astigmatism (uh-STIG-muh-tiz-um) is a common and generally treatable imperfection in the curvature of the eye that causes blurred distance and near vision. Astigmatism occurs when either the front surface of the eye (cornea) or the lens, inside the eye, has mismatched curves.
Causes: Astigmatism is a type of refractive error caused when either the cornea or lens has mismatched curves. If either the cornea or lens is egg shaped with two mismatched curves, light rays aren't bent the same, which forms two different images. Astigmatism isn't caused or made worse by reading in poor light, sitting too close to the television or squinting.
info-Symptoms: Distorted or blurred vision at all distances, eyestrain, headaches

Name: Astrocytoma
Diagnosis: If the primary care doctor suspects one has a brain tumor, one may be referred to a specialist who is trained in treating brain and nervous system disorders (neurologist). In some cases, a dye (contrast material) may be injected through a vein in the arm during the MRI study to help show differences in brain tissue. A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. Brain tumor imaging Collecting and testing a sample of abnormal tissue (biopsy). Depending on the location of the glioma, a biopsy may be performed with a needle before treatment or as part of an operation to remove the brain tumor. Based on this information, a doctor who specializes in diagnosing cancer and other tissue abnormalities (pathologist) can determine the grade or stage of a brain tumor. To rule out other types of brain tumors that may have spread from other parts of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer originated.

Name: Ataxia
Overview: Persistent ataxia usually results from damage to the part of the brain that controls muscle coordination (cerebellum). Many conditions can cause ataxia, including alcohol misuse, certain medication, stroke, tumor, cerebral palsy, brain degeneration and multiple sclerosis.
Causes: Damage, degeneration or loss of nerve cells in the part of the brain that controls muscle coordination (cerebellum), results in ataxia. For some adults who develop sporadic ataxia, no specific cause can be found. Sporadic ataxia can take a number of forms, including multiple system atrophy, a progressive, degenerative disorder. The abnormal proteins hamper the function of nerve cells, primarily in the cerebellum and spinal cord, and cause them to degenerate. In the latter case, it's possible neither parent has the disorder (silent mutation), so there might be no obvious family history. Different gene defects cause different types of ataxia, most of which are progressive. In an autosomal dominant disorder, the abnormal gene is a dominant gene located on one of the nonsex chromosomes (autosomes). There are eight recognized types of ataxia that are episodic rather than progressive EA1 through EA7, plus late-onset episodic ataxia. One might have dizziness (vertigo), fatigue and muscle weakness during the episodes. Episodic ataxia doesn't shorten life span, and symptoms might respond to medication. This common hereditary ataxia involves damage to the cerebellum, spinal cord and peripheral nerves. This rare, progressive childhood disease causes degeneration in the brain and other body systems. The disease also causes immune system breakdown (immunodeficiency disease), which increases susceptibility to other diseases, including infections and tumors. Children with ataxia-telangiectasia are at high risk of developing cancer, particularly leukemia or lymphoma. Most people with the disease need a wheelchair by their teens and die before age 30, usually of cancer or lung (pulmonary) disease. Multiple sclerosis, sarcoidosis, celiac disease and other autoimmune conditions can cause ataxia. A growth on the brain, cancerous (malignant) or noncancerous (benign), can damage the cerebellum. Not getting enough of these nutrients, because of the inability to absorb enough, alcohol misuse or other reasons, can lead to ataxia. This infection may cause ataxia, most commonly in very severe cases. Researchers have identified more than 40 autosomal dominant ataxia genes, and the number continues to grow. In some cases, symptoms resolve in later life.Episodic ataxia doesn't shorten life span, and symptoms might respond to medication. People with this condition accumulate copper in their brains, livers and other organs, which can cause neurological problems, including ataxia.
Diagnosis: Besides conducting a physical exam and a neurological exam, including checking the memory and concentration, vision, hearing, balance, coordination, and reflexes, the doctor might request laboratory tests, including Imaging studies. Complete blood count (CBC) CT scan Genetic testing Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) MRI Urinalysis Imaging studies.
info-Symptoms: Lack of coordination Slurred speech Trouble eating and swallowing Deterioration of fine motor skills Difficulty walking Gait abnormalities Eye movement abnormalities Tremors Heart problems

Name: Atrial fibrillation
Symptoms: The doctor may order an electrocardiogram to determine if the symptoms are related to atrial fibrillation or another heart rhythm disorder (arrhythmia). With this type of atrial fibrillation, the heart rhythm doesn't go back to normal on its own. If one has persistent atrial fibrillation, one will need treatment such as an electrical shock or medications in order to restore the heart rhythm. In this type of atrial fibrillation, the abnormal heart rhythm can't be restored. One will have atrial fibrillation permanently, and one will often require medications to control the heart rate and to prevent blood clots.
Causes: In atrial fibrillation, electrical signals fire from multiple locations in the atria (typically pulmonary veins), causing them to beat chaotically. Atrial fibrillation is an irregular and often rapid heart rate that occurs when the two upper chambers of the heart experience chaotic electrical signals. In atrial fibrillation, the signals in the upper chambers of the heart are chaotic. Atrial flutter is similar to atrial fibrillation, but the rhythm in the atria is more organized and less chaotic than the abnormal patterns common with atrial fibrillation.
Risk factors: The older one is, the greater the risk of developing atrial fibrillation. Anyone with heart disease such as heart valve problems, congenital heart disease, congestive heart failure, coronary artery disease, or a history of heart attack or heart surgery has an increased risk of atrial fibrillation. Having high blood pressure, especially if it's not well-controlled with lifestyle changes or medications, can increase the risk of atrial fibrillation. People with certain chronic conditions such as thyroid problems, sleep apnea, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, chronic kidney disease or lung disease have an increased risk of atrial fibrillation.
Diagnosis: To diagnose atrial fibrillation, the doctor may review the signs and symptoms, review the medical history, and conduct a physical examination. The doctor may order several tests to diagnose the condition, including Electrocardiogram (ECG). It records the heart's activity for 24 hours or longer, which provides the doctor with a prolonged look at the heart rhythms. When one experience symptoms of a fast heart rate, one push a button, and an ECG strip of the preceding few minutes and following few minutes is recorded. The doctor can also use an X-ray to diagnose conditions other than atrial fibrillation that may explain the signs and symptoms.
Remedies: One may need to make lifestyle changes that improve the overall health of the heart, especially to prevent or treat conditions such as high blood pressure and heart disease. The doctor may suggest several lifestyle changes, including Eat heart-healthy foods. Healthy weight loss can help to manage symptoms of atrial fibrillation and may improve the results of catheter ablation. Make lifestyle changes and take medications as prescribed to correct high blood pressure (hypertension) or high cholesterol. Binge drinking (having five drinks in two hours for men or four drinks for women) can increase the chances of atrial fibrillation.
info-Symptoms: None, heart palpitations, fainting, shortness of breath, chest pain
info-Risk factors: High blood pressure, valvular heart disease, coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, congenital heart disease, COPD, obesity, smoking, sleep apnea
info-Treatment: Lifestyle modifications, rate control, rhythm control, anticoagulation

Name: Atrial tachycardia
Diagnosis: The doctor may ask about or test for conditions that may trigger the SVT, such as heart disease or a problem with the thyroid gland. The doctor may also perform heart-monitoring tests specific to arrhythmia. These may include If the doctor doesn't find an arrhythmia during those tests, he or she may try to trigger the arrhythmia with other tests, which may include Electrophysiological testing and mapping. In this test, doctors thread thin tubes (catheters) tipped with electrodes through the blood vessels to a variety of spots within the heart. In addition, the cardiologist can use the electrodes to stimulate the heart to beat at rates that may trigger or halt an arrhythmia. During an ECG, sensors (electrodes) that can detect the electrical activity of the heart are attached to the chest and sometimes to the limbs. In this noninvasive test, a hand-held device (transducer) placed on the chest uses sound waves to produce images of the heart's size, structure and motion. During a stress test, one will be asked to exercise on a treadmill or stationary bicycle while the heart activity is monitored. If doctors are evaluating one to determine if coronary artery disease may be causing the arrhythmia, and one has difficulty exercising, then the doctor may use a drug to stimulate the heart in a way that's similar to exercise.
Remedies: The doctor may suggest that, in addition to other treatments, one make lifestyle changes that will keep the heart as healthy as possible. Eat a healthy diet that's low in salt and solid fats and rich in fruits, vegetables and whole grains. Make lifestyle changes and take medications as prescribed to correct high blood pressure (hypertension) or high cholesterol. For healthy adults, that means up to one drink a day for women of all ages and men older than age 65, and up to two drinks a day for men age 65 and younger.

Name: Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder ( ADHD ) in children
Symptoms: ADHD symptoms start before age 12, and in some children, they're noticeable as early as 3 years of age. Even in older children and teenagers, attention span often depends on the level of interest. The same is true of children who are hyperactive or inattentive at home, but whose schoolwork and friendships remain unaffected.
Overview: Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a chronic condition that affects millions of children and often continues into adulthood. Children with ADHD may also struggle with low self-esteem, troubled relationships and poor performance in school. While treatment won't cure ADHD, it can help a great deal with symptoms.
Remedies: Because ADHD is complex and each person with ADHD is unique, it's hard to make recommendations that work for every child. If the child has a hard time accepting verbal signs of affection, a smile, a pat on the shoulder or a hug can show one care. Children with ADHD often do well with art projects, music or dance lessons, or martial arts classes. Try to avoid situations that are difficult for the child, such as sitting through long presentations or shopping in malls and stores where the array of merchandise can be overwhelming. Help the child learn social skills by modeling, recognizing and rewarding positive interactions with peers. Be sure teachers closely monitor the child's work, provide positive feedback, and are flexible and patient.

Name: Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder in adults
Symptoms: Some people with ADHD have fewer symptoms as they age, but some adults continue to have major symptoms that interfere with daily functioning. Adults with ADHD may find it difficult to focus and prioritize, leading to missed deadlines and forgotten meetings or social plans. Diagnosis of ADHD in adults can be difficult because certain ADHD symptoms are similar to those caused by other conditions, such as anxiety or mood disorders.
Causes: ADHD can run in families, and studies indicate that genes may play a role. Certain environmental factors also may increase risk, such as lead exposure as a child. Problems with the central nervous system at key moments in development may play a role.
Remedies: Take time to set up systems to file and organize information, both on the electronic devices and for paper documents. Make a list of tasks Break down tasks Use sticky pads Keep an appointment book Carry a notebook or electronic device with one Take time to set up systems to file and organize information, Follow a routine Ask for help
Medication: Counseling for adult ADHD generally includes psychological counseling (psychotherapy), education about the disorder and learning skills to help one be successful. Psychotherapy may help one: Common types of psychotherapy for ADHD include If one is like many adults with ADHD, one may be unpredictable and forget appointments, miss deadlines, and make impulsive or irrational decisions. Stimulants, such as products that include methylphenidate or amphetamine, are typically the most commonly prescribed medications for ADHD, but other medications may be prescribed. Atomoxetine and antidepressants work slower than stimulants do, but these may be good options if one can't take stimulants because of health problems or if stimulants cause severe side effects. Improve the time management and organizational skills Learn how to reduce the impulsive behavior Develop better problem-solving skills Cope with past academic, work or social failures Improve the self-esteem Learn ways to improve relationships with the family, co-workers and friends Develop strategies for controlling the temper Cognitive behavioral therapy.

Name: Atypical depression
Causes: Atypical depression often starts in the teenage years, earlier than other types of depression, and can have a more long-term (chronic) course. When these chemicals are abnormal or impaired, the function of nerve receptors and nerve systems change, leading to depression.
Diagnosis: These exams and tests can help the doctor rule out other problems that could be causing the symptoms, determine a diagnosis and check for any related complications: Physical exam. For example, the doctor may do a blood test called a complete blood count (CBC) or test the thyroid to make sure it's functioning properly. To help make a diagnosis, the mental health professional may compare the symptoms with the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association.
Remedies: But in addition to professional treatment, these self-care steps can help: Stick to the treatment plan. If one stop, depression symptoms may come back, and one could also experience withdrawal-like symptoms. It may seem like alcohol or drugs lessen depression symptoms, but in the long run they generally worsen symptoms and make depression harder to treat.
Medication: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), as well as other types of psychotherapy, can help one: As part of the treatment, it's important to also address other conditions that often accompany atypical depression, in particular anxiety and drug or alcohol misuse, as they can make the depression more difficult to treat. However, some experts feel that MAOIs, especially phenelzine (Nardil), can be effective for atypical depression. Using MAOIs requires a strict diet because of dangerous (or even deadly) interactions with certain foods and some prescription and over-the-counter medications, such as decongestants and certain herbal supplements. Learn how to identify and change unhealthy behavior or thoughts Explore relationships and experiences Find better ways to cope and solve problems Set realistic goals for the life Regain a sense of satisfaction and control in the life Help ease depression symptoms such as hopelessness and anger Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs).
info-Symptoms: Low mood, mood reactivity, hyperphagia, hypersomnia, leaden paralysis, interpersonal rejection sensitivity
info-Risk factors: Bipolar disorder, anxiety disorder, female sex

Name: Atypical hyperplasia of the breast
Overview: Ductal breast cancer is thought to begin with abnormal tissue growth in a breast duct. E. Eventually the cancer cells grow beyond the breast duct (invasive ductal carcinoma) and can spread to other areas of the body. Over the course of the lifetime, if the atypical hyperplasia cells keep dividing and become more abnormal, this can transition into noninvasive breast cancer (carcinoma in situ) or invasive breast cancer.
Causes: Atypical hyperplasia forms when breast cells become abnormal in number, size, shape, growth pattern and appearance. The progression to breast cancer typically involves: Atypical ductal hyperplasia causes abnormal cells that appear similar to the cells of the breast ducts. Atypical lobular hyperplasia causes abnormal cells that appear similar to the cells of the breast lobules. The process begins when normal cell development and growth become disrupted, causing an overproduction of normal-looking cells (hyperplasia). Left untreated, the cancer cells may eventually become invasive cancer, invading surrounding tissue, blood vessels or lymph channels.

Name: Autism spectrum disorder
Symptoms: Some children show signs of autism spectrum disorder in early infancy, such as reduced eye contact, lack of response to their name or indifference to caregivers. Some children with autism spectrum disorder have difficulty learning, and some have signs of lower than normal intelligence. But children with autism spectrum disorder usually show some signs of delayed development before age 2 years. If one is concerned about the child's development or one suspect that the child may have autism spectrum disorder, discuss the concerns with the doctor.
Overview: Autism spectrum disorder is a condition related to brain development that impacts how a person perceives and socializes with others, causing problems in social interaction and communication. Autism spectrum disorder includes conditions that were previously considered separate autism, Asperger's syndrome, childhood disintegrative disorder and an unspecified form of pervasive developmental disorder.
Causes: Despite extensive research, no reliable study has shown a link between autism spectrum disorder and any vaccines. For some children, autism spectrum disorder can be associated with a genetic disorder, such as Rett syndrome or fragile X syndrome. For other children, genetic changes (mutations) may increase the risk of autism spectrum disorder. Researchers are currently exploring whether factors such as viral infections, medications or complications during pregnancy, or air pollutants play a role in triggering autism spectrum disorder.
Risk factors: Autism spectrum disorder affects children of all races and nationalities, but certain factors increase a child's risk. It's also not uncommon for parents or relatives of a child with autism spectrum disorder to have minor problems with social or communication skills themselves or to engage in certain behaviors typical of the disorder. Children with certain medical conditions have a higher than normal risk of autism spectrum disorder or autism-like symptoms. Examples include fragile X syndrome, an inherited disorder that causes intellectual problems; tuberous sclerosis, a condition in which benign tumors develop in the brain; and Rett syndrome, a genetic condition occurring almost exclusively in girls, which causes slowing of head growth, intellectual disability and loss of purposeful hand use. There may be a connection between children born to older parents and autism spectrum disorder, but more research is necessary to establish this link.
Treatment: Early intervention during the preschool years can help the child learn critical social, communication, functional and behavioral skills. The range of home-based and school-based treatments and interventions for autism spectrum disorder can be overwhelming, and the child's needs may change over time. If the child is diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder, talk to experts about creating a treatment strategy and build a team of professionals to meet the child's needs. Many programs address the range of social, language and behavioral difficulties associated with autism spectrum disorder. Parents and other family members can learn how to play and interact with their children in ways that promote social interaction skills, manage problem behaviors, and teach daily living skills and communication. Depending on the child's needs, speech therapy to improve communication skills, occupational therapy to teach activities of daily living, and physical therapy to improve movement and balance may be beneficial. For example, certain medications may be prescribed if the child is hyperactive; antipsychotic drugs are sometimes used to treat severe behavioral problems; and antidepressants may be prescribed for anxiety.
info-Specialty: Clinical psychology, psychiatry, pediatrics, occupational medicine
info-Symptoms: Impairments in social interaction, verbal and nonverbal communication, and the presence of restricted interests and repetitive behavior
info-Risk factors: Family history, certain genetic conditions, having older parents, certain prescribed drugs, perinatal and neonatal health issues
info-Diagnostic method: Based on observation of behavior and development
info-Treatment: Behavioral therapy, educational therapy, psychotropic medication

Name: Autoimmune pancreatitis
Symptoms: Other differences between type 1 and type 2 AIP are: Autoimmune pancreatitis often doesn't cause any symptoms. Type 2 AIP affects only the pancreas, although the disease is associated with another autoimmune condition, inflammatory bowel disease.
Overview: Autoimmune pancreatitis, also called AIP, is a chronic inflammation that is thought to be caused by the body's immune system attacking the pancreas and that responds to steroid therapy. Type 1 AIP is also called IgG4-related pancreatitis and is part of a disease called IgG4-related disease (IgG4-RD) that often affects multiple organs including the pancreas, bile ducts in the liver, salivary glands, kidneys and lymph nodes.
Diagnosis: To pinpoint the diagnosis and determine which type of AIP one has, blood and imaging tests are necessary. People with type 1 AIP, but not with type 2 AIP, will have highly elevated blood levels of IgG4. A small number of people who don't have autoimmune pancreatitis, including some with pancreatic cancer, also have high blood levels of IgG4. Doctors insert a small tube (endoscope) through the mouth into the stomach and, guided by ultrasound, remove some tissue from the pancreas using a special needle. Tests of the pancreas and other organs may include CT, MRI, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) and endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatograph (ERCP). Because autoimmune pancreatitis is the only pancreatic disorder known to respond to steroids, doctors sometimes use a trial course of this drug to confirm a diagnosis.
Treatment: To help reduce the serious side effects associated with extended steroid use, doctors often add drugs that suppress or modify the immune system, sometimes called steroid-sparing medications, to the treatment. One may be able to stop taking steroids altogether Immunosuppressants and immunomodulators include mercaptopurine (Purinethol, Purixan), azathioprine (Imuran, Azasan) and rituximab (Rituxan). Before starting medication, sometimes doctors will insert a tube to drain the biliary ducts (biliary stenting) in people with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. One may be able to stop taking steroids altogetherttImmunosuppressants and immunomodulators include mercaptopurine (Purinethol, Purixan), azathioprine (Imuran, Azasan) and rituximab (Rituxan). In general, they have been used in small sample groups and long-term benefits are still being studied.t Treatment for pancreatic insufficiency. If one need supplements, the doctor will prescribe pancreatic enzymes (Creon, Viokace, Pancreaze, Zenpep, Pertzye). Type 1 AIP often is associated with other organ involvement, including enlarged lymph nodes and salivary glands, scarring of the bile ducts, liver inflammation, and kidney disease.
info-Symptoms: Painless jaundice, pancreatic mass

Name: AVNRT
Diagnosis: The doctor may ask about or test for conditions that may trigger the SVT, such as heart disease or a problem with the thyroid gland. The doctor may also perform heart-monitoring tests specific to arrhythmia. These may include If the doctor doesn't find an arrhythmia during those tests, he or she may try to trigger the arrhythmia with other tests, which may include Electrophysiological testing and mapping. In this test, doctors thread thin tubes (catheters) tipped with electrodes through the blood vessels to a variety of spots within the heart. In addition, the cardiologist can use the electrodes to stimulate the heart to beat at rates that may trigger or halt an arrhythmia. During an ECG, sensors (electrodes) that can detect the electrical activity of the heart are attached to the chest and sometimes to the limbs. In this noninvasive test, a hand-held device (transducer) placed on the chest uses sound waves to produce images of the heart's size, structure and motion. During a stress test, one will be asked to exercise on a treadmill or stationary bicycle while the heart activity is monitored. If doctors are evaluating one to determine if coronary artery disease may be causing the arrhythmia, and one has difficulty exercising, then the doctor may use a drug to stimulate the heart in a way that's similar to exercise.
Remedies: The doctor may suggest that, in addition to other treatments, one make lifestyle changes that will keep the heart as healthy as possible. Eat a healthy diet that's low in salt and solid fats and rich in fruits, vegetables and whole grains. Make lifestyle changes and take medications as prescribed to correct high blood pressure (hypertension) or high cholesterol. For healthy adults, that means up to one drink a day for women of all ages and men older than age 65, and up to two drinks a day for men age 65 and younger.
info-Symptoms: Palpitations, chest tightness, neck pulsation
info-Medication: adenosine, calcium channel antagonists, beta blockers, flecainide

Name: Baby acne
Treatment: If the baby's acne lingers for much longer, the baby's doctor may recommend a medicated cream or other treatment. These tips are useful for caring for the baby's skin while he or she has acne: If one is following a standard well-baby exam schedule, the baby will likely visit with the family doctor or pediatrician soon. For baby acne, some basic questions to ask the doctor include Keep the baby's face clean.
Remedies: These tips are useful for caring for the baby's skin while he or she has acne: Keep the baby's face clean. Wash the baby's face daily with warm water and mild baby soap. Avoid using lotions or oils on the baby's face.

Name: Back pain
Causes: Back pain that comes on suddenly and lasts no more than six weeks (acute) can be caused by a fall or heavy lifting. Back pain that lasts more than three months (chronic) is less common than acute pain. Back pain often develops without a cause that the doctor can identify with a test or an imaging study. Conditions commonly linked to back pain include Muscle or ligament strain. If one is in poor physical condition, constant strain on the back can cause painful muscle spasms. However, one can have a bulging or ruptured disk without back pain. A condition in which the spine curves to the side (scoliosis) also can lead to back pain, but generally not until middle age.
Risk factors: Anyone can develop back pain, even children and teens. These factors might put one at greater risk of developing back pain: Age. Back pain is more common as one get older, starting around age 30 or 40. Weak, unused muscles in the back and abdomen might lead to back pain. People prone to depression and anxiety appear to have a greater risk of back pain. This reduces blood flow to the lower spine, which can keep the body from delivering enough nutrients to the disks in the back.
Diagnosis: If there is reason to suspect that a specific condition is causing the back pain, the doctor might order one or more tests: X-ray. These images alone won't show problems with the spinal cord, muscles, nerves or disks. These scans generate images that can reveal herniated disks or problems with bones, muscles, tissue, tendons, nerves, ligaments and blood vessels. In rare cases, the doctor might use a bone scan to look for bone tumors or compression fractures caused by osteoporosis.
Medication: Depending on the type of back pain one has, the doctor might recommend the following: There's no commonly accepted program to teach people with back pain how to manage the condition effectively. A physical therapist can apply a variety of treatments, such as heat, ultrasound, electrical stimulation and muscle-release techniques, to the back muscles and soft tissues to reduce pain. As pain improves, the therapist can teach one exercises to increase the flexibility, strengthen the back and abdominal muscles, and improve the posture. If one has unrelenting pain associated with radiating leg pain or progressive muscle weakness caused by nerve compression, one might benefit from surgery. Otherwise, surgery usually is reserved for pain related to structural problems, such as narrowing of the spine (spinal stenosis) or a herniated disk, that hasn't responded to other therapy. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve), might relieve acute back pain. If OTC pain relievers don't relieve the pain, the doctor might suggest prescription NSAIDs. If mild to moderate back pain doesn't improve with OTC pain relievers, the doctor might also prescribe a muscle relaxant. Low doses of certain types of antidepressants particularly tricyclic antidepressants, such as amitriptyline have been shown to relieve some types of chronic back pain independent of their effect on depression. If other measures don't relieve the pain, and if the pain radiates down the leg, the doctor may inject cortisone an anti-inflammatory medication or numbing medication into the space around the spinal cord (epidural space).

Name: Bacterial vaginosis
Risk factors: Doctors don't fully understand the link between sexual activity and bacterial vaginosis, but the condition occurs more often in women who have multiple sex partners or a new sex partner. If the natural vaginal environment doesn't produce enough of the good lactobacilli bacteria, one is more likely to develop bacterial vaginosis.
Diagnosis: During a pelvic exam, the doctor visually examines the vagina for signs of infection, and inserts two fingers into the vagina while pressing on the abdomen with the other hand to check the pelvic organs for signs that may indicate disease. The doctor may examine the vaginal secretions under a microscope, looking for clue cells, vaginal cells covered with bacteria that are a sign of bacterial vaginosis.
Treatment: To treat bacterial vaginosis, the doctor may prescribe one of the following medications: It's generally not necessary to treat an infected woman's male sexual partner, but bacterial vaginosis can spread between female sexual partners. To reduce the risk of stomach upset, abdominal pain or nausea while using this medication, avoid alcohol during treatment and for at least one day after completing treatment check the instructions on the product. Tinidazole has the same potential for stomach upset and nausea as oral metronidazole does, so avoid alcohol during treatment and for at least three days after completing treatment.
info-Symptoms: Vaginal discharge that often smells like fish, burning with urination
info-Causes: Imbalance of the naturally occurring bacteria in the vagina
info-Risk factors: Douching, new or multiple sex partners, antibiotics, using an intrauterine device

Name: Balance problems
Overview: Balance problems can make one feel dizzy, as if the room is spinning, unsteady, or lightheaded. Many body systems including the muscles, bones, joints, eyes, the balance organ in the inner ear, nerves, heart and blood vessels must work normally for one to have normal balance.
Causes: This inflammatory disorder, probably caused by a virus, can affect the nerves in the balance portion of the inner ear. In addition to sudden and severe vertigo, Meniere's disease can cause fluctuating hearing loss and buzzing, ringing or a feeling of fullness in the ear. This noncancerous (benign), slow-growing tumor develops on a nerve that affects the hearing and balance. One might experience dizziness or loss of balance, but the most common symptoms are hearing loss and ringing in the ear. Also known as herpes zoster oticus, this condition occurs when a shingles-like infection affects the facial, auditory and vestibular nerves near one of the ears. One might experience vertigo, ear pain, facial weakness and hearing loss. Standing or sitting up too quickly can cause some people to experience a significant drop in their blood pressure, resulting in feeling lightheaded or faint. Depression (major depressive disorder), anxiety and other psychiatric disorders can cause dizziness.
Diagnosis: The rotary chair test analyzes eye movements while one sit in a chair that moves slowly in a circle. To determine if the symptoms are caused by problems in the balance function in the inner ear, the doctor is likely to recommend tests. Both tests record the eye movements, which play a role in vestibular function and balance. The doctor carefully turns the head in different positions while watching the eye movements to determine whether one has a false sense of motion or spinning.
Treatment: Therapy can help one compensate for imbalance, adapt to less balance and maintain physical activity. To prevent falls, the therapist might recommend a balance aid, such as a cane, and ways to reduce the risk of falls in the home. If one has BPPV, a therapist might conduct a procedure (canalith repositioning) that clears particles out of the inner ear and deposits them into a different area of the ear. If one has Meniere's disease or migraines, dietary changes are often suggested that can ease symptoms. One may need to limit salt intake and avoid other dietary triggers such as caffeine, alcohol and certain ingredients. If one experience postural hypotension, one might need to drink more fluids or wear compression stockings. If one has severe vertigo that lasts hours or days, one might be prescribed medications that can control dizziness and vomiting. If one has Meniere's disease or acoustic neuroma, the treatment team may recommend surgery. Meniere disease: Evaluation, diagnosis, and management.

Name: Barotrauma
Causes: When a plane climbs or descends, the air pressure changes quickly, and the eustachian tube often doesnt react quickly enough. A narrow passage called the eustachian tube, which is connected to the middle ear, regulates air pressure. The eustachian tube often can't react fast enough, which causes the symptoms of airplane ear. Swallowing or yawning opens the eustachian tube and allows the middle ear to get more air, equalizing the air pressure.
info-Symptoms: Dependent on cause

Name: Barrett 's esophagus
Overview: In Barrett's esophagus, normally flat, pink cells are replaced with a thick, red lining with potential for cancerous changes, thought to be triggered by long-standing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the flat pink lining of the swallowing tube that connects the mouth to the stomach (esophagus) becomes damaged by acid reflux, which causes the lining to thicken and become red.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of Barrett's esophagus include Family history. The odds of having Barrett's esophagus increase if one has a family history of Barrett's esophagus or esophageal cancer. Barrett's esophagus can occur at any age but is more common in adults over 50. Having GERD that doesn't get better when taking medications known as proton pump inhibitors or having GERD that requires regular medication can increase the risk of Barrett's esophagus.
Remedies: Eliminating foods and drinks that trigger the heartburn, such as chocolate, coffee, alcohol and mint. Eliminating foods and drinks that trigger the heartburn, Stopping smoking.

Name: Behcet 's disease
Symptoms: Behcet's disease symptoms vary from person to person, can come and go or become less severe over time. Areas commonly affected by Behcet's disease include Make an appointment with the doctor if one notice unusual signs and symptoms that might indicate Behcet's disease. If one has been diagnosed with the condition, see the doctor if one notice new signs and symptoms. Painful mouth sores that look similar to canker sores are the most common sign of Behcet's disease. Inflammation in the eye (uveitis) causes redness, pain and blurred vision, typically in both eyes. In people with Behcet's disease, the condition can come and go. Inflammation in veins and arteries can cause redness, pain, and swelling in the arms or legs when a blood clot results. A variety of signs and symptoms can affect the digestive system, including abdominal pain, diarrhea and bleeding.
Causes: Behcet's disease might be an autoimmune disorder, which means the body's immune system mistakenly attacks some of its own healthy cells. Some researchers believe a virus or bacterium can trigger Behcet's disease in people who have certain genes that make them susceptible to Behcet's.
Risk factors: Behcet's disease commonly affects men and women in their 20s and 30s, though children and older adults also can develop the condition. People from countries in the Middle East and East Asia, including Turkey, Iran, Japan and China, are more likely to develop Behcet's. While Behcet's disease occurs in both men and women, the disease is usually more severe in men.
Diagnosis: Because nearly everyone with the condition develops mouth sores, mouth sores that have recurred at least three times in 12 months are generally necessary for a diagnosis of Behcet's disease. In addition, a diagnosis of Behcet's disease requires at least two additional signs, such as: Tests one might need include Recurring genital sores Eye inflammation Skin sores Blood tests or other laboratory tests might rule out other conditions.

Name: Benign adrenal tumors
Overview: Perched atop each of the kidneys, the adrenal glands produce hormones that help regulate the metabolism, immune system, blood pressure and other essential functions. As part of the endocrine system, the adrenal glands produce hormones that give instructions to nearly every organ and tissue in the body.

Name: Benign peripheral nerve tumor
Overview: The peripheral nerves link the brain and spinal cord to other parts of the body. Most tumors aren't cancerous (malignant), but they can lead to nerve damage and loss of muscle control. Peripheral nerve tumors affect nerves by growing within them (intraneural tumors) or by pressing against them (extraneural tumors). The most common benign peripheral nerve tumor in adults, a schwannoma, can occur anywhere. Some schwannomas may enlarge and assume unusual shapes within the spine or pelvis, such as dumbbell tumors. If one has a rare schwannoma near the brainstem (an acoustic neuroma), one may notice trouble with the balance or hearing. Also known as a vestibular schwannoma, most of the time this type of tumor forms without being associated with a syndrome, but a few acoustic neuromas may be diagnosed as neurofibromatosis 2 (NF2) tumors. Schwannomas most commonly occur as solitary tumors, though occasionally individuals may have several of them in the arms, legs or body, a condition known as schwannomatosis. Some people who have NF1 may develop other conditions, such as curvature of the spine (scoliosis), another bone deformity or an eye nerve tumor (optic glioma).
Causes: The cause of benign peripheral nerve tumors usually isn't known. Other benign tumors that form outside nerves are soft lumps of slow-growing fat cells called lipomas and ganglion cysts. Peripheral nerve tumors of the extremities. Peripheral nerve tumors. Benign tumors of peripheral nerves.

Name: Bicuspid aortic valve
Diagnosis: To diagnose congenital heart disease, the doctor will do a physical exam and listen to the heart with a stethoscope. Tests to diagnose or rule out congenital heart disease include Electrocardiogram (ECG). An ECG can diagnose many heart problems, including irregular heartbeats and blocked arteries. The doctor can use this test to see how the heart's chambers and valves are pumping blood through the heart. If more-detailed images of the heart are needed, the doctor may recommend a transesophageal echocardiogram. Cardiac MRI uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create images of the heart. The doctor might use this test to check blood flow and blood pressures in the heart. Then, the doctor gently inserts a catheter into an artery or vein in the groin, neck or arm and up to the heart.
Medication: If one is an adult with congenital heart disease, one is at risk of developing complications even if one had surgery to repair a defect during childhood. A device that helps control the heart rate (pacemaker) or that corrects life-threatening irregular heartbeats (implantable cardioverter-defibrillator or ICD) may help improve some of the complications associated with congenital heart defects. If catheter procedures can't fix the heart defect, the doctor might recommend open-heart surgery.

Name: Binge drinking
Symptoms: Alcohol poisoning signs and symptoms include It's not necessary to have all the above signs or symptoms before one seek medical help. If one suspect that someone has alcohol poisoning even if one don't see the classic signs and symptoms seek immediate medical care. Because alcohol poisoning affects the way the gag reflex works, someone with alcohol poisoning may choke on his or her own vomit and not be able to breathe. While waiting for help, don't try to make the person vomit because he or she could choke. If the person must lie down, make sure to turn his or her head to the side this helps prevent choking.
Causes: Alcohol in the form of ethanol (ethyl alcohol) is found in alcoholic beverages, mouthwash, cooking extracts, some medications and certain household products. Ethyl alcohol poisoning generally results from drinking too many alcoholic beverages, especially in a short period of time.
Treatment: Alcohol poisoning treatment usually involves supportive care while the body rids itself of the alcohol. This typically includes: Adults and children who have accidentally consumed methanol or isopropyl alcohol may need hemodialysis a mechanical way of filtering waste and toxins from the system to speed the removal of alcohol from their bloodstream. Home remedies for alcohol poisoning won't work. One can't reverse the effects of alcohol poisoning, and one could actually make things worse through some actions. Here's what doesn't work: Careful monitoring Prevention of breathing or choking problems Oxygen therapy Fluids given through a vein (intravenously) to prevent dehydration Use of vitamins and glucose to help prevent serious complications of alcohol poisoning Sleeping it off one can lose consciousness while asleep Black coffee or caffeine ?
Remedies: Home remedies for alcohol poisoning won't work. One can't reverse the effects of alcohol poisoning, and one could actually make things worse through some actions.

Name: Bladder exstrophy
Overview: In girls born with bladder exstrophy, the bladder is on the outside of the body and the vagina is not fully formed. In boys born with bladder exstrophy, the bladder is on the outside of the body and the penis and the urine tube (urethra) are not fully closed.
Risk factors: Firstborn children, children of a parent with bladder exstrophy or siblings of a child with bladder exstrophy have an increased chance of being born with the condition. Children born through assisted reproductive technology, such as IVF, have a higher risk of bladder exstrophy.
Treatment: The first procedure closes the bladder and the abdomen, and the second repairs the urethra and sex organs. This can be done soon after birth, or when the baby is around two to three months old.Most surgery for newborns will include repair to the pelvic bones. One is done within 72 hours after birth, another at age 6 to 12 months, and the last at 4 to 5 years.The first procedure closes the bladder and the abdomen, and the second repairs the urethra and sex organs.

Name: Bladder stones
Overview: Bladder stones are hard masses of minerals in the bladder. Small bladder stones may pass without treatment, but sometimes bladder stones need medications or surgery.
Causes: The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. An enlarged prostate (benign prostatic hyperplasia, or BPH) can cause bladder stones in men. If these nerves are damaged from a stroke, spinal cord injury or other health problem the bladder may not empty completely. Bladder inflammation, sometimes caused by urinary tract infections or radiation therapy to the pelvis, can lead to bladder stones. Bladder catheters slender tubes inserted through the urethra to help urine drain from the bladder may cause bladder stones. But small kidney stones may travel down the ureters into the bladder and, if not expelled, can grow into bladder stones.
Risk factors: Conditions that can raise the risk of bladder stones include It's possible to have nerve damage and a condition that causes bladder outlet obstruction. Stroke, spinal cord injuries, Parkinson's disease, diabetes, a herniated disk and a number of other problems can damage nerves that control bladder function.
Diagnosis: The doctor will likely feel the lower abdomen to see if the bladder is enlarged (distended) or may perform a rectal exam to determine whether the prostate is enlarged. A urine test also looks for a urinary tract infection, which can cause or be the result of bladder stones. This test bounces sound waves off organs and other structures in the body to create images that help detect bladder stones. An X-ray of the kidneys, ureters and bladder helps the doctor determine whether one has bladder stones.
info-Symptoms: Pain

Name: Blastocystis hominis
Overview: Blastocystis hominis is a microscopic organism that sometimes is found in the stools of people who have ingested contaminated food or water. It can be found in healthy people who aren't having digestive symptoms, and it's also sometimes found in the stools of people who have diarrhea, abdominal pain or other gastrointestinal problems.
Diagnosis: A number of lab tests help diagnose parasitic diseases and other noninfectious causes of gastrointestinal symptoms: Stool (fecal) exam. If one has symptoms, but the fecal exam doesn't reveal the cause, the doctor might request this test. After one is sedated, a doctor, usually a gastroenterologist, inserts a tube into the mouth or rectum to look for the cause of the symptoms. However, the doctor might order blood tests to look for other causes of the signs and symptoms.
Treatment: However, in some cases, one might be referred to someone who specializes in either infectious disease or in digestive system disorders (gastroenterologist). Antibiotics, such as metronidazole (Flagyl) or tinidazole (Tindamax) Combination medications, such as sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim (Bactrim, Septra, others) Anti-protozoal medications, such as paromomycin or nitazoxanide (Alinia)

Name: Blocked tear duct
Overview: The tear glands (lacrimal glands), located above each eyeball, continuously supply tear fluid that's wiped across the surface of the eye each time one blink the eyes. When one has a blocked tear duct, the tears can't drain normally, leaving one with a watery, irritated eye.
Causes: Tears drain into the puncta, located in the inside corners of the upper and lower eyelids. The eyelids have small canals (canaliculi) that move tears to a sac where the lids are attached to the side of the nose (lacrimal sac). From there tears travel down a duct (the nasolacrimal duct) draining into the nose. A blockage can occur at any point in the tear drainage system, from the puncta to the nose. When that happens, the tears don't drain properly, giving one watery eyes and increasing the risk of eye infections and inflammation. As one age, the tiny openings that drain tears (puncta) may get narrower, causing blockage. Chronic infection or inflammation of the eyes, tear drainage system or nose can cause the tear ducts to become blocked. An injury to the face can cause bone damage or scarring near the drainage system, disrupting the normal flow of tears through the ducts. Disorders that cause swelling, such as sarcoidosis or granulomatosis with polyangiitis, can increase the risk of developing a blocked tear duct. Rarely, long-term use of certain medications, such as eyedrops used to treat glaucoma, can cause a blocked tear duct.
Risk factors: If the eyes are continually irritated, red and inflamed (conjunctivitis), one is at higher risk of developing a blocked tear duct. Previous eye, eyelid, nasal or sinus surgery may have caused some scarring of the duct system, possibly resulting in a blocked tear duct later. If one has used these or other topical eye medications, one is at higher risk of developing a blocked tear duct. If one has had radiation or chemotherapy to treat cancer, particularly if the radiation was focused on the face or head, one is at higher risk of developing a blocked tear duct.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects a blocked tear duct, he or she may have one undergo other tests to find the location of the blockage. Or he or she may insert a slender instrument (probe) through the tiny drainage holes at the corner of the lid (puncta) to check for blockages.
Treatment: If the baby's blocked tear duct isn't improving, his or her doctor may teach one a special massage technique to help open the membrane. If one has had a facial injury that caused blocked tear ducts, the doctor may suggest waiting a few months to see if the condition improves as the injury heals. As the swelling goes down, the tear ducts may become unblocked on their own. For adults with partially narrowed puncta, the doctor may dilate the puncta with a small probe and then flush (irrigate) the tear duct.

Name: Body dysmorphic disorder
Symptoms: Shame and embarrassment about the appearance may keep one from seeking treatment for body dysmorphic disorder. If left untreated, it may get worse over time, leading to anxiety, extensive medical bills, severe depression, and even suicidal thoughts and behavior.
Medication: Although there are no medications specifically approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to treat body dysmorphic disorder, medications used to treat other mental health conditions ? In some cases, the body dysmorphic disorder symptoms may be so severe that one require psychiatric hospitalization. Because body dysmorphic disorder is thought to be caused in part by problems related to the brain chemical serotonin, SSRIs may be prescribed. SSRIs appear to be more effective for body dysmorphic disorder than other antidepressants and may help control the negative thoughts and repetitive behaviors.

Name: Bone metastasis
Medication: Medications commonly used to treat people with thinning bones (osteoporosis) may also help people with bone metastasis. These medications can strengthen bones and reduce the pain caused by bone metastasis, reducing the need for strong pain medications. Oral forms of these medications are available, but they generally aren't as effective as the IV or injectable forms, and may cause digestive tract side effects. Pain medications may control the pain caused by bone metastasis. Medications known as steroids can often help to relieve pain associated with bone metastases by decreasing swelling and inflammation around the sites of cancer. Steroids can work quite quickly to help pain and prevent some cancer complications, but they also must be used very cautiously because they have side effects, especially when used for prolonged periods. Radiation therapy may be an option if the bone metastasis is causing pain that isn't controlled with pain medications or if the pain is confined to a small number of areas. If bone metastasis has caused a bone to break, surgeons may work to repair the bone. In general, broken bones caused by bone metastasis aren't helped by placing a cast on the broken bone. Side effects can include damage to nearby structures, such as nerves, and damage to bones that can increase the risk of a broken bone. If cancer has spread to multiple bones, the doctor may recommend chemotherapy. For cancers that are sensitive to chemotherapy, chemotherapy may be the best way to alleviate pain from bone metastases. If the bone is in danger of breaking due to bone metastasis, surgeons can stabilize the bone using metal plates, screws and nails (orthopedic fixation). Bones that can't be easily reinforced with metal plates or screws, such as pelvic bones and bones in the spine, may benefit from bone cement.

Name: Botulism
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of foodborne botulism typically begin between 12 and 36 hours after the toxin gets into the body. Signs and symptoms of foodborne botulism include Signs and symptoms of wound botulism appear about 10 days after the toxin has entered the body. Wound botulism signs and symptoms include The wound may or may not appear red and swollen. If infant botulism is related to food, such as honey, problems generally begin within 18 to 36 hours after the toxin enters the baby's body.
Overview: Botulism is a rare but serious condition caused by toxins from bacteria called Clostridium botulinum. This most common form of botulism begins after Clostridium botulinum bacterial spores grow in a baby's intestinal tract.
info-Symptoms: Weakness, trouble seeing, feeling tired, trouble speaking
info-Diagnostic method: Finding the bacteria or their toxin
info-Prevention: Proper food preparation, no honey for children younger than one

Name: Brachial plexus injury
Symptoms: The most severe type of nerve injury is an avulsion (A), where the nerve roots are torn away from the spinal cord. Less severe injuries involve a stretching (B) of the nerve fibers or a rupture (C), where the nerve is torn into two pieces.
Causes: Many football players experience burners or stingers, which can occur when the nerves in the brachial plexus get stretched beyond their limit during collisions with other players. If an infant's shoulders get wedged within the birth canal, there is an increased risk of a brachial plexus palsy. Several types of trauma including motor vehicle accidents, motorcycle accidents, falls or bullet wounds can result in brachial plexus injuries. Tumors can grow in or along the brachial plexus, or put pressure on the brachial plexus or spread to the nerves.
Diagnosis: To help diagnose the extent and severity of a brachial plexus injury, one may have one or more of the following tests: X-ray. These tests are usually performed as part of the EMG, and they measure the speed of conduction in the nerve when a small current passes through the nerve. CT myelography adds a contrast material, injected during a spinal tap, to produce a detailed picture of the spinal cord and nerve roots during a CT scan.

Name: Brain AVM
Symptoms: A brain arteriovenous malformation may not cause any signs or symptoms until the AVM ruptures, resulting in bleeding in the brain (hemorrhage). Once one reach middle age, however, brain AVMs tend to remain stable and are less likely to cause symptoms. One severe type of brain AVM, called a vein of Galen defect, causes signs and symptoms that emerge soon or immediately after birth. Seek immediate medical attention if one notice any signs or symptoms of a brain AVM, such as seizures, headaches or other symptoms.
Overview: In a brain AVM, blood passes directly from the arteries to the veins via abnormal vessels. In a brain AVM, blood passes directly from arteries to veins via a tangle of abnormal blood vessels. A brain arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is a tangle of abnormal blood vessels connecting arteries and veins in the brain. AVMs are commonly found after a brain scan for another health issue or after the blood vessels rupture and cause bleeding in the brain (hemorrhage).
Risk factors: Cases of AVMs in families have been reported, but it's unclear if there's a certain genetic factor or if the cases are only coincidental. It's also possible to inherit other medical conditions that predispose one to having vascular malformations such as AVMs.
Diagnosis: Cerebral angiogram showing brain AVM CT scans allow doctors to see cross-sectional CT scan images (slices) of the body. In this test, the doctor inserts a long, thin tube (catheter) into an artery in the groin and threads it to the brain using X-ray imaging. Sometimes a doctor injects dye through an intravenous tube into a vein so that the arteries feeding the AVM and the veins draining the AVM can be viewed in greater detail (computerized tomography angiogram). The doctor may also inject dye to see the blood circulation in the brain (magnetic resonance angiogram).

Name: Brain tumor
Overview: A brain tumor can form in the brain cells (as shown), or it can begin elsewhere and spread to the brain. Brain tumors can begin in the brain (primary brain tumors), or cancer can begin in other parts of the body and spread to the brain (secondary, or metastatic, brain tumors).
Causes: An acoustic neuroma (schwannoma) is a benign tumor that develops on the balance and hearing nerves leading from the inner ear to the brain. Primary brain tumors begin when normal cells acquire errors (mutations) in their DNA. In adults, primary brain tumors are much less common than are secondary brain tumors, in which cancer begins elsewhere and spreads to the brain. But in rare cases, a metastatic brain tumor may be the first sign of cancer that began elsewhere in the body. In adults, secondary brain tumors are far more common than are primary brain tumors. These tumors begin in the brain or spinal cord and include astrocytomas, ependymomas, glioblastomas, oligoastrocytomas and oligodendrogliomas. These are benign tumors that develop on the nerves that control balance and hearing leading from the inner ear to the brain. But sometimes germ cell tumors affect other parts of the body, such as the brain. These rare, noncancerous tumors start near the brain's pituitary gland, which secretes hormones that control many body functions.
Diagnosis: If it's suspected that one has a brain tumor, the doctor may recommend a number of tests and procedures, including Imaging tests. A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. Positron emission tomography (PET) may be used for brain imaging, but is generally not as useful for creating images of brain cancer as it is for other types of cancer. A stereotactic needle biopsy may be done for brain tumors in hard to reach areas or very sensitive areas within the brain that might be damaged by a more extensive operation. If it's suspected that the brain tumor may be a result of cancer that has spread from another area of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer originated.
info-Symptoms: Vary depending on the part of the brain involved, headaches, seizures, problem with vision, vomiting, mental changes
info-Risk factors: Neurofibromatosis, exposure to vinyl chloride, Epsteinâ€“Barr virus, ionizing radiation
info-Diagnostic method: Computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, tissue biopsy

Name: Breast cysts
Overview: A breast cyst, an oval or round fluid-filled sac, may move slightly when one press on it. Breast cysts are fluid-filled sacs inside the breast, which are usually not cancerous (benign). Breast cysts are common in women before menopause, between ages 35 and 50.
Causes: Some evidence suggests that excess estrogen in the body, which can stimulate the breast tissue, may contribute to breast cysts. Large breast cysts can put pressure on nearby breast tissue, causing breast pain or discomfort.
Diagnosis: During a fine-needle aspiration, the doctor inserts a thin needle into the breast lump and attempts to withdraw (aspirate) fluid. If the fluid appears bloody or the breast lump doesn't disappear, the doctor may send a sample of the fluid for lab testing and refer one to a breast surgeon or to a radiologist a doctor trained to perform imaging exams and procedures for follow-up. Lack of fluid or a breast lump that doesn't disappear after aspiration suggests that the breast lump or at least a portion of it is solid, and a sample of cells may be collected to check for cancer (fine-needle aspiration biopsy).
Remedies: To minimize discomfort associated with breast cysts, one might try these measures: Wear a well-fitted, supportive bra. If the breast cysts are painful, supporting the breasts may help relieve some discomfort. Some types of breast pain may be eased by the use of acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen (Aleve, Naprosyn, others).

Name: Broken ankle
Overview: A fall or blow to the ankle can break one or more of the three bones in the ankle joint the fibula, the tibia and the talus. A severely broken ankle may require surgery to implant plates, rods or screws into the broken bone to maintain proper position during healing.
Causes: A broken ankle is usually a result of a twisting injury, but can also be caused by a direct blow to the ankle. The most common causes of a broken ankle include Car accidents.
Risk factors: The stresses, direct blows and twisting injuries that occur in sports such as basketball, football, gymnastics, tennis and soccer can cause ankle fractures. Improper training techniques, such as not warming up and stretching, also can cause ankle injuries. Whether one is a trained athlete or someone who's just started exercising, suddenly boosting the frequency or duration of the exercise sessions can increase the risk of a stress fracture.
Diagnosis: The technician may need to take X-rays from several different angles so that the bone images won't overlap too much. A bone scan can help the doctor diagnose fractures that don't show up on X-rays. This imaging helps to show ligaments and bones and can identify fractures not seen on X-rays.
Medication: The doctor may recommend an over-the-counter pain reliever, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). After the bone has healed, one will probably need to loosen up stiff muscles and ligaments in the ankles and feet. If one has a displaced fracture, meaning the two ends of the fracture are not aligned well, the doctor may need to manipulate the pieces back into their proper positions. Depending on the amount of pain and swelling one has, one may need a muscle relaxant, a sedative or a local anesthetic to numb the area before this procedure. In some cases, an orthopedic surgeon may need to use pins, plates or screws to maintain proper position of the bones during healing.
info-Symptoms: Pain, swelling, bruising, inability to walk
info-Diagnostic method: X-rays based on the Ottawa ankle rule

Name: Broken collarbone
Overview: The collarbone connects the breastbone to the shoulder blade. Common causes of a broken collarbone include falls, sports injuries and trauma from traffic accidents.
Medication: After the sling is removed, the doctor might recommend additional rehabilitation exercises or physical therapy to restore muscle strength, joint motion and flexibility. Surgery might be required if the fractured collarbone has broken through the skin, is severely displaced or is in several pieces. Broken collarbone surgery usually includes placing fixation devices plates, screws or rods to maintain proper position of the bone during healing. It might be helpful to write a list that includes: The doctor will likely ask some of the following questions: Detailed descriptions of the symptoms and the event that caused the injury Information about past medical problems All the medications and dietary supplements Questions one want to ask the doctor How did the injury occur?
info-Symptoms: Pain, decreased ability to move the affected arm
info-Causes: Fall onto a shoulder, outstretched arm, or direct trauma
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, confirmed with X-rays
info-Prognosis: Up to five months for complete healing
info-Frequency: 5% of adult fractures, 13% of children's fractures

Name: Broken toe
Medication: One can usually manage pain from a broken toe with over-the-counter medications such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). If the broken fragments of the bone don't fit snugly together, the doctor may need to manipulate the pieces back into their proper positions (reduction). Examples include In some cases, a surgeon may need to use pins, plates or screws to maintain proper position of the bones during healing. If one use ice, wrap it in a towel so that it doesn't make direct contact with the skin, and only apply it for about 15 minutes at a time, taking a break of at least 20 minutes between icing sessions. While one may initially consult the family physician, he or she may refer one to a doctor who specializes in orthopedic surgery. One may want to write a list that includes: The doctor may ask some of the following questions: Buddy taping. If one has a simple fracture in any of the smaller toes, the doctor may tape the injured toe to its neighboring toe. If the fragments of the broken toe won't stay snugly together, one may need a walking cast.
info-Symptoms: Pain, tenderness, bruising, swelling, displacement of the bones.
info-Causes: Stubbing or crushing over-extending a toe joint, stress fracture
info-Treatment: For pain and swelling, rest, icing, elevation and pain medication; wearing a stiff-soled shoe; for smaller toes, buddy wrapping (taping the toe to the nearest toe, with some absorbent padding in-between); rarely, a cast or surgery
info-Prognosis: 4 to 8 weeks for full healing; pain lessens within days

Name: Bronchiolitis
Overview: In the lungs, the main airways (bronchi) branch off into smaller and smaller passageways the smallest, called bronchioles, lead to tiny air sacs (alveoli). Bronchiolitis starts out with symptoms similar to those of a common cold, but then progresses to coughing, wheezing and sometimes difficulty breathing.
Causes: Bronchiolitis occurs when a virus infects the bronchioles, which are the smallest airways in the lungs. Outbreaks of RSV infection occur every winter, and individuals can be reinfected, as previous infection does not appear to cause lasting immunity. Bronchiolitis also can be caused by other viruses, including those that cause the flu or the common cold.
Diagnosis: If the child is at risk of severe bronchiolitis, if symptoms are worsening or if another problem is suspected, the doctor may order tests, including The doctor may also ask one about signs of dehydration, especially if the child has been refusing to drink or eat or has been vomiting. Occasionally, blood tests might be used to check the child's white blood cell count.
Remedies: Here are some tips to try: Don't use over-the-counter medicines, except for fever reducers and pain relievers, to treat coughs and colds in children younger than 6 years old. Also, consider avoiding use of these medicines for children younger than 12 years old. If the air in the child's room is dry, a cool-mist humidifier or vaporizer can moisten the air and help ease congestion and coughing.
