To use them, put several drops into one nostril, then immediately bulb suction that nostril (but don't push the bulb too far in). For treatment of fever or pain, ask the doctor about giving the child infants or children's over-the-counter fever and pain medications such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin, others) as a safer alternative to aspirin. Aspirin is not recommended in children due to the risk of Reye's syndrome, a rare but potentially life-threatening condition. Children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin, as they have a higher risk of Reye's syndrome.
info-Symptoms: Fever, cough, runny nose, wheezing, breathing problems
info-Causes: Viral disease (respiratory syncytial virus, human rhinovirus)
info-Treatment: Symptomatic treatment (oxygen, support with feeding, intravenous fluids)

Name: Bronchitis
Overview: Bronchitis is an inflammation of the lining of the bronchial tubes, which carry air to and from the lungs. Acute bronchitis, also called a chest cold, usually improves within a week to 10 days without lasting effects, although the cough may linger for weeks.
Causes: Acute bronchitis is usually caused by viruses, typically the same viruses that cause colds and flu (influenza). Antibiotics don't kill viruses, so this type of medication isn't useful in most cases of bronchitis.
Diagnosis: In some cases, the doctor may suggest the following tests: Chest X-ray. During a pulmonary function test, one blow into a device called a spirometer, which measures how much air the lungs can hold and how quickly one can get air out of the lungs.
Remedies: To help one feel better, one may want to try the following self-care measures: Avoid lung irritants. Wear a mask when the air is polluted or if one is exposed to irritants, such as paint or household cleaners with strong fumes. If cold air aggravates the cough and causes shortness of breath, put on a cold-air face mask before one go outside.
Medication: In some circumstances, the doctor may recommend other medications, including If one has chronic bronchitis, one may benefit from pulmonary rehabilitation a breathing exercise program in which a respiratory therapist teaches one how to breathe more easily and increase the ability to exercise. If one has allergies, asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), the doctor may recommend an inhaler and other medications to reduce inflammation and open narrowed passages in the lungs.
info-Symptoms: Coughing up mucus, wheezing, shortness of breath, chest discomfort
info-Frequency: Acute: ~5% of people a yearChronic: ~5% of people

Name: Brucellosis
Causes: Brucellosis affects many wild and domestic animals, including A form of brucellosis also affects harbor seals, porpoises and certain whales. Cattle Goats Sheep Pigs and wild hogs Dogs, especially those used in hunting Deer Elk Bison Caribou Moose Camels Eating raw dairy products. Brucella bacteria in the milk of infected animals can spread to humans in unpasteurized milk, ice cream, butter and cheeses. Because normal contact with animals touching, brushing or playing doesn't cause infection, people rarely get brucellosis from their pets.
Diagnosis: Doctors usually confirm a diagnosis of brucellosis by testing blood or bone marrow for the brucella bacteria or by testing blood for antibodies to the bacteria. To help detect complications of brucellosis, the doctor may order additional tests, including X-rays.
info-Symptoms: coughing

Name: Brugada syndrome
Causes: Tiny pores, called channels, on each of these cells direct this electrical activity, which makes the heart beat. In Brugada syndrome, a defect in these channels causes the heart to beat abnormally fast, creating a dangerous heart rhythm (ventricular fibrillation).
Risk factors: Risk factors for Brugada syndrome include Family history of Brugada syndrome. If other family members have had Brugada syndrome, one is at an increased risk of having it, too. A fever doesn't cause Brugada syndrome, but it can irritate the heart and trigger fainting or sudden cardiac arrest in someone with Brugada syndrome, especially in children.
Diagnosis: If the heart beat is normal during the test, the doctor may order a portable ECG that one wear during the daily activities for a full day and night. If one has symptoms of Brugada syndrome, but the initial ECG and 24-hour Holter test were normal, the doctor may give one medications through an IV that may trigger an abnormal heart beat. If the ECG shows signs of Brugada syndrome, or if one has had symptoms such as sudden cardiac arrest, the doctor may recommend an electrophysiology test to see how easy it is to get the heart to go into the abnormal Brugada rhythm. This test cannot diagnose Brugada syndrome on its own, but it can help the doctor rule out any structural problems with the heart.
Treatment: Fever is a known trigger of abnormal heartbeats in people with Brugada syndrome, so use fever-reducing medications at the first sign of a fever. If one is at high risk of a serious irregular heart rhythm, the doctor may tell one not to play competitive sports.
info-Symptoms: Passing out, sudden cardiac death
info-Risk factors: Family history, Asian descent, male

Name: Bullous pemphigoid
Overview: People with bullous pemphigoid may develop multiple blisters. Bullous pemphigoid (BUL-us PEM-fih-goid) is a rare skin condition that causes large, fluid-filled blisters.
Causes: Prescription drugs that may cause bullous pemphigoid include etanercept (Enbrel), sulfasalazine (Azulfidine), furosemide (Lasix) and penicillin. Ultraviolet light therapy to treat certain skin conditions may trigger bullous pemphigoid, as can radiation therapy to treat cancer. Disorders that may trigger bullous pemphigoid include psoriasis, lichen planus, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, ulcerative colitis and multiple sclerosis.
Diagnosis: To confirm the diagnosis, the doctor may order blood tests and take a small sample of the affected skin (skin biopsy) for laboratory testing. The doctor may refer one to a doctor who specializes in conditions of the skin (dermatologist) or eyes (ophthalmologist), depending on the signs and symptoms and the results of the lab tests.
Treatment: Treatment is focused on healing the skin and relieving itching, while minimizing adverse side effects of medications. The doctor will likely prescribe one or a combination of the drugs: If one has bullous pemphigoid, one can help take care of the condition with the following self-care strategies: One may start by seeing the primary care doctor. Examples include azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran) and mycophenolate mofetil (CellCept). If the signs and symptoms involve the eyes or upper digestive tract, the drug rituximab (Rituxan) may be used if other approaches haven't helped. If one has blisters in the mouth, avoid eating hard and crunchy foods, such as chips and raw fruits and vegetables, because these types of foods might aggravate symptoms.
Remedies: If one has bullous pemphigoid, one can help take care of the condition with the following self-care strategies: Wound care. Avoid prolonged sun exposure on any area of the skin affected by bullous pemphigoid. If one has blisters in the mouth, avoid eating hard and crunchy foods, such as chips and raw fruits and vegetables, because these types of foods might aggravate symptoms.

Name: Bundle branch block
Overview: Electrical impulses that cause the heart to beat (contract) originate in the upper right chamber (right atrium) of the heart and travel to the lower chambers (ventricles). Bundle branch block is a condition in which there's a delay or blockage along the pathway that electrical impulses travel to make the heart beat. The delay or blockage can occur on the pathway that sends electrical impulses either to the left or the right side of the bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart.
Treatment: However, if one has a heart condition causing bundle branch block, treatment might involve medications to reduce high blood pressure or lessen the effects of heart failure. This therapy, which is meant to improve the coordination of both lower chambers of the heart so that they contract at the same time, is used in people with low pumping function and a bundle branch block.

Name: Bunions
Overview: When one has a bunion, the tip of the big toe shifts towards the smaller toes, crowding them. Smaller bunions (bunionettes) can develop on the joint at the base of the little toe. This causes the tip of the big toe to get pulled toward the smaller toes and forces the joint at the base of the big toe to stick out.
Risk factors: Wearing high heels forces the toes into the front of the shoes, often crowding the toes. People who wear shoes that are too tight, too narrow or too pointed are more likely to develop bunions. The tendency to develop bunions might be the result of an inherited problem with the structure or anatomy of the foot.
info-Symptoms: Prominent, red, and painful joint at the base of the big toe
info-Risk factors: Wearing overly tight shoes, high-heeled shoes, family history, rheumatoid arthritis

Name: Burns
Overview: A second-degree burn, which often looks wet or moist, affects the first and second layers of skin (epidermis and dermis). Burns are tissue damage that results from heat, overexposure to the sun or other radiation, or chemical or electrical contact.
Remedies: To treat minor burns, follow these steps: Whether the burn was minor or serious, use sunscreen and moisturizer regularly once the wound is healed. Hold the burned area under cool (not cold) running water or apply a cool, wet compress until the pain eases. Try to do this quickly and gently, before the burned area swells. If a blister breaks, clean the area with water (mild soap is optional). Once a burn is completely cooled, apply a lotion, such as one that contains aloe vera or a moisturizer. Bandaging keeps air off the area, reduces pain and protects blistered skin. Over-the-counter medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), can help relieve pain.

Name: Bursitis
Overview: Bursae are small fluid-filled sacs that reduce friction between moving parts in the body's joints. Bursae are small fluid-filled sacs (shown in blue) that reduce friction between moving parts in the body's joints. Bursitis (bur-SY-tis) is a painful condition that affects the small, fluid-filled sacs called bursae (bur-SEE) that cushion the bones, tendons and muscles near the joints.
Risk factors: Anyone can develop bursitis, but certain factors can increase the risk: Age. If the work or hobby requires repetitive motion or pressure on particular bursae, the risk of developing bursitis increases. Certain systemic diseases and conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, gout and diabetes increase the risk of developing bursitis.

Name: C. difficile infection
Symptoms: Some people carry the bacterium C. difficile in their intestines but never become sick, though rarely may still spread the infection. C. difficile can cause the colon to become inflamed and sometimes form patches of raw tissue that can bleed or produce pus.
Overview: Clostridium difficile (klos-TRID-e-um dif-uh-SEEL), also known as Clostridioides difficile and often referred to as C. difficile or C. diff, is a bacterium that can cause symptoms ranging from diarrhea to life-threatening inflammation of the colon.
Causes: C. difficile bacteria are found throughout the environment in soil, air, water, human and animal feces, and food products, such as processed meats. Spores from C. difficile bacteria are passed in feces and spread to food, surfaces and objects when people who are infected don't wash their hands thoroughly. If one touch a surface contaminated with C. difficile spores, one may then unknowingly swallow the bacteria.
Risk factors: The antibiotics that most often lead to C. difficile infections include Proton pump inhibitors, a type of medicine used to reduce stomach acid, also may increase the risk of C. difficile infection. The majority of C. difficile infections occur in people who are or who have recently been in a health care setting including hospitals, nursing homes and long-term care facilities where germs spread easily, antibiotic use is common and people are especially vulnerable to infection. In hospitals and nursing homes, C. difficile spreads mainly on hands from person to person, but also on cart handles, bedrails, bedside tables, toilets, sinks, stethoscopes, thermometers and even telephones and remote controls.
Diagnosis: Several main types of lab tests exist, and they include Testing for C. difficile is unnecessary if one is not having diarrhea or watery stools, and isn't helpful for follow-up treatment. If one isn't having diarrhea, stool shouldn't be tested for C. difficile. In rare instances, to help confirm a diagnosis of C. difficile infection and look for alternative causes of the symptoms, the doctor may examine the inside of the colon. If the doctor is concerned about possible complications of C. difficile, he or she may order an abdominal X-ray or a computerized tomography (CT) scan, which provides images of the colon. The enzyme immunoassay (EIA) test is faster than other tests but isn't sensitive enough to detect many infections and has a higher rate of falsely normal results.
Treatment: The doctor may prescribe vancomycin (Vancocin HCL, Firvanq) or fidaxomicin (Dificid). The doctor may prescribe vancomycin (Vancocin HCL, Firvanq) or fidaxomicin (Dificid).Metronidazole (Flagyl) may be rarely used if vancomycin or fidaxomicin aren't available.
Remedies: Clostridium difficile in adults: Epidemiology, microbiology, and pathophysiology. Clostridium difficile infection, including pseudomembranous colitis. Clinical practice guidelines for Clostridium difficile infection in adults and children: 2017 update by the Infectious Diseases Society of America (ISDA) and Society for Healthcare Epidemiology of America (SHEA). Rochester, Minn.: Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research; 2018.
info-Symptoms: Diarrhea, fever, nausea, abdominal pain
info-Causes: Clostridioides difficile spread by the fecal-oral route
info-Risk factors: Antibiotics, proton pump inhibitors, hospitalization, other health problems, older age
info-Diagnostic method: Stool culture, testing for the bacteria's DNA or toxins
info-Prevention: Hand washing, terminal room cleaning in hospital
info-Treatment: Metronidazole, vancomycin, fidaxomicin, fecal microbiota transplantation

Name: Calciphylaxis
Causes: The exact cause of calciphylaxis is unknown, but recent studies have revealed that most people with the condition have abnormalities in blood-clotting factors. This causes calcium to be deposited in the smallest parts of the arteries (arterioles), which eventually leads to the formation of blood clots in the arterioles.
Diagnosis: Tests may include Read more about the blood urea nitrogen (BUN test), creatinine test and liver function tests. Blood samples measure a variety of substances in the blood calcium, phosphorus, parathyroid hormone, abnormalities in blood-clotting factors, aluminum, urea nitrogen, creatinine and albumin, among others to help the doctor assess the kidney and liver function.
info-Prognosis: 1- and 5-year survival rates are estimated to be 45% and 35%, respectively

Name: Cancer
Causes: Cancer is caused by changes (mutations) to the DNA within cells. Gene mutations can occur for several reasons, for instance: Gene mutations occur frequently during normal cell growth. The gene mutations one is born with and those that one acquire throughout the life work together to cause cancer. For instance, if one has inherited a genetic mutation that predisposes one to cancer, that doesn't mean one is certain to get cancer. Instead, one may need one or more other gene mutations to cause cancer. Cancer cells lose the controls (tumor suppressor genes) that tell them when to stop growing. A mutation in a tumor suppressor gene allows cancer cells to continue growing and accumulating. A mutation in a DNA repair gene may mean that other errors aren't corrected, leading cells to become cancerous.
Risk factors: While doctors have an idea of what may increase the risk of cancer, the majority of cancers occur in people who don't have any known risk factors. Smoking, drinking more than one alcoholic drink a day (for women of all ages and men older than age 65) or two drinks a day (for men age 65 and younger), excessive exposure to the sun or frequent blistering sunburns, being obese, and having unsafe sex can contribute to cancer. Some chronic health conditions, such as ulcerative colitis, can markedly increase the risk of developing certain cancers.
Diagnosis: With this in mind, talk with the doctor about what types of cancer screening may be appropriate for one. Staging tests and procedures may include imaging tests, such as bone scans or X-rays, to see if cancer has spread to other parts of the body. During a physical exam, he or she may look for abnormalities, such as changes in skin color or enlargement of an organ, that may indicate the presence of cancer. Laboratory tests, such as urine and blood tests, may help the doctor identify abnormalities that can be caused by cancer. Imaging tests used in diagnosing cancer may include a computerized tomography (CT) scan, bone scan, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET) scan, ultrasound and X-ray, among others.
info-Symptoms: Lump, abnormal bleeding, prolonged cough, unexplained weight loss, change in bowel movements
info-Risk factors: Tobacco, obesity, poor diet, lack of physical activity, excessive alcohol, certain infections
info-Treatment: Radiation therapy, surgery, chemotherapy, and targeted therapy.

Name: Cancer , anal
Risk factors: Several factors have been found to increase the risk of anal cancer, including Older age. People who have many sexual partners over their lifetimes have a greater risk of anal cancer. People who engage in receptive anal sex have an increased risk of anal cancer. HPV infection increases the risk of several cancers, including anal cancer and cervical cancer. People who take drugs to suppress their immune systems (immunosuppressive drugs), including people who have received organ transplants, may have an increased risk of anal cancer. HIV the virus that causes AIDS suppresses the immune system and increases the risk of anal cancer.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose anal cancer include Once it's confirmed that one has anal cancer, the doctor may recommend additional tests to determine whether the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes or to other areas of the body. The doctor may use a short, lighted tube (anoscope) to inspect the anal canal and rectum for anything unusual. To create a picture of the anal canal, the doctor inserts a probe, similar to a thick thermometer, into the anal canal and rectum. If the doctor discovers any unusual areas, he or she may take small samples of affected tissue (biopsy) and send the samples to a laboratory for analysis.

Name: Cancer , basal cell
Symptoms: The most common type of basal cell carcinoma, this lesion often appears on the face and ears. A white, waxy, scar-like lesion without a clearly defined border, called morpheaform basal cell carcinoma, is the least common.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of basal cell carcinoma include Chronic sun exposure. A lot of time spent in the sun or in commercial tanning beds increases the risk of basal cell carcinoma. Radiation therapy to treat acne or other skin conditions may increase the risk of basal cell carcinoma at previous treatment sites on the skin. The risk of basal cell carcinoma is higher among people who freckle or burn easily or who have very light skin, red or blond hair, or light-colored eyes. Because basal cell carcinoma often takes decades to develop, the majority of basal cell carcinomas occur in older adults. If one has a family history of skin cancer, one may have an increased risk of developing basal cell carcinoma. Arsenic, a toxic metal that's found widely in the environment, increases the risk of basal cell carcinoma and other cancers. Certain rare genetic diseases can increase the risk of basal cell carcinoma, including nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome (Gorlin-Goltz syndrome) and xeroderma pigmentosum.
Diagnosis: In order to assess any growths or changes in the skin, the doctor or a specialist in skin conditions (dermatologist) will conduct a medical history and exam. The doctor will conduct a general physical exam and ask one questions about the medical history, changes in the skin, or any other signs or symptoms one has experienced. Questions may include The doctor will examine not only the suspicious area on the skin but also the rest of the body for other lesions. The doctor may do a skin biopsy, which involves removing a small sample of a lesion for testing in a laboratory.

Name: Cancer , bladder
Risk factors: Smoking cigarettes, cigars or pipes may increase the risk of bladder cancer by causing harmful chemicals to accumulate in the urine. These harmful chemicals may damage the lining of the bladder, which can increase the risk of cancer. Because of this, it's thought that being around certain chemicals may increase the risk of bladder cancer. Chemicals linked to bladder cancer risk include arsenic and chemicals used in the manufacture of dyes, rubber, leather, textiles and paint products. Chronic or repeated urinary infections or inflammations (cystitis), such as might happen with long-term use of a urinary catheter, may increase the risk of a squamous cell bladder cancer. If one of the first-degree relatives a parent, sibling or child has a history of bladder cancer, one may have an increased risk of the disease, although it's rare for bladder cancer to run in families.
Diagnosis: Imaging tests, such as computerized tomography (CT) urogram or retrograde pyelogram, allow the doctor to examine the structures of the urinary tract. During this test, the doctor threads a thin tube (catheter) through the urethra and into the bladder to inject contrast dye into the ureters. After confirming that one has bladder cancer, the doctor may recommend additional tests to determine whether the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes or to other areas of the body. This is known as tumor grade, and the doctor may describe bladder cancer as either low grade or high grade: Cystoscopy. During cystoscopy, the doctor may pass a special tool through the scope and into the bladder to collect a cell sample (biopsy) for testing. Imaging tests, such as computerized tomography (CT) urogram or retrograde pyelogram, allow the doctor to examine the structures of the urinary tract.During a CT urogram, a contrast dye injected into a vein in the hand eventually flows into the kidneys, ureters and bladder. X-ray images taken during the test provide a detailed view of the urinary tract and help the doctor identify any areas that might be cancer.Retrograde pyelogram is an X-ray exam used to get a detailed look at the upper urinary tract.

Name: Cancer , breast
Overview: Each breast contains 15 to 20 lobes of glandular tissue, arranged like the petals of a daisy. Breast cancer survival rates have increased, and the number of deaths associated with this disease is steadily declining, largely due to factors such as earlier detection, a new personalized approach to treatment and a better understanding of the disease.
Risk factors: Many women who develop breast cancer have no known risk factors other than simply being women. If one has had a breast biopsy that found lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) or atypical hyperplasia of the breast, one has an increased risk of breast cancer. If one has had breast cancer in one breast, one has an increased risk of developing cancer in the other breast. If the mother, sister or daughter was diagnosed with breast cancer, particularly at a young age, the risk of breast cancer is increased. These genes can greatly increase the risk of breast cancer and other cancers, but they don't make cancer inevitable. If one received radiation treatments to the chest as a child or young adult, the risk of breast cancer is increased. Beginning the period before age 12 increases the risk of breast cancer. Women who give birth to their first child after age 30 may have an increased risk of breast cancer. Women who take hormone therapy medications that combine estrogen and progesterone to treat the signs and symptoms of menopause have an increased risk of breast cancer.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose breast cancer include Removing a sample of breast cells for testing (biopsy). A biopsy sample is also analyzed to determine the type of cells involved in the breast cancer, the aggressiveness (grade) of the cancer, and whether the cancer cells have hormone receptors or other receptors that may influence the treatment options. Once the doctor has diagnosed the breast cancer, he or she works to establish the extent (stage) of the cancer. Tests and procedures used to stage breast cancer may include Not all women will need all of these tests and procedures. Stage IV breast cancer, also called metastatic breast cancer, indicates cancer that has spread to other areas of the body. Breast cancer staging also takes into account the cancer's grade; the presence of tumor markers, such as receptors for estrogen, progesterone and HER2; and proliferation factors.
Treatment: The doctor determines the breast cancer treatment options based on the type of breast cancer, its stage and grade, size, and whether the cancer cells are sensitive to hormones. Most women undergo surgery for breast cancer and many also receive additional treatment after surgery, such as chemotherapy, hormone therapy or radiation. There are many options for breast cancer treatment, and one may feel overwhelmed as one make complex decisions about the treatment.

Name: Carbon monoxide poisoning
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning may include Carbon monoxide poisoning can be particularly dangerous for people who are sleeping or intoxicated. If one think one or someone one is with may have carbon monoxide poisoning, get into fresh air and seek emergency medical care.
Risk factors: Young children take breaths more frequently than adults do, which may make them more susceptible to carbon monoxide poisoning. Older people who experience carbon monoxide poisoning may be more likely to develop brain damage. People with a history of anemia and breathing problems also are more likely to get sick from exposure to carbon monoxide.
info-Symptoms: Headache, dizziness, weakness, vomiting, chest pain, confusion
info-Prevention: Carbon monoxide detectors, venting of gas appliances, maintenance of exhaust systems
info-Treatment: Supportive care, 100% oxygen, hyperbaric oxygen therapy
info-Frequency: >20,000 emergency visits for non-fire related cases per year (US)

Name: Carbuncles and boils
Overview: A boil is a painful, pus-filled bump under the skin the result of a bacterial infection of one or more hair follicles. A carbuncle is a cluster of boils painful, pus-filled bumps that form a connected area of infection under the skin. A boil is a painful, pus-filled bump that forms under the skin when bacteria infect and inflame one or more of the hair follicles.
Risk factors: Although anyone including otherwise healthy people can develop boils or carbuncles, the following factors can increase the risk: Close contact with a person who has a staph infection. Because they damage the skin's protective barrier, skin problems, such as acne and eczema, make one more susceptible to boils and carbuncles.
Treatment: One can generally treat small boils at home by applying warm compresses to relieve pain and promote natural drainage. For larger boils and carbuncles, treatment may include For small boils, these measures may help the infection heal more quickly and prevent it from spreading: One is likely to see the family doctor or primary care provider first, who may then refer one to a specialist in skin diseases (dermatologist) or infectious diseases. Deep infections that can't be completely drained may be packed with sterile gauze to help soak up and remove additional pus. Sometimes the doctor may prescribe antibiotics to help heal severe or recurrent infections.
Remedies: For small boils, these measures may help the infection heal more quickly and prevent it from spreading: Warm compresses. Apply a warm washcloth or compress to the affected area several times a day, for about 10 minutes each time. Also, launder clothing, towels or compresses that have touched the infected area, especially if one has recurrent infections.

Name: Carcinoid syndrome
Symptoms: Flushing may happen for no obvious reason, though sometimes it can be triggered by stress, exercise or drinking alcohol. Frequent, watery stools sometimes accompanied by abdominal cramps may occur in people who have carcinoid syndrome. Asthma-like signs and symptoms, such as wheezing and shortness of breath, may occur at the same time one experience skin flushing.
Diagnosis: To confirm a diagnosis, the doctor may recommend further tests, including Urine test. The blood may contain high levels of certain substances, including the protein chromogranin A, which is released by some carcinoid tumors. The doctor may start with a computerized tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen, because most carcinoid tumors are found in the gastrointestinal tract.
Treatment: Injections of the medications octreotide (Sandostatin) and lanreotide (Somatuline Depot) may reduce the signs and symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, including skin flushing and diarrhea. In a procedure called hepatic artery embolization, a doctor inserts a catheter through a needle near the groin and threads it up to the main artery that carries blood to the liver (hepatic artery). The doctor injects particles designed to clog the hepatic artery, cutting off the blood supply to cancer cells that have spread to the liver. An injectable medication called interferon alfa, which stimulates the body's immune system to work better, is sometimes used to slow the growth of carcinoid tumors and to relieve symptoms.

Name: Carcinoid tumors
Overview: Carcinoid tumors are a type of slow-growing cancer that can arise in several places throughout the body. Carcinoid tumors, which are one subset of tumors called neuroendocrine tumors, usually begin in the digestive tract (stomach, appendix, small intestine, colon, rectum) or in the lungs.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose carcinoid tumors include A scope or camera that sees inside the body. To see inside the small intestine, the doctor may recommend a test using a pill-sized camera that one swallow (capsule endoscopy). If one has a carcinoid tumor, the blood may contain high levels of hormones secreted by a carcinoid tumor or byproducts created when those hormones are broken down by the body. Imaging tests, including a computerized tomography (CT) scan, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), positron emission tomography (PET), octreotide scan and X-ray, may help the doctor pinpoint the carcinoid tumor's location.
Medication: In PRRT for carcinoid tumors, the drug is injected into the body, where it travels to the cancer cells, binds to the cells and delivers the radiation directly to them. In a procedure called hepatic artery embolization, a doctor clogs the liver's main artery (hepatic artery), cutting off the blood supply to cancer cells that have spread to the liver.

Name: Carcinoma of unknown primary
Overview: Carcinoma of unknown primary is a diagnosis given when doctors aren't able to locate where a cancer began. In carcinoma of unknown primary, also known as occult primary cancer, doctors find the cancer cells that spread in the body, but they can't find the primary tumor.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose carcinoma of unknown primary include If initial tests find cancer cells that came from somewhere else in the body, one might have additional tests to look for the place where the cancer cells originated (primary tumor). Tests might include These tests might help the doctor locate the primary tumor where the cancer started. To confirm that the symptoms are caused by cancer, the doctor may recommend a procedure to remove a sample of cells for lab testing (biopsy). Blood tests that measure the organ function can give the doctor clues about whether cancer might be affecting the organs, such as the kidneys and liver. Blood tests that look for molecules that are sometimes produced by certain types of cancer (tumor markers) might provide more information for the diagnosis. Doctors who specialize in analyzing blood and body tissue (pathologists) might run more-thorough tests of the cancer cells to gather more information for the diagnosis. Pathologists might use high-tech microscopes, special dyes and other technology, such as tests to look for changes in the genes and chromosomes of the cancer cells DNA.
Treatment: To determine which treatments might be best for one, the doctor will consider where the cancer cells were found, which type of normal cells they most closely resemble and the results of lab tests. The concern and understanding of a counselor, medical social worker, clergy member or cancer support group also may be helpful. If the doctor suspects that one might have cancer, one may be referred to a doctor who specializes in caring for people with cancer (oncologist). One or more chemotherapy drugs may be given through a vein in the arm (intravenously), taken orally, or administered with both methods. An operation to cut away the cancer might be an option if the carcinoma of unknown primary is limited to one area, such as a lymph node or the liver. Palliative care can be used while undergoing other aggressive treatments, such as surgery, chemotherapy or radiation therapy. Ask the doctor about the cancer, including the test results, treatment options and, if one like, the prognosis.

Name: Cardiogenic shock
Diagnosis: This allows the doctor to check the size and shape of the heart and its blood vessels and whether there's fluid in the lungs. One will have blood drawn to check for organ damage, infection and heart attack. A liquid dye is injected into the arteries of the heart through a long, thin tube (catheter) that's inserted through an artery, usually in the leg. Blood pressure test Cardiac catheterization Chest X-rays Echocardiogram Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) Blood pressure measurement.
Medication: Fluids and plasma, given through an IV, and medications to treat cardiogenic shock, work to increase the heart's pumping ability. If a blockage is found during a cardiac catheterization, the doctor can insert a long, thin tube (catheter) equipped with a special balloon through an artery, usually in the leg, to a blocked artery in the heart. If medications and medical procedures don't work to treat cardiogenic shock, the doctor might recommend surgery. One might be given medications to improve the heart function, such as norepinephrine (Levophed) or dopamine, until other treatments start to work. These drugs, also called clot busters or fibrinolytics, help dissolve a blood clot that's blocking blood flow to the heart. One will likely receive thrombolytics, such as alteplase (Activase) or reteplase (Retavase), only if emergency cardiac catheterization isn't available. These include medications, such as oral clopidogrel (Plavix), and platelet glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor blockers, such as abciximab (Reopro), tirofiban (Aggrastat) and eptifibatide (Integrilin), which are given through a vein (intravenously). The pump inflates and deflates within the aorta, helping blood flow and taking some of the workload off the heart. Methods newer than the balloon pump are being used to help improve blood flow and supply oxygen to the body, such as extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO). Sometimes an injury, such as a tear in one of the heart's chambers or a damaged heart valve, can cause cardiogenic shock.
info-Symptoms: Fatigue, rapid heartbeat, shortness of breath, hypotension, sweating
info-Causes: Heart attack, myocarditis, endocarditis, certain medications and substances
info-Risk factors: Heart failure, old age, hypertension
info-Prognosis: For patients where the cause is not due to a heart attack, the mortality rate is still relatively high, at about 60%; some progress has been made in treating CS when due to a heart attack, and the mortality rate is now somewhat lower for those with MI who survive and are treated rapidly with current therapies (February 2021)

Name: Cardiomyopathy
Overview: Cardiomyopathy (kahr-dee-o-my-OP-uh-thee) is a disease of the heart muscle that makes it harder for the heart to pump blood to the rest of the body. Treatment which might include medications, surgically implanted devices or, in severe cases, a heart transplant depends on which type of cardiomyopathy one has and how serious it is.
Causes: Note that the heart walls (muscles) are much thicker (hypertrophied) in the heart with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This type involves abnormal thickening of the heart muscle, particularly affecting the muscle of the heart's main pumping chamber (left ventricle). Most affected people have a family history of the disease, and some genetic mutations have been linked to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This least common type of cardiomyopathy can occur at any age, but it most often affects older people. The most common cause is coronary artery disease or heart attack.t ttHypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Most affected people have a family history of the disease, and some genetic mutations have been linked to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.t ttRestrictive cardiomyopathy.
Diagnosis: If the doctor thinks one has cardiomyopathy, one might need to undergo several tests to confirm the diagnosis, including Cardiac catheterization. Several blood tests might be done, including those to check the kidney, thyroid and liver function, and to measure the iron levels. One blood test can measure B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP), a protein produced in the heart. The blood level of BNP might rise when the heart is in heart failure, a common complication of cardiomyopathy. The doctor might recommend this test to evaluate symptoms, determine the exercise capacity and determine if exercise provokes abnormal heart rhythms.
Remedies: Eat a healthy diet, including a variety of fruits and vegetables and whole grains. Reduce the amount of salt in the diet, and aim for less than 1,500 milligrams of sodium daily.
Medication: The doctor might prescribe medications to improve the heart's pumping ability, improve blood flow, lower blood pressure, slow the heart rate, remove excess fluid from the body or keep blood clots from forming. Recent data suggests that at low, medium and even high volume centers there is a gradient of mortality, meaning it's highest at the low volume centers and lowest at the high volume centers. A small portion of the thickened heart muscle is destroyed by injecting alcohol through a long, thin tube (catheter) into the artery supplying blood to that area. To treat abnormal heart rhythms, doctors guide long, flexible tubes (catheters) through the blood vessels to the heart. In this open-heart surgery, the surgeon removes part of the thickened heart muscle wall (septum) that separates the two bottom heart chambers (ventricles).
info-Symptoms: Shortness of breathFeeling tiredSwelling of the legs

Name: Carotid artery disease
Overview: The carotid arteries are a pair of blood vessels located on both sides of the neck that deliver blood to the brain and head. Carotid artery disease occurs when fatty deposits (plaques) clog the blood vessels that deliver blood to the brain and head (carotid arteries).
Causes: Plaques are clumps of cholesterol, calcium, fibrous tissue and other cellular debris that gather at microscopic injury sites within the artery. Clogged carotid arteries have trouble delivering oxygen and nutrients to vital brain structures that are responsible for the day-to-day functioning.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of carotid artery disease include High blood pressure. Diabetes lowers the ability to process fats efficiently, placing one at greater risk of high blood pressure and atherosclerosis. High levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol and high levels of triglycerides, a blood fat, encourage the accumulation of plaques. Excess weight increases the chances of high blood pressure, atherosclerosis and diabetes. It contributes to conditions that damage the arteries, including high blood pressure, diabetes and obesity.

Name: Carpal tunnel syndrome
Symptoms: Carpal tunnel syndrome symptoms usually start gradually and include Tingling or numbness. These symptoms often occur while holding a steering wheel, phone or newspaper, or may wake one from sleep. This may be due to the numbness in the hand or weakness of the thumb's pinching muscles, which are also controlled by the median nerve.
Causes: Anything that squeezes or irritates the median nerve in the carpal tunnel space may lead to carpal tunnel syndrome. A wrist fracture can narrow the carpal tunnel and irritate the nerve, as can the swelling and inflammation caused by rheumatoid arthritis.
Risk factors: Although they may not directly cause carpal tunnel syndrome, they may increase the risk of irritation or damage to the median nerve. A wrist fracture or dislocation, or arthritis that deforms the small bones in the wrist, can alter the space within the carpal tunnel and put pressure on the median nerve. Women who have carpal tunnel syndrome may also have smaller carpal tunnels than women who don't have the condition. Working with vibrating tools or on an assembly line that requires prolonged or repetitive flexing of the wrist may create harmful pressure on the median nerve or worsen existing nerve damage, especially if the work is done in a cold environment. However, the scientific evidence is conflicting and these factors haven't been established work as direct causes of carpal tunnel syndrome. However, there has not been enough quality and consistent evidence to support extensive computer use as a risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome, although it may cause a different form of hand pain. Some studies have shown a link between carpal tunnel syndrome and the use of anastrozole (Arimidex), a drug used to treat breast cancer. Fluid retention may increase the pressure within the carpal tunnel, irritating the median nerve. Certain conditions, such as menopause, thyroid disorders, kidney failure and lymphedema, may increase the chances of carpal tunnel syndrome.
Diagnosis: The doctor may ask one questions and conduct one or more of the following tests to determine whether one has carpal tunnel syndrome: History of symptoms. For example, because the median nerve doesn't provide sensation to the little finger, symptoms in that finger may indicate a problem other than carpal tunnel syndrome. This test can identify damage to the muscles controlled by the median nerve, and also may rule out other conditions.
Remedies: These steps may provide temporary symptom relief: If pain, numbness or weakness recurs and persists, see the doctor. Take short, frequent breaks from repetitive activities involving the use of the hands. Take a pain reliever, such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve).
info-Symptoms: Pain, numbness, tingling in the thumb, index, middle finger, and half of ring finger, weak grip
info-Causes: Compression of the median nerve at the carpal tunnel
info-Risk factors: Genetics, obesity, repetitive wrist work, rheumatoid arthritis
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, specific physical tests, electrodiagnostic tests

Name: Cataracts
Overview: A cataract occurs when the lens of the eye becomes cloudy. Clouded vision caused by cataracts can make it more difficult to read, drive a car (especially at night) or see the expression on a friend's face.
Diagnosis: Using a chart or a viewing device with progressively smaller letters, the eye doctor determines if one has 20/20 vision or if the vision shows signs of impairment. To prepare for a retinal exam, the eye doctor puts drops in the eyes to open the pupils wide (dilate). Using a slit lamp or a special device called an ophthalmoscope, the eye doctor can examine the lens for signs of a cataract.
info-Symptoms: Faded colors, blurry vision, halos around light, trouble with bright lights, trouble seeing at night
info-Causes: Aging, trauma, radiation exposure, following eye surgery, genetic
info-Risk factors: Diabetes, smoking tobacco, prolonged exposure to sunlight, alcohol

Name: Cavernous malformations
Diagnosis: The diagnosis may result from brain imaging for other neurological conditions, or specific symptoms may prompt the doctor to pursue more extensive testing. Depending on why the condition is suspected, doctors may order tests specifically to confirm CCMs, or to identify or rule out other related conditions. Sometimes a doctor may inject a contrast dye into a vein in the arm to look at the brain tissue in a slightly different way, or to better look at the blood vessels in the brain (magnetic resonance angiography or magnetic resonance venography).
Treatment: Doctors trained in brain and nervous system conditions (neurologists and cerebrovascular neurologists), brain and nervous system surgery (neurosurgeons), brain imaging (neuroradiologists), and other specialties work with one to treat CCMs as well as other neurological conditions. If the treatment plan includes surgery, more advanced imaging technologies, such as functional MRI and tractography, may also be useful within specific contexts. If one is not experiencing symptoms, the doctor may initially decide to monitor the cavernous malformation, especially since risk is generally lower for those who are non-symptomatic. If one is experiencing symptoms related to a cavernous malformation that can be reached surgically, the doctor may recommend surgery to remove the malformation.

Name: Cellulite
Symptoms: Cellulite that is more severe makes the skin appear rumpled and bumpy with areas of peaks and valleys. Cellulite is most common around the thighs and buttocks, but it can also be found on the breasts, lower abdomen and upper arms.
Overview: As fat cells increase, they push up against the skin. Cellulite is a very common, harmless skin condition that causes lumpy, dimpled flesh on the thighs, hips, buttocks and abdomen. Many people try, with variable success, to improve the appearance of their skin through weight loss, exercise, massage and creams marketed as a solution to cellulite.
Causes: It involves fibrous connective cords that tether the skin to the underlying muscle, with the fat lying between. In addition, hormonal factors play a large role in the development of cellulite, and genetics determine skin structure, skin texture and body type.
Treatment: In one method, a thin fiber is slipped under the skin to deliver laser heat that destroys the fibrous bands binding fat. There's also a device that uses heat (radiofrequency) for nonablative treatment that improves how the skin looks. The doctor may offer one of various procedures that use needles, blades or other special tools to separate the fibrous bands under the skin (subcision) in an effort to smooth the skin. With cryolipolysis (CoolSculpting), fat below the skin is reduced with a device that uses vacuum suction to raise tissue into contact with cooling plates. With this technique, a technician applies gel to the affected skin and runs a small, hand-held device (transducer) over the area.
Remedies: Retinol helps thicken skin, which reduces the dimpling. If one is carrying extra weight, losing pounds and toning muscles may help improve the appearance of dimpled skin. Find one or more activities that one enjoy and can fit into the routine, such as yoga, Pilates, swimming, walking, biking, stair climbing and dancing. This diet involves consuming less alcohol, caffeine, refined food, carbohydrates and saturated fat, and avoiding smoking, diet pills, sleeping pills, laxatives and diuretics. It encourages a diet based on fresh vegetables and fruits, water, whole-grain foods, fiber-rich foods, and essential nutrients and fatty acids. This diet alone won't cure the cellulite, but it might help. If one want to try such creams, look for products that include caffeine, retinol, and alpha hydroxy acids and aminophylline.

Name: Cellulitis
Overview: Cellulitis is usually a superficial infection of the skin. Cellulitis (sel-u-LIE-tis) is a common, potentially serious bacterial skin infection.
Risk factors: Any cut, fracture, burn or scrape gives bacteria an entry point. Conditions that weaken the immune system such as diabetes, leukemia and HIV/AIDS leave one more susceptible to infections. Conditions such as eczema, athlete's foot and shingles can cause breaks in the skin, which give bacteria an entry point.
Treatment: One may need to be hospitalized and receive antibiotics through the veins (intravenously) if: Usually, doctors prescribe a drug that's effective against both streptococci and staphylococci. Try these steps to help ease any pain and swelling: One is likely to start by seeing the family doctor or a general practitioner, who may refer one to a doctor who specializes in skin disorders (dermatologist). Signs and symptoms don't respond to oral antibiotics Signs and symptoms are extensive One has a high fever Place a cool, damp cloth on the affected area as often as needed for the comfort.
info-Symptoms: Red, hot, painful area of skin, fever
info-Risk factors: Break in the skin, obesity, leg swelling, old age

Name: Central nervous system vascular malformations
Overview: Central nervous system vascular malformations are rare abnormalities of blood vessels in the brain or spinal cord and their membranes. Arteriovenous malformations are abnormal tangles of blood vessels connecting arteries and veins. Cavernous malformations are abnormally formed blood vessels in the brain or spinal cord that have the appearance of a mulberry. Dural arteriovenous fistulas are abnormal connections between arteries and the tough covering over the brain or spinal cord (dura) and a draining vein. Venous malformations, also known as developmental venous anomalies, are abnormally enlarged veins in the brain or spinal cord.

Name: Cerebral aneurysm
Symptoms: Common signs and symptoms of a ruptured aneurysm include In some cases, an aneurysm may leak a slight amount of blood. An unruptured brain aneurysm may produce no symptoms, particularly if it's small. Dr. Bernard Bendok says a ruptured aneurysm is a medical emergency that can cause life-threatening bleeding in the brain. It includes open surgery, or less-invasive options, such as sealing the ruptured artery from within the blood vessel with metal coils and/or stents. Dr. Bendok says 1 to 2 percent of the population have aneurysms, and only a small percentage of that group will experience a rupture.
Overview: An aneurysm is a ballooning at a weak spot in an artery wall. A brain aneurysm can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain (hemorrhagic stroke). Most often a ruptured brain aneurysm occurs in the space between the brain and the thin tissues covering the brain. Most brain aneurysms, however, don't rupture, create health problems or cause symptoms. Treatment for an unruptured brain aneurysm may be appropriate in some cases and may prevent a rupture in the future.
Diagnosis: If one experience a sudden, severe headache or other symptoms possibly related to a ruptured aneurysm, one will be given a test or series of tests to determine whether one has had bleeding into the space between the brain and surrounding tissues (subarachnoid hemorrhage) or possibly another type of stroke. If one show symptoms of an unruptured brain aneurysm such as pain behind the eye, changes in vision or double vision one will also undergo some tests to identify the offending aneurysm. With this test, one may also receive an injection of a dye that makes it easier to observe blood flow in the brain and may indicate the presence of an aneurysm. During this procedure, also called a cerebral arteriogram, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube (catheter) into a large artery usually in the groin and threads it past the heart to the arteries in the brain.
info-Symptoms: None, severe headache, visual problems, nausea and vomiting, confusion
info-Risk factors: Smoking, old age, family history, cocaine use
info-Treatment: Endovascular coiling, surgical clipping, cerebral bypass surgery, pipeline embolization

Name: Cervical cancer
Causes: Two types of cells line the surface of the cervix, and both can become cancerous. Cervical cancer begins when healthy cells in the cervix develop changes (mutations) in their DNA. The main types of cervical cancer are: Sometimes, both types of cells are involved in cervical cancer. This type of cervical cancer begins in the thin, flat cells (squamous cells) lining the outer part of the cervix, which projects into the vagina.
Risk factors: Risk factors for cervical cancer include Many sexual partners. The greater the number of sexual partners and the greater the partner's number of sexual partners the greater the chance of acquiring HPV. One may be more likely to develop cervical cancer if the immune system is weakened by another health condition and one has HPV. If the mother took a drug called diethylstilbestrol (DES) while pregnant in the 1950s, one may have an increased risk of a certain type of cervical cancer called clear cell adenocarcinoma.
Diagnosis: Next, a sample of cells from the cervix is collected using a small cone-shaped brush and a tiny plastic spatula (1 and 2). A Pap test can detect abnormal cells in the cervix, including cancer cells and cells that show changes that increase the risk of cervical cancer. During a cone biopsy (conization), a doctor surgically removes a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix. During the colposcopic examination, the doctor is likely to take a sample of cervical cells (biopsy) for laboratory testing. To obtain tissue, the doctor may use: If the punch biopsy or endocervical curettage is worrisome, the doctor may perform one of the following tests: If the doctor determines that one has cervical cancer, one will have further tests to determine the extent (stage) of the cancer. Endocervical curettage, which uses a small, spoon-shaped instrument (curet) or a thin brush to scrape a tissue sample from the cervix. Cone biopsy (conization), which is a procedure that allows the doctor to obtain deeper layers of cervical cells for laboratory testing. Tests such as X-ray, CT, MRI and positron emission tomography (PET) help the doctor determine whether the cancer has spread beyond the cervix. Punch biopsy, Endocervical curettage, Electrical wire loop, Cone biopsy (conization), Imaging tests.
info-Symptoms: Early: noneLater: vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, pain during sexual intercourse
info-Risk factors: Smoking, weak immune system, birth control pills, starting sex at a young age, many sexual partners or a partner with many sexual partners
info-Diagnostic method: Cervical screening followed by a biopsy
info-Prevention: Regular cervical screening, HPV vaccines, sexual intercourse with condoms, sexual abstinence

Name: Cervicitis
Overview: The ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix and vagina (vaginal canal) make up the female reproductive system. Possible symptoms of cervicitis include bleeding between menstrual periods, pain with intercourse or during a cervical exam, and abnormal vaginal discharge.
Causes: Most often, the bacterial and viral infections that cause cervicitis are transmitted by sexual contact. Cervicitis can result from common sexually transmitted infections (STIs), including gonorrhea, chlamydia, trichomoniasis and genital herpes.
Diagnosis: During a pelvic exam, the doctor inserts two gloved fingers inside the vagina. To diagnose cervicitis, the doctor will likely perform a physical exam that includes: A pelvic exam. In a process similar to a Pap test, the doctor uses a small cotton swab or a brush to gently remove a sample of cervical and vaginal fluid.
Treatment: If one has cervicitis caused by a sexually transmitted infection (STI), both one and the partner will need treatment, often with an antibiotic medication. The doctor may offer antiviral medication if one has genital herpes, which helps decrease the amount of time one has cervicitis symptoms.

Name: Chiari malformation
Symptoms: In Chiari malformation type I, signs and symptoms usually appear during late childhood or adulthood. The signs and symptoms can include those related to a form of spina bifida called myelomeningocele that nearly always accompanies Chiari malformation type II. Signs and symptoms may include Chiari malformation type II is usually noted with ultrasound during pregnancy. If one or the child has any of the signs and symptoms that may be associated with Chiari malformation, see the doctor for an evaluation. Because many symptoms of Chiari malformation can also be associated with other disorders, a thorough medical evaluation is important.
Overview: In Chiari malformation surgery, doctors remove a small section of bone at the back of the skull to make room for part of the brain (cerebellum) and relieve pressure on the brainstem, cerebellum and spinal cord. Doctors categorize Chiari malformation into three types, depending on the anatomy of the brain tissue that is displaced into the spinal canal and whether developmental abnormalities of the brain or spine are present.

Name: Child maltreatment
Overview: Any intentional harm or mistreatment to a child under 18 years old is considered child abuse. In many cases, child abuse is done by someone the child knows and trusts often a parent or other relative. Sexual child abuse is any sexual activity with a child, such as fondling, oral-genital contact, intercourse, exploitation or exposure to child pornography. Medical child abuse occurs when someone gives false information about illness in a child that requires medical attention, putting the child at risk of injury and unnecessary medical care.

Name: Childhood apraxia of speech
Overview: Childhood apraxia of speech (CAS) is an uncommon speech disorder in which a child has difficulty making accurate movements when speaking. To speak correctly, the child's brain has to learn how to make plans that tell his or her speech muscles how to move the lips, jaw and tongue in ways that result in accurate sounds and words spoken with normal speed and rhythm.
Diagnosis: To evaluate the child's condition, the child's speech-language pathologist will review the child's symptoms and medical history, conduct an examination of the muscles used for speech, and examine how the child produces speech sounds, words and phrases. The child's speech-language pathologist will also assess the child's language skills, such as his or her vocabulary, sentence structure and ability to understand speech. The child's speech-language pathologist may be able to determine an appropriate treatment approach for the child, even if the diagnosis is initially uncertain. The child's speech-language pathologist will examine the child's lips, tongue, jaw and palate for structural problems, such as tongue-tie or a cleft palate, or other problems, such as low muscle tone. The child's speech-language pathologist will observe how the child moves his or her lips, tongue and jaw in activities such as blowing, smiling and kissing. To evaluate the child's coordination of movement in speech, the child may be asked to repeat syllables such as pa-ta-ka or say words such as buttercup. If the child can produce sentences, the child's speech-language pathologist will observe the child's melody and rhythm of speech, such as how he or she stresses syllables and words. The child's speech-language pathologist may help the child be more accurate by providing cues, such as saying the word or sound more slowly or providing touch cues to his or her face.

Name: Childhood asthma
Diagnosis: So the child's doctor will have to determine whether the child's symptoms are caused by asthma, a condition other than asthma, or both asthma and another condition. The child might have lung function tests at rest, after exercising and after taking asthma medication. If the child seems to have asthma that's triggered by allergies, the doctor might recommend allergy skin testing. If the diagnosis of asthma is uncertain after lung function tests, the doctor might recommend measuring the level of nitric oxide in an exhaled sample of the child's breath.
Remedies: If one live in a damp climate, talk to the child's doctor about using a device to keep the air drier (dehumidifier). Air conditioning helps reduce the amount of airborne pollen from trees, grasses and weeds that finds its way indoors. Air conditioning also lowers indoor humidity and can reduce the child's exposure to dust mites. If the child's asthma is worsened by cold, dry air, wearing a face mask outside can help.

Name: Chlamydia trachomatis
Diagnosis: For women, the doctor takes a swab of the discharge from the cervix for culture or antigen testing for chlamydia. The rate of chlamydia infection is highest in this group, so a yearly screening test is recommended. If one has a high risk of infection from changing sex partners or because the regular partner might be infected get tested again later in the pregnancy. People who have multiple sex partners, who don't always use a condom or men who have sex with men should consider frequent chlamydia screening.
Treatment: One might receive a one-time dose, or one might need to take the medication daily or multiple times a day for five to 10 days. If one think one has a sexually transmitted infection, such as Chlamydia trachomatis, see the family doctor.

Name: Cholangiocarcinoma ( bile duct cancer )
Risk factors: Scarring of the liver caused by a history of chronic liver disease increases the risk of cholangiocarcinoma. People born with a choledochal cyst, which causes dilated and irregular bile ducts, have an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma. In areas of Southeast Asia, cholangiocarcinoma is associated with liver fluke infection, which can occur from eating raw or undercooked fish.
Diagnosis: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) uses a dye to highlight the bile ducts on X-ray images. A thin, flexible tube (endoscope) with a camera on the end is passed down the throat and into the small intestine. During an endoscopic ultrasound, the doctor inserts a long, flexible tube (endoscope) down the throat and into the abdomen. If the suspicious area is located very near where the bile duct joins the small intestine, the doctor may obtain a biopsy sample during ERCP. If the suspicious area is within or near the liver, the doctor may obtain a tissue sample by inserting a long needle through the skin to the affected area (fine-needle aspiration). During endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), a thin tube equipped with a tiny camera is passed down the throat and through the digestive tract to the small intestine. The doctor may also use this procedure to inject dye into the bile ducts to help them show up better on imaging tests. Techniques used to diagnose bile duct cancer include computerized tomography (CT) scans and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) combined with magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP).
Treatment: Treatments for cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) may include Because cholangiocarcinoma is a very difficult type of tumor to treat, don't hesitate to ask about the doctor's experience with treating the condition. For very small bile duct cancers, this involves removing part of the bile duct and joining the cut ends. For more-advanced bile duct cancers, nearby liver tissue, pancreas tissue or lymph nodes may be removed as well. Surgery to remove the liver and replace it with one from a donor (liver transplant) may be an option in certain cases for people with hilar cholangiocarcinoma. For many, a liver transplant is a cure for hilar cholangiocarcinoma, but there is a risk that the cancer will recur after a liver transplant. Radiation therapy uses high-energy sources, such as photons (x-rays) and protons, to damage or destroy cancer cells. Photodynamic therapy can help relieve the signs and symptoms, and it may also slow cancer growth.

Name: Cholera
Symptoms: But because they shed cholera bacteria in their stool for seven to 14 days, they can still infect others through contaminated water. Most cases of cholera that cause symptoms cause mild or moderate diarrhea that's often hard to tell apart from diarrhea caused by other problems. Others develop more-serious signs and symptoms of cholera, usually within a few days of infection. Dehydration can develop within hours after cholera symptoms start and range from mild to severe. If one develop severe diarrhea after visiting an area with active cholera, see the doctor. If one has diarrhea, especially severe diarrhea, and think one might have been exposed to cholera, seek treatment right away. Cholera-related diarrhea comes on suddenly and can quickly cause dangerous fluid loss as much as a quart (about 1 liter) an hour. Diarrhea due to cholera often has a pale, milky appearance that resembles water in which rice has been rinsed.
Overview: Cholera is a bacterial disease usually spread through contaminated water. The risk of a cholera epidemic is highest when poverty, war or natural disasters force people to live in crowded conditions without adequate sanitation.
Causes: The toxin causes the body to secrete enormous amounts of water, leading to diarrhea and a rapid loss of fluids and salts (electrolytes). Eating raw or undercooked seafood, especially shellfish, that comes from certain places can expose one to cholera bacteria. Raw, unpeeled fruits and vegetables are a frequent source of cholera infection in areas where there's cholera. In developing countries, uncomposted manure fertilizers or irrigation water containing raw sewage can contaminate produce in the field.
Risk factors: Cholera bacteria can't survive in an acidic environment, and ordinary stomach acid often serves as a defense against infection. But people with low levels of stomach acid such as children, older adults, and people who take antacids, H-2 blockers or proton pump inhibitors lack this protection, so they're at greater risk of cholera. For reasons that aren't entirely clear, people with type O blood are twice as likely to develop cholera compared with people with other blood types. Although industrialized nations no longer have large-scale cholera outbreaks, eating shellfish from waters known to harbor the bacteria greatly increases the risk.
Treatment: The goal is to replace lost fluids and electrolytes using a simple rehydration solution, oral rehydration salts (ORS). Without rehydration, approximately half the people with cholera die. Seek immediate medical care if one develop severe diarrhea or vomiting and are in or have very recently returned from a country where cholera occurs. If one believe one has been exposed to cholera, but the symptoms are not severe, call the family doctor. When one make the appointment, ask if there are restrictions one need to follow before the visit. Make a list of: Some questions to ask the doctor about cholera include Rehydration. Most people with cholera can be helped by oral rehydration alone, but severely dehydrated people might also need intravenous fluids. While not a necessary part of cholera treatment, some antibiotics can reduce cholera-related diarrhea and shorten how long it lasts in severely ill people. The symptoms, when they began and how severe they are Recent exposure to possible sources of infection, particularly if one has traveled abroad recently Key medical information, including other conditions for which one is being treated All medications, vitamins or other supplements one take, including doses Questions to ask the doctor Are there other possible causes for my symptoms? The symptoms, Recent exposure to possible sources of infection, Key medical information, All medications, vitamins or other supplements one take, Questions to ask
info-Symptoms: Large amounts of watery diarrhea, vomiting, muscle cramps
info-Causes: Vibrio cholerae spread by fecal-oral route
info-Risk factors: Poor sanitation, not enough clean drinking water, poverty
info-Prevention: Improved sanitation, clean water, hand washing, cholera vaccines
info-Treatment: Oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, intravenous fluids, antibiotics

Name: Chondrosarcoma
Overview: Chondrosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that usually begins in the bones, but can sometimes occur in the soft tissue near bones. Some types of chondrosarcomas grow slowly and, provided they are removed completely, have a low risk of spreading to other organs and bones.

Name: Chordoma
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects a spinal tumor, these tests can help confirm the diagnosis and pinpoint the tumor's location: Spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). MRI uses a powerful magnetic field and radio waves to produce accurate images of the spine, spinal cord and nerves.

Name: Choroid plexus carcinoma
Diagnosis: If it's suspected that one has a brain tumor, the doctor may recommend a number of tests and procedures, including Imaging tests. A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. Positron emission tomography (PET) may be used for brain imaging, but is generally not as useful for creating images of brain cancer as it is for other types of cancer. A stereotactic needle biopsy may be done for brain tumors in hard to reach areas or very sensitive areas within the brain that might be damaged by a more extensive operation. If it's suspected that the brain tumor may be a result of cancer that has spread from another area of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer originated.

Name: Chronic fatigue syndrome
Overview: Chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) is a complicated disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The cause of chronic fatigue syndrome is unknown, although there are many theories ranging from viral infections to psychological stress.
Causes: Because some people develop chronic fatigue syndrome after having a viral infection, researchers question whether some viruses might trigger the disorder. People who have chronic fatigue syndrome also sometimes experience abnormal blood levels of hormones produced in the hypothalamus, pituitary glands or adrenal glands.
Diagnosis: Because the symptoms of chronic fatigue syndrome can mimic so many other health problems, one may need patience while waiting for a diagnosis. A sleep study can determine if the rest is being disturbed by disorders such as obstructive sleep apnea, restless legs syndrome or insomnia. Fatigue is also a symptom of a variety of mental health problems, such as depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder and schizophrenia.
Medication: The most effective treatment for chronic fatigue syndrome appears to be a two-pronged approach that combines cognitive training with a gentle exercise program. Talking with a counselor can help one figure out options to work around some of the limitations that chronic fatigue syndrome imposes on one. Gradually increasing the intensity of the exercise over time may help reduce the hypersensitivity to exercise, just like allergy shots gradually reduce a person's hypersensitivity to a particular allergen.
info-Specialty: Neurology, rheumatology, Infectious disease, physical medicine and rehabilitation, psychiatry, behavioral medicine:â€Š223
info-Symptoms: Worsening of symptoms with activity, long-term fatigue, others
info-Risk factors: Being genetically female, virus and bacterial infections, Having blood relatives with the illness, major injury, bodily response to severe stress and others:â€Š1â€“2

Name: Chronic granulomatous disease
Risk factors: Chronic granulomatous disease: Pathogenesis, clinical manifestations, and diagnosis. Future of care for patients with chronic granulomatous disease: Gene therapy and targeted molecular medicine.
Diagnosis: The doctor may order several tests to diagnose CGD, including Neutrophil function tests. The doctor may conduct a dihydrorhodamine 123 (DHR) test or other tests to see how well a type of white blood cell (neutrophil) in the blood is functioning. Doctors may conduct prenatal testing to diagnose CGD if one of the children already has been diagnosed with CGD.
Treatment: Treatment may include continuous antibiotic therapy, such as trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole combination (Bactrim, Sulfatrim Pediatric) to protect against bacterial infections, and itraconazole (Sporanox, Tolsura) to prevent fungal infection. One may have interferon-gamma injections periodically, which may help boost cells in the immune system to fight infections.

Name: Chronic traumatic encephalopathy
Symptoms: If one has thoughts of hurting theself, call 911, the local emergency number or the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 800-273-TALK (800-273-8255). See the doctor if one has had a head injury, even if one didn't need emergency care. If the child has received a head injury that concerns one, call the child's doctor immediately. Depending on the signs and symptoms, the doctor may recommend seeking immediate medical care.
Overview: Chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) is the term used to describe brain degeneration likely caused by repeated head traumas. Experts are still trying to understand how repeated head traumas including how many head injuries and the severity of those injuries and other factors might contribute to the changes in the brain that result in CTE.
info-Symptoms: Behavioral problems, mood problems, problems with thinking
info-Risk factors: Contact sports, military, domestic abuse, repeated banging of the head

Name: Cirrhosis
Overview: A normal liver (left) shows no signs of scarring. Cirrhosis is a late stage of scarring (fibrosis) of the liver caused by many forms of liver diseases and conditions, such as hepatitis and chronic alcoholism. As cirrhosis progresses, more and more scar tissue forms, making it difficult for the liver to function (decompensated cirrhosis).
Risk factors: Being obese increases the risk of conditions that may lead to cirrhosis, such as nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. Not everyone with chronic hepatitis will develop cirrhosis, but it's one of the world's leading causes of liver disease.
Diagnosis: The doctor may order one or more tests that may suggest a problem with the liver, including Laboratory tests. The doctor may order blood tests to check for signs of liver malfunction, such as excess bilirubin, as well as for certain enzymes that may indicate liver damage. Based on the blood test results, the doctor may be able to diagnose the underlying cause of cirrhosis. If one has cirrhosis, the doctor is likely to recommend regular diagnostic tests to monitor for signs of disease progression or complications, especially esophageal varices and liver cancer. However, the doctor may use it to identify the severity, extent and cause of liver damage.
Remedies: If one has cirrhosis, be careful to limit additional liver damage: Don't drink alcohol. Whether the cirrhosis was caused by chronic alcohol use or another disease, avoid alcohol. Avoid drugs such as aspirin and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others). If one has liver damage, the doctor may recommend one avoid acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or take it in low doses for pain relief.
info-Symptoms: Tiredness, itchiness, swelling in the lower legs, jaundice, easily bruising, fluid build-up in the abdomen
info-Causes: Alcoholic liver disease, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, non-alcoholic steatohepatitis
info-Diagnostic method: Blood tests, medical imaging, liver biopsy
info-Prevention: Vaccination (such as hepatitis B), avoiding alcohol

Name: Claudication
Overview: Claudication is pain caused by too little blood flow to the legs or arms. Claudication is technically a symptom of disease, most often peripheral artery disease, a narrowing of arteries in the limbs that restricts blood flow.
Causes: This is the buildup of cholesterol and other fats, blood cells, and other cellular debris into abnormal structures (plaques) on the lining of an artery. Plaques cause a narrowing and stiffening of the artery, limiting the flow of blood.
Remedies: A healthy lifestyle is essential for improving treatment outcomes and lowering risks associated with claudication and peripheral artery disease. Eat plenty of low-starch vegetables, fruits and whole grains, and modest portions of lean meats, poultry, fish and low-fat dairy.
Medication: These include drugs to manage the following: Talk to the doctor about over-the-counter medications, supplements or other medications that one shouldn't take with the prescribed treatment. The drug cilostazol, which improves blood flow, may reduce pain during exercise and enable one to walk further. Several different classes of drugs may be prescribed to lower blood pressure and reduce the risk of heart attack or stroke. Anti-platelet drugs, which help prevent the formation of blood clots, may reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke or clots blocking blood flow to limbs. Once the artery is widened, the doctor may place a small metal or plastic mesh tube (stent) in the artery to keep it open. During this type of surgery, the doctor takes a healthy blood vessel from another part of the body to replace the vessel that's causing claudication.

Name: Cleft lip and cleft palate
Overview: A cleft lip is an opening or split in the upper lip that occurs when developing facial structures in an unborn baby don't close completely. Cleft lip and cleft palate are openings or splits in the upper lip, the roof of the mouth (palate) or both.
Risk factors: Several factors may increase the likelihood of a baby developing a cleft lip and cleft palate, including Males are more likely to have a cleft lip with or without cleft palate. Cleft lip and cleft palate may be more likely to occur in pregnant women who smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol or take certain medications. There is some evidence that women diagnosed with diabetes before pregnancy may have an increased risk of having a baby with a cleft lip with or without a cleft palate. There is some evidence that babies born to obese women may have increased risk of cleft lip and palate.
info-Symptoms: Opening in the upper lip that may extend into the nose or palate
info-Risk factors: Smoking during pregnancy, diabetes, obesity, older mother, certain medications

Name: Clubfoot
Symptoms: If the child has clubfoot, here's what it might look like: Despite its look, clubfoot itself doesn't cause any discomfort or pain. More than likely the doctor will notice clubfoot soon after the child is born, based on appearance.
Overview: Doctors use the term clubfoot to describe a range of foot abnormalities usually present at birth (congenital). Doctors are usually able to treat clubfoot successfully without surgery, though sometimes children need follow-up surgery later on.
