info-Symptoms: Foot that is rotated inwards and downwards
info-Risk factors: Genetics, mother who smokes cigarettes, males Ethnicity
info-Treatment: Ponseti method (manipulation, casting, cutting the Achilles tendon, braces), French method, surgery

Name: Coarctation of the aorta
Overview: Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing, or constriction, in a portion of the aorta. Narrowing of the aorta (aortic coarctation, pronounced ko-ahrk-TAY-shun) forces the heart to pump harder to move blood through the aorta. Although the condition can affect any part of the aorta, the defect is most often located near a blood vessel called the ductus arteriosus.
Risk factors: The aortic valve separates the lower left chamber (left ventricle) of the heart from the aorta. Sub-aortic stenosis occurs when there is a narrowing of the area below the aortic valve that obstructs blood flow from the left ventricle to the aorta. Some people are born with a hole in the wall (septum) between the upper heart chambers (atrial septal defect) or the lower heart chambers (ventricular septal defect).This causes oxygen-rich blood from the left side of the heart to mix with oxygen-poor blood in the right side of the heart. The mitral valve is between the upper and lower left heart chambers. As a result, the movement of blood between the upper and lower left heart chambers is reduced, increasing the pressure in the upper left chamber (atrium).
Diagnosis: They may often appear healthy until a doctor detects: Tests to confirm a diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta may include Electrocardiogram (ECG). If the coarctation of the aorta is severe, the ECG may show thickening of the walls of the lower heart chambers (ventricular hypertrophy). During this procedure, the doctor inserts a long, thin tube (catheter) into an artery or vein in the groin, arm or neck and threads it to the heart using X-ray imaging. High blood pressure in the arms A blood pressure difference between the arms and legs, with higher blood pressure in the arms and lower blood pressure in the legs A weak or delayed pulse in the legs A heart murmur an abnormal whooshing sound caused by faster blood flow through the narrowed area Echocardiogram. This test can show the location and severity of the coarctation of the aorta, damage to other blood vessels, and any other heart defects. The test can show the location and severity of the coarctation of the aorta and determine whether it affects other blood vessels in the body.
Remedies: Although coarctation of the aorta may be repaired, regular doctor's checkups are needed for the rest of the or the child's life to monitor for complications. Talk to the doctor about whether one need to restrict certain physical activities, such as weightlifting, which can temporarily raise the blood pressure. Women with coarctation of the aorta, even after repair, may have a higher risk of aortic rupture, aortic dissection or other complications during pregnancy and delivery. If one has had aortic coarctation repair and are considering becoming pregnant, careful management of the blood pressure is important to help keep one and the baby healthy.

Name: Cold urticaria
Symptoms: The worst reactions generally occur with full skin exposure, such as swimming in cold water. Even if the reactions are mild, the doctor will want to rule out underlying conditions that may be causing the problem.
Overview: Cold urticaria (ur-tih-KAR-e-uh) is a skin reaction to cold that appears within minutes after cold exposure. For some people with this condition, swimming in cold water could lead to very low blood pressure, fainting or shock.
Risk factors: The most common type primary acquired cold urticaria occurs most frequently in young adults. A less common type secondary acquired cold urticaria can be caused by an underlying health problem, such as hepatitis or cancer.
Treatment: In some people, cold urticaria goes away on its own after weeks or months. The doctor may recommend one try to prevent or reduce symptoms with home remedies, such as using over-the-counter antihistamines and avoiding cold exposure. Prescription medications used to treat cold urticaria include If one has cold urticaria because of an underlying health problem, one may need medications or other treatment for that condition as well. If one has a history of systemic reaction, the doctor may prescribe an epinephrine autoinjector that one will need to carry with one. They can be used to treat mild symptoms of cold urticaria or to prevent a reaction. Over-the-counter (nonprescription) products include loratadine (Claritin) and cetirizine (Zyrtec). He or she may then refer one to a doctor who specializes in skin diseases (dermatologist) or to an allergy specialist (allergist-immunologist). For cold urticaria, some basic questions to ask include Nondrowsy antihistamines. If one know one is going to be exposed to the cold, take an antihistamine beforehand to help prevent a reaction. Examples include loratadine (Claritin), cetirizine (Zyrtec) and desloratadine (Clarinex). Normally prescribed to treat asthma, this drug has been used successfully to treat people with cold urticaria who didn't respond to other medications.

Name: Colorectal cancer
Overview: Colon cancer can occur in any part of the colon. An examination of the entire colon using a long, flexible tube equipped with a camera (colonoscopy) is one way to detect colon cancer and polyps. It usually begins as small, noncancerous (benign) clumps of cells called polyps that form on the inside of the colon.
Causes: In general, colon cancer begins when healthy cells in the colon develop changes (mutations) in their DNA. But when a cell's DNA is damaged and becomes cancerous, cells continue to divide even when new cells aren't needed.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of colon cancer include Older age. African-Americans have a greater risk of colon cancer than do people of other races. If one has already had colon cancer or noncancerous colon polyps, one has a greater risk of colon cancer in the future. Chronic inflammatory diseases of the colon, such as ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease, can increase the risk of colon cancer. The most common inherited syndromes that increase colon cancer risk are familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Lynch syndrome, which is also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). If more than one family member has colon cancer or rectal cancer, the risk is even greater. Some studies have found an increased risk of colon cancer in people who eat diets high in red meat and processed meat. People with diabetes or insulin resistance have an increased risk of colon cancer. People who are obese have an increased risk of colon cancer and an increased risk of dying of colon cancer when compared with people considered normal weight. People who smoke may have an increased risk of colon cancer. Radiation therapy directed at the abdomen to treat previous cancers increases the risk of colon cancer.
Diagnosis: If the signs and symptoms indicate that one could have colon cancer, the doctor may recommend one or more tests and procedures, including Blood tests. The doctor may also test the blood for a chemical sometimes produced by colon cancers (carcinoembryonic antigen, or CEA). The most advanced stage of colon cancer (stage IV) indicates cancer has spread to other areas of the body, such as the liver or lungs. If one has been diagnosed with colon cancer, the doctor may recommend tests to determine the extent (stage) of the cancer.
info-Symptoms: vomiting blood, Blood in the stool, change in bowel movements, weight loss, fatigue.
info-Causes: Old age, lifestyle factors, genetic disorders
info-Risk factors: Diet, obesity, smoking, lack of physical activity, alcohol use
info-Diagnostic method: Tissue biopsy during a sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy
info-Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy

Name: Common cold
Overview: The common cold is a viral infection of the nose and throat (upper respiratory tract). Children younger than 6 are at greatest risk of colds, but healthy adults can also expect to have two or three colds annually.
Risk factors: Children younger than 6 are at greatest risk of colds, especially if they spend time in child-care settings. Both children and adults are more susceptible to colds in fall and winter, but one can get a cold anytime. One is more likely to catch a cold and to have more-severe colds if one is exposed to cigarette smoke. If one is around many people, such as at school or on an airplane, one is likely to be exposed to viruses that cause colds.
Treatment: For a fever, sore throat and headache, many people turn to acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or other mild pain relievers. This is because aspirin has been linked to Reye's syndrome, a rare but potentially life-threatening condition, in such children. These include acetaminophen (Children's Tylenol, FeverAll, others) or ibuprofen (Children's Advil, Children's Motrin, others) to ease symptoms. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the American Academy of Pediatrics strongly recommends against giving OTC cough and cold medicines to children younger than age 4 as they may be harmful. It isn't typically recommended that one give cough or cold medicines to an older child, but if one do, follow the label directions. Don't give the child two medicines with the same active ingredient, such as an antihistamine, decongestant or pain reliever. To make theself as comfortable as possible when one has a cold, try: Using saline nasal drops. One can buy these drops over-the-counter, and they can help relieve symptoms, even in children. In infants, gently suction the nostrils with a bulb syringe (insert the bulb syringe about 1/4 to 1/2 inch, or about 6 to 12 millimeters) after applying saline drops.
Remedies: To make theself as comfortable as possible when one has a cold, try: Using saline nasal drops. To help relieve nasal congestion, try saline nasal drops. One can buy these drops over-the-counter, and they can help relieve symptoms, even in children. In infants, gently suction the nostrils with a bulb syringe (insert the bulb syringe about 1/4 to 1/2 inch, or about 6 to 12 millimeters) after applying saline drops. If the air is dry, a cool-mist humidifier or vaporizer can moisten the air and help ease congestion and coughing. A saltwater gargle 1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon salt dissolved in a 4-ounce to 8-ounce glass of warm water can temporarily relieve a sore or scratchy throat.
info-Symptoms: Cough, sore throat, runny nose, fever
info-Prevention: Hand washing, face masks, cough etiquette, avoiding sick people

Name: Common cold in babies
Overview: A common cold is a viral infection of the baby's nose and throat. Treatment for the common cold in babies involves easing their symptoms, such as by providing fluids, keeping the air moist and helping them keep their nasal passages open.
Causes: The common cold is an infection of the nose and throat (upper respiratory tract infection) that can be caused by one of more than 100 viruses. But because so many viruses cause colds, the baby may have several colds a year and many throughout his or her lifetime. A common cold virus enters the baby's mouth, nose or eyes. When someone who is sick coughs, sneezes or talks, he or she might directly spread the virus to the baby.
Risk factors: Infants are, by nature, at risk of common colds because they haven't yet been exposed to or developed resistance to most of the viruses that cause them. Infants spend time with other children, who don't always wash their hands or cover their coughs and sneezes, which increases the baby's risk of catching a cold.
Remedies: Keep the baby's nasal passages clear with a rubber-bulb syringe. Then insert the tip of the bulb about 1/4 to 1/2 inch (0.64 to 1.27 centimeters) into the baby's nostril, pointing toward the back and side of the nose. Release the bulb, holding it in place while it suctions the mucus from the baby's nose. Remove the syringe from the baby's nostril, and empty the contents onto a tissue by squeezing the bulb rapidly while holding the tip down. The baby's doctor may recommend saline nose drops to loosen thick nasal mucus. Then insert the tip of the bulb about 1/4 to 1/2 inch (0.64 to 1.27 centimeters) into the baby's nostril, pointing toward the back and side of the nose.ttRelease the bulb, holding it in place while it suctions the mucus from the baby's nose.

Name: Common variable immunodeficiency
Causes: In around 10% of people with CVID, a genetic mutation has been identified. Researchers believe that the condition is caused by a combination of both environmental and genetic factors. In: Mandell, Douglas, and Bennett's Principles and Practice of Infectious Diseases.

Name: Compartment syndrome , chronic exertional
Risk factors: Certain factors increase the risk of developing chronic exertional compartment syndrome, including Age. Although people of any age can develop chronic exertional compartment syndrome, the condition is most common in male and female athletes under age 30.
Diagnosis: Other exercise-related problems are more common than chronic exertional compartment syndrome, so the doctor may first try to rule out other causes such as shin splints or stress fractures before moving on to more specialized testing. It has been found to be accurate in detecting chronic exertional compartment syndrome, and may reduce the need for the invasive compartment pressure testing. If results from imaging studies do not show a stress fracture or similar cause of pain, the doctor might suggest measuring the pressure within the muscle compartments. Because it's invasive and mildly painful, involving insertion of needles into the muscles, compartment pressure measurement usually isn't performed unless the medical history and other tests strongly suggest one has this condition.
Remedies: To help relieve the pain of chronic exertional compartment syndrome, try the following: Use athletic shoe inserts (orthotics) or wear better athletic shoes. Use athletic shoe inserts (orthotics) Limit the physical activities Stretch the painful limb

Name: Concussion
Causes: Sudden acceleration or deceleration of the head, caused by events such as a car crash or being violently shaken, also can cause brain injury. These injuries affect brain function, usually for a brief period, resulting in signs and symptoms of concussion. This type of brain injury may lead to bleeding in or around the brain, causing symptoms such as prolonged drowsiness and confusion.
Diagnosis: Tests the doctor may perform or recommend include a neurological examination, cognitive testing and imaging tests. This evaluation includes checking the: The doctor may conduct several tests to evaluate the thinking (cognitive) skills during a neurological examination. Testing may evaluate several factors, including the: Brain imaging may be recommended for some people with signs and symptoms such as severe headaches, seizures, repeated vomiting or symptoms that are becoming worse.
info-Symptoms: Headache, trouble with thinking, memory or concentration, nausea, blurry vision, sleep disturbances, mood changes
info-Causes: Motor vehicle collisions, falls, sports injuries, bicycle accidents
info-Risk factors: Drinking alcohol, playing contact sports such as American football, previous history of concussion
info-Prevention: Head protection equipment, like hard hats, gridiron football, motorcycle, or bicycle helmets
info-Treatment: Physical and cognitive rest for a day or two with a gradual return to activities

Name: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia
Symptoms: CAH may also be identified when male or female babies show signs of severe illness due to low levels of cortisol, aldosterone or both. In children who have nonclassic CAH, signs and symptoms of early puberty may appear.
Overview: Perched atop each of the kidneys, the adrenal glands produce hormones that help regulate the metabolism, immune system, blood pressure and other essential functions. The adrenal glands produce important hormones, including In people who have CAH, a genetic problem results in a lack of one of the enzymes needed to make these hormones. There are two major types of congenital adrenal hyperplasia: Cortisol, which regulates the body's response to illness or stress Mineralocorticoids, such as aldosterone, which regulate sodium and potassium levels Androgens, such as testosterone, which are male sex hormones Classic CAH.
Causes: To have an autosomal recessive disorder, one inherit two abnormal genes, one from each parent. A carrier has one abnormal gene (recessive gene) and one normal gene (dominant gene). Children who have the condition have two parents who either have CAH themselves or who are both carriers of the genetic mutation that causes the condition.
Diagnosis: Tests used to diagnose CAH in fetuses include Doctors recommend that all newborns in the United States be screened for genetic 21-hydroxylase deficiency during the first few days of life. If the doctor suspects CAH based on a physical exam and symptoms, the next step is to confirm the diagnosis with blood and urine tests. In older children and young adults, genetic testing may be needed to diagnose CAH. In female infants who have severe ambiguous genitalia, tests can be done to analyze chromosomes to identify genetic sex.
Medication: During periods of illness or significant stress, such as surgery, additional medications or higher doses may be needed. Medications may include Monitoring the effectiveness of medication includes regularly scheduled: In some female infants who have severe ambiguous genitalia as a result of classic CAH, doctors may recommend reconstructive surgery to improve genital function and make them look more feminine. The doctor will check the child's growth and development, including monitoring changes in height, weight, blood pressure and bone growth. The doctor will monitor the child for side effects, such as the loss of bone mass and impaired growth, particularly if steroid-type replacement medication doses are high and used long term.
info-Symptoms: Excessive urination of sodium, virilism, early, delayed, or absent puberty, hyperandrogenism
info-Causes: Variants in genes responsible the enzymes required for the synthesis of cortisol in the adrenal cortex

Name: Congenital heart defects in children
Causes: The lower chambers, the more muscular right and left ventricles, pump blood out of the heart. To pump blood throughout the body, the heart uses its left and right sides for different tasks. In the lungs, blood picks up oxygen then returns to the heart's left side through the pulmonary veins. When blood vessels or heart valves are narrow because of a heart defect, the heart must work harder to pump blood through them. For example, in hypoplastic left heart syndrome, the left side of the heart hasn't developed enough to effectively pump enough blood to the body.
Risk factors: Most congenital heart defects result from problems early in the child's heart development, the cause of which is unknown. Certain medications taken during pregnancy may cause birth defects, including congenital heart defects. Medications known to increase the risk of congenital heart defects include thalidomide (Thalomid), angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, statins, the acne medication isotretinoin (Absorica, Amnesteem, Claravis) and lithium. Many children with Down syndrome which is caused by an extra 21st chromosome (trisomy 21) have heart defects. A missing piece (deletion) of genetic material on chromosome 22 also causes heart defects. One can reduce the risk of congenital heart defects by carefully controlling the diabetes before attempting to conceive and during pregnancy. Avoid alcohol during pregnancy because it increases the risk of congenital heart defects.
Diagnosis: The child's doctor may initially suspect a problem because he or she hears a heart murmur during a routine exam. Most heart murmurs are innocent, meaning that there is no heart defect and the murmur isn't dangerous to the child's health. Some murmurs, however, may mean blood is flowing through the child's heart abnormally because he or she has a heart defect. If it's possible the child has a heart defect, the doctor or the child's doctor may order several tests to see if the child has a heart problem. The child's doctor may use a regular echocardiogram to diagnose a congenital heart defect after the child has been born. In this noninvasive test, the child's doctor performs an ultrasound to produce images of the heart. An echocardiogram allows the doctor to see the child's heart in motion and to identify abnormalities in the heart muscle and valves. In this test, a thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted into a blood vessel at the baby's groin and guided through it into the heart. Catheterization is sometimes necessary because it may give the child's doctor a much more detailed view of the child's heart defect than an echocardiogram. This test allows the doctor to see if the child has a heart defect before he or she is born, allowing the doctor to better plan treatment. This noninvasive test records the electrical activity of the child's heart and can help diagnose heart defects or rhythm problems. The child may have a chest X-ray to see if the heart is enlarged, or if the lungs have extra blood or other fluid in them.
Treatment: A congenital heart defect may have no long-term effect on the child's health in some instances, such defects can safely go untreated. Depending on the type of heart defect the child has, doctors treat congenital heart defects with: Procedures using catheterization. Some children and adults now have their congenital heart defects repaired using catheterization techniques, which allow the repair to be done without surgically opening the chest and heart. In procedures that can be done using catheterization, the doctor inserts a thin tube (catheter) into a leg vein and guides it to the heart with the help of X-ray images. Some mild congenital heart defects, especially those found later in childhood or adulthood, can be treated with medications that help the heart work more efficiently. Drugs known as angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) and beta blockers and medications that cause fluid loss (diuretics) can help ease stress on the heart by lowering blood pressure, heart rate and the amount of fluid in the chest.

Name: Congenital mitral valve anomalies
Diagnosis: To diagnose congenital heart disease, the doctor will do a physical exam and listen to the heart with a stethoscope. Tests to diagnose or rule out congenital heart disease include Electrocardiogram (ECG). An ECG can diagnose many heart problems, including irregular heartbeats and blocked arteries. The doctor can use this test to see how the heart's chambers and valves are pumping blood through the heart. If more-detailed images of the heart are needed, the doctor may recommend a transesophageal echocardiogram. Cardiac MRI uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create images of the heart. The doctor might use this test to check blood flow and blood pressures in the heart. Then, the doctor gently inserts a catheter into an artery or vein in the groin, neck or arm and up to the heart.
Medication: If one is an adult with congenital heart disease, one is at risk of developing complications even if one had surgery to repair a defect during childhood. A device that helps control the heart rate (pacemaker) or that corrects life-threatening irregular heartbeats (implantable cardioverter-defibrillator or ICD) may help improve some of the complications associated with congenital heart defects. If catheter procedures can't fix the heart defect, the doctor might recommend open-heart surgery.

Name: Congenital myasthenic syndromes
Overview: Congenital myasthenic syndromes are rare hereditary (genetic) conditions resulting from a defect at the junction where the nerve stimulates muscle activity. Congenital myasthenic syndromes may affect the nerve cells (presynaptic), the muscle cells (postsynaptic), or the space between the nerve and muscle cells (synaptic). Congenital myasthenic syndromes: Pathogenesis, diagnosis, and treatment.

Name: Congenital myopathies
Symptoms: Common signs and symptoms include There are different types of congenital myopathies, some of which include Congenital myopathies are usually noticed at birth. These rare conditions cause muscle weakness in the face, arms, legs and eye muscles, and breathing problems. This condition causes muscle weakness in the face, neck, arms, legs and trunk. Nemaline myopathy is one of the more common congenital myopathies and causes muscle weakness in the face, neck, arms and legs, and sometimes scoliosis. This condition has several subtypes and often causes severe muscle weakness in the arms and legs, and scoliosis. This rare condition, which occurs only in males, causes muscle weakness, floppiness and breathing problems. Other rare myopathies include autophagic vacuolar myopathy, cap disease, congenital myopathy with arrest of myogenesis, myosin storage (hyaline body) myopathy and zebra body myopathy.
Overview: Congenital myopathies are rare muscle diseases mostly present at birth (congenital) that result from genetic defects. Other signs and symptoms of some congenital myopathies include feeding and breathing difficulties, as well as skeletal conditions, such as curvature of the spine (scoliosis), weak bones (osteopenia) or hip problems.
Treatment: Congenital myopathies can't be cured, but doctors can help one manage the condition and symptoms. In addition to these treatments, some people with congenital myopathies may benefit from an evaluation from an endocrinologist. An endocrinologist can monitor bone health, as bone diseases such as osteopenia and osteoporosis may develop in some people with congenital myopathies. When one learn the child has a congenital myopathy, one may experience a range of emotions, including anger, fear, worry, sorrow and guilt. But, the effects of some congenital myopathies may not appear until childhood or later. For example, the drug albuterol (Proair HFA, Ventolin HFA, others) may be helpful in some congenital myopathies. Orthopedic support devices or other treatments, such as surgery to correct or improve scoliosis or contractures, may be helpful. Physical, occupational or speech therapy may help manage symptoms.

Name: Conjoined twins
Symptoms: Conjoined twins are typically classified according to where they're joined, usually at matching sites, and sometimes at more than one site. In extremely rare cases, one twin may be found partially developed within the other twin (fetus in fetu). Thoracopagus (thor-uh-KOP-uh-gus) twins are joined face to face at the chest. Many omphalopagus twins share the liver, and some share the lower part of the small intestine (ileum) and colon. Pygopagus (pie-GOP-uh-gus) twins are commonly joined back to back at the base of the spine and the buttocks. Some pygopagus twins share the lower gastrointestinal tract, and a few share the genital and urinary organs. Rachipagus (ray-KIP-uh-gus), also called rachiopagus (ray-kee-OP-uh-gus), twins are joined back to back along the length of the spine. Ischiopagus (is-kee-OP-uh-gus) twins are joined at the pelvis, either face to face or end to end. Many ischiopagus twins share the lower gastrointestinal tract, as well as the liver and genital and urinary tract organs. Each twin may have two legs or, less commonly, the twins share two or three legs. Parapagus (pa-RAP-uh-gus) twins are joined side to side at the pelvis and part or all of the abdomen and chest, but with separate heads. Craniopagus (kray-nee-OP-uh-gus) twins are joined at the back, top or side of the head, but not the face. Cephalopagus (sef-uh-LOP-uh-gus) twins are joined at the face and upper body.
Overview: Conjoined twins may be joined at one of several places. Though many conjoined twins are not alive when born (stillborn) or die shortly after birth, advances in surgery and technology have improved survival rates.
Diagnosis: More-detailed ultrasounds and echocardiograms can be used about halfway through pregnancy to better determine the extent of the twins connection and the functioning of their organs. If an ultrasound detects conjoined twins, a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan may be done.

Name: Constipation
Causes: Causes include Neurological problems can affect the nerves that cause muscles in the colon and rectum to contract and move stool through the intestines. Causes include Problems with the pelvic muscles involved in having a bowel movement may cause chronic constipation.
Diagnosis: In addition to a general physical exam and a digital rectal exam, doctors use the following tests and procedures to diagnose chronic constipation and try to find the cause: Evaluation of how well food moves through the colon (colonic transit study). Examination of the rectum and lower, or sigmoid, colon (sigmoidoscopy). In this procedure, the doctor inserts a lighted, flexible tube into the anus to examine the rectum and the lower portion of the colon. This diagnostic procedure allows the doctor to examine the entire colon with a flexible, camera-equipped tube. In this procedure, the doctor inserts a narrow, flexible tube into the anus and rectum and then inflates a small balloon at the tip of the tube.
info-Symptoms: Infrequent or hard to pass bowel movements, abdominal pain, bloating
info-Causes: Slow movement of stool within the colon, irritable bowel syndrome, celiac disease, non-celiac gluten sensitivity, pelvic floor disorders
info-Risk factors: Hypothyroidism, diabetes, Parkinson's disease, gluten-related disorders, colon cancer, ovarian cancer, diverticulitis, inflammatory bowel disease, certain medications
info-Treatment: Drinking enough fluids, eating more fiber, exercise
info-Medication: Laxatives of the bulk forming agent, osmotic agent, stool softener, or lubricant type

Name: Constipation in children
Overview: Constipation in children is a common problem. Encouraging the child to make simple dietary changes such as eating more fiber-rich fruits and vegetables and drinking more water can go a long way toward alleviating constipation.
Causes: Constipation most commonly occurs when waste or stool moves too slowly through the digestive tract, causing the stool to become hard and dry. Many factors can contribute to constipation in children, including Withholding. Painful bowel movements caused by large, hard stools also may lead to withholding. If toilet training becomes a battle of wills, a voluntary decision to ignore the urge to poop can quickly become an involuntary habit that's tough to change. Any changes in the child's routine such as travel, hot weather or stress can affect bowel function. An allergy to cow's milk or consuming too many dairy products (cheese and cow's milk) sometimes leads to constipation. Rarely, constipation in children indicates an anatomic malformation, a metabolic or digestive system problem, or another underlying condition.
Diagnosis: The child's doctor will: More-extensive testing is usually reserved for only the most severe cases of constipation. The child's physical exam will likely include placing a gloved finger into the child's anus to check for abnormalities or the presence of impacted stool. This standard X-ray test allows the child's doctor to see if there are any blockages in the child's abdomen. In this test, a thin tube called a catheter is placed in the rectum to measure the coordination of the muscles the child uses to pass stool. In this test, the lining of the bowel is coated with a contrast dye (barium) so that the rectum, colon and sometimes part of the small intestine can be clearly seen on an X-ray. In this test, the child will swallow a capsule containing markers that show up on X-rays taken over several days.
Treatment: Depending on the circumstances, the child's doctor may recommend: Over-the-counter fiber supplements or stool softeners. If an accumulation of fecal material creates a blockage, the child's doctor may suggest a laxative or enema to help remove the blockage. In addition to changes in diet and routine, various alternative approaches may help relieve constipation in children: If the child's constipation lasts longer than two weeks, one will likely first seek medical care from the child's doctor. Gently massaging the child's abdomen may relax the muscles that support the bladder and intestines, helping to promote bowel activity.

Name: COPD
Overview: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Emphysema is a condition in which the alveoli at the end of the smallest air passages (bronchioles) of the lungs are destroyed as a result of damaging exposure to cigarette smoke and other irritating gases and particulate matter.
Causes: Only some chronic smokers develop clinically apparent COPD, although many smokers with long smoking histories may develop reduced lung function. COPD causes them to lose their elasticity and over-expand, which leaves some air trapped in the lungs when one exhale. In emphysema, the inner walls of the lungs air sacs (alveoli) are damaged, causing them to eventually rupture. Causes of airway obstruction include In the vast majority of people with COPD, the lung damage that leads to COPD is caused by long-term cigarette smoking. But there are likely other factors at play in the development of COPD, such as a genetic susceptibility to the disease, because not all smokers develop COPD. Other irritants can cause COPD, including cigar smoke, secondhand smoke, pipe smoke, air pollution, and workplace exposure to dust, smoke or fumes. In about 1% of people with COPD, the disease results from a genetic disorder that causes low levels of a protein called alpha-1-antitrypsin (AAt).
Risk factors: Pipe smokers, cigar smokers and marijuana smokers also may be at risk, as well as people exposed to large amounts of secondhand smoke. Asthma, a chronic inflammatory airway disease, may be a risk factor for developing COPD. In the developing world, people exposed to fumes from burning fuel for cooking and heating in poorly ventilated homes are at higher risk of developing COPD.
Diagnosis: To diagnose the condition, the doctor will review the signs and symptoms, discuss the family and medical history, and discuss any exposure one has had to lung irritants especially cigarette smoke. These tests measure the amount of air one can inhale and exhale, and whether the lungs deliver enough oxygen to the blood. During the most common test, called spirometry, one blow into a large tube connected to a small machine to measure how much air the lungs can hold and how fast one can blow the air out of the lungs. Lab tests aren't used to diagnose COPD, but they may be used to determine the cause of the symptoms or rule out other conditions. For example, lab tests may be used to determine if one has the genetic disorder alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency, which may be the cause of COPD in some people.
Remedies: If one has COPD, one can take steps to feel better and slow the damage to the lungs: Control the breathing. Also be sure to discuss breathing positions, energy conservation techniques and relaxation techniques that one can use when one is short of breath. It may seem difficult to exercise when one has trouble breathing, but regular exercise can improve the overall strength and endurance and strengthen the respiratory muscles. If one is overweight, losing weight can significantly help the breathing, especially during times of exertion.
Medication: Examples of these include For people who experience periods when their COPD becomes more severe, called moderate or severe acute exacerbation, short courses (for example, five days) of oral corticosteroids may prevent further worsening of COPD. A medication approved for people with severe COPD and symptoms of chronic bronchitis is roflumilast (Daliresp), a phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitor. When other treatment has been ineffective or if cost is a factor, theophylline (Elixophyllin, Theo-24, Theochron), a less expensive medication, may help improve breathing and prevent episodes of worsening COPD. Side effects are dose related and may include nausea, headache, fast heartbeat and tremor, so tests are used to monitor blood levels of the medication. Some studies show that certain antibiotics, such as azithromycin (Zithromax), prevent episodes of worsening COPD, but side effects and antibiotic resistance may limit their use. Pulmonary rehabilitation after episodes of worsening COPD may reduce readmission to the hospital, increase the ability to participate in everyday activities and improve the quality of life. Evidence supports in-hospital use of breathing devices such as bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP), but some research now supports the benefit of its use at home. A noninvasive ventilation therapy machine with a mask helps to improve breathing and decrease retention of carbon dioxide (hypercapnia) that may lead to acute respiratory failure and hospitalization. When exacerbations occur, one may need additional medications (such as antibiotics, steroids or both), supplemental oxygen or treatment in the hospital. Once symptoms improve, the doctor can talk with one about measures to prevent future exacerbations, such as quitting smoking; taking inhaled steroids, long-acting bronchodilators or other medications; getting the annual flu vaccine; and avoiding air pollution whenever possible. Albuterol (ProAir HFA, Ventolin HFA, others) Ipratropium (Atrovent HFA) Levalbuterol (Xopenex) Aclidinium (Tudorza Pressair) Arformoterol (Brovana) Formoterol (Perforomist) Indacaterol (Arcapta Neoinhaler) Tiotropium (Spiriva) Salmeterol (Serevent) Umeclidinium (Incruse Ellipta) Fluticasone (Flovent HFA) Budesonide (Pulmicort Flexhaler) Fluticasone and vilanterol (Breo Ellipta) Fluticasone, umeclidinium and vilanterol (Trelegy Ellipta) Formoterol and budesonide (Symbicort) Salmeterol and fluticasone (Advair HFA, AirDuo Digihaler, others) Aclidinium and formoterol (Duaklir Pressair) Albuterol and ipratropium (Combivent Respimat) Formoterol and glycopyrrolate (Bevespi Aerosphere) Glycopyrrolate and indacaterol (Utibron) Olodaterol and tiotropium (Stiolto Respimat) Umeclidinium and vilanterol (Anoro Ellipta) Oxygen therapy.
info-Symptoms: Shortness of breath, chronic cough
info-Prevention: Stopping smoking, improving indoor and outdoor air quality, tobacco control measures
info-Treatment: Pulmonary rehabilitation, long-term oxygen therapy, lung volume reduction

Name: Corns and calluses
Overview: Corns and calluses are thick, hardened layers of skin that develop when the skin tries to protect itself against friction and pressure. If one has diabetes or another condition that causes poor blood flow to the feet, one is at greater risk of complications from corns and calluses.
Risk factors: When one has a bunion, the tip of the big toe shifts towards the smaller toes, crowding them. A bunion is an abnormal, bony bump that forms on the joint at the base of the big toe.
Treatment: If a corn or callus persists or becomes painful despite the self-care efforts, medical treatments can provide relief: If one has diabetes or another condition that causes poor blood flow, consult the doctor before treating a corn and callus on the own. If one has no underlying health problems, try these suggestions to help clear up a corn or callus: Trimming away excess skin. The doctor can pare down thickened skin or trim a large corn with a scalpel, usually during an office visit. The doctor may also apply a patch containing 40 percent salicylic acid (Clear Away, MediPlast,others). He or she may recommend that one use a pumice stone, nail file or emery board to smooth away dead skin before applying a new patch. If one has an underlying foot deformity, the doctor may prescribe custom-made padded shoe inserts (orthotics) to prevent recurring corns or calluses. These contain salicylic acid, which can irritate healthy skin and lead to infection, especially in people with diabetes or other conditions that cause poor blood flow. Soaking the hands or feet in warm, soapy water softens corns and calluses. During or after bathing, rub a corn or callus with a pumice stone, nail file, emery board or washcloth to help remove a layer of toughened skin.
Remedies: If one has diabetes or another condition that causes poor blood flow, consult the doctor before treating a corn and callus on the own. If one has no underlying health problems, try these suggestions to help clear up a corn or callus: Use over-the-counter pads. These contain salicylic acid, which can irritate healthy skin and lead to infection, especially in people with diabetes or other conditions that cause poor blood flow. Soaking the hands or feet in warm, soapy water softens corns and calluses. During or after bathing, rub a corn or callus with a pumice stone, nail file, emery board or washcloth to help remove a layer of toughened skin.

Name: Coronary artery disease
Symptoms: If the coronary arteries narrow, they can't supply enough oxygen-rich blood to the heart especially when it's beating hard, such as during exercise. As plaque continues to build up in the coronary arteries, however, one may develop the following coronary artery disease signs and symptoms: Heart attack. Women are somewhat more likely than men are to have less typical signs and symptoms of a heart attack, such as neck or jaw pain. The doctor may want to test one for coronary artery disease, especially if one has signs or symptoms of narrowed arteries. If the heart can't pump enough blood to meet the body's needs, one may develop shortness of breath or extreme fatigue with activity.
Overview: Coronary artery disease develops when the major blood vessels that supply the heart become damaged or diseased. Eventually, the reduced blood flow may cause chest pain (angina), shortness of breath, or other coronary artery disease signs and symptoms. Because coronary artery disease often develops over decades, one might not notice a problem until one has a significant blockage or a heart attack.
Causes: Atherosclerosis is a process in which blood, fats such as cholesterol and other substances build up on the artery walls. If the plaque surface breaks or ruptures, blood cells called platelets clump together at the site to try to repair the artery.
Risk factors: Risk factors for coronary artery disease include Risk factors often occur together and one may trigger another. When grouped together, certain risk factors make one even more likely to develop coronary artery disease. For example, metabolic syndrome a cluster of conditions that includes high blood pressure; high triglycerides; low HDL, or good, cholesterol; high insulin levels and excess body fat around the waist increases the risk of coronary artery disease. A family history of heart disease is associated with a higher risk of coronary artery disease, especially if a close relative developed heart disease at an early age. Breathing in secondhand smoke also increases a person's risk of coronary artery disease. Type 2 diabetes and coronary artery disease share similar risk factors, such as obesity and high blood pressure. Lack of exercise also is associated with coronary artery disease and some of its risk factors, as well. Unrelieved stress in the life may damage the arteries as well as worsen other risk factors for coronary artery disease. Eating too much food that has high amounts of saturated fat, trans fat, salt and sugar can increase the risk of coronary artery disease. Sudden drops in blood oxygen levels that occur during sleep apnea increase blood pressure and strain the cardiovascular system, possibly leading to coronary artery disease. High levels may raise the risk of coronary artery disease, especially for women. But high levels of homocysteine may increase the risk of coronary artery disease.
Diagnosis: During an echocardiogram, the doctor can determine whether all parts of the heart wall are contributing normally to the heart's pumping activity. During cardiac catheterization, a doctor gently inserts a catheter into an artery or vein in the groin, neck or arm and up to the heart. A CT coronary angiogram, in which one receive a contrast dye that is given by IV during a CT scan, can produce detailed images of the heart arteries. If the signs and symptoms occur most often during exercise, the doctor may ask one to walk on a treadmill or ride a stationary bike during an ECG. A tracer is injected into the bloodstream, and special cameras can detect areas in the heart that receive less blood flow.
Remedies: If one has other risk factors for heart disease, the target LDL cholesterol may be below 100 mg/dL (2.6 mmol/L). Some of the main risk factors for coronary artery disease high cholesterol, high blood pressure and diabetes have no symptoms in the early stages. If one has diabetes, tight blood sugar management can help reduce the risk of heart disease. Exercise helps manage weight and control diabetes, high cholesterol and high blood pressure all risk factors for coronary artery disease. If one has had surgery, the doctor may suggest one participate in cardiac rehabilitation a program of education, counseling and exercise training that's designed to help improve the health.
info-Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath
info-Causes: Atherosclerosis of the arteries of the heart
info-Risk factors: High blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, lack of exercise, obesity, high blood cholesterol
info-Diagnostic method: Electrocardiogram, cardiac stress test, coronary computed tomographic angiography, coronary angiogram
info-Prevention: Healthy diet, regular exercise, maintaining a healthy weight, not smoking
info-Treatment: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), coronary artery bypass surgery (CABG)

Name: Corticobasal degeneration
Diagnosis: However, the signs and symptoms could be due to another degenerative disease such as progressive supranuclear palsy, Alzheimer's disease, Pick's disease and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Researchers are looking at whether positron emission tomography (PET) and single-photon emission computerized tomography (SPECT) scans can uncover changes in the brain that are consistent with corticobasal degeneration.

Name: Costosternal syndrome
Overview: Costochondritis most commonly affects the upper ribs on the left-hand side of the body. Pain is often worst where the rib cartilage attaches to the breastbone (sternum), but it can also occur where the cartilage attaches to the rib.
Causes: Occasionally, however, costochondritis may be caused by: Injury. Heavy lifting, strenuous exercise and severe coughing have been linked to costochondritis. Costochondritis might be linked to specific problems, such as osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis or ankylosing spondylitis. Viruses, bacteria and fungi such as tuberculosis, syphilis and aspergillosis can infect the rib joint. Cancer might travel to the joint from another part of the body, such as the breast, thyroid or lung.
Remedies: Ask the doctor about using ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve, others). Try placing hot compresses or a heating pad on the painful area several times a day.
Medication: The doctor might recommend: Physical therapy treatments might include If conservative measures don't work, the doctor might suggest injecting numbing medication and a corticosteroid directly into the painful joint. Although certain medications, such as ibuprofen (Motrin IB) or naproxen sodium (Aleve) are available over the counter, the doctor might prescribe stronger varieties of these nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications. If the pain is severe, the doctor might prescribe medications containing codeine, such as hydrocodone/acetaminophen (Vicodin, Norco) or oxycodone/acetaminophen (Tylox, Roxicet, Percocet). In a procedure called transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), a device sends a weak electrical current via adhesive patches on the skin near the area of pain.

Name: Cough , chronic
Overview: A chronic cough is a cough that lasts eight weeks or longer in adults, or four weeks in children. While it can sometimes be difficult to pinpoint the problem that's triggering a chronic cough, the most common causes are tobacco use, postnasal drip, asthma and acid reflux.
Causes: In one type of asthma (cough-variant asthma), a cough is the main symptom. A common but under-recognized cause of a chronic cough in adults is pertussis, also known as whooping cough. Chronic cough can also occur with fungal infections of the lung, tuberculosis (TB) infection or lung infection with nontuberculous mycobacterial organisms. COPD, a chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs, includes chronic bronchitis and emphysema. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, which are commonly prescribed for high blood pressure and heart failure, are known to cause chronic cough in some people.
Diagnosis: However, many doctors opt to start treatment for one of the common causes of chronic cough rather than ordering expensive tests. The doctor may request an asthma challenge test, which checks how well one can breathe before and after inhaling the drug methacholine (Provocholine). If the doctor isn't able to find an explanation for the cough, special scope tests may be considered to look for possible causes. These tests may include A chest X-ray and spirometry, at a minimum, are typically ordered to find the cause of a chronic cough in children. Although a routine chest X-ray won't reveal the most common reasons for a cough postnasal drip, acid reflux or asthma it may be used to check for lung cancer, pneumonia and other lung diseases. Using a thin, flexible tube equipped with a light and camera (bronchoscope), the doctor can look at the lungs and air passages. Using a fiberoptic scope (rhinoscope), the doctor can view the nasal passageways, sinuses and upper airway.
Treatment: In many cases, more than one underlying condition may be causing the chronic cough. If one is taking an ACE inhibitor medication, the doctor may switch one to another medicine that doesn't have cough as a side effect. Medications used to treat chronic cough may include Antihistamines, corticosteroids and decongestants. The most effective treatments for asthma-related cough are corticosteroids and bronchodilators, which reduce inflammation and open up the airways. If a bacterial, fungal or mycobacterial infection is causing the chronic cough, the doctor may prescribe medications to address the infection. When lifestyle changes don't take care of acid reflux, one may be treated with medications that block acid production.
Remedies: In the meantime, one can also try these tips to ease the cough: Drink fluids. Smoking or breathing secondhand smoke irritates the lungs and can worsen coughs caused by other factors.

Name: Cradle cap
Overview: Cradle cap is characterized by scaly patches on a baby's scalp. Cradle cap appears as patchy scaling or thick crusts on the scalp and greasy skin covered with flaky white or yellow scales. Cradle cap causes crusty or oily scaly patches on a baby's scalp.
Treatment: If frequent shampooing doesn't help, talk with the baby's doctor about products that might help, such as a low-potency hydrocortisone cream or a shampoo with 2 percent antifungal ketoconazole medication. Don't use over-the-counter cortisone or antifungal creams without talking to the baby's doctor, because some of these products can be toxic when absorbed through a baby's skin. If the scales don't loosen easily, rub petroleum jelly or a few drops of mineral oil onto the baby's scalp. Once the scales are gone, wash the baby's hair every two to three days with a mild shampoo to prevent scale buildup.
Remedies: If the scales don't loosen easily, rub petroleum jelly or a few drops of mineral oil onto the baby's scalp. Once the scales are gone, wash the baby's hair every two to three days with a mild shampoo to prevent scale buildup.

Name: Craniopharyngioma
Diagnosis: If it's suspected that one has a brain tumor, the doctor may recommend a number of tests and procedures, including Imaging tests. A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. Positron emission tomography (PET) may be used for brain imaging, but is generally not as useful for creating images of brain cancer as it is for other types of cancer. A stereotactic needle biopsy may be done for brain tumors in hard to reach areas or very sensitive areas within the brain that might be damaged by a more extensive operation. If it's suspected that the brain tumor may be a result of cancer that has spread from another area of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer originated.

Name: Crohn 's disease
Symptoms: Crohn's disease most commonly affects the colon and the last part of the small intestine (ileum). In some people with Crohn's disease, only the last segment of the small intestine (ileum) is affected. The most common areas affected by Crohn's disease are the last part of the small intestine and the colon.
Overview: The colon, also called the large intestine, is a long, tubelike organ in the abdomen. While there's no known cure for Crohn's disease, therapies can greatly reduce its signs and symptoms and even bring about long-term remission.
Causes: Previously, diet and stress were suspected, but now doctors know that these factors may aggravate but don't cause Crohn's disease. Crohn's is more common in people who have family members with the disease, so genes may play a role in making people more susceptible. However, most people with Crohn's disease don't have a family history of the disease.
Risk factors: Crohn's disease can occur at any age, but one is likely to develop the condition when one is young. Although Crohn's disease can affect any ethnic group, whites have the highest risk, including people of Eastern European (Ashkenazi) Jewish descent. However, the incidence of Crohn's disease is increasing among blacks who live in North America and the United Kingdom. If one live in an urban area or in an industrialized country, one is more likely to develop Crohn's disease. This suggests that environmental factors, including a diet high in fat or refined foods, may play a role in Crohn's disease.
Diagnosis: The doctor will likely use a combination of tests to help confirm a diagnosis of Crohn's disease, including Tests for anemia or infection. The doctor may suggest blood tests to check for anemia a condition in which there aren't enough red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to the tissues or to check for signs of infection. One may need to provide a stool sample so that the doctor can test for hidden (occult) blood in the stool. This test allows the doctor to view the entire colon and the very end of the ileum (terminal ileum) using a thin, flexible, lighted tube with an attached camera. During the procedure, the doctor can also take small samples of tissue (biopsy) for laboratory analysis, which may help confirm a diagnosis.
Remedies: Here are some suggestions that may help: Limit fiber, if it's a problem food. If one has inflammatory bowel disease, high-fiber foods, such as fresh fruits and vegetables and whole grains, may make the symptoms worse. In general, one may have more problems with foods in the cabbage family, such as broccoli and cauliflower, and nuts, seeds, corn and popcorn. Smoking increases the risk of developing Crohn's disease, and once one has it, smoking can make it worse. Although stress doesn't cause Crohn's disease, it can make the signs and symptoms worse and may trigger flare-ups. Although it's not always possible to avoid stress, one can learn ways to help manage it, such as: Limit dairy products. Many people with inflammatory bowel disease find that problems such as diarrhea, abdominal pain and gas improve by limiting or eliminating dairy products. One may be lactose intolerant that is, the body can't digest the milk sugar (lactose) in dairy foods. If one has Crohn's disease of the small intestine, one may not be able to digest or absorb fat normally. Spicy foods, alcohol, and caffeine may make the signs and symptoms worse. Because Crohn's disease can interfere with the ability to absorb nutrients and because the diet may be limited, multivitamin and mineral supplements are often helpful.

Name: Croup
Overview: This shows a childs normal airway anatomy. When the upper airway is infected with the virus that causes croup, tissues around the voice box (larynx) and the windpipe (trachea) will swell. The cough and other signs and symptoms of croup are the result of swelling around the voice box (larynx), windpipe (trachea) and bronchial tubes (bronchi).
Remedies: In the meantime, keep the child comfortable with a few simple measures: The child's cough may improve during the day, but don't be surprised if it returns at night. Although there's no evidence of benefit from these practices, many parents believe that humid air or cool air helps a child's breathing. For moist air, one can use a humidifier or sit with the child in a bathroom filled with steam generated by running hot water from the shower. If it's cool outside, one can open a window for the child to breathe the cool air. Hold the child on the lap, or place the child in a favorite chair or infant seat. For older children, soup or frozen fruit pops may be soothing. If the child has a fever, over-the-counter medicines, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), may help. Over-the-counter cold preparations aren't recommended for children of any age, and can be harmful in children less than 2 years of age.
info-Symptoms: "Barky" cough, stridor, fever, stuffy nose
info-Duration: Usually 1â€“2 days but can last up to 7 days

Name: CRPS
Symptoms: Pain, swelling, redness, noticeable changes in temperature and hypersensitivity (particularly to cold and touch) usually occur first. If one experience constant, severe pain that affects a limb and makes touching or moving that limb seem intolerable, see the doctor to determine the cause.
Causes: Other major and minor traumas such as surgery, heart attacks, infections and even sprained ankles also can lead to CRPS. Also known as reflex sympathetic dystrophy (RSD), this type occurs after an illness or injury that didn't directly damage the nerves in the affected limb. But type 2 CRPS occurs after a distinct nerve injury.
Diagnosis: There's no single test that can definitively diagnose CRPS, but the following procedures may provide important clues: Bone scan. Loss of minerals from the bones may show up on an X-ray in later stages of the disease.
Medication: Over-the-counter (OTC) pain relievers such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve) may ease mild pain and inflammation. Taken in appropriate doses, they might help control pain. Sometimes antidepressants, such as amitriptyline, and anticonvulsants, such as gabapentin (Neurontin), are used to treat pain that originates from a damaged nerve (neuropathic pain). Steroid medications, such as prednisone, may reduce inflammation and improve mobility in the affected limb. The doctor may suggest medications to prevent or stall bone loss, such as alendronate (Fosamax) and calcitonin (Miacalcin). Some studies show that low doses of intravenous ketamine, a strong anesthetic, may substantially alleviate pain. Various topical treatments are available that may reduce hypersensitivity, such as over-the-counter capsaicin cream, or lidocaine cream or patches (Lidoderm, LMX 4, LMX 5). Gentle, guided exercising of the affected limbs or modifying daily activities might help decrease pain and improve range of motion and strength. In this therapy, medications that relieve pain are pumped into the spinal cord fluid. The insertion of long, thin needles may help stimulate nerves, muscles and connective tissue to increase blood flow and relieve pain.
info-Treatment: Physical therapy (more effective with early diagnosis); medications (e.g. anti-seizure for nerve pain, opioids, muscle relaxers etc.); Sympathetic Nerve Blocks; ketamine infusions; lidocaine infusions; implanted opioid pump; in rare cases amputation
info-Medication: Anti-seizure medications for nerve pain (e.g. Gabapentin); muscle relaxers (e.g. Baclofen), opioids (may be administered orally, via patch, or implanted intrathecal pump); ketamine or lidocaine infusions

Name: Cryoglobulinemia
Symptoms: Symptoms usually come and go, and may include Skin lesions. Cryoglobulinemia can damage the nerves at the tips of the fingers and toes, causing numbness and other problems.
Causes: Some cancers of the blood, such as multiple myeloma, Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia and chronic lymphocytic leukemia, can sometimes cause cryoglobulinemia. Disease such as lupus, rheumatoid arthritis and Sjogren's syndrome increase the risk of developing cryoglobulinemia.
Treatment: Depending on the underlying cause of cryoglobulinemia, treatment may include medications that suppress the immune system or fight viral infections. For severe symptoms, the doctor may also recommend a procedure that exchanges the blood plasma, which contains much of the cryoglobulins, for donor plasma or a replacement fluid.

Name: Cryptosporidium infection
Symptoms: Seek medical attention if one develop watery diarrhea that does not get better within a few days. Watery diarrhea Dehydration Lack of appetite Weight loss Stomach cramps or pain Fever Nausea Vomiting
Overview: Cryptosporidium infection (cryptosporidiosis) is an illness caused by tiny, one-celled cryptosporidium parasites. One can help prevent a cryptosporidium infection by practicing good hygiene and avoiding swallowing water from pools, recreational water parks, lakes and streams.
Diagnosis: To get cells for the analysis, the doctor might ask for a stool sample or, possibly, take a tissue sample (biopsy) from the intestine. A culture of a sample of the stool can't detect cryptosporidium, but it can help rule out other bacterial pathogens. Once it's clear that the infection is caused by cryptosporidium parasites, one might need further testing to check for complications.
Treatment: If one has a compromised immune system, the treatment goal is to relieve symptoms and improve the immune response. In some cases, he or she may refer one to a doctor who specializes in infectious diseases or a doctor who specializes in disorders of the gastrointestinal tract (gastroenterologist). Azithromycin (Zithromax) may be given with one of these medications in people with compromised immune systems. One will need either oral or intravenous replacement of fluids and electrolytes minerals, such as sodium, potassium and calcium, that maintain the balance of fluids in the body.

Name: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma
Overview: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) is a rare type of cancer that begins in white blood cells called T cells (T lymphocytes). In cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, the T cells develop abnormalities that make them attack the skin. Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma can cause rash-like skin redness, slightly raised or scaly round patches on the skin, and, sometimes, skin tumors. Some types of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, such as mycosis fungoides, progress slowly and others are more aggressive.
Causes: The DNA mutations tell the cells to grow and multiply rapidly, creating many abnormal cells. In cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, the mutations cause too many abnormal T cells that attack the skin.
Diagnosis: Punch biopsy During a punch biopsy, a doctor uses a special circular blade to remove deeper layers of skin for testing. During an excisional biopsy, the doctor removes an entire lump or an entire area of abnormal skin, including a portion of normal skin. A procedure to cut away a small sample of skin (skin biopsy) is usually needed to diagnose cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. A doctor who specializes in analyzing blood and tissue (pathologist) examines the sample in a lab to determine whether it contains cancer cells. If there's concern that the cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body, the doctor might recommend imaging tests, such as computerized tomography (CT) or positron emission tomography (PET) scans.
Treatment: Sometimes phototherapy is done after the application of a medication that makes skin cells more sensitive to light (photodynamic therapy). For people with more areas of cancer, radiation therapy might be done with electron beams, which target the skin and don't affect internal organs. Chemotherapy medicines attack quickly growing cells, including cancer cells. A bone marrow transplant, also known as a stem cell transplant, is a procedure to replace the diseased bone marrow with healthy bone marrow from a matched donor (allogeneic bone marrow transplant).
Remedies: Taking measures to care for the skin may help relieve symptoms, such as itching, and reduce the risk of infections. Applying lotion to the skin after showers and baths can help control itchiness and create a barrier to protect against germs that can cause infections. Ask the doctor whether it may be helpful for one to take regular bleach baths or soaks to reduce the risk of infections. For a bleach bath, add 1/2 cup (118 milliliters) of household bleach, not concentrated bleach, to a 40-gallon (151-liter) bathtub filled with warm water.

Name: Cyclic vomiting syndrome
Overview: Cyclic vomiting syndrome is characterized by episodes of severe vomiting that have no apparent cause. Cyclic vomiting syndrome occurs in all age groups, though it often begins in children around 3 to 7 years old.

Name: Cyclospora infection
Overview: Cyclospora infection (cyclosporiasis) causes watery, and sometimes explosive, diarrhea. Because diarrhea can be caused by many things, it can be difficult to diagnose cyclospora infection unless a specialized stool test is done.

Name: Cyclothymic disorder
Symptoms: Cyclothymia symptoms are similar to those of bipolar I or II disorder, but they're less severe. Although suicidal thoughts might occur with cyclothymia, they're more likely to occur if one has bipolar I or II disorder.
Overview: Cyclothymia (sy-kloe-THIE-me-uh), also called cyclothymic disorder, is a rare mood disorder. Although the highs and lows of cyclothymia are less extreme than those of bipolar disorder, it's critical to seek help managing these symptoms because they can interfere with the ability to function and increase the risk of bipolar I or II disorder.
Diagnosis: The doctor or other health care provider must determine if one has cyclothymia, bipolar I or II disorder, depression, or another condition that may be causing the symptoms. To help pinpoint a diagnosis for the symptoms, one will likely have several exams and tests, which generally include For a diagnosis of cyclothymia, the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association, lists these points: Physical exam. To identify what's going on, the doctor may have one keep a daily record of the moods, sleep patterns or other factors that could help with diagnosis and finding the right treatment.
Remedies: In addition to professional treatment, one can build on the treatment plan by following these lifestyle and self-care steps: Take the medications as directed. Sometimes other medications trigger periods of cyclothymia symptoms or may interfere with medications one is already taking. These records may help one and the mental health provider understand the effect of treatments and identify thinking patterns and behaviors associated with cyclothymia symptoms.
Medication: No medications are approved by the Food and Drug Administration specifically for cyclothymia, but the doctor may prescribe medications used to treat bipolar disorder. Psychotherapy, also called psychological counseling or talk therapy, is a vital part of cyclothymia treatment and can be provided in individual, family or group settings. Several types of therapy may be helpful, such as: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). A common treatment for cyclothymia, the focus of CBT is to identify unhealthy, negative beliefs and behaviors and replace them with healthy, positive ones. People with mood disorders may benefit from establishing a daily routine for sleep, diet and exercise Other therapies.
info-Symptoms: Periods of depression and elevated mood
info-Risk factors: Family history

Name: Cyst , Bartholin 's
Overview: The Bartholin's glands are located on each side of the vaginal opening. If the fluid within the cyst becomes infected, one may develop a collection of pus surrounded by inflamed tissue (abscess).
Causes: A number of bacteria may cause the infection, including Escherichia coli (E. coli) and bacteria that cause sexually transmitted infections such as gonorrhea and chlamydia.
Treatment: For the procedure, the doctor makes a small incision in the cyst, allows it to drain, and then places a small rubber tube (catheter) in the incision. Rarely, for persistent cysts that aren't effectively treated by the above procedures, the doctor may recommend surgery to remove the Bartholin's gland. Daily soaking in warm water, several times a day, may be adequate to resolve an infected Bartholin's cyst or abscess. After a surgical procedure to treat an infected cyst or abscess, soaking in warm water is particularly important. Soaking in a tub filled with a few inches of warm water (sitz bath) several times a day for three or four days may help a small, infected cyst to rupture and drain on its own. If cysts recur or bother one, a marsupialization (mahr-soo-pee-ul-ih-ZAY-shun) procedure may help.

Name: Cystitis
Symptoms: If one has been diagnosed with a UTI in the past and one develop symptoms that mimic a previous UTI, call the doctor. Also call the doctor if cystitis symptoms return after one has finished a course of antibiotics.
Overview: Cystitis (sis-TIE-tis) is the medical term for inflammation of the bladder. Most of the time, the inflammation is caused by a bacterial infection, and it's called a urinary tract infection (UTI). Less commonly, cystitis may occur as a reaction to certain drugs, radiation therapy or potential irritants, such as feminine hygiene spray, spermicidal jellies or long-term use of a catheter.
Causes: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The urinary system includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra. Tubes called ureters carry urine from the kidneys to the bladder, where it's stored until it exits the body through the urethra. Although bacterial infections are the most common cause of cystitis, a number of noninfectious factors also may cause the bladder to become inflamed. Certain medications, particularly the chemotherapy drugs cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide, can cause inflammation of the bladder as the broken-down components of the drugs exit the body.
Risk factors: Women have a shorter urethra, which cuts down on the distance bacteria must travel to reach the bladder. Women at greatest risk of UTIs include those who: Other risk factors in both men and women include In men without any predisposing health issues, cystitis is rare. A depressed immune system increases the risk of bacterial and, in some cases, viral bladder infections. Prolonged use can result in increased vulnerability to bacterial infections as well as bladder tissue damage.
Diagnosis: During a cystoscopy exam, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible device called a cystoscope through the urethra into the bladder. During a cystoscopy exam, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible device called a cystoscope through the urethra into the bladder. In addition to discussing the signs and symptoms and the medical history, the doctor may recommend certain tests, such as: Cystoscopy. During this test, the doctor inserts a cystoscope a thin tube with a light and camera attached through the urethra into the bladder to view the urinary tract for signs of disease.
Remedies: Cystitis can be painful, but one can take steps to ease the discomfort: For recurrent bladder infections, work with the doctor to develop a strategy to reduce recurrences and the discomfort that cystitis can cause. Avoid coffee, alcohol, soft drinks with caffeine and citrus juices as well as spicy foods until the infection clears. Soak in a bathtub of warm water (sitz bath) for 15 to 20 minutes to help relieve pain or discomfort.
info-Symptoms: Pain with urination, frequent urination, feeling the need to urinate despite having an empty bladder
info-Risk factors: Female anatomy, sexual intercourse, diabetes, obesity, family history

Name: Cytomegalovirus infection
Symptoms: Most healthy people who are infected with CMV may experience no symptoms. People who are more likely to experience signs and symptoms of CMV include Most babies who have congenital CMV appear healthy at birth. A few babies who have congenital CMV who appear healthy at birth develop signs over time sometimes not for months or years after birth. Infants who become infected during birth or shortly afterward (perinatal CMV).
Overview: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common virus. For people who have weakened immune systems, especially people who have had an organ, stem cell or bone marrow transplant, CMV infection can be fatal.
Causes: CMV is related to the viruses that cause chickenpox, herpes simplex and mononucleosis. When the virus is active in the body, one can pass the virus to other people. The virus is spread through body fluids including blood, urine, saliva, breast milk, tears, semen and vaginal fluids.
Diagnosis: If one is pregnant, testing to determine whether one has ever been infected with CMV can be important. If the doctor detects a new CMV infection while one is pregnant, a prenatal test (amniocentesis) can determine whether the fetus has been infected. If the doctor suspects the baby has congenital CMV, it's important to test the baby within the first three weeks of birth. If the baby has CMV, the doctor likely will recommend additional tests to check the health of the baby's organs, such as the liver and kidneys.

Name: Dandruff
Risk factors: Almost anyone can have dandruff, but certain factors can make one more susceptible: Age. Because more men have dandruff, some researchers think male hormones may play a role. Parkinson's disease and other diseases that affect the nervous system also seem to increase risk of dandruff.
Treatment: For mild dandruff, first try daily cleansing with a gentle shampoo to reduce oil and skin cell buildup. If that doesn't help, try a medicated dandruff shampoo. Dandruff shampoos are classified according to the medication they contain: If one type of shampoo works for a time and then seems to lose its effectiveness, try alternating between two types of dandruff shampoos. At first, use a medicated shampoo one to three times a week to treat dandruff. If one has used medicated shampoo regularly for several weeks and still have dandruff, talk to the doctor or dermatologist. One can take steps to reduce the risk of developing dandruff or to control it: Pyrithione zinc shampoos (DermaZinc, Head & Shoulders, Jason Dandruff Relief 2 in 1). Shampoos containing salicylic acid (Neutrogena T/Sal, Baker's P & S, others). Selenium sulfide shampoos (Head & Shoulders Intensive, Selsun Blue, others). Use these products as directed and rinse well after shampooing, as they can discolor the hair and scalp. A diet that provides enough zinc, B vitamins and certain types of fats may help prevent dandruff. If one tend to have an oily scalp, daily shampooing may help prevent dandruff. Pyrithione zinc shampoos (DermaZinc, Head & Shoulders, Jason Dandruff Relief 2 in 1).
Remedies: A diet that provides enough zinc, B vitamins and certain types of fats may help prevent dandruff. If one tend to have an oily scalp, daily shampooing may help prevent dandruff.
info-Symptoms: Itchy and flaking skin of the scalp

Name: Delayed ejaculation
Symptoms: Some men with delayed ejaculation need 30 minutes or more of sexual stimulation to have an orgasm and ejaculate. Delayed ejaculation is divided into the following types based on symptoms: These categories help in diagnosing an underlying cause and determining what might be the most effective treatment.
Diagnosis: However, if delayed ejaculation appears to be caused by an underlying problem that might need treatment, one might need further tests or one might need to see a specialist. The health care provider might take a blood sample and send it to a lab to check for signs of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, a low testosterone level and other health problems.
Medication: If one is taking medication that might be causing delayed ejaculation, reducing the dose of a medication or switching medications might fix the problem. Medications sometimes used to treat delayed ejaculation include Psychotherapy can help by addressing underlying mental health problems leading to delayed ejaculation, such as depression or anxiety. Depending on the underlying cause, one might benefit most from seeing a sex therapist a mental health counselor who specializes in talk therapy for sexual problems.

Name: Delirium
Symptoms: In fact, delirium frequently occurs in people with dementia. The input about the person's symptoms, typical thinking and everyday abilities will be important for a proper diagnosis and for finding the underlying cause. The onset of delirium occurs within a short time, while dementia usually begins with relatively minor symptoms that gradually worsen over time. While people with dementia have better and worse times of day, their memory and thinking skills stay at a fairly constant level during the course of a day.
Overview: Delirium is a serious disturbance in mental abilities that results in confused thinking and reduced awareness of the environment. Delirium can often be traced to one or more contributing factors, such as a severe or chronic illness, changes in metabolic balance (such as low sodium), medication, infection, surgery, or alcohol or drug intoxication or withdrawal.
Diagnosis: A doctor can diagnose delirium on the basis of medical history, tests to assess mental status and the identification of possible contributing factors. This may be done informally through conversation, or with tests or screenings that assess mental state, confusion, perception and memory. A neurological exam checking vision, balance, coordination and reflexes can help determine if a stroke or another neurological disease is causing the delirium.
info-Specialty: Psychiatry, Geriatrics, Intensive care medicine, Neurology
info-Symptoms: agitation, confusion, drowsiness, hallucinations, delusions, memory problems
info-Usual onset: Any age, but more often in people 65 or more years of age
info-Risk factors: Infection, chronic health problems, certain medications, neurological problems, sleep deprivation, surgery

Name: Dementia
Causes: Depending on the area of the brain that's affected by the damage, dementia can affect people differently and cause different symptoms.
