Some diseases look like dementias, such as those caused by a reaction to medications or vitamin deficiencies, and they might improve with treatment. While several different genes are probably involved in Alzheimer's disease, one important gene that increases risk is apolipoprotein E4 (APOE). It may also be caused by exposure to diseased brain or nervous system tissue, such as from a cornea transplant. The most common symptoms of vascular dementia include difficulties with problem-solving, slowed thinking, focus and organization. Lewy bodies are abnormal balloonlike clumps of protein that have been found in the brains of people with Lewy body dementia, Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease. Caused by a genetic mutation, this disease causes certain nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord to waste away. Signs and symptoms, including a severe decline in thinking (cognitive) skills, usually appear around age 30 or 40. Many people with Parkinson's disease eventually develop dementia symptoms (Parkinson's disease dementia). Multiple sclerosis and other conditions caused by the body's immune system attacking nerve cells also can cause dementia. Side effects of medications, a reaction to a medication or an interaction of several medications can cause dementia-like symptoms. Rarely, dementia can result from damage caused by a brain tumor. This condition, which is caused by enlarged ventricles in the brain, can cause walking problems, urinary difficulty and memory loss.
Risk factors: However, dementia isn't a normal part of aging, and dementia can occur in younger people. And while no specific diet is known to reduce dementia risk, research indicates a greater incidence of dementia in people who eat an unhealthy diet compared with those who follow a Mediterranean-style diet rich in produce, whole grains, nuts and seeds. If one drink large amounts of alcohol, one might have a higher risk of dementia. Although not yet well-understood, late-life depression might indicate the development of dementia. Having diabetes may increase the risk of dementia, especially if it's poorly controlled. Smoking might increase the risk of developing dementia and blood vessel (vascular) diseases. Low levels of vitamin D, vitamin B-6, vitamin B-12 and folate may increase the risk of dementia.
Diagnosis: People have dementia when they have cognitive impairment and lose their ability to perform daily functions, such as taking their medication, paying bills and driving safely. To diagnose the cause of the dementia, the doctor must recognize the pattern of the loss of skills and function and determine what a person is still able to do. No single test can diagnose dementia, so doctors are likely to run a number of tests that can help pinpoint the problem. A number of tests measure thinking skills, such as memory, orientation, reasoning and judgment, language skills, and attention. Doctors evaluate the memory, language, visual perception, attention, problem-solving, movement, senses, balance, reflexes and other areas. Simple blood tests can detect physical problems that can affect brain function, such as vitamin B-12 deficiency or an underactive thyroid gland. These can show patterns of brain activity and whether the amyloid protein, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease, has been deposited in the brain.
Remedies: The main benefits of exercise in people with dementia include improved strength, balance and cardiovascular health. There is growing evidence that exercise also protects the brain from dementia, especially when combined with a healthy diet and treatment for risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Some research also shows that physical activity might slow the progression of impaired thinking in people with Alzheimer's disease, and it can lessen symptoms of depression. Limiting caffeine, discouraging napping and offering opportunities for exercise during the day might ease nighttime restlessness. Support groups, legal advisers, family members and others might be able to help. Dancing, painting, gardening, cooking, singing and other activities can be fun, can help one connect with the loved one, and can help the loved one focus on what he or she can still do. A calendar might help the loved one remember upcoming events, daily activities and medication schedules.
Medication: These medications including donepezil (Aricept), rivastigmine (Exelon) and galantamine (Razadyne) work by boosting levels of a chemical messenger involved in memory and judgment. Although primarily used to treat Alzheimer's disease, these medications might also be prescribed for other dementias, including vascular dementia, Parkinson's disease dementia and Lewy body dementia. Memantine (Namenda) works by regulating the activity of glutamate, another chemical messenger involved in brain functions, such as learning and memory. Several dementia symptoms and behavior problems might be treated initially using nondrug approaches, such as: Cholinesterase inhibitors. The doctor might prescribe medications to treat other symptoms or conditions, such as depression, sleep disturbances, hallucinations, parkinsonism or agitation. The purpose is to prevent accidents, such as falls; manage behavior; and prepare one for the dementia progression.
info-Symptoms: Decreased ability to think and remember, emotional problems, problems with language, decreased motivation
info-Causes: Alzheimer's disease, vascular disease, Lewy body disease and frontotemporal lobar degeneration.
info-Prevention: Early education, prevent high blood pressure, prevent obesity, no smoking, social engagement

Name: Dementia , Alzheimer 's disease
Symptoms: At first, a person with Alzheimer's disease may be aware of having difficulty with remembering things and organizing thoughts. But the memory loss associated with Alzheimer's disease persists and worsens, affecting the ability to function at work or at home. People with Alzheimer's may: Alzheimer's disease causes difficulty concentrating and thinking, especially about abstract concepts such as numbers. Eventually, people with advanced Alzheimer's may forget how to perform basic tasks such as dressing and bathing.
Overview: Alzheimer's disease is a progressive disorder that causes brain cells to waste away (degenerate) and die. Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia a continuous decline in thinking, behavioral and social skills that disrupts a person's ability to function independently.
Causes: Scientists believe that for most people, Alzheimer's disease is caused by a combination of genetic, lifestyle and environmental factors that affect the brain over time. Less than 1 percent of the time, Alzheimer's is caused by specific genetic changes that virtually guarantee a person will develop the disease. In Alzheimer's disease, tau proteins change shape and organize themselves into structures called neurofibrillary tangles.
Risk factors: A variation of the gene, APOE e4, increases the risk of Alzheimer's disease, but not everyone with this variation of the gene develops the disease. Research has shown that poor sleep patterns, such as difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep, are associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer's disease. For example, regular exercise and a healthy low-fat diet rich in fruits and vegetables are associated with a decreased risk of developing Alzheimer's disease.
Diagnosis: A diagnostic work-up would likely include the following tests: The doctor will perform a physical exam and likely assess overall neurological health by testing the following: Blood tests may help the doctor rule out other potential causes of memory loss and confusion, such as a thyroid disorder or vitamin deficiencies. Images of the brain are now used chiefly to pinpoint visible abnormalities related to conditions other than Alzheimer's disease such as strokes, trauma or tumors that may cause cognitive change. New imaging applications currently used primarily in major medical centers or in clinical trials may enable doctors to detect specific brain changes caused by Alzheimer's. PET imaging may include the following: In special circumstances, such as rapidly progressive dementia or very early onset dementia, other tests may be used to measure abnormal beta-amyloid or tau in the cerebrospinal fluid.
Remedies: People with Alzheimer's who develop trouble walking may still be able to use a stationary bike or participate in chair exercises. People with Alzheimer's may forget to eat, lose interest in preparing meals or not eat a healthy combination of foods. Buy healthy food options that the person with Alzheimer's disease likes and can eat.

Name: Dengue hemorrhagic fever
Symptoms: Many people, especially children and teens, may experience no signs or symptoms during a mild case of dengue fever. Dengue fever causes a high fever 104 F degrees and at least two of the following symptoms: Most people recover within a week or so. If one develop a fever and milder symptoms common to dengue fever, call the doctor.
Overview: Dengue (DENG-gey) fever is a mosquito-borne disease that occurs in tropical and subtropical areas of the world. A severe form of dengue fever, also called dengue hemorrhagic fever, can cause severe bleeding, a sudden drop in blood pressure (shock) and death.
info-Symptoms: Fever, headache, muscle and joint pain, rash
info-Diagnostic method: Detecting antibodies to the virus or its RNA
info-Prevention: Dengue fever vaccine, decreasing mosquito exposure
info-Treatment: Supportive care, intravenous fluids, blood transfusions

Name: Depersonalization-derealization disorder
Symptoms: Symptoms of depersonalization include Symptoms of derealization include Episodes of depersonalization-derealization disorder may last hours, days, weeks or even months at a time. In some people, these episodes turn into ongoing feelings of depersonalization or derealization that may periodically get better or worse. But ongoing or severe feelings of detachment and distortion of the surroundings can be a sign of depersonalization-derealization disorder or another physical or mental health disorder.
Overview: Depersonalization-derealization disorder occurs when one persistently or repeatedly have the feeling that one is observing theself from outside the body or one has a sense that things around one isn't real, or both. But when these feelings keep occurring or never completely go away and interfere with the ability to function, it's considered depersonalization-derealization disorder.
Diagnosis: In some cases, symptoms of depersonalization or derealization may be linked to an underlying physical health problem, medications, recreational drugs or alcohol. The mental health professional asks about the symptoms, thoughts, feelings and behavior patterns, which can help determine if one has depersonalization-derealization disorder or other mental health disorders. The mental health professional may use the criteria for depersonalization-derealization disorder listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association.
info-Symptoms: Depersonalization, Derealization

Name: Dermatitis
Symptoms: Atopic dermatitis can cause small, red bumps, which can be very itchy. Atopic dermatitis most often occurs where the skin flexes inside the elbows, behind the knees and in front of the neck. Contact dermatitis can appear as an itchy, red rash. In addition to the scalp, seborrheic dermatitis can occur on the sides of the nose, in and between the eyebrows, and in other oil-rich areas. This red, itchy stinging rash occurs where the skin has come into contact with substances that irritate the skin or cause an allergic reaction.
Causes: Causes of the most common types of dermatitis include Atopic dermatitis (eczema). Irritants or allergens include poison ivy, perfumes, jewelry containing nickel, cleaning products, and the preservatives in many creams and lotions.
Risk factors: Dermatitis can occur at any age, but atopic dermatitis (eczema) usually begins in infancy. People who have a personal or family history of eczema, allergies, hay fever or asthma are more likely to develop atopic dermatitis. Jobs that put one in contact with certain metals, solvents or cleaning supplies increase the risk of contact dermatitis. Health conditions that put one at increased risk of seborrheic dermatitis include congestive heart failure, Parkinson's disease and HIV/AIDS.
Treatment: For a dilute bleach bath, add 1/2 cup (about 118 milliliters) of household bleach, not concentrated bleach, to a 40-gallon (about 151-liter) bathtub filled with warm water. Many alternative therapies, including those listed below, have helped some people manage their dermatitis. Applying to the affected skin corticosteroid creams, gels or ointments Applying to the affected skin certain creams or ointments that affect the immune system (calcineurin inhibitors) Exposing the affected area to controlled amounts of natural or artificial light (phototherapy) Using oral corticosteroids (pills) or injectable dupilumab, for severe disease Moisturize the skin. Soak for 5 to 10 minutes, pat dry and apply unscented moisturizer while the skin is still damp. A lotion of 12 percent ammonium lactate or 10 percent alpha-hydroxy acid helps with flaky, dry skin. Avoid wool, as itching can flare after removing wool clothing that directly touches the skin. Because the clothes, sheets and towels touch the skin, choose mild, unscented laundry products. Dietary supplements, such as vitamin D and probiotics, for atopic dermatitis Rice bran broth (applied to the skin), for atopic dermatitis 5 percent tea tree oil shampoo, for dandruff Aloe, for seborrheic dermatitis Chinese herbal therapy Moisturize the skin.
Remedies: For a dilute bleach bath, add 1/2 cup (about 118 milliliters) of household bleach, not concentrated bleach, to a 40-gallon (about 151-liter) bathtub filled with warm water. Add 1 cup (about 236 milliliters) of vinegar to a bathtub filled with warm water. Soak for 5 to 10 minutes, pat dry and apply unscented moisturizer while the skin is still damp. A lotion of 12 percent ammonium lactate or 10 percent alpha-hydroxy acid helps with flaky, dry skin. Avoid wool, as itching can flare after removing wool clothing that directly touches the skin. Because the clothes, sheets and towels touch the skin, choose mild, unscented laundry products.
info-Symptoms: Itchiness, red skin, rash
info-Causes: Atopic dermatitis, allergic contact dermatitis, irritant contact dermatitis, seborrhoeic dermatitis, stasis dermatitis

Name: Dermatitis , contact
Causes: Contact dermatitis is caused by a substance one is exposed to that irritates the skin or triggers an allergic reaction. Common irritants include Allergic contact dermatitis occurs when a substance to which one is sensitive (allergen) triggers an immune reaction in the skin. But it may be triggered by something that enters the body through foods, flavorings, medicine, or medical or dental procedures (systemic contact dermatitis).
Treatment: If home care steps don't ease the signs and symptoms, the doctor may prescribe medications. Examples include To help reduce itching and soothe inflamed skin, try these self-care approaches: Avoid the irritant or allergen. In severe cases, the doctor may prescribe oral corticosteroids to reduce inflammation, antihistamines to relieve itching or antibiotics to fight a bacterial infection. A nonprescription oral corticosteroid or antihistamine, such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl), may be helpful if the itching is severe.
Remedies: To help reduce itching and soothe inflamed skin, try these self-care approaches: Avoid the irritant or allergen. A nonprescription oral corticosteroid or antihistamine, such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl), may be helpful if the itching is severe.

Name: Dermatographia
Overview: Dermatographia is a condition in which lightly scratching the skin causes raised, red lines where one has scratched. When people who have dermatographia lightly scratch their skin, the scratches redden into a raised wheal similar to hives.
Treatment: However, if the condition is severe or bothersome, the doctor may recommend antihistamine medications such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl), fexofenadine (Allegra) or cetirizine (Zyrtec). However, in some cases when one call to set up an appointment, one may be referred immediately to a doctor who specializes in skin conditions (dermatologist) or one who specializes in allergies (allergist).

Name: Dermatomyositis
Symptoms: A violet-colored or dusky red rash develops, most commonly on the face and eyelids and on the knuckles, elbows, knees, chest and back. Progressive muscle weakness involves the muscles closest to the trunk, such as those in the hips, thighs, shoulders, upper arms and neck.
Diagnosis: A muscle biopsy might reveal inflammation in the muscles or other problems, such as damage or infection. If the skin biopsy confirms the diagnosis, a muscle biopsy might not be necessary.
Medication: Medications used to treat dermatomyositis include Depending on the severity of the symptoms, the doctor might suggest: Corticosteroids. So the doctor, after prescribing a relatively high dose to control the symptoms, might gradually reduce the dose as the symptoms improve. The two most common medications for dermatomyositis are azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran) and methotrexate (Trexall). Mycophenolate mofetil (Cellcept) is another medication used to treat dermatomyositis, particularly if the lungs are involved. More commonly used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, rituximab is an option if initial therapies don't control the symptoms. For a persistent rash, the doctor might prescribe an antimalarial medication, such as hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil).
info-Symptoms: Rash, muscle weakness, weight loss, fever
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, blood tests, electromyography, muscle biopsies
info-Treatment: Medication, physical therapy, exercise, heat therapy, orthotics, assistive devices, rest

Name: Desmoid tumors
Risk factors: People with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) have an increased risk of desmoid tumors. A small number of desmoid tumors develop in people whove recently had an injury or surgery. Desmoid tumors: Epidemiology, risk factors, molecular pathogenesis, clinical presentation, diagnosis and local therapy.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose desmoid tumors include Removing a sample of tissue for testing (biopsy). To make a definitive diagnosis, the doctor collects a sample of the tumor tissue and sends it to a lab for testing. In the lab, doctors trained in analyzing body tissues (pathologists) examine the sample to determine the types of cells involved and whether the cells are likely to be aggressive.
Treatment: The doctor may recommend chemotherapy if the desmoid tumor is growing quickly and surgery isn't an option. Several other drug treatments have shown promise in people with desmoid tumors, including anti-inflammatory drugs, hormone therapies and targeted therapies. Until then, one may find that it helps to: Make an appointment with the doctor if one has any signs or symptoms that worry one. If the doctor suspects that one might have desmoid tumor, he or she may refer one to a doctor who specializes in treating cancer (oncologist). If the desmoid tumor causes no signs or symptoms, the doctor may recommend monitoring the tumor to see if it grows. If the desmoid tumor causes signs and symptoms, the doctor may recommend an operation to remove the entire tumor and a small margin of healthy tissue that surrounds it. Radiation therapy may be recommended instead of surgery if one is not healthy enough for surgery or if the tumor is located in a place that makes surgery risky. As one learn more about desmoid tumors, one may become more confident in making treatment decisions.

Name: Deviated septum
Symptoms: Some septal deformities, however, may cause the following signs and symptoms: See the doctor if one experience: Obstruction of one or both nostrils. One may notice this more when one has a cold (upper respiratory tract infection) or allergies that can cause the nasal passages to swell and narrow. The surface of the nasal septum may become dry, increasing the risk of nosebleeds. A possible cause of one-sided facial pain could be a severe deviated septum in which surfaces within the nose touch and cause pressure. A deviated septum or swelling of the intranasal tissues can be one of the many reasons for noisy breathing during sleep. Some people may prefer to sleep on a particular side in order to optimize breathing through the nose at night if one nasal passage is narrowed.
Causes: A deviated septum occurs when the nasal septum the thin wall that separates the right and left nasal passages is displaced to one side. In children and adults, a wide array of accidents may lead to a nose injury and deviated septum. The normal aging process may affect nasal structures, worsening a deviated septum over time.

Name: Diabetes
Symptoms: Some people, especially those with prediabetes or type 2 diabetes, may not experience symptoms initially. Type 2 diabetes, the more common type, can develop at any age, though it's more common in people older than 40.
Overview: Diabetes mellitus refers to a group of diseases that affect how the body uses blood sugar (glucose). But, no matter what type of diabetes one has, it can lead to excess sugar in the blood. Potentially reversible diabetes conditions include prediabetes when the blood sugar levels are higher than normal, but not high enough to be classified as diabetes and gestational diabetes, which occurs during pregnancy but may resolve after the baby is delivered.
Causes: Instead of moving into the cells where it's needed for energy, sugar builds up in the bloodstream. Exactly why this happens is uncertain, although it's believed that genetic and environmental factors play a role in the development of type 2 diabetes too. Sugar is absorbed into the bloodstream, where it enters cells with the help of insulin.
Risk factors: Although the exact cause of type 1 diabetes is unknown, factors that may signal an increased risk include Researchers don't fully understand why some people develop prediabetes and type 2 diabetes and others don't. It's clear that certain factors increase the risk, however, including Any pregnant woman can develop gestational diabetes, but some women are at greater risk than are others. If one has these autoantibodies, one has an increased risk of developing type 1 diabetes. Certain countries, such as Finland and Sweden, have higher rates of type 1 diabetes. The risk increases if a parent or sibling has type 2 diabetes. But type 2 diabetes is also increasing among children, adolescents and younger adults. If one developed gestational diabetes when one were pregnant, the risk of developing prediabetes and type 2 diabetes later increases. If one gave birth to a baby weighing more than 9 pounds (4 kilograms), one is also at risk of type 2 diabetes. For women, having polycystic ovary syndrome a common condition characterized by irregular menstrual periods, excess hair growth and obesity increases the risk of diabetes. Having blood pressure over 140/90 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg) is linked to an increased risk of type 2 diabetes. If one has low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL), or good, cholesterol, the risk of type 2 diabetes is higher. People with high levels of triglycerides have an increased risk of type 2 diabetes. The risk increases if one has prediabetes a precursor to type 2 diabetes or if a close family member, such as a parent or sibling, has type 2 diabetes. One is also at greater risk if one had gestational diabetes during a previous pregnancy, if one delivered a very large baby or if one had an unexplained stillbirth.
Diagnosis: If the A1C test results aren't consistent, the test isn't available, or one has certain conditions that can make the A1C test inaccurate such as if one is pregnant or have an uncommon form of hemoglobin (known as a hemoglobin variant) the doctor may use the following tests to diagnose diabetes: Oral glucose tolerance test. A blood sugar level below 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L) is usually considered normal on a glucose challenge test, although this may vary at specific clinics or labs. If at least two of the blood sugar readings are higher than the normal values established for each of the three hours of the test, one will be diagnosed with gestational diabetes. Anyone with a body mass index higher than 25 (23 for Asian-Americans), regardless of age, who has additional risk factors, such as high blood pressure, abnormal cholesterol levels, a sedentary lifestyle, a history of polycystic ovary syndrome or heart disease, and having a close relative with diabetes. Regardless of when one last ate, a random blood sugar level of 200 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) 11.1 millimoles per liter (mmol/L) or higher suggests diabetes. If it's 126 mg/dL (7 mmol/L) or higher on two separate tests, one has diabetes.
Remedies: Regular exercise can help prevent prediabetes and type 2 diabetes, and it can help those who already have diabetes to maintain better blood sugar control. A combination of exercises aerobic exercises, such as walking or dancing on most days, combined with resistance training, such as weightlifting or yoga twice a week often helps control blood sugar more effectively than does either type of exercise alone. In addition, if one has type 1 or type 2 diabetes: Keep the vaccinations up-to-date. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) also currently recommends hepatitis B vaccination if one hasn't previously been vaccinated against hepatitis B and one is an adult ages 19 to 59 with type 1 or type 2 diabetes. If one is age 60 or older, have diabetes, and haven't previously received the vaccine, talk to the doctor about whether it's right for one. Alcohol can cause either high or low blood sugar, depending on how much one drink and if one eat at the same time. Establish a relationship with a diabetes educator, and ask the diabetes treatment team for help when one need it. If one is overweight, losing just 5 percent of the body weight can make a difference in the blood sugar control if one has prediabetes or type 2 diabetes. During the physical, the doctor will look for any diabetes-related complications and screen for other medical problems. And if one has type 1 or type 2 diabetes, schedule regular dental exams. The hormones the body may produce in response to prolonged stress may prevent insulin from working properly, which will raise the blood sugar and stress one even more.
info-Symptoms: Frequent urination, increased thirst, increased hunger
info-Risk factors: Type 1: Family historyType 2: Obesity, lack of exercise, genetics

Name: Diabetes insipidus
Causes: A hormone called anti-diuretic hormone (ADH), or vasopressin, helps control how fast or slow fluids are excreted. If one has diabetes insipidus, the body can't properly balance fluid levels. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus occurs when there's a defect in the kidney tubules the structures in the kidneys that cause water to be excreted or reabsorbed. Certain drugs, such as lithium or antiviral medications such as foscarnet (Foscavir), also can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Also known as dipsogenic diabetes insipidus, this condition can cause production of large amounts of diluted urine. Sometimes, there's no obvious cause of diabetes insipidus. This defect makes the kidneys unable to properly respond to ADH.The defect may be due to an inherited (genetic) disorder or a chronic kidney disorder.
Diagnosis: To prevent dehydration while fluids are restricted, ADH allows the kidneys to decrease the amount of fluid lost in the urine. While fluids are being withheld, the doctor will measure changes in the body weight, urine output, and the concentration of the urine and blood. To prevent dehydration while fluids are restricted, ADH allows the kidneys to decrease the amount of fluid lost in the urine.While fluids are being withheld, the doctor will measure changes in the body weight, urine output, and the concentration of the urine and blood.
Treatment: Although hydrochlorothiazide is a type of drug that usually increases urine output (diuretic), in some people it can reduce urine output for people with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. If the condition is caused by an abnormality in the pituitary gland or hypothalamus (such as a tumor), the doctor will first treat the abnormality.Typically, this form is treated with a man-made hormone called desmopressin (DDAVP, Minirin, others). Taking more desmopressin than one need can cause water retention and potentially serious low-sodium levels in the blood.Other medications may also be prescribed, such as indomethacin (Indocin, Tivorbex) and chlorpropamide. Although hydrochlorothiazide is a type of drug that usually increases urine output (diuretic), in some people it can reduce urine output for people with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.If the symptoms are due to medications one is taking, stopping these medicines may help.
Remedies: As long as one take the medication and have access to water when the medication's effects wear off, one will prevent serious problems. Plan ahead by carrying water with one wherever one go, and keep a supply of medication in the travel bag, at work or at school.
info-Symptoms: Large amounts of dilute urine, increased thirst
info-Diagnostic method: Urine tests, blood tests, fluid deprivation test

Name: Diabetic coma
Overview: A diabetic coma is a life-threatening diabetes complication that causes unconsciousness. If one has diabetes, dangerously high blood sugar (hyperglycemia) or dangerously low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) can lead to a diabetic coma.
Causes: Blood sugar that's either too high or too low for too long may cause various serious conditions, all of which can lead to a diabetic coma. If one has ketones (measured in blood or urine) and high blood sugar, the condition is called diabetic ketoacidosis. The excess sugar passes from the blood into the urine, which triggers a filtering process that draws tremendous amounts of fluid from the body.
Risk factors: Anyone who has diabetes is at risk of a diabetic coma, but the following factors can increase the risk: An illness, trauma or surgery. Medical conditions, such as congestive heart failure or kidney disease, also may increase the risk of diabetic hyperosmolar syndrome. If one don't monitor the blood sugar properly or take the medications as directed, one will have a higher risk of developing long-term complications and a diabetic coma. Illegal drugs, such as cocaine and ecstasy, can increase the risk of severe high blood sugar levels and conditions linked to diabetic coma.

Name: Diabetic hyperosmolar syndrome
Symptoms: Diabetic hyperosmolar syndrome can take days or weeks to develop. Don't wait until the blood sugar is high enough to cause diabetic hyperosmolar syndrome.
Overview: Diabetic hyperosmolar (hi-pur-oz-MOE-lur) syndrome is a serious condition caused by extremely high blood sugar levels. As a result of diabetic hyperosmolar syndrome, the body tries to rid itself of the excess blood sugar by passing it into the urine.
Risk factors: If one don't monitor the blood sugar or one don't yet know one has type 2 diabetes, the risk is higher. Have an infection, such as pneumonia, a urinary tract infection or a virus, which causes the blood sugar levels to rise. Some drugs such as corticosteroids (prednisone), diuretics (hydrochlorothiazide and chlorthalidone) and the anti-seizure medication phenytoin (Dilantin).
Treatment: Treatment typically includes: If one has an infection, or an underlying health condition, such as congestive heart failure or kidney disease, these conditions will be treated, as well. If one has symptoms of high blood sugar, such as extreme thirst and excessive urination, for a few days, check the blood sugar level and call the doctor for advice. If one feel the symptoms of extreme high blood sugar, call 911 or the local emergency number. If one is with someone who has diabetes and is acting confused, has one-sided weakness or has passed out, call for immediate medical help. After one has received treatment and are feeling better, some questions one might want to ask the doctor include Intravenous fluids to counter dehydration Intravenous insulin to lower the blood sugar levels Intravenous potassium, and occasionally sodium phosphate replacement to help the cells function correctly How can I better control my diabetes? Diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state in adults: Epidemiology and pathogenesis. Diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state in adults: Clinical features, evaluation and diagnosis. The management of the hyperosmolar hyperglycaemic state (HHS) in adults with diabetes. Diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state in adults: Treatment.

Name: Diabetic nephropathy
Causes: Conditions such as high blood pressure and diabetes take a toll on kidney function by damaging these filtering units and collecting tubules and causing scarring. The kidneys contain millions of tiny blood vessel clusters (glomeruli) that filter waste from the blood. Over time, poorly controlled diabetes can cause damage to blood vessel clusters in the kidneys that filter waste from the blood. High blood pressure can cause further kidney damage by increasing the pressure in the delicate filtering system of the kidneys.
Diagnosis: During a kidney biopsy, the doctor uses a needle to remove a small sample of kidney tissue for lab testing. To determine whether one has diabetic kidney disease, one may need certain tests and procedures, such as: Blood tests. If one has diabetes, one will need blood tests to monitor the condition and determine how well the kidneys are working. One may also undergo CT scanning and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to determine how well blood is circulating within the kidneys.
Remedies: With the doctor's advice, aim for at least 30 minutes of physical activity most days of the week. Talk with a dietitian about limiting how much sodium is in the diet, choosing lower potassium foods and limiting the amount of protein one eat. If one is a smoker, talk with the doctor about strategies for quitting smoking. If one need to lose weight, talk with the doctor about weight-loss strategies, such as increasing daily physical activity and reducing calories.
Medication: In the early stages of the disease, the treatment plan may include various medications, such as those that help: The doctor may recommend follow-up testing at regular intervals to see whether the kidney disease remains stable or progresses. Medications called angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) are used to treat high blood pressure. Studies support the goal of a blood pressure reading below 140/90 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg) depending on the age and overall risk of cardiovascular disease.
info-Symptoms: Albuminuria, peripheral edema, high blood pressure, tiredness
info-Risk factors: High blood pressure, tobacco smoking, unstable blood glucose

Name: Diaper rash
Causes: Diaper rash can be traced to a number of sources, including Irritation from stool and urine. The baby may be more prone to diaper rash if he or she is experiencing frequent bowel movements or diarrhea because feces are more irritating than urine. These rashes can be found within the creases of the skin, and there may be red dots scattered around the creases. Changes in the baby's diet can also increase the frequency of stools, which can lead to diaper rash. If the baby is breast-fed, he or she may develop diaper rash in response to something the mother has eaten. Babies with skin conditions, such as atopic dermatitis or seborrheic dermatitis (eczema), may be more likely to develop diaper rash. However, the irritated skin of atopic dermatitis and eczema primarily affects areas other than the diaper area. When a baby takes antibiotics, bacteria that keep yeast growth in check may be depleted, resulting in diaper rash due to yeast infection.
Treatment: The best treatment for diaper rash is to keep the baby's skin as clean and dry as possible. If the baby's diaper rash persists despite home treatment, the doctor may prescribe: Use creams or ointments with steroids only if the baby's pediatrician or dermatologist recommends them strong steroids or frequent use can lead to additional problems. Diaper rashes usually require several days to improve, and the rash may come back repeatedly. If the rash persists despite prescription treatment, the doctor may recommend that the baby see a specialist in skin conditions (dermatologist). Generally, a diaper rash can be treated successfully at home with these practices: Keeping diaper area clean and dry. Until the rash is better, this may mean getting up during the night to change the diaper. One study showed that applying breast milk to diaper rash is an effective and safe treatment. Generally, a diaper rash can be treated successfully at home. Make an appointment with the baby's doctor if the rash gets worse despite several days of home treatment, is severe or occurs along with a fever. A mild hydrocortisone (steroid) cream An antifungal cream, if the baby has a fungal infection Topical or oral antibiotics, if the baby has a bacterial infection Keeping diaper area clean and dry. To aid the healing of diaper rash, do what one can to increase air exposure to the diaper region. These tips may help: Air out the baby's skin by letting him or her go without a diaper and ointment for short periods of time, perhaps three times a day for 10 minutes each time, such as during naps.
Remedies: Generally, a diaper rash can be treated successfully at home with these practices: Keeping diaper area clean and dry. Until the rash is better, this may mean getting up during the night to change the diaper. Don't try to scrub off this protective layer completely at the next diaper change, as that could hurt the skin more. One could also apply petroleum jelly on top, which helps keep the diaper from sticking to the cream. To aid the healing of diaper rash, do what one can to increase air exposure to the diaper region. These tips may help: Air out the baby's skin by letting him or her go without a diaper and ointment for short periods of time, perhaps three times a day for 10 minutes each time, such as during naps.

Name: Diarrhea
Overview: The small intestine and colon are components of the digestive tract, which processes the foods one eat. If one has diarrhea for weeks or longer, one may have a condition such as irritable bowel disorder, or a more serious disorder, such as a persistent infection or inflammatory bowel disease.
Causes: A number of diseases and conditions can cause diarrhea, including Viruses. Viruses that can cause diarrhea include Norwalk virus, cytomegalovirus and viral hepatitis. The virus that causes coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has also been associated with gastrointestinal symptoms, including nausea, vomiting and diarrhea. When traveling in developing countries, diarrhea caused by bacteria and parasites is often called traveler's diarrhea. Clostridium difficile is another type of bacteria that can cause serious infections that cause diarrhea, and it can occur after a course of antibiotics or during a hospitalization. Many medications, such as antibiotics, can cause diarrhea. In people who have trouble digesting fructose, it can lead to diarrhea. Sorbitol and mannitol artificial sweeteners found in chewing gum and other sugar-free products can cause diarrhea in some otherwise healthy people. Chronic diarrhea has a number of other causes, such as Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, celiac disease, microscopic colitis and irritable bowel syndrome.
Remedies: To help one cope with the signs and symptoms until the diarrhea goes away, try to: Ask about anti-diarrheal medications. Over-the-counter (OTC) anti-diarrheal medications, such as loperamide and bismuth subsalicylate, might help reduce the number of watery bowel movements and control severe symptoms. These microorganisms may help restore a healthy balance to the intestinal tract by boosting the level of good bacteria, though it's not clear if they can help shorten a bout of diarrhea. Drink plenty of clear liquids, Add semisolid and low-fiber foods gradually Avoid certain foods Ask about anti-diarrheal medications.
info-Symptoms: Loose frequent bowel movements, dehydration
info-Risk factors: Contaminated food or water

Name: Diarrhea , antibiotic-associated
Causes: It's commonly thought to develop when antibacterial medications (antibiotics) upset the balance of good and bad bacteria in the gastrointestinal tract. Antibiotics most commonly involved include When antibiotics upset the balance of bacteria in the digestive system, the bacteria C. difficile can quickly grow out of control. The antibiotics most commonly linked to C. difficile infection include fluoroquinolones, cephalosporins, penicillins and clindamycin.
Remedies: For infants and children with diarrhea, ask the doctor about using an oral rehydration solution, such as Pedialyte, to replenish fluids and electrolytes. But, there's no consensus on whether or not over-the-counter probiotics can help lessen the symptoms of antibiotic-associated diarrhea. In some cases of mild antibiotic-associated diarrhea, the doctor may recommend anti-diarrheal medications, such as loperamide (Imodium A-D).

Name: Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis ( DISH )
Symptoms: For those who have signs and symptoms, the upper portion of the back is most commonly affected. Signs and symptoms might include Make an appointment with the doctor if one has persistent pain or stiffness in any joint or in the back. One might feel pain in the back or in other affected areas, such as the shoulder, elbow, knee or heel.
Overview: Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a bony hardening of ligaments in areas where they attach to the spine. DISH can also affect the neck and lower back, and some people have DISH in other areas, such as shoulders, elbows, knees and heels.
Risk factors: Other conditions that can raise insulin levels in the body may also increase the risk, including hyperinsulinemia, prediabetes and obesity. Long-term use of medications called retinoids, such as isotretinoin (Amnesteem, Claravis, others), which are used to treat skin conditions such as acne, can increase the risk.
Diagnosis: To determine whether one has DISH, the doctor might begin with a physical examination of the spine and joints. The doctor will also order imaging tests, such as X-rays, CT scans or MRIs, to look for changes in the spine.
Remedies: To help one manage pain and stiffness and to halt progression of the disease, try these self-care measures: Exercise regularly. Regular aerobic exercise, such as walking or swimming, can increase the endurance, keep the body more nimble and help one cope with DISH. Since obesity is associated with DISH, losing weight might help keep the disease from progressing and lower the risk of complications.

Name: Dilated cardiomyopathy
Overview: Dilated cardiomyopathy is a disease of the heart muscle, usually starting in the heart's main pumping chamber (left ventricle). A common cause of heart failure the heart's inability to supply the body with enough blood dilated cardiomyopathy can also contribute to irregular heartbeats (arrhythmias), blood clots or sudden death.
Diagnosis: The test enables the doctor to see the coronary arteries on X-ray, measure pressure in the heart and collect a sample of muscle tissue to check for damage that indicates dilated cardiomyopathy. The doctor may order a chest X-ray to check the heart and lungs for changes or abnormalities in the heart's structure and size, and for fluid in or around the lungs. The doctor may ask one to wear a portable ECG device (Holter monitor) to record the heart rhythm for a day or two. This primary tool for diagnosing dilated cardiomyopathy uses sound waves to produce images of the heart, allowing the doctor to see whether the left ventricle is enlarged. In some situations, the doctor might order one of these tests to check the size and function of the heart's pumping chambers. If the doctor can't identify the cause of dilated cardiomyopathy, he or she may suggest screening of other family members to see if the disease is inherited in the family. Cardiac catheterization Chest X-rays CT scan Echocardiogram Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) Genetic testing MRI Stress test Blood tests.
Remedies: In general, competitive sports aren't recommended because they can increase the risk of the heart stopping and causing sudden death. Eating whole grains and a variety of fruits and vegetables, and limiting salt, added sugar, and cholesterol, saturated fats and trans fats is good for the heart.
Medication: Drugs that have proved useful in the treatment of heart failure and dilated cardiomyopathy include Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. ACE inhibitors are a type of drug that widens or dilates blood vessels (vasodilator) to lower blood pressure, improve blood flow and decrease the heart's workload. A beta blocker slows the heart rate, reduces blood pressure and may prevent some of the harmful effects of stress hormones, which are substances produced by the body that can worsen heart failure and trigger abnormal heart rhythms. Implantable cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs), which monitor heart rhythm and deliver electrical shocks when needed to control abnormal, rapid heartbeats, including those that cause the heart to stop. Left ventricular assist devices (LVADs), which are mechanical devices implanted into the abdomen or chest and attached to a weakened heart to help it pump.
info-Symptoms: Feeling tired, leg swelling, shortness of breath, chest pain, fainting
info-Causes: Genetics, alcohol, cocaine, certain toxins, complications of pregnancy, in many cases the cause remains unclear, certain infections
info-Diagnostic method: Supported by electrocardiogram, chest X-ray, echocardiogram
info-Treatment: Lifestyle changes, medications, implantable cardioverter defibrillator, cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT), heart transplant
info-Medication: ACE inhibitor, beta blocker, diuretic, blood thinners

Name: Diphtheria
Causes: When an infected person's sneeze or cough releases a mist of contaminated droplets, people nearby may inhale C. diphtheriae. People occasionally catch diphtheria from handling an infected person's things, such as used tissues or hand towels, that may be contaminated with the bacteria.
Treatment: If a doctor suspects diphtheria, he or she will request a medication that counteracts the diphtheria toxin in the body from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Before giving an antitoxin, doctors may perform skin allergy tests.
info-Symptoms: Sore throat, fever, barking cough
info-Causes: Corynebacterium diphtheriae (spread by direct contact and through the air)

Name: Dislocated elbow
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of a dislocated elbow include Toddlers with nursemaid's elbow might experience pain only when the affected elbow is moved. Seek immediate medical attention if one or the child has extreme pain or obvious distortion of the elbow joint.
Causes: In toddlers, the injury often occurs when an extra pulling motion is applied to an outstretched arm. Falling onto an outstretched hand can pop the upper arm bone out of alignment within the elbow joint. Having the child suddenly step off a curb or stairstep as one is holding his or her hand can pull the elbow out of alignment.
Medication: After the joint's bones are back in their normal alignment, one or the child might need to wear a splint or sling for a few weeks. One might also need to do physical therapy exercises to improve the joint's range of motion and strength. One might need surgery if: One will probably seek medical attention in a hospital's emergency department or at an urgent care center.

Name: Dissecting aneurysm
Overview: An aortic aneurysm occurs when a weak spot in the wall of the aorta begins to bulge (left). Having an aneurysm increases the risk of rupture or an aortic dissection a tear in the lining of the aorta, shown in the image on the right. An aortic dissection is a serious condition in which the inner layer of the aorta, the large blood vessel branching off the heart, tears.
Causes: Chronic high blood pressure may stress the aortic tissue, making it more susceptible to tearing. Rarely, aortic dissections are caused by traumatic injury to the chest area, such as during motor vehicle accidents. Aortic dissections are divided into two groups, depending on which part of the aorta is affected: Type A.
Risk factors: Risk factors for aortic dissection include Certain genetic diseases increase the risk of having an aortic dissection, including Other potential risk factors include Uncontrolled high blood pressure (hypertension) Hardening of the arteries (atherosclerosis) Weakened and bulging artery (pre-existing aortic aneurysm) An aortic valve defect (bicuspid aortic valve) A narrowing of the aorta at birth (aortic coarctation) Turner's syndrome. People with this disorder often have a family history of aneurysms of the aorta and other blood vessels or family history of aortic dissections. This includes Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, a group of connective tissue disorders characterized by skin that bruises or tears easily, loose joints and fragile blood vessels and Loeys-Dietz syndrome, with twisted arteries, especially in the neck. This drug may be a risk factor for aortic dissection because it temporarily raises blood pressure. Infrequently, aortic dissections occur in otherwise healthy women during pregnancy. This and other strenuous resistance training may increase the risk of aortic dissection by increasing blood pressure during the activity.
Diagnosis: Doctors often suspect an aortic dissection if the following signs and symptoms are present: Although these signs and symptoms suggest aortic dissection, more-sensitive imaging techniques are needed. Frequently used imaging procedures include Sudden tearing or ripping chest pain Widening of the aorta on chest X-ray Blood pressure difference between right and left arms Transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE).

Name: Diverticulitis
Symptoms: Pain, which may be constant and persist for several days. Sometimes, however, the right side of the abdomen is more painful, especially in people of Asian descent.
Overview: Diverticulosis occurs when small, bulging pouches (diverticula) develop in the digestive tract. When one or more of the pouches become inflamed, and in some cases infected, that condition is known as diverticulitis (die-vur-tik-yoo-LIE-tis).
Risk factors: A low-fiber diet in combination with a high intake of animal fat seems to increase risk, although the role of low fiber alone isn't clear. Several drugs are associated with an increased risk of diverticulitis, including steroids, opioids and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve).
info-Symptoms: Abdominal pain, fever, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, blood in the stool
info-Risk factors: Obesity, lack of exercise, smoking, family history, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
info-Diagnostic method: Blood tests, CT scan, colonoscopy, lower gastrointestinal series

Name: Dizziness
Causes: Loop-shaped canals in the inner ear contain fluid and fine, hairlike sensors that help one keep the balance. Dizziness has many possible causes, including inner ear disturbance, motion sickness and medication effects. With inner ear disorders, the brain receives signals from the inner ear that aren't consistent with what the eyes and sensory nerves are receiving. One may feel dizzy, faint or off balance if the heart isn't pumping enough blood to the brain. If one also have sudden hearing loss, one may have labyrinthitis. One may also experience fluctuating hearing loss, ringing in the ear and the feeling of a plugged ear. Conditions such as cardiomyopathy, heart attack, heart arrhythmia and transient ischemic attack could cause dizziness. Dizziness can be a side effect of certain medications such as anti-seizure drugs, antidepressants, sedatives and tranquilizers. In particular, blood pressure lowering medications may cause faintness if they lower the blood pressure too much. These include panic attacks and a fear of leaving home or being in large, open spaces (agoraphobia). Other signs and symptoms that may occur along with dizziness if one has anemia include fatigue, weakness and pale skin. Symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning are often described as flu-like and include headache, dizziness, weakness, upset stomach, vomiting, chest pain and confusion. If one is active in hot weather or if one don't drink enough fluids, one may feel dizzy from overheating (hyperthermia) or from dehydration.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects one is having or may have had a stroke, are older or suffered a blow to the head, he or she may immediately order an MRI or CT scan. One may also need a hearing test and balance tests, including In addition, one may be given blood tests to check for infection and other tests to check heart and blood vessel health. If the doctor suspects the vertigo is caused by benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, he or she may do a simple head movement test called the Dix-Hallpike maneuver to verify the diagnosis.
Remedies: If one tend to experience repeated episodes of dizziness, consider these tips: Be aware of the possibility of losing the balance, which can lead to falling and serious injury. Drink enough fluids, eat a healthy diet, get enough sleep and avoid stress. If the dizziness is caused by a medication, talk with the doctor about discontinuing it or lowering the dose. If the dizziness comes with nausea, try an over-the-counter (nonprescription) antihistamine, such as meclizine or dimenhydrinate (Dramamine). If the dizziness is caused by overheating or dehydration, rest in a cool place and drink water or a sports drink (Gatorade, Powerade, others).
Medication: If one has Meniere's disease, the doctor may prescribe a water pill (diuretic). The doctor may prescribe drugs to provide immediate relief from vertigo, dizziness and nausea, including prescription antihistamines and anticholinergics. Diazepam (Valium) and alprazolam (Xanax) are in a class of drugs called benzodiazepines, which may cause addiction. A technique called canalith repositioning (or Epley maneuver) usually helps resolve benign paroxysmal positional vertigo more quickly than simply waiting for the dizziness to go away. This type of therapy may help people whose dizziness is caused by anxiety disorders. This technique may be used if one has serious hearing loss and the dizziness hasn't responded to other treatments.

Name: Double-outlet right ventricle
Diagnosis: The child's doctor may initially suspect a problem because he or she hears a heart murmur during a routine exam. Most heart murmurs are innocent, meaning that there is no heart defect and the murmur isn't dangerous to the child's health. Some murmurs, however, may mean blood is flowing through the child's heart abnormally because he or she has a heart defect. If it's possible the child has a heart defect, the doctor or the child's doctor may order several tests to see if the child has a heart problem. The child's doctor may use a regular echocardiogram to diagnose a congenital heart defect after the child has been born. In this noninvasive test, the child's doctor performs an ultrasound to produce images of the heart. An echocardiogram allows the doctor to see the child's heart in motion and to identify abnormalities in the heart muscle and valves. In this test, a thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted into a blood vessel at the baby's groin and guided through it into the heart. Catheterization is sometimes necessary because it may give the child's doctor a much more detailed view of the child's heart defect than an echocardiogram. This test allows the doctor to see if the child has a heart defect before he or she is born, allowing the doctor to better plan treatment. This noninvasive test records the electrical activity of the child's heart and can help diagnose heart defects or rhythm problems. The child may have a chest X-ray to see if the heart is enlarged, or if the lungs have extra blood or other fluid in them.
Treatment: A congenital heart defect may have no long-term effect on the child's health in some instances, such defects can safely go untreated. Depending on the type of heart defect the child has, doctors treat congenital heart defects with: Procedures using catheterization. Some children and adults now have their congenital heart defects repaired using catheterization techniques, which allow the repair to be done without surgically opening the chest and heart. In procedures that can be done using catheterization, the doctor inserts a thin tube (catheter) into a leg vein and guides it to the heart with the help of X-ray images. Some mild congenital heart defects, especially those found later in childhood or adulthood, can be treated with medications that help the heart work more efficiently. Drugs known as angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) and beta blockers and medications that cause fluid loss (diuretics) can help ease stress on the heart by lowering blood pressure, heart rate and the amount of fluid in the chest.

Name: Drug addiction ( substance use disorder )
Symptoms: Drug addiction symptoms or behaviors include, among others: Sometimes it's difficult to distinguish normal teenage moodiness or angst from signs of drug use. Cannabis often precedes or is used along with other substances, such as alcohol or illegal drugs, and is often the first drug tried. These drugs can cause severe intoxication, which results in dangerous health effects or even death. Signs and symptoms of recent use can include Barbiturates, benzodiazepines and hypnotics are prescription central nervous system depressants. Signs and symptoms of recent use can include Club drugs are commonly used at clubs, concerts and parties. Signs and symptoms of use of club drugs can include Use of hallucinogens can produce different signs and symptoms, depending on the drug. LSD use may cause: PCP use may cause: Signs and symptoms of inhalant use vary, depending on the substance. Some commonly inhaled substances include glue, paint thinners, correction fluid, felt tip marker fluid, gasoline, cleaning fluids and household aerosol products. Signs and symptoms of use can include Opioids are narcotic, painkilling drugs produced from opium or made synthetically. Signs and symptoms of narcotic use and dependence can include If the drug use is out of control or causing problems, get help. Examples include prescription sleeping medications such as zolpidem (Ambien, Intermezzo, others) and zaleplon (Sonata).
Causes: Like many mental health disorders, several factors may contribute to development of drug addiction. The main factors are: Physical addiction appears to occur when repeated use of a drug changes the way the brain feels pleasure. The addicting drug causes physical changes to some nerve cells (neurons) in the brain.
Risk factors: If one has a mental health disorder such as depression, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) or post-traumatic stress disorder, one is more likely to become addicted to drugs. Using drugs can become a way of coping with painful feelings, such as anxiety, depression and loneliness, and can make these problems even worse. Peer pressure is a strong factor in starting to use and misuse drugs, particularly for young people. Difficult family situations or lack of a bond with the parents or siblings may increase the risk of addiction, as can a lack of parental supervision. Using drugs at an early age can cause changes in the developing brain and increase the likelihood of progressing to drug addiction. Some drugs, such as stimulants, cocaine or opioid painkillers, may result in faster development of addiction than other drugs.

Name: Drug allergy
Diagnosis: For other drugs, a negative result may not completely rule out the possibility of a drug allergy. While there are blood tests for detecting allergic reactions to a few drugs, these tests aren't used often because of the relatively limited research on their accuracy. When the doctor analyzes the symptoms and test results, he or she can usually reach one of the following conclusions: These conclusions can help the doctor and one in making future treatment decisions.

Name: Dry socket
Overview: Dry socket (alveolar osteitis) is a painful dental condition that sometimes happens after one has a permanent adult tooth extracted. Dry socket is when the blood clot at the site of the tooth extraction fails to develop, or it dislodges or dissolves before the wound has healed.
Risk factors: Factors that can increase the risk of developing dry socket include Smoking and tobacco use. High estrogen levels from oral contraceptives may disrupt normal healing processes and increase the risk of dry socket. Failure to follow home-care guidelines and poor oral hygiene may increase the risk of dry socket. Current or previous infections around the extracted tooth increase the risk of dry socket.
Diagnosis: He or she will also ask about any other symptoms and examine the mouth to see if one has a blood clot in the tooth socket and whether one has exposed bone. One may need to have X-rays taken of the mouth and teeth to rule out other conditions, such as a bone infection (osteomyelitis) or small fragments of root or bone remaining in the wound after surgery.
Treatment: Dry socket treatment may include Once treatment is started, one may soon begin to feel some pain relief. Take pain medications as prescribed Avoid smoking or using tobacco products Drink plenty of clear liquids to remain hydrated and to prevent nausea that may be associated with some pain medications Rinse the mouth gently with warm salt water several times a day Brush the teeth gently around the dry socket area Use caution with eating or drinking, avoid carbonated beverages, and avoid smoking or using a straw to prevent dislodging the dressing Flushing out the socket.

Name: DSPS
Diagnosis: The doctor may order several tests to diagnose the condition or any other related conditions, such as: Actigraphy. If the doctor suspects one has a different sleep disorder, he or she may order a polysomnogram.
Treatment: Good sleep hygiene involves maintaining a regular sleep schedule, avoiding caffeine and stimulating activities near bedtime, avoiding tobacco and alcohol, and only using the bedroom for sleeping and sex. It's also helpful to exercise in the morning, and avoid moderate to vigorous exercise close to bedtime. Doctors may prescribe a melatonin supplement to take in the early evening, to help adjust the circadian rhythm. Having light exposure in the morning may adjust the internal sleep clock (circadian rhythm). In chronotherapy, doctors may prescribe one a sleep schedule that delays the bedtime by one to 2.5 hours every six days, until the desired bedtime is reached. Rochester, Minn.: Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research; 2017. Novel implications for the treatment of delayed sleep-wake phase disorder. Clinical practice guideline for the treatment of intrinsic circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorders: Advanced sleep-wake phase disorder (ASWPD), delayed sleep-wake phase disorder (DSWPD), non-24-hour sleep-wake rhythm disorder (N24SWD), and irregular sleep-wake rhythm disorder (ISWRD).

Name: DSRCT
Treatment: Surgery is usually used to treat desmoplastic small round cell tumors. Abdominal desmoplastic small round cell tumor: Multimodal treatment combining chemotherapy, surgery and radiotherapy is the best option. Management of desmoplastic small round-cell tumors in children and young adults.

Name: Dupuytren 's contracture
Symptoms: In later stages of Dupuytren's contracture, cords of tissue form under the skin on the palm and can extend up to the fingers. Dupuytren's contracture can occur in both hands, though one hand is usually affected more severely.
Risk factors: Smoking is associated with an increased risk of Dupuytren's contracture, perhaps because of microscopic changes within blood vessels caused by smoking. People with diabetes are reported to have an increased risk of Dupuytren's contracture.

Name: Dural arteriovenous fistulas
Diagnosis: If one has signs or symptoms of a dural arteriovenous fistula (dAVF), the doctor may recommend that one undergo diagnostic tests, including Initial evaluation typically includes cross-sectional imagery from noncontrast head computerized tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). How many fistulae exist and where Anatomy of the external carotid arteries and any branches between them and the dura Fistula blood vessels structure Whether cardiovascular disease is also present How much narrowing or blockage has occurred in the dural sinus Whether any affected veins are dilated and to what extent CT head scans MRIs Catheter-based cerebral angiography digital subtraction angiography
Treatment: In an endovascular procedure, the doctor may insert a long, thin tube (catheter) into a blood vessel in the leg or groin and thread it through blood vessels to the dural arteriovenous fistula using X-ray imaging. The doctor inserts the catheter into the blood vessel that leads to the dAVF and releases coils or a glue-like substance to block the abnormal connection in the blood vessels. In stereotactic radiosurgery, the doctor uses precisely focused radiation to block the abnormal connection in the blood vessels.

Name: Dust mite allergy
Symptoms: In severe cases, the condition may be ongoing (chronic), resulting in persistent sneezing, cough, congestion, facial pressure or severe asthma attack. Some signs and symptoms of dust mite allergy, such as a runny nose or sneezing, are similar to those of the common cold.
Diagnosis: The doctor may suspect a dust mite allergy if the symptoms are worse when one go to bed or while cleaning when dust mite allergens would be temporarily airborne. In this test, tiny amounts of purified allergen extracts including an extract for dust mites are pricked onto the skin's surface. As an alternative, the doctor may order a blood test that screens for specific allergy-causing antibodies to various common allergens, including dust mites.
Remedies: While one can't completely eliminate dust mites from the home, one can significantly reduce their number. These covers, made of tightly woven fabric, prevent dust mites from colonizing or escaping from the mattress or pillows. Wash all sheets, blankets, pillowcases and bedcovers in hot water that is at least 130 F (54.4 C) to kill dust mites and remove allergens. If bedding can't be washed hot, put the items in the dryer for at least 15 minutes at a temperature above 130 F (54.4 C) to kill the mites. Freezing nonwashable items for 24 hours also can kill dust mites, but this won't remove the allergens. A dehumidifier or air conditioner can help keep humidity low, and a hygrometer (available at hardware stores) can measure humidity levels. Vacuuming carpeting and upholstered furniture removes surface dust but vacuuming isn't effective at removing most dust mites and dust mite allergens. Use a vacuum cleaner with a double-layered microfilter bag or a high-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filter to help decrease house-dust emissions from the cleaner. Consider replacing other dust-collecting furnishings in bedrooms, such as upholstered furniture, nonwashable curtains and horizontal blinds.
info-Symptoms: Symptoms

Name: DVT
Symptoms: Deep vein thrombosis signs and symptoms can include Swelling in the affected leg. If one develop signs or symptoms of deep vein thrombosis, contact the doctor. If one develop signs or symptoms of a pulmonary embolism a life-threatening complication of deep vein thrombosis seek immediate medical attention.
Overview: A blood clot in a leg vein may cause pain, warmth and tenderness in the affected area. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) occurs when a blood clot (thrombus) forms in one or more of the deep veins in the body, usually in the legs. Deep vein thrombosis can be very serious because blood clots in the veins can break loose, travel through the bloodstream and lodge in the lungs, blocking blood flow (pulmonary embolism).
Risk factors: When the legs remain still for long periods, the calf muscles don't contract to help blood circulate, which can increase the risk of blood clots. Injury to the veins or surgery can increase the risk of blood clots. Smoking affects blood clotting and circulation, which can increase the risk of DVT. Some forms of cancer treatment also increase the risk of blood clots. Bowel diseases, such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis, increase the risk of DVT. Being older than 60 increases the risk of DVT, though it can occur at any age. When the legs remain still for hours, the calf muscles don't contract, which normally helps blood circulate.
Diagnosis: Depending on how likely one is to have a blood clot, the doctor might suggest tests, including Ultrasound. Sometimes a series of ultrasounds are done over several days to determine whether a blood clot is growing or to check for a new one. An X-ray creates an image of the veins in the legs and feet, to look for clots.
Remedies: Once one receive treatment for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), one need to watch the diet and watch for signs of excessive bleeding, as well as take steps to prevent another DVT. If one is taking warfarin (Coumadin, Jantoven), one will need a blood test to see how well the blood is clotting. Watch for excessive bleeding, which can be a side effect of taking blood thinners. Talk to the doctor about activities that could cause one to bruise or get cut, as even a minor injury could become serious if one is taking blood thinners.
info-Symptoms: Pain, swelling, redness, enlarged veins in the affected limb
info-Risk factors: Recent surgery, older age, active cancer, obesity, infection, inflammatory diseases, antiphospholipid syndrome, personal history or family history of VTE, injuries, trauma, lack of movement, hormonal birth control, pregnancy and the period following delivery, genetic factors
info-Prevention: Frequent walking, calf exercises, maintaining a healthy body weight, anticoagulants (blood thinners), intermittent pneumatic compression, graduated compression stockings, aspirin
info-Frequency: From 0.8â€“2.7 per 1000 people per year, but populations in China and Korea are below this range
info-Medication: Direct oral anticoagulants, low-molecular-weight heparin, fondaparinux, unfractionated heparin, warfarin

Name: Dwarfism
Symptoms: The most common cause of dwarfism is a disorder called achondroplasia, which causes disproportionately short stature. This disorder usually results in the following: Another cause of disproportionate dwarfism is a rare disorder called spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia congenita (SEDC). Signs may include Proportionate dwarfism results from medical conditions present at birth or appearing in early childhood that limit overall growth and development.
Overview: Dwarfism is short stature that results from a genetic or medical condition. In general, the disorders are divided into two broad categories: Some people prefer the term short stature or little people rather than dwarf or dwarfism.
Causes: A person with achondroplasia and with two average-size parents received one mutated copy of the gene associated with the disorder and one normal copy of the gene. Turner syndrome, a condition that affects only girls and women, results when a sex chromosome (the X chromosome) is missing or partially missing. A girl with Turner syndrome has only one fully functioning copy of the female sex chromosome rather than two.
Diagnosis: A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan may reveal abnormalities of the pituitary gland or hypothalamus, both of which play a role in hormone function. The pediatrician may take a history of stature in siblings, parents, grandparents or other relatives to help determine whether the average range of height in the family includes short stature. Hormone disorder specialist (endocrinologist) Ear, nose and throat (ENT) specialist Specialist in skeletal disorders (orthopedist) Specialist in genetic disorders (medical geneticist) Heart specialist (cardiologist) Eye specialist (ophthalmologist) Mental health provider, such as a psychologist or psychiatrist Nervous system abnormalities specialist (neurologist) Dental specialist in correcting problems with teeth alignment (orthodontist) Developmental therapist, who specializes in therapy to help the child develop age-appropriate behaviors, social skills and interpersonal skills Occupational therapist, who specializes in therapy to develop everyday skills and to use adaptive products that help with everyday activities Genetic testing MRI X-ray Measurements.
Remedies: Avoid infant devices such as swings, umbrella strollers, carrying slings, jumper seats and backpack carriers that don't support the neck or that curve the back into a C shape. Support the child's head and neck when he or she is seated by holding the head, neck and upper back in a safe and stable position. Encourage participation in appropriate recreational activities, such as swimming or bicycling, but avoid sports that involve collision or impact, such as football, diving or gymnastics.
info-Causes: Hyposecretion of growth hormone from pituitary gland (growth hormone deficiency), genetic disorders

Name: Dysarthria
Diagnosis: Besides conducting a physical exam, the doctor might order tests to identify underlying conditions, including Imaging tests. Imaging tests, such as an MRI or CT scan, create detailed images of the brain, head and neck that may help identify the cause of the speech problem. A lumbar puncture can help diagnose serious infections, disorders of the central nervous system, and cancers of the brain or spinal cord. These measure the thinking (cognitive) skills, the ability to understand speech, the ability to understand reading and writing, and other skills. CT scan EEG (electroencephalogram) Electromyography (EMG) Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) MRI Urinalysis Imaging tests.
info-Symptoms: Slurred speech, Weak execution of oral musculary movements

Name: Dystonia
Symptoms: Muscle contractions might: Areas of the body that can be affected include Early signs of dystonia often are mild, occasional and linked to a specific activity. Focal dystonia that begins after age 21 usually starts in the neck, arm or face and tends to remain focal or segmental. Contractions cause the head to twist and turn to one side, or pull forward or backward, sometimes causing pain. Spasms usually aren't painful but might increase when one is in bright light, under stress or interacting with people.
Overview: Dystonia is a movement disorder in which the muscles contract involuntarily, causing repetitive or twisting movements. The condition can affect one part of the body (focal dystonia), two or more adjacent parts (segmental dystonia) or all parts of the body (general dystonia).
Diagnosis: To diagnose dystonia, the doctor will start with a medical history and physical examination. To determine if underlying conditions are causing the symptoms, the doctor might recommend: Blood or urine tests. These imaging tests can identify abnormalities in the brain, such as tumors, lesions or evidence of a stroke.
Remedies: Dystonia has no cure, but one can do a number of things to minimize its effects: Sensory tricks to reduce spasms. Learn effective coping skills to manage stress, such as deep breathing, social support and positive self-talk.
Medication: Injections of botulinum toxin (Botox, Dysport, others) into specific muscles might reduce or eliminate the muscle contractions and improve the abnormal postures. The options include The doctor might suggest: If the symptoms are severe, the doctor might recommend: Carbidopa-levodopa (Duopa, Rytary, others). Diazepam (Valium), clonazepam (Klonopin) and baclofen (Lioresal, Gablofen). This procedure, which involves cutting the nerves that control muscle spasms, might be an option to treat some types of dystonia that haven't been successfully treated using other therapies.
info-Causes: hereditary (DYT1); birth injury; head trauma; medication; infection; toxins
info-Diagnostic method: genetic testing, electromyography, blood tests, MRI or CT scan
info-Treatment: medication, physical therapy, botulinum toxin injection, deep brain stimulation

Name: E. coli
Overview: Escherichia coli (E. coli) bacteria normally live in the intestines of healthy people and animals. Healthy adults usually recover from infection with E. coli O157:H7 within a week, but young children and older adults have a greater risk of developing a life-threatening form of kidney failure called hemolytic uremic syndrome.
Causes: Unlike many other disease-causing bacteria, E. coli can cause an infection even if one ingest only small amounts. Because of this, one can be sickened by E. coli from eating a slightly undercooked hamburger or from swallowing a mouthful of contaminated pool water. Although public water systems use chlorine, ultraviolet light or ozone to kill E. coli, some outbreaks have been linked to contaminated municipal water supplies. E. coli bacteria can easily travel from person to person, especially when infected adults and children don't wash their hands properly. When cattle are slaughtered and processed, E. coli bacteria in their intestines can get on the meat.
Risk factors: People who have weakened immune systems from AIDS or drugs to treat cancer or prevent the rejection of organ transplants are more likely to become ill from ingesting E. coli. Though it's not clear why, the majority of E. coli infections in the U.S. occur from June through September. If one take medications to reduce the levels of stomach acid, such as esomeprazole (Nexium), pantoprazole (Protonix), lansoprazole (Prevacid) and omeprazole (Prilosec), one may increase the risk of an E. coli infection.
Treatment: For illness caused by E. coli, no current treatments can cure the infection, relieve symptoms or prevent complications. For most people, treatment includes: Avoid taking an anti-diarrheal medication this slows the digestive system down, preventing the body from getting rid of the toxins. If one has a serious E. coli infection that has caused hemolytic uremic syndrome, one will be hospitalized and given supportive care, including IV fluids, blood transfusions and kidney dialysis. If the symptoms are particularly severe, one may want to visit the primary care doctor or seek immediate care. Dairy products, fatty foods, high-fiber foods or highly seasoned foods can make symptoms worse.
Remedies: Drink plenty of clear liquids, including water, clear sodas and broths, gelatin, and juices. Dairy products, fatty foods, high-fiber foods or highly seasoned foods can make symptoms worse.

Name: Earwax blockage
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of earwax blockage may include If one is experiencing the signs and symptoms of earwax blockage, talk to the doctor. Having signs and symptoms, such as earache or decreased hearing, doesn't necessarily mean one has wax buildup.
