Remedies: If the eardrum doesn't contain a tube or have a hole in it, these self-care measures may help one remove excess earwax that's blocking the ear canal: One may need to repeat this wax-softening and irrigation procedure a few times before the excess earwax falls out. However, the softening agents may only loosen the outer layer of the wax and cause it to lodge deeper in the ear canal or against the eardrum. After a day or two, when the wax is softened, use a rubber-bulb syringe to gently squirt warm water into the ear canal.

Name: Eating disorders
Symptoms: Anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa and binge-eating disorder are the most common eating disorders. Bulimia (boo-LEE-me-uh) nervosa commonly called bulimia is a serious, potentially life-threatening eating disorder. When one has binge-eating disorder, one regularly eat too much food (binge) and feel a lack of control over the eating. If one is experiencing any of these problems, or if one think one may have an eating disorder, seek medical help. Unfortunately, many people with eating disorders may not think they need treatment. Be alert for eating patterns and beliefs that may signal unhealthy behavior, as well as peer pressure that may trigger eating disorders.
Risk factors: Teenage girls and young women are more likely than teenage boys and young men to have anorexia or bulimia, but males can have eating disorders, too. Although eating disorders can occur across a broad age range, they often develop in the teens and early 20s. Certain factors may increase the risk of developing an eating disorder, including Family history. Starvation and weight loss may change the way the brain works in vulnerable individuals, which may perpetuate restrictive eating behaviors and make it difficult to return to normal eating habits. Whether it's heading off to college, moving, landing a new job, or a family or relationship issue, change can bring stress, which may increase the risk of an eating disorder.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects one has an eating disorder, he or she will likely perform an exam and request tests to help pinpoint a diagnosis. Assessments and tests generally include The mental health professional also may use the diagnostic criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association. A doctor or mental health professional will likely ask about the thoughts, feelings and eating habits.
info-Symptoms: Abnormal eating habits that negatively affect physical or mental health
info-Risk factors: Gastrointestinal disorders, history of sexual abuse, being a dancer or gymnast
info-Treatment: Counseling, proper diet, normal amount of exercise, medications

Name: Eating disorders , anorexia
Symptoms: Physical signs and symptoms of anorexia may include Some people who have anorexia binge and purge, similar to individuals who have bulimia. But people with anorexia generally struggle with an abnormally low body weight, while individuals with bulimia typically are normal to above normal weight.
Causes: Although it's not yet clear which genes are involved, there may be genetic changes that make some people at higher risk of developing anorexia. Some people may have a genetic tendency toward perfectionism, sensitivity and perseverance all traits associated with anorexia. Some people with anorexia may have obsessive-compulsive personality traits that make it easier to stick to strict diets and forgo food despite being hungry. They may have an extreme drive for perfectionism, which causes them to think they're never thin enough. Peer pressure may help fuel the desire to be thin, particularly among young girls.
Risk factors: Those with a first-degree relative a parent, sibling or child who had the disorder have a much higher risk of anorexia. Starvation and weight loss may change the way the brain works in vulnerable individuals, which may perpetuate restrictive eating behaviors and make it difficult to return to normal eating habits. Whether it's a new school, home or job; a relationship breakup; or the death or illness of a loved one, change can bring emotional stress and increase the risk of anorexia.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects that one has anorexia nervosa, he or she will typically do several tests and exams to help pinpoint a diagnosis, rule out medical causes for the weight loss, and check for any related complications. These exams and tests generally include The mental health professional also may use the diagnostic criteria for anorexia in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association. This may include measuring the height and weight; checking the vital signs, such as heart rate, blood pressure and temperature; checking the skin and nails for problems; listening to the heart and lungs; and examining the abdomen. These may include a complete blood count (CBC) and more-specialized blood tests to check electrolytes and protein as well as functioning of the liver, kidney and thyroid. Bone density test Complete blood count (CBC) Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) Liver function tests Urinalysis X-ray Physical exam.
Remedies: In addition to professional treatment, follow these steps: Stick to the treatment plan. Don't skip therapy sessions and try not to stray from meal plans, even if they make one uncomfortable. If one is not eating well, chances are the body isn't getting all of the nutrients it needs, such as Vitamin D or iron. However, getting most of the vitamins and minerals from food is typically recommended.

Name: Eating disorders , binge eating
Symptoms: If one has any symptoms of binge-eating disorder, seek medical help as soon as possible. A friend, loved one, teacher or faith leader can help one take the first steps to successful treatment of binge-eating disorder. A person with binge-eating disorder may become an expert at hiding behavior, making it hard for others to detect the problem. If one has a loved one one think may have symptoms of binge-eating disorder, have an open and honest discussion about the concerns.
Overview: Binge-eating disorder is a serious eating disorder in which one frequently consume unusually large amounts of food and feel unable to stop eating. But for some people, excessive overeating that feels out of control and becomes a regular occurrence crosses the line to binge-eating disorder.
Risk factors: Although people of any age can have binge-eating disorder, it often begins in the late teens or early 20s. Factors that can increase the risk of developing binge-eating disorder include Family history.
Remedies: But in addition to professional help, one can take these self-care steps to reinforce the treatment plan: Stick to the treatment. Talk with the medical care provider about appropriate weight management strategies for one don't diet unless it's recommended for the eating disorder treatment and supervised by the medical care provider. Ask the medical care provider what kind of physical activity is appropriate for one, especially if one has health problems related to being overweight.
Medication: Lisdexamfetamine dimesylate (Vyvanse), a drug for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, is the first FDA-approved medication to treat moderate to severe binge-eating disorder in adults. Examples include While these medications can be helpful in controlling binge-eating episodes, they may not have much impact on weight reduction. However, weight-loss programs typically aren't recommended until the binge-eating disorder is treated, because dieting may trigger more binge-eating episodes, making weight loss less successful.

Name: Eating disorders , bulimia
Overview: Bulimia (boo-LEE-me-uh) nervosa, commonly called bulimia, is a serious, potentially life-threatening eating disorder. People with bulimia may secretly binge eating large amounts of food with a loss of control over the eating and then purge, trying to get rid of the extra calories in an unhealthy way.
Risk factors: People with first-degree relatives (siblings, parents or children) with an eating disorder may be more likely to develop an eating disorder, suggesting a possible genetic link. Psychological and emotional problems, such as depression, anxiety disorders or substance use disorders are closely linked with eating disorders. Many people with bulimia severely restrict calories between binge episodes, which may trigger an urge to again binge eat and then purge.
Treatment: When one has bulimia, one may need several types of treatment, although combining psychotherapy with antidepressants may be the most effective for overcoming the disorder. Treatment generally involves a team approach that includes one, the family, the primary care provider, a mental health professional and a dietitian experienced in treating eating disorders.
Remedies: In addition to professional treatment, follow these self-care tips: Stick to the treatment plan. Don't skip therapy sessions and try not to stray from meal plans, even if they make one uncomfortable. If one isn't eating well or one is frequently purging, it's likely the body isn't getting all of the nutrients it needs. Talk to the primary care provider about what kind of physical activity, if any, is appropriate for one, especially if one exercise excessively to burn off post-binge calories.
Medication: The only antidepressant specifically approved by the Food and Drug Administration to treat bulimia is fluoxetine (Prozac), a type of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), which may help even if one is not depressed. If one find theself back in the binge-purge cycle, follow-up sessions with the primary care provider, dietitian and/or mental health professional may help one weather the crisis before the eating disorder spirals out of control again.

Name: Ebstein anomaly
Causes: A normal heart has two upper (receiving) and two lower (pumping) chambers. The lower chambers, the more muscular right and left ventricles, pump blood out of the heart. The tricuspid valve normally sits between the two right heart chambers (right atrium and right ventricle). This can lead to blood leaking backward into the right atrium (tricuspid valve regurgitation). An abnormal heart rhythm or rapid heartbeats make is difficult for the heart to work properly, especially when the tricuspid valve is leaking severely.
Risk factors: Congenital heart defects, such as Ebstein anomaly, occur as the baby's heart develops in the mother's womb. A family history of heart defects or a mother's use of certain medications, such as lithium, during pregnancy might increase the risk of Ebstein anomaly in the child.
Diagnosis: If one or the child doesn't have signs or symptoms of heart trouble, the doctor might suspect a problem only after hearing abnormal heart sounds during a routine physical exam. However, the doctor or the child's doctor will likely refer one to a doctor who specializes in treating heart conditions (cardiologist) to determine the cause. To perform this test, the doctor threads thin, flexible tubes (catheters) tipped with electrodes through the blood vessels to areas within the heart to map the heart's electrical impulses. In addition, the doctor can use the electrodes to stimulate the heart to beat at rates that may trigger or halt an arrhythmia. During this test, the blood pressure, heart rate, heart rhythm and breathing are monitored as the walk on a treadmill or ride a stationary bicycle. A long, thin tube (catheter) is inserted into a blood vessel in the groin, arm or neck and guided to the heart using X-ray imaging. A special dye injected through the catheter helps the doctor see blood flow through the heart, blood vessels and valves; measure pressures and oxygen levels in the heart; and look for abnormalities inside the heart and lungs.
Medication: The doctor might also prescribe medications to ease signs and symptoms of heart failure, such as drugs to prevent water retention (diuretics). If one has certain heart rhythm problems or a hole (atrial septal defect) between the upper heart chambers, the doctor may prescribe medications to prevent blood clots. If the valve can't be repaired, the surgeon might remove it and replace it with either a biological tissue (bioprosthetic) or mechanical valve. If one has any type of artificial valve, one will need to take medication to prevent an inflammation of the inner lining of the heart (endocarditis) before dental procedures. If there's a hole between the upper chambers of the heart (atrial septal defect), the surgeon can repair or replace the defective valve. If one has fast heart rhythms, the surgeon may perform the Maze procedure during valve repair or replacement surgery.

Name: Ectopic pregnancy
Symptoms: However, some women who have an ectopic pregnancy have the usual early signs or symptoms of pregnancy a missed period, breast tenderness and nausea. Often, the first warning signs of an ectopic pregnancy are light vaginal bleeding and pelvic pain.
Overview: In a healthy pregnancy, the fertilized egg attaches itself to the lining of the uterus. In an ectopic pregnancy, the egg attaches itself somewhere outside the uterus usually to the inside of a fallopian tube. An ectopic pregnancy most often occurs in a fallopian tube, which carries eggs from the ovaries to the uterus. Sometimes, an ectopic pregnancy occurs in other areas of the body, such as the ovary, abdominal cavity or the lower part of the uterus (cervix), which connects to the vagina.
Risk factors: Sexually transmitted infections, such as gonorrhea or chlamydia, can cause inflammation in the tubes and other nearby organs, and increase the risk of an ectopic pregnancy. Some research suggests that women who have in vitro fertilization (IVF) or similar treatments are more likely to have an ectopic pregnancy. However, if one do get pregnant with an IUD in place, it's more likely to be ectopic. Tubal ligation, a permanent method of birth control commonly known as having the tubes tied, also raises the risk, if one become pregnant after this procedure. Cigarette smoking just before one get pregnant can increase the risk of an ectopic pregnancy.
Diagnosis: This blood test may be repeated every few days until ultrasound testing can confirm or rule out an ectopic pregnancy usually about five to six weeks after conception. During a transvaginal ultrasound, the doctor or a medical technician inserts a wandlike device (transducer) into the vagina while one lie on the back on an exam table. If one is diagnosed with an ectopic pregnancy, the doctor may also order tests to check the blood type in case one need a transfusion.
info-Symptoms: Abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding
info-Risk factors: Pelvic inflammatory disease, tobacco smoking, prior tubal surgery, history of infertility, use of assisted reproductive technology
info-Diagnostic method: Blood tests for human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), ultrasound

Name: Ectropion
Symptoms: Normally when one blink, the eyelids distribute tears evenly across the eyes, keeping the surfaces of the eyes lubricated. The resulting signs and symptoms can include See the doctor if the eyes are constantly watering or irritated, or the eyelid seems to be sagging or drooping. Stagnant tears or dryness can irritate the eyes, causing a burning sensation and redness in the eyelids and the whites of the eyes. Stagnant tears or dry eyes can irritate the surface of the cornea, making one sensitive to light.
Overview: In ectropion, the lower lid sags away from the eye. In less severe ectropion, only one segment of the eyelid sags away from the eye.
Causes: Certain conditions, such as Bell's palsy, and certain types of tumors can paralyze facial nerves and muscles. Facial paralysis that affects eyelid muscles can lead to ectropion. Skin that has been damaged by burns or trauma, such as a dog bite, can affect the way that the eyelid rests against the eye. Previous eyelid surgery (blepharoplasty) can cause ectropion, particularly if a considerable amount of skin was removed from the eyelid at the time of surgery.

Name: Eczema
Overview: Atopic dermatitis can cause small, red bumps, which can be very itchy. Atopic dermatitis most often occurs where the skin flexes inside the elbows, behind the knees and in front of the neck. Atopic dermatitis (eczema) is a condition that makes the skin red and itchy.
Remedies: To help reduce itching and soothe inflamed skin, try these self-care measures: Moisturize the skin at least twice a day. Once the reaction has improved, one may use this type of cream less often to prevent flare-ups. Also, diphenhydramine (Benadryl, others) may be helpful if itching is severe. Sprinkle the bath water with baking soda, uncooked oatmeal or colloidal oatmeal a finely ground oatmeal that is made for the bathtub (Aveeno, others). Hot, dry indoor air can parch sensitive skin and worsen itching and flaking.
Medication: But the American Academy of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology has concluded that the risk-to-benefit ratios of topical pimecrolimus and tacrolimus are similar to those of most other conventional treatments of persistent eczema and that the data don't support the use of the black box warning. Treatment for eczema in babies (infantile eczema) includes: See the baby's doctor if these measures don't improve the rash or if the rash looks infected. The doctor may also recommend an oral antihistamine to help lessen the itch and to cause drowsiness, which may be helpful for nighttime itching and discomfort. The doctor may prescribe an antibiotic cream if the skin has a bacterial infection, an open sore or cracks. Identifying and avoiding skin irritants Avoiding extreme temperatures Lubricating the baby's skin with bath oils, creams or ointments Creams that control itching and help repair the skin.
info-Symptoms: Itchiness, red skin, rash
info-Causes: Atopic dermatitis, allergic contact dermatitis, irritant contact dermatitis, seborrhoeic dermatitis, stasis dermatitis

Name: Edema
Overview: Edema is swelling caused by excess fluid trapped in the body's tissues. Edema can be the result of medication, pregnancy or an underlying disease often congestive heart failure, kidney disease or cirrhosis of the liver.
Causes: Edema occurs when tiny blood vessels in the body (capillaries) leak fluid. Sometimes, this condition can cause fluid to accumulate in the lungs (pulmonary edema), which can lead to shortness of breath. Fluid may accumulate in the abdominal cavity (ascites) and in the legs as a result of liver damage (cirrhosis). When one has kidney disease, extra fluid and sodium in the circulation may cause edema. Damage to the tiny, filtering blood vessels in the kidneys can result in nephrotic syndrome. In nephrotic syndrome, declining levels of protein (albumin) in the blood can lead to fluid accumulation and edema. An extreme lack (deficiency), of protein in the diet over a long period of time can lead to fluid accumulation and edema.
Remedies: Moving and using the muscles in the part of the body affected by edema, especially the legs, may help pump the excess fluid back toward the heart. In some cases, elevating the affected body part while one sleep may be helpful. Stroking the affected area toward the heart using firm, but not painful, pressure may help move the excess fluid out of that area. If one of the limbs is affected by edema, the doctor may recommend one wear compression stockings, sleeves or gloves, usually worn after the swelling has gone down, to prevent further swelling from occurring.
info-Symptoms: Skin which feels tight, area may feel heavy
info-Causes: Venous insufficiency, heart failure, kidney problems, low protein levels, liver problems, deep vein thrombosis, lymphedema

Name: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
Symptoms: Some people with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome will have overly flexible joints, but few or none of the skin symptoms. People who have Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, vascular type, often share distinctive facial features of a thin nose, thin upper lip, small earlobes and prominent eyes. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, vascular type, can weaken the heart's largest artery (aorta), as well as the arteries to other regions of the body. One may be able to pull a pinch of skin up away from the flesh, but it will snap right back into place when one let go.
Remedies: Walking, swimming, tai chi, recreational biking, using an elliptical machine or a stationary bike are all good choices. To protect the jaw joint, avoid chewing gum, hard rolls and ice. To prevent a collapsed lung, avoid playing reeded wind or brass instruments. A violin, viola or piano would be safer options and would take advantage of the increased flexibility of the hands.
Medication: Surgery may be necessary to repair ruptured blood vessels or organs in people with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, vascular type. Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve) are the mainstay of treatment. Because blood vessels are more fragile in some types of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, the doctor may want to reduce the stress on the vessels by keeping the blood pressure low.
info-Symptoms: Overly flexible joints, stretchy skin, abnormal scar formation
info-Usual onset: Childhood or teens depending on type.
info-Risk factors: Family history

Name: Ehrlichiosis
Overview: Ehrlichiosis is a bacterial illness transmitted by ticks that causes flu-like symptoms. The signs and symptoms of ehrlichiosis range from mild body aches to severe fever and usually appear within a week or two of a tick bite. Tick repellents, thorough body checks after being outside and proper removal of ticks give one the best chance of avoiding ehrlichiosis.
Risk factors: Ehrlichiosis spreads when an infected tick, primarily the Lone Star tick, bites one and feeds on one for 24 hours or longer. Most cases of ehrlichiosis occur in the spring and summer months when populations of the Lone Star tick are at their peak, and people are outside more often.
Diagnosis: If one has ehrlichiosis, the blood tests will likely show: More specific blood tests for ehrlichiosis include If one live in an area where ticks are common, the doctor may start one on antibiotics before the results of the blood tests return because earlier treatment results in a better outcome for some tick-borne diseases. A low white blood cell count these cells are the body's disease fighters A low platelet count platelets are essential to blood clotting Abnormal liver function Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test.
Treatment: If the doctor suspects that one has ehrlichiosis or another tick-borne illness, one will likely receive a prescription for the antibiotic doxycycline (Doryx, Vibramycin, others). If one is pregnant, the doctor may prescribe the antibiotic rifampin (Rifadin, Rimactane) instead, because doxycycline isn't recommended during pregnancy. If one remove the tick within 24 hours of its attachment, it's unlikely one will get ehrlichiosis or other tick-borne illnesses. If one pull too quickly or grab the tick by its body, the tick will likely separate, leaving the mouth parts in the skin. If the tick's mouth parts do break off in the skin, remove them with tweezers. These methods may make matters worse by triggering the tick to release more of its bodily fluids, and that could cause further infection.
Remedies: If one remove the tick within 24 hours of its attachment, it's unlikely one will get ehrlichiosis or other tick-borne illnesses. If one pull too quickly or grab the tick by its body, the tick will likely separate, leaving the mouth parts in the skin. If the tick's mouth parts do break off in the skin, remove them with tweezers. These methods may make matters worse by triggering the tick to release more of its bodily fluids, and that could cause further infection.
info-Symptoms: Fever, chills, severe headaches, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, confusion, and splotchy or pinpoint rash. More severe symptoms include brain or nervous system damage, respiratory failure, uncontrollable bleeding, organ failure, and death.
info-Risk factors: Age, being immunocompromised, having received an organ transplant, and certain medications

Name: Eisenmenger syndrome
Overview: Eisenmenger syndrome is most often a complication of having a hole (shunt) between two chambers of the heart. Here, a hole between the heart's main pumping chambers (ventricular septal defect) causes increased blood flow to the pulmonary arteries. Eisenmenger syndrome occurs when the pressure in the pulmonary arteries becomes so high that it causes oxygen-poor (blue) blood to flow from the right to left ventricle and then to the body, causing cyanosis.
Causes: In performing its basic job pumping blood throughout the body the heart uses its left and right sides for different tasks. In the lungs, oxygen enriches the blood, which circulates to the heart's left side. The left side of the heart pumps blood into a large vessel called the aorta, which circulates blood to the rest of the body. A family history of heart defects also increases the risk of a baby being born with a congenital heart defect, including the possibility of developing Eisenmenger syndrome. An atrial septal defect is a shunt in the wall of tissue that divides the right and left sides of the upper chambers of the heart (atria).
Diagnosis: In this test, doctors insert a thin, flexible tube (catheter) into a vein and artery in the groin and guide the catheter to the heart using X-ray imaging. Doctors use cardiac catheterization to measure blood pressure in the blood vessels or heart's chambers, the size of any septal defect, the pressures across the defect, and the amount of blood in the heart and lungs. Blood tests may be done to check the blood cell counts, which are often high in Eisenmenger syndrome. The kidney and liver function, as well as the iron level, also may be measured with blood tests. In this test, one will lie in a machine that takes images of the heart and lungs so that the doctors can see a cross section of them. This test, which uses no X-rays, is sometimes used to get images of the blood vessels in the lungs and heart structure.
Remedies: Because of the low oxygen levels at high altitudes, the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association recommend against living at an altitude of 5,000 feet (1,524 meters) or higher above sea level. Many prescription and over-the-counter medications or supplements may increase or decrease blood pressure, increase risk of bleeding or blood clots, or affect kidney function in patients who have Eisenmenger syndrome.
Medication: One will need to be monitored closely by a doctor when taking medications for any changes in blood pressure, fluid volume or pulse rate. If one has had a stroke, blood clot or certain types of irregular heart rhythms, the doctor may recommend aspirin or other blood thinners such as warfarin (Coumadin, Jantoven). However, people who have Eisenmenger syndrome are also at increased risk of bleeding when taking these medications, so don't take any blood thinners unless the doctor tells one to do so. Don't take over-the-counter pain medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen (Aleve, others), without talking to the doctor first. Antibiotics taken before these procedures can help destroy or control the harmful bacteria that may lead to an infection of the heart's tissues (endocarditis). Antibiotics are recommended only before certain dental procedures (those that cut the gum tissue or part of the teeth) and procedures involving the respiratory tract, infected skin or tissue that connects muscle to bone. If the red blood cell count becomes too high and is causing symptoms such as headache, difficulty concentrating or visual disturbances, the doctor may recommend having blood drawn to help decrease the blood cell counts.

Name: Elevated blood pressure
Risk factors: Risk factors for elevated blood pressure include Although elevated blood pressure and high blood pressure are most common in adults, children can be at risk, too. For some children, kidney or heart problems can cause high blood pressure. But for a growing number of kids, poor lifestyle habits, such as an unhealthy diet, obesity and lack of exercise, contribute to elevated blood pressure and high blood pressure. Younger adults are more likely to have elevated blood pressure than are older adults because the risk of hypertension increases as one age. Even children can develop elevated blood pressure, especially if they're overweight or obese. High blood pressure is particularly common among people of African heritage, often developing at an earlier age than it does in white people. If a first-degree relative, such as a parent or sibling, has high blood pressure, one is more likely to develop the condition. If one has too much sodium or too little potassium in the diet, one is more likely to have high blood pressure. Smoking cigarettes, chewing tobacco or being around others who smoke (secondhand smoke) can increase the blood pressure. Kidney disease, diabetes and sleep apnea, among others, can increase the risk of elevated blood pressure.
Diagnosis: A blood pressure reading, given in millimeters of mercury (mm Hg), has two numbers. Other blood pressure measurements are categorized as: Because blood pressure tends to fluctuate, a diagnosis of elevated blood pressure is based on the average of two or more blood pressure readings taken on separate occasions in a consistent manner. The doctor might also recommend that one use a home blood pressure monitor, preferably one that can store the readings in its memory, to check the blood pressure regularly. Elevated blood pressure is a systolic pressure ranging from 120 to 129 mm Hg and a diastolic pressure below 80 mm Hg. More-severe hypertension, stage 2 hypertension, is a systolic pressure of 140 mm Hg or higher or a diastolic pressure of 90 mm Hg or higher.
Treatment: If one has elevated blood pressure accompanied by diabetes, kidney disease or cardiovascular disease, the doctor might recommend blood pressure medication in addition to lifestyle changes. If one has been diagnosed with elevated blood pressure, the benefits of medication are less clear. Regular physical activity can help lower the blood pressure, manage stress, reduce the risk of other health problems and keep the weight under control. For most healthy adults, the Department of Health and Human Services recommends that one get at least 150 minutes a week of moderate aerobic activity or 75 minutes a week of vigorous aerobic activity, or a combination of moderate and vigorous activity. If one think one may have elevated blood pressure or high blood pressure, make an appointment with the family doctor to have the blood pressure checked. Because some medications such as over-the-counter cold medicines, pain medications, antidepressants, birth control pills and others can raise the blood pressure, bring a list of all medications, vitamins and other supplements one take and their doses to the doctor's appointment. Getting to and maintaining a healthy weight Eating a healthy, low-salt diet Exercising regularly Limiting the amount of alcohol one drink Quitting smoking Eat healthy foods. Get plenty of potassium, which can help lower blood pressure. Keeping a healthy weight, or losing weight if one is overweight or obese, can help one control the blood pressure and lower the risk of related health problems. In general, one may reduce the blood pressure by about 1 mm Hg with each kilogram (about 2.2 pounds) of weight one lose.
Remedies: Regular physical activity can help lower the blood pressure, manage stress, reduce the risk of other health problems and keep the weight under control. For most healthy adults, the Department of Health and Human Services recommends that one get at least 150 minutes a week of moderate aerobic activity or 75 minutes a week of vigorous aerobic activity, or a combination of moderate and vigorous activity. Keeping a healthy weight, or losing weight if one is overweight or obese, can help one control the blood pressure and lower the risk of related health problems. In general, one may reduce the blood pressure by about 1 mm Hg with each kilogram (about 2.2 pounds) of weight one lose. For healthy adults, that means up to one drink a day for women of all ages and men older than age 65, and up to two drinks a day for men age 65 and younger. One drink equals 12 ounces (355 milliliters) of beer, 5 ounces (148 milliliters) of wine or 1.5 ounces (44 milliliters) of 80-proof liquor.
info-Symptoms: None
info-Risk factors: Lack of sleep, Excess salt, excess body weight, smoking, alcohol Air Pollution

Name: Embryonal tumors
Diagnosis: If it's suspected that one has a brain tumor, the doctor may recommend a number of tests and procedures, including Imaging tests. A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. Positron emission tomography (PET) may be used for brain imaging, but is generally not as useful for creating images of brain cancer as it is for other types of cancer. A stereotactic needle biopsy may be done for brain tumors in hard to reach areas or very sensitive areas within the brain that might be damaged by a more extensive operation. If it's suspected that the brain tumor may be a result of cancer that has spread from another area of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer originated.

Name: Emphysema
Symptoms: One may start avoiding activities that cause one to be short of breath, so the symptom doesn't become a problem until it starts interfering with daily tasks. See the doctor if one has had unexplained shortness of breath for several months, especially if it's getting worse or it's interfering with the daily activities.
Overview: In emphysema, the inner walls of the lungs air sacs (alveoli) are damaged, causing them to eventually rupture. In people with emphysema, the air sacs in the lungs (alveoli) are damaged. Over time, the inner walls of the air sacs weaken and rupture creating larger air spaces instead of many small ones. Chronic bronchitis is inflammation of the tubes that carry air to the lungs (bronchial tubes), which leads to a persistent cough.
Risk factors: Emphysema is most likely to develop in cigarette smokers, but cigar and pipe smokers also are susceptible. Although the lung damage that occurs in emphysema develops gradually, most people with tobacco-related emphysema begin to experience symptoms of the disease between the ages of 40 and 60. Secondhand smoke, also known as passive or environmental tobacco smoke, is smoke that one inadvertently inhale from someone else's cigarette, pipe or cigar. If one breathe fumes from certain chemicals or dust from grain, cotton, wood or mining products, one is more likely to develop emphysema. Breathing indoor pollutants, such as fumes from heating fuel, as well as outdoor pollutants car exhaust, for instance increases the risk of emphysema.
Diagnosis: Computerized tomography (CT) scans combine X-ray images taken from many different directions to create cross-sectional views of internal organs. Blood taken from an artery in the wrist can be tested to determine how well the lungs transfer oxygen into, and remove carbon dioxide from, the bloodstream.
Remedies: If one has emphysema, one can take a number of steps to halt its progression and to protect theself from complications: Stop smoking. Cold air can cause spasms of the bronchial passages, making it even more difficult to breathe. During cold weather, wear a soft scarf or a cold-air mask available from a pharmacy over the mouth and nose before going outside, to warm the air entering the lungs. If one has to mingle with large groups of people during cold and flu season, wear a face mask, wash the hands frequently and carry a small bottle of alcohol-based hand sanitizer to use when needed.
Medication: Depending upon the severity of the symptoms, the doctor might suggest: Depending on the severity of the emphysema, the doctor may suggest one or more different types of surgery, including Bronchodilators. These drugs can help relieve coughing, shortness of breath and breathing problems by relaxing constricted airways. A pulmonary rehabilitation program can teach one breathing exercises and techniques that may help reduce the breathlessness and improve the ability to exercise. In the early stages of emphysema, many people need to lose weight, while people with late-stage emphysema often need to gain weight. If one has severe emphysema with low blood oxygen levels, using oxygen regularly at home and when one exercise may provide some relief. In this procedure, surgeons remove small wedges of damaged lung tissue. Removing the diseased tissue helps the remaining lung tissue expand and work more efficiently and helps improve breathing.
info-Symptoms: Shortness of breath, chronic cough
info-Prevention: Stopping smoking, improving indoor and outdoor air quality, tobacco control measures
info-Treatment: Pulmonary rehabilitation, long-term oxygen therapy, lung volume reduction

Name: Encephalitis
Overview: Encephalitis (en-sef-uh-LIE-tis) is inflammation of the brain. Encephalitis often causes only mild flu-like signs and symptoms such as a fever or headache or no symptoms at all.
Causes: Also known as post-infection encephalitis, secondary encephalitis often occurs two to three weeks after the initial infection. These include the Epstein-Barr virus, which commonly causes infectious mononucleosis, and the varicella-zoster virus, which commonly causes chickenpox and shingles. These viruses include the poliovirus and the coxsackievirus, which usually cause an illness with flu-like symptoms, eye inflammation and abdominal pain. These viruses can cause infections such as West Nile, La Crosse, St. Louis, western equine and eastern equine encephalitis. Infection with the rabies virus, which is usually transmitted by a bite from an infected animal, causes a rapid progression to encephalitis once symptoms begin. Common childhood infections such as measles (rubeola), mumps and German measles (rubella) used to be fairly common causes of secondary encephalitis.
Risk factors: In general, young children and older adults are at greater risk of most types of viral encephalitis. People who have HIV/AIDS, take immune-suppressing drugs or have another condition causing a weakened immune system are at increased risk of encephalitis.
Diagnosis: MRI or CT images can reveal any swelling of the brain or another condition that might be causing the symptoms, such as a tumor. A needle inserted into the lower back removes a small amount of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), the protective fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal column.
info-Symptoms: Headache, fever, confusion, stiff neck, vomiting
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, supported by blood tests, medical imaging, analysis of cerebrospinal fluid
info-Treatment: Antiviral medication, anticonvulsants, corticosteroids, artificial respiration

Name: Endocarditis
Causes: Endocarditis occurs when germs enter the bloodstream, travel to the heart, and attach to abnormal heart valves or damaged heart tissue. Certain types of bacteria cause most cases, but fungi or other microorganisms also may be responsible. The bacteria that can cause endocarditis can also enter the bloodstream through the needles used for tattooing or body piercing. Contaminated needles and syringes are a special concern for people who use illegal intravenous (IV) drugs, such as heroin or cocaine. Often, individuals who use these types of drugs don't have access to clean, unused needles or syringes.
Risk factors: The heart valves, which keep blood flowing in the correct direction, are gates at the chamber openings (for the tricuspid and mitral valves) and exits (for the pulmonary and aortic valves). The germs that cause infection tend to stick to and multiply on damaged or surgically implanted heart valves, or on endocardium that has a rough surface. If one were born with certain types of heart defects, such as an irregular heart or abnormal heart valves, the heart may be more susceptible to infection. Endocarditis can damage heart tissue and valves, increasing the risk of a future heart infection. Certain medical conditions, such as rheumatic fever or infection, can damage or scar one or more of the heart valves.
Diagnosis: In a transthoracic echocardiogram, sound waves directed at the heart from a wandlike device (transducer) held on the chest produce video images of the heart in motion. The doctor may use two different types of echocardiograms to help diagnose endocarditis.In a transthoracic echocardiogram, sound waves directed at the heart from a wandlike device (transducer) held on the chest produce video images of the heart in motion. This test can help the doctor look at the heart's structure and check it for any signs of infection or damage.Doctors may conduct another type of echocardiogram called a transesophogeal echocardiogram to get a closer look at the heart valves.

Name: Endometriosis
Symptoms: The primary symptom of endometriosis is pelvic pain, often associated with menstrual periods. Although many experience cramping during their menstrual periods, those with endometriosis typically describe menstrual pain that's far worse than usual. Endometriosis is sometimes mistaken for other conditions that can cause pelvic pain, such as pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) or ovarian cysts. It may be confused with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), a condition that causes bouts of diarrhea, constipation and abdominal cramping. One may experience fatigue, diarrhea, constipation, bloating or nausea, especially during menstrual periods.
Overview: Endometriosis occurs when bits of the tissue that lines the uterus (endometrium) grow on other pelvic organs, such as the ovaries or fallopian tubes. With endometriosis, the endometrial-like tissue acts as endometrial tissue would it thickens, breaks down and bleeds with each menstrual cycle. Surrounding tissue can become irritated, eventually developing scar tissue and adhesions abnormal bands of fibrous tissue that can cause pelvic tissues and organs to stick to each other.
Causes: In retrograde menstruation, menstrual blood containing endometrial cells flows back through the fallopian tubes and into the pelvic cavity instead of out of the body. Hormones such as estrogen may transform embryonic cells cells in the earliest stages of development into endometrial-like cell implants during puberty. After a surgery, such as a hysterectomy or C-section, endometrial cells may attach to a surgical incision. The blood vessels or tissue fluid (lymphatic) system may transport endometrial cells to other parts of the body. A problem with the immune system may make the body unable to recognize and destroy endometrial-like tissue that's growing outside the uterus.
Diagnosis: During a transvaginal ultrasound, the doctor or a medical technician inserts a wandlike device (transducer) into the vagina while one lie on the back on an exam table. In some cases, the doctor may refer one to a surgeon for a procedure that allows the surgeon to view inside the abdomen (laparoscopy). While one is under general anesthesia, the surgeon makes a tiny incision near the navel and inserts a slender viewing instrument (laparoscope), looking for signs of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. During a pelvic exam, the doctor manually feels (palpates) areas in the pelvis for abnormalities, such as cysts on the reproductive organs or scars behind the uterus. To capture the images, a device called a transducer is either pressed against the abdomen or inserted into the vagina (transvaginal ultrasound). A standard ultrasound imaging test won't definitively tell the doctor whether one has endometriosis, but it can identify cysts associated with endometriosis (endometriomas).
Remedies: If the pain persists or if finding a treatment that works takes some time, one can try measures at home to relieve the discomfort. Over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve), can help ease painful menstrual cramps.
info-Symptoms: Pelvic pain, infertility
info-Risk factors: Family history
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, medical imaging, tissue biopsy
info-Prevention: Combined birth control pills, exercise, avoiding alcohol and caffeine
info-Treatment: NSAIDs, continuous birth control pills, intrauterine device with progestogen, surgery

Name: End-stage renal disease
Diagnosis: To determine what stage kidney disease one has, the doctor performs a blood test to check the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). A discussion of the health history, A physical exam, Blood tests, Urine tests, Imaging tests, Removing a sample of kidney tissue (biopsy),
Remedies: Depending on the situation, kidney function and overall health, the dietitian may recommend that one: Avoid products with added salt. Lower the amount of sodium one eat each day by avoiding products with added salt, including many convenience foods, such as frozen dinners, canned soups and fast foods. Other foods with added salt include salty snack foods, canned vegetables, and processed meats and cheeses.
info-Symptoms: Early: NoneLater: Leg swelling, feeling tired, vomiting, loss of appetite, confusion
info-Causes: Diabetes, high blood pressure, glomerulonephritis, polycystic kidney disease
info-Treatment: Medications to manage blood pressure, blood sugar, and lower cholesterol, renal replacement therapy, kidney transplant

Name: Enlarged breasts in men ( gynecomastia )
Overview: With gynecomastia, tissue inside the breast glands grows. Gynecomastia (guy-nuh-koh-MAS-tee-uh) is an increase in the amount of breast gland tissue in boys or men, caused by an imbalance of the hormones estrogen and testosterone. Newborns, boys going through puberty and older men may develop gynecomastia as a result of normal changes in hormone levels, though other causes also exist.
Causes: The decrease can be caused by conditions that block the effects of testosterone, reduce testosterone or increase the estrogen level. Most people think of estrogen as an exclusively female hormone, but men also produce it though normally in small quantities. These include Plant oils, such as tea tree or lavender, used in shampoos, soaps or lotions have been associated with gynecomastia. Heart medications, such as digoxin (Lanoxin) and calcium channel blockers. Alcohol Amphetamines, used to treat attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder Marijuana Heroin Methadone (Methadose, Dolophine) Hypogonadism. Conditions that interfere with normal testosterone production, such as Klinefelter syndrome or pituitary insufficiency, can be associated with gynecomastia. Hormone changes that occur with normal aging can cause gynecomastia, especially in men who are overweight. Some tumors, such as those involving the testes, adrenal glands or pituitary gland, can produce hormones that alter the male-female hormone balance. When the body is deprived of adequate nutrition, testosterone levels drop while estrogen levels remain the same, causing a hormonal imbalance.
Diagnosis: The doctor will also do a physical examination that may include careful evaluation of the breast tissue, abdomen and genitals. Initial tests to determine the cause of the gynecomastia may include One may need further testing depending on the initial test results, including The doctor will want to be sure the breast swelling is gynecomastia and not another condition. Other conditions that can cause similar symptoms include Blood tests Mammograms Computerized tomography (CT) scans Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans Testicular ultrasounds Tissue biopsies Fatty breast tissue.
Medication: If enlarged breasts are significant and bothersome even after initial treatment or observation, the doctor may advise surgery. Two gynecomastia surgery options are: Tamoxifen (Soltamox) Aromatase inhibitors, such as anastrozole (Arimidex) Liposuction.

Name: Enlarged heart
Overview: As the heart weakens, such as in heart failure, it begins to enlarge, forcing the heart to work harder to pump blood to the rest of the body. An enlarged heart may be the result of a short-term stress on the body, such as pregnancy, or a medical condition, such as the weakening of the heart muscle, coronary artery disease, heart valve problems or abnormal heart rhythms.
Causes: A heart condition one is born with (congenital), damage from a heart attack or an abnormal heartbeat (arrhythmia) can cause the heart to enlarge. The heart may have to pump harder to deliver blood to the rest of the body, enlarging and thickening the muscle. High blood pressure can cause the left ventricle to enlarge, causing the heart muscle eventually to weaken. As it progresses, the heart may enlarge to try to pump more blood. High blood pressure in the artery that connects the heart and lungs (pulmonary hypertension). When a section of heart muscle dies, the heart has to pump harder to get adequate blood to the rest of the body, causing it to enlarge. Both an underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism) and an overactive thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism) can lead to heart problems, including an enlarged heart.
Risk factors: One may be at increased risk of developing an enlarged heart if one has any of the following risk factors: High blood pressure. The heart has four valves aortic, mitral, pulmonary and tricuspid that open and close to direct blood flow through the heart.
Diagnosis: If one has symptoms of a heart problem, the doctor will perform a physical exam and order tests to determine if the heart is enlarged and to find the cause of the condition. The doctor can use the results to see how efficiently the heart is pumping, determine which chambers of the heart are enlarged, look at the heart valves, look for evidence of previous heart attacks and determine if one has congenital heart disease. A stress test, also called an exercise stress test, provides information about how well the heart works during physical activity. An exercise stress test usually involves walking on a treadmill or riding a stationary bike while the heart rhythm, blood pressure and breathing are monitored. In a cardiac MRI, one lie on a table inside a long tubelike machine that uses a magnetic field and radio waves to produce signals that create images of the heart. In this procedure, a thin tube (catheter) is inserted in the groin and threaded through the blood vessels to the heart, where the doctor takes a small sample (biopsy) of the heart to be tested. If the heart is enlarged on an X-ray, other tests will usually be needed to find the cause. The doctor may order blood tests to check the levels of certain substances in the blood that may point to a heart problem.
Medication: For a certain type of enlarged heart (dilated cardiomyopathy), a pacemaker that coordinates the contractions between the left and right ventricles may be necessary. Diuretics to lower the amount of sodium and water in the body, which can help lower the pressure in the arteries and heart Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors to lower the blood pressure and improve the heart's pumping capability Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) to provide the benefits of ACE inhibitors for those who can't take ACE inhibitors Beta blockers to lower blood pressure and improve heart function Anticoagulants to reduce the risk of blood clots that could cause a heart attack or stroke Anti-arrhythmics to keep the heart beating with a normal rhythm Medical devices to regulate the heartbeat. Diuretics Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) Beta blockers Anticoagulants Anti-arrhythmics Medical devices to regulate the heartbeat.

Name: Entropion
Causes: Skin scarred by chemical burns, trauma or surgery can distort the normal curve of the eyelid. An eye infection called trachoma is common in many developing countries of Africa, Asia, Latin America, the Middle East and Pacific Islands. It can cause scarring of the inner eyelid, leading to entropion and even blindness. An irritation of the eye caused by dryness or inflammation can lead one to try to relieve the symptoms by rubbing the eyelids or squeezing them shut. This can lead to a spasm of the eyelid muscles and a rolling of the edge of the lid inward against the cornea (spastic entropion). When entropion is present at birth (congenital), it may be caused by an extra fold of skin on the eyelid that causes turned-in eyelashes.

Name: Eosinophilic esophagitis
Overview: Esophagitis is inflammation that damages the lining of the esophagus. This endoscopic image of eosinophilic esophagitis shows rings of abnormal tissue (esophageal rings) resulting from chronic inflammation. In eosinophilic esophagitis (e-o-sin-o-FILL-ik uh-sof-uh-JIE-tis), a type of white blood cell (eosinophil) builds up in the lining of the tube that connects the mouth to the stomach (esophagus).
Causes: The reaction may occur as follows: There has been a significant increase in numbers of people diagnosed with eosinophilic esophagitis in the past decade. However, studies now suggest the disease is becoming increasingly common, parallel to the increase in asthma and allergy. Inflammation can lead to scarring, narrowing and formation of excessive fibrous tissue in the lining of the esophagus.
Risk factors: People who live in a cold or dry climate are more likely than those in other climates to be diagnosed with eosinophilic esophagitis. One is more likely to be diagnosed between the spring and fall, probably because levels of pollen and other allergens are higher and people are more prone to be outdoors. If the family members have eosinophilic esophagitis, one has a greater chance of being diagnosed. If one has food or environmental allergies, asthma, atopic dermatitis or a chronic respiratory disease, one is more likely to be diagnosed with eosinophilic esophagitis. Originally, eosinophilic esophagitis was thought to be a childhood disease, but now it is known to be common in adults as well.
Diagnosis: Endoscopy involves inserting a long, flexible tube (endoscope) down the throat and into the esophagus. A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). The doctor will use a long narrow tube (endoscope) containing a light and tiny camera and insert it through the mouth down the esophagus. The doctor will inspect the lining of the esophagus for inflammation and swelling, horizontal rings, vertical furrows, narrowing (strictures), and white spots. If doctors suspect eosinophilic esophagitis, one may be given some additional tests to confirm the diagnosis and to begin to look for the sources of the allergic reaction (allergens).
Remedies: If one often have heartburn, these lifestyle changes may help reduce the frequency or severity of symptoms: Maintain a healthy weight. If one is overweight or obese, work to slowly lose weight no more than 1 or 2 pounds (0.5 to 1 kilogram) a week. Common triggers, such as fatty or fried foods, tomato sauce, alcohol, chocolate, mint, garlic, onion, and caffeine, may make heartburn worse.

Name: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis
Symptoms: Also known as EGPA, the syndrome tends to occur in three stages and gets progressively worse. Almost everyone with the condition has asthma, chronic sinusitis and elevated counts of white blood cells called eosinophils. Asthma usually begins five to nine years before the diagnosis of Churg-Strauss syndrome. Churg-Strauss syndrome is rare, and it's more likely that these symptoms have some other cause.
Overview: Churg-Strauss syndrome is a disorder marked by blood vessel inflammation. The disorder can also cause other problems, such as hay fever, rash, gastrointestinal bleeding, and pain and numbness in the hands and feet.
Causes: It's likely that a combination of genes and environmental factors, such as allergens or certain medications, triggers an overactive immune system response. Instead of protecting against invading bacteria and viruses, the immune system targets healthy tissue, causing widespread inflammation.
Diagnosis: The early signs and symptoms, such as asthma and sinusitis, tend to be fairly commonplace, so a diagnosis might not be made until the inflammation has caused serious damage to organs and nerves. The criteria are: To diagnose Churg-Strauss syndrome, the doctor is likely to request several tests, including Blood tests. When the immune system attacks the body's own cells, as happens in Churg-Strauss syndrome, it forms proteins called autoantibodies. A blood test can detect certain autoantibodies in the blood that can suggest, but not confirm, a diagnosis of Churg-Strauss syndrome. Most people diagnosed with Churg-Strauss syndrome have chronic, often severe asthma. If other tests suggest Churg-Strauss syndrome, one might have a small sample of tissue removed for examination under a microscope.
Treatment: There's no cure for Churg-Strauss syndrome, also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). But because high doses of corticosteroids can cause serious side effects, the doctor will decrease the dose gradually until one is taking the smallest amount that will keep the disease under control. Side effects of corticosteroids include bone loss, high blood sugar, weight gain, cataracts and hard-to-treat infections. Other people require another immunosuppressive drug, such as cyclophosphamide, azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran) or methotrexate (Trexall), to further reduce the body's immune reaction. Because these drugs impair the body's ability to fight infection and can cause other serious side effects, the condition will be closely monitored while one is taking them. Drugs such as the recently Food and Drug Administration-approved mepolizumab (Nucala), as well as benralizumab (Fasenra) and rituximab (Rituxan), alter the immune system's response and seem to improve symptoms and decrease the number of eosinophils. One can minimize these problems by taking the following steps: Here are some suggestions for coping with Churg-Strauss syndrome: If one has signs and symptoms common to Churg-Strauss syndrome, make an appointment with the doctor. If the primary care doctor suspects Churg-Strauss syndrome, he or she will likely refer one to a doctor who specializes in disorders that cause blood vessel inflammation (vasculitis), such as a rheumatologist or immunologist. Exercise can help one maintain a healthy weight, which is important when one is taking corticosteroid medications that can cause weight gain. Besides causing serious health problems, smoking also worsens problems one has and can increase side effects of medications.
Remedies: Exercise can help one maintain a healthy weight, which is important when one is taking corticosteroid medications that can cause weight gain. Besides causing serious health problems, smoking also worsens problems one has and can increase side effects of medications.
info-Symptoms: Fatigue, fever, weight loss, night sweats, abdominal pain, cough, joint pain, muscle pain, bleeding into tissues under the skin, a rash with hives, small bumps, or a general feeling of ill.
info-Risk factors: History of allergy, asthma and asthma-associated lung abnormalities (i.e., pulmonary infiltrates).
info-Diagnostic method: antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA); cluster of asthma, eosinophilia, mono- or polyneuropathy, nonfixed pulmonary infiltrates, abnormality of the paranasal sinuses, and extravascular eosinophilia.
info-Treatment: Suppress the activity of the immune system to alleviate inflammation.
info-Medication: Corticosteroid medications such as prednisone or methylprednisolone, and mepolizumab. Proliferation inhibitor for those with the presence of kidney or neurological disease.

Name: Ependymoma
Diagnosis: If it's suspected that one has a brain tumor, the doctor may recommend a number of tests and procedures, including Imaging tests. A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. Positron emission tomography (PET) may be used for brain imaging, but is generally not as useful for creating images of brain cancer as it is for other types of cancer. A stereotactic needle biopsy may be done for brain tumors in hard to reach areas or very sensitive areas within the brain that might be damaged by a more extensive operation. If it's suspected that the brain tumor may be a result of cancer that has spread from another area of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer originated.

Name: Epidermolysis bullosa
Overview: Junctional epidermolysis bullosa generally becomes apparent at birth and may be severe. Large, ulcerated blisters are common to junctional epidermolysis bullosa and can lead to infections and loss of body fluids. Epidermolysis bullosa (ep-ih-dur-MOL-uh-sis buhl-LOE-sah) is a group of rare diseases that cause fragile, blistering skin. Epidermolysis bullosa has no cure, though mild forms may improve with age.
Causes: In an autosomal dominant disorder, the abnormal gene is a dominant gene located on one of the nonsex chromosomes (autosomes). More severe forms of dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa can lead to rough, thickened skin, scarring, and disfigurement of the hands and feet. The disease gene may be passed on from one parent who has the disease (autosomal dominant inheritance).
Remedies: The doctor can also recommend products to help keep the affected areas moist, which helps promote heling and prevent infection. In general, take these steps: A varied, nutritious diet promotes growth and development in children and helps wounds heal. If blisters in the mouth or throat make it difficult for the child to eat, here are some suggestions: Wash the hands. About 30 minutes before a dressing change or other painful procedure, older children and adults may take a prescription-strength pain medication. If one notice redness, heat, pus or a red line leading from the blister, talk with the doctor about prescription antibiotics. For older children, serve nutritious, soft foods that are easy to swallow, such as vegetable soup and fruit smoothies.
Medication: The doctor may prescribe oral antibiotics if the wounds show signs of widespread infection (fever, weakness, swollen lymph glands). Options sometimes used for this condition include Working with a rehabilitation specialist (physical therapist, occupational therapist) can help ease the limitations on motion caused by scarring and contractures. To improve nutrition and help with weight gain, a feeding tube (gastrostomy tube) may be implanted to deliver food directly to the stomach.
info-Symptoms: Painful skin blisters
info-Treatment: Wound care, pain control, controlling infections, nutritional support

Name: Epididymitis
Overview: Epididymitis is an inflammation of the small, coiled tube at the back of the testicle (epididymis). Epididymitis (ep-ih-did-uh-MY-tis) is an inflammation of the coiled tube (epididymis) at the back of the testicle that stores and carries sperm.
Causes: Gonorrhea and chlamydia are the most common causes of epididymitis in young, sexually active men. Also, viral infections, such as the mumps virus, can result in epididymitis. This condition occurs when urine flows backward into the epididymis, possibly because of heavy lifting or straining. Rarely, epididymitis can be caused by tuberculosis infection.
info-Symptoms: Pain in the back of the testicle, swelling of the testicle, burning with urination, frequent urination
info-Causes: Gonorrhea, chlamydia, enteric bacteria, reflux of urine

Name: Epiglottitis
Symptoms: If one or someone one know suddenly has trouble breathing and swallowing, call the local emergency number or go to the nearest hospital emergency department. Try to keep the person quiet and upright, because this position may make it easier to breathe.
Overview: The throat includes the esophagus, windpipe (trachea), voice box (larynx), tonsils and epiglottis. Epiglottitis is a potentially life-threatening condition that occurs when the epiglottis a small cartilage lid that covers the windpipe swells, blocking the flow of air into the lungs. The most common cause of epiglottitis in children in the past was infection with Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), the same bacterium that causes pneumonia, meningitis and infections in the bloodstream.
Causes: In the past, a common cause of swelling and inflammation of the epiglottis and surrounding tissues was infection with Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) bacteria. It's possible to harbor Hib in the nose and throat without becoming sick though one still can spread the bacteria to others.
Diagnosis: If the medical team suspects epiglottitis, the first priority is to ensure that the or the child's airway is open and that enough oxygen is getting through. If oxygen saturation levels drop too low, one or the child may need help breathing. Using a flexible fiber-optic-lighted tube, the doctor may look down the or the child's throat to see what's causing the symptoms. Because of the danger of sudden breathing problems, children may have X-rays taken at their bedsides rather than in the radiology department but only after the airway is protected.
info-Symptoms: Trouble swallowing, drooling, changes to the voice, fever, increased breathing rate, stridor
info-Causes: H. influenzae type b, burns, trauma to the area
info-Diagnostic method: Medical imaging, looking at the epiglottis

Name: Epithelioid sarcoma
Diagnosis: Because there are so many different types of soft tissue sarcoma, it's important to determine the exact nature of each tumor so that the best treatments can be chosen. To evaluate the area of concern, the doctor might employ: If a soft tissue sarcoma is suspected, it's often best to seek care at a medical center that sees many people with this type of cancer. Options include In the lab, a doctor trained in analyzing body tissues (pathologist) examines the tissue sample for signs of cancer.

Name: Esophageal cancer
Overview: The esophagus is a muscular tube that connects the mouth and the stomach. Esophageal cancer is cancer that occurs in the esophagus a long, hollow tube that runs from the throat to the stomach.
Causes: Esophageal cancer occurs when cells in the esophagus develop changes (mutations) in their DNA. Adenocarcinoma is the most common form of esophageal cancer in the United States, and it affects primarily white men. Some rare forms of esophageal cancer include small cell carcinoma, sarcoma, lymphoma, melanoma and choriocarcinoma.
Diagnosis: A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). Tests and procedures used to diagnose esophageal cancer include Once a diagnosis of esophageal cancer is confirmed, the doctor may recommend additional tests to determine whether the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes or to other areas of the body. During endoscopy, the doctor passes a flexible tube equipped with a video lens (videoendoscope) down the throat and into the esophagus. The doctor may use a special scope passed down the throat into the esophagus (endoscope) to collect a sample of suspicious tissue (biopsy).
info-Symptoms: Difficulty swallowing, weight loss, hoarse voice, enlarged lymph nodes around the collarbone, vomiting blood, blood in the stool
info-Risk factors: Smoking tobacco, alcohol, very hot drinks, chewing betel nut, obesity, acid reflux

Name: Esophageal spasms
Overview: The esophagus is a muscular tube that connects the mouth and the stomach. Esophageal spasms are painful contractions within the muscular tube connecting the mouth and stomach (esophagus).
Causes: Esophageal spasms make it difficult for the muscles in the walls of the lower esophagus to coordinate in order to move food to the stomach. Although painful, this type of spasm also referred to as jackhammer esophagus may not cause regurgitation of food or liquids.
Diagnosis: Endoscopy involves inserting a long, flexible tube (endoscope) down the throat and into the esophagus. A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). A flexible tube (endoscope) that is passed down the throat allows the doctor to see the inside of the esophagus. The doctor may remove a tissue sample (biopsy) for testing to rule out other esophageal diseases.
Treatment: If the spasms are occasional, the doctor might recommend avoiding trigger foods or situations. If the spasms make it difficult to eat or drink, the doctor might recommend: To help one cope with occasional esophageal spasms, try to: One may be referred to a doctor who specializes in the digestive system (gastroenterologist). The doctor might recommend a proton pump inhibitor such as lansoprazole to treat GERD, or an antidepressant, such as trazodone or imipramine (Tofranil). Sildenafil (Revatio, Viagra), onobotulinumtoxin A (Botox) injections or calcium channel blockers, such as diltiazem (Cardizem CD, Tiazac, others), can reduce the severity of spasms. If medication doesn't work, the doctor might recommend a procedure that involves cutting the muscle at the lower end of the esophagus, to weaken esophageal contractions. Long-term studies of this approach aren't available, so myotomy generally isn't recommended for esophageal spasms.
Remedies: To help one cope with occasional esophageal spasms, try to: Avoid the triggers. Peppermint oil is a smooth-muscle relaxant and might help ease esophageal spasms.

Name: Esophagitis
Causes: If this valve opens when it shouldn't or doesn't close properly, the contents of the stomach may back up into the esophagus (gastroesophageal reflux). Drugs that have been linked to esophagitis include A bacterial, viral or fungal infection in tissues of the esophagus may cause esophagitis. Infectious esophagitis is relatively rare and occurs most often in people with poor immune system function, such as people with HIV/AIDS or cancer.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and therefore are factors in reflux esophagitis include the following: A number of foods may worsen symptoms of GERD or reflux esophagitis: Risk factors for eosinophilic esophagitis, or allergy-related esophagitis, may include Factors that may increase the risk of drug-induced esophagitis are generally related to issues that prevent quick and complete passage of a pill into the stomach. Eating immediately before going to bed Dietary factors such as excess alcohol, caffeine, chocolate and mint-flavored foods Excessively large and fatty meals Smoking Extra weight, including from pregnancy Tomato-based foods Citrus fruits Caffeine Alcohol Spicy foods Garlic and onions Chocolate Mint-flavored foods A history of certain allergic reactions, including allergic rhinitis, asthma and atopic dermatitis A family history of eosinophilic esophagitis Swallowing a pill with little or no water Taking drugs while lying down Taking drugs right before sleep, probably due in part to the production of less saliva and swallowing less during sleep Older age, possibly because of age-related changes to the muscles of the esophagus or a decreased production of saliva Large or oddly shaped pills
Diagnosis: A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). Doctors guide a long, thin tube equipped with a tiny camera (endoscope) down the throat and into the esophagus.
Remedies: Depending on the type of esophagitis one has, one may lessen symptoms or avoid recurring problems by following these steps: Avoid foods that may increase reflux. Avoid eating excessive amounts of foods that one know worsen the symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux. Avoid some pain relievers and antibiotics, as well as some other medications, if one has an enlarged left upper heart chamber (atrium) or after heart surgery. Avoid stooping or bending, especially soon after eating. Avoid stooping or bending, Avoid lying down after eating.

Name: Essential tremor
Symptoms: Essential tremor doesn't cause other health problems, but Parkinson's disease is associated with stooped posture, slow movement and shuffling gait. Parkinson's disease tremors usually start in the hands, and can affect the legs, chin and other parts of the body.
Risk factors: In an autosomal dominant disorder, the abnormal gene is a dominant gene located on one of the nonsex chromosomes (autosomes). A person with an autosomal dominant disorder in this case, the father has a 50% chance of having an affected child with one abnormal gene and a 50% chance of having an unaffected child with two normal genes. If one has a parent with a genetic mutation for essential tremor, one has a 50 percent chance of developing the disorder theself.
Diagnosis: To do this, the doctor may suggest the following tests: In a neurological examination, the doctor tests the nervous system functioning, including checking the: The blood and urine may be tested for several factors, including One test used to evaluate essential tremor involves having one draw a spiral. To evaluate the tremor itself, the doctor may ask one to: If the doctor is still unsure if the tremor is essential tremor or Parkinson's disease, he or she might order a dopamine transporter scan.
Remedies: Find ways to avoid writing with the hand affected by tremor, such as using online banking and debit cards instead of writing checks. Some people notice that their tremors improve slightly after they drink alcohol, but drinking isn't a good solution. Also, increasing amounts of alcohol eventually are needed to relieve tremors, which can lead to alcoholism. Stress and anxiety tend to make tremors worse, and being relaxed may improve tremors. Although one can't eliminate all stress from the life, one can change how one react to stressful situations using a range of relaxation techniques, such as massage or meditation.
Medication: Botox injections might be useful in treating some types of tremors, especially head and voice tremors. Therapists might suggest adaptive devices to reduce the effect of tremors on the daily activities, including Beta blockers. Normally used to treat high blood pressure, beta blockers such as propranolol (Inderal) help relieve tremors in some people. Epilepsy drugs, such as primidone (Mysoline), may be effective in people who don't respond to beta blockers.
info-Risk factors: Family history, exposure to particular toxins
info-Medication: Beta blockers, primidone, anti-epileptics, topiramate, gabapentin, levetiracetam, benzodiazepines

Name: Ewing sarcoma
Diagnosis: Imaging tests may include A biopsy procedure is used to collect a sample of suspicious cells for laboratory testing. Types of biopsy procedures used to diagnose Ewing sarcoma include Determining the type of biopsy needed and the specifics of how it should be performed requires careful planning by the medical team.
info-Symptoms: Swell and pain near the tumor
info-Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, surgery, stem cell transplant

Name: Exercise-induced asthma
Risk factors: Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction is more likely to occur in: Factors that may increase the risk of the condition or act as triggers include People with asthma. Cold air Dry air Air pollution Chlorine in swimming pools Chemicals used with ice rink resurfacing equipment Activities with extended periods of deep breathing, such as long-distance running, swimming or soccer
Diagnosis: Doctors typically order tests to assess the lung function and rule out other conditions that may be causing the symptoms. As an alternative to the exercise challenge, the doctor may use an inhalation test that simulates the conditions that would likely trigger exercise-induced bronchoconstriction. The doctor may order additional tests to rule out other conditions with symptoms similar to those of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.

Name: Eye focusing
Diagnosis: People with convergence insufficiency might have otherwise normal vision, so it's important to mention reading or learning concerns to the eye care provider. The examiner holds a small target, such as a printed card or penlight, in front of one and slowly moves it closer to one until either one has double vision or the examiner sees an eye drift outward. If one has any other vision problems, such as nearsightedness, the eye doctor might conduct tests to assess the degree of the problem.
Treatment: If convergence insufficiency isn't causing symptoms, one generally don't need treatment. But for people with symptoms, treatment with eye-focusing exercises can increase the eyes convergence ability. Treatment, which can take place in the office of a trained therapist or at the home, might include Recent studies indicate that office-based therapy with home reinforcement is the most effective treatment for convergence insufficiency. Treatment for convergence insufficiency might take three months or longer.

Name: Eyelid inflammation
Overview: Blepharitis is an inflammation along the edges of the eyelids. Blepharitis commonly occurs when tiny oil glands near the base of the eyelashes become clogged, causing irritation and redness.
Diagnosis: The doctor might use a special magnifying instrument to examine the eyelids and the eyes. In certain cases, the doctor might use a swab to collect a sample of the oil or crust that forms on the eyelid.
Treatment: Self-care measures, such as washing the eyes and using warm compresses, might be all that's needed for most cases of blepharitis. If self-care measures aren't enough, the doctor might suggest prescription treatments, including Medications that fight infection. If one don't respond to topical antibiotics, the doctor might suggest an oral antibiotic. If one don't respond to treatment, or if one has also lost eyelashes or only one eye is affected, the condition could be caused by a localized eyelid cancer. Blepharitis caused by seborrheic dermatitis, rosacea or other diseases might be controlled by treating the underlying disease.
Remedies: If one has blepharitis, follow this self-care remedy two to four times a day during flare-ups and once or twice a day after the condition is under control: In some cases, one might need to be more deliberate about cleaning the edge of the eyelids at the eyelashes. Firmly but gently massage the eyelids, using a clean washcloth or a clean finger. Immediately use a clean washcloth or cotton-tipped applicator moistened with warm water and a few drops of diluted baby shampoo or an over-the-counter eyelid cleanser to wash away oily debris or scales at the base of the eyelashes. In some cases, one might need to be more deliberate about cleaning the edge of the eyelids at the eyelashes.

Name: Eyestrain
Diagnosis: The eye doctor will ask one questions about factors that might be causing the symptoms. He or she will perform an eye exam, including testing the vision.
Treatment: For some people, wearing glasses that are prescribed for specific activities, such as for computer use or for reading, helps reduce eyestrain.
