This is especially important for children, who may not make the connection between extended viewing, eyestrain and the need to rest their eyes regularly. Some changes that may help prevent dry eyes include using a humidifier, adjusting the thermostat to reduce blowing air and avoiding smoke. Moving the chair to a different area may help reduce the amount of dry moving air on the eyes and face.
Remedies: If one work at a desk and use a computer, these self-care steps can help take some of the strain off the eyes. This is especially important for children, who may not make the connection between extended viewing, eyestrain and the need to rest their eyes regularly. Some changes that may help prevent dry eyes include using a humidifier, adjusting the thermostat to reduce blowing air and avoiding smoke. Many people blink less than usual when working at a computer, which can contribute to dry eyes.

Name: Factitious disorder
Symptoms: If one think a loved one may be exaggerating or faking health problems, it may help to attempt a gentle conversation about the concerns. Even when an actual medical or psychological condition exists, they may exaggerate symptoms to appear sicker or more impaired than is true. They may give loved ones, health care professionals or support groups a false medical history, such as claiming to have had cancer or AIDS.
Remedies: Along with professional treatment, these tips may help people who have factitious disorder: Stick to the treatment plan. If one feel an urge to harm theself or cause theself to become ill, talk honestly to the therapist or primary care doctor for better ways to cope with emotions. Have one trusted primary provider to manage the medical care, rather than visiting numerous doctors, specialists and surgeons. Resist urges to find a new doctor or to flee to a new town where medical professionals aren't aware of the background. Try to find someone one is able to confide in, share enjoyable times with and offer the own support to.

Name: Factor V Leiden
Overview: Factor V Leiden (FAK-tur five LIDE-n) is a mutation of one of the clotting factors in the blood. Women who carry the factor V Leiden mutation may have an increased tendency to develop blood clots during pregnancy or when taking the hormone estrogen. If one has factor V Leiden and have developed blood clots, anticoagulant medications can lessen the risk of developing additional blood clots and help one avoid potentially serious complications.
Risk factors: People who have inherited factor V Leiden from only one parent have a 5 percent chance of developing an abnormal blood clot by age 65. Inheriting the genetic mutation from both parents instead of just one can significantly increase the risk of abnormal blood clots. Oral contraceptives, hormone replacement therapy and pregnancy can make one more likely to develop blood clots. Surgeries or injuries such as broken bones can increase the risk of abnormal blood clots. Abnormal blood clots are more common in people who have blood types of A, B or AB compared with those with blood type O.
Treatment: However, the doctor might suggest that one take extra precautions to prevent blood clots if one has the factor V Leiden mutation and are going to have surgery. These precautions might include Some precautions to help reduce the risk of blood clots include A short course of blood thinners Leg wraps that inflate and deflate to keep blood moving in the legs Compression stockings Going for walks soon after surgery Keep the legs moving. Oral contraceptives or estrogen replacement therapy can increase the risk of blood clots on their own, so be sure to discuss the risks and the benefits of estrogen-containing medications with the doctor if one has factor V Leiden.
Remedies: Some precautions to help reduce the risk of blood clots include If the factor V Leiden requires one to take anticoagulant medication, here are some steps that might help one prevent injury and avoid excessive bleeding: Keep the legs moving. When the legs remain still for hours, the calf muscles don't contract, which normally helps blood circulate. Oral contraceptives or estrogen replacement therapy can increase the risk of blood clots on their own, so be sure to discuss the risks and the benefits of estrogen-containing medications with the doctor if one has factor V Leiden.

Name: Familial paroxysmal peritonitis
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of familial Mediterranean fever include Between attacks, one will likely feel normal. If one or the child experiences sudden worrisome signs or symptoms, such as shortness of breath or passing out, call 911 or emergency medical help.
Overview: Familial Mediterranean fever is a genetic autoinflammatory disorder that causes recurrent fevers and painful inflammation of the abdomen, lungs and joints. Familial Mediterranean fever is an inherited disorder that usually occurs in people of Mediterranean origin including those of North African, Jewish, Arab, Armenian, Turkish, Greek or Italian ancestry. While there's no cure for this disorder, one may be able to relieve signs and symptoms of familial Mediterranean fever or even prevent them altogether by sticking to the treatment plan.
Diagnosis: A family history of familial Mediterranean fever increases the likelihood of developing the condition because this genetic mutation is passed from parents to their children. Genetic testing may determine if the MEFV gene contains a mutation that is associated with familial Mediterranean fever. Genetic tests aren't advanced enough to test for every gene mutation that's linked to familial Mediterranean fever, so there is a possibility of false-negative results. For this reason, doctors typically don't use genetic tests as the sole method of diagnosing familial Mediterranean fever.
Treatment: Medications used to control signs and symptoms of familial Mediterranean fever include Learning that one or the child has a chronic illness, such as familial Mediterranean fever, can be upsetting and frustrating. Here are some tips that may help one cope: If one has signs and symptoms of familial Mediterranean fever, one may begin by seeing the family doctor. For people whose signs and symptoms aren't controlled with colchicine, medications that block a protein called interleukin-1, which is involved in inflammation, may be prescribed.

Name: FAP
Overview: Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is a rare, inherited condition caused by a defect in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene. Some people have a milder form of the condition, called attenuated familial adenomatous polyposis (AFAP). People with AFAP usually have fewer colon polyps (an average of 30) and develop cancer later in life.
Diagnosis: The doctor may suggest genetic testing if: Ruling out FAP spares at-risk children years of screening and emotional distress. For people with a genetic diagnosis of FAP or family members at risk who haven't had genetic testing, the American College of Gastroenterology recommends annual sigmoidoscopy, beginning at ages 10 to12 years. Two types of scopes are used to inspect the esophagus, stomach and upper part of the small intestine (duodenum and ampulla).

Name: Fetal alcohol syndrome
Causes: When one is pregnant and one drink alcohol: The more one drink while pregnant, the greater the risk to the unborn baby. The baby's brain, heart and blood vessels begin to develop in the early weeks of pregnancy, before one may know one is pregnant.
info-Symptoms: Abnormal appearance, short height, low body weight, small head size, poor coordination, behavior problems similar to those found in ADHD, learning problems
info-Treatment: Parent-child interaction therapy, efforts to modify child behavior, possibly medications
info-Prognosis: Varies depending on the victim. Life expectancy can range from 31 to 37. Average death age is 34.

Name: Fetal macrosomia
Symptoms: Having too much amniotic fluid the fluid that surrounds and protects a baby during pregnancy might be a sign that the baby is larger than average. The amount of amniotic fluid reflects the baby's urine output, and a larger baby produces more urine. During prenatal visits, the health care provider might measure the fundal height the distance from the top of the uterus to the pubic bone.
Overview: The term fetal macrosomia is used to describe a newborn who's much larger than average. A baby who is diagnosed as having fetal macrosomia weighs more than 8 pounds, 13 ounces (4,000 grams), regardless of his or her gestational age. Risks associated with fetal macrosomia increase greatly when birth weight is more than 9 pounds, 15 ounces (4,500 grams).
Risk factors: Many factors might increase the risk of fetal macrosomia some one can control, but others one can't. Fetal macrosomia is more likely if one had diabetes before pregnancy (pre-gestational diabetes) or if one develop diabetes during pregnancy (gestational diabetes). If the diabetes isn't well controlled, the baby is likely to have larger shoulders and greater amounts of body fat than would a baby whose mother doesn't have diabetes. Fetal macrosomia is more likely to be a result of maternal diabetes, obesity or weight gain during pregnancy than other causes. If these risk factors aren't present and fetal macrosomia is suspected, it's possible that the baby might have a rare medical condition that affects fetal growth. Up to the fifth pregnancy, the average birth weight for each successive pregnancy typically increases by up to about 4 ounces (113 grams). If the pregnancy continues by more than two weeks past the due date, the baby is at increased risk of fetal macrosomia.
Diagnosis: However, if one has risk factors for fetal macrosomia, the health care provider will likely use tests to monitor the baby's health and development while one is pregnant, such as: Ultrasound. Toward the end of the third trimester, the health care provider or another member of the health care team might do an ultrasound to take measurements of parts of the baby's body, such as the head, abdomen and femur. If the health care provider suspects fetal macrosomia, he or she might perform antenatal testing, such as a nonstress test or a fetal biophysical profile, to monitor the baby's well-being. A fetal biophysical profile combines nonstress testing with ultrasound to monitor the baby's movement, tone, breathing and volume of amniotic fluid. If the baby's excess growth is thought to be the result of a maternal condition, the health care provider might recommend antenatal testing starting as early as week 32 of pregnancy.
Treatment: If one had diabetes before pregnancy or one develop gestational diabetes and the health care provider estimates that the baby weighs 9 pounds, 15 ounces (4,500 grams) or more, a C-section might be the safest way to deliver the baby. If one don't have pre-gestational or gestational diabetes and the health care provider estimates that the baby weighs 11 pounds (5,000 grams) or more, a C-section might be recommended.

Name: Fever
Symptoms: Ear or forehead thermometers, although convenient, provide less accurate temperature measurements. In infants, doctors generally recommend taking a temperature with a rectal thermometer.
Overview: A fever is a temporary increase in the body temperature, often due to an illness. For an adult, a fever may be uncomfortable, but usually isn't a cause for concern unless it reaches 103 F (39.4 C) or higher.
Remedies: One can try a number of things to make theself or the child more comfortable during a fever: Drink plenty of fluids. Fever can cause fluid loss and dehydration, so drink water, juices or broth.
info-Symptoms: Initially: shivering, feeling cold, chillsLater: flushed, sweating
info-Causes: Virus, bacteria, increase in the body's temperature set point
info-Diagnostic method: Temperature > between 37.2 and 38.3Â Â°C (99.0 and 100.9Â Â°F)
info-Treatment: Based on underlying cause, not required for fever itself

Name: Fever blister
Symptoms: A cold sore usually passes through several stages: Signs and symptoms vary, depending on whether this is the first outbreak or a recurrence. The first time one has a cold sore, symptoms may not start for up to 20 days after one were first exposed to the virus. The sores can last several days, and the blisters can take two to three weeks to heal completely. Many people feel itching, burning or tingling around the lips for a day or so before a small, hard, painful spot appears and blisters erupt. The small blisters may merge and then burst, leaving shallow open sores that ooze and crust over.
Overview: Cold sores, often called fever blisters, are clustered, small, fluid-filled blisters. They're usually caused by herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), and less commonly herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2).
Causes: Cold sores are most contagious when one has oozing blisters because the virus easily spreads through contact with infected body fluids. Many people who are infected with the virus that causes cold sores never develop signs and symptoms. The problem is people can spread the herpes virus whether they develop cold sores or not. Herpes virus spreads through physical contact like kissing, sharing a toothbrush even sharing a drinking glass or through sexual contact.
Treatment: The over-the-counter cold sore ointment docosanol (Abreva) may shorten the healing time of a cold sore. To ease the discomfort of a cold sore: Although study results have been mixed, alternative medicine treatments for cold sores include Cold sores generally clear up without treatment in two to four weeks. Make an appointment with the family doctor if the cold sores: .Acyclovir (Zovirax) Valacyclovir (Valtrex) Famciclovir Penciclovir (Denavir) Try other cold sore remedies. A cold, damp cloth may reduce redness, help remove crusting and promote healing. If the cold sores are triggered by stress, one might want to try relaxation techniques, such as lemon balm extract, deep-breathing exercises and meditation.
Remedies: The over-the-counter cold sore ointment docosanol (Abreva) may shorten the healing time of a cold sore. A cold, damp cloth may reduce redness, help remove crusting and promote healing.
info-Symptoms: Burning pain followed by small blisters or sores
info-Causes: Typically herpes simplex virus type 1 (direct contact)
info-Treatment: Zinc oxide, anesthetic, or antiviral cream, antivirals by mouth

Name: Fibroadenoma
Causes: The cause of fibroadenomas is unknown, but they might be related to reproductive hormones. These can contain changes, such as an overgrowth of cells (hyperplasia) that can grow rapidly. These fibroadenomas can grow large, but most shrink over time, and some disappear. Although usually benign, some phyllodes tumors can become cancerous (malignant).
Diagnosis: The doctor might recommend a breast ultrasound in addition to a mammogram to evaluate a breast lump if one has dense breast tissue. For women younger than 30 who have a breast lump, the doctor likely will order a breast ultrasound first to evaluate the lump. If a mammogram indicates that one has a breast lump or other abnormality, a breast ultrasound might be used to further assess the lump. During fine-needle aspiration, a special needle is inserted into a breast lump, and any fluid is removed (aspirated). Through a thin needle inserted into the breast, the doctor attempts to withdraw the contents of the breast lump.

Name: Fibrocystic breasts
Overview: Fibrocystic breast changes lead to the development of fluid-filled round or oval sacs (cysts) and more prominent scar-like (fibrous) tissue, which can make breasts feel tender, lumpy or ropy. In fact, medical professionals have stopped using the term fibrocystic breast disease and now simply refer to fibrocystic breasts or fibrocystic breast changes because having fibrocystic breasts isn't really a disease. Although many women with fibrocystic breasts don't have symptoms, some women experience breast pain, tenderness and lumpiness especially in the upper, outer area of the breasts.
Causes: The exact cause of fibrocystic breast changes isn't known, but experts suspect that reproductive hormones especially estrogen play a role. Fluctuating hormone levels during the menstrual cycle can cause breast discomfort and areas of lumpy breast tissue that feel tender, sore and swollen.
Diagnosis: If the doctor finds a new lump and suspects fibrocystic changes, one may come back a few weeks later, after the menstrual period, to have another breast exam. If the doctor detects a breast lump or prominent thickening in the breast tissue, one need a diagnostic mammogram an X-ray exam that focuses on a specific area of concern in the breast. Ultrasound is better for evaluating a younger woman's dense breast tissue tissue tightly packed with lobules, ducts and connective tissue (stroma). For a breast lump that feels a lot like a cyst, the doctor may try fine-needle aspiration to see if fluid can be withdrawn from the lump. If a diagnostic mammogram and ultrasound are normal, but the doctor still has concerns about a breast lump, one may be referred to a breast surgeon to determine whether one need a surgical breast biopsy. If a suspicious area is detected during an imaging exam, the radiologist may recommend an ultrasound-guided breast biopsy or a sterotactic biopsy, which uses mammography to pinpoint the exact location for the biopsy.
Treatment: Severe pain or large, painful cysts associated with fibrocystic breasts may warrant treatment. Rarely, surgery may be needed to remove a persistent cyst-like lump that doesn't resolve after repeated aspiration and careful monitoring or has features that concern the doctor during a clinical exam.

Name: Fibromuscular dysplasia
Causes: If someone in the family has fibromuscular dysplasia, one might get the condition, too. Or, one may never get fibromuscular dysplasia at all. Women have fibromuscular dysplasia more often than men do, so researchers think hormones may play a role in the development of the disease. Fibromuscular dysplasia is not linked to a woman's use of birth control pills, number of pregnancies, or age when they gave birth. A lack of oxygen to the arteries or the use of certain medications or tobacco can cause the arteries to develop abnormally, leading to reduced blood flow.
Risk factors: Women have a much greater risk of fibromuscular dysplasia than do men. People who smoke appear to have an increased risk of developing fibromuscular dysplasia. For those already diagnosed with the disease, smoking increases the risk for more serious fibromuscular dysplasia.
Diagnosis: Because fibromuscular dysplasia may not cause any symptoms, it's unlikely the doctor would specifically check for this condition. If someone in the family has or had fibromuscular dysplasia or aneurysm, the doctor may recommend checking one for fibromuscular dysplasia, too. The doctor will perform a physical exam and order blood tests, including blood sugar and cholesterol levels, to check for signs of atherosclerosis, another condition that can narrow the arteries. Once one has been diagnosed with fibromuscular dysplasia, the doctor may repeat imaging tests from time to time to see if the signs and symptoms change or if the condition is getting worse. During this commonly used test for fibromuscular dysplasia, a thin tube (catheter) is inserted into one of the arteries and moved until it reaches the location the doctor wants to examine.

Name: Fibromyalgia
Symptoms: Symptoms of fibromyalgia include Fibromyalgia often co-exists with other painful conditions, such as: Widespread pain. People with fibromyalgia often awaken tired, even though they report sleeping for long periods of time. Sleep is often disrupted by pain, and many patients with fibromyalgia have other sleep disorders, such as restless legs syndrome and sleep apnea.
Overview: Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. Many people who have fibromyalgia also have tension headaches, temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders, irritable bowel syndrome, anxiety and depression.
Causes: Doctors don't know what causes fibromyalgia, but it most likely involves a variety of factors working together. These may include Researchers believe repeated nerve stimulation causes the brains of people with fibromyalgia to change. Because fibromyalgia tends to run in families, there may be certain genetic mutations that may make one more susceptible to developing the disorder. Fibromyalgia can sometimes be triggered by a physical trauma, such as a car accident.
Risk factors: One may be more likely to develop fibromyalgia if a relative also has the condition. If one has osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis or lupus, one may be more likely to develop fibromyalgia.
Remedies: Try stress management techniques, such as deep-breathing exercises or meditation. Because fatigue is one of the main characteristics of fibromyalgia, getting sufficient sleep is essential. In addition to allotting enough time for sleep, practice good sleep habits, such as going to bed and getting up at the same time each day and limiting daytime napping. Appropriate exercises may include walking, swimming, biking and water aerobics. Stretching, good posture and relaxation exercises also are helpful. If one do too much on the good days, one may have more bad days.
Medication: Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve, others) may be helpful. Duloxetine (Cymbalta) and milnacipran (Savella) may help ease the pain and fatigue associated with fibromyalgia. Gabapentin (Neurontin) is sometimes helpful in reducing fibromyalgia symptoms, while pregabalin (Lyrica) was the first drug approved by the Food and Drug Administration to treat fibromyalgia.
info-Symptoms: Widespread pain, feeling tired, sleep problems
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms after ruling out other potential causes
info-Treatment: Sufficient sleep and exercise, healthy diet

Name: Fibrosis , cystic
Symptoms: In the U.S. because of newborn screening, cystic fibrosis can be diagnosed within the first month of life, before symptoms develop. Cystic fibrosis signs and symptoms vary, depending on the severity of the disease.
Overview: In cystic fibrosis, the airways fill with thick, sticky mucus, making it difficult to breathe. Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an inherited disorder that causes severe damage to the lungs, digestive system and other organs in the body. Although cystic fibrosis is progressive and requires daily care, people with CF are usually able to attend school and work.
Diagnosis: To diagnose cystic fibrosis, doctors typically do a physical exam, review the symptoms and conduct several tests. For that reason, other tests may be needed to confirm a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. To evaluate if an infant has cystic fibrosis, doctors may also conduct a sweat test once the infant is at least 2 weeks old. The doctor may suggest genetic and sweat tests for CF if one has recurring bouts of an inflamed pancreas, nasal polyps, chronic sinus or lung infections, bronchiectasis, or male infertility.
Remedies: Cystic fibrosis can cause malnourishment because the enzymes needed for digestion can't reach the small intestine, preventing food from being absorbed. The doctor may recommend: In addition to receiving other usual childhood vaccines, people with cystic fibrosis should have the annual flu vaccine and any other vaccines their doctors recommend, such as the vaccine to prevent pneumonia. Because people with cystic fibrosis are living longer, maintaining good cardiovascular fitness for a healthy life is important. Secondhand smoke is harmful for everyone, but especially for people with cystic fibrosis, as is air pollution. Pancreatic enzyme capsules with every meal and snack Medications to suppress acid production Supplemental high-calorie nutrition Special fat-soluble vitamins Extra fiber to prevent intestinal blockage Extra salt, especially during hot weather or before exercising Adequate water intake, especially during hot weather Make sure to attend the regular follow-up appointments.
Medication: The FDA has approved these medications for treating CF in people with one or more mutations in the CFTR gene: Tim Myer has lived with cystic fibrosis (CF) his whole life. Medications that target gene mutations, including a new medication that combines three drugs to treat the most common genetic mutation causing CF and is considered a major achievement in treatment Antibiotics to treat and prevent lung infections Anti-inflammatory medications to lessen swelling in the airways in the lungs Mucus-thinning drugs, such as hypertonic saline, to help one cough up the mucus, which can improve lung function Inhaled medications called bronchodilators that can help keep the airways open by relaxing the muscles around the bronchial tubes Oral pancreatic enzymes to help the digestive tract absorb nutrients Stool softeners to prevent constipation or bowel obstruction Acid-reducing medications to help pancreatic enzymes work better Specific drugs for diabetes or liver disease, when appropriate The newest combination medication containing elexacaftor, ivacaftor and tezacaftor (Trikafta) is approved for people age 12 years and older and considered a breakthrough by many experts.

Name: Fibrous dysplasia
Overview: Fibrous dysplasia is an uncommon bone disorder in which scar-like (fibrous) tissue develops in place of normal bone. In most cases, fibrous dysplasia occurs at a single site in one bone, but can occur at multiple sites in multiple bones.
Diagnosis: While bone appears solid in an X-ray, a fibrous dysplasia lesion has a relative distinct appearance often described as ground glass. When the body is scanned with a specialized camera, the images can help a doctor identify multiple fibrous dysplasia lesions.
info-Symptoms: Bone pain, bone deformities, local swelling
info-Usual onset: Adolescence or early adulthood (monostotic), before age 10 (polyostotic)

Name: Floaters
Symptoms: And that can cause blindness, which is why it's especially important to have a dilated eye exam within days of noticing new floaters or changes in vision. Most eye floaters don't require treatment, but the eye doctor likely will recommend regular eye exams to ensure the condition doesn't worsen.
Overview: As one age, the vitreous a jelly-like material inside the eyes becomes more liquid. Most eye floaters are caused by age-related changes that occur as the jelly-like substance (vitreous) inside the eyes becomes more liquid. If one notice a sudden increase in eye floaters, contact an eye specialist immediately especially if one also see light flashes or lose the peripheral vision.
Causes: Eye floaters may be caused by the normal aging process or as a result from other diseases or conditions: Age-related eye changes. As one age, the vitreous, or jelly-like substance filling the eyeballs and helping them to maintain their round shape, changes. Over time, the vitreous partially liquefies a process that causes it to pull away from the eyeball's interior surface. This debris blocks some of the light passing through the eye, casting tiny shadows on the retina that are seen as floaters. Certain vitreoretinal surgeries add silicone oil bubbles into the vitreous that can also be seen as floaters.
Treatment: If the eye floaters impair the vision, which happens rarely, one and the eye doctor may consider treatment. Options may include If one is concerned about eye floaters, make an appointment with a doctor who specializes in eye disorders (optometrist or ophthalmologist). An ophthalmologist aims a special laser at the floaters in the vitreous, which may break them up and make them less noticeable.

Name: Floor of the mouth cancer
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose floor of the mouth cancer may include Thorough physical examination. Imaging tests help the doctor determine the extent of the cancer and whether it may have spread. Tests may include a CT, MRI and positron emission tomography (PET).
Treatment: The type of surgery used to treat floor of the mouth cancer depends on the size, type, location and depth of the tumor spread. If the tumor has spread beyond the floor of the mouth, nearby lymph nodes may need to be removed and examined to determine how far the cancer has spread. Radiation therapy uses beams of intense energy, such as X-rays and protons, to kill cancer cells. Radiation may be used alone to treat small floor of the mouth cancers or it may be used after surgery to kill any cancer cells that might remain. For people with floor of the mouth cancer, chemotherapy is often used after surgery to kill any cancer cells that might remain. In this therapy, the doctor will use a medication to make the cancer cells vulnerable to high-intensity light energy, such as from lasers. After the medication has been absorbed by the target tissue, the doctor will expose the cancer cells to a specific wavelength and energy of light that activates the drug and destroys the cancerous or precancerous cells. Depending on the size, location and spread of the cancer, some people may need reconstructive surgery to restore mouth function. Rehabilitation specialists in speech therapy, swallowing therapy, dietetics, physical therapy and occupational therapy help with rehabilitation that may be necessary after surgery or radiation therapy.

Name: Food allergy
Causes: Also known as oral allergy syndrome, pollen-food allergy syndrome affects many people who have hay fever. In this condition, certain fresh fruits and vegetables or nuts and spices can trigger an allergic reaction that causes the mouth to tingle or itch. Proteins in certain fruits, vegetables, nuts and spices cause the reaction because they're similar to allergy-causing proteins found in certain pollens. When one cook foods that trigger pollen-food allergy syndrome, the symptoms may be less severe. This following table shows the specific fruits, vegetables, nuts and spices that can cause pollen-food allergy syndrome in people who are allergic to different pollens. Depending on the type of food intolerance one has, one may be able to eat small amounts of problem foods without a reaction. By contrast, if one has a true food allergy, even a tiny amount of food may trigger an allergic reaction. Like a food allergy, it does involve an immune system response, but it's a unique reaction that's more complex than a simple food allergy.
Risk factors: As one grow older, the digestive system matures and the body is less likely to absorb food or food components that trigger allergies. One is at increased risk of food allergies if asthma, eczema, hives or allergies such as hay fever are common in the family. If one is already allergic to one food, one may be at increased risk of becoming allergic to another. Similarly, if one has other types of allergic reactions, such as hay fever or eczema, the risk of having a food allergy is greater.
Diagnosis: In this test, a small amount of the suspected food is placed on the skin of the forearm or back. Keep in mind, a positive reaction to this test alone isn't enough to confirm a food allergy. A blood test can measure the immune system's response to particular foods by measuring the allergy-related antibody known as immunoglobulin E (IgE). For this test, a blood sample taken in the doctor's office is sent to a medical laboratory, where different foods can be tested. Also, if one has had a severe reaction to a food in the past, an elimination diet may not be safe. Give the doctor a detailed history of the symptoms which foods, and how much, seem to cause problems. During this test, done in the doctor's office, one will be given small but increasing amounts of the food suspected of causing the symptoms. If one don't have a reaction during this test, one may be able to include this food in the diet again.
Treatment: For a minor allergic reaction, over-the-counter or prescribed antihistamines may help reduce symptoms. For a severe allergic reaction, one may need an emergency injection of epinephrine and a trip to the emergency room. For a minor allergic reaction, For a severe allergic reaction, Be sure one know how to use the autoinjector.
Remedies: Read food labels carefully to avoid the most common sources of food allergens: milk, eggs, peanuts, tree nuts, fish, shellfish, soy and wheat. It's also important to let caregivers know what steps they can take to prevent a reaction in the first place, such as careful hand-washing and cleaning any surfaces that might have come in contact with the allergy-causing food.
info-Symptoms: Itchiness, swelling of the tongue, vomiting, diarrhea, hives, trouble breathing, low blood pressure
info-Usual onset: Minutes to several hours of exposure
info-Risk factors: Family history, vitamin D deficiency, obesity, high levels of cleanliness
info-Diagnostic method: Based on a medical history, elimination diet, skin prick test, oral food challenge
info-Treatment: Avoiding the food in question, having a plan if exposure occurs, medical alert jewelry

Name: Food allergy , egg
Symptoms: Anaphylaxis signs and symptoms include Discuss with the doctor any reaction no matter how mild one or the child has to eggs. The severity of egg allergy reactions can vary each time one occurs, so even if a past reaction was mild, the next one could be more serious. If one or the child has signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis, seek immediate emergency treatment and use an autoinjector if one has been prescribed.
Risk factors: Children with this type of skin reaction are much more likely to develop a food allergy than are children who don't have skin problems. One is at increased risk of a food allergy if one or both of the parents have asthma, food allergy or another type of allergy such as hay fever, hives or eczema.
Diagnosis: In many cases, what seems to be an egg allergy is actually caused by food intolerance, which is generally less serious than food allergy and doesn't involve the immune system. If one or the child has egg allergy, a raised bump (hive) may develop at the test location. The or the child's doctor may have one keep a detailed diary of foods eaten and may ask one to eliminate eggs or other foods from the diet one at a time to see whether symptoms improve.

Name: Food-borne illness
Overview: Food poisoning, also called foodborne illness, is illness caused by eating contaminated food. Infectious organisms including bacteria, viruses and parasites or their toxins are the most common causes of food poisoning. Food poisoning symptoms, which can start within hours of eating contaminated food, often include nausea, vomiting or diarrhea.
Risk factors: As one get older, the immune system may not respond as quickly and as effectively to infectious organisms as when one were younger. During pregnancy, changes in metabolism and circulation may increase the risk of food poisoning. Having a chronic condition such as diabetes, liver disease or AIDS or receiving chemotherapy or radiation therapy for cancer reduces the immune response.
Treatment: Treatment for food poisoning typically depends on the source of the illness, if known, and the severity of the symptoms. For most people, the illness resolves without treatment within a few days, though some types of food poisoning may last longer. The doctor may prescribe antibiotics if one has a certain kind of bacterial food poisoning and the symptoms are severe. During pregnancy, prompt antibiotic treatment may help keep the infection from affecting the baby. To help keep theself more comfortable and prevent dehydration while one recover, try the following: If one or the child needs to see a doctor, one will likely see the primary care provider first. Fluids and electrolytes minerals such as sodium, potassium and calcium that maintain the balance of fluids in the body lost to persistent diarrhea need to be replaced. Some children and adults with persistent diarrhea or vomiting may need hospitalization, where they can receive salts and fluids through a vein (intravenously), to prevent or treat dehydration.
Remedies: To help keep theself more comfortable and prevent dehydration while one recover, try the following: Let the stomach settle. One might also try drinking clear soda, clear broth or noncaffeinated sports drinks. Gradually begin to eat bland, low-fat, easy-to-digest foods, such as soda crackers, toast, gelatin, bananas and rice. These include dairy products, caffeine, alcohol, nicotine, and fatty or highly seasoned foods.

Name: Foot drop
Causes: The most common cause of foot drop is compression of a nerve in the leg that controls the muscles involved in lifting the foot (peroneal nerve). This nerve can also be injured during hip or knee replacement surgery, which may cause foot drop. Disorders that affect the spinal cord or brain such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), multiple sclerosis or stroke may cause foot drop.
Diagnosis: Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies measure electrical activity in the muscles and nerves. This technology, which uses sound waves to create images of internal structures, can check for cysts or tumors on the nerve or show swelling on the nerve from compression.

Name: Foot fracture
Overview: A fall or blow to the ankle can break one or more of the three bones in the ankle joint the fibula, the tibia and the talus. A severely broken foot may require surgery to implant plates, rods or screws into the broken bone to maintain proper position during healing.
Causes: The most common causes of a broken foot include Car accidents. The crushing injuries common in car accidents may cause breaks that require surgical repair.
Risk factors: The stresses, direct blows and twisting injuries that occur in sports such as basketball, football, gymnastics, tennis and soccer can causes foot fractures. Improper training techniques, such as not warming up and stretching, also can cause foot injuries. Whether one is a trained athlete or someone who's just started exercising, suddenly boosting the frequency or duration of the exercise sessions can increase the risk of a stress fracture. Certain work environments, such as a construction site, put one at risk of falling from a height or dropping something heavy on the foot.
Diagnosis: The technician may need to take X-rays from several different angles so that the bone images won't overlap too much. CT scans can reveal more detail about the bone and the soft tissues that surround it, which may help the doctor determine the best treatment. This imaging helps to show ligaments and bones and can identify fractures not seen on X-rays.
Medication: Minor foot fractures may only need a removable brace, boot or shoe with a stiff sole. If one has a displaced fracture, meaning the two ends of the fracture are not aligned, the doctor may need to manipulate the pieces back into their proper positions a process called reduction. Depending on the amount of pain and swelling one has, one may need a muscle relaxant, a sedative or even a general anesthetic before this procedure. In some cases, an orthopedic surgeon may need to use pins, plates or screws to maintain proper position of the bones during healing.

Name: Fracture , arm
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms include If one has enough pain in the arm that one can't use it normally, see a doctor right away. Delays in diagnosis and treatment of a broken arm, especially for children, who heal faster than adults do, can lead to poor healing.
Overview: The arm is made up of three bones: the upper arm bone (humerus) and two forearm bones (the ulna and the radius). A broken arm involves one or more of the three bones in the arm the ulna, radius and humerus. A more complicated break might require surgery to realign the broken bone and to implant wires, plates, nails or screws to keep the bone in place during healing.
Causes: Common causes for a broken arm include Falls. Falling onto an outstretched hand or elbow is the most common cause of a broken arm. Direct blows and injuries on the field or court cause all types of arm fractures. Any of the arm bones can break during a car accident, bike accident or other direct trauma. In children, a broken arm might be the result of child abuse.
Treatment: The broken bone pierces the skin, a serious condition that requires immediate, aggressive treatment to decrease the risk of infection. Most broken bones in children are greenstick fractures because children's bones are softer and more flexible than are those of adults. One side of the bone is compressed, which causes the other side to bend (buckle).
Medication: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs can help with pain but might also hamper bone healing, especially if used long term. After the cast or sling is removed, the doctor might recommend additional rehabilitation exercises or physical therapy to restore muscle strength, joint motion and flexibility.

Name: Frontal lobe seizures
Overview: Each side of the brain contains four lobes. Frontal lobe seizures are a common form of epilepsy, a neurological disorder in which clusters of brain cells send abnormal signals and cause seizures. Abnormal brain tissue, infection, injury, stroke, tumors or other conditions can also cause frontal lobe seizures. Because the frontal lobe is large and has important functions, frontal lobe seizures can produce unusual symptoms that can appear to be related to psychiatric problems or a sleep disorder. Medications usually can control frontal lobe seizures, but surgery or an electrical stimulation device might be options if anti-epileptic drugs aren't effective.
Diagnosis: Brain imaging, usually MRI, might reveal the source of frontal lobe seizures. EEGs are often helpful in diagnosing some types of epilepsy, but results can be normal in frontal lobe epilepsy.

Name: Frostbite
Symptoms: Frostnip (2) is mild frostbite that irritates the skin, causing redness and a cold feeling followed by numbness. With superficial frostbite (3), the skin feels warm, a sign of serious skin involvement. With deep frostbite (4), one may experience numbness. Frostnip, a mild form of frostbite, irritates the skin, causing redness and a cold feeling followed by numbness. Because of skin numbness, one may not realize one has frostbite until someone else points it out. If one treat frostbite with rewarming at this stage, the surface of the skin may appear mottled. The skin turns white or bluish gray and one may experience numbness, losing all sensation of cold, pain or discomfort in the affected area.
Causes: Risk increases as air temperature falls below 5 F (minus 15 C), even with low wind speeds. In wind chill of minus 16.6 F (minus 27 C), frostbite can occur on exposed skin in less than 30 minutes.
Diagnosis: The diagnosis of frostbite is usually made based on the signs and symptoms, the appearance of the skin, and a review of recent activities in which one were exposed to cold. The doctor may conduct tests, such as an X-ray, a bone scan or an MRI. As winter drags on and temperatures drop way down, the risk of cold-related injury like frostbite can go way up. We tend to see frostbite, for example, when the temperature is 5 degrees Fahrenheit with minimal windchill, Dr. Kakar explains. If the windchill drops below negative 15 degrees Fahrenheit, not unheard of in the northern half of the U.S. frostbite can set in within half an hour. The most vulnerable areas of frostbite are the nose, ears, fingers and toes. Initially with the milder forms, one can get some pain and some numbness of the tips, but the skin can change its color, Dr. Kakar says. Those most at risk are certain patients with diabetes, patients who have previous history of frostbite are prone to it, the elderly or the very young children, and also, for example, if one is dehydrated, he says.
Treatment: For all other frostbite, after appropriate first aid and assessment for hypothermia, treatment may involve rewarming, medications, wound care, surgery and various therapies, depending on the severity of the injury. Once the skin thaws, the doctor may loosely wrap the area with sterile sheets, towels or dressings to protect the skin. To heal properly, frostbitten skin needs to be free of damaged, dead or infected tissue. To better distinguish between healthy and dead tissue, the doctor may wait one to three months before removing damaged tissue. Soaking in a whirlpool bath (hydrotherapy) can aid healing by keeping skin clean and naturally removing dead tissue. If the skin or blisters appear infected, the doctor may prescribe oral antibiotics. One may receive an intravenous injection (IV) of a drug that helps restore blood flow (thrombolytic), such as tissue plasminogen activator (TPA). A variety of wound care techniques may be used, depending on the extent of injury. People who have experienced severe frostbite may in time need surgery or amputation to remove dead or decaying tissue.
Remedies: To care for the skin after frostbite: Take all medications antibiotics or pain medicine as prescribed by the doctor. For milder cases of frostbite, take over-the-counter ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) to reduce pain and inflammation. For superficial frostbite that has been rewarmed, some people find it soothing to apply aloe vera gel or lotion to the affected area several times a day.
info-Symptoms: Numbness, feeling cold, clumsiness, pale color
info-Risk factors: Alcohol, smoking, mental health problems, certain medications, prior cold injury
info-Prevention: Avoid cold, wear proper clothing, maintain hydration and nutrition, stay active without becoming exhausted

Name: Frozen shoulder
Symptoms: Frozen shoulder typically develops slowly, and in three stages. Any movement of the shoulder causes pain, and the shoulder's range of motion starts to become limited.
Diagnosis: During the physical exam, the doctor may ask one to move in certain ways to check for pain and evaluate the range of motion (active range of motion). The doctor might then ask one to relax the muscles while he or she moves the arm (passive range of motion). In some cases, the doctor might inject the shoulder with a numbing medicine (anesthetic) to determine the passive and active range of motion.
Medication: Over-the-counter pain relievers, such as aspirin and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), can help reduce pain and inflammation associated with frozen shoulder. Injecting corticosteroids into the shoulder joint may help decrease pain and improve shoulder mobility, especially in the early stages of the process. Then the doctor moves the shoulder joint in different directions, to help loosen the tightened tissue. Surgery for frozen shoulder is rare, but if nothing else has helped, the doctor may recommend surgery to remove scar tissue and adhesions from inside the shoulder joint. Doctors usually perform this surgery with lighted, tubular instruments inserted through small incisions around the joint (arthroscopically).
info-Symptoms: Shoulder pain, stiffness
info-Risk factors: Diabetes, hypothyroidism
info-Treatment: NSAIDs, physical therapy, steroids, injecting the shoulder at high pressure, surgery

Name: FSGS
Overview: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) results from scarring of the glomeruli, the tiny structures within the kidney that filter impurities from the blood to create urine. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a disease in which scar tissue develops on the parts of the kidneys that filter waste from the blood (glomeruli). Several factors, such as infection, drug toxicity, diseases such as diabetes or sickle cell disease, obesity, and even other kidney diseases can cause secondary FSGS.

Name: Fuchs ' dystrophy
Symptoms: Fluctuation in vision, with worse symptoms in the morning after awakening and gradually improving during the day. As the disease progresses, blurred vision either can take longer to improve or doesn't improve.
Overview: With Fuchs dystrophy, the body of the cornea (stroma) begins to thicken, and the cornea becomes cloudy. In Fuchs (fewks) dystrophy, fluid builds up in the clear layer (cornea) on the front of the eye, causing the cornea to swell and thicken.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of developing Fuchs dystrophy include Sex. Although there's a rare early-onset type of Fuchs dystrophy that begins in childhood, typically the disease starts in the 30s and 40s, with symptoms developing thereafter.
Diagnosis: Besides testing the vision, the doctor might also have one undergo the following tests to determine whether one has Fuchs dystrophy: Cornea examination and grading. The doctor will make the diagnosis of Fuchs dystrophy by examining the eye with an optical microscope (slit lamp) to look for irregular bumps (guttae) on the inside surface of the cornea. The doctor might obtain a special photograph of the cornea (tomography) to assess for early signs of swelling in the cornea. Sometimes the doctor might use a special instrument to record the number, shape and size of the cells that line the back of the cornea.
Medication: After the genetic abnormality associated with most cases of Fuchs dystrophy was discovered, there is a better understanding of how the disease might develop, and this offers the potential for nonsurgical therapies in the future. Known as Descemet membrane endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK), this procedure involves replacing the back layer of the cornea with healthy endothelial cells from a donor. The doctor may recommend a partial-thickness cornea transplant, a procedure known as Descemet-stripping endothelial keratoplasty (DSEK). Rarely, a full-thickness cornea transplant, known as penetrating keratoplasty (PK), may be recommended.

Name: Functional neurologic disorders/conversion disorder
Overview: Functional neurologic disorders a newer and broader term that includes what some people call conversion disorder feature nervous system (neurological) symptoms that can't be explained by a neurological disease or other medical condition. Functional neurologic disorders are related to how the brain functions, rather than damage to the brain's structure (such as from a stroke, multiple sclerosis, infection or injury).
Causes: Theories regarding what happens in the brain to result in symptoms are complex and involve multiple mechanisms that may differ, depending on the type of functional neurologic disorder. Symptoms of functional neurologic disorders may appear suddenly after a stressful event, or with emotional or physical trauma.
Diagnosis: Functional neurologic disorders are diagnosed based on what is present, such as specific patterns of signs and symptoms, and not just by what is absent, such as a lack of structural changes on an MRI or abnormalities on an EEG. The doctor may use any of these terms: functional neurologic disorders (FNDs), functional neurological symptom disorder or conversion disorder. For example, if the symptoms include problems walking, the doctor may refer to functional gait disorder or functional weakness. The doctor may compare the symptoms to the criteria for diagnosis in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association. One or more symptoms that affect body movement or the senses Symptoms can't be explained by a neurological or other medical condition or another mental health disorder Symptoms cause significant distress or problems in social, work or other areas, or they're significant enough that medical evaluation is recommended EEG (electroencephalogram) X-ray Physical exam.

Name: Galactorrhea
Overview: Galactorrhea (guh-lack-toe-REE-uh) is a milky nipple discharge unrelated to the normal milk production of breast-feeding. Excessive breast stimulation, medication side effects or disorders of the pituitary gland all may contribute to galactorrhea.
Causes: This is called idiopathic galactorrhea, and it may just mean that the breast tissue is particularly sensitive to the milk-producing hormone prolactin in the blood. In males, galactorrhea may be associated with testosterone deficiency (male hypogonadism) and usually occurs with breast enlargement or tenderness (gynecomastia). This can cause enlargement of the baby's breast tissue, which may be associated with a milky nipple discharge.
Diagnosis: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain, to check for a tumor or other abnormality of the pituitary gland if the blood test reveals an elevated prolactin level. Mammogram MRI Ultrasound A physical exam, Analysis of fluid discharged from the nipple, A blood test, A pregnancy test, Mammography, ultrasound or both, Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain,

Name: Gallbladder cancer
Risk factors: Factors that can increase the risk of gallbladder cancer include The sex. Other gallbladder conditions that can increase the risk of gallbladder cancer include gallbladder polyps and chronic gallbladder infection.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose gallbladder cancer include Once the doctor diagnoses the gallbladder cancer, he or she works to find the extent (stage) of the cancer. Tests and procedures used to stage gallbladder cancer include Exploratory surgery. The doctor may recommend surgery to look inside the abdomen for signs that gallbladder cancer has spread. Imaging tests that can create pictures of the gallbladder include ultrasound, computerized tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). At this stage, gallbladder cancer has grown to invade one or more nearby organs, such as the liver, small intestine or stomach. The latest stage of gallbladder cancer includes large tumors that involve multiple nearby organs and tumors of any size that have spread to distant areas of the body.
info-Symptoms: Abdominal pain, Bloating, Fever, Unexplained weight loss, Nausea, Yellowing of the skin, although some people may have no symptoms
info-Risk factors: History of Gallstones and other Gallbladder diseases
info-Diagnostic method: Blood tests, medical imaging, examination of the Bile duct

Name: Gallstones
Causes: Doctors think gallstones may result when: Types of gallstones that can form in the gallbladder include The bile contains too much cholesterol. Normally, the bile contains enough chemicals to dissolve the cholesterol excreted by the liver. But if the liver excretes more cholesterol than the bile can dissolve, the excess cholesterol may form into crystals and eventually into stones. If the gallbladder doesn't empty completely or often enough, bile may become very concentrated, contributing to the formation of gallstones. These gallstones are composed mainly of undissolved cholesterol, but may contain other components.
Diagnosis: A thin, flexible tube (endoscope) with a camera on the end is passed down the throat and into the small intestine. During EUS the doctor passes a thin, flexible tube (endoscope) through the mouth and through the digestive tract. Additional tests may include oral cholecystography, a hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan, computerized tomography (CT), magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) or endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).
info-Symptoms: None, crampy pain in the right upper abdomen
info-Risk factors: Birth control pills, pregnancy, family history, obesity, diabetes, liver disease, rapid weight loss
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, confirmed by ultrasound
info-Prevention: Healthy weight, diet high in fiber, diet low in simple carbohydrates
info-Treatment: Asymptomatic: none, ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) and Chenodeoxycholic acid Pain: surgery ERCP, Cholecystectomy

Name: Ganglion cyst
Symptoms: Ganglion cysts most commonly develop along the tendons or joints of the wrists or hands. Ganglion cysts are round or oval and usually measure less than an inch (2.5 centimeters) in diameter.
Overview: Ganglion cysts are lumps that most commonly develop in the wrist. Ganglion cysts are noncancerous lumps that most commonly develop along the tendons or joints of the wrists or hands. Ganglion cysts are typically round or oval and are filled with a jellylike fluid. Small ganglion cysts can be pea-sized, while larger ones can be around an inch (2.5 centimeters) in diameter.
Diagnosis: The doctor might also recommend imaging tests such as X-rays, ultrasound or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to rule out other conditions, such as arthritis or a tumor. A ganglion cyst diagnosis may be confirmed by aspiration, a process in which the doctor uses a needle and syringe to draw out (aspirate) the fluid in the cyst.
Treatment: If the cyst is causing pain or interfering with joint movement, the doctor may recommend: Immobilization. Because activity can cause the ganglion cyst to get larger, it may help to temporarily immobilize the area with a brace or splint.
Remedies: To relieve pain, consider an over-the-counter pain reliever, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve). In some cases, modifying the shoes or how one lace them can relieve the pain associated with ganglion cysts on the ankles or feet.
info-Symptoms: Small soft lump associated with a joint
info-Treatment: Watchful waiting, splinting the affected joint, needle aspiration, surgery

Name: Gangrene
Overview: Gangrene refers to the death of body tissue due to either a lack of blood flow or a serious bacterial infection. The chances of developing gangrene are higher if one has an underlying condition that can damage the blood vessels and affect blood flow, such as diabetes or hardened arteries (atherosclerosis).
Causes: Gangrene results when blood flow to a certain area of the body is interrupted, causing tissue decay and death. If one has gas gangrene, the surface of the skin may initially appear normal. Gas gangrene is most commonly caused by infection with the bacterium Clostridium perfringens, which develops in an injury or surgical wound that's depleted of blood supply. If bacteria thrive unchecked for long, infection can take over and cause the tissue to die, causing gangrene. Fournier's gangrene usually arises due to an infection in the genital area or urinary tract and causes genital pain, tenderness, redness and swelling. This rare type of gangrene typically occurs after an operation, with painful skin lesions developing one to two weeks after surgery.
Risk factors: If one has diabetes, the body doesn't produce enough of the hormone insulin (which helps the cells take up blood sugar) or is resistant to the effects of insulin. High blood sugar levels can eventually damage blood vessels, decreasing or interrupting blood flow to a part of the body. Hardened and narrowed arteries (atherosclerosis) and blood clots also can block blood flow to an area of the body. Any process that causes trauma to the skin and underlying tissue, including an injury or frostbite, increases the risk of developing gangrene, especially if one has an underlying condition that affects blood flow to the injured area. Obesity often accompanies diabetes and vascular disease, but the stress of extra weight alone can also compress arteries, leading to reduced blood flow and increasing the risk of infection and poor wound healing. If one has an infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or if one is undergoing chemotherapy or radiation therapy, the body's ability to fight off an infection is impaired.
Diagnosis: An X-ray, a computerized tomography (CT) scan or a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan can be used to view interior body structures, such as the internal organs, blood vessels or bones, and assess the extent to which gangrene has spread. A culture of the fluid from a blister on the skin may be examined for the bacterium Clostridium perfringens, a common cause of gas gangrene, or the doctor may look at a tissue sample under a microscope for signs of cell death.
info-Symptoms: Change in skin color to red or black, numbness, pain, skin breakdown, coolness
info-Risk factors: Diabetes, peripheral arterial disease, smoking, major trauma, alcoholism, plague, HIV/AIDS, frostbite, Raynaud's syndrome
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptom, With medical imaging used to identify the underlying cause.

Name: Gas and gas pains
Overview: Gas in the digestive system is part of the normal process of digestion. Certain digestive system disorders, such as irritable bowel syndrome or celiac disease, may cause in addition to other signs and symptoms an increase in gas or gas pain.
Causes: Bacteria also consume some of that gas, but the remaining gas is released when one pass gas from the anus. Eating habits, such as eating too quickly, drinking through a straw, chewing gum, sucking on candies or talking while chewing results in swallowing more air. Fiber supplements containing psyllium, such as Metamucil, may increase colon gas. Sugar substitutes, or artificial sweeteners, such as sorbitol, mannitol and xylitol, found in some sugar-free foods and beverages may cause excess colon gas. Excess gas is often a symptom of chronic intestinal conditions, such as diverticulitis, ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease. An increase or change in the bacteria in the small intestine can cause excess gas, diarrhea and weight loss.
Remedies: If the odor from passing gas concerns one, limiting foods high in sulfur-containing compounds such as broccoli, Brussels sprouts, cabbage, cauliflower, beer and foods high in protein may reduce distinctive odors. Pads, underwear and cushions containing charcoal also may help absorb unpleasant odors from passing gas. Try eating smaller portions of problem foods to see if the body can handle a smaller portion without creating excess gas. Regular exercise reduces the risk of constipation, which can prevent the release of gas from the colon.

Name: Gastritis
Overview: The stomach is a muscular sac about the size of a small melon that expands when one eat or drink to hold as much as a gallon of food or liquid. Once the stomach pulverizes the food, strong muscular contractions (peristaltic waves) push the food toward the pyloric valve, which leads to the upper portion of the small intestine (duodenum).
Risk factors: Called autoimmune gastritis, this type of gastritis occurs when the body attacks the cells that make up the stomach lining. Autoimmune gastritis is more common in people with other autoimmune disorders, including Hashimoto's disease and type 1 diabetes. Although infection with Helicobacter pylori is among the most common worldwide human infections, only some people with the infection develop gastritis or other upper gastrointestinal disorders. Common pain relievers such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen (Aleve, Anaprox) can cause both acute gastritis and chronic gastritis. Older adults have an increased risk of gastritis because the stomach lining tends to thin with age and because older adults are more likely to have H. pylori infection or autoimmune disorders than younger people are. This reaction can wear away at the stomach's protective barrier.Autoimmune gastritis is more common in people with other autoimmune disorders, including Hashimoto's disease and type 1 diabetes. Gastritis may be associated with other medical conditions, including HIV/AIDS, Crohn's disease and parasitic infections.
Diagnosis: A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). During endoscopy, the doctor passes a flexible tube equipped with a lens (endoscope) down the throat and into the esophagus, stomach and small intestine. If a suspicious area is found, the doctor may remove small tissue samples (biopsy) for laboratory examination. H. pylori may be detected in a blood test, in a stool test or by a breath test.For the breath test, one drink a small glass of clear, tasteless liquid that contains radioactive carbon. Using the endoscope, the doctor looks for signs of inflammation.If a suspicious area is found, the doctor may remove small tissue samples (biopsy) for laboratory examination.
Treatment: These drugs include the prescription and over-the-counter medications omeprazole (Prilosec), lansoprazole (Prevacid), rabeprazole (Aciphex), esomeprazole (Nexium), dexlansoprazole (Dexilant) and pantoprazole (Protonix). If the doctor suspects gastritis, one may be referred to a specialist in digestive disorders (gastroenterologist). For H. pylori in the digestive tract, the doctor may recommend a combination of antibiotics, such as clarithromycin (Biaxin) and amoxicillin (Amoxil, Augmentin, others) or metronidazole (Flagyl), to kill the bacterium. Acid blockers also called histamine (H-2) blockers reduce the amount of acid released into the digestive tract, which relieves gastritis pain and encourages healing. Available by prescription or over-the-counter, acid blockers include famotidine (Pepcid), cimetidine (Tagamet HB) and nizatidine (Axid AR). If one use pain relievers that increase the risk of gastritis, ask the doctor whether acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) may be an option for one.
Remedies: One may find some relief from signs and symptoms if one: Eat smaller, more-frequent meals. If one experience frequent indigestion, eat smaller meals more often to help ease the effects of stomach acid. Avoid foods that irritate the stomach, especially those that are spicy, acidic, fried or fatty. If one use pain relievers that increase the risk of gastritis, ask the doctor whether acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) may be an option for one.
info-Symptoms: Upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloating, loss of appetite, heartburn
info-Causes: Helicobacter pylori, NSAIDs, alcohol, smoking, cocaine, severe illness, autoimmune problems
info-Diagnostic method: Endoscopy, upper gastrointestinal series, blood tests, stool tests
info-Treatment: Antacids, H2 blockers, proton pump inhibitors, antibiotics

Name: Gastrointestinal bleeding
Overview: Gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding is a symptom of a disorder in the digestive tract. The blood often appears in stool or vomit but isn't always visible, though it may cause the stool to look black or tarry.
Causes: Stomach acid, either from bacteria or use of anti-inflammatory drugs, damages the lining, leading to formation of sores. Abnormal, enlarged veins in the esophagus (esophageal varices). This inflammation of the esophagus is most commonly caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). This involves the development of small, bulging pouches in the digestive tract (diverticulosis). Noncanerous (benign) or cancerous tumors of the esophagus, stomach, colon or rectum can weaken the lining of the digestive tract and cause bleeding.
Diagnosis: Endoscopy involves inserting a long, flexible tube (endoscope) down the throat and into the esophagus. A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). The doctor will take a medical history, including a history of previous bleeding, conduct a physical exam and possibly order tests. Tests might include If the GI bleeding is severe, and noninvasive tests can't find the source, one might need surgery so that doctors can view the entire small intestine. This procedure uses a tiny camera on the end of a long tube, which is passed through the mouth to enable the doctor to examine the upper gastrointestinal tract. This procedure uses a tiny camera on the end of a long tube, which is passed through the rectum to enable the doctor to examine the large intestine and rectum. A variety of other imaging tests, such as an abdominal CT scan, might be used to find the source of the bleed.
Treatment: If one has an upper GI bleed, one might be given an IV drug known as a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) to suppress stomach acid production. Depending on the amount of blood loss and whether one continue to bleed, one might require fluids through a needle (IV) and, possibly, blood transfusions.
info-Symptoms: Vomiting red blood, vomiting black blood, bloody stool, black stool, feeling tired
info-Causes: Upper: peptic ulcer disease, esophageal varices due to liver cirrhosis, cancerLower: hemorrhoids, cancer, inflammatory bowel disease
info-Diagnostic method: Medical history and physical examination, blood tests
info-Frequency: Upper: 100 per 100,000 adults per yearLower: 25 per 100,000 per year

Name: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor ( GIST )
Diagnosis: Because there are so many different types of soft tissue sarcoma, it's important to determine the exact nature of each tumor so that the best treatments can be chosen. To evaluate the area of concern, the doctor might employ: If a soft tissue sarcoma is suspected, it's often best to seek care at a medical center that sees many people with this type of cancer. Options include In the lab, a doctor trained in analyzing body tissues (pathologist) examines the tissue sample for signs of cancer.

Name: Gastroparesis
Overview: The stomach is a muscular sac about the size of a small melon that expands when one eat or drink to hold as much as a gallon of food or liquid. Once the stomach pulverizes the food, strong muscular contractions (peristaltic waves) push the food toward the pyloric valve, which leads to the upper portion of the small intestine (duodenum).
Diagnosis: A scanner that detects the movement of the radioactive material is placed over the abdomen to monitor the rate at which food leaves the stomach.One will need to stop taking any medications that could slow gastric emptying. This procedure is used to visually examine the upper digestive system the esophagus, stomach and beginning of the small intestine (duodenum) with a tiny camera on the end of a long, flexible tube.This test can also diagnose other conditions, such as peptic ulcer disease or pyloric stenosis, which can have symptoms similar to those of gastroparesis.
Medication: These medications include metoclopramide (Reglan) and erythromycin (Eryc, E.E.S.). In these situations, doctors may recommend a feeding tube (jejunostomy tube) be placed in the small intestine. One procedure used endoscopy to place a small tube (stent) where the stomach connects to the small intestine (duodenum) to keep this connection open. Doctors are also studying the use of a minimally invasive surgical technique when someone needs a feeding tube placed directly into the small intestine (jejunostomy tube). Erythromycin may lose its effectiveness over time, and can cause side effects, such as diarrhea.A newer medication, domperidone, with fewer side effects, is also available with restricted access. Drugs that help ease nausea and vomiting include prochlorperazine (Compro) and diphenhydramine (Benadryl, Unisom). A class of medications that includes ondansetron (Zofran) is sometimes used to help nausea and vomiting.
info-Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, feeling full after eating just a few bites

Name: Gender identity disorder
Overview: Gender dysphoria is the feeling of discomfort or distress that might occur in people whose gender identity differs from their sex assigned at birth or sex-related physical characteristics. Gender dysphoria is a diagnosis listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), a manual published by the American Psychiatric Association to diagnose mental conditions.
Diagnosis: While some adolescents might express their feelings of gender dysphoria to their parents or a doctor, others might instead show symptoms of a mood disorder, anxiety or depression or display social or academic problems. The provider will evaluate one to confirm the incongruence of the gender identity and sex assigned at birth, the history and development of gender dysphoric feelings, the impact of the stigma attached to gender nonconformity on the mental health, and what support one has from family, friends and peers. The mental health professional may use the criteria for gender dysphoria listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association.
Treatment: Treatment can help people who have gender dysphoria to explore their gender identity and find the gender role that feels comfortable for them, easing distress. Treatment options might include changes in gender expression and role, hormone therapy, surgery, and behavioral therapy.
info-Symptoms: Distress related to one's assigned gender or sex

Name: Generalized anxiety disorder
Overview: It's normal to feel anxious from time to time, especially if the life is stressful. However, excessive, ongoing anxiety and worry that are difficult to control and interfere with day-to-day activities may be a sign of generalized anxiety disorder.
Risk factors: The following factors may increase the risk of developing generalized anxiety disorder: Personality. A person whose temperament is timid or negative or who avoids anything dangerous may be more prone to generalized anxiety disorder than others are. People with generalized anxiety disorder may have a history of significant life changes, traumatic or negative experiences during childhood, or a recent traumatic or negative event.
Remedies: While most people with anxiety disorders need psychotherapy or medications to get anxiety under control, lifestyle changes also can make a difference. Visualization techniques, meditation and yoga are examples of relaxation techniques that can ease anxiety. Healthy eating such as focusing on vegetables, fruits, whole grains and fish may be linked to reduced anxiety, but more research is needed.
Medication: Several types of medications are used to treat generalized anxiety disorder, including those below. Antidepressants, including medications in the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) and serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) classes, are the first line medication treatments. Examples of antidepressants used to treat generalized anxiety disorder include escitalopram (Lexapro), duloxetine (Cymbalta), venlafaxine (Effexor XR) and paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva).
info-Symptoms: Excessive worry, restlessness, trouble sleeping, feeling tired, irritability, sweating, trembling

Name: Germ cell tumors
Overview: Germ cell tumors are growths that form from reproductive cells. Most germ cell tumors that are cancerous occur as cancer of the testicles (testicular cancer) or cancer of the ovaries (ovarian cancer).

Name: Gestational diabetes
Overview: Gestational diabetes is diabetes diagnosed for the first time during pregnancy (gestation). Like other types of diabetes, gestational diabetes affects how the cells use sugar (glucose).
Causes: Normally, various hormones work to keep the blood sugar levels in check. But during pregnancy, hormone levels change, making it harder for the body to process blood sugar efficiently.
Diagnosis: A blood sugar below 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L) is usually considered normal on a glucose challenge test, although this may vary by clinic or lab. If the blood sugar level is higher than normal, one will need another glucose tolerance test to determine if one has the condition.
info-Symptoms: Typically few symptoms
info-Usual onset: Most common last three months of pregnancy
info-Causes: Not enough insulin in the setting of insulin resistance
info-Risk factors: Overweight, previously having gestational diabetes, family history of type 2 diabetes, polycystic ovarian syndrome
info-Prevention: Maintaining a healthy weight and exercising before pregnancy

Name: Giant lymph node hyperplasia
Symptoms: If one notice an enlarged lymph node on the side of the neck or in the underarm, collarbone or groin area, talk to the doctor. Also call the doctor if one experience a persistent feeling of fullness in the chest or abdomen, fever, fatigue, or unexplained weight loss.
Overview: Castleman disease is a rare disorder that involves an overgrowth of cells in the body's lymph nodes. Multicentric Castleman disease affects multiple lymph nodes throughout the body and has been associated with human herpes virus type 8 (HHV-8) and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

Name: Giardia infection ( giardiasis )
Overview: Giardia infection is an intestinal infection marked by abdominal cramps, bloating, nausea and bouts of watery diarrhea. Giardia infection is caused by a microscopic parasite that is found worldwide, especially in areas with poor sanitation and unsafe water.
Causes: Before the microscopic parasites are passed in stool, they become encased within hard shells called cysts, which allows them to survive outside the intestines for months. Because cooking food kills giardia, food is a less common source of infection than water is, especially in industrialized countries. One can contract giardiasis if the hands become contaminated with fecal matter parents changing a child's diapers are especially at risk.
Risk factors: Although anyone can pick up giardia parasites, some people are especially at risk: Children. One is at risk if one travel to places where giardiasis is common, especially if one isn't careful about what one eat and drink. Having anal sex without using a condom puts one at increased risk of giardia infection, as well as sexually transmitted infections.
Treatment: When signs and symptoms are severe or the infection persists, doctors usually treat giardiasis with medications such as: There are no consistently recommended medications for giardiasis in pregnancy because of the potential for adverse drug effects to the baby. If the symptoms are mild, the doctor may recommend delaying treatment until after the first trimester. While one may initially bring the symptoms to the attention of the family doctor, he or she may refer one to a gastroenterologist a doctor who specializes in disorders of the digestive system. Side effects may include nausea, flatulence, yellow eyes and brightly colored yellow urine.

Name: Gilbert 's syndrome
Overview: The liver is the largest internal organ. Gilbert's (zheel-BAYRS) syndrome is a common, harmless liver condition in which the liver doesn't properly process bilirubin. If one has Gilbert's syndrome also known as constitutional hepatic dysfunction and familial nonhemolytic jaundice one is born with the condition as a result of an inherited gene mutation. One might not know one has Gilbert's syndrome until it's discovered by accident, such as when a blood test shows elevated bilirubin levels.
Causes: When one has an ineffective gene, the blood contains excess amounts of bilirubin because the body doesn't produce enough of the enzyme. Bilirubin travels through the bloodstream to the liver, where the enzyme breaks down the pigment and removes it from the bloodstream.
Treatment: Gilbert's syndrome doesn't require treatment. The bilirubin levels in the blood may fluctuate over time, and one may occasionally have jaundice, which usually resolves on its on with no ill effects. Certain life events, such as stress, can trigger episodes of higher bilirubin levels in Gilbert's syndrome, leading to jaundice. These steps include Before the appointment, one might want to jot down questions to ask the doctor, including Make sure the doctors know one has Gilbert's syndrome. Because Gilbert's syndrome affects the way the body processes certain medications, every doctor one visit needs to know that one has the condition. Gilbert's syndrome and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to bilirubin overproduction. Make sure the doctors know one has Gilbert's syndrome.
Remedies: Certain life events, such as stress, can trigger episodes of higher bilirubin levels in Gilbert's syndrome, leading to jaundice.
