These steps include Make sure the doctors know one has Gilbert's syndrome. Because Gilbert's syndrome affects the way the body processes certain medications, every doctor one visit needs to know that one has the condition.

Name: Glaucoma
Overview: Normally, fluid (aqueous humor) in the eye flows freely through the anterior chamber and exits through the drainage system (trabecular meshwork). If that system is blocked or isn't functioning well, the pressure inside the eye (intraocular pressure) builds, which in turn damages the optic nerve. Glaucoma is a group of eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, the health of which is vital for good vision. Because vision loss due to glaucoma can't be recovered, it's important to have regular eye exams that include measurements of the eye pressure so a diagnosis can be made in its early stages and treated appropriately.
Causes: For reasons that doctors don't fully understand, this nerve damage is usually related to increased pressure in the eye. When fluid is overproduced or the drainage system doesn't work properly, the fluid can't flow out at its normal rate and eye pressure increases. In some people, scientists have identified genes related to high eye pressure and optic nerve damage. Angle-closure glaucoma, also called closed-angle glaucoma, occurs when the iris bulges forward to narrow or block the drainage angle formed by the cornea and iris. In normal-tension glaucoma, the optic nerve becomes damaged even though the eye pressure is within the normal range. In pigmentary glaucoma, pigment granules from the iris build up in the drainage channels, slowing or blocking fluid exiting the eye.
Treatment: But treatment and regular checkups can help slow or prevent vision loss, especially if one catch the disease in its early stages. Depending on the situation, the options may include prescription eyedrops, oral medications, laser treatment, surgery or a combination of any of these.
Remedies: Eating a healthy diet can help one maintain the health, but it won't prevent glaucoma from worsening. Several vitamins and nutrients are important to eye health, including zinc, copper, selenium, and antioxidant vitamins C, E, and A. Drinking beverages with large amounts of caffeine may increase the eye pressure. Drinking a quart or more of any liquid within a short time may temporarily increase eye pressure. Using a wedge pillow that keeps the head slightly raised, about 20 degrees, has been shown to reduce intraocular pressure while one sleep.
info-Symptoms: Vision loss, eye pain, mid-dilated pupil, redness of the eye, nausea
info-Risk factors: Increased pressure in the eye, family history, high blood pressure

Name: Glioblastoma
Diagnosis: If the primary care doctor suspects one has a brain tumor, one may be referred to a specialist who is trained in treating brain and nervous system disorders (neurologist). In some cases, a dye (contrast material) may be injected through a vein in the arm during the MRI study to help show differences in brain tissue. A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. Brain tumor imaging Collecting and testing a sample of abnormal tissue (biopsy). Depending on the location of the glioma, a biopsy may be performed with a needle before treatment or as part of an operation to remove the brain tumor. Based on this information, a doctor who specializes in diagnosing cancer and other tissue abnormalities (pathologist) can determine the grade or stage of a brain tumor. To rule out other types of brain tumors that may have spread from other parts of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer originated.
info-Symptoms: Initially nonspecific, headaches, personality changes, nausea, symptoms similar to a stroke
info-Risk factors: Genetic disorders (neurofibromatosis, Liâ€“Fraumeni syndrome), previous radiation therapy
info-Diagnostic method: CT scan, MRI scan, tissue biopsy
info-Prognosis: Life expectancy ~ 14 months with treatment (5 year survival <7%)

Name: Glioma
Overview: Gliomas begin in the gluey supportive (glial cells) that surround nerve cells in the brain. Gliomas are classified according to the type of glial cell involved in the tumor, as well as the tumor's genetic features, which can help predict how the tumor will behave over time and the treatments most likely to work.
Risk factors: More-common forms of radiation, such as electromagnetic fields from power lines and radiofrequency radiation from microwave ovens have not been shown to increase the risk of glioma. Because cellphones are a relatively new factor, more long-term research is needed to understand the potential impact on cancer risk. For the time being, if one is concerned about the possible link between cellphones and cancer, experts recommend limiting the exposure by using a speaker or hands-free device, which keeps the cellphone itself away from the head.
Diagnosis: If the primary care doctor suspects one has a brain tumor, one may be referred to a specialist who is trained in treating brain and nervous system disorders (neurologist). In some cases, a dye (contrast material) may be injected through a vein in the arm during the MRI study to help show differences in brain tissue. A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. Brain tumor imaging Collecting and testing a sample of abnormal tissue (biopsy). Depending on the location of the glioma, a biopsy may be performed with a needle before treatment or as part of an operation to remove the brain tumor. Based on this information, a doctor who specializes in diagnosing cancer and other tissue abnormalities (pathologist) can determine the grade or stage of a brain tumor. To rule out other types of brain tumors that may have spread from other parts of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer originated.

Name: Glomerulonephritis
Overview: Blood enters the kidneys through the renal arteries. The glomeruli filter waste products and substances the body needs such as sodium, phosphorus and potassium which then pass through tiny tubules. Glomerulonephritis (gloe-mer-u-low-nuh-FRY-tis) is inflammation of the tiny filters in the kidneys (glomeruli).
Causes: Glomerulonephritis may develop a week or two after recovery from a strep throat infection or, rarely, a skin infection (impetigo). Children are more likely to develop post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis than are adults, and they're also more likely to recover quickly. In addition to the causes listed above, glomerulonephritis is associated with certain cancers, such as multiple myeloma, lung cancer and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Bacteria occasionally can spread through the bloodstream and lodge in the heart, causing an infection of one or more of the heart valves. Viral infections, such as the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), hepatitis B and hepatitis C, can trigger glomerulonephritis. A chronic inflammatory disease, lupus can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, heart and lungs. A rare immunological lung disorder that can mimic pneumonia, Goodpasture's syndrome causes bleeding in the lungs as well as glomerulonephritis. Characterized by recurrent episodes of blood in the urine, this primary glomerular disease results from deposits of immunoglobulin A (IgA) in the glomeruli. This form of vasculitis affects small and medium blood vessels in many parts of the body, such as the heart, kidneys and intestines. This form of vasculitis, formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis, affects small and medium blood vessels in the lungs, upper airways and kidneys.
Diagnosis: During a kidney biopsy, the doctor uses a needle to remove a small sample of kidney tissue for lab testing. Urinalysis results might also show white blood cells, a common indicator of infection or inflammation, and increased protein, which can indicate nephron damage. These can provide information about kidney damage and impairment of the glomeruli by measuring levels of waste products, such as creatinine and blood urea nitrogen. If the doctor detects evidence of damage, he or she may recommend diagnostic studies that allow visualization of the kidneys, such as a kidney X-ray, an ultrasound exam or a CT scan.

Name: Glucocerebrosidase deficiency
Symptoms: There are different types of Gaucher disease, and signs and symptoms of disease vary widely, even within the same type. If one or the child has the signs and symptoms associated with Gaucher disease, make an appointment with the doctor. Gaucher disease can weaken bone, increasing the risk of painful fractures. Gaucher disease also affects the cells responsible for clotting, which can cause easy bruising and nosebleeds.
Overview: Gaucher (go-SHAY) disease is the result of a buildup of certain fatty substances in certain organs, particularly the spleen and liver. An inherited disorder, Gaucher disease is most common in Jewish people of Eastern and Central European descent (Ashkenazi).
Causes: To have an autosomal recessive disorder, one inherit two abnormal genes, one from each parent. Both parents must be carriers of a Gaucher changed (mutated) gene for their child to inherit the condition.
Medication: Many people who have Gaucher disease have seen improvements in their symptoms after beginning treatment with: If the symptoms are severe and one is not a candidate for less invasive treatments, the doctor might suggest: Enzyme replacement therapy. These replacement enzymes are given in an outpatient procedure through a vein (intravenously), typically in high doses at two-week intervals. In this procedure, blood-forming cells that have been damaged by Gaucher disease are removed and replaced, which can reverse many of Gaucher signs and symptoms. Before enzyme replacement therapy became available, removing the spleen was a common treatment for Gaucher disease.

Name: Gonorrhea
Symptoms: The male reproductive system makes, stores and moves sperm. The ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix and vagina (vaginal canal) make up the female reproductive system. In many cases, gonorrhea infection causes no symptoms. Symptoms, however, can affect many sites in the body, but commonly appear in the genital tract. Signs and symptoms include anal itching, pus-like discharge from the rectum, spots of bright red blood on toilet tissue and having to strain during bowel movements. Gonorrhea that affects the eyes can cause eye pain, sensitivity to light, and pus-like discharge from one or both eyes.
Diagnosis: Samples can be collected by: For women, home test kits are available for gonorrhea. Depending on the risk factors, tests for additional sexually transmitted infections could be beneficial as well.
info-Symptoms: None, burning with urination, vaginal discharge, discharge from the penis, pelvic pain, testicular pain
info-Diagnostic method: Testing the urine, urethra in males, or cervix in females
info-Prevention: Condoms, having sex with only one person who is uninfected, not having sex
info-Treatment: Ceftriaxone by injection and azithromycin by mouth

Name: Gout
Symptoms: They include If one experience sudden, intense pain in a joint, call the doctor. Gout usually affects the large joint of the big toe, but it can occur in any joint. Other commonly affected joints include the ankles, knees, elbows, wrists and fingers. After the most severe pain subsides, some joint discomfort may last from a few days to a few weeks. As gout progresses, one may not be able to move the joints normally.
Causes: Other foods also promote higher levels of uric acid, such as alcoholic beverages, especially beer, and drinks sweetened with fruit sugar (fructose). When this happens, uric acid can build up, forming sharp, needlelike urate crystals in a joint or surrounding tissue that cause pain, inflammation and swelling.
Risk factors: One is more likely to develop gout if one has high levels of uric acid in the body. Eating a diet rich in meat and seafood and drinking beverages sweetened with fruit sugar (fructose) increase levels of uric acid, which increase the risk of gout. The use of thiazide diuretics commonly used to treat hypertension and low-dose aspirin also can increase uric acid levels. Gout occurs more often in men, primarily because women tend to have lower uric acid levels. After menopause, however, women's uric acid levels approach those of men. Men are also more likely to develop gout earlier usually between the ages of 30 and 50 whereas women generally develop signs and symptoms after menopause.
Diagnosis: Tests to help diagnose gout may include Joint fluid test. The doctor may recommend a blood test to measure the levels of uric acid and creatinine in the blood.
Medication: NSAIDs include over-the-counter options such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve), as well as more-powerful prescription NSAIDs such as indomethacin (Indocin) or celecoxib (Celebrex). The doctor may recommend colchicine (Colcrys, Mitigare), a type of pain reliever that effectively reduces gout pain. After an acute gout attack resolves, the doctor may prescribe a low daily dose of colchicine to prevent future attacks. If one experience several gout attacks each year, or if the gout attacks are less frequent but particularly painful, the doctor may recommend medication to reduce the risk of gout-related complications. If one already have evidence of damage from gout on joint X-rays, or one has tophi, chronic kidney disease or kidney stones, medications to lower the body's level of uric acid may be recommended. Drugs called xanthine oxidase inhibitors (XOIs), including allopurinol (Aloprim, Lopurin, Zyloprim) and febuxostat (Uloric), limit the amount of uric acid the body makes. These drugs, called uricosurics, include probenecid (Probalan) and lesinurad (Zurampic). This may lower the uric acid levels and reduce the risk of gout, but the level of uric acid in the urine is increased.
info-Symptoms: Joint pain, swelling, and redness
info-Risk factors: Diet high in meat or beer, being overweight
info-Prevention: Weight loss, vitamin C, not drinking alcohol, allopurinol

Name: Granuloma annulare
Symptoms: The bump (lesion) borders are circular or semicircular, with a diameter up to 2 inches (5 centimeters). The reddish or skin-colored bumps occur most commonly on the hands, feet, wrists and ankles of young adults. Less commonly, adults experience this type, which causes itchy, reddish or skin-colored bumps on most of the body, including the trunk, arms and legs.
Overview: Granuloma annulare is a chronic skin condition that causes raised reddish or skin-colored bumps (lesions) in a ring pattern, usually on the hands and feet. Granuloma annulare (gran-u-LOW-muh an-u-LAR-e) is a skin condition that causes raised reddish or skin-colored bumps (lesions) in a ring pattern.
Treatment: But if one is bothered by how the skin looks or feels, ask the doctor about treatment, which can help them disappear faster. The doctor may direct one to cover the cream with bandages or an adhesive patch, to increase the effectiveness of this treatment. If the skin lesions aren't clearing up with topical treatment, the doctor may suggest a corticosteroid injection. Exposing the lesions to certain types of light, including lasers, is sometimes helpful. In severe cases, especially when the lesions are widespread, the doctor might prescribe drugs taken by mouth, such as antibiotics, antimalarials or drugs used to prevent immune system reactions.

Name: Graves ' disease
Risk factors: Although anyone can develop Graves disease, many factors can increase the risk of disease, including Family history. Because a family history of Graves disease is a known risk factor, there is likely a gene or genes that can make a person more susceptible to the disorder. People with other disorders of the immune system, such as type 1 diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis, have an increased risk. Stressful life events or illness may act as a trigger for the onset of Graves disease among people who have genes that increase their risk. Pregnancy or recent childbirth may increase the risk of the disorder, particularly among women who have genes that increase their risk. Cigarette smoking, which can affect the immune system, increases the risk of Graves disease. Smokers who have Graves disease are also at increased risk of developing Graves ophthalmopathy.
Diagnosis: Blood tests can help the doctor determine the levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) the pituitary hormone that normally stimulates the thyroid gland and the levels of thyroid hormones. The doctor may order another lab test to measure the levels of the antibody known to cause Graves disease. By giving one a small amount of radioactive iodine and later measuring the amount of it in the thyroid gland with a specialized scanning camera, the doctor can determine the rate at which the thyroid gland takes up iodine. The amount of radioactive iodine taken up by the thyroid gland helps determine if Graves disease or another condition is the cause of the hyperthyroidism. If the diagnosis of Graves disease isn't clear from a clinical assessment, the doctor may order special imaging tests, such as a CT scan or MRI.
Remedies: If one has Graves disease, make the mental and physical well-being a priority: These steps may make the eyes feel better if one has Graves ophthalmopathy: If the disease affects the skin (Graves dermopathy), use over-the-counter creams or ointments containing hydrocortisone to relieve swelling and reddening. Brittle bones also can occur with Graves disease, and weight-bearing exercises can help maintain bone density. Easing stress may be helpful, as stress may trigger or worsen Graves disease.

Name: Growing pains
Symptoms: Growing pains usually cause an aching or throbbing feeling in the legs. Some children may also experience abdominal pain or headaches during episodes of growing pains. Growing pains often strike in the late afternoon or early evening and disappear by morning.
Treatment: In the meantime, one can help ease the child's discomfort with self-care measures, such as massaging the child's legs. One can help ease the child's discomfort with these home remedies: Most children who have growing pains will not need to see a doctor. Offer the child ibuprofen (Advil, Children's Motrin, others) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). Avoid aspirin, due to the risk of Reye's syndrome a rare but serious condition linked to giving aspirin to children.
Remedies: One can help ease the child's discomfort with these home remedies: Rub the child's legs. Offer the child ibuprofen (Advil, Children's Motrin, others) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). Avoid aspirin, due to the risk of Reye's syndrome a rare but serious condition linked to giving aspirin to children.

Name: Growth hormone excess
Causes: Acromegaly is caused by the pituitary gland overproducing growth hormone (GH) over time. When GH is secreted into the bloodstream, it triggers the liver to produce a hormone called insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-I). In other cases, the tumors produce a hormone called growth hormone-releasing hormone (GH-RH), which stimulates the pituitary gland to make more GH.
Diagnosis: After one has fasted overnight, the doctor will take a blood sample to measure the levels of GH and IGF-I. In this test, the blood levels of GH are measured before and after one drink a preparation of sugar (glucose). The doctor may recommend that one undergo an imaging procedure, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), to help pinpoint the location and size of a tumor of the pituitary gland. If no pituitary tumors are seen, the doctor may look for nonpituitary tumors as the cause of the high GH levels.
Medication: Drugs used to lower the production or block the action of GH include The doctor may recommend radiation treatment when tumor cells remain after surgery. Types of radiation therapy include Even after initial treatment, acromegaly requires periodic monitoring by the doctor to make sure that the pituitary gland is functioning properly, which will help one avoid complications. Given as a daily injection, this medication can normalize IGF-I levels and relieve symptoms in most people with acromegaly, but it doesn't lower GH levels or reduce the tumor size. Proton beam therapy delivers a targeted, high dose of radiation to the tumor, sparing radiation exposure to normal tissues.
info-Symptoms: Enlargement of the hands, feet, forehead, jaw, and nose, thicker skin, deepening of the voice
info-Prognosis: Usually normal (with treatment), 10 year shorter life expectancy (no treatment)

Name: Guillain-Barre syndrome
Symptoms: Guillain-Barre syndrome often begins with tingling and weakness starting in the feet and legs and spreading to the upper body and arms. Signs and symptoms of Guillain-Barre syndrome may include People with Guillain-Barre syndrome usually experience their most significant weakness within two weeks after symptoms begin.
Overview: The demyelinating form of Guillain-Barre syndrome destroys the protective covering of the peripheral nerves (myelin sheath), preventing the nerves from transmitting signals to the brain. Guillain-Barre (gee-YAH-buh-RAY) syndrome is a rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. There's no known cure for Guillain-Barre syndrome, but several treatments can ease symptoms and reduce the duration of the illness. Although most people recover from Guillain-Barre syndrome, the mortality rate is 4% to 7%.
Causes: In Guillain-Barre syndrome, the immune system which usually attacks only invading organisms begins attacking the nerves. In AIDP, the most common form of Guillain-Barre syndrome in the U.S. the nerves protective covering (myelin sheath) is damaged.
info-Symptoms: Muscle weakness beginning in the feet and hands, usually ascending
info-Causes: Typically triggered by an infection; occasionally by surgery and rarely by vaccination
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, nerve conduction studies, lumbar puncture

Name: Hair loss
Symptoms: In the type of patchy hair loss known as alopecia areata, hair loss occurs suddenly and usually starts with one or more circular bald patches that may overlap. Early treatment of a receding hairline (frontal fibrosing alopecia) might help avoid significant permanent baldness. For women who are experiencing a receding hairline (frontal fibrosing alopecia), talk with the doctor about early treatment to avoid significant permanent baldness. An increasingly common hair loss pattern in older women is a receding hairline (frontal fibrosing alopecia). Some conditions and medical treatments, such as chemotherapy for cancer, can result in the loss of hair all over the body.
Causes: A variety of conditions can cause permanent or temporary hair loss, including hormonal changes due to pregnancy, childbirth, menopause and thyroid problems. Excessive hairstyling or hairstyles that pull the hair tight, such as pigtails or cornrows, can cause a type of hair loss called traction alopecia.
Diagnosis: Before making a diagnosis, the doctor will likely give one a physical exam and ask about the diet, the hair care routine, and the medical and family history. The doctor scrapes samples from the skin or from a few hairs plucked from the scalp to examine the hair roots under a microscope.
info-Symptoms: Loss of hair from part of the head or body.
info-Frequency: 50% of males, 25% of females (pattern hair loss by age 50)
info-Medication: Pattern hair loss: minoxidil, finasterideAlopecia areata: steroid injections

Name: Hairy tongue
Treatment: Practicing good oral hygiene and eliminating factors that may contribute to the condition such as avoiding tobacco use or irritating mouthwashes help resolve black hairy tongue. To practice good oral health and to remove the tongue discoloration: Here's information to help one get ready for the appointment, and to know what to expect from the doctor or dentist. Give the tongue a gentle brushing whenever one brush the teeth to remove dead cells, bacteria and food debris. Get professional teeth cleanings and regular oral exams, which can help the dentist prevent problems or spot them early.
Remedies: Give the tongue a gentle brushing whenever one brush the teeth to remove dead cells, bacteria and food debris. Brush the teeth at least twice a day and ideally after every meal, using fluoride toothpaste. Get professional teeth cleanings and regular oral exams, which can help the dentist prevent problems or spot them early.
info-Risk factors: Smoking, poor oral hygiene, soft diet

Name: Halitosis
Causes: Most bad breath starts in the mouth, and there are many possible causes. Eating certain foods, such as onions, garlic and spices, also can cause bad breath. Smokers and oral tobacco users are also more likely to have gum disease, another source of bad breath. If one don't brush and floss daily, food particles remain in the mouth, causing bad breath. Saliva helps cleanse the mouth, removing particles that cause bad odors. A condition called dry mouth or xerostomia (zeero-STOE-me-uh) can contribute to bad breath because production of saliva is decreased. Dry mouth naturally occurs during sleep, leading to morning breath, and it worsens if one sleep with the mouth open. Infections or chronic inflammation in the nose, sinuses or throat, which can contribute to postnasal drip, also can cause bad breath. Diseases, such as some cancers, and conditions such as metabolic disorders, can cause a distinctive breath odor as a result of chemicals they produce. Chronic reflux of stomach acids (gastroesophageal reflux disease, or GERD) can be associated with bad breath. Bad breath in young children can be caused by a foreign body, such as a piece of food, lodged in a nostril.
Treatment: To reduce bad breath, help avoid cavities and lower the risk of gum disease, consistently practice good oral hygiene. If the bad breath is thought to be caused by an underlying health condition, the dentist will likely refer one to the primary care provider. If the bad breath is due to a buildup of bacteria (plaque) on the teeth, the dentist may recommend a mouth rinse that kills the bacteria. Proper flossing removes food particles and plaque from between the teeth, helping to control bad breath. People who have a coated tongue from a significant overgrowth of bacteria (from smoking or dry mouth, for example) may benefit from using a tongue scraper. For chronic dry mouth, the dentist or physician may prescribe an artificial saliva preparation or an oral medication that stimulates the flow of saliva.
Remedies: Proper flossing removes food particles and plaque from between the teeth, helping to control bad breath. People who have a coated tongue from a significant overgrowth of bacteria (from smoking or dry mouth, for example) may benefit from using a tongue scraper. To keep the mouth moist, avoid tobacco and drink plenty of water not coffee, soft drinks or alcohol, which can lead to a drier mouth. For chronic dry mouth, the dentist or physician may prescribe an artificial saliva preparation or an oral medication that stimulates the flow of saliva.
info-Symptoms: Unpleasant smell present on breath
info-Treatment: Depends on cause, tongue cleaning, mouthwash, flossing
info-Medication: Mouthwash containing chlorhexidine or cetylpyridinium chloride

Name: Hamstring injury
Risk factors: Sports that require sprinting or running, or other activities such as dancing that might require extreme stretching, make a hamstring injury more likely. After one has had one hamstring injury, one is more likely to have another one, especially if one try to resume all the activities at pre-injury levels of intensity before the muscles have time to heal and rebuild strength. When the muscles along the front of the thigh the quadriceps become stronger and more developed than the hamstring muscles, one may be more likely to injure the hamstring muscles.

Name: Hand fracture
Overview: The wrist is made up of eight small bones (carpal bones) plus two long bones in the forearm the radius and the ulna. Each finger consists of one hand bone (metacarpal) and three finger bones (phalanges), while each thumb consists of one metacarpal bone and two phalanges. One may be at higher risk of a broken hand if one participate in contact sports like football or hockey, or if one has a condition in which bones become thinner and more fragile (osteoporosis).

Name: Hand-foot-and-mouth disease
Causes: Hand-foot-and-mouth disease isn't related to foot-and-mouth disease (sometimes called hoof-and-mouth disease), which is an infectious viral disease found in farm animals. One can't contract hand-foot-and-mouth disease from pets or other animals, and one can't transmit it to them.
Treatment: Over-the-counter pain medications other than aspirin, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin, others) may help relieve general discomfort. Try these tips to help make blister soreness less bothersome and eating and drinking more tolerable: If the child is able to rinse without swallowing, swishing with warm salt water may be soothing. Have the child do this several times a day or as often as needed to help reduce the pain and inflammation of mouth and throat sores caused by hand-foot-and-mouth disease. If one take the child to a doctor, make the most of the time by writing down information the doctor will need before one go, including Some questions one might want to ask the doctor include Suck on ice pops or ice chips.
info-Symptoms: Fever, flat discolored spots or bumps that may blister

Name: Hangovers
Symptoms: More-severe signs and symptoms that accompany heavy drinking may indicate alcohol poisoning a life-threatening emergency. If one suspect that someone has alcohol poisoning even if one don't see the classic signs and symptoms seek immediate medical care.
Causes: A single alcoholic drink is enough to trigger a hangover for some people, while others may drink heavily and escape a hangover entirely. For example: Alcoholic beverages contain ingredients called congeners, which give many types of alcoholic beverages their flavor and can contribute to hangovers. Alcohol causes the blood vessels to expand, which can lead to headaches. Alcohol can make one sleepy, but it prevents deeper stages of sleep and often causes awakening in the middle of the night.
Risk factors: A genetic variation that affects the way alcohol is metabolized may make some people flush, sweat or become ill after drinking even a small amount of alcohol. Some researchers believe that some hangover symptoms are often due, at least in part, to the poor-quality and short sleep cycle that typically follows a night of drinking.
Treatment: In the meantime, here are a few things one can do to help theself feel better: Proposed alternative remedies for hangovers abound, but studies haven't found any natural remedies that consistently improve hangover symptoms. And if one regularly drink alcohol to excess, acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) can cause severe liver damage even in doses previously thought to be safe. Beyond hangovers: Understanding alcohol's impact on the health. The impact of alcohol hangover symptoms on cognitive and physical functioning, and mood. Interventions for treatment and/or prevention of alcohol hangover: Systematic review. Natural products for the prevention and treatment of hangover and alcohol use disorder. The role of beverage congeners in hangover and other residual effects of alcohol intoxication: A review.

Name: Hardening of the arteries
Symptoms: Also pay attention to early symptoms of inadequate blood flow, such as chest pain (angina), leg pain or numbness. If one has atherosclerosis in the heart arteries, one may have symptoms, such as chest pain or pressure (angina).
Overview: Arteriosclerosis occurs when the blood vessels that carry oxygen and nutrients from the heart to the rest of the body (arteries) become thick and stiff sometimes restricting blood flow to the organs and tissues. Atherosclerosis refers to the buildup of fats, cholesterol and other substances in and on the artery walls (plaque), which can restrict blood flow.
Diagnosis: During a physical exam, the doctor may find signs of narrowed, enlarged or hardened arteries, including Depending on the results of the physical exam, the doctor may suggest one or more diagnostic tests, including Blood tests. A stress test, also called an exercise stress test, is used to gather information about how well the heart works during physical activity. Because exercise makes the heart pump harder and faster than it does during most daily activities, an exercise stress test can reveal problems within the heart that might not be noticeable otherwise. An exercise stress test usually involves walking on a treadmill or riding a stationary bike while the heart rhythm, blood pressure and breathing are monitored. In some types of stress tests, pictures will be taken of the heart, such as during a stress echocardiogram (ultrasound) or nuclear stress test. A liquid dye is injected into the arteries of the heart through a long, thin tube (catheter) that's fed through an artery, usually in the leg, to the arteries in the heart. A weak or absent pulse below the narrowed area of the artery Decreased blood pressure in an affected limb Whooshing sounds (bruits) over the arteries, heard using a stethoscope Blood tests. The doctor may use ultrasound, a computerized tomography (CT) scan or magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) to study the arteries.
Remedies: A heart-healthy diet based on fruits, vegetables and whole grains and low in refined carbohydrates, sugars, saturated fat and sodium can help one control the weight, blood pressure, cholesterol and blood sugar. Try substituting whole-grain bread in place of white bread; grabbing an apple, a banana or carrot sticks as a snack; and reading nutrition labels as a guide to controlling the amount of salt and fat one eat. If one is overweight, losing as few as 5 to 10 pounds (about 2.3 to 4.5 kilograms) can help reduce the risk of high blood pressure and high cholesterol, two of the major risk factors for developing atherosclerosis. If one has high cholesterol, high blood pressure, diabetes or another chronic disease, work with the doctor to manage the condition and promote overall health. If one smoke or use tobacco in any form, quitting is the best way to halt the progression of atherosclerosis and reduce the risk of complications.
Medication: Aggressively lowering the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, the bad cholesterol, can slow, stop or even reverse the buildup of fatty deposits in the arteries. Boosting the high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, the good cholesterol, may help, too. The doctor can choose from a range of cholesterol medications, including drugs known as statins and fibrates. In addition to lowering cholesterol, statins have additional effects that help stabilize the lining of the heart arteries and prevent atherosclerosis. If one has severe symptoms or a blockage that threatens muscle or skin tissue survival, one may be a candidate for one of the following surgical procedures: Angioplasty and stent placement. In this procedure, the doctor inserts a long, thin tube (catheter) into the blocked or narrowed part of the artery. The doctor may prescribe anti-platelet medications, such as aspirin, to reduce the likelihood that platelets will clump in narrowed arteries, form a blood clot and cause further blockage. These medications may help slow the progression of atherosclerosis by lowering blood pressure and producing other beneficial effects on the heart arteries. The doctor may suggest certain medications to control specific risk factors for atherosclerosis, such as diabetes. Sometimes specific medications to treat symptoms of atherosclerosis, such as leg pain during exercise, are prescribed. If one has an artery that's blocked by a blood clot, the doctor may use a clot-dissolving drug to break it apart.
info-Symptoms: None
info-Risk factors: High blood pressure, diabetes, smoking, obesity, family history, unhealthy diet
info-Prevention: Healthy diet, exercise, not smoking, maintaining a normal weight

Name: Head and neck cancers
Overview: Head and neck cancers are a broad category of cancers that occur in the head and neck region. After treatment, recovery from head and neck cancers may involve working with rehabilitation specialists and other experts to cope with side effects, such as hearing loss, difficulty eating, dental problems, thyroid issues, difficulty breathing or difficulty speaking.
info-Symptoms: Lump or sore that does not heal, sore throat that does not go away, trouble swallowing, change in the voice
info-Risk factors: Alcohol, tobacco, betel quid, human papillomavirus, radiation exposure, certain workplace exposures, Epstein-Barr virus
info-Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy

Name: Headache , chronic daily
Treatment: These medications can also help treat the depression, anxiety and sleep disturbances that often accompany chronic daily headaches. Other antidepressants, such as the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) fluoxetine (Prozac, Sarafem, others), might help in treating depression and anxiety, but have not been shown to be more effective than placebo for headaches. Some anti-seizure drugs seem to prevent migraines and might be used to prevent chronic daily headaches, as well. Options include topiramate (Topamax, Qudexy XR, others), divalproex sodium (Depakote) and gabapentin (Neurontin, Gralise). Prescription nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as naproxen sodium (Anaprox, Naprelan) might be helpful, especially if one is withdrawing from other pain relievers.

Name: Headache , cluster
Symptoms: A cluster headache strikes quickly, usually without warning, although one might first have migraine-like nausea and aura. Some migraine-like symptoms including sensitivity to light and sound can occur with a cluster headache, though usually on one side. Chronic cluster periods might continue for more than a year, or pain-free periods might last less than one month.
Overview: Cluster headaches, which occur in cyclical patterns or cluster periods, are one of the most painful types of headache. Bouts of frequent attacks, known as cluster periods, can last from weeks to months, usually followed by remission periods when the headaches stop.
Risk factors: Risk factors for cluster headaches include Sex. Most people who develop cluster headaches are between ages 20 and 50, although the condition can develop at any age. If one has cluster headaches, drinking alcohol during a cluster period may increase the risk of an attack.

Name: Headache , exercise
Overview: Exercise headaches occur during or after sustained, strenuous exercise. Secondary exercise headaches are caused by an underlying, often serious problem within the brain such as bleeding or a tumor or outside the brain such as coronary artery disease.
Diagnosis: The doctor will likely recommend an imaging test, especially if: In these cases, different types of imaging tests can help the doctor verify that one has the harmless variety of exercise headache, rather than the type caused by a structural or vascular abnormality. Sometimes a spinal tap (lumbar puncture) is needed as well, especially if the headache started abruptly and very recently and brain imaging appears normal. The headaches last more than a few hours The headaches strike suddenly, like a thunderclap One is older than age 40 One has other signs and symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting or vision disturbances Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
Treatment: If no underlying structural or vascular problem is causing the exercise headaches, the doctor may recommend medications to take regularly to help prevent the headaches. Propranolol (Inderal, Innopran XL), a blood pressure medication, also is used to prevent exercise headaches.

Name: Headache , external compression
Symptoms: The pain of external compression headaches is often described as moderate, constant pressure. It's usually not necessary to see a doctor for a compression headache because it goes away, usually within an hour of removing whatever is causing the pressure.
Overview: External compression headaches can occur when something worn on the head puts continuous pressure on the forehead or scalp. People likely to get external compression headaches include construction workers, people in the military, police officers and athletes.
Treatment: To end the headache, remove the headwear that's causing the pressure. If one has a history of migraines, wearing tight headwear may trigger an attack that requires migraine medication for relief. The international classification of headache disorders, 3rd edition (beta version).

Name: Headache , primary cough
Causes: Secondary cough headaches may be caused by: A defect in the cerebellum, the part of the brain that controls balance. A defect in the cerebellum, the part of the brain that controls balance.
Risk factors: Risk factors for primary cough headaches include Risk factors for secondary cough headaches include Age. Primary cough headaches most often affect people older than age 40.

Name: Headaches in children
Symptoms: For example, migraine pain in adults often lasts at least four hours but in children, the pain may be much less than that. Tension-type headaches can cause: Younger children may withdraw from regular play and want to sleep more. CDH may be caused by an infection, minor head injury or taking pain medications even nonprescription pain medications too often.
Overview: Headaches in children are common and usually aren't serious. Like adults, children can develop different types of headaches, including migraines or stress-related (tension) headaches.
Causes: Common illnesses such as colds, flu, and ear and sinus infections are some of the most frequent causes of headaches in children. Very rarely, meningitis or encephalitis may cause headaches. Stress and anxiety perhaps triggered by problems with peers, teachers or parents can play a role in children's headaches. Children with depression may complain of headaches, particularly if they have trouble recognizing feelings of sadness and loneliness. Nitrates a food preservative found in cured meats, such as bacon, bologna and hot dogs can trigger headaches, as can the food additive MSG. Also, too much caffeine contained in soda, chocolates, coffees and teas can cause headaches.
Diagnosis: To learn about the nature of the child's headache, the doctor will likely look to: If the child is otherwise healthy and headaches are the only symptom, no further testing usually is needed. The doctor asks one and the child to describe the headaches in detail, to see if there's a pattern or a common trigger. The doctor may also ask one to keep a headache diary for a time, so one can record more details about the child's headaches, such as frequency, severity of pain and possible triggers. The doctor performs a physical exam, including measuring the child's height, weight, head circumference, blood pressure and pulse, and examining the child's eyes, neck, head, shoulders and spine. This helps doctors diagnose tumors, infections and other medical problems that can cause headaches. If the doctor suspects that an underlying condition, such as bacterial or viral meningitis, is causing the child's headaches, he or she may recommend a spinal tap (lumbar puncture).
Remedies: OTC pain medications, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin, others), are usually effective in reducing headache pain. Before giving the child pain medication, keep these points in mind: In addition to OTC pain medications, the following can help ease the child's headache: Read labels carefully and use only the dosages recommended for the child. Daily use can trigger a medication overuse headache, a type of headache caused by overuse of pain medications. Though aspirin is approved for use in children older than age 3, children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin. This is because aspirin has been linked to Reye's syndrome, a rare but potentially life-threatening condition, in such children.
Medication: Acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin, others) can typically relieve headaches for the child. Though aspirin is approved for use in children older than age 3, children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin. Aspirin has been linked to Reye's syndrome, a rare but potentially life-threatening condition, in such children. Triptans, prescription drugs used to treat migraines, are effective and can be used safely in children older than 6 years of age. If the child experiences nausea and vomiting with migraines, the doctor may prescribe an anti-nausea drug. If the child takes medications regularly, including products one buy over-the-counter, discuss the risks and benefits with the doctor. During a biofeedback session, the child is connected to devices that monitor and give feedback on body functions, such as muscle tension, heart rate and blood pressure. During this type of talk therapy, a counselor helps the child learn ways to view and cope with life events more positively.

Name: Heart arrhythmias
Symptoms: If this occurs, follow these steps: Find out if an automated external defibrillator (AED) is available nearby. If there's no one nearby trained in cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), provide hands-only CPR. If one or someone nearby knows CPR, begin providing it if it's needed.
Overview: Heart rhythm problems (heart arrhythmias) occur when the electrical impulses that coordinate the heartbeats don't work properly, causing the heart to beat too fast, too slow or irregularly. However, some heart arrhythmias may cause bothersome sometimes even life-threatening signs and symptoms. In addition, because troublesome heart arrhythmias are often made worse or are even caused by a weak or damaged heart, one may be able to reduce the arrhythmia risk by adopting a heart-healthy lifestyle. Doctors classify arrhythmias not only by where they originate (atria or ventricles) but also by the speed of heart rate they cause: Not all tachycardias or bradycardias mean one has heart disease. Ventricular fibrillation occurs when rapid, chaotic electrical impulses cause the ventricles to quiver ineffectively instead of pumping necessary blood to the body. The rapid heartbeats, caused by changes in the electrical system of the heart, may lead to fainting, and can be life-threatening. If one is physically fit, one may have an efficient heart capable of pumping an adequate supply of blood with fewer than 60 beats a minute at rest. However, if one has a slow heart rate and the heart isn't pumping enough blood, one may have one of several bradycardias, including Conduction block. A block of the heart's electrical pathways can occur in or near the AV node, which lies on the pathway between the atria and the ventricles. If the signal is completely blocked, certain cells in the AV node or ventricles can make a steady, although usually slower, heartbeat. Premature heartbeats may occur when one is resting or may sometimes be caused by stress, strenuous exercise or stimulants, such as caffeine or nicotine. This pathway may allow electrical signals to pass between the atria and the ventricles without passing through the AV node, leading to short circuits and rapid heartbeats. Ventricular tachycardia is a rapid, regular heart rate that originates with abnormal electrical signals in the ventricles. Ventricular tachycardia may not cause serious problems if one has an otherwise healthy heart, but it can be a medical emergency that requires prompt medical treatment if one has heart disease or a weak heart. If the sinus node, which is responsible for setting the pace of the heart, isn't sending impulses properly, the heart rate may alternate between too slow (bradycardia) and too fast (tachycardia).
Risk factors: These include Other factors that may put one at higher risk of developing an arrhythmia include Coronary artery disease, other heart problems and previous heart surgery. Narrowed heart arteries, a heart attack, abnormal heart valves, prior heart surgery, heart failure, cardiomyopathy and other heart damage are risk factors for almost any kind of arrhythmia. It may also cause the walls of the left ventricle to become stiff and thick, which can change how electrical impulses travel through the heart. Substances in the blood called electrolytes such as potassium, sodium, calcium and magnesium help trigger and conduct the electrical impulses in the heart. Caffeine, nicotine and other stimulants can cause the heart to beat faster and may contribute to the development of more-serious arrhythmias. Illegal drugs, such as amphetamines and cocaine, may profoundly affect the heart and lead to many types of arrhythmias or to sudden death due to ventricular fibrillation.
Diagnosis: The doctor may ask about or test for conditions that may trigger the arrhythmia, such as heart disease or a problem with the thyroid gland. The doctor may also perform heart-monitoring tests specific to arrhythmias. These may include If the doctor doesn't find an arrhythmia during those tests, he or she may try to trigger the arrhythmia with other tests, which may include Electrophysiological testing and mapping. In this test, doctors thread thin, flexible tubes (catheters) tipped with electrodes through the blood vessels to a variety of spots within the heart. In addition, the cardiologist can use the electrodes to stimulate the heart to beat at rates that may trigger or halt an arrhythmia. During an ECG, sensors (electrodes) that can detect the electrical activity of the heart are attached to the chest and sometimes to the limbs. In this noninvasive test, a hand-held device (transducer) placed on the chest uses sound waves to produce images of the heart's size, structure and motion. If the symptoms are very infrequent, an event recorder may be implanted under the skin in the chest area to continually record the heart's electrical activity and detect abnormal heart rhythms. If doctors are evaluating one to determine if coronary artery disease may be causing the arrhythmia, and one has difficulty exercising, then the doctor may use a drug to stimulate the heart in a way that's similar to exercise.
Remedies: The doctor may suggest that, in addition to other treatments, one make lifestyle changes that will keep the heart as healthy as possible. Eat a healthy diet that's low in salt and solid fats and rich in fruits, vegetables and whole grains. For healthy adults, that means up to one drink a day for women of all ages and men older than age 65, and up to two drinks a day for men age 65 and younger.
info-Symptoms: Palpitations, lightheadedness, passing out, shortness of breath, chest pain
info-Causes: Problems with the electrical conduction system of the heart

Name: Heart defects in adults
Symptoms: Common congenital heart disease symptoms in adults include If one is having worrisome symptoms, such as chest pain or shortness of breath, seek emergency medical attention. If one has signs or symptoms of congenital heart disease or were treated for a congenital heart defect as a child, make an appointment to see the doctor.
Overview: Congenital heart disease is one or more problems with the heart's structure that exist since birth. Congenital heart disease, also called congenital heart defect, can change the way blood flows through the heart. Sometimes, signs and symptoms of congenital heart disease aren't seen until one is an adult.
Risk factors: Certain environmental and genetic risk factors might play a role in the development of congenital heart disease, including The genes. Congenital heart disease appears to run in families (inherited) and is associated with many genetic syndromes. Having type 1 or type 2 diabetes during pregnancy also may affect a baby's heart development. Taking certain medications while pregnant can cause congenital heart disease and other birth defects. Medications linked to heart defects include lithium for bipolar disorder and isotretinoin (Claravis, Myorisan, Zenatane, others), which is used to treat acne.
Diagnosis: To diagnose congenital heart disease, the doctor will do a physical exam and listen to the heart with a stethoscope. Tests to diagnose or rule out congenital heart disease include Electrocardiogram (ECG). An ECG can diagnose many heart problems, including irregular heartbeats and blocked arteries. The doctor can use this test to see how the heart's chambers and valves are pumping blood through the heart. If more-detailed images of the heart are needed, the doctor may recommend a transesophageal echocardiogram. Cardiac MRI uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create images of the heart. The doctor might use this test to check blood flow and blood pressures in the heart. Then, the doctor gently inserts a catheter into an artery or vein in the groin, neck or arm and up to the heart.
Medication: If one is an adult with congenital heart disease, one is at risk of developing complications even if one had surgery to repair a defect during childhood. A device that helps control the heart rate (pacemaker) or that corrects life-threatening irregular heartbeats (implantable cardioverter-defibrillator or ICD) may help improve some of the complications associated with congenital heart defects. If catheter procedures can't fix the heart defect, the doctor might recommend open-heart surgery.

Name: Heart disease
Symptoms: Symptoms can include One might not be diagnosed with cardiovascular disease until one has a heart attack, angina, stroke or heart failure. Heart arrhythmia symptoms can include Serious congenital heart defects defects one is born with usually become evident soon after birth. Signs and symptoms of congenital heart defects that usually aren't immediately life-threatening include In early stages of cardiomyopathy, one may have no symptoms. If one think one may have heart disease, based on new signs or symptoms one is having, make an appointment to see the doctor.
Overview: Heart disease describes a range of conditions that affect the heart. Diseases under the heart disease umbrella include blood vessel diseases, such as coronary artery disease; heart rhythm problems (arrhythmias); and heart defects one is born with (congenital heart defects), among others. Cardiovascular disease generally refers to conditions that involve narrowed or blocked blood vessels that can lead to a heart attack, chest pain (angina) or stroke.
Causes: The lower chambers, the right and left ventricles, pump blood out of the heart. The heart's electrical wiring keeps it beating, which controls the continuous exchange of oxygen-rich blood with oxygen-poor blood. That's primarily because a healthy person's heart is free from any abnormal conditions that cause an arrhythmia, such as an area of scarred tissue. Heart defects can develop as the heart develops, about a month after conception, changing the flow of blood in the heart. Oxygen-rich blood then enters the left side of the heart, comprising the left atrium and ventricle. During relaxation (diastole), the ventricles are filled with blood coming from the upper chambers (left and right atria). Electrical impulses begin high in the right atrium and travel through specialized pathways to the ventricles, delivering the signal for the heart to pump. The conduction system keeps the heart beating in a coordinated and normal rhythm, which keeps blood circulating. This least common type of cardiomyopathy, which causes the heart muscle to become rigid and less elastic, can occur for no known reason.
Risk factors: Risk factors for developing heart disease include Age. A family history of heart disease increases the risk of coronary artery disease, especially if a parent developed it at an early age (before age 55 for a male relative, such as the brother or father, and 65 for a female relative, such as the mother or sister). A diet that's high in fat, salt, sugar and cholesterol can contribute to the development of heart disease. Both conditions share similar risk factors, such as obesity and high blood pressure. Lack of exercise also is associated with many forms of heart disease and some of its other risk factors, as well. Unrelieved stress may damage the arteries and worsen other risk factors for heart disease. Not regularly washing the hands and not establishing other habits that can help prevent viral or bacterial infections can put one at risk of heart infections, especially if one already have an underlying heart condition.
Diagnosis: Besides blood tests and a chest X-ray, tests to diagnose heart disease can include Cardiac catheterization. Aided by X-ray images on a monitor, the doctor threads the guide catheter through that artery until it reaches the heart. The dye can be seen on an X-ray, which helps the doctor see the blood flow through the heart, blood vessels and valves to check for abnormalities. Aided by X-ray images on a monitor, the doctor threads the guide catheter through that artery until it reaches the heart.The pressures in the heart chambers can be measured, and dye can be injected.
Treatment: In general, treatment for heart disease usually includes: Lifestyle changes. If lifestyle changes alone aren't enough, the doctor may prescribe medications to control the heart disease.
Remedies: Most people should aim for an LDL level below 130 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 3.4 millimoles per liter (mmol/L). If one has other risk factors for heart disease, one should aim for an LDL below 100 mg/dL (2.6 mmol/L). If one is at very high risk of heart disease if one has already had a heart attack or have diabetes, for example aim for an even lower LDL level below 70 mg/dL (1.8 mmol/L). Exercise helps one achieve and maintain a healthy weight and control diabetes, elevated cholesterol and high blood pressure all risk factors for heart disease. If the test results aren't within desirable ranges, the doctor may recommend more frequent measurements.Most people should aim for an LDL level below 130 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 3.4 millimoles per liter (mmol/L). If one has diabetes, tight blood sugar control can help reduce the risk of heart disease. If one has a heart arrhythmia or heart defect, there may be some restrictions on the activities one can do, so talk to the doctor.With the doctor's OK, aim for 30 to 60 minutes of physical activity most days of the week. A heart-healthy diet based on fruits, vegetables and whole grains and low in saturated fat, cholesterol, sodium and added sugar can help one control the weight, blood pressure and cholesterol.
info-Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath
info-Prevention: Healthy eating, exercise, avoiding tobacco smoke, limited alcohol intake
info-Treatment: Treating high blood pressure, high blood lipids, diabetes

Name: Heart failure
Symptoms: Heart failure can be ongoing (chronic), or the condition may start suddenly (acute). Heart failure signs and symptoms may include See the doctor if one think one might be experiencing signs or symptoms of heart failure. Emergency room doctors will try to stabilize the condition and determine if the symptoms are due to heart failure or something else.
Causes: The lower chambers, the right and left ventricles, pump blood out of the heart. In heart failure, the main pumping chambers of the heart (the ventricles) may become stiff and not fill properly between beats. Heart failure can involve the left side (left ventricle), right side (right ventricle) or both sides of the heart. Generally, heart failure begins with the left side, specifically the left ventricle the heart's main pumping chamber. The disease results from the buildup of fatty deposits (plaque) in the arteries, which reduce blood flow and can lead to heart attack. It's most commonly caused by a virus, including COVID-19, and can lead to left-sided heart failure.
Risk factors: A single risk factor may be enough to cause heart failure, but a combination of factors also increases the risk. Narrowed arteries may limit the heart's supply of oxygen-rich blood, resulting in weakened heart muscle. The diabetes drugs rosiglitazone (Avandia) and pioglitazone (Actos) have been found to increase the risk of heart failure in some people. Medications that may increase the risk of heart problems include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs); certain anesthesia medications; some anti-arrhythmic medications; certain medications used to treat high blood pressure, cancer, blood conditions, neurological conditions, psychiatric conditions, lung conditions, urological conditions, inflammatory conditions and infections; and other prescription and over-the-counter medications. The inability to breathe properly while one sleep at night results in low blood oxygen levels and increased risk of abnormal heart rhythms. People with valvular heart disease have a higher risk of heart failure. These abnormal rhythms, especially if they are very frequent and fast, can weaken the heart muscle and cause heart failure.
Diagnosis: To diagnose heart failure, the doctor will take a careful medical history, review the symptoms and perform a physical examination. The doctor can also use an X-ray to diagnose conditions other than heart failure that may explain the signs and symptoms. An echocardiogram measures the ejection fraction, an important measurement of how well the heart is pumping, and which is used to help classify heart failure and guide treatment. If the doctor also wants to see images of the heart while one is exercising, he or she may use imaging techniques to visualize the heart during the test. A dye injected through the catheter makes the arteries supplying the heart visible on an X-ray, helping doctors spot blockages. In this test, the doctor inserts a small, flexible biopsy cord into a vein in the neck or groin, and small pieces of the heart muscle are taken. To determine the most appropriate treatment for the condition, doctors may classify heart failure using two systems: New York Heart Association classification. For example, a person who has several risk factors for heart failure but no signs or symptoms of heart failure is Stage A. Someone who has heart disease and is experiencing or has experienced signs or symptoms of heart failure is Stage C. A person with advanced heart failure requiring specialized treatments is Stage D. Doctors use this classification system to identify the risk factors and begin early, more aggressive treatment to help prevent or delay heart failure. Someone who has heart disease and is experiencing or has experienced signs or symptoms of heart failure is Stage C. A person with advanced heart failure requiring specialized treatments is Stage D. Doctors use this classification system to identify the risk factors and begin early, more aggressive treatment to help prevent or delay heart failure.
Remedies: Smoking damages the blood vessels, raises blood pressure, reduces the amount of oxygen in the blood and makes the heart beat faster. Too much sodium contributes to water retention, which makes the heart work harder and causes shortness of breath and swollen legs, ankles and feet. If one has heart failure, one may want to get influenza and pneumonia vaccinations. In addition to avoiding high-sodium foods, limit the amount of saturated fat and trans fat also called trans-fatty acids in the diet. The doctor may recommend that one don't drink alcohol if one has heart failure, since it can interact with the medication, weaken the heart muscle and increase the risk of abnormal heart rhythms. If one has severe heart failure, the doctor may also suggest one limit the amount of fluids one drink. Moderate aerobic activity helps keep the rest of the body healthy and conditioned, reducing the demands on the heart muscle. When one is anxious or upset, the heart beats faster, one breathe more heavily and the blood pressure often goes up. This can make heart failure worse, since the heart is already having trouble meeting the body's demands.
Medication: ACE inhibitors are a type of vasodilator, a drug that widens blood vessels to lower blood pressure, improve blood flow and decrease the workload on the heart. Beta blockers may reduce signs and symptoms of heart failure, improve heart function, and help one live longer. These are potassium-sparing diuretics, which also have additional properties that may help people with severe systolic heart failure live longer. The doctor may prescribe other heart medications as well such as nitrates for chest pain, a statin to lower cholesterol or blood-thinning medications to help prevent blood clots along with heart failure medications. While in the hospital, one may receive additional medications to help the heart pump better and relieve the symptoms. If one has severe heart failure, one may need to use supplemental oxygen long term. In some cases, doctors recommend surgery to treat the underlying problem that led to heart failure. If severely blocked arteries are contributing to the heart failure, the doctor may recommend coronary artery bypass surgery. If a faulty heart valve causes the heart failure, the doctor may recommend repairing or replacing the valve. Certain types of heart valve repair or replacement can now be done without open heart surgery, using either minimally invasive surgery or cardiac catheterization techniques. A biventricular pacemaker sends timed electrical impulses to both of the heart's lower chambers (the left and right ventricles) so that they pump in a more efficient, coordinated manner. A VAD, also known as a mechanical circulatory support device, is an implantable mechanical pump that helps pump blood from the lower chambers of the heart (the ventricles) to the rest of the body. If one has an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), one important consideration to discuss with the family and doctors is turning off the defibrillator so that it can't deliver shocks to make the heart continue beating.
info-Symptoms: Shortness of breath, feeling tired, leg swelling
info-Causes: Heart attack, high blood pressure, abnormal heart rhythm, excessive alcohol use, infection, heart damage
info-Risk factors: Smoking, sedentary lifestyle, exposure to second-hand smoke

Name: Heart murmurs
Causes: In children, abnormal murmurs are usually caused by congenital heart disease. In adults, abnormal murmurs are most often due to acquired heart valve problems. The most common cause of abnormal murmurs in children is when babies are born with structural problems of the heart (congenital heart defects). Cardiac shunts occur when there's an abnormal blood flow between the heart chambers or blood vessels, which may lead to a heart murmur. Other causes of abnormal heart murmurs include infections and conditions that damage the structures of the heart and are more common in older children or adults. Congenital heart valve abnormalities are present at birth, but sometimes aren't discovered until much later in life. Valves may become narrowed (stenotic), making it harder for blood to flow through the heart, resulting in murmurs.
Risk factors: Certain medical conditions, including uncontrolled high blood pressure (hypertension), hyperthyroidism, an infection of the lining of the heart (endocarditis), high blood pressure in the lungs (pulmonary hypertension), carcinoid syndrome, hypereosinophilic syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, a weakened heart muscle or a history of rheumatic fever, can increase the risk of a heart murmur later in life. Having some conditions during pregnancy, such as uncontrolled diabetes or a rubella infection, increases the baby's risk of developing heart defects and a heart murmur.
Diagnosis: Heart murmurs are usually detected when the doctor listens to the heart using a stethoscope during a physical exam. To check whether the murmur is innocent or abnormal, the doctor will consider: The doctor will also look for other signs and symptoms of heart problems and ask about the medical history and whether other family members have had heart murmurs or other heart conditions. If the doctor thinks the heart murmur is abnormal, one or the child may need additional tests, including Cardiac catheterization. In this test, a catheter is inserted into a vein or artery in the leg or arm until it reaches the heart. The dye can be seen on an X-ray, which helps the doctor see the blood flow through the heart, blood vessels and valves to check for problems. Murmurs that happen when the heart is filling with blood (diastolic murmur) or throughout the heartbeat (continuous murmur) may indicate a heart problem. Murmurs that occur when the heart is emptying (systolic) generally are innocent heart murmurs that don't cause health issues, but sometimes they may reflect a heart condition. A chest X-ray shows an image of the heart, lungs and blood vessels. It can reveal if the heart is enlarged, which may mean an underlying condition is causing the heart murmur. In this noninvasive test, a technician will place probes on the chest that record the electrical impulses that make the heart beat. An ECG records these electrical signals and can help the doctor look for heart rhythm and structure problems. Echocardiography can help identify abnormal heart valves, such as those that are hardened (calcified) or leaking, and can also detect most heart defects.
Medication: Depending on the heart condition, the doctor may recommend one of these options to treat a damaged or leaky valve: To repair a valve, the doctor may recommend one of the following procedures: In many cases, the valve has to be replaced. If one receive a mechanical valve, one will need to take an anticoagulant medication, such as warfarin (Coumadin, Jantoven), for life to prevent blood clots. Tissue valves which may come from a pig, cow or human deceased donor often eventually need replacement. In some cases, a valve can be inserted via a catheter into a tissue replacement valve that needs to be replaced (valve-in-valve procedure). Doctors no longer recommend antibiotics before procedures, except for people at highest risk of complications of infective endocarditis, such as those who have an artificial heart valve or people with certain congenital heart defects. Having high cholesterol seems to worsen some heart valve problems, including some heart murmurs. During a balloon valvuloplasty, a small catheter containing an expandable balloon is threaded into the heart, placed into the valve and then expanded to help widen the narrowed valve. In this procedure, the surgeon replaces or shortens the cords that support the valves (chordae tendineae and papillary muscles) to repair the structural support. In valve leaflet repair, the surgeon surgically separates, cuts or pleats a valve flap (leaflet).
info-Symptoms: Whooshing

Name: Heartburn
Causes: Acid reflux occurs when the sphincter muscle at the lower end of the esophagus relaxes at the wrong time, allowing stomach acid to back up into the esophagus. Heartburn occurs when stomach acid backs up into the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach (esophagus). If the lower esophageal sphincter relaxes abnormally or weakens, stomach acid can flow back up into the esophagus (acid reflux) and cause heartburn.
Treatment: H-2-receptor antagonists (H2RAs), which can reduce stomach acid. H2RAs don't act as quickly as antacids, but may provide longer relief. Proton pump inhibitors, such as lansoprazole (Prevacid 24HR) and omeprazole (Nexium 24HR, Prilosec OTC), which also can reduce stomach acid. Antacids, H-2-receptor antagonists (H2RAs), Proton pump inhibitors, Maintain a healthy weight.
Remedies: Avoid tightfitting clothing, which puts pressure on the abdomen and the lower esophageal sphincter. Avoid tightfitting clothing, Avoid foods that trigger the heartburn.
info-Symptoms: Burning, stabbing, or squeezing sensation in the chest, nausea, belching
info-Risk factors: Smoking, obesity,
info-Diagnostic method: Physical examination, medical history, antacid response, imaging, manometry,
info-Prevention: Avoid foods that are high in fats, spicy, high in artificial flavors. Avoid reclining 3-4 hours after a meal, heavy NSAID use, heavy alcohol consumption, decrease peppermint consumption. Chew foods thoroughly between bites, consume meals with plenty of liquid, and ensure adequate time to eat meals in a non-hurried fashion

Name: Heat exhaustion
Risk factors: The body's ability to regulate its temperature isn't fully developed in the young and may be reduced by illness, medications or other factors in older adults. Medications that affect the body's ability to stay hydrated and respond appropriately to heat include some used to treat high blood pressure and heart problems (beta blockers, diuretics), reduce allergy symptoms (antihistamines), calm one (tranquilizers), or reduce psychiatric symptoms such as delusions (antipsychotics). Traveling to a warm climate from a cold one or living in an area that has experienced an early heat wave can put one at risk of a heat-related illness because the body hasn't had a chance to get used to the higher temperatures. When the humidity is high, the sweat can't evaporate as easily and the body has more difficulty cooling itself, making one prone to heat exhaustion and heatstroke. When the heat index is 91 F (33 C) or higher, one should take precautions to keep cool.
Treatment: To cool the body to a normal temperature, the doctor may use these heatstroke treatment techniques: Rest in a cool place. If possible, take a cool shower, soak in a cool bath, or put towels soaked in cool water on the skin. If one is outdoors and not near shelter, soaking in a cool pond or stream can help bring the temperature down. A bath of cold or ice water has been proved to be the most effective way of quickly lowering the core body temperature. If the core body temperature is not in the heatstroke range and if cold water immersion is not available, health care workers may try to lower the body temperature using an evaporation method. Cool water is misted on the body while warm air is fanned over one, causing the water to evaporate and cool the skin. Another method is to wrap one in a special cooling blanket and apply ice packs to the groin, neck, back and armpits to lower the temperature. If treatments to lower the body temperature make one shiver, the doctor may give one a muscle relaxant, such as a benzodiazepine. Shivering increases the body temperature, making treatment less effective.

Name: Heatstroke
Symptoms: Heatstroke signs and symptoms include If one think a person may be experiencing heatstroke, seek immediate medical help. A core body temperature of 104 F (40 C) or higher, obtained with a rectal thermometer, is the main sign of heatstroke. Confusion, agitation, slurred speech, irritability, delirium, seizures and coma can all result from heatstroke. In heatstroke brought on by hot weather, the skin will feel hot and dry to the touch. However, in heatstroke brought on by strenuous exercise, the skin may feel dry or slightly moist. The pulse may significantly increase because heat stress places a tremendous burden on the heart to help cool the body.
Overview: Heatstroke is a condition caused by the body overheating, usually as a result of prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures. This most serious form of heat injury, heatstroke, can occur if the body temperature rises to 104 F (40 C) or higher.
Causes: In a type of heatstroke, called nonexertional (classic) heatstroke, being in a hot environment leads to a rise in core body temperature. Anyone exercising or working in hot weather can get exertional heatstroke, but it's most likely to occur if one is not used to high temperatures.
Risk factors: Anyone can develop heatstroke, but several factors increase the risk: Certain medications. Be especially careful in hot weather if one take medications that narrow the blood vessels (vasoconstrictors), regulate the blood pressure by blocking adrenaline (beta blockers), rid the body of sodium and water (diuretics), or reduce psychiatric symptoms (antidepressants or antipsychotics). In the very young, the central nervous system is not fully developed, and in adults over 65, the central nervous system begins to deteriorate, which makes the body less able to cope with changes in body temperature. Military training and participating in sports, such as football or long-distance running events, in hot weather are among the situations that can lead to heatstroke. One may be more susceptible to heat-related illness if one is exposed to a sudden increase in temperature, such as during an early-summer heat wave or travel to a hotter climate. However, one may still have an increased risk of heatstroke until one has experienced several weeks of higher temperatures. Fans may make one feel better, but during sustained hot weather, air conditioning is the most effective way to cool down and lower humidity. Certain chronic illnesses, such as heart or lung disease, might increase the risk of heatstroke.
Treatment: Heatstroke treatment centers on cooling the body to a normal temperature to prevent or reduce damage to the brain and vital organs. To do this, the doctor may take these steps: Home treatment isn't enough for heatstroke. If one notice signs of heat-related illness, lower the body temperature and prevent the condition from progressing to heatstroke. In a lesser heat emergency, such as heat cramps or heat exhaustion, the following steps may lower the body temperature: Immerse one in cold water. If cold water immersion is unavailable, health care workers may try to lower the body temperature using an evaporation method. Cool water is misted on the body while warm air is fanned over one, causing the water to evaporate and cool the skin. Another method is to wrap one in a special cooling blanket and apply ice packs to the groin, neck, back and armpits to lower the temperature. If treatments to lower the body temperature make one shiver, the doctor may give one a muscle relaxant, such as a benzodiazepine. If one is with someone who's experiencing heat-related symptoms, cool the person by covering him or her with damp sheets or by spraying with cool water.
Remedies: If one has signs or symptoms of heatstroke, seek emergency medical help. If one notice signs of heat-related illness, lower the body temperature and prevent the condition from progressing to heatstroke. In a lesser heat emergency, such as heat cramps or heat exhaustion, the following steps may lower the body temperature: Get to a shady or air-conditioned place. If one don't have air conditioning at home, go someplace with air conditioning, such as the mall, movie theater or public library. If one is with someone who's experiencing heat-related symptoms, cool the person by covering him or her with damp sheets or by spraying with cool water. If one is outdoors and not near shelter, soaking in a cool pond or stream can help bring the temperature down. If the doctor has restricted the fluid or salt intake, check with him or her to see how much one should drink and whether one should replace salt.
