Exertional heat illness in adolescents and adults: Epidemiology, thermoregulation, risk factors, and diagnosis.
info-Symptoms: High body temperature, red, dry or damp skin, headache, dizziness, confusion, nausea
info-Risk factors: Extremes of age, heat waves, high humidity, certain drugs, heart disease, skin disorders
info-Prognosis: Risk of death <5% (exercise induced), up to 65% (non exercise induced)

Name: Helicobacter pylori ( H. pylori ) infection
Overview: Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection occurs when H. pylori bacteria infect the stomach. A common cause of peptic ulcers, H. pylori infection may be present in more than half the people in the world.
Causes: H. pylori bacteria may be passed from person to person through direct contact with saliva, vomit or fecal matter.
Risk factors: Risk factors for H. pylori infection are related to living conditions in the childhood, such as: Living in crowded conditions. People living in developing countries, where crowded and unsanitary living conditions may be more common, have a higher risk of H. pylori infection.
Diagnosis: This test isn't generally recommended solely to diagnose an H. pylori infection because it's more invasive than a breath or stool test, but it may be used to diagnose H. pylori ulcers or if it's needed to rule out other digestive conditions. However, breath and stool tests are better at detecting active H. pylori infections than is a blood test. A laboratory test called a stool antigen test looks for foreign proteins (antigens) associated with H. pylori infection in the stool. As with the breath test, PPIs and bismuth subsalicylate can affect the results of this test, so the doctor will ask one to stop taking them for two weeks before the test.
Treatment: H. pylori infections are usually treated with at least two different antibiotics at once, to help prevent the bacteria from developing a resistance to one particular antibiotic. The doctor may test and treat one for H. pylori infection, or refer one to a specialist who treats diseases of the digestive system (gastroenterologist). Some examples of PPIs are omeprazole (Prilosec), esomeprazole (Nexium), lansoprazole (Prevacid) and pantoprazole (Protonix).

Name: Hemifacial spasm
Treatment: Treatment for hemifacial spasm may include Microvascular decompression surgery. In this surgery, the surgeon makes an opening in the skull and opens the covering of the brain (dura) to expose the facial nerve as it leaves the brainstem. The surgeon locates the blood vessel pressing on or irritating the facial nerve and puts a spongelike material between the nerve and blood vessel, removing the pressure on the nerve. The doctor may inject botulinum toxin (Botox) into the affected muscles, which temporarily paralyzes those muscles. Medications, including anticonvulsant drugs, can relieve hemifacial spasm in some people. Hemifacial spasm: The past, present and future.

Name: Hemolytic uremic syndrome ( HUS )
Overview: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a condition that can occur when the small blood vessels in the kidneys become damaged and inflamed. In many cases, HUS is caused by infection with certain strains of Escherichia coli (E. coli) bacteria. HUS may also be caused by other infections, certain medications or conditions such as pregnancy, cancer or autoimmune disease.
Causes: The most common cause of HUS particularly in children under the age of 5 is infection with certain strains of E. coli bacteria.
Risk factors: Exposure to E. coli can occur when one: The risk of developing HUS is highest for: Eat contaminated meat or produce Swim in pools or lakes contaminated with feces Have close contact with an infected person, such as within a family or at a child care center.
Diagnosis: To confirm a diagnosis of HUS, the doctor is likely to perform a physical exam and recommend lab tests, including If the cause of HUS is not clear, the doctor may also recommend additional tests to help determine the cause. Blood tests can also reveal a low platelet count, low red blood cell count or a higher than normal level of creatinine, a waste product normally removed by the kidneys.
Medication: If one has lasting kidney damage from HUS, the doctor might recommend a medication to lower the blood pressure, to prevent or delay further kidney damage. If one develop complications or have the form of HUS that's caused by a genetic mutation (atypical HUS), the doctor may recommend eculizumab (Soliris) to help prevent additional damage to the blood vessels. Depending on the symptoms, the cause of the HUS and whether one has any complications, the doctor may recommend other treatments, including Kidney dialysis.

Name: Hemophilia
Overview: Hemophilia is a rare disorder in which the blood doesn't clot normally because it lacks sufficient blood-clotting proteins (clotting factors). If one has a severe deficiency of the clotting factor protein, the greater health concern is deep bleeding inside the body, especially in the knees, ankles and elbows.
Causes: In these people, an unexpected change occurs in one of the genes associated with hemophilia. Acquired hemophilia is a rare variety of the condition that occurs when a person's immune system attacks clotting factors in the blood. It can be associated with: In the most common types of hemophilia, the faulty gene is located on the X chromosome. This means that hemophilia almost always occurs in boys and is passed from mother to son through one of the mother's genes.
Diagnosis: For people with a family history of hemophilia, it's possible to determine during pregnancy if the fetus is affected by hemophilia. Depending on the severity of the deficiency, hemophilia symptoms can first arise at various ages.
Treatment: The main treatment for severe hemophilia involves receiving replacement of the specific clotting factor that one need through a tube placed in a vein. Similar products, called recombinant clotting factors, are manufactured in a laboratory and aren't made from human blood.
Remedies: Drugs that can aggravate bleeding include aspirin and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others). Instead, use acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), which is a safer alternative for mild pain relief. Medications that prevent blood from clotting include heparin, warfarin (Coumadin, Jantoven), clopidogrel (Plavix), prasugrel (Effient), ticagrelor (Brilinta), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), apixaban (Eliquis), edoxaban (Savaysa) and dabigatran (Pradaxa).
info-Symptoms: Easy and prolonged bleeding
info-Frequency: 1 in 7,500 males (haemophilia A), 1 in 40,000 males (haemophilia B)

Name: Hepatitis A
Overview: Hepatitis A is a highly contagious liver infection caused by the hepatitis A virus. The virus is one of several types of hepatitis viruses that cause inflammation and affect the liver's ability to function.
Treatment: In most cases of hepatitis A, the liver heals within six months with no lasting damage. If someone close to one is diagnosed with hepatitis A, ask the doctor or local health department if one should have the hepatitis A vaccine to prevent infection. If one has signs and symptoms of hepatitis A, make an appointment with the family doctor or a primary doctor.
info-Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dark urine, jaundice, fever, abdominal pain
info-Causes: Eating food or drinking water contaminated with Hepatovirus A infected feces
info-Prevention: Hepatitis A vaccine, hand washing, properly cooking food

Name: Hepatitis B
Causes: Common ways that HBV can spread are: Hepatitis B infection may be either short-lived (acute) or long lasting (chronic). The younger one is when one get hepatitis B particularly newborns or children younger than 5 the higher the risk of the infection becoming chronic. Most people who get hepatitis B as adults have an acute infection, but it can lead to chronic infection. Chronic hepatitis B infection may last a lifetime, possibly leading to serious illnesses such as cirrhosis and liver cancer.
Diagnosis: Tests that can help diagnose hepatitis B or its complications are: Doctors sometimes test certain healthy people for hepatitis B infection because the virus can damage the liver before causing signs and symptoms. Are pregnant Live with someone who has hepatitis B Have had many sexual partners Have had sex with someone who has hepatitis B Are a man who has sex with men Have a history of a sexually transmitted illness Have HIV or hepatitis C Have a liver enzyme test with unexplained abnormal results Receive kidney dialysis Take medications that suppress the immune system, such as those used to prevent rejection after an organ transplant Use illegal injected drugs Are in prison Were born in a country where hepatitis B is common, including Asia, the Pacific Islands, Africa and Eastern Europe Have parents or adopted children from places where hepatitis B is common, including Asia, the Pacific Islands, Africa and Eastern Europe Liver biopsy Liver function tests Blood tests.
Remedies: If one is sexually active, tell the partner one has HBV and talk about the risk of transmitting it to him or her. Use a new latex condom every time one has sex, but remember that condoms reduce but don't eliminate the risk.
info-Symptoms: None, yellowish skin, tiredness, dark urine, abdominal pain
info-Usual onset: Symptoms may take up to 6 months to appear
info-Causes: Hepatitis B virus spread by some body fluids
info-Risk factors: Intravenous drug use, sexual intercourse, dialysis, living with an infected person

Name: Hepatitis C
Overview: The liver is the largest internal organ. Until recently, hepatitis C treatment required weekly injections and oral medications that many HCV-infected people couldn't take because of other health problems or unacceptable side effects. For that reason, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends that all adults ages 18 to 79 years be screened for hepatitis C, even those without symptoms or known liver disease.
Diagnosis: Screening for HCV is especially important if one is at high risk of exposure, including If an initial blood test shows that one has hepatitis C, additional blood tests will: Doctors typically use one or more of the following tests to assess liver damage in chronic hepatitis C. A member of the care team performs transient elastography a painless alternative to liver biopsy to assess liver damage. Anyone who has ever injected or inhaled illicit drugs Anyone who has abnormal liver function test results with no identified cause Babies born to mothers with hepatitis C Health care and emergency workers who have been exposed to blood or accidental needle sticks People with hemophilia who were treated with clotting factors before 1987 People who have undergone long-term hemodialysis treatments People who received blood transfusions or organ transplants before 1992 Sexual partners of anyone diagnosed with hepatitis C infection People with HIV infection Anyone born from 1945 to 1965 Anyone who has been in prison Measure the quantity of the hepatitis C virus in the blood (viral load) Identify the genotype of the virus Magnetic resonance elastography (MRE).
Remedies: These measures will help keep one healthy longer and protect the health of others as well: Stop drinking alcohol. Review the medications with the doctor, including over-the-counter medications one take as well as herbal preparations and dietary supplements.
info-Symptoms: Typically none
info-Causes: Hepatitis C virus usually spread by blood-to-blood contact
info-Diagnostic method: Blood testing for antibodies or viral RNA

Name: Hepatitis , autoimmune
Causes: Autoimmune hepatitis occurs when the body's immune system, which ordinarily attacks viruses, bacteria and other pathogens, instead targets the liver. About half the people with type 1 autoimmune hepatitis have other autoimmune disorders, such as celiac disease, rheumatoid arthritis or ulcerative colitis. Although adults can develop type 2 autoimmune hepatitis, it's most common in children and young people.
Risk factors: Although both males and females can develop autoimmune hepatitis, the disease is more common in females. Autoimmune hepatitis may develop after one is infected with the measles, herpes simplex or Epstein-Barr virus. People who already have an autoimmune disease, such as celiac disease, rheumatoid arthritis or hyperthyroidism (Graves disease or Hashimoto's thyroiditis), may be more likely to develop autoimmune hepatitis.

Name: Hepatocellular carcinoma
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose liver cancer include Removing a sample of liver tissue for testing. Imaging tests used to stage liver cancer include CTs, MRIs and bone scans.

Name: Hepatopulmonary syndrome
Overview: Hepatopulmonary (hep-uh-toe-POOL-moe-nar-e) syndrome is an uncommon condition that affects the lungs of people with advanced liver disease. Hepatopulmonary syndrome is caused by blood vessels in the lungs expanding (dilating) and increasing in number, making it hard for red blood cells to properly absorb oxygen.
Diagnosis: In pulse oximetry, a sensor attached to the finger or ear uses light to determine how much oxygen is in the blood. X-rays, computerized tomography (CT) scanning or echocardiogram imaging can help rule out other heart or lungs conditions.

Name: Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia
Overview: Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (tuh-lan-jee-uk-TAY-zhuh) is an inherited disorder that causes abnormal connections, called arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), to develop between arteries and veins. Also known as Osler-Weber-Rendu disease, hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) is a genetic disorder that one inherit from the parents.
Causes: It is an autosomal dominant disorder, which means that if one of the parents has HHT, one has a 50 percent chance of inheriting it. Chovlin C. Clinical manifestations and diagnosis of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome). Surgical management of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. Rochester, Minn.: Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research; 2018. Effect of center volume on outcomes in hospitalized patients with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia.
Diagnosis: The doctor may diagnose HHT based on a physical examination, results of imaging tests and a family history. To locate AVMs, the doctor may recommend one or more of the following imaging tests: Ultrasound imaging. To screen for any abnormal blood flow caused by an AVM in a lung, the doctor may recommend a special echocardiogram called a bubble study. If a bubble study reveals a feature that looks like a lung AVM, the doctor may order a CT scan of the lungs to confirm the diagnosis and assess whether one need surgery.
Remedies: To help prevent HHT nosebleeds, one may want to: Avoid certain medications. The risk of bleeding can be increased by over-the-counter drugs and supplements such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), fish oil supplements, ginkgo and St. John's wort. In some people, HHT nosebleeds are triggered when they consume blueberries, red wine, dark chocolate or spicy foods.
Medication: Drugs that help reduce the bleeding associated with HHT can be divided into three broad categories: If one develop iron deficiency anemia, the doctor may also suggest intravenous iron replacement treatments, which usually are more effective than taking iron pills. Procedures to reduce the frequency and severity of nosebleeds may include The most common organs affected by HHT are the lungs, brain and liver. Tranexamic acid (Cyklokapron, Lysteda) can help stop extreme bleeding in emergencies and may be useful if taken regularly to prevent bleeding. The doctor may suggest taking a skin graft from another part of the body, usually the thigh, to transplant inside the nose. In this procedure, a long, slender tube is threaded through the blood vessels to the problem area, where a plug or a metal coil is deployed to block blood from entering the AVM, which eventually shrinks and heals. In some people, the best option is to surgically remove AVMs in the lungs, brain or liver.
info-Symptoms: Nosebleeds, Gastrointestinal bleeding

Name: Herpes , genital
Symptoms: Sores associated with genital herpes can be small red bumps, blisters or open sores. Scabs eventually form and the sores heal, but they tend to recur. When present, symptoms may begin about two to 12 days after exposure to the virus. One can spread the infection by touching a sore and then rubbing or scratching another area of the body, including the eyes. The signs and symptoms may recur, off and on, for years.
Overview: Genital herpes is a common sexually transmitted infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). There's no cure for genital herpes, but medications can ease symptoms and reduce the risk of infecting others.
Diagnosis: The doctor usually can diagnose genital herpes based on a physical exam and the results of certain laboratory tests: tViral culture. This test analyzes a sample of the blood for the presence of HSV antibodies to detect a past herpes infection.
Treatment: Treatment with prescription antiviral medications may: Antiviral medications used for genital herpes include The doctor may recommend that one take the medicine only when one has symptoms of an outbreak or that one take a certain medication daily, even when one has no signs of an outbreak. Here are healthy ways to cope with having genital herpes: If one think one has genital herpes or other sexually transmitted infection, make an appointment to see the primary care doctor or gynecologist. Help sores heal sooner during an initial outbreak Lessen the severity and duration of symptoms in recurrent outbreaks Reduce the frequency of recurrence Minimize the chance of transmitting the herpes virus to another Acyclovir (Zovirax) Valacyclovir (Valtrex) Communicate with the partner. Genital herpes can lie dormant in the body for years, so it's often difficult to determine when one became infected.

Name: Hiatal hernia
Overview: A hiatal hernia occurs when the upper part of the stomach bulges through the diaphragm into the chest cavity. A hiatal hernia occurs when the upper part of the stomach bulges through the large muscle separating the abdomen and chest (diaphragm).
Diagnosis: Endoscopy involves inserting a long, flexible tube (endoscope) down the throat and into the esophagus. A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). The doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube equipped with a light and camera (endoscope) down the throat, to examine the inside of the esophagus and stomach and check for inflammation.
Medication: If one experience heartburn and acid reflux, the doctor may recommend: Sometimes a hiatal hernia requires surgery. These medications known as H-2-receptor blockers include cimetidine (Tagamet), famotidine (Pepcid) and nizatidine (Axid). Over-the-counter proton pump inhibitors include lansoprazole (Prevacid 24HR) and omeprazole (Prilosec, Zegerid).
info-Symptoms: Taste of acid in the back of the mouth, heartburn, trouble swallowing
info-Risk factors: Obesity, older age, major trauma
info-Treatment: Raising the head of the bed, weight loss, medications, surgery

Name: Hiccups
Overview: Hiccups are caused by involuntary contractions of the diaphragm the muscle that separates the chest from the abdomen and plays an important role in breathing. Hiccups are involuntary contractions of the diaphragm the muscle that separates the chest from the abdomen and plays an important role in breathing.

Name: Hidradenitis suppurativa
Symptoms: Excess weight, stress, hormonal changes, heat or humidity may worsen symptoms. The condition usually starts with a single, painful lump under the skin that persists for weeks or months. They usually appear in areas with hair follicles with many oil and sweat glands, such as the armpits, groin and anal area. Over time, tracts connecting the lumps may form under the skin.
Overview: Hidradenitis suppurativa usually appears as one or more red, tender bumps that fill with pus. Hidradenitis suppurativa (hi-drad-uh-NIE-tis sup-yoo-ruh-TIE-vuh) is a skin condition that causes small, painful lumps to form under the skin.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the chance of developing hidradenitis suppurativa include Age. Hidradenitis suppurativa most commonly occurs in women between the ages of 18 and 29. Women are more likely to develop hidradenitis suppurativa than are men.
Remedies: The following suggestions may help relieve discomfort, speed healing or prevent outbreaks: Follow a daily skin care routine. When washing, avoid using washcloths, loofahs or other items on affected areas, as they can irritate skin. Gently applying a wet, warm washcloth, tea bag or other sort of compress can help reduce swelling and ease pain. Hidradenitis symptoms may be worsened by diets that include dairy, red meat and foods with a high glycemic index.
Medication: The doctor might prescribe one or more of the following types of medications: Surgical options include More studies of surgical options are needed to improve hidradenitis suppurativa care. In particular, good-quality clinical trials are needed to evaluate the timing or surgery and type of surgical procedure. For more widespread diseases, antibiotics taken by mouth, such as clindamycin, rifampin and doxycycline, may help. An injection of adalimumab may be used for moderate to severe disease, though it may take about two weeks to notice any benefit. If over-the-counter pain relievers don't help, the doctor may prescribe a stronger type. In men whose condition involves the area between the anus and scrotum, surgical removal of the scrotum is almost always necessary. The method may be considered to provide short-term pain relief, but sores tend to flare again.
info-Symptoms: Multiple inflamed and swollen skin lesions
info-Frequency: 1â€“4% of people, when mild cases are included

Name: High blood pressure in children
Diagnosis: These tests might be used to look for another condition that could be causing the child's high blood pressure: To confirm a diagnosis of high blood pressure, the child's doctor might recommend ambulatory monitoring. Blood test to check the child's blood sugar, kidney function and blood cell counts Urine sample test (urinalysis) Echocardiogram, a test to check the blood flow through the child's heart, if the child's doctor suspects a structural heart problem may be causing high blood pressure Ultrasound of the child's kidneys Complete blood count (CBC) Echocardiogram Ultrasound Urinalysis Blood test Urine sample test Echocardiogram Ultrasound
Treatment: If the child is diagnosed with slightly or moderately high blood pressure (stage 1 hypertension), the child's doctor will likely suggest trying lifestyle changes, such as a heart-healthy diet and more exercise, before prescribing medications. If lifestyle changes don't help, the child's doctor might recommend blood pressure medication. If the child is diagnosed with severely high blood pressure (stage 2 hypertension), the child's doctor will likely recommend blood pressure medications. If the child's high blood pressure is caused by obesity, losing weight might make medication unnecessary. Although little is known about the long-term effects of blood pressure medication on a child's growth and development, many of these medications are generally considered safe to take during childhood. High blood pressure is treated similarly in children and adults, usually starting with lifestyle changes. Even if the child takes medication for high blood pressure, lifestyle changes can make the medication work better. Cutting the amount of salt (sodium) in the child's diet will help lower his or her blood pressure. Also known as water pills, these act on the child's kidneys to help the child remove sodium and water, reducing blood pressure. This makes it easier for the child's blood to flow, reducing blood pressure. If the child is overweight, losing excess pounds or maintaining the same weight while getting taller can lower blood pressure.
Remedies: High blood pressure is treated similarly in children and adults, usually starting with lifestyle changes. Even if the child takes medication for high blood pressure, lifestyle changes can make the medication work better. Children ages 4 to 8 shouldn't have more than 1,200 milligrams (mg) a day, and older children shouldn't have more than 1,500 mg a day. If the child is overweight, losing excess pounds or maintaining the same weight while getting taller can lower blood pressure. Encourage the child to eat a heart-healthy diet, emphasizing fruits, vegetables, whole grains, low-fat dairy products and lean sources of protein, such as fish and beans, and limiting fat and sugar. To encourage the child to be more active, limit time in front of the television, computer or other devices no television before age 2, and no more than two hours of screen time a day after age 2.

Name: Hip dysplasia
Overview: Hip dysplasia is the medical term for a hip socket that doesn't fully cover the ball portion of the upper thighbone. Hip dysplasia can damage the cartilage lining the joint, and it can also hurt the soft cartilage (labrum) that rims the socket portion of the hip joint.
info-Symptoms: None, hip aches, one leg shorter, limping
info-Risk factors: Family history, swaddling, breech birth

Name: Hip fracture
Overview: A hip fracture is a serious injury, with complications that can be life-threatening. Multiple medications, poor vision and balance problems also make older people more likely to fall one of the most common causes of hip fracture.
Risk factors: Intestinal disorders, which can reduce the absorption of vitamin D and calcium, also can lead to weakened bones. Medical conditions that affect the brain and nervous system, including cognitive impairment, dementia, Parkinson's disease, stroke and peripheral neuropathy, also increase the risk of falling. Women lose bone density faster than men do, in part because the drop in estrogen levels that occurs with menopause accelerates bone loss. However, men also can develop dangerously low levels of bone density. If one has this condition, which causes bones to weaken, one is at increased risk of fractures. Lack of regular weight-bearing exercise, such as walking, can result in weakened bones and muscles, making falls and fractures more likely.
Diagnosis: Most hip fractures occur in one of two locations at the femoral neck or in the intertrochanteric region. If the X-ray doesn't show a fracture but one still have hip pain, the doctor might order an MRI or bone scan to look for a hairline fracture. Most hip fractures occur in one of two locations on the long bone that extends from the pelvis to the knee (femur): The femoral neck.
info-Symptoms: Pain around the hip particularly with movement, shortening of the leg
info-Risk factors: Osteoporosis, taking many medications, alcohol use, metastatic cancer
info-Diagnostic method: X-ray, MRI, CT scan, bone scan
info-Prevention: Improved lighting, removal of loose rugs, exercise, treatment of osteoporosis
info-Prognosis: ~20% one year risk of death (older people)

Name: Hip impingement
Overview: Hip impingement occurs when the ball and socket of the hip joint don't fit together properly. Most people with hip impingement experience pain in the groin area during or after flexing the hip, as when running, jumping or sitting for a long time.

Name: Hip labral tear
Causes: The cause of a hip labral tear might be: Trauma. Some people are born with hip problems that can accelerate wear and tear of the joint and eventually cause a hip labral tear.
Diagnosis: During the physical exam, the doctor will move the leg, and especially the hip joint, into various positions to check for pain and evaluate the hip's range of motion. In most cases, other structures within the hip joint also have injuries. A contrast material might be injected into the hip joint space to make a labral tear easier to see. If this relieves the pain, it's likely that the problem is inside the hip joint.
Medication: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve), can relieve pain and reduce inflammation. If conservative treatments don't relieve the symptoms, the doctor might recommend arthroscopic surgery in which a fiber-optic camera and surgical tools are inserted via small incisions in the skin.

Name: Hirsutism
Symptoms: Signs of virilization might include If one think one has too much coarse hair on the face or body, talk with the doctor about treatment options. See the doctor for assessment if over a few months one experience severe or rapid hair growth on the face or body or signs of virilization.
Overview: Hirsutism is excess hair most often noticeable around the mouth and chin. Hirsutism (HUR-soot-iz-um) is a condition in women that results in excessive growth of dark or coarse hair in a male-like pattern face, chest and back.
Causes: This condition, which often begins with puberty, causes an imbalance of sex hormones. Over years, PCOS may slowly result in excess hair growth, irregular periods, obesity, infertility and sometimes multiple cysts on the ovaries. This inherited condition is characterized by abnormal production of steroid hormones, including cortisol and androgen, by the adrenal glands. Rarely, an androgen-secreting tumor in the ovaries or adrenal glands can cause hirsutism.
Risk factors: Several factors can influence the likelihood of developing hirsutism, including Family history. Several conditions that cause hirsutism, including congenital adrenal hyperplasia and polycystic ovary syndrome, run in families. Women of Mediterranean, Middle Eastern and South Asian ancestry are more likely to have more body hair with no identifiable cause than are other women.
Remedies: Plucking is a good method to remove a few stray hairs, but is not useful for removing a large area of hair. This hair removal method may be done with tweezers, thin threads (threading) or other devices designed for this purpose. Once the wax hardens, one pull it from the skin to remove hair. Waxing removes hair from a large area quickly, but it may sting temporarily and sometimes causes skin irritation and redness. Bleaching lightens hair color, making it less noticeable on people with light skin. Hair-bleaching products, which usually contain hydrogen peroxide, may cause skin irritation.
Medication: If cosmetic or self-care methods of hair removal havent worked for one, talk with the doctor about drugs that treat hirsutism. With these medications it usually takes up to six months, the average life cycle of a hair follicle, before one see a significant difference in hair growth. Hair removal methods whose results may last longer than self-care methods and which may be combined with medical therapy include Laser therapy. A beam of highly concentrated light (laser) is passed over the skin to damage hair follicles and prevent hair from growing (photoepilation). For people whose unwanted hair is black, brown or auburn, photoepilation is usually a better option than electrolysis. People with tanned or darkly pigmented skin are at increased risk of side effects from certain lasers, including a darkening or lightening of their usual skin tones, blistering, and inflammation. For people with naturally blond or white hair, electrolysis is a better option than laser therapy.
info-Treatment: Birth control pills, antiandrogens, insulin sensitizers

Name: Histoplasmosis
Symptoms: The mildest forms of histoplasmosis cause no signs or symptoms, but severe infections can be life-threatening. Called disseminated histoplasmosis, it can affect nearly any part of the body, including the mouth, liver, central nervous system, skin and adrenal glands.
Overview: Histoplasmosis is an infection caused by breathing in spores of a fungus often found in bird and bat droppings. Soil contaminated by bird or bat droppings also can spread histoplasmosis, putting farmers and landscapers at a higher risk of the disease.

Name: Hoarding disorder
Symptoms: Although collections can be large, they aren't usually cluttered and they don't cause the distress and impairments that are part of hoarding disorder. If one or a loved one has symptoms of hoarding disorder, talk with a doctor or mental health professional as soon as possible.
Overview: Hoarding disorder is a persistent difficulty discarding or parting with possessions because of a perceived need to save them. Hoarding often creates such cramped living conditions that homes may be filled to capacity, with only narrow pathways winding through stacks of clutter. But intensive treatment can help people with hoarding disorder understand how their beliefs and behaviors can be changed so that they can live safer, more enjoyable lives.
Treatment: Treatment of hoarding disorder can be challenging because many people don't recognize the negative impact of hoarding on their lives or don't believe they need treatment. If these possessions or animals are taken away, people will often react with frustration and anger and quickly collect more to help fulfill emotional needs.
Remedies: In addition to professional treatment, here are some steps one can take to help care for theself: Stick to the treatment plan. Local resources, professional organizers and loved ones can work with one to make decisions about how best to organize and unclutter the home and to stay safe and healthy. It may take time to get back to a safe home environment, and help is often needed to maintain organization around the home. If the number of pets one has has grown beyond the ability to care for them properly, remind theself that they deserve to live healthy and happy lives and that's not possible if one can't provide them with proper nutrition, sanitation and veterinary care.
info-Causes: not clear, possibly genetic, and stressful life experiences
info-Risk factors: Traumatic events
info-Frequency: 2-5% of the UK population. Up to 6% (US)

Name: Hot flashes
Symptoms: Nighttime hot flashes (night sweats) may wake one from sleep and can cause long-term sleep disruptions. How often hot flashes occur varies among women, but most women who report having hot flashes experience them daily. If hot flashes affect the daily activities or nighttime sleep, consider seeing the doctor to discuss treatment options.
Overview: A hot flash is the sudden feeling of warmth in the upper body, which is usually most intense over the face, neck and chest. Although other medical conditions can cause them, hot flashes most commonly are due to menopause the time when menstrual periods become irregular and eventually stop.
Risk factors: Not all women who go through menopause have hot flashes, and it's not clear why some women do have them. More black women report having hot flashes during menopause than do women of other races. Hot flashes are reported least frequently in Asian women.
Remedies: If the hot flashes are mild, try managing them with these lifestyle changes: Keep cool. Hot and spicy foods, caffeinated beverages and alcohol can trigger hot flashes. Some women find relief from mild hot flashes through meditation; slow, deep breathing; or other stress-reducing techniques. Even if these approaches don't quell the hot flashes, they might provide other benefits, such as easing sleep disturbances that tend to occur with menopause. By not smoking, one might reduce hot flashes, as well as the risk of many serious health conditions, such as heart disease, stroke and cancer. If one is overweight or obese, losing weight might help ease the hot flashes.

Name: Human immunodeficiency virus
Causes: To become infected with HIV, infected blood, semen or vaginal secretions must enter the body. That means one can't catch HIV or AIDS by hugging, kissing, dancing or shaking hands with someone who has the infection. One may become infected if one has vaginal, anal or oral sex with an infected partner whose blood, semen or vaginal secretions enter the body. Sharing contaminated IV drug paraphernalia (needles and syringes) puts one at high risk of HIV and other infectious diseases, such as hepatitis. American hospitals and blood banks now screen the blood supply for HIV antibodies, so this risk is very small.
Risk factors: Anyone of any age, race, sex or sexual orientation can be infected with HIV/AIDS. However, one is at greatest risk of HIV/AIDS if one: Have unprotected sex.
Diagnosis: Antigens are substances on the HIV virus itself and are usually detectable a positive test in the blood within a few weeks after exposure to HIV. If one has been diagnosed with HIV, it's important to find a specialist trained in diagnosing and treating HIV to help one: If one receive a diagnosis of HIV/AIDS, several tests can help the doctor determine the stage of the disease and the best treatment, including The doctor might also order lab tests to check for other infections or complications, including Antigen/antibody tests. Antigens are substances on the HIV virus itself and are usually detectable a positive test in the blood within a few weeks after exposure to HIV.Antibodies are produced by the immune system when it's exposed to HIV. Determine whether one need additional testing Determine which HIV antiretroviral therapy (ART) will be best for one Monitor the progress and work with one to manage the health CD4 T cell count. Tuberculosis Hepatitis B or hepatitis C virus infection STIs Liver or kidney damage Urinary tract infection Cervical and anal cancer Cytomegalovirus Toxoplasmosis HIV testing Liver function tests Urinalysis Antigen/antibody tests.
Treatment: The classes of anti-HIV drugs include Account for individual drug resistance (viral genotype) Avoid creating new drug-resistant strains of HIV Maximize suppression of virus in the blood Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs) turn off a protein needed by HIV to make copies of itself. Nucleoside or nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) are faulty versions of the building blocks that HIV needs to make copies of itself. Examples include abacavir (Ziagen), tenofovir (Viread), emtricitabine (Emtriva), lamivudine (Epivir) and zidovudine (Retrovir). Combination drugs also are available, such as emtricitabine/tenofovir (Truvada) and emtricitabine/tenofovir alafenamide (Descovy). Protease inhibitors (PIs) inactivate HIV protease, another protein that HIV needs to make copies of itself. Examples include bictegravir sodium/emtricitabine/tenofovir alafenamide fumar (Biktarvy), raltegravir (Isentress) and dolutegravir (Tivicay).
Remedies: Along with receiving medical treatment, it's essential to take an active role in the own care. Fresh fruits and vegetables, whole grains, and lean protein help keep one strong, give one more energy and support the immune system. Avoid unpasteurized dairy products, raw eggs and raw seafood such as oysters, sushi or sashimi. The doctor may also recommend other vaccinations, including for HPV, hepatitis A and hepatitis B. Inactivated vaccines are generally safe, but most vaccines with live viruses are not, due to the weakened immune system.

Name: Human papillomavirus infection
Symptoms: In women, genital warts can also grow inside the vagina. In most cases, the body's immune system defeats an HPV infection before it creates warts. When warts do appear, they vary in appearance depending on which kind of HPV is involved: Genital warts. In women, genital warts appear mostly on the vulva but can also occur near the anus, on the cervix or in the vagina. In men, genital warts appear on the penis and scrotum or around the anus. Genital warts rarely cause discomfort or pain, though they may itch or feel tender. Common warts appear as rough, raised bumps and usually occur on the hands and fingers. In most cases, common warts are simply unsightly, but they can also be painful or susceptible to injury or bleeding. Plantar warts are hard, grainy growths that usually appear on the heels or balls of the feet.
Overview: HPV infection is a viral infection that commonly causes skin or mucous membrane growths (warts). Other types of cancers, including cancers of the anus, penis, vagina, vulva and back of the throat (oropharyngeal), have been linked to HPV infection.
Causes: Genital HPV infections are contracted through sexual intercourse, anal sex and other skin-to-skin contact in the genital region. If one is pregnant and have an HPV infection with genital warts, it's possible the baby may get the infection.
Risk factors: Risk factors for HPV infection include Number of sexual partners. People who have weakened immune systems are at greater risk of HPV infections. Touching someone's warts or not wearing protection before contacting surfaces that have been exposed to HPV such as public showers or swimming pools might increase the risk of HPV infection.
Diagnosis: If genital warts aren't visible, one will need one or more of the following tests: Vinegar (acetic acid) solution test. This test, conducted on cells from the cervix, can recognize the DNA of the high-risk varieties of HPV that have been linked to genital cancers. Pap smear Vinegar (acetic acid) solution test.
Medication: Examples include If medications don't work, the doctor might suggest removing warts by one of these methods: If one has an abnormal HPV or Pap test, the gynecologist will perform a procedure called a colposcopy. Using an instrument that provides a magnified view of the cervix (colposcope), the doctor will look closely at the cervix and take samples (biopsy) of any areas that look abnormal. Options include freezing (cryosurgery), laser, surgical removal, loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) and cold knife conization. LEEP uses a thin looped wire charged with an electric current to remove a thin layer of a section of the cervix and cold knife conization is a surgical procedure that removes a cone-shaped piece of the cervix. For use on common warts, salicylic acid can cause skin irritation and isn't for use on the face. Freezing with liquid nitrogen (cryotherapy) Burning with an electrical current (electrocautery) Surgical removal Laser surgery Salicylic acid.
info-Symptoms: None, warts
info-Causes: Human papillomavirus spread by direct contact
info-Risk factors: sexual contact
info-Frequency: Most people are infected at some point in time

Name: Huntington 's disease
Diagnosis: A preliminary diagnosis of Huntington's disease is based primarily on the answers to questions, a general physical exam, a review of the family medical history, and neurological and psychiatric examinations. The neurologist will ask one questions and conduct relatively simple tests of the: The neurologist may also perform standardized tests to check the: One will likely be referred to a psychiatrist for an examination to look for a number of factors that could contribute to the diagnosis, including The doctor may order brain-imaging tests for assessing the structure or function of the brain. If symptoms strongly suggest Huntington's disease, the doctor may recommend a genetic test for the defective gene. It may also be valuable if there's no known family history of Huntington's disease or if no other family member's diagnosis was confirmed with a genetic test.
Remedies: Factors regarding eating and nutrition include the following: Eventually, a person with Huntington's disease will need assistance with eating and drinking. Using calendars and schedules to help keep a regular routine Initiating tasks with reminders or assistance Prioritizing or organizing work or activities Breaking down tasks into manageable steps Creating an environment that is as calm, simple and structured as possible Identifying and avoiding stressors that can trigger outbursts, irritability, depression or other problems For school-age children or adolescents, consulting with school staff to develop an appropriate individual education plan Providing opportunities for the person to maintain social interactions and friendships as much as possible Difficulty maintaining a healthy body weight.
Medication: Drugs to treat movement disorders include the following: Antipsychotic drugs, such as haloperidol (Haldol) and fluphenazine, have a side effect of suppressing movements. However, these drugs may worsen involuntary contractions (dystonia), restlessness and drowsiness. Other drugs, such as risperidone (Risperdal), olanzapine (Zyprexa) and quetiapine (Seroquel), may have fewer side effects but still should be used with caution, as they may also worsen symptoms. These strategies may include Drugs to control movement include tetrabenazine (Xenazine) and deutetrabenazine (Austedo), which have been specifically approved by the Food and Drug Administration to suppress the involuntary jerking and writhing movements (chorea) associated with Huntington's disease. Antipsychotic drugs, such as haloperidol (Haldol) and fluphenazine, have a side effect of suppressing movements. Other medications that may help suppress chorea include amantadine (Gocovri ER, Osmolex ER), levetiracetam (Keppra, Elepsia XR, Spritam) and clonazepam (Klonopin). Antipsychotic drugs such as quetiapine (Seroquel), risperidone (Risperdal) and olanzapine (Zyprexa) may suppress violent outbursts, agitation, and other symptoms of mood disorders or psychosis. Mood-stabilizing drugs that can help prevent the highs and lows associated with bipolar disorder include anticonvulsants, such as divalproex (Depakote), carbamazepine (Carbatrol, Epitol, others) and lamotrigine (Lamictal).

Name: Hydrocele
Symptoms: But if the baby's hydrocele doesn't disappear after a year or if it enlarges, ask the child's doctor to examine the hydrocele again. Get immediate medical treatment if one or the child develops sudden, severe scrotal pain or swelling, especially within several hours of an injury to the scrotum.
Diagnosis: It's likely to include After that, the doctor might recommend: Checking for tenderness in an enlarged scrotum. Blood and urine tests to help determine if one or the child has an infection, such as epididymitis Ultrasound to help rule out hernia, testicular tumor or other causes of scrotal swelling CT scan MRI Ultrasound Urinalysis
Treatment: A hydrocele that doesn't disappear on its own might need to be surgically removed, typically as an outpatient procedure. If a hydrocele is found during surgery to repair an inguinal hernia, the surgeon might remove the hydrocele even if it's causing no discomfort.

Name: Hydrocephalus
Overview: Hydrocephalus is the buildup of fluid in the cavities (ventricles) deep within the brain. But the pressure of too much cerebrospinal fluid associated with hydrocephalus can damage brain tissues and cause a range of impairments in brain function.
Causes: This fluid also fills large open structures, called ventricles, which lie deep inside the brain. Cerebrospinal fluid is produced by tissues lining the ventricles of the brain.
Diagnosis: These tests may include Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) uses radio waves and a magnetic field to produce detailed 3D or cross-sectional images of the brain. Ultrasound imaging, which uses high-frequency sound waves to produce images, is often used for an initial assessment for infants because it's a relatively simple, low-risk procedure. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) uses radio waves and a magnetic field to produce detailed 3D or cross-sectional images of the brain.
info-Symptoms: Babies: rapid head growth, vomiting, sleepiness, seizuresOlder people: Headaches, double vision, poor balance, urinary incontinence, personality changes, mental impairment
info-Causes: Neural tube defects, meningitis, brain tumors, traumatic brain injury, brain bleed during birth, intraventricular hemorrhage
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and medical imaging

Name: Hydronephrosis
Diagnosis: A thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted through the urethra and into the bladder while the child lies on his or her back on an X-ray table. After contrast dye is injected into the bladder through the catheter, the child's bladder is X-rayed in various positions. Then the catheter is removed so that the child can urinate, and more X-rays are taken of the bladder and urethra during urination to see whether the urinary tract is functioning correctly. Risks associated with this test include discomfort from the catheter or from having a full bladder and the possibility of a new urinary tract infection.
Remedies: They include If bladder and bowel dysfunction (BBD) contributes to the child's vesicoureteral reflux, encourage healthy toileting habits. Encourage the child to drink fluids, Provide a heating pad or a warm blanket or towel.
Medication: This includes periodic physical exams and urine tests to detect breakthrough infections UTIs that occur despite the antibiotic treatment and occasional radiographic scans of the bladder and kidneys to determine if the child has outgrown vesicoureteral reflux. Similar to open surgery, this procedure involves repairing the valve between the ureter and the bladder, but it's performed using small incisions. In this procedure, the doctor inserts a lighted tube (cystoscope) through the urethra to see inside the child's bladder, and then injects a bulking agent around the opening of the affected ureter to try to strengthen the valve's ability to close properly. This type of surgery usually requires a few days stay in the hospital, during which a catheter is kept in place to drain the child's bladder.

Name: Hypercalcemia
Symptoms: More-severe cases produce signs and symptoms related to the parts of the body affected by the high calcium levels in the blood. Examples include Contact the doctor if one develop signs and symptoms that might indicate hypercalcemia, such as being extremely thirsty, urinating frequently and having abdominal pain. Hypercalcemia can cause stomach upset, nausea, vomiting and constipation. In most cases, the excess calcium in the blood was leached from the bones, which weakens them. Hypercalcemia can interfere with how the brain works, resulting in confusion, lethargy and fatigue. Rarely, severe hypercalcemia can interfere with the heart function, causing palpitations and fainting, indications of cardiac arrhythmia, and other heart problems.
Overview: The parathyroid glands, which lie behind the thyroid, manufacture the parathyroid hormone, which plays a role in regulating the body's levels of the minerals calcium and phosphorus. Other causes of hypercalcemia include cancer, certain other medical disorders, some medications, and taking too much of calcium and vitamin D supplements.
Causes: Besides building strong bones and teeth, calcium helps muscles contract and nerves transmit signals. This most common cause of hypercalcemia can stem from a small, noncancerous (benign) tumor or enlargement of one or more of the four parathyroid glands. Lung cancer and breast cancer, as well as some blood cancers, can increase the risk of hypercalcemia. Certain diseases, such as tuberculosis and sarcoidosis, can raise blood levels of vitamin D, which stimulates the digestive tract to absorb more calcium. A rare genetic disorder known as familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia causes an increase of calcium in the blood because of faulty calcium receptors in the body. Over time, bones that don't bear weight release calcium into the blood. Certain drugs such as lithium, used to treat bipolar disorder might increase the release of parathyroid hormone. Taking excessive amounts of calcium or vitamin D supplements over time can raise calcium levels in the blood above normal.
Medication: In some cases, the doctor might recommend: Problems associated with overactive parathyroid glands often can be cured by surgery to remove the tissue that's causing the problem. Intravenous osteoporosis drugs, which can quickly lower calcium levels, are often used to treat hypercalcemia due to cancer. If the hypercalcemia is caused by high levels of vitamin D, short-term use of steroid pills such as prednisone are usually helpful. One might need hospitalization for treatment with IV fluids and diuretics to promptly lower the calcium level to prevent heart rhythm problems or damage to the nervous system.
info-Symptoms: Abdominal pain, bone pain, confusion, depression, weakness
info-Causes: Primary hyperparathyroidism, cancer, sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, Paget disease, multiple endocrine neoplasia, vitamin D toxicity
info-Diagnostic method: Blood serum level > 2.6Â mmol/l (corrected calcium or ionized calcium)
info-Treatment: Underlying cause, intravenous fluids, furosemide, calcitonin, pamidronate, hemodialysis

Name: Hypercholesterolemia
Symptoms: Retesting for adults with no risk factors for heart disease is usually done every five years. If the test results aren't within desirable ranges, the doctor might recommend more-frequent measurements.
Causes: Factors one can control such as inactivity, obesity and an unhealthy diet contribute to high cholesterol and low HDL cholesterol. For example, the genetic makeup might keep cells from removing LDL cholesterol from the blood efficiently or cause the liver to produce too much cholesterol.
Risk factors: Eating saturated fat, found in animal products, and trans fats, found in some commercially baked cookies and crackers and microwave popcorn, can raise the cholesterol level. Foods that are high in cholesterol, such as red meat and full-fat dairy products, will also increase the cholesterol. Exercise helps boost the body's HDL, or good, cholesterol while increasing the size of the particles that make up the LDL, or bad, cholesterol, which makes it less harmful. Smoking might also lower the level of HDL, or good, cholesterol. Because the body's chemistry changes as one age, the risk of high cholesterol climbs. High blood sugar contributes to higher levels of a dangerous cholesterol called very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) and lower HDL cholesterol.
Treatment: Choices include atorvastatin (Lipitor), fluvastatin (Lescol XL), lovastatin (Altoprev), pitavastatin (Livalo), pravastatin (Pravachol), rosuvastatin (Crestor) and simvastatin (Zocor). The medications cholestyramine (Prevalite), colesevelam (Welchol) and colestipol (Colestid) lower cholesterol indirectly by binding to bile acids. The drug ezetimibe (Zetia) helps reduce blood cholesterol by limiting the absorption of dietary cholesterol. A newer class of drugs, known as PCSK9 inhibitors, can help the liver absorb more LDL cholesterol which lowers the amount of cholesterol circulating in the blood. Alirocumab (Praluent) and evolocumab (Repatha) might be used for people who have a genetic condition that causes very high levels of LDL or in people with a history of coronary disease who have intolerance to statins or other cholesterol medications.
Remedies: To bring the numbers down, try the following: Eat a heart-healthy diet. Limit saturated fats, found in red meat and full-fat dairy products, and trans fats, found in many processed foods. With the doctor's OK, work up to at least 30 minutes of moderate intensity exercise five times a week or vigorous exercise five times a week.
Medication: The medications fenofibrate (TriCor, Fenoglide, others) and gemfibrozil (Lopid) reduce the liver's production of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) cholesterol and speed the removal of triglycerides from the blood. If one choose to take over-the-counter supplements, get the doctor's OK. Omega-3 fatty acid supplements could affect other medications one is taking. If one decide to take cholesterol medication, the doctor might recommend liver function tests to monitor the medication's effect on the liver. Niacin has also been linked to liver damage and strokes, so most doctors now recommend it only for people who can't take statins. They are available by prescription or over-the-counter.If one choose to take over-the-counter supplements, get the doctor's OK. Omega-3 fatty acid supplements could affect other medications one is taking.
info-Causes: Poor diet, junk food, fast food, diabetes, alcoholism, monoclonal gammopathy, dialysis therapy, nephrotic syndrome, hypothyroidism, Cushingâ€™s syndrome, anorexia nervosa

Name: Hypercholesterolemia , familial
Overview: Familial hypercholesterolemia affects the way the body processes cholesterol. As a result, people with familial hypercholesterolemia have a higher risk of heart disease and a greater risk of early heart attack.
Causes: This defect prevents the body from ridding itself of the type of cholesterol that can build up in the arteries and cause heart disease. This type of cholesterol is called low-density lipoprotein but it's also commonly known as LDL or bad cholesterol.
Treatment: Specific recommendations include With familial hypercholesterolemia, the doctor likely will also recommend that one take medication to help lower the LDL cholesterol levels. Statins may also help the body reabsorb cholesterol from built-up deposits on the artery walls, potentially reversing coronary artery disease. Choices include atorvastatin (Lipitor), fluvastatin (Lescol), lovastatin (Altoprev,), pitavastatin (Livalo), pravastatin (Pravachol), rosuvastatin (Crestor) and simvastatin (Zocor). The liver uses cholesterol to make bile acids, a substance needed for digestion. The medications cholestyramine (Prevalite), colesevelam (Welchol) and colestipol (Colestid) lower cholesterol indirectly by binding to bile acids. This prompts the liver to use excess cholesterol to make more bile acids, which reduces the level of cholesterol in the blood. The drug ezetimibe (Zetia) helps reduce blood cholesterol by limiting the absorption of dietary cholesterol. The combination drug ezetimibe-simvastatin (Vytorin) decreases both absorption of dietary cholesterol in the small intestine and production of cholesterol in the liver.
Medication: If one also have high triglycerides, the doctor may prescribe: Tolerance of medications varies from person to person. If one decide to take cholesterol-lowering medication, the doctor may recommend liver function tests to monitor the medication's effect on the liver. The medications fenofibrate (Tricor) and gemfibrozil (Lopid) decrease triglycerides by reducing the liver's production of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) cholesterol and by speeding up the removal of triglycerides from the blood. Niacin (Niaspan) decreases triglycerides by limiting the liver's ability to produce LDL and VLDL cholesterol. Niacin has also been linked to liver damage and stroke, so most doctors now recommend it only for people who can't take statins.

Name: Hypercortisolism
Overview: Left untreated, Cushing syndrome can result in exaggerated facial roundness, weight gain around the midsection and upper back, thinning of the arms and legs, easy bruising and stretch marks. Too much cortisol can produce some of the hallmark signs of Cushing syndrome a fatty hump between the shoulders, a rounded face, and pink or purple stretch marks on the skin.
Causes: However, when the level of cortisol is too high in the body, one may develop Cushing syndrome. It's also possible to develop Cushing syndrome from injectable corticosteroids for example, repeated injections for joint pain, bursitis and back pain. The condition may also be due to the body's own overproduction of cortisol (endogenous Cushing syndrome). This may occur from excess production by one or both adrenal glands, or overproduction of the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which normally regulates cortisol production. Cancerous tumors of the adrenal cortex (adrenocortical carcinomas) are rare, but they can cause Cushing syndrome as well. Rarely, a tumor that develops in an organ that normally does not produce ACTH will begin to secrete this hormone in excess, resulting in Cushing syndrome. Rarely, people inherit a tendency to develop tumors on one or more of their endocrine glands, affecting cortisol levels and causing Cushing syndrome.
Diagnosis: He or she may suspect Cushing syndrome if one has signs such as rounding of the face (moon face), a pad of fatty tissue between the shoulders and neck (buffalo hump), and thin skin with bruises and stretch marks. If one has been taking a corticosteroid medication for a long time, the doctor may suspect that one has developed Cushing syndrome as a result of this medication. These tests help the doctor diagnose Cushing syndrome, and they may help rule out other medical conditions with similar signs and symptoms. For example, polycystic ovary syndrome a hormone disorder in women with enlarged ovaries shares some of the same signs and symptoms as Cushing syndrome, such as excessive hair growth and irregular menstrual periods. By analyzing cortisol levels from a small sample of saliva collected late at night, doctors can see if cortisol levels are too high, suggesting a diagnosis of Cushing syndrome.
Remedies: One didn't develop Cushing syndrome overnight, and the symptoms won't disappear overnight, either. Nutritious, wholesome foods provide a good source of fuel for the recovering body and can help one lose the extra pounds that one gained from Cushing syndrome. Make sure one is getting enough calcium and vitamin D. Taken together, they help the body absorb calcium, which can help strengthen the bones, counteracting the bone density loss that often occurs with Cushing syndrome. Depression can be a side effect of Cushing syndrome, but it can also persist or develop after treatment begins. Hot baths, massages and low-impact exercises, such as water aerobics and tai chi, can help alleviate some of the muscle and joint pain that accompanies Cushing syndrome recovery.
Medication: Medications to control excessive production of cortisol at the adrenal gland include ketoconazole, mitotane (Lysodren) and metyrapone (Metopirone). Side effects from these medications may include fatigue, nausea, vomiting, headaches, muscle aches, high blood pressure, low potassium and swelling. If none of these treatment options is appropriate or effective, the doctor may recommend surgical removal of the adrenal glands (bilateral adrenalectomy).
info-Symptoms: High blood pressure, abdominal obesity with thin arms and legs, reddish stretch marks, round red face, fat lump between the shoulders, weak muscles, acne, fragile skin

Name: Hypereosinophilic syndrome
Medication: One might also be prescribed blood-thinning medications such as warfarin (Coumadin). Depending on the symptoms, one may be referred to specialists in blood diseases (hematology), heart conditions (cardiology) or allergies. Any medications, including vitamins, herbs and over-the-counter medicines that one is taking, and their dosages Key personal information, including any major stresses or recent changes in the life Will I need additional tests? What, if anything, seems to improve the symptoms? What, if anything, appears to worsen the symptoms?

Name: Hyperglycemia in diabetes
Diagnosis: If the blood sugar level is 240 mg/dL (13.3 mmol/L) or above, use an over-the-counter urine ketones test kit. Between 80 and 120 mg/dL (4.4 and 6.7 mmol/L) for people age 59 and younger who have no other underlying medical conditions Between 100 and 140 mg/dL (5.6 and 7.8 mmol/L) for people age 60 and older, those who have other medical conditions, such as heart, lung or kidney disease, or those who have a history of low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) or who have difficulty recognizing the symptoms of hypoglycemia Between 80 and 130 mg/dL (4.4 and 7.2 mmol/L) before meals Less than 180 mg/dL (10 mmol/L) two hours after meals A1C test

Name: Hyperopia
Overview: Farsightedness (hyperopia) is a common vision condition in which one can see distant objects clearly, but objects nearby may be blurry. People with severe farsightedness may be able to clearly see only objects a great distance away, while those with mild farsightedness may be able to clearly see objects that are closer.
Causes: In farsightedness (hyperopia), the cornea doesn't refract light properly, so the point of focus falls behind the retina. If the cornea or lens isn't evenly and smoothly curved, light rays aren't refracted properly, and one has a refractive error. In addition to farsightedness, other refractive errors include The cornea is the clear, dome-shaped front surface of the eye. Instead of being focused precisely on the retina, light is focused in front of the retina, resulting in a blurry appearance for distant objects.
Remedies: One can't prevent farsightedness, but one can help protect the eyes and the vision by following these tips: See the doctor immediately if one has any of these symptoms: Sudden loss of vision in one eye with or without pain; sudden hazy or blurred vision; double vision; or visual flashes of light, black spots or halos around lights. Certain conditions, such as diabetes and high blood pressure, can affect the vision if not treated. And studies show that the eyes benefit if one also include in the diet fish high in omega-3 fatty acids, such as tuna and salmon. Just as smoking isn't good for the rest of the body, smoking can adversely affect the eye health as well. Look away from the computer or near-task work, including reading, every 20 minutes for 20 seconds at something 20 feet away.
info-Symptoms: Near blur, Distance and near blur, Asthenopia
info-Causes: Axial length of eyeball is too short, lens or cornea is flatter than normal, aphakia
info-Risk factors: Ageing, hereditary
info-Treatment: Eyeglasses, contact lenses, refractive surgeries, IOL implantation

Name: Hyperoxaluria and oxalosis
Overview: Hyperoxaluria occurs when one has too much oxalate in the urine. Hyperoxaluria can be caused by inherited (genetic) disorders, an intestinal disease or eating too many oxalate-rich foods. Oxalosis happens after the kidneys fail in people who have primary and intestinal causes of hyperoxaluria, and excess oxalate builds up in the blood.
Causes: The extra oxalate can combine with calcium to create kidney stones and crystals, which can damage the kidneys and cause them to stop working (renal failure). Because of the very large amounts of oxalate produced, the kidneys of many people with primary hyperoxaluria fail by early to middle adulthood. But renal failure can occur as early as infancy, while others with primary hyperoxaluria never develop kidney failure.

Name: Hyperparathyroidism
Overview: The parathyroid glands, which lie behind the thyroid, manufacture the parathyroid hormone, which plays a role in regulating the body's levels of the minerals calcium and phosphorus. In primary hyperparathyroidism, an enlargement of one or more of the parathyroid glands causes overproduction of the hormone.
Causes: When calcium levels in the blood fall too low, the parathyroid glands secrete enough PTH to restore the balance. When blood-calcium levels are too high, the parathyroid glands produce less PTH. If one don't get enough vitamin D, then calcium levels may drop. If the kidneys work poorly, usable vitamin D may decline and calcium levels drop, causing parathyroid hormone levels to go up. The body may not get enough calcium from the diet, often because the digestive system doesn't absorb the calcium from it. If one don't get enough vitamin D, then calcium levels may drop.t ttChronic kidney failure.
Diagnosis: If blood test results show one has high calcium levels in the blood, the doctor will likely repeat the test to confirm the results after one hasn't eaten for a period of time. But the doctor can diagnose hyperparathyroidism if blood tests show one also have high levels of parathyroid hormone. After diagnosing hyperparathyroidism, the doctor will likely order more tests to rule out possible secondary causes, to identify possible complications and to judge the severity of the condition. If the doctor recommends surgery, he or she will likely use one of these imaging tests to locate the parathyroid gland or glands that are causing problems: Sestamibi parathyroid scan.
Remedies: If one and the doctor have chosen to monitor, rather than treat, the hyperparathyroidism, the following suggestions can help prevent complications: Monitor how much calcium and vitamin D one get in the diet. The daily recommended amount of calcium for adults ages 19 to 50 and men ages 51 to 70 is 1,000 milligrams (mg) of calcium a day. That calcium recommendation increases to 1,200 mg a day for women age 51 and older and men age 71 and older. The daily recommended amount of vitamin D is 600 international units (IUs) of vitamin D a day for people ages 1 to 70 and 800 IUs a day for adults age 71 and older.
info-Symptoms: None, kidney stones, weakness, depression, bone pains, confusion, increased urination
info-Causes: Primary: parathyroid adenoma, multiple benign tumors, parathyroid cancerSecondary: vitamin D deficiency, chronic kidney disease, low blood calcium
info-Diagnostic method: High blood calcium and high PTH levels
info-Treatment: Monitoring, surgery, intravenous normal saline, cinacalcet

Name: Hypertension
Symptoms: The doctor will likely recommend more frequent readings if one has already been diagnosed with high blood pressure or have other risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Public blood pressure machines, such as those found in pharmacies, may provide helpful information about the blood pressure, but they may have some limitations.
Causes: This type of high blood pressure, called primary (essential) hypertension, tends to develop gradually over many years. This type of high blood pressure, called secondary hypertension, tends to appear suddenly and cause higher blood pressure than does primary hypertension.
Risk factors: High blood pressure has many risk factors, including Drinking too much alcohol. Sometimes pregnancy contributes to high blood pressure, as well. Although high blood pressure is most common in adults, children may be at risk, too. For some children, high blood pressure is caused by problems with the kidneys or heart. But for a growing number of kids, poor lifestyle habits, such as an unhealthy diet, obesity and lack of exercise, contribute to high blood pressure. Until about age 64, high blood pressure is more common in men. High blood pressure is particularly common among people of African heritage, often developing at an earlier age than it does in whites. As the volume of blood circulated through the blood vessels increases, so does the pressure on the artery walls. Not only does smoking or chewing tobacco immediately raise the blood pressure temporarily, but the chemicals in tobacco can damage the lining of the artery walls. Too much sodium in the diet can cause the body to retain fluid, which increases blood pressure. If one try to relax by eating more, using tobacco or drinking alcohol, one may only increase problems with high blood pressure. Certain chronic conditions also may increase the risk of high blood pressure, such as kidney disease, diabetes and sleep apnea.
Diagnosis: A blood pressure reading, as shown in the blood pressure monitor in the image, measures the pressure in the arteries when the heart beats (systolic pressure) in the first number, and the pressure in the arteries between heartbeats (diastolic pressure) in the second number. A blood pressure reading, given in millimeters of mercury (mm Hg), has two numbers. This is because blood pressure normally varies throughout the day, and it may be elevated during visits to the doctor (white coat hypertension).
Treatment: The blood pressure treatment goal should be less than 130/80 mm Hg if: Although 120/80 mm Hg or lower is the ideal blood pressure goal, doctors are unsure if one need treatment (medications) to reach that level. If one is age 65 or older, and use of medications produces lower systolic blood pressure (such as less than 130 mm Hg), the medications won't need to be changed unless they cause negative effects to the health or quality of life. Eating a heart-healthy diet with less salt Getting regular physical activity Maintaining a healthy weight or losing weight if one is overweight or obese Limiting the amount of alcohol one drink One is a healthy adult age 65 or older One is a healthy adult younger than age 65 with a 10 percent or higher risk of developing cardiovascular disease in the next 10 years One has chronic kidney disease, diabetes or coronary artery disease
Remedies: Lifestyle changes can help one control and prevent high blood pressure, even if one is taking blood pressure medication. Regular physical activity can help lower the blood pressure, manage stress, reduce the risk of several health problems and keep the weight under control. Home blood pressure monitoring can help one keep closer tabs on the blood pressure, show if medication is working, and even alert one and the doctor to potential complications. Home blood pressure monitoring isn't a substitute for visits to the doctor, and home blood pressure monitors may have some limitations. If the blood pressure is under control, check with the doctor about how often one need to check it. Get plenty of potassium, which can help prevent and control high blood pressure. Keeping a healthy weight, or losing weight if one is overweight or obese, can help one control the high blood pressure and lower the risk of related health problems. In general, one may reduce the blood pressure by about 1 mm Hg with each kilogram (about 2.2 pounds) of weight one lose. Even if one is healthy, alcohol can raise the blood pressure. According to the American Heart Association, device-guided breathing may be a reasonable nondrug option for lowering blood pressure, especially when anxiety accompanies high blood pressure or standard treatments aren't well-tolerated. If one is a woman with high blood pressure, discuss with the doctor how to control the blood pressure during pregnancy.
Medication: Thiazide diuretics are often the first, but not the only, choice in high blood pressure medications. If one is not taking a diuretic and the blood pressure remains high, talk to the doctor about adding one or replacing a drug one currently take with a diuretic. These medications including amlodipine (Norvasc), diltiazem (Cardizem, Tiazac, others) and others help relax the muscles of the blood vessels. If one is having trouble reaching the blood pressure goal with combinations of the above medications, the doctor may prescribe: Beta blockers. Beta blockers aren't usually recommended as the only medication one is prescribed, but they may be effective when combined with other blood pressure medications. Aliskiren (Tekturna) slows down the production of renin, an enzyme produced by the kidneys that starts a chain of chemical steps that increases blood pressure. If the blood pressure remains stubbornly high despite taking at least three different types of high blood pressure drugs, one of which usually should be a diuretic, one may have resistant hypertension. In fact, if one and the doctor can identify what's behind the persistently high blood pressure, there's a good chance one can meet the goal with the help of treatment that's more effective. If one don't take the high blood pressure medications exactly as directed, the blood pressure can pay the price. These medications such as lisinopril (Zestril), benazepril (Lotensin), captopril (Capoten) and others help relax blood vessels by blocking the formation of a natural chemical that narrows blood vessels. Evaluate potential causes of the condition and determine if those can be treated Review medications one is taking for other conditions and recommend one not take any that worsen the blood pressure Recommend that one monitor the blood pressure at home to see if one may have higher blood pressure in the doctor's office (white coat hypertension) Suggest healthy lifestyle changes, such as eating a healthy diet with less salt, maintaining a healthy weight and limiting how much alcohol one drink Make changes to the high blood pressure medications to come up with the most effective combination and doses Consider adding an aldosterone antagonist such as spironolactone (Aldactone), which may lead to control of resistant hypertension Thiazide diuretics.
info-Symptoms: None
info-Risk factors: Lack of sleep, Excess salt, excess body weight, smoking, alcohol Air Pollution

Name: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Overview: Illustrations of a normal heart (left) and a heart with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). However, in a small number of people with HCM, the thickened heart muscle can cause shortness of breath, chest pain or problems in the heart's electrical system, resulting in life-threatening abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias) or sudden death.
Causes: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is usually caused by abnormal genes (gene mutations) that cause the heart muscle to grow abnormally thick. In most people with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, the muscular wall (septum) between the two bottom chambers of the heart (ventricles) becomes thicker than normal. People with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy also have an abnormal arrangement of heart muscle cells (myofiber disarray).
Diagnosis: The doctor will likely order tests to diagnose hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) or rule out other conditions that can cause similar symptoms. This test uses sound waves (ultrasound) to see if the heart's muscle is abnormally thick.
Remedies: The doctor may recommend lifestyle changes, including Women who have hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can generally have normal pregnancies. However, if one has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, the doctor may recommend that one see a doctor experienced in caring for women with high-risk conditions during the pregnancy. Competitive sports are generally not recommended for people with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, with the possible exception of some low-intensity sports. If one has symptoms or a history of rhythms provoked by alcohol, ask the doctor for guidance about safe levels of alcohol use.
info-Symptoms: Feeling tired, leg swelling, shortness of breath, chest pain, fainting
info-Causes: Genetics, Fabry disease, Friedreich's ataxia, certain medications
info-Diagnostic method: Electrocardiogram, echocardiogram, stress testing, genetic testing
info-Prognosis: Less than 1% per year risk of death (with treatment)

Name: Hypoglycemia , diabetic
Overview: Diabetic hypoglycemia occurs when someone with diabetes doesn't have enough sugar (glucose) in his or her blood. Low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) is defined as a blood sugar level below 70 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 3.9 millimoles per liter (mmol/L).

Name: Hypohidrosis
Overview: Anhidrosis is the inability to sweat normally. When one don't sweat (perspire), the body can't cool itself, which can lead to overheating and sometimes to heatstroke a potentially fatal condition.
Diagnosis: During this test, known as a thermoregulatory sweat test, one is coated with a powder that changes color when and where one sweat. For this test, skin cells and sometimes sweat glands are removed for examination under a microscope.

Name: Hypohydration
Causes: Other dehydration causes include Diarrhea, vomiting. If one has vomiting along with diarrhea, one lose even more fluids and minerals. In general, the higher the fever, the more dehydrated one may become. If one do vigorous activity and don't replace fluids as one go along, one can become dehydrated. Hot, humid weather increases the amount one sweat and the amount of fluid one lose. Certain medications, such as diuretics and some blood pressure medications, also can lead to dehydration, generally because they cause one to urinate more.
