Diagnosis: If one is dehydrated, one is also likely to have low blood pressure, especially when moving from a lying to a standing position, a faster than normal heart rate and reduced blood flow to the extremities. To help confirm the diagnosis and pinpoint the degree of dehydration, one may have other tests, such as: Blood tests. Blood samples may be used to check for a number of factors, such as the levels of the electrolytes especially sodium and potassium and how well the kidneys are working.
Treatment: For infants and children who have become dehydrated from diarrhea, vomiting or fever, use an over-the-counter oral rehydration solution. Most adults with mild to moderate dehydration from diarrhea, vomiting or fever can improve their condition by drinking more water or other liquids.

Name: Hyponatremia
Overview: Hyponatremia occurs when the concentration of sodium in the blood is abnormally low. In hyponatremia, one or more factors ranging from an underlying medical condition to drinking too much water cause the sodium in the body to become diluted.
Causes: It helps maintain normal blood pressure, supports the work of the nerves and muscles, and regulates the body's fluid balance. This causes the body to lose electrolytes, such as sodium, and also increases ADH levels. Adrenal gland insufficiency (Addison's disease) affects the adrenal glands ability to produce hormones that help maintain the body's balance of sodium, potassium and water.
Risk factors: Older adults may have more contributing factors for hyponatremia, including age-related changes, taking certain medications and a greater likelihood of developing a chronic disease that alters the body's sodium balance. Medical conditions that may increase the risk of hyponatremia include kidney disease, syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone (SIADH) and heart failure, among others. People who drink too much water while taking part in marathons, ultramarathons, triathlons and other long-distance, high-intensity activities are at an increased risk of hyponatremia.
Treatment: If one has moderate, chronic hyponatremia due to the diet, diuretics or drinking too much water, the doctor may recommend temporarily cutting back on fluids. Options include Seek emergency care for anyone who develops severe signs and symptoms of hyponatremia, such as nausea and vomiting, confusion, seizures, or lost consciousness. Depending on the extent and duration of these signs and symptoms, the doctor may recommend seeking immediate medical care. One may take medications to manage the signs and symptoms of hyponatremia, such as headaches, nausea and seizures.
info-Symptoms: Decreased ability to think, headaches, nausea, poor balance, confusion, seizures, coma

Name: Hypoparathyroidism
Treatment: However, at high doses, calcium supplements can cause gastrointestinal side effects, such as constipation, in some people. Vitamin D. High doses of vitamin D, generally in the form of calcitriol, can help the body absorb calcium and eliminate phosphorus. If the calcium levels remain low even with treatment, thiazide diuretics can help decrease the amount of calcium lost through the urine. Because of the potential risk of bone cancer (osteosarcoma), at least in animal studies, this drug is available only through a restricted program to people whose calcium levels can't be controlled with calcium and vitamin D supplements and who understand the risks.

Name: Hypoplastic left heart syndrome
Overview: Hypoplastic left heart syndrome is a complex and rare heart defect present at birth (congenital). Medication to prevent closure of the connection (ductus arteriosus) between the right and left sides, followed by either surgery or a heart transplant, is necessary to treat hypoplastic left heart syndrome.
Causes: The lower chambers, the more muscular right and left ventricles, pump blood out of the heart. In performing its basic job pumping blood throughout the body the heart uses its left and right sides for different tasks. The left side of the heart pumps blood into a large vessel called the aorta, which circulates the oxygen-rich blood to the rest of the body. In this condition, the left side of the heart including the aorta, aortic valve, left ventricle and mitral valve is underdeveloped (hypoplastic). The oxygen-rich blood returns to the right side of the heart through a natural opening (foramen ovale) between the right chambers of the heart (atria).
Diagnosis: After the baby is born, his or her doctor may suspect a heart defect, such as hypoplastic left heart syndrome, if the baby has grayish-blue skin color or has trouble breathing. The baby's doctor may also suspect a heart defect if he or she hears a heart murmur when listening to the heart with a stethoscope an abnormal whooshing sound caused by turbulent blood flow.

Name: Hypospadias
Overview: Hypospadias is a condition in which the opening of the urethra is on the underside of the penis instead of at the tip. The location of the opening can vary and can be anywhere from underneath the tip of the penis (more common) to the base of the penis (less common). Hypospadias (hi-poe-SPAY-dee-us) is a birth defect (congenital condition) in which the opening of the urethra is on the underside of the penis instead of at the tip.
Risk factors: Although the cause of hypospadias is usually unknown, these factors may be associated with the condition: Family history. There is some speculation about an association between hypospadias and a mother's exposure to certain hormones or certain compounds such as pesticides or industrial chemicals, but further studies are needed to confirm this.

Name: Ice cream headaches
Treatment: The international classification of headache disorders, 3rd edition (beta version). Ice cream headache in students and family history of headache: A cross-sectional epidemiological study.

Name: Idiopathic hypersomnia
Overview: Idiopathic hypersomnia is an uncommon sleep disorder that causes one to be excessively sleepy during the day even after a good night's sleep. The need to sleep can strike at any time, including when one is driving a car or working, which makes idiopathic hypersomnia potentially dangerous.
Diagnosis: To diagnose the condition, the doctor will review the symptoms, go over the family and medical history, including the medications, and conduct a physical examination. The doctor might order several tests to diagnose the condition, determine the cause of the condition and rule out other conditions. The doctor may ask one to rate the sleepiness with this tool to help determine how sleep affects the daily life. A polysomnogram monitors the brain activity, eye movements, leg movements, heart rate, breathing functions and oxygen levels as one sleep.
Treatment: Because the cause of idiopathic hypersomnia isn't known, the treatment is aimed at easing symptoms. Stimulant medication, such as modafinil (Provigil), might be prescribed to help one stay awake during the day. In addition, the doctor might recommend that one develop a regular nighttime sleep schedule and avoid alcohol and medications that can affect the sleep. Hypersomnia evaluation, treatment and social and economic aspects.

Name: IgA nephropathy ( Berger 's disease )
Causes: The glomeruli filter waste products and substances the body needs such as sodium, phosphorus and potassium which then pass through tiny tubules. Each kidney contains tiny blood vessels that filter waste, excess water and other substances from the blood as they pass through the kidneys. The filtered blood reenters the bloodstream, while the waste material passes into the bladder and out of the body when one urinate. But in IgA nephropathy, this antibody collects in the glomeruli, causing inflammation (glomerulonephritis) and gradually affecting their filtering ability.
Risk factors: Although the exact cause of IgA nephropathy is unknown, these factors might increase the risk of developing this condition: Sex. In North America and Western Europe, IgA nephropathy affects at least twice as many men as it does women. In some cases, IgA nephropathy appears to run in families, indicating that genetic factors contribute to the disease.
Diagnosis: Blood or protein in the urine, a possible first sign of IgA nephropathy, might be discovered during a routine checkup. If the doctor suspects that one has problems with the kidneys, one might be asked to collect the urine for 24 hours for additional kidney function tests. The doctor may also recommend this test, which uses a special contrast agent to track how well the kidneys are filtering wastes.
Treatment: Or contact the National Kidney Foundation (NKF) to learn about NKF Peers, a national, telephone-based peer support program. However, one might be referred to a doctor who specializes in treating kidney disorders (nephrologist). Taking angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) can lower the blood pressure and reduce protein loss. In some cases, corticosteroid medications, such as prednisone, and other potent drugs that suppress the immune response (immunosuppressants) might keep the immune system from attacking the glomeruli. These drugs can cause serious side effects, such as high blood pressure, high blood sugar and increased risk of infection. If one has high cholesterol, cholesterol-lowering medications can help control it and slow the progression of kidney damage. Keeping the blood pressure levels near normal can help slow kidney damage from IgA nephropathy. Healthy changes in the lifestyle including limiting the salt intake, losing excess weight, being physically active, using alcohol in moderation and taking the blood pressure medications as prescribed are ways to keep the blood pressure under control. Reducing the amount of protein one eat and taking steps to decrease the cholesterol levels may help slow the progression of IgA nephropathy and protect the kidneys.

Name: IgA vasculitis
Symptoms: The four main characteristics of Henoch-Schonlein purpura include See the doctor if one has Henoch-Schonlein purpura and it's causing serious problems with the digestive tract. People with Henoch-Schonlein purpura often have pain and swelling around the joints mainly in the knees and ankles. Many children with Henoch-Schonlein purpura develop belly pain, nausea, vomiting and bloody stools.
Overview: Henoch-Schonlein purpura is an inflammation of the small blood vessels of the skin, joints, bowels and kidneys. When blood vessels get inflamed, they can bleed into the skin, causing a reddish-purple rash (purpura). Henoch-Schonlein purpura (also known as IgA vasculitis) is a disorder that causes the small blood vessels in the skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys to become inflamed and bleed.
Causes: In Henoch-Schonlein purpura, some of the body's small blood vessels become inflamed, which can cause bleeding in the skin, abdomen and kidneys. Other triggers include chickenpox, strep throat, measles, hepatitis, certain medications, food, insect bites and exposure to cold weather.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of developing Henoch-Schonlein purpura include Age. The disease affects primarily children and young adults, with the majority of cases occurring in children between the ages of 2 and 6. White and Asian children are more likely to develop Henoch-Schonlein purpura than are black children.

Name: Illness anxiety disorder
Overview: Illness anxiety disorder, sometimes called hypochondriasis or health anxiety, is worrying excessively that one is or may become seriously ill. One may have no physical symptoms. Or one may believe that normal body sensations or minor symptoms are signs of severe illness, even though a thorough medical exam doesn't reveal a serious medical condition. Instead, people previously diagnosed with hypochondriasis may be diagnosed as having illness anxiety disorder, in which the focus of the fear and worry is on uncomfortable or unusual physical sensations being an indication of a serious medical condition.
Causes: The exact cause of illness anxiety disorder isn't clear, but these factors may play a role: Beliefs. One may have had experience with serious illness in childhood, so physical sensations may be frightening to one.
Remedies: In addition to profession treatment for illness anxiety disorder, these self-care steps can help: Work with the provider. Work with the primary care provider or mental health professional to determine a regular schedule for visits to discuss the concerns and build a trusting relationship. Learning stress management and relaxation methods, such as progressive muscle relaxation, may help reduce anxiety. A graduated activity program may have a calming effect on the mood, reduce the anxiety and help improve the physical functioning. If one has symptoms that concern one, talk to the primary care provider at the next scheduled appointment.
info-Symptoms: Excessive and persistent fear of, or preoccupation with, having or developing a severe illness

Name: Impetigo
Symptoms: Bullous impetigo causes fluid-filled blisters often on the trunk, arms and legs of infants and children younger than 2 years. A less common form of the disorder, called bullous impetigo, may feature larger blisters that occur on the trunk of infants and young children.
Overview: Impetigo starts as a red sore that ruptures, oozes for a few days and then forms a honey-colored crust. Impetigo usually appears as red sores on the face, especially around a child's nose and mouth, and on hands and feet.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of impetigo include Adults and people with diabetes or a weakened immune system are more likely to develop ecthyma. Participation in sports that involve skin-to-skin contact, such as football or wrestling, increases the risk of developing impetigo. The bacteria that cause impetigo often enter the skin through a small skin injury, insect bite or rash.
info-Symptoms: Yellowish skin crusts, painful
info-Causes: Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes which spreads by direct contact
info-Risk factors: Day care, crowding, poor nutrition, diabetes mellitus, contact sports, breaks in the skin
info-Prevention: Hand washing, avoiding infected people, cleaning injuries

Name: Impotence
Diagnosis: For many people, a physical exam and answering questions (medical history) are all that's needed for a doctor to diagnose erectile dysfunction and recommend a treatment. If one has chronic health conditions or the doctor suspects that an underlying condition might be involved, one might need further tests or a consultation with a specialist. A sample of the blood might be sent to a lab to check for signs of heart disease, diabetes, low testosterone levels and other health conditions. Like blood tests, urine tests are used to look for signs of diabetes and other underlying health conditions.
info-Symptoms: Inability to gain or maintain an erection
info-Risk factors: cardiovascular disease, diabetes

Name: Incompetent cervix
Overview: The ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix and vagina (vaginal canal) make up the female reproductive system. If the cervix begins to open early, or one has a history of cervical insufficiency, the doctor might recommend preventive medication during pregnancy, frequent ultrasounds or a procedure that closes the cervix with strong sutures (cervical cerclage).
Risk factors: Some surgical procedures used to treat cervical abnormalities associated with an abnormal Pap smear can result in cervical insufficiency. Uterine abnormalities and genetic disorders affecting a fibrous type of protein that makes up the body's connective tissues (collagen) might cause an incompetent cervix. Exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES), a synthetic form of the hormone estrogen, before birth also has been linked to cervical insufficiency.
Diagnosis: During a transvaginal ultrasound, the doctor or a medical technician inserts a wandlike device (transducer) into the vagina while one lie on the back on an exam table. The doctor might diagnose an incompetent cervix if one has: Tests and procedures to help diagnose an incompetent cervix during the second trimester include There aren't any tests that can be done before pregnancy to reliably predict an incompetent cervix. However, certain tests done before pregnancy, such as an MRI or an ultrasound, can help detect uterine abnormalities that might cause an incompetent cervix. A history of painless cervical dilation and second trimester deliveries Advanced cervical dilation and effacement before week 24 of pregnancy without painful contractions, vaginal bleeding, water breaking (ruptured membranes) or infection Transvaginal ultrasound. If fetal membranes are visible and an ultrasound shows signs of inflammation but one don't have symptoms of an infection, the doctor might test a sample of amniotic fluid (amniocentesis) to diagnose or rule out an infection of the amniotic sac and fluid (chorioamnionitis).

Name: Incomplete fracture
Symptoms: More-severe greenstick fractures may cause an obvious deformity, accompanied by significant pain and swelling. Seek immediate medical attention if a child is unable to bear weight or if there is obvious pain, deformity and swelling.
Overview: A greenstick fracture occurs when a bone bends and cracks, instead of breaking completely into separate pieces. A greenstick fracture occurs when a bone bends and cracks, instead of breaking completely into separate pieces.
Diagnosis: During the physical exam, the doctor will inspect the affected area for tenderness, swelling, deformity, numbness or an open wound. The doctor may want to take X-rays of the uninjured limb, for comparison purposes.

Name: Incontinence , fecal
Symptoms: Fecal incontinence may occur temporarily during an occasional bout of diarrhea, but for some people, fecal incontinence is chronic or recurring. Another type of fecal incontinence occurs in people who are not aware of the need to pass stool. Often, people are reluctant to tell their doctors about fecal incontinence.
Overview: Fecal incontinence is the inability to control bowel movements, causing stool (feces) to leak unexpectedly from the rectum. Also called bowel incontinence, fecal incontinence ranges from an occasional leakage of stool while passing gas to a complete loss of bowel control.
Causes: Injury to the rings of muscle at the end of the rectum (anal sphincter) may make it difficult to hold stool back properly. Injury to the nerves that sense stool in the rectum or those that control the anal sphincter can lead to fecal incontinence. The nerve damage can be caused by childbirth, constant straining during bowel movements, spinal cord injury or stroke. Some diseases, such as diabetes and multiple sclerosis, also can affect these nerves and cause damage that leads to fecal incontinence. Chronic constipation may cause a dry, hard mass of stool (impacted stool) to form in the rectum and become too large to pass. Chronic constipation may also cause nerve damage that leads to fecal incontinence. Solid stool is easier to retain in the rectum than is loose stool, so the loose stools of diarrhea can cause or worsen fecal incontinence. When the veins in the rectum swell, causing hemorrhoids, this keeps the anus from closing completely, which can allow stool to leak out. Fecal incontinence can be a result of this condition, in which the rectum drops down into the anus. In women, fecal incontinence can occur if the rectum protrudes through the vagina.
Risk factors: A number of factors may increase the risk of developing fecal incontinence, including Age. People who have long-standing diabetes or multiple sclerosis conditions that can damage nerves that help control defecation may be at risk of fecal incontinence. An injury that caused a physical disability also may cause rectal nerve damage, leading to fecal incontinence.
Remedies: Kegel exercises strengthen the pelvic floor muscles, which support the bladder and bowel and, in women, the uterus, and may help reduce incontinence. As the muscles strengthen, hold the contraction longer, gradually working the way up to three sets of 10 contractions every day. Foods that can cause diarrhea or gas and worsen fecal incontinence include spicy foods, fatty and greasy foods, and dairy products (if one is lactose intolerant). When medical treatments can't completely eliminate incontinence, products such as absorbent pads and disposable underwear can help one manage the problem. If one use pads or adult diapers, be sure they have an absorbent wicking layer on top, to help keep moisture away from the skin. If one is short on time, one can gently pat the area dry with toilet paper or a clean washcloth.
Medication: If constipation is causing fecal incontinence, the doctor may recommend drinking plenty of fluids and eating fiber-rich foods. If muscle damage is causing fecal incontinence, the doctor may recommend a program of exercise and other therapies to restore muscle strength. Options include Treating fecal incontinence may require surgery to correct an underlying problem, such as rectal prolapse or sphincter damage caused by childbirth. Anti-diarrheal drugs such as loperamide hydrochloride (ImodiumA-D) and diphenoxylate and atropine sulfate (Lomotil) Bulk laxatives such as methylcellulose (Citrucel) and psyllium (Metamucil), if chronic constipation is causing the incontinence Biofeedback. People learn how to strengthen pelvic floor muscles, sense when stool is ready to be released and contract the muscles if having a bowel movement at a certain time is inconvenient. The sacral nerves run from the spinal cord to muscles in the pelvis, and regulate the sensation and strength of the rectal and anal sphincter muscles.

Name: Infant jaundice
Risk factors: Premature babies also may feed less and have fewer bowel movements, resulting in less bilirubin eliminated through stool. If the mother's blood type is different from her baby's, the baby may have received antibodies through the placenta that cause abnormally rapid breakdown of red blood cells. Breast-fed babies, particularly those who have difficulty nursing or getting enough nutrition from breast-feeding, are at higher risk of jaundice.
Treatment: For moderate or severe jaundice, the baby may need to stay longer in the newborn nursery or be readmitted to the hospital. Treatments to lower the level of bilirubin in the baby's blood may include Enhanced nutrition. Intravenous transfusion of an immunoglobulin a blood protein that can reduce levels of antibodies may decrease jaundice and lessen the need for an exchange transfusion, although results are not conclusive. Rarely, when severe jaundice doesn't respond to other treatments, a baby may need an exchange transfusion of blood. This involves repeatedly withdrawing small amounts of blood and replacing it with donor blood, thereby diluting the bilirubin and maternal antibodies a procedure that's performed in a newborn intensive care unit.
Remedies: If the baby is having trouble breast-feeding, is losing weight, or is dehydrated, the doctor may suggest giving the baby formula or expressed milk to supplement breast-feeding. In some cases, the doctor may recommend using formula alone for a couple of days and then resuming breast-feeding.

Name: Infant reflux
Causes: In infants, the ring of muscle between the esophagus and the stomach the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is not yet fully mature. Eventually, the LES will open only when the baby swallows and will remain tightly closed at other times, keeping stomach contents where they belong. A valve between the stomach and the small intestine is narrowed, preventing stomach contents from emptying into the small intestine.
Diagnosis: If the baby is healthy, growing as expected and seems content, then further testing usually isn't needed. To measure the acidity in the baby's esophagus, the doctor will insert a thin tube through the baby's nose or mouth and into the esophagus. A special tube equipped with a camera lens and light (endoscope) is passed through the baby's mouth and into the esophagus, stomach and first part of the small intestine.
Treatment: In the meantime, the doctor might recommend: Giving the baby smaller, more-frequent feedings. Eliminating dairy products, beef or eggs from the diet if one is breast-feeding, to test if the baby has an allergy. Although recognized as a reasonable strategy, thickening adds potentially unnecessary calories to the baby's diet.
Remedies: Also hold the baby in a sitting position for 30 minutes after feeding, if possible. Feed the baby slightly less than usual if one is bottle-feeding, or cut back a little on the amount of nursing time.
info-Symptoms: Taste of acid, heartburn, bad breath, chest pain, breathing problems
info-Causes: Inadequate closure of the lower esophageal sphincter
info-Risk factors: Obesity, pregnancy, smoking, hiatal hernia, taking certain medicines
info-Diagnostic method: Gastroscopy, upper GI series, esophageal pH monitoring, esophageal manometry
info-Medication: Antacids, H2 receptor blockers, proton pump inhibitors, prokinetics

Name: Infectious diseases
Overview: Infectious diseases are disorders caused by organisms such as bacteria, viruses, fungi or parasites. Many infectious diseases, such as measles and chickenpox, can be prevented by vaccines.
Causes: Infectious diseases can be caused by: An easy way to catch most infectious diseases is by coming in contact with a person or an animal with the infection. Infectious diseases commonly spread through the direct transfer of bacteria, viruses or other germs from one person to another. The person who passes the germ may have no symptoms of the disease, but may simply be a carrier. Some germs rely on insect carriers such as mosquitoes, fleas, lice or ticks to move from host to host. Escherichia coli (E. coli), for example, is a bacterium present in or on certain foods such as undercooked hamburger or unpasteurized fruit juice. Even smaller than bacteria, viruses cause a multitude of diseases ranging from the common cold to AIDS. Many skin diseases, such as ringworm and athlete's foot, are caused by fungi. Being bitten or scratched by an infected animal even a pet can make one sick and, in extreme circumstances, can be fatal. A pregnant woman may pass germs that cause infectious diseases to her unborn baby.
Diagnosis: Imaging procedures such as X-rays, computerized tomography and magnetic resonance imaging can help pinpoint diagnoses and rule out other conditions that may be causing symptoms. To avoid potential contamination of the sample, one may be instructed to cleanse the genital area with an antiseptic pad and to collect the urine midstream. Samples from the throat, or other moist areas of the body, may be obtained with a sterile swab.

Name: Infertility , female
Symptoms: Up to age 35, most doctors recommend trying to get pregnant for at least a year before testing or treatment. If one is older than 40, the doctor may want to begin testing or treatment right away.
Causes: The ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix and vagina (vaginal canal) make up the female reproductive system. Fertilization and implantation During fertilization, the sperm and egg unite in one of the fallopian tubes to form a zygote. Problems with the regulation of reproductive hormones by the hypothalamus or the pituitary gland, or problems in the ovary, can cause ovulation disorders. Damaged or blocked fallopian tubes keep sperm from getting to the egg or block the passage of the fertilized egg into the uterus. Causes of fallopian tube damage or blockage can include Endometriosis occurs when tissue that normally grows in the uterus implants and grows in other locations. This extra tissue growth and the surgical removal of it can cause scarring, which may block fallopian tubes and keep an egg and sperm from uniting. Endometriosis can also affect the lining of the uterus, disrupting implantation of the fertilized egg. The condition also seems to affect fertility in less-direct ways, such as damage to the sperm or egg. Several uterine or cervical causes can impact fertility by interfering with implantation or increasing the likelihood of a miscarriage: Sometimes, the cause of infertility is never found. The egg and sperm meet in the fallopian tubes, and the embryo needs a healthy uterus in which to grow. Sperm swim up the cervix, through the uterus and into the fallopian tube to reach the egg for fertilization. The pituitary gland may cause excess production of prolactin (hyperprolactinemia), which reduces estrogen production and may cause infertility. Some can block fallopian tubes or interfere with implantation, affecting fertility. Uterine abnormalities present from birth, such as an abnormally shaped uterus, can cause problems becoming or remaining pregnant.
Risk factors: Certain factors may put one at higher risk of infertility, including Age. Besides damaging the cervix and fallopian tubes, smoking increases the risk of miscarriage and ectopic pregnancy. Having unprotected intercourse with multiple partners increases the risk of a sexually transmitted infection that may cause fertility problems later.
Diagnosis: Fertility tests may include Depending on the situation, rarely the testing may include Ovulation testing. During hysterosalpingography (his-tur-o-sal-ping-GOG-ruh-fee), X-ray contrast is injected into the uterus and an X-ray is taken to detect abnormalities in the uterine cavity. Depending on the symptoms, the doctor may request a hysteroscopy to look for uterine or fallopian tube disease. This minimally invasive surgery involves making a small incision beneath the navel and inserting a thin viewing device to examine the fallopian tubes, ovaries and uterus. A laparoscopy may identify endometriosis, scarring, blockages or irregularities of the fallopian tubes, and problems with the ovaries and uterus.

Name: Inflammatory bowel disease ( IBD )
Symptoms: Inflammatory bowel disease symptoms vary, depending on the severity of inflammation and where it occurs. Although inflammatory bowel disease usually isn't fatal, it's a serious disease that, in some cases, may cause life-threatening complications.
Overview: Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both forms of inflammatory bowel disease. Crohn's disease most commonly affects the colon and the last part of the small intestine (ileum). Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is an umbrella term used to describe disorders that involve chronic inflammation of the digestive tract. Types of IBD include Both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease usually involve severe diarrhea, abdominal pain, fatigue and weight loss.
Risk factors: Although whites have the highest risk of the disease, it can occur in any race. One is at higher risk if one has a close relative such as a parent, sibling or child with the disease. Although smoking may provide some protection against ulcerative colitis, the overall health benefits of not smoking make it important to try to quit. These include ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve), diclofenac sodium (Voltaren) and others. These medications may increase the risk of developing IBD or worsen disease in people who have IBD.
Diagnosis: To help confirm a diagnosis of IBD, one may have one or more of the following tests and procedures: During a colonoscopy, the doctor inserts a colonoscope into the rectum to check for abnormalities in the entire colon. During a flexible sigmoidoscopy exam, the doctor inserts a sigmoidoscope into the rectum to check for abnormalities in the sigmoid colon and most of the descending colon. The doctor may suggest blood tests to check for anemia a condition in which there aren't enough red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to the tissues or to check for signs of infection from bacteria or viruses. This exam allows the doctor to view the entire colon using a thin, flexible, lighted tube with an attached camera. During the procedure, the doctor can also take small samples of tissue (biopsy) for laboratory analysis. The doctor uses a slender, flexible, lighted tube to examine the rectum and sigmoid, the last portion of the colon. If the colon is severely inflamed, the doctor may perform this test instead of a full colonoscopy. In this procedure, the doctor uses a slender, flexible, lighted tube to examine the esophagus, stomach and first part of the small intestine (duodenum). While it is rare for these areas to be involved with Crohn's disease, this test may be recommended if one is having nausea and vomiting, difficulty eating or upper abdominal pain. If one has severe symptoms, the doctor may use a standard X-ray of the abdominal area to rule out serious complications, such as a perforated colon.
Remedies: If one has inflammatory bowel disease, high-fiber foods, such as fresh fruits and vegetables and whole grains, may make the symptoms worse. In general, one may have more problems with foods in the cabbage family, such as broccoli and cauliflower, and nuts, seeds, corn and popcorn. Smoking increases the risk of developing Crohn's disease, and once one has it, smoking can make it worse. The association of stress with Crohn's disease is controversial, but many people who have the disease report symptom flares during high-stress periods. Many people with inflammatory bowel disease find that problems such as diarrhea, abdominal pain and gas improve by limiting or eliminating dairy products. One may be lactose intolerant that is, the body can't digest the milk sugar (lactose) in dairy foods. If one has Crohn's disease of the small intestine, one may not be able to digest or absorb fat normally. Spicy foods, alcohol and caffeine may make the signs and symptoms worse. Because Crohn's disease can interfere with the ability to absorb nutrients and because the diet may be limited, multivitamin and mineral supplements are often helpful.

Name: Inflammatory breast cancer
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of inflammatory breast cancer include Inflammatory breast cancer doesn't commonly form a lump, as occurs with other forms of breast cancer. But if the redness does not improve, then the doctor may consider more serious causes of the symptoms, such as inflammatory breast cancer.
Risk factors: Women are more likely to be diagnosed with inflammatory breast cancer than are men but men can develop inflammatory breast cancer, too. Black women have a higher risk of inflammatory breast cancer than do white women. People who are obese have a greater risk of inflammatory breast cancer compared with those of normal weight.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose inflammatory breast cancer include Additional tests may be necessary to determine whether the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes or to other areas of the body. Stages of inflammatory breast cancer range from III to IV, with the higher stage indicating that cancer has spread to other areas of the body. The doctor may recommend a breast X-ray (mammogram) or a breast ultrasound to look for signs of cancer in the breast, such as thickened skin.

Name: Inflammed gallbladder
Overview: The gallbladder serves as a reservoir for bile, a yellow-green fluid produced in the liver. When one eat, the gallbladder releases bile into the bile duct, where it's carried to the upper part of the small intestine (duodenum) to help break down fat in food.
Causes: Most often, cholecystitis is the result of hard particles that develop in the gallbladder (gallstones). Gallstones can block the tube (cystic duct) through which bile flows when it leaves the gallbladder. A tumor may prevent bile from draining out of the gallbladder properly, causing bile buildup that can lead to cholecystitis. A very severe illness can damage blood vessels and decrease blood flow to the gallbladder, leading to cholecystitis.

Name: Influenza ( flu )
Overview: Influenza is a viral infection that attacks the respiratory system the nose, throat and lungs. People at higher risk of developing flu complications include Though the annual influenza vaccine isn't 100 percent effective, it's still the best defense against the flu.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of developing influenza or its complications include Age. People who live or work in facilities with many other residents, such as nursing homes or military barracks, are more likely to develop influenza. This can make it easier for one to catch influenza and may also increase the risk of developing complications. Chronic conditions, including lung diseases such as asthma, diabetes, heart disease, neurological or neurodevelopmental disease, an airway abnormality, and kidney, liver or blood disease, may increase the risk of influenza complications. People who are younger than 19 years of age and receiving long-term aspirin therapy are at risk of developing Reye's syndrome if infected with influenza. Pregnant women are more likely to develop influenza complications, particularly in the second and third trimesters.
Treatment: But if one has severe infection or are at higher risk for complications, the doctor may prescribe an antiviral medication, such as oseltamivir (Tamiflu), zanamivir (Relenza), peramivir (Rapivab) or baloxavir (Xofluza). Most circulating strains of influenza have become resistant to amantadine and rimantadine (Flumadine), which are older antiviral drugs that are no longer recommended.
Remedies: If one do come down with the flu, these measures may help ease the symptoms: To help control the spread of influenza in the community, stay home and keep sick children home until fever has been gone for 24 hours. Use an over-the-counter pain reliever, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), to combat the achiness associated with influenza. Children and teens recovering from flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin because of the risk of Reye's syndrome, a rare but potentially fatal condition. Rochester, Minn.: Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research; 2017. Prevention and control of seasonal influenza with vaccines: Recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices United States, 2018-2019 influenza season. Prevention and control of seasonal influenza with vaccines: Recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices United States, 2019-2020 influenza season.

Name: Influenza , avian
Overview: Bird flu is caused by a type of influenza virus that rarely infects humans. More than a dozen types of bird flu have been identified, including the two strains that have most recently infected humans H5N1 and H7N9.
Treatment: Many influenza viruses have become resistant to the effects of a category of antiviral drugs that includes amantadine and rimantadine (Flumadine). Health officials recommend the use of oseltamivir (Tamiflu) or, if oseltamivir can't be used, zanamivir (Relenza).

Name: Ingrown hair
Symptoms: Ingrown hairs most commonly appear in the beard area, including the chin and cheeks and, especially, the neck. Other common areas for ingrown hairs are the armpits, pubic area and legs.
Remedies: To release ingrown hairs, one can: Wash the affected area using a washcloth or soft-bristled toothbrush. Use a sterile needle, inserting it under hair loops, to gently lift embedded hair tips.
Medication: Retinoids applied to the skin, such as tretinoin (Renova, Retin-A, others), help with clearing dead cells from the skin (exfoliation). For mild infections caused by scratching the affected area, the doctor may recommend an antibiotic ointment.

Name: Ingrown toenails
Overview: An ingrown toenail may cause pain, redness, swelling and, sometimes, an infection around the toenail. If the pain is severe or spreading, the doctor can take steps to relieve the discomfort and help one avoid complications of ingrown toenails. If one has diabetes or another condition that causes poor blood flow to the feet, one is at greater risk of complications of ingrown toenails.
Remedies: After each soaking, put fresh bits of cotton or waxed dental floss under the ingrown edge. Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve) may help ease the toe pain.

Name: Inguinal hernia
Overview: Inguinal hernias occur when part of the membrane lining the abdominal cavity (omentum) or intestine protrudes through a weak spot in the abdomen often along the inguinal canal, which carries the spermatic cord in men. An inguinal hernia occurs when tissue, such as part of the intestine, protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal muscles.
Risk factors: Factors that contribute to developing an inguinal hernia include Being male. Men are eight times more likely to develop an inguinal hernia than are women. Even if the previous hernia occurred in childhood, one is at higher risk of developing another inguinal hernia.
info-Symptoms: Pain, bulging in the groin
info-Risk factors: Family history, smoking, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, obesity, pregnancy, peritoneal dialysis, collagen vascular disease, connective tissue disease, previous open appendectomy

Name: Inherited metabolic disorders
Overview: Inherited metabolic disorders refer to different types of medical conditions caused by genetic defects most commonly inherited from both parents that interfere with the body's metabolism. Inherited metabolic disorders fall into different categories, depending on the specific substance and whether it builds up in harmful amounts (because it can't be broken down), it's too low or it's missing. There are hundreds of inherited metabolic disorders, caused by different genetic defects. Because there are so many types of inherited metabolic disorders, treatment recommendations may vary considerably from dietary restrictions to liver transplants. Inborn errors of metabolism: Epidemiology, pathogenesis and clinical features.

Name: Intestinal obstruction
Overview: The small intestine and colon are components of the digestive tract, which processes the foods one eat. Causes of intestinal obstruction may include fibrous bands of tissue (adhesions) in the abdomen that form after surgery, an inflamed intestine (Crohn's disease), infected pouches in the intestine (diverticulitis), hernias and colon cancer.
Diagnosis: To confirm a diagnosis of intestinal obstruction, the doctor may recommend an abdominal X-ray. However, some intestinal obstructions can't be seen using standard X-rays. These images are more detailed than a standard X-ray, and are more likely to show an intestinal obstruction. An air or barium enema is basically enhanced imaging of the colon that may be done for certain suspected causes of obstruction.
info-Symptoms: Abdominal pain, vomiting, bloating, not passing gas
info-Causes: Adhesions, hernias, volvulus, endometriosis, inflammatory bowel disease, appendicitis, tumors, diverticulitis, ischemic bowel, tuberculosis, intussusception

Name: Intracranial venous malformations
Overview: Intracranial venous malformations are abnormally enlarged veins in the brain. Intracranial venous malformations might remain undetected or be found incidentally when one has a brain-imaging test for another condition.
Diagnosis: A CT scan creates a series of X-rays to create detailed, cross-sectional images of the blood vessels and the brain. In some cases, dye is injected into a vein to assess the brain tissue or the blood vessels in greater detail (CT angiogram or CT venogram). In some cases a contrast dye is injected into a vein to look at the brain tissue in a different way, and to evaluate the blood vessels (magnetic resonance angiography or magnetic resonance venography).
Treatment: Doctors usually don't treat intracranial venous malformations because they rarely cause symptoms. Rarely, people who have intracranial venous malformations have seizures or bleeding in the brain (brain hemorrhage).

Name: Intraductal carcinoma
Symptoms: Ask the doctor when one should consider breast cancer screening and how often it should be repeated. Most groups recommend considering routine breast cancer screening beginning in the 40s.
Overview: Each breast contains 15 to 20 lobes of glandular tissue, arranged like the petals of a daisy. Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is the presence of abnormal cells inside a milk duct in the breast.
Diagnosis: If the mammogram shows suspicious areas such as bright white specks (microcalcifications) that are in a cluster and have irregular shapes or sizes, the radiologist likely will recommend additional breast imaging. During a core needle biopsy, a radiologist or surgeon uses a hollow needle to remove tissue samples from the suspicious area, sometimes guided by ultrasound (ultrasound-guided breast biopsy) or by X-ray (stereotactic breast biopsy). In a lab, a doctor who specializes in analyzing blood and body tissue (pathologist) will examine the samples to determine whether abnormal cells are present and if so, how aggressive those abnormal cells appear to be.

Name: Intussusception
Symptoms: The first sign of intussusception in an otherwise healthy infant may be sudden, loud crying caused by abdominal pain. In infants, remember that signs of abdominal pain may include recurrent bouts of pulling the knees to the chest and crying.
Overview: Intussusception is a rare, serious disorder in which one part of the intestine slides inside another part. Intussusception also cuts off the blood supply to the part of the intestine that's affected, which can lead to a tear in the bowel (perforation), infection and death of bowel tissue.
Risk factors: Children especially young children are much more likely to develop intussusception than adults are. Intestinal malrotation is a condition in which the intestine doesn't develop or rotate correctly, and it increases the risk for intussusception. Once one has had intussusception, one is at increased risk of developing it again. Siblings of someone who's had an intussusception are at a much higher risk of the disorder.
Diagnosis: To confirm the diagnosis, the doctor may order: Air or barium enema. In addition, an air or barium enema can actually fix intussusception 90 percent of the time in children, and no further treatment is needed.

Name: Invasive lobular carcinoma
Symptoms: Ask the doctor when to begin screening tests for breast cancer to help detect cancer early and before one may have any signs or symptoms. Various organizations differ on their screening recommendations, but many suggest women with an average risk of breast cancer consider beginning mammograms in their 40s.
Causes: Doctors know that invasive lobular carcinoma begins when cells in one or more milk-producing glands of the breast develop mutations in their DNA. Lobular carcinoma cells tend to invade breast tissue by spreading out in a distinct way rather than forming a firm nodule.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of invasive lobular carcinoma include Inherited genetic cancer syndromes. Women with a rare inherited condition called hereditary diffuse gastric cancer syndrome have an increased risk of both stomach (gastric) cancer and invasive lobular carcinoma. Women with certain inherited genes may have an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers. Women with invasive lobular carcinoma tend to be a few years older than women diagnosed with other types of breast cancer. If one has been diagnosed with LCIS abnormal cells confined within breast lobules the risk of developing invasive cancer in either breast is increased.
Diagnosis: If an abnormality is detected, the doctor may recommend a biopsy procedure to remove a sample of suspicious breast tissue for laboratory testing. Once it's determined that one has invasive lobular carcinoma, the doctor will determine if additional tests are needed to learn the extent (stage) of the cancer.

Name: Iritis
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of iritis include Iritis that develops suddenly, over hours or days, is known as acute iritis. If one has eye pain and vision problems with other signs and symptoms, one might need urgent medical care.
Overview: The uvea consists of the layer and structures of the eye beneath the white of the eye (sclera). It has three parts: (1) the iris, which is the colored part of the eye;(2) the ciliary body, which is the structure in the eye that secretes the transparent liquid within the eye; and (3) the choroid, which is the layer of blood vessels and connective tissue between the sclera and the retina. Iritis (i-RYE-tis) is swelling and irritation (inflammation) in the colored ring around the eye's pupil (iris).
Causes: In some cases, iritis can be linked to eye trauma, genetic factors or certain diseases. Viral infections on the face, such as cold sores and shingles caused by herpes viruses, can cause iritis. Blunt force trauma, a penetrating injury, or a burn from a chemical or fire can cause acute iritis. People who develop certain autoimmune diseases because of a gene alteration that affects their immune systems might also develop acute iritis. Diseases include a type of arthritis called ankylosing spondylitis, reactive arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease and psoriatic arthritis. An uncommon cause of acute iritis in Western countries, this condition is also characterized by joint problems, mouth sores and genital sores.
Risk factors: The risk of developing iritis increases if one: Have a specific genetic alteration. People with a specific change in a gene that's essential for healthy immune system function are more likely to develop iritis. Certain infections, such as syphilis or HIV/AIDS, are linked with a significant risk of iritis.
Diagnosis: The eye doctor will conduct a complete eye exam, including If the eye doctor suspects that a disease or condition is causing the iritis, he or she may work with the primary care doctor to pinpoint the underlying cause. The doctor might use a penlight to look at the pupils, observe the pattern of redness in one or both eyes, and check for signs of discharge. Using a special microscope with a light on it, the doctor views the inside of the eye looking for signs of iritis.
info-Symptoms: Headaches, red eyes, blurred vision, photophobia, burning and redness of the eye
info-Causes: BehÃ§et disease, Crohn's disease, Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, HLA-B27 related uveitis, Juvenile idiopathic arthritis, Sarcoidosis, Spondyloarthritis, Sympathetic ophthalmia, Tubulointerstitial nephritis and uveitis syndrome, brucellosis, herpesviruses, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, presumed ocular histoplasmosis syndrome, syphilis, toxocariasis, toxoplasmic chorioretinitis, tuberculosis, Zika fever

Name: Iron deficiency anemia
Causes: An intestinal disorder, such as celiac disease, which affects the intestine's ability to absorb nutrients from digested food, can lead to iron deficiency anemia. If part of the small intestine has been bypassed or removed surgically, that may affect the ability to absorb iron and other nutrients.
Risk factors: Because women lose blood during menstruation, women in general are at greater risk of iron deficiency anemia. Infants, especially those who were low birth weight or born prematurely, who don't get enough iron from breast milk or formula may be at risk of iron deficiency. People who don't eat meat may have a greater risk of iron deficiency anemia if they don't eat other iron-rich foods. People who routinely donate blood may have an increased risk of iron deficiency anemia since blood donation can deplete iron stores.
Diagnosis: To diagnose iron deficiency anemia, the doctor may run tests to look for: If the bloodwork indicates iron deficiency anemia, the doctor may order additional tests to identify an underlying cause, such as: The doctor may order these or other tests after a trial period of treatment with iron supplementation. With iron deficiency anemia, red blood cells are smaller and paler in color than normal. To rule out lower intestinal sources of bleeding, the doctor may recommend a procedure called a colonoscopy. Women may also have a pelvic ultrasound to look for the cause of excess menstrual bleeding, such as uterine fibroids. Colonoscopy Ferritin test Hematocrit test Hemoglobin test Ultrasound Upper endoscopy Red blood cell size and color.
info-Symptoms: Feeling tired, weakness, shortness of breath, confusion, pallor
info-Medication: Iron supplements, vitamin C, blood transfusions

Name: Iron overload
Overview: The liver is the largest internal organ. About the size of a football, it's located mainly in the upper right portion of the abdomen beneath the diaphragm and above the stomach but a small portion extends into the upper left quadrant. Because much of the body's iron is contained in red blood cells, this treatment lowers iron levels.
Causes: Hereditary hemochromatosis is caused by a mutation in a gene that controls the amount of iron the body absorbs from the food one eat. In hemochromatosis, the normal role of hepcidin is disrupted, causing the body to absorb more iron that it needs. Though many people have faulty genes that cause hemochromatosis, only about 10 percent of them develop iron overload to a degree that causes tissue and organ damage. Other types include If one inherit 2 abnormal genes, one may develop hemochromatosis. But, not everyone who inherits two genes develops problems linked to the iron overload of hemochromatosis. If one inherit 1 abnormal gene, one is unlikely to develop hemochromatosis. People with certain types of anemia or chronic liver disease may need multiple blood transfusions, which can lead to excess iron accumulation.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of hereditary hemochromatosis include Having 2 copies of a mutated HFE gene. If one has a first-degree relative a parent or sibling with hemochromatosis, one is more likely to develop the disease.
Diagnosis: Hemochromatosis may be identified because of abnormal blood tests done for other reasons or from screening of family members of people diagnosed with the disease. The two key tests to detect iron overload are: Because a number of other conditions can also cause elevated ferritin, both blood tests are typically abnormal among people with this disorder and are best performed after one has been fasting. People with abnormal iron tests should undergo genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis. The doctor may suggest other tests to confirm the diagnosis and to look for other problems: Genetic testing is recommended for all first-degree relatives parents, siblings and children of anyone diagnosed with hemochromatosis. Genetic testing Liver function tests MRI Needle biopsy Serum transferrin saturation.
Remedies: In addition to therapeutic blood removal, one may further reduce the risk of complications from hemochromatosis if one: Additional dietary changes generally aren't required for people receiving blood removal treatment. People with hereditary hemochromatosis are susceptible to infections, particularly those caused by certain bacteria in raw fish and shellfish.

Name: Irritable bowel syndrome
Causes: Factors that appear to play a role include Symptoms of IBS can be triggered by: Muscle contractions in the intestine. IBS can develop after a severe bout of diarrhea (gastroenteritis) caused by bacteria or a virus. IBS might also be associated with a surplus of bacteria in the intestines (bacterial overgrowth). Most people with IBS experience worse or more frequent signs and symptoms during periods of increased stress. Women are twice as likely to have IBS, which might indicate that hormonal changes play a role.
Risk factors: Genes may play a role, as may shared factors in a family's environment or a combination of genes and environment. Anxiety, depression and other mental health issues are associated with IBS.
Diagnosis: If one has IBS with diarrhea, one likely will be tested for gluten intolerance (celiac disease). After other conditions have been ruled out, the doctor is likely to use one of these sets of diagnostic criteria for IBS: The doctor will also likely assess whether one has other signs or symptoms that might suggest another, more serious, condition. These signs and symptoms include If one has these signs or symptoms, or if an initial treatment for IBS doesn't work, one will likely need additional tests. The doctor may recommend several tests, including stool studies to check for infection or problems with the intestine's ability to take in the nutrients from food (malabsorption). These criteria include abdominal pain and discomfort lasting on average at least one day a week in the last three months, associated with at least two of these factors: Pain and discomfort are related to defecation, the frequency of defecation is altered, or stool consistency is altered. Onset of signs and symptoms after age 50 Weight loss Rectal bleeding Fever Nausea or recurrent vomiting Abdominal pain, especially if it's not completely relieved by a bowel movement, or occurs at night Diarrhea that is persistent or awakens one from sleep Anemia related to low iron Flexible sigmoidoscopy. The doctor examines the lower part of the colon (sigmoid) with a flexible, lighted tube (sigmoidoscope). These tests produce images of the abdomen and pelvis that might allow the doctor to rule out other causes of the symptoms, especially if one has abdominal pain. The stool might be examined for bacteria or parasites, or a digestive liquid produced in the liver (bile acid), if one has chronic diarrhea.
Treatment: If the problems are moderate or severe, the doctor might suggest counseling especially if one has depression or if stress tends to worsen the symptoms. In addition, based on the symptoms the doctor might suggest medications such as: Avoid foods that trigger the symptoms Eat high-fiber foods Drink plenty of fluids Exercise regularly Get enough sleep High-gas foods. Research shows that some people with IBS report improvement in diarrhea symptoms if they stop eating gluten (wheat, barley and rye) even if they don't have celiac disease. If fiber doesn't help symptoms, the doctor may prescribe magnesium hydroxide oral (Phillips Milk of Magnesia) or polyethylene glycol (Miralax). Over-the-counter medications, such as loperamide (Imodium), can help control diarrhea. The doctor might also prescribe a bile acid binder, such as cholestyramine (Prevalite), colestipol (Colestid) or colesevelam (Welchol). If one has diarrhea and abdominal pain without depression, the doctor may suggest a lower than normal dose of imipramine (Tofranil), desipramine (Norpramine) or nortriptyline (Pamelor). Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressants, such as fluoxetine (Prozac, Sarafem) or paroxetine (Paxil), may help if one is depressed and have pain and constipation.
Remedies: Try slowly increasing the amount of fiber in the diet over a period of weeks with foods such as whole grains, fruits, vegetables and beans. Don't skip meals, and try to eat at about the same time each day to help regulate bowel function. If one has diarrhea, one may find that eating small, frequent meals makes one feel better. But if one is constipated, eating larger amounts of high-fiber foods may help move food through the intestines. Exercise helps relieve depression and stress, stimulates normal contractions of the intestines, and can help one feel better about theself.
Medication: Serum-derived bovine immunoglobulin/protein isolate (SBI), a nutritional therapy, has shown some promise as a treatment for IBS with diarrhea. Studies also show that, in people who have IBS with diarrhea, a specially coated tablet that slowly releases peppermint oil in the small intestine (enteric-coated peppermint oil) eases bloating, urgency, abdominal pain and pain while passing stool. Alosetron can be prescribed only by doctors enrolled in a special program, is intended for severe cases of diarrhea-predominant IBS in women who haven't responded to other treatments, and isn't approved for use by men. It's approved for women who have IBS with constipation, and is generally prescribed only for women with severe symptoms that haven't responded to other treatments.
info-Symptoms: Diarrhea, constipation, abdominal pain
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, exclusion of other diseases

Name: Ischemia , intestinal
Overview: The small intestine and colon are components of the digestive tract, which processes the foods one eat. Intestinal ischemia (is-KEE-me-uh) describes a variety of conditions that occur when blood flow to the intestines decreases due to a blocked blood vessel, usually an artery.
Causes: Intestinal ischemia occurs when the blood flow through the major arteries that supply blood to the intestines slows or stops. Intestinal ischemia is often divided into categories: This type of intestinal ischemia, which is the most common, occurs when blood flow to the colon is slowed.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of intestinal ischemia include Buildup of fatty deposits in the arteries (atherosclerosis). If one has had other conditions caused by atherosclerosis, such as decreased blood flow to the heart (coronary artery disease), legs (peripheral vascular disease) or the arteries serving the brain (carotid artery disease), one has an increased risk of intestinal ischemia. Emphysema and other smoking-related lung diseases increase the risk of intestinal ischemia. The risk of intestinal ischemia is increased if one has congestive heart failure or an irregular heartbeat such as atrial fibrillation. Certain medications may increase the risk of intestinal ischemia. Diseases and conditions that increase the risk of blood clots may increase the risk of intestinal ischemia.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects intestinal ischemia, one may undergo several diagnostic tests, based on the signs and symptoms, including Blood tests. When inserted in the mouth (endoscopy), the scope examines the upper portion of the small intestine. When inserted in the rectum, the scope examines the last 2 feet of the colon (sigmoidoscopy) or the entire colon (colonoscopy). During this test (angiography), a long, thin tube (catheter) is inserted into an artery in the groin or arm, then passed through the artery to the aorta.

Name: Ischemic colitis
Overview: Ischemic colitis occurs when blood flow to part of the large intestine is reduced or blocked. Ischemic colitis occurs when blood flow to part of the large intestine (colon) is reduced, usually due to narrowed or blocked blood vessels (arteries).The diminished blood flow doesn't provide enough oxygen for the cells in the digestive system. Any part of the colon can be affected, but ischemic colitis usually causes pain on the left side of the belly area (abdomen).
Risk factors: Ischemic colitis that occurs in a young adult may be a sign of a blood-clotting abnormality or inflammation of the blood vessels (vasculitis). Conditions that affect the way the blood clots, such as factor V Leiden, may increase the risk of ischemic colitis. Heavy exercise, such as marathon running, which can lead to reduced blood flow to the colon.

Name: ITP
Symptoms: When they do occur, they may include Make an appointment with the doctor if one or the child develops warning signs that worry one. Seek immediate help if one or the child experiences bleeding that can't be controlled by the usual first-aid techniques, such as applying pressure to the area.
Treatment: Most adults with ITP will eventually need treatment, as the condition often becomes severe or long term (chronic). Treatment may include a number of approaches, such as medications to boost the platelet count or surgery to remove the spleen (splenectomy).
Remedies: If one has immune thrombocytopenia, try to: Avoid contact sports. Depending on the risk of bleeding, head impacts during sports like boxing, martial arts and football could cause bleeding in the brain. If one has had the spleen removed, be alert for any signs of infection, including fever, and seek prompt treatment. Nonprescription drugs such as aspirin and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) can impair platelet function.
Medication: Medications to treat ITP may include If the condition is severe or persists despite initial drug treatment, the doctor may suggest surgery to remove the spleen. If corticosteroids don't help, the doctor may give one an injection of immune globulin. Rituximab (Rituxan, Truxima) helps increase the platelet count by reducing the immune system response that's damaging the platelets. But this drug also can reduce the effectiveness of vaccinations, which may be needed if one later choose surgery to remove the spleen.

Name: Jet lag disorder
Symptoms: Jet lag symptoms may include Jet lag symptoms usually occur within a day or two of travel if one has traveled across at least two time zones. Symptoms are likely to be worse or last longer the more time zones that one has crossed, especially if one travel in an easterly direction. But if one is a frequent traveler and continually struggle with jet lag, one may benefit from seeing a sleep specialist.
Causes: That's because light influences the regulation of melatonin, a hormone that helps synchronize cells throughout the body. At night, when the light signal is low, the hypothalamus tells the pineal gland, a small organ situated in the brain, to release melatonin. During daylight hours, the opposite occurs, and the pineal gland produces very little melatonin.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the likelihood one will experience jet lag include Number of time zones crossed. The more time zones one cross, the more likely one is to be jet-lagged. One may find it harder to fly east, when one lose time, than to fly west, when one gain it back.

Name: Joint dislocation
Overview: A dislocation is an injury to a joint a place where two or more bones come together in which the ends of the bones are forced from their normal positions. If one suspect a dislocation, seek prompt medical attention to return the bones to their proper positions. When treated properly, most dislocations return to normal function after several weeks of rest and rehabilitation.
Risk factors: Falling increases the chances of a dislocated joint if one use the arms to brace for impact or if one land forcefully on a body part, such as the hip or shoulder. Many dislocations occur during high-impact or contact sports, such as gymnastics, wrestling, basketball and football. These are the most common cause of hip dislocations, especially for people not wearing a seat belt.
Treatment: It might involve: Try these steps to help ease discomfort and encourage healing after being treated for a dislocation injury: Reduction. Depending on the amount of pain and swelling, one might need a local anesthetic or even a general anesthetic before manipulation of the bones. After the bones are back in position, the doctor might immobilize the joint with a splint or sling for several weeks. How long one wear the splint or sling depends on the joint involved and the extent of damage to nerves, blood vessels and supporting tissues. One might need surgery if the doctor can't move the dislocated bones into their correct positions or if the nearby blood vessels, nerves or ligaments have been damaged. Surgery may also be necessary if one has had recurring dislocations, especially of the shoulder. After the splint or sling is removed, one will begin a gradual rehabilitation program designed to restore the joint's range of motion and strength. Don't repeat the action that caused the injury, and try to avoid painful movements. After two or three days, when the pain and inflammation have improved, hot packs or a heating pad may help relax tightened and sore muscles. Over-the-counter medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), can help relieve pain. After one or two days, do some gentle exercises as directed by the doctor or physical therapist to help maintain range of motion in the injured joint.
Remedies: Try these steps to help ease discomfort and encourage healing after being treated for a dislocation injury: Rest the dislocated joint. Don't repeat the action that caused the injury, and try to avoid painful movements. After two or three days, when the pain and inflammation have improved, hot packs or a heating pad may help relax tightened and sore muscles. Over-the-counter medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), can help relieve pain. After one or two days, do some gentle exercises as directed by the doctor or physical therapist to help maintain range of motion in the injured joint.

Name: Juvenile fibromyalgia
Symptoms: In children with fibromyalgia, symptoms include Widespread diffuse pain. Despite complaints of severe fatigue, these children often take an hour or more to fall asleep. People with fibromyalgia often awaken tired, even though they report sleeping for long periods of time. Sleep is often disrupted by pain, and many patients with fibromyalgia have other sleep disorders, such as restless legs syndrome and sleep apnea.
Overview: Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep and mood issues. Estimates suggest that juvenile-onset fibromyalgia affects 2 to 6 percent of school children, mostly adolescent girls.
Causes: Doctors don't know what causes fibromyalgia, but it most likely involves a variety of factors working together. These may include Researchers believe repeated nerve stimulation causes the brains of people with fibromyalgia to change. Because fibromyalgia tends to run in families, there may be certain genetic mutations that may make one more susceptible to developing the disorder.
Remedies: Try stress management techniques, such as deep-breathing exercises or meditation. Because fatigue is one of the main characteristics of fibromyalgia, getting sufficient sleep is essential. In addition to allotting enough time for sleep, practice good sleep habits, such as going to bed and getting up at the same time each day and limiting daytime napping. Appropriate exercises may include walking, swimming, biking and water aerobics. Stretching, good posture and relaxation exercises also are helpful. If one do too much on the good days, one may have more bad days.
Medication: Common choices include Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is an intervention that has been well-studied in the treatment of chronic pain in children, and has been found to help reduce disability and depression. Other antidepressants, such as amitriptyline and fluoxetine (Prozac), are sometimes prescribed and appear to help promote sleep. Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve, others) may be helpful. Pain reliever such as tramadol (Ultram, Conzip) are also sometimes prescribed. Gabapentin (Neurontin, Gralise) and pregabalin (Lyrica) are sometimes prescribed for adults to reduce fibromyalgia symptoms.

Name: Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis
Symptoms: There are several different subtypes of juvenile idiopathic arthritis, but the main ones are systemic, oligoarticular and polyarticular. Which type the child has depends on symptoms, the number of joints affected, and if a fever and rashes are prominent features. Like other forms of arthritis, juvenile idiopathic arthritis is characterized by times when symptoms flare up and times when symptoms disappear. While the child might not complain of joint pain, one may notice that he or she limps especially first thing in the morning or after a nap. In some cases, high fever, swollen lymph nodes or a rash on the trunk may occur which is usually worse in the evenings.
Overview: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis, formerly known as juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, is the most common type of arthritis in children under the age of 16. Some types of juvenile idiopathic arthritis can cause serious complications, such as growth problems, joint damage and eye inflammation.
Diagnosis: Some of the most common blood tests for suspected cases include In many children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis, no significant abnormality will be found in these blood tests. X-rays or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may be taken to exclude other conditions, such as fractures, tumors, infection or congenital defects. Like the rheumatoid factor, the CCP is another antibody that may be found in the blood of children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Antinuclear antibody (ANA) test C-reactive protein test MRI Rheumatoid factor Sed rate (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) X-ray Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).
Remedies: Caregivers can help children learn self-care techniques that help limit the effects of juvenile idiopathic arthritis. Adequate calcium in the diet is important because children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis are at risk of developing weak bones (osteoporosis) due to the disease, the use of corticosteroids, and decreased physical activity and weight bearing. Stiffness affects many children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis, particularly in the morning. Although some children respond well to cold packs, most children prefer a hot pack or a hot bath or shower.
Medication: The medications used to help children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis are chosen to decrease pain, improve function and minimize potential joint damage. Also known as biologic response modifiers, this newer class of drugs includes tumor necrosis factor (TNF) blockers, such as etanercept (Enbrel) and adalimumab (Humira). Other biologic agents work to suppress the immune system, including abatacept (Orencia), rituximab (Rituxan), anakinra (Kineret) and tocilizumab (Actemra). They are also used to treat inflammation when it is not in the joints, such as inflammation of the sac around the heart (pericarditis). These medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve), reduce pain and swelling.

Name: Kaposi 's sarcoma
Diagnosis: Because there are so many different types of soft tissue sarcoma, it's important to determine the exact nature of each tumor so that the best treatments can be chosen. To evaluate the area of concern, the doctor might employ: If a soft tissue sarcoma is suspected, it's often best to seek care at a medical center that sees many people with this type of cancer. Options include In the lab, a doctor trained in analyzing body tissues (pathologist) examines the tissue sample for signs of cancer.

Name: Keratitis
Causes: If any object scratches or injures the surface of the cornea, noninfectious keratitis may result. In addition, an injury may allow microorganisms to gain access to the damaged cornea, causing infectious keratitis. Bacteria, fungi or parasites particularly the microscopic parasite acanthamoeba may inhabit the surface of a contact lens or contact lens carrying case. The cornea may become contaminated when the lens is in the eye, resulting in infectious keratitis. Over-wearing the contact lenses can cause keratitis, which can become infectious.
Risk factors: Wearing contact lenses especially sleeping in the lenses increases the risk of both infectious and noninfectious keratitis. The risk typically stems from wearing them longer than recommended, improper disinfection or wearing contact lenses while swimming. Keratitis is more common in people who use extended-wear contacts, or wear contacts continuously, than in those who use daily wear contacts and take them out at night. Use of corticosteroid eyedrops to treat an eye disorder can increase the risk of developing infectious keratitis or worsen existing keratitis.
Diagnosis: Although it may be uncomfortable to open the eyes for the exam, it's important that the doctor examines the eyes. The doctor may examine the eye using a penlight, to check the pupil's reaction, size and other factors. The doctor may apply a stain to the surface of the eye, to help identify the extent and character of surface irregularities and ulcers of the cornea.

Name: Keratoconus
Overview: In keratoconus, the cornea thins and gradually bulges outward into a cone shape. Keratoconus (ker-uh-toe-KOH-nus) occurs when the cornea the clear, dome-shaped front surface of the eye thins and gradually bulges outward into a cone shape.
Diagnosis: To diagnose keratoconus, the eye doctor (ophthalmologist or optometrist) will review the medical and family history and conduct an eye exam. In this test the eye doctor focuses a circle of light on the cornea and measures the reflection to determine the basic shape of the cornea. Special photographic tests, such as optical coherence tomography and corneal topography, record images of the cornea to create a detailed shape map of the cornea's surface.
info-Symptoms: Blurry vision, nearsightedness, light sensitivity

Name: Ketoacidosis , diabetic
Causes: Without enough insulin, the body can't use sugar properly for energy. Unfortunately, these hormones counter the effect of insulin sometimes triggering an episode of diabetic ketoacidosis. Missed insulin treatments or inadequate insulin therapy can leave one with too little insulin in the system, triggering diabetic ketoacidosis.
Diagnosis: Blood tests used in the diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis will measure: The doctor may order tests to identify underlying health problems that might have contributed to diabetic ketoacidosis and to check for complications. If there isn't enough insulin in the body to allow sugar to enter the cells, the blood sugar level will rise (hyperglycemia). Blood electrolyte tests Urinalysis Chest X-ray A recording of the electrical activity of the heart (electrocardiogram) Chest X-rays Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) Urinalysis Blood sugar level.
Treatment: If one is diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis, one might be treated in the emergency room or admitted to the hospital. Treatment usually involves: As the body chemistry returns to normal, the doctor will consider additional testing to check for possible triggers for the diabetic ketoacidosis. Depending on circumstances, one might need additional treatment. For example, the doctor will help one create a diabetes treatment plan. If a heart attack seems possible, the doctor might recommend further evaluation of the heart. If one develop mild signs and symptoms, contact the doctor immediately. Call 911 or the local emergency number if: A medical provider who sees one for possible diabetic ketoacidosis will need answers to these questions as quickly as possible: Fluid replacement. The fluids will replace those one has lost through excessive urination, as well as help dilute the excess sugar in the blood. Electrolytes are minerals in the blood that carry an electric charge, such as sodium, potassium and chloride. One will receive electrolytes through a vein to help keep the heart, muscles and nerve cells functioning normally. In addition to fluids and electrolytes, one will receive insulin therapy usually through a vein. When the blood sugar level falls to about 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) and the blood is no longer acidic, one may be able to stop intravenous insulin therapy and resume the normal subcutaneous insulin therapy. Diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state in adults: Clinical features, evaluation and diagnosis. Diabetic ketoacidosis and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state in adults: Treatment.

Name: Kidney failure , chronic
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of kidney disease may include Signs and symptoms of kidney disease are often nonspecific, meaning they can also be caused by other illnesses.
