Because the kidneys are highly adaptable and able to compensate for lost function, signs and symptoms may not appear until irreversible damage has occurred.
Diagnosis: During a kidney biopsy, the doctor uses a needle to remove a small sample of kidney tissue for lab testing. Among other things, the doctor might ask questions about whether one has been diagnosed with high blood pressure, if one has taken a medication that might affect kidney function, if one has noticed changes in the urinary habits, and whether one has any family members who have kidney disease. For kidney disease diagnosis, one may also need certain tests and procedures, such as: Blood tests.
Remedies: Lower the amount of sodium one eat each day by avoiding products with added salt, including many convenience foods, such as frozen dinners, canned soups and fast foods. Other foods with added salt include salty snack foods, canned vegetables, and processed meats and cheeses.

Name: Klatskin tumor
Diagnosis: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) uses a dye to highlight the bile ducts on X-ray images. A thin, flexible tube (endoscope) with a camera on the end is passed down the throat and into the small intestine. During an endoscopic ultrasound, the doctor inserts a long, flexible tube (endoscope) down the throat and into the abdomen. If the suspicious area is located very near where the bile duct joins the small intestine, the doctor may obtain a biopsy sample during ERCP. If the suspicious area is within or near the liver, the doctor may obtain a tissue sample by inserting a long needle through the skin to the affected area (fine-needle aspiration). During endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), a thin tube equipped with a tiny camera is passed down the throat and through the digestive tract to the small intestine. The doctor may also use this procedure to inject dye into the bile ducts to help them show up better on imaging tests. Techniques used to diagnose bile duct cancer include computerized tomography (CT) scans and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) combined with magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP).
Treatment: Treatments for cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer) may include Because cholangiocarcinoma is a very difficult type of tumor to treat, don't hesitate to ask about the doctor's experience with treating the condition. For very small bile duct cancers, this involves removing part of the bile duct and joining the cut ends. For more-advanced bile duct cancers, nearby liver tissue, pancreas tissue or lymph nodes may be removed as well. Surgery to remove the liver and replace it with one from a donor (liver transplant) may be an option in certain cases for people with hilar cholangiocarcinoma. For many, a liver transplant is a cure for hilar cholangiocarcinoma, but there is a risk that the cancer will recur after a liver transplant. Radiation therapy uses high-energy sources, such as photons (x-rays) and protons, to damage or destroy cancer cells. Photodynamic therapy can help relieve the signs and symptoms, and it may also slow cancer growth.

Name: Klinefelter syndrome
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of Klinefelter syndrome vary widely among males with the disorder. Delays in growth and development can be the first sign of a number of conditions that need treatment including Klinefelter syndrome. Many men with Klinefelter syndrome aren't diagnosed with infertility until they realize they're unable to father a child.
Diagnosis: The syndrome might be identified in pregnancy during a procedure to examine fetal cells drawn from the amniotic fluid (amniocentesis) or placenta for another reason such as being older than age 35 or having a family history of genetic conditions. Also called karyotype analysis, this test is used to confirm a diagnosis of Klinefelter syndrome.
Treatment: If one or the son is diagnosed with Klinefelter syndrome, the health care team may include a doctor who specializes in diagnosing and treating disorders involving the body's glands and hormones (endocrinologist), a speech therapist, a pediatrician, a physical therapist, a genetic counselor, a reproductive medicine or infertility specialist, and a counselor or psychologist. Although there's no way to repair the sex chromosome changes due to Klinefelter syndrome, treatments can help minimize its effects. Starting at the time of the usual onset of puberty, testosterone replacement therapy can be given to help stimulate changes that normally occur at puberty, such as developing a deeper voice, growing facial and body hair, and increasing muscle mass and sexual desire (libido). Testosterone replacement therapy can also improve bone density and reduce the risk of fractures, and it may improve mood and behavior. These treatments can help boys with Klinefelter syndrome who have problems with speech, language and muscle weakness. For some men with minimal sperm production, a procedure called intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) may help.
info-Symptoms: Above average height, weaker muscles, poor coordination, less body hair, breast growth, less interest in sex, infertility.
info-Causes: Two or more X chromosomes in males
info-Risk factors: Older mother
info-Treatment: Physical therapy, speech and language therapy, counseling

Name: Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome
Symptoms: People who have Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome may have the following features, which can range from mild to more extensive: Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome is usually identified at birth. The birthmark usually covers part of one leg, but can involve any portion of the skin, and may get darker or lighter with age. These include swollen, twisted veins (varicose veins) usually on the surface of the legs. Deeper abnormal veins in the arms, legs, abdomen and pelvis can occur. This begins in infancy and is usually limited to one leg, but it can occur in an arm or, rarely, in the trunk or face.
Overview: Klippel-Trenaunay (klih-PEL tray-no-NAY) syndrome ? is a rare disorder found at birth (congenital) involving abnormal development of blood vessels, soft tissues (such as skin and muscles), bones, and the lymphatic system. The main features include a red birthmark (port-wine stain), overgrowth of tissues and bones, and vein malformations with or without lymphatic abnormalities.
Causes: It involves genetic changes (mutations) most commonly in the PIK3CA gene. These genetic changes are responsible for development of tissues in the body, resulting in overgrowth.
Diagnosis: Some tests include Asks questions about the family and medical history Does an exam to look for swelling, varicose veins and port-wine stains Visually evaluates growth of bones and soft tissues Duplex scanning. Also called scanner photography, this X-ray technique helps to see images of bones and measure their lengths. A CT scan creates 3-D images of the body that helps look for blood clots in veins. This procedure involves injecting a dye into veins and taking X-rays that can reveal abnormal veins, blockages or blood clots.
Treatment: Although there's no cure for Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome, the doctor can help one manage symptoms and prevent complications. Because KTS may affect many systems in the body, the health care team may include specialists in vascular medicine and surgery, skin diseases (dermatology), interventional radiology, orthopedic surgery, physical therapy and rehabilitation, and other areas as needed. Treatments may include In addition, treatment may be needed for complications such as bleeding, pain, infection, blood clots or skin ulcers. Talking with a psychologist, psychiatrist or other mental health professional may also be helpful to many people with KTS. Bandages or elastic garments are wrapped around affected limbs to help prevent swelling, problems with varicose veins and skin ulcers. Massage, compression and limb movement as appropriate may help relieve lymphedema in arms or legs and swelling of the blood vessels. In some cases, surgical removal or reconstruction of affected veins, removal of excess tissue, and correction of the overgrowth of bone may be beneficial. Early research indicates that a drug called sirolimus (Rapamune) may help to treat symptomatic complex vascular malformations, but it may have significant side effects and more studies are needed. Encouraging use of affected limbs as appropriate may help relieve lymphedema and swelling of the blood vessels.

Name: Knee bursitis
Symptoms: Knee bursitis signs and symptoms vary, depending on which bursa is affected and what's causing the inflammation. In general, the affected portion of the knee might feel warm, tender and swollen when one put pressure on it.
Risk factors: People who work on their knees for long periods carpet layers, plumbers and gardeners are at increased risk of knee bursitis. Sports that result in direct blows or frequent falls on the knee such as wrestling, football and volleyball can increase the risk of knee bursitis.
Diagnosis: The doctor will: To help rule out injuries that can cause signs and symptoms similar to those of bursitis, the doctor might request one or more of the following imaging tests: If the doctor suspects that one has an infection or gout in the bursa, he or she might take a sample of the bursa fluid for testing by inserting a needle into the affected area and draining some of the fluid. Compare the condition of both knees, particularly if only one is painful Gently press on areas of the knee to detect warmth, swelling and the source of pain Inspect the skin over the tender area for redness or other signs of infection Carefully move the legs and knees to determine the knee's range of motion and whether it hurts to bend or flex it X-ray. Using sound waves to produce images in real time, ultrasound can help the doctor better visualize swelling in the affected bursa.
Remedies: Short-term use of an anti-inflammatory drug, such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve, others), can help relieve pain. Apply an ice pack to the knee for 20 minutes at a time several times a day until the pain goes away and the knee no longer feels warm to the touch.
Medication: Protective knee braces might help if one can't avoid kneeling, and compressive knee sleeves can help reduce swelling. If the bursitis is persistent and not responding to basic treatments, the doctor might inject a corticosteroid drug into an affected bursa to reduce inflammation. Aspiration might cause short-term pain and swelling, and one might need to wear a knee immobilizer for a short period after the injection to reduce the chance of recurrent swelling. If one has severe chronic or recurrent bursitis and don't respond to other treatments, the doctor might recommend surgery to remove the bursa.

Name: Knee pain
Causes: Knee pain can be caused by injuries, mechanical problems, types of arthritis and other problems. The meniscus is a C-shaped piece of tough, rubbery cartilage that acts as a shock absorber between the shinbone and thighbone. Some of the more common knee injuries include Some examples of mechanical problems that can cause knee pain include More than 100 different types of arthritis exist. The bones of the knee, including the kneecap (patella), can be broken during motor vehicle collisions or falls. This occurs when the triangular bone (patella) that covers the front of the knee slips out of place, usually to the outside of the knee. In some cases, problems in the hip or foot can cause knee pain. The most debilitating form of arthritis, rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune condition that can affect almost any joint in the body, including the knees. Sometimes the knee joint can become infected, leading to swelling, pain and redness. Septic arthritis often occurs with a fever, and there's usually no trauma before the onset of pain.
Risk factors: Being overweight or obese increases stress on the knee joints, even during ordinary activities such as walking or going up and down stairs. Alpine skiing with its rigid ski boots and potential for falls, basketball's jumps and pivots, and the repeated pounding the knees take when one run or jog all increase the risk of knee injury.
Diagnosis: During the physical exam, the doctor is likely to: In some cases, the doctor might suggest tests such as: If the doctor suspects an infection or inflammation, one is likely to have blood tests and sometimes a procedure called arthrocentesis, in which a small amount of fluid is removed from within the knee joint with a needle and sent to a laboratory for analysis. Inspect the knee for swelling, pain, tenderness, warmth and visible bruising Check to see how far one can move the lower leg in different directions Push on or pull the joint to evaluate the integrity of the structures in the knee X-ray. The doctor may first recommend having an X-ray, which can help detect bone fractures and degenerative joint disease.
Remedies: Over-the-counter medications such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve) may help ease knee pain. Some people find relief by rubbing the affected knee with creams containing a numbing agent, such as lidocaine, or capsaicin, the substance that makes chili peppers hot. Take a break from the normal activities to reduce repetitive strain on the knee, give the injury time to heal and help prevent further damage. Although ice therapy is generally safe and effective, don't use ice for longer than 20 minutes at a time because of the risk of damage to the nerves and skin.
Medication: If one is physically active or practice a sport, one may need exercises to correct movement patterns that may be affecting the knees and to establish good technique during the sport or activity. In certain conditions, different types of braces may be used to help protect and support the knee joint. Depending on the injury, the doctor may be able to examine and repair the joint damage using a fiber-optic camera and long, narrow tools inserted through just a few small incisions around the knee. Arthroscopy may be used to remove loose bodies from the knee joint, remove or repair damaged cartilage (especially if it is causing the knee to lock), and reconstruct torn ligaments. In this procedure, the surgeon cuts away damaged bone and cartilage from the thighbone, shinbone and kneecap, and replaces it with an artificial joint made of metal alloys, high-grade plastics and polymers.

Name: KP
Overview: Keratosis pilaris causes small bumps to appear on the upper arms, legs or buttocks. Keratosis pilaris (ker-uh-TOE-sis pih-LAIR-is) is a common, harmless skin condition that causes dry, rough patches and tiny bumps, usually on the upper arms, thighs, cheeks or buttocks.
Causes: Usually plugs form in many hair follicles, causing patches of rough, bumpy skin. Usually many plugs form, causing patches of rough, bumpy skin.
Treatment: In the meantime, one might use any of the various products available to help improve the appearance of affected skin. If moisturizing and other self-care measures don't help, the doctor may prescribe medicated creams. For keratosis pilaris, some basic questions include Creams to remove dead skin cells. Creams containing alpha hydroxy acid, lactic acid, salicylic acid or urea help loosen and remove dead skin cells. Depending on their strength, these creams (topical exfoliants) are available over-the-counter or with a prescription. The acids in these creams may cause redness, stinging or skin irritation, so they aren't recommended for young children. Creams derived from vitamin A (topical retinoids) work by promoting cell turnover and preventing plugged hair follicles. Tretinoin (Retin-A, Renova, Avita) and tazarotene (Avage, Tazorac) are examples of topical retinoids. Also, if one is pregnant or nursing, the doctor may suggest delaying topical retinoid therapy or choosing another treatment Use warm water and limit bath time. Gently remove dead skin (exfoliate) with a washcloth or loofah. After washing or bathing, gently pat or blot the skin with a towel so that some moisture remains. Apply an over-the-counter cream that contains urea (Nutraplus, Eucerin), lactic acid (AmLactin, Lac-Hydrin), alpha hydroxy acid or salicylic acid. While the skin is still moist from bathing, apply a moisturizer that contains lanolin (Lansinoh, Medela), petroleum jelly (Vaseline) or glycerin (Glysolid).
Remedies: After washing or bathing, gently pat or blot the skin with a towel so that some moisture remains. Apply an over-the-counter cream that contains urea (Nutraplus, Eucerin), lactic acid (AmLactin, Lac-Hydrin), alpha hydroxy acid or salicylic acid. While the skin is still moist from bathing, apply a moisturizer that contains lanolin (Lansinoh, Medela), petroleum jelly (Vaseline) or glycerin (Glysolid).

Name: Krabbe disease
Symptoms: Common signs and symptoms early in the course of the disease include the following: As the disease progresses, signs and symptoms become more severe. They may include When Krabbe disease develops later in childhood or during adulthood, signs and symptoms can vary widely.
Causes: In the case of Krabbe disease, two mutated copies of a particular gene result in little or no production of an enzyme called galactocerebrosidase (GALC). The process of cleaning up excessive galactolipids transforms these normally helpful cells into abnormal, toxic cells called globoid cells, which promote myelin-damaging inflammation.
Risk factors: Two carriers have a 25% chance of having an unaffected child with two normal genes (left), a 50% chance of having an unaffected child who also is a carrier (middle), and a 25% chance of having an affected child with two recessive genes (right). If each parent has one mutated copy of the gene, the risk for a child would be as follows: Genetic testing to understand the risk of having a child with Krabbe disease may be considered in certain situations: Genetic testing should be carefully considered. A 25 percent chance of inheriting two mutated copies, which would result in the disease A 50 percent chance of inheriting only one mutated copy, which would result in the child being a carrier of the mutation but would not result in the disease itself A 25 percent chance of inheriting two normal copies of the gene If one or both parents are likely carriers of a GALC gene mutation because of a known family history of Krabbe disease, a couple may want to have tests to understand the risks in their own family.
info-Symptoms: Infancy: Developmental delay, irritability, spasticity, hypotonia, microcephaly, optic atrophyJuvenile: Muscle weakness, vision loss, developmental regressionAdult: Burning paresthesias in extremities, loss of manual dexterity, muscle weakness, sensory neuropathy, muscle atrophy
info-Usual onset: Within 3 to 6 months of birth, but can present in childhood or even adulthood
info-Risk factors: Parents who are heterozygous (only one copy) for the mutation to the GALC gene
info-Prevention: Prenatal diagnosis and screening of at-risk couples
info-Treatment: Symptomatic and supportive treatment only, but stem cell transplantation may be beneficial
info-Prognosis: One-, two-, and three-year survival rates of 60%, 26%, and 14%, respectively

Name: Laryngitis
Symptoms: In most cases laryngitis symptoms last less than a couple of weeks and are caused by something minor, such as a virus. Laryngitis signs and symptoms can include One can manage most acute cases of laryngitis with self-care steps, such as resting the voice and drinking plenty of fluids.
Overview: Speech occurs when air flows from the lungs, up the windpipe (trachea) and through the voice box (larynx). Laryngitis is an inflammation of the voice box (larynx) from overuse, irritation or infection.
Diagnosis: If one has chronic hoarseness, the doctor may want to listen to the voice and to examine the vocal cords, and he or she may refer one to an ear, nose and throat specialist. The doctor can visually examine the vocal cords in a procedure called laryngoscopy, by using a light and a tiny mirror to look into the back of the throat.
Treatment: Chronic laryngitis treatments are aimed at treating the underlying causes, such as heartburn, smoking or excessive use of alcohol. Some self-care methods and home treatments may relieve the symptoms of laryngitis and reduce strain on the voice: One is likely to start by seeing the family doctor, a general practitioner or a pediatrician. In almost all cases of laryngitis, an antibiotic won't do any good because the cause is usually viral. However, this treatment is used only when there's an urgent need to treat laryngitis for example, when one need to use the voice to sing or give a speech or oral presentation, or in some cases when a toddler has laryngitis associated with croup.
info-Symptoms: Hoarse voice, fever, pain
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, examination via laryngoscopy if concerns

Name: Latex allergy
Symptoms: Mild latex allergy symptoms include These include The most serious allergic reaction to latex is anaphylaxis, which can be deadly. An anaphylactic (an-uh-fuh-LAK-tik) reaction develops immediately after latex exposure in highly sensitive people, but it rarely happens the first time one is exposed.
Causes: In a latex allergy, the immune system identifies latex as a harmful substance and triggers certain antibodies to fight it off. The more times one is exposed to latex, the more strongly the immune system is likely to respond. Products containing man-made (synthetic) latex, such as latex paint, are unlikely to cause a reaction. The most common cause of latex allergy involves touching latex-containing products, including latex gloves, condoms and balloons. Latex products, especially gloves, release latex particles, which one can breathe in when they become airborne. Not an allergy, this skin irritation is caused by wearing rubber gloves or exposure to the powder inside them.
Risk factors: Certain people are at greater risk of developing a latex allergy: Certain fruits contain the same allergens found in latex. The risk of latex allergy is highest in people with spina bifida a birth defect that affects the development of the spine. Repeated exposure to latex gloves and medical products increases the risk of developing latex allergy. If one work in health care, one is at increased risk of developing a latex allergy. One is at increased risk of latex allergy if one has other allergies such as hay fever or a food allergy or they're common in the family.
Treatment: If one has had a severe allergic reaction to latex, one may need to carry injectable epinephrine with one at all times. For less severe reactions, the doctor may prescribe antihistamines or corticosteroids, which one can take after exposure to latex to control the reaction and help relieve discomfort.

Name: Lazy eye ( amblyopia )
Causes: Anything that blurs a child's vision or causes the eyes to cross or turn out can result in lazy eye. Common causes of the condition include Difference in sharpness of vision between the eyes (refractive amblyopia). Difference in sharpness of vision between the eyes (refractive amblyopia).
Diagnosis: The doctor will conduct an eye exam, checking for eye health, a wandering eye, a difference in vision between the eyes or poor vision in both eyes. The method used to test vision depends on the child's age and stage of development: Preverbal children.
Treatment: It's important to start treatment for lazy eye as soon as possible in childhood, when the complicated connections between the eye and the brain are forming. Treatment options depend on the cause of lazy eye and on how much the condition is affecting the child's vision. For most children with lazy eye, proper treatment improves vision within weeks to months. To stimulate the weaker eye, the child wears an eye patch over the eye with better vision for two to six or more hours a day. Usually prescribed for use on weekends or daily, use of the drops encourages the child to use the weaker eye, and offers an alternative to a patch. If the child's eyes continue to cross or wander apart with the appropriate glasses, the doctor might recommend surgical repair to straighten the eyes, in addition to other lazy eye treatments.

Name: Lead poisoning
Causes: Lead was also once used in paint and gasoline and is still used in batteries, solder, pipes, pottery, roofing materials and some cosmetics. Lead-based paints for homes, children's toys and household furniture have been banned in the United States since 1978. Lead pipes, brass plumbing fixtures and copper pipes soldered with lead can release lead particles into tap water. Lead solder in food cans, banned in the United States, is still used in some countries. Glazes found on some ceramics, china and porcelain can contain lead that can leach into food served or stored in the pottery. Lead poisoning has been linked to greta and azarcon, traditional Hispanic medicines, as well as some from India, China and other countries. Tamarind, an ingredient used in some candies made in Mexico, might contain lead.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of lead poisoning include Lead can harm an unborn child, so pregnant women or women likely to become pregnant should be especially careful to avoid exposure to lead. Young children also absorb lead more easily, and it's more harmful for them than it is for adults and older children. Although the use of lead-based paints has been banned since the 1970s, older homes and buildings often retain remnants of this paint.
Diagnosis: Some areas, such as those with older homes, have a higher lead exposure risk, so more frequent testing might be recommended for children who live in those areas. If the area doesn't have specific lead testing recommendations, the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends the child be tested for lead levels at ages 1 and 2.
info-Symptoms: Intellectual disability, abdominal pain, constipation, headaches, irritability, memory problems, inability to have children, tingling in the hands and feet
info-Causes: Exposure to lead via contaminated air, water, dust, food, consumer products
info-Risk factors: Being a child
info-Prevention: Removing lead from the home, improved monitoring and education in the workplace, laws that ban lead in products

Name: Left ventricular hypertrophy
Overview: Left ventricular hypertrophy is a thickening of the wall of the heart's main pumping chamber. Left ventricular hypertrophy is enlargement and thickening (hypertrophy) of the walls of the heart's main pumping chamber (left ventricle). Left ventricular hypertrophy can develop in response to some factor such as high blood pressure or a heart condition that causes the left ventricle to work harder. But no matter what the blood pressure is, developing left ventricular hypertrophy puts one at higher risk of a heart attack and stroke.
Causes: Left ventricular hypertrophy can occur when some factor makes the heart work harder than normal to pump blood to the body. Factors that can cause the heart to work harder include High blood pressure (hypertension). This disease is a narrowing of the aortic valve that separates the left ventricle from the large blood vessel leaving the heart (aorta). The narrowing of the aortic valve requires the left ventricle to work harder to pump blood into the aorta. This genetic disease occurs when the heart muscle becomes abnormally thick, even with completely normal blood pressure, making it harder for the heart to pump blood.
Risk factors: In addition to hypertension and aortic valve stenosis, factors that increase the risk of left ventricular hypertrophy include Age. Being overweight increases the risk of high blood pressure and left ventricular hypertrophy. Left ventricular hypertrophy has been found to be linked to a higher risk of diabetes. African-Americans are at higher risk of left ventricular hypertrophy than are white people with similar blood pressure measurements. Women with hypertension are at higher risk of left ventricular hypertrophy than are men with similar blood pressure measurements.
Diagnosis: The doctor will start with a health history, family history and thorough physical examination, including checking the blood pressure and heart function. The doctor can look for patterns that indicate abnormal heart function and increased left ventricle muscle tissue. Echocardiogram can reveal thickened muscle tissue in the left ventricle, blood flow through the heart with each beat, and heart abnormalities related to left ventricular hypertrophy, such as aortic valve stenosis.
Remedies: Lifestyle changes can help lower the blood pressure, improve the heart health and improve left ventricular hypertrophy signs if the left ventricular hypertrophy is caused by high blood pressure. Keeping a healthy weight, or losing weight if one is overweight or obese, can also help control the blood pressure. Alcohol can also raise the blood pressure, especially if consumed in large amounts. Ask the doctor if one need to restrict certain physical activities, such as very heavy weightlifting, which may temporarily raise the blood pressure.

Name: Leg fracture
Overview: A broken leg (leg fracture) is a break or crack in one of the bones in the leg. A severely broken leg may require surgery to implant devices into the broken bone to maintain proper alignment during healing.
Causes: In children, a broken leg may be the result of child abuse, especially when such an injury occurs before the child can walk. Stress fractures are tiny cracks that develop in the weight-bearing bones of the body, including the shinbone. Stress fractures are usually caused by repetitive force or overuse, such as running long distances.
Medication: To reduce pain and inflammation, the doctor may recommend an over-the-counter pain reliever, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or a combination of the two. However, one may need surgery to implant internal fixation devices, such as plates, rods or screws, to maintain proper position of the bones during healing. These internal fixation devices may be necessary if one has the following injuries: For some injuries, the doctor may also recommend an external fixation device a frame outside the leg attached to the bone with pins.

Name: Legg-Calve-Perthes disease
Overview: The hip joint is a ball-and-socket joint. The ball (femoral head) is at the top of the thigh bone (femur) and the socket (acetabulum) is part of the hipbone. Legg-Calve-Perthes (LEG-kahl-VAY-PER-tuz) disease is a childhood condition that occurs when blood supply to the ball part (femoral head) of the hip joint is temporarily interrupted and the bone begins to die.
Risk factors: Although Legg-Calve-Perthes disease can affect children of nearly any age, it most commonly begins between ages 4 and 10. For a small number of people, Legg-Calve-Perthes disease appears to be linked to mutations in certain genes, but more study is needed.
Treatment: The types of treatment recommended will depend on the: As Legg-Calve-Perthes disease progresses, the ball part of the joint (femoral head) weakens and fragments. During healing, the socket part of the joint can serve as a mold to help the fragmented femoral head retain its round shape. In this age group, the hip socket is naturally more moldable, so the ball and socket typically continue to fit together well without surgery.
info-Symptoms: Pain in the hip, knee, ankle (hip pathology can refer pain to a normal knee or ankle), or groin.
info-Causes: Artery of the ligmentum teres femoris being constricted or even blocked too early

Name: Legionnaires ' disease
Causes: Outdoors, legione willa bacteria survive in soil and water, but rarely cause infections. However, legione willa bacteria can multiply in water systems made by humans, such as air conditioners. If one aspirate water containing legione willa bacteria, one can develop Legionnaires disease.
Risk factors: One is more likely to develop the infection if one: Legionnaires disease can be a problem in hospitals and nursing homes, where germs can spread easily and people are vulnerable to infection. Smoking damages the lungs, making one more susceptible to all types of lung infections. This can be a result of HIV/AIDS or certain medications, especially corticosteroids and drugs taken to prevent organ rejection after a transplant.

Name: Leiomyosarcoma
Diagnosis: Because there are so many different types of soft tissue sarcoma, it's important to determine the exact nature of each tumor so that the best treatments can be chosen. To evaluate the area of concern, the doctor might employ: If a soft tissue sarcoma is suspected, it's often best to seek care at a medical center that sees many people with this type of cancer. Options include In the lab, a doctor trained in analyzing body tissues (pathologist) examines the tissue sample for signs of cancer.

Name: Leukemia , acute lymphocytic
Risk factors: Children and adults whove had certain types of chemotherapy and radiation therapy for other kinds of cancer may have an increased risk of developing acute lymphocytic leukemia. People exposed to very high levels of radiation, such as survivors of a nuclear reactor accident, have an increased risk of developing acute lymphocytic leukemia. Certain genetic disorders, such as Down syndrome, are associated with an increased risk of acute lymphocytic leukemia. People who have a sibling, including a twin, with acute lymphocytic leukemia have an increased risk of ALL.
Diagnosis: In a bone marrow aspiration, a doctor or nurse uses a thin needle to remove a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot in the back of the hipbone (pelvis). The sample is sent to a lab for testing to look for leukemia cells.Doctors in the lab will classify blood cells into specific types based on their size, shape and other genetic or molecular features. Imaging tests such as an X-ray, computerized tomography (CT) scan or ultrasound scan may help determine whether cancer has spread to the brain and spinal cord or other parts of the body. A lumbar puncture test, also called a spinal tap, may be used to collect a sample of spinal fluid the fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord.
Treatment: A bone marrow transplant, also known as a stem cell transplant, may be used as consolidation therapy in people at high risk of relapse or for treating relapse when it occurs. A bone marrow transplant begins with high doses of chemotherapy or radiation to destroy any leukemia-producing bone marrow. During each phase of therapy, people with acute lymphocytic leukemia may receive additional treatment to kill leukemia cells located in the central nervous system. Chemotherapy, which uses drugs to kill cancer cells, is typically used as an induction therapy for children and adults with acute lymphocytic leukemia. Targeted drugs attack specific abnormalities present in cancer cells that help them grow and thrive.A certain abnormality called the Philadelphia chromosome is found in some people with acute lymphocytic leukemia. This procedure allows someone with leukemia to re-establish healthy bone marrow by replacing leukemic bone marrow with leukemia-free marrow from a healthy person.A bone marrow transplant begins with high doses of chemotherapy or radiation to destroy any leukemia-producing bone marrow.

Name: Leukemia , acute myelogenous
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of acute myelogenous leukemia include Many people with AML have no known risk factors, and many people who have risk factors never develop the cancer. People whove had certain types of chemotherapy and radiation therapy may have a greater risk of developing AML. People exposed to very high levels of radiation, such as survivors of a nuclear reactor accident, have an increased risk of developing AML. Exposure to certain chemicals, such as benzene, is linked to a greater risk of AML. People whove had another blood disorder, such as myelodysplasia, myelofibrosis, polycythemia vera or thrombocythemia, are at greater risk of developing AML. Certain genetic disorders, such as Down syndrome, are associated with an increased risk of AML.
Diagnosis: In a bone marrow aspiration, a doctor or nurse uses a thin needle to remove a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot in the back of the hipbone (pelvis). If one has signs or symptoms of acute myelogenous leukemia, the doctor may recommend that one undergo diagnostic tests, including Bone marrow test. A blood test can suggest leukemia, but it usually takes a bone marrow test to confirm the diagnosis. The presence of blast cells immature cells normally found in bone marrow but not circulating in the blood is another indicator of acute myelogenous leukemia. A blood test can suggest leukemia, but it usually takes a bone marrow test to confirm the diagnosis.During a bone marrow biopsy, a needle is used to remove a sample of the bone marrow.
Treatment: People with AML generally stay in the hospital during chemotherapy treatments because the drugs destroy many normal blood cells in the process of killing leukemia cells. A bone marrow transplant, also called a stem cell transplant, may be used for consolidation therapy. A bone marrow transplant helps re-establish healthy stem cells by replacing unhealthy bone marrow with leukemia-free stem cells that will regenerate healthy bone marrow. Prior to a bone marrow transplant, one receive very high doses of chemotherapy or radiation therapy to destroy the leukemia-producing bone marrow. One can also receive the own stem cells (autologous transplant) if one were previously in remission and had the healthy stem cells removed and stored for a future transplant. Also called post-remission therapy, maintenance therapy or intensification, this phase of treatment is aimed at destroying the remaining leukemia cells. Chemotherapy uses chemicals to kill cancer cells in the body.People with AML generally stay in the hospital during chemotherapy treatments because the drugs destroy many normal blood cells in the process of killing leukemia cells. Arsenic trioxide (Trisenox) and all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) are anti-cancer drugs that can be used alone or in combination with chemotherapy for remission induction of a certain subtype of AML called promyelocytic leukemia. A bone marrow transplant helps re-establish healthy stem cells by replacing unhealthy bone marrow with leukemia-free stem cells that will regenerate healthy bone marrow.Prior to a bone marrow transplant, one receive very high doses of chemotherapy or radiation therapy to destroy the leukemia-producing bone marrow. Then one receive infusions of stem cells from a compatible donor (allogeneic transplant).One can also receive the own stem cells (autologous transplant) if one were previously in remission and had the healthy stem cells removed and stored for a future transplant.

Name: Leukemia , chronic lymphocytic
Overview: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow the spongy tissue inside bones where blood cells are made. The term lymphocytic in chronic lymphocytic leukemia comes from the cells affected by the disease a group of white blood cells called lymphocytes, which help the body fight infection.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of chronic lymphocytic leukemia include The age. A family history of chronic lymphocytic leukemia or other blood and bone marrow cancers may increase the risk. Certain herbicides and insecticides, including Agent Orange used during the Vietnam War, have been linked to an increased risk of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
Diagnosis: A test called flow cytometry or immunophenotyping helps determine whether an increased number of lymphocytes is due to chronic lymphocytic leukemia, a different blood disorder or the body's reaction to another process, such as infection. If chronic lymphocytic leukemia is present, flow cytometry may also help analyze the leukemia cells for characteristics that help predict how aggressive the cells are. In some cases, the doctor may order additional tests and procedures to aid in diagnosis, such as: Once a diagnosis is confirmed, the doctor determines the extent (stage) of the chronic lymphocytic leukemia. A test called flow cytometry or immunophenotyping helps determine whether an increased number of lymphocytes is due to chronic lymphocytic leukemia, a different blood disorder or the body's reaction to another process, such as infection.If chronic lymphocytic leukemia is present, flow cytometry may also help analyze the leukemia cells for characteristics that help predict how aggressive the cells are.

Name: Leukemia , chronic myelogenous
Overview: Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is an uncommon type of cancer of the bone marrow the spongy tissue inside bones where blood cells are made. The term myelogenous (my-uh-LOHJ-uh-nus) in chronic myelogenous leukemia refers to the type of cells affected by this cancer.
Causes: This creates an abnormally small chromosome 22 and a new combination of instructions for the cells that can lead to the development of chronic myelogenous leukemia. In people with chronic myelogenous leukemia, the chromosomes in the blood cells swap sections with each other. The Philadelphia chromosome is present in the blood cells of 90 percent of people with chronic myelogenous leukemia.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of chronic myelogenous leukemia: The mutation that leads to chronic myelogenous leukemia isn't passed from parents to children. Plymouth Meeting, Pa.: National Comprehensive Cancer Network. Rochester, Minn.: Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research; 2019. A prospective analysis of symptom burden for patients with chronic myeloid leukemia in chronic phase treated with frontline second- and third-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
Diagnosis: In a bone marrow aspiration, a doctor or nurse uses a thin needle to remove a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot in the back of the hipbone (pelvis). Tests and procedures used to diagnose chronic myelogenous leukemia include The phase of chronic myelogenous leukemia refers to the aggressiveness of the disease. The doctor determines the phase by measuring the proportion of diseased cells to healthy cells in the blood or bone marrow. Specialized tests, such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) analysis and the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test, analyze blood or bone marrow samples for the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome or the BCR-ABL gene.
Remedies: Self-care measures to help one adjust and cope with a chronic illness include Talk to the doctor about the side effects. Powerful cancer medications can cause many side effects, but those side effects often can be managed with other medications or treatments. If one develop unpleasant side effects, such as skin rashes or fatigue, don't simply quit the medication without consulting the health care professionals. Likewise, don't stop taking the medications if one feel better and think the disease may be gone.

Name: Leukemia , general
Overview: Leukemia is cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system. But in people with leukemia, the bone marrow produces abnormal white blood cells, which don't function properly.
Causes: In general, leukemia is thought to occur when some blood cells acquire mutations in their DNA the instructions inside each cell that guide its action. In acute leukemia, the abnormal blood cells are immature blood cells (blasts). This type of leukemia affects the lymphoid cells (lymphocytes), which form lymphoid or lymphatic tissue. With CLL, the most common chronic adult leukemia, one may feel well for years without needing treatment.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of developing some types of leukemia include However, most people with known risk factors don't get leukemia. People whove had certain types of chemotherapy and radiation therapy for other cancers have an increased risk of developing certain types of leukemia. Certain genetic disorders, such as Down syndrome, are associated with an increased risk of leukemia. Exposure to certain chemicals, such as benzene which is found in gasoline and is used by the chemical industry is linked to an increased risk of some kinds of leukemia. If members of the family have been diagnosed with leukemia, the risk of the disease may be increased.
Diagnosis: In a bone marrow aspiration, a doctor or nurse uses a thin needle to remove a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot in the back of the hipbone (pelvis). By looking at a sample of the blood, the doctor can determine if one has abnormal levels of red or white blood cells or platelets which may suggest leukemia.
Treatment: One may receive radiation in one specific area of the body where there is a collection of leukemia cells, or one may receive radiation over the whole body. Before a stem cell transplant, one receive high doses of chemotherapy or radiation therapy to destroy the diseased bone marrow. This drug treatment uses chemicals to kill leukemia cells.Depending on the type of leukemia one has, one may receive a single drug or a combination of drugs. Targeted therapy uses drugs that attack specific vulnerabilities within the cancer cells.For example, the drug imatinib (Gleevec) stops the action of a protein within the leukemia cells of people with chronic myelogenous leukemia. During radiation therapy, one lie on a table while a large machine moves around one, directing the radiation to precise points on the body.One may receive radiation in one specific area of the body where there is a collection of leukemia cells, or one may receive radiation over the whole body. A stem cell transplant is a procedure to replace the diseased bone marrow with healthy bone marrow.Before a stem cell transplant, one receive high doses of chemotherapy or radiation therapy to destroy the diseased bone marrow. Then one receive an infusion of blood-forming stem cells that help to rebuild the bone marrow.One may receive stem cells from a donor, or in some cases one may be able to use the own stem cells.

Name: Leukemia , hairy cell
Overview: Hairy cell leukemia cells, which appear as the darker cells in this photo, are surrounded by a halo of fine projections (villi). Hairy cell leukemia is a rare, slow-growing cancer of the blood in which the bone marrow makes too many B cells (lymphocytes), a type of white blood cell that fights infection.
Diagnosis: In a bone marrow aspiration, a doctor or nurse uses a thin needle to remove a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot in the back of the hipbone (pelvis). To diagnose hairy cell leukemia, the doctor may take a sample of bone marrow from the body and examine it under a microscope to look for hairy cells. The doctor uses blood tests, such as the complete blood count, to monitor the levels of blood cells in the blood. People with hairy cell leukemia have low levels of all three types of blood cells red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets. Careful analysis of hairy cell leukemia cells in the blood and bone marrow samples may reveal certain genetic and chemical changes that give the doctor an idea of the prognosis and play a role in determining the treatment options.

Name: Leukoplakia
Overview: Leukoplakia appears as thick, white patches on the inside surfaces of the mouth. With leukoplakia (loo-koh-PLAY-key-uh), thickened, white patches form on the gums, the insides of the cheeks, the bottom of the mouth and, sometimes, the tongue.
Treatment: Leukoplakia treatment is most successful when a lesion is found and treated early, when it's small. Regular checkups are important, as is routinely inspecting the mouth for areas that don't look normal. When this isn't effective or if the lesions show early signs of cancer, the treatment plan may involve: Removal of leukoplakia patches. Patches may be removed using a scalpel, a laser or an extremely cold probe that freezes and destroys cancer cells (cryoprobe).
info-Symptoms: Firmly attached white patch on a mucous membrane, changes with time
info-Risk factors: Smoking, chewing tobacco, excessive alcohol, betel nuts
info-Diagnostic method: Made after other possible causes ruled out, tissue biopsy
info-Treatment: Close follow up, stop smoking, limit alcohol, surgical removal

Name: Lewy body dementia
Symptoms: Sound (auditory), smell (olfactory) or touch (tactile) hallucinations are possible. Signs of Parkinson's disease (parkinsonian signs), such as slowed movement, rigid muscles, tremor or a shuffling walk may occur. Blood pressure, pulse, sweating and the digestive process are regulated by a part of the nervous system that is often affected by Lewy body dementia. One may experience thinking (cognitive) problems similar to those of Alzheimer's disease, such as confusion, poor attention, visual-spatial problems and memory loss. One may have rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder, which can cause one to physically act out the dreams while one is asleep.
Risk factors: A few factors seem to increase the risk of developing Lewy body dementia, including Age. Those who have a family member with Lewy body dementia or Parkinson's disease are at greater risk.
Diagnosis: A diagnosis of Lewy body dementia requires a progressive decline in the ability to think, as well as two of the following: Autonomic dysfunction, which involves instability in blood pressure and heart rate, poor regulation of body temperature, sweating, and related symptoms, supports a Lewy body dementia diagnosis. Tests may include The doctor may check for signs of Parkinson's disease, strokes, tumors or other medical conditions that can affect the brain and physical function. If the diagnosis is unclear or the signs and symptoms aren't typical, the doctor may suggest some additional imaging tests, including these that can support a diagnosis of Lewy body dementia: The doctor may order a sleep evaluation to check for REM sleep behavior disorder or an autonomic function test to look for signs of heart rate and blood pressure instability. The doctor may also order a heart test called myocardial scintigraphy to check the blood flow to the heart, which can be a sign of Lewy body dementia.
Remedies: Caregivers may need to adapt the following tips to individual situations: Limiting caffeine during the day, discouraging daytime napping and offering opportunities for daytime exercise may help prevent nighttime restlessness. Participating in games, crossword puzzles and other activities that involve using thinking skills may help slow mental decline in people with dementia.
Medication: These Alzheimer's disease medications, such as rivastigmine (Exelon), donepezil (Aricept) and galantamine (Razadyne), work by increasing the levels of chemical messengers believed to be important for memory, thought and judgment (neurotransmitters) in the brain. In some people with moderate or severe dementia, an N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA)-receptor antagonist called memantine (Namenda) may be added to the cholinesterase inhibitor. If possible, avoid medications with anticholinergic properties, which can worsen cognition, or dopamine agonists, which can cause hallucinations. First-generation antipsychotic medications, such as haloperidol (Haldol), should not be used to treat Lewy body dementia. Because antipsychotic drugs can worsen Lewy body dementia symptoms, it might be helpful to first try nondrug approaches, such as: Cholinesterase inhibitors. These medications, such as carbidopa-levodopa (Sinemet, Rytary, Duopa) may help reduce parkinsonian signs and symptoms, such as rigid muscles and slow movement. However, these medications may also increase confusion, hallucinations and delusions. The doctor may prescribe medications to treat other signs and symptoms associated with Lewy body dementia, such as sleep or movement problems.

Name: Lice
Symptoms: Things often mistaken for nits include Intense itching on the scalp, body or in the genital area. Lice on the scalp, body, clothing, or pubic or other body hair. Nits can be mistaken for dandruff, but unlike dandruff, they can't be easily brushed out of hair.
Overview: Head lice occur on the scalp and are easiest to see at the nape of the neck and over the ears. Body lice most often affect people who aren't able to bathe or launder clothing regularly, such as homeless individuals. Commonly called crabs, these lice occur on the skin and hair of the pubic area and, less frequently, on coarse body hair, such as chest hair, eyebrows or eyelashes.
Causes: Lice feed on human blood and can infest the human head, body and pubic area. These may include clothing, headphones, brushes, combs, hair decorations, towels, blankets, pillows and stuffed toys. Lying on a bed or sitting in overstuffed, cloth-covered furniture recently used by someone with lice can spread them. Pubic lice usually spread through sexual contact and most commonly affect adults.
Remedies: One can get rid of lice with a patient, thorough approach that involves cleaning theself or the child and any personal belongings that may be contaminated. Choose from among several over-the-counter lotions and shampoos (Nix, Rid, others) designed to kill lice. Wash bedding, stuffed animals, clothing and hats with hot, soapy water at least 130 F (54 C) and dry them at high heat for at least 20 minutes. Use very hot, soapy water at least 130 F (54 C) or soak combs and brushes in rubbing alcohol for an hour.

Name: Lice , body
Overview: Body lice are tiny insects, about the size of a sesame seed. Clothing and bedding that have been infested with body lice should be laundered in hot, soapy water and machine dried using the hot cycle.

Name: Lichen nitidus
Symptoms: Lichen nitidus appears as clusters of tiny, glistening bumps (papules). Because a number of conditions can cause skin reactions, it's best to get a prompt and accurate diagnosis. Get immediate care if the skin condition is accompanied by other signs and symptoms, such as: Size. They may be slightly pink on people with lighter skin, or lighter than normal skin color on people with darker skin. Lichen nitidus bumps commonly occur on the chest, abdomen, arms and genital areas, including the penis. In rare cases, the bumps of lichen nitidus may itch, sometimes intensely.
Overview: Lichen nitidus is an uncommon, inflammatory skin condition. Lichen nitidus (LIE-kun ni-TIE-dus) is a rare skin condition that usually appears as tiny, skin-colored, glistening bumps on the surface of the skin.
Treatment: If lichen nitidus causes itching or if one has concerns about the appearance or the child's appearance, the doctor may prescribe one of the following treatments: Retinoid is a synthetic version of vitamin A that can be a topical or oral treatment. The topical treatment doesn't cause the side effects associated with corticosteroids, but it may irritate the skin. The side effects vary depending on whether it's used as an ointment applied directly to the skin (topical) or taken as a pill (oral). Long-term use of topical corticosteroids can cause thinning of the skin, a lessening of the treatment effect and other skin problems. Long-term use of oral corticosteroids can cause weakening of the bones (osteoporosis), diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels. A topical drug called tacrolimus (Protopic) helps to suppress the immune response and may be helpful for lichen nitidus. One type uses ultraviolet A (UVA) light, which penetrates deep into the skin.

Name: Lichen planus
Overview: Lichen planus is an inflammatory disorder that appears as purplish, flat-topped bumps when it affects the skin. Lichen planus (LIE-kun PLAY-nus) is a condition that can cause swelling and irritation in the skin, hair, nails and mucous membranes. On the skin, lichen planus usually appears as purplish, itchy, flat bumps that develop over several weeks. In the mouth, vagina and other areas covered by a mucous membrane, lichen planus forms lacy white patches, sometimes with painful sores.
Diagnosis: The doctor makes a diagnosis of lichen planus based on the symptoms, the medical history, a physical examination and, if necessary, the results of lab tests. These tests may include Other tests may be needed if the doctor suspects one has any of the several variations of lichen planus, such as the type that affects the esophagus, genitals, ears or mouth. One may have the blood drawn to test for hepatitis C, which is a possible trigger for lichen planus. The doctor may refer one to an allergy specialist (allergist) or dermatologist to find out if one is allergic to something that can trigger lichen planus.
Treatment: Other oral medicines used in selected situations for this condition are the antimalarial hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil) and the antibiotic metronidazole (Flagyl, others). Severe signs and symptoms may require prescription medications that suppress or modify the body's immune response, such as azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran), mycophenolate (Cellcept), cyclosporine (Gengraf, Sandimmune, others) and methotrexate (Trexall). The most common phototherapy for lichen planus uses ultraviolet B (UVB) light, which penetrates only the upper layer of skin (epidermis). If the condition doesn't respond to corticosteroids or light therapy, the doctor might prescribe a retinoid medication taken by mouth, such as acitretin (Soriatane).

Name: Lip cancer
Causes: In general, cancer starts when cells develop changes (mutations) in their DNA. The changes tell the cell to begin multiplying uncontrollably and to continue living when healthy cells would die.
Diagnosis: During a physical exam, the doctor will examine the lip, mouth, face and neck to look for signs of cancer. In the laboratory, a doctor who analyzes body tissue (pathologist) can determine whether cancer is present, the type of cancer and the level of aggressiveness that's present in the cancer cells. Imaging tests may include computerized tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or positron emission tomography (PET).
Treatment: For small lip cancers, repairing the lip after surgery may be a simple procedure. But for larger lip cancers, skilled plastic and reconstructive surgeons may be needed to repair the lip. Radiation therapy for lip cancer may be used on its own or it may be used after surgery. For lip cancer, chemotherapy is sometimes used in combination with radiation therapy to increase the effectiveness of treatment. In cases of advanced lip cancer that has spread to other areas of the body, chemotherapy may be used to reduce signs and symptoms and make one more comfortable. For cancer of the lip, immunotherapy might be considered when the cancer is advanced and other treatments aren't an option.

Name: Lipoma
Symptoms: But if one notice a lump or swelling anywhere on the body, have it checked by the doctor. They commonly occur in the neck, shoulders, back, abdomen, arms and thighs. Lipomas are typically less than 2 inches (5 centimeters) in diameter, but they can grow. Lipomas can be painful if they grow and press on nearby nerves or if they contain many blood vessels.
Overview: A lipoma is a fatty tumor located just below the skin. A lipoma is a slow-growing, fatty lump that's most often situated between the skin and the underlying muscle layer. A lipoma, which feels doughy and usually isn't tender, moves readily with slight finger pressure. Treatment generally isn't necessary, but if the lipoma bothers one, is painful or is growing, one may want to have it removed.
Risk factors: Several factors may increase the risk of developing a lipoma, including Being between 40 and 60 years old. Although lipomas can occur at any age, they're most common in this age group.
info-Symptoms: Soft, movable, usually painless lump
info-Risk factors: Family history, obesity, insufficient exercise

Name: Liposarcoma
Overview: Liposarcoma is a type of cancer that occurs in fat cells in the body, most often in the muscles of the limbs or the abdomen. Liposarcoma can occur in fat cells in any part of the body, but most cases occur in the muscles of the limbs or in the abdomen.
Treatment: In those situations, the doctor may recommend other treatments to shrink the liposarcoma to make it easier to remove during an operation. Chemotherapy may be used after surgery to kill any cancer cells that remain or before surgery to shrink a tumor. Radiation therapy uses powerful energy beams, such as X-rays and protons, to kill cancer cells. Clinical trials might give one a chance to try the latest treatments, such as new types of chemotherapy and targeted therapy drugs.
info-Symptoms: Lump under skin, pain, swelling, organ dysfunction

Name: Listeriosis
Overview: Listeria infection is a foodborne bacterial illness that can be very serious for pregnant women, people older than 65 and people with weakened immune systems. Healthy people rarely become ill from listeria infection, but the disease can be fatal to unborn babies, newborns and people with weakened immune systems.
Diagnosis: A blood test is often the most effective way to determine whether one has a listeria infection. In some cases, samples of urine or spinal fluid will be tested as well.
Treatment: Treatment of listeria infection varies, depending on the severity of the signs and symptoms. If one has eaten food that has been recalled because of listeria contamination, see a doctor only if one has signs and symptoms of a listeria infection.
info-Symptoms: Diarrhea, fever, headache
info-Risk factors: Immunocompromisation, pregnancy, diabetes mellitus
info-Diagnostic method: Culture of blood or spinal fluid
info-Prevention: Safe handling and preparation of food, avoidance of soft cheese by pregnant women

Name: Liver cancer
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of primary liver cancer include Chronic infection with HBV or HCV. Chronic infection with the hepatitis B virus (HBV) or hepatitis C virus (HCV) increases the risk of liver cancer. This progressive and irreversible condition causes scar tissue to form in the liver and increases the chances of developing liver cancer. Liver diseases that can increase the risk of liver cancer include hemochromatosis and Wilson's disease. People with this blood sugar disorder have a greater risk of liver cancer than those who don't have diabetes. Consuming more than a moderate amount of alcohol daily over many years can lead to irreversible liver damage and increase the risk of liver cancer.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose liver cancer include Removing a sample of liver tissue for testing. Imaging tests used to stage liver cancer include CTs, MRIs and bone scans.
info-Symptoms: Lump or pain in the right side below the rib cage, swelling of the abdomen, yellowish skin, easy bruising, weight loss, weakness
info-Causes: hepatitis B, hepatitis C, alcohol, aflatoxin, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, liver flukes
info-Diagnostic method: Blood tests, medical imaging, tissue biopsy
info-Prevention: Immunization against hepatitis B, treating those infected with hepatitis B or C, decreasing exposure to aflatoxin, decreasing high levels of alcohol consumption

Name: Liver disease
Overview: Liver problems that can occur include fatty liver disease and cirrhosis. Liver problems can also be caused by a variety of factors that damage the liver, such as viruses, alcohol use and obesity. Over time, conditions that damage the liver can lead to scarring (cirrhosis), which can lead to liver failure, a life-threatening condition.
Diagnosis: Removing a tissue sample (biopsy) from the liver may help diagnose liver disease and look for signs of liver damage. A liver biopsy is most often done using a long needle inserted through the skin to extract a tissue sample that's sent to a lab for testing.

Name: Liver failure , acute
Overview: Acute liver failure is loss of liver function that occurs rapidly in days or weeks usually in a person who has no pre-existing liver disease. Acute liver failure, also known as fulminant hepatic failure, can cause serious complications, including excessive bleeding and increasing pressure in the brain.
Causes: Taking too much acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) is the most common cause of acute liver failure in the United States. Acute liver failure can occur after one very large dose of acetaminophen, or after higher than recommended doses every day for several days. Some prescription medications, including antibiotics, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and anticonvulsants, can cause acute liver failure. Herbal drugs and supplements, including kava, ephedra, skullcap and pennyroyal, have been linked to acute liver failure. Hepatitis A, hepatitis B and hepatitis E can cause acute liver failure. Other viruses that can cause acute liver failure include Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus and herpes simplex virus. Toxins that can cause acute liver failure include the poisonous wild mushroom Amanita phalloides, which is sometimes mistaken for one that is safe to eat. Liver failure can be caused by autoimmune hepatitis a disease in which the immune system attacks liver cells, causing inflammation and injury. Vascular diseases, such as Budd-Chiari syndrome, can cause blockages in the veins of the liver and lead to acute liver failure. Rare metabolic diseases, such as Wilson's disease and acute fatty liver of pregnancy, infrequently cause acute liver failure. Overwhelming infection (sepsis) and shock can severely impair blood flow to the liver, causing liver failure.
Diagnosis: The doctor may also recommend abdominal computerized tomography (CT) scanning or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to look at the liver and blood vessels. Since people with acute liver failure are at risk of bleeding during biopsy, the doctor may perform a transjugular liver biopsy.
Treatment: People with acute liver failure are often treated in the intensive care unit of a hospital in a facility that can perform a liver transplant, if necessary. The doctor may try to treat the liver damage itself, but in many cases, treatment involves controlling complications and giving the liver time to heal. Acute liver failure treatments may include The doctor also will work to control signs and symptoms one is experiencing and try to prevent complications caused by acute liver failure. This medication may also help treat other causes of acute liver failure. Mushroom and other poisonings also may be treated with drugs that can reverse the effects of the toxin and may reduce liver damage. When acute liver failure can't be reversed, the only treatment may be a liver transplant.

Name: Liver hemangioma
Risk factors: A liver hemangioma can be diagnosed at any age, but it's most commonly diagnosed in people ages 30 to 50. Women who have been pregnant are more likely to be diagnosed with a liver hemangioma than women who have never been pregnant. It's believed the hormone estrogen, which rises during pregnancy, may play a role in liver hemangioma growth. Women who used hormone replacement therapy for menopausal symptoms may be more likely to be diagnosed with a liver hemangioma than women who did not.
Treatment: If the hemangioma can be easily separated from the liver, the doctor may recommend surgery to remove the mass. In some cases, surgeons may need to remove a portion of the liver along with the hemangioma. In the unlikely event that one has a large hemangioma or multiple hemangiomas that can't be treated by other means, the doctor may recommend surgery to remove the liver and replace it with a liver from a donor.

Name: Liver , enlarged
Overview: An enlarged liver can have many possible causes. Rather than a disease, an enlarged liver is a sign of an underlying problem, such as liver disease, congestive heart failure or cancer.
Risk factors: Factors that can increase the risk of liver problems include Large doses of medicines, vitamins or supplements. Taking larger than recommended doses of vitamins, supplements, or over-the-counter (OTC) or prescription medicines can increase the risk of liver damage. Certain supplements, including black cohosh, ma huang and valerian, can increase the risk of liver damage. Infectious diseases, viral, bacterial or parasitic, can increase the risk of liver damage. Being overweight increases the risk of liver disease, as does eating unhealthy foods, such as those with excess fat or sugar.

Name: Lobular carcinoma in situ ( LCIS )
Symptoms: Ask the doctor when one should consider breast cancer screening and how often it should be repeated. Most groups recommend considering routine breast cancer screening beginning in the 40s.
Overview: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) develops in a milk-producing gland (lobule) and does not spread into nearby breast tissue. Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is an uncommon condition in which abnormal cells form in the milk glands (lobules) in the breast. If one is diagnosed with LCIS, the doctor may recommend increased breast cancer screening and may ask one to consider medical treatments to reduce the risk of developing invasive breast cancer.
Causes: The risk of breast cancer in women diagnosed with LCIS is thought to be approximately 20 percent. Put another way, for every 100 women diagnosed with LCIS, 20 will be diagnosed with breast cancer and 80 won't be diagnosed with breast cancer. Put another way, for every 100 women in the general population, 12 will be diagnosed with breast cancer.
Diagnosis: A core needle biopsy uses a long, hollow tube to extract a sample of tissue. Types of breast biopsy that may be used include The tissue removed during the biopsy is sent to a laboratory where doctors that specialize in analyzing blood and body tissues (pathologists) closely examine the cells to determine if one has LCIS. Imaging techniques, such as ultrasound or MRI, are often used to help guide the needle used in a core needle biopsy.
Remedies: If one is worried about the risk of breast cancer, take steps to reduce the risk, such as: Maintain a healthy weight. If one choose to take hormone therapy for menopause signs and symptoms, limit the use to the lowest dose for the shortest length of time necessary to provide relief.

Name: Long QT syndrome
Symptoms: However, congenital long QT syndrome signs and symptoms can occur in babies during the first weeks to months after birth, or in childhood or later. If one has a first-degree relative (parent, sibling or child) with long QT syndrome, it's important to let the doctor know.
Overview: Long QT syndrome (LQTS) is a heart rhythm condition that can potentially cause fast, chaotic heartbeats. Some people are born with a genetic mutation that causes long QT syndrome (congenital long QT syndrome). Long QT syndrome may be caused by certain medications, mineral imbalances or medical conditions (acquired long QT syndrome).
Causes: Long QT syndrome is a heart rhythm disorder caused by abnormalities in the heart's electrical recharging system. In long QT syndrome, the heart's electrical system takes longer than normal to recharge between beats. Long QT syndrome is often grouped into two main categories, depending on the cause. More than 17 genes have been linked to long QT syndrome so far, and researchers have identified hundreds of mutations within these genes. Medications that can cause acquired long QT syndrome include If the condition is caused by a medication, it may be called drug-induced long QT syndrome. Other causes of acquired long QT syndrome include If one is born with the condition, it's called congenital long QT syndrome. If an underlying medical condition or medication causes it, it's called acquired long QT syndrome.
Diagnosis: To diagnose long QT syndrome, the doctor will perform a physical exam and ask questions about the or the child's symptoms and medical and family history. During an ECG, sticky patches (electrodes) are placed on the chest to record the heart's electrical signals, which cause the heart to beat. The test labels the heart's electrical signals as five waves using the letters P, Q, R, S and T. The waves labeled Q through T show the electrical activity in the heart's lower chambers (ventricles). If the interval takes longer than normal to occur, it's called a prolonged QT interval. If the long QT symptoms tend to come and go, they may not be captured during a standard ECG recording. It's important to understand that genetic tests for long QT syndrome can't detect all inherited cases of long QT syndrome. If one has a positive genetic test for long QT syndrome, the doctor may recommend that other family members also be tested to determine whether they inherited the same gene.
Treatment: Treatment for long QT syndrome involves lifestyle changes, medications, and possibly surgery or other procedures. The doctor will discuss with one the most appropriate treatment options based on the symptoms and the type of long QT syndrome. If one has drug-induced long QT syndrome, stopping the medication causing the symptoms may be all that is needed to treat the condition.
Remedies: In addition to recommending medications or surgery, the doctor might suggest lifestyle changes to reduce the chances of a long QT syndrome-related fainting spell or sudden cardiac death. It may be possible to stay fully active in sports, including competitive sports, after carefully reviewing the risks and benefits with the doctor. Being very excited, angry or surprised can trigger heartbeat changes in some people with long QT syndrome. It's a good idea to let one doctor know about all the medications and supplements one take, even those one buy without a prescription.
Medication: Medications won't cure long QT syndrome, but they can help protect against possible life-threatening heart rhythm changes. Depending on the symptoms, the doctor might consider other long QT syndrome treatments for one, including Left cardiac sympathetic denervation (LCSD) surgery. LCSD is generally reserved for people with long QT and persistent heart rhythm problems who are at high risk of symptoms and cannot take or tolerate beta blockers. Beta blockers used to treat long QT syndrome include nadolol (Corgard) and propranolol (Inderal LA, InnoPran XL). Taking this heart rhythm drug in combination with a beta blocker might help shorten the QT interval and reduce the risk of fainting, seizure or sudden death.
info-Symptoms: Fainting, hearing loss, seizures
info-Causes: Genetic, certain medications, low blood potassium, low blood calcium, heart failure
info-Risk factors: Family history of sudden death
info-Treatment: Avoiding strenuous exercise, getting sufficient potassium, beta blockers, implantable cardiac defibrillator

Name: Low blood pressure ( hypotension )
Causes: Blood pressure varies throughout the day, depending on: Blood pressure is usually lowest at night and rises sharply on waking. Some types of low blood pressure include Low blood pressure on standing up (orthostatic or postural) hypotension). But in people with orthostatic hypotension, this compensating mechanism fails and blood pressure falls, leading to dizziness, lightheadedness, blurred vision and even fainting. Ordinarily, the body increases the heart rate and constricts certain blood vessels to help maintain normal blood pressure. Because the circulatory system expands rapidly during pregnancy, blood pressure is likely to drop. This is normal, and blood pressure usually returns to the pre-pregnancy level after one has given birth. Some heart conditions that can lead to low blood pressure include extremely low heart rate (bradycardia), heart valve problems, heart attack and heart failure. When an infection in the body enters the bloodstream, it can lead to a life-threatening drop in blood pressure called septic shock. Anaphylaxis can cause breathing problems, hives, itching, a swollen throat and a dangerous drop in blood pressure. A lack of the vitamin B-12, folate and iron can keep the body from producing enough red blood cells (anemia), causing low blood pressure. This disorder, which causes a blood pressure drop after standing for long periods, mostly affects young adults and children. Low blood pressure due to nervous system damage (multiple system atrophy with orthostatic hypotension). It causes progressive damage to the autonomic nervous system, which controls involuntary functions such as blood pressure, heart rate, breathing and digestion.
Risk factors: Low blood pressure (hypotension) can occur in anyone, though certain types of low blood pressure are more common depending on the age or other factors: Age. People who take certain medications, for example, high blood pressure medications such as alpha blockers, have a greater risk of low blood pressure. Parkinson's disease, diabetes and some heart conditions put one at a greater risk of developing low blood pressure.
Diagnosis: During this test, the heart rate and blood pressure are monitored to evaluate the body's cardiovascular response to the change in position. If one has low blood pressure on standing or from faulty brain signals (neurally mediated hypotension), a tilt table test can evaluate how the body reacts to changes in position. During the test, one lie on a table that's tilted to raise the upper part of the body, which simulates the movement from horizontal to a standing position. These can provide information about the overall health as well as whether one has low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), high blood sugar (hyperglycemia or diabetes) or a low red blood cell count (anemia), all of which can cause lower than normal blood pressure. Blood pressure test Echocardiogram Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) Stress test Tilt table test Blood tests.
Remedies: Depending on the reason for the low blood pressure, one might be able to reduce or prevent symptoms. If one begin to get symptoms while standing, cross the thighs in a scissors fashion and squeeze, or put one foot on a ledge or chair and lean as far forward as possible. To help prevent blood pressure from dropping sharply after meals, eat small portions several times a day and limit high-carbohydrate foods such as potatoes, rice, pasta and bread. Don't drink caffeine throughout the day because one will become less sensitive to caffeine, and caffeine can cause dehydration.

Name: Low blood sugar
Overview: Hypoglycemia is a condition in which the blood sugar (glucose) level is lower than normal. But other drugs and a variety of conditions many rare can cause low blood sugar in people who don't have diabetes Hypoglycemia needs immediate treatment when blood sugar levels are low. For many people, a fasting blood sugar of 70 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 3.9 millimoles per liter (mmol/L), or below should serve as an alert for hypoglycemia.
Causes: Hypoglycemia occurs when the blood sugar (glucose) level falls too low. If one has diabetes, one might not make enough insulin (type 1 diabetes) or one might be less responsive to it (type 2 diabetes). But too much insulin or other diabetes medications may cause the blood sugar level to drop too low, causing hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemia can also occur if one eat less than usual after taking diabetes medication, or if one exercise more than one normally do. Kidney disorders, which can keep the body from properly excreting medications, can affect glucose levels due to a buildup of those medications. Long-term starvation, as can occur in the eating disorder anorexia nervosa, can result in too little of substances the body needs to create glucose. Sometimes hypoglycemia symptoms occur after certain meals high in sugar because the body produces more insulin than one need.
