Other medications can cause hypoglycemia, especially in children or in people with kidney failure. Drinking heavily without eating can block the liver from releasing stored glucose into the bloodstream, causing hypoglycemia. A rare tumor of the pancreas (insulinoma) can cause one to produce too much insulin, resulting in hypoglycemia. Enlargement of cells of the pancreas that produce insulin can result in excessive insulin release, causing hypoglycemia.
Diagnosis: If one use insulin or another diabetes medication to lower the blood sugar, and one has signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia, test the blood sugar levels with a blood glucose meter. If one don't use medications known to cause hypoglycemia, the doctor will want to know the following: What were the signs and symptoms?
info-Symptoms: Clumsiness, shakiness, dizziness and giddiness, weakness, sweating, difficulty talking, confusion, loss of consciousness, seizures
info-Causes: Medications (insulin and sulfonylureas), sepsis, kidney failure, certain tumors, liver disease
info-Diagnostic method: Blood sugar level < 3.9Â mmol/L (70Â mg/dL) in a diabetic
info-Treatment: Eating foods high in simple sugars, dextrose, glucagon

Name: Low body temperature
Causes: If one is in direct contact with something very cold, such as cold water or the cold ground, heat is conducted away from the body. Because water is very good at transferring heat from the body, body heat is lost much faster in cold water than in cold air. Similarly, heat loss from the body is much faster if the clothes are wet, as when one is caught out in the rain.
Risk factors: Alcohol may make the body feel warm inside, but it causes the blood vessels to expand, resulting in more rapid heat loss from the surface of the skin. In addition, the use of alcohol or recreational drugs can affect the judgment about the need to get inside or wear warm clothes in cold-weather conditions. If a person is intoxicated and passes out in cold weather, he or she is likely to develop hypothermia. As winter drags on and temperatures drop way down, the risk of cold-related injury like frostbite can go way up. We tend to see frostbite, for example, when the temperature is 5 degrees Fahrenheit with minimal windchill, Dr. Kakar explains. If the windchill drops below negative 15 degrees Fahrenheit, not unheard of in the northern half of the U.S. frostbite can set in within half an hour. Initially with the milder forms, one can get some pain and some numbness of the tips, but the skin can change its color, Dr. Kakar says. Those most at risk are certain patients with diabetes, patients who have previous history of frostbite are prone to it, the elderly or the very young children, and also, for example, if one is dehydrated, he says. People with a mental illness, dementia or other conditions that interfere with judgment may not dress appropriately for the weather or understand the risk of cold weather. People with dementia may wander from home or get lost easily, making them more likely to be stranded outside in cold or wet weather. Examples include an underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism), poor nutrition or anorexia nervosa, diabetes, stroke, severe arthritis, Parkinson's disease, trauma, and spinal cord injuries. Examples include certain antidepressants, antipsychotics, narcotic pain medications and sedatives.
info-Symptoms: Mild: Shivering, mental confusion Moderate: No shivering, increased confusion Severe: Paradoxical undressing, cardiac arrest
info-Causes: Mainly exposure to cold weather and cold water immersion
info-Risk factors: Alcohol intoxication, low blood sugar, anorexia, advanced age
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms or body temperature below 35.0Â Â°C (95.0Â Â°F)
info-Prevention: wearing adequate clothes for weather, staying warm
info-Treatment: Mild: Warm drinks, warm clothing, physical activity Moderate: Heating blankets, warmed intravenous fluid Severe: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, cardiopulmonary bypass

Name: Low sex drive in women
Overview: Women's sexual desires naturally fluctuate over the years. If the lack of interest in sex continues or returns and causes personal distress, one may have a condition called sexual interest/arousal disorder. If one is bothered by a low sex drive or decreased sex drive, there are lifestyle changes and sexual techniques that may put one in the mood more often.
Causes: If one is experiencing a problem in any of these areas, it can affect the desire for sex. There are many psychological causes of low sex drive, including For many women, emotional closeness is an essential prelude to sexual intimacy. Decreased interest in sex is often a result of ongoing issues, such as: Sexual problems. Many nonsexual diseases can affect sex drive, including arthritis, cancer, diabetes, high blood pressure, coronary artery disease and neurological diseases. Certain prescription drugs, especially antidepressants called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, are known to lower the sex drive. A glass of wine may put one in the mood, but too much alcohol can affect the sex drive. Any surgery related to the breasts or genital tract can affect the body image, sexual function and desire for sex. This can make one less interested in sex and cause dry vaginal tissues, resulting in painful or uncomfortable sex. Although many women still have satisfying sex during menopause and beyond, some experience a lagging libido during this hormonal change. Hormone changes during pregnancy, just after having a baby and during breast-feeding can put a damper on sex drive. Fatigue, changes in body image, and the pressures of pregnancy or caring for a new baby also can contribute to changes in the sexual desire.
Diagnosis: By definition, one may be diagnosed with hypoactive sexual desire disorder if one frequently lack sexual thoughts or desire, and the absence of these feelings causes personal distress. In addition to asking one questions about the medical and sexual history, the doctor may also: Perform a pelvic exam. During a pelvic exam, the doctor can check for signs of physical changes contributing to low sexual desire, such as thinning of the genital tissues, vaginal dryness or pain-triggering spots.
Remedies: Finding a better way to cope with work stress, financial stress and daily hassles can enhance the sex drive. Couples who learn to communicate in an open, honest way usually maintain a stronger emotional connection, which can lead to better sex. Try a different sexual position, a different time of day or a different location for sex. If one and the partner are open to experimentation, sex toys and fantasy can help rekindle the sexual desire. Ditching these bad habits may help give the sex drive a boost and improve the overall health.
Medication: For example, antidepressants such as paroxetine (Paxil) and fluoxetine (Prozac, Sarafem) may lower sex drive. Switching to bupropion (Wellbutrin SR, Wellbutrin XL) a different type of antidepressant usually improves sex drive and is sometimes prescribed for women with sexual interest/arousal disorder. Dryness or shrinking of the vagina, one of the hallmark signs of genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM), might make sex uncomfortable and, in turn, reduce the desire. Drinking alcohol or taking fluconazole (Diflucan), a common medication to treat vaginal yeast infections, can make these side effects worse. Bremelanotide (Vyleesi), an injection one give theself just under the skin in the belly or thigh before anticipated sexual activity. The male hormone testosterone plays an important role in female sexual function, even though testosterone occurs in much lower amounts in women. Testosterone isn't approved by the FDA for sexual dysfunction in women, but sometimes it's prescribed off-label to help lift a lagging libido.

Name: Low sperm count
Causes: Once sperm are produced in the testicles, delicate tubes transport them until they mix with semen and are ejaculated out of the penis. Also, there can be problems of abnormal sperm shape (morphology), movement (motility) or function. However, often the cause of low sperm count isn't identified. Various health conditions can cause retrograde ejaculation or lack of ejaculation, including diabetes, spinal injuries, and surgery of the bladder, prostate or urethra. In most cases of permanent ejaculation problems, sperm can still be retrieved directly from the testicles. Sperm production or function can be affected by overexposure to certain environmental elements, including Overheating the testicles. Elevated temperatures impair sperm production and function.Although studies are limited and are inconclusive, frequent use of saunas or hot tubs might temporarily impair sperm count. Although the exact reason that varicoceles cause infertility is unknown, it might be related to abnormal testicular temperature regulation. These include inflammation of the epididymis (epididymitis) or testicles (orchitis) and some sexually transmitted infections, including gonorrhea or HIV. Although some infections can result in permanent testicular damage, most often sperm can still be retrieved. The hypothalamus, pituitary and testicles produce hormones that are necessary to create sperm. Alterations in these hormones, as well as from other systems such as the thyroid and adrenal gland, may impair sperm production. In most cases, surgery can be performed to either reverse these blockages or to retrieve sperm directly from the epididymis and testicles. Extended exposure to benzenes, toluene, xylene, herbicides, pesticides, organic solvents, painting materials and lead might contribute to low sperm counts. With high doses of radiation, sperm production can be permanently reduced. Anabolic steroids taken to stimulate muscle strength and growth can cause the testicles to shrink and sperm production to decrease. Certain occupations might be linked with a risk of infertility, including welding or those associated with prolonged sitting, such as truck driving. Severe or prolonged emotional stress, including stress about fertility, might interfere with hormones needed to produce sperm. Obesity can impair fertility in several ways, including directly impacting sperm and by causing hormone changes that reduce male fertility.
Diagnosis: Even if the doctor thinks low sperm count is the problem, it is recommended that the partner be evaluated to rule out potential contributing factors and determine if assisted reproductive techniques may be required. To ensure accuracy in a collection, the doctor will: Normal sperm densities range from 15 million to greater than 200 million sperm per milliliter of semen. There are many factors involved in reproduction, and the number of sperm in the semen is only one. Even if one has enough sperm, other factors are important to achieve a pregnancy, including normal sperm movement (motility). Depending on initial findings, the doctor might recommend additional tests to look for the cause of the low sperm count and other possible causes of male infertility. These can include Ask one to make sure all of the semen makes it into the collection cup or collection condom when one ejaculate Have one abstain from ejaculating for at least two but no longer than 11 days before collecting a sample Collect a second sample at least two weeks after the first Have one avoid the use of lubricants because these products can affect sperm motility Scrotal ultrasound. The doctor might recommend a blood test to determine the level of hormones produced by the pituitary gland and testicles, which play a key role in sexual development and sperm production. These tests, which are used to check for immune cells (antibodies) that attack sperm and affect their ability to function, are not common. A number of tests can be used to check how well the sperm survive after ejaculation, how well they can penetrate an egg and whether there's any problem attaching to the egg.
Treatment: In cases where no sperm are present in the ejaculate, sperm can often be retrieved directly from the testicles or epididymis using sperm retrieval techniques. The doctor might recommend hormone replacement or medications in cases where infertility is caused by high or low levels of certain hormones or problems with the way the body uses hormones. ART treatments involve obtaining sperm through normal ejaculation, surgical extraction or from donor individuals, depending on the specific situation and wishes.
Remedies: There are steps one can take at home to increase the chances of getting the partner pregnant, including Increasing the frequency of sex. Having sexual intercourse every day or every other day beginning at least four days before ovulation increases the chances of getting the partner pregnant.

Name: Lung cancer
Risk factors: Even if one don't smoke, the risk of lung cancer increases if one is exposed to secondhand smoke. If one has undergone radiation therapy to the chest for another type of cancer, one may have an increased risk of developing lung cancer. Workplace exposure to asbestos and other substances known to cause cancer such as arsenic, chromium and nickel can increase the risk of developing lung cancer, especially if one is a smoker. People with a parent, sibling or child with lung cancer have an increased risk of the disease.
Diagnosis: If there's reason to think that one may have lung cancer, the doctor can order a number of tests to look for cancerous cells and to rule out other conditions. The doctor can perform a biopsy in a number of ways, including bronchoscopy, in which the doctor examines abnormal areas of the lungs using a lighted tube that's passed down the throat and into the lungs. Another option is needle biopsy, in which the doctor uses X-ray or CT images to guide a needle through the chest wall and into the lung tissue to collect suspicious cells. Once the lung cancer has been diagnosed, the doctor will work to determine the extent (stage) of the cancer. Staging tests may include imaging procedures that allow the doctor to look for evidence that cancer has spread beyond the lungs.
Remedies: To cope with shortness of breath, it may help to: Tell the doctor if one experience shortness of breath or if the symptoms worsen, as there are many other treatments available to relieve shortness of breath. When one begin to feel short of breath, try to manage the fear by choosing an activity that helps one relax.
info-Symptoms: Coughing (including coughing up blood), weight loss, shortness of breath, chest pains
info-Risk factors: Tobacco smokinggenetic factorsradon gasasbestosair pollution
info-Prevention: Not smoking, avoiding radon gas, asbestos, second-hand smoke, or other forms of air pollution exposure.

Name: Lung collapse
Causes: Atelectasis occurs from a blocked airway (obstructive) or pressure from outside the lung (nonobstructive). It changes the regular pattern of breathing and affects the exchange of lung gases, which can cause the air sacs (alveoli) to deflate. Obstructive atelectasis may be caused by many things, including Possible causes of nonobstructive atelectasis include Mucus plug. Drugs given during surgery make one breathe less deeply, so normal secretions collect in the airways. Suctioning the lungs during surgery helps clear them, but sometimes they still build up. Atelectasis is common in children who have inhaled an object, such as a peanut or small toy part, into their lungs. This condition involves the buildup of fluid between the tissues (pleura) that line the lungs and the inside of the chest wall. Various types of pneumonia, a lung infection, can cause atelectasis. Air leaks into the space between the lungs and chest wall, indirectly causing some or all of a lung to collapse. Scarring could be caused by injury, lung disease or surgery.
Diagnosis: However, other tests may be done to confirm the diagnosis or determine the type or severity of atelectasis. Since a CT is a more sensitive technique than an X-ray, it may sometimes help better detect the cause and type of atelectasis. This noninvasive test can help tell the difference between atelectasis, hardening and swelling of a lung due to fluid in the air sacs (lung consolidation), and pleural effusion. A flexible, lighted tube inserted down the throat allows the doctor to see what may be causing a blockage, such as a mucus plug, tumor or foreign body.
Treatment: Mild atelectasis may go away without treatment. If the condition is due to a blockage, surgery or other treatments may be needed.
info-Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, tiredness
info-Risk factors: COPD, tuberculosis, smoking
info-Treatment: conservative, needle aspiration, chest tube, pleurodesis

Name: Lung disease , interstitial
Symptoms: The primary signs and symptoms of interstitial lung disease are: By the time symptoms appear, irreversible lung damage has often already occurred. Many conditions other than interstitial lung disease can affect the lungs, and getting an early and accurate diagnosis is important for proper treatment.
Causes: But in interstitial lung disease, the repair process goes awry and the tissue around the air sacs (alveoli) becomes scarred and thickened. Interstitial lung disease can be triggered by many different things including airborne toxins in the workplace, drugs and some types of medical treatments. Drugs designed to kill cancer cells, such as methotrexate (Otrexup, Trexall, others) and cyclophosphamide, can also damage lung tissue. Some drugs used to treat irregular heartbeats, such as amiodarone (Nexterone, Pacerone) or propranolol (Inderal, Innopran), may harm lung tissue. Nitrofurantoin (Macrobid, Macrodantin, others) and ethambutol (Myambutol) can cause lung damage. Certain anti-inflammatory drugs, such as rituximab (Rituxan) or sulfasalazine (Azulfidine), can cause lung damage.
Risk factors: Interstitial lung disease is much more likely to affect adults, although infants and children sometimes develop the disorder. If one work in mining, farming or construction or for any reason are exposed to pollutants known to damage the lungs, the risk of interstitial lung disease is increased. If one has uncontrolled acid reflux or indigestion, one may be at increased risk of interstitial lung disease. Some forms of interstitial lung disease are more likely to occur in people with a history of smoking, and active smoking may make the condition worse, especially if there is associated emphysema.
Diagnosis: In addition, the signs and symptoms of a wide range of medical conditions can mimic interstitial lung disease, and doctors must rule these out before making a definitive diagnosis. Often, pulmonary fibrosis can be definitively diagnosed only by examining a small amount of lung tissue (biopsy) in a laboratory. This imaging test is key to, and sometimes the first step in, the diagnosis of interstitial lung disease. This test requires one to exhale quickly and forcefully through a tube connected to a machine that measures how much air the lungs can hold, and how quickly one can move air out of the lungs. In this procedure, the doctor removes very small tissue samples generally no larger than the head of a pin using a small, flexible tube (bronchoscope) that's passed through the mouth or nose into the lungs. Although bronchoalveolar lavage samples a larger area of the lung than other procedures do, it may not provide enough information to diagnose pulmonary fibrosis. Although this is a more invasive procedure with potential complications, it's often the only way to obtain a large enough tissue sample to make an accurate diagnosis.
Remedies: Talk to the doctor about options for quitting, including smoking cessation programs, which use a variety of proven techniques to help people quit. And because secondhand smoke also can be harmful to the lungs, don't allow people to smoke around one. People with lung disease may lose weight both because it's uncomfortable to eat and because of the extra energy it takes to breathe.
Medication: Based on currently available, scientific evidence, however, the doctor may recommend: Using oxygen can't stop lung damage, but it can: One is most likely to receive oxygen when one sleep or exercise, although some people may use it round-the-clock. To that end, pulmonary rehabilitation programs focus on: Lung transplantation may be an option of last resort for some people with severe interstitial lung disease who haven't benefited from other treatment options. Many people diagnosed with interstitial lung diseases are initially treated with a corticosteroid (prednisone), sometimes in combination with other drugs that suppress the immune system. If one has symptoms of acid reflux, the doctor may prescribe GERD therapies that reduce stomach acid, including H-2-receptor antagonists or proton pump inhibitors such as lansoprazole (Prevacid 24HR), omeprazole (Prilosec OTC) and pantoprazole (protonix).

Name: Lupus nephritis
Overview: Blood enters the kidneys through the renal arteries. The glomeruli filter waste products and substances the body needs such as sodium, phosphorus and potassium which then pass through tiny tubules.
Diagnosis: Tests to diagnose lupus nephritis include Blood and urine tests. In addition to standard blood and urine tests, one may be asked to collect the urine for an entire day. A biopsy where the doctor removes a small section of kidney tissue for lab analysis is the most definitive test for diagnosing lupus nephritis.
info-Symptoms: Joint pain or swelling

Name: Lyme disease
Symptoms: However, these signs and symptoms can occur within a month after one has been infected: Rash. From three to 30 days after an infected tick bite, an expanding red area might appear that sometimes clears in the center, forming a bull's-eye pattern. Erythema migrans is one of the hallmarks of Lyme disease, although not everyone with Lyme disease develops the rash. If untreated, new signs and symptoms of Lyme infection might appear in the following weeks to months. These include Several weeks after infection, some people develop: Only a minority of tick bites leads to Lyme disease. Untreated, Lyme disease can spread to other parts of the body for several months to years after infection, causing arthritis and nervous system problems.
Causes: In the United States, Lyme disease is caused by the bacteria Borrelia burgdorferi and Borrelia mayonii, carried primarily by black-legged or deer ticks. In most cases, to transmit Lyme disease, a deer tick must be attached for 36 to 48 hours.
Risk factors: The most common risk factors for Lyme disease include Spending time in wooded or grassy areas. In the United States, deer ticks are found mostly in the heavily wooded areas of the Northeast and Midwest.
Diagnosis: The test used most often to detect Lyme disease, ELISA detects antibodies to B. burgdorferi. This test might not be positive during the early stage of Lyme disease, but the rash is distinctive enough to make the diagnosis without further testing in people who live in areas infested with ticks that transmit Lyme disease.
info-Symptoms: Expanding area of redness at the site of a tick bite, fever, headache, tiredness
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, tick exposure, blood tests
info-Prevention: Prevention of tick bites (clothing the limbs, DEET), doxycycline

Name: Lymphedema
Symptoms: The body's lymphatic system is part of the immune system, which protects one against infection and disease. The lymphatic system includes the spleen, thymus, lymph nodes and lymph channels, as well as the tonsils and adenoids.
Causes: Lymphedema occurs when the lymph vessels are unable to adequately drain lymph fluid, usually from an arm or leg. This means it can occur on its own (primary lymphedema), or it can be caused by another disease or condition (secondary lymphedema). Causes include Primary lymphedema is a rare, inherited condition caused by problems with the development of lymph vessels in the body. If cancer cells block lymphatic vessels, lymphedema may result. This disorder often causes lymphedema around puberty or during pregnancy, though it can occur later, until age 35.
Diagnosis: If one is at risk of lymphedema for instance, if one has recently had cancer surgery involving the lymph nodes the doctor may diagnose lymphedema based on the signs and symptoms. If the cause of the lymphedema isn't as obvious, the doctor may order imaging tests to get a look at the lymph system.
Treatment: Light exercises in which one move the affected limb may encourage lymph fluid drainage and help prepare one for everyday tasks, such as carrying groceries. A sleeve worn over the affected arm or leg connects to a pump that intermittently inflates the sleeve, putting pressure on the limb and moving lymph fluid away from the fingers or toes. Long sleeves or stockings made to compress the arm or leg encourage the flow of the lymph fluid out of the affected limb. If one has difficulties putting on or taking off the compression garment, there are special techniques and aids to help with this; the lymphedema therapist can review options with one. In cases of severe lymphedema, the doctor may consider surgery to remove excess tissue in the arm or leg to reduce swelling.
info-Specialty: Vascular medicine, Rheumatology, Physical medicine and rehabilitation General surgery, Plastic surgery

Name: Lymphoma
Overview: The body's lymphatic system is part of the immune system, which protects one against infection and disease. The lymphatic system includes the spleen, thymus, lymph nodes and lymph channels, as well as the tonsils and adenoids. Lymphoma is a cancer of the lymphatic system, which is part of the body's germ-fighting network. The lymphatic system includes the lymph nodes (lymph glands), spleen, thymus gland and bone marrow.
Risk factors: Some types of lymphoma are more common in young adults, while others are most often diagnosed in people over 55. Lymphoma is more common in people with immune system diseases or in people who take drugs that suppress their immune system. Some infections are associated with an increased risk of lymphoma, including the Epstein-Barr virus and Helicobacter pylori infection.
Treatment: The concern and understanding of a counselor, medical social worker, clergy member or cancer support group also may be helpful. If the doctor suspects one has lymphoma, he or she may refer one to a doctor who specializes in diseases that affect the blood cells (hematologist). Chemotherapy uses drugs to destroy fast-growing cells, such as cancer cells. Radiation therapy uses high-powered beams of energy, such as X-rays and protons, to kill cancer cells. A bone marrow transplant, also known as a stem cell transplant, involves using high doses of chemotherapy and radiation to suppress the bone marrow. A specialized treatment called chimeric antigen receptor (CAR)-T cell therapy takes the body's germ-fighting T cells, engineers them to fight cancer and infuses them back into the body. If oned like to know more about the lymphoma, ask the doctor for the details of the cancer the type, the stage and the prognosis. The concern and understanding of a counselor, medical social worker, clergy member or cancer support group also may be helpful.Ask the doctor about support groups in the area.
info-Symptoms: Enlarged lymph nodes, fever, sweats, unintended weight loss, itching, feeling tired
info-Risk factors: Epsteinâ€“Barr virus, autoimmune diseases, HIV/AIDS, tobacco smoking
info-Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, proton therapy, targeted therapy, surgery

Name: Lymphoma , Hodgkin 's
Overview: The body's lymphatic system is part of the immune system, which protects one against infection and disease. Hodgkin's lymphoma formerly known as Hodgkin's disease is a cancer of the lymphatic system, which is part of the immune system. In Hodgkin's lymphoma, cells in the lymphatic system grow abnormally and may spread beyond it.
Causes: Various types of Hodgkin's lymphoma exist. Classical Hodgkin's lymphoma is the more common type of this disease. People with this type of Hodgkin's lymphoma may have a better chance of a cure when the disease is diagnosed at an early stage.
Diagnosis: In a bone marrow aspiration, a doctor or nurse uses a thin needle to remove a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot in the back of the hipbone (pelvis). He or she may then have one undergo tests and procedures used to diagnose Hodgkin's lymphoma, including Other tests and procedures may be used depending on the situation. After the doctor has determined the extent of the Hodgkin's lymphoma, the cancer will be assigned a stage. Stages of Hodgkin's lymphoma include Additionally, the doctor uses the letters A and B to indicate whether one is experiencing symptoms of Hodgkin's lymphoma: Many types of Hodgkin's lymphoma exist, including rare forms that are difficult for inexperienced pathologists to identify. The doctor may recommend imaging tests to look for signs of Hodgkin's lymphoma in other areas of the body. He or she will diagnose classical Hodgkin's lymphoma if abnormal cells called Reed-Sternberg cells are found within the lymph node. In this stage, the cancer is in two lymph node regions or the cancer has invaded one organ and the nearby lymph nodes. When the cancer moves to lymph nodes both above and below the diaphragm, it's considered stage III. Stage IV Hodgkin's lymphoma affects not only the lymph nodes but also other parts of the body, such as the liver, lungs or bones.

Name: Lynch syndrome
Diagnosis: If it's suspected that one has Lynch syndrome, the doctor may ask one questions about the family history of colon cancer, endometrial cancer and other cancers. The doctor may refer one for further Lynch syndrome evaluation if one has: If one or someone in the family has been diagnosed with cancer, special testing may reveal whether the tumor has specific characteristics of Lynch syndrome cancers. Tumor testing can reveal whether the cancer was caused by the genes related to Lynch syndrome. But the results can't tell one whether one has Lynch syndrome because some people develop these gene mutations only in their cancer cells. Increasingly, IHC or MSI testing is being offered to anyone diagnosed with colon cancer or endometrial cancer to look for Lynch syndrome. Sometimes genetic testing for Lynch syndrome is part of a test for multiple cancer-related genetic mutations.

Name: Macular degeneration , dry
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of macular degeneration include Age. Smoking cigarettes or being regularly exposed to smoke significantly increases the risk of macular degeneration. Research indicates that being obese may increase the chance that early or intermediate macular degeneration will progress to the more severe form of the disease. If one has had diseases that affected the heart and blood vessels, one may be at higher risk of macular degeneration.
Diagnosis: Viewing an Amsler grid in an advanced stage of macular degeneration, one may see distorted grid lines or a blank spot near the center of the grid (right). The appearance of drusen yellow deposits in the retina indicates the development of early-stage dry macular degeneration (left). During an eye examination, the eye doctor may use an Amsler grid to test for defects in the center of the vision. Macular degeneration may cause some of the straight lines in the grid to look faded, broken or distorted.
Remedies: Even after receiving a diagnosis of dry macular degeneration, one can take steps that may help slow vision loss. Kale, spinach, broccoli, squash and other vegetables have high levels of antioxidants, including lutein and zeaxanthin, which may benefit people with macular degeneration. And research studies have shown that a diet high in omega-3 fatty acids, such as found in salmon, tuna and walnuts, may lower the risk for advanced AMD. For people with intermediate or advanced disease, taking a high-dose formulation of antioxidant vitamins and minerals may help reduce the risk of vision loss, the American Academy of Ophthalmology says.

Name: Macular degeneration , wet
Overview: As macular degeneration develops, clear, normal vision (shown left) becomes impaired by a distorted blur with missing areas. With advanced macular degeneration, a blind spot typically forms at the center of the visual field (shown right).
Causes: Wet macular degeneration can develop in different ways: Vision loss caused by abnormal blood vessel growth. The choroid is the layer of blood vessels between the retina and the outer, firm coat of the eye (sclera).
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of macular degeneration include Age. Smoking cigarettes or being regularly exposed to smoke significantly increases the risk of macular degeneration. Research indicates that being obese increases the chance that early or intermediate macular degeneration will progress to a more severe form of the disease. If one has diseases that affect the heart and blood vessels, one may be at higher risk of macular degeneration.
Diagnosis: The appearance of drusen yellow deposits in the retina indicates the development of early-stage dry macular degeneration (left). Viewing an Amsler grid in an advanced stage of macular degeneration, one may see distorted grid lines or a blank spot near the center of the grid (right). To confirm a diagnosis of macular degeneration, he or she may do several other tests, including Examination of the back of the eye. During an eye exam, the eye doctor may use an Amsler grid to test for defects in the central vision.
Remedies: Even after receiving a diagnosis of wet macular degeneration, one can take steps that may help slow vision loss. Kale, spinach, broccoli, squash and other vegetables have high levels of antioxidants, including lutein and zeaxanthin, which may benefit people with macular degeneration. And research studies have shown that a diet high in omega-3 fatty acids, such as those found in salmon, tuna and walnuts, may lower the risk of advanced macular degeneration. For people with intermediate or advanced disease, taking a high-dose formulation of antioxidant vitamins and minerals may help reduce the risk of vision loss, the American Academy of Ophthalmology says. If one has cardiovascular disease or high blood pressure, for example, take the medication and follow the doctor's instructions for controlling the condition.
Medication: In some instances, one may partially recover vision as the blood vessels shrink and the fluid under the retina absorbs, allowing retinal cells to regain some function. During photodynamic therapy, the doctor injects a drug called verteporfin (Visudyne) into a vein in the arm, which travels to blood vessels in the eye. One may need repeated treatments over time, as the treated blood vessels may reopen. During photocoagulation therapy, the doctor uses a high-energy laser beam to seal abnormal blood vessels under the macula. It may be beneficial for one to work with a low vision rehabilitation specialist, an occupational therapist, the eye doctor and others trained in low vision rehabilitation.

Name: Major depressive disorder
Symptoms: Although depression may occur only once during the life, people typically have multiple episodes. Unfortunately, depression often goes undiagnosed and untreated in older adults, and they may feel reluctant to seek help. If one think one may hurt theself or attempt suicide, call 911 or the local emergency number immediately.
Overview: Depression is a mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. Also called major depressive disorder or clinical depression, it affects how one feel, think and behave and can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems.
Causes: Changes in the body's balance of hormones may be involved in causing or triggering depression. Hormone changes can result with pregnancy and during the weeks or months after delivery (postpartum) and from thyroid problems, menopause or a number of other conditions.
Diagnosis: A specifier means that one has depression with specific features, such as: Several other disorders, such as those below, include depression as a symptom. The mental health professional may use the criteria for depression listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association. Anxious distress depression with unusual restlessness or worry about possible events or loss of control Mixed features simultaneous depression and mania, which includes elevated self-esteem, talking too much and increased energy Melancholic features severe depression with lack of response to something that used to bring pleasure and associated with early morning awakening, worsened mood in the morning, major changes in appetite, and feelings of guilt, agitation or sluggishness Atypical features depression that includes the ability to temporarily be cheered by happy events, increased appetite, excessive need for sleep, sensitivity to rejection, and a heavy feeling in the arms or legs Psychotic features depression accompanied by delusions or hallucinations, which may involve personal inadequacy or other negative themes Catatonia depression that includes motor activity that involves either uncontrollable and purposeless movement or fixed and inflexible posture Peripartum onset depression that occurs during pregnancy or in the weeks or months after delivery (postpartum) Seasonal pattern depression related to changes in seasons and reduced exposure to sunlight Bipolar I and II disorders. This involves depression symptoms associated with hormone changes that begin a week before and improve within a few days after the onset of the period, and are minimal or gone after completion of the period.
Remedies: But in addition to professional treatment, these self-care steps can help: Stick to the treatment plan. If one stop, depression symptoms may come back, and one could also experience withdrawal-like symptoms. It may seem like alcohol or drugs lessen depression symptoms, but in the long run they generally worsen symptoms and make depression harder to treat.
Medication: In some cases, where available, results of genetic tests (done by a blood test or cheek swab) may offer clues about how the body may respond to a particular antidepressant. Antidepressants aren't considered addictive, but sometimes physical dependence (which is different from addiction) can occur. If one is pregnant or breast-feeding, some antidepressants may pose an increased health risk to the unborn child or nursing child. Most antidepressants are generally safe, but the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) requires all antidepressants to carry a black box warning, the strictest warning for prescriptions. In some cases, children, teenagers and young adults under age 25 may have an increase in suicidal thoughts or behavior when taking antidepressants, especially in the first few weeks after starting or when the dose is changed. For some people, other procedures, sometimes called brain stimulation therapies, may be suggested: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). SSRIs include citalopram (Celexa), escitalopram (Lexapro), fluoxetine (Prozac), paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva), sertraline (Zoloft) and vilazodone (Viibryd). Examples of SNRIs include duloxetine (Cymbalta), venlafaxine (Effexor XR), desvenlafaxine (Pristiq, Khedezla) and levomilnacipran (Fetzima). They include bupropion (Wellbutrin XL, Wellbutrin SR, Aplenzin, Forfivo XL), mirtazapine (Remeron), nefazodone, trazodone and vortioxetine (Trintellix). These drugs such as imipramine (Tofranil), nortriptyline (Pamelor), amitriptyline, doxepin, trimipramine (Surmontil), desipramine (Norpramin) and protriptyline (Vivactil) can be very effective, but tend to cause more-severe side effects than newer antidepressants. MAOIs such as tranylcypromine (Parnate), phenelzine (Nardil) and isocarboxazid (Marplan) may be prescribed, typically when other drugs haven't worked, because they can have serious side effects. Selegiline (Emsam), a newer MAOI that sticks on the skin as a patch, may cause fewer side effects than other MAOIs do. Adjust to a crisis or other current difficulty Identify negative beliefs and behaviors and replace them with healthy, positive ones Explore relationships and experiences, and develop positive interactions with others Find better ways to cope and solve problems Identify issues that contribute to the depression and change behaviors that make it worse Regain a sense of satisfaction and control in the life and help ease depression symptoms, such as hopelessness and anger Learn to set realistic goals for the life Develop the ability to tolerate and accept distress using healthier behaviors Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). ECT is usually used for people who don't get better with medications, can't take antidepressants for health reasons or are at high risk of suicide.
info-Symptoms: Low mood, low self-esteem, loss of interest in normally enjoyable activities, low energy, pain without a clear cause
info-Causes: environmental (adverse life experiences, stressful life events), Genetic and psychological factors
info-Risk factors: Family history, major life changes, certain medications, chronic health problems, substance use disorder
info-Treatment: Psychotherapy, antidepressant medication, electroconvulsive therapy, exercise

Name: Malaria
Overview: Malaria is a disease caused by a parasite. If one is traveling to locations where malaria is common, take steps to prevent mosquito bites by wearing protective clothing, using insect repellants and sleeping under treated mosquito nets.
Causes: Malaria spreads when a mosquito becomes infected with the disease after biting an infected person, and the infected mosquito then bites a noninfected person. The malaria parasites enter that person's bloodstream and travel to the liver. When the parasites mature, they leave the liver and infect red blood cells. Because the parasites that cause malaria affect red blood cells, people can also catch malaria from exposure to infected blood, including Uninfected mosquito. If this mosquito bites one in the future, it can transmit malaria parasites to one. Once the parasites enter the body, they travel to the liver where some types can lie dormant for as long as a year. When the parasites mature, they leave the liver and infect the red blood cells.
info-Symptoms: Fever, vomiting, headache, yellow skin
info-Diagnostic method: Examination of the blood, antigen detection tests
info-Prevention: Mosquito nets, insect repellent, mosquito control, medications

Name: Male breast cancer
Causes: Breast tissue consists of milk-producing glands (lobules), ducts that carry milk to the nipples, and fat. But because men are born with a small amount of breast tissue, they can develop breast cancer. Types of breast cancer diagnosed in men include Some men inherit abnormal (mutated) genes from their parents that increase the risk of breast cancer. Mutations in one of several genes, especially a gene called BRCA2, put one at greater risk of developing breast and prostate cancers. Other, rarer types of breast cancer that can occur in men include Paget's disease of the nipple and inflammatory breast cancer.
Risk factors: If one take estrogen-related drugs, such as those used for hormone therapy for prostate cancer, the risk of breast cancer is increased. As a result, men with this syndrome produce lower levels of certain male hormones (androgens) and more female hormones (estrogens). Certain conditions, such as cirrhosis of the liver, can reduce male hormones and increase female hormones, increasing the risk of breast cancer. Obesity is associated with higher levels of estrogen in the body, which increases the risk of male breast cancer. Having inflamed testicles (orchitis) or surgery to remove a testicle (orchiectomy) can increase the risk of male breast cancer.
Diagnosis: The doctor may conduct a number of diagnostic tests and procedures, such as: Removing a sample of breast cells for testing (biopsy). A biopsy sample is also analyzed to determine the type of cells involved in the breast cancer, the aggressiveness (grade) of the cancer, and whether the cancer cells have hormone receptors or other receptors that may influence the treatment options.

Name: Male infertility
Causes: To get the partner pregnant, the following must occur: Problems with male fertility can be caused by a number of health issues and medical treatments. Although the exact reason that varicoceles cause infertility is unknown, it may be related to abnormal testicular temperature regulation. Treating the varicocele can improve sperm numbers and function, and may potentially improve outcomes when using assisted reproductive techniques such as in vitro fertilization. Some men with spinal cord injuries or certain diseases can't ejaculate semen, even though they still produce sperm. Overexposure to certain environmental elements such as heat, toxins and chemicals can reduce sperm production or sperm function. Although studies are limited and are inconclusive, frequent use of saunas or hot tubs may temporarily impair the sperm count. At least one of the testicles must be functioning correctly, and the body must produce testosterone and other hormones to trigger and maintain sperm production. Once sperm are produced in the testicles, delicate tubes transport them until they mix with semen and are ejaculated out of the penis. If the movement (motility) or function of the sperm is abnormal, the sperm may not be able to reach or penetrate the partner's egg. Although some infections can result in permanent testicular damage, most often sperm can still be retrieved. In some males, during fetal development one or both testicles fail to descend from the abdomen into the sac that normally contains the testicles (scrotum). Infertility can result from disorders of the testicles themselves or an abnormality affecting other hormonal systems including the hypothalamus, pituitary, thyroid and adrenal glands. A digestive disorder caused by sensitivity to gluten, celiac disease can cause male infertility. In most cases, surgery can be performed to either reverse these blockage or to retrieve sperm directly from the epididymis and testicles. Extended exposure to benzenes, toluene, xylene, pesticides, herbicides, organic solvents, painting materials and lead may contribute to low sperm counts. Exposure to radiation can reduce sperm production, though it will often eventually return to normal. With high doses of radiation, sperm production can be permanently reduced. Drinking alcohol can lower testosterone levels, cause erectile dysfunction and decrease sperm production. Severe or prolonged emotional stress, including problems with fertility, can affect the sperm count. In addition, depression in men may cause sexual dysfunction due to reduced libido, erectile dysfunction, or delayed or inhibited ejaculation. Obesity can impair fertility in several ways, including directly impacting sperm themselves as well as by causing hormone changes that reduce male fertility.
Diagnosis: In most cases, several semen analysis tests are done over a period of time to ensure accurate results. If the sperm analysis is normal, the doctor will likely recommend thorough testing of the female partner before conducting any more male infertility tests. Hormones produced by the pituitary gland, hypothalamus and testicles play a key role in sexual development and sperm production. If the results of the testicular biopsy show that sperm production is normal, the problem is likely caused by a blockage or another problem with sperm transport. A number of tests can be used to check how well the sperm survive after ejaculation, how well they can penetrate an egg and whether there's any problem attaching to the egg.
Treatment: Even if an exact cause isn't clear, the doctor might be able to recommend treatments or procedures that will result in conception. The doctor might recommend hormone replacement or medications in cases where infertility is caused by high or low levels of certain hormones or problems with the way the body uses hormones. ART treatments involve obtaining sperm through normal ejaculation, surgical extraction or from donor individuals, depending on the specific case and wishes.

Name: Malignant hyperthermia
Overview: Malignant hyperthermia is a severe reaction to certain drugs used for anesthesia. In most cases, the defective gene that puts one at risk of malignant hyperthermia is inherited, though sometimes it's the result of a random genetic defect. Treatments for malignant hyperthermia include the medication dantrolene (Dantrium, Ryanodex, Revonto), ice packs and other measures to cool body temperature, as well as supportive care.
Causes: Malignant hyperthermia susceptibility (MHS) is caused by a genetic defect (mutation). The abnormal gene increases the risk of malignant hyperthermia when one is exposed to certain anesthesia medications that trigger a reaction.
Risk factors: The risk of having malignant hyperthermia is also higher if one or a close relative has: If one of the parents has the abnormal gene, one has a 50% chance of having it too (autosomal dominant inheritance pattern). A history of an event that is suspected to be malignant hyperthermia during anesthesia A history of muscle tissue breakdown called rhabdomyolysis, which can be triggered by exercise in extreme heat and humidity or when taking a statin drug Certain muscle diseases and disorders caused by inherited abnormal genes
Diagnosis: Testing to find out if one is at increased risk of malignant hyperthermia (susceptibility testing) may be recommended if one has risk factors. Genetic testing can reveal changes (mutations) in the genes that may make one susceptible to malignant hyperthermia.
Treatment: If one or someone in the family has malignant hyperthermia and one need to have anesthesia, it's important to tell the doctor and anesthesiologist. A drug called dantrolene (Dantrium, Ryanodex, Revonto) is used to treat the reaction by stopping the release of calcium into the muscle. Ice packs, cooling blankets, a fan with cool mist and chilled intravenous (IV) fluids may be used to help reduce body temperature. One may need to stay in the hospital in intensive care for a day or two to monitor the temperature, blood pressure, heart rate, breathing and response to treatment.
info-Symptoms: Muscle rigidity, high body temperature, fast heart rate
info-Causes: Volatile anesthetic agents or succinylcholine in those who are susceptible
info-Prevention: Avoiding potential triggers in those susceptible
info-Frequency: ~1 in 25,000 cases where anesthetic gases are used

Name: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors
Overview: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors are a rare type of cancer that occurs in the lining of the nerves that extend from the spinal cord into the body. Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors can occur anywhere in the body, but most often occur in the deep tissue of the arms, legs and trunk.
Diagnosis: A detailed, comprehensive neurological examination helps the doctor understand the symptoms and gather clues about the diagnosis. Imaging tests help doctors understand the size of a tumor and look for signs that cancer has spread to other areas of the body. Imaging tests may include an MRI, magnetic resonance neurography, CT and positron emission tomography (PET).
Treatment: Depending on the location and size of the malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, surgery can cause nerve damage and disability. If one is diagnosed with a malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, one will likely be referred to a doctor who specializes in: Because appointments can be brief and because there's often a lot of ground to cover, it's a good idea to be well-prepared. After surgery, radiation therapy may be used to kill any cancer cells that might remain. If the malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor has spread to other parts of the body, the doctor may recommend chemotherapy to control the symptoms and slow the growth of the cancer.

Name: Mallet toe and hammertoe
Overview: A hammertoe is curled due to a bend in the middle joint of the toe. Hammertoe and mallet toe are foot deformities that occur due to an imbalance in the muscles, tendons or ligaments that normally hold the toe straight.
Causes: High-heeled shoes or footwear that's too tight in the toe box can crowd the toes into a space in which they can't lie flat. An injury in which one stub, jam or break a toe can make it more likely for that digit to develop hammertoe or mallet toe.
Risk factors: Factors that can increase one risk of hammertoe and mallet toe include Age. The risk of hammertoe and mallet toe increases with age. Women are much more likely to develop hammertoe or mallet toe than are men. If the second toe is longer than the big toe, it's at higher risk of hammertoe or mallet toe.
Treatment: If the toe is still flexible, the doctor might recommend that one change to roomier, more comfortable footwear and that one wear shoe inserts (orthotics) or pads. If conservative treatments don't help, the doctor might recommend surgery to release the tendon that's preventing the toe from lying flat.

Name: Mammary duct ectasia
Overview: Mammary duct ectasia occurs when one or more milk ducts beneath the nipple becomes wider (dilated). Mammary duct ectasia usually causes no signs or symptoms, but some women may have nipple discharge, breast tenderness or inflammation of the clogged duct. The condition often causes no symptoms, but some women may have nipple discharge, breast tenderness or inflammation of the clogged duct (periductal mastitis).
Causes: The breasts are made up of connective tissues that include a system of tiny passages that carry milk to the nipples (milk ducts). These normal breast changes can sometimes lead to a blocked milk duct and the inflammation associated with mammary duct ectasia. Cigarette smoking may be associated with widening of milk ducts, which can lead to inflammation and, possibly, mammary duct ectasia. A newly inverted nipple may obstruct milk ducts, causing inflammation and infection.
Treatment: If the symptoms are bothersome, however, treatment options may include To relieve discomfort associated with mammary duct ectasia, one might try these self-care measures: For evaluation of a new breast lump or changes in the breast, one is likely to start by seeing the primary care doctor. In some cases, based on a clinical breast exam or findings on the mammogram or ultrasound, one may be referred to a breast health specialist. One could try a mild pain reliever, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), as needed for breast discomfort. If an abscess has developed and antibiotics and self-care don't work, the affected milk duct may be surgically removed.
info-Symptoms: nipple retraction, inversion, pain, green-brown discharge

Name: Manic-depressive illness
Symptoms: Although bipolar disorder can occur at any age, typically it's diagnosed in the teenage years or early 20s. In addition, bipolar symptoms may occur during pregnancy or change with the seasons. Children and teens may have distinct major depressive or manic or hypomanic episodes, but the pattern can vary from that of adults with bipolar disorder. The most prominent signs of bipolar disorder in children and teenagers may include severe mood swings that are different from their usual mood swings. And if one is like some people with bipolar disorder, one may enjoy the feelings of euphoria and cycles of being more productive.
Diagnosis: To determine if one has bipolar disorder, the evaluation may include Although diagnosis of children and teenagers with bipolar disorder includes the same criteria that are used for adults, symptoms in children and teens often have different patterns and may not fit neatly into the diagnostic categories. Also, children who have bipolar disorder are frequently also diagnosed with other mental health conditions such as attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) or behavior problems, which can make diagnosis more complicated. The psychiatrist may compare the symptoms with the criteria for bipolar and related disorders in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association.
Treatment: Treatment is best guided by a medical doctor who specializes in diagnosing and treating mental health conditions (psychiatrist) who is skilled in treating bipolar and related disorders. Depending on the needs, treatment may include The primary treatments for bipolar disorder include medications and psychological counseling (psychotherapy) to control symptoms, and also may include education and support groups. Bipolar disorder requires lifelong treatment with medications, even during periods when one feel better.
Remedies: Call the doctor who's treating one for bipolar disorder before one take medications prescribed by another doctor or any over-the-counter supplements or medications. Keeping a record of the daily moods, treatments, sleep, activities and feelings may help identify triggers, effective treatment options and when treatment needs to be adjusted.
Medication: Mild side effects often improve as one find the right medications and doses that work for one, and the body adjusts to the medications. Also, birth control medications may lose effectiveness when taken along with certain bipolar disorder medications. If one is taking medication to treat the bipolar disorder and think one may be pregnant, talk to the doctor right away. ECT may be an option for bipolar treatment if one don't get better with medications, can't take antidepressants for health reasons such as pregnancy or are at high risk of suicide. Treatments for children and teenagers are generally decided on a case-by-case basis, depending on symptoms, medication side effects and other factors. Examples of mood stabilizers include lithium (Lithobid), valproic acid (Depakene), divalproex sodium (Depakote), carbamazepine (Tegretol, Equetro, others) and lamotrigine (Lamictal). If symptoms of depression or mania persist in spite of treatment with other medications, adding an antipsychotic drug such as olanzapine (Zyprexa), risperidone (Risperdal), quetiapine (Seroquel), aripiprazole (Abilify), ziprasidone (Geodon), lurasidone (Latuda) or asenapine (Saphris) may help. There's less research on the safety and effectiveness of bipolar medications in children than in adults, so treatment decisions are often based on adult research. Psychotherapy can help children and teens manage their routines, develop coping skills, address learning difficulties, resolve social problems, and help strengthen family bonds and communication. And, if needed, it can help treat substance abuse problems common in older children and teens with bipolar disorder. Psychoeducation can include learning the symptoms of bipolar disorder and how they differ from behavior related to the child's developmental age, the situation and appropriate cultural behavior.
info-Symptoms: Periods of depression and elevated mood
info-Risk factors: Family history, childhood abuse, long-term stress

Name: Marburg virus
Causes: Ebola virus has been found in African monkeys, chimps and other nonhuman primates. Marburg virus has been found in monkeys, chimps and fruit bats in Africa. Experts suspect that both viruses are transmitted to humans through an infected animal's bodily fluids. Butchering or eating infected animals can spread the viruses. Tourists in certain African caves and some underground mine workers have been infected with the Marburg virus, possibly through contact with the feces or urine of infected bats.
Risk factors: For most people, the risk of getting Ebola hemorrhagic fever or Marburg hemorrhagic fever is low. One is at increased risk if one visit or work in areas where Ebola virus or Marburg virus outbreaks have occurred. People are more likely to contract the Ebola or Marburg virus if they conduct animal research with monkeys imported from Africa or the Philippines. The bodies of people who have died of Ebola or Marburg hemorrhagic fever are still contagious.
Treatment: Supportive hospital care includes: The possibility of contracting Ebola or Marburg virus is extremely low unless one has had direct contact with the body fluids of an infected person or animal. If one think that one or a family member may have been exposed to one of the viruses, call the doctor or go to the nearest emergency room immediately.

Name: Marfan syndrome
Symptoms: The signs and symptoms of Marfan syndrome vary greatly, even among members of the same family. Marfan syndrome features may include If one think that one or the child may have Marfan syndrome, talk to the doctor or pediatrician.
Diagnosis: Even among members of the same family, the signs and symptoms of Marfan syndrome vary widely both in their features and in their severity. If the doctor suspects Marfan syndrome, one of the first tests he or she may recommend is an echocardiogram. If one is diagnosed with Marfan syndrome, one will need to have regular imaging tests to monitor the size and condition of the aorta. Eye exams that may be needed include Genetic testing is often used to confirm the diagnosis of Marfan syndrome. One may also want to talk to a genetic counselor before starting a family, to see what the chances are of passing on Marfan syndrome to the future children.
info-Symptoms: Tall, thin build; long arms, legs and fingers; flexible fingers and toes
info-Medication: Beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, ACE inhibitors

Name: Mastalgia
Symptoms: Extramammary breast pain feels like it starts in the breast tissue, but its source is actually somewhere else. Pulling a muscle in the chest, for example, can cause pain in the chest wall or rib cage that spreads (radiates) to the breast.
Overview: Breast pain (mastalgia) a common complaint among women can include breast tenderness, sharp burning pain or tightness in the breast tissue. It may occur: Postmenopausal women sometimes have breast pain, but breast pain is more common in younger women who haven't completed menopause. Still, unexplained breast pain that doesn't go away after one or two menstrual cycles or that persists after menopause needs to be evaluated by the doctor.
Causes: Breast pain may also start outside the breast in the chest wall, muscles, joints or heart, for example and radiate to the breast. Certain hormonal medications, including some infertility treatments and oral birth control pills, may be associated with breast pain. Breast pain may be associated with certain antidepressants, including selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressants. Neck, shoulder and back pain may accompany breast pain due to large breasts.
Diagnosis: If the doctor feels a breast lump or unusual thickening, or detects a focused area of pain in the breast tissue, one will need an X-ray exam of the breast that evaluates the area of concern found during the breast exam (diagnostic mammogram). Suspicious breast lumps, areas of thickening or unusual areas seen during imaging exams may require a biopsy before the doctor can make a diagnosis.
Treatment: If one do require treatment, the doctor might recommend that one: Eliminate an underlying cause or aggravating factor. If one take birth control pills, skipping the pill-free week or switching birth control methods may help breast pain symptoms. Tamoxifen, a prescription medication for breast cancer treatment and prevention, may be recommended for some women, but this drug also carries the potential for side effects that may be more bothersome than the breast pain itself.
info-Causes: Menstrual cycle related, birth control pills, hormone therapy, psychiatric medication, breast cancer
info-Treatment: Reassurance after ruling out cancer, medications

Name: Mastitis
Causes: If one is breast-feeding, ducts carry milk from the alveoli toward the dark area of skin in the center of the breast (areola). Most women's breast tissue changes as they age, with more fat relative to the amount of dense tissue. Oxygen and nutrients travel to breast tissue through the blood in the arteries and capillaries thin, fragile blood vessels. If a breast doesn't completely empty at feedings, one of the milk ducts can become clogged.
Treatment: If one has trouble emptying a portion of the breast, apply warm and moist heat to the breast before breast-feeding or pumping milk. Breast-feeding on the affected side first, when the infant is hungrier and sucking more strongly.
info-Symptoms: Localized breast pain and redness, fever

Name: MCAD deficiency
Symptoms: If one notice signs and symptoms of MCAD deficiency or if one has concerns about the child's health, contact the doctor. After the initial evaluation, one may be referred to a doctor trained in evaluating and treating MCAD deficiency and other health care team members such as a dietitian.
Causes: Though both parents are carriers each one has an abnormal gene they typically don't have symptoms of the condition. If one inherit only one affected gene, one won't develop MCAD deficiency, but one is a carrier and can pass the abnormal gene to the children.
Diagnosis: MCAD deficiency is diagnosed through newborn screening followed by genetic testing. Episodes of low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) thought to be caused by MCAD deficiency are evaluated by a discussion of signs and symptoms, as well as dietary habits, usually followed by lab tests to identify problems with metabolism and treat or prevent complications.
Treatment: Newborn screening at birth allows MCAD deficiency to be diagnosed and treated early, before symptoms occur, preventing complications. Infants with MCAD deficiency require frequent feedings with adequate calories from complex carbohydrates to maintain blood sugar and avoid hypoglycemia. Work with the health care team, including a dietitian, to develop a treatment plan tailored to the child?s or the metabolic needs. Recommendations to prevent hypoglycemia generally include The health care team may recommend a carnitine supplement to aid in fatty acid metabolism. Prevention tips include If one or the child has been diagnosed with MCAD deficiency, wear a medical alert bracelet or necklace or carry a medical card. This lets health care providers know of the condition, even in an emergency. Avoid fasting longer than recommended by the health care team Eat regular meals and snacks with adequate calories from complex carbohydrates, such as brown bread, rice, pasta and cereal, for energy needs Choose foods that are high in complex carbohydrates and lower in fat Increase calories by eating extra complex carbohydrates during illness, stress or increased activity Taking simple carbohydrates, such as sugar (glucose) tablets or sweetened, nondiet beverages. Avoid fasting Know the warning signs of hypoglycemia and treat it immediately Eat complex carbohydrates before extra activity or exercise Increase calories with extra complex carbohydrates during illness, stress or increased activity Always carry complex carbohydrate snacks Always carry a source of simple carbohydrates to treat hypoglycemia Learn about the disorder. Help family members, caregivers, teachers and friends understand the condition, the care needed, and the consequences of not following dietary instructions. Medical centers with specialty teams can offer one information about the disorder, as well as nutritional advice and support, and can help one manage care. Medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency full gene analysis, varies.

Name: Medial epicondylitis
Symptoms: By contrast, the pain of tennis elbow usually occurs at the bony bump on the outside of the elbow (lateral epicondyle). Golfer's elbow is characterized by: The pain of golfer's elbow can come on suddenly or gradually. Consult the doctor if rest, ice and over-the-counter pain relievers don't ease the elbow pain and tenderness. Usually felt on the inner side of the elbow, the pain sometimes extends along the inner side of the forearm.
Overview: Golfer's elbow is a condition that causes pain where the tendons of the forearm muscles attach to the bony bump on the inside of the elbow. Tennis players and others who repeatedly use their wrists or clench their fingers also can develop golfer's elbow.
Causes: Golfer's elbow, also known as medial epicondylitis, is caused by damage to the muscles and tendons that control the wrist and fingers. Improper lifting, throwing or hitting, as well as too little warmup or poor conditioning, also can contribute to golfer's elbow. Improper technique with tennis strokes, especially the backhand, can cause injury to the tendon. Football, archery and javelin throwing also can cause golfer's elbow. Lifting weights using improper technique, such as curling the wrists during a biceps exercise, can overload the elbow muscles and tendons.

Name: Medulloblastoma
Diagnosis: If it's suspected that one has a brain tumor, the doctor may recommend a number of tests and procedures, including Imaging tests. A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. Positron emission tomography (PET) may be used for brain imaging, but is generally not as useful for creating images of brain cancer as it is for other types of cancer. A stereotactic needle biopsy may be done for brain tumors in hard to reach areas or very sensitive areas within the brain that might be damaged by a more extensive operation. If it's suspected that the brain tumor may be a result of cancer that has spread from another area of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer originated.

Name: Megacolon
Overview: In children with Hirschsprung's disease, nerves fail to form in all or part of the large intestine (colon). Hirschsprung's (HIRSH-sproongz) disease is a condition that affects the large intestine (colon) and causes problems with passing stool.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of Hirschsprung's disease include Having a sibling who has Hirschsprung's disease. Hirschsprung's disease is associated with certain inherited conditions, such as Down syndrome and other abnormalities present at birth, such as congenital heart disease.
Remedies: If the child has constipation after surgery for Hirschsprung's disease, discuss with the doctor whether to try any of the following: Serve high-fiber foods. Because a sudden increase in high-fiber foods can worsen constipation at first, add high-fiber foods to the child's diet slowly. If the child isn't eating solid foods yet, ask the doctor about formulas that might help relieve constipation. If the child doesn't respond to or can't tolerate increased fiber, water or physical activity, certain laxatives medications to encourage bowel movements might help relieve constipation.

Name: Membranous nephropathy
Overview: Blood enters the kidneys through the renal arteries. Membranous nephropathy (MEM-bruh-nus nuh-FROP-uh-thee) occurs when the small blood vessels in the kidney (glomeruli), which filter wastes from the blood, become damaged and thickened. As a result, proteins leak from the damaged blood vessels into the urine (proteinuria).
Risk factors: Certain diseases and conditions increase the risk of developing membranous nephropathy, such as lupus and other autoimmune diseases. Examples of infections that increase the risk of membranous nephropathy include hepatitis B, hepatitis C and syphilis.
Diagnosis: Sometimes, it's diagnosed when a routine urine test performed for another health reason shows that one has high levels of protein in the urine (proteinuria). Blood, urine and imaging tests can tell the doctor how well the kidneys are working and diagnose membranous nephropathy. A blood sample allows the doctor to check for high cholesterol, high triglycerides, high blood sugar and other factors that can affect the kidneys. Other blood tests can be done to check for autoimmune diseases or viral infections that can cause kidney damage, such as hepatitis B or C. Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) test.
Treatment: However, up to three out of 10 people with membranous nephropathy have their symptoms completely disappear (remission) after five years without any treatment. In cases where membranous nephropathy is caused by a medication or another disease such as cancer stopping the medication or controlling the other disease usually improves the condition.

Name: Meniere 's disease
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of Meniere's disease include After an episode, signs and symptoms improve and might disappear entirely for a while. Episodes of vertigo occur without warning and usually last 20 minutes to several hours, but not more than 24 hours. Hearing loss in Meniere's disease may come and go, particularly early on. People with Meniere's disease often feel pressure in an affected ear (aural fullness).
Diagnosis: A diagnosis of Meniere's disease requires: A hearing test (audiometry) assesses how well one detect sounds at different pitches and volumes and how well one distinguish between similar-sounding words. Tests that assess function of the inner ear include Blood tests and imaging scans such as an MRI may be used to rule out disorders that can cause problems similar to those of Meniere's disease, such as a tumor in the brain or multiple sclerosis. Two episodes of vertigo, each lasting 20 minutes or longer but not longer than 12 hours Hearing loss verified by a hearing test Tinnitus or a feeling of fullness in the ear Exclusion of other known causes of these problems Videonystagmography (VNG). This computerized test reveals which part of the balance system vision, inner ear function, or sensations from the skin, muscles, tendons and joints one rely on the most and which parts may cause problems. It might help to determine if there is an abnormal buildup of fluid in the inner ear, but isn't specific for Meniere's disease.
Remedies: Consider these tips for use during an episode: To avoid triggering a vertigo attack, try the following. During an episode of vertigo, avoid things that can make the signs and symptoms worse, such as sudden movement, bright lights, watching television or reading.
Medication: Some people with Meniere's disease may benefit from other noninvasive therapies and procedures, such as: Positive pressure therapy. For vertigo that's hard to treat, this therapy involves applying pressure to the middle ear to lessen fluid buildup. Medications injected into the middle ear, and then absorbed into the inner ear, may improve vertigo symptoms. Injections available include If vertigo attacks associated with Meniere's disease are severe and debilitating and other treatments don't help, surgery might be an option. Procedures include Motion sickness medications, such as meclizine or diazepam (Valium), may reduce the spinning sensation and help control nausea and vomiting. Gentamicin, an antibiotic that's toxic to the inner ear, reduces the balancing function of the ear, and the other ear assumes responsibility for balance. Although dexamethasone may be slightly less effective than gentamicin, it's less likely than gentamicin to cause further hearing loss. With this procedure, the surgeon removes the balance portion of the inner ear, thereby removing both balance and hearing function from the affected ear.

Name: Meningioma
Overview: Three layers of membranes known as meninges protect the brain and spinal cord. Although not technically a brain tumor, it is included in this category because it may compress or squeeze the adjacent brain, nerves and vessels. Because most meningiomas grow slowly, often without any significant signs and symptoms, they do not always require immediate treatment and may be monitored over time.
Causes: Doctors know that something alters some cells in the meninges to make them multiply out of control, leading to a meningioma tumor. There is no solid evidence to support the assertion that meningiomas occur in association with cellphone use.
Risk factors: Meningiomas are more common in women, leading doctors to believe that female hormones may play a role. Some studies have also suggested a link between breast cancer and meningioma risk related to the role of hormones. A high body mass index (BMI) is an established risk factor for many types of cancers, and a higher prevalence of meningiomas among obese people has been observed in several large studies.
Diagnosis: If the primary care provider suspects a meningioma, one may be referred to a doctor who specializes in neurological conditions (neurologist). To diagnose a meningioma, a neurologist will conduct a thorough neurological exam followed by an imaging test with contrast dye, such as: In some cases, examination of a sample of the tumor (biopsy) may be needed to rule out other types of tumors and confirm a meningioma diagnosis.
info-Symptoms: None, seizures, dementia, trouble talking, vision problems, one sided weakness
info-Risk factors: Ionizing radiation, family history
info-Prognosis: 95% ten year survival with complete removal

Name: Meningitis
Overview: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding the brain and spinal cord. Most cases of meningitis in the United States are caused by a viral infection, but bacterial, parasitic and fungal infections are other causes.
Causes: Viral infections are the most common cause of meningitis, followed by bacterial infections and, rarely, fungal infections. Because bacterial infections can be life-threatening, identifying the cause is essential. Several strains of bacteria can cause acute bacterial meningitis, most commonly: Viral meningitis is usually mild and often clears on its own. Most cases in the United States are caused by a group of viruses known as enteroviruses, which are most common in late summer and early fall. Viruses such as herpes simplex virus, HIV, mumps, West Nile virus and others also can cause viral meningitis. Slow-growing organisms (such as fungi and Mycobacterium tuberculosis) that invade the membranes and fluid surrounding the brain cause chronic meningitis. Cryptococcal meningitis is a common fungal form of the disease that affects people with immune deficiencies, such as AIDS. Meningitis can also result from noninfectious causes, such as chemical reactions, drug allergies, some types of cancer and inflammatory diseases such as sarcoidosis. This bacterium is the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in infants, young children and adults in the United States. Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) bacterium was once the leading cause of bacterial meningitis in children.
Risk factors: College students living in dormitories, personnel on military bases, and children in boarding schools and child care facilities are at greater risk of meningococcal meningitis. Pregnancy increases the risk of listeriosis an infection caused by listeria bacteria, which may also cause meningitis. Listeriosis increases the risk of miscarriage, stillbirth and premature delivery. AIDS, alcoholism, diabetes, use of immunosuppressant drugs and other factors that affect the immune system also make one more susceptible to meningitis. Having the spleen removed also increases the risk, and anyone without a spleen should get vaccinated to minimize that risk.
Diagnosis: In people with meningitis, the CSF often shows a low sugar (glucose) level along with an increased white blood cell count and increased protein.
