If the doctor suspects viral meningitis, he or she may order a DNA-based test known as a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification or a test to check for antibodies against certain viruses to determine the specific cause and determine proper treatment.
info-Symptoms: Fever, headache, neck stiffness

Name: Menopause
Symptoms: Often, menstrual periods will skip a month and return, or skip several months and then start monthly cycles again for a few months. If one has skipped a period but aren't sure one has started the menopausal transition, consider a pregnancy test. Preventive health care as one age may include recommended health screening tests, such as colonoscopy, mammography and triglyceride screening. The doctor might recommend other tests and exams, too, including thyroid testing if suggested by the history, and breast and pelvic exams.
Overview: Menopause is the time that marks the end of the menstrual cycles. But the physical symptoms, such as hot flashes, and emotional symptoms of menopause may disrupt the sleep, lower the energy or affect emotional health.
Causes: As one approach the late 30s, the ovaries start making less estrogen and progesterone the hormones that regulate menstruation and the fertility declines. But surgery that removes both the uterus and the ovaries (total hysterectomy and bilateral oophorectomy) does cause immediate menopause. The halt to menstruation (and fertility) is not always permanent following chemotherapy, so birth control measures may still be desired. Menopause may result from primary ovarian insufficiency when the ovaries fail to produce normal levels of reproductive hormones stemming from genetic factors or autoimmune disease.
Diagnosis: But under certain circumstances, the doctor may recommend blood tests to check the level of: Over-the-counter home tests to check FSH levels in the urine are available. But, since FSH levels rise and fall during the course of the menstrual cycle, home FSH tests can't really tell one whether or not one is definitely in a stage of menopause. Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and estrogen (estradiol), because the FSH levels increase and estradiol levels decrease as menopause occurs Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), because an underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism) can cause symptoms similar to those of menopause
Treatment: Treatments may include Before deciding on any form of treatment, talk with the doctor about the options and the risks and benefits involved with each. Depending on the personal and family medical history, the doctor may recommend estrogen in the lowest dose and the shortest time frame needed to provide symptom relief for one. Long-term use of hormone therapy may have some cardiovascular and breast cancer risks, but starting hormones around the time of menopause has shown benefits for some women.
Remedies: For many women, triggers may include hot beverages, caffeine, spicy foods, alcohol, stress, hot weather and even a warm room. Use over-the-counter, water-based vaginal lubricants (Astroglide, K-Y jelly, others), silicone-based lubricants or moisturizers (Replens, others). Avoid caffeine, which can make it hard to get to sleep, and avoid drinking too much alcohol, which can interrupt sleep. If hot flashes disturb the sleep, one may need to find a way to manage them before one can get adequate rest. Techniques such as deep breathing, paced breathing, guided imagery, massage and progressive muscle relaxation may help with menopausal symptoms. One can find a number of books, CDs and online offerings on different relaxation exercises. Pelvic floor muscle exercises, called Kegel exercises, can improve some forms of urinary incontinence. Get regular physical activity or exercise on most days to help protect against heart disease, diabetes, osteoporosis and other conditions associated with aging.
info-Symptoms: No menstrual periods for a year
info-Causes: Usually a natural change. Can also be caused by surgery that removes both ovaries and some types of chemotherapy.
info-Medication: Menopausal hormone therapy, clonidine, gabapentin, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors

Name: Menstrual bleeding , excessive
Overview: Menorrhagia is the medical term for menstrual periods with abnormally heavy or prolonged bleeding. Although heavy menstrual bleeding is a common concern, most women don't experience blood loss severe enough to be defined as menorrhagia.
Causes: Irregular menstrual bleeding, bleeding after menopause, excessively heavy menstrual flow or bleeding between periods could signal the presence of uterine polyps. With adenomyosis, the same tissue that lines the uterus (endometrial tissue) is present within and grows into the muscular walls of the uterus. In some cases, the cause of heavy menstrual bleeding is unknown, but a number of conditions may cause menorrhagia. If a hormone imbalance occurs, the endometrium develops in excess and eventually sheds by way of heavy menstrual bleeding. A number of conditions can cause hormone imbalances, including polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), obesity, insulin resistance and thyroid problems. Uterine fibroids may cause heavier than normal or prolonged menstrual bleeding. Small, benign growths on the lining of the uterus (uterine polyps) may cause heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding. This condition occurs when glands from the endometrium become embedded in the uterine muscle, often causing heavy bleeding and painful periods. Another cause of heavy bleeding during pregnancy includes an unusual location of the placenta, such as a low-lying placenta or placenta previa. Uterine cancer and cervical cancer can cause excessive menstrual bleeding, especially if one is postmenopausal or have had an abnormal Pap test in the past. Some bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand's disease, a condition in which an important blood-clotting factor is deficient or impaired can cause abnormal menstrual bleeding.
Diagnosis: During hysterosonography (his-tur-o-suh-NOG-ruh-fee), the doctor uses a thin, flexible tube (catheter) to inject salt water (saline) into the hollow part of the uterus. Using an ultrasound probe, the doctor obtains images of the inside of the uterus and checks for any irregularities. During hysteroscopy, the doctor uses a thin, lighted instrument (hysteroscope) to view the inside of the uterus. The doctor will do a physical exam and may recommend one or more tests or procedures such as: Based on the results of the initial tests, the doctor may recommend further testing, including Doctors can be certain of a diagnosis of menorrhagia only after ruling out other menstrual disorders, medical conditions or medications as possible causes or aggravations of this condition. A sample of the blood may be evaluated for iron deficiency (anemia) and other conditions, such as thyroid disorders or blood-clotting abnormalities. This exam involves inserting a thin, lighted instrument through the vagina and cervix into the uterus, which allows the doctor to see the inside of the uterus.
Medication: NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve), help reduce menstrual blood loss. Tranexamic acid (Lysteda) helps reduce menstrual blood loss and only needs to be taken at the time of the bleeding. Aside from providing birth control, oral contraceptives can help regulate menstrual cycles and reduce episodes of excessive or prolonged menstrual bleeding.

Name: Mental illness
Symptoms: If one has any signs or symptoms of a mental illness, see the primary care provider or a mental health professional. Most mental illnesses don't improve on their own, and if untreated, a mental illness may get worse over time and cause serious problems. If one think one may hurt theself or attempt suicide, get help right away: Suicidal thinking doesn't get better on its own so get help. If the loved one shows signs of mental illness, have an open and honest discussion with him or her about the concerns.
Causes: Mental illnesses, in general, are thought to be caused by a variety of genetic and environmental factors: Inherited traits. Certain genes may increase the risk of developing a mental illness, and the life situation may trigger it. Exposure to environmental stressors, inflammatory conditions, toxins, alcohol or drugs while in the womb can sometimes be linked to mental illness.
Diagnosis: The defining symptoms for each mental illness are detailed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association. Examples include autism spectrum disorder, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and learning disorders. The most notable example is schizophrenia, although other classes of disorders can be associated with detachment from reality at times. This class includes disorders with alternating episodes of mania periods of excessive activity, energy and excitement and depression. These include disorders that affect how one feel emotionally, such as the level of sadness and happiness, and they can disrupt the ability to function. A person with one of these disorders may have physical symptoms that cause major emotional distress and problems functioning. The disorders include somatic symptom disorder, illness anxiety disorder and factitious disorder. These disorders include disturbances related to eating that impact nutrition and health, such as anorexia nervosa and binge-eating disorder. These include disorders of sexual response, such as premature ejaculation and female orgasmic disorder. These disorders include problems with emotional and behavioral self-control, such as kleptomania or intermittent explosive disorder. These acquired (rather than developmental) cognitive problems include delirium, as well as neurocognitive disorders due to conditions or diseases such as traumatic brain injury or Alzheimer's disease. Examples include borderline, antisocial and narcissistic personality disorders.
Remedies: In most cases, a mental illness won't get better if one try to treat it on the own without professional care. Maintaining a regular schedule that includes sufficient sleep, healthy eating and regular physical activity are important to the mental health. Avoid decision-making when one is in the depth of mental illness symptoms, since one may not be thinking clearly.
Medication: Although psychiatric medications don't cure mental illness, they can often significantly improve symptoms. Psychiatric medications can also help make other treatments, such as psychotherapy, more effective. Some of the most commonly used classes of prescription psychiatric medications include Psychotherapy, also called talk therapy, involves talking about the condition and related issues with a mental health professional. Psychotherapy often can be successfully completed in a few months, but in some cases, long-term treatment may be needed. Options include 24-hour inpatient care, partial or day hospitalization, or residential treatment, which offers a temporary supportive place to live. Working together, one and the primary care provider or mental health professional can decide which treatment may be best, depending on the symptoms and their severity, the personal preferences, medication side effects, and other factors. In some cases, a mental illness may be so severe that a doctor or loved one may need to guide the care until one is well enough to participate in decision-making. Fast-acting anti-anxiety drugs help with short-term relief, but they also have the potential to cause dependency, so ideally theyd be used short term. Mood stabilizers are most commonly used to treat bipolar disorders, which involves alternating episodes of mania and depression.
info-Symptoms: Agitation, anxiety, depression, mania, paranoia, psychosis
info-Medication: Antidepressants, antipsychotics, anxiolytics, mood stabilizers, stimulants

Name: Meralgia paresthetica
Risk factors: The following might increase the risk of meralgia paresthetica: Extra weight. Being overweight or obese can increase the pressure on the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. A growing belly puts added pressure on the groin, through which the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve passes.
Diagnosis: He or she might test the sensation of the affected thigh, ask one to describe the pain, and ask one to trace the numb or painful area on the thigh. Although no specific changes are evident on X-ray if one has meralgia paresthetica, images of the hip and pelvic area might be helpful to exclude other conditions as a cause of the symptoms. Results of this test are normal in meralgia paresthetica, but the test might be needed to exclude other disorders when the diagnosis isn't clear.
Medication: If symptoms persist for more than two months or the pain is severe, treatment might include Rarely, surgery to decompress the nerve is considered. Possible side effects include joint infection, nerve damage, pain and whitening of skin around the injection site. Side effects include drowsiness, dry mouth, constipation and impaired sexual functioning.

Name: Mesenteric ischemia
Overview: In mesenteric ischemia, a blockage in an artery cuts off blood flow to a portion of the intestine. Sudden loss of blood flow to the small intestine (acute mesenteric ischemia) from a blood clot requires immediate surgery.
Causes: Both acute and chronic mesenteric ischemia are caused by a decrease in blood flow to the small intestine. Acute mesenteric ischemia is most commonly caused by a blood clot in the main mesenteric artery.
Diagnosis: The doctor might recommend a CT scan, MRI or X-ray of the abdomen to determine if the arteries to the small intestine have narrowed. Adding a contrast dye (mesenteric angiogram, CT angiography or magnetic resonance angiography) can help pinpoint the narrowing.
Treatment: If a blood clot causes a sudden loss of blood flow to the small intestine, one might require immediate surgery to treat the mesenteric ischemia. Mesenteric ischemia that develops over time might be treated with a procedure that uses a balloon to open the narrowed area. Mesenteric ischemia can also be treated via open surgery through an incision. Mesenteric arterial ischemia (adults). Acute mesenteric ischemia (part I) Incidence, etiologies and how to improve early diagnosis.
info-Symptoms: Acute: sudden severe painChronic: abdominal pain after eating, unintentional weight loss, vomiting
info-Risk factors: Atrial fibrillation, heart failure, chronic kidney failure, being prone to forming blood clots, previous myocardial infarction
info-Treatment: Stenting, medications to break down clot, surgery
info-Frequency: Acute: 5 per 100,000 per year (developed world)Chronic: 1 per 100,000

Name: Mesenteric lymphadenitis
Overview: The mesentery is a fold of membrane that attaches the intestine to the abdominal wall and holds it in place. When the condition affects the lymph nodes in the membrane that connects the bowel to the abdominal wall (mesentery), it's called mesenteric lymphadenitis (mez-un-TER-ik lim-fad-uh-NIE-tis).
Treatment: Mild, uncomplicated cases of mesenteric lymphadenitis and those caused by a virus usually go away on their own, although full recovery can take four weeks or more. For treatment of fever or pain, consider giving the child infants or children's over-the-counter fever and pain medications such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin, others) as a safer alternative to aspirin. Though aspirin is approved for use in children older than age 3, children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin. This is because aspirin has been linked to Reye's syndrome, a rare but potentially life-threatening condition, in such children. For the pain and fever of mesenteric lymphadenitis, have the child: If the child has signs and symptoms common to mesenteric lymphadenitis, make an appointment with the family doctor or a pediatrician.
Remedies: For the pain and fever of mesenteric lymphadenitis, have the child: Get plenty of rest. A warm, moist washcloth applied to the abdomen can help ease discomfort.
info-Symptoms: fever; Hard, fixed, rapidly growing nodes, indicating a possible cancer or lymphoma; night sweats; Runny nose; sore throat
info-Causes: infections; autoimmune diseases; malignancies;histiocytoses; storage diseases; benign hyperplasia; drug reactions
info-Risk factors: back pain; constipation; urinary frequency

Name: Mesothelioma
Overview: Malignant mesothelioma (me-zoe-thee-lee-O-muh) is a type of cancer that occurs in the thin layer of tissue that covers the majority of the internal organs (mesothelium). Other, rarer types of mesothelioma affect tissue in the abdomen (peritoneal mesothelioma), around the heart and around the testicles.
Causes: In general, cancer begins when a series of changes (mutations) happens in a cell's DNA. It isn't clear what causes the initial genetic mutations that lead to mesothelioma, though researchers have identified factors that may increase the risk. It's likely that cancers form because of an interaction between many factors, such as inherited conditions, the environment, the health conditions and the lifestyle choices.
Risk factors: Asbestos fibers are strong and resistant to heat, making them useful in a wide variety of applications, such as in insulation, brakes, shingles, flooring and many other products. If the dust is inhaled or swallowed, the asbestos fibers will settle in the lungs or in the stomach, where they can cause irritation that may lead to mesothelioma. Factors that may increase the risk of mesothelioma include Personal history of asbestos exposure. If one has been directly exposed to asbestos fibers at work or at home, the risk of mesothelioma is greatly increased.
Diagnosis: Biopsy, a procedure to remove a small portion of tissue for laboratory examination, is the only way to determine whether one has mesothelioma. Once the mesothelioma is confirmed, the doctor may recommend additional tests to understand whether the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes or to other areas of the body.
info-Symptoms: Shortness of breath, swollen abdomen, chest wall pain, cough, feeling tired, weight loss
info-Risk factors: Genetics, infection with simian virus 40
info-Diagnostic method: Medical imaging, examining fluid produced by the cancer, tissue biopsy

Name: Metachromatic leukodystrophy
Symptoms: This is the most common form of metachromatic leukodystrophy, starting around 2 years of age or younger. Although the juvenile form doesn't progress as fast as the late infantile form, survival is generally less than 20 years after symptoms begin. Signs progress slowly and may begin with behavior and psychiatric problems, drug and alcohol misuse, and issues with school and work.
Overview: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a rare hereditary (genetic) disorder that causes fatty substances (lipids) to build up in cells, particularly in the brain, spinal cord and peripheral nerves. There are three forms of metachromatic leukodystrophy, which involve different age ranges: late infantile form, juvenile form and adult form. Depending on the form and age of onset, early identification and treatment may help manage some signs and symptoms and delay progression of the disorder.
Causes: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an inherited disorder caused by an abnormal (mutated) gene. The abnormal recessive gene is located on one of the nonsex chromosomes (autosomes). Rarely, metachromatic leukodystrophy is caused by a deficiency in another kind of protein (activator protein) that breaks down sulfatides.
Diagnosis: The doctor may conduct genetic tests for mutations in the gene associated with metachromatic leukodystrophy. He or she may also recommend testing family members, particularly women who are pregnant (prenatal testing), for mutations in the gene. The doctor may use this test to look for nerve damage (peripheral neuropathy), which is common in people with metachromatic leukodystrophy.
Treatment: Current treatment is aimed at preventing nerve damage, slowing progression of the disorder, preventing complications and providing supportive care. Regular follow-up appointments with a team of medical professionals experienced in managing this disorder may help prevent certain complications and link one with appropriate support at home, school or work. Medications may reduce signs and symptoms, such as behavioral problems, seizures, difficulty with sleeping, gastrointestinal issues, infection and pain. Examples include a wheelchair, walker or other assistive devices; mechanical ventilation to assist with breathing; treatments to prevent or address complications; and long-term care or hospitalization.
info-Symptoms: Progressive neurologic decline
info-Usual onset: Late infantile (1-2 years), juvenile (3-20 years) or adulthood (around 40s)
info-Duration: Late infantile (3-10 years), juvenile and adult (varies)

Name: Metatarsalgia
Causes: Distance runners are at risk of metatarsalgia, primarily because the front of the foot absorbs significant force when a person runs. So can having a second toe that's longer than the big toe, which causes more weight than normal to be shifted to the second metatarsal head. A downward-curling toe (hammertoe) and swollen, painful bumps at the base of the big toes (bunions) can cause metatarsalgia. Because most of the body weight transfers to the forefoot when one move, extra pounds mean more pressure on the metatarsals. High heels, which transfer extra weight to the front of the foot, are a common cause of metatarsalgia in women. Small breaks in the metatarsals or toe bones can be painful and change the way one put weight on the foot.
Diagnosis: To help pinpoint the source of the pain, the doctor will examine the foot while one stand and while one sit and ask about the lifestyle and activity level. One might need an X-ray to identify or rule out a stress fracture or other foot problems.
Treatment: Conservative measures such as resting, changing shoes or using a metatarsal pad might be all one need to relieve signs and symptoms. In rare cases, when conservative measures don't relieve the pain and the metatarsalgia is complicated by foot conditions such as hammertoe, surgery to realign the metatarsal bones might be an option. To help ease the metatarsalgia pain, One will either see the family doctor or general practitioner or be referred to a bone specialist (orthopedist) or a foot specialist (podiatrist). Try ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) or aspirin to reduce pain and inflammation. If insoles don't help, the doctor might recommend arch supports to minimize stress on the metatarsal bones and improve foot function.
Remedies: To help ease the metatarsalgia pain, Rest. Try ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) or aspirin to reduce pain and inflammation. These off-the-shelf pads are placed in the shoes just ahead of the metatarsal bone to help deflect stress from the painful area. If insoles don't help, the doctor might recommend arch supports to minimize stress on the metatarsal bones and improve foot function.

Name: Microcephaly
Overview: Microcephaly (my-kroh-SEF-uh-lee) is a rare neurological condition in which an infant's head is significantly smaller than the heads of other children of the same age and sex. Generally there's no treatment for microcephaly, but early intervention with supportive therapies, such as speech and occupational therapies, may help enhance the child's development and improve quality of life.
Causes: Microcephaly usually is the result of abnormal brain development, which can occur in the womb (congenital) or during infancy. The premature fusing of the joints (sutures) between the bony plates that form an infant's skull keeps the brain from growing. Treating craniosynostosis (kray-nee-o-sin-os-TOE-sis) usually means the infant needs surgery to separate the fused bones. These include toxoplasmosis, cytomegalovirus, German measles (rubella), chickenpox (varicella) and Zika virus. Uncontrolled phenylketonuria (fen-ul-kee-toe-NU-ree-uh), also known as PKU, in the mother.
Treatment: Except for surgery for craniosynostosis, there's generally no treatment that will enlarge the child's head or reverse complications of microcephaly. Early childhood intervention programs that include speech, physical and occupational therapy may help the child strengthen abilities. When one learn the child has microcephaly, the emotions might include anger, fear, worry, sorrow and guilt. Create a team of doctors, teachers and therapists and other professionals who can help one evaluate the resources in the area and explain state and federal programs for children with disabilities. Medical specialties the child might require include pediatrics and developmental pediatrics, infectious diseases, neurology, ophthalmology, genetics and psychology. If one has just learned the child has microcephaly or one suspect the child's head is too small, one is likely to start by seeing the pediatrician.
info-Symptoms: Abnormally small head and brain, neurological impairments
info-Causes: Usually genetic or toxin exposure during pregnancy

Name: Microscopic colitis
Overview: The colon, also called the large intestine, is a long, tubelike organ in the abdomen. Collagenous colitis, in which a thick layer of protein (collagen) develops in colon tissue Lymphocytic colitis, in which white blood cells (lymphocytes) increase in colon tissue Incomplete microscopic colitis, in which there are mixed features of collagenous and lymphocytic colitis.
Risk factors: Risk factors for microscopic colitis include Some research studies indicate that using certain medications may increase the risk of microscopic colitis. People with microscopic colitis sometimes also have an autoimmune disorder, such as celiac disease, thyroid disease, rheumatoid arthritis, type 1 diabetes or psoriasis. Recent research studies have shown an association between tobacco smoking and microscopic colitis, especially in people ages 16 to 44. Pain relievers, such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve) Proton pump inhibitors including lansoprazole (Prevacid), esomeprazole (Nexium), pantoprazole (Protonix), rabeprazole (Aciphex), omeprazole (Prilosec) and dexlansoprazole (Dexilant) Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as sertraline (Zoloft) Acarbose (Precose) Flutamide Ranitidine Carbamazepine (Carbatrol, Tegretol) Clozapine (Clozaril, Fazaclo) Entacapone (Comtan) Paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva) Simvastatin (Zocor) Topiramate
Diagnosis: The doctor will also ask about any medications one is taking particularly aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve), proton pump inhibitors, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) which may increase the risk of microscopic colitis. This procedure is similar to a colonoscopy, but rather than viewing the entire colon, a flexible sigmoidoscopy allows the doctor to view the inside of the rectum and most of the sigmoid colon about the last 2 feet (61 centimeters) of the large intestine. The doctor uses a slender, flexible, lighted tube (sigmoidoscope) to examine the intestinal lining. Because intestinal issues often appear normal in microscopic colitis, a definite diagnosis of microscopic colitis requires a colon tissue sample (biopsy) obtained during a colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy. This exam allows the doctor to view the entire colon using a thin, flexible, lighted tube (colonoscope) with an attached camera.
Remedies: Water is best, but fluids with added sodium and potassium (electrolytes) may help as well. Avoid beverages that are high in sugar or sorbitol or contain alcohol or caffeine, such as coffee, tea and colas, which may aggravate the symptoms. Avoid high-fiber foods such as beans and nuts, and eat only well-cooked vegetables. If one feel as though the symptoms are improving, slowly add high-fiber foods back to the diet.
info-Symptoms: Persistent diarrhea

Name: Migraine
Symptoms: Migraines, which often begin in childhood, adolescence or early adulthood, can progress through four stages: prodrome, aura, attack and post-drome. After a migraine attack, an individual might feel drained, confused and washed out for up to a day.
Overview: A migraine can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. It can also include visual disturbances, such as flashes of light or blind spots, or other disturbances, such as tingling on one side of the face or in an arm or leg and difficulty speaking.
Causes: Though migraine causes aren't fully understood, genetics and environmental factors appear to play a role. Changes in the brainstem and its interactions with the trigeminal nerve, a major pain pathway, might be involved. Certain neurotransmitters play a role in the pain of migraine, including calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP). There are a number of migraine triggers, including Hormonal changes in women. Hormonal medications, such as oral contraceptives and hormone replacement therapy, also can worsen migraines. Some women, however, find their migraines occurring less often when taking these medications. Bright lights and sun glare can induce migraines, as can loud sounds. Strong smells including perfume, paint thinner, secondhand smoke and others trigger migraines in some people. Missing sleep, getting too much sleep or jet lag can trigger migraines in some people. Intense physical exertion, including sexual activity, might provoke migraines. Oral contraceptives and vasodilators, such as nitroglycerin, can aggravate migraines. The causes also include the sweetener aspartame and the preservative monosodium glutamate (MSG), found in many foods.
Risk factors: Several factors make a person more prone to having migraines, including Family history. Migraines can begin at any age, though the first often occurs during adolescence. Migraines tend to peak during the 30s and gradually become less severe and less frequent in the following decades. For women who have migraines, headaches might begin just before or shortly after the onset of menstruation.
Diagnosis: MRI scans help doctors diagnose tumors, strokes, bleeding in the brain, infections, and other brain and nervous system (neurological) conditions. This in turn assists doctors to diagnose possible medical problems that may be causing migraine headaches.
Treatment: The treatment choices depend on the frequency and severity of the headaches, whether an individual has nausea and vomiting with the headaches, how disabling the headaches are, and other medical conditions one has. Also known as an acute or abortive treatment, medicational drugs are taken during migraine attacks and are designed to stop symptoms.
Remedies: Regular exercise can also help one lose weight or maintain a healthy body weight, as obesity is thought to be a factor in migraines. Biofeedback and other forms of relaxation training teach ways to deal with stressful situations, which might help reduce the number of migraines one has.
Medication: Migraine relief medications that combine caffeine, aspirin and acetaminophen (Excedrin Migraine) may be helpful, but usually only against mild migraine pain. Available as a nasal spray or injection, these are most effective when taken shortly after the start of migraine symptoms for migraines that tend to last longer than 24 hours. When taken too long, these might cause medication-overuse headaches, and possibly ulcers and bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract.
info-Symptoms: Headaches, nausea, sensitivity to light, sensitivity to sound, sensitivity to smell
info-Risk factors: Family history, female

Name: Migraine with aura
Symptoms: Migraine aura usually occurs within an hour before head pain begins and generally lasts less than 60 minutes. Sometimes migraine aura occurs with little or no headache, especially in people age 50 and older.
Diagnosis: The doctor might diagnose the migraine with aura based on the signs and symptoms, the medical and family history, and a physical exam. If the aura isn't followed by head pain or if the visual disturbances affect only one eye, the doctor might recommend certain tests to rule out more-serious conditions, such as a retinal tear or a TIA. Assessments might include The doctor might refer one to a doctor who specializes in nervous system disorders (neurologist) to rule out brain conditions that could be causing the symptoms. A thorough eye exam, done by an eye specialist (ophthalmologist), can help rule out eye problems that might be causing aura.
Medication: Depending on how severe the migraine pain is, types of medications that can be used to treat it include Pain relievers. These over-the-counter or prescription pain relievers include aspirin or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others). Migraine relief medications that combine caffeine, aspirin and acetaminophen (Excedrin Migraine) may be helpful, but usually only against mild migraine pain. Available as a nasal spray or injection, these are most effective when taken shortly after the start of migraine symptoms for migraines that tend to last longer than 24 hours. Medications can help prevent frequent migraines, with or without aura. The doctor might recommend preventive medications if one has frequent, long-lasting or severe headaches that don't respond well to treatment. These are prescription drugs such as sumatriptan (Imitrex, Tosymra) and rizatriptan (Maxalt) are prescription drugs used for migraine because they block pain pathways in the brain. Anti-nausea drugs include chlorpromazine, metoclopramide (Reglan) or prochlorperazine (Compro). These include beta blockers such as propranolol (Inderal, Innopran XL, others), metoprolol tartrate (Lopressor) and timolol (Betimol). Calcium channel blockers such as verapamil (Calan, Verelan, others) can be helpful in preventing migraines with aura. Valproate (Depacon) and topiramate (Topamax) might help one has less frequent migraines, but can cause side effects such as dizziness, weight changes, nausea and more. Erenumab (Aimovig), fremanezumab (Ajovy) and galcanezumab (Emgality) are newer drugs approved by the FDA to treat migraines. Biofeedback and other forms of relaxation training teach one ways to deal with stressful situations, which might help reduce the number of migraines one has.

Name: Mild cognitive impairment ( MCI )
Symptoms: But consistent or increasing concern about the mental performance may suggest mild cognitive impairment (MCI). One feel increasingly overwhelmed by making decisions, planning steps to accomplish a task or understanding instructions.
Causes: These MRIs reveal shrinkage of the hippocampus, a part of the brain associated with memory, during the transition from normal cognitive function to mild cognitive impairment. There's no single cause of mild cognitive impairment (MCI), just as there's no single outcome for the disorder. Symptoms of MCI may remain stable for years, progress to Alzheimer's disease or another type of dementia, or improve over time.
Diagnosis: Many doctors diagnose MCI based on the following criteria developed by a panel of international experts: As part of the physical exam, the doctor may perform some basic tests that indicate how well the brain and nervous system are working. These tests can help detect neurological signs of Parkinson's disease, strokes, tumors or other medical conditions that can impair the memory as well as the physical function. The neurological exam may test: Blood tests can help rule out physical problems that can affect memory, such as a vitamin B-12 deficiency or an underactive thyroid gland. The medical history shows that the overall abilities and daily activities generally aren't impaired, although specific symptoms may cause worry and inconvenience. More-detailed neuropsychological testing may help determine the degree of memory impairment, which types of memory are most affected and whether other mental skills also are impaired. The problems that one describe and that the doctor documents through corroborating reports, the medical history, and mental status testing aren't severe enough to be diagnosed as Alzheimer's disease or another type of dementia.

Name: Milia
Overview: Milia are tiny white bumps on a baby's nose, chin or cheeks. Milia are tiny white bumps that appear across a baby's nose, chin or cheeks.
Treatment: Try these tips to help the baby's skin look its best: If one is following a standard well-check schedule, the baby will likely visit with the family doctor or pediatrician soon. These regular appointments offer a good opportunity to discuss concerns about the baby's health. For milia, some basic questions to ask the doctor include Keep the baby's face clean. Wash the baby's face daily with warm water and mild baby soap. Dry the baby's face gently. Simply pat the baby's skin dry. Avoid using lotions or oils on the baby's face. Milia Keep the baby's face clean.
Remedies: Try these tips to help the baby's skin look its best: Keep the baby's face clean. Wash the baby's face daily with warm water and mild baby soap. Avoid using lotions or oils on the baby's face.

Name: Milk allergy
Overview: Milk allergy is an abnormal response by the body's immune system to milk and products containing milk. Cow's milk is the usual cause of milk allergy, but milk from sheep, goats, buffalo and other mammals also can cause a reaction.
Causes: And most people who react to cow's milk will react to sheep's, goat's and buffalo's milk. Less commonly, people allergic to cow's milk are also allergic to soy milk.
Risk factors: Certain factors may increase the risk of developing milk allergy: Other allergies. Children who have atopic dermatitis a common, chronic inflammation of the skin are much more likely to develop a food allergy. A person's risk of a food allergy increases if one or both parents have a food allergy or another type of allergy or allergic disease such as hay fever, asthma, hives or eczema.
Diagnosis: To evaluate whether one or the child has milk allergy, the doctor may: He or she may also recommend one or both of the following tests: If the examination and test results can't confirm milk allergy, the doctor might administer an oral challenge, in which one is fed different foods that may or may not contain milk in increasing amounts to see if one react to the ones that contain milk. Ask detailed questions about signs and symptoms Perform a physical exam Have one keep a detailed diary of the foods one or the child eats Have one eliminate milk from the diet or the child's diet (elimination diet) and then have one add back the food to see if it causes a reaction Skin test.
Treatment: Despite the best efforts, if one or the child accidentally consumes milk, medications such as antihistamines may reduce a mild allergic reaction. If one or the child has a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis), one may need an emergency injection of epinephrine (adrenaline) and a trip to the emergency room. If one is at risk of having a severe reaction, one or the child may need to carry injectable epinephrine (EpiPen, Adrenaclick, others) at all times. Besides offering support and encouragement, they may also provide useful coping tips, such as how to deal effectively with school officials to ensure the child's medical needs are met.

Name: Milk intolerance
Causes: In primary lactose intolerance, lactase production falls off sharply by adulthood, making milk products difficult to digest. This form of lactose intolerance occurs when the small intestine decreases lactase production after an illness, injury or surgery involving the small intestine.
Risk factors: Lactose intolerance is most common in people of African, Asian, Hispanic and American Indian descent. Infants born prematurely might have reduced levels of lactase because the small intestine doesn't develop lactase-producing cells until late in the third trimester. Small intestine problems that can cause lactose intolerance include bacterial overgrowth, celiac disease and Crohn's disease. If one has had radiation therapy for cancer in the stomach or one has intestinal complications from chemotherapy, the risk of developing lactose intolerance increases.
Diagnosis: After one drink a liquid that contains high levels of lactose, the doctor measures the amount of hydrogen in the breath at regular intervals. Two hours after drinking a liquid that contains high levels of lactose, one will undergo blood tests to measure the amount of glucose in the bloodstream.
Remedies: Few people have such severe lactose intolerance that they have to cut out all milk products and be wary of nondairy foods or medications that contain lactose. Calcium is found in many other foods, such as: Also make sure one get enough vitamin D, which is typically supplied in fortified milk. Even without restricting dairy foods, though, many adults don't get enough vitamin D. Talk to the doctor about taking vitamin D and calcium supplements to be sure. Ice cream and milk contain the most lactose, but the high fat content in ice cream might allow one to eat it without symptoms. Broccoli and leafy green vegetables Calcium-fortified products, such as cereals and juices Canned salmon or sardines Milk substitutes, such as soy milk and rice milk Oranges Almonds, Brazil nuts and dried beans Choosing smaller servings of dairy. Over-the-counter tablets or drops containing the lactase enzyme (Lactaid, others) might help one digest dairy products.
info-Symptoms: Abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, flatulence, nausea
info-Causes: Decreased ability to digest lactose (genetic, small intestine injury)
info-Treatment: Decreasing lactose in the diet, lactase supplements, treat the underlying cause
info-Frequency: ~65% of people (less common in Northern Europeans)

Name: Miscarriage
Overview: Miscarriage is the spontaneous loss of a pregnancy before the 20th week. But the actual number is likely higher because many miscarriages occur so early in pregnancy that a woman doesn't realize she's pregnant.
Causes: Chromosomal abnormalities might lead to: Molar pregnancy and partial molar pregnancy. With a molar pregnancy, both sets of chromosomes come from the father. A molar pregnancy is associated with abnormal growth of the placenta; there is usually no fetal development. A partial molar pregnancy occurs when the mother's chromosomes remain, but the father provides two sets of chromosomes. A partial molar pregnancy is usually associated with abnormalities of the placenta, and an abnormal fetus.
Risk factors: Various factors increase the risk of miscarriage, including Age. Women who have a chronic condition, such as uncontrolled diabetes, have a higher risk of miscarriage. Certain uterine abnormalities or weak cervical tissues (incompetent cervix) might increase the risk of miscarriage. Some invasive prenatal genetic tests, such as chorionic villus sampling and amniocentesis, carry a slight risk of miscarriage.
Diagnosis: During an ultrasound, the health care provider will check for a fetal heartbeat and determine if the embryo is developing normally. The health care provider might check the level of the pregnancy hormone, human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG), in the blood and compare it to previous measurements. The health care provider might check to see if one is anemic which could happen if one has experienced significant bleeding and may also check the blood type. If one has passed tissue, it can be sent to a lab to confirm that a miscarriage has occurred and that the symptoms aren't related to another cause. If one has had two or more previous miscarriages, the health care provider may order blood tests for both one and the partner to determine if the chromosomes are a factor. If one pass fetal or placental material but some remains in the uterus, it's considered an incomplete miscarriage.
info-Symptoms: Vaginal bleeding with or without pain
info-Risk factors: Being an older parent, previous miscarriage, exposure to tobacco smoke, obesity, diabetes, autoimmune diseases, drug or alcohol use
info-Diagnostic method: Physical examination, human chorionic gonadotropin, ultrasound
info-Treatment: Expectant management, vacuum aspiration, emotional support

Name: Mitral valve disease
Overview: In mitral valve disease, the mitral valve, which is located between the left heart chambers (left atrium and left ventricle), doesn't work properly. In mitral valve prolapse, the leaflets of the mitral valve bulge (prolapse) into the left atrium like a parachute during the heart's contraction. In this condition, the flaps (leaflets) of the mitral valve don't close tightly, causing blood to leak backward into the left atrium of the heart. This condition is commonly caused by mitral valve prolapse, in which the leaflets bulge back into the left atrium as the heart contracts.
Diagnosis: In a physical examination, the doctor will likely listen for a heart murmur, as this can be a sign of a mitral valve condition. A chest X-ray can help the doctor to determine whether the heart is enlarged, which can be a sign of certain types of heart valve disease. In this procedure, a doctor threads a thin tube (catheter) through a blood vessel in the arm or groin to an artery in the heart and injects dye through the catheter. Cardiac catheterization isn't often used to diagnose mitral valve disease, but it may be used if other tests haven't diagnosed the condition or to check to see if coronary artery disease is present.
Remedies: The doctor may suggest one incorporate several heart-healthy lifestyle changes into the life, including For women with mitral valve disease, it's important to talk with the doctor before one become pregnant. The doctor can discuss with one which medications one can safely take, and whether one may need a procedure to treat the valve condition prior to pregnancy. If one is overweight or obese, the doctor may recommend that one lose weight. Aim to include about 30 minutes of physical activity, such as brisk walks, into the daily fitness routine. Find ways to help manage the stress, such as through relaxation activities, meditation, physical activity, and spending time with family and friends.
info-Symptoms: Heart murmur, shortness of breath during exercise or laying down, fatigue, palpitations, swollen feet or ankles
info-Causes: mitral valve prolapse, ageing, rheumatic fever, mitral annular calcification, infective endocarditis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
info-Treatment: Medication, Mitral valve repair, Mitral valve replacement, MitraClip

Name: Mittelschmerz
Causes: Mittelschmerz occurs during ovulation, when the follicle ruptures and releases its egg. Here in the fallopian tube, the egg may be fertilized by a sperm. If the egg isn't fertilized, it's simply reabsorbed by the body perhaps before it even reaches the uterus. Just before an egg is released with ovulation, follicle growth stretches the surface of the ovary, causing pain. Blood or fluid released from the ruptured follicle irritates the lining of the abdomen (peritoneum), leading to pain.
Treatment: For the relief of discomfort from mittelschmerz, try an over-the-counter drug such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve). If mittelschmerz causes one a lot of discomfort or occurs monthly, ask the doctor about taking birth control pills.

Name: Mixed connective tissue disease
Symptoms: Cold and numb fingers or toes (Raynaud's phenomenon). In response to cold or stress, the fingers or toes might turn white and then purplish blue. After warming, the fingers or toes turn red. Joints can become inflamed, swollen and deformed, similar to what occurs with rheumatoid arthritis.
Overview: Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD) has signs and symptoms of a combination of disorders primarily lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis. In mixed connective tissue disease, the symptoms of the separate diseases usually don't appear all at once.
Treatment: Other ways to control symptoms of mixed connective tissue disease include One might be referred to a doctor who specializes in joint diseases (rheumatologist). Drugs, such as prednisone (Deltasone, Rayos), can help prevent the immune system from attacking healthy cells and suppress inflammation. Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil) can treat mild mixed connective tissue disease and might prevent flare-ups. This category of medications, including nifedipine (Adalat CC, Procardia) and amlodipine (Norvasc), that help relax the muscles in the walls of the blood vessels might be used to treat Raynaud's phenomenon. For example, if they're similar to those of lupus, the doctor might recommend medications typically prescribed for people with lupus. Bosentan (Tracleer) or sildenafil (Revatio, Viagra) might be prescribed. These medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve), might help relieve the pain and inflammation if the condition is mild. Smoking causes blood vessels to narrow, which can worsen the effects of Raynaud's phenomenon.
Remedies: These medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve), might help relieve the pain and inflammation if the condition is mild. Wearing gloves and taking other measures to keep the hands warm can help prevent Raynaud's phenomenon. Smoking causes blood vessels to narrow, which can worsen the effects of Raynaud's phenomenon.

Name: Molar pregnancy
Causes: In a complete molar pregnancy, an empty egg is fertilized by one or two sperm, and all of the genetic material is from the father. In a partial or incomplete molar pregnancy, the mother's chromosomes remain but the father provides two sets of chromosomes. This most often occurs when two sperm fertilize an egg, resulting in an extra copy of the father's genetic material.
Treatment: To treat a molar pregnancy, the doctor will remove the molar tissue from the uterus with a procedure called dilation and curettage (D&C). After the molar tissue is removed, the doctor will repeat measurements of the HCG level until it returns to normal. Once treatment for the molar pregnancy is complete, the doctor may continue to monitor the HCG levels for six months to one year to make sure there's no remaining molar tissue. Because pregnancy HCG levels also increase during a normal pregnancy, the doctor may recommend one wait six to 12 months before trying to become pregnant again. Rarely, if there is increased risk of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) and there's no desire for future pregnancies, the uterus may be removed (hysterectomy).

Name: Mold allergy
Causes: After the exposure has passed, one still produce antibodies that remember this invader so that any later contact with the mold causes the immune system to react. This reaction triggers the release of substances such as histamine, which cause itchy, watery eyes, runny nose, sneezing and other mold allergy symptoms.
Risk factors: A number of factors can make one more likely to develop a mold allergy or worsen the existing mold allergy symptoms, including Living in a house with high humidity. If the indoor humidity is higher than 50 percent, one may have increased exposure to mold in the home. Mold can grow virtually anywhere if the conditions are right in basements, behind walls in framing, on soap-coated grout and other damp surfaces, in carpet pads, and in the carpet itself. Occupations where mold exposure may be high include farming, dairy work, logging, baking, millwork, carpentry, greenhouse work, winemaking and furniture repair. Tight window and door seals may trap moisture indoors and prevent proper ventilation, creating ideal conditions for mold growth.
Treatment: While there's no sure way to cure allergic rhinitis caused by a mold allergy, a number of medications can ease the symptoms. Examples include ciclesonide (Omnaris, Zetonna), fluticasone (Xhance), mometasone (Nasonex), triamcinolone and budesonide (Rhinocort). Nosebleeds and nasal dryness are the most common side effects of these medications, which are generally safe for long-term use. Over-the-counter (OTC) antihistamines include loratadine (Alavert, Claritin), fexofenadine (Allegra Allergy) and cetirizine (Xyzal Allergy 24Hrs, Zyrtec Allergy). The nasal sprays azelastine (Astelin, Astepro) and olopatadine (Patanase) are available by prescription. Use a specially designed squeeze bottle, such as the one included in saline kits (Sinus Rinse, others), bulb syringe or neti pot to irrigate the nasal passages. To keep mold allergy symptoms at bay, take these measures: Many people are diagnosed and treated for allergies by their primary care physicians. Because oral decongestants can raise blood pressure, avoid them if one has high blood pressure (hypertension). Possible side effects include high blood pressure, insomnia, loss of appetite, heart pounding (palpitations), anxiety and restlessness.

Name: Molluscum contagiosum
Overview: Molluscum contagiosum is a common skin infection that results in raised, round, flesh-colored bumps on the skin. Molluscum contagiosum (mo-LUS-kum kun-tay-jee-OH-sum) is a relatively common viral infection of the skin that results in round, firm, painless bumps ranging in size from a pinhead to a pencil eraser.
info-Symptoms: Small, raised, pink lesions with a dimple in the center
info-Duration: Usually 6-12 months, may last up to four years
info-Causes: Molluscum contagiosum virus spread by direct contact or contaminated objects
info-Risk factors: Weak immune system, atopic dermatitis, crowded living conditions
info-Prevention: Hand washing, not sharing personal items
info-Treatment: None, freezing, opening up the lesion and scraping the inside, laser therapy

Name: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance ( MGUS )
Overview: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is a condition in which an abnormal protein known as monoclonal protein or M protein is in the blood. This abnormal protein is formed within the bone marrow, the soft, blood-producing tissue that fills in the center of most of the bones. If one has high amounts of this protein in the blood, it's important to have regular checkups so that one can get earlier treatment if it does progress.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of developing MGUS include Age. Africans and African Americans are more likely to experience MGUS than are white people. One may have a higher risk of MGUS if other people in the family have the condition.
Diagnosis: If one is experiencing bone pain, the doctor might recommend an MRI or ositron emission tomography (PET) scan. Bone marrow analysis is generally done only when one is at risk of developing a more serious disease or if one has unexplained anemia, kidney failure, bone lesions or high calcium levels.

Name: Mononucleosis
Overview: Infectious mononucleosis (mono) is often called the kissing disease. The virus that causes mono is transmitted through saliva, so one can get it through kissing, but one can also be exposed through a cough or sneeze, or by sharing a glass or food utensils with someone who has mono.
Diagnosis: If there's a need for additional confirmation, a monospot test may be done to check the blood for antibodies to the Epstein-Barr virus. A different antibody test requires a longer result time, but can detect the disease even within the first week of symptoms. The doctor may use other blood tests to look for an elevated number of white blood cells (lymphocytes) or abnormal-looking lymphocytes.
Remedies: Besides getting plenty of rest, these steps can help relieve symptoms of mononucleosis: Take an over-the-counter pain reliever. Use pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) as needed. Though aspirin is approved for use in children older than age 3, children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin. To help one avoid the risk of rupturing the spleen, the doctor may suggest that one wait about one month before returning to vigorous activities, heavy lifting, roughhousing or contact sports.
info-Symptoms: Fever, sore throat, enlarged lymph nodes in the neck, tiredness
info-Causes: Epsteinâ€“Barr virus (EBV) usually spread via saliva
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and blood tests
info-Treatment: Drinking enough fluids, getting sufficient rest, pain medications such as paracetamol (acetaminophen) and ibuprofen

Name: Mood disorders
Overview: If one has a mood disorder, the general emotional state or mood is distorted or inconsistent with the circumstances and interferes with the ability to function. Major depressive disorder prolonged and persistent periods of extreme sadness Bipolar disorder also called manic depression or bipolar affective disorder, depression that includes alternating times of depression and mania Seasonal affective disorder (SAD) a form of depression most often associated with fewer hours of daylight in the far northern and southern latitudes from late fall to early spring Cyclothymic disorder a disorder that causes emotional ups and downs that are less extreme than bipolar disorder Premenstrual dysphoric disorder mood changes and irritability that occur during the premenstrual phase of a woman's cycle and go away with the onset of menses Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) a long-term (chronic) form of depression Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder a disorder of chronic, severe and persistent irritability in children that often includes frequent temper outbursts that are inconsistent with the child's developmental age Depression related to medical illness a persistent depressed mood and a significant loss of pleasure in most or all activities that's directly related to the physical effects of another medical condition Depression induced by substance use or medication ?
Treatment: For most people, mood disorders can be successfully treated with medications and talk therapy. In: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders DSM-5.

Name: Morning sickness
Remedies: Select foods that are high in protein, low in fat and easy to digest, and avoid greasy, spicy and fatty foods. Bland foods, such as bananas, rice, applesauce and toast may be easy to digest. Salty foods are sometimes helpful, as are foods that contain ginger such as ginger lollipops. Nibble throughout the day, rather than eating three larger meals so that the stomach doesn't get too full. If one feel queasy after taking prenatal vitamins, take the vitamins with a snack or just before bed. If these steps don't help, ask the health care provider about other ways one can get the iron and vitamins one need during pregnancy.
info-Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms after other causes have been ruled out

Name: Morphea
Overview: Morphea is a rare skin condition characterized by small red or purple patches that develop firm white or ivory centers. Morphea (mor-FEE-uh) is a rare skin condition that causes painless, discolored patches on the skin.
Diagnosis: He or she may take a small sample of the affected skin (skin biopsy) for examination in the laboratory. This may reveal changes in the skin, such as thickening of a protein (collagen) in the second layer of skin (dermis). So the doctor may refer one to a specialist in skin disorders (dermatologist) or diseases of the joints, bones and muscles (rheumatologist).
Treatment: Morphea usually goes away without treatment, though it may leave scars or areas of discolored skin. The doctor may prescribe a vitamin D cream, such as calcipotriene (Calcipotriene, Dovonex, Taclonex), to help soften the skin patches. For severe or widespread morphea, treatment may include the use of ultraviolet light (phototherapy). For severe or widespread morphea, the doctor may prescribe an immunosuppressive medication, such as oral methotrexate (Trexall), corticosteroid pills or both.

Name: Mosquito bites
Remedies: There are millions of mosquitoes swarming this summer, sucking blood and leaving itchy, red bumps on the skin. Their saliva deposits in the skin from where the bite is, and it's causing a reaction to that saliva. Calamine lotion, over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream and even a cold compress can ease the itch. Although using insect repellent and other prevention tips can reduce the chances of being bit, really, getting at least one skeeter bite this summer is almost inevitable. Try soothing the bite by applying a cold pack or a cool, moist cloth for a few minutes.

Name: Movement disorders
Overview: The term movement disorders refers to a group of nervous system (neurological) conditions that cause abnormal increased movements, which may be voluntary or involuntary. Ataxia may cause uncoordinated or clumsy balance, speech or limb movements, and other symptoms. This condition causes long-lasting contractions (spasms) or intermittent contractions of the neck muscles, causing the neck to turn in different ways. Chorea is characterized by repetitive, brief, irregular, somewhat rapid, involuntary movements that typically involve the face, mouth, trunk and limbs. This condition involves sustained involuntary muscle contractions with twisting, repetitive movements. This condition may resemble any of the movement disorders, but is not due to neurological disease. This is an inherited progressive, neurodegenerative disorder that causes uncontrolled movements (chorea), impaired cognitive abilities and psychiatric conditions. Multiple system atrophy causes a movement disorder, such as ataxia or parkinsonism. This slowly progressive, neurodegenerative disorder causes tremor, stiffness (rigidity), slow decreased movement (bradykinesia) or imbalance. This is a rare neurological disorder that causes problems with walking, balance and eye movements. This movement disorder causes unpleasant, abnormal feelings in the legs while relaxing or lying down, often relieved by movement. Tardive dyskinesia causes repetitive and involuntary movements such as grimacing, eye blinking and other movements. This is a neurological condition that starts between childhood and teenage years and is associated with repetitive movements (motor tics) and vocal sounds (vocal tics). This movement disorder causes involuntary rhythmic shaking of parts of the body, such as the hands, head or other parts of the body. This is a rare inherited disorder that causes excessive amounts of copper to build up in the body, causing neurological problems.

Name: Moyamoya disease
Symptoms: The first symptom of moyamoya disease is usually stroke or recurrent transient ischemic attack (TIA), especially in children. Adults also may experience these symptoms but also experience bleeding in the brain (hemorrhagic stroke) from abnormal brain vessels. Seek immediate medical attention if one notice any signs or symptoms of a stroke or TIA, even if they seem to fluctuate or disappear. The longer a stroke goes untreated, the greater the potential for brain damage and disability. If one is with someone one suspect is having a stroke, watch the person carefully while waiting for emergency assistance. If one observe any of these signs, call 911 or emergency medical help immediately.
Overview: In moyamoya disease, arteries to the brain become narrow and may even close, leading to reduced delivery of oxygen-rich blood to the brain. Moyamoya disease is a rare blood vessel (vascular) disorder in which the carotid artery in the skull becomes blocked or narrowed, reducing blood flow to the brain.
Causes: Moyamoya disease is most commonly seen in Japan, Korea and China, but it also occurs in other parts of the world. Moyamoya is also associated with certain conditions, such as Down syndrome, sickle cell anemia, neurofibromatosis type 1 and hyperthyroidism.
Risk factors: Though the cause of moyamoya disease is unknown, certain factors may increase the risk of having the condition, including Being of Asian descent. Moyamoya disease is found all over the world, but it's more common in East Asian countries, especially Korea, Japan and China. If one has a family member with moyamoya disease, the risk of having the condition is 30 to 40 times higher than that of the general population a factor that strongly suggests a genetic component. Moyamoya disease sometimes occurs in association with another disorder, including neurofibromatosis type 1, sickle cell disease and Down syndrome, among many others. Though adults can have moyamoya disease, children younger than 15 years old are most commonly affected.
Diagnosis: The doctor may inject a dye into a blood vessel to view the arteries and veins and highlight blood circulation (magnetic resonance angiogram). The doctor may inject a dye into a blood vessel to highlight blood flow in the arteries and veins (CT angiogram). During a cerebral angiogram, the doctor inserts a long, thin tube (catheter) into a blood vessel in the groin and guides it to the brain using X-ray imaging. The doctor then injects dye through the catheter into the blood vessels of the brain to make them visible under X-ray imaging.

Name: MRSA infection
Symptoms: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections start out as small red bumps that can quickly turn into deep, painful abscesses. Staph skin infections, including MRSA, generally start as swollen, painful red bumps that might resemble pimples or spider bites.
Causes: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, around 2 percent of the population chronically carries the type of staph bacteria known as MRSA. Even when antibiotics are used appropriately, they contribute to the rise of drug-resistant bacteria because they don't destroy every germ they target.
Risk factors: Because hospital and community strains of MRSA generally occur in different settings, the risk factors for the two strains differ. MRSA remains a concern in hospitals, where it can attack those most vulnerable older adults and people with weakened immune systems. Medical tubing such as intravenous lines or urinary catheters can provide a pathway for MRSA to travel into the body. Outbreaks of MRSA have occurred in military training camps, child care centers and jails. People who inject drugs are an estimated 16.3 times more likely to develop invasive MRSA infections than others.

Name: Mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome
Overview: Kawasaki disease causes swelling (inflammation) in the walls of medium-sized arteries throughout the body. Kawasaki disease is sometimes called mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome because it also affects glands that swell during an infection (lymph nodes), skin, and the mucous membranes inside the mouth, nose and throat.
Risk factors: Three things are known to increase the child's risk of developing Kawasaki disease. Children under 5 years old are most at risk of Kawasaki disease. Children of Asian or Pacific Island descent, such as Japanese or Korean, have higher rates of Kawasaki disease.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves ruling out other diseases that cause similar signs and symptoms, including The doctor will do a physical examination and order blood and urine tests to help in the diagnosis. Blood tests help rule out other diseases and check the child's blood cell count. Testing for a substance called B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) that's released when the heart is under stress may be helpful in diagnosing Kawasaki disease. Scarlet fever, which is caused by streptococcal bacteria and results in fever, rash, chills and sore throat Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis Stevens-Johnson syndrome, a disorder of the mucous membranes Toxic shock syndrome Measles Certain tick-borne illnesses, such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever Blood tests.
info-Symptoms: Fever > 5 days, large lymph nodes, rash, sore throat, diarrhea
info-Risk factors: Age of < 5 years old
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, ultrasound of the heart

Name: Mucopolysaccharidosis type II
Overview: Hunter syndrome is a very rare, inherited genetic disorder caused by a missing or malfunctioning enzyme. The buildup of massive amounts of these harmful substances eventually causes permanent, progressive damage affecting appearance, mental development, organ function and physical abilities.
Risk factors: A woman who is a carrier of an X-linked recessive disorder has a 25% chance of having an unaffected son, a 25% chance of having an affected son, a 25% chance of having an unaffected daughter and a 25% chance of having a daughter who also is a carrier. Hunter syndrome is what's known as an X-linked recessive disease, which means that women carry the defective disease-causing X chromosome and can pass it on.
Diagnosis: Hunter syndrome progresses slowly and its signs and symptoms overlap with a number of other disorders, so a definitive diagnosis may take awhile. Prenatal testing of the fluid that surrounds the baby (amniocentesis) or of a tissue sample from the placenta (chorionic villus sampling) can verify if the unborn child carries a copy of the defective gene or is affected with the disorder.
info-Symptoms: Skeletal abnormalities, hearing loss, retinal degeneration, enlarged liver and spleen
info-Prognosis: In severe cases, death usually occurs by age 15. In attenuated cases, patients may survive into their 50s

Name: Multiple myeloma
Causes: The myeloma cells continue trying to produce antibodies, as healthy plasma cells do, but the myeloma cells produce abnormal antibodies that the body can't use. MGUS, like multiple myeloma, is marked by the presence of M proteins produced by abnormal plasma cells in the blood.
Risk factors: The risk of multiple myeloma increases as one age, with most people diagnosed in their mid-60s. Black people are about twice as likely to develop multiple myeloma as are white people. If a brother, sister or parent has multiple myeloma, one has an increased risk of the disease. Every year 1 percent of the people with MGUS in the United States develop multiple myeloma.
Diagnosis: In some cases, the doctor may detect multiple myeloma accidentally when one undergo a blood test for some other condition. If tests indicate one has multiple myeloma, the doctor will use the information gathered from the diagnostic tests to classify the disease as stage I, stage II or stage III.
info-Symptoms: Bone pain, fatigue:â€Š653
info-Risk factors: Obesity
info-Diagnostic method: Blood or urine tests, bone marrow biopsy, medical imaging
info-Treatment: Steroids, chemotherapy, thalidomide, stem cell transplant, bisphosphonates, radiation therapy
info-Prognosis: Five-year survival rate 54% / life expectancy 6 years (USA)

Name: Multiple personality disorder
Symptoms: If one or a loved one has less urgent symptoms that may indicate a dissociative disorder, call the doctor. Or call a suicide hotline number in the United States, call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (1-800-273-8255) to reach a trained counselor. Dissociative amnesia can be specific to events in a certain time, such as intense combat, or more rarely, can involve complete loss of memory about theself.
Overview: Dissociative disorders are mental disorders that involve experiencing a disconnection and lack of continuity between thoughts, memories, surroundings, actions and identity. Although treating dissociative disorders can be difficult, many people learn new ways of coping and lead healthy, productive lives.
Diagnosis: Certain tests may eliminate physical conditions for example, head injury, certain brain diseases, sleep deprivation or intoxication that can cause symptoms such as memory loss and a sense of unreality. The mental health professional may compare the symptoms to the criteria for diagnosis in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association. Also, the symptoms are not due to alcohol or other drugs, and they're not caused by a neurological or other medical condition, such as amnesia related to head trauma. One may also experience dissociative fugue, where one purposefully travel or experience confused wandering that involves amnesia inability to remember the identity or other important personal information.
info-Symptoms: At least two distinct and relatively enduring personality states, trouble remembering certain events

Name: Mumps
Overview: One has three pairs of major salivary glands parotid, sublingual and submandibular. Mumps is a viral infection that primarily affects saliva-producing (salivary) glands that are located near the ears. However, mumps outbreaks still occur in the United States, and the number of cases has crept up in recent years.
info-Symptoms: Parotitis and non-specific symptoms such as fever, headache, malaise, muscle pain, and loss of appetite
info-Risk factors: Exposure to someone with mumps
info-Diagnostic method: Antibody testing, viral cultures, and reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction
info-Prognosis: Usually excellent; case fatality rate of 1.6â€“3.8 people per 10,000
info-Frequency: Most common in childhood and in countries that do not vaccinate

Name: Muscle cramp
Overview: A muscle cramp is a sudden and involuntary contraction of one or more of the muscles. If one has ever been awakened in the night or stopped in the tracks by a sudden charley horse, one know that muscle cramps can cause severe pain.
Causes: Although most muscle cramps are harmless, some may be related to an underlying medical condition, such as: Inadequate blood supply. Narrowing of the arteries that deliver blood to the legs (arteriosclerosis of the extremities) can produce cramp-like pain in the legs and feet while one is exercising. Compression of nerves in the spine (lumbar stenosis) also can produce cramp-like pain in the legs.
Risk factors: Factors that might increase the risk of muscle cramps include Age. Athletes who become fatigued and dehydrated while participating in warm-weather sports frequently develop muscle cramps. One might be at higher risk of muscle cramps if one has diabetes, or nerve, liver or thyroid disorders.
Treatment: For a front thigh (quadriceps) cramp, use a chair to steady theself and try pulling the foot on the affected side up toward the buttock. Make an appointment with the doctor if one has muscle cramps that are severe, frequent and not getting better with self-care.
info-Symptoms: sudden muscle pain and a paralysis-like immobility
info-Treatment: quinine, Stretching, massage, and drinking liquids

Name: Muscle strains
Overview: A muscle strain is an injury to a muscle or a tendon the fibrous tissue that connects muscles to bones. Sometimes called pulled muscles, strains commonly occur in the lower back and in the muscles at the back of the thigh (hamstrings). The difference between a strain and a sprain is that a strain involves an injury to a muscle or to the band of tissue that attaches a muscle to a bone, while a sprain injures the bands of tissue that connect two bones together.
Risk factors: Participating in contact sports such as soccer, football, hockey, boxing and wrestling can increase the risk of muscle strains. Sports that feature quick starts and jumping, such as hurdling and basketball, can be particularly tough on the Achilles tendon in the ankle. Gripping sports, such as gymnastics or golf, can increase the risk of muscle strains in the hands.
Treatment: approach rest, ice, compression, elevation: Some doctors recommend avoiding over-the-counter pain medications that can increase the risk of bleeding such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve) during the first 48 hours after a muscle strain. Acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) can be helpful for pain relief during this time period. For some injuries, such as a torn tendon, surgery may be considered While one may initially consult the family physician, he or she may refer one to a doctor who specializes in sports medicine or orthopedic surgery. Even if one is seeking medical help, ice the area immediately. To help stop swelling, compress the area with an elastic bandage until the swelling stops. Loosen the wrap if the pain increases, the area becomes numb or swelling is occurring below the wrapped area. Elevate the injured area above the level of the heart, especially at night, which allows gravity to help reduce swelling.
info-Symptoms: Bruise, swelling, redness and soreness
info-Causes: Excessive stress and/or repeated injury on a muscle

Name: Muscular dystrophy
Overview: Muscular dystrophy is a group of diseases that cause progressive weakness and loss of muscle mass. In muscular dystrophy, abnormal genes (mutations) interfere with the production of proteins needed to form healthy muscle.
Diagnosis: Damaged muscles release enzymes, such as creatine kinase (CK), into the blood. In a person who hasn't had a traumatic injury, high blood levels of CK suggest a muscle disease. These tests are used to check heart function, especially in people diagnosed with myotonic muscular dystrophy.
Treatment: Although there's no cure for any form of muscular dystrophy, treatment for some forms of the disease can help extend the time a person with the disease can remain mobile and help with heart and lung muscle strength. Their care team should include a neurologist with expertise in neuromuscular diseases, a physical medicine and rehabilitation specialist, and physical and occupational therapists. Some people might also need a lung specialist (pulmonologist), a heart specialist (cardiologist, a sleep specialist, a specialist in the endocrine system (endocrinologist), an orthopedic surgeon and other specialists.
Medication: The doctor might recommend: Newer drugs include eteplirsen (Exondys 51), the first medication to be approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) specifically to treat some people with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. In 2019, the FDA approved golodirsen (Vyondys 53) for treatment of some people with Duchenne dystrophy who have a certain genetic mutation. Corticosteroids, such as prednisone and deflazacort (Emflaza), which can help muscle strength and delay the progression of certain types of muscular dystrophy. Newer drugs include eteplirsen (Exondys 51), the first medication to be approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) specifically to treat some people with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Heart medications, such as angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or beta blockers, if muscular dystrophy damages the heart.
info-Symptoms: Increasing weakening, breakdown of skeletal muscles, trouble walking
info-Causes: Genetic (X-linked recessive, autosomal recessive, or autosomal dominant)
info-Treatment: Pharmacotherapy, physical therapy, braces, corrective surgery, assisted ventilation

Name: Myasthenia gravis
Symptoms: Because symptoms usually improve with rest, muscle weakness can come and go. Although myasthenia gravis can affect any of the muscles that one control voluntarily, certain muscle groups are more commonly affected than others. The speech might sound soft or nasal, depending on which muscles have been affected. The muscles used for chewing might wear out halfway through a meal, particularly if one has been eating something hard to chew, such as steak.
Overview: Myasthenia gravis (my-us-THEE-nee-uh GRAY-vis) is characterized by weakness and rapid fatigue of any of the muscles under the voluntary control. There's no cure for myasthenia gravis, but treatment can help relieve signs and symptoms, such as weakness of arm or leg muscles, double vision, drooping eyelids, and difficulties with speech, chewing, swallowing and breathing.
