Causes: In myasthenia gravis, certain receptor sites are blocked or destroyed, causing muscle weakness. In myasthenia gravis, the immune system produces antibodies that block or destroy many of the muscles receptor sites for a neurotransmitter called acetylcholine (as-uh-teel-KOH-leen). Rarely, mothers with myasthenia gravis have children who are born with myasthenia gravis (neonatal myasthenia gravis).
Diagnosis: The doctor might use several tests, including The doctor may check the neurological health by testing: Tests to help confirm a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis might include Injection of the chemical edrophonium chloride that results in a sudden, temporary improvement in muscle strength might indicate that one has myasthenia gravis. To diagnose myasthenia gravis, doctors will test the nerve repeatedly to see if its ability to send signals worsens with fatigue.
Remedies: Also, try eating mainly soft foods and avoid foods that require more chewing, such as raw fruits or vegetables. Outside the home, keep paths, sidewalks and driveways cleared of leaves, snow and other debris that could cause one to stumble. To help one maintain the energy, try using an electric toothbrush, electric can openers and other electrical tools to perform tasks.
Medication: Medications such as pyridostigmine (Mestinon, Regonal) and neostigmine (Bloxiverz) enhance communication between nerves and muscles. The doctor might also prescribe other medications that alter the immune system, such as azathioprine (Azasan,, Imuran) mycophenolate mofetil (Cellcept), cyclosporine (Sandimmune) methotrexate (Trexall) or tacrolimus (Astrograf XL, Prograf). If one has a tumor, called a thymoma, doctors will surgically remove the thymus gland (thymectomy). Even if one don't have a tumor in the thymus gland, removing the gland might improve the myasthenia gravis symptoms. In open surgery, the surgeon splits the central breastbone (sternum) to open the chest and remove the thymus gland. It might also involve: These procedures might cause less blood loss, less pain, lower mortality rates and shorter hospital stays compared with open surgery. Prolonged use of corticosteroids, however, can lead to serious side effects, such as bone thinning, weight gain, diabetes and increased risk of some infections. They then use a long, thin camera (video endoscope) and small instruments to see and remove the thymus gland. In this form of thymectomy, surgeons make several small incisions in the side of the chest and remove the thymus gland using a robotic system, which includes a camera arm and mechanical arms.
info-Symptoms: Varying degrees muscle weakness, double vision, drooping eyelids, trouble talking, trouble walking
info-Diagnostic method: Blood tests for specific antibodies, edrophonium test, nerve conduction studies
info-Treatment: Medications, surgical removal of the thymus, plasmapheresis

Name: Myelodysplastic syndromes
Overview: Myelodysplastic syndromes are a group of disorders caused by poorly formed blood cells or ones that don't work properly. Myelodysplastic syndromes result from something amiss in the spongy material inside the bones where blood cells are made (bone marrow).
Causes: The World Health Organization divides myelodysplastic syndromes into subtypes based on the type of blood cells red cells, white cells and platelets involved. One blood cell type white blood cells, red blood cells or platelets is low in number and appears abnormal under the microscope. People with this syndrome have low numbers of red blood cells, and the cells have a specific mutation in their DNA.
Risk factors: Chemotherapy or radiation therapy, both of which are commonly used to treat cancer, can increase the risk of myelodysplastic syndromes. Chemicals linked to myelodysplastic syndromes include tobacco smoke, pesticides and industrial chemicals, such as benzene.
Diagnosis: In a bone marrow aspiration, a doctor or nurse uses a thin needle to remove a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot in the back of the hipbone (pelvis). During a bone marrow biopsy and aspiration, a thin needle is used to withdraw (aspirate) a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot on the back of the hipbone.
Treatment: Treatment for myelodysplastic syndromes most often targets slowing disease progression, managing symptoms, such as fatigue, and preventing bleeding and infections. If one has no symptoms, the doctor might recommend watchful waiting with regular exams and lab tests to see if the disease progresses.
Remedies: Because people with certain myelodysplastic syndromes have low white blood cell counts, they're subject to recurrent, and often serious, infections. Wash hands frequently and thoroughly with warm, soapy water, especially before eating or preparing food. Avoid fruits and vegetables one can't peel, especially lettuce, and wash all produce one do use before peeling.
Medication: Some growth factors, such as epoetin alfa (Epogen, Procrit) or darbepoetin alfa (Aranesp), reduce the need for blood transfusions by increasing red blood cells. Others, such as filgrastim (Neupogen, Zarxio) might help prevent infections by increasing white blood cells in people with certain myelodysplastic syndromes. During a bone marrow transplant, also known as a stem cell transplant, high doses of chemotherapy drugs are used to clear out the defective blood cells from the bone marrow. Then the abnormal bone marrow stem cells are replaced with healthy, donated cells (allogeneic transplant). Medications such as azacitidine (Vidaza) and decitabine (Dacogen) might improve the quality of life of people with certain myelodysplastic syndromes and reduce the risk of acute myelogenous leukemia. These types of medications are used in certain myelodysplastic syndromes, and might lessen the need for red blood cell transfusions.
info-Symptoms: None, feeling tired, shortness of breath, easy bleeding, frequent infections
info-Risk factors: Previous chemotherapy, radiation therapy, certain chemicals such as tobacco smoke, pesticides, and benzene, exposure to mercury or lead
info-Treatment: Supportive care, medications, stem cell transplantation

Name: Myelofibrosis
Diagnosis: In a bone marrow aspiration, a doctor or nurse uses a thin needle to remove a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot in the back of the hipbone (pelvis). In a bone marrow biopsy, a needle is used to draw a sample of hardened bone marrow from the hipbone. During the same procedure, another type of needle may be used to withdraw a sample of the liquid portion of the bone marrow. In myelofibrosis, a complete blood count typically shows abnormally low levels of red blood cells, a sign of anemia common in people with myelofibrosis. Often, white blood cell levels are higher than normal, although in some people they may be normal or even lower than normal. A sample of the blood or bone marrow may be analyzed in a laboratory to look for gene mutations in the blood cells that are associated with myelofibrosis.

Name: Myocardial infarction
Symptoms: However, the more signs and symptoms one has, the greater the chance one is having a heart attack. Some heart attacks strike suddenly, but many people have warning signs and symptoms hours, days or weeks in advance. If one suspect one is having a heart attack, don't hesitate. If one don't have access to emergency medical services, have someone drive one to the nearest hospital. Aspirin can interact with other medications, however, so don't take an aspirin unless the doctor or emergency medical personnel recommend it. If one see someone who's unconscious and one believe is having a heart attack, first call for emergency medical help.
Causes: Over time, a buildup of fatty deposits, including cholesterol, form substances called plaques, which can narrow the arteries (atherosclerosis). This condition, called coronary artery disease, causes most heart attacks. If the clot is large, it can block blood flow through the coronary artery, starving the heart of oxygen and nutrients (ischemia).
Risk factors: Over time, high blood pressure can damage arteries that lead to the heart. High blood pressure that occurs with other conditions, such as obesity, high cholesterol or diabetes, increases the risk even more. A high level of triglycerides, a type of blood fat related to the diet, also increases the risk of a heart attack. However, a high level of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol (good cholesterol) may lower the risk. Obesity is linked with high blood cholesterol levels, high triglyceride levels, high blood pressure and diabetes. Not producing enough of a hormone secreted by the pancreas (insulin) or not responding to insulin properly causes the body's blood sugar levels to rise, increasing the risk of a heart attack. If the siblings, parents or grandparents have had early heart attacks (by age 55 for males and by age 65 for females), one might be at increased risk. This condition causes high blood pressure during pregnancy and increases the lifetime risk of heart disease.
Diagnosis: Ideally, the doctor should screen one during regular physical exams for risk factors that can lead to a heart attack. If one is in an emergency setting for symptoms of a heart attack, one will be asked about the symptoms and have the blood pressure, pulse and temperature checked. Tests to diagnose a heart attack include If one has had or are having a heart attack, doctors will take immediate steps to treat the condition. Because injured heart muscle doesn't conduct electrical impulses normally, the ECG may show that a heart attack has occurred or is in progress. A liquid dye is injected into the arteries of the heart through a long, thin tube (catheter) that's fed through an artery, usually in the leg or groin, to the arteries in the heart.
Remedies: Some of the major risk factors for a heart attack high blood cholesterol, high blood pressure and diabetes cause no symptoms early on. Excess weight strains the heart and can contribute to high cholesterol, high blood pressure and diabetes. Saturated fat, trans fats and cholesterol in the diet can narrow arteries to the heart, and too much salt can raise blood pressure. Eat a heart-healthy diet that includes lean proteins, such as fish and beans, and fruits and vegetables and whole grains. Regular exercise, eating well and losing weight all help to keep blood sugar levels at more-desirable levels.
Medication: Medications to treat a heart attack might include In addition to medications, one might have one of these procedures to treat the heart attack: Coronary angioplasty and stenting. In this procedure, also known as percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), doctors guide a long, thin tube (catheter) through an artery in the groin or wrist to a blocked artery in the heart. If one has had a heart attack, this procedure is often done immediately after a cardiac catheterization, a procedure used to find blockages. A metal mesh stent almost always is inserted into the artery to keep it open long term, restoring blood flow to the heart. In some cases, doctors perform emergency bypass surgery at the time of a heart attack. If possible, however, one might have bypass surgery after the heart has had time about three to seven days to recover from the heart attack. Bypass surgery involves sewing veins or arteries in place beyond a blocked or narrowed coronary artery, allowing blood flow to the heart to bypass the narrowed section. Aspirin reduces blood clotting, thus helping maintain blood flow through a narrowed artery. These drugs, also called clotbusters, help dissolve a blood clot that's blocking blood flow to the heart. The earlier one receive a thrombolytic drug after a heart attack, the greater the chance one will survive and have less heart damage. One will likely be given other medications, such as heparin, to make the blood less sticky and less likely to form clots. This medication, used to treat chest pain (angina), can help improve blood flow to the heart by widening (dilating) the blood vessels. These medications help relax the heart muscle, slow the heartbeat and decrease blood pressure, making the heart's job easier.
info-Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, feeling faint, cold sweat, feeling tired; arm, neck, back, jaw, or stomach pain
info-Risk factors: High blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, lack of exercise, obesity, high blood cholesterol

Name: Myocardial ischemia
Causes: Myocardial ischemia occurs when the blood flow through one or more of the coronary arteries is decreased. Conditions that can cause myocardial ischemia include Chest pain associated with myocardial ischemia can be triggered by: Coronary artery disease (atherosclerosis). The clot might block an artery and lead to sudden, severe myocardial ischemia, resulting in a heart attack. Rarely, a blood clot might travel to the coronary artery from elsewhere in the body.
Risk factors: Over time, high blood pressure can accelerate atherosclerosis, resulting in damage to the coronary arteries. A high level of bad (low-density lipoprotein, or LDL) cholesterol in the blood may be due to an inherited condition or a diet high in saturated fats and cholesterol. Obesity is associated with diabetes, high blood pressure and high blood cholesterol levels. A waist measurement of more than 35 inches (89 centimeters) for women and 40 inches (102 cm) in men increases the risk of high blood pressure, diabetes, and heart disease.
Diagnosis: Exercise makes the heart pump harder and faster than usual, so a stress test can detect heart problems that might not be noticeable otherwise. A stress echocardiogram is similar to a regular echocardiogram, except the test is done after one exercise in the doctor's office on a treadmill or stationary bike. While one exercise, the doctor can watch as it flows through the heart and lungs allowing blood-flow problems to be identified. Coronary angiogram Echocardiogram Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) Holter monitor Nuclear stress test Electrocardiogram (ECG).
Remedies: Some of the main risk factors for myocardial ischemia high cholesterol, high blood pressure and diabetes have no symptoms in the early stages. Treat diseases or conditions that can increase the risk of myocardial ischemia, such as diabetes, high blood pressure and high blood cholesterol.
Medication: Medications to treat myocardial ischemia include Sometimes, more-aggressive treatment is needed to improve blood flow. A daily aspirin or other blood thinner can reduce the risk of blood clots, which might help prevent blockage of the coronary arteries. These medications widen arteries, improving blood flow to and from the heart. These medications help relax the heart muscle, slow the heartbeat and decrease blood pressure so blood can flow to the heart more easily. These medications relax and widen blood vessels, increasing blood flow in the heart. A surgeon uses a vessel from another part of the body to create a graft that allows blood to flow around the blocked or narrowed coronary artery.
info-Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath
info-Causes: Atherosclerosis of the arteries of the heart
info-Risk factors: High blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, lack of exercise, obesity, high blood cholesterol
info-Diagnostic method: Electrocardiogram, cardiac stress test, coronary computed tomographic angiography, coronary angiogram
info-Prevention: Healthy diet, regular exercise, maintaining a healthy weight, not smoking
info-Treatment: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), coronary artery bypass surgery (CABG)

Name: Myocarditis
Overview: Myocarditis is inflammation of the heart muscle. Myocarditis can affect the heart muscle and the heart's electrical system, reducing the heart's ability to pump and causing rapid or abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias).
Causes: Potential causes are many, but the likelihood of developing myocarditis is rare. Gastrointestinal infections (echoviruses), mononucleosis (Epstein-Barr virus) and German measles (rubella) also can cause myocarditis. It's also common in people with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. Numerous bacteria can cause myocarditis, including staphylococcus, streptococcus, the bacterium that causes diphtheria and the tick-borne bacterium responsible for Lyme disease. Among these are such parasites as Trypanosoma cruzi and toxoplasma, including some that are transmitted by insects and can cause a condition called Chagas disease. These include drugs used to treat cancer; antibiotics, such as penicillin and sulfonamide drugs; some anti-seizure medications; and some illegal substances, such as cocaine. Exposure to certain chemicals, such as carbon monoxide, and radiation can sometimes cause myocarditis.
Diagnosis: An X-ray image shows the size and shape of the heart, as well as whether one has fluid in or around the heart that might indicate heart failure. An echocardiogram might detect enlargement of the heart, poor pumping function, valve problems, a clot within the heart or fluid around the heart. These measure white and red blood cell counts, as well as levels of certain enzymes that indicate damage to the heart muscle. In some cases, doctors use a special instrument to remove a tiny sample of heart muscle tissue (biopsy) for analysis in the lab to check for inflammation or infection.
info-Symptoms: Shortness of breath, chest pain, decreased ability to exercise, irregular heartbeat
info-Causes: Usually viral infection, also bacterial infections, certain medications, autoimmune disorders
info-Diagnostic method: Electrocardiogram, blood troponin, heart MRI, heart biopsy
info-Treatment: Medications, implantable cardiac defibrillator, heart transplant
info-Medication: ACE inhibitors, beta blockers, diuretics, corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulin

Name: Myoclonus
Overview: Myoclonus refers to a quick, involuntary muscle jerk. Other forms of myoclonus may occur because of a nervous system (neurological) disorder, such as epilepsy, a metabolic condition, or a reaction to a medication.
Diagnosis: To determine the cause of myoclonus and rule out other potential causes of the condition, the doctor may recommend several tests, including This procedure records the electrical activity of the brain and may help determine where in the brain the myoclonus originates. An MRI scan may be used to check for structural problems or tumors inside the brain or spinal cord, which may cause the myoclonus symptoms.
Medication: The most common anticonvulsants used for myoclonus are levetiracetam (Keppra, Roweepra, Spritam), valproic acid (Depakene) and primidone (Mysoline). OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) injections may be helpful in treating various forms of myoclonus, particularly if only a single area is affected. If the myoclonus symptoms are caused by a tumor or lesion in the brain or spinal cord, surgery may be an option. Clonazepam (Klonopin), a tranquilizer, is the most common drug used to combat myoclonus symptoms.

Name: Myofascial pain syndrome
Overview: Myofascial pain syndrome is a chronic pain disorder. In this condition, pressure on sensitive points in the muscles (trigger points) causes pain in the muscle and sometimes in seemingly unrelated parts of the body. While nearly everyone has experienced muscle tension pain, the discomfort associated with myofascial pain syndrome persists or worsens.
Remedies: Self-care measures to keep the body healthy may make it easier for one to concentrate on coping with the pain. Take care of the body so that one can put the energy toward coping with the pain.
Medication: Medications used for myofascial pain syndrome include A physical therapist can devise a plan to help relieve the pain based on the signs and symptoms. Physical therapy to relieve myofascial pain syndrome may involve: Injecting a numbing agent or a steroid into a trigger point can help relieve pain. Over-the-counter pain relievers such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve) may help some people. A physical therapist may lead one through gentle stretching exercises to help ease the pain in the affected muscle. If one feel trigger point pain when stretching, the physical therapist may spray a numbing solution on the skin. A physical therapist may massage the affected muscle to help relieve the pain. Applying heat, via a hot pack or a hot shower, can help relieve muscle tension and reduce pain. This type of therapy uses sound waves to increase blood circulation and warmth, which may promote healing in muscles affected by myofascial pain syndrome.

Name: Myxofibrosarcoma
Diagnosis: Because there are so many different types of soft tissue sarcoma, it's important to determine the exact nature of each tumor so that the best treatments can be chosen. To evaluate the area of concern, the doctor might employ: If a soft tissue sarcoma is suspected, it's often best to seek care at a medical center that sees many people with this type of cancer. Options include In the lab, a doctor trained in analyzing body tissues (pathologist) examines the tissue sample for signs of cancer.
info-Specialty: Dermatology, Dermatopathology, Pathology, Surgical oncology, Oncology

Name: Naegleria infection
Causes: Naegleria infection is caused by the Naegleria fowleri amoeba, which is commonly found in warm bodies of fresh water around the world, usually during the summer months. The amoeba enters the body through the nose, via contaminated water or dust, and travels to the brain through the nerves that transmit the sense of smell.
Risk factors: In the United States, millions of people are exposed to the amoeba that causes naegleria infection each year, but few people get sick from it. Children and young adults are the most likely age groups to be affected, possibly because they're likely to stay in the water longer and are more active in the water.
Diagnosis: During a lumbar puncture (spinal tap) procedure, one typically lie on the side with the knees drawn up to the chest. CT scan Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) MRI CT scan.
Treatment: The primary treatment for naegleria infection is an antifungal drug, amphotericin B usually injected into a vein (intravenously) or into the space around the spinal cord to kill the amoebas. An investigational drug called miltefosine (Impavido) is now available for emergency treatment of naegleria infection. Naegleria fowleri Primary Amebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM) Amebic Encephalitis. Parasites Naegleria fowleri Primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) Amebic encephalitis: General information.

Name: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
Overview: The throat (pharynx) is a muscular tube that runs from the back of the nose down into the neck. Nasopharyngeal (nay-zoh-fuh-RIN-jee-ul) carcinoma is cancer that occurs in the nasopharynx, which is located behind the nose and above the back of the throat. That's probably because the nasopharynx isn't easy to examine and symptoms of nasopharyngeal carcinoma mimic those of other, more-common conditions.
Risk factors: Researchers have identified some factors that appear to increase the risk of developing nasopharyngeal carcinoma, including Sex. Nasopharyngeal cancer can occur at any age, but it's most commonly diagnosed in adults between the ages of 30 and 50. Chemicals released in steam when cooking salt-cured foods, such as fish and preserved vegetables, may enter the nasal cavity, increasing the risk of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The Epstein-Barr virus is also linked to several rare cancers, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose nasopharyngeal carcinoma include Exam using a camera to see inside the nasopharynx. Once the diagnosis is confirmed, the doctor orders other tests to determine the extent (stage) of the cancer, such as imaging tests. Imaging tests may include Once the doctor has determined the extent of the cancer, a Roman numeral that signifies its stage is assigned. The doctor may also use the endoscope or another instrument to take a small tissue sample (biopsy) to be tested for cancer. Computerized tomography (CT) Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) Positron emission tomography (PET) X-ray CT scan MRI Needle biopsy Positron emission tomography scan X-ray Physical exam.

Name: Nearsightedness
Overview: With normal vision, an image is sharply focused onto the retina. In nearsightedness (myopia), the point of focus is in front of the retina, making distant objects appear blurry. Nearsightedness (myopia) is a common vision condition in which one can see objects near to one clearly, but objects farther away are blurry. It occurs when the shape of the eye causes light rays to bend (refract) incorrectly, focusing images in front of the retina instead of on the retina.
Causes: If the cornea or lens isn't evenly and smoothly curved, light rays aren't refracted properly, and one has a refractive error. Nearsightedness usually occurs when the eyeball is longer than normal or the cornea is curved too steeply. Instead of being focused precisely on the retina, light is focused in front of the retina, resulting in a blurry appearance for distant objects. In addition to nearsightedness, other refractive errors include The cornea is the clear, dome-shaped front surface of the eye.
Remedies: One can, however, help protect the eyes and the vision by following these tips: Have the eyes checked. Certain conditions, such as diabetes and high blood pressure, can affect the vision if one don't receive proper treatment. And studies show that the eyes benefit if one also include in the diet fish high in omega-3 fatty acids, such as tuna and salmon. Just as smoking isn't good for the rest of the body, smoking can adversely affect the eye health as well. Look away from the computer or near-task work, including reading, every 20 minutes for 20 seconds at something 20 feet away. See the doctor immediately if one experience any of these symptoms: Sudden loss of vision in one eye with or without pain; sudden hazy or blurred vision; double vision; or one see flashes of light, black spots or halos around lights.
info-Symptoms: Distant objects appear blurry, close objects appear normal, headaches, eye strain
info-Causes: Combination of genetic and environmental factors
info-Risk factors: Near work, greater time spent indoors, family history

Name: Neck pain
Causes: The neck is flexible and supports the weight of the head, so it can be vulnerable to injuries and conditions that cause pain and restrict motion. Even minor things, such as reading in bed or gritting the teeth, can strain neck muscles. Rear-end auto collisions often result in whiplash injury, which occurs when the head is jerked backward and then forward, straining the soft tissues of the neck. Certain diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis, meningitis or cancer, can cause neck pain.
Diagnosis: X-rays can reveal areas in the neck where the nerves or spinal cord might be pinched by bone spurs or other degenerative changes. MRI uses radio waves and a strong magnetic field to create detailed images of bones and soft tissues, including the spinal cord and the nerves coming from the spinal cord. If the doctor suspects the neck pain might be related to a pinched nerve, he or she might suggest an EMG.
Remedies: Try over-the-counter pain relievers, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) and acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). Reduce inflammation by applying cold, such as an ice pack or ice wrapped in a towel, for up to 20 minutes several times a day.
Medication: The doctor might prescribe stronger pain medicine than what one can get over-the-counter, as well as muscle relaxants and tricyclic antidepressants for pain relief. A physical therapist can teach one correct posture, alignment and neck-strengthening exercises, and can use heat, ice, electrical stimulation and other measures to help ease the pain and prevent a recurrence. This therapy, under supervision of a medical professional and physical therapist, may provide relief of some neck pain, especially pain related to nerve root irritation. The doctor might inject corticosteroid medications near the nerve roots, into the small facet joints in the bones of the cervical spine or into the muscles in the neck to help with pain. Rarely needed for neck pain, surgery might be an option for relieving nerve root or spinal cord compression.

Name: Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis
Treatment: There is no cure for nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, and no treatment is consistently successful in halting or reversing the progression of the disease. More research is needed to determine if these treatments help, but they have shown limited success in some people: These medications have been shown to help some people, but side effects limit their use: Hemodialysis. In people with severely reduced kidney function, performing hemodialysis immediately after receiving gadolinium-containing contrast may decrease the possibility of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis. For people who are appropriate candidates, improvement in renal function because of a kidney transplant may help improve nephrogenic systemic fibrosis over time. Exposure of the skin to ultraviolet A light may reduce the skin thickening and hardening, but it's unclear if the treatment penetrates deeply enough into the skin to be effective. This procedure involves removing unwanted substances from the blood by separating solid blood cells from plasma, replacing plasma with donor plasma or albumin, then mixing it with the original solid blood cells and returning it to the body. There is limited success with this medication, which theoretically decreases the thickness and stickiness (viscosity) of blood, aiding circulation.
info-Causes: iatrogenic disease caused by exposure to gadolinium-based contrast agents
info-Risk factors: impaired kidney function is the major risk factor

Name: Nephrotic syndrome
Overview: Blood enters the kidneys through the renal arteries. The glomeruli filter waste products and substances the body needs such as sodium, phosphorus and potassium which then pass through tiny tubules. Nephrotic syndrome is usually caused by damage to the clusters of small blood vessels in the kidneys that filter waste and excess water from the blood.
Causes: Nephrotic syndrome is usually caused by damage to the clusters of tiny blood vessels (glomeruli) of the kidneys. The glomeruli filter the blood as it passes through the kidneys, separating things the body needs from those it doesn't. Healthy glomeruli keep blood protein (mainly albumin) which is needed to maintain the right amount of fluid in the body from seeping into the urine. When damaged, glomeruli allow too much blood protein to leave the body, leading to nephrotic syndrome. Many diseases and conditions can cause glomerular damage and lead to nephrotic syndrome, including Diabetic kidney disease. Minimal change disease results in abnormal kidney function, but when the kidney tissue is examined under a microscope, it appears normal or nearly normal. Characterized by scarring of some of the glomeruli, this condition can result from another disease, a genetic defect or certain medications or occur for no known reason.
Risk factors: Certain diseases and conditions increase the risk of developing nephrotic syndrome, such as diabetes, lupus, amyloidosis, reflux nephropathy and other kidney diseases. Infections that increase the risk of nephrotic syndrome include HIV, hepatitis B, hepatitis C and malaria.
Treatment: Drugs called angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors reduce blood pressure and the amount of protein released in urine. Medications in this category include lisinopril (Prinvil, Qbrelis, Zestril), benazepril (Lotensin), captopril and enalapril (Vasotec). Statins include atorvastatin (Lipitor), fluvastatin (Lescol XL), lovastatin (Altoprev), pravastatin (Pravachol), rosuvastatin (Crestor, Ezallor) and simvastatin (Zocor). If the doctor suspects one or the child has a kidney problem, such as nephrotic syndrome, one might be referred to a doctor who specializes in the kidneys (nephrologist). Others include spironolactone (Aldactone, Carospir) and thiazides, such as hydrochlorothiazide or metolazone (Zaroxolyn). Anticoagulants include heparin, warfarin (Coumadin, Jantoven), dabigatran (Pradaxa), apixaban (Eliquis) and rivaroxaban (Xarelto). Medications include rituximab (Rituxan), cyclosporine and cyclophosphamide.
info-Symptoms: Swelling, weight gain, feeling tired, foamy urine
info-Causes: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, membranous nephropathy, minimal change disease, diabetes, lupus

Name: Neuroblastoma
Causes: Neuroblastoma begins in neuroblasts immature nerve cells that a fetus makes as part of its development process. As the fetus matures, neuroblasts eventually turn into nerve cells and fibers and the cells that make up the adrenal glands.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose neuroblastoma include Once neuroblastoma is diagnosed, the child's doctor may order further testing to determine the extent of the cancer and whether it has spread to distant organs a process called staging. Imaging tests used to stage cancer include X-rays, bone scans, and CT, MRI and MIBG scans, among others. Imaging tests may include an X-ray, ultrasound, computerized tomography (CT) scan, metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) scan and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), among others. If a mass is found, the child's doctor may want to remove a sample of the tissue for laboratory testing (biopsy). The child may also undergo bone marrow biopsy and bone marrow aspiration procedures to see if neuroblastoma has spread to the bone marrow the spongy material inside the largest bones where blood cells are formed. In order to remove bone marrow for testing, a needle is inserted into the child's hipbone or lower back to draw out the marrow.
info-Symptoms: Bone pain, lumps
info-Treatment: Observation, surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, stem cell transplantation
info-Prognosis: US five-year survival ~95% (< 1 year old), 68% (1â€“14 years old)

Name: Neurodermatitis
Overview: Neurodermatitis is a skin condition characterized by chronic itching or scaling. One will notice raised, rough, itchy areas of skin typically on the neck, wrists, forearms, legs or anal region. One may develop several itchy spots, typically on the neck, wrists, forearms, legs or anal region. Breaking the itch-scratch cycle of neurodermatitis is challenging, and neurodermatitis is usually a lifelong condition.
Causes: The persistent rubbing and scratching that characterize the condition may begin with something that simply irritates the skin, such as tight clothing or a bug bite. In some cases, neurodermatitis is associated with chronic skin conditions such as dry skin, eczema or psoriasis.
Risk factors: Certain factors may affect the risk of neurodermatitis, including The sex and age. People with a personal or family history of dermatitis, eczema, psoriasis or similar skin conditions are more likely to develop neurodermatitis.
Treatment: If over-the-counter corticosteroid cream isn't helping, the doctor may prescribe a stronger corticosteroid or a nonsteroidal anti-itch product. The doctor may inject corticosteroids directly into the affected skin to help it heal. Because anxiety and stress can trigger neurodermatitis, anti-anxiety drugs may help prevent the itchiness. For stubborn itching, the doctor may suggest topical lidocaine 5 percent or capsaicin 8 percent patches.
Remedies: These self-care measures can help one manage neurodermatitis: Take short, warm baths and moisturize the skin. The itching may be intense, but avoiding rubbing and scratching is key to controlling the condition and preventing a recurrence. Putting a cool, wet compress on the affected skin for a few minutes before one apply a medicated cream helps the cream soak into the skin. Short nails may do less damage to the skin, especially if one tend to scratch while one is asleep. Take short, warm baths and moisturize the skin. For example, use stress management techniques and avoid clothing that irritates the skin.
info-Symptoms: Thick leathery skin, exaggerated skin markings, small bumps, patches, scratch marks, scale

Name: Neuroendocrine carcinoma of the skin
Overview: Merkel cell carcinoma is a rare, aggressive skin cancer. Merkel cell carcinoma is a rare type of skin cancer that usually appears as a flesh-colored or bluish-red nodule, often on the face, head or neck.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of Merkel cell carcinoma include Excessive exposure to natural or artificial sunlight. Being exposed to ultraviolet light, such as the light that comes from the sun or from tanning beds, increases the risk of Merkel cell carcinoma. People with weakened immune systems including those with HIV infection, those taking drugs that suppress the immune response or those with chronic leukemias are more likely to develop Merkel cell carcinoma. Merkel cell carcinoma is associated with the development of other skin cancers, such as basal cell or squamous cell carcinoma.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose Merkel cell carcinoma include The doctor may use the following tests to help determine whether the cancer has spread beyond the skin: Sentinel node biopsy. The doctor may recommend a chest X-ray and a CT scan of the chest and abdomen to help determine whether the cancer has spread to other organs. The doctor may also consider other imaging tests such as a positron emission tomography (PET) scan or an octreotide scan a test that uses an injection of a radioactive tracer to check for the spread of cancer cells. The doctor may recommend a chest X-ray and a CT scan of the chest and abdomen to help determine whether the cancer has spread to other organs.The doctor may also consider other imaging tests such as a positron emission tomography (PET) scan or an octreotide scan a test that uses an injection of a radioactive tracer to check for the spread of cancer cells.
Treatment: Chemotherapy is not used often, but the doctor may recommend it if the Merkel cell carcinoma has spread to the lymph nodes or other organs in the body, or if it has returned despite treatment. If there's evidence that the cancer has spread to lymph nodes in the area of the skin tumor, those lymph nodes are removed (lymph node dissection).The surgeon most often uses a scalpel to cut away the cancer. In some cases, the doctor may use a procedure called Mohs surgery.During Mohs surgery, thin layers of tissue are methodically removed and analyzed under a microscope to see whether they contain cancer cells. During radiation treatment, one is positioned on a table and a large machine moves around one, directing the beams to precise points on the body.Radiation therapy is sometimes used after surgery to destroy any cancer cells that remain after the tumor is removed.Radiation may also be used as the sole treatment in people who choose not to undergo surgery. Chemotherapy drugs can be administered through a vein in the arm or taken as a pill or both.Chemotherapy is not used often, but the doctor may recommend it if the Merkel cell carcinoma has spread to the lymph nodes or other organs in the body, or if it has returned despite treatment.

Name: Neuroendocrine tumors
Overview: Neuroendocrine tumors are cancers that begin in specialized cells called neuroendocrine cells. Diagnosis and treatment of neuroendocrine tumors depend on the type of tumor, its location, whether it produces excess hormones, how aggressive it is and whether it has spread to other parts of the body.
Diagnosis: In general, tests might include If there's a risk that the neuroendocrine tumor may have spread to other parts of the body, one might have additional tests to determine the extent of the cancer. For neuroendocrine tumors, pictures are sometimes created using positron emission tomography (PET) with a radioactive tracer that's injected into a vein. To collect the cells, the doctor might insert a long, thin tube with a light and a camera on the end into the lungs (bronchoscopy), the esophagus (endoscopy) or the rectum (colonoscopy), depending on the situation.
Treatment: The treatment options for the neuroendocrine tumor will depend on the type of tumor, its location, and whether one is experiencing signs and symptoms of excess hormones produced by the tumor. In general, neuroendocrine tumor treatment options might include Other treatments might be available to one depending on the particular situation and the specific type of neuroendocrine tumor. By blocking these abnormalities, targeted drug treatments can cause tumor cells to die. One PRRT drug, lutetium Lu 177 dotatate (Lutathera), is used to treat advanced neuroendocrine tumors. If the neuroendocrine tumor releases excess hormones, the doctor might recommend medications to control the signs and symptoms.

Name: Neurofibroma
Diagnosis: MRI scan To diagnosis a peripheral nerve tumor, the doctor may ask one about signs and symptoms, discuss the medical history, and perform both a general physical and neurological exam. A computer uses the images to make a detailed view of the peripheral nerve tumor so that the doctor can evaluate how it may be affecting one. If imaging tests identify a nerve tumor, the doctor may remove and analyze a small sample of cells (biopsy) from the tumor. If one has a condition such as progressive peripheral neuropathy or enlarged nerves that mimic nerve tumors, the doctor may take a nerve biopsy.

Name: Neurofibromatosis
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms include Neurofibromatosis 2 (NF2) is much less common than NF1. Signs and symptoms of NF2 usually result from the development of benign, slow-growing tumors in both ears (acoustic neuromas), which can cause hearing loss. Signs and symptoms generally appear in the late teen and early adult years, and can vary in severity. Because tumors don't usually grow on both hearing nerves, schwannomatosis doesn't cause the hearing loss experienced by people with NF2. Flat, light brown spots on the skin (cafe au lait spots). These tumors usually appear by age 3, rarely in late childhood and adolescence, and almost never in adults.
Overview: Neurofibromatosis is a genetic disorder that causes tumors to form on nerve tissue. However, complications of neurofibromatosis can include hearing loss, learning impairment, heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) problems, loss of vision, and severe pain.
Causes: The mutated gene causes a loss of neurofibromin, which allows cells to grow uncontrolled. The NF2 gene is located on chromosome 22, and produces a protein called merlin (also called schwannomin), which suppresses tumors. The mutated gene causes a loss of merlin, leading to uncontrolled cell growth. Mutations of the genes SMARCB1 and LZTR1, which suppress tumors, are associated with this type of neurofibromatosis.
Risk factors: A person with an autosomal dominant disorder in this case, the father has a 50% chance of having an affected child with one abnormal gene and a 50% chance of having an unaffected child with two normal genes. NF1 and NF2 are both autosomal dominant disorders, which means that any child of a parent with the disorder has a 50 percent chance of inheriting the genetic mutation.
Diagnosis: The doctor may use a special lamp to check the skin for caf au lait spots, which can help diagnose NF1. If additional tests are needed to diagnose NF1, NF2 or schwannomatosis, the doctor might recommend: For a diagnosis of NF1, one must have at least two signs of the condition. If the child has only one sign and no family history of NF1, the doctor will likely monitor the child for the development of any additional signs. A test that measures hearing (audiometry), a test that uses electrodes to record the eye movements (electronystagmography) and a test that measures the electrical messages that carry sound from the inner ear to the brain (brainstem auditory evoked response) can help assess hearing and balance problems in people with NF2. Genetic tests won't always identify schwannomatosis because other, unknown genes may be involved with the disorder.
info-Symptoms: Small lumps within the skin, scoliosis, hearing loss, vision loss
info-Prognosis: NF1: variable, but most of the time normal life expectancyNF2: shortened life expectancy

Name: Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder
Overview: Neuromyelitis optica (NMO) is a central nervous system disorder that primarily affects the eye nerves (optic neuritis) and the spinal cord (myelitis). Neuromyelitis optica may cause blindness in one or both eyes, weakness or paralysis in the legs or arms, painful spasms, loss of sensation, uncontrollable vomiting and hiccups, and bladder or bowel dysfunction from spinal cord damage.
Diagnosis: To learn how well the brain responds to stimuli such as sounds, sights or touch, one will undergo a test called evoked potentials (they may also be called evoked response tests). During these tests, doctors attach small wires (electrodes) to the scalp and, in some cases, the earlobes, neck, arm, leg and back. These tests help the doctor to find lesions or damaged areas in the nerves, spinal cord, optic nerve, brain or brainstem. The doctor might test the blood for the autoantibody NMO-IgG (also known as the aquaporin-4 autoantibody AQP4), which helps doctors distinguish NMO from MS and other neurological conditions.
Treatment: Neuromyelitis optica can't be cured, though long-term remission may be possible with the right management. In the early stage of an NMO attack, the doctor may give one a corticosteroid medication, methylprednisolone (Solu-Medrol), through a vein in the arm (intravenously). Plasma exchange is frequently recommended as the first or second treatment, usually in addition to steroid therapy. In this procedure, some blood is removed from the body, and blood cells are mechanically separated from fluid (plasma). Doctors mix the blood cells with a replacement solution and return the blood into the body.Doctors can also help manage other symptoms one may experience, such as pain or muscle problems. Doctors may recommend that one take a lower dose of corticosteroids for an extensive period of time to prevent future NMO attacks and relapses. The doctor may also recommend taking a medication that suppresses the immune system, in addition to corticosteroids, to prevent future NMO attacks. Immunosuppressive medications that may be prescribed include azathioprine (Imuran, Azasan), mycophenolate mofetil (Cellcept) or rituximab (Rituxan).
info-Symptoms: Vision loss, sensory loss, weakness, bladder dysfunction
info-Usual onset: Median: age 40 for AQP4-IgG, age 31 for MOG-IgG
info-Risk factors: Female sex, genetic factors
info-Medication: Eculizumab, inebilizumab, satralizumab, rituximab, methylprednisolone, azathioprine, cellCept, mitoxantrone, methotrexate, intravenous immunoglobulin, cyclophosphamide

Name: Neuropathy , autonomic
Overview: Autonomic neuropathy occurs when the nerves that control involuntary bodily functions are damaged. The nerve damage interferes with the messages sent between the brain and other organs and areas of the autonomic nervous system, such as the heart, blood vessels and sweat glands.
Causes: Some common causes of autonomic neuropathy include Autoimmune diseases, in which the immune system attacks and damages parts of the body, including the nerves. An abnormal attack by the immune system that occurs as a result of some cancers (paraneoplastic syndrome) can also cause autonomic neuropathy. Autoimmune diseases, in which the immune system attacks and damages parts of the body, including the nerves.
Risk factors: Diabetes, especially when poorly controlled, increases the risk of autonomic neuropathy and other nerve damage. Amyloidosis, porphyria, hypothyroidism and cancer (usually due to side effects from treatment) also can increase the risk of autonomic neuropathy.
Diagnosis: Autonomic neuropathy is a possible complication of a number of diseases, and the tests one will need depend on the symptoms and risk factors for autonomic neuropathy. The doctor might recommend tests to evaluate autonomic functions, including Tilt-table test. If one has bladder or urinary signs and symptoms, a series of urine and bladder tests can evaluate bladder function.
Remedies: Flex the feet and make fists with the hands for a few seconds before standing up, to increase blood flow. Once standing, try tensing the leg muscles while crossing one leg over the other a few times to increase blood pressure. If one has low blood pressure, it might help to raise the head of the bed by about 4 inches by placing blocks or risers under the legs at the head of the bed.

Name: Neuropathy , diabetic
Symptoms: This type of neuropathy may also be called distal symmetric peripheral neuropathy. One may have: There are two types of mononeuropathy cranial and peripheral.
Overview: Diabetic neuropathy is a type of nerve damage that can occur if one has diabetes. Depending on the affected nerves, diabetic neuropathy symptoms can range from pain and numbness in the legs and feet to problems with the digestive system, urinary tract, blood vessels and heart.
Risk factors: But these risk factors make one more likely to get nerve damage: Poor blood sugar control. Uncontrolled blood sugar puts one at risk of every diabetes complication, including nerve damage. The risk of diabetic neuropathy increases the longer one has diabetes, especially if the blood sugar isn't well controlled.
Remedies: Exercise helps lower blood sugar, improves blood flow and keeps the heart healthy. Try to keep the blood pressure in the range the doctor recommends, and be sure to have it checked at every office visit.

Name: Nevus
Symptoms: Hormonal changes of adolescence and pregnancy may cause moles to become darker and larger. Make an appointment with the doctor if a mole looks unusual, grows or changes. Moles can be brown, tan, black, red, blue or pink. Moles are usually less than 1/4 inch (about 6 millimeters) in diameter the size of a pencil eraser. Rarely, moles present at birth (congenital nevi) can be much bigger, covering wide areas of the face, torso or a limb. Look for moles with irregular, notched or scalloped borders. Look for growths that have changed color, have many colors or have uneven color. Watch for moles that change in size, shape, color or height, especially if part or all of a mole turns black. Moles may also evolve to develop new signs and symptoms, such as itchiness or bleeding.
Overview: Moles are usually harmless. Most people have 10 to 40 moles, some of which may change in appearance or fade away over time. Monitoring moles and other pigmented patches is an important step in detecting skin cancer, especially malignant melanoma.

Name: Nickel allergy
Risk factors: Certain factors may increase the risk of developing a nickel allergy, including Working with metal. If one work in an occupation that constantly exposes one to nickel, the risk of developing an allergy may be higher than it is for someone who doesn't work with the metal. Other people who may have an increased risk of nickel allergy include metalworkers, tailors and hairdressers.
Diagnosis: If the cause of the rash isn't apparent, however, the doctor may recommend a patch test (contact hypersensitivity allergy test). During a patch test, very small quantities of potential allergens (including nickel) are applied to the skin and covered with small patches.
Medication: Corticosteroid cream, such as clobetasol (Clobex, Cormax, others) and betamethasone dipropionate (Diprolene). Nonsteroidal creams, such as pimecrolimus (Elidel) and tacrolimus (Protopic). Oral antihistamine, such as fexofenadine (Allegra) and cetirizine (Zyrtec), for relief of itching.

Name: Nicotine dependence
Symptoms: Signs that one may be addicted include One is not alone if one has tried to stop smoking but haven't been able to stop for good. Using medications and working with a counselor specially trained to help people stop smoking (a tobacco treatment specialist) will significantly boost the chances of success. Ask the health care team to help one develop a treatment plan that works for one or to advise one on where to get help to stop smoking.
Causes: In many people, nicotine from cigarettes stimulates receptors in the brain to release dopamine, triggering a pleasure response. When one quit smoking, one cut off the brain's pleasure response because the receptors don't get nicotine, triggering nicotine withdrawal symptoms. In the brain, nicotine increases the release of brain chemicals called neurotransmitters, which help regulate mood and behavior.
Medication: Any of these products can help reduce nicotine cravings and withdrawal symptoms making it more likely that one will stop smoking for good. Medications help one cope by reducing withdrawal symptoms and cravings, while behavioral treatments help one develop the skills one need to give up tobacco for good.

Name: Niemann-Pick
Overview: Niemann-Pick is a rare, inherited disease that affects the body's ability to metabolize fat (cholesterol and lipids) within cells. Niemann-Pick disease can affect the brain, nerves, liver, spleen, bone marrow and, in severe cases, lungs.
Causes: Niemann-Pick is caused by mutations in specific genes related to how the body metabolizes fat (cholesterol and lipids). This affects the body's ability to metabolize fat (cholesterol and lipids), resulting in a buildup of fat in cells. Type A occurs mainly in infants, who show severe, progressive brain disease. The genetic mutations of this type cause cholesterol and other fats to accumulate in the liver, spleen or lungs.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease begins with a thorough physical exam, which can show an early warning sign such as an enlarged liver or spleen. But in the early stages of Niemann-Pick, an MRI may be normal because symptoms typically occur before the loss of brain cells. An eye exam can show signs that may be an indication of Niemann-Pick disease, such as eye movement difficulties. DNA testing of a blood sample may show the specific abnormal genes that cause Niemann-Pick types A, B and C. DNA tests can show who the carriers are for all types of Niemann-Pick disease if the mutations have been described in the first person identified in a family (the index case). Ultrasound can detect the enlarged liver and spleen that's caused by type C. And amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling may be used to confirm a diagnosis of Niemann-Pick.
Treatment: An international study of 92 people with type C Niemann-Pick showed improved neurological symptoms after taking miglustat regularly for an average of two years. People with Niemann-Pick disease need to see their doctors regularly, because the disease progresses and symptoms worsen. Stable or improved neurological manifestations during miglustat therapy in patients from the international disease registry for Niemann-Pick disease type C: An observational cohort study.

Name: Nightmare disorder
Overview: A nightmare is a disturbing dream associated with negative feelings, such as anxiety or fear that awakens one. Nightmare disorder is when nightmares happen often, cause distress, disrupt sleep, cause problems with daytime functioning or create fear of going to sleep.
Causes: Nightmares usually occur during the stage of sleep known as rapid eye movement (REM). Nightmares can be triggered by many factors, including Stress or anxiety. Sometimes the ordinary stresses of daily life, such as a problem at home or school, trigger nightmares. Nightmares are common after an accident, injury, physical or sexual abuse, or other traumatic event. Changes in the schedule that cause irregular sleeping and waking times or that interrupt or reduce the amount of sleep can increase the risk of having nightmares. Nightmares can happen along with some medical conditions, such as heart disease or cancer. For some people, reading scary books or watching frightening movies, especially before bed, can be associated with nightmares.
Diagnosis: The doctor may also ask one or the partner about the sleep behaviors and discuss the possibility of other sleep disorders, if indicated. If the sleep is severely disturbed, the doctor may recommend an overnight sleep study to help determine if the nightmares are connected to another sleep disorder.
Treatment: However, treatment may be needed if the nightmares are causing one distress or sleep disturbance and interfering with the daytime functioning. If the nightmares are associated with an underlying medical condition, treatment is aimed at the underlying problem. If a mental health condition, such as stress or anxiety, seems to be contributing to the nightmares, the doctor may suggest stress-reduction techniques, counseling or therapy with a mental health professional. Often used with people who have nightmares as a result of PTSD, imagery rehearsal therapy involves changing the ending to the remembered nightmare while awake so that it's no longer threatening. However, medication may be recommended for severe nightmares associated with PTSD.
Remedies: If nightmares are a problem for one or the child, try these strategies: Establish a regular, relaxing routine before bedtime. If the child is struggling with nightmares, be patient, calm and reassuring. After the child awakens from a nightmare, respond quickly and soothe the child at the bedside. For the child, one may encourage him or her to draw a picture of the nightmare, talk to the characters in the nightmare or write about the nightmare in a journal. The child might feel more secure if he or she sleeps with a favorite stuffed animal, blanket or other comfort object. Leave the door open, too, in case the child needs comfort during the night. If the child wakes up during the night, the light may be reassuring.

Name: Noctural enuresis
Overview: Bed-wetting also called nighttime incontinence or nocturnal enuresis is involuntary urination while asleep after the age at which staying dry at night can be reasonably expected. Lifestyle changes, bladder training, moisture alarms and sometimes medication may help reduce bed-wetting.
Causes: No one knows for sure what causes bed-wetting, but various factors may play a role: A small bladder. The child's bladder may not be developed enough to hold urine produced during the night. If the nerves that control the bladder are slow to mature, a full bladder may not wake the child especially if the child is a deep sleeper. During childhood, some kids don't produce enough anti-diuretic hormone (ADH) to slow nighttime urine production. Signs and symptoms may include bed-wetting, daytime accidents, frequent urination, red or pink urine, and pain during urination. For a child who's usually dry at night, bed-wetting may be the first sign of diabetes. Other signs and symptoms may include passing large amounts of urine at once, increased thirst, fatigue and weight loss in spite of a good appetite. Rarely, bed-wetting is related to a defect in the child's neurological system or urinary system.
Remedies: It's important to get enough fluids, so there's no need to limit how much the child drinks in a day. Because caffeine may stimulate the bladder, it's especially discouraged in the evening. During the day and evening, suggest that the child urinate every two hours or so, or at least often enough to avoid a feeling of urgency. To prevent a rash caused by wet underwear, help the child rinse his or her bottom and genital area every morning.

Name: Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
Overview: Compared with a normal liver (left), a fatty liver (right) appears enlarged and discolored. Tissue samples reveal fat deposits in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, while inflammation and advanced scarring (cirrhosis) are visible in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. Some individuals with NAFLD can develop nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), an aggressive form of fatty liver disease, which is marked by liver inflammation and may progress to advanced scarring (cirrhosis) and liver failure.
Diagnosis: Tests done to pinpoint the diagnosis and determine disease severity include Imaging procedures used to diagnose NAFLD include If other tests are inconclusive, the doctor may recommend a procedure to remove a sample of tissue from the liver (liver biopsy). Complete blood count Liver enzyme and liver function tests Tests for chronic viral hepatitis (hepatitis A, hepatitis C and others) Celiac disease screening test Fasting blood sugar Hemoglobin A1C, which shows how stable the blood sugar is Lipid profile, which measures blood fats, such as cholesterol and triglycerides Abdominal ultrasound, which is often the initial test when liver disease is suspected.
Remedies: With the doctor's help, one can take steps to control the nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. If one is overweight or obese, reduce the number of calories one eat each day and increase the physical activity in order to lose weight. If one has tried to lose weight in the past and have been unsuccessful, ask the doctor for help. Eat a healthy diet that's rich in fruits, vegetables and whole grains, and keep track of all calories one take in. If one is trying to lose weight, one might find that more exercise is helpful. But if one don't already exercise regularly, get the doctor's OK first and start slowly. A healthy plant-based diet, exercise and medications can help keep the cholesterol and the triglycerides at healthy levels.
info-Symptoms: Asymptomatic, liver dysfunction
info-Risk factors: Obesity, metabolic syndrome, type 2 diabetes mellitus, liver disease
info-Frequency: 24% in worldwide population, 80% in obese, 20% in normal-weight

Name: Non-Hodgkin 's lymphoma
Overview: The body's lymphatic system is part of the immune system, which protects one against infection and disease. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma is cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, the disease-fighting network spread throughout the body.
Causes: In most cases, doctors don't know what causes non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. In non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, the lymphocytes don't die, but continue to grow and divide. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma can begin in the: Whether the non-Hodgkin's lymphoma arises from the B cells or T cells helps to determine the treatment options. Occasionally, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma involves organs outside of the lymphatic system. Subtypes of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma that involve B cells include diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, follicular lymphoma, mantle cell lymphoma and Burkitt lymphoma. Subtypes of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma that involve T cells include peripheral T-cell lymphoma and cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
Risk factors: In most cases, people diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma don't have any obvious risk factors. Some factors that may increase the risk of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma include Medications that suppress the immune system. Certain viral and bacterial infections appear to increase the risk of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Viruses linked to increased non-Hodgkin's lymphoma risk include HIV and Epstein-Barr infection. Bacteria linked to an increased risk of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma include the ulcer-causing Helicobacter pylori. Certain chemicals, such as those used to kill insects and weeds, may increase the risk of developing non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma can occur at any age, but the risk increases with age.
Diagnosis: In a bone marrow aspiration, a doctor or nurse uses a thin needle to remove a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot in the back of the hipbone (pelvis). He or she may then have one undergo tests and procedures used to diagnose non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, including Other tests and procedures may be used depending on the situation. After the doctor has determined the extent of the non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, the cancer will be assigned a stage. Stages of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma include Additionally, the doctor uses the letters A and B to indicate whether one is experiencing symptoms of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma: Many types of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma exist, including rare forms that are difficult for inexperienced pathologists to identify. The doctor checks for swollen lymph nodes, including in the neck, underarm and groin, as well as for a swollen spleen or liver. Analyzing lymph node tissue in a lab may reveal whether one has non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and, if so, which type. In this stage, the cancer is in two lymph node regions, or the cancer has invaded one organ and the nearby lymph nodes. When the cancer moves to lymph nodes both above and below the diaphragm, it's considered stage III. Stage IV non-Hodgkin's lymphoma may also affect other parts of the body, such as the liver, lungs or bones.

Name: Nontropical sprue
Diagnosis: A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). If the results of these tests indicate celiac disease, the doctor will likely order one of the following tests: If the doctor suspects one has dermatitis herpetiformis, he or she might take a small sample of skin tissue to examine under a microscope (skin biopsy). The camera enables the doctor to view the small intestine and take a small tissue sample (biopsy) to analyze for damage to the villi.
Treatment: Besides wheat, foods that contain gluten include A dietitian who works with people with celiac disease can help one plan a healthy gluten-free diet. Gluten can be hidden in foods, medications and nonfood products, including Removing gluten from the diet will gradually reduce inflammation in the small intestine, causing one to feel better and eventually heal.
info-Symptoms: None or non-specific, abdominal distention, diarrhoea, constipation, malabsorption, weight loss, dermatitis herpetiformis
info-Risk factors: Genetic predisposition, type 1 diabetes, autoimmune thyroid disease, Down and Turner syndrome
info-Diagnostic method: Family history, blood antibody tests, intestinal biopsies, genetic testing, response to gluten withdrawal

Name: Noonan syndrome
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of Noonan syndrome vary greatly among individuals and may be mild to severe. Some forms of congenital heart disease associated with this disorder include Noonan syndrome can affect normal growth. Issues may include the following: Some common issues can include Intelligence isn't affected for most people with Noonan syndrome. However, individuals may have: A common sign of Noonan syndrome is abnormalities of the eyes and eyelids. These may include Noonan syndrome can cause hearing deficits due to nerve issues or to structural abnormalities in the inner ear bones. Noonan syndrome can cause problems with the lymphatic system, which drains excess fluid from the body and helps fight infection. These problems: Many people, especially males, with Noonan syndrome can have problems with the genitals and kidneys. People with Noonan syndrome may have skin conditions, which most commonly are: The signs and symptoms of Noonan syndrome can be subtle. If the unborn child is at risk because of a family history of Noonan syndrome, prenatal tests may be available. It's the most common heart problem seen with Noonan syndrome, and it may occur alone or with other heart defects. This is abnormal growth or thickening of the heart muscle that affects some people with Noonan syndrome. By adulthood, some people with Noonan syndrome may have normal height, but short stature is more common.
Overview: Noonan syndrome is a genetic disorder that prevents normal development in various parts of the body. Noonan syndrome is caused by a genetic mutation and is acquired when a child inherits a copy of an affected gene from a parent (dominant inheritance).
Causes: In an autosomal dominant disorder, the abnormal gene is a dominant gene located on one of the nonsex chromosomes (autosomes). Children who have one parent with Noonan syndrome who carries the defective gene (autosomal dominant) have a 50 percent chance of developing the disorder. Noonan syndrome can develop because of a new mutation in children who don't have a genetic predisposition for the disorder (de novo).
Diagnosis: A diagnosis of Noonan syndrome is usually made after a doctor observes some key signs, but this can be difficult because some features are subtle and hard to identify. If there's evidence of heart problems, a doctor who specializes in heart conditions (cardiologist) can assess the type and severity.
Treatment: Although there's no way to repair the gene changes that cause Noonan syndrome, treatments can help minimize its effects. Recommended approaches may include Other evaluations and regular follow-up care may be recommended depending on specific issues, for example, regular dental care. If the child's growth hormone levels are insufficient, growth hormone therapy may be a treatment option. If one or both testicles haven't moved into proper position within the first few months of life (undescended testicle), surgery may be needed.
info-Symptoms: Mildly unusual facial features, short height, congenital heart disease, bleeding problems, skeletal malformations
info-Diagnostic method: Suspected based on symptoms, confirmed with genetic testing
info-Prognosis: Depends on the severity of heart problems

Name: Norovirus infection
Overview: Norovirus infection can cause the sudden onset of severe vomiting and diarrhea. However, for some people especially infants, older adults and people with underlying disease vomiting and diarrhea can be severely dehydrating and require medical attention. Norovirus infection occurs most frequently in closed and crowded environments such as hospitals, nursing homes, child care centers, schools and cruise ships.
Treatment: If one is unable to drink enough fluids to prevent dehydration, one might need to receive fluids through a vein. If the family includes young children, it's a good idea to have commercially prepared oral rehydration solutions on hand. Adults can drink sports drinks, broths or oral rehydration solutions.
info-Symptoms: Diarrhea, vomiting, stomach pain, headache
info-Prevention: Hand washing, disinfection of contaminated surfaces
info-Treatment: Supportive care (drinking sufficient fluids or intravenous fluids)

Name: Nose fracture
Overview: A broken nose, also called a nasal fracture, is a break or crack in a bone in the nose often the bone over the bridge of the nose. Common causes of a broken nose include contact sports, physical fights, falls and motor vehicle accidents that result in facial trauma.
Diagnosis: The doctor may use anesthetics either a nasal spray or local injections to make one more comfortable during the exam. However, the doctor may recommend a computerized tomography (CT) scan if the severity of the injuries makes a thorough physical exam impossible or if the doctor suspects one may have other injuries.
Remedies: If one think one may have broken the nose, take these steps to reduce pain and swelling before seeing the doctor: Act quickly. When the break first occurs, breathe through the mouth and lean forward to reduce the amount of blood that drains into the throat. Apply ice packs or cold compresses immediately after the injury, and then at least four times a day for the first 24 to 48 hours to reduce swelling. Try not to apply too much pressure, which can cause additional pain or damage to the nose. Take over-the-counter pain relievers, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve, others), as necessary.
info-Symptoms: Nose bleed, swelling, bruising
info-Causes: Assault, trauma during sports, falls, motor vehicle collisions
info-Diagnostic method: Typically based on symptoms, occasionally plain X rays
info-Treatment: Pain medication, cold compresses, possible reduction post resolution of swelling

Name: Novel coronavirus
Symptoms: If one has COVID-19 symptoms or one has been in contact with someone diagnosed with COVID-19, contact the doctor or clinic right away for medical advice. Emergency signs and symptoms can include If one has signs or symptoms of COVID-19, contact the doctor or clinic for guidance.
Overview: Coronavirus is a family of viruses that can cause respiratory illnesses such as the common cold, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS). Coronaviruses are a family of viruses that can cause illnesses such as the common cold, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS).
Causes: Infection with the new coronavirus (severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2, or SARS-CoV-2) causes coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Data has shown that it spreads from person to person among those in close contact (within about 6 feet, or 2 meters).
Diagnosis: If one develop symptoms of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) and one has been exposed to the COVID-19 virus, contact the doctor. In the U.S. the doctor will determine whether to conduct tests for the virus that causes COVID-19 based on the signs and symptoms, as well as whether one has had close contact with someone diagnosed with COVID-19 or traveled to or lived in any areas with ongoing community spread of the COVID-19 virus in the past 14 days.
Treatment: Supportive care is aimed at relieving symptoms and may include There is no evidence that ibuprofen or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) need to be avoided. One will likely be asked to isolate theself as much as possible from family and pets while one is sick, wear a mask when one is around people and pets, and use a separate bedroom and bathroom.

Name: Obesity , childhood
Overview: Childhood obesity is a serious medical condition that affects children and adolescents. Childhood obesity is particularly troubling because the extra pounds often start children on the path to health problems that were once considered adult problems diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol.
Risk factors: Regularly eating high-calorie foods, such as fast foods, baked goods and vending machine snacks, can cause the child to gain weight. Candy and desserts also can cause weight gain, and more and more evidence points to sugary drinks, including fruit juices, as culprits in obesity in some people. If the child comes from a family of overweight people, he or she may be more likely to put on weight. Also, people who live in lower income neighborhoods might not have access to a safe place to exercise.
Diagnosis: Cutoff points on these growth charts, established by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, help identify children who are overweight and obese: Because BMI doesn't consider things such as being muscular or having a larger than average body frame and because growth patterns vary greatly among children, the doctor also factors in the child's growth and development. In addition to BMI and charting weight on the growth charts, the doctor evaluates: The child's doctor might order blood tests if he or she finds that the child is obese. BMI between 85th and 94th percentiles overweight BMI 95th percentile or above obesity The family's history of obesity and weight-related health problems, such as diabetes The child's eating habits The child's activity level Other health conditions the child has Psychosocial history, including incidences of depression, sleep disturbances, and sadness and whether the child feels isolated or alone or is the target of bullying A cholesterol test A blood sugar test Other blood tests to check for hormone imbalances, vitamin D deficiency or other conditions associated with obesity Cholesterol test
Remedies: If one is overweight and thinking of becoming pregnant, losing weight and eating well might affect the child's future. For children who are overweight or obese, their best chance of achieving and maintaining a healthy weight is to start eating a healthy diet and moving more.

Name: Obstetric cholestasis
Causes: Doctors think this may slow the normal flow of bile the digestive fluid made in the liver that helps the digestive system break down fats. As a result, bile salts eventually enter the bloodstream, which can make one feel itchy.

Name: Occupational asthma
Symptoms: During an asthma attack, the narrowed airways make it harder to breathe, and one may cough and wheeze. Breathing problems may be a sign of asthma, especially if symptoms seem to be getting worse over time or appear to be aggravated by specific triggers or irritants. The longer one is exposed to the asthma-causing substance, the more likely one will have long-lasting or permanent asthma symptoms.
Causes: With occupational asthma, lung inflammation may be triggered by an allergic response to a substance, which usually develops over time. Alternatively, inhaling fumes from a lung irritant, such as chlorine, can trigger immediate asthma symptoms in the absence of allergy.
Risk factors: In addition, one will have increased risk if: It's possible to develop occupational asthma in almost any workplace. Although this can increase the risk, many people who have allergies or asthma do jobs that expose them to lung irritants and never have symptoms.
Diagnosis: The doctor may order blood tests, X-rays or other tests to rule out a cause other than occupational asthma. The doctor has one inhale a bronchodilator drug used in asthma treatment, then retake the spirometry test. These tests can't be used to diagnose sensitivities to chemicals but may be useful in evaluating sensitivity to animal dander, mold, dust mites and latex.
Treatment: However, once one become sensitive to a substance, tiny amounts may trigger asthma symptoms, even if one wear a mask or respirator. The right medication for one depends on a number of things, including the age, symptoms, asthma triggers and what seems to work best to keep the asthma under control.
Medication: If one find one need to use a quick-relief inhaler more often than the doctor recommends, one may need to adjust the long-term control medication. Inhaled corticosteroids reduce inflammation and have a relatively low risk of side effects. For asthma, LABAs generally should only be taken in combination with an inhaled corticosteroid.

Name: OCD
Symptoms: OCD obsessions are repeated, persistent and unwanted thoughts, urges or images that are intrusive and cause distress or anxiety. Obsessions often have themes to them, such as: Examples of obsession signs and symptoms include OCD compulsions are repetitive behaviors that one feel driven to perform. OCD, usually considered a lifelong disorder, can have mild to moderate symptoms or be so severe and time-consuming that it becomes disabling.
Causes: OCD may be a result of changes in the body's own natural chemistry or brain functions. OCD may have a genetic component, but specific genes have yet to be identified. Obsessive fears and compulsive behaviors can be learned from watching family members or gradually learned over time.
Diagnosis: Steps to help diagnose obsessive-compulsive disorder may include It's sometimes difficult to diagnose OCD because symptoms can be similar to those of obsessive-compulsive personality disorder, anxiety disorders, depression, schizophrenia or other mental health disorders. The doctor may use criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association.
Remedies: While OCD warrants treatment by a professional, one can do some things for theself to build on the treatment plan: Practice what one learn. Work with the mental health professional to identify techniques and skills that help manage symptoms, and practice these regularly.
