Contact the doctor who's treating one for OCD before one take medications prescribed by another doctor or before taking any over-the-counter medications, vitamins, herbal remedies or other supplements to avoid possible interactions.
Medication: Antidepressants approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to treat OCD include However, the doctor may prescribe other antidepressants and psychiatric medications. Sometimes, psychotherapy and medications aren't effective enough to control OCD symptoms. In treatment-resistant cases, other options may be offered: Talk with the doctor to make sure one understand all the pros and cons and possible health risks of DBS and TMS if one is considering one of these procedures. Clomipramine (Anafranil) for adults and children 10 years and older Fluoxetine (Prozac) for adults and children 7 years and older Fluvoxamine for adults and children 8 years and older Paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva) for adults only Sertraline (Zoloft) for adults and children 6 years and older Choosing a medication. In some cases, children, teenagers and young adults under 25 may have an increase in suicidal thoughts or behavior when taking antidepressants, especially in the first few weeks after starting or when the dose is changed. Antidepressants aren't considered addictive, but sometimes physical dependence (which is different from addiction) can occur. Don't stop taking the medication without talking to the doctor, even if one is feeling better one may have a relapse of OCD symptoms. The FDA approved a specific device (BrainsWay Deep Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation) to treat OCD in adults ages 22 to 68 years, when traditional treatment approaches have not been effective.
info-Symptoms: Feel the need to check things repeatedly, perform certain routines repeatedly, have certain thoughts repeatedly
info-Risk factors: Child abuse, stress
info-Treatment: Counseling, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, clomipramine

Name: Ocular rosacea
Treatment: The doctor may prescribe temporary use of oral antibiotics, such as tetracycline, doxycycline, erythromycin and minocycline. Avoid wearing contact lenses during flare-ups, especially if the symptoms include dry eyes. Prevent flare-ups by avoiding things that trigger or worsen the rosacea or ocular rosacea, if possible.
Remedies: Avoid wearing contact lenses during flare-ups, especially if the symptoms include dry eyes. Prevent flare-ups by avoiding things that trigger or worsen the rosacea or ocular rosacea, if possible.

Name: Oculocutaneous albinism
Symptoms: Skin coloring (pigmentation) and hair color can range from white to brown, and may be nearly the same as that of parents or siblings without albinism. With exposure to the sun, some people may develop: For some people with albinism, skin pigmentation never changes. People of African or Asian descent who have albinism may have hair color that's yellow, reddish or brown.
Causes: Different types of albinism can occur, based mainly on which gene mutation caused the disorder. It's the result of a mutation in one of seven genes, labeled from OCA1 to OCA7.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis of albinism is based on: A medical doctor specializing in vision and eye disorders (ophthalmologist) should conduct the child's eye exam. A physical exam that includes checking skin and hair pigmentation A thorough eye exam Comparison of the child's pigmentation to that of other family members Review of the child's medical history, including whether there has been bleeding that doesn't stop, excessive bruising or unexpected infections Eye exam
Treatment: The care team may involve the primary care doctor and doctors specializing in eye care (ophthalmologist), skin care (dermatologist) and genetics. Use low vision aids, such as a hand-held magnifying glass, a monocular or a magnifier that attaches to glasses, and a tablet synced to a smart board (an interactive electronic board with a touch screen) in the classroom. Protect eyes wearing dark, UV-blocking sunglasses or transition lenses (photochromic lenses) that darken in bright light.

Name: Oculosympathetic palsy
Symptoms: Common signs and symptoms include Signs and symptoms, particularly ptosis and anhidrosis, may be subtle and difficult to detect. Additional signs and symptoms in children with Horner syndrome may include A number of factors, some more serious than others, can cause Horner syndrome.
Overview: Decreased eye pupil size is a key sign of Horner syndrome. Typically, Horner syndrome results in a decreased pupil size, a drooping eyelid and decreased sweating on the affected side of the face.

Name: Odontogenic tumors and cysts
Symptoms: This tumor can recur after treatment; however, aggressive surgical treatments will typically reduce the chance of recurrence. Some of these tumors can grow rapidly, can cause pain and destroy bone, and have a tendency to recur after surgical treatment. Rarely, a tumor may shrink or resolve on its own, but typically these tumors require surgical treatment. Also referred to as keratocystic odontogenic tumor because of its tumorlike tendency to recur after surgical treatment, this slow-growing, benign cyst can be destructive to local structures. This is a rare, slow-growing, benign tumor that occurs most often in the lower jaw. Odontogenic myxomas are known to recur after surgical treatment; however, the chances of tumor recurrence are typically lessened by aggressive surgical treatment.
Causes: Odontogenic jaw tumors and cysts originate from cells and tissues that are involved in normal tooth development. Others tumors that affect the jaws can be nonodontogenic, meaning that they can develop from other tissues within the jaws that are not related to the teeth. Generally, the cause of jaw tumors and cysts is not known; however, some are associated with genetic syndromes. People with nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome, also called Gorlin-Goltz syndrome, lack a gene that suppresses tumors. This syndrome results in the development of multiple odontogenic keratocysts within the jaws, multiple basal cell skin cancers and other characteristics. Update from the 4th edition of the World Health Organization Classification of Health and Neck Tumours: Odontogenic and maxillofacial bone tumors. Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Medicine, and Pathology. Aggressive central giant cell granuloma of the mandible, a diagnostic dilemma.
Treatment: Treatment options for jaw tumors and cysts vary, depending on the type of lesion one has, the lesion's stage of growth and the symptoms. In some cases, treatment may be medical therapy or a combination of surgery and medical therapy. During surgery, the doctor removes the jaw tumor or cyst, which may include removing nearby teeth, tissue and jawbone, and sends it to the lab for examination. Update from the 4th edition of the World Health Organization Classification of Health and Neck Tumours: Odontogenic and maxillofacial bone tumors. Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Medicine, and Pathology.

Name: Olfactory neuroblastoma
Overview: Esthesioneuroblastoma (es-thee-zee-o-noo-row-blas-TOE-muh) is a rare type of cancer that begins in the upper portion of the nasal cavity. The area where esthesioneuroblastoma begins is separated from the brain by a bone that contains tiny holes that allow the nerves that control smell (olfactory nerves) to pass through. Esthesioneuroblastoma, which can occur at any age in adults, generally begins as a tumor in the nasal cavity and may grow or extend into the sinus, eyes and brain.
Diagnosis: A careful history of the signs and symptoms and an examination of the eyes, nose, and head and neck give doctors important information to understand the tumor's extent and aid in diagnosis. The tube is attached to a camera that allows doctors to look at the extent of the tumor in the nose, back of the nose (nasopharynx) and in the sinus area of the nasal cavity.

Name: Oligodendroglioma
Diagnosis: If the primary care doctor suspects one has a brain tumor, one may be referred to a specialist who is trained in treating brain and nervous system disorders (neurologist). In some cases, a dye (contrast material) may be injected through a vein in the arm during the MRI study to help show differences in brain tissue. A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. Brain tumor imaging Collecting and testing a sample of abnormal tissue (biopsy). Depending on the location of the glioma, a biopsy may be performed with a needle before treatment or as part of an operation to remove the brain tumor. Based on this information, a doctor who specializes in diagnosing cancer and other tissue abnormalities (pathologist) can determine the grade or stage of a brain tumor. To rule out other types of brain tumors that may have spread from other parts of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer originated.

Name: Oppositional defiant disorder ( ODD )
Symptoms: The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association, lists criteria for diagnosing ODD. Symptoms occur only in one setting, such as only at home, school, work or with peers.
Overview: Even the best-behaved children can be difficult and challenging at times. But if the child or teenager has a frequent and persistent pattern of anger, irritability, arguing, defiance or vindictiveness toward one and other authority figures, he or she may have oppositional defiant disorder (ODD).
Treatment: Treatment for oppositional defiant disorder primarily involves family-based interventions, but it may include other types of psychotherapy and training for the child as well as for parents. If the child has coexisting disorders, such as ADHD, anxiety or depression, medications may help improve these symptoms. The cornerstones of treatment for ODD usually include As part of parent training, one may learn how to manage the child's behavior by: Although some parenting techniques may seem like common sense, learning to use them consistently in the face of opposition isn't easy, especially if there are other stressors at home. A mental health professional with experience treating ODD may help one develop parenting skills that are more consistent, positive and less frustrating for one and the child. In some cases, the child may participate in this training with one, so everyone in the family develops shared goals for how to handle problems. In one approach, the therapist sits behind a one-way mirror and, using an ear bug audio device, guides parents through strategies that reinforce their child's positive behavior. As a result, parents learn more-effective parenting techniques, the quality of the parent-child relationship improves, and problem behaviors decrease.
Remedies: At home, one can begin chipping away at problem behaviors of oppositional defiant disorder by practicing these strategies: With perseverance and consistency, the initial hard work often pays off with improved behavior and relationships. Initially, it's important to set the child up for success with tasks that are relatively easy to achieve and gradually blend in more important and challenging expectations. Recognize and praise Model the behavior Pick the battles Set limits Set up a routine Build in time together Work together Assign a household chore Be prepared for challenges early on.

Name: Optic neuritis
Symptoms: Some can lead to permanent vision loss, and some are associated with other serious medical problems. Most people have at least some temporary reduction in vision, but the extent of loss varies. Noticeable vision loss usually develops over hours or days and improves over several weeks to months. One develop new symptoms, such as eye pain or a change in the vision.
Overview: The optic nerve is a bundle of nerve fibers that serves as the communication cable between the eyes and the brain. Optic neuritis occurs when swelling (inflammation) damages the optic nerve a bundle of nerve fibers that transmits visual information from the eye to the brain. Signs and symptoms of optic neuritis can be the first indication of multiple sclerosis (MS), or they can occur later in the course of MS. MS is a disease that causes inflammation and damage to nerves in the brain as well as the optic nerve.
Causes: In people with optic neuritis, the risk of developing multiple sclerosis after one episode of optic neuritis is about 50% over a lifetime. When symptoms of optic neuritis are more complex, other associated causes need to be considered, including Multiple sclerosis. Neuromyelitis optica has similarities to multiple sclerosis, but neuromyelitis optica doesn't cause damage to the nerves in the brain as often as multiple sclerosis does. Bacterial infections, including Lyme disease, cat-scratch fever and syphilis, or viruses, such as measles, mumps and herpes, can cause optic neuritis. Diseases such as sarcoidosis, Behcet's disease and lupus can cause recurrent optic neuritis.
Risk factors: Risk factors for developing optic neuritis include Age. Certain genetic mutations might increase the risk of developing optic neuritis or multiple sclerosis.
Diagnosis: The ophthalmologist likely will perform the following eye tests: Other tests to diagnose optic neuritis might include Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). During an MRI to check for optic neuritis, one might receive an injection of a contrast solution to make the optic nerve and other parts of the brain more visible on the images. If one has optic neuritis, the pupils won't constrict as much as pupils in healthy eyes would when exposed to light. People with severe optic neuritis may undergo this test to determine whether they're likely to develop neuromyelitis optica. For atypical cases of optic neuritis, blood may also be tested for MOG antibodies. This test measures the thickness of the eye's retinal nerve fiber layer, which is often thinner from optic neuritis.
Treatment: Intravenous steroid therapy quickens vision recovery, but it doesn't appear to affect the amount of vision one will recover for typical optic neuritis. When steroid therapy fails and severe vision loss persists, a treatment called plasma exchange therapy might help some people recover their vision.

Name: Oral cancer
Causes: Mouth cancers form when cells on the lips or in the mouth develop changes (mutations) in their DNA. Mouth cancers most commonly begin in the flat, thin cells (squamous cells) that line the lips and the inside of the mouth.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose mouth cancer include Leukoplakia appears as thick, white patches on the inside surfaces of the mouth. Once mouth cancer is diagnosed, the doctor works to determine the extent (stage) of the cancer. Mouth cancer staging tests may include Mouth cancer stages are indicated using Roman numerals I through IV. The doctor or dentist will examine the lips and mouth to look for abnormalities areas of irritation, such as sores and white patches (leukoplakia). During a procedure called endoscopy, the doctor may pass a small, flexible camera equipped with a light down the throat to look for signs that cancer has spread beyond the mouth.
Remedies: Mouth cancers are closely linked to tobacco use, including cigarettes, cigars, pipes, chewing tobacco and snuff, among others. Alcohol, particularly when combined with tobacco use, greatly increases the risk of mouth cancer.
info-Specialty: Oncology, oral and maxillofacial surgery, ENT surgery
info-Symptoms: Persistent rough white or red patch in the mouth lasting longer than 2 weeks, ulceration, lumps/bumps in the neck, pain, loose teeth, difficulty swallowing
info-Risk factors: Smoking, alcohol, HPV infection, sun exposure, chewing tobacco

Name: Oral lichen planus
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of oral lichen planus affect the mucous membranes of the mouth. Lesions usually appear as purplish, flat-topped bumps that are often itchy. Lesions on the female genitalia often cause pain or burning and discomfort with intercourse. When skin lesions appear on the scalp, they may cause temporary or permanent hair loss. Rarely, lichen planus may involve the mucous membrane surfaces of the eyes, and can cause scarring and blindness.
Overview: This white lacelike patch on the interior surface of the cheek is typical for oral lichen planus. Oral lichen planus may appear as white, lacy patches; red, swollen tissues; or open sores. Symptoms can usually be managed, but people who have oral lichen planus need regular monitoring because they may be at risk of developing mouth cancer in the affected areas.
Diagnosis: The doctor makes a diagnosis of oral lichen planus based on: He or she also may request lab tests such as: Discussion of the medical and dental history and the medications one is taking Review of symptoms, including lesions in the mouth and any other places on the body Examination of the mouth, and other areas as appropriate Biopsy. A small tissue sample is taken from one or more lesions in the mouth and examined under a microscope to look for indications of oral lichen planus. Other more specialized microscopic tests may be needed to identify immune system proteins commonly associated with oral lichen planus. These may be done to identify conditions such as hepatitis C, which may rarely be associated with oral lichen planus, and lupus, which may look similar to oral lichen planus.
Treatment: There is no cure, so the treatment focuses on helping severe lesions heal and reducing pain or other discomfort. If one has no pain or discomfort and if only white, lacy lesions are present, one may not need any treatment.
Remedies: In addition to regular medical and dental treatment, self-care measures may help improve the oral lichen planus symptoms or help prevent recurring episodes of severe symptoms: Practice good oral hygiene. Because stress may complicate symptoms or trigger symptom recurrence, one may need to develop skills to avoid or manage stress. The doctor may refer one to a mental health professional who can help one identify stressors, develop stress management strategies or address other mental health concerns. Because long-term treatment is often required, talk to the doctor or dentist about how often one should be seen to evaluate how the treatment is working and for cancer screening.

Name: Orchitis
Overview: Orchitis (or-KIE-tis) is an inflammation of one or both testicles. Bacterial orchitis might be associated with epididymitis an inflammation of the coiled tube (epididymis) at the back of the testicle that stores and carries sperm.
Diagnosis: The doctor is likely to start with the medical history and a physical exam to check for enlarged lymph nodes in the groin and an enlarged testicle on the affected side. Ultrasound with color Doppler can determine if the blood flow to the testicles is lower than normal indicating torsion or higher than normal, which helps confirm the diagnosis of orchitis.

Name: Osgood-Schlatter disease
Symptoms: Pain usually worsens during certain activities, such as running, kneeling and jumping, and eases with rest. Seek medical attention if the knee is swollen and red, or if the knee pain is associated with fever, locking or instability of the knee joint.
Overview: Osgood-Schlatter disease can cause a painful, bony bump on the shinbone just below the knee. Osgood-Schlatter disease occurs most often in children who participate in sports that involve running, jumping and swift changes of direction such as soccer, basketball, figure skating and ballet.
Risk factors: Osgood-Schlatter disease typically occurs in boys ages 12 to 14 and girls ages 10 to 13. Osgood-Schlatter disease is more common in boys, but the gender gap is narrowing as more girls become involved with sports.
Diagnosis: During the physical exam, the doctor will check the child's knee for tenderness, swelling, pain and redness. X-rays may be taken to look at the bones of the knee and leg and to more closely examine the area where the kneecap tendon attaches to the shinbone.
Remedies: Stretching the muscles on the front of the thigh (quadriceps), is especially important. When the child is participating in sports, have him or her wear a pad over the affected knee where the knee can become irritated. It can help to tack down the kneecap's tendon during activities and distribute some of the force away from the shinbone. Suggest that the child switch to activities that don't involve jumping or running, such as cycling or swimming, until symptoms subside.
Medication: Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, Children's Motrin, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve) might help. A physical therapist can teach the child exercises to stretch the thigh's quadriceps, which can help reduce the tension where the kneecap (patella) tendon attaches to the shinbone.
info-Symptoms: Painful bump just below the knee, worse with activity and better with rest
info-Usual onset: Males between the ages of 10 and 15
info-Risk factors: Sports that involve running or jumping

Name: Osteoarthritis
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of osteoarthritis include If one has joint pain or stiffness that doesn't go away, make an appointment with the doctor. Joint stiffness might be most noticeable upon awakening or after being inactive. The joint might feel tender when one apply light pressure to or near it. One might feel a grating sensation when one use the joint, and one might hear popping or crackling. These extra bits of bone, which feel like hard lumps, can form around the affected joint.
Overview: Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis, affecting millions of people worldwide. Although osteoarthritis can damage any joint, the disorder most commonly affects joints in the hands, knees, hips and spine.
Risk factors: Carrying extra body weight contributes to osteoarthritis in several ways, and the more one weigh, the greater the risk. Increased weight adds stress to weight-bearing joints, such as the hips and knees. Injuries, such as those that occur when playing sports or from an accident, can increase the risk of osteoarthritis. Even injuries that occurred many years ago and seemingly healed can increase the risk of osteoarthritis. If the job or a sport one play places repetitive stress on a joint, that joint might eventually develop osteoarthritis.
Diagnosis: To get pictures of the affected joint, the doctor might recommend: Analyzing the blood or joint fluid can help confirm the diagnosis. Cartilage doesn't show up on X-ray images, but cartilage loss is revealed by a narrowing of the space between the bones in the joint. An MRI uses radio waves and a strong magnetic field to produce detailed images of bone and soft tissues, including cartilage. Although there's no blood test for osteoarthritis, certain tests can help rule out other causes of joint pain, such as rheumatoid arthritis.
Remedies: Exercising and losing weight if one is overweight are important ways to lessen the joint pain and stiffness of osteoarthritis. New pain that lasts for hours after one exercise probably means one has overdone it, not that one has caused damage or that one should stop exercising. Many people use these therapies to reduce stress in their lives, and research suggests that tai chi and yoga might reduce osteoarthritis pain and improve movement. Carrying extra weight increases the stress on the weight-bearing joints, such as the knees and the hips. Heat, especially moist heat, can help muscles relax and ease pain. Topical capsaicin, a chili pepper extract, applied to the skin over an arthritic joint might help some people.
Medication: Medications that can help relieve osteoarthritis symptoms, primarily pain, include Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Over-the-counter NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve, others), taken at the recommended doses, typically relieve osteoarthritis pain. NSAIDs as gels, applied to the skin over the affected joint, have fewer side effects and may relieve pain just as well. Acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) has been shown to help some people with osteoarthritis who have mild to moderate pain.
info-Symptoms: Joint pain, stiffness, joint swelling, decreased range of motion
info-Causes: Connective tissue disease, previous joint injury, abnormal joint or limb development, inherited factors
info-Risk factors: Overweight, legs of different lengths, job with high levels of joint stress
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, supported by other testing
info-Treatment: Exercise, efforts to decrease joint stress, support groups, pain medications, joint replacement

Name: Osteochondritis dissecans
Symptoms: This most common symptom of osteochondritis dissecans might be triggered by physical activity walking up stairs, climbing a hill or playing sports. The joint might pop or stick in one position if a loose fragment gets caught between bones during movement.

Name: Osteomalacia
Symptoms: As osteomalacia progresses, one might develop bone pain and muscle weakness. The dull, aching pain associated with osteomalacia most commonly affects the lower back, pelvis, hips, legs and ribs.
Causes: Dietary vitamin D is usually from foods to which the vitamin has been added, such as cow's milk. People who live in areas where sunlight is limited, get little exposure to sunlight or eat a diet low in vitamin D can develop osteomalacia. A damaged intestinal lining doesn't absorb nutrients well, and can lead to vitamin D and calcium deficiency. Some drugs used to treat seizures, including phenytoin (Dilantin, Phenytek) and phenobarbital, can cause severe vitamin D deficiency and osteomalacia.
Diagnosis: To pinpoint the cause and to rule out other bone disorders, such as osteoporosis, one might undergo one or more of the following tests: Blood and urine tests. Using general anesthesia, a surgeon inserts a slender needle through the skin and into the pelvic bone above the hip to withdraw a small sample of bone. Although a bone biopsy is accurate in detecting osteomalacia, it's rarely needed to make the diagnosis.
Treatment: The health care provider might also recommend that one increase the calcium or phosphorus intake, either through supplements or diet. Treating conditions that affect vitamin D metabolism, such as kidney and liver disease or low phosphate levels, often helps improve the signs and symptoms of osteomalacia. One will likely start by seeing the primary care provider, who might refer one to a doctor who specializes in diseases of the joints and muscles (rheumatologist) or one who specializes in metabolic bone disorders (endocrinologist). Make a list of: For osteomalacia, basic questions to ask the doctor include Don't hesitate to ask other questions. The symptoms, including any that seem unrelated to the reason for making the appointment, and when they began Key personal information, including other medical conditions and family medical history All medications, vitamins and other supplements one take, including doses Questions to ask the doctor What's the most likely cause of my symptoms? The symptoms, Key personal information, All medications, vitamins and other supplements one take, Questions to ask

Name: Osteomyelitis
Overview: Osteomyelitis is an infection in a bone. Smokers and people with chronic health conditions, such as diabetes or kidney failure, are more at risk of developing osteomyelitis.
Causes: Most cases of osteomyelitis are caused by staphylococcus bacteria, types of germs commonly found on the skin or in the nose of even healthy individuals. Germs can enter a bone in a variety of ways, including The bloodstream. Germs can also enter the body if one has broken a bone so severely that part of it is sticking out through the skin.
Diagnosis: The doctor may order a combination of tests and procedures to diagnose osteomyelitis and to determine which germ is causing the infection. Tests may include Blood tests may reveal elevated levels of white blood cells and other factors that may indicate that the body is fighting an infection. If osteomyelitis is caused by an infection in the blood, tests may reveal which germs are to blame. However, blood tests can give clues to help the doctor decide what additional tests and procedures one may need.
info-Symptoms: Pain in a specific bone, overlying redness, fever, weakness
info-Risk factors: Diabetes, intravenous drug use, prior removal of the spleen, trauma to the area
info-Diagnostic method: Blood tests, medical imaging, bone biopsy
info-Prognosis: Low risk of death with treatment

Name: Osteonecrosis
Causes: Reduced blood supply can be caused by: For about 25 percent of people with avascular necrosis, the cause of interrupted blood flow is unknown. The fat (lipids) can block small blood vessels, reducing the blood flow that feeds bones. Medical conditions, such as sickle cell anemia and Gaucher's disease, also can cause diminished blood flow to bone.
Risk factors: Injuries, such as hip dislocation or fracture, can damage nearby blood vessels and reduce blood flow to bones. Use of high-dose corticosteroids, such as prednisone, is a common cause of avascular necrosis. The reason is unknown, but one hypothesis is that corticosteroids can increase lipid levels in the blood, reducing blood flow. Consuming several alcoholic drinks a day for several years also can cause fatty deposits to form in the blood vessels.
Medication: In the early stages of avascular necrosis, symptoms might be eased with medication and therapy. The doctor might recommend: Because most people don't develop symptoms until avascular necrosis is fairly advanced, the doctor might recommend surgery. Medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve) might help relieve the pain associated with avascular necrosis. Medications, such as alendronate (Fosamax, Binosto), might slow the progression of avascular necrosis, but the evidence is mixed. If one has a clotting disorder, blood thinners, such as warfarin (Coumadin, Jantoven), might be recommended to prevent clots in the vessels feeding the bones. Besides reducing the pain, the extra space within the bone stimulates the production of healthy bone tissue and new blood vessels. A wedge of bone is removed above or below a weight-bearing joint, to help shift the weight off the damaged bone. If the diseased bone has collapsed or other treatments aren't helping, one might need surgery to replace the damaged parts of the joint with plastic or metal parts. Bone marrow aspirate and concentration is a newer procedure that might be appropriate for early stage avascular necrosis of the hip. During surgery, a core of dead hipbone is removed and stem cells inserted in its place, potentially allowing for growth of new bone.
info-Symptoms: Joint pain, decreased ability to move
info-Risk factors: Bone fractures, joint dislocations, alcoholism, high dose steroids
info-Treatment: Medication, not walking on the affected leg, stretching, surgery

Name: Osteophytes
Symptoms: In some cases, though, bone spurs can cause pain and loss of motion in the joints. Bone spurs in the knee can make it painful to extend and bend the leg. On the vertebrae, bone spurs can narrow the space that contains the spinal cord. These bone spurs can pinch the spinal cord or its nerve roots and can cause weakness or numbness in the arms or legs. Bone spurs can make it painful to move the hip, although one might feel the pain in the knee. Depending on their placement, bone spurs can reduce the range of motion in the hip joint.
Overview: Bone spurs are bony projections that develop along bone edges. Bone spurs (osteophytes) often form where bones meet each other in the joints.

Name: Osteoporosis
Overview: Osteoporosis causes bones to become weak and brittle so brittle that a fall or even mild stresses such as bending over or coughing can cause a fracture. Medications, healthy diet and weight-bearing exercise can help prevent bone loss or strengthen already weak bones.
Risk factors: A number of factors can increase the likelihood that one will develop osteoporosis including the age, race, lifestyle choices, and medical conditions and treatments. Some risk factors for osteoporosis are out of the control, including Osteoporosis is more common in people who have too much or too little of certain hormones in their bodies. The reduction of estrogen levels in women at menopause is one of the strongest risk factors for developing osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is more likely to occur in people who have: Long-term use of oral or injected corticosteroid medications, such as prednisone and cortisone, interferes with the bone-rebuilding process. Osteoporosis has also been associated with medications used to combat or prevent: The risk of osteoporosis is higher in people who have certain medical problems, including Some bad habits can increase the risk of osteoporosis. The reduction of estrogen levels in women at menopause is one of the strongest risk factors for developing osteoporosis.Men have a gradual reduction in testosterone levels as they age. Low calcium intake contributes to diminished bone density, early bone loss and an increased risk of fractures. The exact role tobacco plays in osteoporosis isn't clear, but it has been shown that tobacco use contributes to weak bones.
Remedies: These suggestions might help reduce the risk of developing osteoporosis or breaking bones: Don't smoke. Wear low-heeled shoes with nonslip soles and check the house for electrical cords, area rugs and slippery surfaces that might cause one to fall. Keep rooms brightly lit, install grab bars just inside and outside the shower door, and make sure one can get into and out of the bed easily.
info-Symptoms: Increased risk of a broken bone
info-Risk factors: Alcoholism, anorexia, European or Asian ethnicity, hyperthyroidism, gastrointestinal diseases, surgical removal of the ovaries, kidney disease, smoking, certain medications
info-Treatment: Good diet, exercise, fall prevention, stopping smoking

Name: Osteosarcoma
Overview: Osteosarcoma, the most common type of bone cancer, often starts in the long bones the legs or the arms but it can occur in any bone. Doctors select treatment options based on where the osteosarcoma starts, the size of the cancer, the type and grade of the osteosarcoma, and whether the cancer has spread beyond the bone.
Diagnosis: X-ray Computerized tomography (CT) Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) Positron emission tomography (PET) Bone scan Needle biopsy. The doctor makes an incision through the skin and removes either the entire tumor (excisional biopsy) or a portion of the tumor (incisional biopsy).

Name: Otitis media
Causes: This infection often results from another illness cold, flu or allergy that causes congestion and swelling of the nasal passages, throat and eustachian tubes. The eustachian tubes are a pair of narrow tubes that run from each middle ear to high in the back of the throat, behind the nasal passages. The throat end of the tubes open and close to: Swollen eustachian tubes can become blocked, causing fluids to build up in the middle ear. Because adenoids are near the opening of the eustachian tubes, swelling of the adenoids may block the tubes. Chronic otitis media with effusion, occurs when fluid remains in the middle ear and continues to return without bacterial or viral infection.
Risk factors: Children between the ages of 6 months and 2 years are more susceptible to ear infections because of the size and shape of their eustachian tubes and because their immune systems are still developing. Children cared for in group settings are more likely to get colds and ear infections than are children who stay home. People with seasonal allergies may have a greater risk of ear infections when pollen counts are high. Exposure to tobacco smoke or high levels of air pollution can increase the risk of ear infections.
Diagnosis: If the middle ear is filled with fluid, the doctor will observe little to no movement of the eardrum. However, the more pressure there is from fluid in the middle ear, the more sound the eardrum will reflect. Rarely, a doctor may use a tiny tube that pierces the eardrum to drain fluid from the middle ear a procedure called tympanocentesis. If the child has had multiple ear infections or fluid buildup in the middle ear, the doctor may refer one to a hearing specialist (audiologist), speech therapist or developmental therapist for tests of hearing, speech skills, language comprehension or developmental abilities. The doctor likely makes this diagnosis if he or she sees signs of fluid in the middle ear, if there are signs or symptoms of an infection, and if symptoms started relatively suddenly. If the diagnosis is otitis media with effusion, the doctor has found evidence of fluid in the middle ear, but there are presently no signs or symptoms of infection. If the doctor makes a diagnosis of chronic suppurative otitis media, he or she has found that a long-term ear infection resulted in tearing of the eardrum.
info-Symptoms: Ear pain, fever, hearing loss
info-Risk factors: Smoke exposure, daycare

Name: Ovarian cancer
Overview: Ovarian cancer is a type of cancer that begins in the ovaries. The ovaries each about the size of an almond produce eggs (ova) as well as the hormones estrogen, progesterone and testosterone.
Causes: Ovarian cancer types include Epithelial tumors, which begin in the thin layer of tissue that covers the outside of the ovaries. Stromal tumors, which begin in the ovarian tissue that contains hormone-producing cells.
Risk factors: Factors that can increase the risk of ovarian cancer include Inherited gene mutations. The genes known to increase the risk of ovarian cancer are called breast cancer gene 1 (BRCA1) and breast cancer gene 2 (BRCA2). Other gene mutations, including those associated with Lynch syndrome, are known to increase the risk of ovarian cancer. Beginning menstruation at an early age or starting menopause at a later age, or both, may increase the risk of ovarian cancer.
Diagnosis: For example, a cancer antigen (CA) 125 test can detect a protein that's often found on the surface of ovarian cancer cells. These tests can't tell the doctor whether one has cancer, but may give clues about the diagnosis and prognosis. Once it's confirmed that one has ovarian cancer, the doctor will use information from the tests and procedures to assign the cancer a stage. During a pelvic exam, the doctor inserts gloved fingers into the vagina and simultaneously presses a hand on the abdomen in order to feel (palpate) the pelvic organs.
info-Symptoms: Early: vagueLater: bloating, pelvic pain, constipation, abdominal swelling, loss of appetite
info-Usual onset: Usual age of diagnosis 63 years old
info-Risk factors: Never having children, hormone therapy after menopause, fertility medication, obesity, genetics

Name: Ovarian cysts
Overview: The ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix and vagina (vaginal canal) make up the female reproductive system. However, ovarian cysts especially those that have ruptured can cause serious symptoms.
Causes: A follicular cyst occurs when the follicle of the ovary doesn't rupture or release its egg. Fluid accumulates inside the follicle, and a corpus luteum cyst develops. If a normal monthly follicle keeps growing, it's known as a functional cyst. The egg travels through the fallopian tube, propelled in part by contractions in the fallopian tube walls. Here in the fallopian tube, the egg may be fertilized by a sperm. If the egg is fertilized, the egg and sperm unite to form a one-celled entity called a zygote. If the egg isn't fertilized, it's simply reabsorbed by the body perhaps before it even reaches the uterus. Around the midpoint of the menstrual cycle, an egg bursts out of its follicle and travels down the fallopian tube. A follicular cyst begins when the follicle doesn't rupture or release its egg, but continues to grow. When a follicle releases its egg, it begins producing estrogen and progesterone for conception. Sometimes, fluid accumulates inside the follicle, causing the corpus luteum to grow into a cyst.
Risk factors: These include taking the fertility drug clomiphene (Clomid), which is used to cause one to ovulate. Sometimes, the cyst that forms when one ovulate stays on the ovary throughout the pregnancy.
Diagnosis: Depending on its size and whether it's fluid filled, solid or mixed, the doctor likely will recommend tests to determine its type and whether one need treatment. If the cyst is partially solid and one is at high risk of ovarian cancer, the doctor might order this test. Elevated CA 125 levels can also occur in noncancerous conditions, such as endometriosis, uterine fibroids and pelvic inflammatory disease. The doctor analyzes the image to confirm the presence of a cyst, help identify its location and determine whether it's solid, filled with fluid or mixed. Using a laparoscope a slim, lighted instrument inserted into the abdomen through a small incision the doctor can see the ovaries and remove the ovarian cyst.
Treatment: The doctor might suggest removing a cyst that is large, doesn't look like a functional cyst, is growing, continues through two or three menstrual cycles, or causes pain. In some cases, the doctor might suggest removing the affected ovary and leaving the other intact (oophorectomy). The doctor might recommend hormonal contraceptives, such as birth control pills, to keep ovarian cysts from recurring.
info-Symptoms: None, bloating, lower abdominal pain, lower back pain

Name: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome
Symptoms: With mild to moderate ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, symptoms can include Some women who use injectable fertility drugs get a mild form of OHSS. With severe ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, one might have: If one is having fertility treatments and one experience symptoms of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, tell the doctor. Even if one has a mild case of OHSS, the doctor will want to observe one for sudden weight gain or worsening symptoms.
Overview: During in vitro fertilization, eggs are removed from mature follicles within an ovary (A). OHSS may occur in women undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) or ovulation induction with injectable medications.
Diagnosis: For ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, the doctor may make a diagnosis based on: A physical exam. If one has OHSS, an ultrasound may show that the ovaries are bigger than normal, with large fluid-filled cysts where follicles developed.

Name: Overactive bladder
Causes: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine.
Diagnosis: The appointment will likely include a: The doctor may order tests to assess how well the bladder is functioning and its ability to empty steadily and completely (urodynamic tests). To measure residual urine after one has voided, the doctor may request an ultrasound scan of the bladder. In some cases, a thin tube (catheter) is passed through the urethra and into the bladder to drain the remaining urine, which can then be measured. Medical history Physical exam, which may include a rectal exam and a pelvic exam in women Urine sample to test for infection, traces of blood or other abnormalities Focused neurological exam that may identify sensory problems or abnormal reflexes Measuring urine left in the bladder.
Remedies: Drinking too much fluid can worsen the symptoms, but not drinking enough can make the urine become concentrated and can irritate the lining of the bladder. Some foods and drinks that may irritate the bladder include caffeine, alcohol, tea, carbonated drinks, citrus juice and fruit, chocolate, spicy foods, and tomatoes.
Medication: These drugs include Common side effects of most of these drugs include dry eyes and dry mouth, but drinking water to quench thirst can aggravate symptoms of overactive bladder. The doctor may recommend that one sip small amounts of water or suck on a piece of sugar-free candy or chew sugar-free gum to relieve dry mouth, and use eyedrops to keep the eyes moist.
info-Symptoms: Frequent feeling of needing to urinate, incontinence
info-Risk factors: Obesity, caffeine, constipation
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms after ruling out other possible causes
info-Treatment: Pelvic floor exercises, bladder training, drinking moderate fluids, weight loss

Name: Oxyphil cell carcinoma
Overview: The thyroid gland is located at the base of the neck, just below the Adam's apple. Hurthle (HEERT-luh) cell cancer is a rare cancer that affects the thyroid gland.
Diagnosis: The doctor will examine the neck, checking the size of the thyroid and seeing whether the lymph nodes are swollen. Imaging tests, including ultrasound and CT, can help the doctor determine whether an abnormal growth is present in the thyroid. During a thyroid biopsy, a fine needle is passed through the skin of the neck guided by ultrasound images.

Name: Paget 's disease of bone
Symptoms: When symptoms occur, the most common complaint is bone pain. Paget's disease of bone in the pelvis can cause hip pain. As the bones weaken, they may bend causing one to become bowlegged. Enlarged and misshapen bones in the legs can put extra stress on nearby joints, which may cause osteoarthritis in the knee or hip.
Overview: Paget's disease of bone interferes with the body's normal recycling process, in which new bone tissue gradually replaces old bone tissue. Complications of Paget's disease of bone can include broken bones, hearing loss and pinched nerves in the spine.
Risk factors: Factors that can increase the risk of Paget's disease of bone include Age. People older than 40 are most likely to develop Paget's disease of bone. Paget's disease of bone is more common in England, Scotland, central Europe and Greece as well as countries settled by European immigrants. If one has a relative who has Paget's disease of bone, one is more likely to develop the condition.
Diagnosis: He or she may also order X-rays and blood tests that can help confirm the diagnosis of Paget's disease of bone. Bone changes common to Paget's disease of bone can be revealed by: People who have Paget's disease of bone usually have elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase in their blood, which can be revealed by a blood test. X-ray images of the bones can show areas of bone reabsorption, enlargement of the bone and deformities that are characteristic of Paget's disease of bone, such as bowing of the long bones. This material travels to the spots on the bones most affected by Paget's disease of bone, so they light up on the scan images.
Remedies: To reduce the risk of complications associated with Paget's disease of bone, Prevent falls. Remove slippery floor coverings, use nonskid mats in the bathtub or shower, tuck away cords, and install handrails on stairways and grab bars in the bathroom. Be sure the diet includes adequate levels of calcium and vitamin D, which helps bones absorb calcium.
Medication: Bisphosphonates can also increase the risk of a rare condition in which a section of jawbone dies and deteriorates (osteonecrosis of the jawbone), usually associated with active dental disease or oral surgery. In rare cases, surgery might be required to: Paget's disease of bone often causes the body to produce too many blood vessels in the affected bones, increasing the risk of serious blood loss during an operation. If one is scheduled for surgery that involves bones affected by Paget's disease, the doctor might prescribe medications to reduce the activity of the disease, which may help reduce blood loss during surgery.

Name: Paget 's disease of the nipple
Overview: Breast and nipple changes can be a sign of breast cancer. Most women with Paget's disease of the breast have underlying ductal breast cancer, either in situ meaning in its original place or, less commonly, invasive breast cancer.
Risk factors: Risk factors that affect the likelihood of developing Paget's disease of the breast are the same factors that affect the risk of developing any other type of breast cancer. Some factors that make one more susceptible to breast cancer include Having one or more risk factors doesn't necessarily mean one will develop breast cancer. If one has had breast cancer in one breast, one has an increased risk of developing cancer in the other breast. If one has had lobular carcinoma in situ or atypical hyperplasia, the risk of developing breast cancer is higher. If one has a mother, sister or daughter with breast or ovarian cancer or both, or even a father or brother with breast cancer, one has a greater chance of developing breast cancer. Defects in one of several genes, especially BRCA1 or BRCA2, put one at greater risk of developing breast cancer as well as ovarian and other cancers. Women with dense breast tissue, as seen on a mammogram, face a higher risk of breast cancer. If one received radiation treatments to the chest as a child or young adult to treat another cancer, one is more likely to develop breast cancer later in life. Weighing more than is healthy for the age and height increases the risk of breast cancer especially after menopause and if one gained weight as an adult. Drinking large amounts of alcohol increases the risk of developing breast cancer.
Diagnosis: A mammogram an X-ray exam of the breast tissue may indicate whether the nipple and skin changes are linked to an underlying breast cancer, as is usually the case in Paget's disease of the breast. If results from mammography in both breasts don't reveal any signs of breast cancer, the doctor may follow up with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which may detect cancer that's not able to be seen on a mammogram. If one has invasive breast cancer, the lymph nodes under the arm (axillary lymph nodes) need to be checked to see if the cancer has spread to this area. During the biopsy, the surgeon locates the sentinel nodes the first lymph nodes to receive the drainage from breast tumors and therefore the first place cancer cells will travel. During this exam, the doctor physically checks for unusual areas in both breasts, noting the appearance of the skin on and around the nipples and feeling for any lumps or areas of thickening.

Name: Pain , chest
Overview: Chest pain appears in many forms, ranging from a sharp stab to a dull ache. Because chest pain can indicate a serious problem, it's important to seek immediate medical help.
Causes: Chest pain has many possible causes, all of which need medical attention. A heart attack results from blocked blood flow, often from a blood clot, to the heart muscle. Angina is the term for chest pain caused by poor blood flow to the heart. This is often caused by the buildup of thick plaques on the inner walls of the arteries that carry blood to the heart. These plaques narrow the arteries and restrict the heart's blood supply, particularly during exertion. If the inner layers of this blood vessel separate, blood is forced between the layers and can cause the aorta to rupture. In this condition, the cartilage of the rib cage, particularly the cartilage that joins the ribs to the breastbone, becomes inflamed and painful. Chronic pain syndromes, such as fibromyalgia, can produce persistent muscle-related chest pain. This occurs when a blood clot becomes lodged in a lung (pulmonary) artery, blocking blood flow to lung tissue. If the membrane that covers the lungs becomes inflamed, it can cause chest pain that worsens when one inhale or cough. The chest pain associated with a collapsed lung typically begins suddenly and can last for hours, and is generally associated with shortness of breath. This condition occurs when one has high blood pressure in the arteries carrying blood to the lungs, which can produce chest pain. Caused by a reactivation of the chickenpox virus, shingles can produce pain and a band of blisters from the back around to the chest wall.
Diagnosis: Some of the first tests the doctor may order include Depending upon the results from these initial tests, one may need follow-up testing, which may include Electrocardiogram (ECG). Because injured heart muscle doesn't conduct electrical impulses normally, the ECG may show that one has had or are having a heart attack. The doctor may order blood tests to check for increased levels of certain proteins or enzymes normally found in heart muscle. Damage to heart cells from a heart attack may allow these proteins or enzymes to leak, over a period of hours, into the blood. An X-ray of the chest allows doctors to check the condition of the lungs and the size and shape of the heart and major blood vessels. A CT coronary angiogram can also be done with dye to check the heart and lung arteries for blockages and other problems. These measure how the heart and blood vessels respond to exertion, which may indicate if the chest pain is heart-related. A liquid dye is injected into the arteries of the heart through a long, thin tube (catheter) that's fed through an artery, either through the wrist or the groin, to arteries in the heart.
Medication: Nitroglycerin usually taken as a tablet under the tongue relaxes heart arteries, so blood can flow more easily through the narrowed spaces. If doctors suspect that the chest pain is related to the heart, one will likely be given aspirin. If one has a clot in an artery feeding the heart or lungs, one will be given drugs that inhibit blood clotting to prevent the formation of more clots. If the chest pain is caused by stomach acid splashing into the esophagus, the doctor may suggest medications that reduce the amount of acid in the stomach. If the chest pain is caused by a blockage in an artery feeding the heart, the doctor will insert a catheter with a balloon on the end into a large blood vessel in the groin, and thread it up to the blockage. During this procedure, surgeons take a blood vessel from another part of the body and use it to create an alternative route for blood to go around the blocked artery. One may need emergency surgery to repair an aortic dissection a life-threatening condition in which the artery that carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body ruptures.

Name: Painful bladder syndrome
Symptoms: Interstitial cystitis signs and symptoms include Symptoms severity is different for everyone, and some people may experience symptom-free periods. Although signs and symptoms of interstitial cystitis may resemble those of a chronic urinary tract infection, there's usually no infection. However, symptoms may worsen if a person with interstitial cystitis gets a urinary tract infection.
Overview: The bladder, kidneys, ureters and urethra make up the urinary system. When one has interstitial cystitis, the walls of the bladder become irritated and inflamed (shown right), compared with those of a normal bladder (shown top). Interstitial cystitis (in-tur-STISH-ul sis-TIE-tis) is a chronic condition causing bladder pressure, bladder pain and sometimes pelvic pain. With interstitial cystitis, these signals get mixed up one feel the need to urinate more often and with smaller volumes of urine than most people.
Risk factors: Symptoms in men may mimic interstitial cystitis, but they're more often associated with an inflammation of the prostate gland (prostatitis). Having fair skin and red hair has been associated with a greater risk of interstitial cystitis. Interstitial cystitis may be associated with other chronic pain disorder, such as irritable bowel syndrome or fibromyalgia.
Diagnosis: The doctor will ask one to describe the symptoms and may ask one to keep a bladder diary, recording the volume of fluids one drink and the volume of urine one pass. The doctor inserts a thin tube with a tiny camera (cystoscope) through the urethra, showing the lining of the bladder. During cystoscopy under anesthesia, the doctor may remove a sample of tissue (biopsy) from the bladder and the urethra for examination under a microscope. The doctor places (instills) two solutions water and potassium chloride into the bladder, one at a time. If one feel noticeably more pain or urgency with the potassium solution than with the water, the doctor may diagnose interstitial cystitis.
Remedies: Eliminating or reducing foods in the diet that irritate the bladder may help to relieve the discomfort of interstitial cystitis. Common bladder irritants known as the four Cs include carbonated beverages, caffeine in all forms (including chocolate), citrus products and food containing high concentrations of vitamin C. Consider avoiding similar foods, such as tomatoes, pickled foods, alcohol and spices. If one think certain foods may irritate the bladder, try eliminating them from the diet. During bladder training, one may learn to control urinary urges by using relaxation techniques, such as breathing slowly and deeply or distracting theself with another activity. Smoking may worsen any painful condition, and smoking contributes to bladder cancer.
Medication: In bladder instillation, the doctor places the prescription medication dimethyl sulfoxide (Rimso-50) into the bladder through a thin, flexible tube (catheter) inserted through the urethra. One might receive dimethyl sulfoxide also called DMSO treatment weekly for six to eight weeks, and then have maintenance treatments as needed such as every couple of weeks, for up to one year. A newer approach to bladder instillation uses a solution containing the medications lidocaine, sodium bicarbonate, and either pentosan or heparin. People with severe pain or those whose bladders can hold only very small volumes of urine are possible candidates for surgery, but usually only after other treatments fail and symptoms affect quality of life.
info-Symptoms: Chronic pain of the bladder, feeling the need to urinate right away, needing to urinate often, pain with sex
info-Diagnostic method: Based on the symptoms after ruling out other conditions

Name: Painful intercourse ( dyspareunia )
Overview: Painful intercourse can occur for reasons that range from structural problems to psychological concerns. The medical term for painful intercourse is dyspareunia (dis-puh-ROO-nee-uh), defined as persistent or recurrent genital pain that occurs just before, during or after intercourse.
Causes: Physical causes of painful intercourse differ, depending on whether the pain occurs at entry or with deep thrusting. Pain during penetration might be associated with a range of factors, including Not enough lubrication. Certain medications are known to affect sexual desire or arousal, which can decrease lubrication and make sex painful. Causes include Emotions are deeply intertwined with sexual activity, so they might play a role in sexual pain. This includes injury or irritation from an accident, pelvic surgery, female circumcision or a cut made during childbirth to enlarge the birth canal (episiotomy). Scarring from pelvic surgery, including hysterectomy, can cause painful intercourse. Medical treatments for cancer, such as radiation and chemotherapy, can cause changes that make sex painful.
Diagnosis: The doctor might ask when the pain began, where it hurts, how it feels and if it happens with every sexual partner and every sexual position. The doctor might also inquire about the sexual history, surgical history and childbirth. If the doctor suspects certain causes of painful intercourse, he or she might also recommend a pelvic ultrasound.
Remedies: One and the partner might be able to minimize pain with a few changes to the sexual routine: Change positions. If one has sharp pain during thrusting, try different positions, such as being on top. In this position, one might be able to regulate penetration to a depth that feels good to one.
Medication: The Food and Drug Administration approved the drug ospemifene (Osphena) to treat moderate to severe dyspareunia in women who have problems with vaginal lubrication. Drawbacks are that the drug might cause hot flashes, and it carries a risk of stroke, blood clots and cancer of the lining of the uterus (endometrium). If one and the partner have avoided intimacy because of painful intercourse, one might also need help improving communication with the partner and restoring sexual intimacy.

Name: Painful periods
Overview: Menstrual cramps (dysmenorrhea) are throbbing or cramping pains in the lower abdomen. Menstrual cramps that aren't caused by another condition tend to lessen with age and often improve after giving birth.
Causes: During the menstrual period, the uterus contracts to help expel its lining. The tissue that lines the uterus becomes implanted outside the uterus, most commonly on the fallopian tubes, ovaries or the tissue lining the pelvis. In some women, the opening of the cervix is small enough to impede menstrual flow, causing a painful increase of pressure within the uterus.
Diagnosis: During the pelvic exam, the doctor will check for abnormalities in the reproductive organs and look for signs of infection. If the doctor suspects that a disorder is causing the menstrual cramps, he or she may recommend other tests, such as: Other imaging tests. CT combines X-ray images taken from many angles to produce cross-sectional images of bones, organs and other soft tissues inside the body. Although not usually necessary to diagnosis menstrual cramps, laparoscopy can help detect an underlying condition, such as endometriosis, adhesions, fibroids, ovarian cysts and ectopic pregnancy. During this outpatient surgery, the doctor views the abdominal cavity and reproductive organs by making tiny incisions in the abdomen and inserting a fiber-optic tube with a small camera lens.
Treatment: To ease the menstrual cramps, the doctor might recommend: Pain relievers. Over-the-counter pain relievers, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve), at regular doses starting the day before one expect the period to begin can help control the pain of cramps. Besides getting enough sleep and rest, things one might want to try include Most alternative therapies for treating menstrual cramps haven't been studied enough for experts to recommend them. However, some alternative treatments might help, including Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS). If one has bothersome menstrual cramps, make an appointment with either the primary physician or a doctor who specializes in the female reproductive system (gynecologist). These hormones can also be delivered in several other forms: an injection, a skin patch, an implant placed under the skin of the arm, a flexible ring that one insert into the vagina, or an intrauterine device (IUD). If the menstrual cramps are caused by a disorder such as endometriosis or fibroids, surgery to correct the problem might help the symptoms. Physical activity, including sex, helps ease menstrual cramps for some women. Soaking in a hot bath or using a heating pad, hot water bottle or heat patch on the lower abdomen might ease menstrual cramps. A number of studies have indicated that vitamin E, omega-3 fatty acids, vitamin B-1 (thiamin), vitamin B-6 and magnesium supplements might reduce menstrual cramps. Some herbal products, such as pycnogenol, fennel or combination products, might provide some relief from menstrual cramps. Although research on acupressure and menstrual cramps is limited, it appears that acupressure may be more effective than a placebo in easing menstrual cramps.
Remedies: Besides getting enough sleep and rest, things one might want to try include Exercise regularly. Soaking in a hot bath or using a heating pad, hot water bottle or heat patch on the lower abdomen might ease menstrual cramps. A number of studies have indicated that vitamin E, omega-3 fatty acids, vitamin B-1 (thiamin), vitamin B-6 and magnesium supplements might reduce menstrual cramps.
info-Symptoms: Pain during menstruation, diarrhea, nausea
info-Usual onset: Within a year of the first menstrual period
info-Causes: No underlying problem, uterine fibroids, adenomyosis, endometriosis
info-Medication: NSAIDs such as ibuprofen, hormonal birth control, IUD with progestogen

Name: Palsy , cerebral
Overview: Cerebral palsy is a group of disorders that affect movement and muscle tone or posture. In general, cerebral palsy causes impaired movement associated with abnormal reflexes, floppiness or rigidity of the limbs and trunk, abnormal posture, involuntary movements, unsteady walking, or some combination of these. People with cerebral palsy can have problems swallowing and commonly have eye muscle imbalance, in which the eyes don't focus on the same object.
Risk factors: A number of factors are associated with an increased risk of cerebral palsy. Certain infections or toxic exposures during pregnancy can significantly increase cerebral palsy risk to the baby. Infections of particular concern include Illnesses in a newborn baby that can greatly increase the risk of cerebral palsy include While the potential contribution from each is limited, additional pregnancy or birth factors associated with increased cerebral palsy risk include Cytomegalovirus. Infants for whom maternal Zika infection causes their head size to be smaller than normal (microcephaly) can develop cerebral palsy. Other conditions that can increase the risk of cerebral palsy include thyroid problems, intellectual disabilities or seizures, and exposure to toxins, such as methyl mercury. Babies who weigh less than 5.5 pounds (2.5 kilograms) are at higher risk of developing cerebral palsy. Cerebral palsy risk increases with the number of babies sharing the uterus. If one or more of the babies die, the survivors risk of cerebral palsy increases. Babies born fewer than 28 weeks into the pregnancy are at higher risk of cerebral palsy. The earlier a baby is born, the greater the cerebral palsy risk.
Diagnosis: If the family doctor or pediatrician suspects the child has cerebral palsy, he or she will evaluate the child's signs and symptoms, monitor growth and development, review the child's medical history, and conduct a physical exam. The doctor might refer one to a specialist trained in treating children with brain and nervous system conditions (pediatric neurologist, pediatric physical medicine and rehabilitation specialist, or child developmental specialist). An MRI scan uses radio waves and a magnetic field to produce detailed 3D or cross-sectional images of the child's brain. If the child is diagnosed with cerebral palsy, one will likely be referred to specialists to test the child for other conditions often associated with the disorder. An ultrasound doesn't produce a detailed image, but it may be used because it's quick and inexpensive, and it can provide a valuable preliminary assessment of the brain.
Medication: Medications that can lessen muscle tightness might be used to improve functional abilities, treat pain and manage complications related to spasticity or other cerebral palsy symptoms. To treat tightening of a specific muscle, the doctor might recommend injections of onabotulinumtoxinA (Botox, Dysport) or another agent. Drugs such as diazepam (Valium), dantrolene (Dantrium), baclofen (Gablofen, Lioresal) and tizanidine (Zanaflex) are often used to relax muscles. Muscle training and exercises can help the child's strength, flexibility, balance, motor development and mobility. One will also learn how to safely care for the child's everyday needs at home, such as bathing and feeding the child. Braces or splints might be recommended for the child to help with function, such as improved walking, and stretching stiff muscles. Children with severe contractures or deformities might need surgery on bones or joints to place their arms, hips or legs in their correct positions. Occupational therapists work to help the child gain independence in daily activities and routines in the home, the school and the community. This type of therapy can help improve the child's motor skills, speech and emotional well-being. In some severe cases, when other treatments haven't helped, surgeons might cut the nerves serving the spastic muscles in a procedure called selective dorsal rhizotomy.

Name: Palsy , facial
Overview: The symptoms of Bell's palsy include sudden weakness in the facial muscles. Bell's palsy, also known as acute peripheral facial palsy of unknown cause, can occur at any age.
Diagnosis: Other conditions such as a stroke, infections, Lyme disease and tumors can cause facial muscle weakness that mimics Bell's palsy. If the cause of the symptoms isn't clear, the doctor may recommend other tests, including Electromyography (EMG). Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or computerized tomography (CT) may be needed on occasion to rule out other possible sources of pressure on the facial nerve, such as a tumor or skull fracture.
Medication: However, despite this, valacyclovir (Valtrex) or acyclovir (Zovirax) is sometimes given in combination with prednisone in people with severe facial palsy. In the past, decompression surgery was used to relieve the pressure on the facial nerve by opening the bony passage that the nerve passes through. Rarely, plastic surgery may be needed to correct lasting facial nerve problems. Examples of this type of surgery include eyebrow lift, eyelid lift, facial implants and nerve grafts.

Name: Pancreatic cancer
Overview: The pancreas is a long, flat gland that lies horizontally behind the stomach. Pancreatic cancer begins in the tissues of the pancreas an organ in the abdomen that lies behind the lower part of the stomach. The most common type of cancer that forms in the pancreas begins in the cells that line the ducts that carry digestive enzymes out of the pancreas (pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma).
Causes: Pancreatic cancer occurs when cells in the pancreas develop changes (mutations) in their DNA. When left untreated, the pancreatic cancer cells can spread to nearby organs and blood vessels and to distant parts of the body. Less frequently, cancer can form in the hormone-producing cells or the neuroendocrine cells of the pancreas. These types of cancer are called pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, islet cell tumors or pancreatic endocrine cancer.
Diagnosis: During an endoscopic ultrasound of the pancreas, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube (endoscope) down the throat and into the abdomen. If the doctor suspects pancreatic cancer, he or she may have one undergo one or more of the following tests: If the doctor confirms a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer, he or she tries to determine the extent (stage) of the cancer. Using information from staging tests, the doctor assigns the pancreatic cancer a stage, which helps determine what treatments are most likely to benefit one. Techniques used to diagnose pancreatic cancer include ultrasound, computerized tomography (CT) scans, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and, sometimes, positron emission tomography (PET) scans. The doctor may test the blood for specific proteins (tumor markers) shed by pancreatic cancer cells.
info-Symptoms: Yellow skin, abdominal or back pain, unexplained weight loss, light-colored stools, dark urine, loss of appetite
info-Risk factors: Tobacco smoking, heavy alcohol intake, obesity, diabetes, certain rare genetic conditions
info-Diagnostic method: Medical imaging, blood tests, tissue biopsy
info-Prevention: Not smoking, low alcohol intake, maintaining a healthy weight, low red meat diet

Name: Pancreatic cysts
Symptoms: One may not have symptoms from pancreatic cysts, which are often found when imaging tests of the abdomen are done for another reason. When signs or symptoms of pancreatic cysts do occur, they typically include Rarely, cysts can become infected.
Causes: Some cysts are associated with rare illnesses, including polycystic kidney disease or von Hippel-Lindau disease, a genetic disorder that can affect the pancreas and other organs. Pseudocysts often follow a bout of a painful condition in which digestive enzymes become prematurely active and irritate the pancreas (pancreatitis).
Diagnosis: Tests include The characteristics and location of the pancreatic cyst, along with the age and sex, can sometimes help doctors determine the type of cyst one has: Computerized tomography (CT) scan. This imaging test can highlight subtle details of a pancreatic cyst, including whether it has any components that suggest a higher risk of cancer. Mucinous cystic neoplasms are usually situated in the body or tail of the pancreas and nearly always occurs in women, most often in middle-aged women.

Name: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
Overview: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (pNET) are a group of cancers that can occur in the hormone-producing cells of the pancreas. Some pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor cells continue to secrete hormones (known as functional tumors), creating too much of the given hormone in the body.
Diagnosis: During an endoscopic ultrasound of the pancreas, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube (endoscope) down the throat and into the abdomen. The tracer sticks to pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors so that they show clearly on the images, which may be created with positron emission tomography (PET) that's combined with CT or MRI. In some cases, the doctor may recommend minimally invasive surgery to obtain a tissue sample for testing (biopsy).
Treatment: Treatment for a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor varies based on the types of cells involved in the cancer, the extent and characteristics of the cancer, the preferences, and the overall health. For cancers that occurs in the tail of the pancreas, surgery may involve removing the tail of the pancreas (distal pancreatectomy), leaving the head portion intact. Cancers that affect the head of the pancreas may require a Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy), which involves removing the cancer and part or most of the pancreas. Over days to weeks, the medication delivers radiation directly to the cancer cells, causing them to die. One PRRT, lutetium Lu 177 dotatate (Lutathera), is used to treat advanced cancers. Options include treatment to block blood flow to liver tumors (hepatic artery occlusion), treatment to deliver chemotherapy directly to the liver (chemoembolization), treatment to deliver radiation directly to the liver (radioembolization) and liver transplant.

Name: Pancreatitis
Treatment: If the pancreatitis persists and one still experience pain when eating, the doctor may recommend a feeding tube to help one get nutrition. Depending on the cause of the pancreatitis, treatment may include Procedures to remove bile duct obstructions. Pancreatitis caused by a narrowed or blocked bile duct may require procedures to open or widen the bile duct. If gallstones caused the pancreatitis, the doctor may recommend surgery to remove the gallbladder (cholecystectomy). If this is the cause of the pancreatitis, the doctor may recommend one enter a treatment program for alcohol addiction.
Remedies: Once one leave the hospital, one can take steps to continue the recovery from pancreatitis, such as: Stop drinking alcohol. If one is unable to stop drinking alcohol on the own, ask the doctor for help.
info-Symptoms: Pain in the upper abdomen, nausea, vomiting, fever, fatty stool
info-Causes: Gallstones, heavy alcohol use, direct trauma, certain medications, mumps
info-Risk factors: Smoking
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, blood amylase or lipase

Name: Panic attacks and panic disorder
Overview: A panic attack is a sudden episode of intense fear that triggers severe physical reactions when there is no real danger or apparent cause. Many people have just one or two panic attacks in their lifetimes, and the problem goes away, perhaps when a stressful situation ends. But if one has had recurrent, unexpected panic attacks and spent long periods in constant fear of another attack, one may have a condition called panic disorder.
Diagnosis: For a diagnosis of panic disorder, the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association, lists these points: If one has panic attacks but not a diagnosed panic disorder, one can still benefit from treatment. A complete physical exam Blood tests to check the thyroid and other possible conditions and tests on the heart, such as an electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) A psychological evaluation to talk about the symptoms, fears or concerns, stressful situations, relationship problems, situations one may be avoiding, and family history One has frequent, unexpected panic attacks. At least one of the attacks has been followed by one month or more of ongoing worry about having another attack; continued fear of the consequences of an attack, such as losing control, having a heart attack or going crazy; or significant changes in the behavior, such as avoiding situations that one think may trigger a panic attack.
Remedies: While panic attacks and panic disorder benefit from professional treatment, these self-care steps can help one manage symptoms: Stick to the treatment plan. Facing the fears can be difficult, but treatment can help one feel like one is not a hostage in the own home. For example, yoga, deep breathing and progressive muscle relaxation tensing one muscle at a time, and then completely releasing the tension until every muscle in the body is relaxed also may be helpful.
Medication: Several types of medication have been shown to be effective in managing symptoms of panic attacks, including If one medication doesn't work well for one, the doctor may recommend switching to another or combining certain medications to boost effectiveness. Generally safe with a low risk of serious side effects, SSRI antidepressants are typically recommended as the first choice of medications to treat panic attacks. SSRIs approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for the treatment of panic disorder include fluoxetine (Prozac), paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva) and sertraline (Zoloft). Benzodiazepines approved by the FDA for the treatment of panic disorder include alprazolam (Xanax) and clonazepam (Klonopin).

Name: Paraganglioma
Diagnosis: In general, tests might include If there's a risk that the neuroendocrine tumor may have spread to other parts of the body, one might have additional tests to determine the extent of the cancer. For neuroendocrine tumors, pictures are sometimes created using positron emission tomography (PET) with a radioactive tracer that's injected into a vein. To collect the cells, the doctor might insert a long, thin tube with a light and a camera on the end into the lungs (bronchoscopy), the esophagus (endoscopy) or the rectum (colonoscopy), depending on the situation.
Treatment: The treatment options for the neuroendocrine tumor will depend on the type of tumor, its location, and whether one is experiencing signs and symptoms of excess hormones produced by the tumor. In general, neuroendocrine tumor treatment options might include Other treatments might be available to one depending on the particular situation and the specific type of neuroendocrine tumor. By blocking these abnormalities, targeted drug treatments can cause tumor cells to die. One PRRT drug, lutetium Lu 177 dotatate (Lutathera), is used to treat advanced neuroendocrine tumors. If the neuroendocrine tumor releases excess hormones, the doctor might recommend medications to control the signs and symptoms.
