Name: Paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system can develop relatively quickly, often over days to weeks. Signs and symptoms of paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system often begin even before a cancer is diagnosed. Signs and symptoms vary depending on the body part being injured, and may include Examples of paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system include Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome. Signs and symptoms include pelvic and lower extremity muscle weakness, fatigue, difficulty swallowing, difficulty speaking, irregular eye movement, and double vision. When it occurs as a paraneoplastic syndrome, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome is typically associated with lung cancer. When myasthenia gravis occurs as a paraneoplastic syndrome, it is typically associated with cancer of the thymus gland (thymoma). The signs and symptoms of paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system are similar to those of many conditions, including cancer, cancer complications and even some cancer treatments. But if one has any signs or symptoms suggesting a paraneoplastic syndrome, see the doctor as soon as possible. This is inflammation affecting a region of the brain known as the limbic system, which controls emotions, behaviors and certain memory functions. It can cause rapid, irregular eye movements (opsoclonus) and involuntary, chaotic muscle jerks (myoclonus) in the limbs and trunk. Previously called stiff man syndrome, this syndrome is characterized by progressive, severe muscle stiffness or rigidity, mainly affecting the spine and legs. These impulses can cause twitching, muscle rippling that looks like a bag of worms, progressive stiffness, muscle cramps, slowed movement and other muscle impairments. When damage involves only the sensory nerves of the peripheral nervous system, one can have pain and disturbances in sensation anywhere in the body. When this part of the nervous system is affected, common symptoms are low blood pressure, irregular heartbeats and trouble breathing.
Overview: Paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system are a group of uncommon disorders that develop in some people who have cancer. Paraneoplastic syndromes of the nervous system occur when cancer-fighting agents of the immune system also attack parts of the brain, spinal cord, peripheral nerves or muscle.
Medication: In addition to drugs, such as chemotherapy, to combat the cancer, the doctor may prescribe one or more of the following drugs to stop the immune system from attacking the nervous system: Depending on the type of neurological syndrome and symptoms, other medications may include Other treatments that may improve symptoms include Other therapies may be helpful if a paraneoplastic syndrome has caused significant disability: Corticosteroids, such as prednisone, inhibit inflammation. Serious long-term side effects include weakening of the bones (osteoporosis), type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol and others. Drugs may include azathioprine (Imuran, Azasan) and cyclophosphamide. Anti-seizure medications, which may help control seizures associated with syndromes that cause electrical instability in the brain. Medications to enhance nerve-to-muscle transmission, which may improve symptoms of syndromes affecting muscle function. Technicians return the red and white blood cells, along with the platelets, to the body, while discarding the plasma, which contains unwanted antibodies, and replacing it with other fluids. Corticosteroids Immunosuppressants Anti-seizure medications, Medications to enhance nerve-to-muscle transmission, Plasmapheresis Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) Physical therapy.

Name: Parkinson 's disease
Symptoms: Symptoms often begin on one side of the body and usually remain worse on that side, even after symptoms begin to affect both sides. One may a rub the thumb and forefinger back-and-forth, known as a pill-rolling tremor. Over time, Parkinson's disease may slow the movement, making simple tasks difficult and time-consuming. The posture may become stooped, or one may have balance problems as a result of Parkinson's disease. One may have a decreased ability to perform unconscious movements, including blinking, smiling or swinging the arms when one walk. One may speak softly, quickly, slur or hesitate before talking. It may become hard to write, and the writing may appear small.
Overview: Parkinson's disease is a progressive nervous system disorder that affects movement. Although Parkinson's disease can't be cured, medications might significantly improve the symptoms.
Causes: In Parkinson's disease, certain nerve cells (neurons) in the brain gradually break down or die. When dopamine levels decrease, it causes abnormal brain activity, leading to symptoms of Parkinson's disease. The cause of Parkinson's disease is unknown, but several factors appear to play a role, including The genes. Researchers have also noted that many changes occur in the brains of people with Parkinson's disease, although it's not clear why these changes occur. These are called Lewy bodies, and researchers believe these Lewy bodies hold an important clue to the cause of Parkinson's disease. Although many substances are found within Lewy bodies, scientists believe an important one is the natural and widespread protein called alpha-synuclein (a-synuclein).
Risk factors: Risk factors for Parkinson's disease include Age. Having a close relative with Parkinson's disease increases the chances that one will develop the disease. However, the risks are still small unless one has many relatives in the family with Parkinson's disease. Ongoing exposure to herbicides and pesticides may slightly increase the risk of Parkinson's disease.
Diagnosis: The doctor trained in nervous system conditions (neurologist) will diagnose Parkinson's disease based on the medical history, a review of the signs and symptoms, and a neurological and physical examination. In addition to the examination, the doctor may give one carbidopa-levodopa (Rytary, Sinemet, others), a Parkinson's disease medication. Doctors may recommend regular follow-up appointments with neurologists trained in movement disorders to evaluate the condition and symptoms over time and diagnose Parkinson's disease.
Remedies: If one has received a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease, one will need to work closely with the doctor to find a treatment plan that offers one the greatest relief from symptoms with the fewest side effects. Certain lifestyle changes also may help make living with Parkinson's disease easier. While no food or combination of foods has been proved to help in Parkinson's disease, some foods may help ease some of the symptoms. For example, eating foods high in fiber and drinking an adequate amount of fluids can help prevent constipation that is common in Parkinson's disease. A balanced diet also provides nutrients, such as omega-3 fatty acids, that might be beneficial for people with Parkinson's disease. One may also try exercises such as walking, swimming, gardening, dancing, water aerobics or stretching. Parkinson's disease can disturb the sense of balance, making it difficult to walk with a normal gait. These suggestions may also help: In the later stages of the disease, one may fall more easily. The following suggestions may help: Daily living activities such as dressing, eating, bathing and writing can be difficult for people with Parkinson's disease.
Medication: Levodopa, the most effective Parkinson's disease medication, is a natural chemical that passes into the brain and is converted to dopamine. Levodopa is combined with carbidopa (Lodosyn), which protects levodopa from early conversion to dopamine outside the brain. After years, as the disease progresses, the benefit from levodopa may become less stable, with a tendency to wax and wane (wearing off). Also, one may experience involuntary movements (dyskinesia) after taking higher doses of levodopa. Dopamine agonists include pramipexole (Mirapex), ropinirole (Requip) and rotigotine (Neupro, given as a patch). Apomorphine (Apokyn), is a short-acting injectable dopamine agonist used for quick relief. These medications include selegiline (Eldepryl, Zelapar), rasagiline (Azilect) and safinamide (Xadago). Side effects, including an increased risk of involuntary movements (dyskinesia), mainly result from an enhanced levodopa effect. Several anticholinergic medications are available, including benztropine (Cogentin) or trihexyphenidyl. It may also be given with carbidopa-levodopa therapy during the later stages of Parkinson's disease to control involuntary movements (dyskinesia) induced by carbidopa-levodopa.

Name: Parotid tumors
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose salivary gland tumors include If one is diagnosed with salivary gland cancer, the doctor will determine the extent (stage) of the cancer. Imaging tests, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), computerized tomography (CT), positron emission tomography (PET), ultrasound or X-ray, may help the doctor determine the size and location of the salivary gland tumor.

Name: Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return
Diagnosis: To diagnose congenital heart disease, the doctor will do a physical exam and listen to the heart with a stethoscope. Tests to diagnose or rule out congenital heart disease include Electrocardiogram (ECG). An ECG can diagnose many heart problems, including irregular heartbeats and blocked arteries. The doctor can use this test to see how the heart's chambers and valves are pumping blood through the heart. If more-detailed images of the heart are needed, the doctor may recommend a transesophageal echocardiogram. Cardiac MRI uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create images of the heart. The doctor might use this test to check blood flow and blood pressures in the heart. Then, the doctor gently inserts a catheter into an artery or vein in the groin, neck or arm and up to the heart.
Medication: If one is an adult with congenital heart disease, one is at risk of developing complications even if one had surgery to repair a defect during childhood. A device that helps control the heart rate (pacemaker) or that corrects life-threatening irregular heartbeats (implantable cardioverter-defibrillator or ICD) may help improve some of the complications associated with congenital heart defects. If catheter procedures can't fix the heart defect, the doctor might recommend open-heart surgery.

Name: Patent foramen ovale
Overview: A patent foramen ovale (PFO) is a hole in the heart that didn't close the way it should after birth. During fetal development, a small flap-like opening the foramen ovale (foh-RAY-mun oh-VAY-lee) is normally present in the wall between the right and left upper chambers of the heart (atria).
Causes: The upper chambers, the right and left atria, receive incoming blood. The lower chambers, the right and left ventricles, pump blood out of the heart. The heart has four pumping chambers that circulate the blood: Because a baby in the womb isn't breathing, the lungs aren't functioning yet. Blood also travels from the right atrium to the right ventricle, which also pumps blood to the body via another bypass system. The upper right chamber (right atrium) receives oxygen-poor blood from the body and pumps it into the right ventricle through the tricuspid valve. The blood is pumped through the pulmonary valve, which closes when the right ventricle relaxes between beats.
Diagnosis: A doctor trained in heart conditions (cardiologist) may order one or more of the following tests to diagnose a patent foramen ovale: An echocardiogram shows the anatomy, structure and function of the heart. Variations of this procedure may be used to identify patent foramen ovale, including Color flow Doppler. If one has a patent foramen ovale, a color flow Doppler echocardiogram could detect the flow of blood between the right atrium and left atrium. This is generally the most accurate available test for doctors to see a patent foramen ovale by using the ultrasound in combination with color flow Doppler or a saline contrast study.
info-Symptoms: asymptomatic

Name: Pathological gambling
Symptoms: Because denial is almost always a feature of compulsive or addictive behavior, it may be difficult for one to realize that one has a problem. If one recognize the own behavior from the list of signs and symptoms for compulsive gambling, seek professional help.
Overview: Compulsive gambling, also called gambling disorder, is the uncontrollable urge to keep gambling despite the toll it takes on the life. If one has a problem with compulsive gambling, one may continually chase bets that lead to losses, hide the behavior, deplete savings, accumulate debt, or even resort to theft or fraud to support the addiction.
Risk factors: Although most people who play cards or wager never develop a gambling problem, certain factors are more often associated with compulsive gambling: Mental health disorders. People who gamble compulsively often have substance abuse problems, personality disorders, depression or anxiety. Compulsive gambling may also be associated with bipolar disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) or attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Drugs called dopamine agonists have a rare side effect that may result in compulsive behaviors, including gambling, in some people. Being highly competitive, a workaholic, impulsive, restless or easily bored may increase the risk of compulsive gambling.
Diagnosis: If one recognize that one may have a problem with the gambling, talk with the primary care doctor about an evaluation or seek help from a mental health professional. To evaluate the problem with gambling, the doctor or mental health professional will likely: Ask questions related to the gambling habits. Depending on the signs and symptoms, one may be evaluated for mental health disorders that are sometimes related to excessive gambling.
Treatment: Treatment for compulsive gambling may include these approaches: Treatment for compulsive gambling may involve an outpatient program, inpatient program or a residential treatment program, depending on the needs and resources. Treatment for substance abuse, depression, anxiety or any other mental health disorder may be part of the treatment plan for compulsive gambling. Antidepressants and mood stabilizers may help problems that often go along with compulsive gambling such as depression, OCD or ADHD. Medications called narcotic antagonists, useful in treating substance abuse, may help treat compulsive gambling.
info-Symptoms: Spending a lot of money and time in casino/sports betting, Video game addiction

Name: Pathological stealing
Risk factors: However, some people with kleptomania may never seek treatment, or they're simply jailed after repeated thefts, so some cases of kleptomania may never be diagnosed. Having a first-degree relative, such as a parent or sibling, with kleptomania, obsessive-compulsive disorder, or an alcohol or other substance use disorder may increase the risk of kleptomania. People with kleptomania often have another mental illness, such as bipolar disorder, anxiety disorder, an eating disorder, substance use disorder or a personality disorder.
Treatment: Although fear, humiliation or embarrassment may make it hard for one to seek treatment for kleptomania, it's important to get help. However, there's no standard kleptomania treatment, and researchers are still trying to understand what may work best.

Name: PDA
Overview: Patent ductus arterious, shown in the heart on the right, is an abnormal opening between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. However, a large patent ductus arteriosus left untreated can allow poorly oxygenated blood to flow in the wrong direction, weakening the heart muscle and causing heart failure and other complications.
Causes: The ductus arteriosus diverts blood from a baby's lungs while they develop, and the baby receives oxygen from the mother's circulation. Untreated, the blood pressure in the baby's lungs might increase (pulmonary hypertension) and the baby's heart might enlarge and weaken.
Risk factors: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) occurs more commonly in babies who are born too early than in babies who are born full term. A family history of heart defects and other genetic conditions, such as Down syndrome, increase the risk of having a PDA. If one contract German measles (rubella) during pregnancy, the baby's risk of heart defects increases. Babies born above 10,000 feet (3,048 meters) have a greater risk of a PDA than babies born at lower altitudes.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects a heart defect, he or she might request one or more of the following tests: Echocardiogram. Sound waves produce images of the heart that can help the doctor identify a PDA, see if the heart chambers are enlarged, and judge how well the heart is pumping. This test isn't usually necessary for diagnosing a PDA alone, but it might be done to examine other congenital heart defects found during an echocardiogram or if a catheter procedure is being considered to treat a PDA.
Treatment: However, if the baby doesn't have PDA-related health problems, the doctor might recommend waiting until the baby is older to do a catheter procedure to correct the PDA. Catheter procedures can also be used to treat full-term babies, children and adults. For full-term babies, children and adults who have small PDAs that aren't causing other health problems, monitoring might be all that's needed. In a premature baby, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen (Advil, Infant's Motrin, others) or indomethacin (Indocin) might be used to help close a PDA. A surgeon makes a small cut between the child's ribs to reach the child's heart and repair the open duct using stitches or clips.After the surgery, the child will remain in the hospital for several days for observation. Catheter procedures can also be used to treat full-term babies, children and adults.In a catheter procedure, a thin tube (catheter) is inserted into a blood vessel in the groin and threaded up to the heart. Through the catheter, a plug or coil is inserted to close the ductus arteriosus.If the procedure is done on an outpatient basis, one or the child probably won't stay overnight in the hospital.
Remedies: For most people who have a patent ductus arteriosus, regularly brushing and flossing teeth and regular dental checkups are the best ways to help prevent infection. People and parents of children who have congenital heart defects often worry about the risks of vigorous activity and rough play, even after successful treatment. Although some children and adults might need to limit the amount or type of exercise, most people who have patent ductus arteriosus will lead normal lives.

Name: Peanut allergy
Overview: Peanut allergy is one of the most common causes of severe allergy attacks. For some people with peanut allergy, even tiny amounts of peanuts can cause a serious reaction that can even be life-threatening (anaphylaxis).
Causes: Direct or indirect contact with peanuts causes the immune system to release symptom-causing chemicals into the bloodstream. An allergic reaction may occur if one inhale dust or aerosols containing peanuts, from a source such as peanut flour or peanut oil cooking spray.
Risk factors: However, people with certain risk factors have a greater chance of developing peanut allergy. Likewise, having another type of allergy, such as hay fever, increases the risk of having a food allergy. One is at increased risk of peanut allergy if other allergies, especially other types of food allergies, are common in the family.
Diagnosis: The next steps typically include some of the following: Information from all these sources may help determine if one has a peanut allergy or if the symptoms are likely due to something else, such as food intolerance. The doctor may ask one to keep a food diary of the eating habits, symptoms and medications. If it isn't clear that peanuts are causing the symptoms, or if the doctor thinks one may have a reaction to more than one type of food, he or she may recommend an elimination diet. One may be asked to eliminate peanuts or other suspect foods for a week or two, and then add the food items back into the diet one at a time. A blood test can measure the immune system's response to particular foods by checking the amount of allergy-type antibodies in the bloodstream, known as immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies.
Treatment: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration recently approved the first oral immunotherapy drug, Peanut (Arachis hypogaea) Allergen Powder-dnfp (Palforzia), to treat children ages 4 to 17 years old with a confirmed peanut allergy.
Remedies: The following foods often contain peanuts: Some foods that may contain peanuts or peanut proteins either because they were made with them or because they came in contact with them during the manufacturing process are less obvious. Ground or mixed nuts Baked goods, such as cookies and pastries Ice cream and frozen desserts Energy bars Cereals and granola Grain breads Marzipan, a candy made of nuts, egg whites and sugar Nougat Salad dressings Chocolate candies, nut butters (such as almond butter) and sunflower seeds Ethnic foods including African, Chinese, Indonesian, Mexican, Thai and Vietnamese dishes Foods sold in bakeries and ice cream shops Arachis oil, another name for peanut oil Pet food Never assume that a food doesn't contain peanuts.
info-Symptoms: Itchiness, hives, swelling, eczema, sneezing, asthma attack, abdominal pain, drop in blood pressure, diarrhea, cardiac arrest
info-Risk factors: Childhood in developed countries
info-Diagnostic method: Medical history and physical examination by an approved doctor
info-Prevention: Proper early introduction to peanuts and their products during pregnancy and infancy

Name: Pectus carinatum
Overview: Pectus carinatum is an uncommon birth defect in which a child's breastbone protrudes outward abnormally. While surgical repair is an option for people with severe pectus carinatum, the use of a brace to help flatten the chest is the preferred treatment for children whose bones are still growing.
Treatment: For severe pectus carinatum, surgery can repair the defect. Rochester, Minn.: Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research; 2016. Paravertebral regional blocks decrease length of stay following surgery for pectus excavatum in children. Minimally invasive repairs of pectus excavatum: Surgical outcomes, quality of life and predictors of reoperation.

Name: Pediatric brain tumors
Overview: This shows a child's tumor that likely began in the brain cells. Treatment and chance of recovery (prognosis) depend on the type of tumor, its location within the brain, whether it has spread, and the child's age and general health. Treatment for brain tumors in children is typically quite different from treatment for adult brain tumors, so it's very important to enlist the expertise and experience of pediatric specialists in neurology and cancer.
Diagnosis: If it's suspected that the child has a brain tumor, the doctor may recommend several tests and procedures to aid in diagnosis and help determine treatment options. Removing a sample of tissue for testing (biopsy) may be done as part of surgery to remove the brain tumor. Or if the brain tumor is hard to reach or in a sensitive area that might be damaged by extensive surgery, a stereotactic needle biopsy may be done. If it's suspected that the child's brain tumor may be a result of cancer that has spread from another area of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer started.

Name: Pediculosis capitis
Symptoms: The most common symptom of a lice infestation is itching on the scalp, neck and ears. When a person has a lice infestation for the first time, itching may not occur for four to six weeks after infestation. Lice may be visible but are difficult to spot because they're small, avoid light and move quickly.
Causes: A louse goes through three stages: Head lice crawl, but they can't jump or fly. For example, hats or scarves hung on the same hook or stored in the same school locker could serve as vehicles for transmitting lice. Household pets, such as dogs and cats, don't play a role in spreading head lice. Nymphs, immature forms of the louse that become mature adults after nine to 12 days.
Remedies: Small clinical studies have suggested that some natural plant oils may kill lice by suffocation, but effectiveness is uncertain. These products include These products are not required to meet safety, efficacy and manufacturing standards used for drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), and can sometimes cause allergic reactions. These products are thought to deprive the lice of air when generous amounts are applied to the hair, covered with a shower cap and left on overnight.
info-Symptoms: Itching that can result in trouble sleeping
info-Usual onset: Up to six weeks from infestation
info-Causes: Head louse spread by direct contact
info-Treatment: Combing the hair with a fine tooth comb, shaving the head, medications

Name: Pelvic pain , chronic
Overview: Chronic pelvic pain is pain in the area below the bellybutton and between the hips that lasts six months or longer. If the chronic pelvic pain appears to be caused by another medical problem, treating that problem may be enough to eliminate the pain.
Causes: For example, a woman might have endometriosis and interstitial cystitis, both of which contribute to chronic pelvic pain. Instead, they remain in the abdomen, where they may lead to painful cysts and fibrous bands of scar tissue (adhesions). After surgical removal of the uterus, ovaries and fallopian tubes, a small piece of ovary may accidentally be left inside and later develop painful cysts. Symptoms associated with irritable bowel syndrome bloating, constipation or diarrhea can be a source of pelvic pain and pressure. One may experience pelvic pain as the bladder fills, which may improve temporarily after one empty the bladder. Some doctors believe enlarged, varicose-type veins around the uterus and ovaries may result in pelvic pain. Depression, chronic stress or a history of sexual or physical abuse may increase the risk of chronic pelvic pain.
Diagnosis: In addition to a detailed interview about the pain, the personal health history and the family history, the doctor may ask one to keep a journal of the pain and other symptoms. Tests or exams the doctor might suggest include Finding the underlying cause of chronic pelvic pain can be a long process, and in some cases, a clear explanation may never be found. Let the doctor know if one feel any discomfort during this exam, especially if the pain is similar to the pain one has been experiencing. During the pelvic exam, the doctor may order labs to check for infections, such as chlamydia or gonorrhea. The doctor may recommend abdominal X-rays, computerized tomography (CT) scans or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to help detect abnormal structures or growths.
Medication: Depending on the cause, the doctor may recommend a number of medications to treat the condition, such as: The doctor may recommend specific therapies or procedures as a part of the treatment for chronic pelvic pain. These may include To correct an underlying problem that causes chronic pelvic pain, the doctor may recommend a surgical procedure, such as: One may need to try a combination of treatment approaches before one find what works best for one. Over-the-counter pain remedies, such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), may provide partial relief from the pelvic pain. When this is the case, birth control pills or other hormonal medications may help relieve pelvic pain. If an infection is the source of the pain, the doctor may prescribe antibiotics. Tricyclic antidepressants, such as amitriptyline, nortriptyline (Pamelor) and others, seem to have pain-relieving as well as antidepressant effects. Stretching exercises, massage and other relaxation techniques may improve the chronic pelvic pain. It may be helpful, depending on the cause of the pelvic pain. If the doctor finds specific points where one feel pain, one may benefit from having a numbing medicine injected into those painful spots (trigger points). If the pain could be intertwined with depression, sexual abuse, a personality disorder, a troubled marriage or a family crisis, one may find it helpful to talk with a psychologist or psychiatrist. In rare complicated cases, the doctors may recommend removal of the uterus (hysterectomy), fallopian tubes (salpingectomy) or ovaries (oophorectomy).

Name: Pemphigus
Overview: Pemphigus is a rare skin disorder characterized by blistering of the skin and mucous membranes. The most common type is pemphigus vulgaris, which involves painful sores and blisters on the skin and in the mouth. Pemphigus is a disease that causes blisters and sores on the skin or mucous membranes, such as in the mouth or on the genitals.
Causes: Normally, the immune system produces antibodies to fight off harmful invaders, such viruses and bacteria. But in pemphigus, the body produces antibodies that damage cells of the skin and mucous membranes. Rarely, pemphigus is triggered by the use of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, penicillamine and other drugs.
Diagnosis: In addition, one may undergo tests, including A skin biopsy. If one has pemphigus vulgaris, the doctor may have one undergo endoscopy to check for sores in the throat.
Medication: The following prescription medications may be used alone or in combination, depending on the type and severity of the pemphigus and whether one has other medical conditions: Corticosteroids. Using corticosteroids for a long time or in high doses may cause serious side effects, including diabetes, bone loss, an increased risk of infection, stomach ulcers and a redistribution of body fat, leading to a round face (moon face). If first-line drugs aren't helping one, the doctor may suggest another drug, such as dapsone, intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab (Rituxan).

Name: Penicillin allergy
Diagnosis: If the diagnosis of a penicillin allergy is uncertain, a graded drug challenge may be recommended. If one reach the therapeutic dose with no reaction, then the doctor will conclude one isn't allergic to that type of penicillin. If one is allergic to one type of penicillin, the doctor may recommend a graded challenge with a type of penicillin or cephalosporin that's less likely because of known chemical properties to cause an allergic reaction.

Name: Pericardial effusion
Diagnosis: If one has signs or symptoms of pericardial effusion, a series of blood and imaging tests will be done to confirm the diagnosis, identify possible causes and determine treatment. There are two types of echocardiograms: An electrocardiogram, also called an ECG or EKG, records electrical signals as they travel through the heart. Computerized tomography (CT) scans and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can detect pericardial effusion, although they're not generally used to look for it.
Medication: If one don't have tamponade or there's no immediate threat of tamponade, the doctor might prescribe an anti-inflammatory drug to reduce inflammation of the pericardium: If anti-inflammatory treatments don't correct the problem or one has or are likely to have tamponade, the cardiologist may recommend one of the following procedures to drain fluids or prevent fluids from accumulating again. Aspirin Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as indomethacin (Indocin) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) Colchicine (Colcrys) Corticosteroid, such as prednisone Drain the fluid. The doctor can enter the pericardial space with a needle and then use a small tube (catheter) to drain fluid a procedure called pericardiocentesis. If there's bleeding into the pericardium, especially due to recent heart surgery or other complications, open-heart surgery may be done to drain the pericardium and repair damage.

Name: Pericarditis
Symptoms: If one has acute pericarditis, the most common symptom is sharp, stabbing chest pain behind the breastbone or in the left side of the chest. However, some people with acute pericarditis describe their chest pain as dull, achy or pressure-like instead, and of varying intensity.
Overview: The heart on the right shows a heart with pericarditis, in which the membrane (pericardium) that surrounds the heart is swollen and infected. Pericarditis is swelling and irritation of the pericardium, the thin saclike membrane surrounding the heart.
Causes: Pericarditis can also develop shortly after a major heart attack, due to the irritation of the underlying damaged heart muscle. In addition, a delayed form of pericarditis may occur weeks after a heart attack or heart surgery. Dressler's syndrome may also be called postpericardiotomy syndrome, post-myocardial infarction syndrome and post-cardiac injury syndrome.
Diagnosis: While listening to the heart, the doctor will place a stethoscope on the chest to check for the sounds characteristic of pericarditis, which are made when the pericardial layers rub against each other. The doctor may have one undergo tests that can help determine whether one has had a heart attack, whether fluid has collected in the pericardial sac or whether there are signs of inflammation. In this test, patches with wires (electrodes) are attached to the skin to measure the electrical impulses given off by the heart. CT scanning may be done to exclude other causes of acute chest pain, such as a blood clot in a lung artery (pulmonary embolus) or a tear in the aorta (aortic dissection). This test uses high-frequency sound waves to create an image of the heart and its structures, including fluid accumulation in the pericardium. This technique uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create cross-sectional images of the heart that can reveal thickening, inflammation or other changes in the pericardium.
Medication: Medications to reduce the inflammation and swelling associated with pericarditis are often prescribed, including Colchicine (Colcrys, Mitigare). This drug, which reduces inflammation in the body, may be prescribed for acute pericarditis or as a treatment for recurrent symptoms. One will likely need hospitalization if the doctor suspects cardiac tamponade, a dangerous complication of pericarditis due to fluid buildup around the heart. If cardiac tamponade is present, the doctor may recommend a procedure to relieve fluid buildup, such as: Pain relievers. Most pain associated with pericarditis responds well to treatment with pain relievers available without a prescription, such as aspirin or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others). If one don't respond to pain relievers or colchicine or if one has recurrent symptoms of pericarditis, the doctor may prescribe a steroid medication, such as prednisone. In this procedure, a doctor uses a sterile needle or a small tube (catheter) to remove and drain the excess fluid from the pericardial cavity. If one is diagnosed with constrictive pericarditis, one may need to undergo a surgical procedure (pericardiectomy) to remove the entire pericardium that has become rigid and is making it hard for the heart to pump.
info-Symptoms: Sharp chest pain, better sitting up and worse with lying down, fever
info-Causes: Viral infection, tuberculosis, uremic pericarditis, following a heart attack, cancer, autoimmune disorders, chest trauma
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, electrocardiogram, fluid around the heart

Name: Perimenopause
Symptoms: Throughout the menopausal transition, some subtle and some not-so-subtle changes in the body may take place. If one has a persistent change of seven days or more in the length of the menstrual cycle, one may be in early perimenopause. Sleep problems are often due to hot flashes or night sweats, but sometimes sleep becomes unpredictable even without them. Mood swings, irritability or increased risk of depression may happen during perimenopause. When estrogen levels diminish, the vaginal tissues may lose lubrication and elasticity, making intercourse painful. During perimenopause, sexual arousal and desire may change. With declining estrogen levels, one start to lose bone more quickly than one replace it, increasing the risk of osteoporosis a disease that causes fragile bones.
Overview: Perimenopause means around menopause and refers to the time during which the body makes the natural transition to menopause, marking the end of the reproductive years. Once one has gone through 12 consecutive months without a menstrual period, one has officially reached menopause, and the perimenopause period is over.
Risk factors: Although not always conclusive, some evidence suggests that certain factors may make it more likely that one start perimenopause at an earlier age, including Smoking. The onset of menopause occurs one to two years earlier in women who smoke than in women who don't smoke.
Treatment: Systemic estrogen therapy which comes in pill, skin patch, gel or cream form remains the most effective treatment option for relieving perimenopausal and menopausal hot flashes and night sweats. Depending on the personal and family medical history, the doctor may recommend estrogen in the lowest dose needed to provide symptom relief for one. An antidepressant for management of hot flashes may be useful for women who can't take estrogen for health reasons or for women who need an antidepressant for a mood disorder.
Remedies: Use over-the-counter, water-based vaginal lubricants (Astroglide, K-Y jelly, others) or moisturizers (Replens, Vagisil, others). Because the risk of osteoporosis and heart disease increases at this time, a healthy diet is more important than ever. Ask the doctor if one should also take a calcium supplement and if so, what type and how much also ask if one need more vitamin D, which helps the body absorb calcium. Regular exercise and physical activity helps prevent weight gain, improves the sleep and elevates the mood. Avoid caffeine, which can make it hard to get to sleep, and avoid drinking too much alcohol, which can interrupt sleep. Practiced regularly, stress-reduction techniques, such as meditation or yoga, can promote relaxation and good health throughout the lifetime, but they may be particularly helpful during the menopausal transition.
info-Symptoms: No menstrual periods for a year
info-Causes: Usually a natural change. Can also be caused by surgery that removes both ovaries and some types of chemotherapy.
info-Medication: Menopausal hormone therapy, clonidine, gabapentin, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors

Name: Periodontal disease , gingivitis
Overview: Gingivitis is a common and mild form of gum disease (periodontal disease) that causes irritation, redness and swelling (inflammation) of the gingiva, the part of the gum around the base of the teeth. Good oral health habits, such as brushing at least twice a day, flossing daily and getting regular dental checkups, can help prevent and reverse gingivitis.
Causes: The most common cause of gingivitis is poor oral hygiene that encourages plaque to form on teeth, causing inflammation of the surrounding gum tissues. Plaque that stays on the teeth can harden under the gumline into tartar (calculus), which collects bacteria. Tartar makes plaque more difficult to remove, creates a protective shield for bacteria and causes irritation along the gumline.
Diagnosis: Measuring the pocket depth of the groove between the gums and the teeth by inserting a dental probe beside the tooth beneath the gum line, usually at several sites throughout the mouth. Review of the dental and medical history Examination of the teeth, gums, mouth and tongue Measuring the pocket depth Dental X-rays Other tests as needed.
Treatment: Professional gingivitis care includes: If one is consistent with the home oral hygiene, one should see the return of pink, healthy gum tissue within days or weeks. The initial professional cleaning will include removing all traces of plaque, tartar and bacterial products a procedure known as scaling and root planing. Misaligned teeth or poorly fitting crowns, bridges or other dental restorations may irritate the gums and make it harder to remove plaque during daily oral care. If problems with the teeth or dental restorations contribute to the gingivitis, the dentist may recommend fixing these problems.
Remedies: Steps one can take at home to prevent and reverse gingivitis include Brush the teeth twice a day or, better yet, after every meal or snack. Supplement brushing and flossing with an interdental cleaner, such as a dental pick, interdental brush or dental stick specially designed to clean between the teeth.

Name: Periodontitis
Overview: Periodontitis is a severe gum infection that can lead to tooth loss and other serious health complications. Periodontitis (per-e-o-don-TIE-tis), also called gum disease, is a serious gum infection that damages the soft tissue and, without treatment, can destroy the bone that supports the teeth. Brushing at least twice a day, flossing daily and getting regular dental checkups can greatly improve the chances of successful treatment for periodontitis and can also reduce the chance of developing it.
Remedies: Try these measures to reduce or prevent periodontitis: Brush the teeth twice a day or, better yet, after every meal or snack. Supplement brushing and flossing with an interdental cleaner, such as a dental pick, interdental brush or dental stick specially designed to clean between the teeth.
info-Symptoms: Red, swollen, painful, bleeding gums, loose teeth, bad breath
info-Risk factors: Smoking, diabetes, HIV/AIDS, certain medications
info-Treatment: Good oral hygiene, regular professional cleaning

Name: Peripheral nerve injuries
Symptoms: With a peripheral nerve injury, one may experience symptoms that range from mild to seriously limiting the daily activities. Damage to these nerves is typically associated with muscle weakness, painful cramps and uncontrollable muscle twitching. Because these nerves relay information about touch, temperature and pain, one may experience a variety of symptoms. This group of nerves regulates activities that are not controlled consciously, such as breathing, heart and thyroid function, and digesting food.

Name: Peripheral nerve tumors
Overview: Benign tumors can occur in nerves, muscle and bone. An acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) is a benign tumor that develops on the balance and hearing nerves leading from the inner ear to the brain. Peripheral nerve tumors are growths in or near the strands of tissue (nerves) that transmit signals from the brain to the rest of the body.
Causes: The spinal cord is housed within a hollow chamber within the vertebrae (spinal canal). Some are linked to known inherited syndromes, such as neurofibromatosis (types 1 and 2) and schwannomatosis.
Diagnosis: MRI scan To diagnosis a peripheral nerve tumor, the doctor may ask one about signs and symptoms, discuss the medical history, and perform both a general physical and neurological exam. A computer uses the images to make a detailed view of the peripheral nerve tumor so that the doctor can evaluate how it may be affecting one. If imaging tests identify a nerve tumor, the doctor may remove and analyze a small sample of cells (biopsy) from the tumor. If one has a condition such as progressive peripheral neuropathy or enlarged nerves that mimic nerve tumors, the doctor may take a nerve biopsy.

Name: Peripheral neuropathy
Symptoms: Every nerve in the peripheral system has a specific function, so symptoms depend on the type of nerves affected. Early diagnosis and treatment offer the best chance for controlling the symptoms and preventing further damage to the peripheral nerves.
Overview: Peripheral neuropathy, a result of damage to the nerves outside of the brain and spinal cord (peripheral nerves), often causes weakness, numbness and pain, usually in the hands and feet. Peripheral neuropathy can result from traumatic injuries, infections, metabolic problems, inherited causes and exposure to toxins.
Causes: Not a single disease, peripheral neuropathy is nerve damage caused by a number of conditions. Health conditions that can cause peripheral neuropathy include Other causes of neuropathies include In a number of cases, no cause can be identified (idiopathic). These include Sjogren's syndrome, lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy and vasculitis. These include certain viral or bacterial infections, including Lyme disease, shingles, Epstein-Barr virus, hepatitis B and C, leprosy, diphtheria, and HIV. Growths, cancerous (malignant) and noncancerous (benign), can develop on the nerves or press nerves. Also, polyneuropathy can arise as a result of some cancers related to the body's immune response. These include an abnormal protein in the blood (monoclonal gammopathies), a form of bone cancer (myeloma), lymphoma and the rare disease amyloidosis. These include kidney disease, liver disease, connective tissue disorders and an underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism). Certain medications, especially those used to treat cancer (chemotherapy), can cause peripheral neuropathy. Traumas, such as from motor vehicle accidents, falls or sports injuries, can sever or damage peripheral nerves. B vitamins including B-1, B-6 and B-12 vitamin E and niacin are crucial to nerve health.
Diagnosis: Besides a physical exam, which may include blood tests, diagnosis usually requires: The doctor may order tests, including Nerve function tests. At the same time as an electromyogram, the doctor or an EMG technician typically performs a nerve conduction study. The doctor will review the medical history, including the symptoms, the lifestyle, exposure to toxins, drinking habits and a family history of nervous system (neurological) diseases. The doctor might check the tendon reflexes, the muscle strength and tone, the ability to feel certain sensations, and the posture and coordination. These might include an autonomic reflex screen that records how the autonomic nerve fibers work, a sweat test that measures the body's ability to sweat, and sensory tests that record how one feel touch, vibration, cooling and heat. This involves removing a small portion of a nerve, usually a sensory nerve, to look for abnormalities.
Remedies: To help one manage peripheral neuropathy: Take care of the feet, especially if one has diabetes. Regular exercise, such as walking three times a week, can reduce neuropathy pain, improve muscle strength and help control blood sugar levels. If one has diabetes, this will help keep the blood glucose under control and might help improve the neuropathy.
Medication: Besides medications used to treat conditions associated with peripheral neuropathy, medications used to relieve peripheral neuropathy signs and symptoms include Pain relievers. Over-the-counter pain medications, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, can relieve mild symptoms. Medications containing opioids, such as tramadol (Conzip, Ultram) or oxycodone (Oxycontin, Roxicodone, others), can lead to dependence and addiction, so these drugs generally are prescribed only when other treatments fail. Capsaicin cream, which contains a substance found in hot peppers, can cause modest improvements in peripheral neuropathy symptoms. Certain tricyclic antidepressants, such as amitriptyline, doxepin (Silenor, Zonalon) and nortriptyline (Pamelor), have been found to help relieve pain by interfering with chemical processes in the brain and spinal cord that cause one to feel pain. The serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor duloxetine (Cymbalta) and the extended-release antidepressant venlafaxine (Effexor XR) also might ease the pain of peripheral neuropathy caused by diabetes. Side effects of antidepressants may include dry mouth, nausea, drowsiness, dizziness, decreased appetite and constipation. In immune globulin therapy, one receive high levels of proteins that work as antibodies (immunoglobulins). Medications such as gabapentin (Gralise, Neurontin, Horizant) and pregabalin (Lyrica), developed to treat epilepsy, may relieve nerve pain.

Name: Peritonitis
Overview: Peritonitis is inflammation of the peritoneum a silk-like membrane that lines the inner abdominal wall and covers the organs within the abdomen that is usually due to a bacterial or fungal infection. There are two types of peritonitis: Peritonitis requires prompt medical attention to fight the infection and, if necessary, to treat any underlying medical conditions.
Causes: In most cases, the cause is a rupture (perforation) within the abdominal wall. Peritoneal dialysis uses tubes (catheters) to remove waste products from the blood when the kidneys can no longer adequately do so. An infection may occur during peritoneal dialysis due to unclean surroundings, poor hygiene or contaminated equipment. Inflammation of the pancreas (pancreatitis) complicated by infection may lead to peritonitis if the bacteria spreads outside the pancreas. Injury or trauma may cause peritonitis by allowing bacteria or chemicals from other parts of the body to enter the peritoneum.
Diagnosis: When peritonitis is associated with peritoneal dialysis, the signs and symptoms, particularly cloudy dialysis fluid, may be enough for the doctor to diagnose the condition. In cases of peritonitis in which the infection may be a result of other medical conditions (secondary peritonitis) or in which the infection arises from fluid buildup in the abdominal cavity (spontaneous bacterial peritonitis), the doctor may recommend the following tests to confirm a diagnosis: The above tests may also be necessary if one is receiving peritoneal dialysis and a diagnosis of peritonitis is uncertain after a physical exam and an examination of the dialysis fluid. Using a thin needle, the doctor may take a sample of the fluid in the peritoneum (paracentesis), especially if one receive peritoneal dialysis or have fluid in the abdomen from liver disease. If one has peritonitis, examination of this fluid may show an increased white blood cell count, which typically indicates an infection or inflammation.
Treatment: One will also need to stay in the hospital for peritonitis that's caused by infection from other medical conditions (secondary peritonitis). Surgery is often needed to remove infected tissue, treat the underlying cause of the infection, and prevent the infection from spreading, especially if peritonitis is due to a ruptured appendix, stomach or colon. Depending on the signs and symptoms, the treatment while in the hospital will likely include pain medications, fluids given through a tube (intravenous fluids), oxygen and, in some cases, a blood transfusion.
info-Symptoms: Severe pain, swelling of the abdomen, fever
info-Causes: Perforation of the intestinal tract, pancreatitis, pelvic inflammatory disease, cirrhosis, ruptured appendix
info-Risk factors: Ascites, peritoneal dialysis
info-Treatment: Antibiotics, intravenous fluids, pain medication, surgery

Name: Pernio
Overview: Chilblains cause red, swollen skin, which appears several hours after exposure to extreme cold. The best approach to chilblains is to avoid developing them by limiting the exposure to cold, dressing warmly and covering exposed skin.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of chilblains include Clothing that is tight or exposes skin to the cold. Wearing tight-fitting clothing and shoes in cold, damp weather may make one more susceptible to chilblains. And skin that's exposed to cold, damp conditions is more likely to develop chilblains. Chilblains are less likely in colder and drier areas because the living conditions and clothing used in these areas are more protective against cold. The risk of chilblains is higher if one live in an area with high humidity and cold, but not freezing, temperatures. People with poor circulation tend to be more sensitive to changes in temperature, making them more susceptible to chilblains.
Treatment: The first line of treatment for chilblains generally includes measures to keep hands and feet warm and dry, such as keeping the indoor environment warm and dry, using gloves and socks, and changing damp gloves and socks when needed. If the chilblains don't clear up with these home remedies, the doctor may recommend medication, including Chilblains usually clear up in one to three weeks after cold exposure. Rewarming affected skin gently, without massaging, rubbing or applying direct heat Avoiding cold exposure whenever possible Keeping the affected skin dry and warm, but away from sources of heat Applying lotion to alleviate itching Making sure the affected skin is cleaned with an antiseptic and gently bandaged to prevent infection Avoiding scratching Quitting smoking, as smoking can constrict the blood vessels and slow wound healing Nifedipine (Procardia).

Name: Peroneal muscular atrophy
Overview: Charcot (shahr-KOH)-Marie-Tooth disease is a group of inherited disorders that cause nerve damage. Symptoms of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease typically appear in adolescence or early adulthood, but may also develop in midlife.
Causes: It occurs when there are mutations in the genes that affect the nerves in the feet, legs, hands and arms. That means some of the muscles in the feet may not receive the brain's signal to contract, so one is more likely to trip and fall.
Diagnosis: During the physical exam, the doctor may check for: The doctor may also recommend the following tests, which can help provide information about the extent of the nerve damage and what may be causing it. Signs of muscle weakness in the arms, legs, hands and feet Decreased muscle bulk in the lower legs, resulting in an inverted champagne bottle appearance Reduced reflexes Sensory loss in the feet and hands Foot deformities, such as high arches or hammertoes Other orthopedic problems, such as mild scoliosis or hip dysplasia Nerve conduction studies.
Remedies: Started early and followed regularly, at-home activities can provide protection and relief: Because of foot deformities and loss of sensation, regular foot care is important to help relieve symptoms and to prevent complications: Stretch regularly. If one has Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, regular stretching can prevent or reduce joint deformities that may result from uneven pulling of muscle on the bones. By strengthening the muscles and bones, one can improve the balance and coordination, reducing the risk of falls. Muscle weakness associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease may cause one to be unsteady on the feet, resulting in falls and serious injury.
Medication: If foot deformities are severe, corrective foot surgery may help alleviate pain and improve the ability to walk. Potential therapies include medications, gene therapy and in vitro procedures that may help prevent passing the disease to future generations. Occupational therapy can help through the use of assistive devices, such as special rubber grips on doorknobs or clothing with snaps instead of buttons.
info-Specialty: Neurology, podiatry, orthopedics, physical medicine and rehabilitation
info-Symptoms: Foot drop, hammer toe, peripheral muscle wasting of lower legs and lower arm/hands
info-Risk factors: Family history (genetics), high-arched feet, flat-arched feet
info-Diagnostic method: Genetic testing, nerve conduction study or electromyogram (EMG)

Name: Persistent depressive disorder ( dysthymia )
Symptoms: Persistent depressive disorder symptoms usually come and go over a period of years, and their intensity can change over time. In addition, major depression episodes may occur before or during persistent depressive disorder this is sometimes called double depression. Symptoms of persistent depressive disorder can cause significant impairment and may include In children, symptoms of persistent depressive disorder may include depressed mood and irritability.
Causes: As with major depression, it may involve more than one cause, such as: Biological differences. People with persistent depressive disorder may have physical changes in their brains. The significance of these changes is still uncertain, but they may eventually help pinpoint causes. Persistent depressive disorder appears to be more common in people whose blood relatives also have the condition.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects one has persistent depressive disorder, exams and tests may include For a diagnosis of persistent depressive disorder, the main indication for an adult differs somewhat from that of a child: Symptoms caused by persistent depressive disorder can vary from person to person. When persistent depressive disorder starts before age 21, it's called early onset; if it starts at age 21 or older, it's called late onset. This evaluation can help determine if one has persistent depressive disorder or another condition that can affect mood, such as major depression, bipolar disorder or seasonal affective disorder.
Remedies: But, in addition to professional treatment, these self-care steps can help: Stick to the treatment plan. It may seem like alcohol or drugs lessen depression-related symptoms, but in the long run they generally worsen depression and make it harder to treat.
Medication: When one has persistent depressive disorder, one may need to take antidepressants long term to keep symptoms under control If one is pregnant or breast-feeding, some antidepressants may pose an increased health risk to the unborn baby or nursing child. In some cases, children, teens and young adults under 25 may have an increase in suicidal thoughts or behavior when taking antidepressants, especially in the first few weeks after starting or when the dose is changed. Psychotherapy can help one: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) Serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) Adjust to a crisis or other current difficulty Identify issues that contribute to the depression and change behaviors that make it worse Identify negative beliefs and behaviors and replace them with healthy, positive ones Find better ways to cope and solve problems Explore relationships and experiences, and develop positive interactions with others Regain a sense of satisfaction and control in the life and help ease depression symptoms, such as hopelessness and anger Learn to set realistic goals for the life

Name: Personality disorder , antisocial
Overview: Antisocial personality disorder, sometimes called sociopathy, is a mental disorder in which a person consistently shows no regard for right and wrong and ignores the rights and feelings of others. People with antisocial personality disorder tend to antagonize, manipulate or treat others harshly or with callous indifference.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis of antisocial personality disorder is typically based on: Though typically antisocial personality disorder isn't diagnosed before age 18, some signs and symptoms may occur in childhood or the early teen years. A psychological evaluation that explores thoughts, feelings, relationships, behavior patterns and family history Personal and medical history Symptoms listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association Complete blood count (CBC)

Name: Personality disorder , borderline
Symptoms: In the U.S. call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (1-800-273-8255) any time of day.
Risk factors: One may be at a higher risk if a close relative the mother, father, brother or sister has the same or a similar disorder. Some people have lost or were separated from a parent or close caregiver when they were young or had parents or caregivers with substance misuse or other mental health issues.
Medication: Although no drugs have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration specifically for the treatment of borderline personality disorder, certain medications may help with symptoms or co-occurring problems such as depression, impulsiveness, aggression or anxiety. Most people improve considerably, but one may always struggle with some symptoms of borderline personality disorder.

Name: Personality disorder , narcissistic
Remedies: The nature of narcissistic personality disorder can also leave one feeling that therapy is not worth the time and attention, and one may be tempted to quit. Stay motivated by keeping the goals in mind and reminding theself that one can work to repair damaged relationships and become more content with the life.

Name: Personality disorders
Overview: A personality disorder is a type of mental disorder in which one has a rigid and unhealthy pattern of thinking, functioning and behaving. In some cases, one may not realize that one has a personality disorder because the way of thinking and behaving seems natural to one.
Causes: Personality is the combination of thoughts, emotions and behaviors that makes one unique. Personality forms during childhood, shaped through an interaction of: Personality disorders are thought to be caused by a combination of these genetic and environmental influences. The genes may make one vulnerable to developing a personality disorder, and a life situation may trigger the actual development.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects one has a personality disorder, a diagnosis may be determined by: Each personality disorder has its own set of diagnostic criteria. However, according to the DSM-5, generally the diagnosis of a personality disorder includes long-term marked deviation from cultural expectations that leads to significant distress or impairment in at least two of these areas: Sometimes it can be difficult to determine the type of personality disorder, as some personality disorders share similar symptoms and more than one type may be present. The doctor may compare the symptoms to the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association.
Remedies: Along with the professional treatment plan, consider these lifestyle and self-care strategies: Be an active participant in the care. Even if one is feeling well, don't skip the medications. Don't neglect checkups or skip visits to the primary care professional, especially if one isn't feeling well.
Medication: However, several types of psychiatric medications may help with various personality disorder symptoms. In some cases, a personality disorder may be so severe that one need to be admitted to a hospital for psychiatric care. Antidepressants may be useful if one has a depressed mood, anger, impulsivity, irritability or hopelessness, which may be associated with personality disorders. Also called neuroleptics, these may be helpful if the symptoms include losing touch with reality (psychosis) or in some cases if one has anxiety or anger problems.

Name: Pes planus
Diagnosis: If one is having a lot of pain in the feet, the doctor may order tests such as: X-rays. If the doctor suspects an injured tendon, he or she may request this test, which uses sound waves to produce detailed images of soft tissues within the body. Using radio waves and a strong magnet, MRIs provide excellent detail of both hard and soft tissues.
Remedies: If the flatfeet cause one minor pain, one might want to try: Rest. Participate in low-impact activities such as walking, biking or swimming rather than jumping and running activities.

Name: Pet allergy
Causes: Allergies occur when the immune system reacts to a foreign substance such as pollen, mold or pet dander. When one has allergies, the immune system makes antibodies that identify the particular allergen as something harmful, even though it isn't. Allergens from rodents are usually present in hair, dander, saliva and urine.
Diagnosis: In this test, tiny amounts of purified allergen extracts including extracts with animal proteins are pricked into the skin's surface. As an alternative, the doctor may order a blood test that screens the blood for specific allergy-causing antibodies to various common allergens, including various animals.
Remedies: Even after a thorough cleaning, the house may have significant levels of pet allergens for several weeks or months. The following steps can help lower pet allergen levels in a newly pet-free home: If one keep the pet, one can help minimize the allergens in the home with these tips: Clean. Replace upholstered furniture if possible, as cleaning won't remove all pet allergens from upholstery. Replace sheets, blankets and other bedcovers, because it's difficult to wash away pet allergens completely. High-efficiency particulate air (HEPA) filters for the air ducts may trap allergens in the air, and HEPA vacuum bags may reduce the amount of dander rustled up by the cleaning. If possible, replace wall-to-wall carpeting with tile, wood, linoleum or vinyl flooring that won't harbor pet allergens as easily. When it comes time to clean the pet's kennel, litter box or cage, ask a family member or friend who doesn't have pet allergies to do the work.
info-Symptoms: Red eyes, itchy rash, runny nose, shortness of breath, swelling, sneezing
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, skin prick test, blood test
info-Treatment: Avoiding known allergens, medications, allergen immunotherapy
info-Medication: Steroids, antihistamines, epinephrine, mast cell stabilizers, antileukotrienes

Name: Peyronie 's disease
Symptoms: Peyronie's disease signs and symptoms might appear suddenly or develop gradually. The most common signs and symptoms include The curvature and penile shortening associated with Peyronie's disease might gradually worsen. Pain during erections usually improves within one to two years, but the scar tissue, penile shortening and curvature often remain. In some men, both the curvature and pain associated with Peyronie's disease improve without treatment. Peyronie's disease might cause problems getting or maintaining an erection (erectile dysfunction). But, often men report erectile dysfunction before the beginning of Peyronie's disease symptoms.
Risk factors: However, various factors can contribute to poor wound healing and scar tissue buildup that might play a role in Peyronie's disease. These include Other factors including certain health conditions, smoking and some types of prostate surgery might be linked to Peyronie's disease. Men who have certain connective tissue disorders appear to have an increased risk of developing Peyronie's disease. For example, a number of men who have Peyronie's disease also have a cordlike thickening across the palm that causes the fingers to pull inward (Dupuytren's contracture). Peyronie's disease can occur in men of any age, but the prevalence of the condition increases with age, especially for men in their 50s and 60s.
Diagnosis: A physical exam is often sufficient to identify the presence of scar tissue in the penis and diagnose Peyronie's disease. The doctor will feel (palpate) the penis when it's not erect, to identify the location and amount of scar tissue. The doctor might order an ultrasound or other tests to examine the penis when it's erect.
Treatment: For the acute phase of the disease, treatments range from: For the chronic phase of the disease, several potential treatments are available. They may be done alone or in combination: Oral medications aren't recommended in the chronic phase, as they haven't been shown to be effective at this stage of the disease. The acute phase happens early in the disease and may last only two to four weeks but sometimes lasts for up to a year or longer. The chronic phase happens later in the disease and generally occurs around three to 12 months after symptoms begin. When used early in the disease process, penile traction therapy prevents length loss and minimizes the extent of curvature that occurs.
Medication: A number of oral medications have been tried to treat Peyronie's disease, but they have not been shown to be effective consistently and are not as effective as surgery. In some men, drugs injected directly into the penis might reduce curvature and pain associated with Peyronie's disease. It appears to disrupt the production of collagen, a protein that might be a key factor in the formation of Peyronie's disease scar tissue. Interferon also has been shown to reduce penile pain in men with Peyronie's disease.

Name: Pheochromocytoma
Overview: A pheochromocytoma can cause wild fluctuations in blood pressure with normal blood pressure in between spells. The graph shows a nine-day period of short, irregular bursts in blood pressure due to a pheochromocytoma. For example, the first burst in blood pressure is seen on day two with a reading of 250/110 millimeters of mercury. A pheochromocytoma (fee-o-kroe-moe-sy-TOE-muh) is a rare, usually noncancerous (benign) tumor that develops in an adrenal gland. If one has a pheochromocytoma, the tumor releases hormones that may cause high blood pressure, headache, sweating and symptoms of a panic attack.
Causes: The tumor develops in specialized cells, called chromaffin cells, located in the center of an adrenal gland. Chromaffin cell tumors, called paragangliomas, may result in the same effects on the body.
Diagnosis: The following tests measure levels of adrenaline, noradrenaline or byproducts of those hormones in the body: For both types of tests, talk with the doctor about special preparations, such as fasting or skipping a medication. If the lab test results suggest the presence of a pheochromocytoma or paraganglioma, the doctor will likely order one or more imaging tests to locate a possible tumor. CT scan, a specialized X-ray technology MRI, which uses radio waves and a magnetic field to produce detailed images M-iodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) imaging, a scanning technology that can detect tiny amounts of an injected radioactive compound taken up by pheochromocytomas or paragangliomas Positron emission tomography (PET), a scanning technology that also can detect radioactive compounds taken up by a tumor Because some inherited disorders can cause multiple conditions, test results may indicate the need to screen for other medical problems.
info-Symptoms: Hypertension, tachycardia, sweating, headache, pallor
info-Diagnostic method: Elevated plasma free metanephrines, plasma catecholamines, or urinary catecholamines
info-Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, radiation, and pharmacologic agents

Name: Pick 's disease
Overview: Frontotemporal dementia is an umbrella term for a group of uncommon brain disorders that primarily affect the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain. Some people with frontotemporal dementia have dramatic changes in their personality and become socially inappropriate, impulsive or emotionally indifferent, while others lose the ability to use language properly.
Diagnosis: Some symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea (memory and thinking problems and behavioral changes) can be similar to those of frontotemporal dementia. If one also have symptoms of sleep apnea (loud snoring and pauses in breathing while sleeping), the doctor may have one undergo a sleep study to rule out obstructive sleep apnea as a cause of the symptoms. By looking at images of the brain, doctors may be able to pinpoint any visible abnormalities such as clots, bleeding or tumors that may be causing signs and symptoms.
Medication: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as citalopram (Celexa), paroxetine (Paxil) or sertraline (Zoloft) also have been effective in some people. Antipsychotic medications, such as olanzapine (Zyprexa) or quetiapine (Seroquel), are sometimes used to combat the behavioral problems of frontotemporal dementia.

Name: PID
Diagnosis: During a pelvic exam, the doctor inserts two gloved fingers inside the vagina. Instead, the doctor will rely on a combination of findings from: If the diagnosis is still unclear, the doctor may recommend additional tests, such as: The medical history. The doctor will likely ask about the sexual habits, history of sexually transmitted infections and method of birth control. During the exam, the doctor will check the pelvic region for tenderness and swelling. These tests may be used to test for pregnancy, HIV or other sexually transmitted infections, or to measure white blood cell counts or other markers of infection or inflammation. During this procedure, the doctor inserts a thin, lighted instrument through a small incision in the abdomen to view the pelvic organs. During this procedure, the doctor inserts a thin tube into the uterus to remove a small sample of endometrial tissue.
Treatment: Treatment for PID most often includes: If one is pregnant, seriously ill, have a suspected abscess or haven't responded to oral medications, one might need hospitalization. One might also need surgery if one don't respond to antibiotic treatment or have a questionable diagnosis, such as when one or more of the signs or symptoms of PID are absent. To help one cope with the ups and downs of the diagnosis, consider these strategies: If one has signs or symptoms of pelvic inflammatory disease, make an appointment to see the doctor. After receiving the lab test results, the doctor might adjust the prescription to better match what's causing the infection. Nevertheless, one and the partner should both seek immediate treatment to lessen the severity of PID and to prevent reinfection. If one has been trying to get pregnant without success, make an appointment with the doctor for an infertility evaluation. Although sexual health, infertility and chronic pain can be deeply personal issues, reach out to the partner, close family members or friends, or a professional for support.

Name: Piles
Symptoms: Don't assume rectal bleeding is due to hemorrhoids, especially if one has changes in bowel habits or if the stools change in color or consistency. Itching or irritation in the anal region Pain or discomfort Swelling around the anus Bleeding Painless bleeding during bowel movements.
Overview: Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the lower rectum. Hemorrhoids (HEM-uh-roids), also called piles, are swollen veins in the anus and lower rectum, similar to varicose veins.
info-Symptoms: Internal: Painless, bright red rectal bleedingExternal: Pain and swelling around the anus
info-Risk factors: Constipation, diarrhea, sitting on the toilet for a long time, pregnancy
info-Treatment: Increased fiber, drinking fluids, NSAIDs, rest, surgery

Name: Pilonidal cyst
Symptoms: When it's infected, a pilonidal cyst becomes a swollen mass (abscess). Signs and symptoms of an infected pilonidal cyst include If one notice any signs or symptoms of a pilonidal cyst, see the doctor.
Causes: Friction and pressure skin rubbing against skin, tight clothing, bicycling, long periods of sitting or similar factors force the hair down into skin. For example, barbers, dog groomers and sheep shearers have developed pilonidal cysts in the skin between fingers.
info-Symptoms: Pain, swelling, redness, drainage of fluid
info-Risk factors: Obesity, family history, prolonged sitting, greater amounts of hair, not enough exercise

Name: Pinched nerve
Risk factors: Bone spurs can stiffen the spine as well as narrow the space where the nerves travel, pinching nerves. Inflammation caused by rheumatoid arthritis can compress nerves, especially in the joints. Jobs or hobbies that require repetitive hand, wrist or shoulder movements, such as assembly line work, increase the likelihood of a pinched nerve. Water and weight gain associated with pregnancy can swell nerve pathways, compressing the nerves.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects a pinched nerve, one may undergo some tests. This test measures electrical nerve impulses and functioning in the muscles and nerves through electrodes placed on the skin.

Name: Pineoblastoma
Diagnosis: If it's suspected that one has a brain tumor, the doctor may recommend a number of tests and procedures, including Imaging tests. A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. Positron emission tomography (PET) may be used for brain imaging, but is generally not as useful for creating images of brain cancer as it is for other types of cancer. A stereotactic needle biopsy may be done for brain tumors in hard to reach areas or very sensitive areas within the brain that might be damaged by a more extensive operation. If it's suspected that the brain tumor may be a result of cancer that has spread from another area of the body, the doctor may recommend tests and procedures to determine where the cancer originated.

Name: Pink eye ( conjunctivitis )
Overview: Pink eye (conjunctivitis) is the inflammation or infection of the transparent membrane that lines the eyelid and eyeball. Pink eye (conjunctivitis) is an inflammation or infection of the transparent membrane (conjunctiva) that lines the eyelid and covers the white part of the eyeball. Pink eye is commonly caused by a bacterial or viral infection, an allergic reaction, or in babies an incompletely opened tear duct.
Causes: This antibody triggers special cells called mast cells in the mucous lining of the eyes and airways to release inflammatory substances, including histamines. The body's release of histamine can produce a number of allergy signs and symptoms, including red or pink eyes. If one has allergic conjunctivitis, one may experience intense itching, tearing and inflammation of the eyes as well as sneezing and watery nasal discharge. Signs and symptoms, which may include watery eyes and a mucous discharge, usually clear up on their own within about a day.
Treatment: The doctor may recommend using artificial tears, cleaning the eyelids with a wet cloth, and applying cold or warm compresses several times daily. Since conjunctivitis is usually viral, antibiotics won't help, and may even cause harm by reducing their effectiveness in the future or causing a medication reaction.
Remedies: To help one cope with the signs and symptoms of pink eye until it goes away, try to: Apply a compress to the eyes. If one wear contact lenses, one may need to stop wearing them until the eyes feel better.

Name: Pinworm infection
Overview: An adult pinworm generally is 1/4 to 1/2 inch (about 6 to 13 millimeters) in length. Pinworms are thin and white, measuring about 1/4 to 1/2 inch (about 6 to 13 millimeters) in length.
info-Symptoms: Itchy anal area
info-Risk factors: Attending school
info-Prevention: Handwashing, daily bathing in the morning, daily changing of underwear

Name: Pituitary insufficiency
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of hypopituitarism vary from person to person, depending on which pituitary hormones are affected and to what degree. In people who have more than one pituitary hormone deficiency, the second deficiency may increase or, in some cases, hide the symptoms of the first deficiency. This causes symptoms such as: This hormone helps the adrenal glands work properly, and helps the body react to stress. Symptoms of ACTH deficiency include This hormone, which is also called vasopressin, helps the body balance its fluid levels. An ADH deficiency can cause a disorder called diabetes insipidus, which can cause: Prolactin is the hormone that tells the body when to start making breast milk. These could be signs and symptoms of sudden destruction of the pituitary gland tissue (pituitary apoplexy), often caused by bleeding into the pituitary gland.
