Overview: The pituitary gland and the hypothalamus are located within the brain and control hormone production. It is part of the body's endocrine system, which consists of all the glands that produce and regulate hormones. Despite its small size, the pituitary gland creates and releases a number of hormones that act on nearly every part of the body.
Causes: In addition to tumors, certain diseases or events that cause damage to the pituitary gland may also trigger hypopituitarism. Tumors or diseases of the hypothalamus, a portion of the brain situated just above the pituitary, also can cause hypopituitarism.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects a problem with the pituitary hormones, he or she will likely order several tests to check hormone levels in the body and search for a cause. For example, blood tests can identify low levels of thyroid, adrenal or sex hormones. The tests can determine if these low levels are associated with pituitary hormone production. These tests check the body's hormone levels after one has taken certain medications to stimulate hormone production.
Medication: Hormone replacement medications may include A doctor who specializes in endocrine disorders (endocrinologist) may monitor the symptoms and the levels of these hormones in the blood to ensure one is getting the appropriate amounts. These drugs, such as hydrocortisone (Cortef) or prednisone (Rayos), replace the adrenal hormones that aren't being produced because of an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) deficiency. Also called somatropin (Genotropin, Humatrope, others), growth hormone is administered through an injection beneath the skin. Adults with symptoms of growth hormone deficiency also may benefit from growth hormone replacement, but they won't grow taller.

Name: Pituitary tumors
Symptoms: Pituitary tumors that make hormones (functioning) can cause a variety of signs and symptoms depending on the hormone they produce. The signs and symptoms of pituitary tumors that don't make hormones (nonfunctioning) are related to their growth and the pressure they put on other structures. Signs and symptoms of pressure from a pituitary tumor may include Functioning pituitary tumors cause an overproduction of hormones. Signs and symptoms include ACTH tumors produce the hormone adrenocorticotropin, which stimulates the adrenal glands to make the hormone cortisol. Overproduction of prolactin from a pituitary tumor (prolactinoma) can cause a decrease in normal levels of sex hormones estrogen in women and testosterone in men. Signs and symptoms can include When a pituitary tumor overproduces thyroid-stimulating hormone, the thyroid gland makes too much of the hormone thyroxine.
Diagnosis: To diagnose a pituitary tumor, the doctor will likely take a detailed history and perform a physical exam. A CT scan or MRI scan of the brain can help the doctor judge the location and size of a pituitary tumor.
Treatment: Treatment involves a team of medical experts, possibly including a brain surgeon (neurosurgeon), endocrine system specialist (endocrinologist) and a radiation oncologist. Doctors generally use surgery, radiation therapy and medications, either alone or in combination, to treat a pituitary tumor and return hormone production to normal levels.
Medication: Treatment with medications may help to block excess hormone secretion and sometimes shrink certain types of pituitary tumors: ACTH-producing tumors (Cushing syndrome). Mifepristone (Korlym, Mifeprex) is approved for people with Cushing syndrome who have type 2 diabetes or glucose intolerance. Side effects may include fatigue, nausea, vomiting, headaches, muscle aches, high blood pressure, low potassium and swelling. The newest medication for Cushing syndrome is pasireotide (Signifor), and it works by decreasing ACTH production from a pituitary tumor. Side effects are fairly common, and may include diarrhea, nausea, high blood sugar, headache, abdominal pain and fatigue. One type of drugs known as somatostatin analogs, which includes drugs such as octreotide (Sandostatin) and lanreotide (Somatuline Depot), causes a decrease in growth hormone production and may shrink the tumor. These drugs can cause side effects such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, dizziness, headache and pain at the site of injection. The second type of drugs, pegvisomant (Somavert), blocks the effect of excess growth hormone on the body. If a pituitary tumor or surgery to remove it decreases hormone production, one will likely need to take replacement hormones to maintain normal hormone levels.

Name: Pityriasis rosea
Overview: Pityriasis rosea typically begins with a large, slightly raised, scaly patch called the herald patch. Pityriasis rosea is a rash that usually begins as a large circular or oval spot on the chest, abdomen or back.
info-Symptoms: Single red and slightly scaly area, followed

Name: PKU
Symptoms: If women don't follow the special PKU diet before and during pregnancy, blood phenylalanine levels can become high and harm the developing fetus or cause a miscarriage. Even women with less severe forms of PKU may place their unborn children at risk by not following the PKU diet. In mild or moderate forms, the enzyme retains some function, so phenylalanine levels are not as high, resulting in a smaller risk of significant brain damage. If routine newborn screening tests show that the baby may have PKU, the child's doctor will want to start dietary treatment right away to prevent long-term problems.
Overview: Phenylketonuria (fen-ul-key-toe-NU-ree-uh), also called PKU, is a rare inherited disorder that causes an amino acid called phenylalanine to build up in the body. Without the enzyme necessary to process phenylalanine, a dangerous buildup can develop when a person with PKU eats foods that contain protein or eats aspartame, an artificial sweetener. For the rest of their lives, people with PKU babies, children and adults need to follow a diet that limits phenylalanine, which is found mostly in foods that contain protein.
Causes: To have an autosomal recessive disorder, one inherit two abnormal genes, one from each parent. A defective gene (genetic mutation) causes PKU, which can be mild, moderate or severe. In a person with PKU, this defective gene causes a lack of or deficiency of the enzyme that's needed to process phenylalanine, an amino acid. It's possible for a parent to be a carrier to have the defective gene that causes PKU, but not have the disease.
Remedies: If one or the child is following a low-phenylalanine diet, one will need to keep records of the food eaten every day to be sure one is sticking to the specific, individualized dietary guidelines recommended by the dietitian. Food diaries or computer programs are available that list the amount of phenylalanine in baby foods, solid foods, PKU formulas, and common baking and cooking ingredients. To add variety to the diet, buy some of the many low-protein products, such as low-protein pasta, rice, flour and bread, which are available through specialty food retailers.
info-Symptoms: Without treatment intellectual disability, seizures, behavioral problems, mental disorders, musty odor
info-Diagnostic method: Newborn screening programs in many countries
info-Treatment: Diet low in foods that contain phenylalanine; special supplements

Name: Placenta accreta
Overview: Placenta accreta occurs when the placenta grows too deeply into the uterine wall during pregnancy. Placenta accreta is a serious pregnancy condition that occurs when the placenta grows too deeply into the uterine wall. It's also possible for the placenta to invade the muscles of the uterus (placenta increta) or grow through the uterine wall (placenta percreta).
Risk factors: Many factors can increase the risk of placenta accreta, including Previous uterine surgery. The risk of placenta accreta increases with the number of C-sections or other uterine surgeries one has had. If the placenta partially or totally covers the cervix (placenta previa) or sits in the lower portion of the uterus, one is at increased risk of placenta accreta.

Name: Placenta previa
Overview: The placenta is a structure that develops in the uterus during pregnancy. The placenta is a structure that develops inside the uterus during pregnancy, providing oxygen and nutrition to and removing wastes from the baby.
Diagnosis: Placenta previa is diagnosed through ultrasound, either during a routine prenatal appointment or after an episode of vaginal bleeding. If the health care provider suspects placenta previa, he or she will avoid routine vaginal exams to reduce the risk of heavy bleeding.
info-Symptoms: Bright red vaginal bleeding without pain
info-Risk factors: Older age, smoking, prior cesarean section, labor induction, or termination of pregnancy

Name: Placental abruption
Overview: The placenta is an organ that develops in the uterus during pregnancy. Placental abruption can deprive the baby of oxygen and nutrients and cause heavy bleeding in the mother. Placental abruption occurs when the placenta partly or completely separates from the inner wall of the uterus before delivery.
info-Symptoms: Vaginal bleeding, low abdominal pain, dangerously low blood pressure
info-Risk factors: Smoking, preeclampsia, prior abruption

Name: Plantar fasciitis
Overview: Plantar fasciitis is an inflammation of the fibrous tissue (plantar fascia) along the bottom of the foot that connects the heel bone to the toes. It involves inflammation of a thick band of tissue that runs across the bottom of the foot and connects the heel bone to the toes (plantar fascia).
Risk factors: Even though plantar fasciitis can develop without an obvious cause, some factors can increase the risk of developing this condition. Activities that place a lot of stress on the heel and attached tissue such as long-distance running, ballet dancing and aerobic dance can contribute to the onset of plantar fasciitis. Flat feet, a high arch or even an abnormal pattern of walking can affect the way weight is distributed when one is standing and can put added stress on the plantar fascia. Factory workers, teachers and others who spend most of their work hours walking or standing on hard surfaces can damage the plantar fascia.
Diagnosis: The doctor might suggest an X-ray or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to make sure another problem, such as a stress fracture, is not causing one pain. In the past, these bone spurs were often blamed for heel pain and removed surgically.
Remedies: To reduce the pain of plantar fasciitis, try these self-care tips: Maintain a healthy weight. Buy shoes with a low to moderate heel, thick soles, good arch support and extra cushioning. Simple home exercises can stretch the plantar fascia, Achilles tendon and calf muscles.
Medication: Pain relievers such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve) may ease the pain and inflammation caused by plantar fasciitis. They include If more-conservative measures aren't working after several months, the doctor might recommend: Physical therapy. A physical therapist can show one a series of exercises to stretch the plantar fascia and Achilles tendon and to strengthen lower leg muscles. Using ultrasound imaging, platelet-rich plasma obtained from the patient's own blood can be injected to promote tissue healing.
info-Specialty: Orthopedics, sports medicine, plastic surgery, podiatry
info-Symptoms: Pain in the heel and bottom of the foot
info-Risk factors: Overuse (long periods of standing), obesity, inward rolling of the foot

Name: Plantar neuroma
Overview: Morton's neuroma involves a thickening of the tissue around one of the nerves leading to the toes. Morton's neuroma is a painful condition that affects the ball of the foot, most commonly the area between the third and fourth toes. Morton's neuroma involves a thickening of the tissue around one of the nerves leading to the toes.
Risk factors: Wearing high-heeled shoes or shoes that are tight or ill fitting can place extra pressure on the toes and the ball of the foot. Sports that feature tight shoes, such as snow skiing or rock climbing, can put pressure on the toes. People who have bunions, hammertoes, high arches or flatfeet are at higher risk of developing Morton's neuroma.
Diagnosis: The doctor is likely to order X-rays of the foot, to rule out other causes of the pain such as a stress fracture. Using radio waves and a strong magnetic field, an MRI also is good at visualizing soft tissues.
Remedies: To help relieve the pain associated with Morton's neuroma and allow the nerve to heal, consider the following self-care tips: Take anti-inflammatory medications. Over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen (Aleve), can reduce swelling and relieve pain.

Name: Pleuritis
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of pleurisy might include Pain caused by pleurisy might worsen with movement of the upper body and can radiate to the shoulders or back. Pleurisy can be accompanied by pleural effusion, atelectasis or empyema: Call the doctor right away if one experience unexplained, intense chest pain during breathing. A large amount of fluid in the pleural space can create pressure, compressing the lung to the point that it partially or completely collapses (atelectasis).
Overview: Pleurisy occurs when the pleura a membrane consisting of a layer of tissue that lines the chest cavity and a layer of tissue that surrounds the lungs becomes inflamed, causing chest pain. Pleurisy (PLOOR-ih-see) is a condition in which the pleura two large, thin layers of tissue that separate the lungs from the chest wall becomes inflamed.
Diagnosis: To determine if one has pleurisy and identify the cause, the doctor might recommend: In some cases, the doctor might remove fluid and tissue from the pleural space for testing. If TB or cancer is a suspected cause of the condition, the doctor might perform a thoracoscopy also called a pleuroscopy in which a tiny camera (thoracoscope) is inserted through a small incision in the chest wall.
Treatment: The pain and inflammation associated with pleurisy is usually treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others). One may want to bring a family member or friend along, if possible, to help one remember questions to ask and what the doctor said.
info-Symptoms: Sharp chest pain
info-Causes: Viral infection, bacterial infection, pneumonia, pulmonary embolism

Name: Pneumonia
Overview: Most pneumonia occurs when a breakdown in the body's natural defenses allows germs to invade and multiply within the lungs. Along with bacteria and fungi, they fill the air sacs within the lungs (alveoli). A classic sign of bacterial pneumonia is a cough that produces thick, blood-tinged or yellowish-greenish sputum with pus. The air sacs may fill with fluid or pus (purulent material), causing cough with phlegm or pus, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing.
Causes: Hospital-acquired pneumonia can be serious because the bacteria causing it may be more resistant to antibiotics and because the people who get it are already sick. People who are on breathing machines (ventilators), often used in intensive care units, are at higher risk of this type of pneumonia. Health care-acquired pneumonia is a bacterial infection that occurs in people who live in long-term care facilities or who receive care in outpatient clinics, including kidney dialysis centers. Like hospital-acquired pneumonia, health care-acquired pneumonia can be caused by bacteria that are more resistant to antibiotics. This type of pneumonia is most common in people with chronic health problems or weakened immune systems, and in people who have inhaled large doses of the organisms. Coronavirus 2019 (COVID-19) may cause pneumonia, which can become severe.
Risk factors: But the two age groups at highest risk are: Other risk factors include Children who are 2 years old or younger People who are age 65 or older Being hospitalized. One is at greater risk of pneumonia if one is in a hospital intensive care unit, especially if one is on a machine that helps one breathe (a ventilator). One is more likely to get pneumonia if one has asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or heart disease.
Diagnosis: If pneumonia is suspected, the doctor may recommend the following tests: The doctor might order additional tests if one is older than age 65, are in the hospital, or have serious symptoms or health conditions. A sample of fluid from the lungs (sputum) is taken after a deep cough and analyzed to help pinpoint the cause of the infection. If the pneumonia isn't clearing as quickly as expected, the doctor may recommend a chest CT scan to obtain a more detailed image of the lungs.
Treatment: Because coughing helps loosen and move fluid from the lungs, it's a good idea not to eliminate the cough completely. In addition, one should know that very few studies have looked at whether over-the-counter cough medicines lessen coughing caused by pneumonia.
Remedies: Because pneumonia can recur, it's better not to jump back into the routine until one is fully recovered. Drink plenty of fluids, especially water, to help loosen mucus in the lungs. If one stop taking medication too soon, the lungs may continue to harbor bacteria that can multiply and cause the pneumonia to recur.
info-Symptoms: Cough, difficulty breathing, rapid breathing, fever
info-Risk factors: Cystic fibrosis, COPD, sickle cell disease, asthma, diabetes, heart failure, history of smoking, older age

Name: Pneumonitis
Overview: Pneumonitis (noo-moe-NIE-tis) is a general term that refers to inflammation of lung tissue. Pneumonitis, however, is usually used by doctors to refer to noninfectious causes of lung inflammation.
Causes: Pneumonitis occurs when an irritating substance causes the tiny air sacs (alveoli) in the lungs to become inflamed. Many irritants, ranging from airborne molds to chemotherapy drugs, have been linked to pneumonitis. A variety of drugs can cause pneumonitis, including some antibiotics, several types of chemotherapy drugs and medications that keep the heartbeat regular. Specific varieties of mold-related pneumonitis have received nicknames, such as farmer's lung or hot tub lung. Some people who undergo radiation therapy to the chest, such as for breast or lung cancer, may develop pneumonitis. Pneumonitis also can occur after whole-body radiation therapy, which is needed to prepare a person for a bone marrow transplant.
Risk factors: Some occupations and hobbies carry higher risks of pneumonitis, including Some chemotherapy drugs can cause pneumonitis, as can radiation therapy to the lungs. Inhaling airborne particles from moldy hay is one of the most common causes of occupational pneumonitis. Poultry workers and people who breed or keep pigeons are often exposed to droppings, feathers and other materials that can cause pneumonitis. Moldy conditions in hot tubs can trigger pneumonitis because the bubbling action makes a mist that can be inhaled.
Diagnosis: Imaging tests are useful because in most cases, pneumonia affects only a small, localized portion of the lungs, while the effects of noninfectious pneumonitis are often spread throughout all five lobes of the lungs. In some cases, the doctor may want to examine larger samples of tissue from several locations in the lungs that cannot be reached via bronchoscopy.
Treatment: In severe cases of pneumonitis, treatment may also include A diagnosis of pneumonitis may mean that one will have to make changes to the lifestyle to protect the health. For example, if the job duties expose one to substances that irritate the lungs, talk to the doctor and supervisor at work about ways to protect theself, such as wearing a pollen mask or personal dust respirator. If one is having a lot of trouble breathing, one may need oxygen therapy through a mask or plastic tubing with prongs that fit into the nostrils.

Name: Pneumothorax
Overview: In a collapsed lung, air from the lung leaks into the chest cavity. A pneumothorax occurs when air leaks into the space between the lung and chest wall. A pneumothorax can be caused by a blunt or penetrating chest injury, certain medical procedures, or damage from underlying lung disease.
Causes: Some injuries may happen during physical assaults or car crashes, while others may inadvertently occur during medical procedures that involve the insertion of a needle into the chest. Lung damage can be caused by many types of underlying diseases, including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), cystic fibrosis and pneumonia. Small air blisters (blebs) can develop on the top of the lungs.
Risk factors: The type of pneumothorax caused by ruptured air blisters is most likely to occur in people between 20 and 40 years old, especially if the person is very tall and underweight. Having an underlying lung disease especially chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) makes a collapsed lung more likely.
info-Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, tiredness
info-Risk factors: COPD, tuberculosis, smoking
info-Treatment: conservative, needle aspiration, chest tube, pleurodesis

Name: POEMS syndrome
Overview: POEMS syndrome is a rare blood disorder that damages the nerves and affects other parts of the body. These cells produce an abnormal amount of a type of protein, which can damage other parts of the body. POEMS syndrome progresses rapidly without treatment and can become life-threatening, so early diagnosis is important. Abnormal hormone levels that can result in an underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism), diabetes, sexual problems, fatigue, swelling in the limbs, and problems with metabolism and other essential functions.

Name: Polio
Overview: Polio is a contagious viral illness that in its most severe form causes nerve injury leading to paralysis, difficulty breathing and sometimes death. Adults who have been vaccinated who plan to travel to an area where polio is occurring should receive a booster dose of inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV).
info-Symptoms: Muscle weakness resulting in an inability to move
info-Diagnostic method: Finding the virus in the feces or antibodies in the blood

Name: Polycystic kidney disease
Overview: A healthy kidney (left) eliminates waste from the blood and maintains the body's normal chemical balance. Fluid-filled sacs (right), called cysts, characterize polycystic kidney disease. Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is an inherited disorder in which clusters of cysts develop primarily within the kidneys, causing the kidneys to enlarge and lose function over time.
Causes: In an autosomal dominant disorder, the abnormal gene is a dominant gene located on one of the nonsex chromosomes (autosomes). Abnormal genes cause polycystic kidney disease, which means that in most cases, the disease runs in families. The two main types of polycystic kidney disease, caused by different genetic flaws, are: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Sometimes, symptoms don't appear until later in childhood or during adolescence.Both parents must have abnormal genes to pass on this form of the disease.
Diagnosis: For polycystic kidney disease, certain tests can detect the size and number of kidney cysts one has and evaluate the amount of healthy kidney tissue, including Ultrasound. As one lie inside a large cylinder, magnetic fields and radio waves generate cross-sectional views of the kidneys.
Treatment: Treating polycystic kidney disease involves dealing with the following signs, symptoms and complications in their early stages: High blood pressure. Combining a low-sodium, low-fat diet that's moderate in protein and calorie content with not smoking, increasing exercise and reducing stress may help control high blood pressure. However, medications are usually needed to control high blood pressure. Nonsurgical treatment of small aneurysms may involve controlling high blood pressure and high blood cholesterol, as well as quitting smoking. Combining a low-sodium, low-fat diet that's moderate in protein and calorie content with not smoking, increasing exercise and reducing stress may help control high blood pressure.However, medications are usually needed to control high blood pressure.
info-Symptoms: Abdominal pain

Name: Polyhydramnios
Diagnosis: If the initial ultrasound shows evidence of polyhydramnios, the health care provider may do a more detailed ultrasound. Additional tests may include If one is diagnosed with polyhydramnios, the health care provider will closely monitor the pregnancy. Amniocentesis is a procedure in which a sample of amniotic fluid which contains fetal cells and various chemicals produced by the baby is removed from the uterus for testing. Testing may include a karyotype analysis, used to screen the baby's chromosomes for abnormalities. This test uses an ultrasound to provide more information about the baby's breathing, tone and movement, as well as the volume of amniotic fluid in the uterus.
Treatment: Treatment may include After treatment, the doctor will still want to monitor the amniotic fluid level approximately every one to three weeks. The health care provider may prescribe the oral medication indomethacin (Indocin) to help reduce fetal urine production and amniotic fluid volume.

Name: Polymyalgia rheumatica
Causes: Two factors appear to be involved in the development of this condition: Polymyalgia rheumatica and another disease known as giant cell arteritis share many similarities. New cases of polymyalgia rheumatica tend to come in cycles, possibly developing seasonally.
Diagnosis: Besides checking the complete blood counts, the doctor will look for two indicators of inflammation erythrocyte sedimentation rate (sed rate) and C-reactive protein. New, unusual or persistent headaches Jaw pain or tenderness Blurred or double vision or visual loss Scalp tenderness C-reactive protein test Sed rate (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) Ultrasound Blood tests.
Remedies: Over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve), are not usually recommended for easing the signs and symptoms of polymyalgia rheumatica. Eat a diet of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat protein and dairy products. Consider using luggage and grocery carts, reaching aids, shower grab bars, and other assistive devices to help make daily tasks easier.
Medication: After the first two to four weeks of treatment, the doctor might begin to gradually decrease the dosage depending on the symptoms and the results of blood tests. Long-term use of corticosteroids can result in serious side effects, including weight gain, loss of bone density, high blood pressure, diabetes and cataracts. Calcium and vitamin D. The doctor will likely prescribe daily doses of calcium and vitamin D supplements to help prevent bone loss as a result of corticosteroid treatment. The American College of Rheumatology recommends 1,000 to 1,200 milligrams of calcium supplements and 600 to 800 international units of vitamin D supplements for anyone taking corticosteroids for three months or more. It might be useful early in the course of treatment or later, if one relapse or don't respond to corticosteroids.
info-Symptoms: Shoulder, neck and hip pain
info-Diagnostic method: Elevated inflammatory markers, CRP and ESR

Name: Polymyositis
Overview: Polymyositis (pol-e-my-o-SY-tis) is an uncommon inflammatory disease that causes muscle weakness affecting both sides of the body. While there is no cure for polymyositis, treatment ranging from medications to physical therapy can improve the muscle strength and function.
Medication: The most commonly used medications to treat polymyositis include Depending on the severity of the symptoms, the doctor might suggest: Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) is a purified blood product that contains healthy antibodies from thousands of blood donors. The two most common medications used for polymyositis are azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran) and methotrexate (Trexall). Other medications prescribed for polymyositis include mycophenolate mofetil (CellCept), cyclosporine and tacrolimus. More commonly used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, rituximab is an option if initial therapies don't adequately control the polymyositis symptoms.

Name: Polyps , colon
Symptoms: But some people with colon polyps experience: See the doctor if one experience: One should be screened regularly for polyps if: Rectal bleeding. A large colon polyp can partially obstruct the bowel, leading to crampy abdominal pain. Bleeding from polyps can occur slowly over time, without visible blood in the stool. Abdominal pain Blood in the stool A change in the bowel habits that lasts longer than a week One is age 50 or older.
Overview: A colon polyp is a small clump of cells that forms on the lining of the colon. But over time, some colon polyps can develop into colon cancer, which is often fatal when found in its later stages. One is at higher risk if one is 50 or older, are overweight or a smoker, or have a personal or family history of colon polyps or colon cancer. It's important to have regular screening tests, such as a colonoscopy, because colon polyps found in the early stages can usually be removed safely and completely.
Causes: This image of the inside of the colon shows two small polyps whose diameters are about the size of a pencil eraser (about 6 to 7 millimeters). Although the polyps themselves are not a significant threat, having ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease of the colon increases the overall risk of colon cancer. Serrated polyps may become cancerous, depending on their size and location in the colon.
Risk factors: Factors that may contribute to the formation of colon polyps or cancer include Rarely, people inherit genetic mutations that cause colon polyps to form. One is more likely to develop colon polyps or cancer if one has a parent, sibling or child with them. People with Lynch syndrome tend to develop relatively few colon polyps, but those polyps can quickly become malignant. Lynch syndrome is the most common form of inherited colon cancer and is also associated with tumors in the breast, stomach, small intestine, urinary tract and ovaries. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a rare disorder that causes hundreds or even thousands of polyps to develop in the lining of the colon beginning during the teenage years. If the polyps aren't treated, the risk of developing colon cancer is nearly 100 percent, usually before age 40. Gardner's syndrome, a variant of FAP that causes polyps to develop throughout the colon and small intestine. These polyps may become malignant, so people with this condition have an increased risk of colon cancer. Serrated polyposis syndrome, a condition that leads to multiple serrated adenomatous polyps in the upper part of the colon.
Diagnosis: Screening methods include Generally speaking, we encourage all adults over the age of 50 and even older adults who have at least 10 years of very high-quality life expectancy to participate in screening, Dr. Kisiel says. So, one know, maybe a third or even a half of all patients getting a colonoscopy will have precancerous polyps. Although 1 in 20 Americans will be diagnosed with colorectal cancer in his or her lifetime, Dr. Kisiel says having polyps does not necessarily mean one will get cancer. Colonoscopy, the most sensitive test for colorectal polyps and cancer.
Treatment: But a doctor who specializes in analyzing tissue samples (pathologist) usually must examine polyp tissue under a microscope to determine whether it's potentially cancerous. If a polyp is larger than 0.4 inches (about 1 centimeter), a liquid may be injected under it to lift and isolate the polyp from surrounding tissue so that it can be removed.

Name: Polyps , nasal
Overview: Nasal polyps are soft, noncancerous growths on the lining of the nose or sinuses. Larger growths or groups of nasal polyps can block the nasal passages or lead to breathing problems, a lost sense of smell and frequent infections.
Diagnosis: These studies may also help the doctor rule out other possible blockages in the nasal cavity, such as structural abnormalities or another type of cancerous or noncancerous growth. If a skin test can't be performed, the doctor may order a blood test that screens for specific antibodies to various allergens. If one has a child diagnosed with nasal polyps, the doctor may suggest testing for cystic fibrosis, an inherited condition affecting the glands that produce mucus, tears, sweat, saliva and digestive juices. Images obtained with computerized tomography (CT) can help the doctor pinpoint the size and location of polyps in deeper areas of the sinuses and evaluate the extent of swelling and irritation (inflammation).These studies may also help the doctor rule out other possible blockages in the nasal cavity, such as structural abnormalities or another type of cancerous or noncancerous growth. The doctor or nurse then observes the skin for signs of allergic reactions.If a skin test can't be performed, the doctor may order a blood test that screens for specific antibodies to various allergens. If one has a child diagnosed with nasal polyps, the doctor may suggest testing for cystic fibrosis, an inherited condition affecting the glands that produce mucus, tears, sweat, saliva and digestive juices.The standard diagnostic test for cystic fibrosis is a noninvasive sweat test, which determines whether the child's perspiration is saltier than most people's sweat is.
Medication: Nasal corticosteroids include fluticasone (Flonase Allergy Relief, Flovent HFA, Xhance), budesonide (Rhinocort), mometasone (Nasonex, Asmanex HFA), triamcinolone (Nasacort Allergy 24HR), beclomethasone (Beconase AQ, Qvar Redihaler, Qnasl) and ciclesonide (Omnaris, Alvesco, Zetonna). If a nasal corticosteroid isn't effective, the doctor may prescribe an oral corticosteroid, such as prednisone, either alone or in combination with a nasal spray. Aspirin desensitization, under the care of an allergy specialist with experience in desensitization, may benefit some patients with nasal polyps and aspirin sensitivity. If one has nasal polyps and chronic sinusitis, the doctor may give one an injection of a medication called dupilumab (Dupixent) to treat the condition.

Name: Pompholyx
Symptoms: The blisters are usually small about the width of a standard pencil lead and grouped in clusters, with an appearance similar to tapioca. Once the blisters dry and flake off, which occurs in about three weeks, the underlying skin may be red and tender.
Overview: Dyshidrosis causes very small, fluid-filled blisters to occur on the soles of the feet, the palms of the hands or sides of the fingers. Dyshidrosis is a skin condition that causes small, fluid-filled blisters to form on the palms of the hands and sides of the fingers.
Treatment: Depending on the severity of the signs and symptoms, treatment options may include Corticosteroids. If other treatments aren't effective, the doctor may recommend a special kind of light therapy that combines exposure to ultraviolet light with drugs that help make the skin more receptive to the effects of this type of light. Medications such as tacrolimus (Protopic) and pimecrolimus (Elidel) may be helpful for people who want to limit their exposure to steroids. Some doctors may consider recommending botulinum toxin injections to treat severe cases of dyshidrosis.

Name: Poor color vision
Symptoms: If one suspect one has problems distinguishing certain colors or the color vision changes, see an eye doctor for testing. There's no cure for inherited color deficiencies, but if illness or eye disease is the cause, treatment may improve color vision.
Overview: The eye is a complex and compact structure measuring about 1 inch (2.5 centimeters) in diameter. Though many people commonly use the term color blind for this condition, true color blindness in which everything is seen in shades of black and white is rare. Less commonly, people with color blindness can't distinguish between shades of blue and yellow.
Causes: The cones are sensitive to short (blue), medium (green) or long (red) wavelengths of light. But if the cones lack one or more wavelength-sensitive chemicals, one will be unable to distinguish the colors red, green or blue. The most common color deficiency is red-green, with blue-yellow deficiency being much less common. Inherited color deficiencies usually affect both eyes, and the severity doesn't change over the lifetime. It is rare to have no color vision at all.One can inherit a mild, moderate or severe degree of the disorder. One eye may be more affected than the other, and the color deficit may get better if the underlying disease can be treated. Exposure to some chemicals in the workplace, such as carbon disulfide and fertilizers, may cause loss of color vision.

Name: Popliteal artery aneurysm
Overview: A popliteal artery aneurysm is an abnormal bulge that occurs in the wall of the artery that runs through the area behind the knee joint. Femoral and popliteal artery aneurysms.

Name: Popliteal artery entrapment
Causes: Popliteal artery entrapment syndrome (PAES) is caused by an abnormal calf muscle, usually the gastrocnemius muscle. The abnormal calf muscle presses on the main artery behind the knee (popliteal artery), reducing blood flow to the lower leg.
Diagnosis: However, because most people with popliteal artery entrapment syndrome (PAES) are young and usually healthy, diagnosing the condition can sometimes be challenging. The doctor will rule out other causes of leg pain, including muscle strains, stress fractures, chronic exertional compartment syndrome and peripheral artery disease, which results from clogged arteries. Tests used to rule out other conditions and diagnose PAES include the following: Ankle-brachial index (ABI) measurement is usually the first test done to diagnose PAES.
Treatment: During surgery, the surgeon makes an incision on the inner calf just below the knee, or in the back of the knee, to release the abnormal calf muscle and give the artery more room. Bypass surgery is usually done only on those who have severe narrowing of the artery (stenosis) due to long-term popliteal artery entrapment syndrome. If one think one may have popliteal artery entrapment syndrome, it's important that one make an appointment with the doctor.

Name: Popliteal cyst
Treatment: xa0However, if the cyst is large and causes pain, the doctor may recommend the following treatments: If possible, doctors treat the underlying cause of the cyst. If the doctor determines that a cartilage tear is causing the overproduction of synovial fluid, he or she may recommend surgery to remove or repair the torn cartilage. The doctor may inject a corticosteroid medication, such as cortisone, into the knee to reduce inflammation. Icing, a compression wrap and crutches may help reduce pain and swelling.
Remedies: If the doctor determines that arthritis is causing the cyst, he or she may advise one to take some or all of the following steps: Follow the R.I.C.E. Drugs such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve, others), acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) and aspirin can help relieve pain. The doctor can offer one guidance on how long one need to reduce the activity levels, and he or she may be able to suggest alternative forms of exercise one can do in the meantime.
info-Symptoms: None, swelling behind the knee, stiffness, pain
info-Risk factors: Knee problems such as osteoarthritis, meniscal tears, rheumatoid arthritis

Name: Porphyria
Symptoms: Acute porphyrias include forms of the disease that typically cause nervous system symptoms, which appear quickly and can be severe. As a result of sun exposure, one may experience: Many signs and symptoms of porphyria are similar to those of other, more common conditions.
Overview: Porphyria (por-FEAR-e-uh) refers to a group of disorders that result from a buildup of natural chemicals that produce porphyrin in the body. There are two general categories of porphyria: acute, which mainly affects the nervous system, and cutaneous, which mainly affects the skin. Although porphyria can't be cured, certain lifestyle changes to avoid triggering symptoms may help one manage it.
Causes: In an autosomal dominant disorder, the abnormal gene is a dominant gene located on one of the nonsex chromosomes (autosomes). To have an autosomal recessive disorder, one inherit two abnormal genes, one from each parent. A carrier has one abnormal gene (recessive gene) and one normal gene (dominant gene). Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) typically is acquired rather than inherited, although the enzyme deficiency may be inherited.
info-Symptoms: Depending on subtypeâ€”abdominal pain, chest pain, vomiting, confusion, constipation, fever, seizures, blisters with sunlight
info-Usual onset: Recurrent attacks that last days to weeks
info-Diagnostic method: Blood, urine, and stool tests, genetic testing

Name: Post-chemotherapy cognitive impairment
Overview: Chemo brain is a common term used by cancer survivors to describe thinking and memory problems that can occur during and after cancer treatment. Though chemo brain is a widely used term, the causes of concentration and memory problems aren't well-understood.
Remedies: Before tackling a complicated task that requires concentration, take steps to ensure that one will have the best chance for success. Take up a new hobby or master a new skill, such as learning to play a musical instrument or learning a language.

Name: Post-concussion syndrome
Overview: Post-concussion syndrome is a complex disorder in which various symptoms such as headaches and dizziness last for weeks and sometimes months after the injury that caused the concussion. In fact, the risk of post-concussion syndrome doesn't appear to be associated with the severity of the initial injury.
Diagnosis: The doctor may want to order a scan of the brain to check for other potential problems that could be causing the symptoms. A computerized tomography (CT) scan or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may be performed to detect structural brain abnormalities. A referral to a psychologist or licensed counselor may be in order if the symptoms include anxiety or depression, or if one is having problems with memory or problem-solving.
info-Specialty: Psychiatry, Neurology, physical medicine and rehabilitation

Name: Posterior cortical atrophy
Diagnosis: To diagnose posterior cortical atrophy, the doctor will review the medical history and symptoms, including vision difficulties, and conduct a physical examination and a neurological examination. The doctor may order several tests to help diagnose the condition and exclude other conditions that may cause similar symptoms, including Mental status and neuropsychological tests. The blood may be tested for vitamin deficiency, thyroid disorders and other conditions that may be causing the symptoms. In this test, the doctor can view abnormalities in the brain that may be causing the symptoms. In these tests, a doctor injects a small amount of radioactive material and places emission detectors on the brain.
Treatment: Posterior cortical atrophy can't be cured, but the doctor can help one manage the condition. These therapies may help one regain or retain skills that are affected by posterior cortical atrophy.

Name: Posterior cruciate ligament injury
Symptoms: Over time, the pain might worsen and the knee might feel more unstable. If other parts of the knee have also been injured, the signs and symptoms will likely be more severe. Knee swelling occurs rapidly, within hours of the injury. The knee might feel loose, as if it's going to give way.
Overview: Two of the four ligaments that connect the thighbone (femur) to the shinbone (tibia) are the posterior cruciate ligament and the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury happens far less often than does injury to the knee's more vulnerable counterpart, the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL).
Causes: The posterior cruciate ligament can tear if the shinbone is hit hard just below the knee or if one fall on a bent knee. Athletes in sports such as football and soccer can tear their posterior cruciate ligament when they fall on a bent knee with their foot pointed down.
Diagnosis: During the physical exam, the doctor might press on the knee to feel for injury, looseness or fluid in the joint from bleeding. People with posterior cruciate ligament injuries sometimes have breaks in which a small chunk of bone, attached to the ligament, pulls away from the main bone (avulsion fracture). If it's unclear how extensive the knee injury is, the doctor might use a surgical technique called arthroscopy to look inside the knee joint.
Treatment: Treatment depends on the extent of the injury and whether it just happened or if one has had it for a while. In most cases, surgery isn't required.
Remedies: rest, ice, compression and elevation can help speed recovery of mild to moderate joint injuries. Apply ice packs to the knee for 20 to 30 minutes every three to four hours for two to three days.
Medication: Over-the-counter pain relievers, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve), can help relieve pain and reduce swelling. If the injury is severe especially if it's combined with other torn knee ligaments, cartilage damage or a broken bone one might need surgery to reconstruct the ligament. This surgery usually can be performed arthroscopically by inserting a fiber-optic camera and long, slender surgical tools through several small incisions around the knee.

Name: Postherpetic neuralgia
Causes: As one age or if the immune system is suppressed, such as from medications or chemotherapy, the virus can reactivate, causing shingles. Instead, the messages become confused and exaggerated, causing chronic, often excruciating pain that can last months or even years.
Risk factors: When one has shingles, one might be at greater risk of developing postherpetic neuralgia as a result of: Age. The shingles antiviral treatment was delayed for more than 72 hours after the rash appeared.
Remedies: Capsaicin cream, made from the seeds of hot chili peppers, might relieve pain from postherpetic neuralgia. Capsaicin (Capzasin-P, Zostrix, others) can cause a burning sensation and irritate the skin, but these side effects usually disappear over time. Because capsaicin cream can irritate the skin, avoid getting it on unaffected parts of the body.
info-Symptoms: burning or stabbing pain, pain doesn't end after the shingles subsides.

Name: Postmyocardial infarction syndrome
Overview: The heart on the right shows a heart with pericarditis, in which the membrane (pericardium) that surrounds the heart is swollen and infected. Dressler's syndrome is believed to be an immune system response after damage to heart tissue or to the pericardium, from events such as a heart attack, surgery or traumatic injury.
Diagnosis: Sound waves produce an image of the heart, helping the doctor to see if fluid is collecting around it. But electrocardiogram readings may be abnormal after heart surgery, so the doctor likely won't rely on this one test for a diagnosis of Dressler's syndrome. An X-ray can help detect fluid building up around the heart or lungs and can help exclude other causes of the symptoms, such as pneumonia.
Treatment: The doctor might recommend medications, such as: If those medications don't help, the doctor might prescribe: Aspirin Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) Indomethacin Colchicine. This anti-inflammatory medication might be used, along with over-the-counter medications, to treat Dressler's syndrome.

Name: Postpartum depression
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of depression after childbirth vary, and they can range from mild to severe. Postpartum depression signs and symptoms may include Untreated, postpartum depression may last for many months or longer. With postpartum psychosis a rare condition that typically develops within the first week after delivery the signs and symptoms are severe. Signs and symptoms may include Postpartum psychosis may lead to life-threatening thoughts or behaviors and requires immediate treatment. New fathers can experience postpartum depression, too. Fathers who are young, have a history of depression, experience relationship problems or are struggling financially are most at risk of postpartum depression. But if one experience any symptoms of postpartum baby blues or postpartum depression, call the doctor and schedule an appointment. If one has symptoms that suggest one may have postpartum psychosis, get help immediately. If one suspect that a friend or loved one has postpartum depression or is developing postpartum psychosis, help them seek medical attention immediately.
Overview: The birth of a baby can trigger a jumble of powerful emotions, from excitement and joy to fear and anxiety. Most new moms experience postpartum baby blues after childbirth, which commonly include mood swings, crying spells, anxiety and difficulty sleeping.
Causes: There's no single cause of postpartum depression, but physical and emotional issues may play a role. After childbirth, a dramatic drop in hormones (estrogen and progesterone) in the body may contribute to postpartum depression. Other hormones produced by the thyroid gland also may drop sharply which can leave one feeling tired, sluggish and depressed.
Diagnosis: The doctor will usually talk with one about the feelings, thoughts and mental health to distinguish between a short-term case of postpartum baby blues and a more severe form of depression. As part of the evaluation, the doctor may: Do a depression screening that may include having one fill out a questionnaire Order blood tests to determine whether an underactive thyroid is contributing to the signs and symptoms Order other tests, if warranted, to rule out other causes for the symptoms
Remedies: If one can sleep, take a nap, or maybe one can catch a movie or meet for coffee with friends. One may also benefit from asking for help with parenting skills that can include caregiving techniques to improve the baby's sleep and soothe fussing and crying.
info-Symptoms: Extreme sadness, low energy, anxiety, changes in sleeping or eating patterns, crying episodes, irritability
info-Usual onset: A week to a month after childbirth
info-Risk factors: Prior postpartum depression, bipolar disorder, family history of depression, psychological stress, complications of childbirth, lack of support, drug use disorder

Name: Postpartum preeclampsia
Risk factors: Limited research suggests that risk factors for postpartum preeclampsia might include High blood pressure during the most recent pregnancy. One is at increased risk of postpartum preeclampsia if one developed high blood pressure after 20 weeks of pregnancy (gestational hypertension). Having uncontrolled high blood pressure before pregnancy increases the risk of preeclampsia and postpartum preeclampsia.
Diagnosis: If one has already been discharged from the hospital after childbirth and the health care provider suspects that one has postpartum preeclampsia, one might need to be readmitted to the hospital. The health care provider might test a sample of the urine to see if it contains protein, or might have one collect the urine for 24 hours and test it for the total amount of protein.
Treatment: If one has recently given birth and one has any signs or symptoms of postpartum preeclampsia, contact the health care provider right away. If the blood pressure is dangerously high, the health care provider might prescribe a medication to lower the blood pressure (antihypertensive medication). After treatment with magnesium sulfate, the health care provider will closely monitor the blood pressure, urination and other symptoms.

Name: Postpartum thyroiditis
Treatment: If one develop severe signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism, the doctor will likely recommend treatment with a drug that blocks the effects of thyroid hormone on the body (beta blocker). If one develop severe signs and symptoms of hypothyroidism, one will likely need thyroid hormone therapy for six to 12 months.

Name: Post-polio syndrome
Risk factors: Factors that can increase the risk of developing post-polio syndrome include Severity of initial polio infection. If one developed polio as an adolescent or adult rather than as a child, the chances of developing post-polio syndrome increase. The greater the recovery after acute polio, the more likely it seems that post-polio syndrome will develop, perhaps because greater recovery places additional stress on motor neurons. If one often exercise to the point of exhaustion or fatigue, one might overwork already stressed-out motor neurons and increase the risk of post-polio syndrome.
Diagnosis: For a diagnosis of post-polio syndrome, doctors look for three indicators: In addition, because the signs and symptoms of post-polio syndrome are similar to those of other disorders, the doctor will attempt to exclude other possible causes, such as arthritis, fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome and scoliosis. Because there are no tests that confirm a post-polio syndrome diagnosis, the doctor may use certain tests to rule out other conditions, including Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies. These tests help identify and exclude conditions such as an abnormal condition of the nerves (neuropathy) and a muscle tissue disorder (myopathy). A noninvasive test shows promise for evaluating the severity of post-polio syndrome and monitoring its progression is muscle ultrasound, which uses sound waves to create images of muscles. These tests can help exclude spinal disorders, such as the degenerative spine condition spondylosis or narrowing of the spinal column that puts pressure on the nerves (spinal stenosis).
Treatment: Exercising to maintain fitness is important, but avoid overusing the muscles and joints and exercising to the point of pain or fatigue. Other possible treatment options may include the anticonvulsant drug gabapentin (Neurontin, Gralise) which is often used to treat nerve pain. However, one will likely be referred to a doctor who specializes in nervous system disorders (neurologist). Assistive devices such as a cane, walker, wheelchair or motor scooter can help one conserve energy. One might need to change the sleeping patterns, such as avoiding sleeping on the back, or use a device that helps open the airway when one sleep. Pain relievers such as aspirin, acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) might ease muscle and joint pain.
Remedies: Recovering from the initial illness required drive and determination, but now the late effects of polio require one to rest and conserve the energy. Get rid of throw rugs and loose clutter on the floor, wear good shoes, and avoid slippery or icy surfaces. Eat a balanced diet, stop smoking and decrease caffeine intake to keep fit, breathe easier and sleep better.

Name: Postural hypotension
Causes: Normally, special cells (baroreceptors) near the heart and neck arteries sense this lower blood pressure. The baroreceptors send signals to centers in the brain, which signals the heart to beat faster and pump more blood, which stabilizes blood pressure. Fever, vomiting, not drinking enough fluids, severe diarrhea and strenuous exercise with a lot of sweating can all lead to dehydration, which decreases blood volume. Some heart conditions that can lead to low blood pressure include extremely low heart rate (bradycardia), heart valve problems, heart attack and heart failure. Thyroid conditions, adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) and low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) can cause orthostatic hypotension.
Risk factors: These include medications used to treat high blood pressure or heart disease, such as diuretics, alpha blockers, beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and nitrates. Other medications that may increase the risk of orthostatic hypotension include medications used to treat Parkinson's disease, certain antidepressants, certain antipsychotics, muscle relaxants, medications to treat erectile dysfunction and narcotics. Some heart conditions, such as heart valve problems, heart attack and heart failure; certain nervous system disorders, such as Parkinson's disease; and diseases that cause nerve damage (neuropathy), such as diabetes, increase the risk of low blood pressure. Being in a hot environment can cause heavy sweating and possibly dehydration, which can lower the blood pressure and trigger orthostatic hypotension.
Diagnosis: During this test, the heart rate and blood pressure are monitored to evaluate the body's cardiovascular response to the change in position. The doctor will diagnose orthostatic hypotension if one has a drop of 20 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg) in the systolic blood pressure or a drop of 10 mm Hg in the diastolic blood pressure within two to five minutes of standing, or if standing causes signs and symptoms. These can provide information about the overall health, including low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) or low red blood cell levels (anemia), both of which can cause low blood pressure. This noninvasive test checks the functioning of the autonomic nervous system by analyzing the heart rate and blood pressure after several cycles of a type of deep breathing: One breathe in deeply and push the air out through the lips, as if one were trying to blow up a stiff balloon. Blood pressure test Echocardiogram Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) Stress test Tilt table test Blood pressure monitoring.
Remedies: Too much salt can cause the blood pressure to increase beyond a healthy level, creating new health risks. If the blood pressure drops after eating, the doctor may recommend small, low-carbohydrate meals. Both anemia and vitamin B-12 deficiency can affect blood flow and worsen symptoms of orthostatic hypotension, so iron and vitamin supplements might be helpful for one if one is deficient. These may help improve blood flow and reduce the symptoms of orthostatic hypotension. If one begin to get symptoms while standing, cross the thighs in a scissors fashion and squeeze, or put one foot on a ledge or chair and lean as far forward as possible.
info-Symptoms: symptoms that are worse when sitting or standing and improve when lying down, including lightheadedness, vertigo, tinnitus, slurred speech, confusion, coathanger pain in neck and shoulders, grayed or blurred vision, severe fatigue, fainting or near fainting
info-Diagnostic method: in-office (lay down for at least 20 minutes, take BP; stand for 3 minutes, take BP), or tilt-table testing by an autonomic specialist
info-Treatment: identify and treat causes (medications, dehydration), midodrine, compression garments, bed tilting
info-Prognosis: depends on frequency, severity, and underlying cause; neurogenic orthostatic hypotension is a chronic, debilitating, and often progressively fatal condition

Name: Pouchitis
Overview: Pouchitis is inflammation that occurs in the lining of a pouch created during surgery to treat ulcerative colitis or certain other diseases. Many people with ulcerative colitis need to have their diseased colon removed and the bowel reconnected with a procedure called J pouch surgery (ileoanal anastomosis IPAA). Signs and symptoms of pouchitis can include diarrhea, abdominal pain, joint pain, cramps, fever, an increased number of bowel movements, nighttime fecal seepage, fecal incontinence, and a strong urge to have a bowel movement.

Name: Prader-Willi syndrome
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms that may be present from birth include Other features of Prader-Willi syndrome appear during early childhood and remain throughout life, requiring careful management. Babies may rest with their elbows and knees loosely extended instead of fixed, and they may feel floppy or like rag dolls when they're held. Children may be born with almond-shaped eyes, a narrowing of the head at the temples, a turned-down mouth and a thin upper lip. A baby may seem unusually tired, respond poorly to stimulation, have a hard time waking up or have a weak cry. In females, the clitoris and labia may be small. A classic sign of Prader-Willi syndrome is a constant craving for food, resulting in rapid weight gain, starting around age 2 years. Unusual food-seeking behaviors, such as hoarding food, or eating frozen food or even garbage, may develop. This results in underdeveloped sex organs, incomplete or delayed puberty, and in nearly all cases, infertility. Other endocrine problems may include underproduction of thyroid hormone (hypothyroidism) or central adrenal insufficiency, which prevents the body from responding appropriately during stress or infections. Toddlers with Prader-Willi syndrome often reach milestones in physical movement for example, sitting up or walking later than other children do. Children and adults may at times be stubborn, angry, controlling or manipulative. They may throw temper tantrums, especially when denied food, and may not tolerate changes in routine. They may also develop obsessive-compulsive or repetitive behaviors, or both. Other mental health disorders, such as anxiety and skin picking, may develop.
Overview: Prader-Willi (PRAH-dur VIL-e) syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that results in a number of physical, mental and behavioral problems. Best managed by a team approach, various specialists can work with one to manage symptoms of this complex disorder, reduce the risk of developing complications and improve the quality of life for the loved one with Prader-Willi syndrome.
Treatment: The team may include a doctor who treats hormonal disorders (endocrinologist), behavior specialists, a dietitian, physical and occupational therapists, a mental health professional, a geneticist, and other specialists as needed. Although specific treatments vary depending on symptoms, most children with Prader-Willi syndrome will need the following: Good nutrition for infants. HGH treatment in children with Prader-Willi syndrome helps increase growth, improves muscle tone and decreases body fat. The endocrinologist may suggest that the child take hormone replacement therapy (testosterone for males or estrogen and progesterone for females) to replenish low levels of sex hormones. A dietitian can help one develop a healthy, reduced-calorie diet to help manage the child's weight while ensuring proper nutrition. The child will likely benefit from a range of therapies, including physical therapy to improve movement skills and strength, speech therapy to improve verbal skills, and occupational therapy to learn everyday skills. Developmental therapy to learn age-appropriate behaviors, social skills and interpersonal skills also may help. A mental health professional, such as a psychologist or a psychiatrist, may help address psychological problems for example, obsessive-compulsive behaviors, skin picking or a mood disorder.
Remedies: Tips to help one take care of the loved one with Prader-Willi syndrome include the following: Learn about Prader-Willi syndrome. Talk with the doctor about a regular schedule of health appointments and tests to check for problems or complications related to Prader-Willi syndrome.
info-Symptoms: Babies: weak muscles, poor feeding, slow developmentChildren: constantly hungry, intellectual impairment, behavioural problems
info-Treatment: Feeding tubes, strict food supervision, exercise program, counseling

Name: Prediabetes
Overview: Prediabetes means one has a higher than normal blood sugar level. The same lifestyle changes that can help prevent type 2 diabetes in adults might also help bring children's blood sugar levels back to normal.
Causes: Moving sugar from the bloodstream to the body's cells requires a hormone called insulin. As insulin circulates, it allows sugar to enter the cells and lowers the amount of sugar in the blood. When the blood sugar level starts to drop, the pancreas slows down the secretion of insulin into the blood. The pancreas may not make enough insulin or cells become resistant to insulin and don't allow as much sugar in.
Risk factors: These factors include Other conditions associated with prediabetes include When these conditions occur with obesity, they are associated with insulin resistance. Eating red meat and processed meat, and drinking sugar-sweetened beverages, is associated with a higher risk of prediabetes. A diet high in fruits, vegetables, nuts, whole grains and olive oil is associated with a lower risk of prediabetes. The less active one is, the greater the risk of prediabetes. Although diabetes can develop at any age, the risk of prediabetes increases after age 45. Although it's unclear why, people of certain races including African Americans, Hispanics, Native Americans, Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders are more likely to develop prediabetes. If one had diabetes while pregnant (gestational diabetes), one and the child are at higher risk of developing prediabetes. Women with this common condition characterized by irregular menstrual periods, excess hair growth and obesity have a higher risk of prediabetes.
Diagnosis: In general: If one has prediabetes, the doctor will typically check the blood sugar levels at least once a year. These other risk factors include The ranges of blood sugar level considered normal, prediabetic and diabetic are the same for children and adults. Children who have prediabetes should be tested annually for type 2 diabetes or more often if the child experiences a change in weight or develops signs or symptoms of diabetes, such as increased thirst, increased urination, fatigue or blurred vision. An A1C level below 5.7% is considered normal An A1C level between 5.7% and 6.4% is considered prediabetes An A1C level of 6.5% or higher on two separate tests indicates type 2 diabetes A fasting blood sugar level below 100 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) 5.6 millimoles per liter (mmol/L) is considered normal. A fasting blood sugar level from 100 to 125 mg/dL (5.6 to 7.0 mmol/L) is considered prediabetes. A fasting blood sugar level of 126 mg/dL (7.0 mmol/L) or higher indicates type 2 diabetes. A blood sugar level less than 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L) is considered normal. A blood sugar level from 140 to 199 mg/dL (7.8 to 11.0 mmol/L) is considered prediabetes. A blood sugar level of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher indicates type 2 diabetes.
Treatment: Healthy lifestyle choices can help one bring the blood sugar level back to normal, or at least keep it from rising toward the levels seen in type 2 diabetes. To prevent prediabetes from progressing to type 2 diabetes, try to: Eat healthy foods. If one is overweight, losing just 5% to 7% of the body weight about 14 pounds (6.4 kilograms) if one weigh 200 pounds (91 kilograms) can reduce the risk of type 2 diabetes. If one is at high risk of diabetes, the doctor might recommend metformin (Glumetza, others).

Name: Premature birth
Overview: A premature birth is a birth that takes place more than three weeks before the baby's estimated due date. Depending on how early a baby is born, he or she may be: Most premature births occur in the late preterm stage.
Diagnosis: Blood samples are collected through a heel stick or a needle inserted into a vein to monitor a number of critical substances, including calcium, glucose and bilirubin levels in the baby's blood. If the baby's doctor anticipates that several blood samples will be needed, the NICU staff may insert a central umbilical intravenous (IV) line, to avoid having to stick the baby with a needle each time blood is needed. Ultrasound scans may be done to check the brain for bleeding or fluid buildup or to examine the abdominal organs for problems in the gastrointestinal tract, liver or kidneys. An ophthalmologist (eye doctor) may examine the baby's eyes and vision to check for problems with the retina (retinopathy of prematurity).
Remedies: When it's time to bring the baby home, one might feel relieved, excited and anxious. Make sure one is comfortable caring for the baby, especially if one will need to administer medications, use special monitors, or give the baby supplemental oxygen or other treatments. Discuss symptoms such as infant breathing or feeding problems that might necessitate a call to the baby's care provider. Try to minimize the baby's exposure to crowded places, and make sure everyone who comes into contact with the baby washes his or her hands first. Because preemies are especially at risk of a serious infection of the lungs and respiratory tract (respiratory syncytial virus, or RSV), the baby's doctor might recommend a preventive medication called palivizumab (Synagis), which helps protect the baby from this serious infection. One may also protect the preterm infant by ensuring that others in the home are up to date on their immunizations, including influenza.xa0Pregnant women, family members and adult caregivers should also check with their doctors to be sure they're up to date on their whooping cough (pertussis) vaccine. The preterm baby may initially need to see his or her care provider every week or two to have his or her growth, medical needs and care monitored. The baby's care provider may also monitor the baby for developmental delays and disabilities in the coming months.
info-Symptoms: Birth of a baby at younger than 37 weeks' gestational age
info-Risk factors: Diabetes, high blood pressure, Multiple gestation, obesity or underweight, a number of vaginal infections, celiac disease, tobacco smoking, psychological stress
info-Treatment: Corticosteroids, keeping the baby warm through skin-to-skin contact, supporting breastfeeding, treating infections, supporting breathing

Name: Premature ejaculation
Symptoms: Instead these men might have natural variable premature ejaculation, which includes periods of rapid ejaculation as well as periods of normal ejaculation. For some men, a conversation with a doctor might help lessen concerns about premature ejaculation. Acquired premature ejaculation develops after one has had previous sexual experiences without ejaculatory problems.
Overview: Premature ejaculation occurs when a man ejaculates sooner during sexual intercourse than he or his partner would like. Always or nearly always ejaculate within one minute of penetration Are unable to delay ejaculation during intercourse all or nearly all of the time Feel distressed and frustrated, and tend to avoid sexual intimacy as a result
Causes: While it was once thought to be only psychological, doctors now know premature ejaculation involves a complex interaction of psychological and biological factors. Men who are anxious about obtaining or maintaining an erection during sexual intercourse might form a pattern of rushing to ejaculate, which can be difficult to change. Many men with premature ejaculation also have problems with anxiety either specifically about sexual performance or related to other issues.
Medication: Anesthetic creams and sprays that contain a numbing agent, such as benzocaine, lidocaine or prilocaine, are sometimes used to treat premature ejaculation. Although none of these drugs are specifically approved by the Food and Drug Administration to treat premature ejaculation, some are used for this purpose, including antidepressants, analgesics and phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors. These medications might be prescribed for either on-demand or daily use, and might be prescribed alone or in combination with other treatments. For this reason, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as escitalopram (Lexapro), sertraline (Zoloft), paroxetine (Paxil) or fluoxetine (Prozac, Sarafem), are used to help delay ejaculation. If SSRIs don't improve the timing of the ejaculation, the doctor might prescribe the tricyclic antidepressant clomipramine (Anafranil). Unwanted side effects of antidepressants might include nausea, perspiration, drowsiness and decreased libido. Unwanted side effects might include nausea, headache, sleepiness and dizziness. Research suggests that several drugs that might be helpful in treating premature ejaculation, but further study is needed. With premature ejaculation, one might feel one lose some of the closeness shared with a sexual partner. Some medications used to treat erectile dysfunction, such as sildenafil (Viagra, Revatio), tadalafil (Cialis, Adcirca) or vardenafil (Levitra, Staxyn), also might help premature ejaculation.

Name: Premature puberty
Causes: To understand what causes precocious puberty in some children, it's helpful to know what causes puberty to begin. In rare cases, central precocious puberty may be caused by: Estrogen or testosterone in the child's body causes this type of precocious puberty. The less common peripheral precocious puberty occurs without the involvement of the hormone in the brain (GnRH) that normally triggers the start of puberty.
Risk factors: Factors that increase a child's risk of precocious puberty include Being a girl. Coming in contact with an estrogen or testosterone cream or ointment, or other substances that contain these hormones (such as an adult's medication or dietary supplements), can increase the child's risk of developing precocious puberty. Precocious puberty may be a complication of McCune-Albright syndrome or congenital adrenal hyperplasia conditions that involve abnormal production of the male hormones (androgens). Radiation treatment for tumors, leukemia or other conditions can increase the risk of precocious puberty.

Name: Premenstrual syndrome ( PMS )
Symptoms: The list of potential signs and symptoms for premenstrual syndrome is long, but most women only experience a few of these problems. PMDD signs and symptoms include depression, mood swings, anger, anxiety, feeling overwhelmed, difficulty concentrating, irritability and tension.
Causes: Exactly what causes premenstrual syndrome is unknown, but several factors may contribute to the condition: Cyclic changes in hormones. Fluctuations of serotonin, a brain chemical (neurotransmitter) that's thought to play a crucial role in mood states, could trigger PMS symptoms. Insufficient amounts of serotonin may contribute to premenstrual depression, as well as to fatigue, food cravings and sleep problems.
Treatment: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) which include fluoxetine (Prozac, Sarafem), paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva), sertraline (Zoloft) and others have been successful in reducing mood symptoms. Taken before or at the onset of the period, NSAIDs such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve) can ease cramping and breast discomfort. When exercise and limiting salt intake aren't enough to reduce the weight gain, swelling and bloating of PMS, taking water pills (diuretics) can help the body shed excess fluid through the kidneys.
Remedies: One can sometimes manage or reduce the symptoms of premenstrual syndrome by making changes in the way one eat, exercise and approach daily life. Regular daily exercise can help improve the overall health and alleviate certain symptoms, such as fatigue and a depressed mood. If one can't tolerate dairy products or aren't getting adequate calcium in the diet, a daily calcium supplement may help. Practice progressive muscle relaxation or deep-breathing exercises to help reduce headaches, anxiety or trouble sleeping (insomnia).

Name: Presbycusis
Overview: Hearing loss that occurs gradually as one age (presbycusis) is common. These bones are separated from the outer ear by the eardrum (tympanic membrane), which when struck by a sound wave, vibrates. The snail-shaped chamber, called the cochlea (KOK-lee-uh), plays a role in hearing. The other fluid-filled chambers of the inner ear include three tubes called the semicircular canals (vestibular labyrinth).
Causes: When these hairs or nerve cells are damaged or missing, electrical signals aren't transmitted as efficiently, and hearing loss occurs. Vivien Williams: Dr. Matthew Carlson says temporary hearing loss can happen when the ears are plugged with wax or fluid behind the ear drum, for example. Dr. Carlson says just about all types of sensorineural hearing loss have to do with the loss of the function of hair cells in the inner ear. For people with profound hearing loss, cochlear implants work by bypassing the hair cells and sending signals directly to the hearing nerve and brain. In the outer or middle ear, any of these can cause hearing loss. Loud blasts of noise, sudden changes in pressure, poking the eardrum with an object and infection can cause the eardrum to rupture and affect the hearing.
Risk factors: Factors that may damage or lead to loss of the hairs and nerve cells in the inner ear include The chart below lists common sounds and their decibel levels. The louder the noise, the less time it takes to cause permanent hearing damage. Below are the maximum noise levels on the job to which one may be exposed without hearing protection, and for how long. Damage can occur with long-term exposure to loud noises, or from a short blast of noise, such as from a gunshot. Jobs where loud noise is a regular part of the working environment, such as farming, construction or factory work, can lead to damage inside the ear. Exposure to explosive noises, such as from firearms and jet engines, can cause immediate, permanent hearing loss. Other recreational activities with dangerously high noise levels include snowmobiling, motorcycling, carpentry or listening to loud music. Drugs such as the antibiotic gentamicin, sildenafil (Viagra) and certain chemotherapy drugs, can damage the inner ear. Temporary effects on the hearing ringing in the ear (tinnitus) or hearing loss can occur if one take very high doses of aspirin, other pain relievers, antimalarial drugs or loop diuretics.
Diagnosis: Tests to diagnose hearing loss may include Physical exam. The doctor will look in the ear for possible causes of the hearing loss, such as earwax or inflammation from an infection. The doctor may use the whisper test, asking one to cover one ear at a time to see how well one hear words spoken at various volumes and how one respond to other sounds. Simple tests with tuning forks can help the doctor detect hearing loss.

Name: Presbyopia
Overview: Presbyopia is the gradual loss of the eyes ability to focus on nearby objects. Presbyopia usually becomes noticeable in the early to mid-40s and continues to worsen until around age 65. One may become aware of presbyopia when one start holding books and newspapers at arm's length to be able to read them.
Causes: If one has presbyopia, the inflexible lens doesn't adjust to focus light properly, so the point of focus falls behind the retina (bottom image). To form an image, the eye relies on the cornea and the lens to focus the light reflected from objects. As the lens becomes less flexible, it can no longer change shape to focus on close-up images. Both of these structures bend (refract) light entering the eye to focus the image on the retina, located on the inside back wall of the eye.
Risk factors: Certain factors can make one more likely to develop presbyopia, including Age. Being farsighted or having certain diseases such as diabetes, multiple sclerosis or cardiovascular diseases can increase the risk of premature presbyopia, which is presbyopia in people younger than 40.
Remedies: One can help protect the eyes and the vision by following these tips: Have the eyes checked. Certain conditions, such as diabetes and high blood pressure, can affect the vision if one don't receive proper treatment.
