See the doctor immediately if one experience any of these symptoms sudden loss of vision in one eye with or without pain, sudden hazy or blurred vision, double vision, or see flashes of light, black spots or halos around lights.
info-Symptoms: Difficulty reading small print, having to hold reading material farther away, headaches, eyestrain
info-Usual onset: Progressively worsening in those over 40 years old
info-Causes: Aging-related hardening of the lens of the eye

Name: Pressure ulcer
Causes: Bedsores are caused by pressure against the skin that limits blood flow to the skin. Limited movement can make skin vulnerable to damage and lead to development of bedsores. Without these essential nutrients, skin and nearby tissues are damaged and might eventually die. As the tailbone moves down, the skin over the bone might stay in place essentially pulling in the opposite direction.
Risk factors: Spinal cord injuries, neurological disorders and other conditions can result in a loss of sensation. People need enough fluids, calories, protein, vitamins and minerals in their daily diets to maintain healthy skin and prevent the breakdown of tissues. Health problems that can affect blood flow, such as diabetes and vascular disease, can increase the risk of tissue damage such as bedsores.
Diagnosis: The doctor will likely look closely at the skin to decide if one has a pressure ulcer and, if so, to assign a stage to the wound. The doctor might ask questions such as: When did the pressure sore first appear? What medical conditions have one been diagnosed with, and what is the current treatment?

Name: Preterm labor
Overview: Preterm labor occurs when regular contractions result in the opening of the cervix after week 20 and before week 37 of pregnancy. Certain risk factors might increase the chance of preterm labor, but preterm labor can also occur in pregnant women with no known risk factors.
Diagnosis: If one is experiencing regular uterine contractions and the cervix has begun to soften, thin and open (dilate) before 37 weeks of pregnancy, one will likely be diagnosed with preterm labor. The health care provider might evaluate the firmness and tenderness of the uterus and the baby's size and position. If the water hasn't broken and there's no concern that the placenta is covering the cervix (placenta previa), he or she might also do a pelvic exam to determine whether the cervix has begun to open. An ultrasound might also be done to check for problems with the baby or placenta, confirm the baby's position, assess the volume of amniotic fluid, and estimate the baby's weight. The health care provider might take a swab of the vaginal secretions to check for the presence of certain infections and fetal fibronectin a substance that acts like a glue between the fetal sac and the lining of the uterus and is discharged during labor.
Medication: If one is between 23 and 34 weeks, the doctor will likely recommend corticosteroids if one is thought to be at increased risk of delivery in the next one to seven days. One might be given a repeat course of corticosteroids if one is less than 34 weeks pregnant, at risk of delivering within seven days, and one had a prior course of corticosteroids more than 14 days previously. Tocolytics may be used for 48 hours to delay preterm labor to allow corticosteroids to provide the maximum benefit or, if necessary, for one to be transported to a hospital that can provide specialized care for the premature baby. If one is not hospitalized, one might need to schedule weekly or more-frequent visits with the health care provider so that he or she can monitor signs and symptoms of preterm labor. If one is at risk of preterm labor because of a short cervix, the doctor may suggest a surgical procedure known as cervical cerclage. Cervical cerclage might be recommended if one is less than 24 weeks pregnant, one has a history of early premature birth, and an ultrasound shows the cervix is opening or the cervical length is less than 25 millimeters. If one has a history of premature birth, the health care provider might suggest weekly shots of a form of the hormone progesterone called hydroxyprogesterone caproate, starting during the second trimester and continuing until week 37 of pregnancy. In addition, the health care provider might offer progesterone, which is inserted in the vagina, as a preventive measure against preterm birth. If one is diagnosed with a short cervix before week 24 of pregnancy, the health care provider might also recommend use of progesterone until week 37 of pregnancy.
info-Symptoms: Birth of a baby at younger than 37 weeks' gestational age
info-Risk factors: Diabetes, high blood pressure, Multiple gestation, obesity or underweight, a number of vaginal infections, celiac disease, tobacco smoking, psychological stress
info-Treatment: Corticosteroids, keeping the baby warm through skin-to-skin contact, supporting breastfeeding, treating infections, supporting breathing

Name: Priapism
Symptoms: Ischemic priapism, also called low-flow priapism, is the result of blood not being able to leave the penis. Signs and symptoms include Recurrent or stuttering priapism, a form of ischemic priapism, is an uncommon condition. Nonischemic priapism, also known as high-flow priapism, occurs when penile blood flow isn't regulated appropriately. This is necessary because the treatment for each is different, and treatment for ischemic priapism needs to be done as soon as possible.
Overview: Priapism is a prolonged erection of the penis. Prompt treatment for priapism is usually needed to prevent tissue damage that could result in the inability to get or maintain an erection (erectile dysfunction).
Causes: This stimulation causes certain smooth muscles to relax, increasing blood flow to spongy tissues in the penis. Priapism occurs when some part of this system the blood, blood vessels, smooth muscles or nerves changes normal blood flow, and an erection persists. Blood-related diseases might contribute to priapism usually ischemic priapism, when blood isn't able to flow out of the penis.
info-Symptoms: Penis remains erect for hours
info-Causes: Sickle cell disease, antipsychotics, SSRIs, blood thinners, cocaine, cannabis, trauma
info-Treatment: Ischemic: Removal of blood from the corpus cavernosum with a needleNon-ischemic: Cold packs and compression

Name: Prickly heat
Symptoms: A type that occurs deeper in the skin (miliaria rubra) is sometimes called prickly heat. Occasionally, the fluid-containing sacs (vesicles) of miliaria rubra become inflamed and pus-filled (pustular). A less common form of heat rash (miliaria profunda) affects the dermis, a deeper layer of skin.
Overview: Miliaria rubra (A), one type of heat rash, appears as red clusters of small blister-like bumps that can produce intense itching. Miliaria crystallina (B), another type of heat rash, appears as clear, fluid-filled bumps that produce no other signs or symptoms.
Causes: Instead of evaporating, perspiration gets trapped beneath the skin, causing inflammation and rash. It's not always clear why the sweat ducts become blocked, but certain factors seem to play a role, including Immature sweat ducts. Intense exercise, hard work or any activity that causes one to sweat heavily can lead to heat rash. Heat rash can also occur in people who are confined to bed for long periods, especially if they have a fever.
Risk factors: People living in the tropics are far more likely to have heat rash than are people in temperate climates. Anything that makes one sweat heavily, especially if one is not wearing clothing that allows the sweat to evaporate, can trigger heat rash.

Name: Primary adrenal insufficiency
Causes: Perched atop each of the kidneys, the adrenal glands produce hormones that help regulate the metabolism, immune system, blood pressure and other essential functions. Addison's disease is caused by damage to the adrenal glands, resulting in not enough of the hormone cortisol and, often, not enough aldosterone as well. Corticosteroids include When the cortex is damaged and doesn't produce enough adrenocortical hormones, the condition is called primary adrenal insufficiency. Other causes of adrenal gland failure may include The pituitary gland makes a hormone called adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). Too little ACTH can lead to too little of the glucocorticoids and androgens normally produced by the adrenal glands, even though the adrenal glands themselves aren't damaged. However, people with secondary adrenal insufficiency don't have hyperpigmentation and are less likely to have severe dehydration or low blood pressure. These male sex hormones are produced in small amounts by the adrenal glands in both men and women.
Diagnosis: One may be given this test if doctors think one may have adrenal insufficiency as a result of pituitary disease (secondary adrenal insufficiency). In certain situations doctors may do alternative tests for secondary adrenal insufficiency, such as a low-dose ACTH stimulation test, prolonged ACTH stimulation test or glucagon stimulation test. Tests can measure the blood levels of sodium, potassium, cortisol and adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which stimulates the adrenal cortex to produce its hormones.
Treatment: Some options for treatment include oral corticosteroids such as: One will need to get plenty of salt (sodium) in the diet, especially during heavy exercise, when the weather is hot or if one has gastrointestinal upsets, such as diarrhea. If one is ill with vomiting and can't keep down oral medications, one may need injections of corticosteroids. Other treatment recommendations include Treatment for an addisonian crisis, which is a medical emergency, typically includes intravenous injections of: Hydrocortisone (Cortef), prednisone or methylprednisolone to replace cortisol. Corticosteroids Saline solution Sugar (dextrose) Hydrocortisone (Cortef), prednisone or methylprednisolone Fludrocortisone acetate Carry a medical alert card and bracelet at all times.
info-Symptoms: Abdominal pain, weakness, weight loss, darkening of the skin
info-Diagnostic method: Blood tests, urine tests, medical imaging
info-Treatment: Synthetic Corticosteroid such as hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone

Name: Primary biliary cirrhosis
Overview: The bile ducts carry bile from the liver to the small intestine. When bile ducts become damaged, bile can back up into the liver, causing damage to liver cells. Primary biliary cholangitis, previously called primary biliary cirrhosis, is a chronic disease in which the bile ducts in the liver are slowly destroyed. When the bile ducts are damaged, bile can back up in the liver and sometimes lead to irreversible scarring of liver tissue (cirrhosis).
Causes: The liver inflammation seen in primary biliary cholangitis starts when certain types of white blood cells called T cells (T lymphocytes) start to collect in the liver. But in primary biliary cholangitis, they mistakenly destroy the healthy cells lining the small bile ducts in the liver.
Diagnosis: Imaging tests looking at the liver and bile ducts may include If the diagnosis is still uncertain, the doctor may perform a liver biopsy. It's examined in a laboratory, either to confirm the diagnosis or to determine the extent (stage) of the disease. More than half the people with primary biliary cholangitis have extreme increases in blood fats (lipids), including total cholesterol level. These blood tests check the levels of enzymes that may signal liver disease and bile duct injury. Blood tests may be done to check for anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMAs). This special magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) exam creates detailed images of the organs and bile ducts.
Remedies: Here are some things one can do to improve some primary biliary cholangitis symptoms and, possibly, help prevent certain complications: Choose reduced-sodium foods. Opt for low-sodium foods or naturally sodium-free foods, since sodium contributes to tissue swelling and to the buildup of fluid in the abdominal cavity (ascites). Because the liver isn't working normally, one will likely be more sensitive to the effects of over-the-counter and prescription medications, as well as some dietary supplements, so check with the doctor before taking anything new.
info-Symptoms: Cholestasis, pruritus, fatigue
info-Risk factors: Female sex

Name: Primary hypoaldosteronism
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects primary aldosteronism, one will likely have a test to measure levels of aldosterone and renin in the blood. If the aldosterone-renin test suggests primary aldosteronism, one will need other tests to confirm the diagnosis and look for potential causes.
Remedies: Diets that highlight a healthy variety of foods including grains, fruits, vegetables and low-fat dairy products can help with weight loss and help lower blood pressure. If the body mass index (BMI) is 25 or more, losing as little as 3% to 5% of the body weight may lower the blood pressure.

Name: Primary immunodeficiency
Overview: Primary immunodeficiency disorders also called primary immune disorders or primary immunodeficiency weaken the immune system, allowing infections and other health problems to occur more easily. Many people with primary immunodeficiency are born missing some of the body's immune defenses or with the immune system not working properly, which leaves them more susceptible to germs that can cause infections.
Diagnosis: Blood tests can determine if one has normal levels of infection-fighting proteins (immunoglobulin) in the blood and measure the levels of blood cells and immune system cells. Blood tests can also determine if the immune system is responding properly and producing proteins that identify and kill foreign invaders such as bacteria or viruses (antibodies). Samples of the amniotic fluid, blood or cells from the tissue that will become the placenta (chorion) are tested for abnormalities.

Name: Primary lateral sclerosis ( PLS )
Overview: Primary lateral sclerosis (PLS) is a type of motor neuron disease that causes nerves within the brain to slowly break down. Primary lateral sclerosis is often mistaken for another, more common motor neuron disease called amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
Causes: In primary lateral sclerosis (PLS), the nerve cells in the brain that control movement fail over time. When the instructions are changed in someone with juvenile PLS, the protein alsin becomes unstable and doesn't work properly, which in turn impairs normal muscle function.
Diagnosis: In fact, because the disease can mimic signs and symptoms of other neurological diseases such as multiple sclerosis and ALS, the doctor is likely to order several tests to rule out other diseases. After taking a careful record of the medical history and family history and performing a neurological examination, the doctor might order the following tests: MRI. An MRI can show other causes of the symptoms, such as structural abnormalities, multiple sclerosis or spinal cord tumors. The doctor uses a thin, hollow needle to remove from the spinal canal small samples of the fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord (cerebrospinal fluid) for laboratory analysis.
Treatment: The doctor might prescribe medication such as baclofen, tizanidine (Zanaflex) or clonazepam (Klonopin) to relieve muscle spasms (spasticity). If the spasticity isn't controlled with oral medication, the doctor might recommend surgically implanting a medication pump to deliver baclofen directly to the spinal fluid (intrathecal baclofen). To cope with the disease and its effects, consider these tips: Seek emotional support. Because PLS is an uncommon diagnosis, it might be a challenge to find a local support group for people with the condition. If one reach a point where the disease is restricting the activities significantly, ask the doctor about devices designed to help one stay independent. Stretching and strengthening exercises can help maintain muscle strength, flexibility and range of motion, and prevent joint immobility. If the facial muscles are affected by PLS, speech therapy might help. Physical or occupational therapists might evaluate one periodically to determine whether one need assistive devices, such as a cane, walker or wheelchair, as PLS progresses.

Name: Primary ovarian insufficiency
Overview: Primary ovarian insufficiency also called premature ovarian failure occurs when the ovaries stop functioning normally before age 40. Restoring estrogen levels in women with primary ovarian insufficiency helps prevent some complications that occur as a result of low estrogen, such as osteoporosis.
Causes: Primary ovarian insufficiency may be caused by: Ovulation is the release of an egg from one of the ovaries. The egg travels through the fallopian tube, propelled in part by contractions in the fallopian tube walls. Here in the fallopian tube, the egg may be fertilized by a sperm. If the egg is fertilized, the egg and sperm unite to form a one-celled entity called a zygote. If the egg isn't fertilized, it's simply reabsorbed by the body perhaps before it even reaches the uterus. Other toxins such as cigarette smoke, chemicals, pesticides and viruses might hasten ovarian failure. In this rare form, the immune system produces antibodies against the ovarian tissue, harming the egg-containing follicles and damaging the egg.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of developing primary ovarian insufficiency include Age. Having a family history of primary ovarian insufficiency increases the risk of developing this disorder.
Diagnosis: Most women have few signs of primary ovarian insufficiency, but the doctor may suspect the condition if one has irregular periods or are having trouble conceiving. The doctor might ask questions about the menstrual cycle, exposure to toxins, such as chemotherapy or radiation therapy, and previous ovarian surgery. The doctor may check the levels of a number of hormones in the blood, including follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), a type of estrogen called estradiol, and the hormone that stimulates breast milk production (prolactin).
Treatment: In older women, long-term estrogen plus progestin therapy has been linked to an increased risk of heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) disease and breast cancer. For women ages 19 through 50, experts generally recommend 1,000 milligrams (mg) of calcium a day through food or supplements, increasing to 1,200 mg a day for women age 51 and older.
Remedies: If oned like to add to the family, talk to the doctor about options such as in vitro fertilization using donor eggs or adoption. Eat a calcium-rich diet, do weight-bearing exercises such as walking and strength training exercises for the upper body, and don't smoke.

Name: Primary polycythemia
Overview: Polycythemia vera (pol-e-sy-THEE-me-uh VEER-uh) is a type of blood cancer. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, which may cause serious problems, such as blood clots.
Diagnosis: If one has polycythemia vera, blood tests might reveal: In a bone marrow aspiration, a doctor or nurse uses a thin needle to remove a small amount of liquid bone marrow, usually from a spot in the back of the hipbone (pelvis). More red blood cells than normal and, sometimes, an increase in platelets or white blood cells A greater percentage of red blood cells that make up total blood volume (hematocrit measurement) Elevated levels of the iron-rich protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen (hemoglobin) Very low levels of a hormone that stimulates bone marrow to produce new red blood cells (erythropoietin) Bone marrow biopsy Complete blood count (CBC) Genetic testing More red blood cells than normal A greater percentage of red blood cells Elevated levels of the iron-rich protein Very low levels of a hormone
Treatment: If one has bothersome itching, the doctor may prescribe medication, such as antihistamines, or recommend ultraviolet light treatment to relieve the discomfort. Medications that are normally used to treat depression, called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), helped relieve itching in clinical trials. If phlebotomy alone doesn't help, medications that suppress the bone marrow's ability to produce blood cells, such as hydroxyurea (Droxia, Hydrea), might be used. It helps the immune system destroy cancer cells, and can improve some polycythemia vera symptoms. Busulfan (Busulfex, Myleran) is another medication that destroys cancer cells that may be prescribed if other treatments aren't working well. The doctor will also likely prescribe medications to control risk factors for heart and blood vessel disease, including high blood pressure, diabetes and abnormal cholesterol. If one is diagnosed with polycythemia vera, one might be referred to a doctor who specializes in blood conditions (hematologist). Using tobacco can cause the blood vessels to narrow, increasing the risk of heart attack or stroke due to blood clots. Living at high altitudes, skiing or climbing in mountains all reduce the oxygen levels in the blood even further.
Remedies: To reduce itching, bathe in cool water, use a gentle cleanser and pat the skin dry. Using tobacco can cause the blood vessels to narrow, increasing the risk of heart attack or stroke due to blood clots. Living at high altitudes, skiing or climbing in mountains all reduce the oxygen levels in the blood even further. Poor circulation can make it difficult for sores to heal, particularly on the hands and feet.

Name: Primary progressive aphasia
Overview: Different areas of the brain are responsible for different vital functions. People with primary progressive aphasia can lose the ability to speak and write and, eventually, to understand written or spoken language. Primary progressive aphasia is a type of frontotemporal dementia, a cluster of related disorders that results from the degeneration of the frontal or temporal lobes of the brain, which include brain tissue involved in speech and language.
Diagnosis: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans can help diagnose primary progressive aphasia, detect shrinking of certain areas of the brain and show which area of the brain might be affected. A single-photon emission computerized tomography (SPECT) scan, which creates a 3D image of the brain, or a positron emission tomography (PET) scan, which shows brain function, can uncover blood flow or glucose metabolism abnormalities.

Name: Progeria
Causes: The gene, known as lamin A (LMNA), makes a protein necessary for holding the center (nucleus) of a cell together. When this gene has a defect (mutation), an abnormal form of the lamin A protein called progerin is produced and makes cells unstable.
Treatment: There's no cure for progeria, but regular monitoring for heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) disease may help with managing the child's condition. During medical visits, the child's weight and height is measured and plotted on a chart of normal growth values. Additional regular evaluations, including electrocardiograms and dental, vision and hearing exams, may be recommended by the doctor to check for changes. Depending on the child's condition, the doctor may prescribe other medications, such as statins to lower cholesterol, drugs to lower blood pressure, anticoagulants to help prevent blood clots, and medications to treat headaches and seizures.
Remedies: Be sure the child drinks plenty of water, especially during an illness, with activity or in hot weather. Because nutrition and growth can be an issue for children with progeria, giving the child smaller meals more often may help increase calorie intake. Apply sunscreen generously, and reapply every two hours or more often if the child is swimming or perspiring. A child with progeria isn't at increased risk of infection, but like all children, is at risk if exposed to infectious diseases. Progeria won't affect the child's intellect, so he or she can attend school at an age-appropriate level. These can include household changes so that the child can reach items such as faucets or light switches, clothes with special closures or in special sizes, and extra padding for chairs and beds.
info-Symptoms: Growth delay, short height, small face, hair loss
info-Prognosis: Average age of death is 13 years

Name: Prolactinoma
Causes: Despite its small size, the pituitary gland influences nearly every part of the body. Other possible causes of prolactin overproduction include medications, other types of pituitary tumors, an underactive thyroid gland, ongoing irritation to the chest, pregnancy and breast-feeding.
Diagnosis: If one has signs and symptoms that suggest one has prolactinoma, the doctor may recommend: In addition, the doctor may refer one for more extensive testing with a doctor who specializes in treating disorders of the endocrine system (endocrinologist). Blood tests can detect the overproduction of prolactin and whether levels of other hormones controlled by the pituitary are within the normal range. The doctor may be able to detect a pituitary tumor on an image generated by a magnetic resonance imaging scan of the brain.
Medication: If medication shrinks the tumor significantly and the prolactin level remains normal for two years, one may be able to taper off the medication with the doctor's guidance. However, if one has a large prolactinoma or one develop signs and symptoms such as headaches or vision changes, the doctor may recommend that one restart the medication to prevent complications from prolactinoma. The type of surgery one has will depend largely on the size and extent of the tumor: The outcome of surgery depends on the size and location of the tumor and the prolactin levels before surgery, as well as the skill of the surgeon. For people with larger tumors that can only be partially removed, drug therapy often can return the prolactin level to a normal range after surgery. For people who don't respond to medication and aren't candidates for surgery, radiation therapy may be an option.

Name: Prolapse , mitral valve
Symptoms: Although mitral valve prolapse is usually a lifelong disorder, many people with this condition never have symptoms. Many other conditions cause the same symptoms as mitral valve prolapse, so only a visit to the doctor can determine the cause of the symptoms. If one has already been diagnosed with mitral valve prolapse, see the doctor if the symptoms worsen.
Diagnosis: The doctor may also detect a heart murmur, which would be due to blood leaking back into the left atrium. The doctor may order a stress test to see if mitral valve regurgitation limits the ability to exercise. It isn't generally used to diagnose mitral valve prolapse but may reveal the condition when one is being tested for another suspected diagnosis. A chest X-ray shows a picture of the heart, lungs and blood vessels and can help the doctor make a diagnosis.
Medication: If one has atrial fibrillation, a history of heart failure or a history of strokes, the doctor may suggest a blood thinner to prevent the blood from clotting. Though most people with mitral valve prolapse don't need surgery, the doctor may suggest surgical treatment if one has severe mitral valve regurgitation, whether one has symptoms or not. Severe mitral valve regurgitation can eventually cause heart failure, preventing the heart from effectively pumping blood. If mitral valve repair isn't possible, the surgeon may replace it with an artificial valve that is man-made (mechanical) or is made from human tissue or taken from cows or pigs. One generally won't need to take a blood thinner with a valve made from human or animal tissue, but those valves only last about 10 years. If one has severe mitral regurgitation and can't have surgery, the doctor may recommend a less invasive approach called transcatheter valve therapy. The new technique allows the doctor to repair a valve by implanting a device using a tube (catheter) inserted in a blood vessel in the groin and guided to the heart. However, the American Heart Association has said antibiotics are no longer necessary in most cases for someone with mitral valve regurgitation or mitral valve prolapse. If one has mitral valve prolapse and a history of strokes, the doctor might prescribe aspirin to reduce the risk of blood clots.

Name: Prolapsed bladder
Overview: A dropped or prolapsed bladder (cystocele) occurs when the bladder bulges into the vaginal space. Anterior vaginal prolapse, also known as a cystocele (SIS-toe-seel) or a prolapsed bladder, is when the bladder drops from its normal position in the pelvis and pushes on the wall of the vagina. The organs of the pelvis including the bladder, uterus and intestines are normally held in place by the muscles and connective tissues of the pelvic floor.
Risk factors: These factors may increase the risk of anterior prolapse: Pregnancy and childbirth. Women who have had a vaginal or instrument-assisted delivery, multiple pregnancies, or whose infants had a high birth weight have a higher risk of anterior prolapse. This is especially true after menopause, when the body's production of estrogen which helps keep the pelvic floor strong decreases. Some women are born with weaker connective tissues, making them more susceptible to anterior prolapse. Women who are overweight or obese are at higher risk of anterior prolapse.
Diagnosis: One may fill out a form that helps the doctor assess the medical history, the degree of the prolapse and how much it affects the quality of life. The doctor might also run a test on a urine sample to look for signs of a bladder infection, if it seems that one is retaining more urine in the bladder than is normal after urinating.
Remedies: To perform Kegel exercises, follow these steps: Ask the doctor for instructions on how to properly perform a Kegel, and for feedback on whether one is using the right muscles. Once one has learned the proper method, one can do Kegel exercises discreetly just about anytime, whether one is sitting at the desk or relaxing on the couch. To help keep an anterior prolapse from progressing, one can also try these lifestyle modifications: Tighten (contract) the pelvic floor muscles the muscles one use to stop urinating.
info-Symptoms: Trouble starting urination, incomplete urination, urinary incontinence, frequent urination
info-Risk factors: Childbirth, constipation, chronic cough, heavy lifting, being overweight
info-Treatment: Lifestyle changes, pelvic muscle exercises, vaginal pessary, surgery

Name: Prostate cancer
Risk factors: For reasons not yet determined, black men carry a greater risk of prostate cancer than do men of other races. If men in the family have had prostate cancer, the risk may be increased. Also, if one has a family history of genes that increase the risk of breast cancer (BRCA1 or BRCA2) or a very strong family history of breast cancer, the risk of prostate cancer may be higher.
Diagnosis: Some medical organizations recommend men consider prostate cancer screening in their 50s, or sooner for men who have risk factors for prostate cancer. Gleason scoring combines two numbers and can range from 2 (nonaggressive cancer) to 10 (very aggressive cancer), though the lower part of the range isn't used as often. In addition, genomic testing is increasingly being used to more accurately assess risk and detect aggressive prostate cancer. The technology helps caregivers distinguish between insignificant and significant prostate cancer, as well as identify particularly aggressive prostate cancer in men undergoing surgery. Once a prostate cancer diagnosis has been made, the doctor works to determine the extent (stage) of the cancer. Mayo clinicians also use recent 7 Tesla (7T) magnet imaging technology advancements to differentiate between prostate cancer that does or doesn't require immediate intervention. By stage IV, the cancer has grown beyond the prostate and may have spread to other areas of the body. However, if a higher than normal level is found, it may indicate prostate infection, inflammation, enlargement or cancer. If initial test results suggest prostate cancer, the doctor may recommend a procedure to collect a sample of cells from the prostate (prostate biopsy).
info-Symptoms: None, difficulty urinating, blood in the urine, pain in the pelvis, back, or when urinating
info-Risk factors: Older age, family history, race
info-Treatment: Active surveillance, surgery, radiation therapy, hormone therapy, chemotherapy

Name: Prostate gland enlargement
Diagnosis: This initial exam is likely to include After that, the doctor might recommend additional tests to help confirm an enlarged prostate and to rule out other conditions. The test can be done using ultrasound or by inserting a catheter into the bladder after one urinate to measure how much urine is left in the bladder. A lighted, flexible instrument (cystoscope) is inserted into the urethra, allowing the doctor to see inside the urethra and bladder.
Remedies: To help control the symptoms of an enlarged prostate, try to: Limit beverages in the evening. These drugs tighten the band of muscles around the urethra that control urine flow, making it harder to urinate. Try to urinate at regular times such as every four to six hours during the day to retrain the bladder. Colder temperatures can cause urine retention and increase the urgency to urinate.

Name: Prostatitis
Causes: Prostatitis is a disease of the prostate that results in pain in the groin, painful urination, difficulty urinating and other symptoms. If they don't eliminate the bacteria prostatitis might recur or be difficult to treat (chronic bacterial prostatitis).
Diagnosis: Initial diagnostic tests might include Based on the symptoms and test results, the doctor might conclude that one has one of the following types of prostatitis: Urine tests. Often caused by common strains of bacteria, this type of prostatitis generally starts suddenly and causes flu-like signs and symptoms, such as fever, chills, nausea and vomiting. When antibiotics don't eliminate the bacteria causing prostatitis, one can develop recurring or difficult-to-treat infections. Between bouts of chronic bacterial prostatitis, one might have no symptoms or only minor ones. This type of prostatitis doesn't cause symptoms and is usually found only by chance when one is undergoing tests for other conditions.
Treatment: If one has severe symptoms, one might need intravenous (IV) antibiotics. One will likely need to take oral antibiotics for four to six weeks but might need longer treatment for chronic or recurring prostatitis.
Remedies: The following might ease some symptoms of prostatitis: Soak in a warm bath (sitz bath) or use a heating pad. Limit or avoid alcohol, caffeine, and spicy or acidic foods, which can irritate the bladder.

Name: Pseudocholinesterase deficiency
Overview: Pseudocholinesterase (soo-doe-koh-lin-ES-tur-ays) deficiency is a rare condition that makes one sensitive to certain muscle relaxants ? With pseudocholinesterase deficiency, the body muscles stay relaxed for a longer time. Pseudocholinesterase deficiency can be caused by a genetic defect (mutation) that either is inherited or is acquired due to illness, injury or certain medications. But if one is diagnosed with the condition, the doctor can use other types of muscle relaxants that won't cause prolonged muscle relaxation.
Treatment: If one has pseudocholinesterase deficiency, the anesthesiologist can avoid giving one drugs that may trigger prolonged muscle relaxation and choose other muscle relaxants instead. If one has the condition and one receive muscle relaxants that prolong the anesthesia recovery, one will likely need medical assistance. With pseudocholinesterase deficiency, one may also be sensitive to other drugs and chemicals. If one has been diagnosed with pseudocholinesterase deficiency, wear a medical alert bracelet or necklace.
info-Symptoms: Prolonged paralysis
info-Usual onset: Cocaine use, Administration of plasma cholinesterase metabolized pharmaceuticals
info-Diagnostic method: Prolonged recovery from paralysis in self or blood relative
info-Prevention: Alternative neuromuscular blockade agents, cocaine avoidance

Name: Pseudogout
Overview: Pseudogout (SOO-doe-gout) is a form of arthritis characterized by sudden, painful swelling in one or more of the joints. Also called calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease or CPPD, the common term pseudogout was coined for the condition's similarity to gout. It isn't clear why crystals form in the joints and cause pseudogout, but the risk increases with age.
Risk factors: The risk of developing pseudogout increases with age. Trauma to a joint, such as a serious injury or surgery, increases the risk of pseudogout in that joint. The risk of pseudogout is higher for people who have excessive calcium or iron in their blood or too little magnesium.
Diagnosis: Pseudogout signs and symptoms can mimic those of gout and other types of arthritis, so lab and imaging tests are usually necessary to confirm a diagnosis. Blood tests can check for problems with the thyroid and parathyroid glands, as well as for a variety of mineral imbalances that have been linked to pseudogout.
Medication: If over-the-counter pain relievers aren't enough, the doctor may suggest: To relieve pain and pressure in an affected joint, the doctor inserts a needle and removes some of the joint fluid, which helps remove some of the crystals from the joint. If one can't take NSAIDs or colchicine, the doctor may suggest taking corticosteroid pills, such as prednisone, to reduce inflammation and end the attack.

Name: Pseudomembranous colitis
Overview: The colon, also called the large intestine, is a long, tubelike organ in the abdomen. Pseudomembranous (SOO-doe-mem-bruh-nus) colitis, also called antibiotic-associated colitis or C. difficile colitis, is inflammation of the colon associated with an overgrowth of the bacterium Clostridium difficile (C. diff).
Causes: The body usually keeps the many bacteria in the colon in a naturally healthy balance, but antibiotics and other medications can upset this balance. Certain toxins produced by C. difficile, which are usually present in only tiny amounts, rise to levels high enough to damage the colon. Increasingly, C. difficile has been reported in people with no known risk factors, including people with no recent health care contact or use of antibiotics.
Treatment: One may be given antibiotics by mouth, through a vein or through a tube inserted through the nose into the stomach (nasogastric tube). If the condition is extremely severe, one may be given a transplant of stool (fecal transplant) from a healthy donor to restore the balance of bacteria in the colon.
Remedies: Some research suggests that concentrated supplements of good bacteria and yeasts (probiotics) can help prevent C. difficile infection, but more studies are needed for their use in treating recurrences. Examples include sports drinks (Gatorade, Powerade, others), oral rehydration solutions (Pedialyte, Ceralyte, others), noncaffeinated soft drinks, broths and fruit juices.

Name: Pseudotumor cerebri
Medication: If the vision worsens, surgery to reduce the pressure around the optic nerve or to decrease the intracranial pressure might be necessary. In this procedure, a surgeon cuts a window into the membrane that surrounds the optic nerve to allow excess cerebrospinal fluid to escape. In another type of surgery, the doctor inserts a long, thin tube (shunt) into the brain or lower spine to help drain excess cerebrospinal fluid. The tubing is burrowed under the skin to the abdomen, where the shunt releases the excess fluid. If acetazolamide alone isn't effective, it's sometimes combined with another diuretic, which reduces fluid retention by increasing urine output.
info-Symptoms: Headache, vision problems, ringing in the ears with the heartbeat
info-Risk factors: Overweight, tetracycline
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, lumbar puncture, brain imaging
info-Treatment: Healthy diet, salt restriction, exercise, surgery

Name: Psoriasis
Symptoms: It usually causes dry, red skin lesions (plaques) covered with silvery scales. Guttate psoriasis, more common in children and adults younger than 30, appears as small, water-drop-shaped lesions on the trunk, arms, legs and scalp. Psoriasis causes red patches of skin covered with silvery scales and a thick crust on the scalp most often extending just past the hairline that may bleed when removed. Inverse psoriasis causes smooth patches of red, inflamed skin. Psoriasis can affect fingernails and toenails, causing pitting, abnormal nail growth and discoloration. Pustular psoriasis generally develops quickly, with pus-filled blisters appearing just hours after the skin becomes red and tender. The least common type of psoriasis, erythrodermic psoriasis can cover the entire body with a red, peeling rash that can itch or burn intensely. The most commonly affected areas are the lower back, elbows, knees, legs, soles of the feet, scalp, face and palms. Most types of psoriasis go through cycles, flaring for a few weeks or months, then subsiding for a time or even going into remission. There are several types of psoriasis, including If one suspect that one may have psoriasis, see the doctor. Also, talk to the doctor if the psoriasis: Viven Williams: The fingernails are clues to the overall health. Viven Williams: But Dr. Rachel Miest says there are other nail changes one should not ignore that may indicate Rachel Miest, M.D. The most common form, plaque psoriasis causes dry, raised, red skin patches (lesions) covered with silvery scales.
Overview: In psoriasis, the life cycle of the skin cells greatly accelerates, leading to a buildup of dead cells on the surface of the epidermis. Psoriasis is a skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk and scalp.
Causes: Psoriasis is thought to be an immune system problem that causes the skin to regenerate at faster than normal rates. In the most common type of psoriasis, known as plaque psoriasis, this rapid turnover of cells results in scales and red patches. Many people who are predisposed to psoriasis may be free of symptoms for years until the disease is triggered by some environmental factor.
Risk factors: Having one parent with psoriasis increases the risk of getting the disease, and having two parents with psoriasis increases the risk even more. Because stress can impact the immune system, high stress levels may increase the risk of psoriasis. Smoking tobacco not only increases the risk of psoriasis but also may increase the severity of the disease.
Remedies: After bathing, gently pat dry and apply a heavy, ointment-based moisturizer while the skin is still moist. For very dry skin, oils may be preferable they have more staying power than creams or lotions do. If moisturizing seems to improve the skin, apply it one to three times daily. Before going to bed, apply an ointment-based moisturizer to the affected skin and wrap with plastic wrap. A controlled amount of sunlight can improve psoriasis, but too much sun can trigger or worsen outbreaks and increase the risk of skin cancer. Log the time in the sun, and protect skin that isn't affected by psoriasis with sunscreen with a sun protection factor (SPF) of at least 30. If one has scalp psoriasis, try a medicated shampoo that contains coal tar. Notice what triggers the psoriasis, and take steps to prevent or avoid them. Infections, injuries to the skin, stress, smoking and intense sun exposure can all worsen psoriasis. In addition to quitting smoking and drinking moderately, if at all, one can manage the psoriasis by being active, eating well and maintaining a healthy weight.
info-Symptoms: Red (purple on darker skin), itchy, scaly patches of skin
info-Causes: Genetic disease triggered by environmental factors
info-Treatment: Steroid creams, vitamin D3 cream, ultraviolet light, Immunosuppressive drugs such as methotrexate

Name: Psoriatic arthritis
Symptoms: However, psoriatic arthritis is more likely to also cause: If one has psoriasis, be sure to tell the doctor if one develop joint pain. Psoriatic arthritis can cause a painful, sausage-like swelling of the fingers and toes.
Overview: Psoriasis causes cells to build up rapidly on the surface of the skin, forming thick, silvery scales and itchy, dry, red patches that are sometimes painful. Most people develop psoriasis first and are later diagnosed with psoriatic arthritis, but the joint problems can sometimes begin before skin patches appear.
Risk factors: Several factors can increase the risk of psoriatic arthritis, including Psoriasis. People who have pitted, deformed nails are especially likely to develop psoriatic arthritis. Although anyone can develop psoriatic arthritis, it occurs most often in adults between the ages of 30 and 50.
Remedies: For example, one can avoid straining the finger joints by using gadgets such as jar openers to twist the lids from jars, by lifting heavy pans or other objects with both hands, and by pushing doors open with the whole body instead of just the fingers. Maintaining a healthy weight places less strain on the joints, leading to reduced pain and increased energy and mobility. Some psoriatic arthritis medications are less effective in people who have a body mass index of 25.0 to 29.9 (overweight). Alcohol can increase the risk of psoriasis, decrease the effectiveness of the treatment and increase side effects from some medications, such as methotrexate. Maintain a healthy weight with psoriatic arthritis Manage stress to improve psoriatic arthritis symptoms Psoriatic arthritis and diet Psoriatic arthritis and intimacy: Tips for a better relationship Psoriatic arthritis: Cold weather skin care How to determine the psoriatic arthritis triggers Managing psoriatic arthritis pain Sleep and psoriatic arthritis Protect the joints.
Medication: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can relieve pain and reduce inflammation. Over-the-counter NSAIDs include ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve). Common DMARDs include methotrexate (Trexall, Otrexup, others), leflunomide (Arava) and sulfasalazine (Azulfidine). Side effects vary but may include liver damage, bone marrow suppression and severe lung infections. Examples include azathioprine (Imuran, Azasan) and cyclosporine (Gengraf, Neoral, Sandimmune). Also known as biologic response modifiers, this newer class of DMARDs includes abatacept (Orencia), adalimumab (Humira), certolizumab (Cimzia), etanercept (Enbrel), golimumab (Simponi), infliximab (Remicade), ixekizumab (Taltz), secukinumab (Cosentyx), tofacitinib (Xeljanz) and ustekinumab (Stelara). Apremilast (Otezla) decreases the activity of an enzyme in the body that controls the activity of inflammation within cells.

Name: PTSD
Symptoms: Post-traumatic stress disorder symptoms may start within one month of a traumatic event, but sometimes symptoms may not appear until years after the event. PTSD symptoms are generally grouped into four types: intrusive memories, avoidance, negative changes in thinking and mood, and changes in physical and emotional reactions. One may have more PTSD symptoms when one is stressed in general, or when one come across reminders of what one went through. Call a suicide hotline number in the United States, call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (1-800-273-8255) to reach a trained counselor.
Medication: Several types of medications can help improve symptoms of PTSD: One and the doctor can work together to figure out the best medication, with the fewest side effects, for the symptoms and situation. One may need to try more than one or a combination of medications, or the doctor may need to adjust the dosage or medication schedule before finding the right fit for one. The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) medications sertraline (Zoloft) and paroxetine (Paxil) are approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for PTSD treatment. While several studies indicated that prazosin (Minipress) may reduce or suppress nightmares in some people with PTSD, a more recent study showed no benefit over placebo.
info-Symptoms: Disturbing thoughts, feelings, or dreams related to the event; mental or physical distress to trauma-related cues; efforts to avoid trauma-related situations; increased fight-or-flight response

Name: Pubic lice ( crabs )
Overview: Pubic lice, commonly called crabs, are tiny insects found in the genital area. Measuring 1/16 inch (1.6 millimeters) or less, pubic lice received their nickname because their bodies resemble tiny crabs.
Treatment: If over-the-counter lotions or shampoos (Nix, Rid, others) don't kill the pubic lice, the doctor may prescribe stronger treatments, such as: Eyelash and eyebrow treatments. If pubic lice are found in eyelashes and eyebrows, one can treat them by carefully applying petroleum jelly with a cotton swab at night and washing it off in the morning. One can get rid of pubic lice with a patient, thorough approach that involves cleaning theself and any personal belongings that may be contaminated. These steps may help one eliminate lice infestations: If one can't get rid of pubic lice on the own, one may need to talk to the family doctor. This medication is taken as a single dose of two pills, with an option to take another dose in 10 days if the treatment isn't initially successful. Choose from among several over-the-counter lotions and shampoos (Nix, Rid, others) designed to kill lice. Wash bedding, clothing and towels used in the two days prior to treatment with hot, soapy water at least 130 F (54 C) and dry them at high heat for at least 20 minutes.
Remedies: One can get rid of pubic lice with a patient, thorough approach that involves cleaning theself and any personal belongings that may be contaminated. Choose from among several over-the-counter lotions and shampoos (Nix, Rid, others) designed to kill lice. Wash bedding, clothing and towels used in the two days prior to treatment with hot, soapy water at least 130 F (54 C) and dry them at high heat for at least 20 minutes.

Name: Pulmonary atresia
Overview: In pulmonary atresia, the valve that lets blood flow from the heart to the lungs isn't formed properly. Instead, some blood may reach the lungs via a temporary connection (ductus arteriosus) between a baby's aorta and the pulmonary artery. In pulmonary atresia, the valve that lets blood out of the heart to go to the or the baby's lungs (pulmonary valve) doesn't form correctly.
Causes: In the lungs, blood picks up oxygen then returns to the heart's left side through the pulmonary veins. The valve that allows blood out of the baby's heart and into the lungs to pick up oxygen is called the pulmonary valve. In pulmonary atresia, without a working pulmonary valve, blood must find another route to reach the baby's lungs.
Diagnosis: In this test, sensor patches with wires attached (electrodes) measure the electrical impulses given off by the child's heart. The doctor may diagnose the baby's pulmonary atresia through an echocardiogram of the abdomen before one deliver the baby (fetal echocardiogram). In this test, the child's doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube (catheter) into a blood vessel in the child's groin and guides it to the child's heart using X-ray imaging. This test provides detailed information about the child's heart structure and the blood pressure and oxygen levels in the child's heart, pulmonary artery and aorta.
Medication: An intravenous drug called prostaglandin will prevent closure of the natural connection (ductus arteriosus) between the pulmonary artery and the aorta. In some cases, repairs can be made via a long, thin tube (catheter) inserted into a large vein in the baby's groin and threaded up to the heart. The baby's doctor may place a rigid tube (stent) in the natural connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery (ductus arteriosus). Creating a bypass (shunt) from the main blood vessel leading out of the heart (aorta) to the pulmonary arteries allows for adequate blood flow to the lungs. In this surgery, one of the large veins that normally returns blood to the heart is connected directly to the pulmonary artery instead. Another large vein continues to provide blood to the right side of the heart, which pumps it through the surgically repaired pulmonary valve. If the right ventricle remains too small to be useful, surgeons may use a Fontan procedure to create a pathway that allows most, if not all, of the blood coming to the heart to flow directly into the pulmonary artery.
info-Symptoms: Cyanosis
info-Causes: No known cause for pulmonary atresia

Name: Pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum
Diagnosis: In this test, sensor patches with wires attached (electrodes) measure the electrical impulses given off by the child's heart. The doctor may diagnose the baby's pulmonary atresia through an echocardiogram of the abdomen before one deliver the baby (fetal echocardiogram). In this test, the child's doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube (catheter) into a blood vessel in the child's groin and guides it to the child's heart using X-ray imaging. This test provides detailed information about the child's heart structure and the blood pressure and oxygen levels in the child's heart, pulmonary artery and aorta.
Medication: An intravenous drug called prostaglandin will prevent closure of the natural connection (ductus arteriosus) between the pulmonary artery and the aorta. In some cases, repairs can be made via a long, thin tube (catheter) inserted into a large vein in the baby's groin and threaded up to the heart. The baby's doctor may place a rigid tube (stent) in the natural connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery (ductus arteriosus). Creating a bypass (shunt) from the main blood vessel leading out of the heart (aorta) to the pulmonary arteries allows for adequate blood flow to the lungs. In this surgery, one of the large veins that normally returns blood to the heart is connected directly to the pulmonary artery instead. Another large vein continues to provide blood to the right side of the heart, which pumps it through the surgically repaired pulmonary valve. If the right ventricle remains too small to be useful, surgeons may use a Fontan procedure to create a pathway that allows most, if not all, of the blood coming to the heart to flow directly into the pulmonary artery.

Name: Pulmonary atresia with ventricular septum defect
Diagnosis: In this test, sensor patches with wires attached (electrodes) measure the electrical impulses given off by the child's heart. The doctor may diagnose the baby's pulmonary atresia through an echocardiogram of the abdomen before one deliver the baby (fetal echocardiogram). In this test, the child's doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube (catheter) into a blood vessel in the child's groin and guides it to the child's heart using X-ray imaging. This test provides detailed information about the child's heart structure and the blood pressure and oxygen levels in the child's heart, pulmonary artery and aorta.
Medication: An intravenous drug called prostaglandin will prevent closure of the natural connection (ductus arteriosus) between the pulmonary artery and the aorta. In some cases, repairs can be made via a long, thin tube (catheter) inserted into a large vein in the baby's groin and threaded up to the heart. The baby's doctor may place a rigid tube (stent) in the natural connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery (ductus arteriosus). Creating a bypass (shunt) from the main blood vessel leading out of the heart (aorta) to the pulmonary arteries allows for adequate blood flow to the lungs. In this surgery, one of the large veins that normally returns blood to the heart is connected directly to the pulmonary artery instead. Another large vein continues to provide blood to the right side of the heart, which pumps it through the surgically repaired pulmonary valve. If the right ventricle remains too small to be useful, surgeons may use a Fontan procedure to create a pathway that allows most, if not all, of the blood coming to the heart to flow directly into the pulmonary artery.

Name: Pulmonary edema
Causes: A number of things can cause fluid to accumulate in the lungs, but most have to do with the heart (cardiogenic pulmonary edema). The lower chambers, the right and left ventricles, pump blood out of the heart. The lower chambers (the more muscular right and left ventricles) pump blood out of the heart. Over time, the arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle can become narrow from fatty deposits (plaques). Or, they don't close completely, allowing blood to flow backward through the valve (insufficiency or regurgitation). The increased pressure extends into the left atrium and then to the pulmonary veins, causing fluid to accumulate in the lungs. On the other hand, if the mitral valve leaks, some blood is backwashed toward the lung each time the heart pumps. In normal lungs, air sacs (alveoli) take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide. In high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE), it's theorized that vessels in the lungs constrict, causing increased pressure. Although the exact cause isn't completely understood, HAPE seems to develop as a result of increased pressure from constriction of the pulmonary capillaries. Pulmonary embolism, a condition that occurs when blood clots travel from blood vessels in the legs to the lungs, can lead to pulmonary edema.
Diagnosis: Other blood tests may be done including tests of the kidney function, thyroid function and blood count as well as tests to exclude a heart attack as the cause of the pulmonary edema. The test can help diagnose a number of heart problems, including heart valve problems, abnormal motions of the ventricular walls, fluid around the heart (pericardial effusion) and congenital heart defects. If tests such as an ECG or echocardiography don't uncover the cause of the pulmonary edema, or one also have chest pain, the doctor may suggest cardiac catheterization and coronary angiogram. During cardiac catheterization, a doctor inserts a long, thin catheter in an artery or vein in the groin, neck or arm and threads it through the blood vessels to the heart using X-ray imaging. Cardiac catheterization can also be used to measure the pressure in the heart chambers, assess the heart valves and look for causes of pulmonary edema.
Treatment: Depending on the condition and the reason for the pulmonary edema, one may also receive one or more of the following medications: Blood pressure medications. If one has high blood pressure when one develop pulmonary edema, one will be given medications to control it. The doctor may also prescribe blood pressure medications that ease the pressure going into (preload reducers) or out of (afterload reducers) the heart. Medications such as nitroprusside (Nitropress) are afterload reducers that dilate the blood vessels and take a pressure load off the heart's left ventricle. Doctors commonly prescribe diuretics, such as furosemide (Lasix), to decrease the pressure caused by excess fluid in the heart and lungs.
Remedies: Depending on the condition, the doctor may recommend lifestyle changes, including Controlling the high blood pressure. If one has high blood pressure, take the medications as prescribed and check the blood pressure regularly.

Name: Pulmonary embolism
Symptoms: Seek urgent medical attention if one experience unexplained shortness of breath, chest pain or a cough that produces bloody sputum. The pain is often sharp and felt when one breathe in deeply, often stopping one from being able to take a deep breath.
Overview: Pulmonary embolism occurs when a blood clot gets lodged in an artery in the lung, blocking blood flow to part of the lung. In most cases, pulmonary embolism is caused by blood clots that travel to the lungs from deep veins in the legs or, rarely, from veins in other parts of the body (deep vein thrombosis).
Causes: Pulmonary embolism occurs when a clump of material, most often a blood clot, gets wedged into an artery in the lungs. These blood clots most commonly come from the deep veins of the legs, a condition known as deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
Risk factors: Although anyone can develop blood clots and subsequent pulmonary embolism, certain factors can increase the risk. In addition, some medical conditions and treatments put one at risk, such as: Blood clots are more likely to form during periods of inactivity, such as: Heart disease. Certain cancers especially brain, ovary, pancreas, colon, stomach, lung and kidney cancers, and cancers that have spread can increase the risk of blood clots, and chemotherapy further increases the risk. Being confined to bed for an extended period after surgery, a heart attack, leg fracture, trauma or any serious illness makes one more vulnerable to blood clots. When the lower extremities are horizontal for long periods, the flow of venous blood slows and blood can pool in the legs, sometimes resulting in blood clots. Sitting in a cramped position during lengthy plane or car trips slows blood flow in the legs, which contributes to the formation of clots. For reasons that aren't well understood, tobacco use predisposes some people to blood clot formation, especially when combined with other risk factors. The estrogen in birth control pills and in hormone replacement therapy can increase clotting factors in the blood, especially if one smoke or are overweight.
Diagnosis: High levels may suggest an increased likelihood of blood clots, although many other factors can also cause high D dimer levels. Although X-rays can't diagnose pulmonary embolism and may even appear normal when pulmonary embolism exists, they can rule out conditions that mimic the disease. A noninvasive test known as duplex ultrasonography (sometimes called duplex scan or compression ultrasonography) uses sound waves to scan the veins in the thigh, knee and calf, and sometimes in the arms, to check for deep vein blood clots. It's the most accurate way to diagnose pulmonary embolism, but because it requires a high degree of skill to administer and has potentially serious risks, it's usually performed when other tests fail to provide a definitive diagnosis. In a pulmonary angiogram, a flexible tube (catheter) is inserted into a large vein usually in the groin and threaded through the heart and into the pulmonary arteries.
Medication: Because one may be at risk of another deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism, it's important to continue treatment, such as remaining on blood thinners, and be monitored as often as suggested by the doctor. While clots usually dissolve on their own, sometimes thrombolytics given through the vein can dissolve clots quickly. If one has a very large, life-threatening clot in the lung, the doctor may suggest removing it via a thin, flexible tube (catheter) threaded through the blood vessels.
info-Symptoms: Shortness of breath, chest pain, coughing up blood
info-Risk factors: Cancer, prolonged bed rest, smoking, stroke, certain genetic conditions, estrogen-based medication, pregnancy, obesity, after surgery
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, D-dimer, CT pulmonary angiography, lung ventilation/perfusion scan

Name: Pulmonary fibrosis
Overview: Pulmonary fibrosis scars and thickens the tissue around and between the air sacs (alveoli) in the lungs, as shown on the right. The lung damage caused by pulmonary fibrosis can't be repaired, but medications and therapies can sometimes help ease symptoms and improve quality of life.
Causes: The damage can be caused by many different factors including long-term exposure to certain toxins, certain medical conditions, radiation therapy and some medications. Researchers have several theories about what might trigger idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, including viruses and exposure to tobacco smoke. Also, some forms of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis run in families, and heredity may play a role in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Ongoing research is evaluating if GERD may be a risk factor for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, or if GERD may lead to a more rapid progression of the condition. However, more research is needed to determine the association between idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and GERD. Drugs designed to kill cancer cells, such as methotrexate (Trexall, Otrexup, others) and cyclophosphamide, can also damage lung tissue. Some drugs used to treat irregular heartbeats, such as amiodarone (Cordarone, Nexterone, Pacerone), may harm lung tissue. Antibiotics such as nitrofurantoin (Macrobid, Macrodantin, others) or ethambutol can cause lung damage.
Risk factors: Although pulmonary fibrosis has been diagnosed in children and infants, the disorder is much more likely to affect middle-aged and older adults. One has an increased risk of developing pulmonary fibrosis if one work in mining, farming or construction or if one is exposed to pollutants known to damage the lungs. Having radiation treatments to the chest or using certain chemotherapy drugs can increase the risk of pulmonary fibrosis. Some types of pulmonary fibrosis run in families, and genetic factors may be a component.
Diagnosis: To diagnose the condition, the doctor may review the medical and family history, discuss the signs and symptoms, review any exposure one has had to dusts, gases and chemicals, and conduct a physical exam. If other tests haven't diagnosed the condition, doctors may need to remove a small amount of lung tissue (biopsy). In this procedure, the doctor removes very small tissue samples generally no larger than the head of a pin using a small, flexible tube (bronchoscope) that's passed through the mouth or nose into the lungs. During bronchoscopy, the doctor may conduct an additional procedure called bronchoalveolar lavage. Although bronchoalveolar lavage samples a larger area of the lung than other procedures do, it may not provide enough information to diagnose pulmonary fibrosis. Although a surgical biopsy is more invasive and has potential complications, it may be the only way to obtain a large enough tissue sample to make an accurate diagnosis. This procedure may be done as a minimally invasive surgery, called video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS), or as an open surgery (thoracotomy). During open surgery (thoracotomy), a surgeon removes a lung sample through an incision in the chest between the ribs. Doctors may also order blood tests to evaluate the liver and kidney function, and to test for and rule out other conditions. However, serious complications can include bleeding or a deflated lung.During bronchoscopy, the doctor may conduct an additional procedure called bronchoalveolar lavage. The solution that's withdrawn contains cells from the air sacs.Although bronchoalveolar lavage samples a larger area of the lung than other procedures do, it may not provide enough information to diagnose pulmonary fibrosis. This procedure may be done as a minimally invasive surgery, called video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS), or as an open surgery (thoracotomy).During VATS, the surgeon inserts surgical instruments and a small camera through two or three small incisions between the ribs. This procedure is performed after one has been given a general anesthetic, so one will be asleep during the procedure.During open surgery (thoracotomy), a surgeon removes a lung sample through an incision in the chest between the ribs.
Remedies: For that reason, it's important to: Stop smoking. If one has lung disease, it's very important to stop smoking. Talk to the doctor about options for quitting, including smoking cessation programs, which use a variety of proven techniques to help people quit. And because secondhand smoke can be harmful to the lungs, avoid being around people who are smoking. Aim to eat a variety of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, low-fat or fat-free dairy products, and lean meats. Try to eat smaller meals more often during the day.Aim to eat a variety of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, low-fat or fat-free dairy products, and lean meats. Follow the doctor's instructions, take the medications as prescribed, and adjust the diet and exercise as needed.
Medication: The doctor may recommend newer medications, including pirfenidone (Esbriet) and nintedanib (Ofev). Doctors may recommend anti-acid medications to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), a digestive condition that commonly occurs in people with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Using oxygen can't stop lung damage, but it can: One may receive oxygen when one sleep or exercise, although some people may use it all the time.
info-Symptoms: Shortness of breath, dry cough, feeling tired, weight loss, nail clubbing
info-Causes: Tobacco smoking, environmental pollution, certain medications, connective tissue diseases, interstitial lung disease, unknown
info-Treatment: Oxygen therapy, pulmonary rehabilitation, lung transplantation

Name: Pulmonary hypertension
Overview: When the tiny blood vessels in the lungs become thickened, narrowed, blocked or destroyed, it's harder for blood to flow through the lungs. In one form of pulmonary hypertension, called pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), blood vessels in the lungs are narrowed, blocked or destroyed.
Causes: The blood normally flows easily through blood vessels in the lungs (pulmonary arteries, capillaries and veins) to the left side of the heart. It's most commonly caused by a large hole in the heart between the two lower heart chambers (ventricles), called a ventricular septal defect.
Diagnosis: The doctor will order tests to help diagnose pulmonary hypertension and determine its cause. It can be used to determine the size and thickness of the right ventricle, and to measure the pressure in the pulmonary arteries. If an echocardiogram reveals pulmonary hypertension, one will likely have a right heart catheterization to confirm the diagnosis. The doctor might also order one or more of the following tests to check the condition of the lungs and pulmonary arteries and further determine the cause of pulmonary hypertension: Computerized tomography (CT). A CT scan can show the heart's size, spot blood clots in the lungs arteries, and look closely for lung diseases that might lead to pulmonary hypertension, such as COPD or pulmonary fibrosis. If a family member has had pulmonary hypertension, the doctor might screen one for genes that are linked with pulmonary hypertension. Once one has been diagnosed with pulmonary hypertension, the doctor might classify the severity of the disease into one of several classes, including Blood tests. Blood tests can help the doctor determine the cause of pulmonary hypertension or look for signs of complications. It can show enlargement of the right ventricle of the heart or the pulmonary arteries, which can occur in pulmonary hypertension. The doctor may also use a chest X-ray to check for other lung conditions that can cause pulmonary hypertension. It can help diagnose a sleep disorder such as obstructive sleep apnea, which can cause pulmonary hypertension. Rarely, a doctor might recommend an open-lung biopsy to check for a possible cause of pulmonary hypertension. Although one has been diagnosed with pulmonary hypertension, one has no symptoms with normal activity.
Remedies: Although medical treatment can't cure pulmonary hypertension, it can lessen symptoms. In most cases, it's recommended that people with pulmonary hypertension not lift heavy weights. If one can't stop smoking by theself, ask the doctor to prescribe a treatment plan to help one quit. If one do become pregnant, it's important to consult with the doctor as pulmonary hypertension can cause serious complications to both mom and her baby. If one live at an altitude of 8,000 feet (2,438 meters) or higher, the doctor might recommend that one move to a lower altitude. Ask the doctor about any other medications before taking them, as some can interfere with pulmonary hypertension treatments or make the symptoms worse. Let the doctor know if one has any questions about the condition or medications one is taking, or if one has any symptoms or side effects from the medications. If pulmonary hypertension affects the quality of life, ask the doctor about options that could help. The doctor may work together with another specialist to initiate and manage any medications for pulmonary hypertension. The doctor may recommend getting an influenza and pneumonia vaccine, as these conditions can cause serious issues for people with pulmonary hypertension.
Medication: One of the most commonly prescribed vasodilators for pulmonary hypertension is epoprostenol (Flolan, Veletri). This drug continuously flows through an intravenous (IV) line attached to a small pump, which one wear in a pack on the belt or shoulder. Other types of vasodilators, including treprostinil (Tyvaso, Remodulin, Orenitram), can be inhaled, injected, or taken by mouth. The drug iloprost (Ventavis) is given while one breathe in through a nebulizer, a machine that vaporizes the medication. The doctor is likely to prescribe warfarin (Coumadin, Jantoven) to help prevent blood clots in the lung's arteries. In an atrial septostomy, a surgeon creates an opening between the upper left and right chambers of the heart (atria) to relieve the pressure on the right side of the heart. Atrial septostomy can have serious complications, including heart rhythm problems (arrhythmias). Riociguat (Adempas) increases nitric oxide in the body, which relaxes the pulmonary arteries and lowers pressure within them. Such drugs include bosentan (Tracleer), macitentan (Opsumit), and ambrisentan (Letairis). Sildenafil (Revatio, Viagra) and tadalafil (Adcirca, Cialis) are commonly used to treat erectile dysfunction. They include amlodipine (Norvasc), diltiazem (Cardizem, Tiazac, others) and nifedipine (Procardia, others). The doctor might suggest that one sometimes breathe pure oxygen to help treat pulmonary hypertension, especially if one live at a high altitude or have sleep apnea.
info-Symptoms: Chest pain, fatigue
info-Risk factors: Family history, pulmonary embolism, HIV/AIDS, sickle cell disease, cocaine use, COPD, sleep apnea, living at high altitudes
info-Diagnostic method: Following ruling out other potential causes
info-Treatment: Supportive care, various medications, lung transplantation
info-Medication: Epoprostenol, treprostinil, iloprost, bosentan, ambrisentan, macitentan, sildenafil

Name: Pulmonary valve disease
Overview: Pulmonary valve disease is a condition in which the pulmonary valve located between the heart's lower right heart chamber (right ventricle) and the artery that delivers blood to the lungs (pulmonary artery) doesn't work properly. The pulmonary valve normally acts like a one-way door from the heart's right ventricle to the lungs. Blood flows from the right ventricle through the pulmonary valve to the pulmonary artery and then into the lungs, where it picks up oxygen to deliver to the body. Types of pulmonary valve disease include Many types of pulmonary valve disease are due to heart conditions present at birth (congenital heart defects). Narrowing of the pulmonary valve reduces the blood flow from the heart to the pulmonary artery and lungs. The flaps (leaflets) of the pulmonary valve don't close tightly, causing blood to leak backward into the right ventricle. Instead, a solid sheet of tissue blocks blood flow from the right side of the heart, so blood can't go to the lungs to pick up oxygen.

Name: PVD
Overview: Claudication is pain caused by too little blood flow to the legs or arms. Peripheral artery disease (also called peripheral arterial disease) is a common circulatory problem in which narrowed arteries reduce blood flow to the limbs. When one develop peripheral artery disease (PAD), the extremities usually the legs don't receive enough blood flow to keep up with demand.
Diagnosis: To get a blood pressure reading, the doctor uses a regular blood pressure cuff and a special ultrasound device to evaluate blood pressure and flow. Using a dye (contrast material) injected into the blood vessels, this test allows the doctor to view blood flow through the arteries as it happens. The doctor is able to trace the flow of the contrast material using imaging techniques, such as X-ray imaging or procedures called magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) or computerized tomography angiography (CTA). After finding the narrowed area of a blood vessel, the doctor can then widen it by inserting and expanding a tiny balloon or by administering medication that improves blood flow. The doctor may find signs of PAD during a physical examination, such as a weak or absent pulse below a narrowed area of the artery, whooshing sounds (bruits) over the arteries that can be heard with a stethoscope, evidence of poor wound healing in the area where the blood flow is restricted, and decreased blood pressure in the affected limb. Special ultrasound imaging techniques, such as Doppler ultrasound, can help the doctor evaluate blood flow through the blood vessels and identify blocked or narrowed arteries.
Remedies: Many people can manage the symptoms of peripheral artery disease and stop the progression of the disease through lifestyle changes, especially quitting smoking. If one is having trouble quitting on the own, ask the doctor about smoking cessation options, including medications to help one quit. People with peripheral artery disease, especially those who also have diabetes, are at risk of poor healing of sores and injuries on the lower legs and feet. Over-the-counter cold remedies that contain pseudoephedrine (Advil Cold & Sinus, Aleve-D Sinus & Cold, others) constrict the blood vessels and may increase the PAD symptoms. Wash the feet daily, dry them thoroughly and moisturize often to prevent cracks that can lead to infection.
Medication: The goal for people who have peripheral artery disease is to reduce low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, the bad cholesterol, to less than 100 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 2.6 millimoles per liter (mmol/L). If one also have high blood pressure, the doctor may prescribe medications to lower it. A blood pressure reading, given in millimeters of mercury (mm Hg), has two numbers. If one also have diabetes, it becomes even more important to control the blood sugar (glucose) levels.

Name: Pyelonephritis
Overview: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine.
Risk factors: This includes anything that slows the flow of urine or reduces the ability to empty the bladder when urinating including a kidney stone, something abnormal in the urinary tract's structure or, in men, an enlarged prostate gland. In vesicoureteral reflux, small amounts of urine flow from the bladder back up into the ureters and kidneys.
Diagnosis: To confirm that one has a kidney infection, one will likely be asked to provide a urine sample to test for bacteria, blood or pus in the urine. The doctor might also take a blood sample for a culture a lab test that checks for bacteria or other organisms in the blood.
Remedies: To reduce discomfort while one recover from a kidney infection, one might: Apply heat. Place a heating pad on the abdomen, back or side to ease pain. For fever or discomfort, take a nonaspirin pain reliever such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Motrin IB, Advil, others).
