info-Symptoms: Fever, flank tenderness, nausea, burning with urination, frequent urination
info-Risk factors: Sexual intercourse, prior urinary tract infections, diabetes, structural problems of the urinary tract, spermicide use
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and supported by urinalysis
info-Prevention: Urination after sex, drinking sufficient fluids

Name: Pyoderma gangrenosum
Overview: Pyoderma gangrenosum can cause painful, open sores (ulcers) that have bluish, overhanging borders. Pyoderma gangrenosum (pie-o-DUR-muh gang-ruh-NO-sum) is a rare condition that causes large, painful sores (ulcers) to develop on the skin, most often on the legs.
Causes: It's often associated with autoimmune diseases such as ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease and arthritis. If one has pyoderma gangrenosum, new skin trauma, such as a cut or puncture wound, may trigger new ulcers.
Risk factors: Certain factors may increase the risk of pyoderma gangrenosum, including The age and sex. People with a digestive tract disease such as ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease are at increased risk of pyoderma gangrenosum. People with acute myelogenous leukemia, myelodysplasia or a myeloproliferative disorder are at increased risk of pyoderma gangrenosum.
Medication: In addition to applying medicine directly to the wounds, the doctor or wound care specialist will cover them with a nonadherent, moist (not wet or dry) dressing and, perhaps, an elasticized wrap. Because pyoderma gangrenosum can be made worse by cuts to the skin, surgery to remove dead tissue is not usually considered a good treatment option. These drugs may be applied to the skin, injected into the wound or taken by mouth (prednisone). Other options include mycophenolate (Cellcept), immunoglobulins, dapsone, infliximab (Remicade) and tacrolimus (Protopic), which is a calcineurin inhibitor. Depending on the type of drug used, it may be applied to the wounds, injected or taken by mouth. Depending on the extent of the wounds, one may benefit from pain medication, especially when dressings are being changed.

Name: Query fever
Overview: Q fever is an infection caused by the bacterium Coxiella burnetii. But if Q fever recurs, one may need to take antibiotics for at least 18 months.
Risk factors: Certain factors can increase the risk of being infected with Q fever bacteria, including The risk of eventually developing the more deadly form of Q fever is increased in people who have: Occupation. Simply being near a farm or farming facility may put one at higher risk of Q fever, because the bacteria can travel long distances, accompanying dust particles in the air. Q fever can occur at any time of the year, but the number of infections usually peaks in April and May in the U.S. Heart valve disease Blood vessel abnormalities Weakened immune systems Impaired kidney function
Diagnosis: To diagnose Q fever, the doctor will perform one or more blood tests, along with additional tests if chronic Q fever is suspected. If chronic Q fever is suspected, the doctor may do an echocardiogram to check for problems with the heart valves.
Treatment: Even after successful chronic Q fever treatment, one will need to go back for follow-up tests for years in case the infection returns. However, if one has symptoms of Q fever or if one is pregnant, antibiotic treatment is recommended.
info-Risk factors: Contact with livestock

Name: Rabies
Overview: Rabies is a deadly virus spread to people from the saliva of infected animals. Animals most likely to transmit rabies in the United States include bats, coyotes, foxes, raccoons and skunks. Jason Howland: The deadly virus is transmitted from the saliva of infected animals to humans, usually through a bite. Jason Howland: Dr. Poland says that's why if one wake up and find a bat in the room, one should get the rabies vaccine.
info-Symptoms: Fever, fear of water, confusion, excessive salivation, hallucinations, trouble sleeping, paralysis, coma
info-Prevention: Rabies vaccine, animal control, rabies immunoglobulin
info-Prognosis: Virtually 100% fatal after onset of symptoms

Name: Radiation enteritis
Symptoms: Radiation enteritis symptoms include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and belly cramps. Radiation enteritis that goes on for longer can cause anemia and partial bowel obstruction.
Overview: Radiation enteritis is inflammation of the intestines that occurs after radiation therapy. Radiation enteritis causes diarrhea, nausea, vomiting and stomach cramps in people receiving radiation aimed at the abdomen, pelvis or rectum. For most people, radiation enteritis is temporary and the inflammation usually subsides several weeks after treatment ends.
info-Symptoms: Diarrhea, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, anorexia and malaise
info-Usual onset: Acute: several weeks after radiation Chronic: 8-12 months after radiation

Name: Radiation sickness
Overview: Radiation sickness is damage to the body caused by a large dose of radiation often received over a short period of time (acute). Since the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Japan, during World War II, most cases of radiation sickness have occurred after nuclear industrial accidents, such as the 1986 explosion and fire that damaged the nuclear power plant at Chernobyl, Ukraine.
Diagnosis: When a person has experienced known or probable exposure to a high dose of radiation from an accident or attack, medical personnel take a number of steps to determine the absorbed radiation dose. The time between radiation exposure and the onset of vomiting is a fairly accurate screening tool to estimate absorbed radiation dose. The severity and timing of other signs and symptoms also may help medical personnel determine the absorbed dose. A device called a dosimeter can measure the absorbed dose of radiation but only if it was exposed to the same radiation event as the affected person.
info-Symptoms: Early: Nausea, vomiting, loss of appetiteLater: Infections, bleeding, dehydration, confusion
info-Causes: Large amounts of ionizing radiation over a short period of time
info-Diagnostic method: Based on history of exposure and symptoms
info-Treatment: Supportive care (blood transfusions, antibiotics, colony stimulating factors, stem cell transplant)

Name: Ramsay Hunt syndrome
Symptoms: The two main signs and symptoms of Ramsay Hunt syndrome are: Usually, the rash and the facial paralysis occur at the same time. If one has Ramsay Hunt syndrome, one might also experience: Call the doctor if one experience facial paralysis or a shingles rash on the face.
Overview: The nerve that controls the facial muscles passes through a narrow corridor of bone on its way to the face. Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus) occurs when a shingles outbreak affects the facial nerve near one of the ears. In addition to the painful shingles rash, Ramsay Hunt syndrome can cause facial paralysis and hearing loss in the affected ear. Prompt treatment of Ramsay Hunt syndrome can reduce the risk of complications, which can include permanent facial muscle weakness and deafness.
Treatment: Medications may include The following can help reduce the discomfort of Ramsay Hunt syndrome: If facial weakness makes it difficult for one to close one of the eyes, take the following steps to protect the vision: One is likely to start by first seeing the family doctor. He or she may refer one to a doctor who specializes in nervous system disorders (neurologist) or to an ear, nose and throat specialist (otolaryngologist). Medications such as acyclovir (Zovirax), famciclovir (Famvir) or valacyclovir (Valtrex) often help combat the chickenpox virus. Take an over-the-counter pain reliever or anti-inflammatory drug, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others).

Name: Rapid gastric emptying
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of dumping syndrome generally occur right after eating, especially after a meal rich in table sugar (sucrose) or fruit sugar (fructose). Signs and symptoms might include Late dumping syndrome starts one to three hours after one eat a high-sugar meal. The signs and symptoms develop that long after one eat because the body releases large amounts of insulin to absorb the sugars entering the small intestine. Signs and symptoms of late dumping syndrome can include Some people have both early and late signs and symptoms.
Overview: Dumping syndrome is a condition that can develop after surgery to remove all or part of the stomach or after surgery to bypass the stomach to help one lose weight. Most people with dumping syndrome develop signs and symptoms, such as abdominal cramps and diarrhea, 10 to 30 minutes after eating.
Diagnosis: The doctor can often diagnose dumping syndrome by taking a medical history, particularly if one has had stomach surgery, and evaluating the signs and symptoms. Because low blood sugar is sometimes associated with dumping syndrome, the doctor may order a test (oral glucose tolerance) to measure the blood sugar level at the peak time of the symptoms to help confirm the diagnosis.
Remedies: Eat more protein meat, poultry, creamy peanut butter and fish and complex carbohydrates oatmeal and other whole-grain foods high in fiber. Limit high-sugar foods, such as candy, table sugar, syrup, sodas and juices. At first, limit fluid with meals to 1/2 cup (118 milliliters). Limit high-sugar foods, such as candy, table sugar, syrup, sodas and juices.ttThe natural sugar in dairy products (lactose) might worsen the symptoms.

Name: Rash , poison ivy
Causes: Poison ivy leaves vary greatly in their shape, color and texture. Poison ivy can produce small, greenish flowers and green or off-white berries. Unlike poison ivy and poison oak, it doesn't grow in a three-leaf-per-stem pattern. It's found in the leaves, stems and roots of poison ivy, poison oak and poison sumac. Even the smoke from burning poison ivy, poison oak and poison sumac contains urushiol and can irritate or harm the nasal passages or lungs.
Treatment: If the rash is widespread or results in a large number of blisters, the doctor may prescribe an oral corticosteroid, such as prednisone. Topical treatments include calamine lotion; oatmeal baths; a mixture of baking soda and water; or a cool, wet compress. Take oral antihistamines, such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl, others), which may also help one sleep better.
Remedies: Poison ivy, poison oak and poison sumac all have an oily resin throughout the plant that can create an allergic reaction that lasts for weeks. Topical treatments include calamine lotion; oatmeal baths; a mixture of baking soda and water; or a cool, wet compress. Take oral antihistamines, such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl, others), which may also help one sleep better.

Name: Raynaud 's disease
Overview: Raynaud's (ray-NOHZ) disease causes some areas of the body such as the fingers and toes to feel numb and cold in response to cold temperatures or stress. In Raynaud's disease, smaller arteries that supply blood to the skin narrow, limiting blood circulation to affected areas (vasospasm).
Causes: Doctors don't completely understand the cause of Raynaud's attacks, but blood vessels in the hands and feet appear to overreact to cold temperatures or stress. With Raynaud's, arteries to the fingers and toes go into vasospasm when exposed to cold or stress, narrowing the vessels and temporarily limiting blood supply. Also called Raynaud's disease, this most common form isn't the result of an associated medical condition. Also called Raynaud's phenomenon, this form is caused by an underlying problem. Although secondary Raynaud's is less common than the primary form, it tends to be more serious. Signs and symptoms of secondary Raynaud's usually appear around age 40, later than they do for primary Raynaud's. Other diseases that increase the risk of Raynaud's include lupus, rheumatoid arthritis and Sjogren's syndrome.
Risk factors: Risk factors for primary Raynaud's include Risk factors for secondary Raynaud's include Sex. Although anyone can develop the condition, primary Raynaud's often begins between the ages of 15 and 30. A first-degree relative a parent, sibling or child having the disease appears to increase the risk of primary Raynaud's. This includes smoking, taking medications that affect the blood vessels and being exposed to certain chemicals, such as vinyl chloride.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects that another condition, such as an autoimmune or connective tissue disease, underlies Raynaud's, he or she will likely order blood tests, such as: No one blood test can diagnose Raynaud's. The doctor might order other tests, such as those that rule out diseases of the arteries, to help pinpoint a condition that can be associated with Raynaud's. A positive test for the presence of these antibodies produced by the immune system might indicate a stimulated immune system, common in people who have connective tissue diseases or other autoimmune disorders.
Remedies: To gently warm the fingers and toes: If stress triggers an attack, get out of the stressful situation and relax. Practice a stress-reduction technique that works for one, and warm the hands or feet in water to help lessen the attack. Get indoors or to a warmer area Wiggle the fingers and toes Place hands under armpits Make wide circles (windmills) with the arms Run warm not hot water over the fingers and toes Massage the hands and feet Avoid smoke.
Medication: To widen (dilate) blood vessels and promote circulation, the doctor might prescribe: Calcium channel blockers. These drugs relax and open small blood vessels in the hands and feet, decreasing the frequency and severity of attacks in most people with Raynaud's. Examples include nifedipine (Afeditab CR, Procardia, others), amlodipine (Norvasc), felodipine and isradipine. These drugs, which relax blood vessels, include nitroglycerin cream applied to the base of the fingers to help heal skin ulcers. Other vasodilators include the high blood pressure drug losartan (Cozaar), the erectile dysfunction medication sildenafil (Viagra, Revatio), the antidepressant fluoxetine (Prozac, Sarafem, others) and a class of medications called prostaglandins. Through small incisions in the affected hands or feet, a doctor strips these tiny nerves around the blood vessels. This surgery (sympathectomy), if successful, might reduce the frequency and duration of attacks.

Name: Rebound headache
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of medication overuse headaches may differ according to the type of original headache being treated and the medication used. Medication overuse headaches tend to: Other signs and symptoms may include Occasional headaches are common.
Overview: Medication overuse headaches or rebound headaches are caused by regular, long-term use of medication to treat headaches, such as migraines. Pain relievers taken regularly for another condition, such as arthritis, haven't been shown to cause medication overuse headaches in people who never had a headache disorder.
Causes: Over-the-counter (OTC) pain relievers that combine caffeine, aspirin and acetaminophen (Excedrin, others) are common culprits. Butalbital-containing compounds have an especially high risk of causing medication overuse headaches, so it's best not to take them to treat headaches. Daily doses of caffeine from coffee, soda, and pain relievers and other products containing this mild stimulant may fuel medication overuse headaches, as well. Common pain relievers such as aspirin and acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) may contribute to medication overuse headaches especially if one exceed the recommended daily dosages. Pain relievers such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve) have a low risk of contributing to medication overuse headaches. Butalbital-containing compounds have an especially high risk of causing medication overuse headaches, so it's best not to take them to treat headaches.t Migraine medications.

Name: Rectal cancer
Causes: But when a cell's DNA is damaged and becomes cancerous, cells continue to divide even when new cells aren't needed. Some genes linked to rectal cancer increase an individual's risk of developing the disease, but they don't make it inevitable. Two well-defined genetic colorectal cancer syndromes are: FAP, HNPCC and other, rarer inherited colorectal cancer syndromes can be detected through genetic testing.
Risk factors: People of African ancestry born in the United States have a greater risk of colorectal cancer than do people of European ancestry. If one has already had rectal cancer, colon cancer or adenomatous polyps, one has a greater risk of colorectal cancer in the future. Chronic inflammatory diseases of the colon and rectum, such as ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease, increase the risk of colorectal cancer. Genetic syndromes passed through generations of the family can increase the risk of colorectal cancer. People with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes and insulin resistance may have an increased risk of colorectal cancer. People who are obese have an increased risk of colorectal cancer and an increased risk of dying of colon or rectal cancer when compared with people considered normal weight. People who smoke may have an increased risk of colon cancer. Regularly drinking more than three alcoholic beverages a week may increase the risk of colorectal cancer. Radiation therapy directed at the abdomen to treat previous cancers may increase the risk of colorectal cancer.
Diagnosis: In a colonoscopy, a doctor uses a thin, flexible, lighted tube with a video camera at its tip (a colonoscope) to view the inside of the colon and rectum. People without symptoms may learn they have rectal cancer when they have a screening colonoscopy that is, a colonoscopy recommended at age 50 for everyone with an average risk of colorectal cancer. Once one is diagnosed with rectal cancer, the next step is to determine the cancer's extent (stage). The following blood tests and imaging studies are involved in staging rectal cancer: Rectal cancers fall into one of five possible stages (stage 0 through stage 4). The stages, in simplified form, are: Staging also involves examining a sample of tissue taken from the tumor (a biopsy) to determine the tumor's grade. A CBC shows whether the red blood cell count is low (anemia), which suggests that a tumor is causing blood loss. A high level of white blood cells is a sign of infection, which is a risk if a rectal tumor grows through the wall of the rectum. One such marker, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), may be higher than normal in people with colorectal cancer. Cancer cells on the surface of the rectal lining (mucosa), sometimes within a polyp Stage I. Tumor extending below the rectal mucosa, sometimes penetrating into the rectal wall Stage II. Tumor extending into or through the rectal wall, sometimes reaching and growing on or sticking to tissues next to the rectum Stage III. Tumor invading lymph nodes next to the rectum, as well as structures and tissues outside the rectal wall Stage IV.
info-Symptoms: vomiting blood, Blood in the stool, change in bowel movements, weight loss, fatigue.
info-Causes: Old age, lifestyle factors, genetic disorders
info-Risk factors: Diet, obesity, smoking, lack of physical activity, alcohol use
info-Diagnostic method: Tissue biopsy during a sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy
info-Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy

Name: Rectal inflammation
Overview: Proctitis is inflammation of the lining of the rectum. Proctitis can cause rectal pain, diarrhea, bleeding and discharge, as well as the continuous feeling that one need to have a bowel movement. Proctitis is common in people who have inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis).
Causes: Sexually transmitted infections, spread particularly by people who engage in anal intercourse, can result in proctitis. Sexually transmitted infections that can cause proctitis include gonorrhea, genital herpes and chlamydia. Infections associated with foodborne illness, such as salmone willa, shigella and campylobacter infections, also can cause proctitis. Radiation therapy directed at the rectum or nearby areas, such as the prostate, can cause rectal inflammation. Sometimes antibiotics used to treat an infection can kill helpful bacteria in the bowels, allowing the harmful Clostridium difficile bacteria to grow in the rectum.
Risk factors: Having an inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis ) increases the risk of proctitis. Radiation therapy directed at or near the rectum (such as for rectal, ovarian or prostate cancer) increases the risk of proctitis.
Diagnosis: During a flexible sigmoidoscopy exam, the doctor inserts a sigmoidoscope into the rectum to check for abnormalities in the sigmoid colon and most of the descending colon. During this test (flexible sigmoidoscopy), the doctor uses a slender, flexible, lighted tube to examine the last part of the colon (sigmoid), as well as the rectum. This test (colonoscopy) allows the doctor to view the entire colon using a thin, flexible, lighted tube with an attached camera.

Name: Rectal itching
Overview: Anal itching is a common condition. Also called pruritus ani (proo-RIE-tus A-nie), anal itching has many possible causes, such as skin problems, hemorrhoids, and washing too much or not enough.
Causes: Or the skin care routine may include products or behaviors that irritate the skin, such as using harsh soaps or moist wipes and washing too aggressively. Sometimes anal itching is the result of a specific skin condition, such as psoriasis or contact dermatitis.
Diagnosis: The doctor may be able to diagnose the cause of the itching simply by asking one questions about the symptoms, medical history and personal care habits. If the cause of the itching isn't obvious or it doesn't respond to initial treatment, the doctor may refer one to a skin specialist (dermatologist).
Treatment: Prevention of anal itching mainly involves a careful washing routine that keeps the area clean, cool and dry, while avoiding further irritating the skin. If one already have anal itching, try these self-care measures: Cleanse gently. If one has fecal incontinence or diarrhea, clean the area around the anus with moist cotton balls or a squirt bottle of plain water. One may find some relief by applying a moist, room-temperature compress to the area or taking a lukewarm oatmeal bath. Cut back on or avoid coffee, cola, alcohol, citrus fruits, chocolate, spicy foods, tomatoes and foods that may cause diarrhea. Protect the affected skin from moisture by applying a thin layer of a zinc oxide ointment (Desitin, Balmex) or petroleum jelly (Vaseline). If soft stools or frequent bowel movements are a problem, gradually adding fiber to the diet may help.
Remedies: Prevention of anal itching mainly involves a careful washing routine that keeps the area clean, cool and dry, while avoiding further irritating the skin. If one has fecal incontinence or diarrhea, clean the area around the anus with moist cotton balls or a squirt bottle of plain water. One may find some relief by applying a moist, room-temperature compress to the area or taking a lukewarm oatmeal bath. Cut back on or avoid coffee, cola, alcohol, citrus fruits, chocolate, spicy foods, tomatoes and foods that may cause diarrhea. Protect the affected skin from moisture by applying a thin layer of a zinc oxide ointment (Desitin, Balmex) or petroleum jelly (Vaseline). If soft stools or frequent bowel movements are a problem, gradually adding fiber to the diet may help.

Name: Rectal prolapse
Overview: Rectal prolapse occurs when the rectum becomes stretched out and protrudes from the anus. Rectal prolapse occurs when part of the large intestine's lowest section (rectum) slips outside the muscular opening at the end of the digestive tract (anus).
Treatment: Overview of rectal procidentia (rectal prolapse). Evaluation, diagnosis, and medical management of rectal prolapse. Surgical approach to rectal procidentia (rectal prolapse). Kronfol R. Overview of rectal prolapse in children.

Name: Rectovaginal fistula
Causes: These types of fistulas may also involve injury to the anal sphincter, the rings of muscle at the end of the rectum that help one hold in stool. The second most common cause of rectovaginal fistulas, Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease in which the digestive tract lining is inflamed. Most women with Crohn's disease never develop a rectovaginal fistula, but having Crohn's disease does increase the risk of the condition. A cancerous tumor in the rectum, cervix, vagina, uterus or anal canal can result in a rectovaginal fistula. Prior surgery in the lower pelvic region, such as removal of the uterus (hysterectomy), in rare cases can lead to development of a fistula.
Diagnosis: The doctor will perform a physical exam to try to locate the rectovaginal fistula and check for a possible tumor mass, infection or abscess. The doctor's exam includes inspecting the vagina, anus and the area between them (perineum) with a gloved hand. Unless the fistula is very low in the vagina and readily visible, the doctor may use a speculum to see inside the vagina. During the procedure, the doctor can take small samples of tissue (biopsy) for lab analysis, which can help confirm Crohn's disease. Barium enema Colonoscopy Computerized tomography (CT) urogram CT scan MRI Needle biopsy Contrast tests.
Remedies: Other home remedies for people living with a rectovaginal fistula include For best results, be sure to follow any other recommendations from the health care team. Soap can dry and irritate the skin, but one may need a gentle unscented soap in moderation. Allow the area to air-dry after washing, or gently pat the area dry with a clean cloth or towel. Products such as absorbent pads, disposable underwear or adult diapers can help if one is passing liquid or stool, but be sure they have an absorbent wicking layer on top.
info-Diagnostic method: â€¢ No anal opening â€¢ A gloved finger or thermometer cannot be inserted into the infants rectum â€¢ No history of passage of meconium â€¢ Presence of abdominal distension â€¢ Presence of meconium in urine

Name: Recurrent breast cancer
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms include After the breast cancer treatment ends, the doctor will likely create a schedule of follow-up exams for one. During follow-up exams, the doctor checks for any symptoms or signs of cancer recurrence.
Risk factors: For breast cancer survivors, factors that increase the risk of a recurrence include Positive or close tumor margins. If any part of the border has cancer cells (positive margin), or the margin between the tumor and normal tissue is close, the risk of breast cancer recurrence is increased. Most people who choose a lumpectomy (wide local excision) for breast cancer undergo breast radiation therapy to reduce the risk of recurrence. Those who don't undergo the radiation therapy have an increased risk of local breast cancer recurrence. Younger people, particularly those under age 35 at the time of their original breast cancer diagnosis, face a higher risk of recurrent breast cancer. People with inflammatory breast cancer have a higher risk of local recurrence. In people who have a certain type of breast cancer, not receiving endocrine therapy can raise their risk of recurrence. If the breast cancer wasn't responsive to hormone therapy or treatments directed at the HER2 gene (triple negative breast cancer), one may have an increased risk of breast cancer recurrence.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects one may have recurrent breast cancer based on results of a mammogram or physical exam, or because of signs and symptoms, he or she may recommend additional tests to confirm the diagnosis. Imaging tests may include magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), computerized tomography (CT), X-ray, bone scan or positron emission tomography (PET). The doctor may recommend a biopsy procedure to collect suspicious cells for testing, as this is the only way to confirm whether the cancer has returned. Tests also show whether the cancer is sensitive to hormone treatment or targeted therapy, since these may have changed since the original cancer diagnosis.

Name: Reflux , bile
Overview: Bile reflux occurs when bile a digestive liquid produced in the liver backs up (refluxes) into the stomach and, in some cases, into the tube that connects the mouth and stomach (esophagus). Bile reflux may accompany the reflux (backwash) of stomach acid (gastric acid) into the esophagus. Gastric reflux may lead to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), a potentially serious problem that causes irritation and inflammation of esophageal tissue (esophagitis).
Causes: Acid reflux occurs when the sphincter muscle at the lower end of the esophagus relaxes at the wrong time, allowing stomach acid to back up into the esophagus. Bile and food mix in the duodenum and enter the small intestine through the pyloric valve, a heavy ring of muscle located at the outlet of the stomach. In many cases of bile reflux, the valve doesn't close properly, and bile washes back into the stomach. Bile and stomach acid can reflux into the esophagus when another muscular valve, the lower esophageal sphincter, malfunctions. Gastric surgery, including total removal of the stomach (gastrectomy) and gastric bypass surgery for weight loss, is responsible for most bile reflux. Stagnant food in the stomach can lead to increased gastric pressure and allow bile and stomach acid to back up into the esophagus.
Diagnosis: These tests use an acid-measuring probe to identify when, and for how long, acid refluxes into the esophagus. In one test, a thin, flexible tube (catheter) with a probe at the end is threaded through the nose into the esophagus. In another test (the Bravo test), the probe is attached to the lower portion of the esophagus during endoscopy. As in a standard probe test, esophageal impedance uses a probe that's placed into the esophagus with a catheter.
Remedies: Unlike acid reflux, bile reflux seems unrelated to lifestyle factors. But because many people experience both acid reflux and bile reflux, the symptoms may be eased by lifestyle changes: Stop smoking. Smoking increases the production of stomach acid and dries up saliva, which helps protect the esophagus. Eating smaller, more-frequent meals reduces pressure on the lower esophageal sphincter, helping to prevent the valve from opening at the wrong time. Some foods increase the production of stomach acid and may relax the lower esophageal sphincter. Among the foods with this effect are caffeinated and carbonated drinks, chocolate, citrus foods and juices, vinegar-based dressings, onions, tomato-based foods, spicy foods and mint.
Medication: Bile acid sequestrants.Doctors often prescribe bile acid sequestrants, which disrupt the circulation of bile, but studies show that these drugs are less effective than other treatments. Proton pump inhibitors.These medications are often prescribed to block acid production, but they don't have a clear role in treating bile reflux. In Roux-en-Y, surgeons make a new connection for bile drainage farther down in the small intestine, diverting bile away from the stomach.

Name: Reflux , gastroesophageal
Overview: Acid reflux occurs when the sphincter muscle at the lower end of the esophagus relaxes at the wrong time, allowing stomach acid to back up into the esophagus. Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) occurs when stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting the mouth and stomach (esophagus).
Causes: If the sphincter relaxes abnormally or weakens, stomach acid can flow back up into the esophagus. This constant backwash of acid irritates the lining of the esophagus, often causing it to become inflamed.
Diagnosis: Endoscopy involves inserting a long, flexible tube (endoscope) down the throat and into the esophagus. A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). The doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube equipped with a light and camera (endoscope) down the throat, to examine the inside of the esophagus and stomach. Test results can often be normal when reflux is present, but an endoscopy may detect inflammation of the esophagus (esophagitis) or other complications. The monitor might be a thin, flexible tube (catheter) that's threaded through the nose into the esophagus, or a clip that's placed in the esophagus during an endoscopy and that gets passed into the stool after about two days.
Remedies: Excess pounds put pressure on the abdomen, pushing up the stomach and causing acid to reflux into the esophagus. If one regularly experience heartburn while trying to sleep, place wood or cement blocks under the feet of the bed so that the head end is raised by 6 to 9 inches. If one can't elevate the bed, one can insert a wedge between the mattress and box spring to elevate the body from the waist up. Common triggers include fatty or fried foods, tomato sauce, alcohol, chocolate, mint, garlic, onion, and caffeine.

Name: Regurgitation , aortic valve
Overview: In aortic valve regurgitation, the aortic valve doesn't close properly, causing blood to leak backward from the aorta into the left ventricle. Aortic valve regurgitation allows some of the blood that was pumped out of the heart's main pumping chamber (left ventricle) to leak back into it.
Causes: Sometimes, the valves don't open or close properly, disrupting the blood flow through the heart and potentially impairing the ability to pump blood to the body. In some cases a valve may only have one cusp (unicuspid) or four cusps (quadricuspid), but this is less common. Other rare conditions can enlarge the aorta and aortic valve and lead to regurgitation, including Marfan syndrome, a connective tissue disease.
Diagnosis: To diagnose aortic valve regurgitation, the doctor may review the signs and symptoms, discuss the and the family's medical history, and conduct a physical examination. The doctor may listen to the heart with a stethoscope to determine if one has a heart murmur that may indicate an aortic valve condition. The doctor may order several tests to diagnose the condition, and determine the cause and severity of the condition. It can help doctors determine the cause and severity of the condition, and see if one has additional heart valve conditions. This test isn't often used to diagnose aortic valve regurgitation, but it may be used if other tests aren't able to diagnose the condition or determine its severity. Doctors may also conduct cardiac catheterization prior to valve replacement surgery to see if there are obstructions in the coronary arteries, so they can be fixed at the time of the valve surgery. In cardiac catheterization, a doctor threads a thin tube (catheter) through a blood vessel in the arm or groin to an artery in the heart and injects dye through the catheter to make the artery visible on an X-ray. Exercise tests help doctors see whether one has signs and symptoms of aortic valve disease during physical activity, and these tests can help determine the severity of the condition.
Remedies: While lifestyle changes can't prevent or treat the condition, the doctor might suggest that one incorporate several heart-healthy lifestyle changes into the life. These may include For women with aortic valve regurgitation, it's important to talk with the doctor before one become pregnant. The doctor can discuss with one which medications one can safely take, and whether one may need a procedure to treat the valve condition prior to pregnancy. If one is overweight or obese, the doctor may recommend that one lose weight. If one is taking blood pressure medication, ensure one take it as the doctor has prescribed.

Name: Regurgitation , mitral valve
Overview: Mitral valve regurgitation also called mitral regurgitation, mitral insufficiency or mitral incompetence is a condition in which the heart's mitral valve doesn't close tightly, allowing blood to flow backward in the heart. Left untreated, severe mitral valve regurgitation can cause heart failure or heart rhythm problems (arrhythmias).
Causes: Sometimes, the valves don't open or close properly, disrupting the blood flow through the heart to the body. The mitral valve separates the two chambers (atrium and ventricle) of the left side of the heart. In mitral valve prolapse, the leaflets of the mitral valve bulge (prolapse) into the left atrium like a parachute during the heart's contraction. Sometimes mitral valve prolapse causes blood to leak back into the atrium from the ventricle, which is called mitral valve regurgitation. Mitral valve regurgitation can be caused by problems with the mitral valve, also called primary mitral valve regurgitation. In this condition, the mitral valve's leaflets bulge back into the left atrium during the heart's contraction. This common heart defect can prevent the mitral valve from closing tightly and lead to regurgitation. Rheumatic fever a complication of untreated strep throat can damage the mitral valve, leading to mitral valve regurgitation early or later in life. The mitral valve may be damaged by an infection of the lining of the heart (endocarditis) that can involve heart valves. A heart attack can damage the area of the heart muscle that supports the mitral valve, affecting the function of the valve. If the damage is extensive enough, a heart attack can cause sudden and severe mitral valve regurgitation. Experiencing trauma, such as in a car accident, can lead to mitral valve regurgitation. In rare cases, radiation therapy for cancer that is focused on the chest area can lead to mitral valve regurgitation. Atrial fibrillation is a common heart rhythm problem that can be a potential cause of mitral valve regurgitation.
Risk factors: Several factors can increase the risk of mitral valve regurgitation, including A history of mitral valve prolapse or mitral valve stenosis. However, having either condition doesn't necessarily mean one will develop mitral valve regurgitation. A heart attack can damage the heart, affecting the function of the mitral valve. Certain forms of heart disease, such as coronary artery disease, can lead to mitral valve regurgitation. People who take drugs containing ergotamine (Cafergot, Migergot) and similar medicines for migraines or who take cabergoline have an increased risk of mitral regurgitation. By middle age, many people have some mitral valve regurgitation caused by natural deterioration of the valve.
Diagnosis: Mitral valve regurgitation usually produces a sound of blood leaking backward through the mitral valve (heart murmur). In this test, sound waves directed at the heart from a wandlike device (transducer) held on the chest produce video images of the heart in motion. This test assesses the structure of the heart, the mitral valve and the blood flow through the heart. In this test, a small transducer attached to the end of a tube is inserted down the esophagus, which allows a closer look at the mitral valve than a regular echocardiogram does. This test may be used to determine the severity of the condition and assess the size and function of the lower left heart chamber (left ventricle). Cardiac CT. A CT angiogram may be performed of the chest, abdomen and pelvis to determine whether one is a candidate for robotic mitral valve repair. This invasive technique involves threading a thin tube (catheter) through a blood vessel in the arm or groin to an artery in the heart and injecting dye through the catheter to make the artery visible on an X-ray.
Remedies: The doctor may suggest one incorporate several heart-healthy lifestyle changes into the life, including If one is a woman with mitral valve regurgitation, it's important to talk to the doctor before one become pregnant. If one has had a heart valve replaced, the doctor may recommend one take antibiotics before dental procedures to prevent an infection called infective endocarditis. Excessive alcohol use can also cause cardiomyopathy, a condition of weakened heart muscle that leads to mitral regurgitation. Ask the doctor for guidance before starting to exercise, especially if one is considering competitive sports.
Medication: Doctors may suggest mitral valve repair or replacement even if one isn't experiencing symptoms, as this may prevent complications and improve outcomes. If one need surgery for another heart condition, the doctor may repair or replace the diseased mitral valve at the same time. In some cases, doctors may conduct minimally invasive heart surgery, which involves the use of smaller incisions than those used in open-heart surgery. High blood pressure makes mitral valve regurgitation worse, so if one has high blood pressure, the doctor may prescribe medication to help lower it.

Name: Reiter 's syndrome
Symptoms: They might include If one develop joint pain within a month of having diarrhea or a genital infection, contact the doctor. The joint pain associated with reactive arthritis most commonly occurs in the knees, ankles and feet. Many people who have reactive arthritis also develop eye inflammation (conjunctivitis). Reactive arthritis can affect the skin a variety of ways, including a rash on the soles and palms and mouth sores.
Overview: Reactive arthritis is joint pain and swelling triggered by an infection in another part of the body most often the intestines, genitals or urinary tract. Previously, reactive arthritis was sometimes called Reiter's syndrome, which was characterized by eye, urethra and joint inflammation.
Risk factors: Women and men are equally likely to develop reactive arthritis in response to foodborne infections. However, men are more likely than are women to develop reactive arthritis in response to sexually transmitted bacteria.
Diagnosis: During the physical exam, the doctor is likely to check the joints for signs and symptoms of inflammation, such as swelling, warmth and tenderness, and test range of motion in the spine and affected joints. The doctor might recommend that a sample of the blood be tested for: The doctor might use a needle to withdraw a sample of fluid from within an affected joint. This fluid will be tested for: X-rays of the low back, pelvis and joints can indicate whether one has any of the characteristic signs of reactive arthritis. Evidence of past or current infection Signs of inflammation Antibodies associated with other types of arthritis A genetic marker linked to reactive arthritis White blood cell count. Bacteria in the joint fluid might indicate septic arthritis, which can result in severe joint damage.
Medication: If the reactive arthritis was triggered by a bacterial infection, the doctor might prescribe an antibiotic if there is evidence of persistent infection. Prescription NSAIDs, such as indomethacin (Indocin), can relieve the inflammation and pain of reactive arthritis. Limited evidence suggests that medications such as sulfasalazine (Azulfidine), methotrexate (Trexall) or etanercept (Enbrel) can relieve pain and stiffness for some people with reactive arthritis.

Name: REM sleep behavior disorder
Diagnosis: The evaluation may include To diagnose REM sleep behavior disorder, sleep medicine physicians typically use the symptom criteria in the International Classification of Sleep Disorders, Third Edition (ICSD-3). For a diagnosis of REM sleep behavior disorder, criteria include the following: REM sleep behavior disorder can be the first indication of development of a neurodegenerative disease, such as Parkinson's disease, multiple system atrophy or dementia with Lewy bodies. One has repeated times of arousal during sleep where one talk, make noises or perform complex motor behaviors, such as punching, kicking or running movements that often relate to the content of the dreams One recall dreams associated with these movements or sounds If one awaken during the episode, one is alert and not confused or disoriented A sleep study (polysomnogram) shows one has increased muscle activity during REM sleep The sleep disturbance is not caused by another sleep disturbance, a mental health disorder, medication or substance abuse Physical and neurological exam.
Medication: Examples of treatment options for REM sleep behavior disorder include Doctors continue to study several other medications that may treat REM sleep behavior disorder. This prescription medication, often used to treat anxiety, is also the traditional choice for treating REM sleep behavior disorder, appearing to effectively reduce symptoms.

Name: Renal artery stenosis
Diagnosis: For diagnosis of renal artery stenosis, the doctor may start with: Imaging tests commonly done to diagnose renal artery stenosis include A physical exam that includes the doctor listening through a stethoscope over the kidney areas for sounds that may mean the artery to the kidney is narrowed A review of the medical history Blood and urine tests to check the kidney function Blood and urine tests to measure the levels of hormones that regulate blood pressure Doppler ultrasound. Before an X-ray is taken, the doctor injects a dye into the renal arteries through a long, thin tube (catheter) to outline the arteries and show blood flow more clearly.
Remedies: As a part of the treatment plan for renal artery stenosis, the doctor may recommend making certain lifestyle changes: Maintain a healthy weight. If one is overweight, losing weight may help to lower the blood pressure. This may increase the volume of the blood and, in turn, increase the blood pressure. Being physically active on a regular basis may help one lose weight, lower the risk of heart disease, lower the cholesterol and lower the blood pressure. Check with the doctor before beginning an exercise program, especially if one has high blood pressure and haven't been active in the past.
info-Risk factors: Smoking, High blood pressure

Name: Renal cancer
Risk factors: People who are obese have a higher risk of kidney cancer than people who are considered to have a healthy weight. High blood pressure increases the risk of kidney cancer. People who receive long-term dialysis to treat chronic kidney failure have a greater risk of developing kidney cancer. People who are born with certain inherited syndromes may have an increased risk of kidney cancer, such as those who have von Hippel-Lindau disease, Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome, tuberous sclerosis complex, hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma or familial renal cancer. The risk of kidney cancer is higher if close family members have had the disease.
Diagnosis: The tumor is larger than 2 3/4 inches (7 centimeters) in diameter, but it's still confined to the kidney. Cancer spreads outside the kidney, to multiple lymph nodes or to distant parts of the body, such as the bones, liver or lungs. Tests and procedures used to diagnose kidney cancer include Once the doctor identifies a kidney lesion that might be kidney cancer, the next step is to determine the extent (stage) of the cancer. Staging tests for kidney cancer may include additional CT scans or other imaging tests the doctor feels are appropriate. In some situations, the doctor may recommend a procedure to remove a small sample of cells (biopsy) from a suspicious area of the kidney.
info-Symptoms: Blood in the urine, lump in the abdomen, back pain
info-Risk factors: Smoking, certain pain medications, previous bladder cancer, being overweight, high blood pressure, certain chemicals, family history
info-Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy, targeted therapy

Name: Renal failure , acute
Overview: Blood enters the kidneys through the renal arteries. Acute kidney failure occurs when the kidneys suddenly become unable to filter waste products from the blood. When the kidneys lose their filtering ability, dangerous levels of wastes may accumulate, and the blood's chemical makeup may get out of balance. Acute kidney failure also called acute renal failure or acute kidney injury develops rapidly, usually in less than a few days.
Diagnosis: During a kidney biopsy, the doctor uses a needle to remove a small sample of kidney tissue for lab testing. If the signs and symptoms suggest that one has acute kidney failure, the doctor may recommend certain tests and procedures to verify the diagnosis. In some situations, the doctor may recommend a kidney biopsy to remove a small sample of kidney tissue for lab testing.
Remedies: During the recovery from acute kidney failure, the doctor may recommend a special diet to help support the kidneys and limit the work they must do. Depending on the situation, the dietitian may recommend that one: As the kidneys recover, one may no longer need to eat a special diet, although healthy eating remains important. Lower the amount of sodium one eat each day by avoiding products with added salt, including many convenience foods, such as frozen dinners, canned soups and fast foods. Other foods with added salt include salty snack foods, canned vegetables, and processed meats and cheeses.

Name: Residual limb pain
Remedies: One may not have control over whether one develop phantom pain after surgery, but one can reduce the discomfort and improve the quality of life. One or more of these approaches may help one get through a flare-up of phantom pain: Remember that managing phantom pain can make a big difference in how one feel. Find activities that take the focus off the pain, such as reading or listening to music. Take a warm bath not too hot, as heat may aggravate the pain.
Medication: Although no medications specifically for phantom pain exist, some drugs designed to treat other conditions have been helpful in relieving nerve pain. Taken in appropriate doses under the doctor's direction, they may help control phantom pain. In studies, NMDA receptor antagonists ketamine and dextromethorphan helped relieve phantom pain. Some studies, though not all, have found that this exercise may help relieve phantom pain. Research suggests that this therapy may be helpful for phantom pain, though it isn't yet specifically approved for this condition. Although this technique has been tested only on a small number of people, it appears to help relieve phantom pain. Acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve) might relieve phantom pain. Epilepsy drugs such as gabapentin (Gralise, Neurontin) and pregabalin (Lyrica) may be used to treat nerve pain. Although the data are still limited and these treatments aren't specifically approved for phantom pain, brain stimulation appears to be a promising option in selected individuals.

Name: Retinal detachment
Symptoms: And that can cause blindness, which is why it's especially important to have a dilated eye exam within days of noticing new floaters or changes in vision. Most eye floaters don't require treatment, but the eye doctor likely will recommend regular eye exams to ensure the condition doesn't worsen.
Overview: Retinal detachment describes an emergency situation in which a thin layer of tissue (the retina) at the back of the eye pulls away from the layer of blood vessels that provides it with oxygen and nutrients. Retinal detachment describes an emergency situation in which a thin layer of tissue (the retina) at the back of the eye pulls away from its normal position.
Causes: There are three different types of retinal detachment: Rhegmatogenous (reg-ma-TODGE-uh-nus). Normally, the vitreous separates from the surface of the retina without any complications a common condition called posterior vitreous detachment (PVD). As the vitreous separates or peels off the retina, it may tug on the retina with enough force to create a retinal tear. Left untreated, the liquid vitreous can pass through the tear into the space behind the retina, causing the retina to become detached. This type of detachment can occur when scar tissue grows on the retina's surface, causing the retina to pull away from the back of the eye. In this type of detachment, fluid accumulates beneath the retina, but there are no holes or tears in the retina.
Diagnosis: The doctor may use the following tests, instruments and procedures to diagnose retinal detachment: The doctor will likely examine both eyes even if one has symptoms in just one. If a tear is not identified at this visit, the doctor may ask one to return within a few weeks to confirm that the eye has not developed a delayed tear as a result of the same vitreous separation. The doctor may use an instrument with a bright light and special lenses to examine the back of the eye, including the retina. This type of device provides a highly detailed view of the whole eye, allowing the doctor to see any retinal holes, tears or detachments.

Name: Retinal diseases
Overview: The eye is a complex and compact structure measuring about 1 inch (2.5 centimeters) in diameter. Retinal diseases vary widely, but most of them cause visual symptoms. Retinal diseases can affect any part of the retina, a thin layer of tissue on the inside back wall of the eye. Untreated, some retinal diseases can cause severe vision loss or blindness. A retinal tear occurs when the clear, gel-like substance in the center of the eye (vitreous) shrinks and tugs on the thin layer of tissue lining the back of the eye (retina) with enough traction to cause a break in the tissue. This usually occurs when fluid passes through a retinal tear, causing the retina to lift away from the underlying tissue layers. If one has diabetes, the tiny blood vessels (capillaries) in the back of the eye can deteriorate and leak fluid into and under the retina.
Diagnosis: He or she will ask one if the lines of the grid seem faded, broken or distorted and will note where the distortion occurs on the grid to better understand the extent of retinal damage. This test is an excellent technique for capturing precise images of the retina to diagnose epiretinal membranes, macular holes and macular swelling (edema), to monitor the extent of age-related wet macular degeneration, and to monitor responses to treatment. FAF may be used to determine the advancement of retinal diseases, including macular degeneration. This helps to exactly identify closed blood vessels, leaking blood vessels, new abnormal blood vessels and subtle changes in the back of the eye. The resulting images show retinal blood vessels and the deeper, harder-to-see blood vessels behind the retina in a tissue called the choroid. This test uses high-frequency sound waves (ultrasonography) to help view the retina and other structures in the eye.

Name: Retinoblastoma
Causes: In the majority of cases, it's not clear what causes the genetic mutations that lead to retinoblastoma. Although a genetic mutation increases a child's risk of retinoblastoma, it doesn't mean that cancer is inevitable.
Diagnosis: Scans and other imaging tests can help the child's doctor determine whether retinoblastoma has grown to affect other structures around the eye. Imaging tests may include ultrasound, computerized tomography (CT) scan and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), among others. The child's doctor may refer one to other specialists, such as a doctor who specializes in treating cancer (oncologist), a genetic counselor or a surgeon.

Name: Retinopathy , diabetic
Causes: In the early stages of diabetic retinopathy, the walls of the blood vessels in the retina weaken. As diabetic retinopathy progresses, new blood vessels may grow and threaten the vision. In this more common form called nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR) new blood vessels aren't growing (proliferating). Tiny bulges (microaneurysms) protrude from the vessel walls of the smaller vessels, sometimes leaking fluid and blood into the retina. Eventually, scar tissue stimulated by the growth of new blood vessels may cause the retina to detach from the back of the eye.
Diagnosis: For this exam, drops placed in the eyes widen (dilate) the pupils to allow the doctor to better view inside the eyes. During the exam, the eye doctor will look for: In addition, the eye doctor may: With the eyes dilated, the doctor takes pictures of the inside of the eyes. Abnormal blood vessels Swelling, blood or fatty deposits in the retina Growth of new blood vessels and scar tissue Bleeding in the clear, jelly-like substance that fills the center of the eye (vitreous) Retinal detachment Abnormalities in the optic nerve Test the vision Measure the eye pressure to test for glaucoma Look for evidence of cataracts Eye exam

Name: Retrograde ejaculation
Diagnosis: The doctor will: If one has dry orgasms, but the doctor doesn't find semen in the bladder, one might have a problem with semen production. If the doctor suspects the dry orgasm is something other than retrograde ejaculation, one might need further tests or a referral to a specialist to find the cause. The doctor might also ask about any health problems, surgeries or cancers one has had and what medications one take. The doctor will ask one to empty the bladder, masturbate to climax and then provide a urine sample for laboratory analysis.
Medication: Drugs to treat retrograde ejaculation are drugs primarily used to treat other conditions, including These medications help keep the bladder neck muscle closed during ejaculation. Certain medications used to treat retrograde ejaculation can increase the blood pressure and heart rate, which can be dangerous if one has high blood pressure or heart disease.

Name: Rett syndrome
Symptoms: Rett syndrome signs and symptoms include Rett syndrome is commonly divided into four stages: Signs and symptoms of Rett syndrome can be subtle in the early stages. See the child's doctor right away if one begin to notice physical problems or changes in behavior after apparently normal development, such as: Slowed growth. Children with Rett syndrome typically begin to lose the ability to speak, to make eye contact and to communicate in other ways. Over time, children may gradually regain eye contact and develop nonverbal communication skills. Children with Rett syndrome typically develop repetitive, purposeless hand movements that may differ for each person. Hand movements may include hand-wringing, squeezing, clapping, tapping or rubbing. Children with Rett syndrome tend to have unusual eye movements, such as intense staring, blinking, crossed eyes or closing one eye at a time. These include breath-holding, abnormally rapid breathing (hyperventilation), forceful exhalation of air or saliva, and swallowing air. Periods of crying or screaming may begin suddenly, for no apparent reason, and last for hours. These may include, for example, sudden, odd facial expressions and long bouts of laughter, hand licking, and grasping of hair or clothing. Abnormal sleep patterns can include irregular sleep times, falling asleep during the day and being awake at night, or waking in the night with crying or screaming. Starting between 1 and 4 years of age, children lose the ability to perform skills they previously had. Although problems with movement continue, behavior may have limited improvement, with less crying and irritability, and some improvement in hand use and communication. Understanding, communication and hand skills generally remain stable or improve slightly, and seizures may occur less often.
Overview: Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurological and developmental disorder that affects the way the brain develops, causing a progressive loss of motor skills and speech. Most babies with Rett syndrome seem to develop normally for the first 6 to 18 months of age, and then lose skills they previously had such as the ability to crawl, walk, communicate or use their hands. Current treatment focuses on improving movement and communication, treating seizures, and providing care and support for children and adults with Rett syndrome and their families.
Causes: Classic Rett syndrome, as well as several variants with milder or more-severe symptoms, can occur based on the specific genetic mutation. Because males have a different chromosome combination from females, boys who have the genetic mutation that causes Rett syndrome are affected in devastating ways. Similar to girls with Rett syndrome, these boys will likely live to adulthood, but they're still at risk of a number of intellectual and developmental problems.
Diagnosis: If the child's doctor suspects Rett syndrome after evaluation, he or she may recommend a genetic test (DNA analysis) to confirm the diagnosis. Other genetic disorders Autism Cerebral palsy Hearing or vision problems Metabolic disorders, such as phenylketonuria (PKU) Disorders that cause the brain or body to break down (degenerative disorders) Brain disorders caused by trauma or infection Brain damage before birth (prenatal) Blood tests Urine tests Imaging tests such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or computerized tomography (CT) scans Hearing tests Eye and vision exams Brain activity tests (electroencephalograms, also called EEGs) Partial or complete loss of purposeful hand skills Partial or complete loss of spoken language Walking abnormalities, such as problems walking or not being able to walk Repetitive purposeless hand movements, such as hand-wringing, squeezing, clapping or tapping, putting hands in the mouth, or washing and rubbing movements CT scan EEG (electroencephalogram) Eye exam Genetic testing MRI Urinalysis
Treatment: Although there is no cure for Rett syndrome, treatments are directed toward symptoms and providing support, which may improve the potential for movement, communication and social participation. Treatments that can help children and adults with Rett syndrome include A few examples of complementary therapies that have been tried in children with Rett syndrome include Although there's not much evidence that these approaches are effective, they may offer opportunities for increased movement and social and recreational enrichment. If one think alternative or complementary therapies might help the child, talk to the doctor or therapist about the possible benefits and risks, and how the approach might fit into the medical treatment plan. Children and adults with Rett syndrome need help with most daily tasks, such as eating, walking and using the bathroom. Though medications can't cure Rett syndrome, they may help control some signs and symptoms associated with the disorder, such as seizures, muscle stiffness, or problems with breathing, sleep, the gastrointestinal tract or the heart. In some cases, physical therapy can also help maintain movement, create a proper sitting position, and improve walking skills, balance and flexibility. If repetitive arm and hand movements are a problem, splints that restrict elbow or wrist motion may be helpful. Academic, social and job-training services may help with integration into school, work and social activities.
info-Symptoms: Impairments in language and coordination, and repetitive movements, slower growth, smaller head
info-Prognosis: Life expectancy for many is middle age.

Name: Reye 's syndrome
Overview: Reye's (Reye) syndrome is a rare but serious condition that causes swelling in the liver and brain. Aspirin has been linked with Reye's syndrome, so use caution when giving aspirin to children or teenagers for fever or pain. For the treatment of fever or pain, consider giving the child infants or children's over-the-counter fever and pain medications such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin, others) as a safer alternative to aspirin.
Diagnosis: During a lumbar puncture (spinal tap) procedure, one typically lie on the side with the knees drawn up to the chest. A spinal tap can help the doctor identify or rule out other diseases with similar signs and symptoms, such as infection of the lining that surrounds the brain and spinal cord (meningitis) or inflammation or infection of the brain (encephalitis). During a skin biopsy, a doctor takes a small skin sample (biopsy) for analysis in a lab. CT scan Liver biopsy Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) MRI Skin biopsy Urinalysis Spinal tap (lumbar puncture).
Treatment: Specific treatment may include If the child has trouble breathing, he or she may need assistance from a breathing machine (ventilator). Reye's syndrome is often diagnosed in an emergency situation because of serious signs and symptoms, such as seizures or loss of consciousness.

Name: Rhabdomyosarcoma
Overview: Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is a rare type of cancer that forms in soft tissue specifically skeletal muscle tissue or sometimes hollow organs such as the bladder or uterus. Although RMS can arise anywhere in the body, it's more likely to start in the: The outlook (prognosis) and treatment decisions depend on the type of rhabdomyosarcoma, where it starts, tumor size and whether the cancer has spread.
Diagnosis: Imaging tests may include A biopsy procedure is used to collect a sample of suspicious cells for laboratory testing. Types of biopsy procedures used to diagnose rhabdomyosarcoma include Determining the type of biopsy needed and the specifics of how it should be performed requires careful planning by the medical team. X-ray Computerized tomography (CT) Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) Positron emission tomography (PET) Bone scan Needle biopsy. The doctor makes an incision through the skin and removes either the entire tumor (excisional biopsy) or a portion of the tumor (incisional biopsy).

Name: Rheumatic fever
Treatment: The goals of treatment for rheumatic fever are to destroy remaining group A streptococcal bacteria, relieve symptoms, control inflammation and prevent the condition from returning. After the child has completed the full antibiotic treatment, the doctor will begin another course of antibiotics to prevent recurrence of rheumatic fever. The doctor will prescribe a pain reliever, such as aspirin or naproxen (Naprosyn, Naprelan, Anaprox DS), to reduce inflammation, fever and pain. For severe involuntary movements caused by Sydenham chorea, the doctor might prescribe antiseizure medications, such as valproic acid (Depakene) or carbamazepine (Carbatrol, Tegretol, others).
info-Symptoms: Fever, multiple painful joints, involuntary muscle movements, erythema marginatum
info-Usual onset: 2â€“4 weeks after a streptococcal throat infection, age 5-14 years
info-Causes: Autoimmune disease triggered by Streptococcus pyogenes
info-Risk factors: Genetics, malnutrition, poverty
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and infection history
info-Prevention: Antibiotics for strep throat, improved sanitation
info-Treatment: Prolonged periods of antibiotics, valve replacement surgery, valve repair

Name: Rheumatoid arthritis
Overview: Rheumatoid arthritis can cause pain, swelling and deformity. Unlike the wear-and-tear damage of osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis affects the lining of the joints, causing a painful swelling that can eventually result in bone erosion and joint deformity.
Causes: Osteoarthritis, the most common form of arthritis, involves the wearing away of the cartilage that caps the bones in the joints. With rheumatoid arthritis, the synovial membrane that protects and lubricates joints becomes inflamed, causing pain and swelling.
Risk factors: If a member of the family has rheumatoid arthritis, one may have an increased risk of the disease. Cigarette smoking increases the risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis, particularly if one has a genetic predisposition for developing the disease. Although poorly understood, some exposures such as asbestos or silica may increase the risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis. Emergency workers exposed to dust from the collapse of the World Trade Center are at higher risk of autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis. People especially women age 55 and younger who are overweight or obese appear to be at a somewhat higher risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis.
Remedies: These self-care measures, when used along with the rheumatoid arthritis medications, can help one manage the signs and symptoms: Exercise regularly. Gentle exercise can help strengthen the muscles around the joints, and it can help fight fatigue one might feel. Heat can help ease the pain and relax tense, painful muscles. Rheumatoid arthritis and exercise Rheumatoid arthritis pain: Tips for protecting the joints Rheumatoid arthritis diet Exercise regularly.
Medication: Common DMARDs include methotrexate (Trexall, Otrexup, others), leflunomide (Arava), hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil) and sulfasalazine (Azulfidine). Side effects vary but may include liver damage, bone marrow suppression and severe lung infections. Also known as biologic response modifiers, this newer class of DMARDs includes abatacept (Orencia), adalimumab (Humira), anakinra (Kineret), baricitinib (Olumiant), certolizumab (Cimzia), etanercept (Enbrel), golimumab (Simponi), infliximab (Remicade), rituximab (Rituxan), sarilumab (Kevzara), tocilizumab (Actemra) and tofacitinib (Xeljanz). The therapist may also suggest new ways to do daily tasks, which will be easier on the joints. If medications fail to prevent or slow joint damage, one and the doctor may consider surgery to repair damaged joints. Rheumatoid arthritis surgery may involve one or more of the following procedures: Surgery carries a risk of bleeding, infection and pain. Over-the-counter NSAIDs include ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB) and naproxen sodium (Aleve). Corticosteroid medications, such as prednisone, reduce inflammation and pain and slow joint damage. Surgery to remove the inflamed lining of the joint (synovium) can be performed on knees, elbows, wrists, fingers and hips. During joint replacement surgery, the surgeon removes the damaged parts of the joint and inserts a prosthesis made of metal and plastic.
info-Symptoms: Warm, swollen, painful joints
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, medical imaging, blood tests
info-Medication: Pain medications, steroids, Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs

Name: Rib fracture
Risk factors: Playing contact sports, such as hockey or football, increases the risk of trauma to the chest. A cancerous lesion can weaken the bone, making it more susceptible to breaks.
info-Symptoms: Chest pain that is worse with breathing in

Name: Rickets
Overview: Rickets is the softening and weakening of bones in children, usually because of an extreme and prolonged vitamin D deficiency. Not enough vitamin D makes it difficult to maintain proper calcium and phosphorus levels in bones, which can cause rickets.
Causes: The child's body needs vitamin D to absorb calcium and phosphorus from food. Rickets can occur if the child's body doesn't get enough vitamin D or if his or her body has problems using vitamin D properly. They're also more likely to use sunscreen, which blocks the sun's rays that trigger the skin's production of vitamin D. Food.
Risk factors: Dark skin has more of the pigment melanin, which lowers the skin's ability to produce vitamin D from sunlight. A baby born to a mother with severe vitamin D deficiency can be born with signs of rickets or develop them within a few months after birth. Babies born before their due dates tend have lower levels of vitamin D because they had less time to receive the vitamin from their mothers in the womb. Certain types of anti-seizure medications and antiretroviral medications, used to treat HIV infections, appear to interfere with the body's ability to use vitamin D. Exclusive breast-feeding.
Diagnosis: During the exam, the doctor will gently press on the child's bones, checking for abnormalities. Babies who have rickets often have softer skull bones and might have a delay in the closure of the soft spots (fontanels). Some children with rickets develop abnormalities in their rib cages, which can flatten and cause their breastbones to protrude.
info-Symptoms: Bowed legs, stunted growth, bone pain, large forehead, trouble sleeping
info-Causes: Diet without enough vitamin D or calcium, too little sun exposure, exclusive breastfeeding without supplementation, celiac disease, certain genetic conditions
info-Prevention: Vitamin D supplements for exclusively-breastfed babies

Name: RLS
Symptoms: Common accompanying characteristics of RLS include People typically describe RLS symptoms as abnormal, unpleasant sensations in their legs or feet. The sensations, which generally occur within the limb rather than on the skin, are described as: Sometimes the sensations are difficult to explain. The sensation typically begins after one has been lying down or sitting for an extended time, such as in a car, airplane or movie theater. The sensation of RLS lessens with movement, such as stretching, jiggling the legs, pacing or walking.
Overview: Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is a condition that causes an uncontrollable urge to move the legs, usually because of an uncomfortable sensation. Restless legs syndrome, also known as Willis-Ekbom disease, can begin at any age and generally worsens as one age.
Risk factors: Even without anemia, iron deficiency can cause or worsen RLS. If one has a history of bleeding from the stomach or bowels, experience heavy menstrual periods, or repeatedly donate blood, one may have iron deficiency. If one has kidney failure, one may also have iron deficiency, often with anemia. Having had anesthesia to the spinal cord, such as a spinal block, also increases the risk of developing RLS.
Diagnosis: A diagnosis of RLS is based on the following criteria, established by the International Restless Legs Syndrome Study Group: The doctor may conduct a physical and a neurological exam. This may involve an overnight stay at a sleep clinic, where doctors can study the sleep if another sleep disorder such as sleep apnea is suspected.
Remedies: Fatigue tends to worsen symptoms of RLS, so it's important that one practice good sleep hygiene. Ideally, have a cool, quiet, comfortable sleeping environment; go to bed and rise at the same time daily; and get at least seven hours of sleep nightly. Try to avoid caffeine-containing products, including chocolate, coffee, tea and soft drinks, for a few weeks to see if this helps.
Medication: Ropinirole (Requip), rotigotine (Neupro) and pramipexole (Mirapex) are approved by the Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of moderate to severe RLS. Sometimes dopamine medications that have worked for a while to relieve the RLS become ineffective, or one notice the symptoms returning earlier in the day or involving the arms. However, if one need to take these medications, talk to the doctor about adding drugs to help manage the RLS. Certain medications, such as gabapentin (Neurontin, Gralise), gabapentin enacarbil (Horizant) and pregabalin (Lyrica), work for some people with RLS. Narcotic medications can relieve mild to severe symptoms, but they may be addicting if used in high doses.

Name: Road rage
Causes: Intermittent explosive disorder can begin in childhood after the age of 6 years or during the teenage years. The exact cause of the disorder is unknown, but it's probably caused by a number of environmental and biological factors. Most people with this disorder grew up in families where explosive behavior and verbal and physical abuse were common. There may be differences in the structure, function and chemistry of the brain in people with intermittent explosive disorder compared to people who don't have the disorder.
Diagnosis: To determine a diagnosis of intermittent explosive disorder and eliminate other physical conditions or mental health disorders that may be causing the symptoms, the doctor will likely: Do a physical exam. The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association, is often used by mental health professionals to diagnose mental conditions.

Name: Rocky Mountain spotted fever
Symptoms: The red, nonitchy rash associated with Rocky Mountain spotted fever typically appears three to five days after the initial signs and symptoms begin. Some people who are infected with Rocky Mountain spotted fever don't ever develop a rash, which makes diagnosis much more difficult.
Overview: Rocky Mountain spotted fever is a bacterial infection transmitted by a tick. Without prompt treatment, Rocky Mountain spotted fever can cause serious damage to internal organs, such as the kidneys and heart. Although it was first identified in the Rocky Mountains, Rocky Mountain spotted fever is most commonly found in the southeastern part of the United States.
Causes: Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by infection with the organism Rickettsia rickettsii. Rocky Mountain spotted fever primarily occurs when ticks are most active and during warm weather when people tend to spend more time outdoors.
info-Symptoms: Early: Fever, headacheLater: Rash

Name: Rosacea
Symptoms: Over time, rosacea can thicken the skin on the nose, causing the nose to appear bulbous (rhinophyma). Many people with rosacea also experience dry, irritated, swollen eyes and red, swollen eyelids. Over time, rosacea can thicken the skin on the nose, causing the nose to appear bulbous (rhinophyma).
Overview: Changes typical of rosacea are redness of the cheeks, nose and central face, with small red bumps or pustules. However, rosacea still causes redness and dilation of small blood vessels on the surface of the skin.
Remedies: These self-care practices may help one control the signs and symptoms of rosacea and prevent flare-ups: Protect the face. Apply sunscreen after one apply any topical medication one is using for the face, and before applying any cosmetics. Take other steps to protect the skin, such as wearing a hat and avoiding midday sun.
Medication: For mild to moderate rosacea, the doctor may prescribe a cream or gel that one apply to the affected skin. These drugs include azelaic acid (Azelex, Finacea), metronidazole (Metrogel, Noritate, others) and ivermectin (Soolantra). The doctor may prescribe an oral antibiotic such as doxycycline (Oracea, others) for moderate to severe rosacea with bumps and pimples. If one has severe rosacea that doesn't respond to other therapies, the doctor may suggest isotretinoin (Amnesteem, Claravis, others).
info-Symptoms: Facial redness, swelling, and small and superficial dilated blood vessels
info-Risk factors: Family history
info-Medication: Antibiotics either by mouth or applied to the skin

Name: Roseola
Symptoms: However, usually by the time one notice the child's high temperature, the threat of a possible seizure has already passed. Call the child's doctor if: If the immune system is compromised and one come in contact with someone who has roseola, contact the doctor. Roseola typically starts with a sudden, high fever often greater than 103 F (39.4 C). Some children also may have a sore throat, runny nose or cough along with or preceding the fever.
Overview: Roseola is a generally mild infection that usually affects children by age 2. Some children develop only a very mild case of roseola and never show any clear indication of illness, while others experience the full range of signs and symptoms.
Causes: Like other viral illnesses, such as a common cold, roseola spreads from person to person through contact with an infected person's respiratory secretions or saliva. Unlike chickenpox and other childhood viral illnesses that spread rapidly, roseola rarely results in a communitywide outbreak.
Risk factors: Older infants are at greatest risk of acquiring roseola because they haven't had time yet to develop their own antibodies against many viruses. While in the uterus, babies receive antibodies from their mothers that protect them as newborns from contracting infections, such as roseola.
