Treatment: With the doctor's advice, one can give the child over-the-counter medications to reduce fever, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin, others). Though aspirin is approved for use in children older than age 3, children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin. This is because aspirin has been linked to Reye's syndrome, a rare but potentially life-threatening condition, in such children. There's no specific treatment for roseola, although some doctors may prescribe the antiviral medication ganciclovir (Cytovene) to treat the infection in people with weakened immunity. To treat the child's fever at home, the doctor may recommend: There's no specific treatment for the rash of roseola, which fades on its own in a short time. Make an appointment with the child's doctor if the child has a rash that doesn't improve after a few days, or if the child has a fever that lasts more than a week or exceeds 103 F (39.4 C). Encourage the child to drink clear fluids, such as water, ginger ale, lemon-lime soda, clear broth, or an electrolyte rehydration solution (Pedialyte, others) or sports drinks, such as Gatorade or Powerade, to prevent dehydration.
Remedies: To treat the child's fever at home, the doctor may recommend: There's no specific treatment for the rash of roseola, which fades on its own in a short time. Encourage the child to drink clear fluids, such as water, ginger ale, lemon-lime soda, clear broth, or an electrolyte rehydration solution (Pedialyte, others) or sports drinks, such as Gatorade or Powerade, to prevent dehydration.
info-Symptoms: Fever followed by rash

Name: Rotator cuff injury
Overview: Rotator cuff injuries can range in severity from simple inflammation to complete tendon tears. The rotator cuff is a group of muscles and tendons that surround the shoulder joint, keeping the head of the upper arm bone firmly within the shallow socket of the shoulder. Many people with rotator cuff disease can manage their symptoms and return to activities with physical therapy exercises that improve flexibility and strength of the muscles surrounding the shoulder joint. Extensive rotator cuff tears may not be fixable, and transfer of alternative tendons or joint replacement may be possible.
Risk factors: As one get older, the risk of a rotator cuff injury increases. Occupations such as carpentry or house painting require repetitive arm motions, often overhead, that can damage the rotator cuff over time. There may be a genetic component involved with rotator cuff injuries as they appear to occur more commonly in certain families.
Diagnosis: Although a rotator cuff tear won't show up on an X-ray, this test can visualize bone spurs or other potential causes for the pain such as arthritis. This type of test uses sound waves to produce images of structures within the body, particularly soft tissues such as muscles and tendons. It allows dynamic testing, assessing the structures of the shoulder as they move.
info-Symptoms: Shoulder pain, weakness
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, examination, medical imaging

Name: Rotavirus
Overview: Rotavirus is a very contagious virus that causes diarrhea. Although rotavirus infections are unpleasant, one can usually treat this infection at home with extra fluids to prevent dehydration.
Treatment: If the child has severe diarrhea, ask the doctor about offering an oral rehydration fluid such as Pedialyte or Enfalyte especially if the diarrhea lasts longer than a few days. If the baby drinks formula, offer a small amount of an oral rehydration fluid or regular formula.

Name: Round back
Overview: An increased front-to-back curve of the upper spine is called kyphosis. Age-related kyphosis is often due to weakness in the spinal bones that causes them to compress or crack. Other types of kyphosis can appear in infants or teens due to malformation of the spine or wedging of the spinal bones over time.
Causes: Broken or crushed vertebrae (compression fractures) can result in curvature of the spine. This bone-thinning disorder can cause spinal curvature, especially if weakened vertebrae result in compression fractures. Also called Scheuermann's kyphosis, this disease typically begins during the growth spurt that occurs before puberty. Cancer in the spine can weaken vertebrae and make them more prone to compression fractures, as can chemotherapy and radiation cancer treatments.
Diagnosis: After evaluating the signs and symptoms, the doctor may recommend: X-rays or CT scans. If one is experiencing numbness or muscle weakness, the doctor may recommend tests to determine how well nerve impulses are traveling between the spinal cord and the extremities.
Medication: The doctor might suggest medication, including Therapy can help manage certain types of kyphosis. To help one maintain good bone density, the doctor might recommend: Pain relievers. If over-the-counter medicines such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve) aren't enough, stronger pain medications are available by prescription.

Name: RSV
Symptoms: These include Respiratory syncytial virus infection can spread to the lower respiratory tract, causing pneumonia or bronchiolitis inflammation of the small airway passages entering the lungs. Other signs and symptoms of severe RSV infection in infants include Most children and adults recover in one to two weeks, although some might have repeated wheezing.
Overview: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) causes infections of the lungs and respiratory tract. RSV can cause severe infection in some people, especially premature babies, older adults, infants and adults with heart and lung disease, or anyone with a very weak immune system (immunocompromised).
Causes: Respiratory syncytial virus enters the body through the eyes, nose or mouth. Touch the mouth, nose or eyes after touching a contaminated object and one is likely to pick up the virus.
Remedies: One may not be able to shorten the length of a respiratory syncytial virus infection, but one can try to relieve some signs and symptoms. If the air is dry, a cool-mist humidifier or vaporizer can moisten the air and help ease congestion and coughing. Offer warm fluids, such as soup, which may help loosen thickened secretions. Over-the-counter (OTC) drops are a safe, effective way to ease congestion, even for young children. Drip several drops into one nostril to loosen hardened or thick mucus, then immediately suction that nostril, using a bulb syringe. OTC pain relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) may help reduce fever and relieve a sore throat.

Name: Rubeola
Symptoms: The measles rash gradually recedes, fading first from the face and last from the thighs and feet. For the first 10 to 14 days after one is infected, the measles virus incubates. Measles typically begins with a mild to moderate fever, often accompanied by a persistent cough, runny nose, inflamed eyes (conjunctivitis) and sore throat.
Overview: Measles causes a red, blotchy rash that usually appears first on the face and behind the ears, then spreads downward to the chest and back and finally to the feet. While death rates have been falling worldwide as more children receive the measles vaccine, the disease still kills more than 100,000 people a year, most under the age of 5.
Risk factors: If one hasn't received the vaccine for measles, one is much more likely to develop the disease. If one travel to developing countries, where measles is more common, one is at higher risk of catching the disease. If one don't have enough vitamin A in the diet, one is more likely to have more-severe symptoms and complications.
Treatment: Nonimmunized people, including infants, may be given the measles vaccination within 72 hours of exposure to the measles virus to provide protection against the disease. Pregnant women, infants and people with weakened immune systems who are exposed to the virus may receive an injection of proteins (antibodies) called immune serum globulin. When given within six days of exposure to the virus, these antibodies can prevent measles or make symptoms less severe.
Remedies: If one or the child has measles, keep in touch with the doctor as one monitor the progress of the disease and watch for complications. Drink plenty of water, fruit juice and herbal tea to replace fluids lost by fever and sweating. If one or the child finds bright light bothersome, as do many people with measles, keep the lights low or wear sunglasses.
Medication: One or the child may also take over-the-counter medications such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Children's Motrin, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve) to help relieve the fever that accompanies measles. Though aspirin is approved for use in children older than age 3, children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin. It's generally given as a large dose of 200,000 international units (IU) for children older than a year.
info-Symptoms: Fever, cough, runny nose, inflamed eyes, rash

Name: Rumination syndrome
Diagnosis: Other tests that may be used to rule out other possible causes of the or the child's symptoms include Esophagogastroduodenoscopy. This test allows the doctor to inspect the esophagus, stomach and upper part of the small intestine (duodenum) to rule out any obstruction.

Name: Runner 's knee
Causes: Doctors aren't certain what causes patellofemoral pain syndrome, but it's been associated with: Overuse. Patellofemoral pain can occur when the muscles around the hip and knee don't keep the kneecap properly aligned. Trauma to the kneecap, such as a dislocation or fracture, has been linked to patellofemoral pain syndrome. Knee surgery, particularly repair to the anterior cruciate ligament using the own patellar tendon as a graft, increases the risk of patellofemoral pain.
Risk factors: This may be because a woman's wider pelvis increases the angle at which the bones in the knee joint meet. Participation in running and jumping sports can put extra stress on the knees, especially when one increase the training level.
Diagnosis: To help determine the cause of the knee pain, the doctor might recommend imaging tests such as: X-rays. CT scans can visualize both bone and soft tissues, but the procedure delivers a much higher dose of radiation than do plain X-rays. Using radio waves and a strong magnetic field, MRIs produce detailed images of bones and soft tissues, such as the knee ligaments and cartilage.
Medication: If needed, take over-the-counter pain relievers, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve). A physical therapist might suggest: If nonsurgical treatments aren't effective, the doctor might suggest: Rehabilitation exercises. Specific exercises can strengthen the muscles that support the knees and control limb alignment, such as the quadriceps, hamstrings and the muscles around the hips, especially hip abductors. During the recovery, one may want to restrict theself to low-impact activities that are easier on the knees such as bicycling and swimming or water running. During this procedure, the doctor inserts a pencil-thin device equipped with a camera lens and light (arthroscope) into the knee through a tiny incision. In more-severe cases, a surgeon may need to operate on the knee to realign the angle of the kneecap or relieve pressure on the cartilage.

Name: Ruptured eardrum ( perforated eardrum )
Overview: A ruptured (perforated) eardrum prevents the proper transmission of sound waves to the middle ear and leaves the middle ear vulnerable to infectious agents, water and other foreign substances. A ruptured eardrum (tympanic membrane perforation) is a hole or tear in the thin tissue that separates the ear canal from the middle ear (eardrum).
Causes: The middle ear includes three small bones the hammer (malleus), anvil (incus) and stirrup (stapes). Causes of a ruptured (perforated) eardrum may include Barotrauma. A loud sound or blast, as from an explosion or gunshot essentially an overpowering sound wave can rarely cause a tear in the eardrum. Severe injury, such as a skull base fracture, may cause the dislocation of or damage to middle and inner ear structures, including the eardrum.
Diagnosis: The family doctor or ENT specialist can often determine if one has a ruptured (perforated) eardrum with a visual inspection using a lighted instrument (otoscope or microscope). He or she may conduct or order additional tests to determine the cause of the ear symptoms or to detect the presence of any hearing loss. Simple tests with tuning forks can help the doctor detect hearing loss. A tuning fork evaluation may also reveal whether hearing loss is caused by damage to the vibrating parts of the middle ear (including the eardrum), damage to sensors or nerves of the inner ear, or damage to both.

Name: Ruptured spleen
Overview: The spleen is located just under the rib cage on the left side. The spleen, situated just under the rib cage on the left side, helps the body fight infection and filter old blood cells from the bloodstream. A forceful blow to the abdomen during a sporting mishap, a fistfight or a car crash, for example is the usual cause of a ruptured spleen.

Name: Sacral dimple
Overview: A sacral dimple is an indentation, present at birth, in the skin on the lower back. Sacral dimples that are accompanied by a nearby tuft of hair, skin tag or certain types of skin discoloration are sometimes associated with a serious underlying abnormality of the spine or spinal cord.
Diagnosis: If the dimple is very large or is accompanied by a nearby tuft of hair, skin tag or certain types of skin discoloration, the doctor may suggest imaging tests to rule out spinal cord problems. If more detail is needed, the doctor may recommend an MRI, which uses radio waves and a strong magnetic field to create cross-sectional images of the body.
Treatment: Treatment is unnecessary for a simple sacral dimple. In general, the child won't need to see a doctor for a sacral dimple. If one has questions about the sacral dimple, one can also bring these up at the child's routine office visits. Sacral dimples. The simple sacral dimple: Diagnostic yield of ultrasound in neonates.

Name: Sacroiliitis
Overview: The sacroiliac joints link the pelvis and lower spine. They're made up of the sacrum the bony structure above the tailbone and below the lower vertebrae and the top part (ilium) of the pelvis. Sacroiliitis (say-kroe-il-e-I-tis) is an inflammation of one or both of the sacroiliac joints situated where the lower spine and pelvis connect.
Causes: A sudden impact, such as a motor vehicle accident or a fall, can damage the sacroiliac joints. Wear-and-tear arthritis (osteoarthritis) can occur in sacroiliac joints, as can ankylosing spondylitis a type of inflammatory arthritis that affects the spine.
Diagnosis: If ankylosing spondylitis is suspected, the doctor might recommend an MRI a test that uses radio waves and a strong magnetic field to produce very detailed cross-sectional images of both bone and soft tissues. Because low back pain can have many causes, the doctor might suggest using numbing injections (anesthetics) to help with the diagnosis.
Remedies: Drugs such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) may help relieve pain associated with sacroiliitis. Some of these drugs can cause stomach upset, or kidney or liver problems; the Food and Drug Administration recently strengthened its warning about an increased risk of heart attack and stroke with use of nonsteroidal anti-inflamatory drugs, such as ibuprofen. Alternating ice and heat might help relieve sacroiliac pain Over-the-counter pain relievers.
Medication: Depending on the cause of the pain, the doctor might recommend: The doctor or physical therapist can help one learn range-of-motion and stretching exercises to maintain joint flexibility, and strengthening exercises to make the muscles more stable. If other methods haven't relieved the pain, one doctor might suggest: Pain relievers. Medications such as cyclobenzaprine (Amrix, Fexmid) might help reduce the muscle spasms often associated with sacroiliitis. Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors such as etanercept (Enbrel), adalimumab (Humira) and infliximab (Remicade) often help relieve sacroiliitis that's associated with ankylosing spondylitis. Although surgery is rarely used to treat sacroiliitis, fusing the two bones together with metal hardware can sometimes relieve sacroiliitis pain.

Name: Salmonellosis
Symptoms: Possible signs and symptoms include Signs and symptoms of salmone willa infection generally last two to seven days. Diarrhea may last up to 10 days, although it may take several months before bowels return to normal.
Causes: Infection also can occur if one touch something that is contaminated, including pets, especially birds and reptiles, and then put the fingers in the mouth. While an egg's shell may seem to be a perfect barrier to contamination, some infected chickens produce eggs that contain salmone willa before the shell is even formed. Some fresh produce, particularly imported varieties, may be hydrated in the field or washed during processing with water contaminated with salmone willa. Contamination also can occur in the kitchen, when juices from raw meat and poultry come into contact with uncooked foods, such as salads.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of salmone willa infection include activities that may bring one into closer contact with salmone willa bacteria and health problems that may weaken the resistance to infection in general. For example, strong stomach acid can kill many types of salmone willa bacteria. Examples include The following medical problems or medications appear to increase the risk of contracting salmone willa by impairing the immune system. Salmone willa infection, including varieties that cause typhoid fever, is more common in developing countries with poor sanitation. Some pets, particularly birds and reptiles, can carry salmone willa bacteria. This disorder damages the lining of the intestines, which makes it easier for salmone willa bacteria to take hold. This can reduce the number of good bacteria in the intestines, which may impair the ability to fight off a salmone willa infection.
Medication: Medications such as loperamide (Imodium A-D) can help relieve cramping, but they may also prolong the diarrhea associated with salmone willa infection. If the doctor suspects that salmone willa bacteria have entered the bloodstream, or if one has a severe case or a compromised immune system, he or she may prescribe antibiotics to kill the bacteria. In fact, antibiotics may prolong the period in which one carry the bacteria and can infect others, and they can increase the risk of relapse.
info-Symptoms: Diarrhea, fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting
info-Risk factors: Old, young, weak immune system, bottle feeding, proton pump inhibitors
info-Prevention: Proper preparation and cooking of food and supervising contact between young children and pets
info-Treatment: Fluids by mouth, intravenous fluids, antibiotics

Name: Sarcoidosis
Overview: Sarcoidosis is a disease characterized by the growth of tiny collections of inflammatory cells (granulomas) in any part of the body most commonly the lungs and lymph nodes. Some research suggests that infectious agents, chemicals, dust and a potential abnormal reaction to the body's own proteins (self-proteins) could be responsible for the formation of granulomas in people who are genetically predisposed.
Risk factors: While anyone can develop sarcoidosis, factors that may increase the risk include Age and sex. If someone in the family has had sarcoidosis, one is more likely to develop the disease.
Remedies: In addition to treatment, these self-care tips can help: Take the medication as prescribed. Even if one start to feel better, don't stop taking the medication without talking with the doctor. Engaging in regular physical exercise can improve mood, strengthen muscles and help reduce fatigue that can interfere with the daily activities.
Medication: Depending on the symptoms or complications, other treatments may be recommended. For example, one may have physical therapy to reduce fatigue and improve muscle strength, pulmonary rehabilitation to decrease respiratory symptoms, or an implanted cardiac pacemaker or defibrillator for heart arrhythmias. The doctor will monitor the symptoms, determine the effectiveness of treatments and check for complications. For example, one may have regular chest X-rays, lab and urine tests, EKGs, and exams of the lungs, eyes, skin and any other organ involved. Organ transplant may be considered if sarcoidosis has severely damaged the lungs, heart or liver. Medications such as methotrexate (Trexall) and azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran) reduce inflammation by suppressing the immune system.
info-Symptoms: Depends on the organ involvedLungs: wheezing, cough, shortness of breath, chest painSkin: lumps, ulcers, discolored skinChildren: weight loss, bone pain, feeling tired
info-Risk factors: Family history
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and tissue biopsy

Name: Sarcoma
Overview: Sarcoma is a type of cancer that can occur in various locations in the body. Sarcoma is the general term for a broad group of cancers that begin in the bones and in the soft (also called connective) tissues (soft tissue sarcoma). Soft tissue sarcoma forms in the tissues that connect, support and surround other body structures.
Risk factors: Examples of syndromes that increase the risk of sarcoma include familial retinoblastoma and neurofibromatosis type 1. Radiation treatment for cancer increases the risk of developing a sarcoma later. Certain chemicals, such as some industrial chemicals and herbicides, can increase the risk of sarcoma that affects the liver. The virus called human herpesvirus 8 can increase the risk of a type of sarcoma called Kaposi's sarcoma in people with weakened immune systems.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose sarcoma and determine its extent (stage) include Removing a sample of tissue for testing (biopsy). Other imaging tests might include ultrasound, CT, bone scans and positron emission tomography (PET) scans. Tests can also reveal information that's helpful for choosing the best treatments.How a biopsy sample is collected depends on the particular situation.
Treatment: Which treatments are best for one will depend on the type of sarcoma, its location, how aggressive the cells are and whether cancer has spread to other parts of the body. The concern and understanding of a counselor, medical social worker, clergy member or cancer support group also may be helpful. Sometimes it's necessary to amputate an arm or leg to remove all of the cancer, but surgeons try to preserve limb function when possible. Radiation therapy uses high-powered energy beams, such as X-rays and protons, to kill cancer cells. Targeted therapy is a drug treatment that uses medicines that attack specific weaknesses in cancer cells. Ablation therapy treatments destroy cancer cells by applying electricity to heat the cells, very cold liquid to freeze the cells or high-frequency ultrasound waves to damage the cells. As one learn more about cancer, one may become more confident in making treatment decisions. The concern and understanding of a counselor, medical social worker, clergy member or cancer support group also may be helpful.Ask the doctor about support groups in the area.

Name: Sarcoma , bone cancer
Causes: A small number of bone cancers have been linked to hereditary factors, while others are related to previous radiation exposure. This variety of bone cancer occurs most often in children and young adults, in the bones of the leg or arm. Ewing sarcoma tumors most commonly arise in the pelvis, legs or arms of children and young adults.

Name: Scabies
Overview: Scabies is caused by tiny mites that burrow into the skin. Scabies is contagious and can spread quickly through close physical contact in a family, child care group, school class, nursing home or prison. Because scabies is so contagious, doctors often recommend treatment for entire families or contact groups.< Scabies can be readily treated.
Treatment: Medications commonly prescribed for scabies include Although these medications kill the mites promptly, one may find that the itching doesn't stop entirely for several weeks. Doctors may prescribe other topical medications, such as sulfur compounded in petrolatum, for people who don't respond to or can't use these medications. This medication isn't safe for children younger than age 10 years, women who are pregnant or nursing, or anyone who weighs less than 110 pounds (50 kilograms). The safety of this medication hasn't been established in children, adults 65 and older, or women who are pregnant or nursing. Doctors may prescribe this oral medication for people with altered immune systems, for people who have crusted scabies, or for people who don't respond to the prescription lotions and creams. Ivermectin isn't recommended for women who are pregnant or nursing, or for children who weigh less than 33 pounds (15 kilograms). At the doctor's suggestion, one may find that over-the-counter antihistamines relieve the allergic symptoms caused by scabies.
Remedies: Soaking in cool water or an oatmeal bath, or applying a cool, wet washcloth to irritated areas of the skin may minimize itching. Calamine lotion, available without a prescription, can effectively relieve the pain and itching of minor skin irritations.
info-Symptoms: itchiness, pimple-like rash
info-Causes: Sarcoptes scabiei mite spread by close contact
info-Risk factors: Crowded living conditions (child care facilities, group homes, prisons), lack of access to water

Name: Scarlet fever
Symptoms: The signs and symptoms that give scarlet fever its name include The rash and the redness in the face and tongue usually last about a week. Other signs and symptoms associated with scarlet fever include Talk to the doctor if the child has a sore throat with: Red rash. The folds of skin around the groin, armpits, elbows, knees and neck usually become a deeper red than the surrounding rash.
Treatment: However, when one call to set up the appointment, one may be urged to seek immediate medical care if the child is experiencing any of the following: Treat fever and pain. Use ibuprofen (Advil, Children's Motrin, others) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) to control the fever and minimize throat pain. High fever Severe sore throat with difficulty swallowing Intense abdominal pain or vomiting Severe headache Treat fever and pain.
Remedies: Use ibuprofen (Advil, Children's Motrin, others) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) to control the fever and minimize throat pain. Use a cool mist humidifier to eliminate dry air that may further irritate a sore throat. Children older than age 4 can suck on lozenges to relieve a sore throat.
info-Symptoms: Sore throat, fever, headaches, swollen lymph nodes, characteristic rash
info-Prevention: Handwashing, not sharing personal items, staying away from sick people

Name: Schizoaffective disorder
Symptoms: Although one can't force someone to seek professional help, one can offer encouragement and support and help find a qualified doctor or mental health professional. If one has a loved one who is in danger of attempting suicide or has made a suicide attempt, make sure someone stays with that person.
Overview: Schizoaffective disorder is a mental health disorder that is marked by a combination of schizophrenia symptoms, such as hallucinations or delusions, and mood disorder symptoms, such as depression or mania. Untreated schizoaffective disorder may lead to problems functioning at work, at school and in social situations, causing loneliness and trouble holding down a job or attending school.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder involves ruling out other mental health disorders and concluding that symptoms are not due to substance use, medication or a medical condition. These may include tests that help rule out conditions with similar symptoms, and screening for alcohol and drugs. A doctor or mental health professional checks mental status by observing appearance and demeanor and asking about thoughts, moods, delusions, hallucinations, substance use and potential for suicide. The doctor or mental health professional may use the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders DSM-5, published by the American Psychiatric Association.
Treatment: People with schizoaffective disorder generally respond best to a combination of medications, psychotherapy and life skills training. Treatment varies, depending on the type and severity of symptoms and whether the disorder is the depressive or bipolar type.
Medication: In general, doctors prescribe medications for schizoaffective disorder to relieve psychotic symptoms, stabilize mood and treat depression. These medications may include In addition to medication, psychotherapy, also called talk therapy, may help. For adults with schizoaffective disorder who do not respond to psychotherapy or medications, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) may be considered. However, doctors may prescribe other antipsychotic drugs to help manage psychotic symptoms such as delusions and hallucinations. When the schizoaffective disorder is bipolar type, mood stabilizers can help level out the mania highs and depression lows. When depression is the underlying mood disorder, antidepressants can help manage feelings of sadness, hopelessness, or difficulty with sleep and concentration. Supportive group settings can also help reduce social isolation, provide a reality check during periods of psychosis, increase appropriate use of medications and develop better social skills. This focuses on helping people with schizoaffective disorder prepare for, find and keep jobs.
info-Symptoms: Hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, depressed mood, manic behavior
info-Risk factors: Genetics, brain chemistry and structure, stress, drug use, trauma from abuse
info-Prognosis: Depends on the individual, medication response, and therapeutic support available

Name: Schizoid personality disorder
Overview: Schizoid personality disorder is an uncommon condition in which people avoid social activities and consistently shy away from interaction with others. If one has schizoid personality disorder, one may be seen as a loner or dismissive of others, and one may lack the desire or skill to form close personal relationships.
Treatment: If one has schizoid personality disorder, one may prefer to go the own way and avoid interacting with others, including doctors. If oned like to develop closer relationships, a modified form of cognitive behavioral therapy may help one change the beliefs and behaviors that are problems. Although there's no specific drug to treat schizoid personality disorder, certain drugs can help with issues such as anxiety or depression.
info-Symptoms: Pervasive emotional detachment, reduced affect, lack of close friends, apathy, anhedonia, unintentional insensitivity to social norms, sexual abstinence, preoccupation with fantasy, autistic thinking without loss of skill to recognize reality
info-Risk factors: Family history
info-Medication: Not general practice but may include low dose benzodiazepines, Î²-blockers, nefazodone, bupropion

Name: Schizophrenia
Symptoms: Schizophrenia involves a range of problems with thinking (cognition), behavior and emotions. Signs and symptoms may vary, but usually involve delusions, hallucinations or disorganized speech, and reflect an impaired ability to function. Symptoms may include Symptoms can vary in type and severity over time, with periods of worsening and remission of symptoms. In men, schizophrenia symptoms typically start in the early to mid-20s. Schizophrenia symptoms in teenagers are similar to those in adults, but the condition may be more difficult to recognize. Compared with schizophrenia symptoms in adults, teens may be: People with schizophrenia often lack awareness that their difficulties stem from a mental disorder that requires medical attention. If one think someone one know may have symptoms of schizophrenia, talk to him or her about the concerns. Rarely, speech may include putting together meaningless words that can't be understood, sometimes known as word salad. Also, the person may lose interest in everyday activities, socially withdraw or lack the ability to experience pleasure.
Overview: Schizophrenia is a serious mental disorder in which people interpret reality abnormally. Schizophrenia may result in some combination of hallucinations, delusions, and extremely disordered thinking and behavior that impairs daily functioning, and can be disabling.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis of schizophrenia involves ruling out other mental health disorders and determining that symptoms are not due to substance abuse, medication or a medical condition. These may include tests that help rule out conditions with similar symptoms, and screening for alcohol and drugs. A doctor or mental health professional checks mental status by observing appearance and demeanor and asking about thoughts, moods, delusions, hallucinations, substance use, and potential for violence or suicide. A doctor or mental health professional may use the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association.
Medication: Because medications for schizophrenia can cause serious side effects, people with schizophrenia may be reluctant to take them. These newer, second-generation medications are generally preferred because they pose a lower risk of serious side effects than do first-generation antipsychotics. Second-generation antipsychotics include These first-generation antipsychotics have frequent and potentially significant neurological side effects, including the possibility of developing a movement disorder (tardive dyskinesia) that may or may not be reversible. Common medications that are available as an injection include Once psychosis recedes, in addition to continuing on medication, psychological and social (psychosocial) interventions are important. For adults with schizophrenia who do not respond to drug therapy, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) may be considered. Aripiprazole (Abilify) Asenapine (Saphris) Brexpiprazole (Rexulti) Cariprazine (Vraylar) Clozapine (Clozaril, Versacloz) Iloperidone (Fanapt) Lurasidone (Latuda) Olanzapine (Zyprexa) Paliperidone (Invega) Quetiapine (Seroquel) Risperidone (Risperdal) Ziprasidone (Geodon) Chlorpromazine Fluphenazine Haloperidol Perphenazine Aripiprazole (Abilify Maintena, Aristada) Fluphenazine decanoate Haloperidol decanoate Paliperidone (Invega Sustenna, Invega Trinza) Risperidone (Risperdal Consta, Perseris) Individual therapy.
info-Symptoms: Hallucinations (usually hearing voices), delusions, paranoia, confused thinking
info-Risk factors: Family history, cannabis use in adolescence, problems during pregnancy, childhood adversity, birth in late winter or early spring, older father, being born or raised in a city
info-Diagnostic method: Based on observed behavior, reported experiences, and reports of others familiar with the person

Name: Schizophrenia , juvenile
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms may vary, but usually involve delusions, hallucinations or disorganized speech, and reflect an impaired ability to function. Schizophrenia symptoms in teenagers are similar to those in adults, but the condition may be more difficult to recognize in this age group. Signs and symptoms may include When childhood schizophrenia begins early in life, symptoms may build up gradually. The early signs and symptoms may be so vague that one can't recognize what's wrong, or one may attribute them to a developmental phase. As time goes on, symptoms may become more severe and more noticeable. Eventually, the child may develop the symptoms of psychosis, including hallucinations, delusions and difficulty organizing thoughts. As thoughts become more disorganized, there's often a break from reality (psychosis) frequently requiring hospitalization and treatment with medication. Rarely, speech may include putting together meaningless words that can't be understood, sometimes known as word salad.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis of childhood schizophrenia involves ruling out other mental health disorders and determining that symptoms aren't due to substance abuse, medication or a medical condition. A child psychiatrist may want to monitor the child's behaviors, perceptions and thinking patterns for six months or more. As thinking and behavior patterns and signs and symptoms become clearer over time, a diagnosis of schizophrenia may be made. These may include tests that help rule out conditions with similar symptoms, and screening for alcohol and drugs. This includes observing appearance and demeanor, asking about thoughts, feelings and behavior patterns, including any thoughts of self-harm or harming others, evaluating ability to think and function at an age-appropriate level, and assessing mood, anxiety and possible psychotic symptoms. The doctor or mental health professional may use the criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association.
Remedies: Try to make sure that the child takes medications as prescribed, even if he or she is feeling well and has no current symptoms. If medications are stopped or taken infrequently, the symptoms are likely to come back and the doctor will have a hard time knowing what the best and safest dose is. Contact the doctor who's treating the child for schizophrenia before the child takes medications prescribed by another doctor or before taking any over-the-counter medications, vitamins, minerals, herbs or other supplements. Contact the child's doctor or therapist if one notice any changes in symptoms, to prevent the situation from worsening. Alcohol, street drugs and tobacco can worsen schizophrenia symptoms or interfere with antipsychotic medications.
Medication: Examples of second-generation antipsychotics approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to treat schizophrenia in teenagers age 13 and older include Paliperidone (Invega) is FDA-approved for children 12 years of age and older. In addition to having side effects similar to those of second-generation antipsychotics, first-generation antipsychotics also may have frequent and potentially significant neurological side effects. Because of the increased risk of serious side effects with first-generation antipsychotics, they often aren't recommended for use in children until other options have been tried without success. Examples of first-generation antipsychotics approved by the FDA to treat schizophrenia in children and teens include First-generation antipsychotics are often cheaper than second-generation antipsychotics, especially the generic versions, which can be an important consideration when long-term treatment is necessary. Side effects in children and teenagers may not be the same as those in adults, and sometimes they may be more serious. In addition to medication, psychotherapy, sometimes called talk therapy, can help manage symptoms and help one and the child cope with the disorder.

Name: Schizotypal personality disorder
Symptoms: Schizotypal personality disorder can easily be confused with schizophrenia, a severe mental illness in which people lose contact with reality (psychosis). While people with schizotypal personality disorder may experience brief psychotic episodes with delusions or hallucinations, the episodes are not as frequent, prolonged or intense as in schizophrenia. Despite the differences, people with schizotypal personality disorder can benefit from treatments similar to those used for schizophrenia.
Overview: People with schizotypal personality disorder are often described as odd or eccentric and usually have few, if any, close relationships. These problems may lead to severe anxiety and a tendency to avoid social situations, as the person with schizotypal personality disorder tends to hold peculiar beliefs and may have difficulty with responding appropriately to social cues.
info-Symptoms: strange thinking or behavior, unusual beliefs, paranoia, severe anxiety, lack of friends
info-Risk factors: Family history

Name: Schwannoma
Diagnosis: MRI scan To diagnosis a peripheral nerve tumor, the doctor may ask one about signs and symptoms, discuss the medical history, and perform both a general physical and neurological exam. A computer uses the images to make a detailed view of the peripheral nerve tumor so that the doctor can evaluate how it may be affecting one. If imaging tests identify a nerve tumor, the doctor may remove and analyze a small sample of cells (biopsy) from the tumor. If one has a condition such as progressive peripheral neuropathy or enlarged nerves that mimic nerve tumors, the doctor may take a nerve biopsy.

Name: Sciatica
Overview: The sciatic nerves branches from the lower back through the hips and buttocks and down each leg. Sciatica refers to pain that radiates along the path of the sciatic nerve, which branches from the lower back through the hips and buttocks and down each leg.
Risk factors: Age-related changes in the spine, such as herniated disks and bone spurs, are the most common causes of sciatica. By increasing the stress on the spine, excess body weight can contribute to the spinal changes that trigger sciatica. A job that requires one to twist the back, carry heavy loads or drive a motor vehicle for long periods might play a role in sciatica, but there's no conclusive evidence of this link.
Remedies: Initially, one might get relief from a cold pack placed on the painful area for up to 20 minutes several times a day. Pain relievers such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve) are sometimes helpful for sciatica.
Medication: The types of drugs that might be prescribed for sciatica pain include Once the acute pain improves, the doctor or a physical therapist can design a rehabilitation program to help one prevent future injuries. This option is usually reserved for when the compressed nerve causes significant weakness, loss of bowel or bladder control, or when one has pain that progressively worsens or doesn't improve with other therapies.
info-Symptoms: Pain going down the leg from the lower back, weakness or numbness of the affected leg
info-Duration: 90% of the time less than 6 weeks
info-Causes: Spinal disc herniation, spondylolisthesis, spinal stenosis, piriformis syndrome, pelvic tumor

Name: Scleroderma , limited
Symptoms: This condition occurs when small blood vessels in the fingers and toes spasm in response to cold or emotional stress, blocking the flow of blood. In most people, the skin turns white before becoming blue, cold and numb. When circulation improves, the skin usually reddens and might throb or tingle. Raynaud's phenomena is often the first sign of limited scleroderma, but many people who have Raynaud's never develop scleroderma. In limited scleroderma, skin changes typically affect only the lower arms and legs, including fingers and toes, and sometimes the face and neck. In most people, the skin turns white before becoming blue, cold and numb.When circulation improves, the skin usually reddens and might throb or tingle. The swelling of tiny blood vessels near the skin's surface cause these small red spots or lines (telangiectasias). Limited scleroderma can cause tiny calcium deposits (calcinosis) to develop under the skin, mainly on the elbows, knees and fingers.
Overview: Limited scleroderma, also known as CREST syndrome, is one subtype of scleroderma a condition whose name means hardened skin. The skin changes associated with limited scleroderma typically occur only in the lower arms and legs, below the elbows and knees, and sometimes affect the face and neck.
Risk factors: In the United States, limited scleroderma tends to be more severe in blacks and Native Americans than in whites. If someone in the family has an autoimmune disease such as lupus, rheumatoid arthritis or Hashimoto's disease one has an increased risk of developing limited scleroderma. Certain toxic substances such as polyvinyl chloride, benzene, silica and trichloroethylene might trigger scleroderma in people with a genetic predisposition to the disease.
Diagnosis: Tests that might aid in the diagnosis include The doctor might recommend additional tests to identify lung, heart, kidney or gastrointestinal complications. Although biopsies can be helpful, they can't definitively diagnose limited scleroderma.
Remedies: To reduce Raynaud's symptoms, wear gloves or mittens outdoors when the weather is cool and indoors when one reach into the freezer. To maintain the body's core temperature when it's cool, dress in layers, and wear a hat or scarf, thermal socks, and well-fitting boots or shoes that don't cut off the circulation. To minimize acid reflux: Excess collagen destroys sweat and oil glands, leaving the skin stiff and dry. Eat small, frequent meals Avoid spicy or fatty foods, chocolate, caffeine, and alcohol Don't exercise immediately before or after eating Elevate the head of the bed using blocks Remain upright for two or three hours after a meal and don't eat before bedtime Avoid harsh soaps and detergents. Bathe every other day, and take brief baths and showers, using warm rather than hot water. Apply a rich, oil-based, fragrance-free moisturizer after washing the hands or bathing, while the skin is still damp.
Medication: Several types of medications can help ease the signs and symptoms of limited scleroderma, including Stiff, painful joints and skin are common problems in limited scleroderma. If skin ulcers become infected, one might need to apply topical antibiotics and bandage the area. Medications that open small blood vessels and increase circulation might help relieve Raynaud's symptoms and reduce increased pressure in the arteries between the heart, lungs and kidney.

Name: Sclerosing cholangitis
Symptoms: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is often diagnosed before symptoms appear when a routine blood test or an X-ray taken for an unrelated condition shows liver abnormalities. Early symptoms often include Many people diagnosed with primary sclerosing cholangitis before they have symptoms continue to feel generally well for several years.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of primary sclerosing cholangitis include The age. Primary sclerosing cholangitis can occur at any age, but it's most often diagnosed between the ages of 30 and 50. A large proportion of people with primary sclerosing cholangitis also have inflammatory bowel disease. People with Northern European heritage have a higher risk of primary sclerosing cholangitis.
Diagnosis: To make the bile ducts visible on an X-ray, the doctor uses a flexible tube passed down the throat to inject dye into the area of the small intestine where the bile ducts empty. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (koh-lan-jee-o-pan-cree-uh-TOG-ruh-fee) uses magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to make images of the liver and bile ducts and is the test of choice to diagnose primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Name: Sclerosing mesenteritis
Overview: The mesentery is a fold of membrane that attaches the intestine to the abdominal wall and holds it in place. Sclerosing mesenteritis, also called mesenteric panniculitis, occurs when the tissue (mesentery) that holds the small intestines in place becomes inflamed and forms scar tissue. In rare cases, scar tissue formed by sclerosing mesenteritis can block food from moving through the digestive tract.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose sclerosing mesenteritis include Removing a sample of tissue for testing (biopsy). If one is experiencing sclerosing mesenteritis signs and symptoms, the doctor may recommend a biopsy to rule out other diseases and to make a definitive diagnosis.
Medication: Medications may include If sclerosing mesenteritis advances to block the flow of food through the digestive system, one may need surgery to remove the blockage. Tamoxifen (Soltamox) is typically combined with corticosteroids or other medications and may be used long term. Progesterone (Prometrium) may be used as an alternative to tamoxifen, but it also has significant side effects. Several other medications have been used to treat sclerosing mesenteritis, such as azathioprine (Imuran, Azasan), colchicine (Colcrys, Mitigare), cyclophosphamide and thalidomide (Thalomid).

Name: Sclerosis , amyotrophic lateral
Overview: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (a-my-o-TROE-fik LAT-ur-ul skluh-ROE-sis), or ALS, is a progressive nervous system disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control. Eventually, ALS affects control of the muscles needed to move, speak, eat and breathe.
Causes: ALS affects the nerve cells that control voluntary muscle movements such as walking and talking (motor neurons). ALS causes the motor neurons to gradually deteriorate, and then die. When motor neurons are damaged, they stop sending messages to the muscles, so the muscles can't function.
Risk factors: Established risk factors for ALS include Environmental factors, such as the following, might trigger ALS. In most people with familial ALS, their children have a 50-50 chance of developing the disease. ALS risk increases with age, and is most common between the ages of 40 and the mid-60s. Some studies examining the entire human genome found many similarities in the genetic variations of people with familial ALS and some people with noninherited ALS. Much study has been done, but no single agent or chemical has been consistently associated with ALS. It might include exposure to certain metals or chemicals, traumatic injuries, viral infections, and intense exertion.
Medication: The Food and Drug Administration has approved two drugs for treating ALS: The doctor might also prescribe medications to provide relief from other symptoms, including Breathing care. A physical therapist can address pain, walking, mobility, bracing and equipment needs that help one stay independent. A physical therapist can also help one adjust to a brace, walker or wheelchair and might suggest devices such as ramps that make it easier for one to get around. Speech therapists can also help one explore other methods of communication, such as an alphabet board or pen and paper. The team might include a social worker to help with financial issues, insurance, and getting equipment and paying for devices one need.

Name: Sclerosis , multiple
Symptoms: Multiple sclerosis signs and symptoms may differ greatly from person to person and over the course of the disease depending on the location of affected nerve fibers. Small increases in body temperature can temporarily worsen signs and symptoms of MS, but these aren't considered true disease relapses.
Overview: In multiple sclerosis, the protective coating on nerve fibers (myelin) is damaged and may eventually be destroyed. In MS, the immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between the brain and the rest of the body.
Causes: In the case of MS, this immune system malfunction destroys the fatty substance that coats and protects nerve fibers in the brain and spinal cord (myelin). When the protective myelin is damaged and the nerve fiber is exposed, the messages that travel along that nerve fiber may be slowed or blocked.
Risk factors: If one of the parents or siblings has had MS, one is at higher risk of developing the disease. White people, particularly those of Northern European descent, are at highest risk of developing MS. People of Asian, African or Native American descent have the lowest risk. MS is far more common in countries with temperate climates, including Canada, the northern United States, New Zealand, southeastern Australia and Europe. One has a slightly higher risk of developing MS if one has other autoimmune disorders such as thyroid disease, pernicious anemia, psoriasis, type 1 diabetes or inflammatory bowel disease.
Diagnosis: The doctor may then recommend: In most people with relapsing-remitting MS, the diagnosis is fairly straightforward and based on a pattern of symptoms consistent with the disease and confirmed by brain imaging scans, such as MRI. Blood tests, to help rule out other diseases with symptoms similar to MS. Tests to check for specific biomarkers associated with MS are currently under development and may also aid in diagnosing the disease. This sample can show abnormalities in antibodies that are associated with MS. A spinal tap can also help rule out infections and other conditions with symptoms similar to MS. MRI, which can reveal areas of MS (lesions) on the brain and spinal cord.
Remedies: To help relieve the signs and symptoms of MS, try to: Get plenty of rest. To make sure one is getting enough sleep, one may need to be evaluated and possibly treated for sleep disorders such as obstructive sleep apnea. If one has mild to moderate MS, regular exercise can help improve the strength, muscle tone, balance and coordination. Other types of mild to moderate exercise recommended for people with MS include walking, stretching, low-impact aerobics, stationary bicycling, yoga and tai chi. Yoga, tai chi, massage, meditation or deep breathing may help.

Name: Scrotal masses
Causes: A number of disorders can result in a scrotal mass or an abnormality in the scrotum, including Testicular cancer. Testicular cancer is a tumor containing abnormal testicular tissue, which can usually be felt as a nontender lump in the scrotum. Less commonly, epididymitis is caused by a viral infection or an abnormal flow of urine into the epididymis. A small amount of fluid in this space is normal, but the excess fluid of a hydrocele usually results in a painless swelling of the scrotum. In infants, a hydrocele occurs usually because an opening between the abdomen and the scrotum hasn't properly sealed during development. In infants, an inguinal hernia usually occurs because the passageway from the abdomen to the scrotum has failed to close during development. This is a twisting of the spermatic cord, the bundle of blood vessels, nerves and the tube that carries semen from the testicle to the penis. Varicocele is more common on the left side of the scrotum because of differences in how blood circulates from each side.A varicocele might cause infertility.
Diagnosis: Shining a bright light through the scrotum might provide information about the size, location and makeup of a scrotal mass. Using sound waves to create an image of internal organs, this test can provide detailed information about the size, location and makeup of a scrotal mass, as well as the condition of the testicles. Laboratory tests of a sample of urine might detect a bacterial or viral infection or the presence of blood or pus in the urine. Laboratory tests of a blood sample might detect a bacterial or viral infection or elevated levels of certain proteins that are associated with testicular cancer. If other tests indicate testicular cancer, one will likely undergo a specialized X-ray exam (CT scan) of the chest, abdomen and groin to see if cancer has spread to other tissues or organs.
Remedies: To perform a testicular self-examination, grasp and roll the testicle between the thumbs and forefingers, feeling for lumps, swelling, hardness or other changes. To do a testicular self-exam, follow these steps: If one find a lump or other abnormality, call the doctor as soon as possible. Examine the testicles once a month, especially if one has had testicular cancer or one has a family history of testicular cancer. Feel along the soft, comma-shaped structure that runs above and behind the testicle (epididymis) to check for swelling.

Name: Seasonal affective disorder ( SAD )
Causes: A drop in serotonin, a brain chemical (neurotransmitter) that affects mood, might play a role in SAD. The change in season can disrupt the balance of the body's level of melatonin, which plays a role in sleep patterns and mood.
Diagnosis: Even with a thorough evaluation, it can sometimes be difficult for the doctor or mental health professional to diagnose seasonal affective disorder because other types of depression or other mental health conditions can cause similar symptoms. To help diagnose SAD, the doctor or mental health professional may do a thorough evaluation, which generally includes: Physical exam. For example, the doctor may do a blood test called a complete blood count (CBC) or test the thyroid to make sure it's functioning properly. To check for signs of depression, the doctor or mental health professional asks about the symptoms, thoughts, feelings and behavior patterns. The mental health professional may use the criteria for seasonal depressive episodes listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), published by the American Psychiatric Association.

Name: Seasonal allergy
Symptoms: Hay fever signs and symptoms can include The hay fever signs and symptoms may start or worsen at a particular time of year. See the doctor if: Many people especially children get used to hay fever symptoms, so they might not seek treatment until the symptoms become severe.
Overview: Hay fever, also called allergic rhinitis, causes cold-like signs and symptoms, such as a runny nose, itchy eyes, congestion, sneezing and sinus pressure. Hay fever is caused by an allergic response to outdoor or indoor allergens, such as pollen, dust mites, or tiny flecks of skin and saliva shed by cats, dogs, and other animals with fur or feathers (pet dander).
Diagnosis: The doctor will perform a physical examination, take a medical history, and possibly recommend one or both of the following tests: Skin prick test. Also called the radioallergosorbent test (RAST), this test measures the amount of allergy-causing antibodies in the bloodstream, known as immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies.
Medication: These prescription nasal sprays help prevent and treat the nasal inflammation, nasal itching and runny nose caused by hay fever. Examples include mometasone (Nasonex) and budesonide (Rhinocort), both available by prescription, and Fluticasone (Flonase Allergy Relief), budesonide (Rhinocort Allergy) and triamcinolone (Nasacort Allergy 24 Hour), available over the counter. Over-the-counter pills include loratadine (Claritin, Alavert), cetirizine (Zyrtec Allergy) and fexofenadine (Allegra Allergy). The prescription antihistamine nasal sprays azelastine (Astelin, Astepro) and olopatadine (Patanase) can relieve nasal symptoms. These medications are available in over-the-counter and prescription liquids, tablets and nasal sprays. Over-the-counter oral decongestants include pseudoephedrine (Sudafed, Afrinol, others). Don't use a decongestant nasal spray for more than two or three days at a time because it can actually worsen symptoms when used continuously (rebound congestion). Available in a prescription nasal spray, ipratropium helps relieve severe runny nose by preventing the glands in the nose from producing excess fluid. If medications don't relieve the hay fever symptoms or cause too many side effects, the doctor may recommend allergy shots (immunotherapy or desensitization therapy). Rinsing the nasal passages with distilled, sterile saline (nasal irrigation) is a quick, inexpensive and effective way to relieve nasal congestion. Because the long-term use of corticosteroids can cause serious side effects such as cataracts, osteoporosis and muscle weakness, they're usually prescribed for only short periods of time.

Name: Sebaceous cysts
Treatment: If one seek treatment, talk with the doctor about these options: One can't stop epidermoid cysts from forming. If the cyst is inflamed, the doctor may delay the surgery.

Name: Seborrheic dermatitis
Overview: Seborrheic dermatitis causes a red rash with yellowish and somewhat oily scales. In addition to the scalp, seborrheic dermatitis can occur on the sides of the nose, in and between the eyebrows, and in other oil-rich areas. Seborrheic dermatitis can also affect oily areas of the body, such as the face, sides of the nose, eyebrows, ears, eyelids and chest.
Risk factors: A number of factors increase the risk of developing seborrheic dermatitis, including Neurologic and psychiatric conditions, such as Parkinson's disease and depression A weakened immune system, such as seen in organ transplant recipients and people with HIV/AIDS, alcoholic pancreatitis and some cancers Recovery from stressful medical conditions, such as a heart attack Some medications Gibson LE (expert opinion). Seborrheic dermatitis: Etiology, risk factors and treatments: Facts and controversies. Rochester, Minn.: Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research; 2016.
Diagnosis: He or she may scrape off skin cells for examination (biopsy) to rule out conditions with symptoms similar to seborrheic dermatitis, including Psoriasis. This skin reaction causes itchy, inflamed skin in the folds of the elbows, on the backs of the knees or on the front of the neck.
Treatment: Prescription-strength hydrocortisone, fluocinolone (Capex, Synalar), clobetasol (Clobex, Cormax) and desonide (Desowen, Desonate) are corticosteroids one apply to the scalp or other affected area. If used for many weeks or months without a break, they can cause side effects, such as thinning skin or skin showing streaks or lines. Creams or lotions containing the calcineurin inhibitors tacrolimus (Protopic) and pimecrolimus (Elidel) may be effective and have fewer side effects than corticosteroids do. If used for many weeks or months without a break, they can cause side effects, such as thinning skin or skin showing streaks or lines.Creams or lotions containing the calcineurin inhibitors tacrolimus (Protopic) and pimecrolimus (Elidel) may be effective and have fewer side effects than corticosteroids do. Depending on the affected area and the severity of the symptoms, the doctor might prescribe a product with 2 percent ketoconazole (Nizoral) or 1 percent ciclopirox.
Remedies: The best approach for one depends on the skin type, the severity of the condition, and whether the symptoms affect the scalp or other areas of the body. They are classified according to the active ingredient they contain: Use a product daily until the signs and symptoms begin to subside, and then use it one to three times a week as needed. Shampoo that contains tar can discolor light-colored hair, so one may want to use other products. The following over-the-counter treatments and self-care tips may help one control seborrheic dermatitis: Pyrithione zinc (Dermazinc, Head & Shoulders) Selenium sulfide (Selsun Blue) Ketoconazole (Nizoral A-D) Tar (Neutrogena T/Gel, DHS Tar) Salicylic acid (Neutrogena T/Sal) Soften and remove scales from the hair. If the eyelids show signs of redness or scaling, wash them each night with baby shampoo and wipe away scales with a cotton swab.
info-Symptoms: Itchy, flaking, greasy, red, and inflamed skin
info-Risk factors: Stress, winter, poor immune function, Parkinson disease
info-Medication: Antifungal cream, anti-inflammatory agents, coal tar, phototherapy

Name: Seborrheic keratosis
Symptoms: One may develop a single growth, though multiple growths are more common. One notice suspicious changes in the skin, such as sores or growths that grow rapidly, bleed and don't heal.
Overview: Seborrheic keratoses are very common on the back. They appear as waxy light tan, brown or black growths that look as if they were dripped onto the skin by a candle. Seborrheic keratoses are usually brown, black or light tan.
Treatment: In some cases when one call to set up an appointment, one may be referred directly to a specialist in skin diseases (dermatologist). It doesn't always work on raised, thicker growths, and it may result in discoloration of treated skin. If one has a raised growth, the doctor may prescribe a solution of 40% hydrogen peroxide (Eskata), which is applied to the skin.

Name: Secondary brain cancer
Overview: This shows tumors that developed after cancer from a tumor elsewhere in the body spread (metastasized) to the brain. Any cancer can spread to the brain, but the types most likely to cause brain metastases are lung, breast, colon, kidney and melanoma. Brain metastases, or secondary brain tumors, occur in 10 to 30 percent of adults with cancer.
Causes: Brain metastases occur when cancer cells travel through the bloodstream or the lymph system from the original tumor and spread (metastasize) to the brain. Brain metastases from lung cancer are often found early in the course of the disease, and those from breast cancer develop late.
Diagnosis: A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment. A dye may be injected through a vein in the arm during the MRI study.A number of specialized MRI scan components including functional MRI, perfusion MRI and magnetic resonance spectroscopy may help the doctor evaluate the tumor and plan treatment.Other imaging tests may include computerized tomography (CT) and positron emission tomography (PET). A biopsy can be performed as part of an operation to remove a brain tumor, or it can be performed using a needle.The biopsy sample is then viewed under a microscope to determine if it is cancerous (malignant) or noncancerous (benign) and whether the cells are metastatic cancer or from a primary tumor.
Treatment: Treatment options for people with brain metastases often include medication, surgery, stereotactic radiosurgery, whole-brain radiation therapy or some combination of these. What treatments are best for one will depend on the size, number and location of the tumors, as well as the signs and symptoms, overall health, and preferences.

Name: Secondary hypertension
Overview: Secondary hypertension (secondary high blood pressure) is high blood pressure that's caused by another medical condition. Secondary hypertension differs from the usual type of high blood pressure (primary hypertension or essential hypertension), which is often referred to simply as high blood pressure. Proper treatment of secondary hypertension can often control both the underlying condition and the high blood pressure, which reduces the risk of serious complications including heart disease, kidney failure and strokes.
Causes: Several kidney diseases may cause secondary hypertension, including Renovascular hypertension. Not getting enough oxygen may damage the lining of the blood vessel walls, which may make the blood vessels less effective in regulating the blood pressure. In addition, sleep apnea causes part of the nervous system to be overactive and release certain chemicals that increase blood pressure. This puts added pressure on the artery walls, increasing the blood pressure. In addition, fat deposits can release chemicals that raise blood pressure. Many illegal drugs, such as cocaine and methamphetamine, also increase blood pressure. Diabetes can damage the kidneys filtering system, which can lead to high blood pressure. In this inherited condition, cysts in the kidneys prevent the kidneys from working normally and can raise blood pressure. If the swollen glomeruli can't work normally, one may develop high blood pressure. This makes the kidneys retain salt and water and lose too much potassium, which raises blood pressure. When the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone (hypothyroidism) or produces too much thyroid hormone (hyperthyroidism), high blood pressure can result. If the glands secrete too much parathyroid hormone, the amount of calcium in the blood rises which triggers a rise in blood pressure. This, in turn, raises blood pressure particularly in the arms. Pregnancy can make existing high blood pressure worse, or may cause high blood pressure to develop (pregnancy-induced hypertension or preeclampsia).
Diagnosis: To diagnose secondary hypertension, the doctor will first take a blood pressure reading using an inflatable cuff, just as the blood pressure is measured during a typical doctor's appointment. The doctor may not diagnose secondary hypertension based on only one higher than normal blood pressure reading. It may take three to six high blood pressure measurements at separate appointments to diagnose secondary hypertension. Since many kidney conditions are linked to secondary hypertension, the doctor may order an ultrasound of the kidneys and blood vessels. The doctor may want to check the potassium, sodium, creatinine, fasting blood glucose, total cholesterol and triglycerides, and other chemicals in the blood to help make a diagnosis. The doctor may want to check the urine for markers that could show the high blood pressure is caused by another medical condition.
Treatment: Often, however, lifestyle changes such as eating healthy foods, increasing physical activity and maintaining a healthy weight can help keep the blood pressure low. One may need to continue to take blood pressure medication as well, and any underlying medical condition one has may affect the doctor's choice of medication. Diuretics, sometimes called water pills, are medications that act on the kidneys to help the body eliminate sodium and water, reducing blood volume. If one is not taking a diuretic and the blood pressure remains high, talk to the doctor about adding one or replacing a drug one currently take with a diuretic. These medications reduce the workload on the heart and open the blood vessels, causing the heart to beat slower and with less force. When prescribed alone, beta blockers don't work as well in black people but they're effective when combined with a thiazide diuretic. ACE inhibitors may be especially important in treating high blood pressure in people with coronary artery disease, heart failure or kidney failure. Like beta blockers, ACE inhibitors don't work as well in black people when prescribed alone, but they're effective when combined with a thiazide diuretic. Like ACE inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor blockers often are useful for people with coronary artery disease, heart failure or kidney failure. Grapefruit juice interacts with some calcium channel blockers, increasing blood levels of the medication and putting one at higher risk of side effects. Although lowering secondary hypertension can be difficult, making the same lifestyle changes one would make if one had primary high blood pressure can help. A lower sodium level 1,500 milligrams (mg) a day is appropriate for people 51 years of age and older and for people of any age who are black or who have hypertension, diabetes or chronic kidney disease. At that point, the primary care doctor may order more tests or refer one to a doctor who specializes in treating whatever the suspected underlying cause of the high blood pressure may be. For example, if the doctor believes that a kidney problem is causing the high blood pressure, one will likely be referred to a doctor who specializes in treating kidney disorders (nephrologist). Get plenty of potassium, which is found in fruits and vegetables such as potatoes, spinach, bananas and apricots, to help prevent and control high blood pressure. If one is overweight, losing even 10 pounds (4.5 kilograms) can lower the blood pressure.
Remedies: Although lowering secondary hypertension can be difficult, making the same lifestyle changes one would make if one had primary high blood pressure can help. A lower sodium level 1,500 milligrams (mg) a day is appropriate for people 51 years of age and older and for people of any age who are black or who have hypertension, diabetes or chronic kidney disease. While one can reduce the amount of salt one eat by putting down the saltshaker, one should also pay attention to the amount of salt that's in the processed foods one eat, such as canned soups or frozen dinners. Try the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet, which emphasizes fruits, vegetables, whole grains and low-fat dairy foods. Get plenty of potassium, which is found in fruits and vegetables such as potatoes, spinach, bananas and apricots, to help prevent and control high blood pressure. If one is overweight, losing even 10 pounds (4.5 kilograms) can lower the blood pressure. If one choose to drink alcohol, do so in moderation up to one drink a day for women and two drinks a day for men aged 65 or younger.

Name: Seizure disorder
Symptoms: Because epilepsy is caused by abnormal activity in the brain, seizures can affect any process the brain coordinates. Doctors generally classify seizures as either focal or generalized, based on how the abnormal brain activity begins. When seizures appear to result from abnormal activity in just one area of the brain, they're called focal (partial) seizures. These seizures fall into two categories: Symptoms of focal seizures may be confused with other neurological disorders, such as migraine, narcolepsy or mental illness. Once called simple partial seizures, these seizures don't cause a loss of consciousness. Once called complex partial seizures, these seizures involve a change or loss of consciousness or awareness. These seizures usually affect muscles in the back, arms and legs and may cause one to fall to the ground. Atonic seizures, also known as drop seizures, cause a loss of muscle control, which may cause one to suddenly collapse or fall down. These seizures usually affect the neck, face and arms.
Causes: Some types of epilepsy, which are categorized by the type of seizure one experience or the part of the brain that is affected, run in families. Researchers have linked some types of epilepsy to specific genes, but for most people, genes are only part of the cause of epilepsy. Brain conditions that cause damage to the brain, such as brain tumors or strokes, can cause epilepsy. Infectious diseases, such as meningitis, AIDS and viral encephalitis, can cause epilepsy.
Risk factors: If one has a family history of epilepsy, one may be at an increased risk of developing a seizure disorder. One can reduce the risk by wearing a seat belt while riding in a car and by wearing a helmet while bicycling, skiing, riding a motorcycle or engaging in other activities with a high risk of head injury. One can take a number of steps to reduce the risk of these diseases, including limiting the intake of alcohol and avoiding cigarettes, eating a healthy diet, and exercising regularly. The risk of epilepsy increases if a child has a long seizure, another nervous system condition or a family history of epilepsy.
Diagnosis: The evaluation may include An electroencephalogram (EEG) can show irregular activity in the brain that can indicate seizures. EEG results show changes in brain activity that may be useful in diagnosing brain conditions, especially epilepsy and other seizure disorders. The doctor may also suggest tests to detect brain abnormalities, such as: Electroencephalogram (EEG). The doctor may monitor one on video when conducting an EEG while one is awake or asleep, to record any seizures one experience. The doctor may give one instructions to do something that will cause seizures, such as getting little sleep prior to the test. A SPECT test uses a small amount of low-dose radioactive material that's injected into a vein to create a detailed, 3-D map of the blood flow activity in the brain during seizures. Doctors also may conduct a form of a SPECT test called subtraction ictal SPECT coregistered to MRI (SISCOM), which may provide even more-detailed results. Along with the test results, the doctor may use a combination of analysis techniques to help pinpoint where in the brain seizures start: Accurate diagnosis of the seizure type and where seizures begin gives one the best chance for finding an effective treatment. High-density EEG may help the doctor more precisely determine which areas of the brain are affected by seizures. SPM is a method of comparing areas of the brain that have increased metabolism during seizures to normal brains, which can give doctors an idea of where seizures begin. Curry analysis is a technique that takes EEG data and projects it onto an MRI of the brain to show doctors where seizures are occurring.
Remedies: Understanding the condition can help one take better control of it: In addition, make healthy life choices, such as managing stress, limiting alcoholic beverages and avoiding cigarettes. Make sure to drink enough water, and rest if one get tired during exercise.
info-Symptoms: Periods of vigorous shaking, nearly undetectable spells
info-Causes: Unknown, brain injury, stroke, brain tumors, infections of the brain, birth defects
info-Diagnostic method: Electroencephalogram, ruling out other possible causes

Name: Seizure , febrile
Symptoms: Simple febrile seizures do not recur within a 24-hour period and are not specific to one part of the body. This type lasts longer than 15 minutes, occurs more than once within 24 hours or is confined to one side of the child's body.
Causes: The fevers that trigger febrile seizures are usually caused by a viral infection, and less commonly by a bacterial infection. Influenza and the virus that causes roseola, which often are accompanied by high fevers, appear to be most frequently associated with febrile seizures.
Diagnosis: In children with delayed immunization or a compromised immune system, the doctor may recommend tests to look for severe infections: To diagnose the cause of a complex febrile seizure, the doctor may also recommend an electroencephalogram (EEG), a test that measures brain activity. The doctor may also recommend an MRI to check the child's brain if the child has: A blood test A urine test A spinal tap (lumbar puncture), to find out if the child has a central nervous system infection, such as meningitis An unusually large head An abnormal neurological evaluation Signs and symptoms of increased pressure in the skull A febrile seizure that lasted an unusually long time EEG (electroencephalogram) Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) Urinalysis

Name: Seizure , petit mal
Causes: In general, seizures are caused by abnormal electrical impulses from nerve cells (neurons) in the brain. People who have seizures may also have altered levels of the chemical messengers that help the nerve cells communicate with one another (neurotransmitters).
Risk factors: Certain factors are common to children who have absence seizures, including Age. Absence seizures are more common in children between the ages of 4 and 14.
Diagnosis: EEG results show changes in brain activity that may be useful in diagnosing brain conditions, especially epilepsy and other seizure disorders. In absence seizures, brain-imaging studies, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), will be normal.
Treatment: Valproic acid has been associated with higher risk of birth defects in babies, and doctors advise women against using it during pregnancy or while trying to conceive. Doctors may recommend the use of valproic acid in children who have both absence and grand mal (tonic-clonic) seizures.
Remedies: Following a diet that's high in fat and low in carbohydrates, known as a ketogenic diet, can improve seizure control. This diet isn't easy to maintain, but is successful at reducing seizures for some people.
