Variations on a high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet, such as the glycemic index and modified Atkins diets, though less effective, aren't as restrictive as the ketogenic diet and may also provide benefit.

Name: Seizures
Symptoms: Seizure signs and symptoms may include Doctors generally classify seizures as either focal or generalized, based on how and where abnormal brain activity begins. Seizures may also be classified as unknown onset, if how the seizure began isn't known. These seizures may alter emotions or change the way things look, smell, feel, taste or sound, but one don't lose consciousness. These seizures usually affect muscles in the back, arms and legs and may cause one to fall to the ground. Atonic seizures, also known as drop seizures, cause a loss of muscle control, which may cause one to suddenly collapse or fall down. Clonic seizures are associated with repeated or rhythmic, jerking muscle movements. These seizures usually affect the neck, face and arms.
Overview: A seizure is a sudden, uncontrolled electrical disturbance in the brain. Most seizure disorders can be controlled with medication, but management of seizures can still have a significant impact on the daily life.
Diagnosis: EEG results show changes in brain activity that may be useful in diagnosing brain conditions, especially epilepsy and other seizure disorders. Tests may include Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create clear and detailed cross-sectional images of the head and body.One don't need to prepare for an MRI. Tell the MRI technologist if one has metal or electronic devices in the body, because their presence may be a safety hazard. Depending on where one need magnetic resonance imaging, a small device called a coil may be placed around the body part being examined. Magnetic resonance imaging is safe for children, and an adult may stay in the scanning room for reassurance. The doctor may test the behavior, motor abilities and mental function to determine if one has a problem with the brain and nervous system. If the doctor suspects an infection as the cause of a seizure, one may need to have a sample of cerebrospinal fluid removed for testing. A SPECT test uses a small amount of low-dose radioactive material that's injected into a vein to create a detailed, 3-D map of the blood flow activity in the brain that happens during a seizure. Doctors also may conduct a form of a SPECT test called subtraction ictal SPECT coregistered to MRI (SISCOM), which may provide even more-detailed results.
Remedies: Here are some steps one can take to help with seizure control: Seizures don't usually result in serious injury, but if one has recurrent seizures, injury is a possibility. These steps can help one avoid injury during a seizure: It's helpful to know what to do if one witness someone having a seizure. If one is at risk of having seizures in the future, pass this information along to family, friends and co-workers so that they know what to do if one has a seizure. Carefully roll the person onto one side Place something soft under his or her head Loosen tight neckwear Avoid putting the fingers or other objects in the person's mouth Don't try to restrain someone having a seizure Clear away dangerous objects, if the person is moving Stay with the person until medical personnel arrive Observe the person closely so that one can provide details on what happened Time the seizure Stay calm Take medication correctly.
info-Symptoms: Variable
info-Causes: Provoked: Low blood sugar, alcohol withdrawal, low blood sodium, fever, brain infection, concussionUnprovoked: Unknown, brain injury, brain tumor, previous stroke
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, blood tests, medical imaging, electroencephalography
info-Treatment: Less than 5 min: Place person on their side, remove nearby dangerous objectsMore than 5 min: Treat as per status epilepticus
info-Frequency: ~10% of people (at one point in time)

Name: Selective IgA deficiency
Overview: Selective IgA deficiency is an immune system condition in which one lack or don't have enough immunoglobulin A (IgA), a protein that fights infection (antibody). However, some people who have IgA deficiency experience pneumonia, ear infections, sinus infections, allergies, asthma and diarrhea. Autoimmune diseases, in which the immune system attacks particular organs or tissues in the own body, can be found with selective IgA deficiency. Common autoimmune conditions found with IgA deficiency include rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, celiac disease or inflammatory bowel disease.
Treatment: Most people with selective IgA deficiency don't need treatment unless they have frequent infections. In some cases, treatment may include a long course of antibiotics to help prevent an infection from returning.

Name: Self-injury/cutting
Symptoms: If one is injuring theself, even in a minor way, or if one has thoughts of harming theself, reach out for help. While one may feel ashamed and embarrassed about the behavior, one can find supportive, caring and nonjudgmental help. If one has a friend or loved one who is self-injuring, one may be shocked and scared. Although one might feel that oned be betraying a confidence, self-injury is too big a problem to ignore or to deal with alone. Suggest that the friend talk to parents, a teacher, a school counselor or another trusted adult. Seek help from the school nurse or counselor, teacher, doctor, or other health care provider.
Overview: Nonsuicidal self-injury, often simply called self-injury, is the act of deliberately harming the own body, such as cutting or burning theself. While self-injury may bring a momentary sense of calm and a release of tension, it's usually followed by guilt and shame and the return of painful emotions.
Risk factors: Most people who self-injure are teenagers and young adults, although those in other age groups also self-injure. Self-injury often starts in the preteen or early teen years, when emotions are more volatile and teens face increasing peer pressure, loneliness, and conflicts with parents or other authority figures. Certain factors may increase the risk of self-injury, including Having friends who self-injure. They may have grown up and still remain in an unstable family environment, or they may be young people questioning their personal identity or sexuality. In addition, self-injury is commonly associated with certain mental disorders, such as borderline personality disorder, depression, anxiety disorders, post-traumatic stress disorder and eating disorders.
Treatment: Because self-injury can become a major part of the life, it's best to get treatment from a mental health professional experienced in self-injury issues. If the self-injury behavior is associated with a mental health disorder, such as depression or borderline personality disorder, the treatment plan focuses on that disorder, as well as the self-injury behavior.
Remedies: In addition to professional treatment, here are some important self-care tips: Stick to the treatment plan. Make a plan for other ways to soothe or distract theself or to get support, so one is ready the next time one feel the urge to self-injure.

Name: Separation anxiety disorder
Overview: Separation anxiety is a normal stage of development for infants and toddlers. Less often, separation anxiety disorder can also occur in teenagers and adults, causing significant problems leaving home or going to work.
Treatment: Psychotherapy, sometimes called talk therapy or psychological counseling, involves working with a therapist to reduce separation anxiety symptoms. While separation anxiety disorder benefits from professional treatment, one can also take these steps to help ease the child's separation anxiety: Coping with a child who has separation anxiety disorder can be frustrating and cause conflict with family members or cause a great deal of worry and anxiety for parents. For example, the therapist may advise one to: It's also important to develop and maintain supportive relationships for theself, so one can better help the child. Learn about the child's separation anxiety disorder. Practice the strategies developed with the mental health professional so one is ready to deal with the child's anxious feelings during separations.
Remedies: While separation anxiety disorder benefits from professional treatment, one can also take these steps to help ease the child's separation anxiety: Learn about the child's separation anxiety disorder. Talk to the child's mental health professional to learn about the disorder and help the child understand it. Practice the strategies developed with the mental health professional so one is ready to deal with the child's anxious feelings during separations. Learn about the child's separation anxiety disorder.

Name: Sepsis
Overview: Sepsis is a potentially life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection. Sepsis occurs when the body's response to these chemicals is out of balance, triggering changes that can damage multiple organ systems. Sepsis is most common and most dangerous in: Early treatment of sepsis, usually with antibiotics and large amounts of intravenous fluids, improves chances for survival.
Diagnosis: A blood sample drawn from two distinct sites is tested for: Depending on the symptoms, the doctor may also want to run tests on one or more of the following bodily fluids: If the site of infection is not obvious, the doctor may order one or more of the following imaging tests: Evidence of infection Clotting problems Abnormal liver or kidney function Impaired oxygen availability Electrolyte imbalances Urine. If the doctor suspects that one has a urinary tract infection, he or she may want to check the urine for signs of bacteria. If one is coughing up mucus (sputum), it may be tested to determine what type of germ is causing the infection.
Medication: After learning the results of blood tests, the doctor may switch to a different antibiotic that's targeted to fight the particular bacteria causing the infection. Other medications one may receive include low doses of corticosteroids, insulin to help maintain stable blood sugar levels, drugs that modify the immune system responses, and painkillers or sedatives. Surgery may be needed to remove sources of infection, such as collections of pus (abscesses), infected tissues or gangrene. People who have sepsis often receive intravenous fluids right away, usually within three hours. If the blood pressure remains too low even after receiving intravenous fluids, one may be given a vasopressor medication, which constricts blood vessels and helps to increase blood pressure.
info-Symptoms: Fever, increased heart rate, low blood pressure, increased breathing rate, low urine output or absent or near absent urine output, severe pain, confusion
info-Usual onset: May be rapid (<3 hours) or prolonged (several days)
info-Causes: Immune response triggered by an infection
info-Risk factors: Young or old age, cancer, diabetes, major trauma, asthma, Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, multiple myeloma, burns

Name: Septal defect , atrial
Causes: The lower chambers, the right and left ventricles, pump blood out of the heart. To pump blood throughout the body, the heart uses its left and right sides for different tasks. In the lungs, blood picks up oxygen then returns it to the heart's left side. Doctors know that heart defects present at birth (congenital) arise from errors early in the heart's development, but there's often no clear cause. A large atrial septal defect can cause extra blood to overfill the lungs and overwork the right side of the heart.
Risk factors: It's not known why atrial septal defects occur, but some congenital heart defects appear to run in families and sometimes occur with other genetic problems, such as Down syndrome. Some conditions that one has during pregnancy can increase the risk of having a baby with a heart defect, including Rubella infection.
Diagnosis: Hearing a heart murmur during a checkup might cause the or the child's doctor to suspect an atrial septal defect or other heart defect. For a suspected heart defect, the doctor might request one or more of the following tests: Echocardiogram. Through catheterization, doctors can diagnose congenital heart defects, test how well the heart is pumping, check heart valve function and measure the blood pressure in the lungs. Doctors might also use catheterization techniques to repair heart defects. The doctor might request an MRI if echocardiography can't definitively diagnose an atrial septal defect or related conditions. It can be used to diagnose an atrial septal defect and related congenital heart defects if echocardiography hasn't definitely diagnosed an atrial septal defect.
Remedies: Atrial septal defects generally aren't associated with infective endocarditis, though the doctor will likely recommend preventive antibiotics for about six months after closure whenever one has dental work done. But if one has other heart defects besides an atrial septal defect, or if one has had atrial septal defect repair within the last six months, one might need to take antibiotics before certain dental or surgical procedures.
Medication: Medications won't repair the hole, but they may be used to reduce some of the signs and symptoms that can accompany an atrial septal defect. Some large secundum atrial septal defects, however, might require open-heart surgery. This procedure can be done using small incisions (minimally invasive surgery) and with a robot for some types of atrial septal defects. For simple atrial septal defects closed during childhood, only occasional follow-up care generally is needed. Adults whove had atrial septal defect repair need to be monitored throughout life to check for complications, such as pulmonary hypertension, arrhythmias, heart failure or valve problems.

Name: Septal defect , atrioventricular
Symptoms: Atrioventricular canal defect can involve only the two upper chambers of the heart (partial) or all four chambers (complete). These signs and symptoms can include See the doctor if one or the child develops signs or symptoms of atrioventricular canal defect.
Overview: Atrioventricular canal defect is a combination of heart problems resulting in a defect in the center of the heart. Untreated, atrioventricular canal defect can cause heart failure and high blood pressure in the lungs.
Causes: The upper chambers, the right and left atria, receive incoming blood. The lower chambers, the right and left ventricles, pump blood out of the heart. Atrioventricular canal defect includes a hole in the wall between the heart's chambers and flaws in the heart's valves. The heart is divided into four chambers, two on the right and two on the left. There's a large hole in the center of the heart where the walls between the atria and the lower chambers (ventricles) meet. Instead of separate valves on the right and left, there's one large valve between the upper and lower chambers.
Diagnosis: When listening to the baby's heart, the doctor might hear an abnormal whooshing sound (heart murmur) caused by turbulent blood flow. If the baby is experiencing the signs and symptoms of atrioventricular canal defect, the doctor might recommend: Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG). A thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted into a blood vessel in the groin and up to the heart.

Name: Septic arthritis
Overview: Septic arthritis is a painful infection in a joint. Knees are most commonly affected, but septic arthritis also can affect hips, shoulders and other joints.
Risk factors: Chronic diseases and conditions that affect the joints such as osteoarthritis, gout, rheumatoid arthritis or lupus can increase the risk of septic arthritis, as can an artificial joint, previous joint surgery and joint injury. People with rheumatoid arthritis have a further increase in risk because of medications they take that can suppress the immune system, making infections more likely to occur. Skin conditions such as psoriasis and eczema increase the risk of septic arthritis, as do infected skin wounds. Animal bites, puncture wounds or cuts over a joint can put one at risk of septic arthritis.
Diagnosis: The following tests typically help diagnose septic arthritis: Joint fluid analysis. Infections can alter the color, consistency, volume and makeup of the fluid within the joints.
info-Symptoms: Red, hot, painful single joint
info-Risk factors: Artificial joint, prior arthritis, diabetes, poor immune function
info-Prognosis: 15% risk of death (treatment), 66% risk of death (without treatment)

Name: Serotonin syndrome
Overview: Serotonin syndrome occurs when one take medications that cause high levels of the chemical serotonin to accumulate in the body. Milder forms of serotonin syndrome may go away within a day of stopping the medications that cause symptoms and, sometimes, after taking drugs that block serotonin.
Causes: Under normal circumstances, nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord produce serotonin that helps regulate the attention, behavior and body temperature. For example, serotonin syndrome may occur if one take an antidepressant with a migraine medication. A number of over-the-counter and prescription drugs may be associated with serotonin syndrome, especially antidepressants.
Diagnosis: To make sure the symptoms are caused by serotonin syndrome and not due to another cause, the doctor may use tests to: A number of conditions can cause symptoms similar to those of serotonin syndrome. Minor symptoms can be caused by several conditions, while moderate and severe symptoms similar to those of serotonin syndrome could be caused by: The doctor may order additional tests to rule out other causes of the symptoms. Tests may include Measure levels of any drugs one is using Check for signs of infection Check body functions that may be affected by serotonin syndrome A serious reaction to certain medications, such as some anesthetics, antipsychotic drugs and other agents known to produce these severe reactions An overdose of illegal drugs, antidepressant medications or other medications that increase serotonin levels Damage associated with illegal drug use Severe alcohol withdrawal Blood and urine tests Chest X-ray CT scan Spinal tap (lumbar puncture)
Treatment: Depending on the symptoms, one may receive the following treatments: Drugs that control heart rate and blood pressure. If the blood pressure is too low, the doctor may give one phenylephrine (Vazculep) or epinephrine (Adrenalin, Epipen, others). Milder forms of serotonin syndrome usually go away within 24 to 72 hours of stopping medications that increase serotonin, and by taking medications to block the effects of serotonin already in the system if they're needed. If the symptoms are minor, If one has symptoms that concern the doctor, If one has severe serotonin syndrome, Muscle relaxants.
info-Symptoms: High body temperature, agitation, increased reflexes, tremor, sweating, dilated pupils, diarrhea
info-Causes: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI), tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), amphetamines, pethidine (meperidine), tramadol, dextromethorphan, ondansetron, cocaine
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and medication use

Name: Severe acute respiratory syndrome ( SARS )
Treatment: Despite a concerted global effort, scientists have yet to find an effective treatment for SARS. McIntosh K. Severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). Hospital infection control guidance for severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

Name: Severe brain injury , coma
Overview: A coma is a state of prolonged unconsciousness that can be caused by a variety of problems traumatic head injury, stroke, brain tumor, drug or alcohol intoxication, or even an underlying illness, such as diabetes or an infection. Depending on the cause of a coma, people who are in a persistent vegetative state for more than one year are extremely unlikely to awaken.
Causes: Traumatic brain injuries, often caused by traffic collisions or acts of violence, are common causes of comas. In people with diabetes, blood sugar levels that become too high (hyperglycemia) or too low (hypoglycemia) can cause a coma. Infections such as encephalitis and meningitis cause swelling (inflammation) of the brain, spinal cord or the tissues that surround the brain. Severe cases of these infections can result in brain damage or a coma. Exposure to toxins, such as carbon monoxide or lead, can cause brain damage and a coma.
Diagnosis: Be prepared to provide information about the affected person, including In a physical exam, doctors will check the affected person's movements and reflexes, response to painful stimuli, and pupil size. To determine the affected person's level of consciousness, doctors may speak loudly or press on the angle of the jaw or nail bed. Tests may include Events leading up to the coma, such as vomiting or headaches Details about how the affected person lost consciousness, including whether it occurred suddenly or over time Any noticeable signs or symptoms prior to losing consciousness The affected person's medical history, including other conditions he or she may have had in the past, such as a stroke or transient ischemic attacks Recent changes in the affected person's health or behavior The affected person's drug use, including prescription and over-the-counter medications as well as unapproved medications or illegal, recreational drugs Complete blood count Electrolytes, glucose, thyroid, kidney and liver function Carbon monoxide poisoning Drug or alcohol overdose Computerized tomography (CT) scan.
Treatment: Emergency personnel may administer glucose or antibiotics intravenously, even before blood test results return, in case of diabetic shock or an infection affecting the brain. If the coma is the result of drug overdose, doctors will give medications to treat the condition. If the coma is due to seizures, doctors will administer medications to control seizures. Other treatments may focus on medications or therapies to address an underlying disease, such as diabetes or liver disease. Sometimes the cause of a coma can be completely reversed and the affected person will regain normal function. But if the affected person has suffered severe brain damage, he or she may sustain permanent disabilities or may never regain consciousness. If one is with a person who develops signs and symptoms of a coma, call 911 or the local emergency number immediately. When one arrive at the hospital, emergency room staff will need as much information as possible from family and friends about what happened to the affected person before the coma. Did one notice any changes in the affected person's ability to function in the time leading up to the coma, such as frequent falls or confusion?

Name: Sex headaches
Symptoms: There are two types of sex headaches: In some people, both types of headaches are combined. But consult the doctor right away if one experience a headache during sexual activity especially if it begins abruptly or it's the first headache of this type.
Diagnosis: Sometimes a spinal tap (lumbar puncture) is needed as well especially if the headache started abruptly and very recently and brain imaging is normal. CT scan Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) MRI Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI Computerized tomography (CT).

Name: Sexual dysfunction , female
Symptoms: The desire for sex might be intact, but one has difficulty with arousal or are unable to become aroused or maintain arousal during sexual activity. One has persistent or recurrent difficulty in achieving orgasm after sufficient sexual arousal and ongoing stimulation.
Causes: Major illness, such as cancer, diabetes, or heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) disease, can also contribute to sexual dysfunction. The vaginal lining also becomes thinner and less elastic, particularly if one is not sexually active. The body's hormone levels also shift after giving birth and during breast-feeding, which can lead to vaginal dryness and can affect the desire to have sex. Untreated anxiety or depression can cause or contribute to sexual dysfunction, as can long-term stress and a history of sexual abuse. Any number of medical conditions, including cancer, kidney failure, multiple sclerosis, heart disease and bladder problems, can lead to sexual dysfunction. Certain medications, including some antidepressants, blood pressure medications, antihistamines and chemotherapy drugs, can decrease the sexual desire and the body's ability to experience orgasm.
Diagnosis: To diagnose female sexual dysfunction, the doctor may: The doctor may also refer one to a counselor or therapist specializing in sexual and relationship problems. During the exam, the doctor checks for physical changes that affect the sexual enjoyment, such as thinning of the genital tissues, decreased skin elasticity, scarring or pain.
Remedies: To boost the sexual health, find ways to be comfortable with the sexuality, improve the self-esteem and accept the body. Less blood reaches the sexual organs, which means one could experience decreased sexual arousal and orgasmic response. Being relaxed can enhance the ability to focus on the sexual experiences and may help one attain more satisfying arousal and orgasm.

Name: Sexual obsession
Symptoms: xa0Compulsive sexual behavior tends to escalate over time, so get help when one first recognize there may be a problem. As one decide whether to seek professional help, ask theself: Seeking help for compulsive sexual behavior can be difficult because it's such a deeply personal matter. One feel driven to do certain sexual behaviors, feel a release of the tension afterward, but also feel guilt or remorse. One use compulsive sexual behavior as an escape from other problems, such as loneliness, depression, anxiety or stress. But not all mental health professionals are experienced in treating compulsive sexual behavior, so make sure one find a therapist who is competent in this area.
Causes: Although the causes of compulsive sexual behavior are unclear, they may include An imbalance of natural brain chemicals. Certain diseases or health problems, such as epilepsy and dementia, may cause damage to parts of the brain that affect sexual behavior. In addition, treatment of Parkinson's disease with some dopamine agonist medications may cause compulsive sexual behavior.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase risk of compulsive sexual behavior include Also, an increased risk of compulsive sexual behavior may occur in people who have: Ease of access to sexual content. Alcohol or drug abuse problems Another mental health condition, such as a mood disorder (such as depression or anxiety), or a gambling addiction Family conflicts or family members with problems such as addiction A history of physical or sexual abuse
Medication: In addition to psychotherapy, certain medications may help because they act on brain chemicals linked to obsessive thoughts and behaviors, reduce the chemical rewards these behaviors provide when one act on them, or reduce sexual urges. Certain types of antidepressants used to treat depression, anxiety or obsessive-compulsive disorder may help with compulsive sexual behavior. These medications are generally used to treat bipolar disorder, but may reduce compulsive sexual urges. Because they reduce sexual urges, anti-androgens are often used in men whose compulsive sexual behavior is dangerous to others. Learn about the disorder Find support and understanding of the condition Identify additional treatment options, coping behaviors and resources Help with relapse prevention Antidepressants.

Name: Shaken baby syndrome
Symptoms: Shaken baby syndrome symptoms and signs include One may not see any signs of physical injury to the child's outer body. In mild cases of shaken baby syndrome, a child may appear normal after being shaken, but over time he or she may develop health or behavioral problems. Getting medical care right away may save the child's life or prevent serious health problems.
Diagnosis: A child who's been forcefully shaken may need to be examined by many different medical specialists, as well as an expert in child abuse. Various tests may be needed to detect injuries, including Depending on the extent of the injuries, the baby may need to be monitored in a pediatric intensive care unit. Several X-rays of the bones possibly including the arms, hands, legs, feet, spine, ribs and skull may be used to determine whether fractures are accidental or purposeful. Because MRI is difficult to perform on a child who's unstable, it's usually done two to three days after the injury.
Treatment: Fetal and Pediatric Pathology, 2015;34:169. Acceptance of shaken baby syndrome and abusive head trauma as medical diagnoses. Child abuse: Epidemiology, mechanisms, and types of abusive head trauma in infants and children. Non-accidental trauma in pediatric patients: A review of epidemiology, pathophysiology, diagnosis and treatment.
info-Symptoms: Variable

Name: Sheehan 's syndrome
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of Sheehan's syndrome typically appear slowly, after a period of months or years. Signs and symptoms include For many women, Sheehan's syndrome symptoms are often thought to be caused by other things. It's also possible to remain relatively symptom-free if one has Sheehan's syndrome, depending on the extent of damage to the pituitary gland.
Causes: These factors can be particularly damaging to the pituitary gland, which enlarges during pregnancy, destroying hormone-producing tissue so that the gland can't function normally. Hormones from the front of the pituitary gland include Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). A low level of adrenal hormones caused by damage to the pituitary gland is called secondary adrenal insufficiency.
Diagnosis: Also, be sure to tell the doctor if one didn't produce breast milk or one failed to start menstruating after delivery two key signs of Sheehan's syndrome. One might need stimulation testing of the pituitary hormones, which involves injecting hormones and running repeated blood tests to see how the pituitary responds. One might also need imaging tests, such as an MRI scan or CT scan, to check the size of the pituitary gland and to look for other possible reasons for the symptoms, such as a pituitary tumor.
Treatment: Hydrocortisone (Cortef) or prednisone (Rayos), replace the adrenal hormones that aren't being produced because of an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) deficiency. Preparations containing luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), also called gonadotropins, might make future pregnancies possible. If the primary care provider suspects Sheehan's syndrome, one will likely be referred to a doctor who specializes in hormonal disorders (endocrinologist). Growth hormone may improve the body's muscle-to-fat ratio, maintain bone mass and lower cholesterol levels.

Name: Shellfish allergy
Overview: Shellfish allergy is an abnormal response by the body's immune system to proteins in certain marine animals. Marine animals in the shellfish category include crustaceans and mollusks, such as shrimp, crab, lobster, squid, oysters, scallops and others.
Causes: In shellfish allergy, the immune system mistakenly identifies a certain protein in shellfish as harmful, triggering the production of antibodies to the shellfish protein (allergen). There are several types of shellfish, each containing different proteins: Some people are allergic to only one type of shellfish but can eat others.
Diagnosis: He or she may also recommend one or both of the following tests: A history of allergic reactions shortly after exposure to shellfish can be a sign of a shellfish allergy, but allergy testing is the only sure way to tell what's causing the symptoms and to rule out other possibilities, such as food poisoning. Also called an allergen-specific IgE antibody test or radioallergosorbent (RAST) test, this test can measure the immune system's response to shellfish proteins by measuring the amount of certain antibodies, known as immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies, in the bloodstream.
Treatment: The doctor may instruct one to treat a mild allergic reaction to shellfish with medications such as antihistamines to reduce signs and symptoms, such as a rash and itchiness. If one has a severe allergic reaction to shellfish (anaphylaxis), one will likely need an emergency injection of epinephrine (adrenaline). If one is at risk for anaphylaxis to shellfish, the doctor may instruct one to administer epinephrine even at the first sign of an allergic reaction.

Name: Shigella infection
Causes: If one don't wash the hands well after changing the diaper of a child who has shigella infection, one may become infected theself. Water may become contaminated either from sewage or from a person with shigella infection swimming in it.
Risk factors: Children under age 5 are most likely to get shigella infection, but it can occur at any age. Shigella outbreaks are more common in child care centers, community wading pools, nursing homes, jails and military barracks.

Name: Shin splints
Overview: The term shin splints refers to pain along the shin bone (tibia) the large bone in the front of the lower leg. Medically known as medial tibial stress syndrome, shin splints often occur in athletes who have recently intensified or changed their training routines.
Treatment: In most cases, one can treat shin splints with simple self-care steps: Resume the usual activities gradually after the pain is gone. Avoid activities that cause pain, swelling or discomfort but don't give up all physical activity. Apply ice packs to the affected shin for 15 to 20 minutes at a time, four to eight times a day for several days. Try ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) to reduce pain.
info-Symptoms: Pain along the inside edge of the shinbone
info-Risk factors: Runners, dancers, military personnel
info-Treatment: Rest with gradual return to exercise

Name: Short bowel syndrome
Overview: Short bowel syndrome is a condition in which the body is unable to absorb enough nutrients from the foods one eat because one don't have enough small intestine. Conditions that may require surgical removal of large portions of the small intestine include Crohn's disease, cancer, traumatic injuries and blood clots in the arteries that provide blood to the intestines.
Treatment: The treatment options for short bowel syndrome will depend on what parts of the small intestine are affected, whether the colon is intact and the own preferences. People with small bowel syndrome will need to follow a special diet and take nutritional supplements. Some people may need to get nutrition through a vein (parenteral nutrition) or a feeding tube (enteral nutrition) to prevent malnutrition. In addition to nutritional support, the doctor may recommend drugs to help manage short bowel syndrome, such as medications to help control stomach acid, reduce diarrhea or improve intestinal absorption after surgery. Doctors may recommend surgery for children and adults with short bowel syndrome. Types of surgery include procedures to slow the passage of nutrients through the intestine or a procedure to lengthen the intestine (autologous gastrointestinal reconstruction), as well as small bowel transplantation (SBT).
info-Symptoms: Diarrhea, dehydration, malnutrition, weight loss
info-Causes: Surgical removal of a large portion of the small intestine
info-Risk factors: Crohn's disease, necrotising enterocolitis
info-Prognosis: Depends on amount of small bowel remaining
info-Frequency: 3 per million per year, in which is a rare disorder
info-Medication: Antibiotics, antacids, loperamide, teduglutide, growth hormone

Name: Shoulder dislocation
Symptoms: While one is waiting for medical attention: A visibly deformed or out-of-place shoulder Swelling or bruising Intense pain Inability to move the joint Don't move the joint. Applying ice to the shoulder can help reduce pain and swelling by controlling internal bleeding and the buildup of fluids in and around the shoulder joint.
Causes: In addition, fibrous tissue that joins the bones of the shoulder can be stretched or torn, often complicating the dislocation. Partial dislocation in which the upper arm bone is partially in and partially out of the shoulder socket also may occur.
Treatment: Dislocated shoulder treatment may involve: If one has a fairly simple shoulder dislocation without major nerve or tissue damage, the shoulder joint likely will improve over a few weeks, but one will be at increased risk for future dislocation. After two or three days, when the pain and inflammation have improved, hot packs or a heating pad may help relax tight and sore muscles. Depending on the amount of pain and swelling, one may need a muscle relaxant or sedative or, rarely, a general anesthetic before manipulation of the shoulder bones. When the shoulder bones are back in place, severe pain should improve almost immediately. After the shoulder splint or sling is removed, one will begin a gradual rehabilitation program designed to restore range of motion, strength and stability to the shoulder joint. Don't repeat the specific action that caused the shoulder to dislocate, and try to avoid painful movements. Over-the-counter (OTC) medications, such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), may help relieve pain. After one or two days, do some gentle exercises as directed by the doctor or physical therapist to help maintain the shoulder's range of motion.
Remedies: After two or three days, when the pain and inflammation have improved, hot packs or a heating pad may help relax tight and sore muscles. Don't repeat the specific action that caused the shoulder to dislocate, and try to avoid painful movements. Over-the-counter (OTC) medications, such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), may help relieve pain. After one or two days, do some gentle exercises as directed by the doctor or physical therapist to help maintain the shoulder's range of motion.
info-Symptoms: Shoulder pain
info-Causes: Fall onto an outstretched arm or the shoulder.
info-Medication: Procedural sedation and analgesia, intraarticular lidocaine

Name: Shoulder separation
Medication: Over-the-counter pain relievers, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve), may help ease shoulder pain. If pain persists or if one has a severe separation or fracture of the clavicle, surgery might be an option. Avoid activities that aggravate the shoulder pain, especially crossing the affected arm in front of the body.
info-Symptoms: Pain, deformity, decreased range of motion
info-Risk factors: Contact sports
info-Treatment: Type I and II: Sling and pain medicationType III: Conservative management and surgery if still symptomsType IV, V, VI: Surgery

Name: Shy-Drager syndrome
Overview: Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a rare, degenerative neurological disorder affecting the body's involuntary (autonomic) functions, including blood pressure, breathing, bladder function and motor control. Formerly called Shy-Drager syndrome, olivopontocerebellar atrophy or striatonigral degeneration, MSA shares many Parkinson's disease-like symptoms, such as slow movement, rigid muscles and poor balance.
Diagnosis: Certain signs and symptoms of MSA such as muscle rigidity and unsteady gait also occur with other disorders, such as Parkinson's disease, making the diagnosis more difficult. The clinical examination, with various autonomic tests and imaging studies, can help the doctor determine whether the diagnosis is probable MSA or possible MSA. However, doctors are increasingly aware of the disease and more likely to use physical examination and autonomic tests to determine if MSA is the most likely cause of the symptoms. If the doctor suspects multiple system atrophy, he or she will obtain a medical history, perform a physical examination and possibly order blood tests. Brain imaging scans, such as an MRI, can show signs that may suggest MSA and also help determine if there are other causes that may be contributing to the symptoms. Doctors may order other tests to assess the body's involuntary functions, including If one has sleep irregularities, especially interrupted breathing or snoring, the doctor may recommend an evaluation in a sleep laboratory.
Treatment: To treat specific signs and symptoms, the doctor may recommend: Medications to raise blood pressure. Midodrine (Orvaten) can raise the blood pressure quickly; however, it needs to be taken carefully as it can elevate pressure while lying down. Certain medications used to treat Parkinson's disease, such as combined levodopa and carbidopa (Duopa, Sinemet, others), can be used to reduce Parkinson's disease-like signs and symptoms, such as stiffness, balance problems and slowness of movement. Impotence can be treated with a variety of drugs, such as sildenafil (Revatio, Viagra), designed to manage erectile dysfunction. In advanced MSA, one may require a tube (gastrostomy tube) that delivers food directly into the stomach. Eventually, when the disease becomes advanced, one may need to have a soft tube (catheter) inserted permanently to allow one to drain the bladder.
Remedies: Doctors often advise using certain self-care measures to help minimize MSA symptoms, such as: Take steps to raise the blood pressure. Salt and fluids can increase blood volume and raise the blood pressure. Drink coffee and other caffeinated fluids to raise the blood pressure. Raising the head of the bed by about 4 to 6 inches will minimize increases in blood pressure when one sleep. Wear elastic support stockings up to the waist.xa0This can help keep the blood pressure from dropping.

Name: Sick sinus syndrome
Causes: In a normal heart rhythm, a tiny cluster of cells at the sinus node sends out an electrical signal. The rhythm of the heart is normally controlled by the sinus node, an area of specialized cells in the right upper heart chamber (atrium). From the sinus node, electrical signals travel across the atria to the ventricles, causing them to contract and pump blood to the lungs and body. Signals from the sinus node pause, causing skipped beats. Signals to the upper heart chambers are slowed or blocked, causing a pause or skipped beats. The heart rate alternates between abnormally slow and fast rhythms, usually with a long pause (asystole) between heartbeats.
Diagnosis: Electrodes are placed on the chest to record the heart's electrical signals, which cause the heart to beat. Symptoms of sick sinus syndrome such as dizziness, shortness of breath and fainting only occur when the heart is beating abnormally. To determine if the symptoms are related to problems with the sinus node and heart function, the doctor may use the following tests: This test is rarely used to screen for sick sinus syndrome. During this test, thin, flexible tubes (catheters) tipped with electrodes are threaded through the blood vessels to various spots along the electrical pathways in the heart. Once in place, the electrodes can precisely map the spread of electrical impulses during each beat and may identify the source of heart rhythm problems. During this test, sensors (electrodes) are attached to the chest and legs to create a record of the electrical signals traveling through the heart. The test might show patterns that indicate sick sinus syndrome, including a fast heart rate, slow heart rate or long pause in the heartbeat after a fast heart rate. It automatically records the heart's activity for 24 to 72 hours, which provides the doctor with an extended look at the heart rhythms. This portable ECG, which may be worn up to a month, enables the doctor to correlate symptoms and heart rhythm. This small ECG device is implanted just under the skin of the chest and is used for continuous, long-term monitoring of the heart's electrical activity, particularly if one has infrequent symptoms.
Remedies: One many not necessarily prevent sick sinus syndrome, but one can take steps to keep the heart as healthy as possible and lower the risk of cardiovascular disease: Exercise and eat a healthy diet. If one smoke and can't quit on the own, talk to the doctor about strategies or programs to help one break a smoking habit. If one can't control the alcohol use, talk to the doctor about a program to quit drinking and manage other behaviors related to alcohol use.

Name: Sickle cell anemia
Symptoms: Sickle cells break apart easily and die, leaving one with too few red blood cells. But sickle cells usually die in 10 to 20 days, leaving a shortage of red blood cells (anemia). Without enough red blood cells, the body can't get enough oxygen, causing fatigue. Periodic episodes of pain, called pain crises, are a major symptom of sickle cell anemia. Pain develops when sickle-shaped red blood cells block blood flow through tiny blood vessels to the chest, abdomen and joints. Some adolescents and adults with sickle cell anemia also have chronic pain, which can result from bone and joint damage, ulcers, and other causes. The swelling is caused by sickle-shaped red blood cells blocking blood flow to the hands and feet. Sickle cells can damage the spleen, leaving one more vulnerable to infections. Doctors commonly give infants and children with sickle cell anemia vaccinations and antibiotics to prevent potentially life-threatening infections, such as pneumonia. A shortage of healthy red blood cells can slow growth in infants and children and delay puberty in teenagers. People with sickle cell anemia have an increased risk of serious infection, and fever can be the first sign of an infection.
Overview: Normal red blood cells are rounded and disk-shaped. In sickle cell anemia, some red blood cells become deformed, so they look like sickles used to cut wheat. Sickle cell anemia is an inherited red blood cell disorder in which there aren't enough healthy red blood cells to carry oxygen throughout the body.
Remedies: Taking the following steps to stay healthy may help one avoid complications of sickle cell anemia: Take folic acid supplements daily, and choose a healthy diet. Use OTC pain medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, Children's Motrin, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve), sparingly, if at all, because of the possible effect on the kidneys. Take folic acid supplements daily, and choose a healthy diet.
Medication: Doing so helps prevent infections, such as pneumonia, which can be life-threatening to children with sickle cell anemia. Adults who have sickle cell anemia may need to take penicillin throughout their lives, if theyve had pneumonia or surgery to remove the spleen. In a red blood cell transfusion, red blood cells are removed from a supply of donated blood, then given through a vein to a person with sickle cell anemia. This increases the number of normal red blood cells, which helps reduce symptoms and complications. Also known as bone marrow transplant, this procedure involves replacing bone marrow affected by sickle cell anemia with healthy bone marrow from a donor. The procedure usually uses a matched donor, such as a sibling, who doesn't have sickle cell anemia. Because of the risks associated with a bone marrow transplant, the procedure is recommended only for people, usually children, who have significant symptoms and complications of sickle cell anemia.
info-Symptoms: Attacks of pain, anemia, swelling in the hands and feet, bacterial infections, stroke
info-Treatment: Vaccination, antibiotics, high fluid intake, folic acid supplementation, pain medication, blood transfusions

Name: Sinus headaches
Overview: Sinus headaches are headaches that may feel like an infection in the sinuses (sinusitis). However, many people who assume they have headaches from sinusitis, including many who have received such a diagnosis, actually have migraines.
Diagnosis: The doctor may perform imaging tests to help determine the cause of the headache, including CT scan. CT scans use a computer to create cross-sectional images of the brain and head (including the sinuses) by combining images from an X-ray unit that rotates around the body. With MRIs, a magnetic field and radio waves are used to create cross-sectional images of the structures within the brain.
Treatment: Medications include sumatriptan (Imitrex, Tosymra, others), rizatriptan (Maxalt), almotriptan, naratriptan (Amerge), zolmitriptan (Zomig), frovatriptan (Frova) and eletriptan (Relpax). Ergotamine and caffeine combination drugs (Migergot, Cafergot) are less effective than triptans. Ergotamine may cause worsened nausea and vomiting related to the migraines and other side effects, and it may also lead to medication-overuse headaches. Migraines and other types of headaches may be treated with over-the-counter medications, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB). Frequently prescribed medications are chlorpromazine, metoclopramide (Reglan) or prochlorperazine (Compazine).

Name: Sinusitis , acute
Overview: Acute sinusitis causes the spaces inside the nose (sinuses) to become inflamed and swollen. Unless a bacterial infection develops, most cases resolve within a week to 10 days and home remedies may be all that's needed to treat acute sinusitis.
Causes: Signs and symptoms may include nasal obstruction and congestion, which may block the sinuses and prevent drainage of mucus. Acute sinusitis is most often caused by the common cold, which is a viral infection.
Diagnosis: A thin, flexible tube (endoscope) with a fiber-optic light inserted through the nose allows the doctor to visually inspect the inside of the sinuses. It's not usually recommended for uncomplicated acute sinusitis, but imaging studies might help find abnormalities or suspected complications. However, when the condition fails to respond to treatment or is worsening, tissue samples (cultures) from the nose or sinuses might help find the cause, such as a bacterial infection.
Remedies: Use a specially designed squeeze bottle (Sinus Rinse, others) or neti pot. This home remedy, called nasal lavage, can help clear the sinuses.

Name: Sinusitis , chronic
Causes: Nasal polyps are soft, noncancerous growths on the lining of the nose or sinuses. A crooked septum the wall between the nostrils may restrict or block sinus passages, making the symptoms of sinusitis worse. The complications of conditions such as cystic fibrosis, HIV and other immune system-related diseases can lead to nasal blockage. Infections in the respiratory tract most commonly colds can inflame and thicken the sinus membranes and block mucus drainage.
Diagnosis: A thin, flexible tube with a fiber-optic light inserted through the nose allows the doctor to see the inside of the sinuses. If the doctor suspects that allergies might be triggering the chronic sinusitis, he or she might recommend an allergy skin test. However, when the condition fails to respond to treatment or is worsening, the doctor may swab inside the nose to collect samples that might help determine the cause, such as bacteria or fungi.
Treatment: If the sprays aren't effective enough, the doctor might recommend rinsing with a solution of saline mixed with drops of budesonide or using a nasal mist of the solution. Saline nasal irrigation, with nasal sprays or solutions, reduces drainage and rinses away irritants and allergies. Oral corticosteroids can cause serious side effects when used long term, so they're used only to treat severe symptoms.
Remedies: Or take a hot shower, breathing in the warm, moist air to help ease pain and help mucus drain. Use a specially designed squeeze bottle, saline canister or neti pot to rinse the nasal passages. This home remedy, called nasal lavage, can help clear the sinuses.

Name: Sjogren 's syndrome
Symptoms: The two main symptoms of Sjogren's syndrome are: Some people with Sjogren's syndrome also have one or more of the following: Dry eyes. The mouth might feel like it's full of cotton, making it difficult to swallow or speak.
Overview: Sjogren's (SHOW-grins) syndrome is a disorder of the immune system identified by its two most common symptoms dry eyes and a dry mouth. In Sjogren's syndrome, the mucous membranes and moisture-secreting glands of the eyes and mouth are usually affected first resulting in decreased tears and saliva.
Risk factors: Sjogren's syndrome typically occurs in people with one or more known risk factors, including Age. It's common for people who have Sjogren's syndrome to also have a rheumatic disease such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus.
Diagnosis: The doctor might also do a lip biopsy to detect the presence of clusters of inflammatory cells, which can indicate Sjogren's syndrome. Levels of different types of blood cells Presence of antibodies common in Sjogren's syndrome Evidence of inflammatory conditions Indications of problems with the liver and kidneys Sialogram.
Remedies: To relieve dry eyes: Use artificial tears, an eye lubricant or both. Artificial tears in eyedrop form and eye lubricants in eyedrop, gel or ointment form help relieve the discomfort of dry eyes. The doctor might recommend artificial tears without preservatives, which can irritate the eyes of people with dry eye syndrome. To help prevent those types of problems: If dry skin is a problem, avoid hot water when one bathe and shower. Brush the teeth and floss after every meal Schedule regular dental appointments, at least every six months Use daily topical fluoride treatments and antimicrobial mouthwashes Use artificial tears, an eye lubricant or both.
Medication: Depending on the symptoms, the doctor might suggest medications that: A minor procedure to seal the tear ducts that drain tears from the eyes (punctal occlusion) might help relieve the dry eyes. Drugs such as pilocarpine (Salagen) and cevimeline (Evoxac) can increase the production of saliva, and sometimes tears. If one develop arthritis symptoms, one might benefit from nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or other arthritis medications. Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil), a drug designed to treat malaria, is often helpful in treating Sjogren's syndrome. Drugs that suppress the immune system, such as methotrexate (Trexall), also might be prescribed.

Name: Skin cancer
Symptoms: Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that most often develops on areas of skin exposed to the sun. Merkel cell carcinoma is a rare, aggressive skin cancer. Basal cell carcinoma may appear as: Most often, squamous cell carcinoma occurs on sun-exposed areas of the body, such as the face, ears and hands. People with darker skin are more likely to develop squamous cell carcinoma on areas that aren't often exposed to the sun. Squamous cell carcinoma may appear as: Melanoma can develop anywhere on the body, in otherwise normal skin or in an existing mole that becomes cancerous. Merkel cell carcinoma causes firm, shiny nodules that occur on or just beneath the skin and in hair follicles.
Risk factors: If one has blond or red hair and light-colored eyes, and one freckle or sunburn easily, one is much more likely to develop skin cancer than is a person with darker skin. Having had one or more blistering sunburns as a child or teenager increases the risk of developing skin cancer as an adult. Anyone who spends considerable time in the sun may develop skin cancer, especially if the skin isn't protected by sunscreen or clothing. People who have many moles or abnormal moles called dysplastic nevi are at increased risk of skin cancer. These precancerous skin growths typically appear as rough, scaly patches that range in color from brown to dark pink. If one of the parents or a sibling has had skin cancer, one may have an increased risk of the disease. If one developed skin cancer once, one is at risk of developing it again. People who received radiation treatment for skin conditions such as eczema and acne may have an increased risk of skin cancer, particularly basal cell carcinoma. Exposure to certain substances, such as arsenic, may increase the risk of skin cancer.
Diagnosis: To diagnose skin cancer, the doctor may: If the doctor determines one has skin cancer, one may have additional tests to determine the extent (stage) of the skin cancer. Because superficial skin cancers such as basal cell carcinoma rarely spread, a biopsy that removes the entire growth often is the only test needed to determine the cancer stage.
Treatment: The treatment options for skin cancer and the precancerous skin lesions known as actinic keratoses will vary, depending on the size, type, depth and location of the lesions. This procedure is for larger, recurring or difficult-to-treat skin cancers, which may include both basal and squamous cell carcinomas. During Mohs surgery, the doctor removes the skin growth layer by layer, examining each layer under the microscope, until no abnormal cells remain. After removing most of a growth, the doctor scrapes away layers of cancer cells using a device with a circular blade (curet). These simple, quick procedures may be used to treat basal cell cancers or thin squamous cell cancers. The doctor may destroy actinic keratoses and some small, early skin cancers by freezing them with liquid nitrogen (cryosurgery). It's often used in areas where it's necessary to conserve as much skin as possible, such as on the nose.During Mohs surgery, the doctor removes the skin growth layer by layer, examining each layer under the microscope, until no abnormal cells remain. In a variation of this procedure, liquid nitrogen can be used to freeze the base and edges of the treated area.These simple, quick procedures may be used to treat basal cell cancers or thin squamous cell cancers. For cancers limited to the top layer of skin, creams or lotions containing anti-cancer agents may be applied directly to the skin.
info-Symptoms: Basal-cell: painless raised area of skin that may be shiny with small blood vessel running over it or ulcerationSquamous-cell: hard lump with a scaly topMelanoma: mole that has changed in size, shape, color, or has irregular edges
info-Causes: Ultraviolet radiation from the Sun or tanning beds
info-Risk factors: Light skin, poor immune function
info-Prevention: Decreasing exposure to ultraviolet radiation, sunscreen

Name: Skin cancer , melanoma
Symptoms: The first sign of melanoma is often a mole that changes size, shape or color. Melanomas can also occur in areas that don't receive much sun exposure, such as the soles of the feet, palms of the hands and fingernail beds. Normal moles are generally a uniform color such as tan, brown or black with a distinct border separating the mole from the surrounding skin. When melanoma occurs in people with darker skin, it's more likely to occur in a hidden area. Look for moles with irregular, notched or scalloped borders characteristics of melanomas. Look for changes over time, such as a mole that grows in size or that changes color or shape. Moles may also evolve to develop new signs and symptoms, such as new itchiness or bleeding. Eye melanoma, also called ocular melanoma, most often occurs in the uvea the layer beneath the white of the eye (sclera).
Overview: Melanoma is a form of skin cancer that begins in the cells (melanocytes) that control the pigment in the skin. Melanoma, the most serious type of skin cancer, develops in the cells (melanocytes) that produce melanin the pigment that gives the skin its color. The exact cause of all melanomas isn't clear, but exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation from sunlight or tanning lamps and beds increases the risk of developing melanoma.
Causes: One type of skin cancer called basal cell carcinoma begins in the basal cells, which make skin cells that continuously push older cells toward the surface. Melanoma, another type of skin cancer, arises in the pigment cells (melanocytes).
Risk factors: If one has blond or red hair, light-colored eyes, and freckle or sunburn easily, one is more likely to develop melanoma than is someone with a darker complexion. Exposure to UV radiation, which comes from the sun and from tanning lights and beds, can increase the risk of skin cancer, including melanoma. People living closer to the earth's equator, where the sun's rays are more direct, experience higher amounts of UV radiation than do those living farther north or south.
Diagnosis: To determine whether a suspicious skin lesion is melanoma, the doctor may recommend removing a sample of skin for testing. If the melanoma is thicker, the doctor may recommend additional tests to see if the cancer has spread before determining the treatment options. If there's a risk that the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes, the doctor may recommend a procedure known as a sentinel node biopsy. If these first lymph nodes (sentinel lymph nodes) are cancer-free, there's a good chance that the melanoma has not spread beyond the area where it was first discovered. Other factors may go into determining the risk that the cancer may spread (metastasize), including whether the skin over the area has formed an open sore (ulceration) and how many dividing cancer cells (mitoses) are found when looking under a microscope. For people with more-advanced melanomas, doctors may recommend imaging tests to look for signs that the cancer has spread to other areas of the body.

Name: Skin , itchy
Causes: Many skin conditions itch, including dry skin (xerosis), eczema (dermatitis), psoriasis, scabies, burns, scars, insect bites and hives. These include liver disease, kidney failure, iron deficiency anemia, thyroid problems and certain cancers, including multiple myeloma and lymphoma. Conditions that affect the nervous system such as multiple sclerosis, diabetes, pinched nerves and shingles (herpes zoster) can cause itching. Examples of psychiatric diseases that can cause itchy skin are anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder and depression. Wool, chemicals, soaps and other substances can irritate the skin and cause itching. Also, reactions to certain drugs, such as narcotic pain medications (opioids) can cause itchy skin.
Treatment: If home remedies don't ease the itchy skin, the doctor may recommend prescription medications or other treatments. Drink plenty of water, don't smoke, and wash the face and body each day with a gentle hypoallergenic soap for healthy-looking skin, says Dr. And, after bathing, moisturize with a hypoallergenic, fragrance-free moisturizer when one is done to help the skin hydrate. For temporary relief of itching, try these self-care measures: One is likely to start by seeing the family doctor or primary care doctor. In some cases, one may be referred to a specialist in skin diseases (dermatologist). If the skin is itchy and red, the doctor may suggest applying a medicated cream or ointment to the affected areas. Other treatments that one apply to the skin include calcineurin inhibitors, such as tacrolimus (Protopic) and pimecrolimus (Elidel). Antidepressants called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, such as fluoxetine (Prozac) and sertraline (Zoloft), may be helpful in easing some types of chronic itch. Apply hypoallergenic and fragrance-free moisturizer (Cetaphil, Eucerin, CeraVe, others) to affected skin at least once a day. Use creams, lotions or gels that soothe and cool the skin. Short-term use of nonprescription corticosteroid cream may temporarily relieve an itch accompanied by red, inflamed skin. Use lukewarm bathwater and sprinkle in Epsom salts, baking soda, uncooked oatmeal or colloidal oatmeal a finely ground oatmeal that is made for bathing (Aveeno, others). Then rinse thoroughly, gently dry the skin and apply moisturizer.
Remedies: Drink plenty of water, don't smoke, and wash the face and body each day with a gentle hypoallergenic soap for healthy-looking skin, says Dr. And, after bathing, moisturize with a hypoallergenic, fragrance-free moisturizer when one is done to help the skin hydrate. Oftentimes unscented just means more chemicals, says Dr. Davis. For temporary relief of itching, try these self-care measures: Avoid items or situations that cause one to itch. This might be heavy, rough clothing; an overly heated room; too many hot baths or exposure to a cleaning product. Apply hypoallergenic and fragrance-free moisturizer (Cetaphil, Eucerin, CeraVe, others) to affected skin at least once a day. Use creams, lotions or gels that soothe and cool the skin. Short-term use of nonprescription corticosteroid cream may temporarily relieve an itch accompanied by red, inflamed skin. Use lukewarm bathwater and sprinkle in Epsom salts, baking soda, uncooked oatmeal or colloidal oatmeal a finely ground oatmeal that is made for bathing (Aveeno, others). Then rinse thoroughly, gently dry the skin and apply moisturizer.

Name: Skipped heartbeats
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects that the palpitations are caused by an arrhythmia or other heart condition, tests might include Electrocardiogram (ECG). Holter monitoring is used to detect heart palpitations that aren't found during a regular ECG exam. If one don't have irregular heart rhythms while one wear a Holter monitor or if the events occur less than once weekly, the doctor might recommend an event recorder.
Treatment: Unless the doctor finds that one has a heart condition, heart palpitations seldom require treatment. Instead, the doctor might recommend ways for one to avoid the triggers that cause the palpitations. If one has heart palpitations with severe shortness of breath, chest pain or fainting, seek emergency medical attention.
Remedies: Caffeine, nicotine, some cold medicines and energy drinks can make the heart beat quickly or irregularly. Certain drugs, such as cocaine and amphetamines, can bring on heart palpitations.

Name: Slapped cheek disease
Symptoms: Eventually it may spread to the arms, trunk, thighs and buttocks, where the rash has a pink, lacy, slightly raised appearance. The rash may come and go for up to three weeks, becoming more visible when the child is exposed to extreme temperatures or spends time in the sun.
Overview: A bright red rash on the cheeks is a distinctive sign of parvovirus infection. Parvovirus infection has also been known as fifth disease because, historically, it was fifth in a list of common childhood illnesses characterized by a rash.
Remedies: Though aspirin is approved for use in children older than age 3, children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin. This is because aspirin has been linked to Reye's syndrome, a rare but potentially life-threatening condition, in such children.
info-Symptoms: Red rash, especially on cheeks

Name: Sleep apnea
Causes: Obstructive sleep apnea occurs when the muscles that support the soft tissues in the throat, such as the tongue and soft palate, temporarily relax. When these muscles relax, the airway is narrowed or closed, and breathing is momentarily cut off. This pattern can repeat itself five to 30 times or more each hour, all night, impairing the ability to reach the deep, restful phases of sleep.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of this form of sleep apnea include Risk factors for this form of sleep apnea include Excess weight. Obesity greatly increases the risk of sleep apnea. Having family members with sleep apnea might increase the risk. These substances relax the muscles in the throat, which can worsen obstructive sleep apnea. Smokers are three times more likely to have obstructive sleep apnea than are people whove never smoked. If one has difficulty breathing through the nose whether from an anatomical problem or allergies one is more likely to develop obstructive sleep apnea. Middle-aged and older people have a higher risk of central sleep apnea. Opioid medications, especially long-acting ones such as methadone, increase the risk of central sleep apnea. Having had a stroke increases the risk of central sleep apnea or treatment-emergent central sleep apnea.
Diagnosis: The doctor may make an evaluation based on the signs and symptoms and a sleep history, which one can provide with help from someone who shares the bed or the household, if possible. Portable monitoring devices don't detect all cases of sleep apnea, however, so the doctor might still recommend polysomnography even if the initial results are normal. If one has obstructive sleep apnea, the doctor might refer one to an ear, nose and throat doctor to rule out blockage in the nose or throat. An evaluation by a heart doctor (cardiologist) or a doctor who specializes in the nervous system (neurologist) might be necessary to look for causes of central sleep apnea. During this test, one is hooked up to equipment that monitors the heart, lung and brain activity, breathing patterns, arm and leg movements, and blood oxygen levels while one sleep.
Remedies: In some cases, self-care might be a way for one to deal with obstructive sleep apnea and possibly central sleep apnea. In some cases, sleep apnea can resolve if one return to a healthy weight, but it can recur if one regain the weight. Regular exercise can help ease the symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea even without weight loss. To keep from rolling onto the back while one sleep, try attaching a tennis ball to the back of the pajama top.
info-Symptoms: Pauses breathing or periods of shallow breathing during sleep, snoring, tired during the day
info-Risk factors: Overweight, family history, allergies, enlarged tonsils
info-Treatment: Lifestyle changes, mouthpieces, breathing devices, surgery
info-Frequency: ~ 1 in every 10 people, 2:1 ratio of men to women, aging and obesity higher risk

Name: Sleep apnea in children , obstructive
Diagnosis: To diagnose pediatric sleep apnea, the doctor will review the child's symptoms and medical history and conduct a physical exam. This test uses sensors applied to the body to record brain wave activity, breathing patterns, snoring, oxygen levels, heart rate and muscle activity while the child sleeps. If doctors strongly suspect obstructive sleep apnea, and a full polysomnogram isn't needed or available, an overnight recording of oxygen levels might help make the diagnosis. In an electrocardiogram, sensor patches with wires attached (electrodes) measure the electrical impulses given off by the child's heart.
Treatment: In continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP), small machines gently blow air through a tube and mask attached to the child's nose, or nose and mouth. Topical nasal steroids, such as fluticasone (Dymista, Flonase Allergy Relief, Xhance,) and budesonide (Rhinocort), might ease sleep apnea symptoms for some children with mild obstructive sleep apnea. The doctor might refer the child to a pediatric ear, nose and throat specialist to discuss removing the tonsils and adenoids. Other forms of upper airway surgery might be recommended, based on the child's condition. Oral appliances, such as dental devices or mouthpieces, move the child's bottom jaw and tongue forward to keep the child's upper airway open. All children, but especially those with pediatric obstructive sleep apnea, should avoid tobacco smoke or other indoor allergens or pollutants, as they can cause airway irritation and congestion.

Name: Sleep apnea , central
Causes: Central sleep apnea occurs when the brain fails to transmit signals to the breathing muscles. During the weakest breathing effort, a total lack of airflow (central sleep apnea) can occur. Some people with obstructive sleep apnea develop central sleep apnea while using continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) for their sleep apnea treatment. Several medical conditions, including end-stage kidney disease and stroke, may give rise to central sleep apnea of the non-Cheyne-Stokes variety.
Risk factors: Certain factors put one at increased risk of central sleep apnea: CPAP. Some people with obstructive sleep apnea develop central sleep apnea while using continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). For most people, treatment-emergent central sleep apnea goes away with continued use of a CPAP device. Central sleep apnea is more common among older adults, especially adults older than age 65, possibly because they may have other medical conditions or sleep patterns that are more likely to cause central sleep apnea. People with irregular heartbeats (atrial fibrillation) or whose heart muscles don't pump enough blood for the body's needs (congestive heart failure) are at greater risk of central sleep apnea. Opioid medications may increase the risk of central sleep apnea.

Name: Sleep apnea , obstructive
Causes: When the muscles relax, the airway narrows or closes as one breathe in and breathing may be inadequate for 10 seconds or longer. These disruptions impair the ability to reach the desired deep, restful phases of sleep, and one will probably feel sleepy during the waking hours.
Risk factors: Most but not all people with obstructive sleep apnea are overweight. Medical conditions that are associated with obesity, such as hypothyroidism and polycystic ovary syndrome, also can cause obstructive sleep apnea. However, not everyone with obstructive sleep apnea is overweight and vice versa. Medical conditions that are associated with obesity, such as hypothyroidism and polycystic ovary syndrome, also can cause obstructive sleep apnea.However, not everyone with obstructive sleep apnea is overweight and vice versa. Obstructive sleep apnea is relatively common in people with hypertension. Obstructive sleep apnea occurs twice as often in those who have consistent nasal congestion at night, regardless of the cause. Obstructive sleep apnea may be more common in people with diabetes. In general, men are twice as likely as premenopausal women to have obstructive sleep apnea. If one has family members with obstructive sleep apnea, one may be at increased risk.
Diagnosis: If one is diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea, staff may wake one and give one continuous positive airway pressure for the second half of the night. This sleep study can also help rule out other sleep disorders that can cause excessive daytime sleepiness but require different treatments, such as leg movements during sleep (periodic limb movements) or sudden bouts of sleep during the day (narcolepsy). During this sleep study, one is hooked up to equipment that monitors the heart, lung and brain activity, breathing patterns, arm and leg movements, and blood oxygen levels while one sleep.One may have a full-night study, in which one is monitored all night, or a split-night sleep study.In a split-night sleep study, one will be monitored during the first half of the night. If one is diagnosed with obstructive sleep apnea, staff may wake one and give one continuous positive airway pressure for the second half of the night.Polysomnography can help the doctor diagnose obstructive sleep apnea and adjust positive airway pressure therapy, if appropriate.This sleep study can also help rule out other sleep disorders that can cause excessive daytime sleepiness but require different treatments, such as leg movements during sleep (periodic limb movements) or sudden bouts of sleep during the day (narcolepsy).
Remedies: To prevent sleeping on the back, try sewing a tennis ball in the back of the pajama top or place pillows behind one while one sleep on the side. Sleeping on the back can cause the tongue and soft palate to rest against the back of the throat and block the airway.To prevent sleeping on the back, try sewing a tennis ball in the back of the pajama top or place pillows behind one while one sleep on the side.

Name: Sleep disorders
Overview: Sleep disorders are conditions that result in changes in the way that one sleep. Some of the signs and symptoms of sleep disorders include excessive daytime sleepiness, irregular breathing or increased movement during sleep. Sleep disorders can also be grouped according to behaviors, problems with the natural sleep-wake cycles, breathing problems, difficulty sleeping or how sleepy one feel during the day.
info-Specialty: Clinical psychology, Psychiatry, Sleep medicine, Neurology

Name: Sleep terrors ( night terrors )
Treatment: If the sleep terrors lead to the potential for injury, are disruptive to family members, or result in embarrassment or sleep disruption for the person who has sleep terrors, treatment may be needed. If the sleep terrors are associated with an underlying medical or mental health condition or another sleep disorder, such as obstructive sleep apnea, treatment is aimed at the underlying problem. If stress or anxiety seems to be contributing to the sleep terrors, the doctor may suggest meeting with a therapist or counselor. Medication is rarely used to treat sleep terrors, particularly for children.
Remedies: If sleep terrors are a problem for one or the child, here are some strategies to try: Get adequate sleep. If one is sleep deprived, try an earlier bedtime and a more regular sleep schedule. If the child has a sleep terror episode, consider simply waiting it out. If the child has sleep terrors, keep a sleep diary. For several nights, note how many minutes after bedtime a sleep terror episode occurs.

Name: Sleepiness , daytime
Symptoms: People with narcolepsy fall asleep without warning, anywhere, anytime. Excessive daytime sleepiness usually is the first symptom to appear and is often the most troublesome, making it difficult for one to concentrate and fully function. Some people with narcolepsy experience only one or two episodes of cataplexy a year, while others have numerous episodes daily. People with narcolepsy often experience a temporary inability to move or speak while falling asleep or upon waking. People with narcolepsy often transition quickly to REM sleep, usually within 15 minutes of falling asleep.
Overview: Narcolepsy is a chronic sleep disorder characterized by overwhelming daytime drowsiness and sudden attacks of sleep. Sometimes, narcolepsy can be accompanied by a sudden loss of muscle tone (cataplexy), which can be triggered by strong emotion.
Causes: Exactly what causes the loss of hypocretin-producing cells in the brain isn't known, but experts suspect it's due to an autoimmune reaction. The normal process of falling asleep begins with a phase called non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep. After an hour or so of NREM sleep, the brain activity changes, and REM sleep begins. In narcolepsy, however, one may suddenly enter into REM sleep without first experiencing NREM sleep, both at night and during the day.
Diagnosis: The doctor may make a preliminary diagnosis of narcolepsy based on the excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden loss of muscle tone (cataplexy). One may be asked to keep a detailed diary of the sleep pattern for a week or two, so the doctor can compare how the sleep pattern and alertness are related. Other sleep disorders, such as chronic sleep deprivation, the use of sedating medications and sleep apnea, can cause excessive daytime sleepiness. A part of the history involves filling out the Epworth Sleepiness Scale, which uses a series of short questions to gauge the degree of sleepiness.
Remedies: Naps of 20 minutes at strategic times during the day may be refreshing and reduce sleepiness for one to three hours. Moderate, regular exercise at least four to five hours before bedtime may help one feel more awake during the day and sleep better at night.
