Medication: Some people need treatment with methylphenidate (Aptensio XR, Concerta, Ritalin, others) or various amphetamines. If one has other health problems, such as high blood pressure or diabetes, ask the doctor how the medications one take for the other conditions may interact with those taken for narcolepsy. Emerging treatments being investigated for narcolepsy include drugs acting on the histamine chemical system, hypocretin replacement, hypocretin gene therapy and immunotherapy, but further research is needed before any may be available in the doctor's office. Doctors often prescribe these medications, which suppress REM sleep, to help alleviate the symptoms of cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations and sleep paralysis. They include fluoxetine (Prozac, Sarafem, Selfemra) and venlafaxine (Effexor XR). These older antidepressants, such as protriptyline (Vivactil), imipramine (Tofranil) and clomipramine (Anafranil), are effective for cataplexy, but many people complain of side effects, such as dry mouth and lightheadedness.

Name: Sleeplessness
Overview: Insomnia is a common sleep disorder that can make it hard to fall asleep, hard to stay asleep, or cause one to wake up too early and not be able to get back to sleep. At some point, many adults experience short-term (acute) insomnia, which lasts for days or weeks.
Causes: Chronic insomnia is usually a result of stress, life events or habits that disrupt sleep. Treating the medical condition may help improve sleep, but the insomnia may persist after the medical condition improves. As one get older, one may experience: Sleep problems may be a concern for children and teenagers as well. However, some children and teens simply have trouble getting to sleep or resist a regular bedtime because their internal clocks are more delayed. Concerns about work, school, health, finances or family can keep the mind active at night, making it difficult to sleep. Stressful life events or trauma such as the death or illness of a loved one, divorce, or a job loss also may lead to insomnia. The circadian rhythms act as an internal clock, guiding such things as the sleep-wake cycle, metabolism and body temperature. Many people also experience heartburn, a backflow of acid and food from the stomach into the esophagus after eating, which may keep one awake. Anxiety disorders, such as post-traumatic stress disorder, may disrupt the sleep. Many prescription drugs can interfere with sleep, such as certain antidepressants and medications for asthma or blood pressure. Many over-the-counter medications such as some pain medications, allergy and cold medications, and weight-loss products contain caffeine and other stimulants that can disrupt sleep. Sleep apnea causes one to stop breathing periodically throughout the night, interrupting the sleep. Restless legs syndrome causes unpleasant sensations in the legs and an almost irresistible desire to move them, which may prevent one from falling asleep. Alcohol may help one fall asleep, but it prevents deeper stages of sleep and often causes awakening in the middle of the night. Sleep often becomes less restful as one age, so noise or other changes in the environment are more likely to wake one. Also, the less active one is, the more likely one may be to take a daily nap, which can interfere with sleep at night. Older people typically use more prescription drugs than younger people do, which increases the chance of insomnia associated with medications.
Remedies: If one can't get by without one, try to limit a nap to no more than 30 minutes and don't nap after 3 p.m. Avoid or limit caffeine and alcohol and don't use nicotine. If a painful condition bothers one, talk to the doctor about options for pain relievers that are effective enough to control pain while one is sleeping. Hide all clocks in the bedroom, including the wristwatch and cellphone, so one don't worry about what time it is. Create a relaxing bedtime ritual, such as taking a hot bath, reading, soft music, breathing exercises, yoga or prayer. Don't go to bed too early, before one is sleepy.
info-Symptoms: Trouble sleeping, daytime sleepiness, low energy, irritability, depressed mood
info-Causes: Unknown, psychological stress, chronic pain, heart failure, hyperthyroidism, heartburn, restless leg syndrome, others
info-Treatment: Sleep hygiene, cognitive behavioral therapy, sleeping pills

Name: Sleep-related eating disorder
Diagnosis: In addition to asking one sleep-related questions, the doctor may have one complete a questionnaire to determine the sleep-wake pattern and level of daytime sleepiness. This test monitors and records a variety of body activities while one sleep, including brain waves, breathing, heartbeat, eye movements and body movements.
Treatment: The treatment may include In addition to the treatment plan, lifestyle changes that may help include If one is having sleep problems, one may start by talking to the primary care doctor. The doctor may want to talk to the partner to learn more about the sleep experiences and to help determine if other sleep disorders may exist, such as obstructive sleep apnea. This may involve stopping or changing current medications that may be contributing to the sleep-related eating disorder. Sleep-related eating disorder may be reduced by treating other sleep disorders that are often associated with it, such as sleepwalking, restless legs syndrome or obstructive sleep apnea. The doctor may recommend strategies to ensure safety and offer education to the bed partner and household members on how to safely and gently coax one back to bed without using restraint or awakening one. Also, consider storing foods typically eaten during a sleep-related eating disorder episode outside the kitchen or placing locks on cabinets and the fridge.
Remedies: In addition to the treatment plan, lifestyle changes that may help include Environmental changes. Also, consider storing foods typically eaten during a sleep-related eating disorder episode outside the kitchen or placing locks on cabinets and the fridge.

Name: Slipped disk
Symptoms: Most herniated disks occur in the lower back, although they can also occur in the neck. Seek medical attention if the neck or back pain travels down the arm or leg, or if one also have numbness, tingling or weakness. If the herniated disk is in the lower back, one will typically feel the most pain in the buttocks, thigh and calf. If the herniated disk is in the neck, one will typically feel the most pain in the shoulder and arm. This pain might shoot into the arm or leg when one cough, sneeze or move into certain positions. People who have a herniated disk often have radiating numbness or tingling in the body part served by the affected nerves.
Overview: The rubbery disks that lie between the vertebrae in the spine consist of a soft center (nucleus) surrounded by a tougher exterior (annulus). A herniated disk refers to a problem with one of the rubbery cushions (disks) that sit between the individual bones (vertebrae) that stack to make the spine. A spinal disk has a soft, jellylike center (nucleus) encased in a tougher, rubbery exterior (annulus).
Risk factors: Repetitive lifting, pulling, pushing, bending sideways and twisting also can increase the risk of a herniated disk. It's thought that smoking lessens the oxygen supply to the disk, causing it to break down more quickly.
Diagnosis: The doctor may also perform a neurological exam to check the: In most cases of herniated disk, a physical exam and a medical history are all that's needed for a diagnosis. If the doctor suspects another condition or needs to see which nerves are affected, he or she may order one or more of the following tests. Plain X-rays don't detect herniated disks, but they can rule out other causes of back pain, such as an infection, tumor, spinal alignment issues or a broken bone. This test measures electrical nerve impulses and functioning in the muscles and nerves through electrodes placed on the skin.
Medication: If the pain is mild to moderate, the doctor might recommend over-the-counter pain medication, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve). If the pain doesn't improve with oral medications, the doctor might recommend a corticosteroid that can be injected into the area around the spinal nerves. Because of the side effects of opioids and the potential for addiction, many doctors hesitate to prescribe them for disk herniation. If other medication doesn't relieve the pain, the doctor might consider short-term use of opioids, such as codeine or an oxycodone-acetaminophen combination (Percocet, Roxicet).
info-Risk factors: Connective tissue disease

Name: Slow heartbeat
Overview: Bradycardia is a slower than normal heart rate. If one has bradycardia (brad-e-KAHR-dee-uh), the heart beats fewer than 60 times a minute.
Causes: In a normal heart rhythm, a tiny cluster of cells at the sinus node sends out an electrical signal. A natural pacemaker (the sinus node), situated in the right atrium, normally controls the heart rhythm by producing electrical impulses that initiate each heartbeat. Bradycardia can also occur because electrical signals transmitted through the atria aren't transmitted to the ventricles (heart block, or atrioventricular block). Heart blocks are classified based on the degree to which signals from the atria reach the heart's main pumping chambers (ventricles).
Diagnosis: The doctor will also order tests to measure the heart rate, establish a link between a slow heart rate and the symptoms, and identify conditions that might be causing bradycardia. Because an ECG can't record bradycardia unless it happens during the test, the doctor might have one use a portable ECG device at home. These tests include The doctor will order blood tests to screen for conditions that might be contributing to bradycardia, such as an infection, hypothyroidism or an electrolyte imbalance. If sleep apnea is suspected of contributing to bradycardia, one might undergo tests to monitor the sleep. The doctor might monitor the heart rate while one walk on a treadmill or ride a stationary bike to see whether the heart rate increases appropriately in response to physical activity.

Name: Small bowel cancer
Overview: The small intestine, also known as the small bowel, runs from the stomach to the large intestine (colon). The small intestine, which is also called the small bowel, is a long tube that carries digested food between the stomach and the large intestine (colon).
Causes: In general, small bowel cancer begins when healthy cells in the small bowel develop changes (mutations) in their DNA. But when a cell's DNA is damaged and becomes cancerous, cells continue to divide even when new cells aren't needed.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of small bowel cancer include Gene mutations passed through families. Other diseases and conditions that affect the intestines may increase the risk of small bowel cancer, including Crohn's disease, inflammatory bowel disease and celiac disease. If the body's germ-fighting immune system is weakened, one may have an increased risk of small bowel cancer.
Diagnosis: Imaging tests used to diagnose small bowel cancer include Endoscopic tests involve placing a camera inside the small intestine so that the doctor can examine the inside walls. CT MRI Positron emission tomography (PET) X-rays of the upper digestive system and small bowel after drinking a solution containing barium (upper gastrointestinal series with small bowel follow-through) Nuclear medicine scans, which use a small amount of radioactive tracer to enhance imaging tests Upper endoscopy Capsule endoscopy, which is sometimes called a pill camera Single-balloon enteroscopy Double-balloon enteroscopy Spiral enteroscopy
Treatment: Surgeons work to remove all of the small bowel cancer, when possible. If cancer affects a small portion of the small intestine, surgeons may remove only that section and rejoin the cut ends of the intestine. If a small bowel cancer can't be removed, surgeons might perform a bypass to relieve a blockage in the small intestine. For small bowel cancer, chemotherapy might be recommended after surgery if there's a risk that the cancer could return. With time, one will find what helps one cope with the uncertainty and distress of a small bowel cancer diagnosis. The concern and understanding of a counselor, medical social worker, clergy member or cancer support group also may be helpful. By blocking these weaknesses, targeted drug treatments can cause cancer cells to die. Targeted drugs might be used for certain types of small bowel cancer, including gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) and lymphoma. Immunotherapy might be an option for advanced small bowel cancer if testing shows the cancer cells may respond to this type of treatment. As one learn more about small bowel cancer, one may become more confident in making treatment decisions.
info-Symptoms: vomiting blood, blood in the stool

Name: Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth ( SIBO )
Overview: Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) occurs when there is an abnormal increase in the overall bacterial population in the small intestine particularly types of bacteria not commonly found in that part of the digestive tract. SIBO commonly results when a circumstance such as surgery or disease slows the passage of food and waste products in the digestive tract, creating a breeding ground for bacteria.
Causes: Unlike the large intestine (colon), the small intestine normally has relatively few bacteria due to rapid flow of contents and the presence of bile. But in SIBO, stagnant food in the bypassed small intestine becomes an ideal breeding ground for bacteria.
Diagnosis: In order to diagnose small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO), one may have tests to check for bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine, poor fat absorption, or other problems that may be causing or contributing to the symptoms. In some cases, the doctor may recommend imaging tests, such as X-rays, computerized tomography (CT) scanning or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to look for structural abnormalities of the intestine. To obtain the fluid sample, doctors pass a long, flexible tube (endoscope) down the throat and through the upper digestive tract to the small intestine.

Name: Small intestine prolapse
Overview: Small bowel prolapse (enterocele) occurs when muscles and tissues that hold the intestines (small bowel) in place inside the pelvic cavity weaken, causing the small bowel to descend and bulge into the vagina. Small bowel prolapse, also called enterocele (EN-tur-o-seel), occurs when the small intestine (small bowel) descends into the lower pelvic cavity and pushes at the top part of the vagina, creating a bulge.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of developing small bowel prolapse include Pregnancy and childbirth. Vaginal delivery of one or more children contributes to the weakening of the pelvic floor support structures, increasing the risk of prolapse. The more pregnancies one has, the greater the risk of developing any type of pelvic organ prolapse. Small bowel prolapse and other types of pelvic organ prolapse occur more often with increasing age. Removal of the uterus (hysterectomy) or surgical procedures to treat incontinence may increase the risk of developing small bowel prolapse. Being overweight increases pressure inside the abdomen, which increases the risk of developing small bowel prolapse. For unknown reasons, Hispanic and white women are at higher risk of developing pelvic organ prolapse. One may be genetically prone to prolapse due to weaker connective tissues in the pelvic area, making one naturally more susceptible to small bowel prolapse and other types of pelvic organ prolapse.
Remedies: Depending on the severity of the condition, these self-care measures may provide the symptom relief one need: Kegel exercises strengthen the pelvic floor muscles, which, in part, support the uterus, bladder and bowel. A strong pelvic floor provides better support for the pelvic organs, prevents prolapse from worsening and relieves symptoms associated with pelvic organ prolapse. To perform Kegel exercises, follow these steps: Ask the doctor for feedback on whether one is using the right muscles. Biofeedback involves using monitoring devices that help ensure one is tightening the proper muscles, with optimal intensity and length of time. Once one has learned the proper method, one can do Kegel exercises discreetly just about anytime, whether one is sitting at the desk or relaxing on the couch.

Name: Small vessel disease
Diagnosis: Because large vessel coronary artery disease and small vessel disease have the same signs and symptoms, it's likely the doctor will check the main arteries in the heart first. To diagnose small vessel disease, the doctor will also ask one about the medical history and family history of heart disease. If the doctor can't find blockages in the main arteries based on these tests, one might have an additional test to check for blockages in the smaller arteries of the heart: Endothelial dysfunction test. To test endothelial function, a wire is threaded through a catheter inserted in one of the coronary arteries and a medication is injected into the artery that causes the small vessels in the heart to open. A liquid dye is injected into the arteries of the heart through a catheter a long, thin tube that's fed through an artery, usually in the groin, to arteries in the heart. This test, which uses a radioactive dye and medication, can show the heart's blood flow to other parts of the body.
Treatment: The treatment for small vessel disease involves medications to control the narrowing of the small blood vessels that could lead to a heart attack and to relieve pain. This amino acid that's normally used by the body to help metabolize protein may help treat symptoms of small vessel disease by relaxing the blood vessels. If one has had chest pains or other symptoms of heart disease, the primary care provider will likely refer one to a doctor trained in treating disorders of the heart and circulatory system (cardiologist). These drugs, such as propranolol (Inderal, Innopran XL, others) and bisoprolol (Zebeta), slow the heart rate and decrease the blood pressure. Drugs such as verapamil (Verelan, Calan, others) and diltiazem (Cardizem, Diltzac, others) relax the muscles around the coronary arteries and cause the vessels to open, increasing blood flow to the heart. Medications such as atorvastatin (Lipitor) and simvastatin (Zocor) help lower cholesterol, which contributes to the narrowing of the arteries. Medications such as benazepril (Lotensin) and lisinopril (Prinivil, Zestril) help open the blood vessels and lower the blood pressure. Medications such as azilsartan (Edarbi) and losartan (Cozaar) relax the blood vessels, which lowers the blood pressure and makes it easier for the heart to pump blood.

Name: Snoring
Symptoms: Snoring is often associated with a sleep disorder called obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). People with obstructive sleep apnea usually experience periods when breathing slows or stops at least five times during every hour of sleep. These may indicate the snoring is associated with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Nose and throat problems such as enlarged tonsils and obesity often can narrow a child's airway, which can lead to the child developing OSA.
Causes: Snoring occurs when air flows past relaxed tissues, such as the tongue, soft palate and airway, as one breathe. The sagging tissues narrow the airway, causing these tissues to vibrate. People who are overweight may have extra tissues in the back of their throats that may narrow their airways. Likewise, if the triangular piece of tissue hanging from the soft palate (uvula) is elongated, airflow can be obstructed and vibration increased. Snoring is typically most frequent and loudest when sleeping on the back as gravity's effect on the throat narrows the airway.
Risk factors: Some people may have a long soft palate, or large tonsils or adenoids, which can narrow the airway and cause snoring. Alcohol relaxes the throat muscles, increasing the risk of snoring. If one has a structural defect in the airway, such as a deviated septum, or the nose is chronically congested, the risk of snoring is greater.
Diagnosis: Depending on the severity of the snoring and other symptoms, the doctor may want to conduct a sleep study. However, depending upon the other medical problems and other sleep symptoms, one may need to stay overnight at a sleep center to undergo an in-depth analysis of the breathing during sleep by a study, called a polysomnography.
Remedies: To prevent or quiet snoring, Treat nasal congestion or obstruction. Adhesive strips applied to the bridge of the nose help many people increase the area of their nasal passage, enhancing their breathing. A nasal dilator is a stiffened adhesive strip applied externally across the nostrils that may help decrease airflow resistance so one breathe easier. Nasal strips and external nasal dilators aren't effective for people with OSA, however. Avoid drinking alcoholic beverages at least two hours before bedtime, and let the doctor know about the snoring before taking sedatives.

Name: Social anxiety disorder ( social phobia )
Symptoms: Feelings of shyness or discomfort in certain situations aren't necessarily signs of social anxiety disorder, particularly in children. In contrast to everyday nervousness, social anxiety disorder includes fear, anxiety and avoidance that interfere with daily routine, work, school or other activities. Social anxiety disorder typically begins in the early to mid-teens, though it can sometimes start in younger children or in adults.
Overview: It's normal to feel nervous in some social situations. But in social anxiety disorder, also called social phobia, everyday interactions cause significant anxiety, fear, self-consciousness and embarrassment because one fear being scrutinized or judged by others. Social anxiety disorder is a chronic mental health condition, but learning coping skills in psychotherapy and taking medications can help one gain confidence and improve the ability to interact with others.
Causes: Like many other mental health conditions, social anxiety disorder likely arises from a complex interaction of biological and environmental factors. People who have an overactive amygdala may have a heightened fear response, causing increased anxiety in social situations. Social anxiety disorder may be a learned behavior some people may develop the condition after an unpleasant or embarrassing social situation.
Risk factors: Several factors can increase the risk of developing social anxiety disorder, including Family history. Children who experience teasing, bullying, rejection, ridicule or humiliation may be more prone to social anxiety disorder. In addition, other negative events in life, such as family conflict, trauma or abuse, may be associated with social anxiety disorder. Social anxiety disorder symptoms typically start in the teenage years, but meeting new people, giving a speech in public or making an important work presentation may trigger symptoms for the first time. For example, facial disfigurement, stuttering or tremors due to Parkinson's disease can increase feelings of self-consciousness and may trigger social anxiety disorder in some people.
Remedies: Although social anxiety disorder generally requires help from a medical expert or qualified psychotherapist, one can try some of these techniques to handle situations that are likely to trigger the symptoms: First, consider the fears to identify what situations cause the most anxiety. Consider practicing these situations: At first, being social when one is feeling anxious is challenging. Learn stress reduction skills Get physical exercise or be physically active on a regular basis Get enough sleep Eat a healthy, well-balanced diet Avoid alcohol Limit or avoid caffeine Participate in social situations by reaching out to people with whom one feel comfortable Eat with a close relative, friend or acquaintance in a public setting Purposefully make eye contact and return greetings from others, or be the first to say hello Give someone a compliment Ask a retail clerk to help one find an item Get directions from a stranger Show an interest in others ask about their homes, children, grandchildren, hobbies or travels, for instance Call a friend to make plans Prepare for conversation, for example, by reading the newspaper to identify an interesting story one can talk about.

Name: Soft palate cancer
Overview: The soft palate is located in the upper portion of the back of the mouth, behind the teeth. Doctors treat soft palate cancer similarly to the way they treat other types of throat cancers often with a combination of surgery, radiation therapy and chemotherapy.
Diagnosis: In the lab, specially trained doctors (pathologists) will look for signs of cancer. To better understand the size of the cancer and to look for signs that cancer may have spread beyond the soft palate, the doctor may recommend imaging tests, such as computerized tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and positron emission tomography (PET).
Treatment: Radiation therapy can be used alone or with chemotherapy or surgery to treat soft palate cancers of all stages. Depending on where the cancer is located and how far it has spread, reconstructive surgery may be necessary. Rehabilitation specialists in speech therapy, swallowing therapy, dietetics, physical therapy and occupational therapy help with rehabilitation that may be necessary after surgery or radiation therapy.

Name: Soft tissue sarcoma
Overview: Soft tissue sarcomas are cancerous (malignant) tumors that originate in the soft tissues of the body. Soft tissue sarcoma is a rare type of cancer that begins in the tissues that connect, support and surround other body structures. Soft tissue sarcoma can occur anywhere in the body, but the most common types occur in the arms and legs, and in the abdomen.
Risk factors: Genetic syndromes that increase the risk include hereditary retinoblastoma, Li-Fraumeni syndrome, familial adenomatous polyposis, neurofibromatosis, tuberous sclerosis and Werner syndrome. Being exposed to certain chemicals, such as herbicides, arsenic and dioxin, may increase the risk of soft tissue sarcomas.
Diagnosis: Because there are so many different types of soft tissue sarcoma, it's important to determine the exact nature of each tumor so that the best treatments can be chosen. To evaluate the area of concern, the doctor might employ: If a soft tissue sarcoma is suspected, it's often best to seek care at a medical center that sees many people with this type of cancer. Options include In the lab, a doctor trained in analyzing body tissues (pathologist) examines the tissue sample for signs of cancer.

Name: Solar keratosis
Overview: Actinic keratoses are scaly spots or patches on the top layer of skin. An actinic keratosis (ak-TIN-ik ker-uh-TOE-sis) is a rough, scaly patch on the skin that develops from years of exposure to the sun. Also known as a solar keratosis, an actinic keratosis enlarges slowly and usually causes no signs or symptoms other than a patch or small spot on the skin.
Medication: Prescription products that can be applied to the skin for this purpose include These creams may cause redness, scaling or a burning sensation for a few weeks. Methods used to remove actinic keratoses include Fluorouracil cream (Carac, Fluoroplex, Efudex) Imiquimod cream (Aldara, Zyclara) Ingenol mebutate gel (Picato) Diclofenac gel (Voltaren, Solaraze) Freezing (cryotherapy). Side effects may include blisters, scarring, changes to skin texture, infection and darkening of the skin at the site of treatment. Side effects may include infection, scarring and changes in skin coloration at the site of treatment.

Name: Solar lentigines
Symptoms: Age spots may grow in size and group together, giving the skin a speckled or mottled appearance. Age spots may affect people of all skin types, but they're more common in adults with light skin. Unlike freckles, which are common in children and fade with no sun exposure, age spots don't fade.
Overview: If one has light skin and spend a lot of time in the sun, one is more likely to develop age spots areas of increased pigmentation. True age spots don't need treatment, but they are a sign the skin has received a lot of sun exposure and are an attempt by the skin to protect itself from more sun damage.
Treatment: If one want the age spots to be less noticeable, treatments are available to lighten or remove them. Because the pigment is located at the base of the epidermis the topmost layer of skin any treatments meant to lighten the age spots must penetrate this layer of skin. Age spot treatments include The age spot therapies that remove skin are usually done in a doctor's office and don't require hospitalization. After treatment, when outdoors one will need to use a broad-spectrum sunscreen with a sun protection factor (SPF) of at least 30 and wear protective clothing. And because the procedures can have side effects, discuss the options carefully with a doctor who specializes in skin conditions (dermatologist). Applying prescription bleaching creams (hydroquinone) alone or with retinoids (tretinoin) and a mild steroid might gradually fade the spots over several months. Some laser and intense pulsed light therapies destroy melanin-producing cells (melanocytes) without damaging the skin's surface. Possible side effects include scarring, infection, and lightening or darkening of skin color.

Name: Solitary fibrous tumor
Diagnosis: Because there are so many different types of soft tissue sarcoma, it's important to determine the exact nature of each tumor so that the best treatments can be chosen. To evaluate the area of concern, the doctor might employ: If a soft tissue sarcoma is suspected, it's often best to seek care at a medical center that sees many people with this type of cancer. Options include In the lab, a doctor trained in analyzing body tissues (pathologist) examines the tissue sample for signs of cancer.

Name: Somatic symptom disorder
Remedies: While somatic symptom disorder benefits from professional treatment, one can take some lifestyle and self-care steps, including these: Work with the care providers. Work with the medical care provider and mental health professional to determine a regular schedule for visits to discuss the concerns and build a trusting relationship. Avoid seeking advice from multiple doctors or emergency room visits that can make the care more difficult to coordinate and may subject one to duplicate testing. Learning stress management and relaxation techniques, such as progressive muscle relaxation, may help improve symptoms. A graduated activity program may have a calming effect on the mood, improve the physical symptoms and help improve the physical function.

Name: Somnambulism
Symptoms: Sleepwalking usually occurs early in the night often one to two hours after falling asleep. A sleepwalking episode can occur rarely or often, and an episode generally lasts several minutes, but can last longer.
Risk factors: It's more common if one has one parent who has a history of sleepwalking, and much more common if both parents have a history of the disorder. Sleepwalking occurs more often in children than adults, and onset in adulthood is more likely related to other underlying conditions.
Diagnosis: The doctor may do a physical exam to identify any conditions that may be confused with sleepwalking, such as nighttime seizures, other sleep disorders or panic attacks. If the sleep partner comes with one to the appointment, the doctor may ask him or her whether one appear to sleepwalk.
Treatment: If sleepwalking leads to the potential for injury, is disruptive to family members, or results in embarrassment or sleep disruption for the person who sleepwalks, treatment may be needed. Treatment may include If sleepwalking is a problem for one or the child, try these suggestions. One may want to bring a family member or friend along, if possible, to provide more information about the sleepwalking. Keeping a sleep diary for two weeks before the appointment can help the doctor understand more about the sleep schedule, factors affecting the sleep and when sleepwalking occurs. At the end of the day, record behaviors that may affect sleep, such as sleep schedule disruptions, alcohol intake and any medications taken. Treating any underlying condition, if the sleepwalking is associated with sleep deprivation or an underlying sleep disorder or medical condition Adjusting medication, if it's thought that the sleepwalking results from a drug Anticipatory awakenings waking the person who is sleepwalking about 15 minutes before he or she usually sleepwalks, then staying awake for a few minutes before falling asleep again Medication such as benzodiazepines or certain antidepressants Learning self-hypnosis when done by a trained professional who is familiar with parasomnias, people who are receptive to suggestions during hypnosis may benefit by achieving a deep state of relaxation through which a change in unwanted activities during sleep is promoted Therapy or counseling a mental health professional can help with suggestions for improving sleep, stress-reduction techniques, self-hypnosis and relaxation Make the environment safe. If sleepwalking has led to injuries or may do so, consider these precautions: Close and lock all windows and exterior doors before bedtime. For several nights, note or have another person in the home note how many minutes after bedtime a sleepwalking episode occurs.
Remedies: If sleepwalking has led to injuries or may do so, consider these precautions: Close and lock all windows and exterior doors before bedtime. If one is sleep deprived, try an earlier bedtime, a more regular sleep schedule or a short nap, especially for toddlers. Or if the child sleepwalks and seems anxious or stressed, talk with him or her about any concerns. For several nights, note or have another person in the home note how many minutes after bedtime a sleepwalking episode occurs.

Name: Sore throat
Overview: A sore throat is pain, scratchiness or irritation of the throat that often worsens when one swallow. Strep throat (streptococcal infection), a less common type of sore throat caused by bacteria, requires treatment with antibiotics to prevent complications.
Causes: Less often, bacterial infections cause sore throats. Other causes of a sore throat include Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Other signs or symptoms may include heartburn, hoarseness, regurgitation of stomach contents and the sensation of a lump in the throat. Common cold Flu (influenza) Mono (mononucleosis) Measles Chickenpox Croup a common childhood illness characterized by a harsh, barking cough Allergies. Allergies to pet dander, molds, dust and pollen can cause a sore throat. Breathing through the mouth often because of chronic nasal congestion also can cause a dry, sore throat. Cancerous tumors of the throat, tongue or voice box (larynx) can cause a sore throat.
Risk factors: Although anyone can get a sore throat, some factors make one more susceptible, including Age. Children ages 3 to 15 are also more likely to have strep throat, the most common bacterial infection associated with a sore throat. The use of tobacco products also increases the risk of cancers of the mouth, throat and voice box. Seasonal allergies or ongoing allergic reactions to dust, molds or pet dander make developing a sore throat more likely. Viral and bacterial infections spread easily anywhere people gather, whether in child care centers, classrooms, offices or airplanes. Common causes of lowered immunity include HIV, diabetes, treatment with steroids or chemotherapy drugs, stress, fatigue, and poor diet.
Remedies: Regardless of the cause of the sore throat, these at-home care strategies can help one ease the or the child's symptoms: Rest. Warm liquids broth, caffeine-free tea or warm water with honey and cold treats such as ice pops can soothe a sore throat. A saltwater gargle of 1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon (1.25 to 2.50 milliliters) of table salt to 4 to 8 ounces (120 to 240 milliliters) of warm water can help soothe a sore throat. Use a cool-air humidifier to eliminate dry air that may further irritate a sore throat, being sure to clean the humidifier regularly so it doesn't grow mold or bacteria. Either can soothe a sore throat, but don't give them to children age 4 and younger because of choking risk.

Name: Soy allergy
Risk factors: Certain factors may put one at greater risk of developing a soy allergy: If one is not nursing, ask the doctor for advice on what to feed the child until the appointment to reduce the risk of symptoms. One is at increased risk of allergy to soy or other foods if other allergies, such as hay fever, asthma, hives or eczema, are common in the family. In some cases, people who are allergic to wheat, beans (legumes), milk or other foods can also have an allergic reaction to soy. Also, people who are allergic to soy may have test results showing allergy to other legumes, but may be able to eat them with no problem.

Name: Specific phobias
Symptoms: A specific phobia involves an intense, persistent fear of a specific object or situation that's out of proportion to the actual risk. There are many types of phobias, and it's not unusual to experience a specific phobia about more than one object or situation.
Overview: Specific phobias are an overwhelming and unreasonable fear of objects or situations that pose little real danger but provoke anxiety and avoidance. Unlike the brief anxiety one may feel when giving a speech or taking a test, specific phobias are long lasting, cause intense physical and psychological reactions, and can affect the ability to function normally at work, at school or in social settings.
Causes: Many phobias develop as a result of having a negative experience or panic attack related to a specific object or situation. There may be a link between the own specific phobia and the phobia or anxiety of the parents this could be due to genetics or learned behavior. Changes in brain functioning also may play a role in developing specific phobias.
Risk factors: Specific phobias can first appear in childhood, usually by age 10, but can occur later in life. This could be an inherited tendency, or children may learn specific phobias by observing a family member's phobic reaction to an object or a situation. Experiencing a frightening traumatic event, such as being trapped in an elevator or attacked by an animal, may trigger the development of a specific phobia. Hearing about negative information or experiences, such as plane crashes, can lead to the development of a specific phobia.
Medication: However, sometimes medications can help reduce the anxiety and panic symptoms one experience from thinking about or being exposed to the object or situation one fear. Medications may be used during initial treatment or for short-term use in specific, infrequently encountered situations, such as flying on an airplane, public speaking or going through an MRI procedure. These drugs block the stimulating effects of adrenaline, such as increased heart rate, elevated blood pressure, pounding heart, and shaking voice and limbs that are caused by anxiety.

Name: Specific reading disability
Diagnosis: The doctor may ask for a description of the family and home life, including who lives at home and whether there are any problems at home. The doctor may have the child, family members or teachers answer written questions. These can help determine whether another disorder may be causing or adding to the child's poor reading ability. This can help determine whether social problems, anxiety or depression may be limiting the child's abilities.

Name: Spermatocele
Diagnosis: Although a spermatocele generally isn't painful, one might feel discomfort when the doctor examines (palpates) the mass. If transillumination doesn't clearly indicate a cyst, an ultrasound can help determine what else it might be. This test, which uses high-frequency sound waves to create images of structures, might be used to rule out a testicular tumor or other cause of scrotal swelling.

Name: Spider bites
Symptoms: The ulcer usually stops growing within 10 days after the bite, but full healing can take months. Seek prompt medical care in the following situations: The doctor may recommend a tetanus booster shot if one hasn't had one in the last five years. One may have pain and swelling around the bite, which can spread into the belly, back or chest. The person who was bitten experiences severe pain, abdominal cramping or a growing ulcer at the bite site.
Overview: The black widow spider is known for the red hourglass marking on its belly. Brown recluse spider bites can cause a sting or sharp pain, like a bee sting.

Name: Spina bifida
Symptoms: Children with spina bifida occulta typically don't have any symptoms or complications, so usually only routine pediatric care is needed. But one can sometimes see signs on the newborn's skin above the spinal defect, including an abnormal tuft of hair, or a small dimple or birthmark. Sometimes, the skin marks can be signs of an underlying spinal cord issue that can be discovered with MRI or spinal ultrasound in a newborn.
Overview: Spina bifida is a birth defect that occurs when the spine and spinal cord don't form properly. The neural tube is the structure in a developing embryo that eventually becomes the baby's brain, spinal cord and the tissues that enclose them. In babies with spina bifida, a portion of the neural tube doesn't close or develop properly, causing defects in the spinal cord and in the bones of the spine. Myelomeningocele is a severe type of spina bifida in which the membranes and the spinal nerves protrude at birth, forming a sac on the baby's back. The membranes and spinal nerves push through this opening at birth, forming a sac on the baby's back, typically exposing tissues and nerves.
Risk factors: Although doctors and researchers don't know for sure why spina bifida occurs, they have identified some risk factors: If one has known risk factors for spina bifida, talk with the doctor to determine if one need a larger dose or prescription dose of folic acid, even before a pregnancy begins. If one plan ahead, some medications can be adjusted to diminish the potential risk of spina bifida. A folate deficiency increases the risk of spina bifida and other neural tube defects. In addition, a woman who was born with a neural tube defect has a greater chance of giving birth to a child with spina bifida. For example, anti-seizure medications, such as valproic acid (Depakene), seem to cause neural tube defects when taken during pregnancy. Pre-pregnancy obesity is associated with an increased risk of neural tube birth defects, including spina bifida. Elevating the core body temperature, due to fever or using a sauna or hot tub, has been associated with a possible slightly increased risk of spina bifida.
Diagnosis: If one is pregnant, one will be offered prenatal screening tests to check for spina bifida and other birth defects. Spina bifida can be screened with maternal blood tests, but typically the diagnosis is made with ultrasound. An advanced ultrasound also can detect signs of spina bifida, such as an open spine or particular features in the baby's brain that indicate spina bifida. If the prenatal ultrasound confirms the diagnosis of spina bifida, the doctor may request amniocentesis. For the MSAFP test, a sample of the mother's blood is drawn and tested for alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) a protein produced by the baby. But abnormally high levels of AFP suggest that the baby has a neural tube defect, such as spina bifida, though high levels of AFP don't always occur in spina bifida.
info-Symptoms: Hairy patch, dimple, dark spot, swelling on the lower back
info-Risk factors: Lack of folate during pregnancy, certain antiseizure medications, obesity, poorly controlled diabetes

Name: Spinal arteriovenous malformation ( AVM )
Overview: In an arteriovenous malformation (AVM), blood passes quickly from the artery to vein, disrupting the normal blood flow and depriving the surrounding tissues of oxygen. Spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is a rare, abnormal tangle of blood vessels on, in or near the spinal cord. A spinal arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is an abnormal tangle of blood vessels on, in or near the spinal cord.

Name: Spinal cord tumor
Overview: Intramedullary tumors are growths that develop in the supporting (glial) cells within the spinal cord. These are the main types of intradural tumors: Tumors from other parts of the body can spread (metastasize) to the vertebrae, the supporting network around the spinal cord or, in rare cases, the spinal cord itself. Although they don't begin within the spinal cord itself, these types of tumors may affect spinal cord function by causing spinal cord compression and other problems.
Causes: The spinal anatomy of a typical adult The spinal cord is housed within a hollow chamber within the vertebrae (spinal canal). In some cases, however, spinal cord tumors are linked to known inherited syndromes, such as neurofibromatosis 2 and von Hippel-Lindau disease.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects a spinal tumor, these tests can help confirm the diagnosis and pinpoint the tumor's location: Spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). MRI uses a powerful magnetic field and radio waves to produce accurate images of the spine, spinal cord and nerves.

Name: Spinal curvature
Overview: Viewed from the side, the normal spine takes the form of an elongated S, the upper back bowing outward and the lower back curving slightly inward. Most cases of scoliosis are mild, but some spine deformities continue to get more severe as children grow.
Risk factors: Although both boys and girls develop mild scoliosis at about the same rate, girls have a much higher risk of the curve worsening and requiring treatment. Scoliosis can run in families, but most children with scoliosis don't have a family history of the disease.
Treatment: Most children with scoliosis have mild curves and probably won't need treatment with a brace or surgery. While there are guidelines for mild, moderate and severe curves, the decision to begin treatment is always made on an individual basis. Double curves, also known as S-shaped curves, tend to worsen more often than do C-shaped curves. Curves located in the center (thoracic) section of the spine worsen more often than do curves in the upper or lower sections of the spine.

Name: Spinal headaches
Treatment: Injecting a small amount of the blood into the space over the puncture hole will often form a clot to seal the hole, restoring normal pressure in the spinal fluid and relieving the headache. If one has recently had a spinal procedure and develop a headache that lasts 24 hours or longer, the doctor can help one determine the seriousness of the condition.

Name: Splenomegaly
Overview: The spleen is a small organ normally about the size of the fist. Many conditions including infections, liver disease and some cancers can cause an enlarged spleen, also known as splenomegaly (spleh-no-MEG-uh-lee).
Causes: As the spleen grows larger, it filters normal red blood cells as well as abnormal ones, reducing the number of healthy cells in the bloodstream. An enlarged spleen may even outgrow its own blood supply, which can damage or destroy sections of the organ.
Diagnosis: Sometimes one may need more testing to find the cause of an enlarged spleen, including liver function tests and a bone marrow exam. Blood tests, such as a complete blood count to check the number of red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets in the system Ultrasound or computerized tomography (CT) scan to help determine the size of the spleen and whether it's crowding other organs Magnetic resonance imagining (MRI) to trace blood flow through the spleen Bone marrow biopsy Complete blood count (CBC) CT scan Liver function tests MRI Needle biopsy X-ray Blood tests, Ultrasound or computerized tomography (CT) scan Magnetic resonance imagining (MRI)
Remedies: Avoid contact sports such as soccer, football and hockey and limit other activities as recommended by the doctor. That means at least an annual flu shot, and a tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis booster every 10 years.

Name: Spondylosis , cervical
Overview: Cervical spondylosis is a general term for age-related wear and tear affecting the spinal disks in the neck. As the disks dehydrate and shrink, signs of osteoarthritis develop, including bony projections along the edges of bones (bone spurs).
Causes: Cervical spondylosis is the degeneration of the bones and disks in the neck, which can lead to a variety of problems, including herniated disks and bone spurs. By the age of 40, most people's spinal disks begin drying out and shrinking, which allows more bone-on-bone contact between the vertebrae. Cracks often appear, leading to bulging (herniated) disks which sometimes can press on the spinal cord and nerve roots.
Risk factors: Jobs that involve repetitive neck motions, awkward positioning or a lot of overhead work put extra stress on the neck. Previous neck injuries appear to increase the risk of cervical spondylosis.
Diagnosis: The doctor will likely start with a physical exam that includes: Imaging tests can provide detailed information to guide diagnosis and treatment. The doctor might recommend: The doctor might recommend tests to determine if nerve signals are traveling properly to the muscles. Nerve function tests include Checking the range of motion in the neck Testing the reflexes and muscle strength to find out if there's pressure on the spinal nerves or spinal cord Watching one walk to see if spinal compression is affecting the gait Neck X-ray.
Remedies: Maintaining activity will help speed recovery, even if one has to temporarily modify some of the exercises because of neck pain. Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) is often enough to control the pain associated with cervical spondylosis. However, a neck brace should be worn for only short periods of time because it can eventually weaken neck muscles.
Medication: If over-the-counter pain relievers aren't enough, the doctor might prescribe: A physical therapist can teach one exercises to help stretch and strengthen the muscles in the neck and shoulders. If conservative treatment fails or if the neurological signs and symptoms such as weakness in the arms or legs worsen, one might need surgery to create more room for the spinal cord and nerve roots. While some types of NSAIDs are available over the counter, one may need prescription-strength versions to relieve the pain and inflammation associated with cervical spondylosis.

Name: Spontaneous coronary artery dissection ( SCAD )
Risk factors: Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD), which causes irregular growth of cells in artery walls, is associated with SCAD. Diseases that cause inflammation of the blood vessels, such as lupus and polyarteritis nodosa, have also been associated with SCAD. Genetic diseases that cause problems with the body's connective tissues, such as vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and Marfan syndrome, have been found to occur in people who have had SCAD.
Diagnosis: Tests may include In a cardiac catheterization procedure, doctors insert a catheter in an artery in the wrist (radial artery) or in the groin (femoral artery).The catheter is then threaded through the blood vessels to the heart. In spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD), the arteries in the heart (coronary arteries) may sometimes be twisted (tortuous arteries). To get the dye into the arteries, doctors insert a long, thin tube (catheter) into an artery usually in the leg or arm and thread the tube to the arteries in the heart. During heart catheterization, a special imaging catheter may be passed into the arteries to create pictures using sound waves (ultrasound).
Treatment: In others, doctors may have to restore blood flow by opening the artery with a balloon or stent. The treatments most appropriate for one will depend on the condition, including the size and location of the tear in the artery, as well as any signs or symptoms one is experiencing.
Medication: After SCAD, the doctor may recommend medications, including After the treatment for SCAD, one will need regular follow-up appointments with the doctor to monitor for any changes in the condition. One may continue to take blood pressure drugs indefinitely to reduce the risk of another SCAD. The doctor may recommend using CT angiography to look for weaknesses and abnormalities in other blood vessels, such as FMD.

Name: Sprained ankle
Risk factors: Ankle sprains are a common sports injury, particularly in sports that require jumping, cutting action, or rolling or twisting of the foot such as basketball, tennis, football, soccer and trail running. Shoes that don't fit properly or aren't appropriate for an activity, as well as high-heeled shoes in general, make ankles more vulnerable to injury.
Diagnosis: If the injury is severe, the doctor may recommend one or more of the following imaging scans to rule out a broken bone or to evaluate in more detail the extent of ligament damage: X-ray. MRIs use radio waves and a strong magnetic field to produce detailed cross-sectional or 3-D images of soft internal structures of the ankle, including ligaments.
Medication: In most cases, over-the-counter pain relievers such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve, others) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) are enough to manage the pain of a sprained ankle. Once the swelling and pain is lessened enough to resume movement, the doctor will ask one to begin a series of exercises to restore the ankle's range of motion, strength, flexibility and stability.
info-Specialty: Orthopedics, sports medicine, Physical medicine and rehabilitation, Family medicine
info-Symptoms: Swelling, bruising, pain

Name: Sprains
Overview: A sprain is a stretching or tearing of ligaments the tough bands of fibrous tissue that connect two bones together in the joints. The difference between a sprain and a strain is that a sprain injures the bands of tissue that connect two bones together, while a strain involves an injury to a muscle or to the band of tissue that attaches a muscle to a bone.
Treatment: approach rest, ice, compression, elevation: Over-the-counter pain medications such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) also can be helpful. After the first two days, gently begin to use the injured area. Even if one is seeking medical help, ice the area immediately. To help stop swelling, compress the area with an elastic bandage until the swelling stops. Loosen the wrap if the pain increases, the area becomes numb or swelling is occurring below the wrapped area. Elevate the injured area above the level of the heart, especially at night, which allows gravity to help reduce swelling.
info-Specialty: Sports medicine, physical medicine & rehabilitation, orthopedics, family medicine, emergency medicine
info-Symptoms: Pain, swelling, bruising, joint instability, limited range of motion of the injured joint
info-Duration: Mild cases - few days to six weeks Severe cases - few weeks to months
info-Causes: Trauma, sports injuries, overuse, environmental hazards
info-Risk factors: Environmental factors, age, poor training or sports gear
info-Prevention: Frequent stretching and conditioning, bracing at risk joints during exercise
info-Prognosis: Mild injuries resolve well on their own. Severe injuries likely require surgery and physical therapy.

Name: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
Causes: One type of skin cancer called basal cell carcinoma begins in the basal cells, which make skin cells that continuously push older cells toward the surface. As new cells move upward, they become flattened squamous cells, where a skin cancer called squamous cell carcinoma can occur. Melanoma, another type of skin cancer, arises in the pigment cells (melanocytes).
Risk factors: Anyone, regardless of skin color, can get squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. If one has blond or red hair and light-colored eyes and one freckle or sunburn easily, one is much more likely to develop skin cancer, including squamous cell carcinoma, than is a person with darker skin. Being exposed to UV light from the sun increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. Spending lots of time in the sun particularly if one don't cover the skin with clothing or sunblock increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin even more. People who use indoor tanning beds have an increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. Having had one or more blistering sunburns as a child or teenager increases the risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma of the skin as an adult. Having a precancerous skin lesion, such as actinic keratosis or Bowen's disease, increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. If one has had squamous cell carcinoma of the skin once, one is much more likely to develop it again. People with xeroderma pigmentosum, which causes an extreme sensitivity to sunlight, have a greatly increased risk of developing skin cancer.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose squamous cell carcinoma of the skin include Physical exam. The doctor will ask questions about the health history and examine the skin to look for signs of squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. To confirm a squamous cell carcinoma of the skin diagnosis, the doctor will use a tool to cut away some or all of the suspicious skin lesion (biopsy).
info-Symptoms: Hard lump with a scaly top or ulceration.
info-Risk factors: Ultraviolet radiation, actinic keratosis, tobacco smoking, lighter skin, arsenic exposure, radiation therapy, poor immune system function, HPV infection
info-Treatment: Surgical removal, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy

Name: Stage 4 prostate cancer
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects one may have prostate cancer, tests and procedures may include Imaging tests. To confirm the diagnosis of prostate cancer, the doctor may recommend a biopsy procedure to remove a sample of suspicious cells for laboratory testing.

Name: Staph infections
Symptoms: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections start out as small red bumps that can quickly turn into deep, painful abscesses. Staph infections can range from minor skin problems to endocarditis, a life-threatening infection of the inner lining of the heart (endocardium). Because of this, signs and symptoms of staph infections vary widely, depending on the location and severity of the infection. Skin infections caused by staph bacteria include Boils. The most common type of staph infection is the boil, a pocket of pus that develops in a hair follicle or oil gland. When the blisters break, the top layer of skin comes off leaving a red, raw surface that looks like a burn.
Causes: However, if one develop a staph infection, there's a good chance that it's from bacteria one has been carrying around for some time. Because staph bacteria are so hardy, they can live on objects such as pillowcases or towels long enough to transfer to the next person who touches them.
Risk factors: People who may be more likely to get a staph infection include those with: Despite vigorous attempts to eradicate them, staph bacteria remain present in hospitals, where they attack the most vulnerable, including people with: Staph bacteria can travel along the medical tubing that connects the outside world with the internal organs. Diabetes who use insulin HIV/AIDS Kidney failure requiring dialysis Weakened immune systems either from a disease or medications that suppress the immune system A transplant Cancer, especially those who are undergoing chemotherapy or radiation Skin damage from conditions such as eczema, insect bites or minor trauma that opens the skin Respiratory illness, such as cystic fibrosis or emphysema Weakened immune systems Burns Surgical wounds Dialysis tubing Urinary catheters Feeding tubes Breathing tubes Intravascular catheters
Diagnosis: To diagnose a staph infection, the doctor will: Perform a physical exam. Most often, doctors diagnose staph infections by checking a tissue sample or nasal secretions for signs of the bacteria. If one is diagnosed with a staph infection, the doctor may order an imaging test called an echocardiogram to check if the infection has affected the heart. The doctor may order other imaging tests, depending on the symptoms and the exam results.
Treatment: The doctor may perform tests to identify the staph bacteria behind the infection, and to help choose the antibiotic that will work best. Antibiotics commonly prescribed to treat staph infections include certain cephalosporins such as cefazolin; nafcillin or oxacillin; vancomycin; daptomycin (Cubicin); telavancin (Vibativ); or linezolid (Zyvox).

Name: STDs
Overview: Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) or sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are generally acquired by sexual contact. The organisms (bacteria, viruses or parasites) that cause sexually transmitted diseases may pass from person to person in blood, semen, or vaginal and other bodily fluids.
Risk factors: Anyone who is sexually active risks some degree of exposure to a sexually transmitted disease (STD) or a sexually transmitted infection (STI). Oral sex may be less risky, but infections can still be transmitted without a latex condom or a dental dam a thin, square piece of rubber made with latex or silicone. Certain STIs such as gonorrhea, chlamydia, HIV and syphilis can be passed from an infected mother to her child during pregnancy or delivery. Men who ask their doctors for prescriptions for drugs such as sildenafil (Viagra, Revatio), tadalafil (Cialis, Adcirca) and vardenafil (Levitra) have higher rates of STIs.
Diagnosis: If the sexual history and current signs and symptoms suggest that one has a sexually transmitted disease (STD) or a sexually transmitted infection (STI), laboratory tests can identify the cause and detect coinfections one might also have. Experts recommend immediate testing for syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydia and herpes after being diagnosed with HIV. They also recommend that people with HIV be screened for hepatitis C. Women with HIV may develop aggressive cervical cancer, so experts recommend they have a Pap test within a year of being diagnosed with HIV, and then again six months later. The one STI screening test suggested for everyone ages 13 to 64 is a blood or saliva test for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the virus that causes AIDS. Since the disease often causes no symptoms until it's advanced, experts recommend that everyone in that age group be screened for hepatitis C. Pregnant women. After age 30, experts recommend women have an HPV DNA test and a Pap test every five years. They also recommend that people with HIV be screened for hepatitis C. Women with HIV may develop aggressive cervical cancer, so experts recommend they have a Pap test within a year of being diagnosed with HIV, and then again six months later.

Name: Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome
Symptoms: They generally get worse over time and may include Make an appointment with the doctor if one experience any of the signs and symptoms listed above. This difficulty with focusing the eyes can make some people spill food or appear disinterested in conversation because of poor eye contact.
Treatment: To minimize the effects of progressive supranuclear palsy, one can take certain steps at home: Living with any chronic illness can be difficult, and it's normal to feel angry, depressed or discouraged at times. To manage the stress of living with progressive supranuclear palsy, consider these suggestions: Parkinson's disease medications, which increase levels of a brain chemical involved in smooth, controlled muscle movements. Maintain a strong support system of friends and family Contact a support group, for theself or for family members Discuss the feelings and concerns about living with progressive supranuclear palsy with the doctor or a counselor Parkinson's disease medications, OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox), Eyeglasses with bifocal or prism lenses, Speech and swallowing evaluations, Physical therapy and occupational therapy, Use eyedrops Install grab bars Use a walker Remove small area rugs Avoid climbing stairs.
Remedies: To minimize the effects of progressive supranuclear palsy, one can take certain steps at home: Use eyedrops multiple times a day to help ease dry eyes that can occur as a result of problems with blinking or persistent tearing. Use eyedrops Install grab bars Use a walker Remove small area rugs Avoid climbing stairs.
info-Symptoms: Impaired balance, slowed movements, difficulty moving eyes, dementia

Name: Stein-Leventhal syndrome
Symptoms: A diagnosis of PCOS is made when one experience at least two of these signs: PCOS signs and symptoms are typically more severe if one is obese. Elevated levels of male hormone may result in physical signs, such as excess facial and body hair (hirsutism), and occasionally severe acne and male-pattern baldness.
Causes: Insulin is the hormone produced in the pancreas that allows cells to use sugar, the body's primary energy supply. If the cells become resistant to the action of insulin, then the blood sugar levels can rise and the body might produce more insulin. Excess insulin might increase androgen production, causing difficulty with ovulation.
Remedies: Ask the doctor about a weight-control program, and meet regularly with a dietitian for help in reaching weight-loss goals. If one has PCOS, increasing the daily activity and participating in a regular exercise program may treat or even prevent insulin resistance and help one keep the weight under control and avoid developing diabetes.
Medication: To regulate the menstrual cycle, the doctor might recommend: To help one ovulate, the doctor might recommend: To reduce excessive hair growth, the doctor might recommend: Combination birth control pills. Regulating the hormones can lower the risk of endometrial cancer and correct abnormal bleeding, excess hair growth and acne. Instead of pills, one might use a skin patch or vaginal ring that contains a combination of estrogen and progestin. If one don't become pregnant using clomiphene, the doctor might recommend adding metformin.
info-Symptoms: Irregular menstrual periods, heavy periods, excess hair, acne, pelvic pain, difficulty getting pregnant, patches of thick, darker, velvety skin
info-Risk factors: Obesity, not enough exercise, family history
info-Diagnostic method: Based on anovulation, high androgen levels, ovarian cysts
info-Frequency: 2% to 20% of women of childbearing age

Name: Stenosis , aortic valve
Overview: Aortic valve stenosis or aortic stenosis occurs when the heart's aortic valve narrows. This narrowing prevents the valve from opening fully, which reduces or blocks blood flow from the heart into the main artery to the body (aorta) and onward to the rest of the body. When the blood flow through the aortic valve is reduced or blocked, the heart needs to work harder to pump blood to the body.
Causes: Aortic valve stenosis is a defect that narrows or obstructs the aortic valve opening, making it difficult for the heart to pump blood into the aorta. Sometimes, the valves don't open or close properly, disrupting the blood flow through the heart and potentially impairing the ability to pump blood to the body. Aortic valve stenosis can occur due to many causes, including Congenital heart defect. With age, heart valves may accumulate deposits of calcium (aortic valve calcification). As blood repeatedly flows over the aortic valve, deposits of calcium can build up on the valve's cusps. However, aortic valve stenosis that is related to increasing age and the buildup of calcium deposits on the aortic valve is most common in older people. A complication of strep throat infection, rheumatic fever may result in scar tissue forming on the aortic valve. Scar tissue can also create a rough surface on which calcium deposits can collect, contributing to aortic valve stenosis later in life. Rheumatic fever may damage more than one heart valve, and in more than one way.
Diagnosis: Doctors may use this test to evaluate the heart chambers, the aortic valve and the blood flow through the heart. This test can help doctors closely look at the condition of the aortic valve, and the cause and severity of the condition. This test isn't often used to diagnose aortic valve disease, but it may be used if other tests aren't able to diagnose the condition or to determine its severity. A chest X-ray can help the doctor determine whether the heart is enlarged, which can occur in aortic valve stenosis. Exercise tests help doctors see whether one has signs and symptoms of aortic valve disease during physical activity, and these tests can help determine the severity of the condition.
Remedies: The doctor may suggest one incorporate several heart-healthy lifestyle changes into the life, including For women with aortic valve stenosis, it's important to talk with the doctor before one become pregnant. The doctor can discuss with one which medications one can safely take, and whether one may need a procedure to treat the valve condition prior to pregnancy. If one is overweight or obese, the doctor may recommend that one lose weight. Find ways to help manage the stress, such as through relaxation activities, meditation, physical activity, and spending time with family and friends.

Name: Stenosis , mitral valve
Causes: Causes of mitral valve stenosis include A normal heart has two upper (receiving) and two lower (pumping) chambers. The mitral valve which lies between the two chambers on the left side of the heart comprises two flaps of tissue called leaflets. As one age, calcium deposits can build up around the ring around the mitral valve (annulus), which can occasionally cause mitral valve stenosis. In rare cases, babies are born with a narrowed mitral valve (congenital defect) that causes problems over time.
Diagnosis: Mitral valve stenosis causes an abnormal heart sound, called a heart murmur. The doctor also will listen to the lungs to check lung congestion a buildup of fluid in the lungs that can occur with mitral valve stenosis. Common tests to diagnose mitral valve stenosis include Cardiac tests such as these help the doctor distinguish mitral valve stenosis from other heart conditions, including other mitral valve conditions.
Remedies: To improve the quality of life if one has mitral valve stenosis, the doctor may recommend that one: Women with mitral valve stenosis need to discuss family planning with their doctors before becoming pregnant. How a heart with mitral valve stenosis tolerates the extra work depends on the degree of stenosis and how well the heart pumps. Fast heart rhythms that aren't treated can lead to rapid deterioration in people with mitral valve stenosis. Ask the doctor for guidance before starting to exercise, especially if one is considering competitive sports.
Medication: The doctor might prescribe one or more of the following medications: One may need valve repair or replacement to treat mitral valve stenosis, which may include surgical and nonsurgical options. In this procedure, also called balloon valvotomy, a doctor inserts a soft, thin tube (catheter) tipped with a balloon in an artery in the arm or groin and guides it to the narrowed valve. For some people, balloon valvuloplasty can relieve the signs and symptoms of mitral valve stenosis. If the mitral valve can't be repaired, surgeons may perform mitral valve replacement. In mitral valve replacement, the surgeon removes the damaged valve and replaces it with a mechanical valve or a valve made from cow, pig or human heart tissue (biological tissue valve). If balloon valvuloplasty isn't an option, a cardiac surgeon might perform open-heart surgery to remove calcium deposits and other scar tissue to clear the valve passageway.

Name: Stenosis , pulmonary valve
Causes: In pulmonary stenosis, the flow of blood from the right ventricle to the pulmonary artery is obstructed by narrowing at the pulmonary valve. The greater the constriction, the harder the right ventricle must pump to force blood into the pulmonary artery. This complication of an infection caused by streptococcus bacteria, such as strep throat, may injure the heart valves.
Diagnosis: If the doctor hears a heart murmur during a routine checkup and suspects pulmonary stenosis, he or she may then use a variety of tests to confirm the diagnosis. This test is useful for checking the structure of the pulmonary valve, the location and severity of the narrowing (stenosis), and right ventricle size and function. During this procedure, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube (catheter) into an artery or vein in the groin and threads it up to the heart or blood vessels. Doctors generally use this test only if they suspect that one or the child will need a balloon valvuloplasty, a procedure that can be done at the same time as cardiac catheterization.

Name: Stenosis , pyloric
Symptoms: The baby may vomit forcefully, ejecting breast milk or formula up to several feet away (projectile vomiting). One may notice wave-like contractions (peristalsis) that ripple across the baby's upper abdomen soon after feeding but before vomiting. Since pyloric stenosis prevents food from reaching the intestines, babies with this condition might be constipated. Pyloric stenosis can keep a baby from gaining weight, and sometimes can cause weight loss.
Overview: The pylorus is a muscular valve that holds food in the stomach until it is ready for the next stage in the digestive process. In pyloric stenosis, the pylorus muscles thicken, blocking food from entering the baby's small intestine. Normally, a muscular valve (pylorus) between the stomach and small intestine holds food in the stomach until it is ready for the next stage in the digestive process. In pyloric stenosis, the pylorus muscles thicken and become abnormally large, blocking food from reaching the small intestine.
Risk factors: Babies given certain antibiotics in the first weeks of life erythromycin to treat whooping cough, for example have an increased risk of pyloric stenosis. In addition, babies born to mothers who took certain antibiotics in late pregnancy may have an increased risk of pyloric stenosis. Some studies suggest that bottle-feeding rather than breast-feeding can increase the risk of pyloric stenosis. Most of the people who participated in these studies used formula rather than breast milk, so it isn't clear whether the increased risk is related to formula or the mechanism of bottle-feeding.

Name: Stenosis , spinal
Overview: Spinal stenosis occurs when the space within the spinal canal or around the nerve roots becomes narrowed. Spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spaces within the spine, which can put pressure on the nerves that travel through the spine. In severe cases of spinal stenosis, doctors may recommend surgery to create additional space for the spinal cord or nerves. The types of spinal stenosis are classified according to where on the spine the condition occurs.
Causes: The bones of the spine form a spinal canal, which protects the spinal cord (nerves). Wear and tear damage from osteoarthritis on the spinal bones can prompt the formation of bone spurs, which can grow into the spinal canal. Cracks in a disk's exterior may allow some of the soft inner material to escape and press on the spinal cord or nerves. Abnormal growths can form inside the spinal cord, within the membranes that cover the spinal cord or in the space between the spinal cord and vertebrae.
Risk factors: Though degenerative changes can cause spinal stenosis in younger people, other causes need to be considered. These include trauma, congenital spinal deformity such as scoliosis, and a genetic disease affecting bone and muscle development throughout the body.
Diagnosis: To diagnose spinal stenosis, the doctor may ask one about signs and symptoms, discuss the medical history, and conduct a physical examination. An X-ray of the back can reveal bony changes, such as bone spurs that may be narrowing the space within the spinal canal. If one can't have an MRI, the doctor may recommend computerized tomography (CT), a test that combines X-ray images taken from many different angles to produce detailed, cross-sectional images of the body.
Remedies: He or she may suggest that one incorporate several home treatments into the life, including Trying pain relievers. Over-the-counter medications such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen (Aleve, others) and acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) can help reduce pain and inflammation. Losing excess weight can reduce pain by taking some stress off the back, particularly the lumbar portion of the spine. In addition to providing stability, these assistive devices can help relieve pain by allowing one to bend forward while walking.
Medication: The doctor may prescribe: It's common for people who have spinal stenosis to become less active, in an effort to reduce pain. While injecting a steroid medication (corticosteroid) into the space around impingement won't fix the stenosis, it can help reduce the inflammation and relieve some of the pain. It has also been called minimally invasive lumbar decompression (MILD), but to avoid confusion with minimally invasive surgical procedures, doctors have adopted the term PILD. Pain medications such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen (Aleve, others) and acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) may be used temporarily to ease the discomfort of spinal stenosis. Some anti-seizure drugs, such as gabapentin (Neurontin) and pregabalin (Lyrica), are used to reduce pain caused by damaged nerves. Drugs that contain codeine-related drugs such as oxycodone (Oxycontin, Roxicodone) and hydrocodone (Norco, Vicodin) may be useful for short-term pain relief.

Name: Stevens-Johnson syndrome
Overview: Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a serious adverse reaction of the skin and mucous membranes. Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes.
Risk factors: Among people with HIV, the incidence of Stevens-Johnson syndrome is about 100 times greater than among the general population. People with cancer, particularly blood cancer, are at increased risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome. Having certain genetic variations puts one at increased risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome, especially if one is also taking drugs for seizures, gout or mental illness.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose Stevens-Johnson syndrome include A review of the medical history and a physical exam. Doctors often can identify Stevens-Johnson syndrome based on the medical history, including a review of the current and recently stopped medications, and a physical exam. To confirm the diagnosis, and rule out other possible causes, the doctor removes a sample of skin for laboratory testing (biopsy).
info-Symptoms: Fever, skin blisters, skin peeling, painful skin, red eyes
info-Risk factors: HIV/AIDS, systemic lupus erythematosus, genetics
info-Diagnostic method: <10% of the skin involved, skin biopsy
info-Frequency: 1â€“2 per million per year (together with TEN)
