info-Medication: Pain medication, antihistamines, antibiotics, corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulins

Name: Stickler syndrome
Symptoms: Regular follow-up visits, as well as yearly visits to doctors specializing in eye disorders, are crucial to monitor any progression of symptoms. Hearing should be checked every six months in children through age 5 and then yearly thereafter. In addition to having severe nearsightedness, children who have Stickler syndrome often experience cataracts, glaucoma and retinal detachments. Children who have Stickler syndrome often have overly flexible joints and are more likely to develop abnormal curvatures of the spine, such as scoliosis.
Overview: Stickler syndrome is a genetic disorder that can cause serious vision, hearing and joint problems. Children who have Stickler syndrome often have distinctive facial features prominent eyes, a small nose with a scooped-out facial appearance and a receding chin.
Diagnosis: While Stickler syndrome can sometimes be diagnosed based on the child's medical history and a physical exam, additional tests are needed to determine the severity of the symptoms and help direct treatment decisions. Genetic testing can also be used to help in family planning and to determine the risk of passing on the gene to the children when the hereditary pattern is not clear from the family history. These exams can help the doctor detect problems with the jellylike material (vitreous) that fills the eye or with the lining of the eye (retina), which is crucial for sight.
Remedies: Over-the-counter drugs such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve) may help relieve joint swelling, stiffness and pain. Strenuous physical activity may stress the joints, and contact sports, such as football, may increase the risk of retinal detachment.

Name: Stings , bee
Diagnosis: If one has had a reaction to bee stings that suggests one might be allergic to bee venom, the doctor may suggest one or both of the following tests: Allergy skin tests and allergy blood tests are often used together to diagnose insect allergies. The doctor may also want to test one for allergies to yellow jackets, hornets and wasps which can cause allergic reactions similar to those of bee stings.
Remedies: The following steps may help ease the swelling and itching often associated with large local reactions: If one can, remove the stinger as soon as possible, such as by scraping it off with a fingernail. If itching or swelling is bothersome, take an oral antihistamine that contains diphenhydramine (Benadryl) or chlorpheniramine.

Name: Stings , jellyfish
Causes: While many types of jellyfish are relatively harmless to humans, some can cause severe pain and are more likely to cause a systemic reaction. Also called bluebottle jellyfish, Portuguese man-of-war jellyfish live mostly in warmer seas. Common in both warm and cool seawaters, sea nettles live along the northeast coast of the United States and are abundant in the Chesapeake Bay. These are the world's largest jellyfish, with a body diameter of more than 3 feet (1 meter).

Name: Stings , scorpion
Overview: The bark scorpion is commonly found in the desert of the southwestern United States. In the United States, the bark scorpion, found mainly in the desert Southwest, is the only scorpion species with venom potent enough to cause severe symptoms. But with more than a million scorpion stings taking place each year, deaths from these stings are a significant public health problem in areas where access to medical care is limited.
Treatment: But if symptoms are severe, one may need to receive care in a hospital. Healthy adults may not need further treatment, and these tips can help keep children safe until they see a doctor: Check the or the child's vaccination records to be sure a tetanus vaccine is up to date. The best thing to do is try and immobilize the area, and seek medical treatment right away. One might try ibuprofen (Motrin IB, Children's Motrin, others) to help ease discomfort.
Remedies: Healthy adults may not need further treatment, and these tips can help keep children safe until they see a doctor: Check the or the child's vaccination records to be sure a tetanus vaccine is up to date. The best thing to do is try and immobilize the area, and seek medical treatment right away. If one is going to be outside, it's very important to bring water with one and a lot of it. One might try ibuprofen (Motrin IB, Children's Motrin, others) to help ease discomfort.

Name: Stomach cancer
Overview: The area where the lower end of the esophagus meets the upper part of the stomach is called the gastroesophageal junction. During the same period, cancer in the area where the top part of the stomach (cardia) meets the lower end of the swallowing tube (esophagus) has become much more common.
Diagnosis: A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). Tests and procedures used to diagnose gastroesophageal junction cancer and stomach cancer include The stage of the stomach cancer helps the doctor decide which treatments may be best for one. Tests and procedures used to determine the stage of cancer include Other staging tests may be used, depending on the situation. If the doctor sees anything unusual, such as polyps or cancer, he or she passes special surgical tools through the endoscope to remove tissue or collect a sample to examine it more closely. Imaging tests used to look for stomach cancer include computerized tomography (CT) scans and a special type of X-ray exam sometimes called a barium swallow. The doctor may recommend surgery to look for signs that the cancer has spread beyond the esophagus or stomach, within the chest or abdomen. The cancer at this stage has spread deeper, growing into a deeper muscle layer of the esophagus or stomach wall. At this stage, the cancer may have grown through all the layers of the esophagus or stomach and spread to nearby structures.
info-Symptoms: Early: Heartburn, bloating, upper abdominal pain, nausea, belching, loss of appetite.Later: Weight loss, yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes, vomiting blood, difficulty swallowing, blood in the stool
info-Risk factors: Smoking, dietary factors such as pickled vegetables, obesity
info-Treatment: Surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, targeted therapy

Name: Stomach pain , nonulcer
Diagnosis: A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). The doctor may recommend a test to look for a bacterium called Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) that can cause stomach problems. A thin, flexible, lighted instrument (endoscope) is passed down the throat so that the doctor can view the esophagus, stomach and the first part of the small intestine (duodenum).
Remedies: Consider trying to: Eat smaller, more-frequent meals. Some foods may trigger functional dyspepsia, such as fatty and spicy foods, carbonated beverages, caffeine, and alcohol.
Medication: Medications that may help in managing the signs and symptoms of functional dyspepsia include Medications that block acid pumps. Over-the-counter proton pump inhibitors include lansoprazole (Prevacid 24HR), omeprazole (Prilosec OTC) and esopremazole (Nexium). Called H-2-receptor blockers, these medications are available over-the-counter and include cimetidine (Tagamet HB), famotidine (Pepcid AC) and nizatidine (Axid AR). Doctors may prescribe the medication metoclopramide (Reglan) if they find that emptying of the stomach is delayed, but this drug doesn't work for everyone and may have significant side effects. Tricyclic antidepressants and drugs known as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), taken in low doses, may help inhibit the activity of neurons that control intestinal pain.

Name: Stomach polyps
Overview: The stomach is a muscular sac about the size of a small melon that expands when one eat or drink to hold as much as a gallon of food or liquid. Once the stomach pulverizes the food, strong muscular contractions (peristaltic waves) push the food toward the pyloric valve, which leads to the upper portion of the small intestine (duodenum).
Causes: Hyperplastic polyps are unlikely to become cancerous, although those larger than about 2/5 inch (1 centimeter) carry a greater risk. This rare, inherited syndrome causes certain cells on the stomach's inner lining to a specific type of polyps called fundic gland polyps. When associated with this syndrome, fundic gland polyps are removed because they can become cancerous. Fundic gland polyps are common among people who regularly take proton pump inhibitors to reduce stomach acid.
Risk factors: This rare, inherited syndrome increases the risk of colon cancer and other conditions, including stomach polyps. Long-term use of proton pump inhibitors, which are medications used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease, has been linked to fundic gland polyps.
Treatment: Treatment depends on the type of stomach polyps one has: The doctor will likely recommend follow-up endoscopy to check for recurring polyps. The doctor might recommend periodic monitoring so that growing polyps or polyps that cause signs and symptoms can be removed.

Name: Stomatodynia
Symptoms: Symptoms of burning mouth syndrome may include The discomfort from burning mouth syndrome typically has several different patterns. It may: Whatever pattern of mouth discomfort one has, burning mouth syndrome may last for months to years.
Diagnosis: Instead, the doctor will try to rule out other problems before diagnosing burning mouth syndrome. One may have some of the following tests: Review the medical history and medications Examine the mouth Ask one to describe the symptoms, oral habits and oral care routine Blood tests. Blood tests can check the complete blood count, glucose level, thyroid function, nutritional factors and immune functioning, all of which may provide clues about the source of the mouth discomfort. The doctor may suggest allergy testing to see if one may be allergic to certain foods, additives or even substances in dental work. The doctor may recommend an MRI scan, a CT scan or other imaging tests to check for other health problems. If one take a medication that may contribute to mouth discomfort, the doctor may change the dose, switch to a different medication, or temporarily stop the medication, if possible, to see if the discomfort goes away. One may be asked to fill out questionnaires that can help determine if one has symptoms of depression, anxiety or other mental health conditions.

Name: Stones , kidney
Symptoms: As stones move into the ureters the thin tubes that allow urine to pass from the kidneys to the bladder signs and symptoms can result. A kidney stone usually will not cause symptoms until it moves around within the kidney or passes into the ureters the tubes connecting the kidneys and the bladder.
Overview: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine.
Causes: Kidney stones often have no definite, single cause, although several factors may increase the risk. Kidney stones form when the urine contains more crystal-forming substances such as calcium, oxalate and uric acid than the fluid in the urine can dilute. At the same time, the urine may lack substances that prevent crystals from sticking together, creating an ideal environment for kidney stones to form. Knowing the type of kidney stone one has helps determine its cause, and may give clues on how to reduce the risk of getting more kidney stones. Most kidney stones are calcium stones, usually in the form of calcium oxalate.
Risk factors: If one has already had one or more kidney stones, one is at increased risk of developing another. Eating a diet that's high in protein, sodium (salt) and sugar may increase the risk of some types of kidney stones. High body mass index (BMI), large waist size and weight gain have been linked to an increased risk of kidney stones. Other medical conditions such as renal tubular acidosis, cystinuria, hyperparathyroidism and repeated urinary tract infections also can increase the risk of kidney stones. Certain supplements and medications, such as vitamin C, dietary supplements, laxatives (when used excessively), calcium-based antacids, and certain medications used to treat migraines or depression, can increase the risk of kidney stones.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects that one has a kidney stone, one may have diagnostic tests and procedures, such as: Imaging. Imaging tests may show kidney stones in the urinary tract. Ultrasound, a noninvasive test that is quick and easy to perform, is another imaging option to diagnose kidney stones.
Medication: To help prevent calcium stones from forming, the doctor may prescribe a thiazide diuretic or a phosphate-containing preparation. The doctor may prescribe allopurinol (Zyloprim, Aloprim) to reduce uric acid levels in the blood and urine and a medicine to keep the urine alkaline. To prevent struvite stones, the doctor may recommend strategies to keep the urine free of bacteria that cause infection, including drinking fluids to maintain good urine flow and frequent voiding.

Name: Stool holding
Causes: In constipation, the child's stool is hard, dry and may be painful to pass. When the colon becomes too full, soft or liquid stool may leak out around the retained stool or loss of control over bowel movements may occur.
Remedies: Once the child has been treated for encopresis, it's important that one encourage regular bowel movements. Feed the child a balanced diet that includes plenty of fruits, vegetables, whole grains and other foods high in fiber, which can help form soft stools. In some cases, cow's milk may contribute to constipation, but dairy products also contain important nutrients, so ask the doctor how much dairy the child needs each day. This may make the child more comfortable, and changing the position of his or her legs can put more pressure on the abdomen, making a bowel movement easier. As one help the child overcome encopresis, be patient and use positive reinforcement.

Name: Strawberry hemangioma
Treatment: But if a hemangioma affects vision or causes other problems, treatments include medications or laser surgery: If one is considering treatment for the child's hemangioma, weigh the pros and cons with the child's doctor. Consider that most infantile hemangiomas disappear on their own during childhood and that treatments have potential side effects. In small, superficial hemangiomas, a gel containing the drug timolol may be applied to the affected skin. For children who don't respond to beta blocker treatments or can't use them, corticosteroids may be an option. Sometimes laser surgery can remove a small, thin hemangioma or treat sores on a hemangioma. Infantile hemangiomas: Epidemiology, pathogenesis, clinical features, and complications.
info-Specialty: Dermatology, gastroenterology, Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery
info-Symptoms: Raised red or blue lesion
info-Risk factors: Females, white people, preemies, low birth weight babies

Name: Strep throat
Remedies: In the meantime, try these tips to relieve symptoms of strep throat: Get plenty of rest. If the child is ill, keep him or her at home until there's no sign of fever, and he or she feels better and has taken an antibiotic for at least 24 hours. Easy-to-swallow foods include broths, soups, applesauce, cooked cereal, mashed potatoes, soft fruits, yogurt and soft-cooked eggs. Cold foods, such as sherbet, frozen yogurt or frozen fruit pops also may be soothing. For older children and adults, gargling several times a day can help relieve throat pain. Avoid fumes from paint or cleaning products, which can irritate the throat and lungs.
info-Symptoms: Fever, sore throat, large lymph nodes
info-Risk factors: Sharing drinks or eating utensils

Name: Stress fractures
Risk factors: Stress fractures are more common in people who engage in high-impact sports, such as track and field, basketball, tennis, dance or gymnastics. Stress fractures often occur in people who suddenly shift from a sedentary lifestyle to an active training regimen or who rapidly increase the intensity, duration or frequency of training sessions. Women, especially those who have abnormal or absent menstrual periods, are at higher risk of developing stress fractures. People who have flat feet or high, rigid arches are more likely to develop stress fractures. Eating disorders and lack of vitamin D and calcium can make bones more likely to develop stress fractures.
Treatment: To reduce the bone's weight-bearing load until healing occurs, one might need to wear a walking boot or brace or use crutches. Although unusual, surgery is sometimes necessary to ensure complete healing of some types of stress fractures, especially those that occur in areas with a poor blood supply. Surgery also might be an option to help healing in elite athletes who want to return to their sport more quickly or laborers whose work involves the stress fracture site. To reduce swelling and relieve pain, the doctor might recommend applying ice packs to the injured area as needed 15 minutes every three hours. When the doctor gives the OK, slowly progress from non-weight-bearing activities such as swimming to the usual activities.
Remedies: To reduce swelling and relieve pain, the doctor might recommend applying ice packs to the injured area as needed 15 minutes every three hours. When the doctor gives the OK, slowly progress from non-weight-bearing activities such as swimming to the usual activities. Resume running or other high-impact activities gradually, increasing time and distance slowly.

Name: Stress incontinence
Overview: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. Stress incontinence happens when physical movement or activity such as coughing, laughing, sneezing, running or heavy lifting puts pressure (stress) on the bladder, causing one to leak urine.
Causes: Women's pelvic floor muscles work like a hammock to support the pelvic organs, including the uterus, bladder and rectum. The pelvic floor muscles and urinary sphincter may lose strength because of: Other factors that may worsen stress incontinence include Childbirth. In women, tissue or nerve damage during delivery of a child can weaken the pelvic floor muscles or the sphincter. In men, the surgical removal of the prostate gland to treat prostate cancer (prostatectomy) is the most common factor leading to stress incontinence.
Risk factors: Physical changes that occur as one age, such as the weakening of muscles, may make one more likely to develop stress incontinence. Women whove had a forceps delivery to more rapidly deliver a healthy baby may also have a greater risk of stress incontinence. Women whove had a vacuum-assisted delivery don't appear to have a higher risk for stress incontinence. Hysterectomy in women and surgery for prostate cancer in men can weaken the muscles that support the bladder and urethra, increasing the risk of stress incontinence.
Diagnosis: However, in some cases, the doctor might order tests to assess how well the bladder, urethra and sphincter are functioning (urodynamic tests). The doctor may recommend this test if there's concern about the ability to empty the bladder completely, particularly if one is older, have had prior bladder surgery or have diabetes. This procedure may be combined with a pressure-flow study, which tells how much pressure the bladder has to exert in order to empty completely. Medical history Physical exam, which may include a rectal exam and a pelvic exam in women Urine sample to test for infection, traces of blood or other abnormalities Brief neurological exam to identify any pelvic nerve problems Urinary stress test, in which the doctor observes urine loss when one cough or bear down Measurements of post-void residual urine.
Remedies: If one is overweight the body mass index (BMI) is 25 or higher losing excess pounds can help reduce the overall pressure on the bladder and pelvic floor muscles. If chronic constipation contributes to the urinary incontinence, keeping bowel movements soft and regular reduces the strain placed on the pelvic floor muscles. Try eating high-fiber foods whole grains, legumes, fruits and vegetables to relieve and prevent constipation. If eating chocolate or drinking coffee, tea (regular or decaf) or carbonated beverages seems to make one urinate and leak more frequently, try eliminating that drink, especially on days one really don't want to be bothered by leakage.
Medication: The antidepressant duloxetine (Cymbalta, Drizalma Sprinkle) is used for the treatment of stress incontinence in Europe, however. Certain devices designed for women may help control stress incontinence, including Vaginal pessary. A specialized urinary incontinence pessary, shaped like a ring with two bumps that sit on each side of the urethra, is fitted and put into place by the doctor or nurse. It helps support the bladder base to prevent urine leakage during activity, especially if the bladder has dropped (prolapsed). It's usually used to prevent incontinence during a specific activity, but it may be worn throughout the day. Urethral inserts are generally used only for heavy activity, such as repeated lifting, running or playing tennis.

Name: Stretch marks
Symptoms: Stretch marks can cover large areas of the body, but it happens rarely. Common variations include See the doctor if one is concerned about the appearance of the skin or if the stretch marks cover large areas of the body.
Overview: Some men and women are prone to develop stretch marks on the abdomen, buttocks and thighs. Stretch marks (striae) are indented streaks that often appear on the abdomen, breasts, hips, buttocks and thighs.
Treatment: One may not like how stretch marks make the skin look, but they don't require medical treatment. If one do seek treatment for stretch marks, know that treatments are only partially effective and won't remove them completely. Derived from vitamin A, retinoids such as tretinoin (Retin-A, Renova, Avita) that one apply to the skin may improve the appearance of stretch marks less than a few months old. Tretinoin, when it works, helps to rebuild collagen, making the stretch marks look more like the normal skin. If one is pregnant or nursing, talk with the doctor about other treatment options, because possible side effects of retinoid cream may affect the baby. How long one has had the stretch marks The skin type Convenience, as some therapies require repeated doctor visits Cost, as treatments to improve appearance (cosmetic therapies) often aren't covered by medical insurance The expectations Retinoid cream.

Name: Stroke
Symptoms: If one or someone one is with may be having a stroke, pay particular attention to the time the symptoms began. The longer a stroke goes untreated, the greater the potential for brain damage and disability. If one is with someone one suspect is having a stroke, watch the person carefully while waiting for emergency assistance. One may experience confusion, slur the words or have difficulty understanding speech. Paralysis or numbness of the face, arm or leg. One may develop sudden numbness, weakness or paralysis in the face, arm or leg. If one arm begins to fall, one may be having a stroke. Also, one side of the mouth may droop when one try to smile. One may suddenly have blurred or blackened vision in one or both eyes, or one may see double. A sudden, severe headache, which may be accompanied by vomiting, dizziness or altered consciousness, may indicate that one is having a stroke.
Causes: There are two main causes of stroke: a blocked artery (ischemic stroke) or leaking or bursting of a blood vessel (hemorrhagic stroke). Ischemic stroke occurs when a blood clot blocks or narrows an artery leading to the brain. It happens when the brain's blood vessels become narrowed or blocked, causing severely reduced blood flow (ischemia). A transient ischemic attack (TIA) sometimes known as a ministroke is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those oned have in a stroke. Like an ischemic stroke, a TIA occurs when a clot or debris reduces or blocks blood flow to part of the nervous system.
Diagnosis: Doctors also need to rule out other possible causes of the symptoms, such as a brain tumor or a drug reaction. A stroke if one think about it as interruption of blood flow to the brain, either there isn't enough blood flow getting to the brain or there's too much. The doctor will do a number of tests one is familiar with, such as listening to the heart and checking the blood pressure. One may have several blood tests, including tests to check how fast the blood clots, whether the blood sugar is too high or low, and whether one has an infection. A CT scan can show bleeding in the brain, an ischemic stroke, a tumor or other conditions. Doctors may inject a dye into the bloodstream to view the blood vessels in the neck and brain in greater detail (computerized tomography angiography). The doctor may inject a dye into a blood vessel to view the arteries and veins and highlight blood flow (magnetic resonance angiography or magnetic resonance venography). In this uncommonly used test, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube (catheter) through a small incision, usually in the groin, and guides it through the major arteries and into the carotid or vertebral artery.
info-Symptoms: Inability to move or feel on one side of the body, problems understanding or speaking, dizziness, loss of vision to one side
info-Risk factors: High blood pressure, tobacco smoking, obesity, high blood cholesterol, diabetes mellitus, previous TIA, end-stage kidney disease, atrial fibrillation
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms with medical imaging typically used to rule out bleeding

Name: Stump pain
Remedies: One may not have control over whether one develop phantom pain after surgery, but one can reduce the discomfort and improve the quality of life. One or more of these approaches may help one get through a flare-up of phantom pain: Remember that managing phantom pain can make a big difference in how one feel. Find activities that take the focus off the pain, such as reading or listening to music. Take a warm bath not too hot, as heat may aggravate the pain.
Medication: Although no medications specifically for phantom pain exist, some drugs designed to treat other conditions have been helpful in relieving nerve pain. Taken in appropriate doses under the doctor's direction, they may help control phantom pain. In studies, NMDA receptor antagonists ketamine and dextromethorphan helped relieve phantom pain. Some studies, though not all, have found that this exercise may help relieve phantom pain. Research suggests that this therapy may be helpful for phantom pain, though it isn't yet specifically approved for this condition. Although this technique has been tested only on a small number of people, it appears to help relieve phantom pain. Acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve) might relieve phantom pain. Epilepsy drugs such as gabapentin (Gralise, Neurontin) and pregabalin (Lyrica) may be used to treat nerve pain. Although the data are still limited and these treatments aren't specifically approved for phantom pain, brain stimulation appears to be a promising option in selected individuals.

Name: Stuttering
Overview: Stuttering also called stammering or childhood-onset fluency disorder is a speech disorder that involves frequent and significant problems with normal fluency and flow of speech. Children and adults who stutter may benefit from treatments such as speech therapy, using electronic devices to improve speech fluency or cognitive behavioral therapy.
Causes: Possible causes of developmental stuttering include Speech fluency can be disrupted from causes other than developmental stuttering. A stroke, traumatic brain injury, or other brain disorders can cause speech that is slow or has pauses or repeated sounds (neurogenic stuttering). Speech difficulties that appear after an emotional trauma (psychogenic stuttering) are uncommon and not the same as developmental stuttering. Some evidence indicates that abnormalities in speech motor control, such as timing, sensory and motor coordination, may be involved.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of stuttering include Delayed childhood development. Stress in the family, high parental expectations or other types of pressure can worsen existing stuttering.
Treatment: After a comprehensive evaluation by a speech-language pathologist, a decision about the best treatment approach can be made. Treatment may not eliminate all stuttering, but it can teach skills that help to: A few examples of treatment approaches in no particular order of effectiveness include Improve speech fluency Develop effective communication Participate fully in school, work and social activities Speech therapy. One may speak very slowly and deliberately when beginning speech therapy, but over time, one can work up to a more natural speech pattern.
info-Symptoms: Involuntary sound repetition and disruption or blocking of speech
info-Prognosis: Usually resolves by late childhood; 20% of cases last into adulthood

Name: Sty
Symptoms: Unlike a sty, a chalazion usually isn't painful and tends to be most prominent on the inner side of the eyelid. Try self-care measures first, such as applying a warm washcloth to the closed eyelid for 5 to 10 minutes several times a day and gently massaging the eyelid.
Overview: A sty is a bacterial infection involving one or more of the small glands near the base of the eyelashes. A sty is a red, painful lump near the edge of the eyelid that may look like a boil or a pimple. In the meantime, one may be able to relieve the pain or discomfort of a sty by applying a warm washcloth to the eyelid.
Treatment: For a sty that persists, the doctor may recommend treatments, such as: Until the sty goes away on its own, try to: Start by seeing the family doctor or a general practitioner if the sty is painful or doesn't start to get better in two days. In some cases, the doctor may refer one to a specialist who treats eye diseases and conditions (ophthalmologist). If the eyelid infection persists or spreads beyond the eyelid, the doctor may recommend antibiotics in tablet or pill form. If the sty doesn't clear up, the doctor may make a small cut in it to drain the pus. If one wear contacts, try to go without them until the sty goes away.
Remedies: Until the sty goes away on its own, try to: Leave the sty alone. If one wear contacts, try to go without them until the sty goes away.

Name: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
Overview: A subarachnoid hemorrhage is bleeding in the space between the brain and the surrounding membrane (subarachnoid space). Sometimes bleeding is caused by trauma, an abnormal tangle of blood vessels in the brain (arteriovenous malformation), or other blood vessel or health problems.
Diagnosis: To diagnose a subarachnoid hemorrhage, the doctor is likely to recommend: Up to 22 percent of aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhages don't appear on initial imaging tests. If the initial tests don't show bleeding, the doctor might recommend: CT scan. This imaging test can detect bleeding in the brain.The doctor may inject a contrast dye to view the blood vessels in greater detail (CT angiogram). The doctor might inject a dye into a blood vessel to view the arteries and veins in greater detail (MR angiogram) and to highlight blood flow. The doctor might recommend cerebral angiography to obtain more-detailed images or if a subarachnoid hemorrhage is suspected but the cause isn't clear or doesn't appear on other imaging.
Treatment: If the bleeding is caused by a ruptured brain aneurysm, the doctor might recommend: Endovascular procedures sometimes need to be performed again. Certain aneurysms can be treated with endovascular embolization that uses newer technology such as stent-assisted or balloon-assisted coiling or devices that divert blood flow. Clinical manifestations and diagnosis of aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage. Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage: Epidemiology, risk factors, and pathogenesis. Predictors of excellent functional outcome in aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage. Refining the association of fever with functional outcome in aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage.
info-Symptoms: Severe headache of rapid onset, vomiting, decreased level of consciousness
info-Risk factors: High blood pressure, smoking, alcoholism, cocaine

Name: Subconjunctival hemorrhage ( broken blood vessel in eye )
Overview: A subconjunctival hemorrhage (sub-kun-JUNK-tih-vul HEM-uh-ruj) occurs when a tiny blood vessel breaks just underneath the clear surface of the eye (conjunctiva). One may not even realize one has a subconjunctival hemorrhage until one look in the mirror and notice the white part of the eye is bright red.

Name: Subdural hematoma
Causes: If one is an older adult, even mild head trauma can cause a hematoma. There are three categories of hematoma subdural hematoma, epidural hematoma and intracerebral (intraparenchymal) hematoma. The three types of subdural hematomas are: All three types require medical attention as soon as signs and symptoms appear so that permanent brain damage can be prevented. This type of hematoma, also known as intraparenchymal hematoma, occurs when blood pools in the tissues of the brain. This most dangerous type is generally caused by a severe head injury, and signs and symptoms usually appear immediately. The result of less severe head injuries, this type of hematoma can cause slow bleeding, and symptoms can take weeks and even months to appear. For example, bumping the head while getting into the car can cause bleeding, especially if one is on blood-thinning medication.

Name: Subfertility
Symptoms: Sometimes, a woman with infertility may have irregular or absent menstrual periods. In some cases, a man with infertility may have some signs of hormonal problems, such as changes in hair growth or sexual function. One probably don't need to see a doctor about infertility unless one has been trying regularly to get pregnant for at least one year.
Causes: Fertilization and implantation During fertilization, the sperm and egg unite in one of the fallopian tubes to form a zygote. The ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix and vagina (vaginal canal) make up the female reproductive system. Cigarette smoking, alcohol, marijuana, anabolic steroids, and taking medications to treat bacterial infections, high blood pressure and depression also can affect fertility. Frequent exposure to heat, such as in saunas or hot tubs, can raise body temperature and may affect sperm production. Hyperprolactinemia, a condition in which one has too much prolactin the hormone that stimulates breast milk production also may interfere with ovulation. Fallopian tube damage or blockage, often caused by inflammation of the fallopian tube (salpingitis). Endometriosis, which occurs when endometrial tissue grows outside of the uterus, may affect the function of the ovaries, uterus and fallopian tubes.
Risk factors: Women's fertility gradually declines with age, especially in the mid-30s, and it drops rapidly after age 37. Infertility in older women is likely due to the lower number and quality of eggs, and can also be due to health problems that affect fertility. For women, there's no safe level of alcohol use during conception or pregnancy. Among American women, an inactive lifestyle and being overweight may increase the risk of infertility. Women at risk of fertility problems include those with eating disorders, such as anorexia or bulimia, and those who follow a very low-calorie or restrictive diet. Less often, ovulation problems may be associated with frequent strenuous, intense exercise in women who are not overweight.
Diagnosis: Before infertility testing, the doctor or clinic works to understand the sexual habits and may make recommendations to improve the chances of getting pregnant. Hysterosalpingography, or HSG, is an X-ray test to outline the internal shape of the uterus and show whether the fallopian tubes are blocked. During hysteroscopy, the doctor uses a thin, lighted instrument (hysteroscope) to view the inside of the uterus. During hysterosonography (his-tur-o-suh-NOG-ruh-fee), the doctor uses a thin, flexible tube (catheter) to inject salt water (saline) into the hollow part of the uterus. Specific fertility tests may include Depending on the situation, rarely the testing may include Not everyone needs to have all, or even many, of these tests before the cause of infertility is found. In select cases, a testicular biopsy may be performed to identify abnormalities contributing to infertility or to retrieve sperm for assisted reproductive techniques, such as IVF. In certain situations, imaging studies such as a brain MRI, transrectal or scrotal ultrasound, or a test of the vas deferens (vasography) may be performed. In rare cases, other tests to evaluate the quality of the sperm may be performed, such as evaluating a semen specimen for DNA abnormalities. X-ray contrast is injected into the uterus, and an X-ray is taken to determine if the cavity is normal and to see if the fluid spills out of the fallopian tubes. During the procedure, the doctor inserts a thin, lighted device through the cervix into the uterus to view any potential abnormalities. This minimally invasive surgery involves making a small incision beneath the navel and inserting a thin viewing device to examine the fallopian tubes, ovaries and uterus. A laparoscopy may identify endometriosis, scarring, blockages or irregularities of the fallopian tubes, and problems with the ovaries and uterus.
info-Causes: Common in females: annouvulation, blocked fallopian tube, hormonal imbalance Common in males: low sperm count, abnormal sperm morphology

Name: Sudden cardiac arrest
Symptoms: If one see someone who's unconscious and not breathing normally, do the following: Perform CPR. If one has been trained in CPR, check the person's airway and deliver rescue breaths after every 30 compressions. Deliver one shock if advised by the device and then immediately resume CPR, starting with chest compressions, or give chest compressions only, for about two minutes.
Causes: If a heart attack occurs, often as a result of severe coronary artery disease, it can trigger ventricular fibrillation and sudden cardiac arrest. Then the heart's muscle is abnormal, a condition that often leads to arrhythmias. When sudden cardiac arrest occurs in children or adolescents, it can be due to a heart defect that was present at birth (congenital heart disease).
Diagnosis: Tests the doctor may recommend include During an ECG, sensors (electrodes) that can detect the electrical activity of the heart are attached to the chest and sometimes to the limbs. A sample of the blood might be tested to check the levels of potassium, magnesium, hormones and other chemicals that can affect the heart's ability to function. This test and others, including a nuclear scan, MRI, CT scan and cardiac catheterization, can all determine the heart's pumping capacity by measuring what's called the ejection fraction, one of the most important predictors of the risk of sudden cardiac arrest. During this procedure, a liquid dye is injected into the arteries of the heart through a long, thin tube (catheter) that's advanced through an artery, usually in the arm, to arteries in the heart. It can help identify whether an area of the heart has been damaged by a heart attack and isn't pumping hard enough or whether there are problems with the heart valves.This test and others, including a nuclear scan, MRI, CT scan and cardiac catheterization, can all determine the heart's pumping capacity by measuring what's called the ejection fraction, one of the most important predictors of the risk of sudden cardiac arrest. As the dye fills the arteries, the arteries become visible on X-ray and videotape, revealing areas of blockage.While the catheter is in position, the doctor may treat a blockage by opening the artery (angioplasty) and inserting a stent to hold the artery open.
Remedies: To live a heart-healthy lifestyle: If one already have heart disease or conditions that make one more vulnerable to heart disease, the doctor might recommend that one take steps to improve the health, such as taking medications for high cholesterol or managing diabetes. If one has a certain heart conditions that put one at risk of sudden cardiac arrest, the doctor might recommend anti-arrhythmic drugs. If one has a known risk of cardiac arrest, the doctor might recommend an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). If one live with someone who is at risk of sudden cardiac arrest, it's important that one be trained in CPR. The more people know how to respond to a cardiac emergency, the greater the survival rate for sudden cardiac arrest is likely to be. Cardiovascular collapse, cardiac arrest, and sudden cardiac death.
info-Symptoms: Loss of consciousness, abnormal or no breathing
info-Causes: Coronary artery disease, congenital heart defect, major blood loss, lack of oxygen, very low potassium, heart failure
info-Prevention: Not smoking, physical activity, maintaining a healthy weight, healthy eating
info-Prognosis: Overall survival rate ~ 10% (outside of hospital) 25% (in hospital); depends strongly on type and cause
info-Frequency: 13 per 10,000 people per year (outside hospital in the US)

Name: Sudden infant death syndrome ( SIDS )
Overview: Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is the unexplained death, usually during sleep, of a seemingly healthy baby less than a year old. Although the cause is unknown, it appears that SIDS might be associated with defects in the portion of an infant's brain that controls breathing and arousal from sleep.
Causes: In many of these babies, the portion of the brain that controls breathing and arousal from sleep hasn't matured enough to work properly. Many infants who died of SIDS had recently had a cold, which might contribute to breathing problems. Lying face down on a fluffy comforter, a soft mattress or a waterbed can block an infant's airway.
Risk factors: Although sudden infant death syndrome can strike any infant, researchers have identified several factors that might increase a baby's risk. They include During pregnancy, the mother also affects her baby's risk of SIDS, especially if she: Sex. For reasons that aren't well-understood, nonwhite infants are more likely to develop SIDS. Babies whove had siblings or cousins die of SIDS are at higher risk of SIDS. Both being born early and having a low birth weight increase the baby's chances of SIDS.

Name: Suicide and suicidal thoughts
Overview: Suicide, taking the own life, is a tragic reaction to stressful life situations and all the more tragic because suicide can be prevented. If one think one may attempt suicide, get help now: Call 911 or the local emergency number immediately.
Diagnosis: The doctor may do a physical exam, tests and in-depth questioning about the mental and physical health to help determine what may be causing the suicidal thinking and to determine the best treatment. Assessments may include Children who are feeling suicidal usually need to see a psychiatrist or psychologist experienced in diagnosing and treating children with mental health problems. If this is the case, one may need to see a doctor who specializes in diagnosing and treating mental illness (psychiatrist) or other mental health provider. In some cases, suicidal thinking may be linked to an underlying physical health problem. Many people who feel suicidal need treatment to help them stop using alcohol or drugs, to reduce their suicidal feelings.
Remedies: However, there are a few things that may reduce suicide risk: Avoid drugs and alcohol. Consider walking, jogging, swimming, gardening or taking up another form of physical activity that one enjoy.

Name: Sun allergy
Risk factors: Anyone can have a sun allergy, but certain sun allergies are more common in people with lighter skin. Common substances responsible for this type of reaction include fragrances, disinfectants and even some chemicals used in sunscreens. A number of medications can make the skin sunburn more quickly including tetracycline antibiotics, sulfa-based drugs and pain relievers, such as ketoprofen.
Remedies: Most sun allergy symptoms improve in less than a day or two if one keep the affected skin out of the sun. If one is taking medications for other conditions, talk with the doctor about whether one can stop taking them if they are making the skin more sensitive to the sun.
info-Prevention: Sun protection (SPF 50+) Cover up with densely woven clothing

Name: Sun poisoning
Overview: Polymorphic light eruption occurs most often in areas that are covered in the winter months and exposed in the summer months, such as the front of the neck and chest. Polymorphous light eruption, also known as polymorphic light eruption, is a rash caused by sun exposure in people who have developed sensitivity to sunlight. Polymorphous light eruption occurs most often during spring and early summer when a person's exposure to sunlight increases.
Causes: UV light that reaches the earth is divided into two wavelength bands ultraviolet A (UVA) and ultraviolet B (UVB). So exposure to sunlight through windows or even sunscreen-protected skin may cause a reaction in some people with photosensitivity. After the first episode of polymorphous light eruption, additional episodes are likely to recur each spring or early summer.
Diagnosis: Tests may include The doctor may need to rule out other disorders characterized by light-induced skin reactions. The doctor may refer one to a specialist in skin conditions (dermatologist) for phototesting. If the skin reacts to the UV radiation, one is considered sensitive to sunlight (photosensitive) and may have polymorphous light eruption or another light-induced disorder. When this occurs, the skin reacts each time it's exposed to sunlight after ingesting or coming into contact with a particular chemical. Solar urticaria is a sun-induced allergic reaction that produces hives raised, red, itchy welts that appear and disappear on the skin. One symptom is the appearance of a discolored, bumpy rash on areas of skin exposed to sunlight, such as the face, neck or upper chest.
Remedies: Self-care measures that may help ease the signs and symptoms include To lessen the likelihood of recurring episodes of polymorphous light eruption, take the following precautions: Use sunscreen. Fifteen to 30 minutes before going outdoors, apply a broad-spectrum sunscreen, one that provides protection from both UVA and UVB light. For protection from the sun, wear tightly woven clothing that covers the arms and legs and a broad-brimmed hat, which provides more protection than does a baseball cap or golf visor. Try an over-the-counter (nonprescription) anti-itch cream, which may include products containing at least 1 percent hydrocortisone. Avoid the sun between 10 a.m. and 2 p.m. Because the sun's rays are most intense during this time, try to schedule outdoor activities for other times of the day.

Name: Sunburn
Causes: Sunburns are caused by exposure to too much ultraviolet (UV) light. Ultraviolet A (UVA) is the type of solar radiation most associated with skin aging (photoaging). Eventually, UV light causes the skin to burn, bringing pain, redness and swelling. Snow, sand, water and other surfaces can reflect UV rays, burning the skin as severely as direct sunlight.
Remedies: Once sunburn occurs, one can't do much to limit damage to the skin. But the following tips may reduce the pain and discomfort: Avoid applying -caine products, such as benzocaine. If needed, an over-the-counter pain reliever such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve) may help control the pain and swelling of sunburn, especially if one take it soon after sun exposure. For severe sunburn, try an over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream, which may ease the discomfort. For severe sunburn, try an over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream, Protect the sunburn from further sun exposure.
info-Risk factors: Working outdoors, skin unprotected by clothes or sunscreen, skin type, age
info-Prevention: Use of sunscreen, sun protective clothing

Name: Sunken chest
Diagnosis: The doctor may suggest several different types of tests to check for associated problems with the heart and lungs. A CT scan may be used to help determine the severity of the pectus excavatum and whether the heart or lungs are being compressed. An electrocardiogram can show whether the heart's rhythm is normal or irregular, and if the electrical signals that control the heartbeat are timed properly. An echocardiogram also gives the doctor a look at how the chest wall may be affecting heart function and the flow of blood through the heart. This test monitors how well the heart and lungs function while one exercise, usually on a bike or treadmill.

Name: Suspicious breast lumps
Causes: If one find a breast lump that feels round, smooth and firm, it could be a cyst a dilated milk duct filled with fluid. A breast cyst can be large or small, and the surrounding breast tissue may be tender. With fibrocystic breast changes, one may feel fullness in the breasts with areas of lumpiness or ridgelike areas. Fibroadenomas are solid, noncancerous breast tumors that are smooth and move easily under the skin when touched. A breast lump that's painless, hard, irregularly shaped and different from surrounding breast tissue might be breast cancer.

Name: SVT
Causes: From the sinus node, electrical impulses travel across the atria, causing the atria muscles to contract and pump blood into the ventricles. Supraventricular tachycardia occurs when faulty electrical connections in the heart or abnormal areas of electrical activity trigger and sustain an abnormal rhythm. Unlike AVNRT and AVRT, which always involve the AV node as part of the faulty connection, atrial tachycardia doesn't involve the AV node.
Risk factors: Narrowed heart arteries, a heart attack, abnormal heart valves, prior heart surgery, heart failure, cardiomyopathy and other heart damage increase the risk of developing supraventricular tachycardia. This disorder, in which the breathing is interrupted during sleep, can increase the risk of supraventricular tachycardia. Nicotine and illegal drugs, such as amphetamines and cocaine, may profoundly affect the heart and trigger an episode of supraventricular tachycardia.
Diagnosis: The doctor may ask about or test for conditions that may trigger the SVT, such as heart disease or a problem with the thyroid gland. The doctor may also perform heart-monitoring tests specific to arrhythmia. These may include If the doctor doesn't find an arrhythmia during those tests, he or she may try to trigger the arrhythmia with other tests, which may include Electrophysiological testing and mapping. In this test, doctors thread thin tubes (catheters) tipped with electrodes through the blood vessels to a variety of spots within the heart. In addition, the cardiologist can use the electrodes to stimulate the heart to beat at rates that may trigger or halt an arrhythmia. During an ECG, sensors (electrodes) that can detect the electrical activity of the heart are attached to the chest and sometimes to the limbs. In this noninvasive test, a hand-held device (transducer) placed on the chest uses sound waves to produce images of the heart's size, structure and motion. During a stress test, one will be asked to exercise on a treadmill or stationary bicycle while the heart activity is monitored. If doctors are evaluating one to determine if coronary artery disease may be causing the arrhythmia, and one has difficulty exercising, then the doctor may use a drug to stimulate the heart in a way that's similar to exercise.
Remedies: The doctor may suggest that, in addition to other treatments, one make lifestyle changes that will keep the heart as healthy as possible. Eat a healthy diet that's low in salt and solid fats and rich in fruits, vegetables and whole grains. Make lifestyle changes and take medications as prescribed to correct high blood pressure (hypertension) or high cholesterol. For healthy adults, that means up to one drink a day for women of all ages and men older than age 65, and up to two drinks a day for men age 65 and younger.

Name: Sweating and body odor
Diagnosis: To diagnose a problem with sweating and body odor, the doctor will likely ask about the medical history and do an exam. The tests can show if the problem is caused by a medical condition, such as an infection, diabetes or an overactive thyroid (hyperthyroidism).
Treatment: If one is concerned about sweating and body odor, the solution may be simple: an over-the-counter antiperspirant and deodorant. If over-the-counter antiperspirants don't help control the sweating, the doctor may prescribe a prescription product. In some cases when one call to set up an appointment, one may be referred to a specialist in skin diseases (dermatologist). Antiperspirants contain aluminium-based compounds that temporarily block sweat pores, thereby reducing the amount of perspiration that reaches the skin. They're usually alcohol-based and turn the skin acidic, making it less attractive to bacteria.
Remedies: Regular bathing, especially with an antibacterial soap, reduces the growth of bacteria on the skin. For daily wear, choose natural fabrics, such as cotton, wool and silk. For exercise wear, one might prefer synthetic fabrics developed to wick moisture away from the skin.

Name: Sweating , abnormally excessive
Symptoms: The type of hyperhidrosis that usually affects the hands, feet, underarms or face causes at least one episode a week, during waking hours. Seek immediate medical attention if the heavy sweating is accompanied by lightheadedness, chest pain or nausea.
Overview: Hyperhidrosis (hi-pur-hi-DROE-sis) is abnormally excessive sweating that's not necessarily related to heat or exercise. In severe cases, the doctor may suggest surgery either to remove the sweat glands or to disconnect the nerves responsible for the overproduction of sweat.
Causes: Apocrine glands open into the hair follicle, leading to the surface of the skin. Sweating also normally occurs, especially on the palms, when one is nervous. Conditions that may lead to heavy sweating include Certain medications also can lead to heavy sweating, as can opioid withdrawal.
Remedies: Shoes made of natural materials, such as leather, can help prevent sweaty feet by allowing the feet to breathe. Change socks or hose once or twice a day, drying the feet thoroughly each time. Generally, wear natural fabrics, such as cotton, wool and silk, which allow the skin to breathe.
Medication: The doctor may prescribe an antiperspirant with aluminum chloride (Drysol, Xerac Ac). Treatment with botulinum toxin (Botox, Myobloc, others) temporarily blocks the nerves that cause sweating. If excessive sweating occurs just in the armpits, removing the sweat glands there may help. During this procedure, the surgeon cuts, burns or clamps the spinal nerves that control sweating in the hands. In some cases, this procedure triggers excessive sweating in other areas of the body (compensatory sweating).

Name: Sweet 's syndrome
Risk factors: Sweet's syndrome is uncommon, but certain factors increase the risk, including Sex. Though older adults and even infants can develop Sweet's syndrome, the condition mainly affects people between the ages of 30 and 60. Sweet's syndrome is sometimes associated with cancer, most often leukemia. Sometimes, Sweet's syndrome may be associated with a solid tumor, such as breast or colon cancer. Sweet's syndrome may follow an upper respiratory infection, and many people report having flu-like symptoms before the rash appears. Drugs linked to Sweet's syndrome include azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran), granulocyte colony stimulating factor, certain antibiotics and some nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
Treatment: The most common medications used for Sweet's syndrome are corticosteroids, which come in a variety of forms, including Sometimes other medications are prescribed for Sweet's syndrome, usually for people who don't tolerate long-term corticosteroid use well. Some of the more commonly prescribed medication alternatives to corticosteroids are: The primary care doctor is likely to refer one to a dermatologist for diagnosis and treatment of Sweet's syndrome. Unless one only have a few lesions, one will likely need to take oral corticosteroids.

Name: Swimmer 's ear
Overview: Swimmer's ear is an infection in the outer ear canal, which runs from the eardrum to the outside of the head. Putting fingers, cotton swabs or other objects in the ears also can lead to swimmer's ear by damaging the thin layer of skin lining the ear canal.
Diagnosis: The doctor's initial evaluation will usually include Depending on the initial assessment, symptom severity or the stage of the swimmer's ear, the doctor might recommend additional evaluation, including sending a sample of fluid from the ear to test for bacteria or fungus. If the infection doesn't respond to treatment, the doctor might take a sample of discharge or debris from the ear at a later appointment and send it to a lab to identify the microorganism causing the infection.
Medication: For most cases of swimmer's ear, the doctor will prescribe eardrops that have some combination of the following ingredients, depending on the type and seriousness of the infection: Ask the doctor about the best method for taking the eardrops. Some ideas that may help one use eardrops include the following: If the ear canal is completely blocked by swelling, inflammation or excess discharge, the doctor might insert a wick made of cotton or gauze to promote drainage and help draw medication into the ear canal. The doctor might recommend easing the discomfort of swimmer's ear with over-the-counter pain relievers, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). During treatment, do the following to help keep the ears dry and avoid further irritation: Acidic solution to help restore the ear's normal antibacterial environment Steroid to reduce inflammation Antibiotic to fight bacteria Antifungal medication to fight infection caused by a fungus Reduce the discomfort of cool drops by holding the bottle in the hand for a few minutes to bring the temperature of the drops closer to body temperature. Acidic solution Steroid Antibiotic Antifungal medication Reduce the discomfort of cool drops Lie on the side with the infected ear up If possible, have someone help one To put drops in a child's or adult's ear,

Name: Swimmer 's itch
Overview: Swimmer's itch is an allergic reaction to microscopic parasites that burrow into the skin while one is swimming or wading outdoors. Swimmer's itch is a rash usually caused by an allergic reaction to parasites that burrow into the skin while one is swimming or wading in warm water.
Causes: The parasites that cause swimmer's itch live in the blood of waterfowl and in mammals that live near ponds and lakes. Before infecting birds, other animals or people, the hatched parasites must live for a time within a type of snail. These snails live near the shoreline, which explains why infections occur most often in shallow water.
Treatment: In the meantime, one can control itching with over-the-counter antihistamines or anti-itch creams, such as those that contain calamine. If the itching is severe, the doctor may recommend a prescription medication. Make a paste of baking soda and water, and then apply it to the affected areas.

Name: Swine flu ( H1N1 flu )
Overview: Technically, the term swine flu refers to influenza in pigs. Because so many people around the world got sick that year, the World Health Organization declared the flu caused by H1N1 to be a global pandemic.
Diagnosis: To diagnose flu, including swine flu, the doctor will likely conduct a physical exam, look for signs and symptoms of influenza, and possibly order a test that detects influenza viruses. Doctors are more likely to use a test to diagnose flu if: The doctor may also use a test to determine whether a flu virus is the cause of the symptoms, or if one has or are showing signs of another problem besides the flu, such as: The most commonly used test is called a rapid influenza diagnostic test, which looks for substances (antigens) on a swab sample from the nose or back of the throat.
Treatment: If one has a chronic respiratory disease, the doctor may prescribe additional medications to help relieve the symptoms. To make development of resistance less likely and maintain supplies of these drugs for those who need them most, doctors reserve antivirals for people at high risk of complications and those who are in close contact with people who have high risk of complications. High-risk groups include people who: If one develop any type of flu, these measures may help ease the symptoms: Though aspirin is approved for use in children older than age 3, children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin. Remember, pain relievers may make one more comfortable, but they won't make the symptoms go away faster and they have side effects. Using aspirin during a viral illness increases the risk of developing Reye's syndrome, a rare but potentially fatal disease, in these individuals. Have certain chronic medical conditions, including asthma, emphysema, heart disease, diabetes, neuromuscular disease, or kidney, liver or blood disease. Use an over-the-counter pain reliever, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), cautiously. Also, use caution when giving aspirin to children or teenagers. Prevention and control of seasonal influenza with vaccines: Recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices United States, 2018-2019 influenza season. A mini review of the zoonotic threat potential of influenza viruses, coronaviruses, adenoviruses, and enteroviruses. Rochester, Minn.: Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research; 2018.
Remedies: If one develop any type of flu, these measures may help ease the symptoms: Though aspirin is approved for use in children older than age 3, children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin. Remember, pain relievers may make one more comfortable, but they won't make the symptoms go away faster and they have side effects. Use an over-the-counter pain reliever, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), cautiously. Key facts about human infections with variant viruses (swine origin influenza viruses in humans). Prevention and control of seasonal influenza with vaccines: Recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices United States, 2018-2019 influenza season. A mini review of the zoonotic threat potential of influenza viruses, coronaviruses, adenoviruses, and enteroviruses. Rochester, Minn.: Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research; 2018.

Name: Swollen lymph nodes
Diagnosis: To diagnose what might be causing the swollen lymph nodes, the doctor may need: The medical history. The doctor will also want to check lymph nodes near the surface of the skin for size, tenderness, warmth and texture. The specific tests will depend on the suspected cause, but most likely will include a complete blood count (CBC).
Treatment: When one call to set up the appointment, one may be urged to seek immediate medical care if one is experiencing severe symptoms such as difficulty breathing or swallowing. The most common treatment for swollen lymph nodes caused by a bacterial infection is antibiotics. If the swollen lymph nodes are due to an HIV infection, one will receive specific treatment for that condition. If the swollen lymph nodes are a result of certain conditions, such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, treatment is directed at the underlying condition. Depending on the type of cancer, treatment may involve surgery, radiation or chemotherapy. These include aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin, others), naproxen (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). Though aspirin is approved for use in children older than age 2, children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin.
Remedies: Apply a warm, wet compress, such as a washcloth dipped in hot water and wrung out, to the affected area. These include aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin, others), naproxen (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). Though aspirin is approved for use in children older than age 2, children and teenagers recovering from chickenpox or flu-like symptoms should never take aspirin.
info-Symptoms: fever; Hard, fixed, rapidly growing nodes, indicating a possible cancer or lymphoma; night sweats; Runny nose; sore throat
info-Causes: infections; autoimmune diseases; malignancies;histiocytoses; storage diseases; benign hyperplasia; drug reactions
info-Risk factors: back pain; constipation; urinary frequency

Name: Synostosis
Symptoms: Premature fusion of the sagittal suture that runs from the front to the back at the top of the skull forces the head to grow long and narrow. When both coronal sutures fuse prematurely (bicoronal), the head has a short and wide appearance, often with the forehead tilted forward.
Overview: Joints made of strong, fibrous tissue (cranial sutures) hold the bones of the baby's skull together. Craniosynostosis (kray-nee-o-sin-os-TOE-sis) is a birth defect in which one or more of the fibrous joints between the bones of the baby's skull (cranial sutures) close prematurely (fuse), before the baby's brain is fully formed. In the front of the skull, the sutures meet in the large soft spot (fontanel) on top of the head. Craniosynostosis usually involves premature fusion of a single cranial suture, but can involve more than one of the sutures in the baby's skull (multiple suture craniosynostosis).
Treatment: The doctor may recommend a specially molded helmet to help reshape the baby's head if the cranial sutures are open and the head shape is abnormal. In this situation, the molded helmet can assist the baby's brain growth and correct the shape of the skull. The purpose of surgery is to correct the abnormal head shape, reduce or prevent pressure on the brain, create room for the brain to grow normally, and improve the baby's appearance.

Name: Synovial sarcoma
Diagnosis: Because there are so many different types of soft tissue sarcoma, it's important to determine the exact nature of each tumor so that the best treatments can be chosen. To evaluate the area of concern, the doctor might employ: If a soft tissue sarcoma is suspected, it's often best to seek care at a medical center that sees many people with this type of cancer. Options include In the lab, a doctor trained in analyzing body tissues (pathologist) examines the tissue sample for signs of cancer.

Name: Syphilis
Symptoms: Primary syphilis causes painless sores (chancres) on the genitals, rectum, tongue or lips. The first sign of syphilis is a small sore, called a chancre (SHANG-kur). Many people who have syphilis don't notice the chancre because it's usually painless, and it may be hidden within the vagina or rectum. If one isn't treated for syphilis, the disease moves from the secondary stage to the hidden (latent) stage, when one has no symptoms. Signs and symptoms may never return, or the disease may progress to the third (tertiary) stage. Most newborns with congenital syphilis have no symptoms, although some experience a rash on the palms of their hands and the soles of their feet. However, babies born with syphilis can also be born too early, be born dead (stillborn) or die after birth. Vivien Williams: It may then progress to latent stage syphilis and, finally, the most serious stage: tertiary.
Overview: Syphilis is a bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact. After the initial infection, the syphilis bacteria can remain inactive (dormant) in the body for decades before becoming active again.
Causes: Syphilis can't be spread by using the same toilet, bathtub, clothing or eating utensils, or from doorknobs, swimming pools or hot tubs. However, one can become reinfected if one has contact with someone's syphilis sore.
Diagnosis: Syphilis can be diagnosed by testing samples of: Through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the local health department offers partner services, which will help one notify the sexual partners that they may be infected. If it's suspected that one has nervous system complications of syphilis, the doctor may also suggest collecting a sample of cerebrospinal fluid through a procedure called a lumbar puncture (spinal tap).
info-Symptoms: Firm, painless, non-itchy skin ulcer
info-Causes: Treponema pallidum usually spread by sex
info-Diagnostic method: Blood tests, dark field microscopy of infected fluid

Name: Systemic capillary leak syndrome
Overview: Systemic capillary leak syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by repeated flares of massive leakage of plasma from blood vessels into neighboring body cavities and muscles. Also called Clarkson's disease, this condition can be mistaken for severe reactions to widespread infections (septic shock) or severe allergic reactions (anaphylactic shock).
Treatment: The cause of systemic capillary leak syndrome is unknown, and there's no known cure. Preventive treatment with certain oral medications originally designed to treat asthma also can be helpful, but these drugs may produce troublesome side effects, such as tremors. Idiopathic systemic capillary leak syndrome (Clarkson disease).
info-Symptoms: hemoconcentration, hypotension, hypoalbuminemia, edema, compartment syndromes

Name: Systemic lupus erythematosus
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms may come on suddenly or develop slowly, may be mild or severe, and may be temporary or permanent. The most common signs and symptoms include See the doctor if one develop an unexplained rash, ongoing fever, persistent aching or fatigue.
Overview: Lupus is a systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when the body's immune system attacks the own tissues and organs. Inflammation caused by lupus can affect many different body systems including the joints, skin, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart and lungs.
Causes: It appears that people with an inherited predisposition for lupus may develop the disease when they come into contact with something in the environment that can trigger lupus. Exposure to the sun may bring on lupus skin lesions or trigger an internal response in susceptible people. Lupus can be triggered by certain types of blood pressure medications, anti-seizure medications and antibiotics.
Diagnosis: The combination of blood and urine tests, signs and symptoms, and physical examination findings leads to the diagnosis. Blood and urine tests may include If the doctor suspects that lupus is affecting the lungs or heart, he or she may suggest: Lupus can harm the kidneys in many different ways, and treatments can vary, depending on the type of damage that occurs. This test measures the number of red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets as well as the amount of hemoglobin, a protein in red blood cells. An examination of a sample of the urine may show an increased protein level or red blood cells in the urine, which may occur if lupus has affected the kidneys. Antinuclear antibody (ANA) test Complete blood count (CBC) Echocardiogram Liver function tests Sed rate (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) Urinalysis X-ray Complete blood count.
Treatment: As the signs and symptoms flare and subside, one and the doctor may find that one will need to change medications or dosages. Simple measures can help one prevent lupus flares and, should they occur, better cope with the signs and symptoms one experience. However, there aren't any alternative therapies that have been shown to alter the course of lupus, although some may help ease symptoms of the disease. Complementary and alternative treatments for lupus include If one has lupus, one is likely to have a range of painful feelings about the condition, from fear to extreme frustration. The challenges of living with lupus increase the risk of depression and related mental health problems, such as anxiety, stress and low self-esteem. Lupus can be frustrating for the loved ones because they usually can't see it, and one may not appear sick. One is likely to start by seeing the primary care doctor, but he or she may refer one to a specialist in the diagnosis and treatment of inflammatory joint conditions and immune disorders (rheumatologist). Because the symptoms of lupus can mimic so many other health problems, one may need patience while waiting for a diagnosis. One may need to see a number of specialists such as doctors who treat kidney problems (nephrologists), blood disorders (hematologists) or nervous system disorders (neurologists) depending on the symptoms to help with diagnosis and treatment. Over-the-counter NSAIDs, such as naproxen sodium (Aleve) and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), may be used to treat pain, swelling and fever associated with lupus. Side effects of NSAIDs include stomach bleeding, kidney problems and an increased risk of heart problems. Medications commonly used to treat malaria, such as hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil), affect the immune system and can help decrease the risk of lupus flares. High doses of steroids such as methylprednisolone (A-Methapred, Medrol) are often used to control serious disease that involves the kidneys and brain. Side effects include weight gain, easy bruising, thinning bones (osteoporosis), high blood pressure, diabetes and increased risk of infection. Potential side effects may include an increased risk of infection, liver damage, decreased fertility and an increased risk of cancer. A different type of medication, belimumab (Benlysta) administered intravenously, also reduces lupus symptoms in some people. Having regular checkups instead of only seeing the doctor when the symptoms worsen may help the doctor prevent flare-ups, and can be useful in addressing routine health concerns, such as stress, diet and exercise that can be helpful in preventing lupus complications. Because ultraviolet light can trigger a flare, wear protective clothing such as a hat, long-sleeved shirt and long pants and use sunscreens with a sun protection factor (SPF) of at least 55 every time one go outside. There is some evidence to suggest that people with lupus may benefit from supplemental vitamin D. A 1,200- to 1,500-milligram calcium supplement taken daily may help keep the bones healthy.
Remedies: Having regular checkups instead of only seeing the doctor when the symptoms worsen may help the doctor prevent flare-ups, and can be useful in addressing routine health concerns, such as stress, diet and exercise that can be helpful in preventing lupus complications. Because ultraviolet light can trigger a flare, wear protective clothing such as a hat, long-sleeved shirt and long pants and use sunscreens with a sun protection factor (SPF) of at least 55 every time one go outside. There is some evidence to suggest that people with lupus may benefit from supplemental vitamin D. A 1,200- to 1,500-milligram calcium supplement taken daily may help keep the bones healthy.
info-Symptoms: Painful and swollen joints, fever, chest pain, hair loss, mouth ulcers, swollen lymph nodes, feeling tired, red rash
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and blood tests

Name: Systemic mastocytosis
Overview: Systemic mastocytosis (mas-to-sy-TOE-sis) is a disorder that results in an excessive number of mast cells in the body. But if one has systemic mastocytosis, excess mast cells generally build up in the skin, bone marrow, gastrointestinal tract and bones.
Treatment: Treatment for systemic mastocytosis may include medications like antihistamines, aspirin, and drugs that work against the substances released by mast cells in the body. Aggressive forms of systemic mastocytosis may need powerful chemotherapy drugs to destroy mast cells. Systemic mastocytosis in adults: 2017 update on diagnosis, risk stratification and management. Mastocytosis (cutaneous and systemic): Epidemiology, pathogenesis, and clinical manifestations. Rochester, Minn.: Mayo Foundation for Medical Education and Research; 2016. Systemic mastocytosis: Evolving lessons from large patient registry datasets.
info-Specialty: Clinical Immunology and Allergy, Oncology, hematology

Name: Systemic sclerosis
Symptoms: Scleroderma's signs and symptoms vary, depending on which parts of the body are affected: Skin. Skin can appear shiny because it's so tight, and movement of the affected area may be restricted. Scleroderma can cause a variety of digestive symptoms, depending on which part of the digestive tract is affected.
Overview: Scleroderma (sklair-oh-DUR-muh) is a group of rare diseases that involve the hardening and tightening of the skin and connective tissues. But in many people, scleroderma also harms structures beyond the skin, such as blood vessels, internal organs and the digestive tract (systemic scleroderma).
Risk factors: Research suggests that, in some people, scleroderma symptoms may be triggered by exposure to certain viruses, medications or drugs. In 15 to 20 percent of cases, a person who has scleroderma also has symptoms of another autoimmune disease, such as rheumatoid arthritis, lupus or Sjogren's syndrome.
Medication: For example, the doctor may recommend medications to: Physical or occupational therapists can help one: Used as a last resort, surgical options for scleroderma complications may include Treat or slow skin changes. Steroid creams or pills may help reduce swelling and joint pain, loosen stiff skin, and slow the development of new skin changes. Blood pressure medications that dilate blood vessels may help prevent lung and kidney problems and may help treat Raynaud's disease. Drugs that suppress the immune system, such as those taken after organ transplants, may help reduce scleroderma symptoms. Antibiotics and medications that help move food through the intestines may help reduce bloating, diarrhea and constipation. Antibiotic ointment, cleaning and protection from the cold may help prevent infection of fingertip ulcers caused by Raynaud's disease. If finger sores caused by severe Raynaud's disease have progressed to the point that the fingertip tissue begins to die, amputation may be necessary.

Name: Tachycardia
Overview: In tachycardia, an abnormal electrical impulse starting in the upper or lower chambers of the heart causes the heart to beat faster. But in tachycardia (tak-ih-KAHR-dee-uh), the heart beats faster than normal due to conditions unrelated to normal physiological stress.
