But if left untreated, tachycardia can disrupt normal heart function and lead to serious complications, including Treatments, such as drugs, medical procedures or surgery, may help control a rapid heartbeat or manage other conditions contributing to tachycardia. Atrial fibrillation is a rapid heart rate caused by chaotic, irregular electrical impulses in the upper chambers of the heart (atria). Ventricular tachycardia is a rapid heart rate that starts with abnormal electrical signals in the lower chambers of the heart (ventricles). Ventricular fibrillation occurs when rapid, chaotic electrical impulses cause the lower heart chambers (ventricles) to quiver instead of pumping necessary blood to the body. Supraventricular tachycardia is an abnormally fast heartbeat that starts somewhere above the lower chambers of the heart (ventricles).
Diagnosis: Electrodes are placed on the chest to record the heart's electrical signals, which cause the heart to beat. It's a painless test that detects and records the heart's electrical activity using small sensors (electrodes) attached to the chest and arms. The doctor can print an electrocardiogram strip using the data on the recording device to see the heart's rhythm during the period one wore the monitor. It records the heart's activity for an entire 24-hour period, which provides the doctor with a prolonged look at the heart rhythms. During this test, a doctor inserts thin, flexible tubes (catheters) tipped with electrodes into the groin, arm or neck and guides them through the blood vessels to various spots in the heart. Cardiac imaging tests used to diagnose tachycardia include The doctor may recommend a stress test to see how the heart functions while it is working hard during exercise or when medication is given to make it beat fast. In an exercise stress test, electrodes are placed on the chest to monitor heart function while one exercise, usually by walking on a treadmill. The doctor may order additional tests as needed to diagnose an underlying condition that is contributing to tachycardia and judge the condition of the heart. To study the flow of blood through the heart and blood vessels, the doctor may use a coronary angiogram to reveal potential blockages or abnormalities.

Name: Takayasu 's arteritis
Overview: Takayasu's arteritis is a form of vasculitis inflammation of the blood vessels that damages the large arteries, especially the aorta. Takayasu's arteritis (tah-kah-YAH-sooz ahr-tuh-RIE-tis) is a rare type of vasculitis, a group of disorders that cause blood vessel inflammation. In Takayasu's arteritis, the inflammation damages the aorta the large artery that carries blood from the heart to the rest of the body and its main branches.
Causes: With Takayasu's arteritis, the aorta and other major arteries, including those leading to the head and kidneys, become inflamed. Over time the inflammation causes changes in these arteries, including thickening, narrowing and scarring.
Diagnosis: The resulting images allow the doctor to see if blood is flowing normally or if it's being slowed or interrupted due to narrowing (stenosis) of a blood vessel. During this test, a contrast dye is injected into a vein or artery to help the doctor better see and examine the blood vessels. This is another noninvasive form of angiography combining computerized analysis of X-ray images with the use of intravenous contrast dye to allow the doctor to check the structure of the aorta and its nearby branches and to monitor blood flow. Before the scan, a radioactive drug is injected into a vein or an artery to make it easier for the doctor to see areas of decreased blood flow. C-reactive protein test MRI Positron emission tomography scan Sed rate (erythrocyte sedimentation rate) Ultrasound X-ray Blood tests.
Medication: After a few months, the doctor may gradually begin to lower the dose until one reach the lowest dose one need to control inflammation. Possible side effects of corticosteroids include weight gain, increased risk of infections, bone thinning (osteoporosis) and menstrual irregularities. To help prevent bone loss, the doctor may recommend a calcium supplement and vitamin D. If the arteries become severely narrowed or blocked, one may need surgery to open or bypass these arteries and allow an uninterrupted flow of blood. To help prevent bone loss, the doctor may recommend a calcium supplement and vitamin D. Other drugs that suppress the immune system. If the condition doesn't respond well to corticosteroids or one has trouble as the medication dose is lowered, the doctor may prescribe immunosuppressant drugs. If one don't respond to standard treatments, the doctor may suggest drugs that correct abnormalities in the immune system (biologics).

Name: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
Causes: Drugs that may contribute to broken heart syndrome include Heart attacks are generally caused by a complete or near complete blockage of a heart artery. In broken heart syndrome, the heart arteries are not blocked, although blood flow in the arteries of the heart may be reduced.
Risk factors: There are a number of known risk factors for broken heart syndrome, including Sex. People who have neurological disorders, such as a head injury or a seizure disorder (epilepsy) have a greater risk of broken heart syndrome. If one has had disorders, such as anxiety or depression, one probably have a higher risk of broken heart syndrome.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects one has broken heart syndrome, he or she will use these exams and tests to make a diagnosis: Coronary angiogram. Because broken heart syndrome often mimics the signs and symptoms of a heart attack, a coronary angiogram is often done to rule out a heart attack. People with broken heart syndrome often don't have any blockages in the blood vessels, while people whove had a heart attack usually have a blockage that is visible on an angiogram. Once it's clear that one is not having a heart attack, the doctor will check to see if the signs and symptoms were caused by broken heart syndrome. In addition to a standard physical exam, the doctor will want to know about the medical history, especially whether one has ever had heart disease symptoms. The doctor may also order an echocardiogram to see if the heart is enlarged or has an abnormal shape, a sign of broken heart syndrome.
Treatment: Once it's clear that broken heart syndrome is the cause of the symptoms, the doctor will likely prescribe heart medications for one to take while one is in the hospital, such as angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor blockers, beta blockers or diuretics. Procedures that are often used to treat a heart attack, such as balloon angioplasty and stent placement, or even surgery, aren't helpful in treating broken heart syndrome. Broken heart syndrome is usually diagnosed in an emergency or hospital setting, since most people with the condition have symptoms identical to a heart attack.

Name: Tapeworm infection
Overview: Tapeworm infection is caused by ingesting food or water contaminated with tapeworm eggs or larvae. If one ingest certain tapeworm eggs, they can migrate outside the intestines and form larval cysts in body tissues and organs (invasive infection). If one ingest tapeworm larvae, however, they develop into adult tapeworms in the intestines (intestinal infection).
Causes: If one eat food or drink water contaminated with feces from a person or animal with tapeworm, one ingest microscopic tapeworm eggs. If one eat raw or undercooked meat from an infected animal, one ingest the larvae, which then develop into adult tapeworms in the intestines. One can then be infected when one eat or drink something from the contaminated source.Once inside the intestines, the eggs develop into larvae.
Risk factors: Factors that may put one at greater risk of tapeworm infection include Poor hygiene. Improper cooking may fail to kill tapeworm eggs and larvae contained in contaminated pork or beef. For instance, the risk of coming into contact with eggs of the pork tapeworm (Taenia solium) is greater in areas of Latin America, China, sub-Saharan Africa or Southeast Asia where free-range pigs may be more common.
Diagnosis: For an intestinal tapeworm infection, the doctor may check the stool or send samples to a laboratory for testing. Because the eggs and segments are passed irregularly, the lab may need to collect two to three samples over a period of time to detect the parasite. A laboratory uses microscopic identification techniques to check for eggs or tapeworm segments in the feces.Because the eggs and segments are passed irregularly, the lab may need to collect two to three samples over a period of time to detect the parasite.

Name: Tay-Sachs disease
Overview: Tay-Sachs disease is a rare disorder passed from parents to child. These fatty substances, called gangliosides, build up to toxic levels in the child's brain and affect the function of the nerve cells. If one has a family history of Tay-Sachs disease or if one is a member of a high-risk group and plan to have children, doctors strongly recommend genetic testing and genetic counseling.
Diagnosis: To confirm that the baby has Tay-Sachs disease, the doctor will ask one about the child's symptoms and any hereditary family disorders and will order a diagnostic blood test. While performing a careful eye exam of the child, the doctor may see a cherry-red spot in the back of the child's eyes, which is a sign of the disease.
Treatment: The child may need the mucus using chest physiotherapy (CPT) to help remove mucus from the lungs. The child may have trouble swallowing, or develop respiratory problems by inhaling food or liquid into the lungs while eating. To prevent those problems, the doctor may recommend an assistive feeding device such as a gastrostomy tube, which is inserted through the child's nose and goes to the child's stomach. As the disease progresses, the child may benefit from physical therapy to help keep joints flexible and maintain as much ability to move (range of motion) as possible.
info-Symptoms: Initially: Decreased ability to turn over, sit, or crawlLater: Seizures, hearing loss, inability to move
info-Usual onset: Three to six months of age
info-Diagnostic method: Testing blood hexosaminidase A levels, genetic testing
info-Prognosis: Death often occurs in early childhood

Name: Tears , decreased production
Overview: Dry eyes is a common condition that occurs when the tears aren't able to provide adequate lubrication for the eyes. For example, dry eyes may occur if one don't produce enough tears or if one produce poor-quality tears. One may experience dry eyes in certain situations, such as on an airplane, in an air-conditioned room, while riding a bike or after looking at a computer screen for a few hours.
Risk factors: A lack of tears is more common in women, especially if they experience hormonal changes due to pregnancy, using birth control pills or menopause. Eating a diet that is low in vitamin A, which is found in liver, carrots and broccoli, or low in omega-3 fatty acids, which are found in fish, walnuts and vegetable oils Wearing contact lenses
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures that may be used to determine the cause of the dry eyes include A comprehensive eye exam. An eye exam that includes a complete history of the overall health and the eye health can help the doctor diagnose the cause of the dry eyes.
Remedies: One may be able to manage the dry eyes with frequent eyelid washing and use of over-the-counter (OTC) eyedrops or other products that help lubricate the eyes. If the condition is long term (chronic), use eyedrops even when the eyes feel fine to keep them well-lubricated. A variety of nonprescription products for dry eyes are available, including eyedrops (artificial tears), gels, gel inserts and ointments. If one rely on eyedrops more than four times a day, nonpreservative drops are safe. It's best to avoid these as the solution for dry eyes, as prolonged use can cause irritation. Artificial tears: How to select eyedrops for dry eyes Preservative vs. nonpreservative drops.
Medication: Prescription medications used to treat dry eyes include Other procedures that may be used to treat dry eyes include Closing the tear ducts to reduce tear loss. Some people with severe dry eyes may opt for special contact lenses that protect the surface of the eyes and trap moisture. Antibiotics for dry eyes are usually taken by mouth, though some are used as eyedrops or ointments. Inflammation on the surface of the eyes (cornea) may be controlled with prescription eyedrops that contain the immune-suppressing medication cyclosporine (Restasis) or corticosteroids. If one has moderate to severe dry eye symptoms and artificial tears don't help, another option may be a tiny eye insert that looks like a clear grain of rice. A technique called intense-pulsed light therapy followed by massage of the eyelids has proven to help people with severe dry eyes.

Name: Teen depression
Symptoms: Depression symptoms can vary in severity, but changes in the teen's emotions and behavior may include the examples below. Depressed teenagers may be at risk of suicide, even if signs and symptoms don't appear to be severe. If one is a teen and one think one may be depressed or one has a friend who may be depressed don't wait to get help. Share the concerns with a parent, a close friend, a spiritual leader, a teacher or someone else one trust. If one think one may hurt theself or attempt suicide, call 911 or the local emergency number immediately.
Causes: It's not known exactly what causes depression, but a variety of issues may be involved. When these chemicals are abnormal or impaired, the function of nerve receptors and nerve systems changes, leading to depression. Changes in the body's balance of hormones may be involved in causing or triggering depression. Teen depression may be linked to learning to feel helpless rather than learning to feel capable of finding solutions for life's challenges.
Diagnosis: To clarify the type of depression the teen has, the doctor may use one or more specifiers, which means depression with specific features. The doctor or mental health professional's evaluation will help determine if the symptoms of depression are caused by one of these conditions: Physical exam. The doctor may do a physical exam and ask in-depth questions about the teenager's health to determine what may be causing depression. For example, the teen's doctor may do a blood test called a complete blood count or test the teen's thyroid to make sure it's functioning properly. Anxious distress depression with unusual restlessness or worry about possible events or loss of control Melancholic features severe depression with lack of response to something that used to bring pleasure and associated with early morning awakening, worsened mood in the morning, major changes in appetite, and feelings of guilt, agitation or sluggishness Atypical features depression that includes the ability to be temporarily cheered by happy events, increased appetite, excessive need for sleep, sensitivity to rejection, and a heavy feeling in arms or legs Bipolar I and II disorders. This includes depression that's caused by the use of recreational or illegal drugs, certain prescribed medications, or a medical condition.
Remedies: In addition to professional treatment, here are some steps one and the teen can take that may help: Stick to the treatment plan. If the teen stops taking medications, depression symptoms may come back. The teen may feel as if alcohol, marijuana or other drugs lessen depression symptoms, but in the long run they worsen symptoms and make depression harder to treat. This can include removing or securing guns, and removing sharp items, alcohol or risky medications in the home if one live with a teen who has depression.
Medication: In some cases, children, teens and young adults under 25 may have an increase in suicidal thoughts or behavior when taking antidepressants, especially in the first few weeks after starting or when the dose is changed. Because overdose can be a risk for teens with depression, the doctor may prescribe only small supplies of pills at a time, or recommend that one dole out medication so that the teen does not have a large amount of pills available at once. If the teen becomes pregnant or plans to become pregnant, make certain the teen talks to the doctor about antidepressant medications and managing depression during pregnancy.

Name: Teeth grinding
Overview: Bruxism (BRUK-siz-um) is a condition in which one grind, gnash or clench the teeth. If one has bruxism, one may unconsciously clench the teeth when one is awake (awake bruxism) or clench or grind them during sleep (sleep bruxism).
Risk factors: Having a personality type that's aggressive, competitive or hyperactive can increase the risk of bruxism. Bruxism may be an uncommon side effect of some psychiatric medications, such as certain antidepressants. Smoking tobacco, drinking caffeinated beverages or alcohol, or using recreational drugs may increase the risk of bruxism. If one has bruxism, other members of the family also may have bruxism or a history of it. Bruxism can be associated with some mental health and medical disorders, such as Parkinson's disease, dementia, gastroesophageal reflux disorder (GERD), epilepsy, night terrors, sleep-related disorders such as sleep apnea, and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
Remedies: Listening to music, taking a warm bath or exercising can help one relax and may reduce the risk of developing bruxism. Don't drink caffeinated coffee or caffeinated tea after dinner and avoid alcohol during the evening, as they may worsen bruxism. Getting a good night's sleep, which may include treatment for sleep problems, may help reduce bruxism.
Medication: Examples of medications that may be used for bruxism include Treatment for associated disorders may include Muscle relaxants. Injections of Botox, a form of botulinum toxin, may help some people with severe bruxism who don't respond to other treatments. The doctor may recommend short-term use of antidepressants or anti-anxiety medications to help one deal with stress or other emotional issues that may be causing the bruxism. If one develop bruxism as a side effect of a drug, the doctor may change the medication or prescribe a different one. If an underlying medical condition, such as gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), is identified as the cause, treating this condition may improve bruxism.

Name: Temporal arteritis
Overview: Giant cell arteritis is an inflammation of the lining of the arteries. Giant cell arteritis frequently causes headaches, scalp tenderness, jaw pain and vision problems. Prompt treatment with corticosteroid medications usually relieves symptoms of giant cell arteritis and might prevent loss of vision.
Causes: This swelling narrows the blood vessels, reducing the amount of blood and, therefore, oxygen and vital nutrients that reaches the body's tissues. What causes these arteries to become inflamed isn't known, but it's thought to involve abnormal attacks on artery walls by the immune system.
Risk factors: Several factors can increase the risk of developing giant cell arteritis, including Age. Giant cell arteritis affects adults only, and rarely those under 50. Giant cell arteritis is most common among white people in Northern European populations or of Scandinavian descent. Having polymyalgia rheumatica puts one at increased risk of developing giant cell arteritis.
Diagnosis: Tests might include The best way to confirm a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis is by taking a small sample (biopsy) of the temporal artery. If one has giant cell arteritis, the artery will often show inflammation that includes abnormally large cells, called giant cells, which give the disease its name. If the results aren't clear, the doctor might advise another temporal artery biopsy on the other side of the head. Commonly referred to as the sed rate, this test measures how quickly red blood cells fall to the bottom of a tube of blood. If the doctor suspects one might have giant cell arteritis in large arteries, such as the aorta, he or she might recommend PET.
Treatment: Because immediate treatment is necessary to prevent vision loss, the doctor is likely to start medication even before confirming the diagnosis with a biopsy. If one has visual loss before starting treatment with corticosteroids, it's unlikely that the vision will improve. After the first month, the doctor might gradually begin to lower the dosage until one reach the lowest dose of corticosteroids needed to control inflammation. To counter potential side effects, the doctor is likely to monitor the bone density and might prescribe calcium and vitamin D supplements or other medications to help prevent bone loss. The symptoms will likely improve quickly after beginning corticosteroid treatment, and the vision isn't likely to be affected. Eating well can help prevent potential problems, such as thinning bones, high blood pressure and diabetes. Be sure to get enough calcium and vitamin D. Experts recommend 1,200 milligrams (mg) of calcium and 800 international units (IU) of vitamin D a day for women over 50 and men over 70. Regular aerobic exercise, such as walking, can help prevent bone loss, high blood pressure and diabetes. He or she may refer one to an eye specialist (ophthalmologist) if one is having visual symptoms, a brain and nervous system specialist (neurologist) if one is having headaches, or a specialist in diseases of the joints, bones and muscles (rheumatologist).
Remedies: Eating well can help prevent potential problems, such as thinning bones, high blood pressure and diabetes. Be sure to get enough calcium and vitamin D. Experts recommend 1,200 milligrams (mg) of calcium and 800 international units (IU) of vitamin D a day for women over 50 and men over 70. Regular aerobic exercise, such as walking, can help prevent bone loss, high blood pressure and diabetes.
info-Symptoms: Headache, pain over the temples, flu-like symptoms, double vision, difficulty opening the mouth
info-Causes: Inflammation of the small blood vessels within the walls of larger arteries
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and blood tests, confirmed by biopsy of the temporal artery
info-Frequency: ~ 1 in 15,000 people a year (> 50 years old)

Name: Temporal lobe seizure
Symptoms: An unusual sensation (aura) may precede a temporal lobe seizure, acting as a warning. Not everyone who has temporal lobe seizures has auras, and not everyone who has auras remembers them. Examples of auras include Sometimes temporal lobe seizures impair the ability to respond to others. This type of temporal lobe seizure usually lasts 30 seconds to two minutes. Seek immediate medical help if any of the following occurs: If one experience a seizure for the first time, seek medical advice.
Overview: Temporal lobe seizures begin in the temporal lobes of the brain, which process emotions and are important for short-term memory. Temporal lobe seizures may stem from an anatomical defect or scar in the temporal lobe, but the cause is often unknown.
Diagnosis: EEG results show changes in brain activity that may be useful in diagnosing brain conditions, especially epilepsy and other seizure disorders. The EEG may reveal a pattern that tells doctors whether a seizure is likely to occur again, or help rule out other conditions that mimic epilepsy. A SPECT test uses a small amount of low-dose radioactive material that's injected into a vein to create a detailed, 3-D map of the blood flow activity in the brain that happens during a seizure. Doctors may also conduct a form of a SPECT test called subtraction ictal SPECT coregistered to magnetic resonance imaging (SISCOM), which may provide even more-detailed results.
Remedies: Here are some steps one can take to help with seizure control: Seizures don't usually result in serious injury, but if one has recurrent seizures, injury is a possibility. These steps can help one avoid injury during a seizure: It's helpful to know what to do if one witness someone having a seizure. If one is at risk of having seizures in the future, pass this information along to family, friends and co-workers so that they know what to do if one has a seizure. To help someone during a seizure: Take medication correctly. Carefully roll the person onto one side Place something soft under his or her head Loosen tight neckwear Avoid putting the fingers or other objects in the person's mouth Don't try to restrain someone having a seizure Clear away dangerous objects, if the person is moving Stay with the person until medical personnel arrive Observe the person closely so that one can provide details on what happened Time the seizure Stay calm Take medication correctly.

Name: Tendinitis
Overview: Tendons are thick fibrous cords that attach muscles to bone. While tendinitis can occur in any of the tendons, it's most common around the shoulders, elbows, wrists, knees and heels. Some common names for various tendinitis problems are: Most cases of tendinitis can be successfully treated with rest, physical therapy and medications to reduce pain.
Remedies: is the acronym to remember rest, ice, compression and elevation. Although rest is a key part of treating tendinitis, prolonged inactivity can cause stiffness in the joints. After a few days of completely resting the injured area, gently move it through its full range of motion to maintain joint flexibility. One can also try over-the-counter medications such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) or acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) in an attempt to reduce the discomfort associated with tendinitis. To decrease pain, muscle spasm and swelling, apply ice to the injured area for up to 20 minutes several times a day. Ice packs, ice massage or slush baths with ice and water all can help. For an ice massage, freeze a plastic foam cup full of water so that one can hold the cup while applying the ice directly to the skin. Because swelling can result in loss of motion in an injured joint, compress the area until the swelling has ceased. If tendinitis affects the knee, raise the affected leg above the level of the heart to reduce swelling.
Medication: For tendinitis, the doctor may recommend these medications: One might benefit from a program of specific exercise designed to stretch and strengthen the affected muscle-tendon unit. For instance, eccentric strengthening which emphasizes contraction of a muscle while it's lengthening has been shown to be a very effective treatment for many chronic tendon conditions, and is now considered first line treatment. Taking aspirin, naproxen sodium (Aleve) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) may relieve discomfort associated with tendinitis. Corticosteroids are not recommended for tendinitis lasting over three months (chronic tendinitis), as repeated injections may weaken a tendon and increase the risk of rupturing the tendon. Though research is still underway to determine optimal uses, concentrations and techniques, PRP injection in the region of chronic tendon irritation has shown promise in the treatment of many chronic tendon conditions.
info-Symptoms: Pain, swelling
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, examination, medical imaging

Name: Tendinitis , Achilles
Risk factors: A number of factors may increase the risk of Achilles tendinitis, including The sex. Running in worn-out shoes can increase the risk of Achilles tendinitis. Tendon pain occurs more frequently in cold weather than in warm weather, and running on hilly terrain also can predispose one to Achilles injury. People who have psoriasis or high blood pressure are at higher risk of developing Achilles tendinitis. Certain types of antibiotics, called fluoroquinolones, have been associated with higher rates of Achilles tendinitis.
Diagnosis: While X-rays can't visualize soft tissues such as tendons, they may help rule out other conditions that can cause similar symptoms. Ultrasound can also produce real-time images of the Achilles tendon in motion, and color-Doppler ultrasound can evaluate blood flow around the tendon. Using radio waves and a very strong magnet, MRI machines can produce very detailed images of the Achilles tendon.
Remedies: One may need to avoid exercise for several days or switch to an activity that doesn't strain the Achilles tendon, such as swimming. To decrease pain or swelling, apply an ice pack to the tendon for about 15 minutes after exercising or when one experience pain. Wraps or compressive elastic bandages can help reduce swelling and reduce movement of the tendon.
Medication: If over-the-counter pain medications such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen (Aleve) aren't enough, the doctor might prescribe stronger medications to reduce inflammation and relieve pain. If several months of more-conservative treatments don't work or if the tendon has torn, the doctor may suggest surgery to repair the Achilles tendon.

Name: Tendinitis , patellar
Symptoms: Patellar tendinitis causes pain in the patellar tendon, which runs from the kneecap (patella) to the shinbone (tibia). Pain is the first symptom of patellar tendinitis, usually between the kneecap and where the tendon attaches to the shinbone (tibia).
Risk factors: Sudden increases in how hard or how often one engage in the activity also add stress to the tendon, as can changing the running shoes. Tight thigh muscles (quadriceps) and hamstrings, which run up the back of the thighs, can increase strain on the patellar tendon. If some muscles in the legs are much stronger than others, the stronger muscles could pull harder on the patellar tendon.
Diagnosis: This test uses sound waves to create an image of the knee, revealing tears in the patellar tendon. MRI uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create detailed images that can reveal subtle changes in the patellar tendon.
Medication: Pain relievers such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve, others) may provide short-term relief from pain associated with patellar tendinitis. A variety of physical therapy techniques can help reduce the symptoms associated with patellar tendinitis, including If conservative treatments don't help, the doctor may suggest other therapies, such as: Stretching exercises. Regular, steady stretching exercises can reduce muscle spasm and help lengthen the muscle-tendon unit. Exercises that involve lowering the leg very slowly after extending it can be particularly helpful, as can exercises that strengthen all of the leg muscles in combination, such as a leg press. A strap that applies pressure to the patellar tendon can help to distribute force away from the tendon and direct it through the strap instead. An ultrasound-guided corticosteroid injection into the sheath around the patellar tendon may help relieve pain. In rare cases, if other treatments fail, the doctor might suggest surgical debridement of the patellar tendon.

Name: Tennis elbow
Overview: The pain of tennis elbow occurs primarily where the tendons of the forearm muscles attach to the bony prominence on the outside of the elbow. Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) is a painful condition that occurs when tendons in the elbow are overloaded, usually by repetitive motions of the wrist and arm. The pain of tennis elbow occurs primarily where the tendons of the forearm muscles attach to a bony bump on the outside of the elbow.
Risk factors: While tennis elbow affects people of all ages, it's most common in adults between the ages of 30 and 50. Participating in racket sports increases the risk of tennis elbow, especially if one employ poor stroke technique.
info-Symptoms: Painful and tender outer part of the elbow
info-Causes: Excessive use of the muscles of the back of the forearm
info-Risk factors: Smoking, obesity
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms with medical imaging used to rule out other potential causes
info-Treatment: Changing activities, physical therapy, pain medication

Name: Tenosynovitis , de Quervain 's
Overview: De Quervain's tenosynovitis (dih-kwer-VAINS ten-oh-sine-oh-VIE-tis) is a painful condition affecting the tendons on the thumb side of the wrist. Although the exact cause of de Quervain's tenosynovitis isn't known, any activity that relies on repetitive hand or wrist movement such as working in the garden, playing golf or racket sports, or lifting the baby can make it worse.
Risk factors: Risk factors for de Quervain's tenosynovitis include Age. If one is between the ages of 30 and 50, one has a higher risk of developing de Quervain's tenosynovitis than do other age groups, including children. Lifting the child repeatedly involves using the thumbs as leverage and may also be associated with the condition.
Remedies: If one don't need surgery, caring for the condition is much the same as preventing it: Avoid moving the wrists the same way repeatedly. Note activity that causes pain, swelling or numbness in the thumb and wrist, try to avoid it, and share that information with the doctor.

Name: Tension headache
Causes: Experts used to think tension headaches stemmed from muscle contractions in the face, neck and scalp, perhaps as a result of heightened emotions, tension or stress. Increased muscle tenderness, a common symptom of tension headaches, may result from a sensitized pain system.
Diagnosis: If one has chronic or recurrent headaches, the doctor may conduct physical and neurological exams, then try to pinpoint the type and cause of the headaches using these approaches: The doctor can learn a lot about the headaches from a description of the pain. Be sure to include these details: If one has unusual or complicated headaches, the doctor may order tests to rule out serious causes of head pain, such as a tumor. Two common tests used to image the brain include Pain characteristics. An MRI scan combines a magnetic field, radio waves and computer technology to produce clear images.

Name: Testicle , retractile
Overview: A retractile testicle is a testicle that may move back and forth between the scrotum and the groin. When the retractile testicle is residing in the groin, it might be easily guided by hand into its proper position in the scrotum the bag of skin hanging behind the penis during a physical exam.
Treatment: If the son has a retractile testicle, the son's doctor will monitor any changes in the testicle's position in annual evaluations to determine if it stays in the scrotum, remains retractile or becomes an ascending testicle. If the son has a retractile testicle, he might be sensitive about his appearance. To help the son cope: The son's doctor can usually diagnose a retractile testicle. However, if there is any question about the diagnosis or need for immediate treatment, one might be referred to a doctor who specializes in urinary disorders and problems with male genitals in children (pediatric urologist). Be prepared to answer the following questions on the child's behalf or to help him answer questions: Explain in simple terms what a retractile testicle is. Explain that the position of the testicle is something one, the son and his doctor will pay attention to and fix, if necessary. Undescended testes (cryptorchidism) in children: Clinical features and evaluation. Undescended testes (cryptorchidism) in children: Management.

Name: Testicular cancer
Overview: The male reproductive system makes, stores and moves sperm. Testicular cancer occurs in the testicles (testes), which are located inside the scrotum, a loose bag of skin underneath the penis.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of testicular cancer include An undescended testicle (cryptorchidism). Men who have a testicle that never descended are at greater risk of testicular cancer than are men whose testicles descended normally. Still, the majority of men who develop testicular cancer don't have a history of undescended testicles. The risk remains elevated even if the testicle has been surgically relocated to the scrotum.Still, the majority of men who develop testicular cancer don't have a history of undescended testicles. Conditions that cause testicles to develop abnormally, such as Klinefelter syndrome, may increase the risk of testicular cancer.
Diagnosis: To determine whether a lump is testicular cancer, the doctor may recommend: Ultrasound. An ultrasound test can help the doctor determine the nature of any testicular lumps, such as whether the lumps are solid or fluid-filled. In general, there are two types of testicular cancer: Once the doctor confirms the diagnosis, the next step is to determine the extent (stage) of the cancer. To determine whether cancer has spread outside of the testicle, one may undergo: After these tests, the testicular cancer is assigned a stage. The stages of testicular cancer are indicated by Roman numerals that range from 0 to III, with the lowest stages indicating cancer that is limited to the area around the testicle. A hand-held probe is moved over the scrotum to make the ultrasound image.An ultrasound test can help the doctor determine the nature of any testicular lumps, such as whether the lumps are solid or fluid-filled. Tumor markers are substances that occur normally in the blood, but the levels of these substances may be elevated in certain situations, including testicular cancer. A high level of a tumor marker in the blood doesn't mean one has cancer, but it may help the doctor in determining the diagnosis. If it's determined that the lump on the testicle may be cancerous, surgery to remove the testicle may be recommended. Blood tests to look for elevated tumor markers can help the doctor understand whether cancer likely remains in the body after the testicle is removed.
info-Symptoms: Lump in the testicle, swelling or pain in the scrotum
info-Risk factors: Undescended testis, family history of the disease, previous history of testicular cancer
info-Diagnostic method: Physical exam, ultrasound, blood tests, surgical removal of the testicle
info-Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, stem cell transplantation

Name: Testosterone deficiency
Symptoms: If the body doesn't produce enough testosterone during fetal development, the result may be impaired growth of the external sex organs. It can hamper: And it can cause: In adult males, hypogonadism can alter certain masculine physical characteristics and impair normal reproductive function. Early signs and symptoms might include Over time, men with hypogonadism can develop: Severe hypogonadism can also cause mental and emotional changes.
Causes: Male hypogonadism means the testicles don't produce enough of the male sex hormone testosterone. The extra X chromosome that occurs in Klinefelter syndrome causes abnormal development of the testicles, which in turn results in underproduction of testosterone. If not corrected in early childhood, it can lead to malfunction of the testicles and reduced production of testosterone. In secondary hypogonadism, the testicles are normal but don't function properly due to a problem with the pituitary or hypothalamus. A number of conditions can cause secondary hypogonadism, including Pituitary disorders. An abnormality in the pituitary gland can impair the release of hormones from the pituitary gland to the testicles, affecting normal testosterone production. A pituitary tumor or other type of brain tumor located near the pituitary gland may cause testosterone or other hormone deficiencies. Also, treatment for a brain tumor, such as surgery or radiation therapy, can affect the pituitary gland and cause hypogonadism. This type of hypogonadism indicates a problem in the hypothalamus or the pituitary gland parts of the brain that signal the testicles to produce testosterone. The hypothalamus produces gonadotropin-releasing hormone, which signals the pituitary gland to make follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). A mumps infection involving the testicles that occurs during adolescence or adulthood can damage the testicles, affecting the function of the testicles and testosterone production. Too much iron in the blood can cause testicular failure or pituitary gland dysfunction, affecting testosterone production. Certain inflammatory diseases, such as sarcoidosis, histiocytosis and tuberculosis, involve the hypothalamus and pituitary gland and can affect testosterone production. HIV/AIDS can cause low levels of testosterone by affecting the hypothalamus, the pituitary and the testes. The use of certain drugs, such as opiate pain medications and some hormones, can affect testosterone production.
Diagnosis: Because testosterone levels vary and are generally highest in the morning, blood testing is usually done early in the day, before 10 a.m. possibly on more than one day.

Name: Tetanus
Remedies: Puncture wounds or other deep cuts, animal bites, or particularly dirty wounds put one at increased risk of tetanus infection. Get medical attention if the wound is deep and dirty, particularly if one is unsure of when one were last vaccinated. The doctor may need to clean the wound, prescribe an antibiotic and give one a booster shot of the tetanus toxoid vaccine. If one has a minor wound, these steps will help prevent tetanus: Use antibiotics. After one clean the wound, apply a thin layer of an antibiotic cream or ointment. These antibiotics won't make the wound heal faster, but they can discourage bacterial growth and infection. Exposure to the air might speed healing, but bandages can keep the wound clean and keep harmful bacteria out.
Medication: If one has a severe tetanus infection, one will often need to stay in an intensive care setting. Since sedatives can inhibit breathing, one might temporarily need a ventilator. The doctor may give one a tetanus antitoxin, such as tetanus immune globulin. The doctor may also give one antibiotics, either orally or by injection, to fight tetanus bacteria. Other medications, such as magnesium sulfate and certain beta blockers, might be used to regulate involuntary muscle activity, such as the heartbeat and breathing.
info-Symptoms: fever, cramped-up jaw, Muscle spasms, headache, seizures, sweating, and trouble swallowing
info-Risk factors: Break in the skin
info-Treatment: Tetanus immune globulin, muscle relaxants, mechanical ventilation

Name: Tetralogy of Fallot
Overview: Tetralogy of Fallot is a combination of four congenital abnormalities. Tetralogy of Fallot (teh-TRAL-uh-jee of fuh-LOW) is a rare condition caused by a combination of four heart defects that are present at birth (congenital). With early diagnosis followed by appropriate surgical treatment, most children and adults who have tetralogy of Fallot live relatively normal lives, though theyll need regular medical care throughout life and might have restrictions on exercise.
Causes: In some severe cases, the pulmonary valve doesn't form properly (pulmonary atresia) and causes reduced blood flow to the lungs. This ability for blood to flow through the ventricular septal defect reduces the supply of oxygenated blood to the body and eventually can weaken the heart. In tetralogy of Fallot, the aorta is shifted slightly to the right and lies directly above the ventricular septal defect.
Diagnosis: The or the baby's doctor might suspect tetralogy of Fallot if he or she notices one or the baby has blue-tinged skin or a heart murmur an abnormal whooshing sound caused by turbulent blood flow. It allows the or the baby's doctor to determine if there is a ventricular septal defect and where it's located, if the structure of the pulmonary valve and pulmonary artery is normal, if the right ventricle is functioning properly, if the aorta is positioned properly, and if there are any other heart defects. During this procedure, patches with wires (electrodes) are placed on the or the baby's chest, wrists and ankles. This test helps determine if the right ventricle is enlarged (right ventricular hypertrophy), if the right atrium is enlarged and if the heart rhythm is regular. During this procedure, the or the baby's doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube (catheter) into an artery or vein in the arm, groin or neck and threads it up to the heart. The or the baby's doctor injects a dye through the catheter to make the heart structures visible on X-ray pictures. A common sign of tetralogy of Fallot on an X-ray is a boot-shaped heart, because the right ventricle is enlarged.
Remedies: Parents of children or adolescents with congenital heart defects or adults who have congenital heart defects often worry about the risks of vigorous activity even after successful treatment. If one is an adult who has congenital heart disease, one might have concerns, such as: Pregnancy. The doctor may recommend that one be seen by a doctor trained in congenital heart disease before pregnancy and that one receive care during the pregnancy from doctors trained in congenital heart disease, genetics and high-risk obstetric care. A child, adolescent or adult who has severe heart defects might need to take preventive antibiotics before certain dental and surgical procedures. If one has serious heart rhythm problems or the potential for life-threatening complications, evaluation by a specialty team is needed to determine risk, provide therapy and counsel people regarding employment.
info-Symptoms: Episodes of bluish color to the skin, difficulty breathing, heart murmur, finger clubbing
info-Risk factors: Alcohol, diabetes, >40, rubella during pregnancy

Name: Tetraplegia
Symptoms: In fact, it's safest to assume that trauma victims have a spinal injury until proved otherwise because: Complete. If all feeling (sensory) and all ability to control movement (motor function) are lost below the spinal cord injury, the injury is called complete. If one has some motor or sensory function below the affected area, the injury is called incomplete. Also known as quadriplegia, this means that the arms, hands, trunk, legs and pelvic organs are all affected by the spinal cord injury.
Causes: Spinal cord injuries may result from damage to the vertebrae, ligaments or disks of the spinal column or to the spinal cord itself. Additional damage usually occurs over days or weeks because of bleeding, swelling, inflammation and fluid accumulation in and around the spinal cord. A nontraumatic spinal cord injury may be caused by arthritis, cancer, inflammation, infections or disk degeneration of the spine. Auto and motorcycle accidents are the leading cause of spinal cord injuries, accounting for almost half of new spinal cord injuries each year. Overall, falls cause about 31% of spinal cord injuries. Over 13% of spinal cord injuries result from violent encounters, most commonly involving gunshot wounds. Athletic activities, such as impact sports and diving in shallow water, cause about 10% of spinal cord injuries. Cancer, arthritis, osteoporosis and inflammation of the spinal cord also can cause spinal cord injuries.
Risk factors: Although a spinal cord injury is usually the result of an accident and can happen to anyone, certain factors may predispose one to a higher risk of sustaining a spinal cord injury, including Being male. In fact, females account for only about 20% of traumatic spinal cord injuries in the United States. One is most likely to suffer a traumatic spinal cord injury if one is between the ages of 16 and 30. Diving into too-shallow water or playing sports without wearing the proper safety gear or taking proper precautions can lead to spinal cord injuries. A relatively minor injury can cause a spinal cord injury if one has another disorder that affects the bones or joints, such as arthritis or osteoporosis.
Diagnosis: In the emergency room, a doctor may be able to rule out a spinal cord injury by careful inspection and examination, testing for sensory function and movement, and by asking some questions about the accident. But if the injured person complains of neck pain, isn't fully awake, or has obvious signs of weakness or neurological injury, emergency diagnostic tests may be needed. These tests may include A few days after injury, when some of the swelling may have subsided, the doctor will conduct a more comprehensive neurological exam to determine the level and completeness of the injury. X-rays can reveal vertebral (spinal column) problems, tumors, fractures or degenerative changes in the spine. This test is very helpful for looking at the spinal cord and identifying herniated disks, blood clots or other masses that may be compressing the spinal cord.
Medication: The fastest rate of recovery is often seen in the first six months, but some people experience small improvements for up to one to two years. Improved, lighter weight wheelchairs are making people with spinal cord injuries more mobile and more comfortable. They're often called functional electrical stimulation systems, and they use electrical stimulators to control arm and leg muscles to allow people with spinal cord injuries to stand, walk, reach and grip.
info-Causes: Damage to spinal cord or brain by illness or injury;

Name: Thalassemia
Causes: If one inherit: Two mutated genes, the signs and symptoms will be moderate to severe. Babies born with two defective beta hemoglobin genes usually are healthy at birth but develop signs and symptoms within the first two years of life. A milder form, called thalassemia intermedia, also can result from two mutated genes. Two mutated genes, the thalassemia signs and symptoms will be mild. Three mutated genes, the signs and symptoms will be moderate to severe. Two mutated genes, the signs and symptoms will be moderate to severe.
Treatment: To help rid the body of the extra iron, one might need to take an oral medication, such as deferasirox (Exjade, Jadenu) or deferiprone (Ferriprox). For children with severe thalassemia, it can eliminate the need for lifelong blood transfusions and drugs to control iron overload. More severe forms of thalassemia often require frequent blood transfusions, possibly every few weeks. Over time, blood transfusions cause a buildup of iron in the blood, which can damage the heart, liver and other organs.
Remedies: The doctor might also recommend a folic acid supplement to help the body make new red blood cells. To keep the bones healthy, make sure the diet contains enough calcium and vitamin D. Ask the doctor what the right amounts are for one and whether one need a supplement. Ask the doctor about taking other supplements, as well, such as folic acid. Unless the doctor recommends it, don't take vitamins or other supplements that contain iron.
info-Symptoms: Feeling tired, pale skin, enlarged spleen, yellowish skin, dark urine
info-Treatment: Blood transfusions, iron chelation, folic acid

Name: Thoracic aortic aneurysm
Symptoms: Thoracic aortic aneurysms often grow slowly and usually without symptoms, making them difficult to detect. When they occur in the chest, they're called thoracic aortic aneurysms. Aneurysms can occur anywhere in the thoracic aorta, including near the heart, in the aortic arch and in the lower part of the thoracic aorta. Thoracic aortic aneurysms are less common than aneurysms that form in the lower part of the aorta (abdominal aortic aneurysms). Most people with aortic aneurysms don't have symptoms unless a tear or rupture occurs.
Overview: A thoracic aortic aneurysm is a weakened area in the upper part of the aorta the major blood vessel that feeds blood to the body. A thoracic aortic aneurysm is a weakened area in the major blood vessel that feeds blood to the body (aorta).
Causes: Other family-related disorders can cause an aortic aneurysm, including vascular Ehlers-Danlos, Loeys-Dietz and Turner syndromes. An aortic aneurysm occurs when a weak spot in the wall of the aorta begins to bulge (left). Having an aneurysm increases the risk of rupture or an aortic dissection a tear in the lining of the aorta, shown in the image on the right. In aortic dissection, a tear occurs in the wall of the aorta. This causes bleeding into and along the aortic wall and, in some cases, completely outside the aorta (rupture). An aortic dissection is a potential life-threatening emergency, depending on where in the aorta it occurs. Inflammatory conditions, such as giant cell arteritis and Takayasu arteritis, are associated with thoracic aortic aneurysms. Sometimes people who have problems with the valve that blood flows through as it leaves the heart (aortic valve) have an increased risk of thoracic aortic aneurysm. Though rare, it's possible to develop a thoracic aortic aneurysm if one has had an untreated infection, such as syphilis or salmone willa. Rarely, some people who are injured in falls or motor vehicle crashes develop thoracic aortic aneurysms.
Risk factors: Thoracic aortic aneurysm risk factors include Age. Thoracic aortic aneurysms occur most often in people age 65 and older. Tobacco use is a strong risk factor for the development of an aortic aneurysm. Increased blood pressure damages the blood vessels in the body, raising the chances of developing an aneurysm. People who have a family history of aortic aneurysm are at increased risk of having one. A family history means one may develop aneurysms at a younger age and one is at higher risk of rupture. If one has Marfan syndrome or a related condition, such as Loeys-Dietz syndrome or vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, one has a significantly higher risk of a thoracic aortic aneurysm and aortic or other blood vessel dissection or rupture.
Diagnosis: Thoracic aortic aneurysms are often found during routine medical tests, such as a chest X-ray, CT scan or ultrasound of the heart, sometimes ordered for a different reason. The doctor may recommend screening if a first-degree relative such as a parent, sibling, son or daughter has Marfan syndrome or another condition that could cause a thoracic aortic aneurysm. One downside of the use of a CT in detecting and following aortic aneurysms is the exposure to radiation, particularly for people who require frequent monitoring, such as those with Marfan syndrome. This test may be an alternative to CT scans for people who need frequent monitoring of aneurysms, to reduce their exposure to radiation. If one has a family history of aneurysm or another suspected genetic condition that raises the risk of thoracic aortic aneurysm, one may want to consider genetic testing.
Remedies: If one has been diagnosed with a thoracic aortic aneurysm, the doctor will likely advise one to avoid heavy lifting and some vigorous physical activities, as these can increase blood pressure, putting additional pressure on the aneurysm. If one want to participate in a particular activity, ask the doctor if it would be possible to perform an exercise stress test to see how much exercise raises the blood pressure. If one is going through a particularly emotional time in the life, let the doctor know because the medications may need to be adjusted to keep the blood pressure levels from going too high. There are no medications one can take to prevent an aortic aneurysm, although taking medications to control the blood pressure and cholesterol level may reduce the risk of having complications from a thoracic aortic aneurysm. If one is at risk, the doctor may recommend treatment, including medications to lower the blood pressure and relieve stress on weakened arteries.
Medication: Examples of beta blockers include metoprolol (Lopressor, Toprol-XL, Kapspargo Sprinkle), atenolol (Tenormin) and bisoprolol. Examples of angiotensin II receptor blockers include losartan (Cozaar), valsartan (Diovan) and olmesartan (Benicar).

Name: Thoracic outlet syndrome
Overview: The thoracic outlet is the space between the collarbone (clavicle) and the first rib. Thoracic outlet syndrome is a group of disorders that occur when blood vessels or nerves in the space between the collarbone and the first rib (thoracic outlet) are compressed. Common causes of thoracic outlet syndrome include physical trauma from a car accident, repetitive injuries from job- or sports-related activities, certain anatomical defects (such as having an extra rib), and pregnancy.
Causes: In general, the cause of thoracic outlet syndrome is compression of the nerves or blood vessels in the thoracic outlet, just under the collarbone (clavicle). Drooping the shoulders or holding the head in a forward position can cause compression in the thoracic outlet area. A traumatic event, such as a car accident, can cause internal changes that then compress the nerves in the thoracic outlet. Athletes, such as baseball pitchers and swimmers, also can develop thoracic outlet syndrome from years of repetitive movements. Because joints loosen during pregnancy, signs of thoracic outlet syndrome may first appear while one is pregnant.
Diagnosis: To diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome, the doctor may review the symptoms and medical history and conduct a physical examination. The tests may help the doctor determine the cause of the condition and help rule out other causes that may have similar symptoms. In these tests, the doctor may ask one to move the arms, neck or shoulders in various positions. To confirm the diagnosis of thoracic outlet syndrome, the doctor may order one or more of the following tests: Arteriography and venography. In these tests, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible tube (catheter) through a small incision, usually in the groin. The doctor will perform a physical examination to look for external signs of thoracic outlet syndrome, such as a depression in the shoulder, swelling or pale discoloration in the arm, abnormal pulses, or limited range of motion. The doctor may order an X-ray of the affected area, which may reveal an extra rib (cervical rib). The doctor may use an MRI to determine the location and cause of blood vessel (vascular) compression. An MRI may reveal congenital anomalies, such as a fibrous band connecting the spine to the rib or a cervical rib, which may be the cause of the symptoms.
Treatment: If one has venous or arterial thoracic outlet syndrome and have blood clots, the doctor may administer clot-dissolving medications (thrombolytics) into the veins or arteries to dissolve blood clots. After one is given thrombolytics, the doctor may prescribe medications to prevent blood clots (anticoagulants).
info-Symptoms: Pain, weakness, loss of muscle at the base of the thumb, swelling, paleness, bluish coloration
info-Causes: Compression of the nerves, arteries, or veins in the passageway from the lower neck to the armpit
info-Risk factors: Trauma, repetitive arm movements, tumors, pregnancy, cervical rib

Name: Three-day measles
Treatment: No treatment will shorten the course of rubella infection, and symptoms don't usually need to be treated because they're often mild. However, doctors often recommend isolation from others especially pregnant women during the infectious period. If one contract rubella while one is pregnant, discuss the risks to the baby with the doctor. If one wish to continue the pregnancy, one may be given antibodies called hyperimmune globulin that can fight off the infection. This can reduce the symptoms, but doesn't eliminate the possibility of the baby developing congenital rubella syndrome. Simple self-care measures are required when a child or adult is infected with the virus that causes rubella, such as: As one prepare for the appointment, it's a good idea to write down any questions one has. The doctor may ask: When one check in for the appointment, be sure to tell the check-in desk that one suspect an infectious disease. In: Mandell, Douglas, and Bennett's Principles and Practice of Infectious Diseases. Progress toward rubella and congenital rubella syndrome control and elimination Worldwide, 2000-2018. Measles, mumps, rubella vaccine, live. Measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine safety studies.
info-Symptoms: Rash, swollen lymph nodes, fever, sore throat, feeling tired
info-Diagnostic method: Finding the virus in the blood, throat, or urine, antibody tests

Name: Throat cancer
Overview: The throat (pharynx) is a muscular tube that runs from the back of the nose down into the neck. The throat includes the esophagus, windpipe (trachea), voice box (larynx), tonsils and epiglottis. Throat cancer refers to cancerous tumors that develop in the throat (pharynx), voice box (larynx) or tonsils.
Causes: Throat cancer is a general term that applies to cancer that develops in the throat (pharyngeal cancer) or in the voice box (laryngeal cancer). Though most throat cancers involve the same types of cells, specific terms are used to differentiate the part of the throat where cancer originated. Oropharyngeal cancer begins in the oropharynx the part of the throat right behind the mouth that includes the tonsils. Hypopharyngeal cancer (laryngopharyngeal cancer) begins in the hypopharynx (laryngopharynx) the lower part of the throat, just above the esophagus and windpipe.
Diagnosis: In order to diagnose throat cancer, the doctor may recommend: Using a scope to get a closer look at the throat. The doctor may use a special lighted scope (endoscope) to get a close look at the throat during a procedure called endoscopy. Once throat cancer is diagnosed, the next step is to determine the extent (stage) the cancer. A tiny camera at the end of the endoscope transmits images to a video screen that the doctor watches for signs of abnormalities in the throat.Another type of scope (laryngoscope) can be inserted in the voice box. If abnormalities are found during an endoscopy or laryngoscopy, the doctor can pass surgical instruments through the scope to collect a tissue sample (biopsy). Imaging tests, including X-ray, computerized tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and positron emission tomography (PET), may help the doctor determine the extent of the cancer beyond the surface of the throat or voice box.
info-Symptoms: Lump or sore that does not heal, sore throat that does not go away, trouble swallowing, change in the voice
info-Risk factors: Alcohol, tobacco, betel quid, human papillomavirus, radiation exposure, certain workplace exposures, Epstein-Barr virus
info-Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy

Name: Thromboangiitis obliterans
Overview: In Buerger's disease, the blood vessels swell and can become blocked with blood clots (thrombi). In Buerger's disease also called thromboangiitis obliterans the blood vessels become inflamed, swell and can become blocked with blood clots (thrombi). Buerger's disease usually first shows in the hands and feet and may eventually affect larger areas of the arms and legs.
Diagnosis: While no tests can confirm whether one has Buerger's disease, the doctor will likely order tests to rule out other more common conditions or confirm suspicion of Buerger's disease brought on by the signs and symptoms. Slow blood flow into the hand may indicate a problem, such as Buerger's disease. Buerger's disease almost always affects more than one limb, so even though one may not have signs and symptoms in the other limbs, this test may detect early signs of vessel damage.
Remedies: Getting regular physical activity can benefit one in a number of ways, including helping to ease some of the pain of Buerger's disease. Check the skin on the arms and legs daily for cuts and scrapes, keeping in mind that if one has lost feeling to a finger or toe one may not feel, for example, a cut when it happens. Visit the dentist regularly to keep the gums and teeth in good health and avoid gum disease, which in its chronic form is linked to Buerger's disease.

Name: Thrombocythemia , essential
Overview: Essential thrombocythemia is an uncommon disorder in which the body produces too many blood platelets. Essential thrombocythemia (throm-boe-sie-THEE-me-uh) is more common in people over age 50, though younger people can develop it too. If one has a severe condition, one may need medicine that lowers the platelet count, blood thinners or both.
Causes: In the case of essential thrombocythemia, the bone marrow makes too many cells that create platelets. Someone with essential thrombocythemia has more than 450,000 platelets per microliter of blood.
Diagnosis: Samples of the blood will be checked for: The doctor may also suggest two bone marrow tests: The number of platelets The size of the platelets The activity of the platelets Specific genetic flaws, such as the JAK2, CALR or MPL gene mutation Iron levels Markers of inflammation Bone marrow aspiration. The sample is examined under a microscope to determine whether the bone marrow has a higher than normal number of the large cells that make platelets (megakaryocytes).

Name: Thrombocytopenia ( low platelet count )
Overview: Thrombocytopenia is a condition in which one has a low blood platelet count. Platelets stop bleeding by clumping and forming plugs in blood vessel injuries. In rare cases, the number of platelets can be so low that dangerous internal bleeding occurs.
Causes: Thrombocytopenia means one has fewer than 150,000 platelets per microliter of circulating blood. Because each platelet lives only about 10 days, the body normally renews the platelet supply continually by producing new platelets in the bone marrow. An enlarged spleen which can be caused by a number of disorders can harbor too many platelets, which decreases the number of platelets in circulation. This is a rare condition that occurs when small blood clots suddenly form throughout the body, using up large numbers of platelets. This rare disorder causes a sharp drop in platelets, destruction of red blood cells and impairs kidney function.
Diagnosis: The following can be used to determine whether one has thrombocytopenia: The doctor might suggest other tests and procedures to determine the cause of the condition, depending on the signs and symptoms. A complete blood count determines the number of blood cells, including platelets, in a sample of the blood.
Treatment: If the thrombocytopenia is caused by an underlying condition or a medication, addressing that cause might cure it. For example, if one has heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, the doctor can prescribe a different blood-thinning drug. If the platelet level becomes too low, the doctor can replace lost blood with transfusions of packed red blood cells or platelets. If the condition is related to an immune system problem, the doctor might prescribe drugs to boost the platelet count. If other treatments don't help, the doctor might recommend surgery to remove the spleen (splenectomy).
Remedies: If one has thrombocytopenia, try to: Avoid activities that could cause injury. Over-the-counter pain medications, such as aspirin and ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) can prevent platelets from working properly.

Name: Thrombocytopenia , childhood
Overview: Thrombocytopenia (throm-boe-sie-toe-PEE-nee-uh) is a condition in which there aren't enough platelets in the blood. Less-common causes of thrombocytopenia in children include bone marrow disorders such as leukemia or other autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or hereditary bone marrow disorders.

Name: Thrombocytosis
Overview: Platelets are blood particles produced in the bone marrow that play an important role in the process of forming blood clots. If the blood test indicates thrombocytosis, it's important to determine whether it's reactive thrombocytosis or essential thrombocythemia to know how to manage the condition.

Name: Thrombophlebitis
Overview: A blood clot in a leg vein may cause pain, warmth and tenderness in the affected area. Thrombophlebitis (throm-boe-fluh-BY-tis) is an inflammatory process that causes a blood clot to form and block one or more veins, usually in the legs. The affected vein might be near the surface of the skin (superficial thrombophlebitis) or deep within a muscle (deep vein thrombosis, or DVT).
Diagnosis: To diagnose thrombophlebitis, the doctor will ask one about the discomfort and look for affected veins near the skin's surface. To determine whether one has superficial thrombophlebitis or deep vein thrombosis, the doctor might choose one of these tests: Ultrasound.
info-Symptoms: Skin redness
info-Risk factors: Smoking, Lupus

Name: Thrush , oral
Overview: Oral thrush produces slightly raised, creamy white, sore patches in the mouth or on the tongue. Although oral thrush can affect anyone, it's more likely to occur in babies and older adults because they have reduced immunity; in other people with suppressed immune systems or certain health conditions; or people who take certain medications.
Risk factors: Some medical conditions and treatments can suppress the immune system, such as cancer and its treatments, organ transplantation and required drugs that suppress the immune system, and HIV/AIDS. Drugs such as prednisone, inhaled corticosteroids, or antibiotics that disturb the natural balance of microorganisms in the body can increase the risk of oral thrush. Wearing dentures, especially upper dentures, or having conditions that cause dry mouth can increase the risk of oral thrush.
Diagnosis: To diagnose oral thrush, the doctor or dentist may: To help diagnose thrush in the esophagus, the doctor may recommend any or all of these: Examine the mouth to look at the lesions Take a small scraping of the lesions to examine under a microscope If needed, do a physical exam and certain blood tests to identify any possible underlying medical condition that may be the cause of oral thrush Biopsy. In this procedure, the doctor examines the esophagus, stomach and upper part of the small intestine (duodenum) using a lighted, flexible tube with a camera on the tip (endoscope). If needed, a physical exam and certain blood tests may be done to try to identify any possible underlying medical condition that could cause thrush in the esophagus.
Treatment: The goal of any oral thrush treatment is to stop the rapid spread of the fungus, but the best approach may depend on the age, the overall health and the cause of the infection. Thrush may return even after it's been treated if the underlying cause, such as poorly disinfected dentures or inhaled steroid use, isn't addressed. However, if one has an underlying condition that's contributing to the problem, one may be referred to a specialist for treatment. If one is breast-feeding and the infant has oral thrush, one and the baby could pass the infection back and forth. If one is breast-feeding and develop a fungal infection, use pads to help prevent the fungus from spreading to the clothes. Ask the doctor about the best way to clean the breast nipples, bottle nipples, pacifiers and any detachable parts of a breast pump if one use one.
Remedies: If one is breast-feeding and develop a fungal infection, use pads to help prevent the fungus from spreading to the clothes. Ask the doctor about the best way to clean the breast nipples, bottle nipples, pacifiers and any detachable parts of a breast pump if one use one.

Name: Thumb arthritis
Overview: Thumb arthritis occurs when the cartilage in the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint wears away. Thumb arthritis is common with aging and occurs when cartilage wears away from the ends of the bones that form the joint at the base of the thumb also known as the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint.
Causes: In a normal thumb joint, cartilage covers the ends of the bones acting as a cushion and allowing the bones to glide smoothly against each other. With thumb arthritis, the cartilage that covers the ends of the bones deteriorates, and its smooth surface roughens.
Remedies: To ease pain and improve joint mobility, try to: Toothbrushes with and without foam handles. Consider purchasing adaptive equipment such as jar openers, key turners and large zipper pulls designed for people with limited hand strength. Replace traditional door handles, which one must grasp with the thumb, with levers.

Name: Thunderclap headaches
Overview: Thunderclap headaches live up to their name, striking suddenly like a clap of thunder. Thunderclap headaches are uncommon, but they can warn of potentially life-threatening conditions usually having to do with bleeding in and around the brain.
Diagnosis: CT scans take X-rays that create slice-like, cross-sectional images of the brain and head. A magnetic field and radio waves are used to create cross-sectional images of the structures within the brain. MRI machines can be used to map the blood flow inside the brain in a test called a magnetic resonance angiography (MRA).

Name: Thyroid cancer
Overview: Thyroid cancer occurs in the cells of the thyroid. Thyroid cancer occurs in the cells of the thyroid a butterfly-shaped gland located at the base of the neck, just below the Adam's apple.
Causes: Thyroid cancer occurs when cells in the thyroid undergo genetic changes (mutations). Thyroid cancer is classified into types based on the kinds of cells found in the tumor. The most common form of thyroid cancer, papillary thyroid cancer arises from follicular cells, which produce and store thyroid hormones. Follicular thyroid cancer also arises from the follicular cells of the thyroid. Anaplastic thyroid cancer is a rare type of thyroid cancer that begins in the follicular cells. Medullary thyroid cancer begins in thyroid cells called C cells, which produce the hormone calcitonin.
Diagnosis: The appearance of the thyroid on the ultrasound helps the doctor determine whether a thyroid nodule is likely to be noncancerous (benign) or whether there's a risk that it might be cancerous. During a fine-needle aspiration biopsy, the doctor inserts a long, thin needle through the skin and into the thyroid nodule. One may have one or more imaging tests to help the doctor determine whether the cancer has spread beyond the thyroid.
info-Symptoms: Swelling or lump in the neck
info-Risk factors: Radiation exposure, enlarged thyroid, family history
info-Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, thyroid hormone, targeted therapy, watchful waiting

Name: Thyroid gland enlargement
Causes: The thyroid gland produces two main hormones thyroxine (T-4) and triiodothyronine (T-3). The thyroid gland also produces calcitonin a hormone that helps regulate the amount of calcium in the blood. The thyroid gland, in turn, regulates its production of hormones based on the amount of TSH it receives from the pituitary gland. Even when it's enlarged, the thyroid may produce normal amounts of hormones. This can be caused by single or multiple nodules (lumps) in the thyroid, or by an autoimmune process. Iodine is essential for the production of thyroid hormones, and is found primarily in seawater and in the soil in coastal areas. But instead of causing the thyroid to produce too much hormone, Hashimoto's damages the thyroid so that it produces too little. Sensing a low hormone level, the pituitary gland produces more TSH to stimulate the thyroid, which then causes the gland to enlarge. A goiter can sometimes occur when the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone (hyperthyroidism). In someone who has Graves disease, antibodies produced by the immune system mistakenly attack the thyroid gland, causing it to produce excess thyroxine. In this condition, several solid or fluid-filled lumps called nodules develop in both sides of the thyroid, resulting in overall enlargement of the gland. A hormone produced during pregnancy, human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG), may cause the thyroid gland to enlarge slightly.
Risk factors: People living in areas where iodine is in short supply and who don't have access to iodine supplements are at high risk of goiters. Because women are more prone to thyroid disorders, they're also more likely to develop goiters. For reasons that aren't entirely clear, thyroid problems are more likely to occur during pregnancy and menopause. Some medical treatments, including the heart drug amiodarone (Pacerone, others) and the psychiatric drug lithium (Lithobid, others), increase the risk. The risk increases if one has had radiation treatments to the neck or chest area or one has been exposed to radiation in a nuclear facility, test or accident.
Diagnosis: The doctor may discover an enlarged thyroid gland simply by feeling the neck and having one swallow during a routine physical exam. Blood tests can determine the amount of hormones produced by the thyroid and pituitary glands. At the same time, the level of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) will be elevated because the pituitary gland tries to stimulate the thyroid gland to produce more thyroid hormone. A goiter associated with an overactive thyroid usually involves a high level of thyroid hormone in the blood and a lower than normal TSH level. The time needed for the procedure may vary, depending on how long it takes the isotope to reach the thyroid gland. Thyroid scans provide information about the nature and size of the thyroid, but they're more invasive, time-consuming and expensive than ultrasound tests. The images reveal the size of the thyroid gland and whether the gland contains nodules that the doctor may not have been able to feel. During a fine-needle aspiration biopsy, ultrasound is used to guide a needle into the thyroid to obtain a tissue or fluid sample for testing.
Treatment: If one has hypothyroidism, thyroid hormone replacement with levothyroxine (Levoxyl, Synthroid, Tirosint) will resolve the symptoms of hypothyroidism as well as slow the release of thyroid-stimulating hormone from the pituitary gland, often decreasing the size of the goiter. If one has a goiter that is associated with hyperthyroidism, one may need medications to normalize hormone levels. Removing all or part of the thyroid gland (total or partial thyroidectomy) is an option if one has a large goiter that is uncomfortable or causes difficulty breathing or swallowing, or in some cases, if one has a nodular goiter causing hyperthyroidism. If the goiter is small and doesn't cause problems, and the thyroid is functioning normally, the doctor may suggest a wait-and-see approach. The treatment results in a diminished size of the goiter, but eventually may also cause an underactive thyroid gland.

Name: Thyroid nodules
Overview: The thyroid gland is located at the base of the neck, just below the Adam's apple. Thyroid nodules are solid or fluid-filled lumps that form within the thyroid, a small gland located at the base of the neck, just above the breastbone. Some thyroid nodules, however, may become large enough to be visible or make it difficult to swallow or breathe.
Causes: This can be caused by single or multiple nodules (lumps) in the thyroid, or by an autoimmune process. Several conditions can cause nodules to develop in the thyroid gland, including Overgrowth of normal thyroid tissue. Hashimoto's disease, a thyroid disorder, can cause thyroid inflammation and result in enlarged nodules. The term goiter is used to describe any enlargement of the thyroid gland, which can be caused by iodine deficiency or a thyroid disorder. Lack of iodine in the diet can sometimes cause the thyroid gland to develop thyroid nodules.
Diagnosis: The doctor will also look for signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as tremor, overly active reflexes, and a rapid or irregular heartbeat. Nodules that produce excess thyroid hormone called hot nodules show up on the scan because they take up more of the isotope than normal thyroid tissue does. However, a thyroid scan can't distinguish between cold nodules that are cancerous and those that aren't cancerous.

Name: Thyroid , overactive
