Causes: Hyperthyroidism can be caused by a number of conditions, including Graves disease, Plummer's disease and thyroiditis. The thyroid gland produces two main hormones, thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3), that influence every cell in the body. Hyperfunctioning thyroid nodules (toxic adenoma, toxic multinodular goiter or Plummer's disease).
Diagnosis: Thyroid blood tests may give false results if one is taking biotin a B vitamin supplement that may also be found in multivitamins. If blood tests indicate hyperthyroidism, the doctor may recommend one of the following tests to help determine why the thyroid is overactive: Radioiodine uptake test. For this test, one take a small, oral dose of radioactive iodine (radioiodine) to see how much will collect in the thyroid gland. If one has hyperthyroidism and the radioiodine uptake is low, this indicates that the thyroxine stored in the gland is leaking into the bloodstream, which may mean one has thyroiditis. Ultrasound may be better at detecting thyroid nodules than other tests, and there's no exposure to any radiation.
Treatment: This treatment may cause thyroid activity to slow enough to be considered underactive (hypothyroidism), and one may eventually need to take medication every day to replace thyroxine. Symptoms usually begin to improve within several weeks to months, but treatment with anti-thyroid medications typically continues at least a year and often longer. If one is pregnant or one otherwise can't tolerate anti-thyroid drugs and don't want to or can't have radioactive iodine therapy, one may be a candidate for thyroid surgery, although this is an option in only a few cases. In addition, one will need lifelong treatment with levothyroxine (Levoxyl, Synthroid, others) to supply the body with normal amounts of thyroid hormone. If the parathyroid glands also are removed, one will need medication to keep the blood-calcium levels normal. Although these drugs are usually used to treat high blood pressure and don't affect thyroid levels, they can ease symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as a tremor, rapid heart rate and palpitations.
Remedies: However, the doctor may recommend that one watch out for iodine in the diet because it can cause hyperthyroidism or make it worse. If one has Graves ophthalmopathy or dermopathy, the following suggestions may help the eyes or skin: Don't smoke. If the eyes don't completely close, one can tape the eyelids shut, or use a lubricating gel at bedtime to keep the cornea from drying out. Over-the-counter creams containing hydrocortisone (Cortizone-10, others) may help relieve red, swollen skin on the shins and feet.

Name: Thyroiditis , chronic lymphocytic
Symptoms: One might not notice signs or symptoms of Hashimoto's disease at first, or one may notice a swelling at the front of the throat (goiter). And if one is receiving hormone therapy for hypothyroidism caused by Hashimoto's disease, schedule follow-up visits as often as the doctor recommends.
Overview: The thyroid gland is located at the base of the neck, just below the Adam's apple. Hashimoto's disease is a condition in which the immune system attacks the thyroid, a small gland at the base of the neck below the Adam's apple. Inflammation from Hashimoto's disease, also known as chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, often leads to an underactive thyroid gland (hypothyroidism).
Risk factors: These factors may contribute to the risk of developing Hashimoto's disease: Sex. One is at higher risk for Hashimoto's disease if others in the family have thyroid or other autoimmune diseases. Having another autoimmune disease such as rheumatoid arthritis, type 1 diabetes or lupus increases the risk of developing Hashimoto's disease. People exposed to excessive levels of environmental radiation are more prone to Hashimoto's disease.
Diagnosis: In general, the doctor may test for Hashimoto's disease if one is feeling increasingly tired or sluggish, have dry skin, constipation, and a hoarse voice, or have had previous thyroid problems or a goiter. Diagnosis of Hashimoto's disease is based on the signs and symptoms and the results of blood tests that measure levels of thyroid hormone and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) produced in the pituitary gland. These may include In the past, doctors weren't able to detect an underactive thyroid (hypothyroidism), the main indicator of Hashimoto's disease, until symptoms were fairly advanced. A blood test may confirm the presence of antibodies against thyroid peroxidase (TPO antibodies), an enzyme normally found in the thyroid gland that plays an important role in the production of thyroid hormones.

Name: Tinea barbae
Symptoms: Hot tub folliculitis causes red, round, itchy bumps that may later develop into small pus-filled blisters. Razor bumps (pseudofolliculitis barbae) affects men with curly beards. A carbuncle is a cluster of boils painful, pus-filled bumps that form a connected area of infection under the skin. It occurs when hair follicles become infected with bacteria, usually Staphylococcus aureus (staph). With this type one may develop a rash of red, round, itchy bumps one to two days after exposure to the bacteria that causes it. This type produces chronic, red, itchy pustules on the back and chest and sometimes on the neck, shoulders, upper arms and face. Once healed, the affected skin may be darker than the skin was previously (hyperpigmented).
Medication: For mild infections, the doctor may prescribe an antibiotic cream, lotion or gel. If one has mild eosinophilic folliculitis, the doctor may suggest one try a steroid cream to ease the itching. If one has a large boil or carbuncle, the doctor may make a small incision in it to drain the pus. If other treatments fail, long-term hair removal with laser therapy may clear up the infection.

Name: Tinea capitis
Causes: Ringworm of the scalp is caused by one of several varieties of mold-like fungi called dermatophytes. Ringworm is contagious and can spread in the following ways: The fungi that cause ringworm of the scalp can cause other infections on the body. Dogs and cats, especially puppies and kittens, are often carriers of ringworm.

Name: Tinea corporis
Overview: Ringworm often causes a ring-shaped rash that is itchy, red, scaly and slightly raised. Ringworm of the body (tinea corporis) is a rash caused by a fungal infection. Ringworm of the body is related to athlete's foot (tinea pedis), jock itch (tinea cruris) and ringworm of the scalp (tinea capitis).
Causes: Ringworm is a contagious fungal infection caused by common mold-like parasites that live on the cells in the outer layer of the skin. Ringworm often spreads by direct, skin-to-skin contact with an infected person. In rare cases, ringworm can be spread to humans by contact with infected soil.
Treatment: If over-the-counter treatments don't work, one may need prescription-strength antifungal medications such as a lotion, cream or ointment that one apply to the affected skin. Apply an over-the-counter antifungal lotion, cream or ointment such as clotrimazole (Lotrimin AF) or terbinafine (Lamisil AT) as directed on the packaging.

Name: Tinea cruris
Overview: Jock itch is characterized by an itchy, red rash often on the groin and inner thighs. Jock itch (tinea cruris) is a fungal infection that causes a red and itchy rash in warm and moist areas of the body.
Treatment: For mild jock itch, the doctor may suggest first using an over-the-counter antifungal ointment, lotion, powder or spray. If one also have athlete's foot, it's usually treated at the same time as jock itch to reduce the risk of the rash coming back. Severe jock itch or a rash that doesn't improve with over-the-counter medicine may need prescription-strength creams, ointments or pills. The time with the doctor may be limited, so preparing a list of questions can help one make the most of the appointment. For jock itch, some basic questions to ask the doctor include What's the most likely cause of my symptoms?
info-Symptoms: Itch, rash in groin
info-Risk factors: Excessive sweating Diabetes Obesity
info-Diagnostic method: Microscopy and culture of skin scrapings
info-Prevention: Treat any fungal infections of feet or nails. Keep groin region dry Avoid tight clothing Losing weight if obese

Name: Tinea pedis
Symptoms: Athlete's foot usually causes a scaly red rash. The moccasin variety of athlete's foot causes chronic dryness and scaling on the soles that extends up the side of the foot. If one has a rash on the foot that doesn't improve within two weeks of beginning self-treatment with an over-the-counter antifungal product, see the doctor.
Overview: Athlete's foot is a fungal infection that usually begins between the toes. Signs and symptoms of athlete's foot include a scaly rash that usually causes itching, stinging and burning.
Treatment: If the athlete's foot is mild, the doctor may suggest using an over-the-counter antifungal ointment, cream, powder or spray. If the athlete's foot doesn't respond, one may need a prescription-strength medication to apply to the feet. These tips can help one ease the symptoms of athlete's foot or avoid a recurrence: The primary care doctor or a skin specialist (dermatologist) can diagnose athlete's foot. For example, creams may be applied to dry feet twice a day and used for a week even after the rash is gone.
Remedies: These tips can help one ease the symptoms of athlete's foot or avoid a recurrence: Keep the feet dry, especially between the toes. For example, creams may be applied to dry feet twice a day and used for a week even after the rash is gone.
info-Symptoms: Itching, scaling, redness of the foot
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, confirmed by culture or microscopy
info-Prevention: Avoiding walking barefoot in public showers, keeping toenails short, wearing big enough shoes, changing socks daily
info-Treatment: Antifungal medication applied to the skin or taken by mouth

Name: Tinea versicolor
Treatment: If tinea versicolor is severe or doesn't respond to over-the-counter antifungal medicine, one may need a prescription-strength medication. Examples include Even after successful treatment, the skin color may remain uneven for several weeks, or even months. For a mild case of tinea versicolor, one can apply an over-the-counter antifungal lotion, cream, ointment or shampoo. Most fungal infections respond well to these topical agents, which include When using creams, ointments or lotions, wash and dry the affected area. Ketoconazole (Ketoconazole, Nizoral, others) cream, gel or shampoo Ciclopirox (Loprox, Penlac) cream, gel or shampoo Fluconazole (Diflucan) tablets or oral solution Itraconazole (Onmel, Sporanox) tablets, capsules or oral solution Selenium sulfide (Selsun) 2.5 percent lotion or shampoo Clotrimazole (Lotrimin AF) cream or lotion Miconazole (Micaderm) cream Selenium sulfide (Selsun Blue) 1 percent lotion Terbinafine (Lamisil AT) cream or gel Zinc pyrithione soap
Remedies: For a mild case of tinea versicolor, one can apply an over-the-counter antifungal lotion, cream, ointment or shampoo. Most fungal infections respond well to these topical agents, which include When using creams, ointments or lotions, wash and dry the affected area.

Name: Tinnitus
Symptoms: Hearing loss can be age-related, come from a one-time exposure, or exposure to loud sounds over a lifetime. Dr. Poling says there's no scientifically proven cure for tinnitus, but there are treatment and management options. This rare type of tinnitus may be caused by a blood vessel problem, a middle ear bone condition or muscle contractions.
Overview: Tinnitus can be caused by broken or damaged hairs on auditory cells, turbulence in a carotid artery or jugular vein, temporomandibular joint (TMJ) issues, and problems in the auditory processing pathways of the brain. Tinnitus isn't a condition itself it's a symptom of an underlying condition, such as age-related hearing loss, ear injury or a circulatory system disorder.
Causes: If the hairs inside the inner ear are bent or broken, they can leak random electrical impulses to the brain, causing tinnitus. Medications known to cause or worsen tinnitus include In addition, some herbal supplements can cause tinnitus, as can nicotine and caffeine. For many people, hearing worsens with age, usually starting around age 60. Loud noises, such as those from heavy equipment, chain saws and firearms, are common sources of noise-related hearing loss. Portable music devices, such as MP3 players or iPods, also can cause noise-related hearing loss if played loudly for long periods. Tinnitus caused by short-term exposure, such as attending a loud concert, usually goes away; both short- and long-term exposure to loud sound can cause permanent damage. When too much earwax accumulates, it becomes too hard to wash away naturally, causing hearing loss or irritation of the eardrum, which can lead to tinnitus. Stiffening of the bones in the middle ear (otosclerosis) may affect the hearing and cause tinnitus. Tinnitus can be an early indicator of Meniere's disease, an inner ear disorder that may be caused by abnormal inner ear fluid pressure. Head or neck trauma can affect the inner ear, hearing nerves or brain function linked to hearing. Also called vestibular schwannoma, this condition generally causes tinnitus in only one ear. Muscles in the inner ear can tense up (spasm), which can result in tinnitus, hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in the ear. That causes blood flow to become more forceful, making it easier for the ear to detect the beats. A condition called arteriovenous malformation (AVM), abnormal connections between arteries and veins, can result in tinnitus.
Risk factors: Anyone can experience tinnitus, but these factors may increase the risk: Loud noise exposure. People who work in noisy environments such as factory and construction workers, musicians, and soldiers are particularly at risk. As one age, the number of functioning nerve fibers in the ears declines, possibly causing hearing problems often associated with tinnitus. Conditions that affect the blood flow, such as high blood pressure or narrowed arteries (atherosclerosis), can increase the risk of tinnitus.
Diagnosis: The doctor will examine the ears, head and neck to look for possible causes of tinnitus. Depending on the suspected cause of the tinnitus, one may need imaging tests such as CT or MRI scans. Blood vessel problems, such as high blood pressure, an aneurysm or a tumor, and blockage of the ear canal or eustachian tube can amplify the sound of the heartbeat in the ears (pulsatile tinnitus). However, if there's hearing loss as well, tinnitus may be permanent. Long-term noise exposure, age-related hearing loss or medications can cause a continuous, high-pitched ringing in both ears. Acoustic neuroma can cause continuous, high-pitched ringing in one ear. Stiff inner ear bones (otosclerosis) can cause low-pitched tinnitus that may be continuous or may come and go.
Remedies: In a quiet setting, a fan, soft music or low-volume radio static may help mask the noise from tinnitus. Stress management, whether through relaxation therapy, biofeedback or exercise, may provide some relief. Alcohol increases the force of the blood by dilating the blood vessels, causing greater blood flow, especially in the inner ear area.
Medication: However, these medications are generally used for only severe tinnitus, as they can cause troublesome side effects, including dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation and heart problems. Alprazolam (Xanax) may help reduce tinnitus symptoms, but side effects can include drowsiness and nausea.
info-Symptoms: Hearing sound when no external sound is present
info-Causes: Noise-induced hearing loss, ear infections, disease of the heart or blood vessels, MÃ©niÃ¨re's disease, brain tumors, inner ear tumors, emotional stress, traumatic brain injury, excessive earwax
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, audiogram, neurological exam

Name: TMJ disorders
Overview: TMJ disorders affect the temporomandibular joint, located on each side of the head in front of the ears. Some people who have jaw pain also tend to clench or grind their teeth (bruxism), although many people habitually clench or grind their teeth and never develop TMJ disorders.
Remedies: Becoming more aware of tension-related habits clenching the jaw, grinding the teeth or chewing pencils will help one reduce their frequency. The following tips may help one reduce symptoms of TMJ disorders: Avoid overuse of jaw muscles. The doctor, dentist or physical therapist may show one how to do exercises that stretch and strengthen the jaw muscles and how to massage the muscles theself. Applying warm, moist heat or ice to the side of the face may help alleviate pain.
Medication: Along with other nonsurgical treatments, these medication options may help relieve the pain associated with TMJ disorders: Nondrug therapies for TMJ disorders include Pain relievers and anti-inflammatories. If over-the-counter pain medications aren't enough to relieve TMJ pain, the doctor or dentist may prescribe stronger pain relievers for a limited time, such as prescription strength ibuprofen. These medications, such as amitriptyline, are used mostly for depression, but in low doses, they're sometimes used for pain relief, bruxism control and sleeplessness. Often, people with jaw pain will benefit from wearing a soft or firm device inserted over their teeth, but the reasons why these devices are beneficial are not well-understood. Education and counseling can help one understand the factors and behaviors that may aggravate the pain, so one can avoid them.
info-Specialty: Oral and maxillofacial surgery, Oral medicine

Name: Toe walking in children
Overview: Walking on the toes or the balls of the feet, also known as toe walking, is fairly common in children who are just beginning to walk. Toe walking sometimes can result from certain conditions, including cerebral palsy, muscular dystrophy and autism spectrum disorder.
Causes: Typically, toe walking is a habit that develops when a child learns to walk. In a few cases, toe walking is caused by an underlying condition, such as: A short Achilles tendon. Toe walking sometimes occurs in this genetic disease in which muscle fibers are unusually prone to damage and weaken over time. Toe walking has been linked to autism spectrum disorders, which affect a child's ability to communicate and interact with others.
Diagnosis: In some cases, the doctor may do a gait analysis or an exam known as electromyography (EMG). If the doctor suspects a condition such as cerebral palsy or autism, he or she may recommend a neurological exam or testing for developmental delays.
Treatment: If a physical problem is contributing to toe walking, treatment options might include If the toe walking is associated with cerebral palsy, autism or other problems, treatment focuses on the underlying condition. One will probably first bring the concerns to the attention of the primary care provider family doctor, nurse practitioner, physician assistant or pediatrician. If physical therapy or leg braces aren't helpful, the doctor might suggest trying a series of below-the-knee casts to progressively improve the ability to bring the toes toward the shin. If conservative treatments fail, the doctor might recommend surgery to lengthen the muscles or tendons at the back of the lower leg.

Name: Toenail fungus
Overview: Nail fungus can cause the nail to become thick or ragged and appear yellow, green, brown or black. As the fungal infection goes deeper, nail fungus may cause the nail to discolor, thicken and crumble at the edge. If the nail fungus is painful and has caused thickened nails, self-care steps and medications may help.
Causes: Ms. Williams: Dr. Rachel Miest says bacterial and fungal are the two most common infections. Dr. Miest: Even if all of the appropriate precautions are taken from a cleaning standpoint, bacteria, viruses, fungi - these things are everywhere. Ms. Williams: To reduce the risk, Dr. Miest says don't shave 24 hours beforehand and don't have the cuticles cut. Fungal nail infection can develop in people at any age, but it's more common in older adults. Toenail fungal infection can start from athlete's foot (foot fungus), and it can spread from one nail to another.
Remedies: Often, one can take care of a fungal nail infection at home: Before trimming or using a nail file to thin thick nails, soften them with urea-containing creams. If one has a condition that causes poor blood flow to the feet and one can't trim the nails, see a health care provider regularly to have the nails trimmed. If one notice white markings on the surfaces of the nails, file them off, soak the nails in water, dry them, and apply the medicated cream or lotion.
Medication: The doctor may prescribe antifungal drugs that one take orally or apply to the nail. The doctor may prescribe an antifungal cream, which one rub into the infected nails after soaking. The doctor may prescribe an antifungal nail polish called ciclopirox (Penlac).
info-Symptoms: White or yellow nail discoloration, thickening of the nail
info-Risk factors: Athlete's foot, other nail diseases, exposure to someone with the condition, peripheral vascular disease, poor immune function
info-Diagnostic method: Based on appearance, confirmed by laboratory testing
info-Treatment: None, anti-fungal medication, trimming the nails

Name: Tongue cancer
Overview: Tongue cancer is a form of cancer that begins in the cells of the tongue. Several types of cancer can affect the tongue, but tongue cancer most often begins in the thin, flat squamous cells that line the surface of the tongue. The type of cells involved in the tongue cancer helps determine the prognosis and treatment. Tongue cancer can occur: In the throat, at the base of the tongue, where tongue cancer may develop with few signs and symptoms (hypopharyngeal tongue cancer). Cancer at the base of the tongue is usually diagnosed at an advanced stage, when the tumor is larger and the cancer has spread into the lymph nodes in the neck. Increasingly, cancers at the base of the tongue are associated with human papillomavirus (HPV), which has a profound effect on the prognosis and treatment of the cancer. In the throat, at the base of the tongue, where tongue cancer may develop with few signs and symptoms (hypopharyngeal tongue cancer).
info-Specialty: Oncology, oral and maxillofacial surgery, ENT surgery
info-Symptoms: Persistent rough white or red patch in the mouth lasting longer than 2 weeks, ulceration, lumps/bumps in the neck, pain, loose teeth, difficulty swallowing
info-Risk factors: Smoking, alcohol, HPV infection, sun exposure, chewing tobacco

Name: Tongue-tie ( ankyloglossia )
Overview: Tongue-tie (ankyloglossia) is a condition in which an unusually short, thick or tight band of tissue (lingual frenulum) tethers the bottom of the tongue's tip to the floor of the mouth. With tongue-tie, an unusually short, thick or tight band of tissue (lingual frenulum) tethers the bottom of the tongue's tip to the floor of the mouth, so it may interfere with breast-feeding.
Treatment: In some cases, consultation with a lactation consultant can assist with breast-feeding, and speech therapy with a speech-language pathologist may help improve speech sounds. Surgical treatment of tongue-tie may be needed for infants, children or adults if tongue-tie causes problems.

Name: Tonic-clonic seizure
Symptoms: Loss of consciousness occurs, and the muscles suddenly contract and cause the person to fall down. A period of disorientation often follows a grand mal seizure. Sleepiness is common after a grand mal seizure. Headaches may occur after a grand mal seizure.
Diagnosis: EEG results show changes in brain activity that may be useful in diagnosing brain conditions, especially epilepsy and other seizure disorders. If the doctor suspects an infection as the cause of a seizure, one may need to have a sample of cerebrospinal fluid removed for testing. A SPECT test uses a small amount of low-dose radioactive material that's injected into a vein to create a detailed, 3-D map of the blood flow activity in the brain that happens during a seizure. Doctors may also conduct a form of a SPECT test called subtraction ictal SPECT coregistered to magnetic resonance imaging (SISCOM), which may provide even more-detailed results.
Remedies: Here are some steps one can take to help with seizure control: Seizures don't usually result in serious injury, but if one has recurrent seizures, injury is a possibility. These steps can help one avoid injury during a seizure: It's helpful to know what to do if one witness someone having a seizure. Carefully roll the person onto one side Place something soft under his or her head Loosen tight neckwear Remove eyeglasses Avoid putting the fingers or other objects in the person's mouth Don't try to restrain someone having a seizure Clear away dangerous objects, if the person is moving Stay with the person until medical personnel arrive Observe the person closely so that one can provide details on what happened Time the seizure Check for a medical alert bracelet or ID Stay calm Take medication correctly.
Medication: Many medications are used in the treatment of epilepsy and seizures, including Finding the right medication and dosage can be challenging. Mild side effects of anti-seizure medications can include More-troubling side effects that need to be brought to the doctor's attention immediately include In addition, the drug Lamictal has been linked to an increased risk of aseptic meningitis, an inflammation of the protective membranes that cover the brain and spinal cord that's similar to bacterial meningitis. When anti-seizure medications aren't effective, other treatments may be an option: Women whove had previous seizures usually are able to have healthy pregnancies. Because of the risk of birth defects, and because pregnancy can alter medication levels, preconception planning is particularly important for women whove had seizures. Carbamazepine (Carbatrol, Tegretol, others) Phenytoin (Dilantin, Phenytek) Valproic acid (Depakene) Oxcarbazepine (Oxtellar, Trileptal) Lamotrigine (Lamictal) Gabapentin (Gralise, Neurontin) Topiramate (Topamax) Phenobarbital Zonisamide (Zonegran) Fatigue Dizziness Weight gain Mood disruption Skin rashes Loss of coordination Speech problems Extreme fatigue Surgery. A device implanted underneath the skin of the chest stimulates the vagus nerve in the neck, sending signals to the brain that inhibit seizures. During responsive neurostimulation, a device implanted on the surface of the brain or within brain tissue can detect seizure activity and deliver an electrical stimulation to the detected area to stop the seizure.

Name: Tonsil cancer
Overview: The tonsils are two oval-shaped pads in the back of the mouth. The tonsils are two oval-shaped pads in the back of the mouth that are part of the body's germ-fighting immune system.
info-Symptoms: Sore or blister in back of mouth, difficulty with speech, swallowing or breathing, swelling in neck, loss of appetite, loss of weight, and weakness
info-Causes: Human papillomavirus (HPV), tobacco use (smoking and chewing), alcohol use disorder (long-term effects)
info-Diagnostic method: Endoscopy, biopsy, staining for p16, CT scan

Name: Tonsillitis
Causes: Tonsillitis is most often caused by common viruses, but bacterial infections can also be the cause. The most common bacterium causing tonsillitis is Streptococcus pyogenes (group A streptococcus), the bacterium that causes strep throat. However, the tonsil's immune system function declines after puberty a factor that may account for the rare cases of tonsillitis in adults.
Risk factors: Tonsillitis most often occurs in children, but rarely in those younger than age 2. Tonsillitis caused by bacteria is most common in children ages 5 to 15, while viral tonsillitis is more common in younger children. School-age children are in close contact with their peers and frequently exposed to viruses or bacteria that can cause tonsillitis.
Diagnosis: The child's doctor will start with a physical exam that will include With this simple test, the doctor rubs a sterile swab over the back of the child's throat to get a sample of secretions. Using a lighted instrument to look at the child's throat and likely his or her ears and nose, which may also be sites of infection Checking for a rash known as scarlatina, which is associated with some cases of strep throat Gently feeling (palpating) the child's neck to check for swollen glands (lymph nodes) Listening to his or her breathing with a stethoscope Checking for enlargement of the spleen (for consideration of mononucleosis, which also inflames the tonsils) Complete blood count (CBC)
info-Symptoms: Sore throat, fever, enlargement of the tonsils, trouble swallowing, large lymph nodes around the neck
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, throat swab, rapid strep test

Name: Tooth abscess
Overview: Bacteria can enter the innermost part of the tooth through either a deep cavity or a chip or crack in the tooth. A periapical (per-e-AP-ih-kul) abscess occurs at the tip of the root, whereas a periodontal (per-e-o-DON-tul) abscess occurs in the gums at the side of a tooth root. A periapical tooth abscess usually occurs as a result of an untreated dental cavity, an injury or prior dental work.
Risk factors: Not taking proper care of the teeth and gums such as not brushing the teeth twice a day and not flossing can increase the risk of tooth decay, gum disease, tooth abscess, and other dental and mouth complications. Frequently eating and drinking foods rich in sugar, such as sweets and sodas, can contribute to dental cavities and turn into a tooth abscess.
Diagnosis: The dentist may also use X-rays to determine whether the infection has spread, causing abscesses in other areas. If the infection has spread to other areas within the neck, a CT scan may be used to assess the extent of the infection.
Treatment: To accomplish this, the dentist may: While the area is healing, the dentist may recommend these steps to help ease discomfort: One is likely to start by seeing the dentist. The dentist will make a small cut into the abscess, allowing the pus to drain out, and then wash the area with salt water (saline). To do this, the dentist drills down into the tooth, removes the diseased central tissue (pulp) and drains the abscess. If the affected tooth can't be saved, the dentist will pull (extract) the tooth and drain the abscess to get rid of the infection. But if the infection has spread to nearby teeth, the jaw or other areas, the dentist will likely prescribe antibiotics to stop it from spreading further.

Name: Tooth decay
Overview: Cavities are decayed areas of the teeth that develop into tiny openings or holes. Cavities, also called tooth decay or caries, are caused by a combination of factors, including bacteria in the mouth, frequent snacking, sipping sugary drinks and not cleaning the teeth well.
Causes: When sugars and starches aren't cleaned off the teeth, bacteria quickly begin feeding on them and form plaque. The acids in plaque remove minerals in the tooth's hard, outer enamel. Once areas of enamel are worn away, the bacteria and acid can reach the next layer of the teeth, called dentin.
Risk factors: Everyone who has teeth is at risk of getting cavities, but the following factors can increase risk: Tooth location. Foods that cling to the teeth for a long time such as milk, ice cream, honey, sugar, soda, dried fruit, cake, cookies, hard candy and mints, dry cereal, and chips are more likely to cause decay than foods that are easily washed away by saliva. When one steadily snack or sip sugary drinks, one give mouth bacteria more fuel to produce acids that attack the teeth and wear them down. When babies are given bedtime bottles filled with milk, formula, juice or other sugar-containing liquids, these beverages remain on their teeth for hours while they sleep, feeding decay-causing bacteria. If one don't clean the teeth soon after eating and drinking, plaque forms quickly and the first stages of decay can begin. Fluoride, a naturally occurring mineral, helps prevent cavities and can even reverse the earliest stages of tooth damage. Because of its benefits for teeth, fluoride is added to many public water supplies. Over time, teeth can wear down and gums may recede, making teeth more vulnerable to root decay. Older adults also may use more medications that reduce saliva flow, increasing the risk of tooth decay. Dry mouth is caused by a lack of saliva, which helps prevent tooth decay by washing away food and plaque from the teeth. Certain medications, some medical conditions, radiation to the head or neck, or certain chemotherapy drugs can increase the risk of cavities by reducing saliva production. Heartburn or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) can cause stomach acid to flow into the mouth (reflux), wearing away the enamel of the teeth and causing significant tooth damage.
Treatment: If the cavity just started, a fluoride treatment may help restore the tooth's enamel and can sometimes reverse a cavity in the very early stages. Professional fluoride treatments contain more fluoride than the amount found in tap water, toothpaste and mouth rinses. Fluoride treatments may be liquid, gel, foam or varnish that's brushed onto the teeth or placed in a small tray that fits over the teeth. Fillings are made of various materials, such as tooth-colored composite resins, porcelain or dental amalgam that is a combination of several materials. For extensive decay or weakened teeth, one may need a crown a custom-fitted covering that replaces the tooth's entire natural crown. When decay reaches the inner material of the tooth (pulp), one may need a root canal.
info-Symptoms: Pain, tooth loss, difficulty eating
info-Causes: Bacteria producing acid from food debris
info-Risk factors: Diet high in simple sugar, diabetes mellitus, SjÃ¶gren syndrome, medications that decrease saliva
info-Prevention: Low-sugar diet, teeth brushing, fluoride, flossing

Name: Torn meniscus
Overview: The meniscus is a C-shaped piece of tough, rubbery cartilage that acts as a shock absorber between the shinbone and thighbone. Any activity that causes one to forcefully twist or rotate the knee, especially when putting the full weight on it, can lead to a torn meniscus.
Diagnosis: The doctor might move the knee and leg into different positions, watch one walk and ask one to squat to help pinpoint the cause of the signs and symptoms. If necessary, surgical instruments can be inserted through the arthroscope or through additional small incisions in the knee to trim or repair the tear.

Name: Torsion , testicular
Overview: During testicular torsion a testicle rotates, twisting the spermatic cord that brings blood to the scrotum, the loose bag of skin under the penis that contains the testicles. Testicular torsion occurs when a testicle rotates, twisting the spermatic cord that brings blood to the scrotum.
Causes: Testicular torsion occurs when the testicle rotates on the spermatic cord, which brings blood to the testicle from the abdomen. Testicular torsion often occurs several hours after vigorous activity, after a minor injury to the testicles or while sleeping.
Diagnosis: The doctor will ask one questions to verify whether the signs and symptoms are caused by testicular torsion or something else. Doctors often diagnose testicular torsion with a physical exam of the scrotum, testicles, abdomen and groin. For example: If one has had pain for several hours and the physical exam suggests testicular torsion, one might be taken directly to surgery without any additional testing. But ultrasound doesn't always detect the reduced blood flow, so the test might not rule out testicular torsion. Surgery might be necessary to determine whether the symptoms are caused by testicular torsion or another condition.

Name: Torticollis , spasmodic
Overview: Cervical dystonia, also called spasmodic torticollis, is a painful condition in which the neck muscles contract involuntarily, causing the head to twist or turn to one side. A rare disorder that can occur at any age, cervical dystonia most often occurs in middle-aged people, women more than men.
Risk factors: Risk factors for cervical dystonia include Age. If a close family member has cervical dystonia or some other type of dystonia, one is at higher risk of developing the disorder.
Medication: Botulinum toxin, a paralyzing agent often used to smooth facial wrinkles, can be injected directly into the neck muscles affected by cervical dystonia. To improve results or to help reduce the dosage and frequency of botulinum toxin injections, the doctor might also suggest oral medications that have a muscle-relaxing effect.

Name: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return
Diagnosis: The child's doctor may initially suspect a problem because he or she hears a heart murmur during a routine exam. Most heart murmurs are innocent, meaning that there is no heart defect and the murmur isn't dangerous to the child's health. Some murmurs, however, may mean blood is flowing through the child's heart abnormally because he or she has a heart defect. If it's possible the child has a heart defect, the doctor or the child's doctor may order several tests to see if the child has a heart problem. The child's doctor may use a regular echocardiogram to diagnose a congenital heart defect after the child has been born. In this noninvasive test, the child's doctor performs an ultrasound to produce images of the heart. An echocardiogram allows the doctor to see the child's heart in motion and to identify abnormalities in the heart muscle and valves. In this test, a thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted into a blood vessel at the baby's groin and guided through it into the heart. Catheterization is sometimes necessary because it may give the child's doctor a much more detailed view of the child's heart defect than an echocardiogram. This test allows the doctor to see if the child has a heart defect before he or she is born, allowing the doctor to better plan treatment. This noninvasive test records the electrical activity of the child's heart and can help diagnose heart defects or rhythm problems. The child may have a chest X-ray to see if the heart is enlarged, or if the lungs have extra blood or other fluid in them.
Treatment: A congenital heart defect may have no long-term effect on the child's health in some instances, such defects can safely go untreated. Depending on the type of heart defect the child has, doctors treat congenital heart defects with: Procedures using catheterization. Some children and adults now have their congenital heart defects repaired using catheterization techniques, which allow the repair to be done without surgically opening the chest and heart. In procedures that can be done using catheterization, the doctor inserts a thin tube (catheter) into a leg vein and guides it to the heart with the help of X-ray images. Some mild congenital heart defects, especially those found later in childhood or adulthood, can be treated with medications that help the heart work more efficiently. Drugs known as angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) and beta blockers and medications that cause fluid loss (diuretics) can help ease stress on the heart by lowering blood pressure, heart rate and the amount of fluid in the chest.

Name: Tourette syndrome
Symptoms: Tics sudden, brief, intermittent movements or sounds are the hallmark sign of Tourette syndrome. Tics are classified as: Tics can also involve movement (motor tics) or sounds (vocal tics). These sudden, brief and repetitive tics involve a limited number of muscle groups.
info-Symptoms: Tics
info-Prognosis: 80% will experience improvement to disappearance of tics beginning in late teens
info-Frequency: About 1% of children and adolescentsBetween 0.3% and 1.0% of general population.
info-Medication: Usually none, occasionally neuroleptics and noradrenergics

Name: Toxemia
Symptoms: Blood pressure that exceeds 140/90 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg) or greater documented on two occasions, at least four hours apart is abnormal. Other signs and symptoms of preeclampsia may include Sudden weight gain and swelling (edema) particularly in the face and hands may occur with preeclampsia.
Causes: Causes of this abnormal development may include Preeclampsia is classified as one of four high blood pressure disorders that can occur during pregnancy. Women with gestational hypertension have high blood pressure but no excess protein in their urine or other signs of organ damage.
Risk factors: If one already have chronic hypertension, one has a higher risk of developing preeclampsia. The risk of developing preeclampsia is highest during the first pregnancy. Each pregnancy with a new partner increases the risk of preeclampsia more than does a second or third pregnancy with the same partner. The risk of preeclampsia is higher for very young pregnant women as well as pregnant women older than 35. Black women have a higher risk of developing preeclampsia than women of other races. Having babies less than two years or more than 10 years apart leads to a higher risk of preeclampsia. Having certain conditions before one become pregnant such as chronic high blood pressure, migraines, type 1 or type 2 diabetes, kidney disease, a tendency to develop blood clots, or lupus increases the risk of preeclampsia.
Diagnosis: To diagnose preeclampsia, one has to have high blood pressure and one or more of the following complications after the 20th week of pregnancy: Previously, preeclampsia was only diagnosed if high blood pressure and protein in the urine were present. If the doctor suspects preeclampsia, one may need certain tests, including Protein in the urine (proteinuria) A low platelet count Impaired liver function Signs of kidney problems other than protein in the urine Fluid in the lungs (pulmonary edema) New-onset headaches or visual disturbances Blood tests.
Medication: These medications, called antihypertensives, are used to lower the blood pressure if it's dangerously high. In the hospital, the doctor may perform regular nonstress tests or biophysical profiles to monitor the baby's well-being and measure the volume of amniotic fluid. The readiness of the cervix whether it's beginning to open (dilate), thin (efface) and soften (ripen) also may be a factor in determining whether or when labor will be induced.

Name: Toxic hepatitis
Overview: The liver is the largest internal organ. But toxic hepatitis can permanently damage the liver, leading to irreversible scarring of liver tissue (cirrhosis) and in some cases to liver failure, which can be life-threatening.
Causes: Toxic hepatitis occurs when the liver develops inflammation because of exposure to a toxic substance. Although the liver has a great capacity for regeneration, constant exposure to toxic substances can cause serious, sometimes irreversible harm. Heavy drinking over many years can lead to alcoholic hepatitis inflammation in the liver due to alcohol, which can lead to liver failure. Some herbs considered dangerous to the liver include aloe vera, black cohosh, cascara, chaparral, comfrey, kava and ephedra.
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of toxic hepatitis include Taking over-the-counter pain relievers or certain prescription drugs. Taking a medication or over-the-counter pain reliever that carries a risk of liver damage increases the risk of toxic hepatitis. Chronic infection with a hepatitis virus (hepatitis B, hepatitis C or one of the other extremely rare hepatitis viruses that may persist in the body) makes the liver more vulnerable. Drinking alcohol while taking medications or certain herbal supplements increases the risk of toxicity. Because women seem to metabolize certain toxins more slowly than men do, their livers are exposed to higher blood concentrations of harmful substances for a longer time. Inheriting certain genetic mutations that affect the production and action of the liver enzymes that break down toxins may make one more susceptible to toxic hepatitis.
Diagnosis: The doctor may order blood tests that look for high levels of certain liver enzymes. The doctor may recommend an imaging test to create a picture of the liver using ultrasound, computerized tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). During a liver biopsy, a needle is used to extract a small sample of tissue from the liver.

Name: Toxoplasmosis
Causes: Because T. gondii infectious organisms are excreted only in cat feces, wild and domestic cats are the parasite's ultimate host. Kitchen utensils that come into contact with raw meat can harbor the parasites unless the utensils are washed thoroughly in hot, soapy water.
Risk factors: Many people with HIV/AIDS also have toxoplasmosis, either a recent infection or an old infection that has reactivated. Chemotherapy affects the immune system, making it difficult for the body to fight even minor infections. Medications used to treat certain nonmalignant conditions suppress the immune system and make one more likely to develop complications of toxoplasmosis.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects one has the infection, one may have blood tests that check for antibodies to the parasite. Because these antibody tests can be difficult to interpret, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that all positive results be confirmed by a laboratory that specializes in diagnosing toxoplasmosis. In most cases, a negative toxoplasmosis test result means one has never been infected and therefore aren't immune to the disease. Tests the doctor may recommend include If one has developed a life-threatening illness such as encephalitis, one may need one or more imaging tests to check for lesions or cysts in the brain. In this procedure, which may be done safely after 15 weeks of pregnancy, the doctor uses a fine needle to remove a small amount of fluid from the fluid-filled sac that surrounds the fetus (amniotic sac).
Treatment: But if one is otherwise healthy and have signs and symptoms of acute toxoplasmosis, the doctor may prescribe the following drugs: Pyrimethamine (Daraprim). It may prevent the body from absorbing the B vitamin folate (folic acid, vitamin B-9), especially when one take high doses over a long period.
info-Symptoms: Often none, during pregnancy (birth defects)
info-Risk factors: Eating poorly cooked food, exposure to infected cat feces
info-Treatment: During pregnancy spiramycin or pyrimethamine/sulfadiazine and folinic acid
info-Frequency: Up to 50% of people, 200,000 cases of congenital toxoplasmosis a year

Name: Trachoma
Symptoms: In addition, the lubricating glandular tissue in the lids including the tear-producing glands (lacrimal glands) can be affected. Mild itching and irritation of the eyes and eyelids Discharge from the eyes containing mucus or pus Eyelid swelling Light sensitivity (photophobia) Eye pain Inflammation follicular. In this stage, the eye is now highly infectious and becomes irritated, with a thickening or swelling of the upper eyelid.
Overview: Trachoma (truh-KOH-muh) is a bacterial infection that affects the eyes. Trachoma is contagious, spreading through contact with the eyes, eyelids, and nose or throat secretions of infected people. At first, trachoma may cause mild itching and irritation of the eyes and eyelids.
Risk factors: Poor sanitary conditions and lack of hygiene, such as unclean faces or hands, help spread the disease. In areas where the disease is active, it's most common in children ages 4 to 6. In some areas, women's rate of contracting the disease is two to six times higher than that of men. Populations without access to working latrines a type of communal toilet have a higher incidence of the disease.
info-Symptoms: Eye pain, blindness
info-Risk factors: Crowded living conditions, not enough clean water and toilets

Name: Transient global amnesia
Symptoms: Transient global amnesia is identified by its main symptom, which is the inability to form new memories and to recall the recent past. Although transient global amnesia isn't harmful, there's no easy way to distinguish the condition from the life-threatening illnesses that can also cause sudden memory loss.
Overview: Transient global amnesia is a sudden, temporary episode of memory loss that can't be attributed to a more common neurological condition, such as epilepsy or stroke. During an episode of transient global amnesia, the recall of recent events simply vanishes, so one can't remember where one is or how one got there.
Risk factors: Interestingly, high blood pressure and high cholesterol which are closely linked to strokes are not risk factors for transient global amnesia. If one has migraines, the risk of transient global amnesia is significantly higher than that of someone without migraines.
Treatment: Anyone who experiences sudden loss of memory for all events leading up to the present needs emergency medical care. Because he or she doesn't remember recent events, one will need to provide important information to the doctor.

Name: Transient ischemic attack ( TIA )
Risk factors: Some risk factors for a transient ischemic attack and stroke can't be changed. One can't change the following risk factors for a transient ischemic attack and stroke. One can control or treat a number of factors including certain health conditions and lifestyle choices that increase the risk of a stroke. Having one or more of these risk factors doesn't mean one will have a stroke, but the risk increases if one has two or more of them. But as women age, their risk of a stroke goes up. Sickle-shaped blood cells carry less oxygen and also tend to get stuck in artery walls, hampering blood flow to the brain. However, with proper treatment of sickle cell disease, one can lower the risk of a stroke. The risk of a stroke begins to increase at blood pressure readings higher than 140/90 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg). Obesity, especially carrying extra weight in the abdominal area, increases stroke risk in both men and women. Smoking increases the risk of blood clots, raises the blood pressure and contributes to the development of cholesterol-containing fatty deposits in the arteries (atherosclerosis).
Diagnosis: To help determine the cause of the TIA and to assess the risk of a stroke, the doctor may rely on the following: Physical exam and tests. Or the doctor may use an ophthalmoscope to look for cholesterol fragments or platelet fragments (emboli) in the tiny blood vessels of the retina at the back of the eye. The doctor may check for risk factors of a stroke, including high blood pressure, high cholesterol levels, diabetes and in some cases high levels of the amino acid homocysteine. Or the doctor may use an ophthalmoscope to look for cholesterol fragments or platelet fragments (emboli) in the tiny blood vessels of the retina at the back of the eye.The doctor may check for risk factors of a stroke, including high blood pressure, high cholesterol levels, diabetes and in some cases high levels of the amino acid homocysteine. If the doctor suspects that the carotid artery may be the cause of the TIA, a carotid ultrasound may be considered. The transducer emits sound waves that bounce off different parts of the heart, creating an ultrasound image.Or the doctor may choose to perform another type of echocardiography called a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE). A radiologist inserts a thin, flexible tube (catheter) through a small incision, usually in the groin.The catheter is manipulated through the major arteries and into the carotid or vertebral artery.
Medication: There may be certain situations when the duration of taking both medications together may be extended, such as when the cause of the TIA is a narrowing of a blood vessel located in the head. The doctor may consider prescribing Aggrenox, a combination of low-dose aspirin and the anti-platelet drug dipyridamole, to reduce blood clotting. When blood vessels are injured, sticky platelets begin to form clots, a process completed by clotting proteins in blood plasma.The most frequently used anti-platelet medication is aspirin. An alternative to aspirin is the anti-platelet drug clopidogrel (Plavix).The doctor might prescribe aspirin and clopidogrel to be taken together for about a month after the TIA. There may be certain situations when the duration of taking both medications together may be extended, such as when the cause of the TIA is a narrowing of a blood vessel located in the head.The doctor may consider prescribing Aggrenox, a combination of low-dose aspirin and the anti-platelet drug dipyridamole, to reduce blood clotting.

Name: Transposition of the great arteries
Overview: In transposition of the great arteries, the origins of the main arteries leading away from the heart the aorta and the pulmonary artery are switched (transposed). Transposition of the great arteries is a serious but rare heart defect present at birth (congenital), in which the two main arteries leaving the heart are reversed (transposed).
Causes: However, many people with this condition have other congenital heart defects that may cause symptoms, and these people are usually found to have heart disease as children. The right ventricle may not function well as the main pumping chamber over time, which can lead to heart failure in adults.
Diagnosis: After the baby is born, his or her doctor will immediately suspect a heart defect such as transposition of the great arteries if the baby has blue-tinged skin (cyanosis) or if the baby is having trouble breathing. Sometimes, the bluish skin color isn't as noticeable if the baby has another heart defect, such as a hole in the wall separating the left and right chambers of the heart (septum), that's allowing some oxygen-rich blood to travel through the body. It's also possible the baby could have a patent ductus arteriosus an opening between the heart's two major blood vessels, the aorta and the pulmonary artery that allows oxygen-rich and oxygen-poor blood to mix. The baby's doctor may also suspect a heart defect if he or she hears a heart murmur an abnormal whooshing sound caused by turbulent blood flow. During a cardiac catheterization, the doctor inserts a thin flexible tube (catheter) into an artery or vein in the baby's groin and directs it up to his or her heart. Although a chest X-ray doesn't provide a definitive diagnosis of transposition of the great arteries, it does allow the doctor to see the baby's heart size and the position of the aorta and pulmonary artery.

Name: Transverse myelitis
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of transverse myelitis usually develop over a few hours to a few days and may sometimes progress gradually over several weeks. Typical signs and symptoms include Call the doctor or get emergency medical care if one is experiencing signs and symptoms of transverse myelitis. A number of neurological disorders can cause sensory problems, weakness, and bladder or bowel dysfunction including compression of the spinal cord, which is a surgical emergency. One may feel as if something is tightly wrapping the skin of the chest, abdomen or legs.
Overview: Transverse myelitis is an inflammation of both sides of one section of the spinal cord. There are many different causes of transverse myelitis, including infections and immune system disorders that attack the body's tissues. Other conditions, such as a stroke of the spinal cord, are often confused with transverse myelitis, and these conditions require different treatment approaches.
Causes: Viral, bacterial and fungal infections affecting the spinal cord may cause transverse myelitis. Viruses associated with transverse myelitis are: Other viruses may trigger an autoimmune reaction without directly infecting the spinal cord. Bacterial infections that are associated with transverse myelitis include Bacterial skin infections, gastroenteritis and certain types of bacterial pneumonia also may cause transverse myelitis. However, some people with neuromyelitis optica don't experience eye-related problems and might have only recurrent episodes of transverse myelitis. Transverse myelitis associated with an autoimmune disorder may be a warning sign of neuromyelitis optica.
Diagnosis: These tests, which may indicate inflammation of the spinal cord and rule out other disorders, include the following: Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) uses a needle to draw a small amount of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), the protective fluid that surrounds the spinal cord and brain. Lumbar puncture (spinal tap) uses a needle to draw a small amount of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), the protective fluid that surrounds the spinal cord and brain.
Treatment: It's not certain how this therapy helps people with transverse myelitis, but it may be that plasma exchange removes inflammatory antibodies. Medications that may lessen muscle pain include common pain relievers, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and naproxen sodium (Aleve.) Nerve pain may be treated with antidepressant drugs, such as sertraline (Zoloft), and anticonvulsant drugs, such as gabapentin (Neurontin, Gralise) or pregabalin (Lyrica). The doctor may prescribe other medications as needed to treat problems such as muscle spasticity, urinary or bowel dysfunction, depression, or other complications associated with transverse myelitis. People who have antibodies associated with neuromyelitis optica need ongoing medications, such as corticosteroids and/or immunosuppressants, to reduce their chances of more transverse myelitis attacks or developing optic neuritis.
info-Symptoms: Weakness of the limbs

Name: Traumatic brain injury
Overview: Traumatic brain injury usually results from a violent blow or jolt to the head or body. More-serious traumatic brain injury can result in bruising, torn tissues, bleeding and other physical damage to the brain.
Causes: Common events causing traumatic brain injury include the following: Explosive blasts and other combat injuries. Explosive blasts are a common cause of traumatic brain injury in active-duty military personnel. Traumatic brain injury also results from penetrating wounds, severe blows to the head with shrapnel or debris, and falls or bodily collisions with objects following a blast. Collisions involving cars, motorcycles or bicycles and pedestrians involved in such accidents are a common cause of traumatic brain injury.
Diagnosis: This 15-point test helps a doctor or other emergency medical personnel assess the initial severity of a brain injury by checking a person's ability to follow directions and move their eyes and limbs. If one saw someone sustain an injury or arrived immediately after an injury, one may be able to provide medical personnel with information that's useful in assessing the injured person's condition. Answers to the following questions may be beneficial in judging the severity of injury: Tissue swelling from a traumatic brain injury can increase pressure inside the skull and cause additional damage to the brain. This test is usually the first performed in an emergency room for a suspected traumatic brain injury. A CT scan can quickly visualize fractures and uncover evidence of bleeding in the brain (hemorrhage), blood clots (hematomas), bruised brain tissue (contusions), and brain tissue swelling. This test may be used after the person's condition stabilizes, or if symptoms don't improve soon after the injury.
Medication: The type and duration of rehabilitation is different for everyone, depending on the severity of the brain injury and what part of the brain was injured. Diuretics, given intravenously to people with traumatic brain injury, help reduce pressure inside the brain. This is especially helpful if blood vessels, compressed by increased pressure in the brain, are unable to supply brain cells with normal amounts of nutrients and oxygen. Physiatrist, a doctor trained in physical medicine and rehabilitation, who oversees the entire rehabilitation process, manages medical rehabilitation problems and prescribes medication as needed Occupational therapist, who helps the person learn, relearn or improve skills to perform everyday activities Physical therapist, who helps with mobility and relearning movement patterns, balance and walking Speech and language pathologist, who helps the person improve communication skills and use assistive communication devices if necessary Neuropsychologist, who assesses cognitive impairment and performance, helps the person manage behaviors or learn coping strategies, and provides psychotherapy as needed for emotional and psychological well-being Social worker or case manager, who facilitates access to service agencies, assists with care decisions and planning, and facilitates communication among various professionals, care providers and family members Rehabilitation nurse, who provides ongoing rehabilitation care and services and who helps with discharge planning from the hospital or rehabilitation facility Traumatic brain injury nurse specialist, who helps coordinate care and educates the family about the injury and recovery process Recreational therapist, who assists with time management and leisure activities Vocational counselor, who assesses the ability to return to work and appropriate vocational opportunities and who provides resources for addressing common challenges in the workplace Diuretics. Physiatrist, Occupational therapist, Physical therapist, Speech and language pathologist, Neuropsychologist, Social worker or case manager, Rehabilitation nurse, Traumatic brain injury nurse specialist, Recreational therapist, Vocational counselor,
info-Symptoms: Physical, cognitive, sensory, social, emotional, and behavioral symptoms
info-Risk factors: Old age, alcohol
info-Diagnostic method: Based on neurological exam, medical imaging

Name: Traumatic grief
Overview: Losing a loved one is one of the most distressing and, unfortunately, common experiences people face. But if one is unable to move through these stages more than a year after the death of a loved one, one may have complicated grief.

Name: Traveler 's diarrhea
Overview: The digestive tract stretches from the mouth to the anus. When one visit a place where the climate or sanitary practices are different from thes at home, one has an increased risk of developing traveler's diarrhea.
Causes: It's possible that traveler's diarrhea may stem from the stress of traveling or a change in diet. One typically develop traveler's diarrhea after ingesting food or water that's contaminated with organisms from feces.
Risk factors: High-risk destinations for traveler's diarrhea include areas of: Traveling to Eastern Europe, South Africa and a few Caribbean islands also poses some risk. However, the risk of traveler's diarrhea is generally low in Northern and Western Europe, Japan, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the United States.
Treatment: These medications which include loperamide and drugs containing diphenoxylate provide prompt but temporary relief by reducing muscle spasms in the gastrointestinal tract, slowing the transit time through the digestive system and allowing more time for absorption. Anti-motility medications aren't recommended for infants or people with a fever or bloody diarrhea, as they can delay clearance of the infectious organisms and make the illness worse. Also, stop using anti-motility agents after 48 hours if one has abdominal pain or if the signs or symptoms worsen and the diarrhea continues. Before one leave for the trip, talk to the doctor about taking a prescription with one in case one get a serious bout of traveler's diarrhea. If one has more than four loose stools a day or severe symptoms, including a fever or blood, pus or mucus in the stools, a doctor may prescribe a course of antibiotics.
Remedies: If one do get traveler's diarrhea, avoid caffeine and dairy products, which may worsen symptoms or increase fluid loss. Drink canned fruit juices, weak tea, clear soup, decaffeinated soda or sports drinks to replace lost fluids and minerals. Later, as the diarrhea improves, try a diet of easy-to-eat complex carbohydrates, such as salted crackers, bland cereals, bananas, applesauce, dry toast or bread, rice, potatoes, and plain noodles.

Name: Trichinosis
Overview: Trichinosis (trik-ih-NO-sis), sometimes called trichinellosis (trik-ih-nuh-LOW-sis), is a type of roundworm infection. These parasites primarily infect meat-eating animals (carnivores) such as bears and foxes, or meat- and plant-eating animals (omnivores) such as domestic pigs and wild boars. When humans eat undercooked meat containing trichinella larvae, the larvae mature into adult worms in the small intestine over several weeks.
Diagnosis: Trichinella larvae travel from the small intestine through the arteries to bury themselves inside muscle tissue, so stool sample tests don't often show evidence of the parasite. The doctor may take a blood sample and test it for signs suggesting trichinosis an increase in the number of a certain type of white blood cell (eosinophils) or the formation of antibodies against the parasite after several weeks.
Treatment: If the trichinella parasite is discovered early, albendazole (Albenza) or mebendazole (Emverm) can be effective in eliminating the worms and larvae in the intestine. If the disease is discovered after the larvae bury themselves in muscle tissues, the benefit of anti-parasitic medications is less certain. After muscle invasion, the doctor may prescribe pain relievers to help relieve muscle aches. Eventually, the larvae cysts in the muscles tend to calcify, resulting in destruction of the larvae and the end of muscle aches and fatigue.
info-Symptoms: Initially: diarrhea, abdominal pain, vomitingLater: swelling of the face, inflammation of the whites of the eyes, fever, muscle pains, rash
info-Diagnostic method: Antibodies in the blood, larvae on tissue biopsy

Name: Trichotillomania ( hair-pulling disorder )
Symptoms: Sometimes pulling hairs from pets or dolls or from materials, such as clothes or blankets, may be a sign. For people with trichotillomania, hair pulling can be: The same person may do both focused and automatic hair pulling, depending on the situation and mood. Certain positions or rituals may trigger hair pulling, such as resting the head on the hand or brushing the hair. Some people pull their hair intentionally to relieve tension or distress for example, pulling hair out to get relief from the overwhelming urge to pull hair. Some people may develop elaborate rituals for pulling hair, such as finding just the right hair or biting pulled hairs.
Risk factors: These factors tend to increase the risk of trichotillomania: Although far more women than men are treated for trichotillomania, this may be because women are more likely to seek medical advice. Genetics may play a role in the development of trichotillomania, and the disorder may occur in those who have a close relative with the disorder. People who have trichotillomania may also have other disorders, such as depression, anxiety or obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

Name: Tricuspid atresia
Causes: The lower chambers, the more muscular right and left ventricles, pump blood out of the heart. The right side of the heart moves blood to the lungs, where it picks up oxygen before it circulates to the heart's left side. In tricuspid atresia, the right side of the heart can't pump enough blood to the lungs because the tricuspid valve is missing. However, the valve between the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery (pulmonary valve) might be narrowed, which can reduce blood flow to the lungs.
Diagnosis: The baby's doctor might suspect a heart defect, such as tricuspid atresia, if the newborn has blue-tinged skin or is having trouble breathing. Another indication is hearing a heart murmur, an abnormal whooshing sound caused by blood not flowing properly, when listening to the baby's heart during a physical exam. If tricuspid atresia is suspected, the baby's doctor might order tests including Echocardiogram. In a baby with tricuspid atresia, the echocardiogram reveals the absence of a tricuspid valve, irregular blood flow and other heart defects. A thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted into a blood vessel at the child's groin and guided into the heart. Rarely used to diagnose tricuspid atresia, this test might be used to examine the heart before surgery to treat tricuspid atresia.
Remedies: The or the child's cardiologist will likely recommend preventive antibiotics be taken before certain dental and other procedures to prevent bacteria from infecting the inner lining of the heart (infective endocarditis). If one is an adult with tricuspid atresia, one need to be seen regularly throughout the life by a doctor trained in adult congenital heart conditions. If one do become pregnant, it's best to see a doctor who specializes in pregnancies in women with congenital heart disease. The or the child's cardiologist will likely recommend preventive antibiotics be taken before certain dental and other procedures to prevent bacteria from infecting the inner lining of the heart (infective endocarditis).Practicing good oral hygiene brushing and flossing teeth, getting regular dental checkups also helps prevent infection.

Name: Tricuspid valve disease
Overview: The heart has two upper and two lower chambers. Tricuspid valve disease is a condition in which the valve between the two right heart chambers (right ventricle and right atrium) doesn't function properly. In this condition, the tricuspid valve doesn't close properly, and blood flows back into the heart's upper right chamber (right atrium). In this condition, the tricuspid valve is narrowed, decreasing the amount of blood that can flow through it from the right atrium to the lower right heart chamber (right ventricle). In tricuspid atresia a condition present at birth (congenital) the tricuspid valve isn't formed, and a solid sheet of tissue blocks the blood flow between the right heart chambers.

Name: Tricuspid valve regurgitation
Overview: In tricuspid valve regurgitation, shown in the heart on the right, the valve between the two right heart chambers (right ventricle and right atrium) doesn't close properly. Tricuspid valve regurgitation is a condition in which the valve between the two right heart chambers (right ventricle and right atrium) doesn't close properly. Tricuspid valve regurgitation can be the result of a condition one is born with (congenital heart disease), or it can occur due to valve abnormalities caused by other conditions.
Causes: Tricuspid valve regurgitation can also occur with heart conditions that affect the left side of the heart, such as left-sided heart failure that leads to right-sided heart failure. In this rare condition, the malformed tricuspid valve sits lower than normal in the right ventricle, and the tricuspid valve's leaflets are abnormally formed. Tricuspid valve regurgitation in children is usually caused by heart disease present at birth (congenital heart disease). The lower chambers, the more muscular right and left ventricles, pump blood out of the heart. The tricuspid valve which lies between the two chambers on the right side of the heart consists of three flaps of tissue called leaflets. The tricuspid valve may be damaged by an infection of the lining of the heart (infective endocarditis) that can involve heart valves. Experiencing trauma to the chest, such as in a car accident, can lead to tricuspid valve regurgitation. Rheumatic fever is a complication of untreated strep throat that can damage heart valves, including the tricuspid valve, leading to tricuspid valve regurgitation later in life. Some heart defects present at birth (congenital) may affect the tricuspid valve. Marfan syndrome, a genetic disorder of connective tissue present at birth, is occasionally associated with tricuspid valve regurgitation.
Risk factors: Several factors can increase the risk of tricuspid valve regurgitation, including Infections such as infective endocarditis or rheumatic fever. Heart failure can increase the risk of developing tricuspid valve regurgitation. High blood pressure in the arteries in the lungs (pulmonary hypertension) can increase the risk of tricuspid valve regurgitation. Several forms of heart disease and heart valve disease may increase the risk of developing tricuspid valve regurgitation. One may be born with a condition or heart defect that affects the tricuspid valve, such as Ebstein's anomaly. If one has used stimulant medications such as fenfluramine (no longer sold on the market) or some medications for Parkinson's disease, such as pergolide (no longer sold in the United States) or cabergoline, or certain migraine medications (ergot alkaloids), one may have an increased risk of tricuspid valve regurgitation.
Diagnosis: The doctor may order several tests to diagnose tricuspid valve regurgitation, determine the severity and cause of the condition, and develop an appropriate treatment plan. In this procedure, doctors insert a long, thin tube (catheter) into a blood vessel in the groin, arm or neck and guide it to the heart using X-ray imaging. A special dye injected through the catheter helps the doctor see the blood flow through the heart, blood vessels and valves, and allows the doctor to check for abnormalities inside the heart and lungs.
Remedies: The doctor may recommend that one make some lifestyle changes to improve the heart health and to live with tricuspid valve regurgitation, including Prepare for pregnancy. If one has tricuspid valve regurgitation and one is thinking about becoming pregnant, talk with the doctor first. If one has severe tricuspid valve regurgitation, one will need to be monitored by a cardiologist and medical team experienced in treating women with heart valve conditions during pregnancy. If the condition is due to a congenital heart condition, such as Ebstein's anomaly, one may need to be evaluated by a doctor trained in congenital heart disease. The amount and type of exercise the doctor recommends for one may depend on the condition, if one has other heart valve conditions and if the condition is caused by other conditions. If one has had a heart valve replaced, the doctor may recommend one take antibiotics before dental procedures to prevent an infection called infective endocarditis.

Name: Trigeminal neuralgia
Diagnosis: The doctor will diagnose trigeminal neuralgia mainly based on the description of the pain, including The doctor may conduct many tests to diagnose trigeminal neuralgia and determine underlying causes for the condition, including The facial pain may be caused by many different conditions, so an accurate diagnosis is important. Touching and examining parts of the face can help the doctor determine exactly where the pain is occurring and if one appear to have trigeminal neuralgia which branches of the trigeminal nerve may be affected. The doctor may order an MRI scan of the head to determine if multiple sclerosis or a tumor is causing trigeminal neuralgia. In some cases, the doctor may inject a dye into a blood vessel to view the arteries and veins and highlight blood flow (magnetic resonance angiogram).
Medication: To treat trigeminal neuralgia, the doctor usually will prescribe medications to lessen or block the pain signals sent to the brain. Doctors usually prescribe carbamazepine (Tegretol, Carbatrol, others) for trigeminal neuralgia, and it's been shown to be effective in treating the condition. Other anticonvulsant drugs that may be used to treat trigeminal neuralgia include oxcarbazepine (Trileptal), lamotrigine (Lamictal) and phenytoin (Dilantin, Phenytek). Doctors may also cut part of the trigeminal nerve (neurectomy) during this procedure if arteries aren't pressing on the nerve. In this procedure, a surgeon directs a focused dose of radiation to the root of the trigeminal nerve. In a rhizotomy, the surgeon destroys nerve fibers to reduce pain, and this causes some facial numbness. The doctor guides the needle into the trigeminal cistern, a small sac of spinal fluid that surrounds the trigeminal nerve ganglion where the trigeminal nerve divides into three branches and part of its root. Then, the doctor will inject a small amount of sterile glycerol, which damages the trigeminal nerve and blocks pain signals. In balloon compression, the doctor inserts a hollow needle through the face and guides it to a part of the trigeminal nerve that goes through the base of the skull. While one is sedated, the surgeon inserts a hollow needle through the face and guides it to a part of the trigeminal nerve that goes through an opening at the base of the skull.
info-Symptoms: Typical: episodes of severe, sudden, shock-like pain in one side of the face that lasts for seconds to minutesAtypical: constant burning pain
info-Causes: Believed to be due to problems with myelin of trigeminal nerve

Name: Trigger finger
Risk factors: Factors that put one at risk of developing trigger finger include Repeated gripping. Occupations and hobbies that involve repetitive hand use and prolonged gripping may increase the risk of trigger finger. Trigger finger may be a complication associated with surgery for carpal tunnel syndrome surgery, especially during the first six months after surgery.
Medication: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB) or naproxen (Aleve) may relieve the pain but are unlikely to relieve the swelling constricting the tendon sheath or trapping the tendon. Conservative noninvasive treatments may include If the symptoms are severe or if conservative treatments haven't helped, the doctor might suggest: Steroid injection. An injection of a steroid medication near or into the tendon sheath may reduce inflammation and allow the tendon to glide freely again. This treatment may be done under ultrasound control, so the doctor can see where the tip of the needle is under the skin to be sure it opens the tendon sheath without damaging the tendon or nearby nerves. Working through a small incision near the base of the affected finger, a surgeon can cut open the constricted section of tendon sheath.
info-Specialty: Hand surgery, orthopedic surgery, and plastic surgery
info-Symptoms: Catching or locking of the involved finger, pain
info-Risk factors: Repeated injury, diabetes, kidney disease, thyroid disease, inflammatory disease
info-Treatment: Rest, splinting the finger, NSAIDs, steroid injections, surgery

Name: Trisomy 21 syndrome
Overview: There are 23 pairs of chromosomes, for a total of 46. Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused when abnormal cell division results in an extra full or partial copy of chromosome 21.
Causes: Down syndrome results when abnormal cell division involving chromosome 21 occurs. When balanced translocations are inherited, the mother or father has some rearranged genetic material from chromosome 21 on another chromosome, but no extra genetic material. In this rare form of Down syndrome, a person has only some cells with an extra copy of chromosome 21. Down syndrome can also occur when a portion of chromosome 21 becomes attached (translocated) onto another chromosome, before or at conception. These children have the usual two copies of chromosome 21, but they also have additional genetic material from chromosome 21 attached to another chromosome.
