Diagnosis: The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends offering the option of screening tests and diagnostic tests for Down syndrome to all pregnant women, regardless of age. The health care provider can discuss the types of tests, advantages and disadvantages, benefits and risks, and the meaning of the results. Although screening tests can only identify the risk of carrying a baby with Down syndrome, they can help one make decisions about more-specific diagnostic tests. The first trimester combined test, which is done in two steps, includes: Using the age and the results of the blood test and the ultrasound, the doctor or genetic counselor can estimate the risk of having a baby with Down syndrome. If the screening test results are positive or worrisome, or one is at high risk of having a baby with Down syndrome, one might consider more testing to confirm the diagnosis. Diagnostic tests that can identify Down syndrome include Preimplantation genetic diagnosis is an option for couples undergoing in vitro fertilization who are at increased risk of passing along certain genetic conditions. But the features associated with Down syndrome can be found in babies without Down syndrome, so the health care provider will likely order a test called a chromosomal karyotype to confirm diagnosis. The quad screen measures the blood level of four pregnancy-associated substances: alpha fetoprotein, estriol, HCG and inhibin A. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS). Amniocentesis Chorionic villus sampling Cordocentesis Genetic testing Prenatal cell-free DNA screening Ultrasound Screening tests Diagnostic tests Blood test.
info-Symptoms: Delayed physical growth, characteristic facial features, mild to moderate intellectual disability
info-Risk factors: Older age of mother, prior affected child

Name: Trouble swallowing
Overview: The esophagus is a muscular tube that connects the mouth and the stomach. Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) means it takes more time and effort to move food or liquid from the mouth to the stomach. Occasional difficulty swallowing, which may occur when one eat too fast or don't chew the food well enough, usually isn't cause for concern.
Causes: Muscles in the wall of the esophagus may be weak as well, a condition that tends to worsen over time. This condition produces multiple high-pressure, poorly coordinated contractions of the esophagus, usually after one swallow. Tumors or scar tissue, often caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), can cause narrowing. Older adults with dentures and people who have difficulty chewing their food may be more likely to have a piece of food become lodged in the throat or esophagus. A thin area of narrowing in the lower esophagus can intermittently cause difficulty swallowing solid foods. Damage to esophageal tissues from stomach acid backing up into the esophagus can lead to spasm or scarring and narrowing of the lower esophagus. This condition, which may be related to a food allergy, is caused by an overpopulation of cells called eosinophils in the esophagus. Certain disorders such as multiple sclerosis, muscular dystrophy and Parkinson's disease can cause dysphagia. Certain cancers and some cancer treatments, such as radiation, can cause difficulty swallowing.
Diagnosis: The doctor may also have one swallow solid food or a pill coated with barium to watch the muscles in the throat as one swallow or to look for blockages in the esophagus that the liquid barium solution may not identify. A thin, flexible lighted instrument (endoscope) is passed down the throat so that the doctor can see the esophagus. The doctor may examine the throat with a special camera and lighted tube (endoscope) as one try to swallow. In manometry (muh-NOM-uh-tree), a small tube is inserted into the esophagus and connected to a pressure recorder to measure the muscle contractions of the esophagus as one swallow. These may include a CT scan, which combines a series of X-ray views and computer processing to create cross-sectional images of the body's bones and soft tissues, or an MRI scan, which uses a magnetic field and radio waves to create detailed images of organs and tissues.
Remedies: Also, some things one can try to help ease the symptoms include Changing the eating habits. Thin liquids, such as coffee and juice, are a problem for some people, and sticky foods, such as peanut butter or caramel, can make swallowing difficult.
info-Symptoms: Inability or difficulty swallowing
info-Causes: Esophageal cancer, Esophagitis, Stomach cancer, mental illness, alcoholism, refeeding syndrome, starvation, infection, gastritis, malnutrition

Name: Truncus arteriosus
Causes: At a certain point, all babies have a single large vessel (truncus arteriosus) exiting the heart. The left ventricle, the lower left chamber, pumps the oxygen-rich blood through a large vessel called the aorta and on to the rest of the body.
Risk factors: While the exact cause of congenital heart defects, such as truncus arteriosus, is unknown, several factors may increase the risk of a baby being born with a heart condition. If a woman contracts rubella (German measles) or another viral illness during early pregnancy, the risk of congenital heart defects in her baby is increased. Diabetes that isn't well-managed can increase the risk of birth defects, including heart defects.
Diagnosis: In order for the pediatric or adult congenital cardiologist to check the condition of the or the baby's heart and make a diagnosis, he or she will order one or more tests: Echocardiogram. In a baby with truncus arteriosus, the echocardiogram reveals the single large vessel leading from the heart, a hole in the wall between the left and right ventricles, and abnormalities in the valve between the large vessel and the ventricles. The test can also show how much blood is flowing to the baby's lungs, and whether there's a risk of high blood pressure in the lungs.
Medication: Most commonly the baby's surgeon will: After corrective surgery, the child will need lifelong follow-up care with a cardiologist to monitor his or her heart health. Newer minimally invasive procedures use a cardiac catheter to avoid the need for traditional heart surgery as the child grows or previously placed artificial valves deteriorate. In addition, cardiac catheterization with an inflatable balloon tip can be used to open up an obstructed or narrowed artery, which may delay the need for follow-up surgery. Close the hole between the two ventricles with a patch Separate the upper portion of the pulmonary artery from the single large vessel Implant a tube (conduit) and valve to connect the right ventricle with the upper portion of the pulmonary artery creating a new, complete pulmonary artery Reconstruct the single large vessel and aorta to create a new, complete aorta Diuretics.

Name: Trypanosomiasis , American
Causes: Infected bugs defecate after feeding, leaving behind T. cruzi parasites on the skin.
Treatment: During the acute phase of Chagas disease, the prescription medications benznidazole and nifurtimox may be of benefit. Although benznidazole is approved by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) for use in children ages 2 to 12, it's not yet available in United States pharmacies. But, the drugs may be offered to people younger than age 50 because they may help slow the progression of the disease and its most serious complications.

Name: Tuberculosis
Symptoms: Although the body may harbor the bacteria that cause tuberculosis (TB), the immune system usually can prevent one from becoming sick. In this condition, one has a TB infection, but the bacteria remain in the body in an inactive state and cause no symptoms. Latent TB, also called inactive TB or TB infection, isn't contagious.
Overview: Tuberculosis (TB) is a potentially serious infectious disease that mainly affects the lungs. Once rare in developed countries, tuberculosis infections began increasing in 1985, partly because of the emergence of HIV, the virus that causes AIDS.
Risk factors: These factors include A healthy immune system often successfully fights TB bacteria, but the body can't mount an effective defense if the resistance is low. A number of diseases, conditions and medications can weaken the immune system, including The risk of contracting tuberculosis is higher for people who live in or travel to areas that have high rates of tuberculosis and drug-resistant tuberculosis, including HIV/AIDS Diabetes Severe kidney disease Certain cancers Cancer treatment, such as chemotherapy Drugs to prevent rejection of transplanted organs Some drugs used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn's disease and psoriasis Malnutrition Very young or advanced age Africa Eastern Europe Asia Russia Latin America Caribbean Islands Lack of medical care. If one receive a low or fixed income, live in a remote area, have recently immigrated to the United States, or are homeless, one may lack access to the medical care needed to diagnose and treat TB. People who live or work in prisons, homeless shelters, psychiatric hospitals or nursing homes are all at a higher risk of tuberculosis.
Diagnosis: The most commonly used diagnostic tool for tuberculosis is a simple skin test, though blood tests are becoming more commonplace. False-negative results may occur in certain populations including children, older people and people with AIDS who sometimes don't respond to the TB skin test. A false-negative result can also occur in people whove recently been infected with TB, but whose immune systems haven't yet reacted to the bacteria. A blood test may be useful if one is at high risk of TB infection but have a negative response to the skin test, or if one has recently received the BCG vaccine. This may show white spots in the lungs where the immune system has walled off TB bacteria, or it may reveal changes in the lungs caused by active tuberculosis.
info-Symptoms: Chronic cough, fever, cough with bloody mucus, weight loss
info-Risk factors: Smoking, HIV/AIDS
info-Prevention: Screening those at high risk, treatment of those infected, vaccination with bacillus Calmette-GuÃ©rin (BCG)

Name: Tuberous sclerosis
Symptoms: Although the signs and symptoms are unique for each person with tuberous sclerosis, they can include Signs and symptoms of tuberous sclerosis may be noticed at birth. Contact the child's doctor if one is concerned about the child's development or one notice any of the signs or symptoms of tuberous sclerosis described above. Signs and symptoms of tuberous sclerosis may be noticed at birth. Growths in the brain may be associated with seizures, which can be the first symptom of tuberous sclerosis. Common behavioral problems may include hyperactivity, self-injury or aggression, or issues with social and emotional adjustment. Most people with tuberous sclerosis develop noncancerous growths on their kidneys, and they may develop more growths as they age. Growths that develop in the lungs may cause coughing or shortness of breath, especially with physical activity or exercise.
Risk factors: Tuberous sclerosis can be the result of either: If one has tuberous sclerosis, one has up to a 50 percent chance of passing the condition to the biological children. About two-thirds of people who have tuberous sclerosis have a new mutation in either the TSC1 or TSC2 gene the genes associated with tuberous sclerosis and do not have a family history of tuberous sclerosis. About one-third of people who have tuberous sclerosis inherit an altered TSC1 or TSC2 gene from a parent who has the disorder.
Diagnosis: Depending on the child's signs and symptoms, he or she may be evaluated by several different specialists with expertise in tuberous sclerosis, such as doctors trained to treat problems of the brain (neurologist), heart (cardiologist), eyes (ophthalmologist), skin (dermatologist), kidneys (nephrologist), and other specialists. The child's doctors will do a physical exam, discuss symptoms and family history, and look for typical growths (benign tumors), commonly associated with tuberous sclerosis. To detect growths or tumors in the body, diagnostic testing will likely include To determine whether the child's heart is affected, diagnostic testing will likely include A light and magnifying lens are used to examine the inside of the eye, including the retina. Parents may also consider genetic testing to confirm the diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis in their child, and to understand the risk of tuberous sclerosis for their other children and any future children.
Treatment: Other medications may help manage heart arrhythmias, behavior problems or other signs and symptoms. A drug called everolimus (Afinitor, Zortress) may be used to treat certain types of brain and kidney growths that can't be surgically removed. Early intervention services, such as occupational, physical or speech therapy, can help children with tuberous sclerosis who have special needs in these areas improve their ability to manage daily tasks and activities.

Name: Tularemia
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms include People with glandular tularemia have the same signs and symptoms of ulceroglandular tularemia, but without skin ulcers. Signs and symptoms include This type of tularemia causes signs and symptoms typical of pneumonia: Other forms of tularemia also can spread to the lungs.
Causes: However, tularemia occurs worldwide, especially in rural areas, because many mammals, birds and insects are infected with F. tularensis. Unlike some infectious diseases that spread from animals to people through a single route, tularemia has several modes of transmission. In general, one can get tularemia through: Contaminated food or water. Although uncommon, it's possible to get tularemia from eating undercooked meat of an infected animal or drinking contaminated water. Although a number of insects carry tularemia, ticks and deer flies are most likely to transmit the disease to humans. Ulceroglandular tularemia can also result from handling or being bitten by an infected animal, most often a rabbit or hare.
Risk factors: Although anyone of any age can develop tularemia, engaging in certain occupations or activities or living in certain areas pose a greater risk. Because hunters are exposed to wild animal blood and may eat their flesh, they're at risk of tularemia.
Diagnosis: Doctors may check for F. tularensis in a blood or sputum sample that's cultured to encourage the growth of the bacteria. Sometimes tularemia can be identified by antibodies to the bacteria in a sample of blood, but these only develop several weeks after infection.
info-Symptoms: Fever, skin ulcer, large lymph nodes
info-Causes: Francisella tularensis (spread by ticks, deer flies, contact with infected animals)
info-Prevention: Insect repellent, wearing long pants, rapidly removing ticks, not disturbing dead animals

Name: Tumor , salivary gland
Overview: One has three pairs of major salivary glands parotid, sublingual and submandibular. One has three pairs of major salivary glands under and behind the jaw parotid, sublingual and submandibular.
Causes: Salivary gland tumors begin when some cells in a salivary gland develop changes (mutations) in their DNA. Doctors classify salivary gland tumors based on the type of cells involved in the tumors.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose salivary gland tumors include If one is diagnosed with salivary gland cancer, the doctor will determine the extent (stage) of the cancer. Imaging tests, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), computerized tomography (CT), positron emission tomography (PET), ultrasound or X-ray, may help the doctor determine the size and location of the salivary gland tumor.

Name: Turner syndrome
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of Turner syndrome may vary among girls and women with the disorder. Signs and symptoms can be subtle, developing slowly over time, or significant, such as heart defects. Signs and symptoms of these include Sometimes it's difficult to distinguish the signs and symptoms of Turner syndrome from other disorders.
Causes: In girls who have Turner syndrome, one copy of the X chromosome is missing, partially missing or altered. The complete absence of an X chromosome generally occurs because of an error in the father's sperm or in the mother's egg. Other cells have only one copy of the X chromosome.
Diagnosis: If, based on signs and symptoms, the doctor suspects that the child has Turner syndrome, a lab test will typically be done to analyze the child's chromosomes. Prenatal screening tests that evaluate the baby's DNA in the mother's blood (prenatal cell-free DNA screening or noninvasive prenatal screening) may also indicate an increased risk of Turner syndrome. The pregnancy and childbirth specialist (obstetrician) may ask if one is interested in additional tests to make a diagnosis before the baby's birth.
Treatment: The primary treatments for nearly all girls and women with Turner syndrome include hormone therapies: Other treatments are tailored to address the child's particular problems as needed. For most girls, growth hormone therapy usually given daily as injections of recombinant human growth hormone is recommended to increase height as much as possible at appropriate times during early childhood until the early teen years.
info-Symptoms: Webbed neck, short stature, swollen hands and feet
info-Medication: Human growth hormone, estrogen replacement therapy

Name: Type 1 diabetes
Causes: Other possible causes include Once a significant number of islet cells are destroyed, one will produce little or no insulin. In type 1 diabetes, there's no insulin to let glucose into the cells, so sugar builds up in the bloodstream. Sugar is absorbed into the bloodstream, where it enters cells with the help of insulin.
Risk factors: Some known risk factors for type 1 diabetes include Family history. Anyone with a parent or sibling with type 1 diabetes has a slightly increased risk of developing the condition. The presence of certain genes indicates an increased risk of developing type 1 diabetes. Although type 1 diabetes can appear at any age, it appears at two noticeable peaks.
Diagnosis: Diagnostic tests include If the A1C test isn't available, or if one has certain conditions that can make the A1C test inaccurate such as pregnancy or an uncommon form of hemoglobin (hemoglobin variant) the doctor may use these tests: If one is diagnosed with diabetes, the doctor may also run blood tests to check for autoantibodies that are common in type 1 diabetes. The target A1C goal may vary depending on the age and various other factors, but the American Diabetes Association generally recommends that A1C levels be below 7 percent, which translates to an estimated average glucose of 154 mg/dL (8.5 mmol/L). Compared with repeated daily blood sugar tests, A1C testing better indicates how well the diabetes treatment plan is working. In addition to the A1C test, the doctor will also take blood and urine samples periodically to check the cholesterol levels, thyroid function, liver function and kidney function. Regardless of when one last ate, a random blood sugar level of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher suggests diabetes, especially when coupled with any of the signs and symptoms of diabetes, such as frequent urination and extreme thirst.
Remedies: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends hepatitis B vaccination if one hasn't previously been vaccinated against hepatitis B and one is an adult ages 19 to 59 with type 1 or type 2 diabetes. If one is age 60 or older and have diabetes and haven't previously received the vaccine, talk to the doctor about whether it's right for one. During the physical, the doctor will look for any diabetes-related complications, as well as screen for other medical problems. Smoking increases the risk of diabetes complications, including heart attack, stroke, nerve damage and kidney disease. Alcohol can cause either high or low blood sugar, depending on how much one drink and if one eat at the same time.
info-Symptoms: Frequent urination, increased thirst, increased hunger, weight loss
info-Causes: Body does not produce enough insulin
info-Risk factors: Family history, celiac disease

Name: Type 1 diabetes in children
Overview: Type 1 diabetes in children is a condition in which the child's body no longer produces an important hormone (insulin). Advances in blood sugar monitoring and insulin delivery have improved blood sugar management and quality of life for children with type 1 diabetes.
Causes: Insulin performs the critical job of moving sugar (glucose) from the bloodstream to the body's cells. Without enough insulin, sugar builds up in the child's bloodstream, where it can cause life-threatening complications if left untreated.
Risk factors: Risk factors for type 1 diabetes in children include Family history. Anyone with a parent or siblings with type 1 diabetes has a slightly increased risk of developing the condition. Certain genes indicate an increased risk of type 1 diabetes. In the United States, type 1 diabetes is more common among white children of non-Hispanic descent than among children of other races.
Diagnosis: There are several blood tests for type 1 diabetes in children: If blood sugar testing indicates diabetes, the doctor will likely recommend additional tests to distinguish between type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes because treatment strategies differ by type. A blood sugar level of 200 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 11.1 millimoles per liter (mmol/L), or higher suggests diabetes. A fasting blood sugar level of 126 mg/dL (7.0 mmol/L) or higher suggests type 1 diabetes. Blood tests to check for antibodies that are common in type 1 diabetes Urine or blood tests to check for the presence of ketones, which also suggests type 1 diabetes rather than type 2 A1C test Random blood sugar test.
Remedies: One will need to work with the child's school nurse and teachers to make sure they know the symptoms of high and low blood sugar levels. Encourage him or her to take an increasingly active role in diabetes management Stress the importance of lifelong diabetes care Teach the child how to test his or her blood sugar and inject insulin Help the child make wise food choices Encourage the child to remain physically active Foster a relationship between the child and his or her diabetes treatment team Make sure the child wears a medical identification tag Carbohydrate counting

Name: Type 2 diabetes
Overview: Type 2 diabetes is a chronic condition that affects the way the body metabolizes sugar (glucose) an important source of fuel for the body. With type 2 diabetes, the body either resists the effects of insulin a hormone that regulates the movement of sugar into the cells or doesn't produce enough insulin to maintain normal glucose levels.
Causes: In the much less common type 1 diabetes, the immune system mistakenly destroys the beta cells, leaving the body with little to no insulin. Sugar is absorbed into the bloodstream, where it enters cells with the help of insulin.
Risk factors: However, one don't have to be overweight to develop type 2 diabetes. If one store fat mainly in the abdomen, one has a greater risk of type 2 diabetes than if one store fat elsewhere, such as in the hips and thighs. The risk of type 2 diabetes rises if one is a man with a waist circumference above 40 inches (101.6 centimeters) or a woman with a waist that's greater than 35 inches (88.9 centimeters). The less active one is, the greater the risk of type 2 diabetes. Although it's unclear why, people of certain races including black, Hispanic, American Indian and Asian-American people are more likely to develop type 2 diabetes than white people are. The risk of type 2 diabetes increases as one get older, especially after age 45. But type 2 diabetes is also increasing dramatically among children, adolescents and younger adults. Left untreated, prediabetes often progresses to type 2 diabetes. If one developed gestational diabetes when one were pregnant, the risk of developing type 2 diabetes increases. If one gave birth to a baby weighing more than 9 pounds (4 kilograms), one is also at risk of type 2 diabetes. For women, having polycystic ovarian syndrome a common condition characterized by irregular menstrual periods, excess hair growth and obesity increases the risk of diabetes.
Diagnosis: Type 2 diabetes is usually diagnosed using the: If the A1C test isn't available, or if one has certain conditions such as an uncommon form of hemoglobin (known as a hemoglobin variant) that interfere with A1C test, the doctor may use the following tests to diagnose diabetes: Fasting blood sugar test. If the fasting blood sugar is 126 mg/dL (7 mmol/L) or higher on two separate tests, one has diabetes. Screening is also recommended for people who are under 45 and overweight if there are other heart disease or diabetes risk factors present, such as a sedentary lifestyle, a family history of type 2 diabetes, a personal history of gestational diabetes or blood pressure above 140/90 millimeters of mercury (mm Hg). In addition to the A1C test, the doctor will measure the blood pressure and take blood and urine samples periodically to check the cholesterol levels, thyroid function, liver function and kidney function. Regardless of when one last ate, a blood sample showing that the blood sugar level is 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher suggests diabetes, especially if one also have signs and symptoms of diabetes, such as frequent urination and extreme thirst.
Remedies: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) also recommends the hepatitis B vaccination if one hasn't previously received this vaccine and one is an adult between ages 19 and 59 with type 1 or type 2 diabetes. If one is age 60 or older, have diabetes and haven't previously received the vaccine, talk to the doctor about whether it's right for one. Alcohol, as well as drink mixers, can cause either high or low blood sugar, depending on how much one drink and if one eat at the same time. The recommendation is no more than one drink daily for women, no more than two drinks daily for men age 65 and younger, and one drink a day for men over 65. If one is on insulin or other medications that lower the blood sugar, check the blood sugar before one go to sleep to make sure one is at a safe level. Establish a relationship with a diabetes educator, and ask the diabetes treatment team for help when one need it. Wear a necklace or bracelet that says one has diabetes, especially if one take insulin or other blood sugar-lowering medication.
info-Symptoms: Increased thirst, frequent urination, unexplained weight loss, increased hunger
info-Prevention: Maintaining normal weight, exercising, eating properly
info-Treatment: Dietary changes, metformin, insulin, bariatric surgery

Name: Type 2 diabetes in children
Symptoms: Type 2 diabetes in children may develop so gradually that there are no noticeable symptoms. Other children might experience: See the child's doctor if one notice any of the signs or symptoms of type 2 diabetes. If the child's blood sugar is too high, fluid may be pulled from the lenses of the child's eyes. Before type 2 diabetes develops, certain areas of the skin begin to darken. However, weight loss is less common in children with type 2 diabetes than in children with type 1 diabetes.
Overview: Type 2 diabetes in children is a chronic disease that affects the way the child's body processes sugar (glucose). If diet and exercise aren't enough to control type 2 diabetes in children, oral medication or insulin treatment may be needed.
Causes: Moving sugar from the bloodstream to the body's cells requires the hormone insulin. As insulin circulates, it allows sugar to enter the cells lowering the amount of sugar in the bloodstream. Type 2 diabetes develops when the body becomes resistant to insulin or when the pancreas stops making enough insulin.
Risk factors: Researchers don't fully understand why some children develop type 2 diabetes and others don't, even if they have similar risk factors. Being overweight is a strong risk factor for type 2 diabetes in children. The less active the child is, the greater his or her risk of type 2 diabetes. Children's risk of type 2 diabetes increases if they have a parent or sibling with the disease. Although it's unclear why, people of certain races including African Americans, Hispanics, Native Americans, Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders are more likely to develop type 2 diabetes. Low birth weight and being born to a mother who had gestational diabetes during the pregnancy are both associated with a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Babies born prematurely before 39 to 42 weeks gestation have a greater risk of type 2 diabetes.
Diagnosis: Regardless of when the child last ate, a random blood sugar level of 200 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL), or 11.1 millimoles per liter (mmol/L), or higher suggests diabetes. A fasting blood sugar level of 126 milligrams per deciliter (mg/dL) (7.0 millimoles per liter or mmol/L) or higher indicates type 2 diabetes. A blood sugar level of 200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) or higher generally means the child has type 2 diabetes.

Name: Typhoid fever
Overview: Typhoid fever is caused by Salmone willa typhi bacteria. Most people with typhoid fever feel better within a few days of starting antibiotic treatment, although a small number of them may die of complications.
info-Symptoms: Fever that starts low and increases daily, possibly reaching as high as 104.9 Â°F (40.5 Â°C) Headache, Weakness and fatigue, Muscle aches, Sweating, Dry cough, Loss of appetite and weight loss, Stomach pain, Diarrhea or constipation, Rash, Swollen stomach (enlarged liver or spleen)
info-Duration: Usually 7â€“10 days after antibiotic treatment begins. Longer if there are complications or drug resistance
info-Causes: Gastrointestinal infection of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi
info-Risk factors: Work in or travel to areas where typhoid fever is established, Work as a clinical microbiologist handling Salmonella typhi bacteria, Have close contact with someone who is infected or has recently been infected with typhoid fever, Drink water polluted by sewage that contains Salmonella typhi
info-Prevention: Preventable by vaccine. Travelers to regions with higher typhoid prevalence are usually encouraged to get a vaccination before travel.
info-Treatment: Antibiotics, hydration, surgery in extreme cases. Quarantine to avoid exposing others (not commonly done in modern times)
info-Prognosis: Likely to recover without complications if proper antibiotics administered and diagnosed early. If infecting strain is multi-drug resistant or extensively drug resistant then prognosis more difficult to determine. Among untreated acute cases, 10% will shed bacteria for three months after initial onset of symptoms, and 2â€“5% will become chronic typhoid carriers. Some carriers are diagnosed by positive tissue specimen. Chronic carriers are by definition asymptomatic.

Name: Ulcer , aphthous
Overview: Canker sores occur singly or in clusters on the inside surfaces of the cheeks or lips, on or under the tongue, at the base of the gums, or on the soft palate. Canker sores, also called aphthous ulcers, are small, shallow lesions that develop on the soft tissues in the mouth or at the base of the gums.

Name: Ulcer , peptic
Symptoms: The pain can often be relieved by eating certain foods that buffer stomach acid or by taking an acid-reducing medication, but then it may come back. Less often, ulcers may cause severe signs or symptoms such as: See the doctor if one has the severe signs or symptoms listed above.
Overview: A peptic ulcer is a sore on the lining of the stomach, small intestine or esophagus. Peptic ulcers include The most common causes of peptic ulcers are infection with the bacterium Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) and long-term use of aspirin and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (Advil, Aleve, others).
Causes: Peptic ulcers occur when acid in the digestive tract eats away at the inner surface of the stomach or small intestine. Helicobacter pylori bacteria commonly live in the mucous layer that covers and protects tissues that line the stomach and small intestine. Often, the H. pylori bacterium causes no problems, but it can cause inflammation of the stomach's inner layer, producing an ulcer. These medications include ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve, Anaprox, others), ketoprofen and others.
Risk factors: In addition to taking NSAIDs, one may have an increased risk of peptic ulcers if one: Alone, these factors do not cause ulcers, but they can make them worse and more difficult to heal. Smoking may increase the risk of peptic ulcers in people who are infected with H. pylori. Alcohol can irritate and erode the mucous lining of the stomach, and it increases the amount of stomach acid that's produced.
Diagnosis: A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). During endoscopy, the doctor passes a hollow tube equipped with a lens (endoscope) down the throat and into the esophagus, stomach and small intestine. If the doctor detects an ulcer, small tissue samples (biopsy) may be removed for examination in a lab.
Treatment: These may include amoxicillin (Amoxil), clarithromycin (Biaxin), metronidazole (Flagyl), tinidazole (Tindamax), tetracycline (Tetracycline HCL) and levofloxacin (Levaquin). One will likely need to take antibiotics for two weeks, as well as additional medications to reduce stomach acid, including a proton pump inhibitor and possibly bismuth subsalicylate (Pepto-Bismol). These drugs include the prescription and over-the-counter medications omeprazole (Prilosec), lansoprazole (Prevacid), rabeprazole (Aciphex), esomeprazole (Nexium) and pantoprazole (Protonix). Acid blockers also called histamine (H-2) blockers reduce the amount of stomach acid released into the digestive tract, which relieves ulcer pain and encourages healing. Available by prescription or over-the-counter, acid blockers include the medicationsxa0famotidine (Pepcid), cimetidine (Tagamet HB)xa0andxa0nizatidine (Axid AR).
Remedies: Choose a healthy diet full of fruits, especially with vitamins A and C, vegetables, and whole grains. Sometimes drinking milk will make the ulcer pain better, but then later cause excess acid, which increases pain. If one use pain relievers regularly, ask the doctor whether acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) may be an option for one. Smoking may interfere with the protective lining of the stomach, making the stomach more susceptible to the development of an ulcer. Excessive use of alcohol can irritate and erode the mucous lining in the stomach and intestines, causing inflammation and bleeding.

Name: Ulcer , rectal
Overview: Solitary rectal ulcer syndrome is a condition that occurs when one or more open sores (ulcers) develop in the rectum. Solitary rectal ulcer syndrome is a rare and poorly understood disorder that often occurs in people with chronic constipation. Despite the name, sometimes more than one rectal ulcer occurs in solitary rectal ulcer syndrome. Solitary rectal ulcer syndrome may improve with simple lifestyle strategies, such as changing the diet and drinking more fluids.
Diagnosis: One may have one or more of the following tests to diagnose solitary rectal ulcer syndrome: Other imaging studies. The doctor may recommend an ultrasound to help differentiate solitary rectal ulcer syndrome from other conditions.
Treatment: People with mild signs and symptoms may find relief through lifestyle changes, while people with more severe signs and symptoms may require medical or surgical treatment. In one behavioral technique, called biofeedback, a specialist teaches one to control certain involuntary body responses, such as the tightening of the anus or pelvic floor muscles, during defecation. Certain treatments such as topical steroids, sulfasalazine enemas and onabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) may help ease the rectal ulcer symptoms. If one has a rectal prolapse that's causing symptoms, the doctor may recommend a rectopexy procedure. An operation to remove the rectum may be an option if one has severe signs and symptoms that haven't been helped by other treatments.
Remedies: Bulk laxatives, such as psyllium husk (Metamucil, Natural Fiber Therapy, others) and calcium polycarbophil (FiberCon, Fiber-Lax, others), absorb fluid in the intestines and make stools bulkier, which helps trigger the bowel to contract and push stool out. Stool softeners, such as docusate (Colace, Surfak, others), help mix fluid into stools, making them easier to pass.

Name: Ulcerative colitis
Symptoms: Ulcerative colitis symptoms can vary, depending on the severity of inflammation and where it occurs. Signs and symptoms include bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramping and pain on the left side, and unintended weight loss. Pancolitis often affects the entire colon and causes bouts of bloody diarrhea that may be severe, abdominal cramps and pain, fatigue, and significant weight loss. This rare form of colitis affects the entire colon and causes severe pain, profuse diarrhea, bleeding, fever and inability to eat.
Overview: The colon, also called the large intestine, is a long, tubelike organ in the abdomen. Ulcerative colitis (UL-sur-uh-tiv koe-LIE-tis) is an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes long-lasting inflammation and ulcers (sores) in the digestive tract. Ulcerative colitis affects the innermost lining of the large intestine (colon) and rectum.
Risk factors: But, it can occur at any age, and some people may not develop the disease until after age 60. Although whites have the highest risk of the disease, it can occur in any race. One is at higher risk if one has a close relative, such as a parent, sibling or child, with the disease.
Diagnosis: To help confirm a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis, one may have one or more of the following tests and procedures: Blood tests. The doctor may suggest blood tests to check for anemia a condition in which there aren't enough red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to the tissues or to check for signs of infection. This exam allows the doctor to view the entire colon using a thin, flexible, lighted tube with an attached camera. During the procedure, the doctor can also take small samples of tissue (biopsy) for laboratory analysis. The doctor uses a slender, flexible, lighted tube to examine the rectum and sigmoid, the last portion of the colon. If the colon is severely inflamed, the doctor may perform this test instead of a full colonoscopy. If one has severe symptoms, the doctor may use a standard X-ray of the abdominal area to rule out serious complications, such as a perforated colon.
Remedies: Here are some suggestions that may help: Limit fiber, if it's a problem food. If one has inflammatory bowel disease, high-fiber foods, such as fresh fruits and vegetables and whole grains, may make the symptoms worse. In general, one may have more problems with foods in the cabbage family, such as broccoli and cauliflower, and nuts, seeds, corn and popcorn. Although stress doesn't cause inflammatory bowel disease, it can make the signs and symptoms worse and may trigger flare-ups. To help control stress, try: Limit dairy products. Many people with inflammatory bowel disease find that problems such as diarrhea, abdominal pain and gas improve by limiting or eliminating dairy products. One may be lactose intolerant that is, the body can't digest the milk sugar (lactose) in dairy foods. Spicy foods, alcohol and caffeine may make the signs and symptoms worse.
info-Symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhea mixed with blood, weight loss, fever, anemia
info-Medication: Sulfasalazine, mesalazine, steroids, immunosuppressants such as azathioprine, biological therapy

Name: Ulnar wrist pain
Overview: Ulnar wrist pain is pain on the side of the wrist opposite the thumb. Ulnar wrist pain can be hard to diagnose because it can be linked to many different types of injuries.
Treatment: Treatment for some types of ulnar wrist pain may include surgery. Altman E. The ulnar side of the wrist: Clinically relevant anatomy and biomechanics.

Name: Umbilical hernia
Symptoms: In babies who have an umbilical hernia, the bulge may be visible only when they cry, cough or strain. If one suspect that the baby has an umbilical hernia, talk with the baby's doctor. Seek emergency care if the baby has an umbilical hernia and: Similar guidelines apply to adults.
Overview: An umbilical hernia creates a soft swelling or bulge near the navel. An umbilical hernia occurs when part of the intestine bulges through the opening in the abdominal muscles near the bellybutton (navel). Children's umbilical hernias often close on their own in the first two years of life, though some remain open into the fifth year or longer.

Name: Uncontrollable laughter and crying
Symptoms: The degree of the emotional response caused by PBA is often striking, with crying or laughing lasting up to several minutes. Because pseudobulbar affect often involves crying, the condition is frequently mistaken for depression. However, PBA episodes tend to be short in duration, while depression causes a persistent feeling of sadness. Also, people with PBA often lack certain features of depression, such as sleep disturbances or a loss of appetite.
Overview: Pseudobulbar affect (PBA) is a condition that's characterized by episodes of sudden uncontrollable and inappropriate laughing or crying. Pseudobulbar affect typically occurs in people with certain neurological conditions or injuries, which might affect the way the brain controls emotion.

Name: Underactive thyroid
Symptoms: At first, one may barely notice the symptoms of hypothyroidism, such as fatigue and weight gain. Hypothyroidism signs and symptoms may include Although hypothyroidism most often affects middle-aged and older women, anyone can develop the condition, including infants. Initially, babies born without a thyroid gland or with a gland that doesn't work properly may have few signs and symptoms. They may also have: When hypothyroidism in infants isn't treated, even mild cases can lead to severe physical and mental retardation.
Overview: Hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid) is a condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility and heart disease.
Causes: When the thyroid doesn't produce enough hormones, the balance of chemical reactions in the body can be upset. There can be a number of causes, including autoimmune disease, hyperthyroidism treatments, radiation therapy, thyroid surgery and certain medications. The thyroid is a small, butterfly-shaped gland situated at the base of the front of the neck, just below the Adam's apple. Hypothyroidism may be due to a number of factors, including Autoimmune disease. However it happens, these antibodies affect the thyroid's ability to produce hormones. Less often, hypothyroidism may result from one of the following: Autoimmune disease. But sometimes, correcting hyperthyroidism can end up lowering thyroid hormone production too much, resulting in permanent hypothyroidism. In most cases, the thyroid gland didn't develop normally for unknown reasons, but some children have an inherited form of the disorder. Often, infants with congenital hypothyroidism appear normal at birth. Some women develop hypothyroidism during or after pregnancy (postpartum hypothyroidism), often because they produce antibodies to their own thyroid gland. The trace mineral iodine found primarily in seafood, seaweed, plants grown in iodine-rich soil and iodized salt is essential for the production of thyroid hormones. Too little iodine can lead to hypothyroidism, and too much iodine can worsen hypothyroidism in people who already have the condition.
Diagnosis: Diagnosis of hypothyroidism is based on the symptoms and the results of blood tests that measure the level of TSH and sometimes the level of the thyroid hormone thyroxine. Because the TSH test is the best screening test, the doctor will likely check TSH first and follow with a thyroid hormone test if needed. In addition, TSH tests are used to help diagnose a condition called subclinical hypothyroidism, which usually causes no outward signs or symptoms.
info-Symptoms: Poor ability to tolerate cold, feeling tired, constipation, weight gain, depression, anxiety, irritability

Name: Under-eye puffiness
Remedies: The following tips can help one reduce or eliminate bags under eyes: Use a cool compress. While sitting up, apply the damp washcloth to the skin under and around the eyes for a few minutes using mild pressure. Talk to the doctor about prevention strategies if one develop under-eye reactions due to hair dyes, soaps, cosmetics or other allergens.
Medication: Depending on what's causing bags under the eyes, eyelid surgery (blepharoplasty) may be a treatment option. In addition to correcting bags under eyes, blepharoplasty can also repair: Talk with the doctor about the side effects of eyelid surgery dry eyes, watery eyes, pain, swelling, bruising and blurred vision.

Name: Undescended testicle
Symptoms: Treating an undescended testicle when the son is still a baby might lower the risk of complications later in life, such as infertility and testicular cancer. An ascending testicle, or acquired undescended testicle, that has returned to the groin and can't be easily guided by hand into the scrotum.
Diagnosis: If the son has an undescended testicle, his doctor might recommend surgery for diagnosis and potential treatment: Laparoscopy. The doctor might be able to fix the undescended testicle during the same procedure, but an additional surgery might be needed in some cases. Alternatively, laparoscopy might show no testicle present, or a small remnant of nonfunctioning testicular tissue that is then removed. After birth, if the doctor can't detect any testicles in the scrotum, he or she might order further testing to determine if the testicles aren't there at all rather than undescended.

Name: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma
Causes: The changes tell the cell to multiply rapidly, creating a mass of abnormal cells (tumor). In time, the cancer cells can break away and spread (metastasize) to other parts of the body, such as the lungs and bones.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures may include Removing a sample of tissue for testing (biopsy). In the lab, doctors trained in analyzing body tissues (pathologists) examine the sample to determine the types of cells involved and whether the cells are likely to be aggressive.

Name: Upset stomach
Symptoms: People with indigestion may have one or more of the following symptoms: Less frequent symptoms include vomiting and belching. Heartburn is a pain or burning feeling in the center of the chest that may radiate into the neck or back during or after eating. Contact the doctor right away if pain is severe or accompanied by: Seek immediate medical attention if one has: Early fullness during a meal. One hasn't eaten much of the meal, but one already feel full and may not be able to finish eating. One feel an uncomfortable heat or burning sensation between the bottom of the breastbone and the navel.
Overview: The major organs in the digestive system are the liver, stomach, gallbladder, colon and small intestine. Indigestion is not a disease, but rather some symptoms one experience, including abdominal pain and a feeling of fullness soon after one start eating.
Diagnosis: But if the indigestion began suddenly, and one is experiencing severe symptoms or are older than age 55, the doctor may recommend: If initial testing fails to provide a cause, the doctor may diagnose functional dyspepsia. Breath and stool tests, to check for Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori), the bacterium associated with peptic ulcers, which can cause indigestion.
Remedies: Mild indigestion can often be helped with lifestyle changes, including Eating smaller, more-frequent meals. Fatty and spicy foods, processed foods, carbonated beverages, caffeine, alcohol, and smoking can trigger indigestion. Excess pounds put pressure on the abdomen, pushing up the stomach and causing acid to back up into the esophagus. With the doctor's approval, stop or cut back on pain relievers or other medications that may irritate the stomach lining. If that's not an option, be sure to take these medications with food.
info-Causes: Serious: Appendicitis, perforated stomach ulcer, pancreatitis, ruptured diverticulitis, ovarian torsion, volvulus, ruptured aortic aneurysm, lacerated spleen or liver, ischemic colitis, ischaemic myocardial conditions Common: Gastroenteritis, irritable bowel syndrome

Name: Ureteral cancer
Overview: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. Cancer of the ureter (ureteral cancer) is a type of cancer that begins in the cells that line the inside of the tubes (ureters) that connect the kidneys to the bladder.
Risk factors: People who have been diagnosed with bladder cancer or kidney cancer have an increased risk of ureteral cancer. Smoking tobacco increases the risk of ureteral cancer, as well as other urinary tract cancers, including kidney cancer and bladder cancer.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose ureteral cancer include Use of a thin, lighted tube to view the ureters. In the laboratory, a doctor who specializes in analyzing blood and body tissue (pathologist) will carefully examine the cells for signs of cancer. Imaging tests may be used to help the doctor assess the extent of the ureteral cancer. The doctor may examine the bladder using imaging tests or a scope to see inside the bladder (cystoscopy) to look for signs of bladder cancer.
info-Symptoms: Blood in the urine

Name: Ureteral obstruction
Overview: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine.
Causes: Different types of ureteral obstruction have different causes, some of them present at birth (congenital). This common condition, which is present at birth (congential), causes two ureters to form on the same kidney. If either ureter doesn't function properly, urine can back up into the kidney and cause damage. An abnormality where the ureter connects to the bladder or the kidney, which blocks urine flow. An abnormal connection between the ureter and kidney (ureteropelvic junction) may cause the kidney to swell and eventually stop working. An abnormal connection between the ureter and bladder (ureterovesical junction) may cause urine to back up into the kidneys. The fibers encircle and block the ureters, causing urine to back up into the kidneys.
Diagnosis: Often, doctors diagnose ureteral obstruction disorders before birth during routine prenatal ultrasounds, which can show details of the developing fetus, including the kidneys, ureters and bladder. If the doctor suspects one has an obstructed ureter, some of these tests and scans might be used to reach a diagnosis: Blood and urine tests. The doctor checks samples of the blood and urine for signs of infection and the presence of creatinine, which signals that the kidneys aren't working properly. An ultrasound of the area behind the abdominal organs (retroperitoneal ultrasound) allows the doctor to view the kidneys and ureters. To test for abnormal urine flow, the doctor inserts a small tube (catheter) through the urethra, injects dye into the bladder, and takes X-rays of the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra before and during urination. A CT scan combines a series of X-ray views taken from many different angles and computer processing to create cross-sectional images of the kidneys, ureter and bladder.

Name: Urinary incontinence
Symptoms: But if incontinence is frequent or is affecting the quality of life, it's important to seek medical advice because urinary incontinence may: Stress incontinence. Urge incontinence may be caused by a minor condition, such as infection, or a more-severe condition such as a neurologic disorder or diabetes.
Causes: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. Certain drinks, foods and medications may act as diuretics stimulating the bladder and increasing the volume of urine. Infections can irritate the bladder, causing one to have strong urges to urinate, and sometimes incontinence. Vaginal delivery can weaken muscles needed for bladder control and also damage bladder nerves and supportive tissue, leading to a dropped (prolapsed) pelvic floor. With prolapse, the bladder, uterus, rectum or small intestine can get pushed down from the usual position and protrude into the vagina. After menopause women produce less estrogen, a hormone that helps keep the lining of the bladder and urethra healthy. In women, the bladder and uterus are supported by many of the same muscles and ligaments. Any surgery that involves a woman's reproductive system, including removal of the uterus, may damage the supporting pelvic floor muscles, which can lead to incontinence. Especially in older men, incontinence often stems from enlargement of the prostate gland, a condition known as benign prostatic hyperplasia. A tumor anywhere along the urinary tract can block the normal flow of urine, leading to overflow incontinence. Urinary stones hard, stone-like masses that form in the bladder sometimes cause urine leakage.
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of developing urinary incontinence include Gender. However, men with prostate gland problems are at increased risk of urge and overflow incontinence. Extra weight increases pressure on the bladder and surrounding muscles, which weakens them and allows urine to leak out when one cough or sneeze. If a close family member has urinary incontinence, especially urge incontinence, the risk of developing the condition is higher.
Diagnosis: It's important to determine the type of urinary incontinence that one has, and the symptoms often tell the doctor which type one has. After that, the doctor will likely recommend: If further information is needed, the doctor may recommend more-involved tests, such as urodynamic testing and pelvic ultrasound. For several days one record how much one drink, when one urinate, the amount of urine one produce, whether one had an urge to urinate and the number of incontinence episodes.
Medication: Examples include oxybutynin (Ditropan XL), tolterodine (Detrol), darifenacin (Enablex), fesoterodine (Toviaz), solifenacin (Vesicare) and trospium (Sanctura). In men with urge or overflow incontinence, these medications relax bladder neck muscles and muscle fibers in the prostate and make it easier to empty the bladder. Examples include tamsulosin (Flomax), alfuzosin (Uroxatral), silodosin (Rapaflo), doxazosin (Cardura) and terazosin.

Name: Urinary tract infection ( UTI )
Overview: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. A urinary tract infection (UTI) is an infection in any part of the urinary system the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra.
Causes: This type of UTI is usually caused by Escherichia coli (E. coli), a type of bacteria commonly found in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. Also, because the female urethra is close to the vagina, sexually transmitted infections, such as herpes, gonorrhea, chlamydia and mycoplasma, can cause urethritis.
Risk factors: Urinary tract infections are common in women, and many women experience more than one infection during their lifetimes. After menopause, a decline in circulating estrogen causes changes in the urinary tract that make one more vulnerable to infection. Babies born with urinary tract abnormalities that don't allow urine to leave the body normally or cause urine to back up in the urethra have an increased risk of UTIs. People who can't urinate on their own and use a tube (catheter) to urinate have an increased risk of UTIs. Urinary surgery or an exam of the urinary tract that involves medical instruments can both increase the risk of developing a urinary tract infection.
Diagnosis: During a cystoscopy exam, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible device called a cystoscope through the urethra into the bladder. During a cystoscopy exam, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible device called a cystoscope through the urethra into the bladder. The doctor may ask for a urine sample for lab analysis to look for white blood cells, red blood cells or bacteria. If one is having frequent infections that the doctor thinks may be caused by an abnormality in the urinary tract, one may have an ultrasound, a computerized tomography (CT) scan or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). If one has recurrent UTIs, the doctor may perform a cystoscopy, using a long, thin tube with a lens (cystoscope) to see inside the urethra and bladder.
Remedies: Avoid coffee, alcohol, and soft drinks containing citrus juices or caffeine until the infection has cleared. Apply a warm, but not hot, heating pad to the abdomen to minimize bladder pressure or discomfort.

Name: Urine color
Symptoms: Normal urine color varies, depending on how much water one drink. Fluids dilute the yellow pigments in urine, so the more one drink, the clearer the urine looks. But urine can turn colors far beyond what's normal, including red, blue, green, dark brown and cloudy white. If the urine is dark or orange particularly if one also have pale stools and yellow skin and eyes the liver might be malfunctioning.
Causes: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The kidneys, located in the rear portion of the upper abdomen, produce urine by filtering waste and fluid from the blood. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. Discolored urine is often caused by medications, certain foods or food dyes. In some cases, though, changes in urine color can be caused by specific health problems. In some cases, orange urine can indicate a problem with the liver or bile duct, especially if one also have light-colored stools. A number of medications produce blue or green urine, including amitriptyline, indomethacin (Indocin, Tivorbex) and propofol (Diprivan). Familial benign hypercalcemia, a rare inherited disorder, is sometimes called blue diaper syndrome because children with the disorder have blue urine.
Risk factors: Discolored urine that isn't the result of foods or medications could be caused by a medical condition that affects urine color. Tumors of the bladder and kidney, which can cause blood in the urine, are more common in older people.
Diagnosis: In addition to taking a thorough medical history and performing a physical exam, the doctor might recommend certain diagnostic tests, including Urinalysis. The doctor uses urine tests to look for red blood cells, high levels of protein, and excreted minerals in the urine that may indicate kidney or urinary tract problems.

Name: Urine , blood in
Overview: Seeing blood in the urine can be alarming. While in many instances the cause is harmless, blood in urine (hematuria) can indicate a serious disorder. Urinary blood that's visible only under a microscope (microscopic hematuria) is found when the doctor tests the urine.
Causes: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The kidneys, located in the rear portion of the upper abdomen, produce urine by filtering waste and fluid from the blood. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. In hematuria, the kidneys or other parts of the urinary tract allow blood cells to leak into urine. Then there's usually no mistaking the symptoms kidney stones, especially, can cause excruciating pain. It may be linked to trauma to the bladder, dehydration or the breakdown of red blood cells that occurs with sustained aerobic exercise. Signs and symptoms are often similar to bladder infections, though kidney infections are more likely to cause a fever and flank pain. Microscopic urinary bleeding is a common symptom of glomerulonephritis, an inflammation of the kidneys filtering system. Visible urinary bleeding may be a sign of advanced kidney, bladder or prostate cancer. Sickle cell anemia a hereditary defect of hemoglobin in red blood cells causes blood in urine, both visible and microscopic hematuria.
Risk factors: Kidney inflammation after a viral or bacterial infection (post-infectious glomerulonephritis) is one of the leading causes of visible urinary blood in children. One might be more prone to urinary bleeding if one has a family history of kidney disease or kidney stones. Aspirin, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory pain relievers and antibiotics such as penicillin are known to increase the risk of urinary bleeding.
Diagnosis: During a cystoscopy exam, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible device called a cystoscope through the urethra into the bladder. During a cystoscopy exam, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible device called a cystoscope through the urethra into the bladder. The following tests and exams play a key role in finding a cause for blood in the urine: Sometimes, the cause of urinary bleeding can't be found. In that case, the doctor might recommend regular follow-up tests, especially if one has risk factors for bladder cancer, such as smoking, exposure to environmental toxins or a history of radiation therapy. CT scan Cystoscopy MRI Ultrasound Urinalysis Physical exam, Urine tests.

Name: Urticaria
Overview: Hives may be accompanied by angioedema, which causes red, swollen welts. Hives, also known as urticaria, are reddened, itchy welts that may be triggered by exposure to certain foods, medications or other substances. Hives also known as urticaria (ur-tih-KAR-e-uh) is a skin reaction that causes itchy welts, which range in size from small spots to large blotches.
Causes: Hives and angioedema can be caused by: Oftentimes, no specific cause can be identified, especially in the case of chronic hives. Shellfish, fish, peanuts, tree nuts, soy, wheat, eggs and milk are frequent offenders. Common culprits include penicillin, aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), naproxen sodium (Aleve) and blood pressure medications. Pollen and other allergens that one breathe in can trigger hives, sometimes accompanied by upper and lower respiratory tract symptoms.
Remedies: If one is experiencing mild hives or angioedema, these tips may help relieve the symptoms: Avoid triggers. A nonprescription oral antihistamine, such as loratadine (Claritin), cetirizine (Zyrtec Allergy) or diphenhydramine (Benadryl Allergy, others), may help relieve itching. Some people may also benefit from bathing in cool water sprinkled with baking soda or oatmeal powder (Aveeno, others), but this isn't a solution for long-term control of chronic itching.
Medication: Treatments for hives and angioedema may include prescription drugs, including For a severe attack of hives or angioedema, one may need a trip to the emergency room and an emergency injection of epinephrine a type of adrenaline. For severe hives or angioedema, doctors may sometimes prescribe an oral corticosteroid drug such as prednisone to reduce swelling, redness and itching.
info-Symptoms: Red, raised, itchy bumps
info-Causes: Following an infection, result of an allergic reaction
info-Risk factors: Hay fever, asthma

Name: Urticaria
Overview: Hives may be accompanied by angioedema, which causes red, swollen welts. Hives, also known as urticaria, are reddened, itchy welts that may be triggered by exposure to certain foods, medications or other substances.
Remedies: The following precautions may help prevent or soothe the recurring skin reactions of chronic hives: Wear loose, light clothing. Soothe the affected area with a bath, fan, cool cloth, lotion or anti-itch cream.
info-Symptoms: Red, raised, itchy bumps
info-Causes: Following an infection, result of an allergic reaction
info-Risk factors: Hay fever, asthma

Name: Uterine cancer
Risk factors: Factors that increase the risk of endometrial cancer include Changes in the balance of female hormones in the body. A disease or condition that increases the amount of estrogen, but not the level of progesterone, in the body can increase the risk of endometrial cancer. Taking hormones after menopause that contain estrogen but not progesterone increases the risk of endometrial cancer. Starting menstruation at an early age before age 12 or beginning menopause later increases the risk of endometrial cancer. If one has never been pregnant, one has a higher risk of endometrial cancer than someone who has had at least one pregnancy. As one get older, the risk of endometrial cancer increases. For most, the benefits of tamoxifen outweigh the small risk of endometrial cancer. Lynch syndrome, also called hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is a syndrome that increases the risk of colon cancer and other cancers, including endometrial cancer.
Diagnosis: During a transvaginal ultrasound, the doctor or a medical technician inserts a wandlike device (transducer) into the vagina while one lie on the back on an exam table. During hysteroscopy, the doctor uses a thin, lighted instrument (hysteroscope) to view the inside of the uterus. Tests and procedures used to diagnose endometrial cancer include If endometrial cancer is found, one will likely be referred to a doctor who specializes in treating cancers involving the female reproductive system (gynecologic oncologist). Once the cancer has been diagnosed, the doctor works to determine the extent (stage) of the cancer. Tests used to determine the cancer's stage may include a chest X-ray, a computerized tomography (CT) scan, positron emission tomography (PET) scan and blood tests. During a pelvic exam, the doctor carefully inspects the outer portion of the genitals (vulva), and then inserts two fingers of one hand into the vagina and simultaneously presses the other hand on the abdomen to feel the uterus and ovaries. During a hysteroscopy, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible, lighted tube (hysteroscope) through the vagina and cervix into the uterus. If enough tissue can't be obtained during a biopsy or if the biopsy results are unclear, one will likely need to undergo a procedure called dilation and curettage (D&C).
Treatment: Drug treatments for endometrial cancer include chemotherapy with powerful drugs and hormone therapy to block hormones that cancer cells rely on. Other options might be targeted therapy with drugs that attack specific weaknesses in the cancer cells and immunotherapy to help the immune system fight cancer.
info-Symptoms: Endometrial cancer: vaginal bleeding, pelvic painUterine sarcoma: vaginal bleeding, mass in the vagina
info-Risk factors: Endometrial cancer: obesity, metabolic syndrome, type 2 diabetes, tamoxifen use, unopposed estrogens, late menopause, family history of the conditionUterine sarcoma: radiation therapy to the pelvis
info-Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, hormone therapy, targeted therapy

Name: Uterine myoma
Overview: There are three major types of uterine fibroids. Also called leiomyomas (lie-o-my-O-muhs) or myomas, uterine fibroids aren't associated with an increased risk of uterine cancer and almost never develop into cancer.
Causes: Doctors don't know the cause of uterine fibroids, but research and clinical experience point to these factors: Hormones. Estrogen and progesterone, two hormones that stimulate development of the uterine lining during each menstrual cycle in preparation for pregnancy, appear to promote the growth of fibroids. The growth patterns of uterine fibroids vary they may grow slowly or rapidly, or they may remain the same size. Many fibroids that have been present during pregnancy shrink or disappear after pregnancy, as the uterus goes back to a normal size.
Risk factors: Although any woman of reproductive age can develop fibroids, black women are more likely to have fibroids than are women of other racial groups. In addition, black women have fibroids at younger ages, and they're also likely to have more or larger fibroids, along with more-severe symptoms. Onset of menstruation at an early age; obesity; a vitamin D deficiency; having a diet higher in red meat and lower in green vegetables, fruit and dairy; and drinking alcohol, including beer, appear to increase the risk of developing fibroids.
Diagnosis: If one has symptoms of uterine fibroids, the doctor may order these tests: Ultrasound. A doctor or technician moves the ultrasound device (transducer) over the abdomen (transabdominal) or places it inside the vagina (transvaginal) to get images of the uterus. During hysterosonography (his-tur-o-suh-NOG-ruh-fee), the doctor uses a thin, flexible tube (catheter) to inject salt water (saline) into the hollow part of the uterus. During hysteroscopy, the doctor uses a thin, lighted instrument (hysteroscope) to view the inside of the uterus. Hysterosonography (his-tur-o-suh-NOG-ruh-fee), also called a saline infusion sonogram, uses sterile saline to expand the uterine cavity, making it easier to get images of submucosal fibroids and the lining of the uterus in women attempting pregnancy or who have heavy menstrual bleeding. The doctor then injects saline into the uterus, expanding the uterine cavity and allowing the doctor to examine the walls of the uterus and the openings of the fallopian tubes.
Medication: Medications for uterine fibroids target hormones that regulate the menstrual cycle, treating symptoms such as heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure. Medications called GnRH agonists treat fibroids by blocking the production of estrogen and progesterone, putting one into a temporary menopause-like state. GnRH agonists include leuprolide (Lupron, Eligard, others), goserelin (Zoladex) and triptorelin (Trelstar, Triptodur Kit). Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), which are not hormonal medications, may be effective in relieving pain related to fibroids, but they don't reduce bleeding caused by fibroids.
info-Symptoms: Painful or heavy periods
info-Risk factors: Family history, obesity, eating red meat
info-Medication: Ibuprofen, paracetamol (acetaminophen), iron supplements, gonadotropin releasing hormone agonist

Name: Uterine polyps
Overview: Uterine polyps attach to the uterus by a large base or a thin stalk and can grow to be several centimeters in size. Overgrowth of cells in the lining of the uterus (endometrium) leads to the formation of uterine polyps, also known as endometrial polyps.
Diagnosis: During a transvaginal ultrasound, the doctor or a medical technician inserts a wandlike device (transducer) into the vagina while one lie on the back on an exam table. During hysterosonography (his-tur-o-suh-NOG-ruh-fee), the doctor uses a thin, flexible tube (catheter) to inject salt water (saline) into the hollow part of the uterus. During hysteroscopy, the doctor uses a thin, lighted instrument (hysteroscope) to view the inside of the uterus. A related procedure, known as hysterosonography (his-tur-o-suh-NOG-ruh-fee) also called sonohysterography (son-oh-his-tur-OG-ruh-fee) involves having salt water (saline) injected into the uterus through a small tube threaded through the vagina and cervix. However, some precancerous changes of the uterus (endometrial hyperplasia) or uterine cancers (endometrial carcinomas) appear as uterine polyps. The doctor inserts a thin, flexible, lighted telescope (hysteroscope) through the vagina and cervix into the uterus.
Treatment: For uterine polyps, the doctor might recommend: If a uterine polyp contains cancerous cells, the doctor will talk with one about the next steps in evaluation and treatment. During hysteroscopy, instruments inserted through the hysteroscope the device the doctor uses to see inside the uterus make it possible to remove polyps.

Name: Uterine prolapse
Overview: Normally, supporting ligaments and other connective tissues hold the uterus in place inside the pelvic cavity. Uterine prolapse occurs when pelvic floor muscles and ligaments stretch and weaken and no longer provide enough support for the uterus.
Diagnosis: During a pelvic exam, the doctor inserts two gloved fingers inside the vagina. During the pelvic exam the doctor is likely to ask one: One might fill out a questionnaire that helps the doctor assess how uterine prolapse affects the quality of life. If one has severe incontinence, the doctor might recommend tests to measure how well the bladder functions (urodynamic testing).
info-Symptoms: Vaginal fullness, pain with sex, trouble urinating, urinary incontinence, constipation
info-Risk factors: Pregnancy, childbirth, obesity, constipation, chronic cough

Name: Uterus didelphys
Overview: A double uterus is a rare congenital abnormality. As the fetus develops, the tubes normally join to create one larger, hollow organ the uterus. A double uterus may have one opening (cervix) into one vagina, or each uterine cavity may have a cervix.
Diagnosis: To capture the images, a device called a transducer is either pressed against the abdominal skin or inserted into the vagina (transvaginal ultrasound). The sonohysterogram (son-o-HIS-ter-o-gram), an ultrasound scan, is done after fluid is injected through a tube into the uterus by way of the vagina and cervix. During a hysterosalpingography (his-tur-o-sal-ping-GOG-ruh-fe), a special dye is injected into the uterus through the cervix.

Name: Uveal melanoma
Overview: Eye melanoma most often affects the middle layer of the eye (uvea). Parts of the eye's uvea that can develop melanoma include the colored portion of the eye (iris), the muscle fibers around the eye's lens (ciliary body), and the layer of blood vessels that lines the back of the eye (choroid).
Risk factors: Risk factors for primary melanoma of the eye include Certain inherited skin disorders. A condition called dysplastic nevus syndrome, which causes abnormal moles, may increase the risk of developing melanoma on the skin and in the eye. In addition, people with abnormal skin pigmentation involving the eyelids and adjacent tissues and increased pigmentation on their uvea known as ocular melanocytosis also have an increased risk of developing eye melanoma. There's some evidence that exposure to UV light, such as light from the sun or from tanning beds, may increase the risk of eye melanoma.
Diagnosis: To diagnose eye melanoma, the doctor may recommend: Eye exam. The doctor will examine the outside of the eye, looking for enlarged blood vessels that can indicate a tumor inside the eye. In some cases, the doctor may recommend a procedure to remove a sample of tissue (biopsy) from the eye. Blood tests to measure liver function Chest X-ray Computerized tomography (CT) scan Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan Abdominal ultrasound Positron emission tomography (PET) scan Chest X-rays CT scan Eye exam Liver function tests MRI Ultrasound Eye exam.
info-Symptoms: A sensation of flashes or specks of dust (floaters); growing dark spot on the iris; change in the shape of the pupil; poor or blurry vision in one eye; loss of peripheral vision in one eye.
info-Diagnostic method: clinical examination by biomicroscopy and indirect ophthalmoscopy
info-Prevention: Reduce UV exposure to the eye.
info-Treatment: Brachytherapy, enucleation, proton beam radiotherapy, transpupillary thermotherapy, photocoagulation, photodynamic therapy, and local resection.
info-Frequency: 5 cases per million people per year

Name: Uveitis
Symptoms: Posterior uveitis affects a layer on the inside of the back of the eye, either the retina or the choroid. Panuveitis occurs when all layers of the uvea are inflamed, from the front to the back of the eye.
Diagnosis: When one visit an eye specialist (ophthalmologist), he or she will likely conduct a complete eye exam and gather a thorough health history. The eye examination usually involves the following: The doctor may also recommend: If the ophthalmologist thinks an underlying condition may be the cause of the uveitis, one may be referred to another doctor for a general medical examination and laboratory tests. A tonometry exam measures the pressure inside the eye (intraocular pressure). Also known as funduscopy, this exam involves widening (dilating) the pupil with eyedrops and shining a bright light into the eye to examine the back of the eye.
Medication: For people with difficult-to-treat posterior uveitis, a device that's implanted in the eye may be an option. Uveitis that affects the back of the eye (posterior uveitis or panuveitis, including retinitis or choroiditis) tends to heal more slowly than uveitis in the front of the eye (anterior uveitis or iritis). The doctor may first prescribe eyedrops with an anti-inflammatory medication, such as a corticosteroid. Eyedrops are usually not enough to treat inflammation beyond the front of the eye, so a corticosteroid injection in or around the eye or corticosteroid tablets (taken by mouth) may be necessary. Eyedrops that widen (dilate) the pupil may be prescribed to control spasms in the iris and ciliary body, which can help relieve eye pain. If uveitis is caused by an infection, the doctor may prescribe antibiotics, antiviral medications or other medicines, with or without corticosteroids, to bring the infection under control. One may need immunosuppressive drugs if the uveitis affects both eyes, doesn't respond well to corticosteroids or becomes severe enough to threaten the vision.
info-Symptoms: Headaches, red eyes, blurred vision, photophobia, burning and redness of the eye
info-Causes: BehÃ§et disease, Crohn's disease, Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, HLA-B27 related uveitis, Juvenile idiopathic arthritis, Sarcoidosis, Spondyloarthritis, Sympathetic ophthalmia, Tubulointerstitial nephritis and uveitis syndrome, brucellosis, herpesviruses, leptospirosis, Lyme disease, presumed ocular histoplasmosis syndrome, syphilis, toxocariasis, toxoplasmic chorioretinitis, tuberculosis, Zika fever

Name: Vaginal atrophy
Overview: Vaginal atrophy (atrophic vaginitis) is thinning, drying and inflammation of the vaginal walls that may occur when the body has less estrogen. Because the condition causes both vaginal and urinary symptoms, doctors use the term genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM) to describe vaginal atrophy and its accompanying symptoms.
