Risk factors: Cigarette smoking affects the blood circulation, and may lessen the flow of blood and oxygen to the vagina and other nearby areas. Sexual activity, with or without a partner, increases blood flow and makes the vaginal tissues more elastic.
Treatment: To treat genitourinary syndrome of menopause, the doctor may first recommend over-the-counter treatment options, including If those options don't ease the symptoms, the doctor may recommend: Vaginal moisturizers. Try a vaginal moisturizer (K-Y Liquibeads, Replens, Sliquid, others) to restore some moisture to the vaginal area. These lubricants (Astroglide, K-Y Jelly, Sliquid, others) are applied just before sexual activity and can reduce discomfort during intercourse.
info-Symptoms: Pain with sex, vaginal itchiness or dryness, an urge to urinate
info-Risk factors: Menopause, breastfeeding, certain medications

Name: Vaginal cancer
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of vaginal cancer include Atypical cells in the vagina called vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia. Being diagnosed with vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VAIN) increases the risk of vaginal cancer. VAIN is frequently caused by the sexually transmitted human papillomavirus (HPV), which can cause cervical, vaginal and vulvar cancers, among others. If the mother took a drug called diethylstilbestrol (DES) while pregnant in the 1950s one may have an increased risk of a certain type of vaginal cancer called clear cell adenocarcinoma.
Diagnosis: During a pelvic exam, the doctor carefully inspects the outer genitals, and then inserts two fingers of one hand into the vagina and simultaneously presses the other hand on the abdomen to feel the uterus and ovaries. The doctor may conduct a pelvic exam and Pap test to check for abnormalities that may indicate vaginal cancer. Based on those findings, the doctor may conduct other procedures to determine whether one has vaginal cancer, such as: Once the doctor diagnoses vaginal cancer, steps will be taken to determine the extent of the cancer a process called staging. In order to determine the stage of the cancer, the doctor may use: Inspecting the vagina with a magnifying instrument. Procedures that use tiny cameras to see inside the body may help the doctor determine whether cancer has spread to certain areas.

Name: Vaginal fistula
Overview: A vaginal fistula is an abnormal opening that connects the vagina to another organ, such as the bladder, colon or rectum. Vaginal fistulas can develop as a result of an injury, a surgery, an infection or radiation treatment. Also called a bladder fistula, this opening occurs between the vagina and urinary bladder and is the type that doctors see most often. This type of fistula happens when the abnormal opening develops between the vagina and the ducts that carry urine from the kidneys to the bladder (ureters). In this type of fistula, also called a urethral fistula, the opening occurs between the vagina and the tube that carries urine out of the body (urethra). In this type of fistula, the opening is between the vagina and the lower portion of the large intestine (rectum). With a colovaginal fistula, the opening occurs between the vagina and colon. In this type of fistula, the opening is between the small intestine and the vagina. Colovaginal fistulas: Presentation, evaluation, and management.

Name: Vaginal prolapse , posterior
Overview: A posterior vaginal prolapse, also known as a rectocele, occurs when the wall of fibrous tissue that separates the rectum from the vagina weakens. A posterior vaginal wall prolapse occurs when the thin wall of tissue that separates the rectum from the vagina weakens, allowing the vaginal wall to bulge.
Risk factors: Some women are born with weaker connective tissues in the pelvic area, making them naturally more likely to develop posterior vaginal prolapse. If one has vaginally delivered multiple children, one has a higher risk of developing posterior vaginal prolapse. If one has had tears in the tissue between the vaginal opening and anus (perineal tears) or incisions that extend the opening of the vagina (episiotomies) during childbirth, one may also be at higher risk.
Diagnosis: During the pelvic exam the doctor is likely to ask one: One might fill out a questionnaire that helps the doctor assess how far the bulge extends into the vagina and how much it affects the quality of life. Bearing down may cause the posterior vaginal prolapse to bulge, so the doctor can assess its size and location.

Name: Vaginitis
Symptoms: The main symptom is itching, but one might have a white, thick discharge that resembles cottage cheese. An infection called trichomoniasis (trik-o-moe-NIE-uh-sis) can cause a greenish-yellow, sometimes frothy discharge. Some sexually transmitted infections have signs and symptoms similar to those of a yeast infection or bacterial vaginosis.
Causes: This most common cause of vaginitis results from a change of the normal bacteria found in the vagina, to overgrowth of one of several other organisms. Usually, bacteria normally found in the vagina (lactobacilli) are outnumbered by other bacteria (anaerobes) in the vagina. This common sexually transmitted infection is caused by a microscopic, one-celled parasite called Trichomonas vaginalis. C. albicans also causes infections in other moist areas of the body, such as in the mouth (thrush), skin folds and nail beds. Vaginal sprays, douches, perfumed soaps, scented detergents and spermicidal products may cause an allergic reaction or irritate vulvar and vaginal tissues. Foreign objects, such as tissue paper or forgotten tampons, in the vagina can also irritate vaginal tissues. Reduced estrogen levels after menopause or surgical removal of the ovaries can cause the vaginal lining to thin, sometimes resulting in vaginal irritation, burning and dryness.
Diagnosis: During the pelvic exam, the doctor may use an instrument (speculum) to look inside the vagina for inflammation and abnormal discharge. The doctor might collect a sample of cervical or vaginal discharge for lab testing to confirm what kind of vaginitis one has.
Treatment: For this type of vaginitis, the doctor may prescribe metronidazole (Flagyl) tablets that one take by mouth or metronidazole (MetroGel) gel or clindamycin (Cleocin) cream that one apply to the vagina. Yeast infections usually are treated with an over-the-counter antifungal cream or suppository, such as miconazole (Monistat 1), clotrimazole, butoconazole or tioconazole (Vagistat-1). Yeast infections may also be treated with a prescription oral antifungal medication, such as fluconazole (Diflucan).
Remedies: If one know one has a yeast infection, one can take these steps: Use an over-the-counter medication specifically for yeast infections. Apply a cold compress, such as a washcloth, to the labial area to ease discomfort until the antifungal medication takes full effect.
info-Symptoms: Itching, burning, pain, discharge, bad smell
info-Causes: Infections (bacterial vaginosis, vaginal yeast infection, trichomoniasis), allergic reactions, low estrogen
info-Diagnostic method: Based on examination, measuring the pH, culturing the discharge

Name: Valley fever
Symptoms: This initial, acute illness can develop into a more serious disease, including chronic and disseminated coccidioidomycosis. If the initial coccidioidomycosis infection doesn't completely resolve, it may progress to a chronic form of pneumonia.
Overview: Valley fever is a fungal infection caused by coccidioides (kok-sid-e-OY-deze) organisms. The fungi can then be breathed into the lungs and cause valley fever, also known as acute coccidioidomycosis (kok-sid-e-oy-doh-my-KOH-sis).
Risk factors: People who have jobs that expose them to dust are most at risk construction, road and agricultural workers, ranchers, archeologists, and military personnel on field exercises. For reasons that aren't well-understood, people of Filipino and African heritage are more susceptible to developing serious infection with coccidioidomycosis. People with certain autoimmune diseases, such as rheumatoid arthritis or Crohn's disease, who are being treated with anti-tumor necrosis factor (TNF) drugs also have an increased risk of infection.

Name: Valvular heart disease
Causes: Sometimes, the valves don't open or close properly, disrupting the blood flow through the heart to the body. In this condition, the valve flaps don't close properly, causing blood to leak backward in the heart. In this condition, the valve isn't formed, and a solid sheet of tissue blocks the blood flow between the heart chambers.
Diagnosis: In this test, sound waves directed at the heart from a wandlike device (transducer) held on the chest produce video images of the heart in motion. This test isn't often used to diagnose heart valve disease, but it may be used if other tests aren't able to diagnose the condition or to determine its severity. In this procedure, a doctor threads a thin tube (catheter) through a blood vessel in the arm or groin and guides it to an artery in the heart and injects dye through the catheter to make the artery visible on an X-ray. In this test, wires (electrodes) attached to pads on the skin measure electrical impulses from the heart. A chest X-ray can help the doctor determine whether the heart is enlarged, which can indicate certain types of heart valve disease. This test may be used to determine the severity of the condition and assess the size and function of the lower heart chambers (ventricles).
Treatment: Doctors may suggest heart valve surgery even if one isn't experiencing symptoms, as this may prevent complications and improve outcomes. If one need surgery for another heart condition, the doctor may repair or replace the diseased valve at the same time. Doctors may sometimes conduct minimally invasive heart surgery, which involves the use of smaller incisions than those used in open-heart surgery. In some medical centers, doctors may perform robot-assisted heart surgery, a type of minimally invasive heart surgery in which surgeons use robotic instruments to conduct the procedure. Doctors may also use less invasive procedures to repair certain valves using long, thin tubes (catheters) in some people.
Remedies: The doctor may suggest that one incorporate several heart-healthy lifestyle changes into the life, including For women with heart valve disease, it's important to talk with the doctor before one become pregnant. The doctor can discuss with one which medications one can safely take, and whether one may need a procedure to treat the valve condition prior to pregnancy. If one has a severe valve condition, the doctor may recommend that one avoid pregnancy to reduce the risk of complications. If one is overweight or obese, the doctor may recommend losing weight. Find ways to help manage the stress, such as through relaxation activities, meditation, physical activity, and spending time with family and friends.

Name: Varicella
Symptoms: The itchy blister rash caused by chickenpox infection appears 10 to 21 days after exposure to the virus and usually lasts about five to 10 days. To avoid infecting others in the waiting room, call ahead for an appointment and mention that one think one or the child may have chickenpox.
Remedies: Talk with the doctor before giving any type of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) to someone who has chickenpox. Put gloves on his or her hands, especially at night Trim his or her fingernails A cool bath with added baking soda, aluminum acetate (Domeboro, others), uncooked oatmeal or colloidal oatmeal a finely ground oatmeal that is made for soaking.
info-Symptoms: Small, itchy blisters, headache, loss of appetite, tiredness, fever

Name: Varices , esophageal
Symptoms: If one has been diagnosed with liver disease, ask the doctor about the risk of esophageal varices and what one can do to reduce the risk. If one has been diagnosed with esophageal varices, the doctor is likely to instruct one to watch for signs of bleeding.
Causes: Esophageal varices sometimes form when blood flow to the liver is blocked, most often by scar tissue in the liver caused by liver disease. The blood flow begins to back up, increasing pressure within the large vein (portal vein) that carries blood to the liver. This increased pressure (portal hypertension) forces the blood to seek other pathways through smaller veins, such as those in the lowest part of the esophagus. A blood clot in the portal vein or in a vein that feeds into the portal vein (splenic vein) can cause esophageal varices.
Risk factors: Although many people with advanced liver disease develop esophageal varices, most won't have bleeding. Esophageal varices are more likely to bleed if one has: If one has had bleeding from esophageal varices before, one is more likely to have varices that bleed again. When viewed through a thin, flexible tube (endoscope) passed down the throat, some esophageal varices show long, red streaks or red spots. Most often, the more severe the liver disease, the more likely esophageal varices are to bleed.
Diagnosis: Endoscopy involves inserting a long, flexible tube (endoscope) down the throat and into the esophagus. A tiny camera on the end of the endoscope lets the doctor examine the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). The doctor inserts a thin, flexible, lighted tube (endoscope) through the mouth and into the esophagus, stomach and the beginning of the small intestine (duodenum). An ultrasound test called transient elastography that measures scarring in the liver can help the doctor determine if one has portal hypertension, which may lead to esophageal varices.

Name: Varicocele
Causes: However, many experts believe a varicocele forms when the valves inside the veins in the cord prevent the blood from flowing properly. Varicoceles usually occur on the left side, most likely because of the position of the left testicular vein.
Treatment: However, if the varicocele causes pain, testicular atrophy or infertility or if one is considering assisted reproductive techniques, one might want to undergo varicocele repair. In cases of male infertility, treatment of a varicocele might improve or cure the infertility or improve the quality of sperm if techniques such as in vitro fertilization (IVF) are to be used. Clear indications to repair a varicocele in adolescence include progressive testicular atrophy, pain or abnormal semen analysis results. Although treatment of a varicocele generally improves sperm characteristics, it's not clear if an untreated varicocele leads to progressive worsening of sperm quality over time. Varicocele repair presents relatively few risks, which might include Repair methods include Open surgery. Commonly, the surgeon will approach the vein through the groin (inguinal or subinguinal), but it's also possible to make an incision in the abdomen or below the groin. After that, the doctor might advise one to take over-the-counter painkillers, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) to relieve discomfort. Viewing the enlarged veins on a monitor, the doctor releases coils or a solution that causes scarring to create a blockage in the testicular veins, which interrupts the blood flow and repairs the varicocele. If one has a varicocele that causes one minor discomfort, but doesn't affect the fertility, one might try the following for pain relief: One is likely to start by seeing the primary care doctor. Take over-the-counter painkillers, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others).

Name: Varicose veins
Risk factors: Eventually, that wear causes the valves to allow some blood to flow back into the veins where it collects instead of flowing up to the heart. Hormonal changes during pregnancy, premenstruation or menopause may be a factor because female hormones tend to relax vein walls. Hormone treatments, such as birth control pills, may increase the risk of varicose veins. This change supports the growing fetus, but also can produce an unfortunate side effect enlarged veins in the legs.
Remedies: These same measures can help prevent or slow the development of varicose veins, as well. Don't wear tight clothes around the waist, legs or groin because these garments can reduce blood flow. To improve the circulation in the legs, take several short breaks daily to elevate the legs above the level of the heart.
info-Symptoms: None, fullness, pain in the area
info-Risk factors: Obesity, not enough exercise, leg trauma, family history, pregnancy

Name: Variola
Symptoms: During the incubation period of seven to 17 days, one look and feel healthy and can't infect others. These include A few days later, flat, red spots appear first on the face, hands and forearms, and later on the trunk. Scabs begin to form eight to nine days later and eventually fall off, leaving deep, pitted scars.
Overview: Smallpox is a contagious, disfiguring and often deadly disease that has affected humans for thousands of years. A vaccine can prevent smallpox, but the risk of the vaccine's side effects is too high to justify routine vaccination for people at low risk of exposure to the smallpox virus.
Causes: The virus can be transmitted through the air by droplets that escape when an infected person coughs, sneezes or talks. In rare instances, airborne virus can spread farther, possibly through the ventilation system in a building, infecting people in other rooms or on other floors. Smallpox can also spread through contact with contaminated clothing and bedding, although the risk of infection from these sources is less common.
Treatment: In the event of an infection, treatment would focus on relieving symptoms and keeping the person from becoming dehydrated. The epidemiology, pathogenesis and clinical manifestations of smallpox. Smallpox vaccine: Drug information. Smallpox vaccine: Patient drug information.
info-Symptoms: Early: Fever, vomiting, mouth sores Later: Fluid filled blisters which scab over
info-Causes: Variola major, Variola minor (spread between people)
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and confirmed by PCR

Name: Vascular dementia
Overview: Vascular dementia is a general term describing problems with reasoning, planning, judgment, memory and other thought processes caused by brain damage from impaired blood flow to the brain. Factors that increase the risk of heart disease and stroke including diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol and smoking also raise the vascular dementia risk.
Causes: Common conditions that may lead to vascular dementia include Stroke (infarction) blocking a brain artery. Strokes that block a brain artery usually cause a range of symptoms that may include vascular dementia. These conditions include the wear and tear associated with aging, high blood pressure, abnormal aging of blood vessels (atherosclerosis), diabetes, and brain hemorrhage.
Risk factors: In general, the risk factors for vascular dementia are the same as those for heart disease and stroke. If one has had a heart attack, one may be at increased risk of having blood vessel problems in the brain. The brain damage that occurs with a stroke or a ministroke (transient ischemic attack) may increase the risk of developing dementia. Atherosclerosis can increase the risk of vascular dementia by reducing the flow of blood that nourishes the brain. Elevated levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL), the bad cholesterol, are associated with an increased risk of vascular dementia. Damage in brain blood vessels can increase the risk of stroke and vascular dementia. Smoking directly damages the blood vessels, increasing the risk of atherosclerosis and other circulatory diseases, including vascular dementia. Being overweight is a well-known risk factor for vascular diseases in general, and therefore, presumably increases the risk of vascular dementia. Atrial fibrillation increases the risk of stroke because it causes blood clots to form in the heart that can break off and go to the brain blood vessels.
Diagnosis: The doctor will make a judgment about whether vascular dementia is the most likely cause of the symptoms based on the information one provide, the medical history for stroke or disorders of the heart and blood vessels, and results of tests that may help clarify the diagnosis. If the medical record doesn't include recent values for key indicators of the health of the heart and blood vessels, the doctor will test the: He or she may also order tests to rule out other potential causes of memory loss and confusion, such as: The doctor is likely to check the overall neurological health by testing the: Images of the brain can pinpoint visible abnormalities caused by strokes, blood vessel diseases, tumors or trauma that may cause changes in thinking and reasoning. A CT scan can provide information about the brain's structure; tell whether any regions show shrinkage; and detect evidence of strokes, ministrokes (transient ischemic attacks), blood vessel changes or tumors. Speak, write and understand language Work with numbers Learn and remember information Develop a plan of attack and solve a problem Respond effectively to hypothetical situations Blood pressure test Carotid ultrasound CT scan MRI X-ray Computerized tomography (CT) scan.
info-Symptoms: cognitive impairment

Name: Vascular rings
Diagnosis: The child's doctor may initially suspect a problem because he or she hears a heart murmur during a routine exam. Most heart murmurs are innocent, meaning that there is no heart defect and the murmur isn't dangerous to the child's health. Some murmurs, however, may mean blood is flowing through the child's heart abnormally because he or she has a heart defect. If it's possible the child has a heart defect, the doctor or the child's doctor may order several tests to see if the child has a heart problem. The child's doctor may use a regular echocardiogram to diagnose a congenital heart defect after the child has been born. In this noninvasive test, the child's doctor performs an ultrasound to produce images of the heart. An echocardiogram allows the doctor to see the child's heart in motion and to identify abnormalities in the heart muscle and valves. In this test, a thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted into a blood vessel at the baby's groin and guided through it into the heart. Catheterization is sometimes necessary because it may give the child's doctor a much more detailed view of the child's heart defect than an echocardiogram. This test allows the doctor to see if the child has a heart defect before he or she is born, allowing the doctor to better plan treatment. This noninvasive test records the electrical activity of the child's heart and can help diagnose heart defects or rhythm problems. The child may have a chest X-ray to see if the heart is enlarged, or if the lungs have extra blood or other fluid in them.
Treatment: A congenital heart defect may have no long-term effect on the child's health in some instances, such defects can safely go untreated. Depending on the type of heart defect the child has, doctors treat congenital heart defects with: Procedures using catheterization. Some children and adults now have their congenital heart defects repaired using catheterization techniques, which allow the repair to be done without surgically opening the chest and heart. In procedures that can be done using catheterization, the doctor inserts a thin tube (catheter) into a leg vein and guides it to the heart with the help of X-ray images. Some mild congenital heart defects, especially those found later in childhood or adulthood, can be treated with medications that help the heart work more efficiently. Drugs known as angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) and beta blockers and medications that cause fluid loss (diuretics) can help ease stress on the heart by lowering blood pressure, heart rate and the amount of fluid in the chest.

Name: Vasculitis
Symptoms: Giant cell arteritis causes inflammation of certain arteries, especially those near the temples. Henoch-Schonlein purpura is an inflammation of the small blood vessels of the skin, joints, bowels and kidneys. When blood vessels get inflamed, they can bleed into the skin, causing a reddish-purple rash (purpura). Fever Headache Fatigue Weight loss General aches and pains Night sweats Rash Nerve problems, such as numbness or weakness Behcet's (beh-CHETS) disease. Signs and symptoms include mouth and genital ulcers, eye inflammation, and acne-like skin lesions. This condition causes inflammation and clots in the blood vessels of the hands and feet, resulting in pain and ulcers in these areas. Rarely, Buerger's disease can affect blood vessels in the abdomen, brain and heart. It mainly affects the lungs, skin, kidneys, heart and nerves in the limbs. Signs and symptoms vary greatly and include asthma, skin changes, nerve pain and nasal allergies. Signs and symptoms include rash, joint pain, weakness, and numbness or tingling. Giant cell arteritis can cause headaches, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, blurred or double vision, and even blindness. This condition causes inflammation of the blood vessels in the nose, sinuses, throat, lungs and kidneys. Signs and symptoms include nasal stuffiness, sinus infections, nosebleeds and possibly coughing up blood. Signs and symptoms include abdominal pain, blood in the urine, joint pain, and a rash on the buttocks or lower legs. Sometimes called allergic vasculitis, the primary sign of this condition is red spots on the skin, usually on the lower legs. Signs and symptoms include fever, rash and redness of the eyes. This form of vasculitis affects small blood vessels, usually those in the kidneys, lungs or nerves. This form of vasculitis usually affects the kidneys, the digestive tract, the nerves and the skin.
Overview: Vasculitis is inflammation of the blood vessels. Vasculitis can affect anyone, though some types are more common among certain groups.
Causes: Possible triggers for this immune system reaction include Blood vessels affected by vasculitis may bleed or become inflamed. This narrows the blood vessels, reducing the amount of blood and therefore oxygen and vital nutrients that reaches the body's tissues and organs.
Diagnosis: These tests may reveal whether the urine contains red blood cells or has too much protein, which can signal a medical problem. Imaging tests for vasculitis include X-rays, ultrasound, computerized tomography (CT), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and positron emission tomography (PET). A special dye (contrast medium) is then injected into the catheter, and X-rays are taken as the dye fills the artery or vein.
Medication: The doctor may prescribe a corticosteroid drug, such as prednisone or methylprednisolone (Medrol), to help control inflammation. These medications are sometimes called steroid-sparing and may includemethotrexate (Trexall), azathioprine (Imuran, Azasan), mycophenolate (Cellcept) or cyclophosphamide. Biologic therapies such as rituximab (Rituxan) or tocilizumab (Actemra) may be recommended, depending on the type of vasculitis one has.
info-Symptoms: Weight loss, fever, myalgia, purpura

Name: Vasomotor rhinitis
Overview: Nonallergic rhinitis involves chronic sneezing or a congested, drippy nose with no apparent cause. Triggers of nonallergic rhinitis symptoms vary and can include certain odors or irritants in the air, changes in the weather, some medications, certain foods, and chronic health conditions.
Causes: Nonallergic rhinitis can also be triggered in some people by sedatives, antidepressants, oral contraceptives or drugs used to treat erectile dysfunction. Dust, smog, secondhand smoke or strong odors, such as perfumes, can trigger nonallergic rhinitis. A common cause of nonallergic rhinitis is a viral infection a cold or the flu, for example. Nonallergic rhinitis may occur when one eat, especially when eating hot or spicy foods. Drinking alcoholic beverages also may cause the membranes inside the nose to swell, leading to nasal congestion. Hormonal changes due to pregnancy, menstruation, oral contraceptive use or other hormonal condition such as hypothyroidism may cause nonallergic rhinitis. Lying on the back at night while one sleep can cause nonallergic rhinitis, as can obstructive sleep apnea or acid reflux.
Risk factors: If one is exposed to smog, exhaust fumes or tobacco smoke to name a few one may be at increased risk of developing nonallergic rhinitis. Unlike allergic rhinitis, which usually occurs before age 20, often in childhood, nonallergic rhinitis occurs after age 20 in most people. Using over-the-counter decongestant nasal drops or sprays (Afrin, Dristan, others) for more than a few days can actually cause more-severe nasal congestion when the decongestant wears off, often called rebound congestion.
Diagnosis: The doctor is likely to conclude the symptoms are caused by nonallergic rhinitis if one has nasal congestion, a runny nose or postnasal drip, and tests for other conditions don't reveal an underlying cause such as allergies or a sinus problem. The only way to be sure rhinitis isn't caused by allergies is through allergy testing, which may involve skin or blood tests. If the doctor suspects a sinus problem may be causing the symptoms, one may need an imaging test to view the sinuses. To find out whether the symptoms might be caused by a certain allergen, the skin is pricked and exposed to small amounts of common airborne allergens, such as dust mites, mold, pollen, cat and dog dander. A blood test can measure the immune system's response to common allergens by measuring the amount of certain antibodies in the bloodstream, known as immunoglobulin E (IgE) antibodies.
Treatment: For more-bothersome symptoms, certain medications may provide relief, including Corticosteroid nasal sprays. If the symptoms aren't easily controlled by decongestants or antihistamines, the doctor may suggest a nonprescription corticosteroid nasal spray, such as fluticasone (Flonase) or triamcinolone (Nasacort). Over-the-counter oral antihistamines, such as diphenhydramine (Benadryl), cetirizine (Zyrtec), fexofenadine (Allegra) and loratadine (Claritin), typically don't work nearly as well for nonallergic rhinitis as they do for allergic rhinitis. While oral antihistamines don't seem to help nonallergic rhinitis, nasal sprays containing an antihistamine may reduce symptoms of nonallergic rhinitis. Available over-the-counter or by prescription, examples include pseudoephedrine-containing drugs (Sudafed) and phenylephrine (Afrin, Neo-Synephrine, others).
Remedies: Use a specially designed squeeze bottle, such as the one included in saline kits, bulb syringe or neti pot to irrigate the nasal passages. This home remedy, called nasal lavage, can help keep the nose free of irritants. To prevent infection, use water that's distilled, sterile, previously boiled and cooled, or filtered using a filter with an absolute pore size of 1 micron or smaller to make up the irrigation solution. Also be sure to rinse the irrigation device after each use with similarly distilled, sterile, previously boiled and cooled, or filtered water and leave open to air-dry. Drinking plenty of liquids, including water, juice, and caffeine-free tea, can help loosen the mucus in the nose.

Name: Vasovagal syncope
Diagnosis: These tests may include If no heart problems appear to cause the fainting, the doctor may suggest one undergo a tilt table test. This test uses ultrasound imaging to view the heart and look for conditions, such as valve problems, that can cause fainting.
info-Symptoms: Loss of consciousness before which there may be sweating, decreased ability to see, ringing in the ears
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms after ruling out other possible causes
info-Treatment: Avoiding triggers, drinking sufficient fluids, exercise, cardiac pacemaker

Name: vCJD
Overview: Creutzfeldt-Jakob (KROITS-felt YAH-kobe) disease is a degenerative brain disorder that leads to dementia and, ultimately, death. Symptoms of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) can resemble those of other dementia-like brain disorders, such as Alzheimer's.
Causes: Normally, the proteins are harmless, but when they're misshapen, they can cause devastating illnesses such as BSE disease in cattle and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans. A small number of people have developed CJD after being exposed to infected human tissue during a medical procedure, such as a cornea or skin transplant. Also, because standard sterilization methods do not destroy abnormal prions, a few people have developed CJD after undergoing brain surgery with contaminated instruments. Variant CJD is linked primarily to eating beef infected with mad cow disease (bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or BSE).
Risk factors: A person with an autosomal dominant disorder in this case, the father has a 50% chance of having an affected child with one abnormal gene and a 50% chance of having an unaffected child with two normal genes. The disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion, which means one need to inherit only one copy of the mutated gene, from either parent, to develop the disease. Genetic analysis in people with iatrogenic and vCJD suggest that inheriting identical copies of certain variants of the prion gene may increase the risk of developing CJD if one is exposed to contaminated tissue. People whove received human growth hormone derived from human pituitary glands or whove had grafts of tissue that covers the brain (dura mater) may be at risk of iatrogenic CJD.
Diagnosis: In addition, doctors commonly use these tests to help detect CJD: Electroencephalogram (EEG). In a test called a lumbar puncture popularly known as a spinal tap doctors use a needle to withdraw a small amount of this fluid for testing.
Treatment: For that reason, doctors focus on alleviating pain and other symptoms and on making people with these diseases as comfortable as possible. In some cases when one call for an appointment, one may be referred immediately to a brain specialist (neurologist).
info-Symptoms: Initial: Psychiatric problems, behavioral changes, painful sensations Later: Poor coordination, Dementia, Involuntary movements
info-Risk factors: Eating beef from cows with bovine spongiform encephalopathy
info-Diagnostic method: Suspected based on symptoms, confirmed by Brain biopsy
info-Frequency: Fewer than 250 reported cases as of 2012

Name: Ventricular septal defect
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms of serious heart defects often appear during the first few days, weeks or months of a child's life. Ventricular septal defect (VSD) symptoms in a baby may include One and the doctor may not notice signs of a ventricular septal defect at birth. The doctor may first suspect a heart defect during a regular checkup if he or she hears a murmur while listening to the baby's heart with a stethoscope.
Overview: A ventricular septal defect is an abnormal opening (hole) in the heart that forms between the heart's lower pumping chambers (ventricles), as shown in the heart on the right. A ventricular septal defect (VSD), a hole in the heart, is a common heart defect that's present at birth (congenital). The hole (defect) occurs in the wall (septum) that separates the heart's lower chambers (ventricles) and allows blood to pass from the left to the right side of the heart.
Causes: A VSD allows oxygenated blood to mix with deoxygenated blood, causing the heart to work harder to provide enough oxygen to the body's tissues. It's also possible to acquire a VSD later in life, usually after a heart attack or as a complication following certain heart procedures.
Diagnosis: Ventricular septal defects (VSDs) often cause a heart murmur that the doctor can hear using a stethoscope. If the doctor hears a heart murmur or finds other signs or symptoms of a heart defect, he or she may order several tests including Echocardiogram. In this test, a thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted into a blood vessel at the groin or arm and guided through the blood vessels into the heart. Through cardiac catheterization, doctors can diagnose congenital heart defects and determine the function of the heart valves and chambers.
Treatment: Many babies born with a small ventricular septal defect (VSD) won't need surgery to close the hole. Children and adults who have a medium or large ventricular septal defect or one that's causing significant symptoms may need surgery to close the defect.
Remedies: After the ventricular septal defect (VSD) is repaired, one or the child will need follow-up care throughout life for doctors to monitor the condition and check for any signs of complications. In follow-up appointments, the doctor may evaluate one or the child and order imaging tests to monitor the or the child's condition. Before becoming pregnant, talk to a doctor trained in heart conditions (cardiologist) to determine if one can undergo pregnancy safely. However, having an unrepaired, larger defect; heart failure; pulmonary hypertension; abnormal heart rhythms; or other heart defects poses a high risk to both mother and fetus. One or the child usually won't need to take antibiotics before certain dental procedures to prevent an infection of the heart's inner lining (endocarditis). However, the doctor may recommend antibiotics if one has had prior endocarditis, a heart valve replacement, if one has had a recent VSD repair with artificial material, if one still have leaks through the VSD, if the repaired VSD is next to a defect that's been repaired with artificial material, or if one has a large ventricular septal defect that's causing low oxygen levels.
Medication: Medications for ventricular septal defect may include those to: Surgical treatment for ventricular septal defects involves plugging or patching the abnormal opening between the ventricles. If one or the child is having surgery to repair a ventricular defect, consider having surgery performed by surgeons and cardiologists with training and expertise in conducting these procedures. Procedures may include After repair, the doctor will schedule regular medical follow-up to ensure that the ventricular septal defect remains closed and to look for signs of complications. Rather, the doctor inserts a thin tube (catheter) into a blood vessel in the groin and guides it to the heart.

Name: Ventricular tachycardia
Symptoms: Brief episodes of ventricular tachycardia may not cause any symptoms in some people. Or one may have: Sustained and more-serious episodes of ventricular tachycardia may cause: Many different conditions can cause ventricular tachycardia.
Overview: In ventricular tachycardia, an abnormal electrical impulse originating in the lower chambers of the heart (ventricles) causes the heart to beat faster. Ventricular tachycardia is a heart rhythm disorder (arrhythmia) caused by abnormal electrical signals in the lower chambers of the heart (ventricles). Sometimes, ventricular tachycardia can cause the heart to stop (sudden cardiac arrest), which is a life-threatening medical emergency.
Diagnosis: The doctor can print an electrocardiogram strip using the data on the recording device to see the heart's rhythm during the period one wore the monitor. The painless test detects and records the heart's electrical activity using small sensors (electrodes) attached to the chest and arms. The doctor can look for patterns among the signals to determine what kind of tachycardia one has and how problems in the heart may be causing a fast heart rate. The doctor may also ask one to use a portable ECG device at home to obtain more information about the heart rate. These devices include The doctor may recommend an electrophysiological test to confirm the diagnosis or to pinpoint the location of problems in the heart. During this test, a doctor inserts thin, flexible tubes (catheters) tipped with electrodes into the groin, arm or neck and guides them through the blood vessels to various spots in the heart. The doctor may get images of the heart to determine if structural problems are affecting blood flow and causing the ventricular tachycardia. Cardiac imaging tests used to diagnose ventricular tachycardia include Cardiac MRI provides still or moving pictures of how the blood is flowing through the heart and detects irregularities. In an exercise stress test, electrodes are taped to the chest to detect the heart's rhythm. If the doctor orders a nuclear stress test, one will also receive an injection of radioactive dye that shows the blood flow to the heart muscle. In an exercise stress test, electrodes are placed on the chest to monitor heart function while one exercise, usually by walking on a treadmill. The doctor may order additional tests as needed to diagnose an underlying condition that is contributing to ventricular tachycardia and judge the condition of the heart. It records the heart's activity for an entire 24-hour period, which gives the doctor a prolonged look at the heart rhythms. To study the flow of blood through the heart and blood vessels, the doctor may use a coronary angiogram to reveal potential blockages or abnormalities.
info-Symptoms: Lightheadedness, palpitations, chest pain
info-Causes: Coronary heart disease, aortic stenosis, cardiomyopathy, electrolyte problems, heart attack
info-Prevention: Implantable cardiac defibrillator, calcium channel blockers, amiodarone

Name: Vertebral tumor
Overview: The spinal cord is housed within a hollow chamber within the vertebrae (spinal canal). As these tumors grow within the bone, they may also cause pain, vertebral fractures or spinal instability. Most tumors that affect the vertebrae have spread (metastasized) to the spine from another place in the body often the prostate, breast, lung or kidney. Although the original (primary) cancer is usually diagnosed before back problems develop, back pain may be the first symptom of disease in people with metastatic vertebral tumors.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects a vertebral tumor, one or more of the following tests can help confirm the diagnosis and pinpoint the tumor's location: Spinal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). A contrast agent that helps to highlight certain tissues and structures may be injected into a vein in the hand or forearm during the test.Some people may feel claustrophobic inside the MRI scanner or find the loud thumping sound it makes disturbing.

Name: Vertigo
Causes: It includes three loop-shaped structures (semicircular canals) that contain fluid and fine, hair-like sensors that monitor the rotation of the head. This causes the semicircular canal to become sensitive to head position changes it would normally not respond to, which is what makes one feel dizzy.
Diagnosis: During a physical examination, the doctor will likely look for: If the cause of the signs and symptoms is difficult to determine, the doctor may order additional testing, such as: Signs and symptoms of dizziness that are prompted by eye or head movements and then decrease in less than one minute Dizziness with specific eye movements that occur when one lie on the back with the head turned to one side and tipped slightly over the edge of the examination bed Involuntary movements of the eyes from side to side (nystagmus) Inability to control the eye movements Electronystagmography (ENG) or videonystagmography (VNG). ENG (which uses electrodes) or VNG (which uses small cameras) can help determine if dizziness is due to inner ear disease by measuring involuntary eye movements while the head is placed in different positions or the balance organs are stimulated with water or air.
Remedies: If one experience dizziness associated with benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), consider these tips: BPPV may recur even after successful therapy. Fortunately, although there's no cure, the condition can be managed with physical therapy and home treatments.
info-Symptoms: Feeling of spinning or swaying, vomiting, difficulty walking
info-Causes: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), MÃ©niÃ¨re's disease, labyrinthitis, stroke, brain tumors, brain injury, multiple sclerosis, migraine

Name: Vesicoureteral reflux
Overview: The female urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine. The male urinary system which includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder and urethra is responsible for removing waste from the body through urine.
Causes: Vesicoureteral reflux can develop in two types, primary and secondary: Primary vesicoureteral reflux. Children with primary vesicoureteral reflux are born with a defect in the valve that normally prevents urine from flowing backward from the bladder into the ureters. This type of vesicoureteral reflux tends to run in families, which indicates that it may be genetic, but the exact cause of the defect is unknown.
Risk factors: Children with BBD hold their urine and stool and experience recurrent urinary tract infections, which can contribute to vesicoureteral reflux. White children appear to have a higher risk of vesicoureteral reflux. Siblings of children who have the condition also are at higher risk, so the doctor may recommend screening for siblings of a child with primary vesicoureteral reflux.
Diagnosis: A thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted through the urethra and into the bladder while the child lies on his or her back on an X-ray table. After contrast dye is injected into the bladder through the catheter, the child's bladder is X-rayed in various positions. Then the catheter is removed so that the child can urinate, and more X-rays are taken of the bladder and urethra during urination to see whether the urinary tract is functioning correctly. Risks associated with this test include discomfort from the catheter or from having a full bladder and the possibility of a new urinary tract infection.
Remedies: They include If bladder and bowel dysfunction (BBD) contributes to the child's vesicoureteral reflux, encourage healthy toileting habits. Encourage the child to drink fluids, Provide a heating pad or a warm blanket or towel.
Medication: This includes periodic physical exams and urine tests to detect breakthrough infections UTIs that occur despite the antibiotic treatment and occasional radiographic scans of the bladder and kidneys to determine if the child has outgrown vesicoureteral reflux. Similar to open surgery, this procedure involves repairing the valve between the ureter and the bladder, but it's performed using small incisions. In this procedure, the doctor inserts a lighted tube (cystoscope) through the urethra to see inside the child's bladder, and then injects a bulking agent around the opening of the affected ureter to try to strengthen the valve's ability to close properly. This type of surgery usually requires a few days stay in the hospital, during which a catheter is kept in place to drain the child's bladder.

Name: Vestibular schwannoma
Overview: An acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) is a benign tumor that develops on the balance (vestibular) and hearing, or auditory (cochlear) nerves leading from the inner ear to the brain, as shown in the top image. Acoustic neuroma, also known as vestibular schwannoma, is a noncancerous and usually slow-growing tumor that develops on the main (vestibular) nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain.
Risk factors: A person with an autosomal dominant disorder in this case, the father has a 50% chance of having an affected child with one abnormal gene and a 50% chance of having an unaffected child with two normal genes. Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is known as an autosomal dominant disorder, meaning that the mutation can be passed on by just one parent (dominant gene).
Diagnosis: In this test, conducted by a hearing specialist (audiologist), one hear sounds directed to one ear at a time. Each tone is repeated at faint levels to find out when one can barely hear.The audiologist may also present various words to determine the hearing ability.

Name: V-fib
Symptoms: A condition in which the lower chambers of the heart beat too rapidly (ventricular tachycardia, or VT) can lead to ventricular fibrillation. Chest pain Rapid heartbeat (tachycardia) Dizziness Nausea Shortness of breath Loss of consciousness Call 911 or the emergency number in the area. If no pulse, begin CPR to help maintain blood flow to the organs until an electrical shock (defibrillation) can be given.
Causes: The impulse then travels to the center of the heart, to the atrioventricular node, which lies on the pathway between the atria and the ventricles. Some cases of ventricular fibrillation begin as a rapid heartbeat called ventricular tachycardia (VT).
Diagnosis: The doctors will know if one is in ventricular fibrillation based on results from: To find out what caused the ventricular fibrillation, one will have additional tests, which can include Heart monitoring. Because injured heart muscle doesn't conduct electrical impulses normally, the ECG may show that a heart attack has occurred or is in progress. During an echocardiogram, sound waves are directed at the heart from a transducer, a wandlike device, held on the chest. Processed electronically, the sound waves provide video images of the heart. To determine if the coronary arteries are narrowed or blocked, a liquid dye is injected through a long, thin tube (catheter) that's fed through an artery, usually in the leg, to the arteries in the heart. Chest X-rays CT coronary angiogram CT scan Echocardiogram Electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) Holter monitor MRI Heart monitoring.
Remedies: Heart-healthy foods include fruits, vegetables and whole grains, as well as lean protein sources such as soy, beans, nuts, fish, skinless poultry and low-fat dairy products. Aim for 150 minutes a week of moderate aerobic activity, 75 minutes a week of vigorous aerobic activity, or a combination of moderate and vigorous activity. Take medications as prescribed to correct high blood pressure (hypertension) or high cholesterol, and maintain a healthy body weight. For healthy adults, that means up to one drink a day for women of all ages and men older than age 65, and up to two drinks a day for men age 65 and younger.
info-Symptoms: Cardiac arrest with loss of consciousness and no pulse
info-Causes: Coronary heart disease (including myocardial infarction), valvular heart disease, cardiomyopathy, Brugada syndrome, long QT syndrome, intracranial hemorrhage

Name: Viral gastroenteritis
Causes: A number of viruses can cause gastroenteritis, including Some shellfish, especially raw or undercooked oysters, also can make one sick. Both children and adults are affected by noroviruses, the most common cause of foodborne illness worldwide. In most cases, one pick up the virus from contaminated food or water, although person-to-person transmission also is possible. A vaccine against viral gastroenteritis is available in some countries, including the United States, and appears to be effective in preventing the infection.
Risk factors: Older adults in nursing homes, in particular, are vulnerable because their immune systems weaken and they live in close contact with others who may pass along germs. If the resistance to infection is low for instance, if the immune system is compromised by HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy or another medical condition one may be especially at risk.
Treatment: Antibiotics aren't effective against viruses, and overusing them can contribute to the development of antibiotic-resistant strains of bacteria. To help keep theself more comfortable and prevent dehydration while one recover, try the following: Let the stomach settle. One might also try drinking clear soda, clear broths or noncaffeinated sports drinks. Drink plenty of liquid every day, taking small, frequent sips. Gradually begin to eat bland, easy-to-digest foods, such as soda crackers, toast, gelatin, bananas, rice and chicken. These include dairy products, caffeine, alcohol, nicotine, and fatty or highly seasoned foods. Use many medications, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others), sparingly if at all. Use acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) cautiously; it sometimes can cause liver toxicity, especially in children. Don't give aspirin to children or teens because of the risk of Reye's syndrome, a rare, but potentially fatal disease.
Remedies: To help keep theself more comfortable and prevent dehydration while one recover, try the following: When the child has an intestinal infection, the most important goal is to replace lost fluids and salts. These suggestions may help: If one has a sick infant, let the baby's stomach rest for 15 to 20 minutes after vomiting or a bout of diarrhea, then offer small amounts of liquid. Gradually begin to eat bland, easy-to-digest foods, such as soda crackers, toast, gelatin, bananas, rice and chicken. Use acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) cautiously; it sometimes can cause liver toxicity, especially in children. Don't give aspirin to children or teens because of the risk of Reye's syndrome, a rare, but potentially fatal disease. Before choosing a pain reliever or fever reducer, discuss with the child's pediatrician. Give the child an oral rehydration solution, available at pharmacies without a prescription. Don't give the child plain water in children with gastroenteritis, water isn't absorbed well and won't adequately replace lost electrolytes. Don't give the child dairy products or sugary foods, such as ice cream, sodas and candy. Avoid giving the child over-the-counter anti-diarrheal medications, unless advised by the doctor.
info-Symptoms: Diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fever
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, occasionally stool culture
info-Prevention: Hand washing, drinking clean water, proper disposal of human waste, breastfeeding
info-Treatment: Oral rehydration solution (combination of water, salts, and sugar), intravenous fluids

Name: Viral hemorrhagic fevers
Overview: Viral hemorrhagic (hem-uh-RAJ-ik) fevers are infectious diseases that can cause severe, life-threatening illness. When viral hemorrhagic fevers occur in the United States, they're usually found in people whove recently traveled internationally. Viral hemorrhagic fevers are spread by contact with infected animals, people or insects.
Causes: The viruses that cause viral hemorrhagic fevers live naturally in a variety of animal and insect hosts most commonly mosquitoes, ticks, rodents or bats. Each of these hosts typically lives in a specific geographic area, so each particular disease usually occurs only where that virus's host normally lives. Some viral hemorrhagic fevers also can be transmitted from person to person, and can spread if an infected person travels from one area to another. If one travel to an area where a particular hemorrhagic fever is common, one may become infected there and then develop symptoms after one return home.

Name: Vitamin deficiency anemia
Overview: Vitamin deficiency anemia is a lack of healthy red blood cells caused when one has lower than normal amounts of certain vitamins. Vitamins linked to vitamin deficiency anemia include folate, vitamin B-12 and vitamin C. Vitamin deficiency anemia can occur if one don't eat enough foods containing folate, vitamin B-12 or vitamin C, or it can occur if the body has trouble absorbing or processing these vitamins.
Causes: Or vitamin deficiency anemia may develop because the body can't properly absorb the nutrients from the foods one eat. Causes of vitamin deficiency anemias include Folate, also known as vitamin B-9, is a nutrient found mainly in fruits and leafy green vegetables. Vitamin B-12 deficiency can result from a diet lacking in vitamin B-12, which is found mainly in meat, eggs and milk. Vitamin B-12 deficiency anemia can also occur if the small intestine can't absorb vitamin B-12 for reasons other than a lack of intrinsic factor.
Risk factors: In general, the risk of vitamin deficiency is increased if: The diet contains little to no natural vitamin food sources, such as meat, dairy, fruits and vegetables. The diet contains little to no natural vitamin food sources, such as meat, dairy, fruits and vegetables. Alcohol interferes with the absorption of folate and vitamin C, as well as other vitamins.
Diagnosis: Doctors diagnose vitamin deficiency anemias through blood tests that check: The number and appearance of red blood cells. In vitamin deficiency anemias related to a lack of vitamin B-12 and folate, the red blood cells appear large and underdeveloped. If blood tests reveal a vitamin deficiency, the doctor may perform other tests to determine the type and cause, such as: The number and appearance of red blood cells.

Name: Vitiligo
Symptoms: Depending on the type of vitiligo one has, it may affect: It's difficult to predict how the disease will progress. With this type, called universal vitiligo, the discoloration affects nearly all skin surfaces. With this most common type, called generalized vitiligo, the discolored patches often progress similarly on corresponding body parts (symmetrically). This type, called segmental vitiligo, tends to occur at a younger age, progress for a year or two, then stop.
Overview: The loss of color resulting from vitiligo is sometimes symmetrical. This can result in discolored patches in different areas of the body, including the skin, hair and mucous membranes. Vitiligo (vit-ih-LIE-go) is a disease that causes loss of skin color in patches. Vitiligo affects people of all skin types, but it may be more noticeable in people with darker skin.
Remedies: If one has vitiligo, the following self-care tactics may help one care for the skin and improve its appearance: Protect the skin from the sun and artificial sources of UV light. Damage to the skin, such as that caused by a tattoo, may cause a new patch of vitiligo to appear within two weeks.
Medication: But some drugs, used alone, in combination or with light therapy, can help restore some skin tone. This type of cream is effective and easy to use, but one might not see changes in the skin's color for several months. Given the FDA warning regarding possible risk of skin cancer with use of calcineurin inhibitors, talk with the doctor about the risks and benefits of using these drugs with phototherapy. For people who can't go to a doctor's office for treatment, smaller portable or handheld devices for narrow band ultraviolet B therapy are available for home use. Possible side effects of narrow band ultraviolet B therapy include redness, itching and burning. In this procedure, the doctor transfers very small sections of the healthy, pigmented skin to areas that have lost pigment. Possible risks include infection, scarring, a cobblestone appearance, spotty color and failure of the area to recolor. In this procedure, the doctor creates blisters on the pigmented skin, usually with suction, and then transplants the tops of the blisters to discolored skin. In this procedure, the doctor takes some tissue on the pigmented skin, puts the cells into a solution and then transplants them onto the prepared affected area. Possible risks include scarring, infection and uneven skin tone. Calcineurin inhibitor ointments, such as tacrolimus (Protopic) or pimecrolimus (Elidel) might be effective for people with small areas of depigmentation, especially on the face and neck. After one take psoralen by mouth or apply it to the affected skin, one is exposed to ultraviolet A (UVA) light.
info-Symptoms: Patches of white skin
info-Risk factors: Family history, other autoimmune diseases

Name: Vocal fold paralysis
Causes: In vocal cord paralysis, the nerve impulses to the voice box (larynx) are disrupted, resulting in paralysis of the muscle. Surgery on or near the neck or upper chest can result in damage to the nerves that serve the voice box. Surgeries that carry a risk of damage include surgeries to the thyroid or parathyroid glands, esophagus, neck, and chest. Trauma to the neck or chest may injure the nerves that serve the vocal cords or the voice box itself. Some infections, such as Lyme disease, Epstein-Barr virus and herpes, can cause inflammation and directly damage the nerves in the larynx. If one has certain neurological conditions, such as multiple sclerosis or Parkinson's disease, one may experience vocal cord paralysis.
Diagnosis: The doctor will look at the vocal cords using a mirror or a thin, flexible tube (known as a laryngoscope or endoscope) or both. One may also have a test called videostrobolaryngoscopy that's done using a special scope that contains a tiny camera at its tip or a larger camera connected to the scope's viewing piece. This test doesn't usually provide information that might change the course of treatment, but it may give the doctor information about how well one may recover.

Name: Voice disorders
Diagnosis: A topical anesthetic may be applied to numb the tissues before the doctor uses one of the following tools to examine the vocal cords: Additional tests are sometimes used: Mirror. Similar to a dental mirror, a long, rigid instrument with an angled mirror is inserted into the mouth. Using computer analysis, the doctor can measure irregularities in the sound produced by the vocal cords.
Treatment: Depending on the diagnosis, the doctor will recommend one or more treatments: Rest, liquids and voice therapy. Speech pathology specialists can teach one how to use the voice more efficiently through voice therapy, how to properly clear the throat and how much liquid to drink. If the voice problem is the result of smoking, quitting smoking can help improve the voice along with many other areas of the health, such as boosting the heart health and lowering the cancer risk. Depending on the cause of the voice disorder, one may need medication to reduce inflammation, treat gastroesophageal reflux or prevent blood vessel regrowth.

Name: Von Willebrand disease
Overview: Von Willebrand disease is a lifelong bleeding disorder in which the blood doesn't clot well. People with the disease have low levels of von Willebrand factor, a protein that helps blood clot, or the protein doesn't perform as it should.
Causes: The usual cause of von Willebrand disease is an inherited abnormal gene that controls von Willebrand factor a protein that plays a key role in blood clotting. Many people with von Willebrand disease also have low levels of factor VIII, another protein that helps in clotting.
Risk factors: A person with an autosomal dominant disorder in this case, the father has a 50% chance of having an affected child with one abnormal gene and a 50% chance of having an unaffected child with two normal genes. Two carriers have a 25% chance of having an unaffected child with two normal genes (left), a 50% chance of having an unaffected child who also is a carrier (middle), and a 25% chance of having an affected child with two recessive genes (right). The disease is usually an autosomal dominant inherited disorder, which means one need an abnormal gene from only one parent to be affected.
Diagnosis: To evaluate one for von Willebrand disease, the doctor will likely ask one detailed questions about the medical history and check for bruises or other signs of recent bleeding. If one has von Willebrand disease, the doctor might suggest that family members undergo tests to determine if this condition runs in the family. This evaluates the structure of von Willebrand factor in the blood, its protein complexes and how its molecules break down.
Treatment: Even though von Willebrand disease has no cure, treatment can help prevent or stop bleeding episodes. The treatment depends on: The doctor might suggest one or more of the following treatments to increase the von Willebrand factor, strengthen blood clots or, in women, control heavy menstrual bleeding: Desmopressin. This medication is available as an injection (DDAVP) or nasal spray (Minirin) It's a synthetic hormone that controls bleeding by stimulating the body to release more of the von Willebrand factor stored in the lining of the blood vessels. Another replacement therapy approved by the FDA for treating adults 18 and older is a genetically engineered (recombinant) von Willebrand factor product. These anti-fibrinolytic medications such as aminocaproic acid (Amicar) and tranexamic acid (Cyklokapron, Lysteda) can help stop bleeding by slowing the breakdown of blood clots. To help prevent bleeding episodes, talk with the doctor before taking blood-thinning medications such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve). The doctor might instead recommend pain and fever relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). Let the doctors or dentist know that one has von Willebrand disease before one has surgery, start a new medication or give birth. Make sure it notes that one has von Willebrand disease, which will be helpful to medical personnel if one is in an accident or taken to an emergency room.
Remedies: To help prevent bleeding episodes, talk with the doctor before taking blood-thinning medications such as aspirin, ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) or naproxen sodium (Aleve). The doctor might instead recommend pain and fever relievers such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others). Let the doctors or dentist know that one has von Willebrand disease before one has surgery, start a new medication or give birth. Make sure it notes that one has von Willebrand disease, which will be helpful to medical personnel if one is in an accident or taken to an emergency room.

Name: VPCs
Overview: Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) are extra heartbeats that begin in one of the heart's two lower pumping chambers (ventricles). They're also called: If one has occasional premature ventricular contractions, but one is otherwise healthy, there's probably no reason for concern, and no need for treatment.
Causes: In a normal heart rhythm, a tiny cluster of cells at the sinus node sends out an electrical signal. The rhythm of the heart is normally controlled by the sinoatrial (SA) node or sinus node an area of specialized cells in the right atrium. From the sinus node, electrical impulses travel across the atria to the ventricles, causing them to contract and pump blood to the lungs and body.
Treatment: For most people, PVCs with an otherwise normal heart won't need treatment. However, if one has frequent PVCs, the doctor might recommend treatment. In some cases, if one has heart disease that could lead to more-serious rhythm problems, one might need the following: Medications. Other medications, such as calcium channel blockers, or anti-arrhythmic drugs, such as amiodarone (Pacerone) or flecainide (Tambocor), also might be used if one has ventricular tachycardia or frequent PVCs that interfere with the heart's function. For PVCs that don't respond to lifestyle changes or medications, the doctor might recommend ablation therapy. Caffeine, alcohol, tobacco and other recreational drugs are known triggers of premature ventricular contractions. If one think anxiety is contributing to the condition, try stress-reduction techniques, such as biofeedback, meditation or exercise, or talk to the doctor about anti-anxiety medications.
Remedies: Caffeine, alcohol, tobacco and other recreational drugs are known triggers of premature ventricular contractions. If one think anxiety is contributing to the condition, try stress-reduction techniques, such as biofeedback, meditation or exercise, or talk to the doctor about anti-anxiety medications.

Name: Vulvar cancer
Risk factors: Although the exact cause of vulvar cancer isn't known, certain factors appear to increase the risk of the disease, including Increasing age. The risk of vulvar cancer increases with age, though it can occur at any age. HPV is a sexually transmitted infection that increases the risk of several cancers, including vulvar cancer and cervical cancer. People who take medications to suppress the immune system, such as those whove undergone organ transplant, and those with conditions that weaken the immune system, such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), have an increased risk of vulvar cancer. Lichen sclerosus, which causes the vulvar skin to become thin and itchy, increases the risk of vulvar cancer.
Diagnosis: Tests and procedures used to diagnose vulvar cancer include Once the diagnosis is confirmed, the doctor works to determine the size and extent (stage) of the cancer. To determine whether an area of suspicious skin on the vulva is cancer, the doctor may recommend removing a sample of skin for testing. Stage IV signifies a cancer that has spread more extensively to the lymph nodes, or that has spread to the upper portions of the urethra or vagina, or that has spread to the bladder, rectum or pelvic bone.
info-Symptoms: Lump, itchiness, changes in the skin, or bleeding of the vulva
info-Risk factors: Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), HPV infection, genital warts, smoking, many sexual partners
info-Treatment: Surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, biologic therapy

Name: Vulvodynia
Symptoms: The main vulvodynia symptom is pain in the genital area, which can be characterized as: The pain might be constant or occasional. A similar condition, vestibulodynia, causes pain only when pressure is applied to the area surrounding the entrance to the vagina.
Treatment: This therapy can help reduce pain by teaching one how to relax the pelvic muscles and control how the body responds to the symptoms. Women who have long-standing pain that doesn't respond to other treatments might benefit from local nerve block injections. Many women with vulvodynia have tension in the muscles of the pelvic floor, which supports the uterus, bladder and bowel. In cases of localized vulvodynia or vestibulodynia, surgery to remove the affected skin and tissue (vestibulectomy) relieves pain in some women.
Remedies: Two to three times a day, sit in comfortable, lukewarm (not hot) or cool water with Epsom salts or colloidal oatmeal for five to 10 minutes. Tight clothing restricts airflow to the genital area, often leading to increased temperature and moisture that can cause irritation. Instead, use plain water to gently clean the vulva with the hand and pat the area dry. Avoid activities that put pressure on the vulva, Wash gently.

Name: Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia
Overview: Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (mak-roe-glob-u-lih-NEE-me-uh) is a rare type of cancer that begins in the white blood cells. If one has Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia, the bone marrow produces too many abnormal white blood cells that crowd out healthy blood cells.
Causes: In the bone marrow the soft, blood-producing tissue that fills in the center of most of the bones Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia cells crowd out healthy blood cells. Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia cells continue trying to produce antibodies, as healthy white blood cells do, but instead they produce abnormal proteins that the body can't use.
Risk factors: Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia can occur at any age, but it's most often diagnosed in adults 65 and older. If one has a relative who has been diagnosed with Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia or another type of B-cell lymphoma, one may have an increased risk.
Diagnosis: Also, blood tests are used to detect the IgM proteins produced by the cancer cells. Blood tests may also measure the organ function, which can tell the doctor whether the IgM proteins are affecting the organs, such as the kidneys and the liver.
Treatment: Chemotherapy is a drug treatment that kills quickly growing cells, such as the abnormal blood cells produced by Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. Chemotherapy may be used alone or combined with other drug treatments as an initial treatment for people who experience signs and symptoms of Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. If one is diagnosed with Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia, one will likely be referred to a doctor who specializes in treating blood and bone marrow disorders (hematologist) or a doctor who specializes in treating cancer (oncologist). If one experience signs and symptoms related to having too many IgM proteins in the blood, the doctor may recommend plasma exchange (plasmapheresis) to remove the proteins and replace them with healthy blood plasma. Targeted therapy drugs may be used alone or combined with other medications, such as chemotherapy or biological therapy, as an initial treatment for Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia or in cases where the cancer returns despite treatment. In certain highly selected situations, a bone marrow transplant, also known as a stem cell transplant, may be used to treat Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia.

Name: Warts , common
Overview: Common warts can grow on the hands or fingers. Common warts are small, grainy skin growths that occur most often on the fingers or hands. Rough to the touch, common warts also often feature a pattern of tiny black dots, which are small, clotted blood vessels.
Treatment: Most common warts go away without treatment, though it may take a year or two and new ones may develop nearby. Some people choose to have their warts treated by a doctor because home treatment isn't working and the warts are bothersome, spreading or a cosmetic concern. The doctor may suggest one of the following approaches, based on the location of the warts, the symptoms and the preferences. These methods are sometimes used in combination with home treatments, such as salicylic acid. Unless one has an impaired immune system or diabetes, try these methods: Peeling medicine (salicylic acid). Nonprescription wart removal products such as salicylic acid are available as a patch, ointment, pad and liquid. For common warts, look for a 17 percent salicylic acid solution. These products (Compound W, Dr. Scholl's Clear Away Wart Remover, others) are usually used daily, often for a few weeks. If salicylic acid or freezing isn't working, the doctor may try trichloroacetic acid. Some liquid nitrogen products are available in nonprescription liquid or spray form (Compound W Freeze Off, Dr. Scholl's Freeze Away, others).
Remedies: Nonprescription wart removal products such as salicylic acid are available as a patch, ointment, pad and liquid. These products (Compound W, Dr. Scholl's Clear Away Wart Remover, others) are usually used daily, often for a few weeks. Some liquid nitrogen products are available in nonprescription liquid or spray form (Compound W Freeze Off, Dr. Scholl's Freeze Away, others).

Name: Warts , plantar
Overview: Plantar warts are caused by the same type of virus that causes warts on the hands and fingers. This pressure may also cause plantar warts to grow inward beneath a hard, thick layer of skin (callus).
Treatment: They may also stimulate the immune system's ability to fight the wart.The doctor will likely suggest one apply the medicine regularly at home, followed by occasional office visits. One may need to return to the doctor's office for repeat treatments every two to four weeks until the wart disappears.Some studies suggest that cryotherapy combined with salicylic acid treatment is more effective than just cryotherapy, but further study is needed.
Remedies: Many people have removed warts with these self-care tips: Peeling medicine (salicylic acid). Usually, one is instructed to wash the site, soak it in warm water, and gently remove the top layer of softened skin with a pumice stone or emery board. The Food and Drug Administration cautions that some wart removers are flammable and shouldn't be used around fire, flame, heat sources (such as curling irons) and lit cigarettes. Between applications, soak the wart and gently remove dead tissue with a pumice stone or emery board.

Name: Warts , venereal
Overview: Genital warts are one of the most common types of sexually transmitted infections. Nearly all sexually active people will become infected with at least one type of human papillomavirus (HPV), the virus that causes genital warts, at some point during their lives.
Diagnosis: In a Pap test, the doctor uses a vaginal speculum to hold the vaginal walls apart and to see the cervix. Next, a sample of cells from the cervix is collected using a small cone-shaped brush and a tiny plastic spatula (1 and 2). For women, it's important to have regular pelvic exams and Pap tests, which can help detect vaginal and cervical changes caused by genital warts or the early signs of cervical cancer. During a Pap test, the doctor uses a device called a speculum to hold open the vagina and see the passage between the vagina and the uterus (cervix). A sample of cervical cells, taken during a Pap test, can be tested for these cancer-causing HPV strains.
Medication: Genital wart treatments that can be applied directly to the skin include Imiquimod (Aldara, Zyclara). Other side effects might include blisters, body aches or pain, a cough, rashes, and fatigue. Side effects can include mild skin irritation, sores or pain. One might need surgery to remove larger warts, warts that don't respond to medications or, if one is pregnant, warts that the baby can be exposed to during delivery. Surgical options include Imiquimod (Aldara, Zyclara). This chemical treatment burns off genital warts, and can be used for internal warts. Side effects, such as reddening of the skin, itching or burning, and pain, are often mild. This approach, which uses an intense beam of light, can be expensive and is usually reserved for extensive and tough-to-treat warts.

Name: Water on the knee
Symptoms: The skin around the kneecap can puff up noticeably, especially when one compare the affected knee to the normal one. When the knee joint contains excess fluid, one might not be able to bend or straighten the leg completely. Self-care measures or prescribed medications don't relieve the pain and swelling One knee becomes red and feels warm to the touch compared to the other knee
Risk factors: People who participate in sports that involve twisting the knee, such as basketball, are more likely to experience the types of knee injuries that cause swelling. Excess weight puts added stress on the knee joint, contributing to the tissue and joint overload and knee degeneration that can lead to a swollen knee. Obesity increases the risk of osteoarthritis, one of the more frequent causes of knee swelling.
Diagnosis: This test can detect tendon, ligament and soft tissue injuries that aren't visible on X-rays. Blood, which may stem from injuries or bleeding disorders Bacteria, which may be causing an infection Crystals common to gout or pseudogout Arthroscopy MRI Ultrasound X-ray Arthroscopy X-ray.
Treatment: Treatment varies, depending on the cause of the swollen knee, its severity and the medical history. Treatment generally involves pain medication and procedures to remove fluid from the knee joint.
Remedies: To control pain and swelling, apply ice to the knee for 15 to 20 minutes every two to four hours. When one ice the knee, raise the knee higher than the level of the heart, using pillows for comfort. Over-the-counter medicines such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) can help reduce the knee pain.
Medication: Treating the underlying cause of a swollen knee might require: The doctor might also recommend physical therapy to improve the knee's function and strength. After aspirating joint fluid, the doctor might inject a corticosteroid into the joint to treat inflammation. If bearing weight on the knee joint becomes intolerable, one might need knee replacement surgery.

Name: Wegener 's granulomatosis
