Overview: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is an uncommon disorder that causes inflammation of the blood vessels in the nose, sinuses, throat, lungs and kidneys. Formerly called Wegener's granulomatosis, this condition is one of a group of blood vessel disorders called vasculitis.
Causes: The condition can lead to inflamed, narrowed blood vessels and harmful inflammatory tissue masses (granulomas). Granulomas can destroy normal tissue, and narrowed blood vessels reduce the amount of blood and oxygen that reaches the body's tissues and organs.
Diagnosis: Blood tests can check for: Urine tests can reveal whether the urine contains red blood cells or has too much protein, which might indicate that the disease is affecting the kidneys. Signs of inflammation, such as a high level of C-reactive protein or a high erythrocyte sedimentation rate commonly referred to as a sed rate.
Medication: Other drugs that suppress the immune system include cyclophosphamide, azathioprine (Azasan, Imuran), mycophenolate (CellCept) and methotrexate (Trexall). Also known as plasmapheresis, this treatment removes the liquid portion of the blood (plasma) that contains disease-producing substances.

Name: Weight loss
Risk factors: Obesity usually results from a combination of causes and contributing factors: The genes one inherit from the parents may affect the amount of body fat one store, and where that fat is distributed. Genetics may also play a role in how efficiently the body converts food into energy, how the body regulates the appetite and how the body burns calories during exercise. Medical problems, such as arthritis, also can lead to decreased activity, which may result in weight gain. In addition, the people one spend time with may influence the weight one is more likely to develop obesity if one has friends or relatives with obesity. If one don't consciously control what one eat and become more physically active as one age, one will likely gain weight. A diet that's high in calories, lacking in fruits and vegetables, full of fast food, and laden with high-calorie beverages and oversized portions contributes to weight gain. Other high-calorie beverages, such as sugared soft drinks, can contribute to significant weight gain. And for some, it can lead to enough weight gain to qualify as obesity. One may also crave foods high in calories and carbohydrates, which can contribute to weight gain.
Diagnosis: These exams and tests generally include Gathering all this information helps one and the doctor determine how much weight one need to lose and what health conditions or risks one already have. The doctor may review the weight history, weight-loss efforts, physical activity and exercise habits, eating patterns and appetite control, what other conditions one has had, medications, stress levels, and other issues about the health. Women with a waist measurement (circumference) of more than 35 inches (89 centimeters, or cm) and men with a waist measurement of more than 40 inches (102 cm) may have more health risks than do people with smaller waist measurements. The doctor will also check for other possible health problems, such as high blood pressure and diabetes. The doctor may also recommend certain heart tests, such as an electrocardiogram.
Treatment: One may need to work with a team of health professionals including a dietitian, behavioral counselor or an obesity specialist to help one understand and make changes in the eating and activity habits. That means that if one weigh 200 pounds (91 kg) and have obesity by BMI standards, one would need to lose only about 10 to 20 pounds (4.5 to 9 kg) for the health to begin to improve.
Remedies: When one has to lose a significant amount of weight, one may set goals that are unrealistic, such as trying to lose too much too fast. Be honest with the doctor, therapist or other health care professionals if one find the activity or eating goals slipping. If one take weight-loss medications or medications to treat obesity-related conditions, such as high blood pressure or diabetes, take them exactly as prescribed.

Name: Wermer 's syndrome
Overview: Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1 (MEN 1), sometimes called Wermer's syndrome, is a rare disorder that causes tumors in the endocrine glands and parts of the small intestine and stomach. In MEN 1, the endocrine glands usually the parathyroids, pancreas and pituitary grow tumors and release excessive amounts of hormones that can lead to disease.
Diagnosis: Diagnosing multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1, or MEN 1, starts with a physical exam and a review of the medical history and family history. Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. Multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1 (MEN 1). Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1: Treatment. Safety and efficacy of percutaneous parathyroid ethanol ablation in patients with recurrent primary hyperparathyroidism and multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1.

Name: West Nile virus
Overview: A mosquito-transmitted virus causes most cases of West Nile infection. Most people infected with West Nile virus either don't develop signs or symptoms or have only minor ones, such as fever and mild headache.
Risk factors: Even if one is infected, the risk of developing a serious West Nile virus-related illness is extremely small less than 1 percent of people who are infected become severely ill. And most people who do become sick recover fully.
Diagnosis: Besides conducting a physical exam, the doctor can confirm the presence of West Nile virus or a West Nile-related illness, such as meningitis or encephalitis, by performing one of the following tests: Laboratory tests. In some cases, an electroencephalography (EEG) a procedure that measures the brain's activity or an MRI scan can help detect brain inflammation.

Name: Wheat allergy
Symptoms: Wheat allergy signs and symptoms include For some people, wheat allergy may cause a life-threatening reaction called anaphylaxis. In addition to other signs and symptoms of wheat allergy, anaphylaxis may cause: If someone shows signs of anaphylaxis, call 911 or the local emergency number.
Diagnosis: Tiny drops of purified allergen extracts including extracts for wheat proteins are pricked onto the skin's surface, either on the forearm or on the upper back. If one develop a red, itchy bump where the wheat protein extract was pricked onto the skin, one may be allergic to wheat. If a skin condition or possible interactions with certain medications prevent one from having a skin test, the doctor may order a blood test that screens for specific allergy-causing antibodies to common allergens, including wheat proteins. The doctor may recommend that one remove certain foods from the diet, particularly those that are common allergens.
Remedies: If the child has wheat allergy, make sure that anyone who takes care of the child, including the principal, teachers and nurse at school or child care, knows about the allergy and the signs of wheat exposure. If the child carries epinephrine, make sure school personnel know how to use the pen, if necessary, and that they need to contact emergency care immediately. Wheat proteins, especially gluten, are used as food thickeners, and they appear in many unexpected places. Some specialty stores and supermarkets offer gluten-free foods, which are safe for people with wheat allergies. However, they may also be free of grains that one can eat, so sticking to gluten-free foods may limit the diet needlessly.

Name: Whiplash
Causes: Whiplash typically occurs when the head is forcefully and quickly thrown backward and then forward. This motion can injure bones in the spine, disks between the bones, ligaments, muscles, nerves and other tissues of the neck. Football tackles and other sports-related collisions can sometimes cause whiplash.

Name: Whipple 's disease
Symptoms: Contact the doctor if one experience unusual signs or symptoms, such as unexplained weight loss or joint pain. Even after the infection is diagnosed and one is receiving treatment, let the doctor know if the symptoms don't improve.
Overview: The small intestine has a ridged lining covered with tiny fingerlike projections called villi. Whipple disease interferes with normal digestion by impairing the breakdown of foods, such as fats and carbohydrates, and hampering the body's ability to absorb nutrients.
Causes: The bacteria affect the mucosal lining of the small intestine first, forming small lesions within the intestinal wall. The bacteria also damage the fine, hairlike projections (villi) that line the small intestine.
Diagnosis: An important step in diagnosing Whipple disease is taking a tissue sample (biopsy), usually from the lining of the small intestine. If these tissue samples don't confirm the diagnosis, the doctor might take a tissue sample from an enlarged lymph node or perform other tests. A DNA-based test known as polymerase chain reaction, which is available at some medical centers, can detect Tropheryma whipplei bacteria in biopsy specimens or spinal fluid samples. Blood tests can detect certain conditions associated with Whipple disease, particularly anemia, which is a decline in the number of red blood cells, and low concentrations of albumin, a protein in the blood.

Name: White blood cell disorders in children
Overview: The body produces white blood cells (leukocytes), which help fight bacterial infections, viruses and fungi. If the child has too few or too many white blood cells, in general, here's what it means: There are several types of white blood cells, each with a different disease-fighting activity. The main types are: White blood cell disorders involving a specific type of white blood cell include Low white blood cell count (leukopenia) means having too few leukocytes circulating in the blood. A long-term low white blood cell count increases the risk of infections and may be caused by a number of different diseases and conditions. High white blood cell count (leukocytosis) means having too many leukocytes circulating in the blood, usually from having an infection. Neutropenia (noo-troe-PEE-nee-uh) is a low number of neutrophils, a type of white blood cell that fights infections of fungi and bacteria. Lymphocytopenia (lim-foe-sie-toe-PEE-nee-uh) is a decrease in lymphocytes, the type of white blood cell that, among other tasks, protects the body from viral infections. Eosinophilia (e-o-sin-o-FIL-e-uh) is a higher than normal number of eosinophil cells, a type of disease-fighting white blood cell. Basophils account for only a small number of white blood cells, but they have a role in wound healing, infection and allergic reactions.

Name: Whiteheads
Symptoms: If acne persists or is severe, one may want to seek medical treatment from a doctor who specializes in the skin (dermatologist). The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) warns that some popular nonprescription acne lotions, cleansers and other skin products can cause a serious reaction.
Causes: Other pores in the skin, which are the openings of the sweat glands, aren't usually involved in acne. Studies indicate that certain dietary factors, including skim milk and carbohydrate-rich foods such as bread, bagels and chips may worsen acne. Though working in a greasy area, such as a kitchen with fry vats, does because the oil can stick to the skin and block the hair follicles. In fact, scrubbing the skin too hard or cleansing with harsh soaps or chemicals irritates the skin and can make acne worse. Cosmetics don't necessarily worsen acne, especially if one use oil-free makeup that doesn't clog pores (noncomedogenics) and remove makeup regularly.
Risk factors: People of all ages can get acne, but it's most common in teenagers. Such changes are common in teenagers, women and girls, and people using certain medications, including those containing corticosteroids, androgens or lithium. If both parents had acne, one is likely to develop it, too. One may develop acne where the skin comes into contact with oily lotions and creams or with grease in a work area, such as a kitchen with fry vats. Stress doesn't cause acne, but if one has acne already, it may make it worse.
Treatment: If one has tried over-the-counter (nonprescription) acne products for several weeks and they haven't helped, the doctor can prescribe stronger medications. A dermatologist can help one: Acne medications work by reducing oil production, speeding up skin cell turnover, fighting bacterial infection or reducing inflammation which helps prevent scarring.
Remedies: One can try to avoid or control mild acne with nonprescription products, good basic skin care and other self-care techniques: Wash problem areas with a gentle cleanser. One might also try products containing salicylic acid, glycolic acid or alpha hydroxy acids, which may help with mild and moderate acne. Nonprescription acne medications may cause initial side effects such as redness, dryness and scaling that often improve after the first month of using them. Avoid oily or greasy cosmetics, sunscreens, hairstyling products or acne concealers. Use products labeled water-based or noncomedogenic, which means they are less likely to cause acne. Protect the acne-prone skin from contact with items such as phones, helmets, tight collars or straps, and backpacks.

Name: Whooping cough
Symptoms: Once one become infected with whooping cough, it takes about seven to 10 days for signs and symptoms to appear, though it can sometimes take longer. Severe and prolonged coughing attacks may: However, many people don't develop the characteristic whoop.
Diagnosis: Diagnosing whooping cough in its early stages can be difficult because the signs and symptoms resemble those of other common respiratory illnesses, such as a cold, the flu or bronchitis. A blood sample may be drawn and sent to a lab to check the white blood cell count, because white blood cells help the body fight infections, such as whooping cough. The doctor may order an X-ray to check for the presence of inflammation or fluid in the lungs, which can occur when pneumonia complicates whooping cough and other respiratory infections.
Remedies: The following tips on dealing with coughing spells apply to anyone being treated for whooping cough at home: Get plenty of rest. To avoid vomiting after coughing, eat smaller, more-frequent meals rather than large ones. Keep the home free of irritants that can trigger coughing spells, such as tobacco smoke and fumes from fireplaces.
info-Symptoms: Runny nose, fever, cough

Name: Wilms ' tumor
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of Wilms tumor include Wilms tumor occurs more frequently in children with certain abnormalities or syndromes present at birth, including Wilms tumor can occur as part of rare syndromes, including African-American race. In the United States, African-American children have a slightly higher risk of developing Wilms tumor than children of other races. If someone in the child's family has had Wilms tumor, then the child has an increased risk of developing the disease. This syndrome includes Wilms tumor, aniridia, genital and urinary system abnormalities, and intellectual disabilities. This syndrome includes Wilms tumor, kidney disease and male pseudohermaphroditism (soo-do-her-MAF-roe-dit-iz-um), in which a boy is born with testicles but may exhibit female characteristics.
Diagnosis: To diagnose Wilms tumor, the child's doctor may recommend: Once the child's doctor diagnoses Wilms tumor, he or she works to determine the extent (stage) of the cancer. In the United States, guidelines developed through the National Wilms Tumor Study of the Children's Oncology Group include these five stages: In select cases, a 3-D printer is used to create an exact model of a patient's anatomy to help plan complex operations for Wilms tumor. These lab tests can't detect Wilms tumor, but they can indicate how well the kidneys are working and uncover certain kidney problems or low blood counts. The cancer has spread to the tissues and structures beyond the affected kidney, such as nearby fat or blood vessels, but it can still be completely removed by surgery. The cancer has spread beyond the kidney area to nearby lymph nodes or other structures within the abdomen, the tumor may spill within the abdomen before or during surgery, or it may not be completely removed by surgery.

Name: Wilson 's disease
Diagnosis: Diagnosing Wilson's disease can be challenging because its signs and symptoms are often hard to tell from those of other liver diseases, such as hepatitis. Blood tests can monitor the liver function and check the level of a protein that binds copper in the blood (ceruloplasmin) and the level of copper in the blood. Using a microscope with a high-intensity light source (slit lamp), an ophthalmologist checks the eyes for Kayser-Fleischer rings, which is caused by excess copper in the eyes.
Medication: Zinc acetate might be used as primary therapy if one can't take penicillamine or trientine. A chelating agent, penicillamine can cause serious side effects, including skin and kidney problems, bone marrow suppression, and worsening of neurological symptoms. It is typically used as maintenance therapy to prevent copper from building up again after treatment with penicillamine or trientine.Zinc acetate might be used as primary therapy if one can't take penicillamine or trientine.

Name: Wolff-Parkinson-White ( WPW ) syndrome
Symptoms: Common symptoms of WPW syndrome include An episode of a fast heartbeat can begin suddenly and last a few seconds or several hours. Signs and symptoms in infants with WPW syndrome can include A number of conditions can cause irregular heartbeat (arrhythmia).
Overview: In Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, an extra electrical pathway between the heart's upper chambers and lower chambers causes a rapid heartbeat. In Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, an extra electrical pathway between the heart's upper and lower chambers causes a rapid heartbeat.
Causes: The signal then travels through the atria to the atrioventricular node and then passes into the ventricles, causing them to contract and pump out blood. The sinus node produces electrical impulses, or signals, that cause each heartbeat. These electrical signals travel across the atria, causing muscle contractions that pump blood into the ventricles. When the electrical signals reach the ventricles, muscle contractions pump blood to the lungs and the rest of the body. In WPW syndrome, an extra electrical pathway connects the atria and ventricles, allowing electrical impulses to bypass the AV node.

Name: Wrinkles
Symptoms: With repeated sun exposure, wrinkles can become very pronounced and deep, especially on the back of the neck. Some wrinkles can become deep crevices or furrows and may be especially noticeable around the eyes, mouth and neck.
Causes: This causes loose, saggy skin and more-pronounced lines and crevices. Exposure to UV light breaks down the skin's connective tissue collagen and elastin fibers, which lie in the deeper layer of skin (dermis). Without the supportive connective tissue, the skin loses strength and flexibility. Smoking can accelerate the normal aging process of the skin, contributing to wrinkles. Each time one use a facial muscle, a groove forms beneath the surface of the skin. And as skin ages, it loses its flexibility and is no longer able to spring back in place.

Name: Wrist fracture
Overview: The wrist is made up of eight small bones (carpal bones) plus two long bones in the forearm the radius and the ulna. One may be at higher risk of a broken wrist if one participate in sports like in-line skating or snowboarding, or if one has a condition in which bones become thinner and more fragile (osteoporosis).
Causes: Many wrist fractures occur during contact sports or sports in which one might fall onto an outstretched hand such as in-line skating or snowboarding. Motor vehicle crashes can cause wrist bones to break, sometimes into many pieces, and often require surgical repair.
info-Symptoms: Pain, bruising, and swelling of the wrist
info-Risk factors: Osteoporosis

Name: Wrist pain
Causes: The wrist is made up of eight small bones (carpal bones) plus two long bones in the forearm the radius and the ulna. A disorder in which the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, rheumatoid arthritis commonly involves the wrist. This disorder typically affects young adults and involves the progressive collapse of one of the small bones in the wrist.
Risk factors: Wrist pain can happen to anyone whether one is very sedentary, very active or somewhere in between. Wrist injuries are common in many sports, both those that involve impact and those that involve repetitive stress on the wrist. Almost any activity that involves the hands and wrists even knitting and cutting hair if performed forcefully enough and often enough can lead to disabling wrist pain. Pregnancy, diabetes, obesity, rheumatoid arthritis and gout may increase the risk of developing carpal tunnel syndrome.
Diagnosis: During the physical exam, the doctor may: In some cases, the doctor may suggest imaging tests, arthroscopy or nerve tests. If imaging test results are inconclusive, the doctor may perform an arthroscopy, a procedure in which a pencil-sized instrument called an arthroscope is inserted into the wrist through a small incision in the skin. Check the wrist for tenderness, swelling or deformity Ask one to move the wrist to check for a decrease in the range of motion Assess the grip strength and forearm strength X-rays. For a wrist MRI, one may be able to insert the arm into a smaller device instead of a whole-body MRI machine.
Medication: Over-the-counter pain relievers, such as ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others) and acetaminophen (Tylenol, others), may help reduce wrist pain. If one has sprained or strained the wrist, one may need to wear a splint to protect the injured tendon or ligament while it heals. In some cases, surgery may be necessary to stabilize bone fractures to permit healing. If the symptoms are severe, one may need to have the ligament that forms the roof of the tunnel cut open to relieve the pressure on the nerve.

Name: X , Syndrome
Overview: People who have metabolic syndrome typically have apple-shaped bodies, meaning they have larger waists and carry a lot of weight around their abdomens. It's thought that having a pear-shaped body that is, carrying more of the weight around the hips and having a narrower waist doesn't increase the risk of diabetes, heart disease and other complications of metabolic syndrome.
Risk factors: In the United States, Hispanics especially Hispanic women appear to be at the greatest risk of developing metabolic syndrome. Carrying too much weight, especially in the abdomen, increases the risk of metabolic syndrome. One is more likely to have metabolic syndrome if one had diabetes during pregnancy (gestational diabetes) or if one has a family history of type 2 diabetes. The risk of metabolic syndrome is higher if one has ever had nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, polycystic ovary syndrome or sleep apnea.
Treatment: If aggressive lifestyle changes such as diet and exercise aren't enough, the doctor might suggest medications to help control the blood pressure, cholesterol, and blood sugar levels. If one has been diagnosed with metabolic syndrome or any of its components, making healthy lifestyle changes can help prevent or delay serious health problems, such a heart attack or stroke.
Remedies: If one has been diagnosed with metabolic syndrome or any of its components, making healthy lifestyle changes can help prevent or delay serious health problems, such a heart attack or stroke. A healthy lifestyle includes: Health experts recommend getting at least 30 minutes of exercise, such as brisk walking, daily. Healthy-eating plans, such as the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet and the Mediterranean diet, emphasize eating: And healthy-eating plans tend to recommend limiting: Giving up cigarettes greatly improves the overall health.

Name: Xerosis
Causes: Central heating, wood-burning stoves, space heaters and fireplaces all reduce humidity and dry the skin. Taking long, hot showers or baths can dry the skin. Many popular soaps, detergents and shampoos strip moisture from the skin as they are formulated to remove oil. People with skin conditions such as atopic dermatitis (eczema) or psoriasis are prone to dry skin.
Treatment: In most cases, dry skin responds well to lifestyle measures, such as using moisturizers and avoiding long, hot showers and baths. If one has very dry and scaly skin, the doctor may recommend one use an over-the-counter (nonprescription) cream that contains lactic acid or lactic acid and urea. If one has a more serious skin disease, such as atopic dermatitis, ichthyosis or psoriasis, the doctor may prescribe prescription creams and ointments or other treatments in addition to home care. Sometimes dry skin leads to dermatitis, which causes red, itchy skin. If the skin cracks open, the doctor may prescribe wet dressings to help prevent infection. If the skin is extremely dry, one may want to apply an oil, such as baby oil, while the skin is still moist. If dry skin causes itching, apply cool compresses to the area. Within a couple of minutes of bathing, apply moisturizing cream or ointment to trap moisture in the skin.
Remedies: If the skin is extremely dry, one may want to apply an oil, such as baby oil, while the skin is still moist. If dry skin causes itching, apply cool compresses to the area. It's best to use cleansing creams or gentle skin cleansers and bath or shower gels with added moisturizers. Within a couple of minutes of bathing, apply moisturizing cream or ointment to trap moisture in the skin. Hot, dry, indoor air can parch sensitive skin and worsen itching and flaking.
info-Symptoms: Low skin moisture, itching, scaling, skin cracking
info-Causes: Deficiency of certain vitamins and minerals, exposure to detergents, sunburn, choline inhibitors
info-Risk factors: Low relative humidity of surrounding air, frequent bathing or hand washing

Name: Xerostomia
Overview: One has three pairs of major salivary glands parotid, sublingual and submandibular. Dry mouth, or xerostomia (zeer-o-STOE-me-uh), refers to a condition in which the salivary glands in the mouth don't make enough saliva to keep the mouth wet. Less often, dry mouth may be caused by a condition that directly affects the salivary glands. Decreased saliva and dry mouth can range from being merely a nuisance to something that has a major impact on the general health and the health of the teeth and gums, as well as the appetite and enjoyment of food.
Causes: Dry mouth is caused when the salivary glands in the mouth don't make enough saliva to keep the mouth wet. Hundreds of medications, including many over-the-counter drugs, produce dry mouth as a side effect. Radiation treatments to the head and neck can damage salivary glands, causing a marked decrease in saliva production. An injury or surgery that causes nerve damage to the head and neck area can result in dry mouth. Methamphetamine use can cause severe dry mouth and damage to teeth, a condition also known as meth mouth.
Treatment: The doctor or dentist may: If one has severe dry mouth, the doctor or dentist may: Change medications that cause dry mouth. If the doctor believes medication to be the cause, he or she may adjust the dosage or switch one to another medication that doesn't cause a dry mouth. Mouthwashes designed for dry mouth, especially ones with xylitol, can be effective, such as Biotene Dry Mouth Oral Rinse or Act Dry Mouth Mouthwash, which also offer protection against tooth decay.
Remedies: In addition to the advice from the doctor, these tips may help relieve the dry mouth symptoms: Avoid products that can make the symptoms worse. Taking these steps to protect the teeth may also help the dry mouth condition: Sip water or sugar-free drinks or suck ice chips throughout the day to moisten the mouth, and drink water during meals to aid chewing and swallowing. However, in some people, xylitol, which is often found in sugar-free gum or sugar-free candies, may cause gas or diarrhea if consumed in large amounts. Try over-the-counter saliva substitutes that contain xylitol, such as Mouth Kote or Oasis Moisturizing Mouth Spray, or that contain carboxymethylcellulose (kahr-bok-see-meth-ul-SEL-u-lohs) or hydroxyethyl cellulose (hi-drok-see-ETH-ul SEL-u-lohs), such as Biotene OralBalance Moisturizing Gel. If one smoke or chew tobacco, stop, because tobacco products can dry and irritate the mouth. Ask the dentist if one might benefit from prescription fluoride toothpaste, toothpaste containing betaine, or a tooth gel to neutralize bacteria acids. See the dentist at least twice yearly to have the teeth examined and plaque removed, to help prevent tooth decay. Sip water Chew sugar-free gum Try over-the-counter saliva substitutes Breathe through the nose, Add moisture to the air at night Moisturize the lips Caffeine and alcohol.

Name: XXX syndrome
Symptoms: Signs and symptoms can vary greatly among girls and women with triple X syndrome. Most females with triple X syndrome experience normal sexual development and have the ability to become pregnant. Some girls and women with triple X syndrome have intelligence in the normal range, but possibly slightly lower when compared with siblings.
Causes: In most cases, either the mother's egg cell or the father's sperm cell divides incorrectly, resulting in an extra X chromosome in the child. This random error is called nondisjunction, and all the cells in the child's body will have the extra X chromosome. Occasionally, the extra chromosome results from an incorrect cell division caused by a random event early in the embryo's development. If this is the case, the child has a mosaic form of triple X syndrome, and only some cells have the extra X chromosome.
Treatment: Options that may be helpful include It's quite possible for girls and women with triple X syndrome to lead full and happy lives. Both one and the child may benefit from these strategies: Here's some information to help one get ready for the appointment, and what one might expect from the doctor. If the child has a learning disability, educational help to learn techniques and strategies to be successful in school and daily life can be provided. Girls and women with triple X syndrome may be more prone to anxiety, as well as behavioral and emotional problems. And psychological counseling may help teach one and the family how to demonstrate love and encouragement and discourage behaviors that might negatively impact learning and social functioning. If the child has problems that impact daily functioning, this assistance and support may include help with activities of daily living, social opportunities and employment.
info-Symptoms: Tall stature, skeletal anomalies, minor neurocognitive and behavioural difficulties

Name: Yeast infection ( vaginal )
Causes: An overgrowth of candida or penetration of the fungus into deeper vaginal cell layers causes the signs and symptoms of a yeast infection. Yeast infections caused by other types of candida fungus can be more difficult to treat, and generally need more-aggressive therapies.
Risk factors: Yeast infections are more common in women with higher estrogen levels such as pregnant women or women taking high-dose estrogen birth control pills or estrogen hormone therapy. Women with poorly controlled blood sugar are at greater risk of yeast infections than women with well-controlled blood sugar. Women with lowered immunity such as from corticosteroid therapy or HIV infection are more likely to get yeast infections.
Diagnosis: Next, the doctor places an instrument (speculum) into the vagina to hold the vaginal walls open to examine the vagina and cervix the lower, narrower part of the uterus. The doctor may send a sample of vaginal fluid for testing to determine the type of fungus causing the yeast infection.
Treatment: For mild to moderate symptoms and infrequent episodes, the doctor might recommend: See the doctor again if treatment doesn't resolve the symptoms or if the symptoms return within two months. If the symptoms are severe, or one has frequent yeast infections, the doctor might recommend: No alternative medicine therapies have been proved to treat vaginal yeast infections. If one has been treated for a yeast infection in the past, the doctor may not need to see one and may prescribe a treatment over the phone. The doctor might prescribe an antifungal medication taken daily for up to two weeks, followed by once a week for six months. The doctor might prescribe two or three doses of an antifungal medication to be taken by mouth instead of vaginal therapy.

Symptoms: Once the infection enters the acute phase, one may experience signs and symptoms including: These signs and symptoms usually improve and are gone within several days. Although signs and symptoms may disappear for a day or two following the acute phase, some people with acute yellow fever then enter a toxic phase.
Overview: Yellow fever is a viral infection spread by a particular type of mosquito. But yellow fever can become more serious, causing heart, liver and kidney problems along with bleeding (hemorrhaging).
Causes: When a mosquito bites a human or a monkey infected with yellow fever, the virus enters the mosquito's bloodstream and circulates before settling in the salivary glands. When the infected mosquito bites another monkey or human, the virus then enters the host's bloodstream, where it may cause illness.
Treatment: This includes providing fluids and oxygen, maintaining adequate blood pressure, replacing blood loss, providing dialysis for kidney failure, and treating any other infections that develop. If one has yellow fever, the doctor will likely recommend that one stay inside, away from mosquitoes, to avoid transmitting the disease to others.

Name: Yersinia pestis
Symptoms: Plague is divided into three main types bubonic, septicemic and pneumonic depending on which part of the body is involved. Pneumonic plague needs to be treated with antibiotics within a day after signs and symptoms first appear, or the infection is likely to be fatal.
Overview: Plague is a serious bacterial infection that's transmitted primarily by fleas. The organism that causes plague, Yersinia pestis, lives in small rodents found most commonly in rural and semirural areas of Africa, Asia and the United States.
Diagnosis: If the doctor suspects plague, he or she may look for the Yersinia pestis bacteria in samples taken from the: Buboes. If one has the swollen lymph nodes (buboes) typical of bubonic plague, the doctor may use a needle to take a fluid sample from them (aspiration). To check for pneumonic plague, the doctor will take mucus (sputum) or fluid from the airways using a thin, flexible tube inserted through the nose or mouth and down the throat (endoscopy).

Name: Yips
Overview: The yips are involuntary wrist spasms that occur most commonly when golfers are trying to putt. However, it now appears that some people have the yips due to a neurological condition affecting specific muscles (focal dystonia).
Treatment: Because the yips may be related to overuse of specific muscles, a change of technique or equipment may help. Possible strategies include: While one may initially consult the family physician, he or she may refer one to a doctor who specializes in sports medicine. This technique works for many golfers, because it changes the muscles one use to make the putting stroke. Techniques such as relaxation, visualization or positive thinking can help reduce anxiety, increase concentration and ease fear of the yips. A careful injection of onabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) into the muscles that are overacting can help to limit muscle contractions and calm the yips.

Name: Zika virus
Risk factors: Because the mosquito that carries the Zika virus is found worldwide, it's likely that outbreaks will continue to spread to new regions. Because the mosquito that carries the Zika virus is found worldwide, it's likely that outbreaks will continue to spread to new regions.The mosquitoes that carry the Zika virus are found in some parts of the United States. If male sex partners or a couple that includes a male and female partner travel to an area with a Zika risk, the CDC suggests using condoms or avoiding sex for three months. If female partners travel to an area with a Zika risk, the CDC suggests using condoms or avoiding sex for at least two months. Also, the CDC advises abstinence from sexual activity during pregnancy or condom use during all sexual contact for a pregnant woman or her partner who have traveled to or lived in an area of active Zika virus transmission.
Diagnosis: Talk to the doctor about which tests for the Zika virus or similar diseases such as dengue or chikungunya viruses, which are spread by the same type of mosquitoes are available in the area. Following positive, inconclusive or negative test results, care providers may: Perform an ultrasound to detect microcephaly or other abnormalities of the brain Offer to take a sample of amniotic fluid using a hollow needle inserted into the uterus (amniocentesis) to screen for Zika virus

Name: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
Causes: The syndrome begins when a tumor (gastrinoma) or tumors form in the pancreas, duodenum or the lymph nodes adjacent to the pancreas. Zollinger-Ellison syndrome may be caused by an inherited condition called multiple endocrine neoplasia, type 1 (MEN 1).
Diagnosis: For example, gastrin may also be elevated if the stomach isn't making acid, or one is taking acid-reducing medications, such as proton pump inhibitors. For this test, the doctor first measures the gastrin levels, gives one an injection of the hormone secretin and measures gastrin levels again. After one is sedated, the doctor inserts a thin, flexible instrument with a light and video camera (endoscope) down the throat and into the stomach and duodenum to look for ulcers. Through the endoscope, the doctor may remove a tissue sample (biopsy) from the duodenum to help detect the presence of gastrin-producing tumors. Other helpful imaging tests include ultrasound, computerized tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

Name: Zoster
Risk factors: Factors that may increase the risk of developing shingles include: Being older than 50. Diseases that weaken the immune system, such as HIV/AIDS and cancer, can increase the risk of shingles. Drugs designed to prevent rejection of transplanted organs can increase the risk of shingles as can prolonged use of steroids, such as prednisone.
info-Symptoms: Painful rash occurring in a stripe
info-Risk factors: Old age, poor immune function, having had chickenpox before 18 months of age

Name: 22q11.2 deletion syndrome
Overview: DiGeorge syndrome, more accurately known by a broader term 22q11.2 deletion syndrome is a disorder caused when a small part of chromosome 22 is missing. The term 22q11.2 deletion syndrome covers terms once thought to be separate conditions, including DiGeorge syndrome, velocardiofacial syndrome and other disorders that have the same genetic cause, though features may vary slightly. Medical problems commonly associated with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome include heart defects, poor immune system function, a cleft palate, complications related to low levels of calcium in the blood, and delayed development with behavioral and emotional problems.
Treatment: Although there is no cure for DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome), treatments can usually correct critical problems, such as a heart defect or cleft palate. If the child has some thymic function, infections may be frequent, but not necessarily severe. For most children with moderate thymus impairment, immune system function improves with age. If the impairment of the thymus is severe or there's no thymus, the child is at risk of a number of severe infections. In the United States, early intervention programs providing these types of therapy are usually available through a state or county health department. Treatment may be recommended if the child is later diagnosed with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), autism spectrum disorder, depression, or other mental health or behavioral disorders.
info-Symptoms: Varied; commonly congenital heart problems, specific facial features, cleft palate
info-Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and genetic testing
